title: Fleetwood Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a loss on the sale of two idle plants of 3 cents a share for both quarter and 9 months. The actual amount of the loss was not disclosed.

title: Pitt-Des Moines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Free for 7 Months, Man Faces Prison Again in 1976 Slaying
description: After seven months of freedom, Vincent James Landano faces a return to prison after a Federal appeals panel on Tuesday overturned a lower court ruling that Mr. Landano was the victim of prosecutorial misconduct when he was convicted in 1976 of killing a Newark police officer.

title: Metromedia-ITT
description: Metromedia-ITT Long Distance, a unit of the Metromedia Company, has selected Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss for its advertising account. The long-distance company was created last year when Metromedia Long Distance acquired the domestic units of ITT Corporation. The agency will create a trade advertising campaign first, and a consumer campaign later. The other finalist for the account was Poppe Tyson. Billings were not disclosed.

title: National Sea Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $256,000. The company said costs associated with the rationalization of North American operations accounted for $10.3 million of the fourth-quarter loss and $15.9 million of the full-year loss. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Currents;   It Makes You Only a Little Bit Dizzy
description: SOME people build model airplanes and ships. Danny Koslowski builds model roller coasters, including one that will work.

title: Political Strife Threatens Himalayas Tourism
description: The tourism industry in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, one of the best-known travel destinations in Asia for Himalayan treks and climbs and vacations in houseboats, is likely to be crippled this summer unless anti-India agitation eases.

title: PHM Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $3,702,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $1,998,000 for the year. c-Included extraordinary losses of $92,000 and $1,426,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Shearson Deal May Embrace The Man Who Built the Firm
description: A remarkable comeback appears to be taking shape on Wall Street.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   The Parties That Beat the Sandinistas
description: National Opposition Union was formally registered as an political coalition in September 1989. It coalesced from a broad anti-Sandinista front known as the ''14 party bloc'' that held discussions with the Sandinista Government in 1987 and 1988 over constitutional reforms.

title: DeBus Issue Postponed
description: For the sixth time in six months, an inquiry scheduled to consider testimony against Chuck DeBus, a coach under investigation for possible involvement with performance-enhancing drugs, has been postponed. No new date was set although DeBus's attorney, Craig Dummit, said yesterday that he expected the case to be heard in early April. DeBus, the former coach of the Los Angeles Track Club, has been accused by several athletes of providing them with drugs in training.

title: Natural Gas Refueling Station Opens
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company will open the first compressed natural gas refueling station available to the public on Thursday in Concord, Calif.

title: Child Given Bourbon Dies at Texas Hospital
description: A 5-year-old boy who drank 10 ounces of bourbon Friday night, reportedly at the prompting of an adult, died this morning after suffering irreversible brain damage and being removed from life support systems at a hospital here.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: North Carolina State Facing Questions About Point-Shaving
description: The North Carolina State basketball team has become the subject of investigations by law-enforcement agencies and the National Collegiate Athletic Association centering on Charles Shackleford, the former Wolfpack player who is now a member of the New Jersey Nets.

title: Greenspan Sees Slow Growth
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today that he expects that economic growth in the first three months of the year will be ''slow but positive.''

title: Congress Party of India Beaten in 6 State Elections
description: For the second time in less than 100 days, Indian voters have dealt a severe blow to the Congress Party of the former Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi.

title: Japan's Markets Wrestle With Issue of Volatility
description: With its attempts Monday to stabilize the stock market by curtailing program trading, an American export that has only recently taken root in Japan, the Tokyo Stock Exchange has opened a spirited debate over how the Japanese stock market should be run.

title: Soviet McDonald's Serves 30,000 Daily
description: The first McDonald's restaurant in the Soviet Union is serving 30,000 people a day in Moscow, a company official said. The company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., had originally predicted that the world's largest McDonald's would serve from 10,000 to 15,000 people a day. Over all, McDonald's serves 22 million people daily in 11,000 restaurants in 52 countries.

title: Durocher's Rose-Martin Connection
description: For several years now, Leo Durocher, who in some ways was both the Pete Rose and the Billy Martin of his time, has waited for a phone call that would tell him he had been elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame by its veterans committee. But after the committee of 14 former baseball executives, players and writers took its final vote in Tuesday's meeting, he never got that phone call. Neither did anybody else. For the second time in three years, the veterans committee did not deem anybody worthy of a Cooperstown plaque.

title: Joss Energy reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Critical Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $280,398,000, or $3.85 a share, for the quarter and $346,605,000, or $4.75 a share, for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $16,692,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $32,287,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $857,000, or 1 cent a share, and $41,033,000, or 66 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Harcourt said it took in the third quarter a charge of about $176 million for substantially all non-cash items. This amount included $49 million pre- tax of debt acquisition costs; $17 million for insurance acquisition costs and a general increase in insurance reserves; $12 million for the write-off of certain corporate assets as well as other reserves; $3 million of interest expense as a writedown of deferred interest costs, and writeoffs of $95 million in publishing, including a writedown of inventory, plate, and development costs for some elementary and secondary school publications, as well as certain school publication rights.

title: Imperial Bankruptcy Filing
description: The Imperial Corporation of America, parent company of a savings and loan association seized by the Government, said today that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Electronic Monitoring Doesn't HelpIn Premature Births, a Study Finds
description: Electronic monitoring of the heart rate of premature infants during labor and delivery does not improve chances of survival or normal neurological development and may be linked to higher rates of cerebral palsy, a new study has found.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   MANAGUA VICTORS SEEK TO SOLIDIFY
description: After a boisterous, almost unbelieving celebration of their election victory on Sunday, leaders and supporters of the National Opposition Union have now come face to face with the challenge of how to govern.

title: 4 Senior Editors Resign In Protest at Pantheon
description: Four of the five senior editors at Pantheon Books resigned yesterday in protest over the removal earlier this week of Andre Schiffrin, the publishing house's longtime managing director.

title: Review/Piano;   Haydn, Beethoven and 2 Rarities by Field
description: Malcolm Frager's piano recital in Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening was easier to respect on certain levels than to love. The repertory, composed between about 1771 and 1844, was almost wholly conventional, the only real departure being a pair of nocturnes by John Field. That choice seemed particularly odd, since Mr. Frager's style throughout the evening was all bright lights and brittleness. Nocturnal warmth and mystery were nowhere to be found.

title: Irving Price, 64, Dies; A Real-Estate Broker
description: Irving Price, an accountant, a builder and a real-estate broker in upstate New York for more than 35 years, died of a heart attack on Monday at John F. Kennedy Hospital in Lantana, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived in Hudson, N.Y.

title: XTRA Dissidents' Sale Commitment
description: The independent shareholders' committee of the XTRA Corporation said it was committed to supporting a cash sale of the company that was in the best interests of shareholders. ''If management can commence a transaction that achieves this goal before the annual meeting, we pledge ourselves to its consummation,'' a committee spokesman said. He added that if management did not begin a sale, the shareholders' group would move to have its slate of directors, if they are elected, pursue the sale.

title: Topics of The Times;   Tax Writeoffs in Ski Country
description: The Federal tax code has long invited lawyers, doctors and other professionals to mix a little bit of work with a lot of play by allowing them to deduct most of the costs of attending an educational conference. Not atypically, a recent medical seminar at a Colorado ski resort hotel featured four hours of lectures daily - all artfully scheduled before the lifts opened in the morning and after they closed in late afternoon.

title: H&R Block Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the indictment of the Exxon Corporation in the Alaskan oil spill misidentified the men with Gov. Steve Cowper of Alaska. Garrey Peska, the Governor's chief of staff, was at left; at rear was Doug Bailey, the Alaskan Attorney General.

title: American Power Conversion reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Harcourt Brace Posts Profit
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said today that a big gain on the sale of its theme parks helped the company to post a profit of $316.6 million, or $4.22 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989. That compares with a loss of $53.9 million a year earlier.

title: Topics of The Times;   Dean Keppel and the Lions
description: The prestige of American education is traditionally most precarious at the great universities. Arts and science faculties tend to look down on even their own schools of education. That's why academics often call 120th Street and Morningside Heights in Manhattan the widest street in the country: it separates Columbia University from Columbia Teachers College.

title: Dart Settles Civil Case On Unregistered Actions
description: The Dart Group Corporation, the investment arm of the wealthy Haft family, today settled Federal civil charges that it failed to register with regulators as an investment company over a five-year period beginning in 1984.

title: Capitol Transamerica reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a credit of $550,000 from a cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes.

title: 35 Years After Her Operatic Debut Freni Makes Teen-Agers Credible
description: The operatic heroines Mirella Freni likes best, and the roles that have won her the most lavish praise, are young women who are scarcely past their teens. Manon Lescaut, the Puccini title role she is currently singing at the Metropolitan Opera, is 18 years old and alluring enough to arouse the passions that propel the work. Micaela, a role she sang last season in the Met's ''Carmen,'' is young and innocent. And the roles she plans to sing at the Met next season -Susanna, Figaro's headstrong bride-to-be in Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' and the frail Mimi in Puccini's ''Boheme'' - also require youthful looks and a voice that is pure and flexible.

title: Framing for Long-Term Protection
description: WHAT happens if you do not frame valuable prints, drawings, pastels, posters, photographs or watercolors with museum-quality methods? ''It doesn't disintegrate in front of your eyes, but eventually it does,'' said Richard Cowdery of A.P.F. Inc., an Upper East Side company that specializes in framing artwork on paper with archival materials.

title: Memento of Pregnancy Other Than Baby
description: Being pregnant can be a little like breaking a leg. Or so say Dr. and Mrs. Stork of Sherman Oaks, Calif., who are marketing a pink and blue bucket with everything needed to make a cast for ''a broken stomach.'' The Storks, also known as Fred and Dionne Scobie, call it ''Dr. Stork's Original Pregnant Tummy Cast Kit.''

title: Bonn's Top Banker Urges Caution
description: Despite the wish of politicians in Bonn to speed up the monetary and economic union of East and West Germany, the president of the West German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, said today that it would take ''a few months, at the least,'' even after the East German elections on March 18.

title: Upheaval in the East;   How the Mutiny on 'Red October' Sub Really Happened
description: The Government newspaper Izvestia has confirmed Western news reports of an attempted mutiny aboard a Soviet naval vessel in 1975 that Tom Clancy used as the basis of his bestseller, ''The Hunt for Red October.''

title: Neutrogena Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $345,000, or 1 cent a share, reflecting accounting changes for income taxes.

title: Treasury Issues Decline in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday in spotty trading on fears that monetary authorities in Japan and West Germany may be on the verge of raising interest rates again.

title: Corrections
description: The Bank Money Accounts table in Business Day yesterday misstated the yield for a six-month certificate of deposit at Marine Midland Bank. It is 7.84 percent.

title: Head Injury Linked to Alzheimer's in a Study
description: A new study has bolstered the belief that past head injuries may be related to Alzheimer's disease, scientists said yesterday.

title: Receivership For Empire
description: Federal banking regulators have placed Empire of America Federal Savings Bank in receivership and changed its name to Empire Federal Savings Bank of America.

title: Transition in Managua
description: After Nicaragua's election, the victorious opposition faces the challenge of governing, while the Sandinistas try to adjust to a new role. Page A20.

title: Clerics Urge End to Lebanese Christian Strife
description: The heads of Lebanon's 16 Christian denominations issued an impassioned appeal to warring factions today to stop their fierce fighting.

title: Judge Explains His Ruling in the Jogger Case
description: In explaining a major decision he issued last week, the judge in the Central Park rape case said yesterday that the police were not required to give warnings against self-incrimination to every suspect they questioned on the night of the incident until they began to question them about their specific roles in the attack.

title: Mandela Refuses to Make Concessions to Pretoria
description: Nelson Mandela said today that the African National Congress would make no concessions to the South African Government until South Africa met the organization's conditions for opening talks, including putting the congress on an equal footing with the Government.

title: Newbridge Networks reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: The share earnings were not available. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Maged & Behar
description: Murdoch Magazines has selected Maged & Behar as the advertising agency for the Salon Network, a video magazine program for beauty salons that will make its debut in June. The commercially sponsored program will include features derived from the Murdoch magazines Mirabella, New Woman, Seventeen and European Travel & Life. It will also promote beauty-salon products and services.

title: Currents;   A Long Way From Papyrus
description: PAPER is celebrating its 300th anniversary in this country. In 1690, William Rittenhouse and William Bradford built the country's first paper mill, the Rittenhouse Mill, in Germantown, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the earnings of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. misstated the 1989 net income for Sears, Roebuck & Company's merchandising group. It was $646.9 million.

title: 24,000 Gallons of Oil Spill Off Bayonne
description: More than 24,000 gallons of heating oil leaked from a hole in a barge here at the Constable Hook terminal of the Exxon Company this morning. The leak spread gobs of oil into Upper New York Bay as far as Liberty Island, forcing officials to close the Kill van Kull between this city and Staten Island to marine traffic.

title: Cliffs Drilling Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $5,489,000 primarily from the sale of offshore drilling rigs.

title: TJX Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $7,074,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,505,000 for the quarter, and the year included a loss from discontinued operations of $56,454,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $166,500,000. d-Net loss

title: Bush and Managua
description: The overwhelming defeat of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua has left the Bush Administration with an obvious first order of response - the immediate disbanding of the ''contra'' army organized and directed by the United States and still in place along the Honduran border.

title: BUSH DRAWS FIRE OVER TROOP CUTS
description: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and the Air Force chief of staff expressed concern today that the recent agreement to cut American and Soviet forces in Europe would hamper the Pentagon's ability to deploy forces there.

title: Nordiques Struggling in the Cellar
description: The prettiest road uniforms in the National Hockey League - blue and white with a fleur-de-lis - are not the only things that make the Quebec Nordiques unusual.

title: Syracuse's 9-Year Shutout Of Seton Hall Continues
description: Seton Hall, a team that has played inconsistently all season, kept one constant tonight against Syracuse, losing to the Orangemen for the 20th consecutive time.

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Serbian Novelist Foresees a Democratic Wave Sweeping Yugoslavia
description: At a time when centrifugal forces seem to be gaining momentum with each passing week, splintering the politics of this multinational country, Dobrica Cosic, the most prominent novelist of Serbia, sees a democratic tide sweeping Yugoslavia.

title: Clemson Clinches a Tie For the A.C.C. Title
description: Clemson clinched a share of its first Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season title tonight as Kirkland Howling hit four free throws in the final 17 seconds for a 97-93 victory over Duke.

title: Gorbachev Plan for Family Farms Is Approved by Soviet Lawmakers
description: A qualified plan to allow revival of the family farm but maintain Communism's ban on private ownership of land was approved today by the Supreme Soviet and sent on to likely final approval in the Soviet Congress.

title: Homespun Texan Goes For Republicans' Heart
description: Unannounced and unheralded, Clayton Williams, a candidate for governor in the Texas Republican primary, joined the country western quartet on the stage of a small community center auditorium recently, breaking into a raspy rendition of a rodeo ballad.

title: Prosecutors Say Witness In Race Case Is Missing
description: An important witness in the killing of a black teen-ager in Bensonhurst last summer has disappeared, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday.

title: Justice Officials See Exxon Trial as Risk for U.S.
description: One day after the indictment of the Exxon Corporation on charges stemming from the Alaska oil spill, Federal officials expressed disappointment today about the failure to arrange a plea bargain in the case.

title: Kentucky Medical Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $825,180, or 84 cents a share. c-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $353,938, or 46 cents a share, for the quarter and $737,938, or 96 cents a share, for the year.

title: Rhoden to Retire
description: Rick Rhoden, the right-hander who won 28 games in two seasons with the Yankees, said he was retiring from baseball because of recurring back problems. Rhoden, 36 years old, said he had been bothered by a nerve problem in his back, and the condition prevented him from attempting to sign a contract with a team. ''If I didn't hurt, I was going to keep playing,'' Rhoden said. ''My back is fine except when I start to throw a little. I went through it last year and I didn't want to go through it again.'' Rhoden won 16 games for the Yankees in 1987 and 12 in 1988 before being traded to the Houston Astros in 1989.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21

title: Upheaval in the East;   West Germans Barring Door To Their Kin From the East
description: Last fall, the first waves of East German refugees were greeted with tears and Champagne. Now they are increasingly met with resentment and disdain.

title: Fernandez and O'Connor Clash on Drug-Counseling Sites
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and John Cardinal O'Connor have come into conflict over where publicly financed drug counselors should work with parochial school students.

title: Fisher-Price Plant to Close
description: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that it planned to close one of its five large toy plants for its Fisher-Price division. The closing will result in a charge against earnings of about $11 million, or 8 cents a share, in the third quarter ending on March 31.

title: A Modest Favorite Emerges for the Derby
description: If the 116th Kentucky Derby were being run in 6 days rather than 66, the favorite would be Slavic, and smart-aleck handicappers would be waiting on long lines trying to beat him.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   NICARAGUAN RIVALS FOCUS ON CONTRAS IN ELECTION'S WAKE
description: Three days after his Government was routed in national elections, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today declared an immediate cease-fire with the American-supported contras.

title: Daphne Arnstein; Arts Group Founder In Harlem Was 78
description: Daphne Barritt-Vane Arnstein, an arts patron who founded the Harlem Cultural Council and was a co-founder of the Jazzmobile, died of heart disease Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Consumers Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $24,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $108,000, or 3 cents a share for the year. Year-ago quarter and year results are restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS No. 97.

title: Burnup & Sims reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months included 17 cents a share and 16 cents a share, respectively, both from the sale of investment property.

title: Philips Industries N.V. In Management Shifts
description: Philips Industries N.V., the worldwide electronics and industrial company based in the Netherlands, yesterday announced the planned retirement of Cornelis J. van der Klugt, the company's president and the chairman of the management board.

title: RJR Nabisco Bonds Fall
description: Prices of RJR Nabisco Inc.'s bonds dropped sharply yesterday in an otherwise steady ''junk bond'' market. Prices of some of the company's bonds fell almost 3 points during the day but rebounded in the afternoon. Rumors, which were denied by the company, circulated that it would be unable to make its interest payments.

title: Senators Debate Ways of Using Military Savings
description: The Senate abruptly opened debate today on whether to use the anticipated reductions in military spending for tax cuts or to finance domestic programs, including education and anti-drug efforts.

title: Military Crew for Flight of Shuttle Atlantis
description: John O. Creighton

title: Incumbency Benefits Republicans Equally
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Stocks Fall 2.2%, Ending a 2-Day Rally
description: Rising interest rates and weakness in the yen abruptly reversed a two-day stock market rally and sent prices sharply lower here today.

title: Acme United reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter and year figures included a charge of $1 million from the discounting of a product line and a loss of $580,000 from higher overhead costs related to a reduction in inventories.

title: Cimco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Fund Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell for tax-exempt funds and were unchanged for taxable funds in the week ended yesterday compared with the week before.

title: Clemson Case Revised
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association dropped one of 14 charges of recruiting violations against Clemson's program and amended two others, university officials said yesterday.

title: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. reports earnings for 14wks to Feb 3
description: b-After an extraordinary earthquake loss, net of income taxes of $10,500,000. c-After an extraordinary charge from costs related to the early retirement of debt of $8,300,000 for both the 14 weeks and 27 weeks, and the 27 weeks also included a gain of $15,300,000, or 70 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes. Year-ago second quarter included 13 weeks ended Jan. 28, 1989 and 26 weeks in the fiscal 1989 period.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Dollar Makes Broad Gains Against Mark and Pound
description: Making one of its first broad upward moves of the year, the dollar yesterday rose against the mark, the pound and the Swiss franc.

title: Carmine S. Bellino, 84, Is Dead; A Top Congressional Investigator
description: Carmine S. Bellino, a Congressional investigator for 30 years who was credited with a major role in bringing about the downfall of the teamster leaders James R. Hoffa and Dave Beck, died of prostate cancer on Tuesday at his home in Coconut Creek, Fla., where he had lived in retirement since 1983. He was 84 years old.

title: Twins Sign Candelaria
description: The Minnesota Twins reached contract terms yesterday with the free agent left-hander John Candelaria, a 16-year veteran.

title: Corken International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $31,000, or 1 cent a share, from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. The 1989 figures included the results of Metal Goods Manuafacturing Co., acquired in June 1989.

title: Nahum N. Glatzer Is Dead at 86; Wrote About Jewish Philosophy
description: Nahum N. Glatzer, a scholar, an editor and the author of many works on literature and Jewish philosophy, died on Tuesday after several days in a coma in Tucson, Ariz., where he was spending the winter. He was 86 years old and lived in Watertown, Mass.

title: Del Taco Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net income and included an after- tax gain of $6,520,000, or 76 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Applebee's restaurant business in March 1988.

title: Goodyear Resignation
description: James K. DeVoe, the vice president for worldwide advertising at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, resigned yesterday to become a principal in and the president of an advertising agency in Ohio. Mr. DeVoe, who previously held executive positions at BBDO and N. W. Ayer in New York and at RCA Consumer Electronics, would not disclose the name of the agency he was joining. Mr. DeVoe was involved in the shift of Goodyear's advertising account from the J. Walter Thompson Company to Young & Rubicam in 1987 and then back to Thompson last year.

title: Primark Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,011,000 which included operating loss from Aviation Group Inc., which ceased aviation operations on Dec. 31; and also included an extraordinary loss of $1,387,000 which included a loss on sale of Aviation Group. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $38,678,000, or $1.98 a share, which included income from Telerent Leasing Corp. and Michcon, both disposed of in 1988 and also included operating loss from Aviation Group. The period also included an extraordinary loss of $8,701,000, which included loss on sale of Telerent and gain on sale of Michcon, and an accounting adjustment loss of $1,580,000.

title: Masstor Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the year was after a loss of $8,097,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Hanover Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included investment gains of $2,078,000 for the quarter and $26,288,000 for the year, compared with $3,476,000 and $8,866,000 for same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Ex-Banker to Help U.S. in Marcos Case
description: A former bank executive who was charged with helping Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos transfer $168 million from the Philippines to the United States pleaded guilty yesterday to mail fraud.

title: Alaska Volcano Erupts Again, Sending Ash Into Anchorage
description: The Redoubt Volcano erupted twice in an hour today, disrupting airline flights and dropping ash on Anchorage for the first time since the 10,197-foot peak resumed its sporadic emissions in December after being dormant for more than two decades.

title: Goal Systems International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Gingerly, Rangers Are Adjusting to Top
description: It stares them in the face, yet still does not roll off their tongues. First place, after all, is a fairly foreign concept, so the Rangers speak of it haltingly. Nearly half a century of finishing someplace other than in first will do that to an organization.

title: Upheaval in the East: Ukraine;   Apathy Called Greatest Foe in Ukrainian Elections
description: On a recent warm evening, 14 candidates for the Ukrainian parliament gathered at a hall here to promote their programs to voters in this agricultural and industrial region.

title: In the Weill Empire, Some Mixed Results
description: Sanford I. (Sandy) Weill built one Wall Street empire with a keen eye for value that helped make up for the fact he did not start with a lot of money.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of malfunctions in The Times's newsroom computer network on Tuesday, the News Summary and several articles were omitted from some editions yesterday, or were mutilated. Printing and distribution in some areas were also delayed. The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers.

title: Unilever reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and share earnings are per Fl.4 of ordinary capital. The latest periods are based on 1 pound sterling equaled Fl.3.08 equaled U.S. $1.60 and year- ago periods, 1 pound sterling equaled Fl.3.62 equaled U.S. $1.81.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Reagan Is Invited to Berlin
description: The East German press agency said today that former President Ronald Reagan would make a campaign appearance for the liberal Alliance of Free Democrats.

title: Low U.S. Savings Rate: It's A Myth
description: The buzzword now is ''saving.''

title: Still Mysterious, Architect Gets Her Due
description: IN 1919, at the age of 49, Alice Washburn began designing and building houses at a furious pace. No one knows where the former schoolmistress acquired her architectural skill, but more than 80 of her Colonial Revival-style houses still stand in and around her hometown of Cheshire, Conn., just north of New Haven.

title: Difficulties In Filling Wall's Job
description: The Treasury Department's struggles to find a replacement for M. Danny Wall as the nation's top Federal savings and loan regulator are such that it could be weeks, even months, before a permanent successor is named, Government officials and industry experts said today.

title: At Embassy, a Clue to a Missing Girl
description: As soon as Ivian C. Smith, an American embassy official in Australia, picked the inquiry from the New Zealand police out of his fax machine last fall, he knew he had the key to the mystery in America's most publicized child custody case. The document showed that Hilary Foretich, the 7-year-old girl sent into hiding 30 months earlier, was in New Zealand with her grandparents.

title: Successes of New York's High Schools Aren't Credited Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Republic Pictures reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a writeoff for a cancelled first-run syndication series. c-Included a writeoff of $472,000.

title: Review/Television;   A Prime-Time Ratings Runaway With Low Costs
description: Fin de siecle jitters? Millennium madness? Sociocultural analysts are already busy trying to figure out why ABC's ''America's Funniest Home Videos'' has become television's latest blockbuster series. This phenomenon, folks, is already bigger than Morton Downey Jr. ever dreamed of being. A new dimension has been added to ''reality'' entertainment.

title: TRW Deal Set
description: TRW Inc. plans to buy the electrical division of the Wickes Manufacturing Company to broaden its range of electronic systems and other components in the information systems industry. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. TRW supplies high-technology products and services primarily to the automotive, space, military and information systems markets worldwide. Last year, its sales totaled more than $7.3 billion. The Wickes Electrical division had 1989 assets of $75 million. After the deal is completed, it will become part of TRW's Controls and Fasteners group.

title: Joel M. Tropper, Stage Manager, 46
description: Joel M. Tropper, a stage manager, died of AIDS on Friday in Orlando, Fla. He was 46 years old. Mr. Tropper was a member of Actors' Equity and a founding member and former chairman of the Stage Managers' Association. He managed many Broadway shows, including ''Woman of the Year,'' ''Ain't Misbehavin','' ''Beatlemania,'' ''Porgy and Bess,'' ''Rags'' and ''Elvis.''

title: Residents of Covenant House Split on Its Future and Ritter
description: On this they agreed: after decades of devoted, even life-saving work, Covenant House is suffering an unjust damage to its reputation. But in the wake of the Rev. Bruce Ritter's decision to leave the organization he founded, staff members and residents were divided on other questions.

title: First American Health Conepts reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Accounts
description: * Movietime, a cable television entertainment news service, to BBDO Los Angeles.

title: Swedish Prices Up 3.2%
description: Swedish consumer prices jumped 3.2 percent in January, the highest monthly increase in a decade, from four-tenths of a percent the previous month, the Central Bureau of Statistics said Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Tuesday about Roger A. Enrico, president of Pepsico Worldwide Beverages, misstated his age. He is 45 years old.

title: Ballistic Recovery Systems reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
FPI Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $7,500,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said the extraordianry charge is a provision for estimated reationalization costs. Latest fourth-quarter results included operations of Clouston Foods Canada Ltd., aquired in October. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 5 Laws Cited In Indictment For Oil Spill
description: A Federal grand jury in Alaska invoked five Federal statutes on Tuesday when it indicted the Exxon Corporation and the Exxon Shipping Company on felony and misdemeanor charges in the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: Dr. Joseph Dalven, 90; Led Home for the Aged
description: Dr. Joseph Dalven, a doctor who practiced medicine for more than 60 years, died on Tuesday at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn after a short illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Metro Matters;   For Chancellor, Inroads Mixed With Questions
description: When Joseph A. Fernandez was named New York City schools chancellor six months ago, he shrewdly understood that his predecessor, the late Dr. Richard R. Green, had been all but doomed by two factors: high public expectations and his own failure to identify short-term, achievable and visible goals.

title: Expeditors International Washington reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Regiments of Flowers Protesting Winter's Iron Rule
description: SPRING has been teasing for weeks. It's particularly hard on gardeners tortured by a torrent of mail-order catalogues with pictures of perfect plants. If sanity is to prevail through the latest blast of Arctic air, the antidote might be a pilgrimage to one of those annual extravaganzas called flower shows. The dazzling displays on show or impending in Philadelphia, Morristown, N.J., New York and Boston, all in striking distance of each other, should give gardeners enough of a sense of summer to last until winter ends.

title: Close to Home
description: TO get from where I am staying to where I am presumably working is a curious journey. I am in a motel, the plain kind, the kind without a strip of paper across the toilet seat and complimentary shampoo and a bed that will tickle your back if you put money in the slot. From the window in the shag-carpeted living room, I can see a little courtyard and rooms just like mine. From the window in the tiny kitchen, I can see another motel. I am in transients' territory. Let me call this place Purgatory. When I leave my room, I cross a parking lot, then a highway and, following a curving walkway, eventually enter a hospital lobby. Flowers and books and gift-wrapped toiletries are sold in this lobby, and someone is always getting on one of its elevators carrying a balloon arrangement. A balloon arrangement, I gather, has a greater cheer-up potential than a flower arrangement.

title: PRETORIA LEADERS LINKED TO KILLINGS
description: A retired South African police captain who has said he commanded a ''hit squad'' that killed Government opponents says he has evidence that killings were authorized at the highest levels of the South Africa Government.

title: Rome Journal;   Court Prevents Adoption and Fight Tugs at Child
description: In the milky light of a fading Roman afternoon, surrounded in her sitting room by books and family photographs, Natalia Ginzburg admitted that she was taken aback by the uproar suddenly swirling around her.

title: From Siberia, Songs of Love and Shaman's Dances
description: Sakhalin is a long, mountainous and heavily forested Siberian island with a rugged climate and a turbulent history as a colony of Japan and Russia. Off the coast of the Soviet Far East, between the Sea of Okhotsk and the Sea of Japan, Sakhalin was once a czarist place of exile and provided Chekhov with the basis for a study called ''The Island of Sakhalin.'' But the colorful history and culture of Sakhalin have been influenced by Korea and China, too, and by indigenous groups like the Orok, Nivkh and Nanai peoples.

title: KEY RATES
Cheeks Faces Old Team Tonight at the Garden
description: At some point early in tonight's game at Madison Square Garden between the Atlantic Division-leading Knicks and the second-place Philadelphia 76ers, Maurice Cheeks will replace Mark Jackson as New York's playmaker.

title: Groundwater Technology Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 27
Diaries Are Accurate Even if Reagan Forgot, Poindexter Says
description: John M. Poindexter said in court papers filed today that he believed that Ronald Reagan's diaries while President accurately documented important Iran-contra events that Mr. Reagan now says he has forgotten.

title: Events: Crafts and Psychology of Color
description: aryland Market, Baltimore Convention Center and Festival Hall, Pratt Street between Charles and Conway Streets, Baltimore; 301-962-1122.

title: Oneida Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $1.4 million, or 14 cents a share, on the sale of the company's manufacturing facilities in Bangor, northern Ireland. The latest year and both year-ago periods were restated for 10 percent common stock dividend paid Nov. 17, 1989.

title: Review/Recital;   Love Songs For Tenor And Lute
description: The program of love songs from 17th-century England and Italy presented by the English tenor Nigel Rogers and the American lutanist Paul O'Dette at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening seemed a sort of work in progress. After the Stagebill was printed, the performers substituted one Henry Lawes tune for another, split up and reordered a group of works by Sigismondo d'India and replaced a group of songs by Alessandro Grandi with a cantata by Antonio Cesti. Mr. Rogers announced these changes from the stage with good humor, adding a further air of improvisation and informality to an evening that combined the highest art with utter naturalness.

title: Rights of M.S. Patients
description: To The Home Section:

title: Canadian Roxy Pete reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MAYOR OF CAPITAL PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. pleaded not guilty today to all eight drug and perjury counts against him and predicted that he would be vindicated at trial.

title: Waban Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available; company spun off from Zayre Corp. in June 1989.

title: Tests of Cockpit Radiation Show Levels Above a Federal Standard
description: The first cockpit radiation measurements presented to an aviation health panel confirmed estimates by experts that some airline crew members receive more radiation than the limit set by health officials for pregnant women, panel members said here today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Everex Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A Traditionalist Takes On Feminists Over Shakespeare
description: In one of her best-known essays, Virginia Woolf asks what would have happened if Shakespeare had had a sister every bit as brilliant as he. She answers that the sister, crushed by the anti-feminist oppression of 16th-century English society, would have found it impossible to become a playwright. If for Shakespeare, the great plays were veritable miracles, Woolf writes, they would have been impossible for his imaginary sister.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;   Justices Uphold Property Searches Of Foreigners in Foreign Countries
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution's prohibition against unreasonable searches does not bar American law-enforcement agents who lack warrants from searching and seizing property owned by foreigners in foreign countries.

title: Dynascan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $1.7 million pretax fourth-quarter 1989 charge for consolidation of the company's audio group and $1.5 million fourth-quarter charge for an inventory writedown by its Lloyd's audio unit.

title: Nicaragua, Victory U.S. Fair Play
description: The Nicaraguan election has proved that open, honorable support for a democratic process is one of the most powerful foreign policy tools at Washington's disposal. It is more effective than the sordid practice of using the Central Intelligence Agency to engineer coups and secretly finance political parties. It is more legitimate than military force, and, in this case, it has been more decisive.

title: ON MY MIND Our German Business
description: Time and again hypocrisy, falsehood and self-delusion catch up with us as individuals, just as we had feared and known they would.

title: Blood Tests Link Golub to Crime Scene
description: A police expert testified today that blood found on the clothing of 13-year-old Kelly Ann Tinyes and on attache cases in which her clothing was stuffed matched the blood of Robert Golub.

title: Grace O'Brien O'Neill, Child Psychologist, 87
description: Grace O'Brien O'Neill, a child psychologist who developed innovative programs for the New York City Department of Health in the 1950's, died of cardiac arrest on Feb. 15 at Reston Hospital in Virginia. She was 87 years old and had lived in Leonia, N.J., for 60 years.

title: Home Improvement
description: WALLPAPERING requires skill and practice. Two techniques that are essential - attaching wallpaper to inside and outside corners - are described here.

title: Washington Opera Announces New Season
description: The Washington Opera is to present a new production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' next season at the Kennedy Center to mark the 200th anniversary of the opera's first performance, the company's general director, Martin Feinstein, has announced.

title: Substance Blocks Cold Viruses in Test Tube
description: Researchers have developed a substance that prevents major cold viruses from infecting cells in preliminary laboratory tests. But they caution that the achievement is still far from a cure for the common cold.

title: Scana Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transportation Chief Named in New Jersey
description: Gov. Jim Florio yesterday named Thomas M. Downs, the head of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, as New Jersey's commissioner of transportation.

title: Talking Deals;   The Bass Profits In Savings Bailout
description: A FAVORITE pastime of banking experts in late 1988 was to try to figure out which were the sweetest of the deals the Government had struck to sell insolvent savings and loan institutions to investors.

title: Carbide to Retain Core Businesses
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it would continue operating its core businesses, dashing speculation about a possible takeover of the company or a sale of its primary operations. Robert D. Kennedy, the chemical company's chairman and chief executive, said it planned ''to continue operating the three core businesses of Union Carbide Corp. within the company's existing structure.'' A company statement said the board unanimously endorsed the strategy on Wednesday.

title: Ex-Vice President at Orion Is Chief of Tri-Star Pictures
description: Michael Medavoy, who began his Hollywood career in the mailroom at Universal Studios, has been named chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, with responsibility for developing, producing and marketing Tri-Star products, Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., Tri-Star's parent, has announced.

title: Drivers and Dogs Prepare to Take On Alaska
description: Alaska's annual grueling 1,200-mile Iditarod sled-dog race from Anchorage to Nome over some of the most remote terrain in the world begins Saturday.

title: Fortis Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Which Regency?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Frederick Peters, 81, Publishing Executive
description: Frederick P. Peters, retired executive vice president of the Reinhold Publishing Company in Manhattan and a former professor of management, died of a ruptured aorta on Sunday at the Southwest Florida Regional Medical Center in Fort Myers. He was 81 years old and lived in Naples, Fla., and Summit, N.J.

title: A SPLINTER PARTY FORMED IN ISRAEL
description: Five Likud members of the Israeli Parliament, 13 percent of the party's strength in Parliament, announced the formation of their own opposition party today, putting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who is already in deep political trouble, in an even more excruciating predicament.

title: Forstmann Ends Effort For Fund
description: Theodore J. Forstmann, a senior partner at Forstmann Little & Company, told investors yesterday that he had given up his efforts to raise money for a new investment fund.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: With Progress Stalled, Both Sides Try Some Tough Talk
description: While talks in baseball's labor dispute have cooled down, talk has heated up.

title: Retiring Agents Sharply Attack Drug Policies
description: The agent in charge of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in New York City and a top undercover agent for it are leaving the D.E.A. with harsh words about Federal drug policy, saying that it is ill conceived and that the Government's operations abroad are futile.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: The image of the asthmatic child wheezing on the sidelines, pale and puny, while other children run and jump is fading fast as physicians and patients discover that exercise is not only possible but actually helpful for people with asthma.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Stunned Sandinistas Seek To Define Their New Role
description: Still in shock from their defeat in Sunday's election, leaders and loyalists of the Sandinista National Liberation Front are struggling to redefine their revolutionary movement as a more conventional political party.

title: New York's Patrol Officers to Go on Steady Shifts
description: The New York City Police Department has reversed a longstanding policy and will begin assigning uniformed officers to steady shifts by September, the First Deputy Commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said yesterday.

title: After Delays, Shuttle Launched on Secret Mission
description: The space shuttle Atlantis pierced a cloud-strewn night sky with fire and thunder early today as it lifted off on a secret military mission.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Southern California Quake Rattles Buildings and Nerves
description: A moderately strong earthquake rumbled across Southern California this afternoon, shaking buildings and nerves from Santa Barbara to the Mexican border and even as far east as Las Vegas, 225 miles away.

title: The Battle Of Bedtime: Children Won
description: STEPHEN CECCHETTI, an economist who lives in Columbus, Ohio, says his 2-year-old son Daniel stays up every night until 10 or 10:30. Mr. Cecchetti would like Daniel to go to bed earlier, but he doesn't insist. ''We're not disciplined people,'' says Mr. Cecchetti, whose wife, Ruth Charney, is a mathematician.

title: Harley-Davidson Investor in Filing
description: The Rochester investor Malcolm I. Glazer has recommended that Harley-Davidson Inc. spin off its Holiday Rambler Corporation unit and distribute the proceeds to shareholders. Mr. Glazer suggested in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the division could be spun off as a public company, with the shares being distributed to holders.

title: Review/Dance;   Mozart Allusions and a Fandango That's a Bolero
description: Any dance work by a superb choreographer like Lar Lubovitch is of interest, and the two premieres his company presented at its opening on Tuesday night embody experiments of eye-riveting extremes.

title: Shifts in U.S. Policy Sought To Spur Caribbean Trade
description: By most accounts, the 1984 Reagan Administration plan to increase American trade with 27 nations in the Caribbean and Central America has yet to become what many hailed it at the time: the catalyst needed to generate new industries and more varied agriculture among a largely poor assemblage of one-crop economies.

title: Friends of Animals?
description: To the Editor:

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: DON PEPPERS, whose brash personality and outrageous tactics made him one of the advertising industry's best-known scouts for new business, disclosed yesterday that he was leaving Lintas U.S.A. to become head of worldwide new business development at Chiat/ Day/Mojo.

title: Tech-Sym Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Reviews/Music;   Zydeco Group: Rock-and-Roll And Retrograde
description: Young, high-powered and straight from the bayou country of Opelousas, La., the Sam Brothers are zydeco's next generation - one that knows its rock-and-roll but that isn't about to abandon the two-step. The six-member band is making what is reportedly its first New York City appearance through Thursday at Tramps, 45 West 21st Street. On Tuesday, which was Mardi Gras night, the band's first set made its way backward through juke-joint history, from zydeco versions of recent songs through rhythm-and-blues, blues and raw, driving two-steps.

description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase over the next year about $2 billion in home mortgages orginated by the Sears Mortgage Corporation, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

It was David Cole, not David Lerner, who represented the National Organization for Women. Mr. Cole is a lawyer with the Center for Constitutional Rights; David Lerner is a spokesman for the center.

ZIMROTH, who served as Corporation Counsel for the past three years, has joined Arnold & Porter, Washington's largest law firm. He will be the resident partner in the Manhattan office.

description: Rescuers used hoes and shovels today to dig through thick mud and rock that swept across a Peruvian jungle village, killing at least 21 people. A further 100 bodies are believed to be buried in the mud.

description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;   Grand Army Plaza's Rather Grand History
description: GRAND ARMY PLAZA, at Fifth Avenue and Central Park South, is not only one of Manhattan's famous crossroads, but also the subject of an exhibit.

title: GRUMBLING GROWS IN CHINA'S MILITARY
description: China's 3.1 million soldiers are enjoying a higher budget as their reward for crushing the democracy movement last summer, but Chinese officials say significant tensions are festering within the military leadership.

description: Fitch Investors Service downgraded the debt ratings of Merrill Lynch & Company Tuesday, citing lower levels of profitability.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Decline 0.6%
description: Prices farmers received for raw products declined six-tenths of 1 percent from January to February, but the overall commodity index still averaged 2.7 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Andover Togs reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Marketplace;   Behind the Gains In Air Freight
description: AFTER a decade of price wars, the American overnight document and parcel delivery industry has consolidated into three companies that are raising prices and increasing earnings in the domestic market. While shares in the Federal Express Corporation and the Airborne Freight Corporation have climbed sharply recently, analysts say some of the gains have been the result of acquisition rumors. The third company, United Parcel Service, is privately owned.

title: Head of Varian to Try 'More Balanced Attack'
description: In joining Varian Associates as chairman and chief executive, J. Tracy O'Rourke says he sees his mission as ''revitalizing the company.'' Mr. O'Rourke comes from the Rockwell International Corporation, where he was one of three executive vice presidents and co-chief operating officers.

title: Strong Hoya Defense Defeats Connecticut
description: At the time of the basketball season when they are approaching final examinations, the Hoyas of Georgetown University appear to be mastering their makeup work in John Thompson's course on assertiveness.

title: Reviews/Music;   St. Luke's Orchestra In All-Rieti Program
description: Michael Feldman, the artistic director of the various St. Luke's musical ensembles, studied with Vittorio Rieti, which is one explanation for the admirable St. Luke's loyalty to that composer's music. The loyalty has expressed itself in all-Rieti concerts by the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble every two or three years, the most recent being Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: U.S. Won't Join Hughes Lawsuit
description: The Justice Department said it would not join in a whistle-blower lawsuit that charged the Hughes Aircraft Company with selling $3.2 billion in potentially flawed computer chips to the Navy. A spokesman said the department would ''not join the suit at this time.'' Richard Dore, a Hughes spokesman, said, ''Obviously, we're very satisfied with the Government's decision.''

title: Brooklyn Man Seized In 'Silver Gun' Rapes
description: A Brooklyn parolee has been charged as the ''silver gun rapist'' responsible for a dozen robberies and at least six rapes in three boroughs since January, the police said yesterday.

title: Harper Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,761,000, or 29 cents a share, on the sale of property located in Tokyo, partially offset by writedowns of computer equipment and software costs.

title: Exxon Valdez: The Spill, the Cleanup and the Charges
description: March 24, 1989: The 987-foot tanker Exxon Valdez runs aground on Bligh Reef 25 miles south of Valdez, Alaska, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound.

title: Parent & Child
description: ''I HAVEN'T spoken to my parents in eight years,'' said Nancy S., who is 31 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in a suburb of Minneapolis.

title: Doskocil in Default On $133 Million Loan
description: The Doskocil Companies, a meat-processing concern, said today that it was in default on a $133 million loan made by the Chemical Banking Corporation and a group of other lenders.

title: Air Express International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-recurring gains of about $650,000, or 13 cents a share and $900,000, or 18 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: British Trade Gap Grows
description: Britain said today that the country's foreign trade deficit more than doubled in January from December. The deficit was $:1.88 billion, or $3.16 billion, compared with the revised $:817 million, or $1.37 billion, gap for December. The Central Statistical Office attributed the size of the January gap, which was larger than had been expected, to a deficit in several items that were expected to show a small surplus. These included larger imports of diamonds and smaller exports of aircraft.

title: Scaasi's Spring: Bring On the Flowers
description: ARNOLD SCAASI opened his spring fashion extravaganza yesterday in his Fifth Avenue salon, where forsythia and white tulips were set in silver swans and black and green tote bags holding his perfume were on each seat.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   Kohl Takes Tentative Step On Polish Border Proposal
description: Under pressure at home and abroad, Chancellor Helmut Kohl took a tentative step today toward meeting Poland's demands for a guarantee of its western border once Germany is reunited, but he again declined Warsaw's call for a provisional treaty.

title: Stocks Advance a Third Day; Dow Up 10.13
description: Stocks rose for the third session in a row yesterday on moderately higher volume, and the Dow Jones Industrial average, which was up more than 28 points in the early afternoon, finished 10.13 points higher at 2,627.25.

title: Lynch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Devon Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from an accounting adjustment of $3,912,000, or 56 cents a share.

title: A Hero in Canton, a Harbinger of Prosperity
description: He shies from hand-shaking campaigns and rarely comes out for tree-planting ceremonies even as other Chinese leaders are embracing babies and putting on their best smiles for journalists. But Ye Xuanping nevertheless appears to be one of the most popular political figures in China.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction a front-page article yesterday about Federal diet recommendations appeared in an unfinished version, and described the recommendations incompletely. They were the first call by a Federal agency for a specific reduction in dietary fat content, not the first for a reduction in general. The article also misstated one recommendation; it calls for holding saturated fat (not unsaturated fat) below 10 percent of calories consumed. An adjoining chart also misstated the current consumption of saturated fat; it averages 13 percent. The article also misstated the amount of cholesterol in a large egg. It is 213 milligrams, not 274.

title: Diana Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 6
description: b-Included net gains of $11,206,000 in the latest 9 months, and $1,044,000 in the year-ago 9-month period, related to disposition of operations. c-Included a $400,000 net loss from disposition of operations. d-Net loss

title: Abandoned Newborn Girl Dies
description: A newborn baby girl died last night shortly after she was found in a garbage can in front of an apartment building in the Van Nest section of the Bronx, the police said. The infant's faint cries were heard shortly after 5 P.M. by the building's landlord, said the police. A neighbor helped the landlord lift the lid and pull out a duffel bag. Inside, they found the infant, just as a sanitation truck arrived to make a pick up, the police said. The neighbor called an ambulance, which took the infant, who was about two hours old, to Jacobi Hospital where she was pronounced dead at 6:12 P.M.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Dinkins Warns of a Rise in the Budget Gap
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that New York City faces an additional revenue shortfall of $75 million for the fiscal year that ends June 30, an amount that widens the city's current budget gap to almost $520 million and could lead to a deficit of $1.1 billion for next year.

title: No Charges Against Ritter On Finances
description: The Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday that despite ''some questionable financial transactions,'' no criminal charges would be brought against the Rev. Bruce Ritter, who resigned unexpectedly on Tuesday night as president of Covenant House.

title: Forest Oil Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1988 fourth quarter revenue included receipt of $8.1 million of revenue primarily from the settlement of a take or pay dispute.

title: New York Plans to Double-Bunk Inmates in 10 of Its State Prisons
description: Struggling to house an ever-increasing number of prisoners, New York State will double the capacity of many of its medium-security prisons by installing bunk beds for the first time, Cuomo administration officials said today.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Chrysler Rebates
description: The Chrysler Corporation extended its guaranteed rebate program through the end of March. The cash incentives range from $500 to $2,000 off the price of all Chrysler cars and trucks except for the popular mini-vans and the LeBaron convertible models. The announcement marks the second time Chrysler has extended the rebates since they were introduced in mid-December. Under the program, Chrysler guarantees that rebates on current models will not increase before Sept. 30. If the rebates rise, the buyer receives the difference.

title: No-Fault for Doctors Is Called Feasible
description: A system of no-fault medical malpractice insurance, which would compensate victims of medical injury without a judicial finding of negligence, would not cost significantly more than the existing liability system, according to a state-sponsored study of malpractice in New York hospitals that was released yesterday.

title: Don't Worry About Air Travel Radiation Doses;   Concorde No Riskier
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;   Let's See: the Big Hand Is on the IRT, and . . .
description: DRENTTEL DOYLE PARTNERS, a design and advertising concern in Manhattan, has designed three watches that are both witty and slightly hard to read. One shows the numbers on the rotary dial telephone, one the numbers on an oven dial and the third the numbers of subway trains.

title: Undermining the Undercount Remedy
description: This year's census, which the Commerce Department says may be ''the best ever,'' could prove the worst in decades for big cities with many hard-to-count people. And now Commerce is reneging on a promise to take a fresh, open-minded look at its methods. It has proposed stiff guidelines that would doom the nation to another undercount of urban minorities.

title: CML Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $14,710,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the quarter also included an extraordinary charge of $1,215,000. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $344,000 for the quarter and $979,000 for the 6 months.

title: Dial REIT Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Sunshine-Jr. Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $622,735, or 36 cents a share.

title: Alamco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $119,000 and $669,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After extraordinary charges from debt extinguishment of $159,000 for the quarter and $9,000 for the year. Year-ago quarter and year's shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 1-for-10 reverse stock split paid in December 1989.

title: Little Space, Lots of Style, At $50 a Month
description: ABOUT five years ago, Mark Ohe and Leslie Steven came to Manhattan from Chicago feeling sure they would be able to find a place in which they could both live and work. They did. It just wasn't as easy as they thought it would be.

title: Toll Brothers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Revenues for 1989 were restated to reflect consolidation of mortgage financing partnerships.

title: Bridge
description: The body responsible for tournament play in New York City is the Greater New York Bridge Association, which has had many problems in recent years. The principal ones have been falling attendance and the difficulty in finding appropriate tournament sites.

title: INSIDE
description: An Economic Improvement Is Revealed in Latest Data

title: 2 Wounded in Blast at Madrid Post Office
description: A bombing campaign in Madrid attributed to Basque separatists continued today as a parcel blew up at the main post office and an explosive sent to a Government prosecutor was discovered.

title: Valspar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Freymiller Trucking Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Imperial Metals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an unspecified gain on the sale of property. c-Included the gain on the sale of property and a $3.7 million gain on dilution of the company's interest in Anglesey Mining Plc. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Texfi Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: Per-share net figures reduced by preferred dividend requirements.

title: People
description: * G. Brian Goodall has been promoted to executive vice president at Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago.

title: Lockheed Board's 'Greenmail' Stance
description: The Lockheed Corporation, defending itself against a planned proxy fight by the Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons, said its board had passed a resolution affirming its opposition to the payment of ''greenmail.'' A proposal made on Monday by Mr. Simmons, who owns 18.9 percent of Lockheed, would ban such payments on stock held less than two years. Greenmail is the payment by a company for stock held by a potential suitor at a price above market value.

title: Late Goal Beats Islanders
description: It was an unusual rookie whose late goal beat the Islanders, 4-3, tonight and dropped them into third place in the Patrick Division. Daniel Shank of the Red Wings scored with with 1 minute 31 seconds left, leaving the Islanders below .500 for the first time since Jan. 13 and extending their streak without a victory to seven games, a season high.

title: Dillard Department Stores reports earnings for 14wks to Feb 3
description: Year-ago quarter and year consisted of 13 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively.

title: Minnesota Bill Limiting Abortions Loses Ground
description: A bill that would ban most abortions in Minnesota failed to be recommended by a State Senate committee today, but the author refused to concede defeat.

title: Galveston-Houston Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Storm Stirs Fires on Corsica
description: The Atlantic storm that has killed at least 53 people in northern Europe has reached the Mediterranean, turning small blazes on this island into major brush fires. In Nancy, in eastern France, a motorist died when he was blown off an icy road late Tuesday. Fifty-three deaths have been reported since the storm struck Monday: 17 in Britain, 12 in West Germany, 3 in East Germany, 11 in France, 5 in Belgium, 2 in Switzerland and 1 each in Ireland, Italy and the Netherlands.

title: The Homelessness Test;   There Is a Right Answer
description: >Why did so many people, especially the mentally ill, begin living on the streets of New York City during the 1980's?

title: Peace Talks on Cambodia Break Down
description: The latest peace talks on Cambodia broke down early this morning, with the rival Cambodian factions unable to agree on even a carefully worded communique that elided the central issue: a role for the United Nations in the administration of the country before new elections.

title: Ares-Serono Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Volkswagen's U.S. Outlook
description: Volkswagen is ''in a mess'' in the United States but will not pull out of the market, an executive of the company's American operations said today.

title: Offensive Woes Continue for Devils
description: The Devils managed a single goal against the National Hockey League's worst defense tonight and suffered a 2-1 defeat to the Penguins, who had allowed 14 goals in losing their previous two games.

title: Princeton Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings are diluted. The company said latest fourth- quarter net reflected weaker copper prices and lower-than-anticipated metals output at the Similco copper mine. Revenue for 1989 reflected the consolidation of Similco results for the full year, compared with 7 months in 1988. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CSM Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said financial statements reflect treating progress receivables on long-term contracts not billed to customers as revenues. These amounts also reflect the proportionate elements of profit as revenues based on the stage of completion of the long-term contract.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuania Steps Up Drive to Leave Soviet Union
description: The republic of Lithuania stepped up its campaign to leave the Soviet Union today, announcing a new round of parliamentary elections in concern that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will soon have stronger emergency powers to oppose secession.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Bush Seeks Soviet Help In Nicaragua Transition
description: President Bush appealed today to the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to help insure an orderly transfer of power in Nicaragua, Administration officials said today.

title: Home Resale Rate Off 2.2%
description: Sales of existing homes declined 2.2 percent in January, as rising mortgage interest rates and the usual winter lull combined to reduce sales to their slowest pace since last summer, a real estate trade group said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., named Karl R. Fledderjohn president of sector staff of Allied-Signal Aerospace Co., Torrance, Calif; Nicholas A. Cameron senior vice president and general manager for the chemical intermediates business at Allied-Signal Engineered Materials, and David C. Hill senior vice president and general manager of Engineered Industrial Fibers, Spectra Fibers and Metglas Products. The company also named Joseph M. DeVittorio senior vice president and general manager of Engineered Materials' home furnishings fibers business and appointed Daniel P. Burnham to succeed Mr. Fledderjohn as president of Allied-Signal's AiResearch Group.

title: Kinder and Grayer With the Baby Boom
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;   The Great OpportunityTo Sit in Your Own Lap
description: PHILLIP GRACE's trompe l'oeil portrait chairs combine function and art. If you commission your own portrait, you can sit in your own lap.

title: Bond Wins Court Ruling
description: The Bond Corporation, the embattled company headed by the flamboyant businessman Alan Bond, has won a key court battle to oust a creditor group that had control over some of its financial operations. Bond will revive negotiations to sell its Australian breweries.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie, Paris, the four-nation European consortium, said Japan Fleet Service-Singapore, a Singapore leasing company, ordered four A300-600R jets. No price was disclosed.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Republicans' Duty to the Schools
description: The success of New York City schools depends heavily on excellent teachers. But recruiting and keeping them is hampered by the Board of Examiners, an agency that has outlived its usefulness. The Republican State Senate refuses to abolish it. If it fails to do so in this session, students, teachers and voters will know precisely whom to blame.

title: Norman Blackburn, Writer, 86
description: Norman Blackburn, a writer and producer who worked in film, radio and television and whose movie credits included the Marx Brothers' ''Day at the Races'' and the ''Our Gang'' comedies, died on Feb. 21 after complications from hip surgery. He was 86 years old.

title: Books of the Times;   Of Chekhov's Sister and Her Chekhovian Life
description: Chekhov's Sister

title: New England Bank Signs Lending Pact
description: The Bank of New England Corporation, which lost more than $1.1 billion last year, said yesterday that it had signed agreements with Federal banking regulators that describe in unusual detail how it will improve its lending procedures and seek to recover its financial health.

title: Supercomputer Accord With Japan Advances
description: On the eve of a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Japanese and American negotiators said today that they had agreed to scrap a failed 1987 accord on supercomputers and ''work out new language'' to improve American access to the Japanese market.

title: Binks Stake Sold
description: Illinois Tool Works Inc., which on Feb. 20 made an unsolicited offer of $45 a share for the Binks Manufacturing Company, said its Ransburg Corporation subsidiary was selling some of its Binks holdings. Binks, based in Franklin Park, Ill., had rejected Illinois Tools' offer. Binks's stock closed today at $44.875, down 25 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: C.I.A. Says a Gorbachev Removal Is the Sole Threat to Soviet Change
description: The Director of Central Intelligence said today that changes in the Soviet Union's political and economic structure had progressed so far that only the removal of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and a forced return to Stalinist-style government could reverse them.

title: Worst Tire Inferno Has Put Focus on Disposal Problem
description: The largest tire fire ever in North America is serving as a reminder that one of the most significant waste disposal problems facing the United States and Canada is far from being solved.

title: Man Always Out of Step May Now Lead in East
description: Ibrahim Manfred Bohme is in Moscow today, to see Soviet officials, perhaps even President Mhahail S. Gorbachev.asast weekend he was elected chairman of the Social Democratic Party, a promotion that before the month is over might make him Prime Minister.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about international efforts to prevent another famine in East Africa referred incorrectly in some editions to one country involved. It is Ethiopia, not Egypt. (The other is the Sudan.)

title: Needle Plan Had a Role In Fight Against AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Unigesco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $12,900,000 and $13,400,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which represented the company's share of Provigo Inc.'s extraordinary losses; and losses from discontinued operations of $800,000 and $5,300,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Net income and included losses from discontinued operations of $600,000 and $2,900,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and an extraordinary losses of $900,000 and $1,600,000 for the same periods, respectively. Most of the increase in revenues is due to the acquisition of Sodisco Inc. last May. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Budapest and Moscow Suspend Troop Talks
description: Talks have broken down between the Soviet Union and Hungary on a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet troops, the official press agency M.T.I. said today.

title: Women Can Claim a Long Battlefield History;   The Custer Doctrine
description: To the Editor:

title:
LAW;

Where Rookies Are Turned Into Federal Judges
description: LEAD: However learned they may appear to be, judges newly appointed to the Federal bench do not arrive equipped with everything they need to know. They may be unfamiliar with case management or sentencing guidelines or entire substantive areas of law in which they will have to become experts virtually overnight.

title: When Panama Invasion Outwears Its Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music;   A Composer Gets a Party For His 85th
description: Essential Music, a group that devotes itself to the American experimental repertory, threw an 85th birthday party for the composer William Russell at Florence Gould Hall on Saturday evening. The occasion offered an opportunity to hear rarely performed works by a true original whom history has overlooked.

title: American International Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Regarding year-ago periods--the effect of adopting Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 97 was to reduce previously reported net income by $2.3 million for the quarter and $7.8 million for the year.

title: Comment on Mexican Debt
