description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said today that Mexico's recent debt-reduction accord was agreed upon hours after his Government secretly decided to suspend its foreign debt payments.

title: Prepayment Lag Is Changing Mortgage Security Values
description: A steady decline since 1986 in the rate of prepayments on single-family home mortgages is changing the relative values of mortgage securities, analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. are saying.

title: Wolfpack Subject Of State Inquiry
description: The North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation began a formal investigation today into gambling and point-shaving allegations involving members of the North Carolina State University basketball team.

title: Barkley Sparkles as 76ers Gain On Knicks
description: The Philadelphia 76ers were ahead, 88-86, and the Knicks were in the midst of a rally with two and a half minutes left in the fourth quarter when Charles Barkley decided to test Charles Oakley, one on one.

title: Reagan Aide Denies Report Of Talk at East Berlin Rally
description: A spokesman for former President Ronald Reagan said today there was no basis for a report by the East German press agency Wednesday that Mr. Reagan would speak at a political rally in East Berlin in support of a small grouping of liberal, centrist parties.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the movie version of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' TOM HANKS will play Sherman McCoy, the philandering, self-absorbed bond trader whose ''Yale chin'' and prep-school background figure prominently in the TOM WOLFE best seller. Mr. Hanks visited Yale yesterday, soaking up information and atmosphere. He toured the campus and ate at Mory's.

title: Spartans Are Taking Shot at Big Ten Title
description: Michigan State, a surprise in the Big Ten Conference this season, moved closer to its first conference championship in 11 years by defeating Michigan, 78-70, tonight before a sellout crowd at the Breslin Center.

title: Shuttle Deploys Spy Satellite
description: A $500 million spy satellite was deployed by the space shuttle's astronauts early today, space agency officials said.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Mel Hosansky, Editor, 64
description: Mel Hosansky, editor in chief of Successful Meetings magazine, died of liver cancer on Wednesday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: TV Weekend;   A View of the Gory Horrors Of Mozambique's Civil War
description: Even hardened followers of the nightly news may be shaken by ''Madness in Mozambique,'' which takes up most of tonight's edition of ''20/20.'' Tom Jarriel's report, at 10 P.M. on ABC, focuses on the youngest victims of a brutal, decadelong civil war in the poorest of the African states. It tells of boys as young as 8 years old turned into killers, of 10-year-old girls raped repeatedly, of children forced to witness or even participate in the murder of their parents. Thousands of people have reportedly been massacred, hundreds of villages destroyed, families torn apart.

title: Nautilus in Chapter 11
description: Nautilus Sports-Medical Industries Inc., which makes Nautilus exercise equipment, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. In documents filed in Roanoke, Va., the company listed $38.6 million in liabilities and $27.3 million in assets. The company was moved here in 1987 after it was purchased by Ward International Corp., owned by Dallas investor Travis Ward. Company attorney Ed Creel said Nautilus had received new financing from current lenders and that it had spoken to several prospective buyers.

title: Strawberry Checks Out
description: With a smile and a wave, Darryl Strawberry left the Smithers Center in Manhattan yesterday and headed off toward a court date today in California.

title: Farrakhan, Charging Distortions, Addresses His Remarks on Jews
description: Saying he wanted to end the longtime bitterness between himself and American Jews, the Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan has given interviews with two Washington newspapers this week in which he offered what he characterized as the correct version of his past statements perceived as anti-Semitic slurs.

title: Gorman-Rupp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Refected LIFO inventory adjustment, one-time costs of acquisition of Patterson Pump Co., and promotional expenses for new submersible sewage pump.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., said Earl G. Graves, publisher of Black Enterprise magazine, had been elected to its board.

title: Sale of F-16's Set
description: Portugal will buy 20 General Dynamics Corporation F-16 warplanes from the United States in the next three years for $450 million, a military spokesman said. A United States Embassy spokesman here said much of the cost would be met through grants under the Lajes Accord, which covers United States bases on Portugal's mid-Atlantic Azores Islands and military cooperation between the two NATO allies.

title: 'Roger & Me': Narrow, Simplistic, Wrong
description: Many people were outraged that Michael Moore's documentary, ''Roger & Me,'' was shut out in the Academy Award nominations. I can't understand why. The film mocks American culture brilliantly, but forfeits any claim to distinction by manipulating its audience to believe that General Motors abandoned Flint, Mich., in the pursuit of profits.

title: Salt Lake City On Olympic List
description: Salt Lake City was among six cities officially listed as candidates to be host to the 1998 Winter Olympic Games as the International Olympic Committee closed bidding today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GARDNER RUGG HATHAWAY, known as Gus, is the closest thing the Central Intelligence Agency has to George Smiley. He retired yesterday after 41 years, a long time considering that the agency has existed only 43 years.

title: Doctors Urged To Counsel All About AIDS
description: The State Health Department is starting a campaign calling on all health-care providers in New York to counsel their patients routinely about AIDS and to encourage testing for anyone at risk.

title: LICENSE IS GRANTED TO NUCLEAR PLANT IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to give an operating license to the Seabrook nuclear reactor, the New Hampshire plant that many experts consider the most fought-over nuclear project in America.

title: Fabia Drake Dies; Actress on Stage, TV And Screen Was 86
description: Fabia Drake, an actress whose career spanned 77 years with credits from the Shakespearean stage to television mini-series, died on Wednesday at her home. She was 86 years old.

title: Turner Broadcasting Loss
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. reported a fourth-quarter loss today of $111 million because of a refinancing last October to retire long-term debt.

title: More Protests Of Pantheon Resignation
description: The remaining senior editor at Pantheon Books resigned yesterday, following the departures of the four other senior editors in protest over the removal of Andre Schiffrin as managing director.

title: Stop Appealing Wetlands Appeals
description: Six years ago, New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation began to identify wetlands on Staten Island in New York City, and eventually published a ''tentative'' map showing which lots were wetlands. Some owners and prospective owners assumed they could build on any lot not classified as ''wet.''

title: Bush to Nominate Lehtinen As U.S. Prosecutor in Florida
description: The White House has announced that President Bush will nominate Dexter W. Lehtinen as United States Attorney for South Florida, a post he has held on an acting basis through nearly two years of controversy.

title: Sico Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $280,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Non-Lawyers to Be Partners In Firms in Nation's Capital
description: The District of Columbia Court of Appeals adopted a rule today that will allow non-lawyers to become partners in Washington law firms, the first time that will be permitted anywhere in the nation.

title: Hong Kong Warned on Passport Plan
description: In a move likely to raise anxieties in Hong Kong, China suggested today that it might not recognize foreign passports held by Hong Kong Chinese after the territory returns to China in 1997.

title: A Tribute of Contrasts At a Service for Forbes
description: More than 1,000 mourners mingled in sorrow and exuberance at a memorial service for Malcolm Forbes in St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue yesterday, and they included everybody from a former President and a movie star to Scots in kilts, motorcyclists in leather and Gallic players of the hunting horn who used to perform at Mr. Forbes's Normandy chateau.

title: Stocks End Higher for Fourth Day
description: Stock prices rose yesterday for a fourth consecutive day, with the Dow Jones industrial average eking out a gain of only 8.34 points. The Dow now stands at 2,635.59, having climbed more than 71 points so far this week.

title: Japanese Fear Problems From a Hasty Meeting
description: As Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu prepares to meet President Bush this weekend, Japanese officials say they are suddenly fearful that American demands for rapid action on trade issues could undermine the chances of Japanese concessions down the road.

title: Women Can Claim a Long Battlefield History
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Is Expanding Playoffs And Revenue From Television
description: The National Football League yesterday added two wild-card teams to its playoff format and in the process helped swell television revenue to an expected $30 million a team each year, an increase of $13 million a team.

title: Out of This Nettle
description: What happened in Nicaragua this week was not just a remarkable election. It was a victory for a new approach to intractable conflicts, turning them from bloodshed to the democratic political process.

title: Police Kill a Brooklyn Man; Officers' Account Disputed
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man who had threatened to stab himself died yesterday when he was struck by nine bullets fired by two police officers in his family's apartment, the police said.

title: Jack Conroy, Novelist, 91
description: Jack Conroy, a Depression-era novelist whose writings drew upon his childhood in a mining camp, died on Wednesday. He was 91 years old.

title: Orion Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment loss of $491,000. Year-ago quarter and prior year results reflected the inclusion, from Jan. 1, 1988, of Guaranty National Corp. on a fully consolidated basis, net of a provision for the portion of Guaranty National earnings which are attributable to shareholders other than the company. Accounting adjustment reflected the cumulative effect of adoption of SFAS No. 96.

title: 2 More Workers Fall Ill At Triborough Bridge
description: Two more workers at the Triborough Bridge fell ill yesterday of the mysterious ailment that struck 33 other bridge attendants a week ago.

title: Exxon Unit Head Resigns
description: The president of the Exxon Corporation's shipping subsidary, Frank Iarossi, announced yesterday that he was resigning to manage a standards-setting organization for the shipping trade. Mr. Iarossi, who is 53 years old, had been the head of Exxon Shipping Company since 1982.

title: Latvia and the Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Fertilizer Plants Sold by Freeport
description: Freeport McMoran Resource Partners, a limited partnership that is 62 percent owned by Freeport-McMoran Inc., completed the previously announced sale of its nitrogen fertilizer plants at Blytheville, Ark., and Verdigris, Okla.; selected terminal facilities, and other assets to the Agricultural Minerals Corporation for $230 million in cash and the assumption of liabilities.

title: Cancellation in Europe
description: The International League of American Football, scheduled to begin operations in Europe next month, canceled the season yesterday because of such problems as obtaining work permits for players.

title: Drexel Is Said to Owe Millions to Foreign Governments
description: Many foreign governments and Puerto Rico are owed hundreds of millions of dollars as a result of the collapse of the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people at the firm and lawyers said yesterday.

title: Turner Broadcasting System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter an extraordinary loss of $114,000,000, which included a loss of $98,279,000 on the early extinguishment of debt; the year included an extraordinary loss of $98,300,000 from early extinguishment of debt. The year-end results included a $38.8 million non-recurring benefit from the settlement of a tax matter which originated prior to the company's acquisition of MGM-UA Entertainment Co. The company said certain 1988 amounts have been reclassified to conform to the 1989 presentation.

title: Pan Am Seeking Berlin Routes' Sale
description: The Pan Am Corporation offered to sell its international routes to Berlin to Lufthansa, a spokesman for the West German airline said. According to a report in the daily West German newspaper Suddeutsche Zeitung, Pan Am initially offered the routes for $350 million. The offer was rejected, the paper said, and Pan Am cut its price to $220 million.

title: Paule Marie Boulin, Executive, 89
description: Paule Marie Boulin, for more than 30 years the president of the New York chapter of the Conseil National des Femmes Francaises aux Etats-Unis, a Paris-based cultural group formed to strengthen Franch-American relations, died of a heart attack on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Personal Income and Spending Up
description: Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in January despite a new tax bite from Social Security, the Government said today.

title: On Stage
description: Taming a Shrew in the Old West

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Perry Drug Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Restaurants
description: Just a few years ago, La Caravelle was suffering an advanced case of culinary senescence, and it seemed destined for that big banquette-lined dining room in the sky where it would join former Manhattan luminaries like the Pavillon, the Colony and Luchow's. A transfusion of new blood in the kitchen and the dining room kept the patient breathing, but many still believed the outlook was dim for this icon of a more decorous era.

title: INSIDE
description: Tax Victory for Newhouses

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Sallie Mae Prices $400 Million Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced a $400 million issue of notes due in 1993 through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Early Instruments
description: Dongsok Shin is to conduct La Stravaganza, an early instrument chamber orchestra, in Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons,'' Heinrich Biber's ''Battalia'' and Carlo Farina's ''Capriccio Stravagante'' at Holy Trinity Church, 316 East 88th Street, on Sunday at 5 P.M. Carla Moore, the orchestra's concertmaster, is to be the violin soloist in the three works. Tickets are $8. Information: 860-2077.

title: Ford Settles Dispute At 2d Mexican Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had reached a new labor agreement with the union representing 2,100 hourly workers at its plant in Hermosillo, Mexico.

title: Review/Theater;   A Show Within a Show, With a Lesson in History
description: It is 1924, and the Harlem Renaissance Theater Company is deep into the final rehearsals of a ragtime musical about the life and times of President Warren G. Harding.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a beach restoration project in Sea Bright, N.J., misstated the storm damage that the Corps of Engineers estimates the project would prevent.

title: Editor Held in Plot to Extort $50,000 From Satmar Rabbi
description: Chaim Shaulson runs a gossipy Yiddish- and Hebrew-language newspaper in Brooklyn. Some readers say it is a Hasidic answer to The National Enquirer, with sensational headlines, salacious cartoons and juicy tidbits about wives' cheating on their husbands.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Red Rodney Quintet

title: Alfred L. Ferguson Jr., Executive, 85
description: Alfred L. Ferguson Jr., an investment executive with the Wall Street securities firm of Dominick & Dominick before his retirement in 1965, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at his home in Atlantic Highlands, N.J. He was 85 years old. Mr. Ferguson, who was born in Manhattan, was a graduate of Yale and the Yale Law School. He was with the securities firm of Estabrook & Company before serving in the Army Air Forces in World War II and rising to the rank of lieutenant colonel.

title: Brown Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-After income of $3 million, or 17 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,857,000 for the quarter and $21,851,000 for the year. Both periods also included one-time charges related to the discontinuance of two footwear brands, and a provision for costs related to the sale or closing of 50 family shoe stores. In total, these one-time charges reduced earnings by more than $6 million. The 1989 year's net included a charge of $18 million associated with the decision to withdraw from three businesses.

title: Review/Pop;   Paris's Negresses Vertes
description: Paris has taken on a new role as musical melting pot, a place where a French gloss and some cross-cultural pop hybridization can be added to gypsy, African, Brazilian or Algerian music. Its latest emissaries, who performed Wednesday night at Woody's, are the Negresses Vertes, a group of eight men and two women who fuse an international assortment of folky styles into a newfangled kind of cabaret music.

title: I.M.F. Is Asked To Sell Gold
description: The United States asked the International Monetary Fund today to sell $1.2 billion worth of its gold to give 11 of the world's poorest countries a chance to pay debts.

title: American Standard Deal
description: American Standard Inc. has agreed to sell the North American operations of its Railway Braking Products group to a partnership led by Investment A.B. Cardo of Sweden for $250 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Taxi and Model Change To Limited Circulation
description: Family Media Inc., the magazine publishing company, announced yesterday that it was converting two of its ailing publications for women, Taxi and Model, from paid circulation to controlled-circulation magazines, beginning in the fall.

title: Women Can Claim a Long Battlefield History;   Not in Combat for Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in ''At the Movies'' in Weekend last Friday about the film ''Mountains of the Moon'' quoted an actor who misidentified the people in one battle scene. They were Somalis, not Maoris.

title: WORLD DRUG CROP UP SHARPLY IN 1989 DESPITE U.S. EFFORT
description: The State Department reported today that global production of opium poppies, coca, marijuana and hashish soared in the last year. This occurred despite President Bush's highly publicized effort to curtail drug supply and demand.

title: MCA Buys A Jazz Label
description: MCA Inc. said today that it had acquired GRP Records Inc., a successful independent jazz record label, in exchange for MCA common stock worth about $40 million.

title: Neiman Marcus Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: All per share figures reflected preferred dividend payments. Latest quarter and 6 months consisted of 14 weeks and 27 weeks, respectively, while the year-earlier quarter and 6 months consisted of 13 weeks and 26 weeks, respectively.

title: 'Miss Saigon' Finds Home on Broadway
description: ''Miss Saigon,'' the hit London musical about America's last days in Vietnam, will open at the Broadway Theater in March 1991, the show's producer, Cameron Mackintosh, announced yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
A Resurrected Ensemble Helps Nurture New Music
description: Some celebrations are hard won. Not long ago the National Orchestral Association had cause to wonder whether it would even reach its 60th anniversary this year, let alone feel like celebrating. Founded in 1930 to offer advanced training to aspiring orchestral musicians, the association determined a few years ago that, with music schools increasingly providing this training themselves, it had to some extent outlived its usefulness and needed to redirect its resources if it hoped to continue making a genuine contribution to American musical life. It therefore shut down in 1986 to regroup.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Broadcasting Concern Selects a New Chief
description: LEAD: The Great American Broadcasting Company, the principal subsidiary of the Great American Communications Company, has named George E. Castrucci chief executive.

title: Review/Film;   The Wonder of Czech Cinema's Early Days
description: ''There is definitely something seductive in this new medium,'' the Czechoslovak film theoretician Vaclav Tille wrote in 1908. ''In those silent, swift, nebulous and playfully swarming shadows there is something wonderfully attractive, something clearly evoking in the soul impressions of one's own dreams . . . prompted by unfathomable impulses.'' Film criticism has rarely been this lyrical or astute, describing as it does the imagistic style and dreamy, unconscious influences that mark the modernist sensibility and early Czechoslovak cinema.

title: Reviews/Film;   Connery as Captain of a Renegade Soviet Sub
description: Very early in ''The Hunt for Red October,'' Marko Ramius (Sean Connery), the captain of a new, atomic-powered, top-of-the-line Soviet submarine named the Red October, barehandedly murders a fellow officer aboard ship.

title: Reviews/Film;   Bombay Tour With Murder On the Side
description: Flaming pastels, singsong delivery, facetiously broad acting and jangling musical numbers are among the things that have long made Indian popular cinema an acquired taste for Western audiences. But ''The Perfect Murder,'' which opens today at the Angelika Film Center, is a bustling and touristy, if somewhat overeager, attempt to bridge the gulf.

title: Dr. King's Son Extends Apology to Gay People
description: Martin Luther King 3d, son of the slain civil rights leader, gave a talk earlier this week that enraged homosexuals and lesbians, and he has now issued an apology.

title: Jets Sign Passing Coach
description: The Jets' all-new coaching staff was almost completed yesterday when Joe Daniels was hired to be the quarterback coach. His first question probably will be: who's my quarterback? Coach Bruce Coslet said the job was open between Ken O'Brien and Tony Eason.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AM International Inc., Chicago, a maker of graphics products, said its board had approved the sale of its Wohlenberg Machine Tool and Foundry Businesses to Bremer Vulkan A.G. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Los Angeles Journal;   Catering Trucks: Selective Welcome?
description: It is lunchtime, and Juan Saenz, budding fast-food mogul, is toiling in his catering truck. Fingering a thick wad of $1 bills, he takes three orders for burritos and calls them out to his wife, Mari, furiously working the griddle.

title: Lifeline Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Killing Cocaine at the Source
description: What, fight drugs at the source? The very idea has prompted ridicule among many Americans who believe it simply can't work. But suddenly there's mounting reason to believe that the idea is right and the ridicule is uninformed.

title: Reviews Film;   Technology and Chicken Soup in 'The Laserman'
description: A laser scientist aims an icy-blue beam at his assistant, who accidentally explodes. As if that didn't make life difficult enough, the laser man -a Chinese-American named Arthur Weiss - also has to contend with a Jewish mother convinced she has a Chinese soul, a hoodlum brother-in-law involved with a prostitute, a girlfriend who would rather meditate and describe his previous incarnations than have sex, and a Shanghai-born police detective who sums up the lethal experiment with this version of Confucian wisdom: ''Too much education can be hazardous to your health.''

title: Robert J. Wood, 71, Ex-Chief Executive In Public Relations
description: Robert J. Wood, former chairman and chief executive of the public relations agency of Carl Byoir & Associates, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on Wednesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: During his campaign for Mayor of New York, DAVID N. DINKINS would say he had ''one and a fraction'' grandchildren. Now he has two. KALILA DINKINS-HOGGARD was born Wednesday night to DONNA DINKINS-HOGGARD, Mr. Dinkins's daughter. She and her husband, JAY HOGGARD, also have a son. Kalila was born at New Britain (Conn.) General Hospital. Yesterday, her grandfather canceled his public schedule for the day.

title: Bush and Reagan: Cookies, A Chat and a Contretemps
description: After nine years of complete affinity, George Bush finally confessed to a policy difference with Ronald Reagan.

title: Heavy Trading In USAir Shares
description: A report that Marvin Davis, the West Coast financier, had bought a stake in the USAir Group was cited for heavy trading in the airline's stock. A spokesman for Mr. Davis would not comment on the report in USA Today that he had acquired about a 5 percent stake. USAir's stock closed at $31 yesterday, down $1, after trading as high as $33.75. It was the seventh-most-active issue, with almost 1.5 million shares traded.

title: Weary of Party's Sniping, Soviet Cooperatives Rebel
description: This fertile region of southern Russia, best known for producing wheat, Cossacks and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, is rapidly acquiring a reputation as the graveyard of Soviet free enterprise.

title: Review/Dance;   Eliot Feld Furry Creatures In 'Mother Nature' Debut
description: Eliot Feld has tried something different from his recent choreography in ''Mother Nature,'' a little faux-naif allegory that had its premiere Wednesday night at a gala benefit for the Feld Ballets NY.

title: In California, Bush Tries to Close Gap With Troubled G.O.P.
description: On his second political foray into California in less than a month, President Bush cut a ribbon at a new prison today to show how tough Republicans are on crime, but he found a fast-growing state in political upheaval with a disoriented Republican Party.

title: AM International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net income There were no share earnings in latest 6 months after preferred dvidend requirements.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Worldwide narcotics production reached new levels, corruption undermined enforcement efforts, and a number of governments still failed to exhibit a serious commitment to reducing drug production and trafficking.''

title: Women Can Claim a Long Battlefield History;   Mothers of Civilization
description: To the Editor:

title: Flower Show: A Thousand and One Fantasies in Bloom
description: ON the way to the 1990 New York Flower Show, which can be seen through March 11 on Pier 92, my favorite horticulturist waxed loud and long.

title: Rowe Suspended 2 Years For Positive Drug Test
description: Mark Rowe, a four-time national champion at distances between 400 meters and 600 yards while at Jackson State, has been suspended for two years from track and field after testing positive for the illegal substance methyl testosterone, The Athletics Congress announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Turns Down MCI's Complaint
description: A Federal appeals board rejected the MCI Communications Corporation's challenge to part of the multibillion-dollar Government contracts that have been awarded to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and U S Sprint. Washington-based MCI's complaint involves changes in a contract to redesign and provide voice, data and video telecommunications networks, a project that could total $25 billion over 10 years.

title: Belial and Other Oddities Return in 'Basket Case 2'
description: ''I understand your pain,'' the gray-haired psychiatrist called Granny Ruth says in a kind and comforting voice to the patient on her couch -the mutant severed half of a Siamese twin, a creature resembling a giant Mr. Potato Head with gangly arms and blue eyes. ''But ripping the faces off people may not be in your best interest,'' she croons.

title: Jekyll & Gloat
description: As a responsible pundit, I agree with the horde of stability-loving statesmen and sober-sided seers that it would be counterproductive, even dangerously provocative, to jeer ''nyah, nyah'' and gloat at the defeat of the overconfident Sandinistas.

title: TEXAS AIR ACCUSED ON EASTERN DEALS
description: The court-appointed official supervising the bankruptcy case of Eastern Airlines concluded yesterday that Eastern had been improperly shortchanged by its parent company in various financial transactions.

title: At the Movies
description: After 'Too Beautiful'

title: Bush Seeks Japan Shift On Imports
description: When leaders of the two biggest economic powers meet during the weekend in Palm Springs, Calif., the United States will offer a closer global economic partnership but insist that Japan slash import barriers, Administration officials said today.

title: Rural Senator's Power on Education
description: It has long been a popular parlor game here in the offices of legislators, lobbyists and bureaucrats, but suddenly the stakes are becoming higher. Why is it, people ask one another, that Senator James H. Donovan, a longtime legislator from the Mohawk Valley hamlet of Chadwicks, seems to be the lone person in Albany opposed to abolishing the board that certifies New York City teachers?

title: 85 Penalties For Kings And Oilers
description: It wasn't supposed to be Fight Night at the Forum, but that's what developed Wednesday night when the Los Angeles Kings beat the Edmonton Oilers, 4-2, in the final regular-season meeting of the Smythe Division rivals. Among the events were:

title: Generic Drug Case Grows
description: Federal prosecutors today charged a former official of the Food and Drug Administration's generic drug division with taking a $20,000 gift from a former executive of a drug company.

title: Pianist Cancels Recital
description: The Czechoslovak pianist Ivan Moravec has canceled his all-Chopin recitals at the 92d Street Y, on March 11 and March 15, because of a hand injury. Ticket holders can obtain a refund in person or by mailing a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10128. Information: 427-6000.

title: Upstate New York Nuclear Waste Sites Endanger Milk Supply
description: To the Editor:

title: India's Lost Legacy: A Party in Ruins
description: The rout of Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party in state elections this week, after its loss of power at the national level in November, imperils the future of India's oldest political organization, the movement that led the country to independence in 1947 and has dominated national politics ever since.

title: Brazil Economics Post
description: Brazil's President-elect today named Zelia Cardoso de Mello, a 36-year-old economist, as his economy minister. Fernando Collor de Mello will take office as President on March 15, and she will help him execute plans to combat inflation, now running at more than 70 percent a month. She has been Mr. Collor's economic adviser since early last year and accompanied him on a recent tour of the United States, Japan and Europe. Her appointment came as no surprise.

title: Managua Assembly Race Is Still Untallied
description: Although nearly all ballots have been counted from the election on Sunday, election officials and international observers say it will be some time before they have precise figures on the number of National Assembly seats held by each of the 14 political parties in the victorious National Opposition Union.

title: Polk Awards in Journalism Given To 15, Including 5 From The Times
description: Four reporters and an education columnist for The New York Times are among the winners of the 1990 George Polk Awards in Journalism, announced yesterday by Long Island University.

title: For the Normally Clubby A.B.A., Sudden Rifts Over an Explosive Issue: Abortion
description: In the past few years the American Bar Association has debated gay rights and private clubs, apartheid and AIDS discrimination. But until two weeks ago it had never tackled perhaps the most divisive legal and social issue of them all: abortion. Now, as the A.B.A. sifts the resulting wreckage, it is apparent why.

title: Fate of Principals Splits Some Chicago Schools
description: The decentralization of Chicago's school system, the nation's third largest, hit its first serious snag this week as several communities were divided over the dismissal of principals by parent-led councils.

title: Ethics Questions In Trenton Bring Calls for Reform
description: Public-policy groups and the leaders of both houses of the State Legislature called today for a commission to suggest government-ethics reforms after questions were raised about the influence of lobbyists, businesses and campaign contibutors on legislators.

title: Review/Dance;   Titania, Oberon, Puck & co.
description: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' once again worked its magic on Saturday night when the New York City Ballet presented George Balanchine's choreographic adaptation of Shakespeare's comedy at the New York State Theater.

title: Tax Fraud Discussions
description: The European Community and the United States plan talks next week to increase cooperation against tax fraud. Officials said today that the European Community Tax Commissioner, Christiane Scrivener, would meet with top Bush Administration officials.

title: SENATORS ACHIEVE ACCORD WITH BUSH ON CLEAN AIR BILL
description: After weeks of negotiations in closed sessions, Senate leaders today diluted some provisions of their proposed clean air legislation to meet President Bush's demand for a less costly solution to the nation's pollution problems.

title: Review/Film;   When Bad Things Happen to Good Ideas
description: As Michael Moore has lately demonstrated and Nick Broomfield now reaffirms, sometimes the best thing that can happen to a documentary film maker is for everything to go wrong. Roger Smith, the chairman of General Motors, gave Mr. Moore the lucky break of a lifetime by refusing to have anything to do with him, and in ''Driving Me Crazy,'' Mr. Broomfield is similarly favored by everyone who insults him, ignores him, threatens to cut off his financing and uses him as a sounding board for so-called creative input. Mr. Broomfield never got mad, though that would have been understandable. Instead, he got even.

title: CBS News President Ends Rooney's Suspension
description: After three weeks of persistent lobbying by senior executives of CBS News and its parent company, CBS Inc., Andy Rooney will return to ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday, CBS News announced yesterday, ending a three-month suspension two months early.

title: Why Reagan Added Little to Iran-Contra
description: LEAD: The disappointment that accompanied the release of President Reagan's Iran-contra testimony is unwarranted.

title: Abrams to Investigate Covenant House Loans
description: The New York State Attorney General announced an investigation yesterday into the legality of personal loans that some Covenant House officials, including the Rev. Bruce Ritter, received from the organization.

title: Mary Ann Egan Hogan, Prosecutor's Widow, 81
description: Mary Ann Egan Hogan, widow of Frank S. Hogan, a former Manhattan District Attorney, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page last Friday about recent graduates who have received fellowships to practice public-interest law misidentified a lawyer with the Homeless Family Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society in New York City. He is Andrew Ko.

title: Utility's Stock Falls After Rate Ruling
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company's stock closed at a 52-week low after two administrative law judges recommended a surprisingly small rate increase for a new nuclear plant. The company's shares finished down 11 percent today, or $2.125, at $18. It was the third-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Connecticut Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $1,269,000, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Anglo American Chairman, Apartheid Critic, to Retire
description: The chairman of the Anglo American Corporation, Gavin W. H. Relly, said today that he will retire at the end of this month, leaving the most prominent post in South African business and one he had used to press for greater social responsibility by other national corporate leaders.

title: Zanzibar Journal;   Sultans and Slaves Are Gone, but Not the Strife
description: The ceiling fans in El Jabir restaurant revolve with a soft purr, circulating muggy air, as the owner, in a long white cotton robe, distributes cardamom scented tea to a clientele absorbed in the steamy politics of Zanzibar.

title: Du Pont to Build Complex in Spain
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Spanish Government signed an agreement to invest $1 billion in the next 12 years to build a high-technology industrial complex in the northern region of Asturias. Spain has agreed to put up $300 million for the complex, which is to employ 1,000 people in the hard-pressed region by 2001.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Hot Town Of the 80's Loses Allure
description: ADVERTISING creative people may leave their hearts in San Francisco, but many seem to be taking their resumes and portfolios out of town.

title: Kimmins Environmental Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are stated on a pro forma basis, giving effect to the merger of Kimmins Corp. and K Management Corp. with and into Kimmins Environmental Service Corp. during November 1988. Share earnings are restated to reflect the 1-for-2 stock dividend, effected in the form of a split, paid on Feb. 19.

title: Prague: Neglected Hotbed of Modernism
description: Beginning this weekend, three New York City institutions pay homage to Prague, the Czechoslovak capital that during the first half of this century turns out to have been no less an incubator of modern art than Paris or Moscow or Vienna. Whether it was testing out the waters of new technologies, like film, or giving a distinctively Czechoslovak twist to movements in painting, photography and sculpture like Cubism and Surrealism, Prague turns out to have been a city where modernism was embraced with a remarkable combination of passion and panache. Reviews of ''Czech Modernism: 1900-1945'' at the Brooklyn Museum, the International Center of Photography and Anthology Film Archives are on this page and page C24.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Hawker Siddeley Canada reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $6,472,000 for latest year and $4,251,000 for 1988. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: S.& P. Lowers Merrill Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said late yesterday that it had lowered its ratings on a broad range of short- and long-term debt obligations issued by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Economic Scene;   Behind the Failure Of Soviet Reforms
description: WHY has the Soviet economy failed to respond to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's five-year effort to revitalize it? There is a long list of answers to that question, ranging from the macro and microeconomic to the political and cultural.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Taste of Ethiopia

title: Review/Photography;   Czech Venturesomeness on View: Pictures Rooted in the Future
description: The story of the experimental, disruptive and ultimately exhilaratingly brand of image making known as European modernist photography has been told countless times, most recently by the exhibition ''The New Vision'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But because of the political barrier that has divided Eastern and Western Europe until recently, one chapter of that story - the flourishing of modernist photography in Czechoslovakia, primarily between the wars - has existed only in outline form.

title: Suspect Shot in Mouth
description: A suspect in a street fight was shot in the mouth by the police last night when he pulled a knife on two officers who had chased and cornered him on the roof of a building at 515 West 169th Street in Harlem, the police said. The suspect, who was not identified, was said to be between 25 and 30 years old. He was taken to Harlem Hospital for treatment of his wound, which was described as not serious. The police said they recovered the knife but had not yet charged the man.

title: Man Caught Upside Down, With Pants Up
description: In a glaring example of poor planning, a robbery suspect found himself hanging upside down from a fence yesterday, his pants at his ankles, with 20 police officers waiting on the other side, pistols drawn.

title: First City Trustco reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The prior year restated to reflect an accounting change. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: La Salle Coach Is Wary
description: La Salle, a nationally ranked team with the nation's longest winning streak at 18 games and one of the game's best players in Lionel Simmons, appears unbeatable. Except to Speedy Morris, who happens to coach the 13th-ranked Explorers.

title: BAKER IS PRESSING ISRAELIS ON PEACE
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d stepped up pressure today on Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to advance the Middle East peace process, saying the United States had done all it could and now needed a positive response from Israel.

title: Connecticut Plan to Buy Condos Skips Suburbs
description: A state plan to buy condominiums at bargain prices for housing for low- and moderate-income families has bypassed much of suburban Connecticut, especially Fairfield County, where the problem of prohibitively expensive housing is most overwhelming.

title: Our Towns;   'Fat City' Peace: Dancing to Heal Racial Wounds
description: Eric Salmestrelli is an energetic boy with a sunshine smile that goes well with soft brown eyes that seem to know a lot for a 10-year-old. He's already thought about what he wants to do when he grows up, and with the happy certainty of the very young he sees no conflict in choices.

title: Chronology of Seabrook: Plans, Protests, Building
description: 1966: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire tentatively decides to build a nuclear power plant, among the first in New England, in Newington, N.H. The Atomic Energy Commission says the site is too near Pease Air Force Base.

title: Mercantile Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included charge of $6 million associated with proposed relocation of corporate headquarters. The company said that because of a lower inflation rate in the latest year, it reported a LIFO charge of about 2 cents for the recent year, compared to a charge of 13 cents in the previous year. For the latest quarter, the company reported a credit of about 6 cents per share, compared to a charge of about 4 cents in the previous year.

title: Review/Music;   In Concert for TV, Pavarotti Sings Puccini and Verdi
description: Let it be said straight off that Wednesday's benefit concert with Luciano Pavarotti at Avery Fisher Hall was a television show. As part of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series, the Italian tenor, a number of other singers, the New York City Opera Orchestra and the Collegiate Chorale projected their wares energetically - not just for assembled listeners but also for Public Broadcasting Service audiences and those who will see rebroadcasts tonight and Sunday.

title: Manufacturing Decline Slows a Bit
description: Despite increases in the level of new orders and exports, the manufacturing sector of the nation's economy remained in decline in February for the 10th consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday. But the decline was at a slower rate than in previous months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Angotti Wins Saab Account
description: Saab-Scania of America Inc., the United States unit of the Swedish car maker, yesterday awarded its $25 million advertising account to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge. Saab selected the agency, best known for its work for Wild Turkey bourbon and Orangina soda, over two other finalists, Kirshenbaum & Bond and Slater Hanft Martin.

title: Ivaco Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,266,000 and an extraordinary loss of $19,803,000. c-Included a loss of $11,762,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $1,877,000. The 1988 year was restated.

title: Washington at Work;   Orrin Hatch's Journey: Strict Conservative To Compromise Seeker
description: When Orrin Hatch charged into the Senate in 1976, there was no ambiguity in the flint-hard agenda he advocated. He soon established a reputation as a slashing, give-no-quarter conservative by filibustering to death labor law reform and fair housing bills.

title: Hunter Loses In N.C.A.A.
description: Stockton State College spoiled the first post-season appearance by Hunter College with a 100-84 victory tonight in the first round of the N.C.A.A. Division III Atlantic Region playoffs. The 100 points were a season high for Stockton, which led by 59-41 at halftime.

title: A 'Baby Bell' Outgrows Its Siblings
description: The Pacific Telesis Group, which was considered one of the weakest of the seven regional Bell companies after the Bell system breakup six years ago, is emerging as perhaps the strongest.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Fallon McElligott Quits Federal Express Job
description: Fallon McElligott said yesterday that it had resigned the remaining portion of the Federal Express Corporation account that it won and brought to Minneapolis in 1985.

title: Top Sandinista Security Official Hints He'll Cede to New Leaders
description: In his first public comments since his Government's election defeat on Sunday, the hard-line Sandinista who heads Nicaragua's large security apparatus and secret police has indicated that he will be willing to step down when the opposition takes power on April 25.

title: Studies Find Flaws in Testing for Cholesterol
description: Cholesterol tests are highly inaccurate up to one-fourth of the time and some widely available portable testing machines have unacceptably high error rates even under ideal laboratory conditions, two studies have reported.

title: Kohl, Writing to Rabbi, Says Fear Of Fascist Germany Is Unjustified
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany says he understands the anxieties of Holocaust survivors about the unification of Germany, but he insists that such fears are unjustified.

title: Players Try to Fill Time As the Lockout Drags On
description: Picture this: breezes brushing gently off the Atlantic, sailboats cruising the intracoastal waterway, bikinied bathers frolicking along the beaches and joggers soaking up the afternoon sun. If it's springtime, this must be baseball season. So where is everybody? If you must know, on Day 15 of baseball's lockout, Tim Leary went fishing, Wayne Tolleson removed trees along the side of his house, Claudell Washington ran his Rottweiler, Barry Lyons bowled and Tim Teufel, well, he went to Disney World.

title: Review/Film;   She's Plain, She's Plump; In Short, She's Perfect
description: ''Too Beautiful for You'' was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 22, 1989. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at Cinema Studio, Broadway at 66th Street.

title: Albany Gets Final Say on S.I.
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday signed into law a measure that, depending on whom you believe, makes it easier or more difficult for Staten Island to secede from New York City.

title: Origin of Blood on Girl Questioned by Lawyer
description: Robert Golub's lawyer today sought to raise doubts about whether bloodstains found last March at the murder scene of Kelly Ann Tinyes belonged to Mr. Golub.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shift by Dow Jones
description: Dow Jones & Company has assigned the $8 million advertising account for The Wall Street Journal to the J. Walter Thompson Company. The previous agency was GSD&M. The other finalist for the account was Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners.

title: Review/Art;   Gallery of Unknowns In Brooklyn Exhibition
description: TO discuss Czechoslovak art of the 20th century has long meant to speak about Frantisek Kupka or to say nothing at all. Kupka's name and to a lesser extent the name of Otto Gutfreund have earned mention in most surveys of modern art, although neither has achieved anything like the recognition he deserves (especially Kupka, it should be added, whose experiments in abstraction, as a recent retrospective of the painter's work in Paris confirmed, were no less groundbreaking than Piet Mondrian's and Wassily Kandinsky's).

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Cutty Sark Whisky Goes to Della Femina
description: Della Femina, McNamee WCRS was awarded the Cutty Sark Scots Whisky account yesterday. The brand's advertising had been handled by MacNamara, Clapp & Klein. But last month, the Scotch's distributor, Buckingham Wile U.S., was acquired by Hiram Walker-Allied Vintners, which gave exclusive domestic distribution rights for Cutty Sark to its W.A. Taylor & Company subsidiary.

title: Castro Asks Mandela to Visit
description: President Fidel Castro today invited Nelson Mandela to visit Cuba, the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported. Mr. Mandela received the invitation from a senior Cuban diplomat in Lusaka, Zambia, where he has been holding talks with exiled leaders of the African National Congress. Prensa Latina said Mr. Mandela praised Cuba's support for national independence movements in Africa, including the struggle of the congress to end apartheid in South Africa.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Pro Bono
description: * American Soviet Youth Orchestra, sponsored by the Conservatory of Music at Oberlin College, the Moscow State Conservatory and the Soviet Ministry of Culture, to Hal Riney & Partners.

title: Rap's Trip To a New And Surreal Territory
description: Tonight at the Ritz, the Next New Thing in Pop Music, subchapter hip-hop, will make its appearance. Three rap groups - Third Bass, a duo of white New Yorkers who have the highest-ranking rap album on the black charts; the Jungle Brothers, whose newest record, ''Done by the Forces of Nature,'' is one of the best new rap albums, and a Tribe Called Quest, whose single ''I Left My Wallet in El Segundo'' is a surreal underground favorite - will try to make a claim for themselves on the stage.

title: De Klerk Says He Didn't Know of Military Unit Linked to Killings
description: President F. W. de Klerk told a special session of Parliament today that he had not learned until January of the existence of a secret military unit accused of killing opponents of apartheid.

title: Market Place;   Fewer Companies Lifting Dividends
description: THE economy may not be in a recession, but more and more companies are acting as though they think it may enter one. They are doing that by forgoing dividend increases that might have been made in other years.

title: Michigan Star in Draft
description: Leroy Hoard, the Michigan tailback who was voted the most valuable player in the 1989 Rose Bowl, will forgo his final year of college eligibility and enter the N.F.L. draft.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: The assets of the nation's 499 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.9 billion, to $388.79 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 153 institutional funds fell by $1.15 billion, to $91.54 billion. The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds dropped by $151.5 million, to $132.40 billion. The 101 broker-dealer funds declined by $598.6 million, to $164.86 billion, the institute said.

title: Ex-Exile Emerges at Core of Chamorro Alliance
description: When the Nicaraguan opposition held an enormous rally here before the election on Sunday, huge vertical banners waved with the names of the presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, and her running mate. But a smaller set of signs advertised a third name: Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, the opposition's man behind the throne.

title: Asian Population in U.S. Grew by 70% in the 80's
description: A sustained wave of Asian immigration in the past decade fueled a 70 percent increase in the Asian population of the United States from 1980 to 1988, said a report made public today by the Census Bureau.

title: Josephine Johnson, Nature Writer, Poet And Novelist, 79
description: Josephine Johnson, a novelist and nature writer whose first novel, ''Now in November,'' won the 1935 Pulitzer Prize for fiction, died of pneumonia on Tuesday in Clearmont Mercy Hospital, Batavia, Ohio. She was 79 years old and lived in Mount Carmel, Ohio.

title: Steelers Promote Brazil
description: Dave Brazil, a veteran assistant coach, was promoted to defensive coordinator yesterday by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Greenspan Opposes Rescue Of Failing Securities Firms
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, the first Government regulator called before Congress to discuss the bankruptcy of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, said today that the authorities would almost certainly refuse to rescue even the largest securities firms from the brink of collapse.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Zaiko Langa Langa

title: Simmering Battle on Penrod Begins to Boil
description: A simmering battle for control of the world's largest offshore oil-drilling company, the Penrod Drilling Corporation, has pitted several of its big bankers against a group of investors headed by Richard E. Rainwater, an influential investor from Fort Worth.

title: Barclays Plc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated from pounds sterling into U.S. dollars at the year- end exchange rate. Per share earnings represented American Depositary Shares (ADS) and each ADS comprises 4 ordinary shares.

title: Drug Testing For Jobs Urged By Chancellor
description: Angered by drug use among his employees, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez wants to require drug tests for all applicants for jobs in the New York City schools and is exploring the possibility of doing so.

title: Construction Outlays Jump
description: Construction spending rose 1.8 percent in January, the biggest increase in more than a year, the Government said today. Analysts said the warmest January on record caused the improvement.

title: Gay Cadet Is Asked to Repay R.O.T.C. Scholarship
description: A Reserve Officer Training Corps hearing officer has recommended that the United States Army try to reclaim the scholarship money it gave to a R.O.T.C. member who is homosexual.

title: Crucial Races on Weekend's Card
description: The most important weekend of racing so far this year will feature the leading Triple Crown prospects in Florida on Saturday and three of last year's Breeders' Cup winners in California on Sunday.

title: Mercury General reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1989 reflected a provision of $15 million representing management's estimate of the maximum potential impact of refund liability under the rate rollback mandated by California's Proposition 103.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Newhouses Win Fight With I.R.S.
description: The Newhouse family, one of the nation's largest owners of magazines, newspapers and cable systems, won a seven-year, multimillion-dollar battle against the Internal Revenue Service yesterday.

title: No Rough Stuff Allowed
description: Her coach, Don MacLeod, describes Vicky Sunohara as the Wayne Gretzky of women's hockey. And who's to doubt him?

title: President of Simplesse Enjoys Taste of Success
description: David L. Morley's boss envies his job. The chairman of the Nutrasweet Company, Robert B. Shapiro, regularly tells Mr. Morley that he has one of the most exciting corporate jobs in the country.

title:
Assembling a Site;

30-Story Condo Began With a Gasoline Station
description: LEAD: The ability to assemble sites large enough to accommodate major buildings may be the most important skill needed by Manhattan real estate developers.

title: Witness Backs Account By Prego in AIDS Suit
description: A doctor supported Dr. Veronica Prego's testimony by saying yesterday that an intern at Kings County Hospital sometimes left needles and other medical debris on patients' beds.

title: Union Carbide Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net charge of $56 million associated primarily with restructuring the bulk and packaged gas businesses of the company's industrial gas subsidiary. c-Included a net charge of $58 million for settlement of Bhopal litigation. Results are audited. Results are unchanged from those reported in January 1990.

title: Commissioner Sees No Reason for Talks
description: As the owners' lockout entered its third week, Commissioner Fay Vincent portrayed a bleak picture for baseball yesterday. He said he saw no reason for negotiations in the labor dispute to resume because the union has indicated no willingness to negotiate and compromise.

title: Review/Concert;   A Retelling of the Legend Of Joan of Arc, in Russian
description: There are certain all-but-forgotten operas whose credentials look so promising on paper that periodic attempts to revive them are not only inevitable but also justified, if only for curiosity's sake. Tchaikovsky's ''Maid of Orleans,'' which Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York performed in Russian at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, falls into that interesting category. The composer, after all, would later create ''Eugene Onegin,'' one of the touchstones of the Romantic repertory, and the subject was one he must have felt drawn to: a brave, tragically mistreated woman.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday headed ''International Book Rights'' and showing the breakdown, by country, of the print rights sold for the novel ''Fade the Heat'' misidentified the source of the data. It was the Virginia Barber Literary Agency. The chart also omitted the figure for print rights sold in Norway, Sweden and Denmark. That was 9 percent.

title: $66.7 Million Bonds By New York State
description: The Dormitory Authority of the State of New York yesterday priced $66.7 million in revenue bonds through competitive bidding for the New York State Department of Health.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Decline
description: Prices of Treasury issues dipped yesterday in light trading, as dealers sold securities in the wake of a series of economic reports that were somewhat stronger than anticipated.

title: Air Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax gains on the sale of assets of $1 million for the quarter and $27 million for the year, a $193 million gain on the reduction of the interest in GPA Group Plc for both periods, and provisions for investments and the writedown of goodwill of $54 million for the quarter and $57 million for the year. c-Included pre-tax gains on the sale of assets of $32 million for the quarter and $64 million for the year, and a $15 million gain on the reduction of the interest in GPA Group for the quarter and year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Film;   'New Directions,' 8 Brief Works in 90 Minutes
description: ''New Directions,'' opening today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, is a 90-minute program of eight short subjects, at least six of which are first-rate. Their only common denominator is that they are the work of new film makers.

title: Greville Wynne, Spy for Britain In the Soviet Bloc, Is Dead at 71
description: Greville Wynne, who spied on the Soviet Union for Britain in the cold war and who spent 18 months in a Moscow prison after being caught, died of throat cancer on Wednesday, hospital officials said today. He was 71 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDWARD ROY LARSEN was taken home from the hospital by his adoptive parents, JANE E. AMSTERDAM, a former editor of The New York Post and Manhattan,inc., and JONATHAN Z. LARSEN, the editor in chief of The Village Voice. He is the couple's first child.

title: Ben Hill Griffin Jr., 79, Is Dead; Leader in Florida Citrus Industry
description: Ben Hill Griffin Jr., a major figure in the Florida citrus industry, died yesterday at his home in Avon Park, Fla., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Canadian Imperial Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Review/Organ;   Viennese Plays Clerambault
description: Peter Planyavsky took time from his vast musical responsibilities as cathedral organist at St. Stephen's in his native city of Vienna to play a recital at Holy Trinity Church on Sunday afternoon. At the age of 43, Mr. Planyavsky finds himself overseeing a network of performances in Vienna that numbers over a thousand a year.

title: Christian Army Drives on Beirut Rivals
description: Lebanese Army troops loyal to the Christian commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, mounted a fierce tank and artillery offensive against militia forces in East Beirut today, and the police said there were more than 100 casualties.

title: AIDS Panel Agrees On Sex Counseling Of Catholic Patients
description: In an emotional debate in which one member likened John Cardinal O'Connor to Hitler, a state panel on AIDS policy agreed today that Roman Catholic nursing homes for AIDS patients should provide counseling on safer sex.

title: Review/Art;   The Land and Sea of Stuart Davis, Quick Study
description: If Stuart Davis was a born painter, he was also a fast learner - two traits that served him well throughout his long artistic career. Inspired by the large-scale works of his younger colleagues the Abstract Expressionists, Davis expanded upon his own already bold, streetwise abstractions to make some of the best American paintings of this century in the decade before his death at the age of 72 in 1964.

title: Caught in Downswing
description: When Sandy Lyle arrived at the Doral Ryder Open a year ago, he was at the top of the golf world. But since he left, he has been in a paralyzing slump that has sometimes left him wondering if he will ever play well again.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief report in Sports Pages last Friday about Doug Drabek's salary arbitration victory against the Pittsburgh Pirates referred incorrectly to the arbitrator, Reginald Alleyne. It was his first baseball decision, but he has been a labor arbitrator for 19 years.

title: Israel Devalues Shekel
description: The Israeli shekel was devalued today by about 6 percent in an effort to aid the economy and curb inflation. Israel's last devaluation was in June, when the shekel was devalued by 4.2 percent. Finance Minister Shimon Peres also said the exchange rate would now be allowed to fluctuate as much as 5 percent daily, rather than the current 3 percent limit.

title: The Church, Charity and Condoms
description: From the beginning of the AIDS epidemic, John Cardinal O'Connor and the Catholic Archdiocese of New York have led in selfless caring for the victims. But AIDS activists are now demanding that public funds be withheld from the nursing home care the archdiocese proposes to give. They argue the church's care may be ''judgmental'' and that it refuses to give instruction in preventive measures like the use of condoms. How can this ugly dispute be resolved?

title: SPORTS Of THE TIMES;   Vee's Lessons Now Haunt N.C. State
description: No matter how bad it gets, Vee didn't know nothing, never, as he himself might say in his exaggerated Queens-punk patois.

title: Rio Algom Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $31,500,000 which included a one-time provision of $57 million after tax related to mine closure costs and a $25.5 million tax credit. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $19,600,000, or 45 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A Sampling of Events On Women's History
description: Women's History Month is being celebrated with a variety of events around New York City. Here is a sampling of events this weekend. For more information, consult the Women's History Month Calendar published by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, 52 Chambers Street, Suite 207 (566-3832).

title: Indian Troops Kill 29 Protesters In Secessionist Rally in Kashmir
description: At least 29 people were killed and about 25 wounded today in Srinagar, capital of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, when Indian troops fired on pro-independence crowds, news reports said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CATHERINE FILENE SHOUSE, the 94-year-old founder of Wolf Trap, gave a medal to BARBARA BUSH yesterday at a luncheon at the Willard hotelin Washington, and Mrs. Bush gave Mrs. Shouse a warm thank-you. In 1966, Mrs. Shouse, one of the capital's last grandes dames, donated 100 acres of her farmland and money to build the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts, which opened in 1972 in Vienna, Va.

title: Promises, Promises on Schools
description: The nation's governors have committed themselves to a 10-year strategy to produce better schools and better students. But their admirably lofty rhetoric tells more about where American education ought to be in 10 years than about how to get it there.

title: Wallace Computer Services reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. Orders Airlines To End Restrictions On the Handicapped
description: The Transportation Department told the nation's airlines today to end discrimination against the handicapped. One official estimated the cost of meeting new requirements at $20 million a year for the next 20 years.

title: Smith Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $23,000 and $34,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest and prior periods, respectively.

title: Arts and Congress: A New Round Z
description: As the Senate and House of Representatives begin a series of hearings on Monday on extending the life of the National Endowment for the Arts, officials of the agency and its supporters foresee a rough legislative road ahead.

title: Ren Corp.-USA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: No comparable shares outstanding because the company completed its initial public offering on Nov. 28, 1989. Earnings for latest periods were reduced as a result of non-recurring expenses related to the company's initial public offering. These expenses were equal to 2 cents a share on an after-tax basis.

title: Leading Indicators Unchanged
description: The Government's barometer of economic vitality was flat in January and might have fallen but for a jump in building permits ascribed to mild weather, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Germany And Japan Sell Dollars
description: In an unusual double-barreled assault, the central banks of West Germany and Japan intervened in foreign exchange markets yesterday to defend their currencies against a weeklong rally in the dollar.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer editing error, the sports event listings on each highlights page of the Television section this week are those of a week ago. The events are shown correctly in each day's hourly program tables.

title: Richfood Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 6
description: b-Included an extraorindary loss of $619,000 from the cost of debt extinguishment. c-Net income Latest periods included one-time aftertax charges of $700,000 related to compensation benefits, legal fees, and lease termination costs.

title: Panel Says Broad Health Care Would Cost $86 Billion a Year
description: A sharply divided bipartisan commission today recommended an $86.2-billion-a-year program to provide health insurance and long-term nursing care to every American who needs them. But the panel could not recommend specific ways to raise the money.

title: Award Set In Cigarette Pricing Suit
description: The Liggett Group, the smallest of the nation's leading cigarette makers, won a judgment yesterday worth $148.8 million against a larger rival, the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, for what Liggett termed ''predatory'' cigarette pricing.

title: Quipp Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Patents: Hunt Goes On For a Better Mousetrap;   New Tracking Compound
description: An attempt to develop a more child-proof rat poison comes from ICI Americas, a subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. The poison is a new form of tracking compound, a substance that gets into the fur of a rodent.

title: American Woodmark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Topics of the Times;   007, Arrested
description: James Bond is a master at narrow escapes from life-threatening traps laid by his villainous enemies. It is perhaps less noticed that, no matter how fast he roars through mountain passes on winding two-lane highways, he also escapes traffic cops. Sean Connery, the movies' original 007, isn't so lucky.

title: McCaw-Lin Link
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said it had won bank financing for its $3.4 billion merger with the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, bringing it a step closer to creating the nation's biggest cellular telephone company. The $3 billion bank loan agreement was arranged by a syndicate of 43 commercial banks. McCaw reached the merger pact with New York-based Lin in December after a fierce bidding war with the BellSouth Corporation.

title: Reviews/Theater;   Part Love, Part Siege in a Romance
description: In her plays, ''Warriors From a Long Childhood'' and ''Five in the Killing Zone,'' Lavonne Mueller wrote with effortless authenticity about men in battle. In ''Violent Peace,'' the third play in her war trilogy, she writes about a man and a woman locked in a lifelong relationship that is part love, part siege. Both characters - a general's daughter and her father's adjutant - are permanently wedded to the military. They are a family within a family. Ms. Mueller writes with authority about the strictures and rituals and the emotional dress code of Army life. Her two characters are keenly observed and the dialogue has a visceral quality that overcomes occasional moments of artificiality. At the same time, the play, a production of the Women's Project (at the Apple Corps Theater), has unresolved dramatic problems, beginning with a central premise that is unusual to the point of being bizarre.

title: National Gypsum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $6,351,000 and $17,684,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, primarily from repurchase of debt. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $5,154,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $39,164,000 for the year, both primarily from repurchase of debt. Results for 1988 are restated to reflect adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 95. The company is no longer publicly traded.

title: Aloette Cosmetics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: Devils Are Powered By Unexpected Bunch
description: The Devils got production from unexpected sources tonight and escaped with a 6-5 triumph over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: 'Crowbar' Is Extended
description: ''Crowbar,'' the experimental play by Mac Wellman presented by En Garde Arts at the Victory Theater on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has extended its run to March 25. It had been scheduled to close on March 11.

title: Americana Hotels & Realty Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included $3,000,000 charge for the settlement of a lawsuit, partially offset by a $1,368,000 gain on the sale of a property. c-Net income and included $5,895,000 gain on the sale of a property.

title: Louis Landerson, 40; Theater Group Lawyer
description: Louis Landerson, the general counsel for the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 40 years old.

title: Strong Aftershock Hits Southern California
description: A strong aftershock to Wednesday's earthquake was felt in a wide area of Southern California today. The earthquake caused a rockslide on a mountain road, but there were no reports of significant damage or injuries.

title: Yugoslavia Could Learn From U.S. Federalism;   Prince Paul Betrayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Hialeah Future Bleak
description: The chances that Hialeah Park will ever stage another horse race appeared increasingly bleak yesterday after a last-ditch proposal by John J. Brunetti, the Florida track's owner, which seems unlikely to succeed.

title: Prego's Lawyers Rest Their Case In 8-Week Trial
description: Defense lawyers rested their case yesterday in the eight-week trial of Dr. Veronica Prego's charges that she developed AIDS from accidentally puncturing her finger on a contaminated syringe needle in Kings County Hospital.

title: Investors Title Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Buyers On the Move
description: A new shopping catalogue has been designed solely for commuters. The 24-page booklet, titled ''Love to Commute; The 90's Survival Guide for Commuters,'' lists more than 100 items. Most are for use in the car but others are adaptable to any mode of transportation.

title: Panel Urges NTT Breakup
description: A Government advisory council said today that the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company should be split into three companies within five years.

title: Harley-Davidson Stake Is Allowed
description: A Federal judge has refused to block Malcolm I. Glazer, a businessman, from investing further in Harley-Davidson Inc., the last United States-based motorcycle manufacturer. The Milwaukee-based company filed a lawsuit accusing Mr. Glazer, a financier with interests in Florida and New York who owns a 7.26 percent stake in Harley, of creating a phony takeover scare.

title: Minven Gold Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Bush's 'Whitewash Effect' on Warming
description: In his recent speech to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, President Bush, who promised in his campaign to use the ''White House effect'' to counter the ''greenhouse effect,'' delivered the ''whitewash effect'' instead.

title: ISRAEL TO CENSOR NEWS ON EMIGRES
description: The Israeli military authorities issued a highly unusual order today requiring news organizations to submit all reports on Soviet Jewish immigration to military censors.

title: Alco International Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Upheaval in the East: West Germany;   Kohl Calls for Guarantees From Warsaw in Any Accord on Borders
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl declared today that a treaty in which Germany affirms Poland's western border should also include a waiver by Poland of any further claim to war reparations, as well as guarantees for the German minority in Poland.

title: Falconbridge Gold reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a State Department report on the international drug crop referred incorrectly to the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters. He is Melvyn Levitsky.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chyron Corp., Melville, L.I., terminated a plan to merge with the Midwest Communications Corp. because the companies could not reach an agreement on terms.

title: Investors Insurance reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After non-recurring charges of $1,775,000 in the second quarter for commuted reinsurance and $971,000 in the fourth quarter reflecting the writedown of one bond in default.

title: Judge in Iran-Contra Trial: Forceful Wielder of the Law
description: On a visit to the Holocaust Museum in Jerusalem, Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene stopped at a photograph of a man being paraded through a street wearing a placard that said, ''This will teach me not to complain to the police.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. ;

title: Selas Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $234,000, or 11 cents a share, and $500,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a tax credit of $94,000, or 5 cents a share, and $271,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Per share results reflected retroactive effect of a 2-for-1 stock split declared Feb. 26.

title: Yugoslavia Could Learn From U.S. Federalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Strawberry At Meeting
description: Darryl Strawberry, the Mets outfielder who ended a 26-day treatment in an alcohol-rehabilitation program in New York on Thursday, appeared at the Los Angeles City Attorney's office here today to determine whether he will face misdemeanor charges stemming from a domestic dispute five weeks ago.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When she was 31 years old, JACQUELINE WELLS posed for NORMAN ROCKWELL. Now, more than 30 years later, she has sold that painting, the only known nude study by the illustrator of homey America.

title: Dr. Charles Doan, 93, Retired Medical Dean
description: Dr. Charles Austin Doan, the retired dean of Ohio State University Medical School and a noted hematologist, died of arteriosclerosis on Feb. 13 at a nursing home in West Bloomfield, Mich. He was 93 years old and until last month had lived in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Reliability Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc. reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
I.I.S. Intelligent Information Systems Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that 1989 earnings were reduced because of normal year-end accounting adjustments.

title: Sweden Hasn't Ignored Sub Intrusions
description: To the Editor:

title: Turcotte Is Dazzling In Rangers' Victory
description: The flashes of brilliance are coming one after the other again, dazzling demonstrations of offensive talent that once more threaten to become a single bright blur.
