title: Resumption Of Talks Clouded By Doubt
description: The resumption of talks in baseball's labor dispute remained in question yesterday. Negotiators for the owners and players, who haven't met since last Monday, indicated that they viewed the basis for a possible meeting Monday differently.

title: Penn Engineering & Mfg.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bushes to Head Yearlong Fete
description: Up With People, an international cultural and educational program for young people, yesterday named George and Barbara Bush honorary chairmen of its 25th anniversary celebration under the heading, ''Encouraging Understanding Worldwide.'' The announcement by J. Blanton Belk, founder and president of the organization, said the yearlong observance would open July 25 in Denver, where President Bush has been invited to deliver the keynote address.

title: Time Warner to Buy 25% Pricellular Stake
description: Time Warner Inc., the giant media company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 25 percent of the Pricellular Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Price Communications Corporation, for $13.3 million.

title: Coca-Cola Bottling Co. ConFsol.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $6,239,000 from early retirement of debt. c-After an extraordinary loss of $584,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: Review/Art;   Sculpture, But Not Strictly So
description: The sculptor Barry Le Va came of age in the late 1960's and early 70's, a time of pervasive social unrest and intellectual questioning. The civil rights movement was in high gear, the antiwar movement was gaining speed, women's rights and students' rights were both hotly debated issues and art was not exempt from the ferment.

title: Nicaraguans Plan To Unlock U.S. Funds
description: A team of economic advisers to the Nicaraguan President-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, is to arrive here on Monday seeking at least $550 million in aid from the United States and international lending institutions to revive a war-shattered economy.

title: Laser Precision Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Urges Wider Use of AZT For Adults With AIDS Virus
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved labels recommending that adults infected with the AIDS virus be treated with the drug AZT even if they do not yet have symptoms of the disease.

title: KEY RATES
Skolniks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Books of The Times;   A Writer in Castro's Stifling Shadow
description: Self-Portrait of the Other

title: Treasury Prices Rebound on Bearish News
description: Treasury securities prices rebounded yesterday, helped in large part, dealers said, by bearish domestic economic news and higher yields on key foreign debt issues.

title: 3 Cities in Connecticut Begin Laying Off Workers
description: Facing declining revenues and a rising demand for more social services, three of Connecticut's largest cities - Bridgeport, New Haven and Stamford - have begun laying off employees and paring municipal programs to balance their budgets.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday reported that Chaim Shaulson, who runs a Yiddish-and Hebrew-language newspaper in Brooklyn, had been arrested on extortion charges. He was accused of having demanded $50,000 to stop writing unfavorable articles about Rabbi Moses Teitelbaum, spiritual leader of the Satmar sect.

title: Leisure Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest third quarter's revenue included about $21 million from the sale of properties in New Jersey and Florida. After preferred dividend requrements there were no share earnings.

title: Driver Killed in I-95 Plunge
description: A cement truck plunged off the Gold Star Bridge on Interstate 95 at 8:15 A.M. today and landed in a parking lot, killing the driver, the state police said.

title: Little Change From 1987 in PAC Spending
description: Political action committees raised $171 million last year and spent $132 million, with the teamsters' union PAC retaining its place as the top one in terms of both money raising and spending, according to an analysis by the Federal Election Commission.

title: RB&W Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $449,000, or 9 cents a share, and $1,688,000, or 33 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $252,000, or 5 cents a share, and $570,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: O.I.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $141,000. c-Included tax credits of $279,000 and $105,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: AIDS Benefits to Offer Music of Cole Porter
description: The music and lyrics of Cole Porter will be featured in a series of benefit performances by members of the New York City Gay Men's Chorus, beginning March 22 at 7:30 P.M. at the Sanford Meisner Theater, 164 11th Avenue, near 22d Street.

title: Lawrence Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings per share were adjusted for the acquisition of United Republic Reinsurance Co.

title: National Education reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After unusual aftertax charges of $7,590,000 relating to employee severance, the closing and relocation of certain facilities, and the writeoff of certain intangible assets as a result of the company's restructuring program for the quarter; the year is after unusual aftertax charges of $10,050,000 relating to $11,506,000 of employee severance, the closing and relocation of certain facilities, the writeoff of certain intangible assets, and $4 million for all issued customer creditors. c-Net income and the year net is after an unusual aftertax charge of $1,485,000 resulting from costs of the Spectrum merger.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When he was 9 years old, he made his conducting debut at the 1939 World's Fair in New York. By the time he was 12, he had conducted the New York Philharmonic and the NBC Symphony. On Monday, LOREN MAAZEL turns 60, and he plans to spend the week celebrating with friends like PLACIDO DOMINGO, LUCIANO BERIO, the composer, and HORACIO GUTIERREZ, the pianist, whom he has invited to a dinner for 40 at Le Cirque in Manhattan.

title: For Specialty Ketchups, A Battle With the Giants
description: In a market where a couple of giants have smothered the competition, a handful of entrepreneurs are trying to carve a niche for what they call gourmet ketchup.

title: About New York;   From Apartheid To Another Kind Of Apartness
description: This is, in the end, a tale of how this spinning planet both disappoints and affirms its bewildered passengers. It is about South Africa and New York City, about a son and a mother.

title: Observer;   Get A Horse
description: Many smokers are threatening to quit flying. This is because of a new law making it a crime to smoke on almost every commercial flight in the United States.

title: Beliefs
description: Reaching for a phrase to dismiss the ''Call for Reform in the Catholic Church'' that 4,500 Roman Catholics around the country issued Wednesday, Helen Hull Hitchcock called it ''nothing new.''

title: Surgeon General Confirmed
description: Dr. Antonia Coello Novello was confirmed as Surgeon General by the Senate on Thursday. A 45-year-old pediatrician and expert on AIDS in children, she is the first female and the first Hispanic Surgeon General. She has been deputy director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, one of the National Institutes of Health.

title: School Aide Details Plan On Workers' Drug Tests
description: In proposing drug tests for its employees, the New York City Board of Education is stepping into a tangled and costly new arena of administration, in the hope that the tests increase confidence in the schools.

title: Comment by Baker Angers Shamir
description: An announcement by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that the United States would tie American loan guarantees for Soviet immigrant housing to a halt in new Israeli settlements fell like a bomb here today.

title: Washington REIT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Review/Theater;   Doubts About 'Uncle Vanya' And His Claim to the Title
description: A pervasive pastime for leading playwrights on both sides of the Atlantic these days seems to be rendering new translations of the works of Anton Chekhov. David Mamet and Lanford Wilson have both written American renditions of individual plays and in England, Michael Frayn is translating the entire Chekhov canon.

description: William P. Wingate, executive director of the New York City Ballet, has resigned. Mr. Wingate, who took office in July, submitted his resignation in a letter to the board of directors and to Peter Martins, ballet master in chief, on Monday.

description: b-Included a tax credit of $20,378.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some editions on Sunday, reprinted in all copies on Monday, about the magazine publisher Malcolm S. Forbes included two names erroneously on a list of guests at his 70th-birthday party last year in Tangier, Morocco. Donald J. Trump and the singer Julio Iglesias did not attend.

title: Room Service With a Twist
description: The two men entering a 12th-floor room in a midtown Manhattan hotel yesterday were hardly there to serve the guests, the police said, and what they took was hardly a gratuity - $2 million in gems.

title: 272 Minutes in Penalties As Wings Edge Leafs
description: Steve Yzerman scored his second goal of this penalty-filled game with 1 minutes 16 seconds left in overtime, lifting the Red Wings out of last place with a 3-2 victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

description: b-Included a net gain of about $70 million on settlement of a 1982 rate case.

title: Fordham and Army Gain 2d Round
description: The first game of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament was over almost as soon as it started today. The second game wasn't decided until the final five seconds. The third game took an overtime, and the fourth needed a buzzer-beating shot. But despite their different ways of doing so, Fordham, Army, Fairfield and Canisius all advanced to the tournament's second round.

title: Quiksilver Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
How Much Would Secession Cost?
description: Now that Gov. Mario Cuomo has triggered Staten Island's march toward secession from New York City, he could do something constructive, indeed essential, to help insure that the borough knows what it's doing.

title: North Carolina State Is Under Pressure to Remove Valvano
description: With students and faculty demanding his removal as basketball coach at North Carolina State, an angry Jim Valvano said today that he was ready to leave if school officials thought it best.

title: Yugoslavia Could Learn From U.S. Federalism;   Attack on Albania

title: U.S. Sues Ernst & Young On Savings Unit Audits
description: Federal regulators have sued Ernst & Young, contending that the accounting firm is responsible for audits that failed to detect and report huge losses at the Western Savings Association, a Dallas institution that was seized by regulators in September 1986.

title: Yugoslavia Could Learn From U.S. Federalism;   Fascist Massacres
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush, Kaifu Seek to Bar Trade Split
description: President Bush greeted Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan at this glittering desert spa this afternoon to start a weekend of talks aimed at preventing trade strife from undermining their countries' close political and economic ties.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Moscow's Maverick With a Purpose
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the virtuoso in the evolving Communist art of campaigning against Communism, is in the thick of it again with a bold election stratagem to craft a shadow presidency for himself, the better to challenge the nation's President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

description: Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti warned today that the two Germanys alone should not have ''the last word'' on their reunification or on the future borders of a single German nation.

title: Annenberg to Give $50 Million To United Negro College Fund
description: In the largest act of philanthropy ever directed toward black colleges, Walter H. Annenberg, the former United States Ambassador to Britain, will contribute $50 million to the United Negro College Fund.

title: Clashes and Unrest Grow Fiercer in Ivory Coast
description: Hundreds of students demanding the resignation of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny clashed with riot policemen today in the worst outbreak of violence since anti-Government demonstrations began in this West African nation two weeks ago.

description: LEAD: Wherever the air has cleared, the forces arrayed to ban public smoking have left nicotine addicts growling in their wake.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   Poland's Changes To A Free Market Show Early Gains
description: Poland's pioneering economic ''shock therapy'' appears to be bearing some early results, ending wide-open black-market money changing, putting meat and other formerly scarce goods in the stores and starting to bring down high prices.

title: Upheaval in the East;   1980 Soviet Defector Emerges With Account of K.G.B. Plots
description: The K.G.B. had two sources in the State Department during the 1970's who supplied details of American arms-control strategies and other policies, a former K.G.B. officer who has lived secretly in the United States since 1980 alleged today.

description: Latest quarter results included a $24 million LIFO credit, compared to an $18 million LIFO charge in the year-ago period.

title: No Progress on One Cyprus As U.N. Unity Talks Collapse
description: Talks between the leaders of Greek- and Turkish-speaking Cypriots collapsed here today after a week of efforts to reunite the island of Cyprus.

title: Dow up 24.77; Week's Gain is 96.17
description: Stocks closed a week of five consecutive gains yesterday, as bond yields declined and individuals and small institutional investors appeared to move strongly into telephone issues.

title: Power Shots Outduel Wind For 3 Leaders at the Doral
description: Three of the PGA Tour's brightest young stars used their power games to overcome stiff winds and take charge of the leader board today at the Doral Ryder Open.

title: Valspar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Yugoslavia Could Learn From U.S. Federalism;   Independence for Croats
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST, SATURDAY, MARCH 3, 1990
description: International

title: Reviews/Music;   An Exploration of Two Viennese Schools
description: The current all-Viennese New York Philharmonic subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall looked promising in theory, but proved problematic in practice Thursday night. The idea was to combine a chronological mini-survey of the music of Anton Webern, stretching from the late Romanticism of his student days to his full maturity, and then to reach back to the First Viennese School for Beethoven's ''Emperor'' Piano Concerto. The soloist was Maurizio Pollini, who has a lively interest in the Second Viennese School as well as a striking, modernist way with older music.

title: California Accuses Lincoln Of Misleading Bond Buyers
description: A California agency said today that it had filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against Charles H. Keating Jr. and the American Continental Corporation, contending that the company put pressure on unsophisticated investors to buy its ''junk bonds'' by saying they were insured by the Government and were free of risk.

title: Montfermeil Journal;   For Emigres, a Lesson That Begins in the Nursery
description: Pierre Bernard, Mayor of this working-class suburb on a hill northeast of Paris, examined the four sheets of paper on his oversized desk.

title: Boeing Raises Market Outlook
description: The Boeing Company, the world's largest commercial plane maker, today sharply raised its 16-year jetliner market outlook, predicting demand of $626 billion through 2005. The company also said it expects overall air traffic to grow about 5.5 percent annually through 2005. That growth rate would constitute a near-doubling by 2000.

title: Robert L. McDonald Dies at 45; Film Maker Took Over Perry Ellis
description: Robert L. McDonald, an award-winning film maker who became the chief of the Perry Ellis design house after its founder's death, died of AIDS last night at his home in Manhattan. He was 45 years old.

title: Bridge
description: Invitational events limited to top-ranked players and offering large cash prizes are common in Europe but rare on this side of the Atlantic. For many years the only example has been the Cavendish Club's annual charity event in Manhattan, but it was sincerely flattered by imitation in Toronto last weekend.

title: Review/Concert;   AIDS Benefit by the Gay Men's Chorus
description: The benefit concert given by the New York City Gay Men's Chorus in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening to celebrate its 10th anniversary offered many satisfactions, not least the astonishing work of the sign-language interpreter, Tom McGillis, which has been praised in these pages before. Though technically a distraction and incomprehensible in detail for most listeners, Mr. McGillis's eloquent balletic gestures were consistently compelling, impeccably musical in their point and timing. One couldn't help but wonder how Mr. McGillis might have fared as a conductor if he had turned the same interpretations back on the performers.

title: Logibec Ltee.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Henley International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings are based on 1,655,000 shares outstanding for both fiscal quarters and do not give effect to the issuance of one million shares from the company's initial public offering, completed Feb. 2.

title: After 12 Years, Koch Says Rohatyn Misuses Watchdog Power
description: In a stinging personal rebuke that unleashed the pent-up frustrations of 12 years in office, former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York City has accused Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, of misusing his power as head of the fiscal watchdog agency.

title: Advocate for the Suffering Takes Over as Head of Mental Health
description: As a young Army psychiatrist in Vietnam in 1969, Dr. Billy E. Jones listened to the torments of American soldiers who had been put in a stockade for various crimes during the war. Later, when he was a civilian, his patients were people who, in addition to their own private anguish, suffered lives of poverty.

title: Kaypro Files For Bankruptcy
description: The Kaypro Corporation, whose all-in-one personal computer was once characterized as the Volkswagen Beetle of the high-tech industry, filed today for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company established a market niche in the early days of personal computers with a reliable low-priced machine that included a screen, computer and software in a semi-portable unit. Its sales soared from $5 million in 1982 to $119 million two years later, but 1984 proved to be the peak year for Kaypro.

title: Scott Jarvis, Actor, 46
description: Scott Jarvis, an actor and singer, died of AIDS on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Nine thousand communities, most of them isolated rural towns and farming hamlets, were jolted today by the near-collapse of their only public transit system after drivers struck the Greyhound bus system in a wage dispute.

title: Japan Reports Trade Deficit
description: Japan reported a trade deficit today for the first time in six years, but economists said Tokyo is expected to return to a trade surplus soon.

description: Sales of new single-family homes fell 7.1 percent in January to the lowest level in 10 months, the Commerce Department said today.

Exxon Halts Tanker Traffic In New Jersey
description: The Exxon Corporation suspended tanker and barge traffic at its Bayway Refinery and Bayonne Terminal yesterday after two oil spills in waterways between New Jersey and Staten Island this week and the leak of 567,000 gallons of oil in the area two months ago.

title: Bank Deposit Insurance Plan
description: The nation's largest banking trade group endorsed a plan today to reform deposit insurance and force uninsured depositors to accept some losses in bank failures.

title: Weicker Enters the Race for Governor
description: Former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the maverick liberal Republican who vowed not to make a comeback after he was defeated in a bitter re-election race in 1988, returned today from his self-imposed exile and said he would run for governor as an independent.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a recipe with the De Gustibus column in The Living Section on Wednesday, for baklava of banana, included an instruction erroneously. The instruction - Step 8, which said, ''To assemble, combine banana filling with caramel sauce and stir to mix well'' -should not have appeared. In addition, an adjoining recipe for banana filling omitted an instruction. After Step 3 for the filling, a Step 4 should have appeared, saying, ''Combine banana mixture with cream mixture and stir to mix well.''

Mobil to Pay State $500,000 On Greenpoint Kerosene Leak
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has agreed to pay New York State a $500,000 penalty and to undertake an investigation and cleanup effort in response to a leak of 50,000 gallons of kerosene on Feb. 3 at its Greenpoint terminal in Brooklyn, the State Environmental Conservation Department said yesterday.

title: A Plainclothes Transit Officer Is Shot in Brooklyn
description: A plainclothes transit officer was shot in the arm on a Brooklyn sidewalk yesterday by one of two young men he and his partner were following after they spotted a suspicious bulge under the jacket of one of the suspects in a subway station.

title: An Earlier Exit at Pantheon
description: The five senior editors of Pantheon, who this week resigned effective March 15, were told yesterday not to return. They were told in letters signed by Fred Jordan, who on Tuesday was named publisher of Pantheon Books, replacing Andre Schiffrin, who was forced to resign.

title: INTRUDER ON THE PHONE: ENDING A SALES TALK BEFORE IT BEGINS
description: In 1964 Morey McDaniel, then a Stanford University law student, got one telephone sales call too many. Irate, Mr. McDaniel petitioned the California Public Utilities Commission to let people who did not want such calls have an asterisk placed beside their names in the phone book.

title: Scraping By on Hope in Moscow
description: For a person who has been going to Moscow since childhood, the allure of that paradoxical city never wanes. But this time the strange juxtapositions seemed thrown into particularly stark relief by a series of random encounters that evoked childhood memories and underscored the startling reality of today.

title: Dr. Joseph Dalven, 90; Led Home for the Aged
description: Dr. Joseph Dalven, who practiced medicine for more than 60 years and who directed a home for the aged for 35 years, died on Tuesday at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn after a short illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

description: b-Included gain of $2,744,000, or 22 cents a share, from sale of property.

title: Prosecutor Picked for Inquiry on Ex-H.U.D. Chief
description: A retired Federal judge from Philadelphia, Arlin M. Adams, was named as independent prosecutor today to investigate whether the Reagan Administration's Housing Secretary and his senior aides illegally diverted hundreds of millions of dollars in Government rent subsidies to projects backed by prominent Republican consultants.

title: Guidepost;   Home Improvements
description: Remodeling part of a home can be costly and it is wise to think in terms of how much the remodeling will add to resale value. Almost always, hiring a professional will reduce the time involved and inconvenience. Average building costs for an area can be researched through the local real-estate board or at a public library. Here is a general idea of the kinds of remodeling that gives the best return on resale, based on a 1989 survey of real-estate professionals in the New York metropolitan area. $ Improvement Cost Percentage of Cost Recovered Kitchen remodeling (gut and rebuild) $20,000 80% New kitchen cabinets, counters and fixtures $5,000-10,000 90-100% Adding a full bathroom: Existing space, plumbing nearby $5,000-6,000 Up to 300% Existing space, reroute plumbing $8,000-9,000 100-200% Going through a wall $10,000 100% Adding a fireplace $4,000 plus 100%

title: Probation for Friend of Barry
description: Rasheeda Moore, who helped Federal agents arrest Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington on a drug charge, pleaded no contest today to drunken driving and was sentenced to three years' probation and fined $927. The 38-year-old Ms. Moore, of Burbank, had been stopped by a police officer in North Hollywood on Jan. 1 because she was driving with her headlights off. A friend of Mayor Barry's, she called him to the Washington hotel room where he was arrested Jan. 18.

title: Review/Television;   Walter Matthau Is Back After a 2-Decade Hiatus
description: Walter Matthau is hardly a stranger to television. Back in the 1950's and 60's, he was all over the screen in those live studio dramas (''Philco Playhouse,'' ''Studio One'' et al.) that are now enshrined in memory as the Golden Age of Television. This Sunday, though, after more than 20 years of avoiding the decidedly less golden commercial scene, Mr. Matthau is making his television-movie debut at 9 P.M. on CBS in an ''A.T. & T. Presents'' drama. It's called ''The Incident,'' and it's a first-rate production, solidly put together under the direction of Joseph Sargent (''Day One'').

title: Topics of the Times;   Dear Alan Kiepper
description: People love to give advice to the president of the New York City Transit Authority, but the advice you're getting now, having just taken the job, is mistaken. Having lost your way on the subway and given wrong directions to a stranger, you were told you ought to study the subway map.

description: Because of a rash of injuries, the Milwaukee Bucks have activated 35-year-old Mike Dunleavy, an assistant coach and former player, in time for the game tonight against the Knicks. Dunleavy, a guard, has been pressed into emergency service before.

title: SFE Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Frederick Landis, 78, Former Customs Judge
description: Frederick Landis, a former judge of the United States Customs Court, now the Court of International Trade, and former Chief Judge of the Indiana Supreme Court, died of intestinal cancer on Thursday at a nursing home in Carmel, Ind. He was 78 years old and lived in Indianapolis and Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Patents;   Hunt Goes On For a Better Mousetrap
description: Mousetraps can be inspirational, in their way. They attack one of man's most ancient problems, and inventors never seem to tire of devising new strategies.

description: Tony Conigliaro's rock group was doomed from the start. ''Tony,'' someone had asked him, back then in the spring of 1968, ''what does your rock group try to do?''

title: Upheaval in the East;   21 Ex-Policemen Put On Trial in Romania In Timisoara Deaths
description: The long-awaited trial of 21 former secret police officers charged in connection with scores of deaths in the December revolution began today in Timisoara, the western city where the revolution took form.

title: Washington Talk;   Decisions On Taxes? Forget Numbers
description: When it comes to tax policy, how you count often depends on where you stand.

title: Mandela Named Effective Leader Of the African National Congress
description: The governing wing of the African National Congress elected Nelson Mandela deputy president of the organization today, and the group said it would move its headquarters to Johannesburg ''without delay.''

title: Flyers Trade Propp
description: Stressing a need to acquire younger players, the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday traded 31-year-old Brian Propp, their third-leading career scorer with 849 points, to the Boston Bruins for a second-round selection in this year's National Hockey League draft.

title: What McFarlane Did
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents: Hunt Goes On For a Better Mousetrap;   A Maple Concentrate
description: A simpler approach to bait shyness, using an artificial maple concentrate, has been developed by John P. Hollis of San Antonio. Mr. Hollis, the retired owner of a pest control service, said maple was one of the more persistently successful natural attractants he has encountered. His artificial maple is a new composition consisting of saccharin and alcohol tinctures containing coffee, vanilla and extracts from several other plants. Mr. Hollis received patent 4,842,861. Gary E. Lutz and Charles R. Patterson, inventors in Ames, Iowa, built a device that they said uses a house's electrical wiring to drive mice away. The device's advantage, Mr. Lutz said, is that it provides an alternative to poisonous chemicals that can harm pets or children or contaminate food.

title: United Coasts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Your Money;   How Long Must Records Be Kept?
description: As people sort through their financial records to get things in order for income-tax preparation, many wonder just how long they need to keep various papers. The answers could please only a maker of filing cabinets.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ZSA ZSA GABOR has been slapped with a $10 million suit for slander, assault and emotional distress by PAUL KRAMER, the Beverly Hills police officer who arrested her last June. Mr. Kramer filed suit against Miss Gabor on Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court. On June 14, 1989, he stopped her because the license tags of her Rolls-Royce convertible had expired. She responded by slapping him.

description: At the peak of his gymnastics career, Felix Martinez of Cuba was left to consider the great what-if: what if his country had not boycotted the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, for political reasons?

title: Patriarch Assails Factions as Lebanese War Stalls
description: An offensive by Gen. Michel Aoun's army in Christian-controlled East Beirut halted today after making little headway on the second day of brutal clashes with rival Christian militiamen. As the offensive stalled, the head of the Maronite Catholic Church threatened to excommunicate the combatants.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are building capitalism.

title: Courter Won't Run for House Again
description: Representative Jim Courter, who lost a lopsided race for governor to Jim Florio last November, will not run for re-election to Congress this year.

title: Scan-Optics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary loss of $1,281,000.

title: Fats, Fads, Fasts, Fallacies
description: The Federal Government felt moved this Lenten week to get up in the pulpit and urge its flock to discipline their diets. It admonished every citizen above 2 years of age to eat less fat and more spinach. The sermon is probably salubrious, but the sanctimony can be taken with a modicum of salt.

title: United Illuminating reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said results for the latest period included a charge of $152,145,000 related to the effect of a change in accounting principle. The accounting change is related to non-cash write-offs to recognize reductions in the recoverable cost of the Seabrook Unit 1 power facility. Year-ago figures included a charge similar to the latest period's charge, totaling $32,914,000.

title: SL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Per share data adjusted to reflect the 6 percent stock dividend distributed in November 1989.

title: North Atlantic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $3,200,000 restructuring charge. c-Net income

title: S.E.C. Tells of Investigation Into Bonuses Paid by Drexel
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission began an investigation immediately upon learning that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had paid hundreds of millions of dollars in bonuses to executives in the weeks before its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection, the S.E.C.'s chairman, Richard C. Breeden, said today.

title: A Reading of Frost
description: Poems by Robert Frost will be read by a number of noted actors at a benefit on March 19 at 8 P.M. at City Center Stage I of the Manhattan Theater Club, 131 West 55th Street. Among those taking part in the event, which is a benefit for the Manhattan Theater Club, are Philip Bosco, Anne Pitoniak, Diane Venora and Treat Williams. Tickets are $50. Information: 645-5848.

title: Micro Tempus Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $582,953. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Car C.D. Players
description: The best sound in a car comes from compact disks, but a C.D. player does not have to be installed in the dashboard to obtain it. A personal portable player can be installed by hooking it up to a car radio or tape player and speakers. Sony says a third of all C.D. portables are used this way.

title: Alpharel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $3,544,000 writedown of assets for both the quarter and year.

title: United Industrial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-cash charge of $6,595,000 resulting from an out-of- court settlement between the company's unit, AAI Corp., and Harris Corp.

title: US Facilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $182,000, or 5 cents a share, and $543,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Esquire Radio & Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Apple Official Says He Will Leave
description: Jean-Louis Gassee, who has headed the product-development efforts of Apple Computer Inc. since 1985, confirmed today that he will leave the company at the end of September, when Apple's fiscal year is over.

title: Hadco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Trump Sues, Too
description: Donald Trump has thrown his lawsuit into the ring. Claiming unlawful interference by the Mirage Hotel and Casino with his contractual right to present a rematch between James (Buster) Douglas and Mike Tyson in Atlantic City in June, Trump yesterday sued the Mirage and its owner, Steve Wynn, and the heavyweight champion and his manager, John Johnson.

title: SNC Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,928,000. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $7,080,000 and $9,757,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for the 1989 periods included an unusual after-tax gain of $7.8 million mainly from the sale of its interest in Sandwell Swan Wooster Inc. Year-ago quarter results included a pretax unusual gain of $16,638,000. Prior year results included a pretax unusual charge of $20,862,000.

title: Review/Music;   Two Masters in the Making: Beethoven, 14, Mahler, 16
description: The Lyric Piano Quartet presented an interesting program of relatively unfamiliar and sometimes distinctly unmasterly music by familiar masters at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening. Beginning the concert with a work by a 14-year-old Beethoven (the Quartet in D, WoO 36, No. 2), and the second half with one by a 16-year-old Mahler (a movement for an unfinished Quartet in A minor), was an especially nice touch.

title: State Called New York's Top Polluter
description: The worst polluter in New York State is the state government itself, two leading Assembly members contended yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Federal clean air bill described a type of coal incorrectly in some copies. It was high-sulfur coal that Senate leaders agreed to allow for a longer period at Western and Midwestern power plants.

title: CTS Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,100,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge of $625,000 from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: BATTERY PRODUCER LOSES A BIAS CASE
description: A California appellate court has struck down a ''fetal protection'' policy under which a battery maker denies employment to women of childbearing age in jobs involving substantial exposure to lead.

title: Now for Election Groupies
description: Compared with difficulties ahead, winning Nicaragua's election was the least of Violeta Chamorro's problems. But the elections had to be the first step toward creating (not rebuilding - there never was a substantial foundation) a peaceful, democratic society with a functioning economy.

title: Helian Health Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Decision Is Near on Bonwit's Fate
description: Efforts to sell Bonwit Teller, the century-old retailer based in New York, appear to have reached an impasse yesterday, store executives and garment industry suppliers said, and speculation mounted that the 16-store chain may be on the brink of liquidation. But a spokesman for Sanford C. Sigoloff, chief executive of the L. J. Hooker Corporation, Bonwit's parent company, said the fate of the retailer would be decided next week.

title: Amplified Cello: From Purring To Caterwauling
description: The line separating art music from new-age formulas can be very thin. And in the case of Elise Tobin, an electro-acoustic cellist who performed at Dance Theater Workshop on Monday and Tuesday evenings, the two become virtually synonymous.

title: Panatlas Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Keystone International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $558,000 from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $409,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $1,135,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year. The year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding restated to reflect a 25 percent distribution paid in May 1989. The 1988 periods were restated to reflect the sale of two units as discontinued operations.

title: 2 Investor Groups Go To Waterford's Aid
description: Investor groups led by Morgan Stanley & Company and Anthony J. F. O'Reilly have come to the rescue of Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C., the troubled maker of crystal and china.

title: Alphonse F. D'Andrea, Biaggi Aide, 75
description: Alphonse F. D'Andrea, a retired social worker and an aide to former Congressman Mario Biaggi, died on Monday at a Connecticut nursing home. He was 75 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Tax Filings Up From '89
description: The Internal Revenue Service said this week that it had processed 19.4 percent more returns this year through Feb. 23 than last year - 18.1 million compared with 15.1 million. More than half the processed returns, 9.9 million, have produced refunds, up 20.3 percent from last year. In the first half of the filing season, 31.9 million returns have been received by the I.R.S., about 30 percent of the total expected this year. This year's refunds are averaging $868.

title: Nicaragua Victor Plans to Return Some Land Seized by Sandinistas
description: The government of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will move promptly to return or make compensation for most land confiscated by the Sandinista Government, and will sell many state enterprises, aides to Mrs. Chamorro say.

title: Reviews/Music;   A French Violinist's Debut With Juilliard
description: Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, although not on the faculty of the Juilliard School, is a frequent conductor of the conservatory's orchestra, and he has even taken the student ensemble to Asia on tour. The respect he commands from these young musicians was evident in the polished, full-bodied performance he drew from them Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Disorderly Person Charge In Shackleford Drug Arrest
description: It is unlikely that Charles Shackleford of the Nets will serve time in jail if convicted of possession of marijuana, the police said today. But for a man already facing allegations of point-shaving, Shackleford's arrest could not have come at a more inopportune time.

title: Service Corp. International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $94,935,000 for discontinuance of the company's funeral supply and insurance funded prearranged funeral service businesses. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $15,584,000 and a loss from an accounting adjustment of $16,474,000. Results for latest quarter included a gain of $2,893,000, or 6 cents a share, from a public offering. The company changed from fiscal year ended in April, to a Dec 31, year- end, making the previous year only 8 months.

title: More of Same for the Nets
description: Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen each scored 23 points last night for Chicago as the Bulls defeated the Nets, 112-91.

title: XL Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results for 1988 have been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Dick Clark Productions Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviet Trade Pact Expected
description: United States officials said today that they expect to conclude a new trade accord with the Soviet Union in time for a superpower summit meeting in June, a move that would end a 16-year dispute linking trade with Soviet emigration policy.

title: NCH Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Rauch Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Inside
description: Greyhound Strike Strands People and Towns Alike

title: Petrolite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Bills to Pay? The Number Is . . .
description: The old excuse ''the check is in the mail'' may one day be replaced by ''I've already phoned the bank'' - at least for customers of banks that offer bill-paying by telephone.

title: Vinland Property Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $810,000, or 14 cents a share, on sale of properties. c-Included a gain of $4,906,000, or 82 cents a share, on settlement of debt related to a foreclosed property.

title: Intermark Set To Add Triton
description: Intermark Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the outstanding shares of Triton Group Ltd., its 51.6 percent owned affiliate, in a stock swap deal worth $99.4 million, based on today's stock price.

title: Philippine Proposal Meant to Simplify Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Startel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: On Top and Loving It
description: Up on the top floor of a hotel suite in downtown Duluth, Minn., a bottle of champagne is chilling in an ice-filled bucket. The bucket stands on a table by a bucket. The bucket stands on a table by a window that affords a scenic view of Lake Superior. Two delicate glasses - approximating champagne flutes - complete this still The recipients of the v.i.p. setup are Mr. and Mrs. James (Buster) Douglas of Columbus, Ohio. The last time he came to Duluth, two years earlier, he came alone, staying in a motel that was just down the street from a strip joint in which Douglas acknowledged he spent more than a few hours.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: The colorful pundits who not long ago predicted the demise of black-and-white photography are eating crow. For a variety of reasons, some sociological and some technological, monochromatic pictures are enjoying a renaissance.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off. I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals. I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss. After a month, the stain leached through, and now I have pink streaks.

title: Correction
description: A review of ''Loving Letters From Ogden Nash'' on Feb. 11 referred erroneously to the poet's widow, Frances Leonard Nash, recipient of many of the letters. She remains alive, in Maryland.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: Al Bianchi's Kiki Vandeweghe fixation cost the Knicks the 1989 first-round draft choice and Sidney Green. His ego cost the team Rick Pitino, a great motivating coach who always had the team playing at top intensity. Now Bianchi's trade of Strickland's future for Cheeks' past has cost the Knicks the 1988 first-round draft pick and any hope for meaningful improvement next season.

title: Time to Give Henry V, No Champion of Thatcherism, a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Spartans Nearer To Big Ten Title
description: A mere 48 hours after defeating Michigan in what Coach Jud Heathcote called Michigan State's most significant victory in several seasons, the surprising Spartans pulled off what may be their most important victory of the year this afternoon, defeating Minnesota, 75-73, in a grueling overtime game at Williams Arena.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: Two years from now Strickland will have developed into a better offensive and defensive player than Mark Jackson, and the Knicks will still be without championship rings.

title: Presenting Arms
description: The Army's standard combat weapon, the M-16, in use since the Vietnam War, is still considered the finest extant assault rifle. Nonetheless, since 1982, when six weapons manufacturers were asked to develop new technologies, the Army has been seeking to improve on it. Four companies have produced prototypes - including the Steyr-Mannlicher from Austria (above) - that are now being tested at Fort Benning, Ga., and at Aberdeen Proving Ground, Md.

title: CRIME
description: In choosing a tour guide to crime and corruption in New Orleans, you want to know where the authors will send you for a good time. Julie Smith will stroll you through the Garden District, in NEW ORLEANS MOURNING (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $17.95), and treat you to a muffuletta at the Napoleon House. But according to Steven Womack, in MURPHY'S FAULT (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $17.95), the Napoleon House is ''an artsy-intellectual hangout full of students and frustrated writers and tacky painters and tourists.'' He'll steer you to a sleazy Cajun dance hall called the Keyhole Lounge, ''a good place to go get shot on a Saturday night.'' It's a matter of territory - and perspective.

title: Opening Day and Dog-Track Money
description: High atop Yankee Stadium, the sign promised ''Four Weeks Until Opening Day - Tickets on Sale Now.'' Unless baseball's labor dispute is settled soon, however, it's a promise that will be broken.

title: 2 Suspended
description: Guy Carbonneau and Craig Ludwig have been suspended by the Montreal Canadiens for missing a curfew and were scratched from last night's game against the Minnesota North Stars. It was believed Carbonneau, co-captain of the team, and Ludwig, its most experienced defenseman, disobeyed an order from Coach Pat Burns not to leave their hotel after a 5-3 loss in Boston on Thursday night.(AP)

title: NEGLECTED MINORITY
description: MEXICAN AMERICANS

title: Viewing the Arts And Government
description: According to Prof. Irving Sandler [''Championing Free Artistic Expression,'' Feb. 11] , ''decisions about what'' Government will ''finance should be left to people in the arts; the Federal Government and bureaucrats shouldn't set up any kind of guidelines.''

title: Jennifer Ehrlich and David Rimmer to Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Ehrlich of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Ann Ehrlich to David J. Rimmer, the son of Phyllis Rimmer of Bay Terrace, Queens, and the late Murray Rimmer. A May wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

LIFE: WHAT TO MAKE SOMETHING OF IT?
description: LEAD:

title: Teacher With Visions Of Greater Things
description: Mathias B. Freese has penned an eloquent plea for a grade school Kulturkampf in ''Teachers Have No Chance to Give Their Best'' (Long Island Opinion, Jan. 21), and one which I heartily endorse. I was one of Mr. Freese's advanced 10th-grade English students five years ago, and I consider myself an antecedent to what he cites as a ''general diminishment in students'' over time.

title: Jennifer Graham, an Actress, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Graham of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Smith Graham, to Daniel Peter Brunson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Pete Brunson of Charlotte, N.C. An April wedding is planned. Miss Graham, 26 years old, graduated from the Middlesex School and summa cum laude from the University of Michigan, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. A member of the New York Junior Assembly in 1982, she was presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball. She is an actress currently appearing in a national tour of ''No, No Nanette.''

title: UH-OH, HERE COMES THE MAILMAN
description: A reader in Queens writes:

title: Reviews/Dance;   Inspired by Paintings and Courage
description: ''This Cordate Carcass,'' Llory Wilson's provocative new dance for five women, was inspired by the work of the Mexican painter Frida Kahlo and by a friend's battle against AIDS. The piece, which was presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, alludes frequently to Kahlo's paintings. There is a cool obsessiveness to Ms. Wilson's choreography and to the score, by Rachel Warwick and Arturo Peal, that is reminiscent of Kahlo's paintings. But there is none of the self-laceration of Kahlo's work. The brace and crutches that figure in the two solos are instruments the dancers move resiliently and elegantly beyond, just as the copper and aluminum poles that rise from the dance's spacious landscape serve as spurs to action.

title: Have Bicycle, Will Charm the Vietnamese
description: Virginia Gift, who had become fascinated by Vietnam, decided she was going to do her bit for better relations and teach English in Hanoi, and no one was going to stop her.

title: Captain's Prospects Are Clouded by Exxon Case
description: Every weekday morning for the last five weeks Joseph J. Hazelwood has walked across the iced street from the Captain Cook Hotel to a small room in Alaska Superior Court where he has heard himself alternately described as a reckless mariner and a hero.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of travel arrangements and hotel rates for Trinidad on Feb. 11 with an article about carnival misstated the availability of flights from New York to the island's capital, Port of Spain. There is indeed direct service - with stops but without a change of aircraft - on BWIA and Pan Am.

title: It's Italian, but With a California Accent
description: PASTA VIOLA, a newcomer in Stony Brook, sounds like yet another strutter in Long Island's never-ending parade of Italian restaurants. But take a second look; it is not the same old tarantella. There isn't a Bolognese, Alfredo or carbonara in sight. Insted, fasten your seatbelts for the likes of violet linguine, an amalgam of pasta, sauteed red cabbage, prosciutto and olive oil splashed with balsamic vinegar. Pasta Viola serves Italian food that took a side trip to California, picking up both inspiration and a kitchenload of sun-dried tomatoes on the way.

title: In Defense of Himself
description: To the Editor:

title: A June Wedding For Jane Sarkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Zheutlin of Hillsdale, N.J., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Zheutlin's daughter, Jane Lauren Sarkin, to Martin Bradley O'Connor 2d, a son of Mary L. O'Connor of San Mateo, Calif., and the late Judge Richard R. O'Connor. A June wedding is planned.

title: In Bright, Soaring Colors, Japan's Handcrafted Kites
description: NOWHERE in the world do kites occupy as important a place in national life as they do in Japan. The Japanese both welcome in the new year and celebrate Boys' Day on May 5 by flying kites. Local kite festivals that involve dramatic airborne battles are also a feature of many communities in the spring and summer months. These events often involve huge kites that require large teams of strong, experienced men to handle them.

title: A TOWER COMPETES WITH WALL STREET'S LAST GOLDEN AGE
description: It is not only financiers who spent the 1980's trying to outdo the 1920's. Architects played the same game, and a fair amount of the time managed to overextend themselves just as much, piling up significant levels of esthetic debt as they struggled to capture the combination of flamboyance and dignity that characterized the architecture of the 20's. They plundered the past, putting it on easy credit and elevating short-term pleasure over long-term esthetic value. Who could deny that a lot of the freewheeling skyscrapers of the last decade are the architectural equivalent of junk bonds, putting instant visual impact ahead of any kind of rational structure?

title: Campus Life: Yale;   Where French Course Is a Cause Celebre
description: Call it a case of ''le professeur et la victime'' -only now it is not a lesson in the gender of French nouns. The French course itself is the issue.

title: Owners Might Have Avoided Trouble by Listening to Finley
description: If his fellow owners had listened to Charlie Finley 14 years ago, they wouldn't be in this predicament. Or the lockout.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECENT RELEASES: SOUNDINGS;

Small California Labels Explore the Offbeat
description: LEAD: With America's big classical-music labels sold to foreign investors - and increasingly concentrating on standard European fare - it is left to small, offbeat labels to record innovative repertory. The West Coast boasts two such companies that courageously investigate terrain few others care to explore.

title: Geneva
description: To the Editor: During a tour of Switzerland, my husband and I spent a delightful day in Geneva. After we returned home, I enjoyed reading about your suggestions for museums (''What's Doing in Geneva,'' Nov. 12) but feel you missed a really special one, which is right around the corner from the Museum of Art and History. The museum is the Petit Palais, and it houses a private collection of works from most major modern periods and by important Jewish painters.

title: SEOUL UNCOVERS A BORDER TUNNEL
description: After grinding through more than 1,000 feet of granite, engineers today reached a tunnel that military officials said had been built by North Korea to stage a surprise invasion of the South.

title: Iditarod Is Under Way
description: Seventy dog teams and mushers set out today in the Iditarod Trail sled-dog race, a 1,160-mile, two-week chase that will take them through snow, ice and punishing cold winds before they reach Nome.

title: THE POST-MODERN IN NOW
description: COSMOPOLIS

title: Hotel Rates
description: To the Editor: The Marriott's Leisurelife program offers 50 percent off rack rates for people 62 and over, according to your article ''Getting Breaks on Hotel Rates'' (Practical Traveler, Dec. 24). I called the Marriott in Boca Raton, Fla., twice to book and was told the rate was $124 and no further discount would be allowed.

title: A Barry Le Va Retrospective Moves From Fastidious to Robust
description: WITH 136 of its 176 pages occupied by illustrations, the catalogue to the Neuberger Museum's ''Barry Le Va, 1966 to 1988'' is a visual synopsis of the show. As a result, the viewer can take in almost at a glance what is hard to discern in the display itself: the overall shape of the artist's progress from a fastidious kind of Conceptualism to something more robust, if not more expressive.

title: WHAT'S HAPPENING
description: Not so long ago, there was mostly Health-Tex and Danskin, and style was an afterthought. But for baby-boomer parents nowadays, style is thought of long before they get to the store.

title: Mime Theater By Learning Disabled
description: It was with great interest that I read ''What the Retarded Need: Social Skills.'' Yes, concern, imagination and time are desperately needed attributes for our developmentally disabled population. With these attributes, Theater for the Learning Disabled was established by three professional people for 15 adults. Pride and self-esteem are key elements that have been achieved by the acting group now known as East End Special Players.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Revenue Problems Endanger Budgets In Half the States
description: More than half of the states are battling serious budget problems as they approach the final months of the fiscal year, and eight Eastern states are striving to avoid deficits that could disrupt statewide and local programs.

title: Students in Science Contest Aim At the 'Frontiers of Technology'
description: AT first, Roopak Shah and Jared Muroff appear to be ordinary high school seniors.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Warm Tea and Warm Memories Help Ease Life's Pain
description: LEAD: LAST spring was a hard time for me. My mother had died the June before. She had lived alone, independent to the end, and had been sick only two weeks. Her absence cut a terrific hole in my life that the sympathy of my husband, daughter, co-workers and friends could not fill.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Rio de Janeiro
description: Austrian TV viewers recently saw a cigarette commercial featuring a European tourist sitting naked on Copacabana Beach. Thieves had picked him clean, but they left him his pack of Dames. Rio de Janeiro's pickpockets have become the latest international stereotype, and since 1988 tourism has been declining at the rate of 100,000 visitors a year, down to 610,000 in 1989. With tourism off, visitors can enjoy this lovely city, experiencing a sense of discovery.

title:
Speaking Personally;

On the Kindness of Strangers
description: LEAD: IT had to be the coldest day of the year. The wind was tossing debris from Central Park and the litter from the street was swirling around me in a frenzy. Even the trees were howling for mercy as their branches crackled and fell with the onslaught.

title: Philippine Hotel Seized By a Rebel Governor
description: A suspended provincial governor backed by hundreds of armed men seized a hotel in the northern Philippines after a gunfight today, taking a general and several other people hostage, witnesses said.

title: Lynda R. Dunlop Wed To Michael W. Dzen Jr.
description: Lynda Rose Dunlop, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Dunlop of Jamesburg, N.J., was married Feb. 18 in Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Michael W. Dzen Jr., a son of Mr. Dzen of South Windsor, Conn., and the late Shirley Dzen. The Rev. Terrance N. Gordon, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Royal Caribbean Sandals Resort.

title: A Singer-Songwriter and 'Delicate Pop'
description: LEAD: LORI CARSON, who grew up in Massapequa, appears poised to join the growing ranks of talented female singer-songwriters working within an acoustic framework who have emerged on the popular music scene in recent years.

title: Children's Fashion;   Spring Whimsy
description: Bold, vibrant colors are bursting out all over for spring and summer. Anything goes, and the brighter the better. Nearly every dress, shirt, pair of shorts and pants is meant to look, feel and act like fun, designed with play in mind. For girls, dress silhouettes are simple and pretty, not fussy, with empire or basque waistlines. Boys are still excited by the surfing look, especially when it has a touch of humor. Wide-legged shorts are roomy and of varying lengths, usually topped by a cropped or oversized T-shirt emblazoned with patches, figures, animals or ecological slogans. Both boys and girls are quite taken with vests. There is a bit of wanderlust in these new clothes, with many featuring international motifs that conjure up images of faraway places. And like any tourist, the kids are urged to be multicultural, mixing if not quite matching.

title: Time to Give Henry V, No Champion of Thatcherism, a Break;   'Dash'd to the Walls'
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

New Brunswick's Keystone to Revival
description: LEAD: IN the 15 years since it fell on hard times, New Brunswick has slowly regained its position as a vital urban center, as seen by the recent office towers and residences that seem to line every other street. The turnaround has been dramatic.

title: Probing the Limits of Biography
description: ONCE she won an Oscar. Now her agent hangs up on her. Once she was the victim of the distortions of an unauthorized biographer who snooped around outside her beach house in Malibu. Now she has hired a live-in journalist to record her story - honestly.

title:
RECORDINGS;

The Fruits of Haydn's Labors in England
description: LEAD: In 1761, just past his 29th birthday, Franz Joseph Haydn became court musician and composer to the Esterhazy royal family, serving at the two palaces at Eisenstadt and Esterhaza. Haydn could not have anticipated at the time that this was to be his station for the rest of his life. Until recently it had been assumed that all concerned benefited from this arrangement: Haydn was assured a degree of financial security and the Esterhazy princes could boast of supporting one of the great men of music.

title: Lifestyle;   From Alleys to Centers, Bowlers Keep Rolling
description: Bowling may be the only sport where the participants do not have to break a sweat. And this sport is a perfect way to spend a few hours on a nasty winter day. It can appeal to the intensely competitive or mere fun lovers; adults or children; small groups or large.

title: A SUNSET WORTH THE APPLAUSE
description: Karen comes back from Florida, talking about Key West. She hit the Overseas Highway, and 42 bridges later she was on Duval Street buying a palm frond hat. She checked into a guesthouse called Big Ruby's, stuffed herself with conch fritters and got wasted away in Margaritaville. There was music everywhere, blues and jazz and calypso, and what they call Conchtown. Everybody had wild nicknames, and the headstones in the cemetery had epitaphs like ''I Told You I Was Sick.'' I'd love it, Karen says. Most of my genes were naturally selected in West Africa; other people hate cold - I suffer from it. I'd love any place where the temperature topped 75 degrees.

title: The Andy Rooney Story: A Drama Made for TV
description: ANDY ROONEY, the crabby curmudgeon of CBS News, is back tonight on ''60 Minutes,'' two months before the end of a three-month suspension. Portrayed at first as a compromise - CBS News responds to complaints about offensive remarks without banishing the offender forever - the suspension and its abrupt end ultimately had more to do with internal politics than with the issue of sensitivity versus censorship.

title: Evening Hours;   The Leprechauns Arrived Early
description: A thatched-roof cottage that seemed to have been whipped up by leprechauns was the first thing guests saw upon arriving for the New York Flower Show on Thursday night. The cottage was set in an emerald-green garden on Pier 92 over the windblown Hudson River. The evening was sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York.

title: Reviews/Music;   Fiddler Williams's Jazz
description: About halfway through his first set at the West End Gate on Thursday night, Claude (Fiddler) Williams fiddled away at a solo cadenza as an introduction to the tune ''Laura.'' Soaring through chords and tossing off complicated, jumping rhythms, he eventually wound his way to the first notes of the melody. By that time the audience was sold: Mr. Williams, at 82, had brought everybody into his inventions. And the band, playing clearly and quietly, had done its share as well, creating arrangements on the spot, interacting with Mr. Williams and smiling at his stunning improvisations. Jazz at its best asks an audience to join the musicians in mulling ideas. Mr. Williams, ideas clear and effusive, did just that.

title: Hotel Workers in Hawaii Strike
description: About 7,500 hotel workers went on strike today after contract negotiations collapsed, threatening to disrupt the state's $6-billion-a-year tourism industry.

title: NICARAGUA EXPERT TURNS THE TABLES
description: When Francisco Mayorga Balladares boarded a plane for the United States on Friday to represent Nicaragua's government-elect in vital economic talks, he was well prepared. For make the trip.

title: 'What I Saw at the Revolution'
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING: Sublets;   Co-ops Easing The Rules
description: NEW YORK area cooperatives are beginning to ease their traditional restrictions on the rights of shareholders to rent their apartments to outsiders.

title: A Board's Proper Role
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Mortgage Guarantees;   HOPE for Homes
description: To help as many as 1,000 of their employees buy affordable homes, four New Jersey companies have joined a state agency there to underwrite mortgages in what may be the first such program in the country. Dubbed HOPE, or Home Ownership for Performing Employees, the companies guarantee up to 20 percent of a home loan for selected employees, while the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency underwrites the entire amount. The companies are A. T. & T., Kay Elemetrics Corporation of Pine Brook, Melrose Displays of Passaic and Hesco Electrics Supply Company of Clinton.

title: Mexico Train Crash Injures 60
description: At least 60 people were injured, 15 of them seriously, when two trains collided near the southern Mexican city of Puebla, local officials and the Red Cross said today. The two trains, one carrying freight and the other passengers, collided at Grajales, about 25 miles from Puebla, on Friday, a spokesman for the local government said. He said the injured included the engineer of one of the trains but gave no other details of casualties. Officials said they did not know the cause of the accident, which halted rail traffic between Mexico City and the southern port of Veracruz for several hours.

title: In the Cocaine War ... The Jungle Is Winning
description: NEAR THE TINY VILLAGE OF Santa Lucia, deep in the Peruvian jungle - a vast, untamed land of luxuriant vegetation, steeply rising hills and swollen rivers, where gun-toting narcos and murderous thieves mix with peasant activists and Maoist guerrillas - United States officials are putting the finishing touches on a new military base meant to serve as America's forward outpost in the war on cocaine.

title: Happy April 15
description: When Internal Revenue Service agents set out to separate the Newhouse clan from $609 million seven years ago, they should have known to pack a lunch. Lawyers for S.I. Newhouse Jr. and his brother, Donald, walked out of Federal Tax Court in Washington last week with a victory in one of the biggest tax disputes in I.R.S. history. The court ruled that the estate of Samuel I. Newhouse, the media mogul, was a lot less at the time of his death in 1979 than the $1.32 billion assessment made by the I.R.S. The court agreed with the Newhouse brothers, who are executors of the estate, that their father's holdings were worth only about $237 million. The I.R.S. claimed that based on its valuation of the Newhouse companies - Advance Publications, which controls around 50 newspapers and the Conde Nast magazine group; and Newhouse Broadcasting, then the owner of five television stations -the estate owed more than $600 million. Last week's ruling meant that the I.R.S. would have to settle for what the Newhouses have already paid, $48 million. Said a Newhouse lawyer, ''We are very pleased.''

title: College Steps In to Aid Aaron Copland Camp
description: LEAD: ARNOLD GAMSON, the county's supervisor of performing arts, describes Dr. Joseph N. Hankin, president of Westchester Community College, as ''an utter savior'' who ''came along out of the blue'' to offer his services. But Dr. Hankin says he provided ''a simple funding mechanism - no big deal.''

title: Mary G. O'Connor To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. O'Connor of Loudonville, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Mary Gallagher O'Connor and Christopher Smith Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger P. Morgan of Stonington, Conn.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off. I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals. I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss. After a month, the stain leached through, and now I have pink streaks.

title: Brandy Johnson Falls by the Wayside
description: The harsh realities of world-class gymnastics became painfully clear to Brandy Johnson today. One, it is not a sport for the unhealthy. Two, a younger athlete can pop up anywhere, anytime.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Portland, Me.;   1866 Building Gets a Reprieve
description: SPURNED in its application for a permit to demolish the 124-year-old, downtown Tracy-Causer building, the Fineberg Group, a Wellesley, Mass., developer, has decided instead to restore the 1866 structure.

title: Heavyweights and High Spirits
description: In 1952, when The Paris Review was in its planning stages, the founding editor, George Plimpton, was studying at King's College, Cambridge. And so it was that the magazine received an early potent injection of youthful intellectual curiosity as well as an undergraduate love of nonsense - as evidenced by the Review's retention of those qualities even 38 years later.

title: Surgeon General Confirmed
description: Antonia Coello Novello was confirmed as Surgeon General by the Senate on Thursday. A 45-year-old pediatrician and expert on AIDS in children, she is the first female and the first Hispanic Surgeon General. She has been deputy director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, one of the National Institutes of Health.

description: To the Editor: I was amused by the item about the 34-day Around the World trip for $36,500 (Travel Advisory, Jan. 14).

description: The outlook for the Kentucky Derby grew murkier than ever today when Shot Gun Scott led a blanket finish of long shots across the wire in the Fountain of Youth Stakes and Red Ransom was beaten for the first time in an earlier race at Gulfstream Park.

title: The Needs Of The Retarded
description: I am pleased that Walter McCarthy brought up the topic of social skills for the retarded. Interestingly, it is an area that does receive a great deal of emphasis in schools and agencies, while being an area that the public does not hear much about.

THEATER;

PRAGUE DIARY: ON PERFORMING HAVEL
description: LEAD: Sixteen years ago, Vaclav Havel wrote a one-act play, ''Audience,'' an interview between a dissident writer, Vanek (who works in a brewery, as had the author), and his boss, the Brewmaster. Though the play was banned in Czechoslovakia, it was performed abroad and in 1983 it was produced at the Public Theater.

A Sure Cure for Cabin Fever
description: LEAD: Some New England gardeners accept the enforced idleness of winter with resignation. But the vast majority go into a decline immediately after Thanksgiving.

title: Funds May Fall Short in West Side Park Plan
description: A waterfront park proposed for the West Side of Manhattan may cost as much as $331 million - about $70 million more than is now pledged to the project, a consultant told a panel overseeing the plans for the park.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Se-tenants stand together. These are groups of different stamps, perforated and printed on one sheet. They are usually collected in blocks or strips without separating them. Hobbyists in the United States will be most familiar with the sheets of the 50 state flags (1976), the 50 state birds and flowers (1982) and the 50 stamps picturing wildlife (1987). Each stamp has the same denomination but each design is different.

title:
GARDENING;

Trees That Stand Up to Modern Stresses
description: LEAD: TREES reduce the starkness of the landscape, but many of the shade trees commonly planted in years past no longer seem to be adapted to the urban-suburban setting.

title: College Basketball;   Arizona Shuts Down Payton
description: Matt Muehlbach had 29 points and the Arizona defense stifled Oregon State's Gary Payton as the Wildcats beat the Beavers, 87-60, today to gain a share of the regular-season Pacific-10 title.

title: Debt Interest Will Swallow the 'Peace Dividend'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ROOM WHERE FORSTER LIVED
description: In Edinburgh, a scarred old double-runged wooden stool; in Jerusalem, lying folded on a stand-up desk, a pair of well-used reading glasses. The tall stool (I have one just like it in my kitchen) and the scratched lenses (a dresser-drawerful of these!) are the most commonplace objects in the world - what is more familiar, what is more intimate? But this stool once belonged to Robert Burns, Scotland's national poet, and these glasses to the Nobel laureate S. Y. Agnon, Israel's greatest novelist. It is the electrifying gaze of the literary pilgrim that transforms ordinary human articles into mythic tokens of genius.

title: Bombing Wounds 16 G.I.'s in Panama
description: Two men yelling ''Long live Noriega!'' threw a grenade into a discotheque, wounding 16 American servicemen and 11 other people, witnesses and officials saidtoday.

title: FATE CALLS FOR FRITZ LANG
description: DESTINY EXPRESS

title: POSTINGS: SoHo Conversion;   Peppered Past
description: Long before SoHo became a haven for artists and later a chic residential and retail neighborhood, the area was a manufacturing district that also was home to food and spice trading companies.

title: South African Rebels, Restless in Tanzania, Yearn to Return Home
description: When Ronnie Masango fled South Africa as a radical teen-ager, he thought he would get six months' military training with the African National Congress in the Angolan bush and return with a rifle to help overthrow the white-minority Government.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: Yeah, except for one thing; they sent the wrong guy to San Antonio. It should have been Mark Jackson.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   Berlin Hospital Weathers a Drain of Doctors
description: Friedrichshain Municipal Hospital, a 1,280-bed institution not far from the center of the capital, suffered like the rest of the East German health system from the loss of qualified people when the mass exodus from this country began last summer.

New London's Quirky Individualist Left a Record of the City's Geometry
description: LEAD: THE story has it that Beatrice Cuming was bound for Boston in 1934, when she jumped off the train at New London. She was attracted by the city's marine and industrial landscape, above all by its bold geometry. Miss Cuming used New London has her home port until her death in 1974.

description: A picture caption on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today misattributes a revival of ''The Sound of Music.'' It is being presented by the New York City Opera, not the City Center.

description: Mrs. Victor A. Lord of Albany and Brant Lake, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Victoria Marie Lord to Mark W. Eckenwiler, a son of Leah Eckenwiler of Tulsa, Okla. A June wedding is planned.

title: Two Share Lead But Not by Much
description: Paul Azinger went from the spectacular to the unsteady, while Fred Couples kept a steady level of phlegmatic proficiency as the two young stars remained tied for the lead going into the final round of the Doral Ryder Open.

title: For '92, the Networks Have to Do Better
description: LEAD: Warning: The 1992 Presidential race is coming! Only 24 months until the Iowa caucuses.

title: Reviews/Music;   Erotica Trio at the Y; This Debut Is Official
description: The Eroica Trio, a chamber group that was formed at the Juilliard School in 1986, made its official debut Wednesday evening with an enjoyable program of Mozart, Schubert and Shostakovich at the 92d Street Y. The players - Erika Nickrenz, a pianist; Adela Pena, a violinist, and Sara Sant'Ambrogio, a cellist - are accomplished musicians with interpretive instincts that are solid and well matched. Now and then, a surfeit of incautious enthusiasm led to a dropped note or an occasional squeak or scrape. But the aggregate of their efforts did the trio credit.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Brattleboro, Vt.;

17,000 Sq. Ft. Of Timber
description: LEAD: THE Vermont Building, which its developers say is the largest timber-frame mercantile building in New England and perhaps the largest structure of its kind built in the last century, will be ready for occupancy next month.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off. I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals. I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss. After a month, the stain leached through, and now I have pink streaks.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: ALL over Hunterdon County there were crows in the air, crows on the move, rebel bands skirting the treetops, and black armadas wheeling north. Among them were vultures.

description: I got my first, and worst, tax headache of the year choosing a program to prepare the return.
