IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: IDEOLOGY THRIVES IN ROCK'S OUTER ORBITS
description: Down in front of the stage at CBGB, the action subsided while Prong tuned up. Moments earlier, as the hard-core/metal band growled and battered through its songs, its fans had been ''moshing'' (slam-dancing) to the music - hurling themselves headlong at one another or climbing onstage and then leaping onto their companions, seemingly as mindless a diversion as the 20th century has to offer.

title: Corruption and Corporate 'Perks'
description: To the Editor If your section had less concern for corporations and more for their stockholders, ''Butlers and Crystal as Well as a View'' (Feb. 4) would have appeared on page 1 of The Times, and not on page 29 of your section. More important, the story would not have been about the ''bosses' '' uniformed butlers, crystal decanters, peeled oranges, Acapulco retreats and other ''perks,'' but about their corruption.

title:
FORUM;

Mr. Bush's Perverse Optimism
description: Sar A. Levitan is research professor of economics and director of the Center for Social Policy Studies at George Washington University. By SAR A. LEVITAN AFTER seven years of economic expansion, fears of rising inflation and an economic downturn have abated as the economy achieved - at least temporarily - a soft landing. However, estimates during the final quarter of 1989 of an annual 0.9 percent rise in gross national product do not offer much of a safety net. If such slow growth persists, it is likely to lead to a stagnating economy or worse.

title: Wall Street
description: What happens if you have been saving for a string of rainy days only to see the climate get steadily drier? When the hard times don't materialize, you obviously will find yourself with an unexpected surplus of cash.

title:
Style Makers;

Lat Naylor, 'Planner' of Men's Clothing
description: LEAD: It seems a large leap from planning low-income housing in Oakland, Calif., to designing hip men's clothing in San Francisco. But Lat Naylor, who has done both, is consistent. In both, he has inclined toward designs that are ''big, simple and clean.''

title: Favoring the Legalization of Illicit Drugs
description: BILL MATHESIUS, the Mercer County Executive since 1980, is the most prominent elected official in New Jersey to support publicly the legalization of drugs like marijuana, cocaine and heroin. He is a former Mercer Prosecutor and an assistant United States attorney.

title: Tidewater Ensemble
description: St. Mary's College has been offering higher education in lower Maryland for 150 years. For the last 19, it has also presented a series of spring and summer festivals covering poetry, drama, art and music.

title: Vivi Stevenson Is Engaged to Wed Kirk Robert Pickering in
description: Mrs. Philip Chadwick Foster Smith of Bath and Freeport, Me., and James Hazlet Stevenson 3d of Philadelphia and Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gertrude Gouverneur Stevenson, to Kirk Robert Pickering, the son of the late Silas Wright Pickering 3d and the late Carol Kelly Pickering of Pittsburgh. The prospective bridegroom is the adopted son of Mrs. Silas Wright Pickering 3d of Pittsburgh. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Budd Company's Different Drum
description: Composites combine the properties of two or more materials to accomplish tasks beyond the capabilities of homogeneous substances. An early example was the addition of straw to bricks to resist breakage. Currently, carbon-reinforced plastics produce lighter, stiffer golf clubs and tennis rackets, and designers are looking at exotic metal-ceramic combinations for high-performance aerospace applications.

title: Now Albany Gets Its Opportunity For Fiscal Delusions
description: AFTER the bad old days of the 1970's, when bankruptcy seemed near and boom unimaginable, New York City was ordered to untangle its books and submit them to newly appointed fiscal monitors. The city was also forced to draw up budgets for four years at a clip and to update its spending plans four times a year, so it could not, as one official put it last week, hide its head in the sand for more than three months at a time.

title: FOLLOW THE SERENDIPITY ROAD
description: On a Sunday some months ago, my wife, Lynne, and I were driving west on U.S. 14 from Brookings, S.D. We had spent the night there, after a visit to the South Dakota Art Museum, with its exceptional collection of paintings by the South Dakota artist Harvey Dunn. At De Smet we stopped for a tank of gas, and I studied the map. ''If we turn south here,'' I said, ''we can go to Mitchell. It's out of our way, but I think it's worth it. We can go to the Corn Palace.''

title: Reviews/Music;   Chee-Yun, Violinist, In Debut
description: Chee-Yun, an 18-year-old violinist from South Korea, was a winner in the 1989 Young Concert Artists Auditions, and was presented by that organization in her New York recital debut Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y. There was promise in Chee-Yun's performance. She is a student of Dorothy DeLay at the Juilliard School, and like many of Miss DeLay's other students, she has a smooth, gorgeously focused tone that can sound melting in the right music.

title: POSTINGS: Beetles and Dry Rot;   Sleepy Hollow Church Restoration
description: Restoration work on the Old Dutch Church in North Tarrytown, N.Y., which is immortalized in Washington Irving's ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,'' has started and will continue throughout the year. The first phase is a study of the repairs necessary in the wooden belfry and roof, parts of which have been damaged by dry rot and insects.

title: GERMANY AND INTEREST RATES
description: The meshing of West and East Germany - one a sleek, postwar capitalist engine and the other a shattered, inefficient state-run rowboat with high unemployment - is expected to be a formidable task. While the two halves may some day become a seamless and vibrant economy, the transition is expected to be rough, and unsettling for interest rates around the globe. There are divergent schools of thought on the subject. One group of economists believes that there is a finite amount of capital in the world. As West Germany seeks to finance the redevelopment of East Germany, so the argument goes, borrowers there will bid up interest rates to attract capital, forcing borrowers in the United States and Japan to raise their rates in a global competition for funds.

title:
ART;

A Chance to Reassess Works Of a Disquieting Expressionist
description: LEAD: WHEN the influenza epidemic of 1918 claimed the life of Egon Schiele, it ended the brief but productive career of one of Expressionism's most gifted and disquieting artists.

title: Tenant Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiring a Preparers Can Ease the Pain
description: THE 50 million Americans who will pay someone to prepare their income tax returns this year face an important choice: what kind of service to use.

title: Carol von Glahn and Eric Hussar Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. von Glahn of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Anne von Glahn to Eric Christian Hussar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hussar of Lancaster, Pa. An April wedding is planned.

title: Data Bank/March 4, 1990
Strawberry 'Getting Well,' He Says
description: Darryl Strawberry arrived in Florida today to begin what he termed his ''new life'' after a winter of turmoil and a month of treatment for alcohol abuse, and said: ''I'm not a bad person. I'm a sick person getting well.'' The 27-year-old right fielder for the Mets flew here from Los Angeles and made his first public statement about his troubled times since he entered the Smithers Center in Manhattan on Feb. 3. He appeared in the Mets' spring training stadium, which has been locked for the last three weeks during the baseball labor dispute, and sat alongside Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, who said, ''I've never been more proud of Darryl than at this moment.'

title: EXPLORING DEVONS'S SECRET GARDENS
description: Traveling the 120 miles from London to Devon in March is to make the leap from winter to spring. Thanks to the warm waters of the Gulf Stream, England's southwest peninsula begins to bloom weeks before the rest of the country has emerged from gray dampness and night frosts. Wherever you go in Devon, the ocean is not far away, and its influence makes winter a gentle affair with minimal frost, sea mists and lots of rain. Summers are temperate too. Color comes early to these parts, with brilliant yellow celandines along the lanes from February giving way to wild primroses, which are happier in this cool, wet climate than anywhere else in Britain and grow in profusion, often sharing the wayside with wood anemones and early purple orchids. Through the spring the woodland is carpeted with fragrant wild bluebells, their sheets of blue contrasting with drifts of pink campion.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: The Knicks gave up too much youth, talent and most of all, potential for a player who, however classy and dependable, has his best years behind him.

title: Carol A. Walsh To Wed in June
description: Carol Ann Walsh, an associate vice president of Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, and Louis Mead Treadwell 2d, the chairman of the Siberia-Alaska Trading Company in Anchorage, are planning a June wedding.

title: Curtains for 'Chorus Line' and for a Stage of City History
description: ''A CHORUS LINE,'' the hit musical that is to close this month after a record-breaking Broadway run of 15 years, in some ways is the ideal New York story, both in its own success and in the story it tells. In it, 17 dancers try out for jobs in a show and, although almost all are destined to be losers, their up-and-down careers represent the mood of eternal hope that keeps attracting out-of-towners to New York.

title: Taking a Chance on Luck
description: EVEN in these days of easy access, foreign travel can still hold something of the mysterious and the magical: the unaccustomed can release soundings from the deep. ''For the world . . . ,'' in Matthew Arnold's words, is ''so various, so beautiful, so new . . . .'' Yet it is the same world that is ''Swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight.''

title: In Jordan, Probing Petra's Mysteries
description: THE Texan in the Stetson went by horse-drawn buggy and the grave matron from Japan by Arab steed, and, with many others, they rode in a gaggle to ancient Petra through the defile called the Sik.

title: TWINKLE, TWINKLE, NORTHERN LIGHTS
description: When I was a child I longed to see the aurora borealis, and life being what it is, I still do. I'm told one needn't go all that far north to glimpse this magical display of fairy lights stretching across the night sky - one lucky friend claims to have seen it from the roof of her house in Cambridge, Mass. But that's not very romantic, is it? To get the full effect, one ought to see it in some suitably wild and desolate and snowy place, like Greenland. Someplace cold, with Eskimos and Viking ghosts, and maybe a few wolves howling in the distance.

title: World Markets;   Weighing the West German Markets
description: There is another country, aside from Japan, where the bond market has fallen sharply and sent interest rates to startingly high levels. But in that country - West Germany - the impact has not been nearly as devastating.

title: Regina Napoli Is Wed
description: Regina E. Napoli and Bruce S. Borden were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Smithtown, L.I., by the Rev. Paul Walsh. Mrs. Borden, 28 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Napoli of Hauppauge, L.I. Her husband, 30, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Borden of Cape Elizabeth, Me. The bride is a vice president in New York of the Landerbank Group in Vienna. Mr. Borden is a vice president of the family-owned R. E. Borden Paper Company in Portland, Me.

title: Some Other Predators Dwarf the Tiger
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Perlmutter, Student, Is Wed
description: Genesia Perlmutter and Steven Romain Kamen were married last evening at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Ely Emanuel Pilchik, the bride's stepfather, officiated with Rabbi Barry H. Greene and Cantor Norman Summers.

title: Ecuador
description: To the Editor: I was surprised but happy to learn that trekkers have discovered Oyacachi (''Adventuring in the Cloud Forests of Ecuador,'' by Joan K. Peters, Travel, Nov. 5). As a Peace Corps volunteer, I walked to Oyacachi twice after the earthquake - which was in March 1987, rather than in 1985 as the article stated - to inspect their newly built potable water system. (Incidentally, it took me five hours to walk there without a horse.) As Joan Peters eloquently described, the paramo grass provides a beautiful landscape with several precipitous waterfalls across the gorge to gauge one's progress by.

title: America's Position in the Economic Race: What the Numbers Show and Conceal
description: These are days of confirmation that the American economic system remains the model for those yearning to be rich. But to some, this is a moment of irony: Even as the world learns to stop worrying and love Big Macs, the American economy seems to be losing its productive edge. The nation is borrowing billions to cover expenses and to build high-tech toys like the stealth bomber, the theory goes, while everything from vocational education to computer-chip factories slides into obsolescence. At the same time, the United States is losing its self-declared economic war with the Japanese - Toshiba and Toyota have stolen consumers' hearts - and watching passively as the Latin democracies strangle on debts to American banks.

title: Fighting The War On Cigs
description: The ad looks like this. There is a woman. She has great clothes, important earrings, big hair, some attitude. There is a white box beneath the woman. The box says, ''Smoking Causes Lung Cancer, Heart Disease, Emphysema, And May Complicate Pregnancy.'' The ad appears to be selling two things: sex and death. Of course, it is really selling cigarettes.

title: Theresa Fogarty To Wed in April
description: Mrs. Charles F. Fogarty of Darien, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Theresa Ellen Fogarty to Troy Edwin Stavens, the son of Mrs. Edwin H. Stavens of Hatton, N.D., and the late Mr. Stavens. An April wedding is planned.

title: WHERE EAST MEETS WEST - TO BOOGIE!
description: Dynasty Hao is a restaurant that has recently opened in Tokyo. Its interior has been designed to resemble a bare-beamed SoHo loft, and its sound system speaks riffy American jazz. The food, however, is spicy Taiwanese: pork dumplings, sauteed pumpkin with garlic, minced chicken in lettuce. The restaurant is the second of this name to be opened in Tokyo by Kiddieland, an upscale Japanese toy store. To find most places in Tokyo requires elaborate directions since locations aren't numbered - there are no addresses - but you can get your bearings from the Famous Amos shop near nearby, and the Mexican restaurant, La Jolla, which is just across the street. Young mothers naturally frequent Dynasty Hao after purchasing Cabbage Patch dolls and Babar books at Kiddieland. I'm told that their favorite drink is Perrier flavored with a Japanese plum brandy. The restaurant's liquor list spells it ''Perie'' but Perrier is what it is. Misspellings are part of the fun. So is incomprehensibility. (A place in Nagoya calls itself Cafe L'emoi. I don't know whether the sign is trying to advertise the Me Cafe, or whether it really means to call itself Cafe Flutter - better yet, Cafe Anxiety. Perhaps, to the Japanese, it only says French.) Minced pigeon is a popular dish in many of Tokyo's Chinese restaurants, although the bird is sometimes surreptitiously replaced by chicken. However, if your food is Taiwanese, your surroundings American, your management Japanese, your owner a toy store with a California-style name, then it scarcely matters what has been minced and hidden in the hay: what you are eating is pidgin.

title: P.L.O. Says a New State Could Link With Jordan
description: The No. 2 official in the Palestine Liberation Organization says in an article to be published on Sunday that Palestinians welcome the idea of a confederation with Jordan but only after the establishment of an independent Palestinian homeland.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: PURIM PARTIES

title: POSTINGS: $200,000 Project;   Land-Use Guide
description: A year-long project intended to produce a model guide to land development that would be made available to government agencies in New York State is being undertaken by the New York City Partnership and the New York Land Institute. The $200,000 project is being paid for by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. The guide will be based on an examination of the laws, regulations and practices that have an impact on the real estate development approval process in both New York and other states, as well as on interviews with those involved. The guide would be an evaluation of their use in the oversight and control process.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Whittle Communications begins its Channel One classroom news program.

title: Switch in Latin Crops Won't Help Peasants;   Coca in the Andes
description: To the Editor:

title: House Moves to Restore Health Benefits for Elderly
description: A bipartisan group of four House leaders has moved to restore several health benefits for older Americans that were included in the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act that Congress repealed last year.

title: Laurie Polis Engaged To Richard M. Wind
description: Dr. Laurie Joan Polis, a dermatologist, and Dr. Richard Marc Wind, an obstetrician and gynecologist, both in New York, are planning an April wedding. The announcement was made by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Polis of Williston Park, L.I. Dr. Wind is a son of Samuel Wind of New York and the late Margot Wertheimer Wind.

title: Amy Ziegelman To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Amy Ziegelman to Icho Avital, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Avital of Jerusalem, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Ziegelman of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Style Makers;   Eve J. Alfille, Jewelry Designer
description: When she was a stockbroker, Eve J. Alfille used paper clips to bring her jewelry designs to life. The first pins she created in 1972 were made of something equally functional: transformer parts.

title: Campus Life: Swarthmore;   Dropping Books, 37 Students Enter A Library Race
description: With midterms approaching this week, 25 male and 12 female Swarthmore College undergraduates took a break from their books last Sunday to take part in the annual McCabe Mile - an 18-lap race amid the bookshelves in the McCabe Library basement.

title: Tax Books, a Winning Investment
description: Few investments offer the low-risk, high-reward potential of a good book on income taxes. Almost anyone who spends a few dollars for a book and takes some time to study it is sure to realize tax savings far greater than the cost of the book.

title: Responding to New Office-Space Needs
description: THE General Foods Building in Rye Brook, often called the Taj Mahal of Westchester, is for sale. Nearby, the former AMF headquarters building on Westchester Avenue has been vacant since November 1986.

title: GIRLS TAKE 51.3% IN REGENTS AWARDS
description: Female high-school students in New York State who receive better grades than boys are winning a larger share of the Regents College Scholarship Awards.

title: An April Bridal For Jean Maguire
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry Clinton Maguire Jr. of Merion, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Emily Maguire, to Dr. Gijsbert Arius van Seventer, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Huibert van Seventer of Amstelveen, the Netherlands. An April wedding is planned.

title: Catherine Lea Eisler To Wed S. D. Ackerson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore David Eisler of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Catherine Lea Eisler and Scott D. Ackerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Dee Ackerson of Hilliard, Ohio.

title: MOVIES - THE BIG AND THE BEAUTIFUL
description: LEAD:

title: An Experts' Roundtable - Tax Strategies for Today
description: The Tax Reform Act of 1986 was intended to simplify the nation's tax code, making economics rather than taxes the basis for financial decisions. Frederick Andrews, business-financial editor of The New York Times, and Jan M. Rosen, editor of this supplement, interviewed three leading practitioners about how they are now advising clients in such key areas as retirement planning, saving for their children's education, investing and home ownership. The practitioners are: George E.L. Barbee, executive director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse; Joel S. Isaacson, director of personal financial planning for Weber Lipshie & Company, and Herbert M. Paul, senior tax partner with Mahoney Cohen Paul & Company.

title: Campus Life: Smith;   For a Fund-Raiser, Women Develop A Calendar of Men
description: A new Smith College calendar portrays unusual representatives of a women's college - men.

title: Glittering, Elegant Relics Of Good Times Past
description: ''People do not expect to see much glass at the Winter Antiques Show,'' said Arlene Palmer, a glass specialist from Yarmouth, Me., who visited the show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, in late January.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Synopsis of the Plight Of the Handicapped
description: Walter McCarthy gives a good synopsis of the plight moderately handicapped people face in their efforts to break from the stereotypical vocational situations.

title: Shackleford's Two Benefactors
description: Charles Shackleford is described by one of his former North Carolina State teammates as a mystery man.

title: Eve Iselin to Wed T. M. Sommerfield
description: May wedding plans have been announced for Eve Cecile Iselin, a daughter of Jane Thornton Iselin of Bridgehampton, L.I., and Charles W. Iselin of Huntington, L.I., and Timothy Mack Sommerfield, a son of Joan Bernhard of New York and Barrie Sommerfield of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Prison Bunks, Prison Values
description: New York State's Corrections Commissioner, Thomas Coughlin, vows he will never put two convicts in a cell, but now the rising tide of prisoners is lapping perilously close to his resolve. With no other options, he last week approved replacing single bunks in some prison dormitories - though not individual cells - with double bunks, thereby igniting a debate in Albany.

title: THE MAN WHO OWNS PRIME TIME
description: A STUNNINGLY SUNNY MORNING IN BURBANK: Brandon Tartikoff, the most successful programmer in the history of network television, is conspicuously in his element. He is talking about ideas for television shows. ''I have this idea about a high-powered businessman, about 60, with three daughters. He's a media magnate, like Ted Turner, or maybe a Lee Iacocca. . . .''

title: Protester Slain in Kashmir by Police Gunfire
description: The police killed a protester today in the old downtown area of Srinagar after 25 people came out of their homes in defiance of a curfew, witnesses said. The police and airport officials said India sent hundreds of reinforcements to the Kashmir Valley after troops fired on Muslim protesters this week.

title: Glad It's Over
description: HE came up a free throw short of a chance to end his 34-year coaching career with his 600th victory, but the way Abe Lemons of Oklahoma City saw it after a 78-77 loss to Oklahoma Christian on Friday night, the close call was something of a relief.

title:
FOCUS: Sacramento, Calif.;

Suburbs to Try 'Pedestrian Pockets'
description: LEAD: THIS rapidly growing state capital of 350,000 residents has rarely been thought of as a center of innovation, but planning officials and builders all over northern California are watching the progress of proposals here for three unusual suburban projects that would be developed as ''pedestrian pockets.

title: 'Le Train Bleu' Makes a Brief Stopover
description: Soon after the London opening of ''Le Train Bleu'' during the 1924 season of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, a writer in one of the glossy weeklies complained, ''It is as difficult to get a seat for 'The Blue Train' as it is to get a seat for the thing itself during the height of the Riviera rush.'' The ballet, a lighthearted tribute to fashion in the 1920's, starred the 20-year-old dancer Anton Dolin in a role created to show off his gymnastic skills. Adding to the work's allure was its cast of artistic collaborators: Bronislava Nijinska, Vaslav Nijinsky's sister, contributed the choreography; Jean Cocteau, the libretto; Darius Milhaud, the score; Gabrielle ''Coco'' Chanel, costumes; the Romanian sculptor Henri Laurens, sets, and Pablo Picasso, curtain. Despite its popularity, however, ''Le Train Bleu'' vanished from the Ballets Russes repertory in 1925 when Dolin left the company. The work, whose creation had sparked artistic fireworks, was not seen for more than 60 years until Oakland Ballet restored it to the stage last fall.

title: Ms. Eisenberg to Wed Marc Brandriss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Eisenberg of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy B. Eisenberg to Dr. Marc G. Brandriss, a son of Perla Brandriss of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Rabbi Joseph Brandriss. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE GREATEST LIAR OF THEM All?
description: THE TRAVELS OF MENDES PINTO

title: WHEN A PREGNANT WOMAN DRINKS
description: Your article was informative and, at times, chilling in its implications. However, I do not feel this subject can be thoroughly addressed without presenting the significant issue of male alcoholism and its effect on the fetus.

title: On Language;   The Wetlands Fox
description: FRANCIS MARION, AN American general in the Revolutionary War, bedeviled the British with his surprise attacks from the marshy areas of South Carolina. The short, sickly-looking fellow was among our earliest partisan fighters, pioneering guerrilla tactics against regular troops in skirmishes at Tearcoat Swamp and Halfway Swamp. Because he and his small force would strike and then disappear into seemingly impenetrable bogs, through brambles that tore the red coats of his pursuers, the elusive Marion was given the sobriquet ''the Swamp Fox.''

title: Saving to Retire? Tax Code Helps
description: RETIREMENT can be the time to enjoy the fruits of a life's labor, or it can be a time of penny-pinching uncertainty. To be sure it is the first, an understanding of the role tax laws play, both in saving for retirement and during retirement, is essential.

title: Battling for Tenants in a Slow Market
description: A TWO-YEAR building surge in West Midtown has demonstrated the power of public incentives to direct the path of commercial development. The big question now is how to market a spate of new offices when the New York City economy has sunk into the doldrums.

title: Review/Rock;   Mischief by Jad Fair and Kramer
description: Jad Fair and Kramer, who brought a six-piece band to Wetlands on Monday night, are kindred souls on rock's scruffy fringes. Mr. Fair, who has led the band Half Japanese since the late 1970's, is one of rock's last professional amateurs; he writes blunt, seemingly artless lyrics, sings them in a nasal whine and scratches out scraggly notes and chords from his guitar. Kramer, a bassist, produces albums for his own Shimmy-Disc label that treat rock as a jumbled heritage and a shared joke that might or might not be taken seriously.

title: Indira Desai Wed to Patrick Christie
description: Indira Desai and Patrick Ian Christie were married yesterday at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Robert Hundley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Krishna Desai of Sarasota, Fla. The bridegroom is a son of George Christie of Orleans, Mass., and Pat Goodwin of Middlebury, Vt.

title: Glasnost On the Island
description: PEERING over the border for decades, each side has never hidden its mistrust of its neighbor. It is a relationship forged from years of suspicion and ruthless political competition.

title: Ruth Mead Wed To Jeffrey Barker
description: Ruth Cummings Mead and Jeffrey Pierce Barker were married yesterday at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. John M. Allin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Marx Left the Individual Out of His Equation
description: To the Editor:

title:
MUSIC;

Winner Who Dislikes Competitions
description: LEAD: THE Irish pianist Barry Douglas, who came to public attention after winning a gold medal at the 1986 Tchaikovsky International Competition in Moscow, has nothing encouraging to say about competitions. ''Competitions are the worst inventions ever,'' he said, adding that a musician's job is to interpret, not compete.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: The trade was a terrible one. True, Strickland was bad for the team's morale. But the Knicks should have gotten much more for him than a player who has at most a year or two left. It was a trade you might make if you had a real shot at the championship, but the Knicks don't belong on the same court as the Lakers.

title: In the Sonoran Desert, The Bizarre Is the Rule
description: IN 1922 a botanist named Godfrey Sykes happened upon a bizarre- looking tree in the Sonoran desert, which stretches from Baja California nearly to the eastern border of Arizona. It resembled a 30-foot-tall upside-down green carrot with tiny, tiny branches. ''Ho, ho, a boojum,'' Mr. Sykes said when he saw the unusual plant. ''Definitely a boojum.'' The unusual tree is still called a boojum, after a creature in ''The Great Snark Hunt,'' a poem by Lewis Carroll about a mythical exploration of a far-off fantasy land.

title: HEAVYWEIGHTS AND HIGH SPIRITS
description: THE PARIS REVIEW ANTHOLOGY

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: IVAN LANSBERG;

Psychologist Studies Family Businesses
description: LEAD: AS a doctoral candidate at Columbia University, Ivan Lansberg did a computer search for ''family business'' and was surprised to find only three pages of research citations. He has been adding to scholarship on the subject ever since.

title: A Controversy Is Exploding
description: I was disappointed in the interview with Irving Sandler, co-founder of Artists Space. The interviewer asked if Artists Space would reject pornography or if the National Endowment for the Arts should finance art criticizing political figures. Academics are in near unanimity on these questions.

title: Playing for Bigger Stakes?
description: THE Rev. Jesse Jackson has used an Archimedean approach to politics - ''leverage,'' he calls it - to nudge the Democratic Party this way and that in recent years. But Mr. Jackson also wants to move the world, and for that, he has decided, the Mayor's office in Washington is not the place to stand.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Long Island Weekly last Sunday described the investigation of a car-bombing on Feb. 15 that killed a Suffolk County narcotics detective. It reported that investigators' focus had shifted from the detective's undercover work to his private life.

title: Taxpayers' Savvy Strategies
description: For freelance artists and writers, whose yearly expenses and income are often unpredictable and irregular, staying on top of personal finances is essential for saving on taxes.

title: THE DRINK OF MILLIONS
description: IT IS RAINING ON THE ASHOKAN RESERVOIR. The rain ruffles the surface of the water, and a gray mist slinks off the Catskill Mountains. Several months from now, this rain will emerge, 90 miles to the south, through innumerable New York City faucets and washing machines and fire hydrants. The trip, made by billions of gallons of water every month, will be uneventful. Between the still reservoir and the turbulent city, the water, powered almost exclusively by gravity, will encounter neither a pump nor a meter. It will arrive essentially untreated, save for a dollop of chlorine.

title: Who Oversees The County's Environment?
description: ENVIRONMENTALISTS and county officials have often been at odds. At the moment they agree on one thing: the county's quality of life is increasingly at risk, and no one is minding the environmental store.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. CHARLES P. POLLAK;

The Quest for a Good Night's Sleep
description: LEAD: LADY MACBETH didn't need an expert to tell her why she wasn't sleeping well. Guilt over murder was her problem, and perhaps no expert anywhere could have done much to help her. In real life, the reasons people have sleep problems can be subtle or obvious; physical or, as with Lady Macbeth, mental.

title: Jill Faherty Plans To Marry in June
description: Susan Winslow Smith of Bedminster, N.J., and J. Roger Faherty of Spring Lake, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Jill Christine Faherty to Terence James Haggerty, a son of Judge and Mrs. James C. Haggerty of Short Hills, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE VOICE OF THE CITY: Vaudeville and Popular Culture in New York. By Robert W. Snyder. (Oxford University, $19.95.) Vaudeville may be dead, but traces definitely remain. Comedians like George Burns and Milton Berle have enjoyed long careers based on timing and sketches perfected in front of vaudeville's unforgiving audiences. At the height of its popularity, vaudeville theaters stretched in a circuit that covered most of the country. But, more than any other city, New York represented the economic, spiritual and performance center of vaudeville. Robert W. Snyder, a research fellow at Columbia University, traces the story in ''The Voice of the City,'' a rather academic study of the ways vaudeville reflected and exploited popular culture in New York. The book is well researched (with an exhaustive bibliography) and tells some interesting stories about vaudeville's evolution, as the noisy and often unsavory patrons dubbed ''gallery gods'' were cleaned up and cleared out, and vaudeville became ''decent'' family entertainment (and more profitable as well). There were many conflicts behind the song and dance, Mr. Snyder writes, and this was not surprising given vaudeville's adaptable partnership with an ethnically diverse New York; the Keith-Albee organization's booking monopoly; the union-busting efforts by management; the treatment of black performers, who were usually limited to one per vaudeville bill and imitated by white entertainers. These stories, quirky profiles and excerpts from vintage vaudeville routines reflect the vitality of the performers. But the many repetitions and detours in ''Voice of the City'' make Mr. Snyder's journey seem longer than its 220 pages.

title: Tax Simplification Proves Elusive
description: For the vast majority of Americans, the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 has meant slightly lower taxes and an easier time figuring them out. But for some people, most of them well-to-do, the new law has meant much higher taxes and a nightmare of unfathomable rules and regulations.

title: Lifestyle;   For $350, Capture Your Personality In a Little Bottle and Call It Perfume
description: There's Joan Collins's Spectacular. And let's not forget Elizabeth Taylor's Passion, Cher's Uninhibited, Undeniable by Billy Dee Williams, Only by Julio Iglesias and those named Paloma, Deneuve, Cassini and Misha, named for you know who. Now, in the upper reaches of Madison Avenue, you can have your very own fragrance created for you and you alone and identified not with your name but - how tony can you get? - with your very own locked-in-a-vault secret number.

title: A Sulky Rock Star Among the Prophets
description: Though Elizabeth Swados had wanted to write a musical based on the story of Jonah as long ago as 1972 - ''because I was so keen on what the inside of a whale would sound like'' - it wasn't until she came across Robert Nathan's short, poetic 1925 novel, ''Jonah,'' that she saw how to do it. The novel, she said, ''made Jonah such a prophet for the 80's and 90's, so narcissistic, full of complaints, apathetic, unwilling to do anything for anyone because there wasn't enough in it for him.'' Ms. Swados set to work and on Tuesday a ''Jonah'' composed, adapted and directed by her will open at the Public Theater.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: Maurice Cheeks is a great playmaker and leader as well as a class act. But he does not fill the Knicks' needs, which are a shooting guard and a solid scoring forward. As far as Mo teaching Mark how to play as if he's in the N.B.A., not Central Park, alas, enormous egos don't come equipped with ears.

title: Counting the Homeless: Advocates Are Divided
description: They try to count birds, bugs and everything else; why not count us?'' grunted the black-bearded man in his mid-30's who calls himself ''Bear.''

title: WHY BALI HA'I IS STILL CALLING
description: It's a bleak day in Manhattan as I'm writing this, and I can't help wondering why I'm here and not on some gorgeous tropical island. In fact, I wonder why I've never been on a gorgeous tropical island. My favorite Broadway number is still ''Bali Ha'i,'' from ''South Pacific,'' with its romantic longing for lush, waterlapped surroundings, and its seductive refrain, ''Come to me, come to me.'' And there's probably something innate that keeps drawing me, like a lemming, to water. As a child in Brooklyn, I headed for Coney Island every chance I had. When I was a suburban housewife, it was the sirens of Long Island Sound whose song I heard. Now, my midday respite from the computer usually includes a short walk to Carl Schurz Park, where staring at the East River clears those lines of green letters from the backs of my eyes. But there are no palm trees or bougainvillea in any of these places, and most of my recent, work-related travels have been to landlocked universities. No writing workshop on Aruba or Tahiti has ever crooned, ''Come to me, come to me.'' There have also been perfectly valid reasons for not choosing a tropical vacation: hurricanes, political unrest, overbooked airlines and hotels . . .

title: About Men;   A Back-RoadHorror Ride
description: MY JOB WAS TO open beer bottles and load guns. I hadn't volunteered for the tasks, and like any draftee I was intimidated. I did as I was told, hoping for survival, and soon the back seat of the old Ford was littered with bent bottle caps and spent shell casings.

title: I.R.S. CHIEF FACES TASK OF REBUILDING
description: Although it has made rapid strides in harnessing computer technology and carried out the Congressional overhaul of the tax code, intended in part to make filing a return simpler for tens of millions of taxpayers, the Internal Revenue Service continues to face criticism.

title: A BALKAN CAPITAL, AS IT OUGHT TO BE
description: I have for many years been fascinated by Romania, and in particular by Bucharest. It is a purely literary fascination. It began when I read Olivia Manning's ''Balkan Trilogy,'' from whose pages there rose a seedy glamour, a whiff of alluring decadence that was irresistible. Gradually it attained the status of a disreputable Mecca, something between Anthony Hope's Ruritania and Malcolm Bradbury's Slaka. It was with alarm that I read of Ceausescu's attempts to raze the familiar outlines of the old city, replace it with stony monoliths in his own image. For cities can be destroyed - are indeed terribly fragile things: go looking for true monuments of Dickens's London and see how many you find. But I still hope that, once I go behind the hard-faced boulevards celebrating the (temporary) victories of Ceausescuvian Communism, I will find the sleazy back streets, the decrepit churches with the peeling gold leaf and the unsavory cleric, the unimportant government offices where one must slip bribes to get anything done, the peasants selling half-rotten produce from barrows, the bawling fishwives and the street urchins who will practice their English on you and pick your pockets while they are doing it.

title: Ohio Ballet in a Balanchine Staple
description: The familiar won out over the new on a program by the Ohio Ballet on Friday night at the Whitney Museum of American Art at the Equitable Center. The company, founded in 1976 and based in Akron, is a troupe of disciplined, well-trained young dancers who sailed easily through George Balanchine's ''Concerto Barocco,'' which is fast becoming a staple of the national ballet repertory. The dancers did not look a bit cramped on the rather shallow stage. And Nancy McDermott and Lawrence Hernandez danced the central pas de deux with clarity and truth.

title: A PEEK THROUGH THE PEARLY GATES
description: Never has so much been written about a place of which nobody knows a thing. When religious Victorians put about that the hereafter was not a place but a state of being, the sublime Cardinal Newman opined that the idea of place was inherent in that of the afterlife.

title: Reviews/Music;   An Ode to Salvador Dali
description: ''Salvador,'' Sara Hickman's ode to the late Salvador Dali, may be the most affecting contemporary pop song to pay tribute to a well-known painter since Don McLean's ''Vincent.''

title: Lust Among the Ruins
description: LONDON FIELDS

title: Lifestyle;   Computers on Display But Not on a Pedestal
description: At the Computer Museum here, the technologically timid can consult with a wine adviser about what will complement a chicken dish, commission an original work of art or dicker with a Haymarket street vendor over the price of a pint of strawberries.

title: Ms. Jennings Weds Michael Rosenberg
description: Kathleen Ann Edwards Jennings and Michael Joseph Rosenberg were married yesterday at the Hotel Plaza Athenee in New York by Judge Carol H. Arber of City Civil Court. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vance Edwards of Prescott, Ariz. The bridegroom is a son of Sylvia Sarah Rosenberg of Passaic, N.J., and the late Emanuel Rosenberg.

title: Caring Was the Key
description: On the day they announced that ''A Chorus Line'' would finally close, you could walk over to the Shubert Theater and ask whether any good seats were available for tomorrow night. The answer would be ''You never can tell . . . Sixth row center all right?'' No hangdog looks, no maudlin theatrics, just talking a good game at the box office, right to the end. (Those seats would be fine.) The performers, too, carried on as though nothing were amiss. On stage at least, there was no unprofessional melancholy. It was basically the same production it had been for all 15 record years. And for one who luckily had forgotten which of the 19 gypsies won the eight places in the chorus line, the show evoked the same suspense, the same sense of caring: what would happen to each of those desperate, vulnerable, talented dancers?

title: Soggy Winter Gives Huskies Too Much Mush, Too Little 'Mush!'
description: OUT in Cockaponset State Forest in Haddam, a team of six Siberian huskies paced, howled and whined, while their owner, Lloyd Wyatt, slipped yellow harnesses around their necks.

title: Excerpts of President Bush's Remarks at News Conference at End of Talks
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bush at a joint news conference with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan in Palm Springs, Calif., today, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Dog Barking at Milton

title: This Discussion Series Is One for the Books
description: STARTING this month, public libraries around the state will be offering free book-discussion series in the largest such project ever organized in Connecticut. The project, Connecticut Reading Connections, supported by a Federal grant, will bring 240 individual programs to 60 communities.

title: Ban on Plastics in Suffolk Is Overturned
description: A pioneering law that banned the use of plastic food containers and grocery bags in Suffolk County on Long Island has been overturned by a state appeals court because the county did not prepare an environmental-impact statement.

title: Food;   RALLYING ROUND THE TABLE
description: THE WORDS ''FAMILY SUPPER'' CARRY with them an almost unutterable nostalgia, images and emotions of the past wrapped in the glow of better values. The vision is fueled by Norman Rockwell paintings and television commercials for turkeys, long-distance telephone companies and insurance agencies. The props are large linen napkins, grandparents, paneled dining rooms and vast tables loaded with roasted birds, homemade breads, jams and pickles and a ravishment of pies, cakes and cookies.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: Yes, for Larry Brown and the Spurs.

title: A Playwright Is Free (So Now What?)
description: A certain talented writer who, like myself, came here from Eastern Europe complained to me recently that totalitarianism has ruined him twice: first, by imprisoning him and forcing him to emigrate; second, by falling apart just when the writer had completed an 800-page novel on the very subject of totalitarianism. Needless to say, in the times of glasnost, Lech Walesa, Vaclav Havel and the Berlin Wall, the book was turned down by 11 publishing houses, where it was considered an excellent piece but totally outdated.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Upper West Side
description: SOME call it the Upper Upper West Side, but the area between Riverside Drive and Amsterdam Avenue from 96th Street to 110th Street might also be called the Hollywood Hatchery, for it was home to movie legends and artists.

title: SEE YOU ON JUDGMENT DAY
description: LEAD:

title: Ms. Inaba Is Wed To Dorian Lowell
description: Yumi Inaba, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sukeyuki Inaba of New York and Tokyo, was married yesterday to Dorian Lowell, the son of Peter Lowell and his wife, Dr. Marigold Robins, of Cholesbury, Buckinghamshire, England. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Bruce W. Forbes at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Pro Hockey;   'Stupid Things' Fell Islanders
description: One of the St. Louis goals came after the referee accidentally blocked an Islander clearing pass.

title: A Stronger Profile For Culture Is Urged
description: As the governors of the nation met here this week for the National Governors Conference, a dozen state cultural advisers gathered at the Library of Congress to engage in a little networking.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: A Re-creation Of Stanley's Epic Search

title: For I.B.M. Users, Programs Abound for IBM
description: An irony surrounds the bevy of tax-preparation computer programs on the market these days: Despite countless hours spent by program writers to distinguish their products from the competition, the programs for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers remain essentially alike. As a result, a consumer would be wise to pick a program based on how easy it is to use, whether it offers adequate on-screen help and whether it can generate a finished tax return on the printer the consumer owns.

title: Synopsis Of the Plight of the Handicapped
description: Walter McCarthy's article on social skills for the retarded as the key to advancement from sheltered workshop to successful supported employment in the public sector was a well considered one, raising the questions we need to ask about how retarded children and young adults gain these skills. The relationship with the job trainer, a coach who is eventually faded out as the retarded young adult becomes more able to do his/her job, is vital in training both the employee and the supervisor. Additionally important to success of mainstreamed employment is the attitude of fellow employees.

title: Mandela's Rivals Want No Talks With Pretoria
description: When it comes to negotiations between blacks and whites on South Africa's future, the Pan-Africanist Congress says it plans to stay away.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Suffolk Trims Farmland-Purchase Plans
description: LEAD: SUFFOLK COUNTY'S program to acquire open space to protect watersheds and pine barrens is well on its way, with 3,123 acres already bought or under contract since January 1989 at a cost of $55 million.

title: THE PATH OF MOST RESISTANCE
description: THE DAY I BEGAN MY STUDIES IN PHILOSOPHY

title:
GARDENING;

Trees That Stand Up to Modern Stresses
description: LEAD: TREES reduce the starkness of the landscape, but many of the shade trees commonly planted in years past no longer seem to be adapted to the urban-suburban setting.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Russians Are Going;   Accord Seen on Full Soviet Pullout From Hungary
description: Foreign Minister Gyula Horn said in an interview published today that he expected to reach an agreement on the total withdrawal of Soviet troops from Hungary when he visits Moscow next week.

title: For the German 'Expellees,' The Past Is a Future Vision
description: HIGH on a hill overlooking Bonn from across the Rhine stands Silesia House, an elegant and meticulously restored old mansion where German families expelled from their homeland during World War II gather to maintain old ties, to explore their heritage, to wax nostalgic - and to nurture a bitterness.

title: How One Man Rescued Basketball, and Its Bottom Line
description: David J. Stern is a friend of the Famous Chicken. He thinks it's wonderful that Orlando hates Miami. He sees no reason why fans shouldn't stuff themselves with Charlotte Hornets Caramel Corn.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;

MILAN: FIRST LOOK AT FALL
description: LEAD: MILANESE DESIGNERS ARE STEPPING into the 1990's with relaxed confidence. Today, as they begin showing their collections for next fall and winter, no one seems bent on imposing radical change for the sake of a few headlines. Lengths remain short, except for some sweeping coats that flirt with the ankle, and pants are ubiquitous.

title:
TRAVELER'S EYE: THREE POINTS OF VIEW;

BOSTON: A CITY'S PROUD MEETING PLACE
description: LEAD: Copley Square asserts the expansiveness, repleteness and pride of Victorian Boston. It has continued to evolve along with what used to be called ''the new Boston'' and is now rapidly becoming post-modern Boston. Fortunately, this urban focal point has escaped the obliterative energies that steer many renewal programs.

title: Local Catholic Schools Closing
description: LEAD: THE days of Roman Catholics sending their children to parochial elementary schools in their own neighborhoods on Long Island may be numbered.

title: Pamela Kerr Wed To Scott Martin
description: Pamela Kerr, a daughter of Richard Kerr of Ossining, N.Y., and Singlea Hall of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Martin of Albertson, L.I. The Rev. Wilbert Bradley performed the ceremony at the Searing Roslyn United Methodist Church in Albertson.

title: ALBANIA'S BYRONIC SHORE
description: The southern coast of Albania is sometimes referred to as the Ionian Riviera. In this case the term is not ambiguous. There are no high-rise developments here, no casinos, no jet airports or trailer parks. Polychrome limestone cliffs loom above the sparkling emerald water, grown with cedar, pine and myrtle. In spring the scent of jasmine mingles with the rich sagelike aroma of the maquis, the same tough mountain brush that abounds in the south of France. At the foot of these cliffs, the ocean has carved hundreds of grottoes, some with rock pools and black sandy beaches beside them.

title: About Cars;   Readers Assemble And Opinions Roll
description: Time for reader-speak.

title: Even Noah Might Envy These Casts
description: Some hoofers have four legs. Among this season's pleasures has been ''Rapsodog,'' staged by the Mundial Sisters, a Parisian troupe that made its New York debut early last month at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. A bittersweet comedy about a French market town, ''Rapsodog'' starred three vivid performers. Martine Guillaud - who choreographed the piece and who directs the company with her sister, Veronique Guillaud - portrayed a vegetable seller. Jean-Charles Dumay was a mechanic. And Max, a big white dog with a plumy tail, played himself. He did so superlatively well. Max knew when to sit still, when to sniff inquisitively. At one point, like a French tragedian, he burst into a florid declamation. (Philistines might have called it barking.) He even pretended to bite Mr. Dumay. Max was a true artist.

title: Managing;   Letting Employees In on the News
description: Back in December, the Chrysler Corporation said it wanted to sell its Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary. Less than 24 hours later, Allen E. Paulson, Gulfstream's founder and chief executive, went public with his plans to buy it.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

From Rhapsodies to Rap, Mother Is Singing a New Tune
description: LEAD: ''WHEN you grow up and have children of your own, then you'll have someone to boss around.'' These were the words I heard so often from my mother when I was a rebellious teen-ager. ''I hope they turn out to be just like you,'' she would say. ''You'll get paid back.''

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   Soviet Union Opposition Hits Democracy Circuit for Votes
description: At 2 A.M. today, Ilya I. Zaslavsky, political kingpin, was on the phone with his pollster. A last-minute survey of the Oktobr district of Moscow showed the tide running against the Communist establishment and in favor of Mr. Zaslavsky's slate in Sunday's local elections.

title: The Other Way
description: AFTER years of watching in dismay as star Soviet athletes defected to the United States and other Western nations, Soviet athletic authorities seem to have turned the emigration tide. Dale Mulholland, a 25-year old American Soccer League player who spent last season with the Orlando Lions, said he had signed a contract to become the first American to play with Locomotiv Moscow, one of 22 professional teams in the Soviet Union. Mulholland, who played for the University of Puget Sound before turning pro, said he had spent four years prodding American and Soviet officials to make his dream come true.(AP)

title: PERUVIAN FARMERS SAID TO KILL REBELS
description: Outraged highland peasants armed with sickles and homemade shotguns captured 13 Shining Path guerrillas, killed them and sent their heads to the local army commander, the police said on Friday.

title: Fan of Irish Decries Carping
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Noriega Kin Leave Panama
description: The family of the deposed Panamanian military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, arrived today in Havana after being granted safe passage by the Panamanian Government, a Mexican news agency reported. The agency said General Noriega's wife, three daughters and grandson would travel to the Dominican Republic, where they have been granted asylum and where the general's son-in-law is a citizen.

title: Japan Promises to Ease Trade Tensions
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and President Bush ended two days of talks today, and Mr. Kaifu said he had pledged to take serious action to ease trade tensions between the two countries. As part of that effort, Mr. Kaifu said he would try to improve the quality of life in Japan.

title:
GARDENING;

Trees That Stand Up to Modern Stresses
description: LEAD: TREES reduce the starkness of the landscape, but many of the shade trees commonly planted in years past no longer seem to be adapted to the urban-suburban setting.

title: Fashion;   Shorts Come of Age on Chic City Streets
description: Forget hot pants. Save the cutoffs for the beach. Shorts have taken on a soigne new image.

title: LIFE AND DEATH IN THE MA SAI MARA
description: He seemed somehow to have ascended into ''The Heaven of Animals.'' In a poem by that name, James Dickey described what a paradise for animals would be like:

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

The A.T.P. Tour Is a Mess: Big Surprise!
description: LEAD: Only three weeks into the new ''player-owned, player-run'' Association of Tennis Professionals Tour we are already hearing loud cries of anguish and stories of major dissension in the ranks. Where are the complaints coming from? Naturally, from the the complaints coming from? Naturally, from the players who supposedly own and run the tour.

title: New Pledges by Tokyo On U.S.-Japan Trade
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and President Bush concluded two days of talks, and Mr. Kaifu said he had pledged to take serious action to ease trade tensions.

title: The Talk of Belgrade;   White City More Gray And Sullen
description: The White City, as this ancient urban center has been named for most of its existence, looks a bit grayer to visitors returning after a few years, a result, residents say, of neglect and a decade of economic crisis.

title: Deirdre Sheehan to Wed D. A. Ewald
description: June wedding plans for Deirdre Marie Catherine Sheehan and Douglass Alexander Ewald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Philip Ewald of Greenwich, Conn., have been made known by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Conrad P. Sheehan of Rye, N.Y.

title: Postpartum Problems, Then and Now
description: Kathy Shaskan's article, ''Postpartum Syndrome: A Patient's View'' (Opinion page, Feb. 11), rang a discordant bell with me. In the 1940's, I had four babies in seven years and was quite familiar with the subsequent depression of which the article speaks.

title: Currency;   The Dollar's European Rally
description: Will the dollar continue the small rally it started last week against the West German mark and other European currencies? The West German Bundesbank signaled its concern about the rally of almost three pfennigs by selling dollars in Frankfurt Friday. (See Friday closings for New York at right.) If it is really worried, it will do the same thing again this week. As for the yen, it ought to continue to slide unless there is a major increase in the official discount rate by the Bank of Japan. A week's worth of heavy dollar selling by the central banks in Tokyo and New York has not provided much support. The yen closed the week in New York at 150.25, its lowest level against the dollar in two and a half years.

title: The Monk And the President
description: For five days last month, Tenzin Gyatso, a Buddhist monk who is the Dalai Lama of Tibet, was the guest of Vaclav Havel, a playwright who is the President of Czechoslovakia.

title: Joan Feigenbaum to Marry Jeffrey J. Nussbaum
description: April wedding plans have been announced for Joan Feigenbaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Feigenbaum of Valley Stream, L.I., and Jeffrey J. Nussbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Nussbaum of New Hyde Park, Queens, and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: If Mark Jackson can ignore the boos of the crowd, be patient and pick the brains of Mo Cheeks, he will realize his potential and become the superstar that fans are impatient to see. If that happens within the next year or two, the trade will be more than successful.

title: Dedicated Guardian for Historic Treasures
description: SINCE she became the Wadsworth Atheneum's first curator of African-American art in September, Barbara Hudson's life has been a series of firsts. She is the first black curator at the 147-year-old museum in Hartford, the first curator of the Simpson Collection of African-American Art, which is housed there, and the first executive director of the Amistad Foundation, the fund-raising body that was formed to buy and maintain the collection.

title: MONTANA: THE LAND BEFORE TIME
description: As far as the eye can see, if you think about the expression, is more than a measure of distance. It also can be the prospect of informed wonder, any vista resolved by the eye but enriched with textures only the mind can apply, with brushstrokes fine or broad.

title: The Needs Of the Retarded
description: It was gratifying to read Walter H. McCarthy's piece, ''What the Retarded Need: Social Skills'' [Opinion, Jan. 7] . As the parent of a 32-year-old sheltered workshop client, I agree wholeheartedly with his assessment of the current situation.

description: THE POWER OF THE FINANCIAL PRESS

title: THE HIDDEN LIFE OF NEW ENGLAND
description: A MIDWIFE'S TALE

title: YOUR TAXES: Taxpayers' Savvy Strategies;   AFTER DIVORCE, SECURITY IS HER GOAL
description: When Virginia Fellows was divorced in 1982, after 25 years of marriage, she knew virtually nothing about financial planning.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE SURPRISE OF BURNING, by Michael Doane. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A war photographer and his mother, an aspiring singer with a heroin problem, find that both are instinctively drawn to history's great disasters. Michael Doane ''throws together pivotal events and archetypal characters from our nation's history to create a dazzling Jasper Johns-like construction,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times in 1988. ''This is a fine and powerful novel, a testament to this young writer's rich and maturing talents.''

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on page 3 of the Travel section today refers incorrectly to the fare that qualifies passengers for Economy Select seating on British Airways DC-10 flights to Gatwick Airport near London from Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The midweek $1,102 round-trip fare does not require advance purchase. The column also misstates the basis for calculating the Economy Select fare. British Airways sells the seats, which are roomier, at unrestricted coach fares; there is no additional charge.

description: A LOOK AT THE TITANIC

description: Monte Williams led a balanced attack with 14 points today as Notre Dame moved back into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament picture by stunning Missouri, 98-67.

description: ''We have been drowning.

title: The Struggle for Self-Possession Is Engaged
description: I WAS 15 years old when I began myZfirst diet. As a child I had always been thin, but during my freshman year of high school, I sneaked too many sweets and flew from a size 5 to a size 14.

title: What He Wanted From His Public Were Tears
description: Jean-Baptiste Greuze (1725-1805) is the great whipping boy of 18th-century French art. The name immediately evokes an image of a misty-eyed prepubescent girl, clad only in filmy gauze, her eyes rolled heavenward, her lips illicitly moist. This is the Greuze beloved by the 19th century, the Greuze of the 4th Marquess of Hertford, who paid staggering sums for these ''fancy heads.''

title: Donna L. Turner, Student, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Turner of Needham, Mass., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Donna Lisa Turner, and Frank Augustus DeCosta 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. DeCosta Jr. of Bel Air, Md.

title: Campus Life: Bard;   Group Confronts Four Professors About Harassment
description: Simon's Rock of Bard College is an ''early college'' where professors have traditionally been called by their first names and students - many of high school age -have enjoyed a great deal of personal attention. It was thrown into turmoil last month when a group composed mostly of women, the Defense Guard, began a campaign against what they said was sexual harassment.

title: Rider Injured
description: A leading horse show rider, Katie Monahan Prudent of Middlesburg, Va., was seriously injured Friday when she was thrown from her horse during the winter equestrian festival at the Palm Beach Polo Equestrian Club in Florida. The 35-year-old Prudent, a three-time American Grand Prix Association rider of the year and a member of the 1986 world champion team, suffered head injuries when she fell after her mount tripped on a obstacle. She was reported to be in serious condition yesterday at the Wellington (Fla.) Regional Medical Center.(AP)

title: WHAT DO YOU CALL AN AGING HOOPSTER?
description: Erich Rupprecht delineates exactly the sort of savvy that's needed to compete against younger opponents (About Men: ''What Do You Call an Aging Hoopster?'' Feb. 4). For me (age 44), the moment of ''wisdom'' came 10 or so years ago, when a windmilling, spread-eagled, college-age defender was left gasping when I threw a perfect bounce-pass between his legs to a teammate (older than I), cutting to a basket: two points for us and a Newtonian epiphany for me.

title: Cigarette Wars Move to a New Arena
description: QUICK: Think Virginia Slims and what comes to mind? For millions of Americans, the answer may be tennis stars rather than cigarettes. Last week, accusing the cigarette companies of exploiting athletes' images of health to promote ''addiction, disease and death,'' Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, called on players and promoters to shun tobacco's ''blood money.'' During an average tennis match, Dr. Sullivan said, about 100 Americans ''will die of diseases caused by cigarette smoking.''

title: Rosita Brailovsky Weds
description: Rosita Brailovsky, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Brailovsky of Westfield, N.J., was married there last evening at Temple Emanu-el to Dr. Steven Fine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Fine of Mountainside, N.J. Rabbi Marc Disick officiated. Mrs. Fine, 27 years old, graduated from Cornell University and received a master's degree in counseling psychology in January from Harvard University. The bridegroom, 29, is a fellow in gastroenterology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He graduated from Harvard and the Cornell Medical College.

title: Plan to Reduce Swordfish Catch Assailed
description: NEW JERSEY fishermen are normally a quiet bunch, but a plan to drastically reduce commercial swordfishing has made them enter the political fray.

title: Q and A
description: Using Your Own Car Abroad

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. LOUIS;

Riverport Gets A New Partner
description: LEAD: RIVERPORT, a 500-acre mixed-use development in northwest St. Louis County, has been energized by the addition of McDonnell Douglas Corporation, based here, as a joint venture partner. Sverdrup Corporation, an engineering and architecture concern increasingly active in real estate development, is the founding and managing partner.

title: Long Island Journal
description: The Balsa Ball Park

title: Nicaragua Opens Possibilities For Regional Change
description: THE overwhelming election victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her opposition coalition in Nicaragua has done more than merely stun pollsters, pundits and the ruling Sandinistas. Taken in tandem with the United States invasion of Panama, Mrs. Chamorro's triumph last week may signal the possibility of a significant change in the politics of Central America and in Washington's approach to the region.

title: Rights Nominee Holds Stock With Pretoria Tie
description: President Bush's nominee for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job holds nearly $20,000 worth of stock in a company that does business in South Africa.

title: TOPPING IT OFF WITH COOL
description: SEARCHING for inspiration does not take them to old photographs by Cecil Beaton or exquisitely poised models in fashion magazines. When children contemplate a new haircut, they flip on ''Yo! MTV Raps,'' the music video show on cable television. There, they see the Fade, the Slope, the Gumby, the Fence, the Bowl, the Spike - haircuts with sharp, strong style worn by singers named Def Jef, Bobby Brown, Queen Latifah and the New Kids on the Block.

description: LEAD:

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   How Accountable Is Valvano for his School's Trouble?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Why Curators Are Turning to the Art of the Deal
description: ''It's impossible to be all things to all people,'' said Eric S. McCready, speaking of his 15 years as a museum director, first at the Elvehjem Museum of Art of the University of Wisconsin, then at the Archer M. Huntington Art Gallery of the University of Texas at Austin. ''The demands generally by boards are so complex that very few people are capable or willing to meet them - to be a scholar, a fund raiser, a diplomat, an entertainer, an after-dinner speaker, a budget officer and a personnel officer - and all of that for the glory, for being able to say that you run a museum. It is no longer worth the headache.''

title: In Czechoslovakia's Hearty Pubs, Goulash and Beer
description: ALTHOUGH Czechoslovakia has a history of beer brewing dating to 1082, it did not develop a worldwide reputation for the craft until 1842, when the process that resulted in Pilsner beer was perfected.

title:
Your Own Account;

When Renting Makes More Sense
description: LEAD: The sagging national real estate market means that many American families who must relocate are unable to sell their homes at the price they want - or at any price. For some, renting is becoming increasingly attractive.

title: Bridgeport 'Drug Czar' Sees Long Fight Ahead
description: LEAD: WHEN Mary C. Moran became Bridgeport's Mayor in January, one of her initial acts was to appoint a coordinator for the city's battle against illegal drugs. The man she chose, Mario Gaboury, is the first to hold such a job in Connecticut. Officials in other municipalities are watching to see whether this strategy proves effective.

title: THE COURT PHOTOGRAPHER OF BEBOP
description: If the kingdom of bebop had a court photographer, it was surely Herman Leonard. Among his sharply etched black-and-white studies are some of the most famous images of such musicians as Dizzy Gillespie, Charlie Parker, Fats Navarro and the others who spearheaded modern jazz during the 1940's and 50's. Shot mostly in nightclubs, Mr. Leonard's photographs have an almost film-noir drama about them; the musicians are often back- or side-lighted and crisscrossed with shadows. His characteristically high focus caught every pore and every drop of sweat on his subjects' faces, and every curl of cigarette smoke hanging in the air. Partly for this reason, THE EYE OF JAZZ (Viking, $29.95), a handsome collection of Mr. Leonard's photographs, has a somewhat static feeling about it. Most jazz photographers like to give a sense of time moving around their images. Mr. Leonard did not; he tended to apotheosize his subjects by his exquisite attention to composition and photographic values, in somewhat the same manner as his mentor, Yousuf Karsh. The short portfolios here are arranged by subject, and each has a brief introduction by Mr. Leonard. If this collection sometimes resembles a gallery of icons more than a series of moments snatched from the stream of time, the best of these photographs nonetheless manage to evoke the mordant precision of the music itself.

title: How One Man's Ego Wrecked a Bank
description: It was the Christmas season and the Bank of New England was having a party. Gathered at the swank Meridien Hotel here, bank executives cheerily greeted prominent business people as they dined on hors d'oeuvres and kept their glasses filled. To the casual observer, it was a scene of glad tidings and seasonal bonhomie.

title: Ethel Bush Plans To Marry in June
description: Mrs. Byron Cleveland Herbert of Edenton, N.C., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Ethel Walker Smith Bush and Malcolm Percy McAllister, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hoitt McAllister of Greenwich, Conn.

description: About 300 demonstrators, led by the Rev. Al Sharpton and several other black leaders, marched through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday to protest the prosecution's handling of the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins last summer.

title: Review/Music;   An All-Steidl Program
description: Scott Steidl, a composer from Minneapolis who studied with David Diamond and Elliott Carter at the Juilliard School, presented a program of his music at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening.

title: Not Even an Apple for Poland
description: Solidarity wants an Apple computer so it can do a better job of typesetting its newspaper. The Polish telecommunications authority wants to buy outdated Western equipment so that local callers will be able to dial direct. For now, the Administration says Poland can't have either.

title: Brooklyn Tech Prevails
description: Down for most of the game but never quite out of it, Brooklyn Tech kept fighting and finally battled its way into the Public Schools Athletic League basketball quarterfinals with a 66-65 victory over DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx at Hunter College yesterday.

title: Six Explorers End Crossing Of Antarctica
description: The six members of an international expedition arrived at a Soviet base on Antarctica's eastern coast today, completing a seven-month, 3,800-mile ski and dogsled journey that organizers called the longest unmechanized crossing of the frozen continent.

title: WHEN A PREGNANT WOMAN DRINKS
description: As a writer working on a guide to pregnancy, I am familiar with the dangers posed by alcohol. Yet, I take issue with the way in which Elisabeth Rosenthal uncritically quotes Dr. Claire D. Coles. Dr. Coles seems to regard even the slightest aberration in behavior as a likely symptom of the effect. The fact that a month-old baby ''should be calm'' but isn't is used as evidence that the infant is suffering from the effects of prenatal substance abuse. This observation is subjective and unscientific, as is her method of examining the child, who was ''tested'' by ''shaking rattles near his ear, tweaking a toe with a rubber band, recording his cry.'' It's no wonder he was ''too irritable and too distractable.''

title: Meeting Again
description: The price of the traffic violation that brought Zsa Zsa Gabor to court last year keeps going up. Miss Gabor is currently appealing a sentence of 72 hours in jail and a fine of $10,000 for driving without a license, having an open container of alcohol in her Rolls Royce Corniche and slapping the officer who cited her for those violations. Now the star faces a $10 million suit charging that she slandered and battered Paul Kramer, the officer who pulled her over. Lawyers for Mr. Kramer said his client was suing the actress, who is thought to be 72 years old, not only because she struck him but also because she added insult to injury when, on a cable television show last December, she accused him of being a drug-user and called him a homosexual. Mr. Kramer has said he was neither. His lawyer, A. William Bartz Jr., said that celebrities like Miss Gabor would have to learn that ''if they defame people and try to ruin people's reputations, then they're going to have to suffer the consequences.'' Neither Miss Gabor nor her attorneys could be reached for comment.

title: Accurate Arms, but at a Soccer Game?
description: First of all, I would like to thank the Italian journalist who saved me from a beaning the other day. I didn't catch his name, but his subtle nudge kept me from being hit by a missile precisely launched by one of the tifosi, as Italian fans are called.

title:
TELEVISION;

TRULY FRIENDS TO THE ANIMALS
description: LEAD: The remote area of the Linyanti River in northern Botswana is home to Africa's densest population of elephants, according to the film makers Dereck and Beverly Joubert. The region contains more than 60,000 of the great beasts, as well as other animals who dwell there in abundance. The Jouberts, who have been living in the bush for over a decade, are vastly outnumbered.

title: M. A. Weissman to Wed Leslie Altman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Altman of Katonah, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Leslie Beth Altman, and Michael Anthony Weissman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Weissman of White Plains.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Jan. 21 locating museums in Jerusalem misidentified the street on which the Tax Museum is situated. As a reader has recently written to point out, it is Agron, not Mamilla.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: Rod Strickland for Mo Cheeks is more than simple arithmetic. It is an equation that takes into account stability, chemistry, leadership and unselfishness - all the things that Cheeks has in abundance and the Knicks need. Al Bianchi made the right move. The Knicks are not a player away from title contention. They are the right attitude (reverse the ball and make the extra pass) away from contention.

title: CBS and Writers Near Pact
description: The east and west coast branches of the Writers Guild of America reached an agreement with CBS Friday on a three-year contract that will run through 1992. The contract covers 325 network television and radio employees in New York and Washington and employees at CBS-owned stations in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. It calls for 5 percent wage increases now and in Sept. 1991, and for new safety rules, including the spacing of video display terminals at least three feet apart. Guild members are to vote on the contract tomorrow.

title: Has Joe Roth Got the Key to Success at Fox?
description: When Joe Roth walks from the 20th Century Fox commissary to his office in the executive building a few hundred yards away, he is the master of nearly everything his eye can see. But he ambles down the street instead of bestriding the Fox lot like a mogul.

title:
DREAM DESTINATIONS;

A REMOTE ISLAND OF WILD SURMISE
description: LEAD: I'd give a lot to visit Easter Island. It has been one enormous sculptors' atelier - a tribute either to the passion religious art can generate, or to the monumental boredom produced by living in that tiny precinct of nowhere.

description: The engagement of Celia Ann Vlasin to James Benjamin Martin, a son of Mrs. John McK. Martin of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Martin, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Vlasin of East Lansing, Mich. An April wedding is planned.

title: West Bank's 'Garden Views' and 'Special Loans' Are Luring Jewish Settlers
description: Dozens of new one-bedroom two-bedroom and three-bedroom homes are going up on the edge of this Jewish settlement, the largest in the West Bank.
