description: All afternoon Gerard Depardieu has been talking about his rage for acting, for getting deeply embroiled with auteur directors and their creative torments, for rollicking from film to film, from stage to stage, with an almost reckless abandon and outlaw joy. Now, suddenly, he thrusts up his hand:

title: Message for Nicaragua's Victors: Things Must Get Better, and Fast
description: With the store shelves largely bare and one-third of the work force without a job, Nicaraguans are serving notice that they expect the newly elected government to bring about rapid improvement or face political consequences.

title: MACEDONIA'S STONY STRENGTH
description: On the hill above the old city of Ohrid, in southern Yugoslavia, is an overgrown park, half reclaimed by forest and crowned by the monumental, ruined fortress of Tsar Samuil, who during the 10th century created a Macedonian empire extending from the Danube to the Adriatic. The park is full of ruins: crumbling walls, rusted swing sets, the roofless Sveti Pantelejmon, which, like so many Yugoslav churches, served as a mosque for much of its life. Nearby, hidden in a clearing and covered with a thick layer of powdery dirt, is the foundation of a once-magnificent fifth-century basilica. An old man, picnicking with his little granddaughter, shows my sons how to brush the dust aside with their feet, exposing a grid of tiny, regular white tiles, then gradually - section by section - a dove, a deer, a chalice: the basilica's original mosaics.

title: Princeton Reunion
description: One is a United States Senator. Another is the treasurer of the World Bank and another the president of the Baltimore Orioles. There also are an architect, two attorneys, three investment executives, two presidents of self-owned companies and two educators. Not too shabby a group. Twenty-five years ago, they were not bad, either as they shocked the college basketball world by leading Princeton to its only N.C.A.A. Final Four appearance.

title:
DINING OUT;

Casual Setting, Varied Menu in Harrison
description: LEAD: While we have a couple of reservations, we have many more reasons for holding near and dear this casual, neat little ''restaurant and cafe.'' The menu has variety, the food is nicely prepared, the hours are convenient, the prices right.

description: SOME parents in Deep River thought they had devised a sure way to raise money for high school athletic programs. Their spring fund-raising event, in May, would be a game called Cow Caper.

title: 2 Shows, 'Bad Girls' and 'Personal Visions'
description: WOMEN make up both of the groups now at Aljira, but those in the larger of the two promise more than they can deliver by calling themselves ''Bad Girls.''

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: This department recently listed a handful of players who have achieved the feat of winning a national title at the first attempt.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Commack $190,000

title: Wine Equation Puts Some Noses Out of Joint
description: Calculate the winter rain and the harvest rain (in millimeters). Add summer heat in the vineyard (in degrees centigrade). Subtract 12.145. And what do you have? A very, very passionate argument over wine.

title: With Repairs, Rio Shows It Loves Its Symbol
description: Rio's mountaintop Christ statue is showing the strain of decades spent offering an open-arms greeting to visitors from around the world.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Poland;   Poles Find Crime Replacing Police State
description: As the Communist police state recedes, Poland finds itself with an unforeseen surge in crime, including a 65 percent jump in burglaries last year.

title: SPEAKERS THAT BRING THE ORCHESTRA INTO THE LIVING ROOM
description: Having talked about inexpensive loudspeakers last week, it now seems fair to allot equal time to costly ones. It is also fair to point out at the start that such speakers aren't for average listeners. They are meant for passionate devotees of high-fidelity, unsparing in the effort to narrow the persistent gap between music (the real thing) and its electronic replica.

title: An Eye-Opening 'King Lear,' With Sunglasses
description: IF ''King Lear'' is unplayable - oft times, it has been so declared - then what seems like a recent inundation of stage and screen Lears may have a common cause. That is to prove how Shakespeare's ''very foolish, fond old man'' who is ''every inch a king'' can be played any which way, and the play can happen anytime, anyplace or in limbo.

title: Redmen Frustrated As Pirates Persist
description: Seton Hall, a team that has taken a beating most of the season, fought back with a fury last night against St. John's and defeated the Redmen by 71-65, in the last regular-season game for both teams.

title:
FORUM;

The Truth About Research
description: LEAD: Science, often relegated to the back pages of newspapers, hit the front page of The New York Times a few weeks ago with an article on the dire implications of a National Science Foundation study showing that in 1989, for the first time in 15 years, corporate research and development spending had not kept pace with inflation.

title: GAUDY, BAWDY BARCELONA
description: Barcelona is a city that has been brushed aside by history - and has learned how to take advantage of that neglect. In the 13th century, Catalan culture flourished from Valencia to Nice; if events had taken a different turn, Barcelona might have become the natural center of a country about the size of Portugal. Today, however, although it remains a great Mediterranean port, it is a capital unencumbered by a country, central only to Catalonia, a region in the northeast of Spain.

title: Campus Life: West Virginia;   For First Time, Woman Is Mascot At Sports Events
description: For the first time, West Virginia University last week chose a woman as its buckskin-clad mascot for men's athletic events. The new Mountaineer, 22-year-old Natalie Tennant, said winning the honor was more a matter of showing school spirit than of overcoming a sex barrier.

title: Fashion;   Cork Is Back as an Accessory for Spring
description: Cork, best known for its principal industrial use as a bottle stopper, is making a comeback in fashion accessories.

title: Nicaragua's Family History: An Insider's Tale;   The Chamorro Saga Began Long Ago, But as for the Ortegas . . .
description: IN his moment of defeat after the election last week, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua gave a concession speech. Then he went to the house of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, almost like a neighbor in distress coming to seek solace. ''Come in, my little father, because I love you,'' the handsome woman was quoted as telling the man she had just defeated in the race for president.

title:
The Executive Life;

Bringing Up Managers For the Factory Floor
description: LEAD: Could the Rust Belt rise again? Lewis Cullman thinks so. And he has been right before.

title: Review/Music;   Concert Version of the Gershwins' 'Girl Crazy'
description: Broadway musicals of yesteryear, only recently no more tangible than their faded memorabilia, are being brought to life once again, and welcomed into the all-inclusive genre of ''opera-musical theater.'' But the concert performance Monday night at Alice Tully Hall of one of the Gershwin brothers' sunniest hits, ''Girl Crazy'' of 1930, did not do much to further the revivalist cause.

title: OZARKS: SPRING OF BRIGHT WATER
description: I went back to Greer Spring one day a few months ago. Greer Spring is, arguably, one of the prettiest spots in the Ozarks, and I hadn't been there for several years. The ticks and chiggers and poison ivy that make summer woodland visits in that part of the country so itchy were gone, and the day was such a bright-blue sunny one it demanded a walk in some beautiful spot.

title: AFGHANS: NOW THEY BLAME AMERICA
description: John F. Burns is undoubtedly correct in maintaining that United States policy has been affected adversely by the standards of reporting in the Afghan conflict (''Afghans: Now They Blame America,'' Feb. 4). But it is hardly because of ''selective reporting'' by journalists in the field. It is, rather, the dismal failure on the part of the American press to furnish the sort of coverage that this brutal war, which is far from over, has long merited.

title: I've Got Your Number
description: Last Sunday night, sometime after 10:30 P.M., I put an end to my seventh straight day of work. I left behind the stress of my office to confront another set of pressures -finding transportation home on the coldest day of the year.

title: Broken Covenant?
description: Covenant House is, of course, no bucolic Boys Town, but somehow New York had come to view the juvenile shelter's founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, as a bit like the tough-but-wholesome priests of 1930's Hollywood. There he was, fighting at various times City Hall, landlords, criminals and the odds to save ''these good kids,'' the young runaways and throwaways of Times Square. Then, three months ago came charges from first one, and eventually three young men who claimed that their experience with Convenant House included sexual relationships with Father Ritter. They also said he had used Covenant House funds to pay their personal expenses and buy them gifts. Father Ritter repeatedly denied the charges, but prosecutors began looking into his alleged financial improprieties and the Franciscan order suspended him from Covenant House. Last week, Father Ritter announced his resignation and, a day later, the Manhattan prosecutor dropped his investigation. But just as it seemed things might quiet down, state authorities announced a separate investigation.

title: The Life and Times of 'a Stubborn Old Dutchman'
description: FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT

title: STREETSCAPES: Readers' Questions;   A Dakota Cousin Called the Imperial
description: This is another in a series of columns answering readers' questions about New York's changing streetscapes.

title: More Students in County Choosing Social Work as a Career
description: SOCIAL WORK has become the career of choice for a growing number of students in the county. The deans of two graduate schools recent undergraduates but also by adults changing fields.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE MOBILE MEDICAL UNIT VAN;

Peekskill Health Center Sends Its Staff Out on the Road
description: LEAD: WHEN the time comes to see a doctor, some people procrastinate under the best of circumstances.

title: THE HEAT IS ON
description: FIRE & ICE

title: Back on Track
description: There's nothing like a little righteous indignation, not to mention a rigorous training schedule, to keep a runner in shape during a long layoff. For Sandra Gasser of Switzerland, the combination was good enough for a more than respectable showing in her first major championship meet since being banned from competition after testing positive for steroids at the 1987 world championships in Rome. Gasser, whose two-year ban ended last September, easily qualified yesterday for the 1,500-meter final at the European indoor championships in Glasgow, turning in a time of 4 minutes 10.93 seconds and placing second to Doina Melinte.(AP)

title: The Versatility of Vernon Duke
description: WHEN Vladimir Dukelsky came to America in 1921, the classically trained Russian composer began writing popular songs, and soon thereafter he met George Gershwin.

title: Prenuptial Pacts Increasing
description: THE divorce courts on Long Island are not spilling over with Donald and Ivana Trumps, but the highly publicized marital split will probably create more demand for prenuptial agreements, Long Island lawyers say.

title:
DINING OUT;

Fine View and Emphasis on Seafood
description: LEAD: EIGHT months ago, the Chuckling Oyster, a typical Shore restaurant in the Highlands, moved from its simple building to the attractive modern one in Sea Bright formerly occupied by the Riverhouse on the Quay. The Monmouth County restaurant, which is about a quarter of a mile on the right (facing the ocean) after crossing Highland Bridge, has been completely redecorated by Steve Cross, who owns this establishment as well as a country French restaurant in Colts Neck called

title: Nets Jell and Defeat Hawks
description: By tonight, the Nets had suffered through enough hardships this week, both on and off the court. So they took out their frustration on the Atlanta Hawks.

title: THE SPIRIT OF DICKENS PRESENT
description: THE QUINCUNX

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Feb. 18 misstated the dates of Ash Wednesday this year and next. It fell last week, on Feb. 28, and in 1991 will be on Feb. 13.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

In the Empty Nest, Full Emotions
description: LEAD: I DID not think much about us, my husband and I, being by ourselves without children till this year. The two adult children were going on holidays and our youngest daughter was with us. She is eight years apart from her next sibling, her brother.

title: The Night the Plane Fell: Sealing Up the Memories
description: IT was a reporter's curiosity that brought me to the site. I wanted to see what it was like after the fact, when the confusion had ceased and the cries of pain were etched forever in the deep recesses of suppressed memories.

title: Evelyn F. Abelson to Wed Christopher Andrew Goelz
description: Evelyn F. Abelson of Greenwich, Conn., has announced April wedding plans for her daughter Joanne Sue Abelson and Christopher Andrew Goelz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Goelz of Half Moon Bay, Calif. The prospective bride also is a daughter of the late Lawrence Abelson.

title: The Mysterious Router Explained
description: DESPITE its usefulness, the router is a mysterious power tool to many amateurs, perhaps because its name does not describe its function. A better name might be electric chisel, for a chisel is the hand tool whose operations the router duplicates most closely.

title: WHEN SEEING WAS BELIEVING
description: THE GENIUS OF JACOPO BELLINI

title: Having Company? You Can Still Serve a Roast
description: VIRGIL THOMSON used to say that when you have company, you serve a roast. Perhaps this seems a little old-fashioned in these days of swordfish steaks and composed salads, but few things so firmly state that the meal is a special occasion.

title: A Tour of the Ancient World in Syria
description: ''WITH the right agricultural management, Syria could become another California.'' This was the view of a Dutch agronomist with whom I shared a taxi on my arrival at Damascus Airport. On my departure a week later, I wondered whether the same might be true of Syrian tourism one day. If you tend to think of Syria along with Iran, Libya and Lebanon as places no reasonable American would visit, it is also true that no Americans have been taken hostage in Syria, that it has diplomatic relations with the United States and that, while the State Department advises care with regard to travel there, it does not outright discourage it.

title: Elections in the Slavic Republics
description: More than a million positions are to be filled in the elections in the three Slavic republics: Russia, the Ukraine, and Byelorussia. Voters will receive ballots for election of deputies to several bodies, such as regional councils, city councils, territorial councils and the parliaments of the republics.

title: On the Housatonic, a Watch Without Ice
description: THE annual rite of winter in Kent, the Housatonic Ice Watch, went on as planned this year, even though there was no ice to watch.

title: FOREST SERVICE ABUSING ROLE, DISSIDENTS SAY
description: Saying the Forest Service has abused millions of acres entrusted to it, supervisors and professionals in the service are rebelling against Federal policies that promote logging, mining and road-building in 191 million acres of public forests.

title: GLACIAL PERSPECTIVES: VISIONS OF MONT BLANC
description: LEAD: In the ethereal but oh-how-solid realm of the eternal, ever-changing glacial snows, surrounded by the domes and cupolas of Europe, spires, belfries and the odd phalanx of granite figures - le Grand Capucin, le Petit Capucin, le Roi de Siam - there seem to be no colors other than white and blue. Yet how many nuances and unexpected shades and limpidly revealed shapes are within.

title: Lebow Released
description: After tests showed he did not have a brain tumor, Fred Lebow, the director of the New York City Marathon, was released from Mount Sinai Hospital on Friday night, according to a statement released by his office, which said he had been found to be suffering from encephalitis and was expected to make a full recovery. (AP)

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Whose Baby Is It Anyway?
description: LEAD: THERE seems to be a trend among my peers these days to question, tremulously and otherwise, when their children are going to give them grandchildren (''It's Time for a Grandchild,'' Opinion page, Jan. 14). I'm the oddball, because I have what must be a rather outmoded idea that my married children and their spouses should come to that decision on their own.

title: New Orchestra Offers A Spring Festival
description: THE New Orchestra of Westchester does not resume its subscription concerts for two more weeks, but the ensemble is leading up to them with four special programs under the umbrella ''Spring Festival: Made in the U.S.A.''

title: Carolyn A. Morrissey to Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Morrissey of Belmont, Mass., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Carolyn Anne Morrissey and A. Scott Lemone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony G. Lemone of Woburn, Mass.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

Updating Quaint Quarters
description: LEAD: ON its isolated 10 acres of sharply sloping hills above Long Island Sound, the Coast Guard station at Eaton's Neck used to seem like an outpost to progress.

title: Forget Tomorrow, Recall Yesterday
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Airport Gains But What About Noise?
description: On the surface, the Feb. 11 article on the expansion of international flights at Newark Airport was nothing but good news - so good that it almost seemed like a self-congratulatory press release from the Port Authority. A peek beneath the surface, however, reveals that the Port Authority should be chastising itself rather than patting itself on the back.patting itself on the back.

title: Enter Fauntroy, With Flourishes, to Join Capital Mayoral Race
description: Declaring ''I know what needs to be done,'' Delegate Walter E. Fauntroy announced today that he was giving up his job as the District of Columbia's non-voting member in Congress so he could run in the muddled race for mayor.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Mutual Funds;   High Expenses: Sign of Weakness
description: Mutual fund expenses are rising. But are investors getting their money's worth? In most cases, the answer is no. A fund with a high average expense ratio - the fund's expenses as a percentage of average net assets - usually turns in a weak performance, said D. Tyler Jenks, director of research for Kanon Bloch Carre & Company, mutual fund consultants based in Boston.

title: A VISION OF AN INVISIBLE PYRAMID
description: In 1979 I saw an aerial photograph of the Mayan pyramid at Coba. The pyramid itself was invisible because trees and vines had grown over it. There was only a green hump in the green jungle.

title: No.1 CONCERNS;   The New Dawn Is Casting Some Things In a Bad Light
description: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW once noted that there are two tragedies in life: One is to lose your heart's desire, the other is to gain it.

title: Lisa A. Bippart To Wed in May
description: Lisa Anne Bippart and Timothy Markley Ghriskey plan to marry in May. Miss Bippart, an artist, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Bippart of Basking Ridge, N.J. Her fiance, an investment counselor, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Williamson Ghriskey of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Tech Notes;   Bringing Diesel Up to Snuff Without Alternative Fuels
description: The soot-belching city bus is headed for extinction as a result of stringent Federal emissions standards due to go into effect next year. Buses in urban areas may now emit as much as 0.6 grams of black carbon particles per horsepower of the engine for each mile driven; that allowance will be cut to one-tenth of a gram next Jan. 1.

title: Why a Virtuoso Jazz Pianist Still Provokes Debate
description: The brilliant virtuoso pianist Art Tatum, a major influence on jazz through his own recordings and the playing of musicians who spent time studying him - Coleman Hawkins, Don Byas, Charlie Parker, Thelonious Monk and John Coltrane, among others - can still get a table of jazz fans arguing and gnashing their teeth over his relevance.

title: NONFICTION
description: A BRIDGE OF CHILDHOOD: Truman Capote's Southern Years. By Marianne M. Moates. (Holt, $19.95.) ''He was a kook,'' declares Marianne M. Moates in her prologue to ''A Bridge of Childhood.'' ''He was a squeaky-voiced homosexual who drank too much.'' A rather crotchety view, but typical of the unreverential squint taken at Truman Capote in this homespun reminiscence. A series of anecdotes narrated by Capote's cousin, Jennings Faulk Carter, the book was edited and polished by the unapologetically middlebrow Ms. Moates, a freelance writer. ''Never know what he'll write next,'' she quotes Mr. Carter's mother as remarking. ''He told me he was going to write about some hooligans who murdered a whole family out in Kansas. Can't imagine why he'd want to write about that!'' Mr. Carter's own voice is just as folksy but, fortunately, shrewder. Much of his material would be fascinating simply as a social history of a vanished world - rural Alabama in the 1930's - even if it offered no insights into the growth of a writer; many of the episodes read like the adventures of an Alabama Tom Sawyer, as Mr. Carter, Capote and their good pal Nelle Harper Lee (later to write ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' in which the character of Dill is modeled on the boy Truman) get up to all kinds of high jinks staging homemade freak shows, digging up skeletons and nearly breaking their necks at the old millpond. Ms. Moates claims in her introduction that ''the stories fill an enormous gap'' in what we know about Capote. Well, I guess they just might.

title: IN A BYGONE WORLD OF THE FUTURE
description: CHUNG KUO

title: Where Did All The Nice People Go?
description: SLEAZY politicians. Back-room deals. Payoffs. F.B.I. sting operations. Sex scandals.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: VOYAGES

title: Nation's 1st Wait Period on Rifles Adopted
description: Gov. George Deukmejian today signed a bill requiring a 15-day waiting period to conduct background checks on people who apply to buy rifles and shotguns.

title: From Kiddie Tax to Social Security, Tricky Rules Remain
description: Despite the move toward tax simplification, people in certain situations have tax concerns that call for special attention. Retirees often have complex circumstances that can involve taxes on Social Security, while people with young children worry about the ''kiddie tax.'' The self-employed and highly paid executives with business-related deductions are also affected by still-complex tax laws.

title:
FOCUS;

Homes Planned A Walk From Shops and Jobs
description: LEAD: This rapidly growing state capital of 350,000 residents has rarely been thought of as a center of innovation. But planning officials and builders all over northern California are watching the progress of recent proposals for three large suburban developments with strong transit and pedestrian orientations.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Jan. 28 misstated the location of Haystack Rock. It is in Cannon Beach, Ore., not Astoria.

title: Reviews/Music;   Louisiana Repertory Jazz Ensemble
description: Early New Orleans jazz and the popular dance music of the turn of the century from which jazz developed is usually summarized in the work of Dixieland jazz bands or, at best, the traditional New Orleans bands that play at Preservation Hall. But a concert by the Louisiana Repertory Jazz Ensemble at Town Hall on Thursday revealed that those groups are merely scratching the surface of a rich and varied vein of American music.

title: Campus Life: Southern Methodist;   University Putting New Emphasis On Engineering
description: After the Southern Methodist University board of trustees voted in December to phase out civil engineering, the institution's president, A. Kenneth Pye, committed himself to an aggressive marketing and public-awareness campaign to revive the remaining departments.

title: THERE IS FRENCH OPERA, AND FRENCH OPERA
description: In these contentious times, we hear a great deal about the single-issue voter, the citizen for whom nothing in the political spectrum matters except a candidate's stand on taxes or the burning of the flag. A parallel phenomenon, I have found, is the single-issue reader, whose urge to correspond is set off only by mention of, say, Maria Callas or Glenn Gould or original instruments.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

GOD LET HIM DOWN BY FAILING TO EXIST
description: LEAD:

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

'Oh, You'll Just Love It There'
description: LEAD: THERE'S nothing like getting away in the midst of winter. Filling your eyes with the serenity of lush banana trees and coconut palms as gentle breezes blow. Tickling your toes with smooth, soft sand and filling your lungs with salty air and honeysuckle.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: The restaurant is half empty. You arrive, with a reservation, and are shown to a table either at the back of the room or next to the kitchen door. It's enough to make you wonder (never mind that it's enough to make you mad, as in furious) - why is this happening to you? Do you not have the right kind of power profile? Clothes? Is it your face? Should you have been a little more arrogant with the maitre d'hotel? A little more friendly? What is it, for goodness sakes, what?

title: Arts Groups Seek to Avoid Budget Cuts
description: LEAD: WHILE revenue worries batter voters in New Jersey, artists and arts administrators are working to retain, and possibly expand, their share of the state's next budget. The New Jersey State Council on the Arts five-year plan, to be unveiled in July, will set new priorities as well as sustaining old ones, council members say.

title: A Writing Class Begets a Magazine
description: EVERY few years, The Gryphon appears in Old Lyme. Its full title is The Gryphon: A Literary Review, and it is filled with the work of local writers. It is named after the mythical animal the griffin, guardian of treasures, and after the Old Lyme-Phoebe Griffin Noyes Library, where most of the writers labor to create treasures.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in some editions last Sunday about J. Leonard Spodek, a landlord convicted of failure to maintain two properties properly in Brooklyn, gave an outdated home address for him. It is Long Wood Crossing, Lawrence, L.I.

title: Neediest Cases' $4,372,283.22 Exceeds Totals of Past Years
description: For the fifth consecutive year, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has broken a record for contributions, with a final tally of $4,372,283.22 raised during the 1989-90 drive.

title: At Its Best, Love Is Far From a Fairy Tale
description: In fairy tales, love songs and most Hollywood movies, any boy-meets- girl story takes the long way around to proving the predictable; the neat trajectory of conventional romance always shows that Cinderella and the Prince, tomato and tomahto, Tracy and Hepburn were right for each other all along. But in real life, who hasn't been an idiot in love, defying the odds to find the wrong person at the least convenient time to create an emotional mess?

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECENT RELEASES: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $376,000

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BRATTLEBORO, VT.;

17,000 Sq. Ft. Of Timber
description: LEAD: THE Vermont Building, which its developers say is the largest timber-frame mercantile building in New England and perhaps the largest structure of its kind built in the last century, will be ready for occupancy next month.

title: Where Cork Cooks Stock Up
description: THE Duke of Wellington's campaign was victualed out of Cork City. With its deep natural harbor and adjacent farmlands, Cork was one of the great food centers and the butter capital of Europe in those days. For the perishables that couldn't be shipped - the fresh harvest of Ireland's fields and waters - you had to go to the English Market in Cork City. Today, you can still find an abundance of these foods there.

title: Consultants Understand Workers' Family Duties
description: LEAD: AFTER her daughter was born two years ago, Laurie Young began to think about working part time. She soon discovered that many other mothers had the same goal.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;

Proposals Weighed for Rail Station Sites
description: LEAD: THE Metropolitan Transportation Authority is evaluating proposals to develop land it owns at its Metro-North train stations in Mamaroneck and Harrison.

title: The Senate, and the Sewer
description: Plausibly, 1990 can be the year in which America cleans up the way it pays for politics - if two adversaries can be conquered in coming days. The first is Republicans inside the Senate who seem determined, once again, to torpedo all serious reform. The other is Democrats outside the Senate who seem determined to kill the one reform that would do the most good.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Israeli settlers in the West Bank with the help of the Government are trying to lure Soviet Jewish immigrants with special loans and aid. Thus far, only 1.5 percent of the new immigrants have acted on the offers. 3

title: All-Flute Group Attains New Level
description: LEAD: EVEN with the continued popularity of the flute - and there are thousands of youngsters playing flutes in school bands everywhere - there are not too many professional chamber ensembles composed entirely of the instrument.

title: Warning: More Traffic Jams Ahead
description: LEAD: RELIEVING southwestern Connecticut's traffic congestion for the next 20 years would require six new lanes on Interstate 95 and four on the Merritt Parkway, at a cost of at least $2.5 billion, says a state highway planner.

title: Ann Hunt to Marry in April
description: Ann Frances Hunt, a daughter of Mrs. William E. Hunt of Albany and the late Mr. Hunt, and Dennis Patrick Leddy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo P. Leddy of Spring Lake, N.J., plan to marry in April. Miss Hunt is a graduate of McGill University; Mr. Leddy of Ursinus College. Both are institutional sales traders at securities brokerage houses in New York, she at Muriel Siebert & Company and he at Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: CHURCHILL SLEPT HERE
description: The greatest Englishman of this century was also one of the century's greatest hotel guests, often a nonpaying one.

title: In Moscow, Will Communist Party's Help Hurt Its Candidates?
description: As the day for balloting drew near, Vitaly P. Khlystov, an assembler at Mechanical Factory No. 2 and an unpaid organizer of one the plant's workshop-level Communist Party cells, was not breaking a sweat nor even breathing particularly hard in efforts to promote the party's candidates.

title: Shamir Considers New Proposal From U.S. on Palestinian Talks
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is considering a modified American proposal for starting peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, his office said this morning.

title: Style Makers;   Elizabeth Wilson, Fashion Designer
description: Elizabeth Wilson grew up in Worcester, Mass., far from the worlds of Far Eastern folk art and fashion. But she became enthralled with Oriental textiles while a graduate student in Chinese art history at Columbia University. In 1975, when her husband, Marc, became curator of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., Ms. Wilson decided to turn her expertise into a business.

title: DATA UPDATE
RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Breland Retains Title: Mark Breland, a 26-year-old New Yorker, knocked down Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain six times in less than nine minutes in London yesterday and retained his World Boxing Association welterweight title when the referee stopped the fight at 2 minutes 15 seconds of the third round.(AP) Tennis Gilbert Defeats Tauson: Top-seeded Brad Gilbert of the United States beat Michael Tauson of Denmark yesterday, 6-3, 6-3, in the semifinals of the A.B.N. World tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.(AP) Krickstein and Mayotte Gain: Aaron Krickstein and Tim Mayotte both won their semifinal singles matches in straight sets yesterday to advance to today's final in the Eagle Classic tournament in Scottsdale, Ariz. Krickstein beat Emilio Sanchez. Mayotte beat Jim Grabb.(AP) Stich Advances: Michael Stich of West Germany advanced yesterday to the championship of the Volvo indoor tournament in Memphis with a 7-5, 7-6 victory over Gary Muller. (AP) Track and Field George Mason Takes Lead: Tony Barton won the high jump by leaping 7 feet 2 1/2 inches and Eugene Koranteng took second place in the long jump at 24-1 yesterday to give heavily favored George Mason University the first-day lead in the 69th IC4-A indoor championships, being held at Harvard in Cambridge, Mass. Koranteng was second to Villanova's Mark Rainey, who cleared 24-3 1/2.(AP) City Teams Win Titles: The New York City Public Schools Athletic League, in one of its best showings ever at the New York State indoor track and field championships, swept team titles today at Barton Hall on the Cornell University campus in Ithaca. The P.S.A.L. boys squad tallied 137 points to take the trophy easily while the P.S.A.L. girls team won by 19 points on 104 points. Leading the P.S.A.L. athletes were the state record-setters Michelle Brown of Tilden High School and the DeWitt Clinton 800-meter relay foursome. Brown, a senior from Brooklyn, ran away with the 600 meters in the state-record time of 1 minute 32.12 seconds. Clinton's quartet of Chris Bryant, Solomon Humphrey, Eric Carr and Shawn Benson lowered the state 800 relay standard to 1:29.79. Golf Lead Shrinks: Mitzi Edge lost a big lead with four bogeys on the back nine yesterday, but held a one-stroke advantage after three rounds of the Women's Kemper Open in Wailea, Hawaii. Edge shot 73 on the par-71, 6,139-yard course.(AP) Trevino Ahead by 3: Lee Trevino shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to move to a three-shot lead in the Vintage Chrysler Invitational at Indian Wells, Calif.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 4, Blackhawks 3: Cam Neely scored his 47th goal of the season with 3:21 left as Boston, playing at home, came from behind twice for its league-leading 40th victory of the season.(AP) Oilers 5, Flyers 3: Mark Messier scored four goals for the third time in his 11-year career as Edmonton won at home.(AP) Flames 5, Canucks 1: Doug Gilmour had a goal and three assists as Calgary, playing at home, assured itself of a playoff berth.(AP) Red Wings 5, Maple Leafs 2: Steve Yzerman scored his 54th goal as visiting Detroit won a relatively tame game. Fireworks had been expected after a 272-penalty-minute slugfest the night before.(AP) Nordiques 3, Sabres 3: Peter Stastny scored on the power play at 10:32 of the third period to give Quebec, playing at home, the tie.(AP) North Stars 3, Canadiens 2: Brian Bellows equaled a career high with his 41st goal as Minnesota won at home.(AP)

title: The Bold Murals Of Tucson's Streets
description: WHILE stuck in traffic on Tucson's south side recently, I noticed something that had previously escaped me. It was a painting of a woman asleep on a pillow, in a friendly desert landscape, against a backdrop of waterfalls, canyonland and bluffs. The artistry was confident, but no one would confuse it with museum-quality. The peaceful scene was painted on the side of a restaurant, visible to anyone driving down South Sixth Avenue.

title: Shackleford Denies Shaving Points
description: Reading nervously from a written statement during a news conference at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today, Charles Shackleford of the Nets denied any involvement with point-shaving at North Carolina State.

title: Linda A. Rosenbaum to Wed Christopher Duska
description: Linda Anne Rosenbaum, a third-year medical student at New York University, and Christopher Duska, a teacher in Manhattan, plan to marry in April. Ms. Rosenbaum, 24 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Rosenbaum of Lexington, Mass. Mr. Duska, 24, is a son of Dr. Ronald F. Duska of Havertown, Pa., and the late Barbara Duska.

title: Review/Theater;   How to Give Grandpa A Bar Mitzvah, at Last
description: Bernie, the grandpa, is slowly dying but will survive the play. Bessie, the grandma, is quickly cooking and fussing and will survive grandpa. Neal, the grandson, a modern young man, and you know what that adds up to, has decided to immerse himself in the life of his grandparents and even to get grandpa the bar mitzvah ceremony he missed out on when he turned 13.

title: New Jersey Blast Kills a Woman; Police Find a Weapons Stockpile
description: An explosion in the basement of a house in Cresskill, N.J., where the authorities found weapons and ammunition, killed an 83-year-old woman yesterday and injured her grandson and another family member.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a producer's schedule change, an article on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the musical ''Jonah'' gives an incorrect opening date. ''Jonah,'' now in previews at the Public Theater, will not open on Tuesday; a new date will be announced.

title: City Teams Win Titles
description: The New York City Public Schools Athletic League, in one of its best showings ever at the New York State indoor track and field championships, swept team titles today at Barton Hall on the Cornell University campus. The P.S.A.L. boys squad tallied 137 points to take the trophy easily while the P.S.A.L. girls team won by 19 points on 104 points.

title: REAL FOOD IN L.A.
description: The average person's notion of food in Los Angeles is that it's supermodern, trendy and eclectic. Like all cliches, this is largely true. There's a place on Melrose that serves Tex-Mex dim sum, and a favorite kind of sushi, with avocado, is called California maki. L.A., with its vista west to the Orient, its rich stew of immigrants, its diverse cultures, encourages strange mixtures and makes everything its own, while at the same time preserving individual flavors. Hawaiian papaya and New Zealand mussels rest together nicely in a Los Angeles salad.

title: Campus Life: Yeshiva;   Rolling Up Sleeves to Help Soviet Emigres
description: How would the Yeshiva University students move the hulking bed up two flights of stairs? Besides being narrow and steep, the stairway was poorly lighted.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: It is true, of course, that anyone who wants to reach the top ranks of the game must have an independent mind and not passively take for granted whatever is promulgated by the authorities. Nevertheless, if one is to diverge from the pronouncement of a great player, a very searching analysis is a must.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: Your article on San Francisco on film, ''Golden Gate, Silver Screen'' (Travel, Jan. 7), is very good, though it describes St. Peter's with only a hint about the altar - the 1924 movie ''Greed.''

title: Lynn Chinitz Is Married
description: Dr. Lynn Chinitz, a resident in radiology, and Dr. Steven Gruenstein, a senior fellow in hematology-oncology, both at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, were married last evening at the Puck Building in Manhattan. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Chinitz of Queens. Dr. Gruenstein is a son of Mrs. Walter Gruenstein of New York and the late Mr. Gruenstein.

title: Multiplex Theaters Gain in Downtowns
description: ALTHOUGH some communities are welcoming multiplex theaters to their old downtowns, residents of other towns are opposing plans for the theaters' development and expansion.

title: Donation Rescues Bicycle Sundays
description: BICYCLE Sundays, one of the more unusual recreational activities in the county and possibly its most popular, was saved last week by the intervention of a corporate sponsor and the second thoughts of budget-conscious government officials.

title: Eleanor Adams to Wed K. M. Sheers
description: Eleanor Sinclair Adams and Kenneth Michael Sheers, a son of Mrs. Edward H. Sheers of Columbia, Md., and the late Mr. Sheers, plan Mrs. Edward H. Sheers of Columbia, Md., and the late Mr. Sheers, plan to be married in June, the future bride's mother, Mrs. David B. Findlay Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., has announced. Ms. Adams also is a daughter of the late Peter R. Adams. Ms. Adams, a member of the technical staff at MRJ Inc., a Ms. Adams, a member of the technical staff at MRJ Inc., a computer software firm in Oakton, Va., graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy and Wesleyan University. Her father was a registered representative with Laird, Bissell & Meeds Inc., stockbrokers in New York. Her mother owns Mimi Findlay Antiques-Design in New York, where the future bride's stepfather heads David Findlay Jr. Fine Art.

title: WHEN A PREGNANT WOMAN DRINKS
description: I enjoy an occasional glass of wine (''When a Pregnant Woman Drinks,'' by Elisabeth Rosenthal, Feb. 4). My husband, who is a physician, and I have no children yet. However, when and if I ever become pregnant, my normally mild-mannered husband has informed me that he will not tolerate any alcohol consumption by me during my pregnancy, and for several months thereafter if I choose to breast-feed. I have no argument.

title: PASTIMES:
description: For This Week: Finish pruning grapes. Lime lawns. Indoors start seed of vegetables and annuals that will be planted outdoors in May when the weather settles. Save fireplace wood ashes for use in the garden.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Norristown, Pa.;

Revitalizing Downtown
description: LEAD: AN $11 million, five-story office building is the latest step in an effort to revitalize the downtown of this Montgomery County seat. The 100,000-square-foot building, Lafayette Place, is being built on an abandoned railroad right of way at Lafayette and Swede Streets by Adwin Realty Company of Lester,

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: A young and talented player with an attitude problem traded for a former All-Star, solid and dependable, 10 years his senior. A good deal? I suppose Al Bianchi would also trade Darryl Strawberry for Dave Winfield.

title: As Other Deductions Vanish, Real Estate Endures
description: There's little mystery to successful investing. No matter what the investments, the key, most financial advisers and accountants agree, is careful planning.

title: Mothers in Jail Study Parenting
description: LEAD: MOTHERS in prison in Bedford Hills are getting a chance to learn how to be better parents to their children, and are learning about themselves in the process.

title: Kristie Schmidt Is Married
description: Dr. Kristie Eloise Schmidt, a resident in internal medicine at St. Vincent's Hospital, and Italo Baroni, a shipping manager at Codelco USA, both in New York, were married yesterday in the bride's Manhattan home. The Rev. Gregory Hillis of the Universal Life Church officiated. The bride, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Maureen B. Overton of Carson City, Nev., and Harold B. Schmidt of Tiburon, Calif. Mr. Baroni is a son of Berta R. Baroni of Santiago, Chile, and the late Rafael Baroni.

title: Ellen J. Gottmann To Marry in May
description: Ellen Joy Gottmann and Mark Cooper Kulik plan to marry in May. Ms. Gottmann, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Gottmann of Ramsey, N.J. Her fiance, 25, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Kulik of Ramsey.

title: 'The Sound of Music,' Without Alps
description: As in many other things, New Yorkers are in a class by themselves when it comes to ''The Sound of Music.'' The Rodgers and Hammerstein musical is staged more than 500 times a year in the United States and Canada (it's also very popular in Japan), but the New York City Opera production opening Thursday night at the New York State Theater and running through Sunday, April 22, will be only the second full-scale revival in New York since the musical first came to Broadway on Nov. 16, 1959.

title: YOUR TAXES: Taxpayers' Savvy Strategies;   FINDING THE CASH FOR A NEW BUSINESS
description: LESTER D. MORAN, who left his job as vice president of Bloomingdale's Dallas store last year, put the tax laws to work for him to help get the cash flow needed to start his own company.

title: Deregulation And Cable TV: Benefits for All
description: HAVE consumers benefited from Federal deregulation of the cable industry? State Senator Donald DiFrancesco thinks not. Introducing bills that would restrict the length of time for which a municipality could issue a cable franchise and would change the way the municipal franchise fee is calculated, the Senator charged that cable television companies alone have benefited from deregulation (''Let's Make the Cable TV Industry Live Up to Its Promises,'' Opinion page, Jan. 7).

title: Macintax Zips Through Forms
description: A Macintosh program that costs less than $100 may offer the least painful way to complete a 1989 tax return - short of getting someone else to do it.

title: Recognizing Old Age When It Rounds the Corner
description: AT the age of 79, I was facing the fact that the lease on my Scarsdale home was about to expire. To renew would mean a big rent increase, since the apartment was not covered under the Emergency Tenants Protection Act.

title: WHAT DO YOU CALL AN AGING HOOPSTER?
description: I'm a 16-year-old 6-foot-5-inch-tall power forward for my high-school basketball team in Chatham, N.J. After reading your article, I understand a little more about the ''older men'' I play basketball with at our local gym in the off season. I used to think they were just dirty players trying to win at all costs. They seemed to regard pick-up games, meaningless to me, as do-or-die competitions. I'll look at those ''older guys'' differently, now that I've gotten some insight into their behavior. When they throw that unnecessary elbow in my back as I'm going for a rebound or hack me to the ground on a shot when they could just as easily have had a clean block, I'll know they're only overcompensating for lost abilities.

title: New Beginning For an Ex-Hoya
description: JOHN TURNER leaned back on a row of wooden bleachers in the Mabee Center at Phillips University and wiped the perspiration from his forehead.

title: Age of Maps
description: To the Editor: ''Maps That Try to Hide Their Age'' (Practical Traveler, Jan. 14) represents hard work in your effort to assist the public in purchasing up-to-date maps. Concerning maps produced by General Drafting, however, we would like to amplify on the A20 code on our map of Baltimore mentioned in the colunn.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Sometimes, a Little Bitterness Is Just Right
description: Rape, sometimes called broccoli di rape, began to make its way out of the Italian grocery store and into the supermarket four or five years ago.

title: Barbara J. Kerker To Marry in June
description: Barbara Jayne Kerker and Marc Adam Honig, who expect to receive medical degrees in May from Johns Hopkins University, plan to marry in June.

title: Books From The Times
description: THE COLLAPSE OF COMMUNISM. Edited by Bernard Gwertzman and Michael T. Kaufman. (Times Books/Random House, Paper, $9.95.) The astonishing year 1989 began in the middle of the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan and ended with the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu, Romania's absolute ruler for 24 years. In between, much of the Communist world turned upside down. Collected here are reports by correspondents of The New York Times in Eastern Europe, in Moscow, in Tiananmen Square, wherever the old order was under assault. As edited by Bernard Gwertzman, the foreign editor of The Times, and Michael T. Kaufman, the deputy foreign editor, they form a factual and interpretive chronicle of that unpredictable, revolutionary year.

title: Volunteer Forces Bolstered After Crash
description: LEAD: THE recent crash of Avianca Flight 52 in Cove Neck has resulted in renewed interest in Long Island's volunteer fire departments.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Trafficking

title: 'What I Saw at the Revolution'
description: To the Editor:

title: Storm Signals Flying on U.S.-China Relations
description: As the Year of the Horse began in late January, Chinese-American relations seemed to be improving. The whispers here were about the supposedly imminent release of the dissident Fang Lizhi from his refuge in the American Embassy, and some officials on both sides foresaw a steady warming in relations.

title: Hockey;   Rangers' Streak Halted by Whalers
description: The Rangers do not go in much for moderation. This season they have won in streaks and lost at length. Tonight, in a fashion that was both painful and familiar, they crashed.

title: N.B.A. Drug Bans
description: The National Basketball Association's new drug-testing program for rookies has led to the suspension of Jay Edwards, a Los Angeles Clippers guard. Edwards, who was suspended for the rest of the season, may not return until he completes a treatment program. He is the third rookie to be suspended after failing a random drug test this season.(AP)

title: When Mme. Marcia Ruled
description: To the Editor:

title: Fordham Defeats Iona to Advance
description: Fordham and Iona, two fierce rivals who have been producing tight, bitter basketball games since 1946, added another chapter to their exciting history in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference quarterfinals today.

title: ART VIEW
description: Who can say whether, at the end of his life, George Caleb Bingham was more frustrated by the setbacks of his political career or by the failure of the public to acknowledge him as America's greatest painter. More than half a century passed after his death in 1879 before even a modest display of his work was organized, by the City Art Museum in his chosen home of St. Louis. Shortly after that exhibition, in 1940, the first large study of him was published, with a preface by Thomas Hart Benton in which Bingham was hailed as the most distinctly American of painters, an artist of the people. ''If he painted a tree,'' wrote Benton, ''it was a tree and not a sign pointing to some obscure world of special values with which this cult or that was trying to prove its superior sensibility.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campus Life column last Sunday about Washington University in St. Louis referred incorrectly to the classics department at the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. It is not being eliminated.

title: In Hollywood, Black Is In
description: When Melvin Van Peebles first came to Hollywood 34 years ago to break into movies, he was offered work as an elevator operator. Last month he was honored at the Sundance United States Film Festival as a pioneering black film maker. When Wendell Harris Jr. first came to Hollywood with hopes of working as an actor in 1976, he couldn't get past ''the secretary to the secretary'' to see an agent. Earlier this year, his first feature, ''Chameleon Street,'' won the grand jury prize at the Sundance Festival.

title: The High Life in Barbados
description: LEAD: RENTING a luxury villa in Barbados is not just renting a house; it's renting a life.

title: 'These D...d Little Books!'
description: BEATRIX POTTER'S LETTERS

title: Inventive Guises for the Gourd
description: A HUMBLE gourd can assume many guises in Africa. Calabashes, hard-skinned members of the squash family, have been transformed into fearsome masks, musical instruments and ceremonial vessels in many parts of the continent.

title: Steve Rucker to Wed Susan Borden
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Borden of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Laura Borden, to Dr. Steve Wolf Rucker, a son of Gloria Rucker of West Orange, N.J., and Dr. Maurice Rucker of Alfred, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: The Garden as a Gate Into the Neighborhood
description: HOW to become part of a neighborhood? Buy a house with a garden. Not a garden that's handed over to other people to care for - that destroys the whole purpose. It's all right to have somebody cut the lawn and clip the hedge but the garden itself - the dirty earthy part, the part that gets under your nails and ruins your manicure - must be your baby. This is the stuff that will introduce you to your neighbors and make you a part of the community.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Manhattan Office Vacancies;   Differing Definitions Make the Numbers Slippery
description: NO two analysts agree on the percentages or the dollars. Nor do they agree on what defines an office building or what constitutes midtown Manhattan. They don't even agree on whether empty space is ''vacant'' or ''available,'' or whether it can be measured accurately in the first place.

title: Congenial Setting for Italian Fare
description: CINZANO'S in Fairfield is a year-old restaurant that sends mixed signals to first-time visitors. Outside the entrance are handsome, terra cotta pots, but to enter the restaurant, you have to pass through a mundane bar. Once inside the restaurant proper, you are greeted by a stylish, semiformal decor of tapestry-backed banquettes and chairs, rose-colored carpeting, wood paneling and a back wall covered with an oil painting of a pastoral Italian scene, the front a wall of greenhouse-style glass windows. Outside the windows a row of short, light-festooned, potted evergreens add a twinkling touch.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 4, 1990
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington, the other in Hollywood. 2 5 WEB OF DREAMS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) The origin of a curse that has haunted a family of orphans in five previous novels. 3 99 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 4 1 THE EDGE, by Dick Francis, (Fawcett, $5.95.) Murder and mayhem on a luxury trans-Canadian train trip. 5 5 THE FORTUNE, by Michael Korda. (Warner, $5.95.) A young woman's ill-fated romance with the head of America's richest family. 6 5 BILLY BATHGATE, by E. L. Doctorow (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) The life of a 1930's gangster. 7 6 MUTATION, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) A physician's attempt to create a superior child results in a prodigy that turns into a terror. 8 1 PLAYMATES, by Robert B. Parker. (Berkley, $4.95.) The private eye Spenser on the trail of scandals in the world of college basketball. 9 4 BLACK SAND, by William J. Caunitz. (Bantam, $5.95.) A New York cop joins a Greek policeman in a deadly pursuit of a stolen ancient artifact. 10 2 POWER PLAY, by Penny Jordan. (Harlequin, $5.95.) A woman's passionate, sometimes violent relationship with four men over a dozen years. 11* 1 STORMING INTREPID, by Payne Harrison. (Ivy, $5.95.) Warfare waged in outer space between the United States and the Soviet Union. 12 1 THE HALFLING'S GEM, by R. A. Salvatore. (TSR, $4.95.) The final volume in the "Icewind Dale" fantasy trilogy. 13 19 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in "The Gunslinger." 14 55 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 15* 11 A THIEF OF TIME, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $4.95) Tracking down a missing archeologist, missing artifacts and a murderer. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 15 ALL I REALLY NEEDED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 23 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinness. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J. woman. 3 12 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Grace Catalano (Bantam, $3.50.) The lives and predilections of the five members of a teen-age singing group. 4 3 MURDER IN LITTLE EGYPT, by Darcy O'Brien. (Onyx, $4.95.) The Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde life of a physician in an Illinois community. 5 6 BORN ON THE FOURTH OF JULY, by Ron Kovic. (Pocket, $4.50.) The autobiography of a former Marine, gravely wounded physically in Vietnam, spiritually on his return home. 6 5 IN BROAD DAYLIGHT, by Harry N. MacLean. (Dell, $4.95.) The 1981 killing of a man on Main Street in Skidmore, Mo., witnessed by 45 people, a case that was never brought to court. 7 332 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck (Touchstone/S & S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 8 72 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ways in which mythology illuminates the stages of life. 9 92 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 10 42 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $5.95.) A science that sees order in what appears to be erratic. 11* 15 THE BLOODING, by Joseph Varnbaugh. (Bantam, $5.95.) The murder of two girls in an English village is solved through genetic clues. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 4 50 SIMPLE THINGS YOU CAN DO TO SAVE THE EARTH, by The Earthworks Group. (Earthworks Press/Publishers Group West, $4.95.) Ways to combat environmental problems. 2 79 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 3 1 WALT DISNEY'S WORLD, edited by Stephen Birnbaum. (Avon, $9.95.) A guide to the three Florida theme parks. 4 12 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1990 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 5 1 GOING WITHIN, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $5.95.) A "guide for innertransformation" through meditation. 6* 11 THE WORLD ALMANAC BOOK OF FACTS 1990 (World Almanac, $6.95.) The latest edition.

title: Pupils Learning About Parental Roles
description: ON a small, colorful rug in the center of the classroom, 7-month-old Allison Stumper lay on her back, drinking juice from her bottle.

title: Maryland Penalized
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has decided to levy sanctions against Maryland's men's basketball program, but is not quite ready to release the information, an official of the agency was quoted as saying. ''I'm working out some kind of schedule with the institution,'' David Berst, the N.C.A.A.'s assistant executive director for enforcement said in an interview with The (Baltimore) Sun Friday. Maryland's violations under former Coach Bob Wade included sale of complimentary Atlantic Coast Conference tournament tickets and an attempt to mislead the N.C.A.A. during its investigation.(AP)

title: Tigers First To Gain Berth
description: Princeton became the first team to qualify for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament by capturing its second consecutive Ivy League basketball title with a 73-47 victory over Columbia tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about Fernando de Noronha, an island off Brazil,misstated its location. A reader has recently written to point out that the island's west side faces South America, not Africa.

title: 2 Mouthpieces Noted for Tyson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hospitals Grapple With Ethical Issues
description: LEAD: SEVERAL years ago, Dr. Philip R. Fleishman faced a professional quandary that pulled at his heartstrings. A longtime patient, in her 70's, had suffered a stroke. He recommended artificial nutrition and other medical care to keep her alive. Her family wanted nothing further done.

title: The Executive Computer;   If a Laser Printer Ran Backwards . . .
description: The Caere Corporation, which two years ago created the first optical character-recognition system for personal computers, is preparing to introduce a $10,995 computer that is said to recognize printed words at a rate of 2,500 a minute and convert them to electronic form with a high level of accuracy. The Caere Parallel Page Reader, which is expected to be shown tomorrow at the ''Seybold Seminars 90'' electronic publishing conference in Boston, attaches to a computer network with relative ease and functions as a sort of laser printer in reverse. That is, the user feeds the printed documents into a scanner, and the Parallel Page Reader converts them into word-processing or data-base files.

title: Shy Quarry in Warm Waters
description: I have fished for bonefish on the virgin flats of Christmas Island. I have stalked them in the shadows of the orchid-bedecked ruins of Mayan temples in the Yucatan. Biscayne Bay in Florida is not nearly so remote but is equally pretty, its waters the prettiest light blue I have ever seen. And the fish are really big.

title: All About/Machine Tools;   Fissures in the Industrial Bedrock
description: Machine tool makers are part of the nation's industrial bedrock. Manufacturers rely on them for equipment to forge, cut, grind, drill, bend, trim and stamp the blocks and sheets of metal that become cars, airplanes and appliances.

title: Campus Life: Temple;   Off-the-Wall Style Of Teaching Gets Their Attention
description: When a freshman business major, Barry Abrams, registered for a class called ''Law in Society'' last semester, he had no idea he would be standing in front of 600 students playing the role of an Oxford-educated gorilla who got drunk one Labor Day and chomped off his neighbor's leg.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   A Crisp Bread You Bake Yourself
description: Packages of lavosh are appearing in more and more stores. Lavosh is not the crispy cracker-like bread that has become so popular, but the soft variety that comes folded in half and then tucked in on both sides. There are two sheets to a package.

title: Campus Life: Rutgers;   University Softens On Some Aspects Of Hazing Policy
description: Rutgers University administrators have backed away from several aspects of a policy affecting fraternity pledging at predominantly black fraternities and sororities. But the most controversial dispute is yet to be resolved.

title: In 'Steel Magnolias,' Camaraderie
description: ''LAUGHTER through tears is my favorite emotion,'' says Truvy, the owner of the most successful beauty shop in Chinquapin, La.

title:
GARDENING;

Trees That Stand Up to Modern Stresses
description: LEAD: TREES reduce the starkness of the landscape, but many of the shade trees commonly planted in years past no longer seem to be adapted to the urban-suburban setting.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Heat Wave From the North, With a Hood
description: It's been feeling like the Yukon out there again, but don't worry, it will soon feel like spring again, or maybe summer, maybe even today or tomorrow. In the meantime, keep fashionable cold-weather clothes at hand.

title: Soviet Jews Find Friends Waiting
description: LEAD: IT was a long way from the Soviet Union to Katonah, but the members of the Berlin family looked very much at home in their new apartment. They arrived in November, and are the most recent Soviet-Jewish immigrants to be helped by members of four Jewish congregations in northern Westchester.

title: Tanzania Torn as It Tries to Make Ends Meet
description: Tanzanian politics involve a good deal of self-analysis and what some would consider interminable debate. Although this is a one-party state, politicians here like to say, at least the party's laundry is washed in public.

title: Question of the Week;   Was the Strickland Trade A Good One?
description: This recent trade is just another in a continued series of bad moves - Gerald Henderson, Jawann Oldham, Kiki Vandeweghe, the loss of Sidney Green, the waiving of Pete Myers - by people who haven't the vision, talent or patience for building a championship team. The only reason this team is competitive is Patrick Ewing. And that was just luck.

title: Defining 'Drug'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Madrid Offers Leniency for a Basque Truce
description: The shooting of a retired navy officer in the northern city of San Sebastian was the latest act of violence in a week that began with an offer from Justice Minister Jose Luis Corcuera to the Basque separatist group E.T.A. to exchange generous treatment for a six-month truce.

title: The Pentagon Could Learn From American Business
description: To the Editor:

title: A Budget Survivor: The Mobile Crisis Team
description: LEAD: A COUNTY program that has helped thousands of Westchester residents deal with their personal crises has emerged from a crisis of its own, having survived the county budget crunch that had threatened its existence.

title: THE AIDS WIDOWERS' CLUB
description: LEAD:

title: Airlines Get Rules for Disabled
description: The Transportation Department, formally imposing rules it proposed several weeks ago, announced Friday that it would require more accommodations for disabled people on airliners.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE YALE DIVINITY SCHOOL;

'Tower on the Hill' Strives to Blend the Sacred and the Secular
description: LEAD: THE Yale Divinity School, a quadrangle of Georgian-style red-brick buildings that overlook New Haven, is sometimes called ''the tower on the hill.'' The phrase echoes the New Testament passage: ''Ye are the light of the world. A city that it set on a hill cannot be hid.'' But the reference is no compliment.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Clear Boundaries of Youthful Sport
description: LEAD: THIS is not the same bunch of untutored young savages I've known since the first grade.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Q and A
description: Incorrect Tax Class

title: You Can't Be Too Thin in Economy Class
description: IN economy class, the squeeze is on. If you feel you are having a tougher time getting into your airplane seat than you used to, and if you find sitting there for a long time more trying, it is not your age or your bulk. You are being packed in more snugly. Instead of a seat that occupied 34 inches or even 36 along the aisle four years ago, you will probably now get a seat that takes up only 31 inches. In a can of sardines, that is a considerable loss.

title: Every Cat Has His Day. Here's Stanley's.
description: They filed past the judges with nervous smiles, glancing at the crowd and shifting from one foot to the other as the master of ceremonies made jokes to put them at ease. They were the owners. The cats, naturally, remained aloof and above it all, cradled in their owners' arms, glancing about as if they entered contests all the time.

title: RADIO MOSCOW'S NEW YORK ACCENT
description: PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS

title: Annenberg Gift a Point of Light, Bush Says
description: President Bush, describinghimself as a longtime supporter of the United Negro College Fund, used his best-known term for private charity in praising the gift of $50 million by Walter H. Annenberg to the consortium of private black colleges.

title: A Break With Tradition In High School Sports
description: LEAD: PICTURE a girl destined for sports greatness. She sits on her Bronx fire escape across from Yankee Stadium, gazing at the baseball games and, on a few indelible nights, taking in the championship fights. On summer mornings, when she and her brother decide to play catch, they are welcomed into the stadium, where the person throwing the ball back to them is Casey

title: Americas Tower Now Goes to Arbitration
description: AN arbitration panel will begin next week to untangle the issues in a convoluted dispute between development partners that has halted construction of a huge office project on Avenue of the Americas between 45th and 46th Streets, known as Americas Towers.

title: Words Cannot Express The Senate's Happiness
description: NOTHING unhinges the Senate quite like the mention of Central America.

title: Clarifying Her Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: If collectors go merely by a catalogue description, an unusual coin could be overlooked. Its description, coin 2362, in the catalogue of Pontero and Associates for its mid-March sale is mild: Philip II, 359-336 B.C., Tetradrachm. Laureate head of Zeus right; reverse, naked youth on horseback, right. Lustrous. Choice Extremely Fine. Estimated price $1,000-1,500.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off. I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals. I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss. After a month, the stain leached through, and now I have pink streaks.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RUSSIAN TALE

title: Excellent Education At State Colleges
description: In his Jan. 14 letter to the New Jersey editor regarding institutions' changes in name from college to university in New Jersey, John W. Osborne denigrates our students and dedicated faculty. What does he know about the caliber of students attending New Jersey state colleges who work toward achieving higher education?

title: Cheeks Helps Knicks Defeat Bucks
description: With 4 minutes 22 seconds remaining in tonight's game against the Bucks, Coach Stu Jackson put the Knicks in the hands of Maurice Cheeks instead of Mark Jackson.

title:
MARLBORO TOWNSHIP;

Neighbors Upset Over Escapes From Psychiatric Hospital
description: LEAD: AFTER years of protest, township officials and residents are no closer to resolving a conflict with the State Department of Human Services over frequent escapes of patients from the state-run Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital here.

title: Up for Bids
description: Not long ago, all a defecting Soviet intelligence officer might want from America was protection, a modest living and a chance to die in bed. Now, for Victor I. Sheymov, at least, it is interviews, press conferences and, yes, book deals. Mr. Sheymov surfaced last week in Washington and let the world know that 10 years ago he had defected straight from the inner sanctum of the K.G.B. with the intention of inflicting ''as much damage on the Communist system as I possibly could.'' The former K.G.B. major said that after escaping from Moscow with the help of Central Intelligence agents in 1981, he had told the Americans that there were two State Department sources who were helping the K.G.B., that the K.G.B. had deeply penetrated French intelligence agencies, and that the K.G.B. was behind the 1981 attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II. It was all vaguely interesting, but also a little dated -so why go public now? Mr. Sheymov let it drop that he had finished a book about his experiences and was looking for a publisher.

title: 'Disappointing' Inauguration For Condo Plan
description: STATE officials in Hartford last week began sifting through the responses to an innovative program intended to increase the supply of housing for low- and moderate-income families in Connecticut through the purchase of condominiums. And across Fairfield and Litchfield Counties, housing officials began assessing why so many of their towns were being left out.

title: Q. & A.: Moscow's Party Chief;   Communists Try Working Their Way Up From the Top
description: A quotation in the front-page index last Sunday was misattributed. It was the interviewer - not Yuri A. Prokofiev, the Moscow Communist Party chief - who noted that for Soviet politicians, ''to be a Communist is a minus, and to be a Communist Party functionary is a huge minus.''

title: THE HUT WHERE TOLSTOY DIED
description: Astapovo. It is a tiny railroad station in western Russia, unmarked in any atlas I have seen. There, in the stationmaster's humble little shack beside the tracks, a small iron bedstead was placed in the living room with, beside it, a bedside table with a lamp, a candle, matches and the sick man's notebook. Are they still there? I do not know. But in that room an old man of 82, taken ill while in secret flight from his unhappy marriage, from the pitiless glare of the world's admiration, from the contradictions of a life lived in luxury while he preached poverty, lay doing as he had always done, writing, until at last, his notebook fallen on the floor, his fingers traced words on the bed sheet. He had hoped to go away and die in peace and anonymity, but there in Astapovo, the world claimed him one last time. Journalists, government officials, disciples, priests and police settled in a thick mass outside the little tin-roofed shack. His estranged wife chartered a special train to bring her to his side but was not allowed to see him. There, on Nov. 7, 1910, Count Leo Tolstoy died. Mankind erects monuments to great men, statues, triumphal arches, tombs. From that little room in Astapovo his body went out to a funeral such as no other novelist has ever known. Yet for me, Astapovo is his true last resting place, a reminder that we do not escape what we are, what we have been.

title: Through the Form 1040 Step by Step
description: Top tax professionals work with their clients year round to draw up financial plans tailored to their goals and means, taking advantage of whatever deductions and opportunities are allowed under the nation's tax laws. Thus, studying an expertly prepared return can help taxpayers understand tax strategies, as well as aid in organizing records, even if they, too, turn to a professional to fill out the forms.

title: Tina Essey Plans To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Essey of San Francisco have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Tina Beth Essey, and Trygve Mikkelsen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kjell Mikkelsen of Oslo.

title: Teen-Age Affluence: An Empty World
description: I feel that Roger Keizerstein in his article ''Teen-Agers and the Trap of Affluence'' (Jan. 21) misses the point of what is really missing in their affluent lives. It is this very protection from life in the outside world that creates for them an empty nonworld. Even more to their detriment is the fact that they've never been told that the end of homelessness, the reversal of environmental decay, the elimination of animal exploitation, all rest within their hands.

title: TRACEY ULLMAN - QUEEN OF THE 'SKITCOM'
description: A work in desperation. That's what the writer/director James L. Brooks (''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''Terms of Endearment'') once called ''The Tracey Ullman Show.'' He was in a position to know, being co-creator of the series and one of the executive producers. Fortunately, with Fox Broadcasting itching to set up a fourth network, the show was allowed to lurch on.

title: Mary Louise Beardsley to Wed in June
description: Mrs. Alling Prudden Beardsley of Slingerlands, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Mary Louise Beardsley to Kent Allen Kelley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Allen Kelley of Harlingen, Tex. Ms. Beardsley is also a daughter of the late Mr. Beardsley. A June wedding is planned.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 4, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 3 2 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life, as depicted in verse and pictures. 2 1 6 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam Dalgitesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 3 2 6 THE BAD PLACE by Dean R. Koontz (Putnam, $10.95.)
