title: Switch in Latin Crops Won't Help Peasants
description: To the Editor:

title: An April Bridal For Ms. Sternlieb
description: April wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Sternlieb of Lake Success, L.I., for their daughter Marilyn Susan Sternlieb and Jeffrey Alan Stern, a son of Mrs. Alfred Stern of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Stern.

title: Kurt Weill Comes In From the Cold
description: Kurt Weill would have been 90 years old last Friday, and the world seems to be in a mood finally to acknowledge the significance of a composer who until recently was considered only a marginal figure in 20th-century music. Maybe the world is in too much of a hurry, considering this season's ill-conceived Broadway production of ''The Threepenny Opera'' or the unsuccessful movie version of it, ''Mack the Knife,'' which closed recently after a short engagement in a single New York theater.

title: Beirut General Seen as Likely to Yield Power
description: The failure of Gen. Michel Aoun to crush his militia opponents in the Christian sector after five weeks of fierce battles is likely to force him to step down and turn power over to President Elias Hrawi, according to news reports published today and Arab diplomats.

title: Italy Fears That Its Art Treasures Will Scatter in a Unified Europe
description: With daring and precision, two armed men in masks walked off one recent night with more than 200 valuable statuettes, vases and other objects that had been found in the remains here of the ancient Roman city of Herculaneum.

title: Upheaval in the East;   In Russian Farm Village, Issues Are Down to Earth
description: By noon today, when the morning shift had finished tending the dairy cows on the state farm in this small village, nearly all the eligible voters had cast their ballots at the polling station. Only 14 holdouts remained, mostly those who were still out doing their chores.

title: Manhattan,inc. Seeks to Revive Its Fortunes
description: D. Herbert Lipson, the owner of Manhattan,inc., has been getting a lot of calls lately from admirers - and not just from people praising the magazine's splashy behind-the-scenes business articles. Some callers want to buy the magazine.

title: Prison Term In Juice Case
description: A former owner of a local fruit juice company was sentenced last week to two years in prison for selling orange juice adulterated with ingredients not listed on container labels.

title: Upheaval in the East;   EARLY SOVIET VOTE LEAVES OPPOSITION EXPECTING VICTORY
description: Voters in the Slavic heartland of the Soviet Union went to the polls today in an exercise of limited democracy that pitted an array of grass-roots challengers against the vast Communist Party patronage network.

title: Thank You, Jesse
description: Republicans are joyful that Jesse Jackson has chosen to become the black Stassen.

title: What of Their Courage On the Death Penalty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: NADIA COMANECI revisited the scene of her greatest triumph when she returned to Montreal last week. The former gymnast toured Olympic Stadium, where as a 14-year-old she scored seven perfect 10's and won three gold medals in 1976.

title: Upset Puts Fordham in Tourney Final
description: Fordham will have to wait one more day to leave the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference behind. The Rams, who join the Colonial League next season after a decade in the M.A.A.C., have a chance to leave the league they helped found with their second conference championship.

title: Upheaval in the East: Romania;   Through a Thick Veil of Soot, Romanian City Faces Future
description: For about 15 miles around, every growing thing in this once-gentle valley looks as if it has been dipped in ink. Trees and bushes are black; the grass is stained. The houses and streets look like the inside of a chimney. Even the sheep on the hillsides are a dingy gray.

title: V.M.I. Is Sued by U.S. For Excluding Women
description: As was expected for months, the Justice Department has sued the Virginia Military Institute in an effort to end the exclusion of women from the 1,300-student academy.

title: Weak Season Tied To Ferry Move
description: A less-than-impressive season in Italy may have motivated Danny Ferry, the former Duke all-American, to leave Il Messaggero Roma and sign with the Cleveland Cavaliers, Italy's largest sports daily has reported.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 4, 1990:

title: Andy Rooney Returns to '60 Minutes'
description: Andy Rooney, suspended from the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' last month over remarks attributed to him that offended blacks and homosexuals, returned to the program last night, not with an outright apology, but with the kind of commentary he is known for: provocative questions sprinkled with personal observations.

title: BBC Adds News Programs In U.S. and Eastern Europe
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation has announced plans to expand its news programs in the United States and Eastern Europe.

title: Jet Loses Air Pressure And Dives 25,000 Feet
description: American Airlines Flight 40 from Los Angeles to New York suddenly lost cabin pressure and the pilots put it into a steep dive yesterday, dropping 25,000 feet in several minutes. No one was injured, an airline official said, but passengers on board said they thought they were going to crash.

title: Bad Bargain With Exxon
description: The Exxon Valdez oil spill was arguably the worst environmental disaster in U.S. history, so it's reasonable to expect those responsible to be called to account, clean up the mess and pay damages. The Justice Department chose to pursue those ends through a plea bargain with Exxon. The collapse of that bargain has almost certainly served the larger cause of justice.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Penrod Drilling Corporation misstated the extent of the company's ownership of offshore drilling rigs. Penrod owns 39 modern drilling rigs, not 39 percent of the world's total.

title: Shearson Reversal;   Bearishness Over Securities Business Led American Express to Alter Plans
description: The American Express Company, which had struggled to separate itself from Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., found that doing so was not easy. Now, realizing that its prestige and reputation are inextricably bound up in Shearson's fortunes, it has decided to buy the entire brokerage firm.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 19 about regulation of doctors in Massachusetts misstated two provisions of state law.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Sasabe Journal;   A Tribe's Bitter Drug Lesson: Nothing Is Sacred
description: From time immemorial, the Papago Indians have lived in the harsh desert here, roaming back and forth across what is today the United States-Mexico border. But after fending off conquistadors, miners, ranchers, armies and other Indian tribes, the Papago now confront perhaps the most dangerous threat to their existence: the international drug trade.

title: Mister Frisky, 15 for 15, Gaining Luster
description: Someone will have to win the Kentucky Derby on May 5, but making an early selection is getting harder with each passing round of prep races.

title: Mandela Hailed in Land He Cites as an Example
description: Nelson Mandela was enthusiastically greeted here today as an African nationalist hero by hundreds of South African exiles and thousands of Zimbabweans.

title: Home-Court Advantage
description: TONYA and Greg Grant grew up near basketball courts. They had a backboard in their backyard, and their grandmother lived next to the courts on Walnut Street in Trenton. This was a good thing. It meant there was always some family member around to calm things down.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nobody knew about us. Now people come, and they say we are the most polluted town in the world.''

title: Loyola Star Collapses In Game And Dies
description: Hank Gathers of Loyola Marymount University, one of the leading scorers in National Collegiate Athletic Association history, died tonight after collapsing on the court during Loyola Marymount's game against Portland. He was 23 years old.

title: Norman Beats 3 In Doral Playoff
description: It's a new decade, and today at the Doral Ryder Open Greg Norman played sensational golf to answer those who spent the 1980's labeling him the golfer who has done less with more than anyone else in the game's history.

title: Gunboat Law
description: According to the Supreme Court's peculiar reasoning last week, the Fourth Amendment does not protect a foreigner from a warrantless search by Americans of his home in his native country, and the use of seized evidence at his trial in this country. This 6-to-3 decision is to jurisprudence what gunboats are to diplomacy.

title: Samuel Perlman, Businessman, 82
description: Samuel Perlman, a businessman and philanthropist, died of cardiac arrest on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old. Mr. Perlman, a Brooklyn native, was a graduate of St. John's University and the New York Law School. He served in the Army in World War II and with the American military government in Germany after the war.

title: Next Issue: Talks on Talking
description: Maybe the negotiators in the baseball labor dispute will meet today, after a weeklong recess, and maybe they won't. The only thing known for certain is that they will talk by telephone to discuss whether or not they want to meet.

title: New Jersey Schools: Rich, Poor, Unequal
description: The urban school system here and the suburban district in nearby Millburn are separated by only six miles. Academically, socially and economically, they are worlds apart.

title: Delayed Reaction for Victim Of Robbery - and Shooting
description: A 27-year-old man who said he was robbed by drug dealers discovered the next day - to his surprise - that he had been shot in the stomach, the police said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of an obituary on Saturday about Scott Jarvis, an actor and singer, misstated his age. He was 48 years old.

title: Books of The Times;   So Is the Hero Really Philip Roth, or Not?
description: Deception

title: Feed Ethiopia, Not Its Wars
description: The news from Ethiopia could hardly be grimmer. In a bitter reprise of the famine of 1984-85, millions face starvation as stores from a meager harvest are exhausted. Again, Western relief agencies must deal with a truculent Marxist tyranny led by President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The difference this time is that Mr. Mengistu is losing a war with two insurgencies in northern Ethiopia, meaning that vital corridors for relief convoys are now blocked.

title: Business and the Law;   Troubles Persist In Asbestos Cases
description: FACING a severe cash squeeze, the trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos - who often suffer from fatal diseases - has begun to offer settlements of up to 40 percent in cash and the rest in non-marketable, long-term notes.

title: Don't Relax About Nuclear Winter Just Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: A Generous Reply to the Neediest
description: The 78th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases collected a total of $4,372,283, surpassing last year's record by more than $332,000.

title: An Old Sport Gets New Look
description: Lacrosse, a spring sport now played at 203 colleges, will be different this season. Subtle rules changes aimed at a swifter tempo will mean less dawdling around with the ball, and one defensive specialist, waving a long stick, has been struck out.

title: Gerard Blitz, 78, Dies; Founder of Club Med
description: Gerard Blitz, founder of the Club Mediterranee empire of vacation villages billed as an ''antidote to civilization,'' has died, company officials said today. He was 78 years old.

title: KEY RATES
14 Die as Philippine Troops Fight Rebel Governor
description: A Philippine general and 13 others were killed today when Government troops clashed with supporters of a provincial Governor who took over a hotel in Tuguegarao, 250 miles north of Manila.

title: Space Shuttle Lands, Ending Secret Mission
description: The space shuttle Atlantis landed here this morning, ending a secret military mission of four and a half days for its five astronauts.

title: Frank X. Graves Jr. Is Dead at 66; Hard-Driving Mayor of Paterson
description: Frank X. Graves Jr., the longtime Mayor of Paterson, N.J., and also a State Senator for many years, died after a heart attack yesterday morning at his home in the Lakeview section of the city. He was 66 years old.

title: No Snub Intended in Cheney's Manila Visit
description: To the Editor:

title: At Ease
description: IRONY was presumably not what George F. Will intended when he came up with a title for his new book, which examines the intricacies of major league baseball.

title: Talks End, Wait Begins
description: In an era in which the cold war is ending, the Germanys are moving toward reunification and the South African Government has legalized the major black opposition, is it possible to resolve trade disputes with Japan?

title: Report Cites Maryland Woes
description: The University of Maryland will be banned from postseason play this year and in 1991 under National Collegiate Athletic Association sanctions against the men's basketball program, a published report said today.

title: At 13, Capriati Wonders, Why the Fuss?
description: THE sun is setting behind the tennis courts and a clan of hump-backed raccoons assembles like spectators in the palm trees as Jennifer Capriati, the teen-ager voted most likely to take No. 1 away from Steffi Graf, attempts to wind down from her day.

title: Don't Relax About Nuclear Winter Just Yet;   Germs of the Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: To the Dying, Life Policy Can Bring Money Now
description: For anyone who is terminally ill, with 18 months or less to live, Rob T. Worley Sr., of Albuquerque, N.M., has an offer: Assign a life insurance policy to his company, Living Benefits Inc., and get up to 80 percent of the policy's value, now.

title: Albany's Self-Inflicted Budget Woes
description: LEAD: To hear them talk in Albany, the explanation for New York's fiscal crisis is simple: tax cuts have gone too far, state revenues are falling and spending austerity will not be enough. We're told that what we need is a tax increase.

title: Dorothy J. Roberts, 96; Retold Ancient Myths
description: Dorothy James Roberts, a writer best known for her retelling of ancient Arthurian, Irish and Icelandic myths in historical romances, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 96 and lived in Palo Alto.

title: 'HOMELAND' LEADER DEPOSED IN CISKEI
description: Thousands of people cheered and danced in the streets with soldiers today after military officers overthrew the Government of Ciskei, the nominally independent South African homeland.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, announced the retirements of Malcolm T. Stamper as vice chairman and Harold W. Haynes as executive vice president and chief financial officer. Boeing promoted Dean D. Thornton to the position of executive vice president; he will continue as president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. The company also promoted B. Dan Pinick to executive vice president; he will remain president of the Boeing Defense and Space Group. Boeing promoted Deane D. Cruze, Boyd E. Givan and A. D. Welliver to corporate senior vice presidents of operations, finance, and engineering and technology, respectively.

title: Texas Candidate, Once Leading, Slips
description: Three months ago, Ann Richards seemed headed for victory in this year's gubernatorial race in Texas - a handsome, witty woman apparently destined for stardom in the national Democratic Party.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Soviets Said to Seal Uzbek City After Clashes
description: Security forces reportedly sealed off a city near Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, today after clashes with demonstrators. Officials said at least one soldier had been killed, but a protester reported many dead.

title: Terri L. Newman, A Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Terri Newman Wed to Steven Bleiberg Terri Lynn Newman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan A. Newman of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Steven David Bleiberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Bleiberg of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Daniel Allen officiated.

title: M. Steffy Browne, Economics Professor, 91
description: M. Steffy Browne, professor emeritus of economics at Brooklyn College, died of heart failure Friday at New York Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LIKUD PRESSURING SHAMIR ON TALKS
description: Leading members of the governing Likud party spoke out strongly today against a modified American proposal for peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. The rumblings of dissent came as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met with his three top Cabinet officials to discuss the plan, which the Israeli leader has reportedly leaned closer to accepting in recent days.

title: Jackson and Kennedy Reach Quarterfinals
description: The guards that Coach Chuck Granby of Andrew Jackson High School calls his ''two Teddies'' proved more than enough yesterday to eliminate Hillcrest from the second round of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament at Queensborough Community College.

title: What of Their Courage On the Death Penalty?
description: To the Editor:

title: State Senator Abraham Bernstein; Fighter for Liberal Causes Was 71
description: State Senator Abraham Bernstein, a Bronx Democrat who served almost 30 years in the Legislature and whose district stretched from Riverdale to Co-op City, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 71 years old.

title: Review/Television;   Teen-Agers on the Right Side of Reality
description: Television entertainment is often accused, justifiably, of being on a collision course with reality, and images of teen-agers are a particularly good case in point. Most daily headlines about young people are not encouraging as they follow crises ranging from education failures to drug abuse. Last week it was announced that New York City was doubling its staff of lawyers assigned to prosecute juveniles, because of an enormous surge in Family Court cases as well as crimes.

title: Steady Rates Expected If Dollar Stays Strong
description: Fuzzy signals about the domestic economy and rising foreign interest rates are likely to create a standoff and keep interest rates in the United States in a narrow trading range - as long as the dollar remains strong, many analysts say.

title: New Policy Aids Families of Aliens
description: Diego Trujillo, an immigrant from Colombia who is a legal resident of the United States, and his companion of 13 years were thrilled last month when a Federal immigration policy was changed to try to keep alien families together.

title: Kaifu Returns to Political Outcry in Tokyo
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu returned to Japan on Sunday from his meeting with President Bush in California to face what politicians and commentators agreed was a severe test of his leadership.

title: A Selma March Relives Those First Steps of '65
description: As they did 25 years ago, civil rights marchers gathered today under a cloudless sky and slowly walked onto the Edmund Pettus Bridge.

title: Quietest Man On Television Is Celebrated In a Special
description: Fred Rogers, the host of ''Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood,'' took the pictures of children from his wallet and displayed them, as any proud parent would do. But the photos were not of his children; they were of children who had visited his ''Neighborhood.'' Mr. Rogers simply loves children.

title: A Foldaway Toddler Cart
description: A bicycle trailer for carting children is designed to fold for storage.

title: Ms. Magazine Prepares For a Life Without Ads
description: If Ms. was the magazine that defined feminism, can the new Ms. magazine, scheduled to appear in June, be described as post-feminist?

title: Chronicle
description: The Soviet Ambassador, YURI V. DUBININ, is giving a musicale at his embassy tonight,where the president of Oberlin College, S. FREDERICK STARR, plans to tell guests about the American Soviet Youth Orchestra.

title: A Lapse by Devils Is Capitals' Gain
description: The Devils made a number of mental mistakes against the Capitals this afternoon and took another step backward only two days after they had crawled forward in the Patrick Division race.

title: White House Reneges on Air-Ticket Trade-Off
description: To the Editor:

title: San Francisco Journal;   Sea Lions Test City's Hospitable Reputation
description: The residents of this city pride themselves on cordiality. But overnight, a pack of barking sea lions have emerged in San Francisco Bay, sometimes sorely testing the city's hospitality.

title: Dinkins Visits Family of Man Shot by Police
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins told reporters that he had visited yesterday with the family of David Cotto, the 20-year-old Brooklyn man who died on Thursday when he was struck by nine police bullets.

title: Diamond Trade Gains
description: Belgium's diamond trade, the world's biggest, posted a 25 percent increase in 1989. The Diamond High Council said Friday that Belgium imported diamonds weighing a total of more than 129 million carats and worth 286.7 billion francs, or $8 billion, in 1989. The council said export sales totaled 291.8 billion francs, or $8.15 billion. The total trade of 578.5 billion francs, or $16.15 billion, compared with 461.5 billion francs, or $12.89 billion, in 1988.

title: Obstacles Remain In Path to Solvency
description: Although Eastern Airlines is beginning to attract more passengers and is likely to get an infusion of cash soon from its parent, the Texas Air Corporation, it still faces large hurdles in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy protection as a profitable regional carrier.

title: Creativity Thrives in A Car Culture
description: GENERATIONS of country-and-western singers have equated freeways with freedom, so it is unsurprising that this city ringed and spliced by highways should have become the center of the loosest and least formulaic automobile advertising done today.

title: Athletes Find a Way To Hit Books, Slopes
description: TO ski and to study. That may seem like a prospect too perfect to be true for many high school students looking forward to college. But every year it is attained by thousands of young athletes.

title: Larry Brown's Long and Rough Road to Becoming a Writer
description: One day nine years ago, a 29-year-old firefighter from Yocona, Miss., named Larry Brown decided to become a writer. He sat down at his wife's portable electric typewriter and began seven months of work on a novel about a killer bear running amok in Yellowstone National Park.

title: Harlem Fights Angrily to Keep A Maternity Ward in St. Luke's
description: Amid a merger that will cost hundreds of millions of dollars and shuffle thousands of jobs, a storm of community anger has broken out over the determination of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center to move 42 of its maternity beds downtown.

title: Big Concrete Supplier Faces U.S. Inquiry Into Possible Mob Tie
description: A company that recently expanded to become the largest supplier of concrete in the New York metropolitan area is under Federal investigation for possible financial irregularities and ties to organized crime, according to lawyers, officials and others familiar with the inquiry.

title: At the Golub Trial, the Main Puzzle Is the Suspect
description: As they sit in a Nassau County courtroom here, listening to hour after hour of grim testimony about the murder of 13-year-old Kelly Ann Tinyes, the jurors in the case often turn to stare at the defendant, Robert Golub.

title: Rebuffed by Courts, Anti-Abortion Chief Regroups
description: Southern Tier Women's Services, one of two abortion clinics in Broome County, believes it has perfected the art of keeping unruly anti-abortion protesters off its premises.

title: The National Faces Its Biggest Test Soon
description: The National, the new sports newspaper, has gotten off to a fast start by using discounted introductory rates to lure national advertisers like A.T.&T., Philip Morris and Nike, media analysts say. The tabloid claims a daily circulation of 200,000.

title: How to Learn in College: Group Study, Many Tests
description: Some relatively simple changes in teaching methods can produce significant gains in learning for college students, according to a study made public yesterday by Harvard University.

title: Soaring High, UConn Is Finally Feeling It Belongs
description: AS Jim Calhoun sat in his office last week, his basketball team was little more than 24 hours away from gaining a share of first place in the final regular-season standing for the first time in the University of Connecticut's often depressing history as a member of the Big East Conference.

title: Kim Zmeskal, 14, Wins Her 2d Title
description: Bela Karolyi gets so carried away whenever he talks about the great female gymnasts he has coached that it's easy to factor in a certain degree of skepticism as he gushes over his latest model.

title: Shortly After First Trial, Figures in McMartin Case Brace for the Second
description: Two and a half years, 124 witnesses and 800 exhibits later, prosecutors are ready to seek convictions once again in the McMartin preschool molestation case, this time with a different judge and jury and only one defendant.

title: Guggenheim May Sell Artworks To Pay for a Major New Collection
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum might sell art from its permanent collection to help pay for its recent acquisition of more than 200 contemporary works from Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo.

title: World Bank's Lesser Role in China
description: More than any other foreign institution, the World Bank has had enormous impact on China's economic transformation of the last decade. It was not just a large lending institution but a bank of ideas.

title: Europe's Ski Industry Is in Difficulty
description: After a warm and erratic winter, the European ski industry is troubled.

title: Chamorro Said to Drop Anti-Army Plan
description: Despite campaign promises to ''send all the weapons to the bottom of the sea,'' President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will only gradually reduce Nicaragua's military, and she has backed away from plans to abolish the army entirely, her advisers say.

title: Valvano Facing Uncertainty
description: The fans at North Carolina State's Reynolds Coliseum wore yellow V-shaped ribbons to express their support for Jim Valvano today, and they greeted the embattled basketball coach with a standing ovation.

title: Hoya Coach Ejected as Orange Wins
description: A basketball had just vanished, after a triumphant heave through the noise and into the largest crowd to see a game on a college campus. A net was disappearing at one end of the Carrier Dome, strand by strand, as the Orangemen of Syracuse University took turns sitting on one another's shoulders and the crowd of 33,015 kept its volume turned up.

title: Rangers Nursing Wounds and Hopes
description: There was, in a very real and sad sense, no reason for the Rangers to wait for yesterday morning's diagnoses. Over the years in such instances, the team has assumed the worst and rarely been wrong.

title: Simon at Juilliard
description: The pianist Abbey Simon is to give a free piano recital on March 20 at 8 P.M. at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street. The event is part of the Faculty Recital Series at the school, where Mr. Simon has been a faculty member since 1977. On the program are Beethoven's Sonata No. 31 in A flat, Schumann's Fantasia in C and Liszt's ''Grandes Etudes de Paganini.'' Information: 874-7515.

title: Soviet Union;   In Minsk, the Candidates of Dissent Stand Up to a Bare-Knuckled Party
description: The candidate had been well smeared by broadsides stuffed at the last minute into the mailboxes of the tenement warrens of Communism in the dawn of Election Day in Byelorussia.

title: Anger Greets Democrats' Talks With White House
description: Two Democratic committee leaders in the House of Representatives have angered some colleagues by engaging in independent negotiations with the White House on a hotly disputed child care bill.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Arranges Big Credit Line From Banks
description: In a move that analysts say should calm jittery shareholders, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the troubled advertising and communications giant, confirmed today that it had arranged enough bank financing to see it through its current difficulties.

title: A Health Care Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: Shackleford Back at Practice
description: The day after he denied any involvement with point-shaving at North Carolina State, Charles Shackleford returned to practice with the Nets and tried to regain a sense of normality in his life.

title: A Dome Fit for Expansion?
description: THERE is no mistaking it, not from the distance of the interstate highway that whisks past it and not up close, where it rises unevenly, looking somehow as if it were slipping irreparably into its foundation. And while it is both a little odd to the eye and seemingly out of place here, there is no reason to believe that it won't soon be the home of big league baseball.

title: Chronicle
description: The Nobel prizes were created by ALFRED NOBEL, the inventor of dynamite. Nitro Nobel Company, the Swedish company he founded, also awards a gold medal in the inventor's name, to a scientist who has discovered new ways to blow things up.

title: No Solution in Sight For Labor Dispute
description: Eastern Airlines' striking machinists marked the one-year anniversary of their walkout with demonstrations yesterday at more than half a dozen large airports. Officials on both sides said there was no end in sight to the labor dispute.

title: Ortega Spurned in an Old Stronghold
description: For the last decade, this town has been known throughout Nicaragua as ''the cradle of the insurrection,'' in honor of the singular role that it played in helping the Sandinista Front overthrow Anastasio Somoza Debayle. But when Masaya residents voted last Sunday, they cast aside their reputation as Sandinista loyalists and voted for Violeta Barrios de Chamorro.

title: European Storms Linked to Breakneck Jet Stream
description: The hurricane-force winds that have ripped Western Europe three times in the last six weeks, killing more than 140 people and costing perhaps a billion dollars in damage, marked the return of a weather phenomenon that had not often been seen in the last two decades.

title: F.B.I. Suspends Veteran Agent, Provoking Furor
description: A decorated counterintelligence specialist for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Miami lost his security clearance and was suspended as a result of a nearly three-year investigation that has involved allegations of espionage for Cuba, Government officials and friends of the agent say.

title: Outdoors: Hudson Popular Host for Shad
description: BRAVISSIMO for the American shad, scientifically known as Alosa sapidissima, a name so lyrical that it has been likened to the title of a Verdi opera. In translation, Alosa sapidissima is the Latin for ''shad most delicious,'' a right-on description to anyone who savors shad roe or a juicy boned fillet.

title: In Auto Insurance, Inequality Is Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Show and Tell Proves Telling
description: HIS English is limited, so Sergei Beloglazov teaches with body language. And what better sport could there be for that than wrestling?

title: N. Carolina Foils Duke Hopes
description: King Rice scored 20 points to lead five players in double figures as North Carolina spoiled Duke's hopes for a share of first place in the Atlantic Coast Conference with an 87-75 victory over the Blue Devils today.

title: Question Box
description: One-Team Famers

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Westmark Selects a New President
description: LEAD: Westmark Systems, the holding company that owns Tracor Holdings Inc., a military contractor, has named James B. Skaggs president and chief executive. Mr. Skaggs succeeds Bobby Ray Inman, who resigned at the end of last year.

title: Scary Thingamajig Disrupts A Quiet Morning in Princeton
description: The object looked suspicious. So Patrolman Ernest Silagyi pulled over to talk with the man carrying it down Mount Lucas Road in Princeton, N.J., yesterday morning.

title: Quietest Man on Television Is Celebrated in a Special
description: Fred Rogers, the host of ''Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood,'' took the pictures of children from his wallet and displayed them, as any proud parent would do. But the photos were not of his children; they were of children who had visited his ''Neighborhood.'' Mr. Rogers simply loves children.

title: INSIDE
description: Managua to Keep Army

title: New Tack on Shearson By American Express
description: After months of seeking to reduce its 68 percent stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton, the American Express Company siad it would, instead, buy all the outstanding shares of the investment bank. Weekend talks about selling Shearson to Sanford I. Weill, a Wall Street exectuvie, fell through.

title: A G.I. Wounded in Panama Bombing Dies
description: American soldier has died of wounds suffered in a grenade attack on a discotheque, and 13 American servicemen remain hospitalized, the United States military said today.

title: Alma Nicoll Baker, Interior Designer, 72
description: Alma Nicoll Baker, an interior designer, died of ovarian cancer yesterday at Memorial Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Saudis Study Oil Price Rise
description: Saudi Arabia appeared to be siding with Iraq against Kuwait in seeking higher oil prices as three of the big OPEC oil producers held talks in Kuwait over the weekend, OPEC officials and oil analysts said.

title: The Trials of Putting On a Show For Academy Awards Night
description: If Hollywood press agents had X-ray vision, they would all be trying to pierce the white polyester curtain in Gilbert Cates's office on Sunset Boulevard. The curtain hides a bulletin board plastered with salmon and white index cards, each with a movie star's name on it. The stars are candidates to present one or another of the Oscars at the 62d annual Academy Awards presentations on television in three weeks.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the bankruptcy proceedings of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. misidentified a creditor of one of the firm's subsidiaries. The creditor is the central bank of Portugal, not Puerto Rico.

title: Fixed Mortgages Down
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.23 percent last week, down from 10.31 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.48 percent last week, up from 8.44 percent the week before.

title: Prosecutors Try to Speed the Tedium Of Turning Nasty Acts Into Charges
description: Jesse Sligh, an assistant district attorney, pondered the information the police officer had just given him about an arrest the night before. The suspect had kicked his pregnant wife during a domestic dispute.

title: Review/Dance;   A Feld Premiere, 'Charmed Lives'
description: Still another premiere by Eliot Feld? The fourth this season is ''Charmed Lives,'' whose charm, indeed, lies in the choreographer's gentler treatment of pure movement compared with the mathematical hard edge of some of his recent pieces.

title: Job Growth in Health Care Soars
description: The number of jobs in American health care is soaring at a rate three times faster than the growth of the population, troubling experts concerned about the sharp rise in the nation's medical costs. Thirty-seven of every 1,000 Americans worked in health care last year, compared with about 28 for every 1,000 just 10 years earlier.

title: Miss Akst, Consultant, Is Married in Westchester
description: Susan G. Akst and Archie Granot were married yesterday in Mount Kisco, N.Y., at the home of the bride's sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Jay H. Schecter, by Rabbi Benjamin Blech.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about an interview with Karl Otto Pohl, president of West Germany's central bank, mistranslated a comment on the possible rate at which East German marks will be converted to West German marks under a unification of the two economies. The quotation should have read, ''The better the rate is for the savers, the worse it will be for debtors,'' not creditors.

title: South African Political Prisoners Fasting
description: Several hundred South African political prisoners have begun a hunger strike to force President F. W. de Klerk to release them under a general amnesty that could strengthen the negotiating position of the African National Congress.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Bridge
description: One of the most prestigious positions in bridge journalism has a new occupant: Albert Dormer of London has succeeded Jeremy Flint, who died last November, as columnist for The Times of London, one of the world's most famous newspapers.

title: Dr. Daniel J. Alpert Wed To Dr. Kara Fae Sheinart
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., Dr. Kara Fae Sheinart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sheinart of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Joseph Alpert, a son of Meryl Alpert of Kew Gardens, Queens, and the late Louis Alpert. Rabbi David Moseson officiated.

title: A Mine Explodes as Koreans Search Tunnel at the Border
description: A mine exploded today while soldiers were exploring a tunnel supposedly dug under the border by North Korea, killing a sentry dog but causing no other casualties, officials said.

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Prime Minister Is Bullish on Yugoslavia's Economic Changes
description: There is one big optimist in this country of great economic changes and political tensions. His name is Ante Markovic, and he happens to be the Prime Minister.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Some Went to the Aid of Hit-and-Run Victim
description: To the Editor:

title: Lee Snow and Lisa Steinberg Are Wed
description: Lisa Steinberg and Lee Snow were married yesterday at Nanou, a Manhattan restaurant. Rabbis Kenneth Hain and Irwin Isaacson officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Steinberg of Brooklyn. Her husband is a son of Frances Snow of Brooklyn and the late Mel Snow.

title: What Savings Crisis?
description: One of the peculiar complaints of the Japanese - presumably repeated by Prime Minister Kaifu to President Bush at the Rancho Mirage summit meeting - is that Americans don't save enough. We are accused of spending too much on Japanese cars and other imports, thus increasing our trade deficit through no fault but our own.

title: Harrods Owner Will Not Be Charged
description: After a 20-month investigation, the British Government has decided not to bring any charges in connection with the 1985 takeover by the Fayed family of House of Fraser P.L.C., which owns Harrods, the renowned London department store.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Iran and Syria Discuss Efforts to Free Hostages
description: A senior Iranian envoy discussed efforts to free Western hostages held in Lebanon when he met today with Syria's Foreign Minister, a Syrian said.

title: The Owl That Smoked Cigars
description: WHEN I was growing up, two of the most charming characters in my neighborhood were an owl that smoked cigars and a lunatic bear.

title: A New Upjohn Strategy To Compete Globally
description: In a move intended to bring products to market faster, the Upjohn Company is forming a unit, Upjohn Laboratories, that will integrate research and medical-affairs divisions into a single global operation. Dr. Jerry R. Mitchell will be its president.

title: Thailand's Army Chief Announces He'll Quit
description: Thailand's armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, announced today in Bangkok that he would resign his post this month. It is widely expected that he will join the faltering Government as deputy prime minister.

title: I Quit To Sound An Early Alarm
description: I resigned from the Israeli Government because I fear that its present political initiatives, even if founded in a sincere attempt to achieve peace, reward the Palestinians for their terrorism and increase the risks of war.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Friday, about an exodus of creative people from San Francisco agencies, misidentified the Los Angeles agency that has employed Dan Mountain, a copywriter. It is Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, not Chiat/Day.

title: Legal Scholar on Death Row Fights to Halt Own Execution
description: Joseph Giarratano has spent most of the last 10 years in his cell in Mecklenburg Correctional Facility here, in the undeviating and claustrophobic universe of death row. But more than any of the nation's 2,500 other condemned inmates, his name has traveled beyond the prison walls.

title: Metro Matters;   Killed by Cold: Winter's Fingers Reach Indoors
description: So violent is the Bronx neighborhood where Homer Goodwin died that rumors of his brutal murder were accepted as gospel.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and concluding with an auction of one-year bills on Thursday.

title: Tips to Make Skiing a Bit Easier to Learn
description: HAVE you ever wondered why skiing is so difficult to learn? After all, gravity pulls you down the hill. All you really need to learn is to turn.

title: Motorola Is Offering Work Station
description: Motorola Inc. will introduce computer work stations today that company officials say will offer better performance and lower pricing than the systems introduced last month by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Poindexter, Plain Yet Puzzling Figure In Contra Affair, Goes on Trial Today
description: John M. Poindexter, the Navy admiral who said he made the decision to divert profits from the Iran arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels, goes on trial Monday as the last of the original Iran-contra defendants to face charges.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   As Publishing Turmoil Rises, Business Expertise Is Sought
description: The American publishing industry is in turmoil. Some leading publishers have been forced out; employees have been laid off, and companies are feeling more pressure to focus on profits.

title: American Express in Reversal
description: In an abrupt about-face, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would buy all the publicly held shares of its brokerage firm, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Helping Hands Must Stay Clean
description: THEY are at once loyal alumni, avid boosters and potential saboteurs: dedicated fans whose very eagerness to help old Siwash U. get a leg up on Rival State can cost Siwash the chance to sign a valued prospect or keep an established star.

title: Census Geared To Undercount, Dinkins Asserts He Says Bureau Has Not Listed 1,000 Blocks
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the Federal Census Bureau had omitted a 21-story apartment building on the Lower East Side, along with other buildings and blocks, from a list of the sites in New York City that it intends to canvass in this year's census.

title: Market Place;   Sun's Rebound In Work Stations
description: JUST six months after stunning Wall Street with its first-ever quarterly loss, Sun Microsystems Inc. has put its corporate house back in order, analysts say. Results improved dramatically in the quarter ended Dec. 31 at Sun, the leading maker of work stations, which are powerful desktop computers previously used for scientific and engineering work but now being employed for financial services and other applications.

title: Frozen Food Express IndusFtries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Crestbrook Forest Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Defender of Rain Forest Is Named Secretary of Environment in Brazil
description: A pioneer conservationist is about to become Brazil's new Secretary of Environment.

title: General Housewares Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $70,000 for the quarter and income of $330,000, or 11 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and a loss of $340,000 for both the quarter and year from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,000 for the quarter and $378,000, or 14 cents a share, for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $366,000 from extinguishment of debt.

title: How Many More of the Homeless Must Die in the Subways?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethiopian Leader Wants to End Marxist Economy
description: The President of Ethiopia, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, today proposed scrapping Ethiopia's rigid Soviet-style economic system and replacing it with a mixed economy.

title: G.M. Layoffs: Wait It Out? Start Again?
description: The 1,600 people laid off from the night shift at the General Motors assembly plant here 10 days ago find themselves at a crossroads.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A TV Series Uses Agency For Realism
description: JUST outside Marshall Herskovitz's homey office, with its old, beaten leather couch, there is a basketball hoop attached to a wall, about six feet off the ground. It looks exactly like the basketball hoop that used to be in the office of Michael Steadman and Elliot Weston before their advertising agency went under and they started work at Drentell Ashly Arthur, the hottest shop in Philadelphia.

title: U.S. Panel Cites Risk In NASA Space Plan
description: Before carrying out President Bush's proposal for a base on the Moon and a manned mission to Mars, the space agency needs to study new technologies and eliminate ''unacceptable risks to the crew,'' the National Research Council says.

title: JRM Holdings Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $177,928 and $264,980 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $302,680 for the quarter and $488,510 for the 6 months.

title: Leslie Winship 2d, Dartmouth Administrator, 68
description: Leslie Winship 2d, a former vice president of Dartmouth College, died of a heart attack Friday at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. He was 68 years old and lived in Hanover.

title: Review/Theater;   Madness, Murder and Irrationality, in 'Woyzeck'
description: Though ''Woyzeck'' was written in the 1830's, it is a seminal play of the 20th century, the first to articulate the alienation of modern man driven to madness by forces far beyond his control. In a sequence of cumulative scenes, Buchner's play - based on a true story - follows the downward path of a barber who murders his mistress and suffers tragic consequences.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Mallard Coach Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Health Care REIT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on exercise of options of $500,000 for the latest year and $875,000 for 1988.

title: Electronic Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago quarter's results were after providing for final settlement of a patent infringement suit.

title: Contras Divided on Disbanding, With Some Predicting Civil War
description: Eight days after the Nicaraguan opposition trounced the Sandinistas in national elections, leaders of the 10,000 contras encamped along the Honduran border are struggling to devise a coherent proposal for disbanding and returning home.

title: Broadway Musical Tribute To the Critic Walter Kerr
description: With affection, nostalgia and humor, Broadway paid tribute last night to the longtime drama critic Walter Kerr at the newly restored theater renamed in his honor.

title: Enterra Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $616,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,924,000 which included a charge of $3,595,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect preferred stock dividend requirements.

title: Notebook;   Reggie Williams Gets A Shot With the Spurs
description: Reggie Williams, who in three years slipped from college stardom at Georgetown to being a pro basketball dud, was yesterday given a third chance to make it in the National Basketball Association.

description: Year-ago shares outstanding and share earnings adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend paid in September 1989.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $531,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-Net loss

title: No Grand Turkish Alliance Looms on Horizon;   Armenians Persecuted
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Air Group Inc., Seattle, an airline holding company, said that under its ''Dutch auction'' tender offer, it would buy three million shares of common stock at $22.875 a share.

title: Graham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $757,000 and $498,000 from sales of real estate. c-Included charge of $1,386,000 for discontinued operations and a gain of $347,000 from adoption of accounting standard.

title: American Consumer Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
End-of-Month Vehicle Sales Decline 7.9%
description: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks fell 7.9 percent in late February, dimming hopes that a sales surge at the beginning of the month had signaled an end to the automobile industry's slump.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Coke to Test Sweeter Cola
description: The cola wars appear about to heat up again. The Coca-Cola Company is set to test a new product, called Coke II, that the company will advertise as sweeter than Coca-Cola Classic, marketing executives say.

title: Pacific Nuclear Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1989 figures included the operations of Alaron Inc. for the two-month period after its acquisition on Oct. 31, 1989.

title: U.S. and China Resume Fulbright Program
description: China has agreed to resume participation in the Fulbright program, but on a smaller scale than in recent years, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Silicon Graphics And NKK in Deal
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., a leading maker of computer work stations for processing three-dimensional images, said it was entering a strategic partnership with the NKK Corporation of Tokyo. NKK, which is the second-largest steel company in Japan, will invest $35 million in newly issued Silicon Graphics convertible preferred stock.

title: Landmark American reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Guest Supply Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times;   Slogging Surreally in the Vietnamese Jungle
description: The Things They Carried

description: Ken Atkinson of the University of Richmond scored 25 points tonight as the Spiders won the Colonial Athletic Association tournament for the second time in three years, with a 77-72 victory over top-seeded James Madison.

title: Courier Stake Acquired
description: The investor Victor Posner said today that he had acquired an initial 5.2 percent, or 92,100 common shares, of the Courier Corporation, a Lowell, Mass., printer of telephone directories and books. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Posner said he was holding the shares for investment purposes. Courier's shares rose 75 cents today, to $16.50, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Few Willing to Help Britain Help Hong Kong Emigrants
description: Facing a British political backlash to her plan for granting up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents full British citizenship, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is trying to persuade the United States and other Western nations to make similar offers to the people of Hong Kong.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would use technology from Adobe Systems Inc. for displaying and printing typefaces on virtually its entire line of computers and printers.

title: Penalties for Maryland
description: The men's basketball program at Maryland was banned today from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in 1991 and 1992, prohibited from appearing on television next season and placed on three years' probation for major violations of N.C.A.A. rules.

description: * Parker Brothers, a subsidiary of the Tonka Corporation, to Grey Advertising to advertise its games, with a budget of $20 million.

title: Review/Music;   Old-Fashioned Debut For Siberian Baritone
description: The excitement of the New York debut has been eroded in recent years by a plethora of young performers fresh from the conservatory and an increasing number of midtown concert halls eager to give them a showcase. But every once in a while, a New York debut comes along in the old-fashioned sense of that term, meaning the tirelessly promoted, eagerly awaited first formal appearance of a presumed star of tomorrow. That was the case Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, when an audience packed with this city's vocal cognoscenti turned out to welcome the first full American recital of Dmitri Khvorostovsky, a Siberian baritone.

title: Barrett Resources Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israel Devalues Shekel
description: Israel cut the value of the shekel against the dollar by 1.6 percent today. The shekel has been devalued by 4.2 percent against the dollar since last Wednesday. The new rate is 2.0431 shekels to the dollar, and 2.1779 shekels to one unit of a basket of foreign currencies. The Israeli central bank announced a 5.6 percent devaluation of the median rate against the dollar-dominated basket of currencies last Wednesday.

title: Budget Matters at the Crux Of Kennedy Center Talks
description: James D. Wolfensohn, the New York investment banker who is being wooed to become chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, has told the search committee that his acceptance of the job hinges on a commitment from Congress and the White House to help pay renovation expenses and some of the center's $15 million debt.

title: Bioanalogics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Coca-Cola Drink
description: The Coca-Cola Company has introduced Powerade, a line of non-carbonated soft drinks to compete with Gatorade and other ''sports drinks.'' Powerade will be available only through fountains. Coca-Cola officials said they do not currently plan to sell the drink in cans or bottles. The national rollout, announced today, follows a four-month market test in Bakersfield, Calif.

title: War Stress Of Vietnam Compared In Twins
description: A study of twins who served in the military in the Vietnam era offers new evidence that post-traumatic stress disorder is more a product of combat than of any inborn susceptibility to stress.

title: Breaking the Ice With Japan, Again
description: President Bush's weekend talks with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu produced yet another Japanese pledge of economic reforms that could ease the two nations' tension over trade. Previous Prime Ministers have been unable to deliver as much as they seemed to promise but Mr. Kaifu introduced a welcome new element. His aim, he said, is to improve the quality of life in Japan - that is, to make changes because Japan needs them, not because America demands them.

title: Bank That Laundered Funds Faces Florida Suspension
description: Florida banking officials declined to renew the license today of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, a Luxembourg bank that pleaded guilty earlier this year to charges that it laundered drug money, the bank said.

title: Pressured Agencies Alter Post-Quake Relief Policy
description: Faced with unfamiliar inner-city problems and intense political pressure, the Red Cross and the Federal Emergency Management Agency have found new ways to dispense disaster relief for the low-income victims of the Oct. 17 earthquake here.

description: After a wave of conciliatory gestures following their election defeat last week, Sandinista leaders have begun to issue defiant warnings that the government-elect must not tamper with Sandinista control of the military or the Ministry of the Interior, which controls the secret police.

title: Dibrell to Buy RJR Tobacco Unit
description: Dibrell Brothers Inc. said it had signed an agreement to buy the Brazilian tobacco business of RJR Tobacco International for $50 million in cash. The Reynolds subsidiary makes and markets cigarettes and operates a leaf processing and exporting business in Brazil. Dibrell officials also said an agreement in principle had been reached with Philip Morris Marketing S.A., a subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies, under which its Brazilian affiliate will acquire RJR's Brazilian cigarette business from Dibrell.

description: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimated today that if President Bush's proposed budget becomes law, the Government will spend $131 billion more than it takes in during the next fiscal year, far in excess of the legal limit of $64 billion.

description: The hope of any movement toward peace between Israel and the Palestinians hangs in the balance now. The decision rests with the Government of Israel, and the attempt to come to grips with it is bringing sounds of discord and denunciation from Jerusalem.

title: Moscow Computer Store
description: The first store selling Western computers opened today in Moscow. Most buyers are expected to be from Soviet research institutions and businesses that have access to hard currency. ''We expect to do a $10 million business in the first year.'' said Michael Tseytin, a Soviet emigre and the president of the franchise running the Computerland store near Moscow University. The store carries machines made by the International Business Machines Corporation and other leading companies.

title: 250 Protest Resignation At Pantheon
description: Studs Terkel, Kurt Vonnegut Jr. and Oliver Sacks joined some 250 other authors, literary agents and other sympathizers in a demonstration outside Random House Inc.'s headquarters in Manhattan yesterday afternoon. It was the latest protest against the forced resignation last week of Andre Schiffrin, who was the managing director of Randon House's Pantheon Books division.

title: Second Federal Judge Rejects Law Against Burning the Flag
description: For the second time in two weeks, a Federal district judge has declared unconstitutional the law making it a crime to burn the American flag.

2 Yanks Reach Terms
description: Alvaro Espinoza, the starting shortstop, and Greg Cadaret, a pitcher, agreed yesterday to one-year contracts with the Yankees. Espinoza, 28 years old, hit .282 in 146 games last season. Cadaret was acquired from Oakland in June and finished the season with a 5-5 record and a 4.05 earned-run average.(AP)

title: 2,500 Protest in Argentina
description: Hampered by hyperinflation and recession, the Argentine Government today faced a new groundswell of discontent as 2,500 workers took over a Buenos Aires bank to protest a $2 billion Government cost-cutting program.

description: They felled the statue of Lenin that dominated a huge plaza of the Romanian capital today. But after four decades of Communist rule, this country's new rulers do not know quite what to do with it.

title: Italian Collections in a Lighthearted Mood
description: When it comes to razzle-dazzle, no one can outshine Gianni Versace. Though he promised to lower his voltage by loosening the fit and showing sportier styles, he hardly makes clothes for wallflowers. So with coats and dresses that stop at fingertip level - some hems did not pass the knuckles - with splashy patterns that had an Oriental splendor and buckets of beads delicately applied, he stood out like a lightship in the first days of the fall and winter ready-to-wear showings here.

title: Review/Television;   Where Men Faced Death, With Fear and Bravery
description: They look pretty much like the sort of American tourists who are often kidded by more elegant travelers: a big busload of elderly people, snapping pictures, buying postcards. Their red, white and blue Victory Tours bus seems like a parody. But their itinerary is offbeat: the roads through France and Germany that became the final European battleground of World War II. And they are accompanied by Bill Moyers.

title: Rapist's Victim Wins Right To Sue the Transit Authority
description: The 23-year-old woman was on her way home at 10 P.M. on July 19, 1988, when she became trapped between a revolving-gate exit and a fence blocking the stairs to the street at the 28th Street station of the IRT No. 1 line. There, she was raped and robbed. Yesterday, a state judge ruled that the negligence that let her be trapped that way was so egregious that she can sue the Transit Authority, even though state law normally protects the agency against such action.

title: Chess
description: Some years ago, David Bronstein broached the curious idea of playing a game on at least four or five boards at the same time against the same opponent. The man who played a tie match for the world championship in Moscow in 1951 lamented his inability to realize all the latent possiblities in a chess position and hoped that multiplying the number of boards would help resolve his quandary. Then he could sacrifice a piece on one board, play positionally on another, grab a pawn on a third and play cautiously for a draw on a fourth - all outgrowths of the same stem position.

title: Ambac Indemnity
description: Citicorp announced yesterday that it was considering selling the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, a subsidiary of Citibank that insures interest and principal payments on municipal bonds. The possibility of a sale, which has been previously suggested by banking analysts, is part of Citicorp's plans announced earlier this year to raise capital by selling some operations, the banking company said. Ambac is a leading firm in municipal bond insurance, with $700 million of capital.

title: Morris Margolin, Accountant, 81
description: Morris Margolin, retired founding partner of Margolin, Winer & Evans, an accounting firm in Garden City, L.I., died of an aneurysm on Sunday at J.F.K. Hospital in Atlantis, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

In Texas, Candidate Makes Effort to End Drug-Use Question
description: Trying to revive her faltering campaign for Texas governor, Ann Richards said today that she had not taken illegal drugs anytime in the past decade. But she refused to say anything about her earlier life when, by her own admission, she was a heavy drinker.

description: The latest quarter and year included net investment income of $1,297,502 and $5,208,788, respectively, and the year-ago quarter and year included investment income of $1,133,580 and $3,545,649, respectively.

title: Correction
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times last Tuesday misstated the number of typefaces included when an optional Postscript cartridge is used with the Hewlett-Packard Laserjet III printer. All 35 standard Postscript fonts, not just 22, are available.

Inacomp Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Prego Testifies She Is Feeling Better
description: Dr. Veronica Prego returned to the witness stand yesterday and told the jury in the two-month trial of her lawsuit that she was feeling better.

title: Chronicle
description: The Cesar awards, the French equivalent of the Oscars, this year went mostly to ''Too Beautiful for You.'' The story of a salesman who drops his beautiful wife for a passionate affair with his less-than-beautiful secretary, won five Cesars: for best film; for best director, BERTRAND BLIER; for best actress, CAROLE BOUQUET for editing and for best screenplay. PHILIPPE NOIRET was chosen best actor for ''Life and Nothing Else.'' ''Dangerous Liaisons,'' directed by a Briton, STEPHEN FREARS, was named best foreign film.

title: Volvo Accord With Renault
description: The chairman of Volvo A.B., the Swedish auto maker, said today that it could take until the mid-1990's for the fruits of its alliance with France's state-owned Renault to show up in the form of higher profits.

title: A.L. Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shifting Magnetism
description: Paleomagnetists have determined that the impact of the comet or asteroid that carved out the Bosumtwi crater in Ghana some 900,000 years ago was not responsible for a reversal of the Earth's magnetic field.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 27 about the Forbes publishing enterprise used an erroneous figure for Fortune in the comparison of three magazines' North American circulation. Fortune's figure through June 30 was 672,134, compared with 739,856 in North America for Forbes and 900,989 for Business Week.

title: Seeking Aid, Chamorro Advisers Present Economic Plan to Baker
description: Aides to the President-elect of Nicaragua, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, met today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to lay out an economic recovery plan, plead for United States aid and discuss a timetable for demobilizing the Nicaraguan guerrillas.

President of the Ivory Coast Rejects Democracy Demands
description: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, breaking a five-year public silence in the face of fierce opposition to his 30-year rule, today rejected demands for multiparty democracy and said he would use force to keep order.

title: As a Therapist, Freud Fell Short, Scholars Find
description: A NEW round of historical research on Sigmund Freud is challenging the legend that has long surrounded the founder of psychoanalysis.

title: Melamed Leaving as Head of Chicago Merc
description: Leo Melamed, whose leadership transformed the Chicago Mercantile Exchange from a sleepy backwater where mostly agricultural products were traded into a leading arena for the management of interest-rate and currency risks, announced today that he would relinquish his exchange duties at the end of the year.

title: Notes Issued By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, which generally issues short-term floating-rate notes each month, announced the pricing of a $500 million issue of these type of securities yesterday through various securities dealers.

title: Hamilton Digital Controls reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Music;   Siberian Daily Life, Performed as an Art
description: Poor Bela Bartok, when he wanted first-hand knowledge of the genuine folk music of his native Hungary early in the century, had to pack up his Edison phonograph and trek into the hinterlands. New Yorkers today can have substantial segments of authentic folk cultures from the other side of the globe transported into their midst, as with the Asia Society's current presentation of ''Siberian-American Music and Dance From the Island of Sakhalin, the Soviet Far East.''

title: McCaw Completes Bid For Rest of Lin's Stock
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had completed its $3.38 billion tender offer for 21.9 million shares of the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, extending its influence in the growing cellular telephone market.

title: Valvano Negotiates With N.C. State
description: North Carolina State University officials said today that a representative for Jim Valvano presented a resignation offer just hours before the basketball coach declared Sunday that the word resignation ''is not in my vocabulary.''

title: Wasps Enlisted to Fight Ticks That Spread Lyme Disease
description: MEMORIES of an old experiment in biological control here on Martha's Vineyard have led to an attempt to employ a wasp to help fight the spread of Lyme disease.

title: U.S. Seeking to Drop Bald Eagle From a Danger List
description: AFTER more than three decades of peril from pesticide pollution and destruction of its habitat, the bald eagle has made a comeback, and Federal officials are considering removing it from the endangered species list.

title: Kaifu Defends Trade Talks
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told Parliament today that his meeting with President Bush had produced ''very good results'' in reducing economic friction and was not a case of one-sided yielding to United States pressure on trade issues.

title: Chronicle
description: LYNNE V. CHENEY will be nominated to her second four-year term as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities by PRESIDENT BUSH. With a budget of $156.9 million, the endowment gives money to scholars and issues reports on the teaching of the humanities. In 1987, Ms. Cheney shocked educators and parents by exposing deep gaps in high school students' knowledge of history and literature.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

description: Darryl Strawberry worked out in public yesterday for the first time since he entered treatment for alcohol abuse on Feb. 3, but he declined to discuss his rehabilitation or his return to the Mets.

The impact was partially offset by normal year-end adjustments to inventories and expense accruals that increased pre-tax profit by $1.5 million, and raised net income by 11 cents a share. For the year, writedowns and charges totaled $6,086,000 before taxes, reducing net by 44 cents a share.

Year-ago quarter and prior year results restated for discontinued operations.

title: Study Raises Question of Cancer-Vasectomy Link
description: A SMALL study of men who had vasectomies has found that an unexpectedly large number later developed testicular cancer.

title: Mr. Dinkins Delays; the Poor Pay
description: There may be no more vivid symbol of social policy disaster than New York City's welfare hotels in the 1980's. Desperately poor mothers and children were consigned to squalor while grasping landlords collected luxury rents, all with the concurrence of City Hall. In his last term, under pressure from Washington, Mayor Edward Koch finally began phasing out the hotels, a program left for his successor, David Dinkins, to complete.

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $98,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $212,000.

description: The dollar dropped yesterday after a round of coordinated selling by central banks including the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan, the West German Bundesbank and eight other European central banks.

description: Gov. Jim Florio's auto insurance reform plan was passed by the State Assembly today and approved by an important Senate committee as well.

description: b-Reflected a $107,000 tax loss carryforward.

title: REFORM MAJORITIES LIKELY IN MOSCOW AND IN LENINGRAD
description: Independent Soviet pro-democracy groups today celebrated what appeared to be major gains in elections Sunday, including the election of several former political prisoners and the probability of gaining outright control of local governments in Moscow, Leningrad and some other cities.

title: Ferry's Plans Uncertain
description: Il Messaggero Roma said yesterday that the plans of its young American star, Danny Ferry, are still uncertain and that a final decision about an extension of Ferry's contract would be taken at the end of the regular season in May.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Spin Magazine Names A Publishing Director
description: Bob Guccione Jr., the editor and publisher of Spin, said the monthly rock-music magazine had hired John Skipper for the new position of publishing director and president. Mr. Skipper will relieve Mr. Guccione of much of the responsibility for the business side of the magazine, which plans to branch into a syndicated television program, a radio concert series and book publishing.

title: No Grand Turkish Alliance Looms on Horizon
description: To the Editor:

title: Rate Moves: No Firm Global Link
description: When interest rates go up in one major industrial country, must they also do so in others? The recent rise of West German, Japanese and American rates, in tandem, has given that impression. But plenty of room still exists for the United States to control its own interest rates, even going against the trend in other countries.

title: Crime Program Corners Suspect In Bronx Killing
description: A suspect in the killings of two New York City women surrendered to F.B.I. agents after being coaxed down from a rooftop where he frantically dared them to shoot him, the authorities said.

title: Review/Music;   Chamber Symphony Offers a Sense of Bigness
description: Europe's colonization of this country's classical music - long since undermined by the rise of popular culture and an alternative esthetic from the East - had its greatest influence on the American symphonic composers working in the first half of this century.

title: Air Midwest reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the loss in the fourth quarter to a significant reduction in traffic and excess capacity resulting from the downsizing of its Kansas City Hub after the bankruptcy filing in September by Braniff Inc.

description: * AM International Inc., Chicago, a design and printing systems company, announced the resignation of William Whitescarver as executive vice president and president of its AM Graphics Equipment Group.

title: April 2 Opener in Peril As Sides Review Issues
description: With virtually half of the games on the exhibition schedule canceled and the season openers in peril, negotiators in baseball's labor dispute reported no progress yesterday.

description: The rating on about $2 billion of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. subordinated debt was lowered to AA+ from triple-A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, reflecting what the rating agency termed as changes in the bank's capital structure.

title: Gallup Shifts Emphasis Toward Market Studies
description: The Gallup Organization, which helped invent the public opinion poll more than 50 years ago, is scaling down that business and taking on more market research instead, several current and former Gallup employees said.

description: There is some powerful dance being done today by black women to judge by ''Women in Dance III: African-American Women Choreographers,'' presented by the Thelma Hill Peforming Arts Center on Saturday night at the Majestic Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has agreed to a partnership with Promstroy Bank, the largest bank in the Soviet Union. The goal of the venture is the eventual opening of an office of D'Arcy Masius in Moscow.

title: An All-Out Player All of His Life;   Gathers, 'Like a 2d Coach,' Drove Himself and Others
description: Hank Gathers was only 23 years old when he collapsed in a West Coast Conference tournament game Sunday in Los Angeles and died less than two hours later at a nearby hospital.

title: Penny Stock Guilty Plea
description: A key target in a Federal securities investigation involving Meyer Blinder, founder of a penny stock brokerage, has pleaded guilty and agreed to testify for the Government.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS:Advertising;   Moves at Family Media
description: If, as it promises, Family Media Inc. restarts Taxi and Model magazines in the fall as controlled-circulation publications, the company will do so with an almost entirely new staff. Departing staff members at the magazines said several dozen people were dismissed last week. Only Mary Peacock, Model's editor in chief, and Sharri Jurmain, Model's publisher, have been retained for the new magazines, said Eileen Koslow, Family Media's promotions director.

title: GROWING CRITICISM FOR CLEAN AIR BILL
description: Governors Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Jim Florio of New Jersey today criticized the clean air bill offered as a compromise last week by Senate leaders and the Bush Administration, saying it would impede their ability to fight air pollution.

title: Bill to Seek $500 Million in AIDS Disaster Funds
description: Within days after an earthquake struck the San Francisco area on Oct. 17, killing 67 people, President Bush flew to the scene and Congress agreed to send more than $3 billion in emergency relief. In the same city, 5,000 people have died of AIDS without any such dramatic Federal response.

title: By Design;   The Long Look in Jackets
description: The longer jacket. Is it really a jacket? Or is it akin to a coat? Perhaps it can even replace a dress. The length of some of the newest spring jackets, ending anywhere from well under the derriere to mid-thigh, makes them all of these.

title: Coca Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the $1.7 million increase in net income over 1988 came from record gold production at its California mines.
