title: Hungary Confident on Debt Payment
description: Although Hungary has the highest per capita debt burden in Eastern Europe, the president of the nation's central bank proudly says the Government is against rescheduling its $20.7 billion foreign debt.

title: First Fidelity Cuts 1,400 Jobs
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation announced plans yesterday to cut its work force by about 10 percent, or 1,400 workers, as part of a plan to reduce its expenses by $115 million a year.

title: Correction Panel Approves Double-Bunking of Inmates in New York
description: Despite forecasts of deadly prison uprisings and an emotional plea from a recently attacked corrections officer, the State Commission of Correction today approved a new policy of double-bunking at the state's medium-security prisons.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Saturday about the baseball labor dispute reversed the positions of the two sides on roster size in some copies. The owners want 24 players per team; the players want 25.

title: Pittway Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago figures were restated to reflect the merger of Pittway into Standard Shares Inc. in December 1989; the surviving company assumed the Pittway name.

title: Mexico Picks Cellular Bids
description: The Mexican Government announced last night that it had awarded the first three of eight cellular-telephone service franchises covering the country outside of Mexico City and that several American companies are involved.

title: Clean Air, Common Sense
description: President Bush got more than he asked for. Environmentalists got less than they hoped for. George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, got as much as he bargained for. Nobody in Washington is entirely happy with the compromise clean air bill worked out last week in the Senate. But it may well mark the end of a decade of legislative paralysis, and in that case there's one sure winner: the breathing public.

title: Northgate Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Shirt Shed Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Lilco Bonuses Attacked
description: The Long Island Power Authority filed a petition today asking the New York State Public Service Commission to rescind bonuses and other benefits granted to officials of the Long Island Lighting Company this year. In its petition the power authority asked the commission to cancel $600,000 in bonuses paid to Lilco executives in 1988 and 1989, and to investigate the company's compensation practices. It was disclosed last week that Lilco's chairman, Dr. William A. Catacosinos, had been given a 10-year retirement package worth $5 million. But Joseph D. McDonnell, a spokesman for Lilco, said the commission had already approved the bonuses.

title: Becker Withdraws From Davis Cup Match
description: Boris Becker, the Wimbledon and United States Open champion, yesterday pulled out of West Germany's Davis Cup match with Argentina.

title: Marver Bernstein Is Fire Victim; Former Brandeis Leader Was 71
description: Dr. Marver H. Bernstein, a retired president of Brandeis University and a Jewish lay leader, and his wife, Sheva, were killed last Thursday in a fire at the Heliopolis Sheraton Hotel outside Cairo. He was 71 years old, and she was 69. They lived in Washington and Jerusalem.

title: Rooney's Return Dominates Ratings
description: Sunday's installment of ''60 Minutes'' on CBS - which included the return of Andy Rooney after a three-week suspension - exceeded the combined audience of ABC and NBC, according to preliminary ratings released yesterday by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: M/I Schottenstein Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cape Town Death-Squad Inquiry Opens
description: A secret South African military unit suspected of killing opponents of apartheid planned at one time to replace the heart pills of Nelson Mandela's lawyer with tablets designed to induce a heart attack, judicial investigators were told today.

title: Research On Noise Disappears In the Din
description: AMERICA is noisier than ever, audiologists say, and the costs may include lost hearing, impaired health, reduced learning ability and antisocial behavior.

title: Gandalf Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: The company said the latest periods included a $4,253,000 writedown on investments. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Autopsy On Gathers Will Not Be Released Soon
description: An explanation of why Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball star, collapsed and died Sunday night during the championship game of the West Coast Conference tournament, will not be known for at least a week.

title: DH Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Doskocil Files Under Chapter 11
description: The Doskocil Companies said today that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture yesterday showing Nelson Mandela shaking hands carried an incorrect caption in some editions. He was being greeted as he arrived for a visit in Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe.

title: Urban Gonnoud, 70, Franciscan Brother And a College Head
description: Brother Urban Gonnoud, a member of the Order of St. Francis and a former teacher and president of St. Francis College in Brooklyn, died of heart failure on Saturday at the college faculty residence where he lived. He was 70 years old.

title: Group Warns of Lead Poisoning
description: An environmental group said yesterday that one-third of the young children in the New York metropolitan area have dangerous levels of lead in their blood, but a city health official responded that the figure is greatly overstated.

title: Charles H. Foster, 77, A University Official
description: Charles Harman Foster, a former vice chancellor of the State University of New York, died of leukemia on Sunday at St. Peter's Hospice in Albany. He was 77 years old and lived in Delmar, N.Y.

title: Israeli Party Sets Terms for Palestinian Talks
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and the leaders of his Likud Party agreed early this morning to open talks with Palestinians over the future of the Israeli-occupied territories, but only if the Labor Party agreed to two difficult stipulations.

title: Datamag Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Whitney Trustees Dismiss the Museum's Director
description: Ending a long struggle between the Whitney Museum's trustees and its director, Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the board voted yesterday to dismiss Mr. Armstrong from the position he had held for 15 years.

title: La Salle Is M.A.A.C. Champion
description: Playing with the name and uniform number of their friend Hank Gathers marked on their sneakers, Lionel Simmons and his fellow La Salle Explorers came from behind to beat a determined but tired Fordham team and win their third consecutive Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference championship, 71-61.

title: High Court Voids Provision In North Carolina Death Law
description: The Supreme Court today invalidated a provision of North Carolina's death penalty law, ruling 6 to 3 that it unconstitutionally limited jurors' ability to fully consider evidence favorable to defendants.

title: Begin at the Beginning
description: ''A COMPUTER is not some sort of supernatural, super-intelligent, all-mighty machine poised to take over the world. A computer cannot think for itself; it can only follow instructions. It is not capable of suddenly deciding that it would like to have an ice cream cone, or of feeling the desire to take a long vacation on some sunny island beach. It can, however, follow instructions and perform predefined tasks at an amazingly high rate: a million or so instructions per second.''

title: Medstone International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the year was after an extraordinary gain from operating loss carryforward of $894,000, or 22 cents a share.

title: 3 Officers Shot, One Fatally, in Lower East Side Drug Deal
description: A State Police officer was shot dead and two city detectives were wounded in a hail of gunfire on Manhattan's Lower East Side yesterday when two suspects in a $42,000 cocaine deal tried to rob an undercover officer.

title: Belzbergs Seeking Armstrong Suitor
description: The Belzberg family of Canada said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had begun to seek third parties who might be interested in acquiring Armstrong World Industries, the Lancaster, Pa., interior furnishing concern.

title: Campaign Finance;   Moves for Unity on Spending Lead Parties Into Divisions
description: Campaign finance reform is not only pitting Democrats against Republicans but also dividing Democratic Congressional leaders and state and national leaders.

title: Lincoln Center's Theater Team Looks Back
description: What's happening at Lincoln Center Theater? What's happened to the folks who two seasons ago gave us the successful revival of the 1930's Cole Porter musical ''Anything Goes,'' the hit South African musical ''Sarafina!'' and David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow'' with Madonna on Broadway, and who last season brought us the Tony Award-winning revival of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' at the Lyceum Theater?

title: Can't Tell the Players Without a Ledger
description: LEAD: I was reading in The Columbus Dispatch a profile of a man, of whom it was said, ''He is a Cincinnati Reds fan.'' I was struck by how quaint that phrase sounded.

title: Selection of Jurors Is Started for Trial of Poindexter
description: Jury selection started today in the trial of John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser accused of concealing the Reagan Administration's actions in the Iran-contra affair from Congress.

title: International Microcomputer Software Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: An 18-year-old Queens student took a sawed-off shotgun to school yesterday morning and fired two shells that sent pellets ricocheting through a stairwell, wounding another student and a teacher, the police said.

title: Political Unrest Abroad Raises Oil-Supply Fears
description: Political unrest and food riots shaking major oil-producing countries, including the Soviet Union and some OPEC nations, may lead to significant worldwide oil shortages in this decade.

title: A $1 MILLION FUND TAPPED BY RITTER TO MAKE 4 LOANS
description: Covenant House officials said yesterday that the Rev. Bruce Ritter set up a trust fund of nearly $1 million to benefit runaway youths but that part of the fund was used to make loans to two Covenant House board members.

title: United Brands Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Fourth quarter 1989 results included a special charge of 56 cents a share relating to the closing of certain meat packaging facilities and relocation of operating and administrative offices. This special charge more than offset a previously reported third quarter 49 cents a share gain from the sale of the company's interest in FII-Fyffes.

title: U.S. Remarks On Hostages And Rumors
description: Following are excerpts from a briefing by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, today on reports of efforts to gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon. It was provided by Federal News Service, a transcription company.

title: Bush Said to Have Chosen Interim Savings Regulator
description: President Bush plans to name an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury who has a reputation as a tough enforcement official and strong manager as an interim successor to M. Danny Wall, the nation's top Federal regulator of the savings and loan associations, Administration officials said today.

title: Debut of Commercials on School TV Renews Debate on Programs' Value
description: The camera pans the Berlin wall as the narrator discusses the divided city and the outbreak of the cold war.

title: Mail Boxes Etc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,686,000 from settlement of litigation for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income Share earnings reflected 3-for-2 stock split paid in October 1989.

title: Notebook;   Tourney's Stars Quickly Lose Luster
description: If you are a tournament director in search of a star-studded field for a $250,000 tennis event and you have an extra $400,000 to offer in appearance fees, these days it is not so tough to sign up the top names: money continues to be a great communicator.

description: b-Net income

title: Again, Palestinians Suffer
description: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's remark that a ''big Israel'' needed the occupied Palestinian territories to settle a large number of incoming Soviet Jews has stirred a furor inside and outside the Middle East. One result has been the Government's misguided effort to censor news reports on the emigres that originate in Israel.

title: Nonmedical Workers Strike Jamaica Hospital
description: About 600 nonmedical workers - including nurses' aides and cleaning and clerical employees - went on strike yesterday at Jamaica Hospital and its Trump Pavilion for Nursing and Rehabilitation.

title: Key Official at Witco Gets Top-Level Position
description: The Witco Corporation, a $1.6 billion specialty chemicals and petroleum company, yesterday named a new president and chief operating officer, Denis Andreuzzi, to succeed Thomas J. Bickett, who resigned last week for what the company said were personal reasons.

title: Cleveland Expert Hired To Run New York Jails
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Allyn R. Sielaff, who has headed the prison systems of four states, to be New York City's Correction Commissioner, in charge of nearly 21,000 inmates in overcrowded jails.

title: Chesapeake Utilities Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Dash Industries reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $75,158, or 1 cent a share.

title: Kinder-Care Learning Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included pretax charges of $2,615,000 related to closing of centers, and $6 million related to liquidation of investment portfolio for the quarter and the year included total pretax charges of $25 million related to liquidation of investment portfolio. c-Net income d-Included a pretax charge of $4 million for permanent impairment of certain investment securities for both the quarter and year.

title: Stocks Retreat as Dow Falls 10.81 Points
description: A five-day-long rise in stock prices was cut short yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.81 points to finish at 2,649.55 in light trading. Traders blamed a rise in bond yields, a decline in the dollar and some profit taking for the shift.

title: Arrow Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $13,463,000, or $1.17 a share, which included $7,791,000, or 68 cents a share, gain on sale of operations. Share earnings are after payment of preferred dividends.

title: Berkley (W.R.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 results were restated to reflect FASB Statement No. 97, effective Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Algorex Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary tax credits of $232,000, or 8 cents a share for the quarter and $300,000, or 11 cents a share for the 6 months. The latest periods' losses from continuing operations included $150,000 charge for closing of two remote design centers. Year-ago quarter and 6 months income from continuing operations both included $915,000 pretax gain on the sale of a building.

title: No Grand Turkish Alliance Looms on Horizon;   What 'Ethnic' Conveys
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Shortfall in Corporate Taxes Thwarts Key Goal of 1986 Law
description: Corporate income taxes have produced much less revenue than was predicted when the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 was enacted, and individuals have made up the shortfall.

title: Compaq Computer
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said it had made a small equity investment in Nexgen Microsystems, a company in San Jose, Calif., that is working on a clone of the Intel Corporation's 80386 microprocessor. This is the microprocessor at the heart of most Compaq computers, and it is available only from Intel. Nexgen is developing a four-chip module that it says is compatible with the 80386, but faster. While Nexgen plans to use the module in its own computer systems, it may also make it available to other personal computer manufacturers.

title: Top Suppliers of Weaponry
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is still the nation's biggest military contractor, but Tenneco Inc. has plummeted from fourth to 21st on the Defense Department's list of arms suppliers, the Pentagon said today.

title: Comptronix Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $140,000, or 2 cents a share. The company said its 1989 third and fourth quarter earnings reflected the loss of a major disk drive industry customer.

title: Fairmount Chemcial Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ICM Property Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Rig Count Slips a Bit
description: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs dipped by three this week, to a total of 894, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The year-to-date count remains well ahead of the 1989 tally, however, when 761 rigs were working. Traditionally, the rig count declines in the first quarter of the year. Baker Hughes's rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rotary rigs exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday.

title: Synthetech Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
Book Notes
description: Trimming New Titles

title: Future of Labor Is Seen in Bus Strike
description: Labor specialists say moves by Greyhound Lines to replace its striking union drivers with newly hired personnel have demonstrated again that employers believe they can take the upper hand in labor disputes by threatening strikers with losing their jobs.

title: Fahnestock Viner Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bennington Journal;   Is the Statehood Honeymoon Over?
description: In 1791, Vermont patriots gathered here, voting to join the union as the 14th state. Almost two centuries later, in a pristine clapboard church a few yards from the site where that historic decision was made, an assembly of Vermonters voted by a 2-to-1 margin to secede from the United States.

title: Reviews/Music;   Racial Stereotypes Blur at a Ritz Hip-Hop Show
description: Friday night's hip-hop show at the Ritz was both bizarre and a self-affirming party. The group Third Bass, which headlined the concert, is white in a genre overwhelmingly black; backed by a supportive, racially mixed audience, it crashed stereotypes. And the audience coalesced in a show of real community.

title: First City Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $123.7 million, or $2.29 a share, from gain on sale of interest in Cantel Inc. The 1988 year was restated. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Fugitive Bensonhurst Witness Hid Near Syracuse
description: John S. Vento, the witness in the Bensonhurst murder case who surrendered on Monday in Ohio after a two-month disappearance, spent much of his time living in the Syracuse area, a brother, Michael, said yesterday.

title: Punch Account to Ayer
description: The Proctor & Gamble Company, which acquired Hawaiian Punch from Del Monte in January for $150 million, has assigned the advertising account for the beverage brand to Ayer, New York. The brand has not been advertised much of late, as Del Monte had emphasized promotions.

title: Gephardt Proposes Aid to Soviets
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said today that the United States should offer direct aid to the Soviet Union to insure that its reforms succeed.

title: Government Eases Penalties for Private Pilots
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has said it will loosen its mandatory penalties on private pilots who violate certain safety rules.

title: Champion Parts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $510,000, or 14 cents a share, from an accounting change. c-Net income d-Included an extraordinary credit of $99,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: For Later Presidential Primaries;   Democrat Death Wish
description: To the Editor:

title: Potash Corp. Saskatchewan reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company was not public a year earlier. The latest fourth-quarter per- share figure was not immediately available. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pacificorp Presses Fight for Pinnacle
description: Pacificorp said it would continue its courtship of the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation despite the Arizona utility company's rejection of a sweetened $1.7 billion takeover offer. Pinnacle West announced Monday that its board had rejected the offer by Pacificorp, an electricity and telecommunications company based in Portland, Ore., saying it was subject to a number of conditions that sharply reduced its value.

title: Vincent J. Commisa, Judge, 68
description: Vincent J. Commisa, Chief Judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: AAR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Manila Court Frees Aquino Opponent on Bail
description: Senator Juan Ponce Enrile had accommodated himself pretty well to the week he has spent in confinement on charges of complicity in the December coup against President Corazon C. Aquino. He has spent that time in a two-room air-conditioned apartment, filled with friends, political supporters and a maid to keep things tidy.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Elders Sells Stake In British Brewer
description: Elders IXL Ltd., the Australian brewer, sold a 23 percent stake in Scottish & Newcastle Breweries P.L.C. at a big loss last week. Elders, which makes Foster's lager and controls the Courage chain of pubs in Britain, had hoped to become a leading European brewer after buying the Edinburgh-based company.

title: Dry Spell In 2d Half Is Costly To Knicks
description: Stu Jackson, the Knick coach, looking to put more scoring punch into the second unit, made his first starting-lineup change of the season last night. He moved Trent Tucker, his best shooter, to the starting back court, and demoted Gerald Wilkins to the second team.

title: Howe Let Into Minors
description: Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, said yesterday that he would allow Steve Howe, the left-handed relief pitcher who was suspended from major league baseball four times from 1983 to 1988 for using illegal drugs, to play minor league baseball in 1990. The commissioner added that Howe would continue to be barred from the big leagues until 1991. Vincent met with the 31-year-old Howe on Feb. 8 to consider a request for reinstatement.

title: 'Shopping' With a Fish Pole: Putting Food on the Plate Yourself
description: THE setting could not have been more spectacular: snow-capped volcanoes, glacial lakes and a river so clear it shimmered in the summer sunshine like glass.

title: Contras Accuse the Sandinistas Of Opening a New Military Drive
description: Amid signs that Nicaragua's President-elect has ceased pressing for the immediate demobilization of the Nicaraguan rebels, contra leaders here charged today that the Nicaraguan Government had broken a self-imposed cease-fire and mounted offensive military operations.

title: Japan's Chip Market
description: Foreign companies increased their share of Japan's semiconductor market to a record 12.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989, a Japanese official said today. The figure is nine-tenths of a percentage point higher than the third quarter of 1989 and 2.3 points higher than the fourth quarter of 1988, the Ministry of Trade and Industry official said, quoting figures of World Semiconductor Trade Statistics, a private group. Fourth-quarter sales by foreign chip makers, primarily United States companies, were worth $614 million, up from $569 million in the third quarter, he added.

title: Broadcast TV Revenue
description: Broadcast television advertising revenue totaled $21.35 billion in 1989, up 3.6 percent from 1988, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday. Network revenue fell two-tenths of a percent, to $9.56 billion. Local television advertising rose 4.5 percent, to $5.08 billion, and spot television rose 2.3 percent, to $5.42 billion. National syndication advertising rose 42.9 percent, to $1.29 billion.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Where Nazis Took Fierce Revenge, French Hatred for Germans Recedes
description: Anyone native to this southwestern French town can identify the lampposts and metal terraces near the railroad station where 99 local men were hanged by Nazi stormtroopers on June 9, 1944, in reprisal for the killings of 40 Germans by Resistance fighters.

title: Eating Well
description: FINDING a diet book that is practical, safe and accurate is far more difficult than it should be, given the large number published each year, as difficult as finding that rich, luscious, nonfattening dessert. Books promising instant success for losing weight or lowering cholesterol appear regularly on best-seller lists. But for the most part, they don't work, at least not in the long run. Once the book is purchased, the diet tried and failed, it's on to the next best seller and promises of a new road to instant success.

title: Long Meeting Is Short on Progress
description: With the opening of the season at stake, negotiators in baseball's labor dispute staged their first night ''game'' of the spring last night. When their meeting ended early this morning more than six hours after it had begun, they remained deadlocked over the salary-arbitration eligibility issue.

title: Seoul and North Korea Spar Over Tunnel Under the DMZ
description: President Roh Tae Woo attacked North Korea today over a tunnel found under the border between the countries, and he said Pyongyang was risking its own destruction.

title: G.M.A.C. President Started at the Bottom
description: William J. Lovejoy got his start with the General Motors Acceptance Corporation repossessing cars in Brooklyn 28 years ago. Yesterday, he was named president of the giant financing organization.

title: For Later Presidential Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Left at the Altar: Modern Tale of Woe
description: BACK in the days of chaperones and curfews, of vigilant fathers and chaste brides, and of couples smooching on porch swings, engagements offered many a young man and woman the chance to get to know each other better and in greater privacy. And more often than most people admitted, they didn't like what they found, and the engagement ended in tears, recriminations and sometimes a huge bill for a wedding never held.

title: Food Notes
description: Peanut Butter at 100

title: 2 Hired at First Boston
description: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Michael J. Kugler as a managing director and head of its government securities business. Mr. Kugler, who is 49 years old, had run the government securities operations of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the collapsed brokerage firm. He has worked in the securities industry for 30 years. First Boston said he would replace David Bunting, 47, who is retiring. The company also said it has hired Pendleton King from Salomon Brothers to be a managing director and national sales manager for its domestic fixed-income products.

title: Leak Brings Shutdown at Three Mile Island
description: Workers at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant began shutting down the Unit 1 reactor today after plant monitors detected higher-than-normal amounts of radioactivity being vented into the atmosphere.

title: Afghans Report Crushing Official's Coup Attempt
description: The Government of Afghanistan said today that it had crushed a coup attempt by the Defense Minister after a day of heavy fighting in which rebel forces attacked the Presidential palace in Kabul from the air and engaged loyalist forces around the capital city.

title: Dataram Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Korea in Uranium Pact
description: The South Korean Government approved a plan on Monday that would allow the state-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation to import enriched uranium from the Soviet Union for nuclear power plants, an official said. The decision cleared the way for South Korea and the Soviet Union, which have no diplomatic relations, to begin cooperation in nuclear power. The power company will import 40 tons of uranium each year for 10 years.

title: A First N.C.A.A. Berth for Towson State
description: Towson State earned its first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament berth, defeating Lehigh, 73-60, tonight in the championship game of the East Coast Conference tournament.

title: Conservative Wins Senate Confirmation As an Appeals Judge
description: The Senate today confirmed Clarence Thomas, a conservative civil rights official, to be a Federal appeals judge, brushing aside complaints about his record from some groups representing liberals and the elderly.

title: New Savings Regulator
description: President Bush today named an Assistant Treasury Secretary, Salvatore R. Martoche, as acting director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the agency that regulates the nation's savings and loan institutions. Advance notice of the interim appointment was given by Administration officials on Monday. Mr. Martoche will temporarily fill the vacancy created by the resignation in December of M. Danny Wall, who quit under criticism from members of Congress for his handling of the savings and loan crisis in his two-and-a-half-year tenure.

title: U.S.D.A. Reverses Ruling on 'Range' On Chicken Label
description: AFTER a 30-day legal battle and lobbying effort, the United States Department of Agriculture has reversed itself and will permit Bart Ehman, a chicken rancher in Sebastopol, Calif., to use the label ''Rocky the Range Chicken'' on the birds he has been raising and selling in the western United States for five years.

title: Accel International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $20,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $117,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year, and the year also included a $172,000 gain, after taxes, on the final sale of Accel's investment in United Coasts Corp. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $74,000, or 2 cents a share, and $107,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Continental Dropout
description: Citing an ''unresolvable'' potential conflict with a client, Mexicana Airlines, the J. Walter Thompson Company has withdrawn from the competition for the Continental Airlines account. The other contenders are Hal Riney & Partners, Lintas, TBWA and Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Bowmar Instrument Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: Edgar R. Lorch, 82, A Leader in Building Mathematics Theory
description: Dr. Edgar Raymond Lorch, an author and a leader in the development of modern mathematics theory, died on Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Spy Plane Sets Speed Record, Then Retires
description: One of America's premier spy planes, the SR-71 Blackbirds, had a final fling with the history books today, setting a transcontinental speed record before retiring to a museum home.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The acting Redgraves plan an onstage reunion in Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' with VANESSA and LYNN REDGRAVE, who are sisters, joining Vanessa Redgrave's daughter JOELY RICHARDSON. The sisters have never performed together publicly. Ms. Richardson, 24 years old, appeared in the film ''Wetherby'' with her mother.

title: Reviews/Music;   Of Schoenberg and Emptying Seats
description: The former regime of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center invited patrons to vote on the repertory they most wanted to hear. No poll was announced at the society's concert in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening, but with works by Beethoven, Barber, Milton Babbitt and Elliott Carter on the first half of the program and only Schoenberg's Serenade (Op. 24) on the second, many members of the audience voted with their feet, leaving at intermission.

title: Covenant House: Loyalty or Leadership?
description: Like Jonah, the Rev. Bruce Ritter last week threw himself over the side to try to quell a storm and save a vessel: Covenant House, the shelter for runaway adolescents. But Father Ritter's action may turn out to have been in vain. He waited too long and, when he did resign, he refused to make a clean break.

title: Rossell H. Robbins, 77, Ex-Professor at SUNY
description: Rossell Hope Robbins, retired International Professor of English at the State University of New York at Albany, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Saugerties, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Reviews/Music;   Important but Hard Music in a Town House
description: The Ukrainian Institute of America opened its Chamber Music at the Institute series by investing a luxurious level of performing talent in some difficult and important music. Performers like Vladimir Feltsman, the pianist, are more familiar in big halls attended by way of high-priced tickets, but here he was with four other splendid if not quite so celebrated musicians, playing in a town house ballroom on the Upper East Side. The music was by Schnittke, Ives, Mahler and the Ukrainian composer Myroslav Skoryk.

title: Lukens Hires Outsider; Management Is Shifted
description: Lukens Inc. announced a realignment of manufacturing and administrative responsibilities yesterday, coinciding with the naming of a president and chief operating officer at the Coatesville, Pa., company.

title: Gathers Eulogized In a Mass at Loyola
description: Hank Gathers, the star of the Loyola Marymount basketball team who died Sunday, was remembered today as a gregarious student athlete and a promising National Basketball Association prospect who played the game with agility and strength.

title: In Miami, Satellite Schools Rate High
description: Never mind that the Concorde is landing outside the window of Thomasine Morris's class on arithmetic. That happens every Tuesday and Friday at the Miami International Airport Satellite Learning Center, where 60 children of airport workers are enrolled in kindergarten and first grade.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: PEOPLE who own microwave ovens are often asked by friends, ''Do you use that thing much?'' Notice they do not even use the term ''cook.'' The answers will vary depending on how the owner uses the oven. Some use it for everything because they like the coolness and easy cleanup as much as the speed, while others make only certain foods that are quicker or better when made in the microwave oven, including vegetables and fish. Still others use the microwave oven to help make stocks and blanch vegetables needed in other recipes, and there are those who confess with hanging head that they use it only for reheating coffee and popping corn.

title: Pangloss Flies Again
description: Arrive at airport. Pay for ticket. Everybody so happy-happy. ''Great to have you flying with us today.'' Friendly-skies type chatter.

title: Goldman's 'Junk Bond' Shift
description: In another indication of weakness in the ''junk bond'' market, investment bankers at Goldman, Sachs & Company recently told executives of the Georgia Gulf Corporation that the investment bank would act only as the agent, and not as the underwriter, on a proposed offering of $200 million in notes.

title: Books of The Times;   Fictional and Factual Views On the Future of China
description: Heavy Wings

title: Kysor Industrial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included fourth quarter writedown of goodwill and other intangible assets of $4,219,000, accrued other restructuring costs of $2.1 million, and accrued environmental costs of $1,212,000. The charges totaled $7,531,000. c-Net income

title: Bank Law Reform for Panama and for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene L. Harmon, 62, Former Sears Executive
description: Gene L. Harmon, retired vice president of corporate public affairs for Sears, Roebuck and Company, died of a heart attack Saturday while traveling from Palm Springs, Calif., to his home in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 62 years old.

title: General Cinema reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $6,956,000, or 9 cents a share. Year-ago fourth quarter's income from continuing operations included an after-tax gain of $34.6 million from the sale of securities.

title: Market Place;   Looking Beyond The Debt Burden
description: AS the fallout from the heady days of overleveraging continues, investors have abandoned the stocks of many companies with high levels of debt on their balance sheets.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALAN GREENSPAN, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, turned 64 years old yesterday. To celebrate, he invited three other Washington figures with the same birthday to lunch in his private dining room at the Fed. They were THOMAS S. FOLEY, the Speaker of the House, who is 61; WILLIAM H. WEBSTER, the Director of Central Intelligence, who is 66, and SENATOR CHRISTOPHER S. BOND, Republican of Missouri, who is 51. They had a chocolate cake with orange icing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a $50 million gift from Walter H. Annenberg to the United Negro College Fund omitted a word in some copies from a reference to his gifts to the University of Pennsylvania. He has given more than $300 million to the university's schools of communication and performing arts.

title: Disarm Nicaragua
description: It is not just a clash of wills but stubborn history that clouds the promise of Nicaragua's election. The losing Sandinistas now growl that even in defeat they cannot hand over control of the armed forces and security police to a new government. And despite Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's victory, contra rebels are scorning pleas to disband. Unless both sides back down, there won't be a peaceful democratic transition on April 25, but instead a renewed civil war.

title: Explosion Kills 3 and Injures 14 at Colorado Bank
description: An explosion destroyed a two-story bank in the downtown section of this western Colorado ski resort this morning, killing three people and injuring 14, three of them critically.

title: Finevest Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax provision of $10,675,000 for restructuring dairy operations. c-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We'll see who in the state of Israel wants peace and who doesn't.''

title: Review/Concert;   New and Rare Works by Americans
description: The National Orchestral Association lost much of its reason for being when music schools began to offer the kinds of orchestra training for young musicians this organization initiated 60 years ago. Now the association is enjoying a reincarnation born of new needs. One of them is ensemble training on a postgraduate level. Another is performing unknown music by living American composers and doing so under a different name, the New Music Orchestral Project.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: I.R.S. Issues Summonses to Defense Lawyers
description: The Internal Revenue Service has served summonses on criminal defense lawyers around the country, demanding that they reveal the names of clients who paid large fees with cash, an official of the agency said today.

title: Changes at Intergroup Proposed by Centaur
description: The Centaur Partners Group made two proposals yesterday that would ease its effort to win control of the board of National Intergroup Inc., the troubled Pittsburgh-based holding company with interests in drug distribution and steel.

title: Espey Manufacturing & Elecronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Postal Service Proposes Rate Increases
description: The United States Postal Service today proposed an increase in all classes of mail that would raise the price of a first-class stamp to 30 cents and increase costs to businesses for second- and third-class mailings by billions of dollars a year.

title: Time Warner to Help Build Theaters in Soviet Union
description: Time Warner Inc. today announced a joint venture with the Soviet film industry for the construction of movie theaters in Moscow and Leningrad.

title: Bridge
description: Thumbs are particularly useful for those who read bridge columns, since they make it easy to reproduce the realities of play when only half the cards are in view. Please place yours over the East-West cards shown in the diagram - or, if you prefer, place two pieces of paper -and plan the play in six clubs after a spade lead.

title: 4 Cleared for Pro Draft
description: Four players, including Keith McCants, the junior linebacker from Alabama who has been projected as a possible No. 1 choice, have become the first underclassmen granted permission by the National Football League to enter the 1990 college draft.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Nicaragua to End Restraints On Press, Ortega Announces
description: Acceding to opposition demands, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced today that the Nicaraguan Government intends to repeal the country's press law, long condemned by critics of the ruling Sandinista Front as an unconstitutional restraint on freedom of expression here.

title: Gary Merrill, Actor, Dies at 74; Worked in More Than 40 Films
description: Gary Merrill, a ruggedly handsome actor who appeared in more than 40 films as well as many plays and television shows, died of lung cancer on Monday at his home in Falmouth, Me. He was 74 years old.

title: Ceradyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that the profit in the fourth quarter 1989 was due to a $1,250,000 gain on the sale of its subsidiary, Ceradyne Specialty Products Inc., and a reduced loss from continuing operations. The fourth quarter 1988 net loss included significant asset writedowns relating to the reduced level of defense-related business and the establishment of reserves relating to product and facility consolidations.

title: U.S. Plans to Shift Responsibility For Many Road Pojects to States
description: The Bush Administration is drafting highway legislation that would concentrate Federal spending on major national arteries, while imposing on the states costly new responsibilities for building and maintaining local roads.

title: Studies Cause Confusion on Impact of Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: New research on teen-age mothers has produced seemingly contradictory results and created confusion and concern among those working to prevent teen-age pregnancy.

title: Selma 1990: Old Faces and a New Spirit
description: The writer of the following article, a reporter for The New York Times from 1955 to 1965, was among those covering the civil rights march in Selma, Ala., in 1965.

title: Pop Life
description: Simon Looks Back

title: Police Bullets Hit Detectives, Officials Say
description: The bullets that wounded two detectives during an undercover drug deal in Manhattan on Monday came from their own guns or the gun of a third officer, high-ranking police officials said privately yesterday.

title: Royal Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Preferred-share dividends were $23,836,000 versus $14,499,000. The year-earlier quarter included an after-tax amount of $40 million of past due interest from Brazil. The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: 5 Die in Mexican Crackdown
description: The police broke up opposition party demonstrations at eight city halls in Guerrero state today, and at least three police officers and two activists were killed, government and party officials said. The center-left Democratic Revolutionary Party had paralyzed 20 of the southwestern state's 75 city governments for three months, protesting alleged fraud in Dec. 3 elections. Government officials said about 200 state policemen and cadets were called out to remove 350 people.

title: CNA Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter is after an investment loss of $3,235,000 and the year included an investment gain of $192,804,000. The year-ago quarter and year included investment gains of $50,955,000 and $255,969,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Reviews/Music;   Satori Quintet In a Collection Of Rare Works
description: The Satori Wind Quintet put together a program of rarities for its New York debut concert on Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. For the most part, the works were of greater interest than the playing, which was consistently enthusiastic but not always well tuned, and at times slightly shrill.

title: Japan Backs Bank Merger
description: Japan's Finance Ministry today approved the merger of Mitsui Bank Ltd. and Taiyo Kobe Bank Ltd., paving the way for the establishment in April of the second-largest bank in Japan as measured by deposits.

title: Saudi Gave to Anti-Drug Program
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia donated $1 million to Nancy Reagan's anti-drug campaign in 1985 while the Reagan Administration was considering a request from his country to buy surveillance aircraft, a former White House official said today.

title: Workers End Hospital Strike
description: A strike by 600 nonmedical workers at Jamaica Hospital in Queens ended yesterday after a day and a half when the employees ratified a new three-year contract. James McNeila, the hospital's vice president for support services, said the walkout by nurses' aides and cleaning and clerical employees had not affected patient care at the 317-bed hospital and its 204-bed nursing home wing, at the Van Wyck Expressway and 89th Avenue. Joe Walker, a union spokesman, said the agreement provides a total wage increase of 19.5 percent.

title: Wang to Sell Unit To Reduce Debt
description: Financially troubled Wang Laboratories Inc., the computer-maker based in Lowell, Mass., said it would sell its Intecom Inc. subsidiary, a maker of communication switching systems, to the French electronics company Matra S.A. for an undisclosed price. Proceeds from the transaction will further reduce the computer company's debt and increase its cash, Wang officials said.

title: Women's College Struggles to Keep Its Identity
description: The official T-shirt of the small liberal arts college here reads: ''Mills College: Not a girls' school without men, but a women's college without boys.''

title: Why Polls Flopped In Nicaragua . . .
description: LEAD: The election of Violeta de Barrios Chamorro as President of Nicaragua left lots of U.S. pollsters and pundits with egg on their faces. And with a slew of elections coming up soon in Eastern Europe and other parts of the world, we could end up repeating our mistakes worldwide.

title: Accounts
description: * Old Tyme Soft Drinks Inc., to Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Co. with a budget of $1.8 million.

title: Upheaval in the East;   BONN CABINET ACTS TO REASSURE POLES ON BORDER POLICY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition Government reached agreement today on steps to reassure Warsaw that a future Germany will accept Poland's western border.

title: President of Whitney Foresees New Emphasis on Scholarship
description: Following the dismissal on Monday of Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, director of the Whitney Museum of American Art for 15 years, the museum's president, William S. Woodside, said yesterday that the Whitney's ''emphasis will be more heavily on scholarship than on quickie show-and-tell operations.''

title: A Robot That Can Handle the Office Vacuuming
description: A Canadian inventor has developed a robot that can vacuum office buildings and industrial areas without assistance.

title: Two Players Suspended
description: For biting and scratching each other in a fight on Feb. 27, Dave Manson of the Chicago Black Hawks and Scott Stevens of the Washington Capitals were suspended for three games by the National Hockey League yesterday. Manson, who was suspended for 13 games earlier this season, was also fined $500 by Brian O'Neill, the N.F.L. vice president.

title: British 'Quality' Paper Finds New Financing
description: The combatants in Britain's ''quality'' Sunday newspaper war who had hoped their ranks would thin sooner rather than later got a disappointment today, when the paper seen as the most likely casualty, The Sunday Correspondent, announced new financing and a new shareholder.

title: Review/Television;   Accepting the Lover of a Son Dead of AIDS
description: There are certain programs that vividly illustrate why public television can be indispensable. ''Andre's Mother'' is one. The subject of this ''American Playhouse'' drama, on Channel 13 at 9:10 P.M., is homosexuals and AIDS deaths as seen through the grief, denial and acceptance of those left behind. It is a subject on which prime-time commercial television, most notably all those made-for-TV movies, has been virtually, and shamefully, silent.

title: Valvano's Removal Sought by Trustees
description: LEAD: Meeting in emergency session, members of the executive committee of the North Carolina State University Board of Trustees today instructed school officials to conclude an agreement soon clearing the way for the removal of Jim Valvano as basketball coach.

title: BellSouth Wins In Cellular Bid
description: The BellSouth Corporation announced that a consortium in which it is a major stake holder had won a 20-year franchise to build and operate a cellular telephone network in western Mexico.

title: Factory Orders Fall By 5.4%
description: Orders received by the nation's factories fell in January at the steepest rate in 15 years, the Commerce Department said today, reflecting a slump in the nation's manufacturing sector.

title: Upheaval in the East;   SOVIETS APPROVE THE RIGHT TO OWN SMALL BUSINESSES
description: The Soviet Parliament approved a property law today that gives private citizens the right to own small-scale factories and other businesses for the first time since the 1920's.

title: Latshaw Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary tax credit of $25,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Mandela in Tanzania
description: On the last leg of his three-country Africa tour, Mr. Mandela arrived in this muggy seaside city today to be greeted by a Government that is one of the African National Congress's most generous supporters.

title: Economic Scene;   Global Warming: China Perplex
description: THE bad news, say Alan S. Manne of Stanford University and Richard G. Richels of the Electric Power Research Institute, is that it would probably cost Americans trillions of dollars to reduce their output of ''greenhouse effect'' carbon dioxide gas by as little as 20 percent. The really bad news, the two economists say in a new, unpublished paper, is that a 20 percent cut would almost certainly be offset by increased emissions from poor countries.

title: Iranian Report on Hostages Seen as a Signal to the West
description: West German and French officials said today that an Iranian newspaper editorial calling for freeing the Western hostages in Lebanon represented an Iranian admission that the West will widen economic and diplomatic ties with Iran only after the hostages are free.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates were up modestly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday. It marked the third consecutive week that rates rose. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.1805 percent, up from 8.137 percent last week. Citicorp said it also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.12 percent, up from 8.043 percent.

title: Punchless Devils Get A Victory
description: The Devils obtained Peter Stastny from Quebec in hopes of solving their long-term scoring problems, which continued again tonight in a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: 'Breathable' Film Keeps Decay at Bay
description: LEAD: CONSUMERS who live in Atlanta and Los Angeles and in the suburbs of Philadelphia can buy FreshHold broccoli florets sealed in a plastic box with a strip of ''breathable'' film on top. Shoppers in major cities nationwide are offered Natural Pak's brand-name TomAHtoes which, if stored at room temperature, are said to approximate vine-ripened tomatoes.

title: Approach of 1992 Provides a Sense of Urgency
description: The talks between Daimler-Benzei A.G. and the Mitsubishi group that were made public today are an attempt by both companies to position themselves before the European Community forms a single, borderless market by the end of 1992, industry analysts said.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: ANY top-flight urban restaurant faces daunting competition these days, but the London Chop House here has accepted an especially tough challenge: to regain its status as one of the world's best.

title: K Mart Gambling on Renovation
description: When it comes to merchandising revenues, the K Mart Corporation, Sears, Roebuck & Company and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. are now so close that it is difficult to say which of the three is the nation's largest retailer. But when it comes to merchandising profits, K Mart is a weak third.

title: 3 Quit Covenant House
description: The director of communications of Covenant House and the head of its Institute for Youth Advocacy, who have been criticized in recent investigations, resigned yesterday.

title: Boston Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $167,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $617,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss

title: N.A.A.C.P. in Hiring Pact With South Carolina Mall
description: In an agreement with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a shopping mall has pledged to hire more blacks and stop detaining black teen-agers under a 1960's trespassing law.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: WHEN the doors open at Gira Polli in the North Beach section of San Francisco, the aroma of roasting chickens attracts the most preoccupied passers-by, many of whom decide not to pass by after all.

title: Aldus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANDELA REBUFFED BY A RIVAL GROUP
description: In one of his first setbacks since he was released from prison last month, Nelson Mandela's effort to form a broad anti-apartheid coalition has been rebuffed by a rival South African opposition movement.

title: Ethiopian Students Hail Pledge to Liberalize
description: Several hundred thousand students marched through Addis Ababa today in a huge display of support for President Mengistu Haile Mariam's pledge to liberalize his Marxist regime.

title: Wet Feet and Triangle Trails
description: A New Yorker, returned after a long absence to live in the city, was made aware by yesterday's snowstorm of a change that took place while he was away. Nobody seems worried about dry feet. Walking with eyes down against the wind-driven flakes, he did not see a single pair of old-fashioned rubbers and the only galoshes were on children being herded to school.

title: Galactic Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago periods were restated.

title: Control Resource Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $15,775,000 and $10,760,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: From Nitrogen Fixation To a $20,000 Scholarship
description: Matthew P. Headrick of Chicago, who won first prize in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, joins a field of winners dating to 1942 that includes five who went on to win a Nobel Prize.

title: Hallwood Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reflected accrued interest on 13.5 percent subordinated debentures, distributed to shareholders in May, impacted performance by $1.6 million. c-Net income The latest periods' revenues were after acquisition of Brookwood subsidiary.

title: Kansas Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Debut as Pro, Capriati Wins
description: Her mother developed a stiff neck from nervous tension. Her father's eyes were bloodshot after a sleepless night. But Jennifer Capriati, the 13-year-old tennis phenomenon who finally made her professional debut this afternoon, experienced no debilitating jitters.

title: Yields on C.D.'s Are Mixed
description: Most yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Earlier Gathers Tests Found Serious Disorder
description: Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball star who collapsed and died Sunday night during a West Coast Conference semifinal game in Los Angeles, was previously diagnosed as having a heart condition that could produce a potentially fatal heart-rhythm abnormality, a Los Angeles heart specialist said yesterday.

title: Bank Law Reform for Panama and for Us;   Money Laundering War
description: To the Editor:

title: Rohatyn Rebuts Angry Koch, And Then They Seek a Truce
description: Felix G. Rohatyn lashed out yesterday at what he called former Mayor Edward I. Koch's ''virulent public abuse and attempted smears'' for asserting that he had abused his power as head of the city's fiscal watchdog agency, the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: GEO International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., an energy and chemical company, appointed John D. Van Meter president of its subsidiary Ashland Oil International Ltd., London.

title: Two C.H.S.A.A. Powers Upset
description: St. Nicholas of Tolentine and Christ the King, two schools ranked among the top 15 in the nation, were both upset last night in overtime in the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association tournament.

title: May Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included loss from discontinued operations of $17,000,000, which included a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $23 million. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $46,000,000, or 31 cents a share, and $86,000,000, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The year's income from discontinued operations included a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $29 million, or 20 cents a share. Latest fourth quarter results included a LIFO credit of $34 million, compared with a LIFO credit of $13 million for year-ago period. In the latest fourth quarter, the company announced plans to combine Kaufmann's in Pittsburgh with Sibley's in Rochester, N.Y. into a single operating division operating under the Kaufmann's name, effective in February. The company recorded a pretax charge of $10 million for the estimated cost of this combination. Also in the 1989 fourth quarter, the company recorded a pretax gain of $7 million on the sale of real estate. During the 1988 fourth quarter, the company began consolidating certain department store divisions and closing certain low-productivity store locations, completed the sale of a former department store location and realized a gain on the settlement of pension obligations with retiree participants. As a result of these events, the company recorded a net charge of $18 million. During the 1988 third quarter, May dissolved a real estate partnership, sold two parcels of excess property and prepaid certain long-term debt which in the aggregate resulted in a net gain of $18 million, or 12 cents a share. The annual LIFO impact for 1989 was a $22 million credit, compared to a $3 million credit in 1988. The year-ago periods ended Jan. 28, 1989. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Text of the Soviet Law
description: The Soviet Parliament voted yesterday to allow citizens to own the ''means of production'' and create small-scale factories, making fundamental changes in the Soviet economic system as described by the nation's Constitution. Here are the texts of two key sections of the Constitution, Articles 10 and 17.

title: Chinese Party Holding Closed Session This Week
description: The Communist Party Central Committee plans to hold an important meeting in the capital beginning Wednesday, foreign diplomats and knowledgable Chinese said today.

title: The Best Kind of Soviet Reform
description: Given a voice, Soviet voters shouted for change. Mikhail Gorbachev seized on elections as a stick with which to beat recalcitrant party apparatchiks. Now he may find himself prodded to move faster on reform or beaten back if he tries to grab too much power for himself.

title: Drexel Pact May Be Near
description: At a hearing yesterday, lawyers for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and creditors of its bankrupt parent said they were close to reaching an agreement that would allow a group including at least three members of the Drexel board to oversee the liquidation of the Wall Street firm's holdings.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 24 about an agreement among television networks to create a single Election Day survey of voters leaving the polls misidentified a group formed in 1964 by ABC, CBS, NBC, The Associated Press and United Press International to gather vote totals for news organizations. It is the News Election Service.

title: Handex Environmental ReFcovery reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Star of U.S. Team Injures Leg Ligaments
description: Hugo Perez, a star of the United States soccer team's midfield, said yesterday that he might miss the World Cup competition in Italy this June after tearing ligaments in a leg Saturday in a match in France.

title: Dineen's Hat Trick Sinks Islanders
description: Kevin Dineen of Hartford was sitting on a table just outside the visitors' locker room at Nassau Coliseum, basking in the glow of his three-goal performance, which helped his team defeat the Islanders, 4-2.

title: DeBeers To Become 2 Companies
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the huge South African diamond mining concern, said today that it would split itself in two and base one of the newly formed companies in Switzerland.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR told Congress yesterday that ''the darkest days of the AIDS crisis still lie ahead of us'' as she lobbied for a bill that would provide $600 million in emergency aid to care for people with the disease.

title: Review/Dance;   A Heavy-Breathing Beast Who Breaks Taboos
description: Marie Chouinard, a solo dancer from Montreal who has developed into a performer of stunning theatricality, specializes in imagery that most would like to repress.

title: New I.B.M. Prices
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said that it would raise prices 3 percent for many of its computers, 4 to 5 percent for selected printers and 10 percent for services and many of its software products. The company also said it was reducing the price of memory for its most powerful 3090 mainframe computer by up to 20 percent. The price increases do not affect product prices or price changes announced after last Nov. 30, the company stated. I.B.M.'s stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $105.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Perrier to Return to U.S. Early Next Month
description: Pulled off the market because of a contamination scare, Perrier sparkling water is returning - today in France and by early April in America.

title: 'New' Coke, Newer Name: Will It Sell a Bit Sweeter?
description: Almost exactly five years after it introduced a sweeter, reformulated version of Coca-Cola and found itself mired in one of the greatest marketing fiascos of modern times, the Coca-Cola Company confirmed yesterday that it would soon begin test-marketing a renamed and repackaged version of ''new'' Coke, its dormant Pepsi-Cola taste-alike.

title: Greiner Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 25 percent common stock splits effected in the form of stock dividends paid in 1988 and 1989 and the 4-for-3 common stock split effected in the form of a stock dividend paid in February 1990.

title: Alexander T. Colt, Publishing Executive, 75
description: Alexander T. Colt, an advertising and publishing executive for more than 35 years, died of leukemia Friday at Queen of the Valley Hospital in Napa, Calif. He was 75 years old and lived in Napa.

title: Vito Marzullo, Chicago Politician, 92
description: Vito Marzullo, a former Alderman who ran his West Side ward virtually unchallenged for more than 30 years, died of respiratory illness Monday at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center. He was 92 years old and had been hospitalized for more than a month.

title: Rykoff-Sexton Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: Year-ago periods ended Jan. 28, 1989. The company noted that it has experienced higher labor, rental, insurance and interest expenses, and during this third quarter, incurred a non- recurring $2 million pretax charge related to additional bad debt provisions and employee health care benefits.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Webster and Cheney at Odds Over Soviet Military Threat
description: The Director of Central Intelligence and the Secretary of Defense are at odds over whether the Soviet Union will continue to pose a serious military threat to the United States and the West.

title: Mamet Play in Series Of 4 Staged Readings
description: David Mamet's ''Water Engine'' will be among the plays in a four-part series of staged readings at the New Theater of Brooklyn, Dean Street and Flatbush Avenue in the Prospect Heights section.

title: Barge Carrying Fuel Oil Explodes in Arthur Kill
description: A barge loaded with more than 4.2 million gallons of home heating oil exploded in the Arthur Kill between Staten Island and Linden, N.J., yesterday afternoon. It burst into flames and cracked, spilling an unknown amount of oil into the Kill.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Corestates Financial Corp., Philadelphia, a bank holding company, completed its share-for-share acquisition of First Pennsylvania Corp., Philadelphia, a bank-holding company, valued at about $595 million.

title: Altron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Fernandez Plans Schools in Workplaces
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez plans to open a network of elementary schools inside office buildings and other workplaces, where young children can attend classes as their parents work nearby.

title: 'Handmaid's Tale,' Adapted From Atwood Novel
description: ''The Handmaid's Tale'' is that rare totalitarian fantasy in which the tyrants plant tulips and wear pearls. The United States, now renamed Gilead, has become a male-controlled police state dedicated to the oppression of women, yet there are very few men in either Margaret Atwood's novel or Volker Schlondorff's film version. The men are either roaming the corridors of power, fighting as soldiers called Angels, or (if they are nonwhite) relegated to far-flung colonies in badly polluted parts of the world. So for the most part, it is only the women we see.

title: In Milan, Whimsy With a Sure Touch
description: Whimsy and tailoring, facets of fashion that the Italians understand very well, have dominated the fall and winter ready-to-wear showings of the major players the last two days.

title: Marion Weatherford, Agricultural Leader, 83
description: Marion Weatherford, an agricultural leader, died Feb. 27 at a hotel in The Dalles, Ore., after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Pendleton.

title: For Eastern Europe, a $25 Billion Aid Package
description: The external Soviet empire lasted 45 years. It is shattered, beyond redemption or repair.

title: Norman E. Cash, 71, TV Ad Bureau Leader
description: Norman E. Cash, a former president of the Television Bureau of Advertising, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: Patricia Kendall, 68, Professor of Sociology
description: Patricia Kendall, a professor of sociology at Queens College and the author of several books on medical sociology, died of chronic pulmonary obstructive disease, a respiratory ailment, on Monday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: About New York;   Big Bribe Helps Mothers Fend Off Allure of Crack
description: ''I'm angry that I don't have my drug,'' the pregnant woman said last week. ''I miss my drug.''

title: Larger Deficit Seen in Budget For New York
description: New York's financial outlook grew dimmer today when the State Assembly predicted that the state would collect $600 million less in taxes than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had forecast, and Mr. Cuomo immediately embraced the new estimate.

title: Chandler Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gerald Jeremias, 82; Brokerage Executive
description: Gerald S. Jeremias, founder and chief executive of the Empire Planning Corporation, an independent mutual funds sales organization, died Sunday at New York Hospital after a heart attack. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ritter Drew $140,000 From Youth Trust
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter received $140,000 from a tax-exempt trust created to benefit runaway youths, he and the fund's trustee have acknowledged.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 1 about a protein secreted by tumor cells, with possible use in predicting the recurrence of breast cancer in women, misstated the affiliation of a researcher, Dr. William McGuire. A reader's inquiry this week disclosed that he is at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio, not in Houston.

title: When World Raves, Studios Jump
description: A rapidly growing market for American films abroad is encouraging American studios to pay closer attention to foreign moviegoers.

title: D'Amato's Press Secretary Makes Unusual Request for Documents
description: In a highly unusual letter, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's press secretary has asked Federal agencies to give him copies of all documents about Mr. D'Amato that they give to news organizations under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Rights Panel Scolds Cuba, Not China
description: The United Nations commission charged with encouraging respect for human rights worldwide refused to criticize China tonight for suppressing the student democracy movement last June.

title: Intelogic Trace Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,435,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,684,000, or 20 cents a share, for the 6 months from debt repurchase. c-Net income Intelogic said its latest second- quarter results included a $3 million loss from its investment in Datapoint Corp.

title: Casey's General Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Washington Talk;   Supreme Court's Style: A Richness in Diversity
description: If Supreme Court opinions were paintings, art critics would have trouble defining the Supreme Court style. Sometimes the Court paints with broad strokes, splashing color across the canvas as boldly as any Abstract Expressionist. Sometimes it draws delicately, the results as fragile and fine as a Persian miniature, precise as Pointillism, or filled with Renaissance shadings of light and shadow.

title: Uses for Fetal Tissue Won't Spur Abortions
description: To the Editor:

title: Avant-Gardists Make the Colors Flow
description: Milan is known for its well-tailored, salable and wearable clothes. But it also has its share of fashion iconoclasts, designers who offer ways of dressing that appeal to a younger, freer sensibility.

title: Hoechst Celanese Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company did not disclose share earnings; it is a subsidiary of Hoechst AG of West Germany.

title: Equitable of Iowa (O reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $180,000 for the quarter and $9,180,000 for the year. c-Included a gain from an accounting change of $11,555,000, or $1.39 a share.

title: Enclean Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
250 Million Now in U.S.
description: The nation's population reached 250 million today, according to the Census Bureau, but no one in Washington seemed to know how - or if - they should react to the milestone.

title: People
description: * Richard Fizdale, president and chief creative officer of the Leo Burnett Company, and Mary Moore, vice chairman and chief creative officer of Wells, Rich, Greene, have been named the United States judges at the 1990 International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes.

title: KEY RATES
Gloria Carter Spann, Ex-President's Sister, 63
description: Gloria Carter Spann, the last surviving sibling of former President Jimmy Carter, died of pancreatic cancer Monday at Sumter Regional Hospital here. She was 63 years old. It was in December that Mrs. Spann was found to be suffering from the disease, which killed her father, James Earl Carter; her sister, Ruth Stapleton, and her other brother, Billy.

title: U.S. Intelligence Aides Say Libya Is Again Making Chemical Arms
description: Government intelligence experts have concluded that Libya has renewed production of small quantities of chemical weapons and has stepped up its efforts to put a chemical arms plant into full-scale production, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Rangers Trade Dahlen To Minnesota for Gartner
description: The Rangers, who have gone from good to bad to first in the course of the season, yesterday chose to pretty much go for broke. With the playoffs just around the corner, the Rangers traded for a player they think might at last help them turn the corner in their half-a-century pursuit of the Stanley Cup.

title: GSW Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Frontier Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' revenue figures were restated. The share earnings reflected a 10 percent stock dividend paid in August.

title: Elisa Bialk, 81, Dies; Wrote for Magazines
description: Elisa Bialk Krautter, who wrote under the the name Elisa Bialk, died of cancer last Wednesday at Hilton Head Hospital on Hilton Head Island, S.C. She was 81 years old and lived on the island.

title: Lessons
description: Steve Richardson and his fellow sixth graders at the Yavapai Elementary School recently became curious about the political changes in East Germany. So they went to a computer and tapped into a satellite network linking schools in North America, Europe and the Middle East.

title: Daimler-Benz and Mitsubishi Negotiating Cooperative Plan
description: In what may prove to be one of the most far-reaching industrial linkups, the largest business groups in Japan and West Germany, Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz, said today that they were negotiating a plan of ''intensive cooperation'' in automobile technology, aerospace, microelectronics and a number of service industries.

title: 2-Part Fannie Mae Offering Of Debentures Priced at Par
description: A two-part financing by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, totaling $1.4 billion and consisting of an equal amount of five-year and 10-year debentures, was priced at par yesterday through various securities dealers.

title: Father Charged in Death of Boy
description: The father of a 5-year-old Bronx boy was charged with murder yesterday, a day after the badly bruised child died in a hospital, the police said.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: ''WHEN I was growing up on a farm in the Appalachian Mountains, my family would spend maybe $5 or $6 a month on groceries,'' said Jack McDavid, 34 years old, whose new restaurant, Jack's Firehouse, opened recently near the Museum of Art. ''I thought that we were rich, but we lived on less than a welfare family takes in.

title: Shifting Auto Gears by Computer
description: Sports cars and automatic transmissions have never mixed well. Car enthusiasts say automatics rob a car of performance and fuel economy while giving the driver less control than a manual gearbox.

title: RESPONSE SOUGHT ON DEATH PENALTY
description: Judicial officials in North Carolina began planning today how to deal with a United States Supreme Court decision affecting most of the 84 inmates on the state's death row.

title: For Later Presidential Primaries;   U.S. Can Alleviate Miseries of Haitians
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRYANT GUMBEL is upset over the slide of his show's ratings and he's not going to take it anymore. The host of the NBC News show ''Today'' has agreed to be interviewed by BARBARA WALTERS on her ''20/20'' program on ABC.

title: Real Estate;   Preservation Battle Ends In Manhattan
description: LATE next month, a 24-year-long successful effort to preserve two of Manhattan's prime small commercial buildings will come to an end when the 56-story skyscraper at 712 Fifth Avenue opens, and with it the two five-story structures that all the fuss had been about.

title: Whose History Will Be Taught, and What Is History Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Seized in Demonstration As They Offer New Needles
description: Setting the stage for a court test of New York State laws that restrict possession of hypodermic needles, 10 protesters were arrested yesterday in Manhattan as they tried to offer clean needles to stop the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug addicts.

title: Dinkins, in Washington, Seeks Aid for Cities
description: David N. Dinkins sat in the front of a packed Senate committee room this morning, surrounded by Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, Alan Cranston of California and Paul Simon of Illinois. Just when it seemed the Mayor of New York City could not bask in a warmer spotlight, in walked Elizabeth Taylor.

title: Graf Skips Hilton Head
description: Steffi Graf's recovery from a thumb injury remains on track, but she has decided not to play in the Family Circle Magazine Cup tournament April 2-8 in Hilton Head, S.C., a spokeswoman for her management company said yesterday.

title: Slump in Securities Industry
description: Four senior securities executives told Congress today that their industry was in a period of economic decline, but said only minor legislative changes were needed.

title: Metropolitan Diary
