description: LEAD: ALBERT HSU and Roger Black are waiting for the traffic light to change at 23d Street and Seventh Avenue when they notice a fellow, three stories up, painting the words CRIMINAL LAWYER on a window. Furthermore, the pair also notice that the N is unwittingly reversed. The window watchers jump up and down, wave their arms wildly and shout in an attempt to alert the painter to his error.

title: India Charges 6 Over Submarine Kickbacks
description: The Government of India has filed criminal cases against six people, including the former Secretary of Defense and a top Indian industrialist, accusing them of involvement in illegal kickbacks in a contract for submarines with West Germany worth about $300 million dollars.

title: Dollar General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago quarter income tax provision restated to reflect adoption of SFAS No. 96.

title: Stocks Rise, Spurred by Dip in Bond Yields
description: A decline in bond yields helped push stocks into higher ground yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 27.25 points, to 2,676.80.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in thin trading yesterday, as many dealers who sold securities on Monday turned around and bought them yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Earnings listing of Business Day on Saturday about the Service Corporation International misstated the period of the company's 1988 results. They were recorded for the full 12 months of 1988, ended Dec. 31, not for eight months. The entry also misstated the period during which a gain of $2.9 million was recorded from a public offering. It was included in the results for the latest year, not the quarter. A corrected entry appears today on page D21.

title: Belfast Journal;   Tories Hoping Ulster's Eyes Will Smile on Them
description: Is Laurence Kennedy the diabolical leader of another Protestant plot to make sure Britain does not give up Northern Ireland? Or is he a champion of democracy who is trying to offer both Protestants and Catholics a chance to have a say in their own affairs?

title: Review/Opera;   Carlos Kleiber Leads Placido Domingo In Verdi's 'Otello'
description: In Utopia, every opera performance would be a perfect blend of singing, acting, staging and conducting, all suspended in breathtaking, shimmering equipoise. In the real world of everyday opera such an ideal balance seldom occurs, but the synergy of disparate elements sometimes can produce exciting results. That was true on Monday evening at the Metropolitan Opera in the season's first ''Otello,'' whose main energizing force was the controlled yet impassioned conducting of Carlos Kleiber.

title: Review/Music;   Liszt's Thunder, In the Intimacy Of the Frick
description: Louis Lortie, a pianist from Montreal, devoted his Sunday afternoon recital at the Frick Collection to music by Liszt. His playing was colorful, sensitive and tempestuous in an authentically Lisztian way.

title: No Frothing, No Frothing, No Frothing
description: We tacked the message on our refrigerator door when the baseball follies began two weeks ago.

title: Sharp's Color Fax
description: The Sharp Corporation of Japan said it had developed a desktop facsimile machine that can transmit photograph-like full-color images. The company said the fax machine was the first made for general office use that could transmit full-color pictures. The machine can also send and receive regular black and white faxes. The machine will go on sale in Japan in the fall for about $23,000.

title: Environmental Systems Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Genesee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Republican Leader Has Benign Tumor In Side of His Head
description: The Republican national chairman, Lee Atwater, has ''a small nonmalignant growth in the right side of his head,'' his physician said today.

title: Service Corp. International reports earnings for 12mo to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax income from discontinued operations of $3,017,000, or 6 cents share, and an after-tax loss of $97,952,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income and included an after- tax loss from discontinued operations of $15,584,000 and a loss of $16,474,000 from the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting for income taxes. Results for latest year also included a gain of $2,893,000, or 6 cents a share, related to the public offering of shares by the company's Canadian subsidiary in April 1989. The company in November 1989 announced plans to discontinue its involvement in the funeral supply and insurance prearranged funeral service businesses. Corrected from Saturday, March 3.

title: Easier Rules For A.T.&T. Suggested
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said today that the market in long-distance telephone services was sufficiently competitive that the Government should consider removing some restrictions that were placed on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company before the breakup of the Bell System.

title: Lithuanian Parliament Expected to Declare Independence Sunday
description: The Parliament of Lithuania has scheduled a meeting on Sunday at which it is expected to declare the republic's independence from the Soviet Union, Lithuanian officials said today.

title: Where to Get Straight Talk
description: BOOKS about healthful eating generally are even more difficult to evaluate than diet books. The single most important criterion for books about nutrition and healthful eating is that they are accurate. And it often takes a professional to judge their accuracy. These organizations have compiled lists of, or can provide suggestions on, safe and accurate diet and nutrition books. Almost all are free.

title: No Teams Showing Interest in Anderson
description: Last fall, Ottis Anderson rushed for 1,023 yards for the Giants and Joe Morris rushed for none. But in pro football's current Plan B free-agency period, seven other teams are reported to have shown interest in Morris, none in Anderson.

title: INSIDE
description: Afghan Coup Attempt

title: Gehl Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $708,000, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Lowe's Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Cambrex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Fay's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Fondue, Refreshed, Re-emerges
description: IT was bound to happen.

title: Paramount Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $57,500,000, or 48 cents a share. The company said this year's first quarter net includes interest income of $37.9 million primarily resulting from the investment of the proceeds from the October 1989 sale of the Associates unit to a Ford Motor Co. subsidiary.

title: Back to Die on the Same Streets His Father Escaped
description: Joseph T. Aversa, the 31-year-old state police officer killed in a shootout on the Lower East Side on Monday, moved from the Canarsie section of Brooklyn to this rural hamlet when he was in high school.

title: Reviews/Music;   The Vermeer Plays Haydn and Bartok
description: Great individual playing may produce excellent overall results in chamber music, though not invariably. Conversely, relatively undistinguished individual contributions can add up to a highly accomplished whole, as with the Vermeer Quartet at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening.

title: Norway's War Souvenirs
description: Two 10-ton anchors from the German cruiser Blucher, which sank on April 9, 1940, under torpedo and gun attack by Norwegian forces, have been salvaged from 230 feet of water in the Oslo Fjord, the newspaper Aftenposten reported Monday. It said the anchors will be turned into memorials to mark the German attack on Norway 50 years ago. The cruiser remains on the bottom.

title: ...3 Different Pens Help Tell the Story
description: LEAD: Why were the pre-election polls in Nicaragua so far off in their predictions of the vote? The most popular explanation is that Nicaraguans were intimidated. Distrusting the motives of the interviewers, they concealed their true preferences and told interviewers what they thought the interviewers wanted to hear.

title: Pollution Control Bonds For Texas
description: The Matagorda County Navigational District No. 1 of Texas yesterday tentatively priced a $50 million tax-exempt bond issue due 2020 through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: G.M. to Decide On Electric Car
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would decide within two months whether to put a nonpolluting electric car into production. The world's biggest car company outlined test results for its electric car at a news conference before the 60th Geneva International Motor Show, which opens Thursday.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Kohl Offers Prosperity To East German Voters
description: Speaking to a crowd of 50,000 people in front of this industrial city's cathedral, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today painted a future of East German economic prosperity that will soon approach Bonn's high standards.

title: Labor Party Rejects Likud Terms for Palestinian Talks
description: The Israeli Labor Party rejected Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new terms for initiating talks with Palestinians today and gave his Likud party a day to change its mind if it hopes to keep their coalition Government intact.

title: Swissair Will Sell Interests in Hotels
description: The Swiss national airline Swissair agreed to sell its interests in 17 hotels for an undisclosed amount to the Aoki Corporation, a Japanese construction and hotel group. Aoki owns 67 hotels in 11 countries through its American subsidiary, Westin Hotels and Resorts, and operates a separate nine-hotel chain under the Caesar Park Hotels name.

title: Eastern Plan For Review
description: The management of Eastern Air Lines said today that it would ask the United States Bankruptcy Court to review 12 transactions between Eastern and its parent company, the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Wine Talk
description: CHAP I know, a great wine fan, goes around these days saying: ''No more green bananas. I'm buying no more green bananas.''

title: Time Warner Plans to Start First Book Club for Children
description: Lured by the fast-growing market for juvenile books, Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would start the country's first book club for children, offering a monthly selection of reading for everyone from toddlers to young teen-agers.

title: Patrick T. Finnegan, Executive, 74
description: Patrick T. Finnegan, a retired executive vice president of the James Gordon Bennett Foundation and a former newspaper industry executive, died of a pulmonary embolism on Thursday at a nursing home in Martin, Tenn. He was 74 years old and until recently had lived in Carlisle, Pa.

title: Bio-Rad Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss from earthquake-related writeoffs and costs of $1,168,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After a loss of $304,000 from early debt retirement.

title: Peter von Blanckenhagen, Professor, 80
description: Prof. Peter H. von Blanckenhagen, a scholar of Greek and Roman art who was the Robert Lehman Professor Emeritus of Fine Arts at the New York University Institute of Fine Arts, died of complications from a respiratory ailment yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING

title: Guatemalan Says U.S. Is Unfair on Rights
description: President Vinicio Cerezo, responding to the recall of the American Ambassador for consultations on the deteriorating human rights situation in Guatemala, attacked the move today as unfair and inconsistent.

title: U.S. Revising Guidelines On Computer Exports
description: Responding to intense industry criticism, the Commerce Department is reworking proposed Federal rules that would ease export restrictions on high-performance computers to Western allies, agency officials said. The new version, they said, would for the first time take account of foreign competition.

title: College Drinking: Changes in Attitude and Habit
description: Despite the adoption by all 50 states of the 21-year-old legal drinking age and the tightening of alcohol policies on virtually every campus, most college students continue to drink regularly and often heavily.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SHRIMP are ideal for time-pressed cooks since they can be prepared in just minutes. With an a la minute sauce, like the quick curry described here, dinner can be on the table in well under 60 minutes. This curry sauce is made with a good curry powder, preferably homemade, and counterbalancing sweet ingredients, in this case onions and apples.

title: Editor for Men's Life
description: Barry Golson, who has spent 17 years at Playboy and has supervised the magazine's Interview feature, has resigned to become publication director and editor in chief of Men's Life. Murdoch Magazines plans to introduce the quarterly magazine, which will be aimed at men in their 30's, by the end of the year. The publisher will be Leo E. Scullin, formerly a senior vice president and director of print relations at Young & Rubicam.

title: Soaring Slam-Dunk Leaper on Ice
description: She is the Michael Jordan of figure skating, a dazzling athlete of uncommon skill who performs at a level unattained by many skaters, unattainable by most others.

title: Move Over Ivana And Don, Here's Ed and Felix
description: rrMoney. Power. A love-hate triangle. Angry recriminations over previous agreements on how to divide shared assets. Years of muffled resentment finally exploding into an unseemly public affair.

title: CR/PL Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included an extraordinary charge of $37,255.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * Counihan, Bridgewater & Associates has merged with Louden, Kaplan & Elegant to form Counihan, Bridgewater, Elegant Inc., with offices at 747 Third Ave. in Manhattan.

title: Opponents Go to Court In Fight Over Seabrook
description: As expected, the State of Massachusetts and two groups opposed to operation of the Seabrook nuclear power plant asked a Federal appeals court today to void the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's decision last week granting the plant a full-power license.

title: Checkrobot Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is a development stage company.

title: Rymer Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $111,000, or 3 cents a share, and an extraordinary credit of $77,000, or 3 cents a share, from early retirement of debt. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $814,000 and an extraordinary credit of $1,064,000, or 37 cents a share, from early retirement of debt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Multimedia Campaign Set for Newspapers
description: The A. H. Belo Corporation, the owner of The Dallas Morning News, and the Universal Press Syndicate said the companies were developing a multimedia advertising campaign intended to increase newspaper readership. The ads use Abigail Van Buren, known as ''Dear Abby,'' and the comic characters ''Cathy'' and ''Ziggy'' to attract the casual reader to newspapers.

title: After Large Study of Abortion Pill, French Maker Considers Wider Sale
description: Buoyed by promising results from the largest study yet on the French abortion pill, RU 486, the drug's manufacturer is considering marketing the drug in other countries.

title: Q&A
description: Off-Track Sliding Door

title: Clippers Overcome Nets' 15-Point Lead
description: The exasperated look on Bill Fitch's face after tonight's game summed up the Nets' performance. His forehead was creased, his tie was undone, and he spoke in a low monotone.

title: Kahler Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $236,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $185,000 for the year. c-Net income The latest quarter's results included a pre-tax gain of $1,000, compared with a pre-tax gain of $1,185,000 for year-ago period on sale of assets. The latest year results included a pre-tax charge of $50,000, compared with a pre-tax gain of $1,933,000 for 1988 on sale of assets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   4 Leave Riney To Form Shop
description: Four young executives at Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco have resigned to form their own advertising agency.

title: New line Cinema reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Credit Cards Back National City Issue
description: The National City Corporation, a Cleveland-based bank holding company, is selling $350 million in asset-backed securities through a newly formed National City Credit Card Trust 1990-A.

title: Consumer Debt Rose 5.9% In January on Auto Sales
description: Americans took out $3.54 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in January as they flocked to auto dealerships to lock in the latest round of sales incentives, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Talking Deals;   Music Producer Faces Big Choice
description: A BATTLE over the David Geffen Company is being waged.

title: Singles or Doubles, Capriati Hits Homers
description: Tennis's million-dollar baby continued her assault on the establishment today.

title: Soviet Press Snaps Back at Castro, Painting an Outdated Police State
description: After more than a year of quietly tolerating gibes from Fidel Castro about the folly of the changes under way in the Soviet Union, the Soviet press this week opened up on the Cuban leadership with a dose of withering scorn.

title: Eastern Environmental Servce reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fast Merger of Germanys Is Opposed
description: The opposition Social Democratic Party called today for German unity through negotiations rather than annexation, echoing a growing chorus of appeals against a headlong rush to merge East Germany into West Germany.

title: Vine Deloria Sr., Episcopal Executive, 88
description: Vine Deloria Sr., a former Episcopal archdeacon of South Dakota and a missionary among Sioux Indians, died on Feb. 26 at a nursing home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 88 years old.

title: Former Broadcaster May Get New Franchise
description: Predicting the future is often risky in the National Hockey League, but it seems safe to suggest this: Lloyd Pettit, a former broadcaster for the Chicago Blackhawks, has a good chance of obtaining a franchise for Milwaukee when the league expands in this decade.

title: Comdata Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time expense of $5.7 million recorded in the fourth quarter from the writedown of certain equipment and from a reduction in the carrying value of certain real estate holdings.

title: Charlotte Sitterly, 91; Devoted Career to Sunlight Studies
description: Charlotte M. Sitterly, an astrophysicist whose analysis of sunlight first showed that the element technitium exists in nature, died of heart failure on Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 91. Dr. Sitterly had devoted much of her career to the study of the sun's spectrum, including wavelengths that could not penetrate the atmosphere and were therefore observed from rockets.

title: Hemodynamics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said results included the operations of its majority-owned Myo-Tech Corp. unit. The latest fourth quarter and year included a charge of about $650,000 in connection with the company's acquisition of Medco Diagnostic Plc, which resulted from the pooling of interest method of accounting.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Revenue Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Chronicle
description: L. CHARLES BIRCH, the zoologist, and MURLIDHAR DEVIDAS AMTE, who built a modern leper community, will share the Templeton Prize for progress in religion, the largest prize given in any field.

title: Calligraphy Is Flourishing: Italic, Gothic, Etc.
description: WEDDINGS, benefits, confirmations - the spring social season is going to be a killer. The calligraphers are getting busy.

title: Britain Critical of al-Fayeds
description: The three al-Fayed brothers lied during their successful takeover in 1985 of the House of Fraser P.L.C., the owner of the famous London department store Harrods, the British Government said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Babcock Industries, Fairfield, Conn., a diversified manufacturer that is a subsidiary of FKI P.L.C., Halifax, England, promoted Robert M. Miller to vice president of legal and to secretary.

title: Article 879090 -- No Title
description: It's as though America just won the lottery. With Communism collapsing, the United States, having defended the free world for half a century, now stands to save a fortune. Defense spending could drop by $20 billion next year and $150 billion a year before the decade ends.

title: Incstar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $187,800 on early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income The company said that non-recurring expenses related to its acquisition of Clinical Sciences Inc. and the transfer of two subsidiary businesses to its primary Stillwater, Minn., facilities led to the loss in the latest third quarter and 9 months. The latest third quarter included $2.8 million of one-time expenses associated with the business combination. In addition, the company said it announced in December that the closing of its Clinical Sciences' New Jersey facility and the transfer of those operations to its Minnesota facility, resulted in a non-recurring charge of $1.1 million for the latest third quarter. The 9 months' results included $3.3 million in acquisition expenses. In addition to the $1.1 million charge, the results also included a non-recurring charge of $900,000 due to the closing in mid-1989 of its Atlantic Antibodies production facility.

title: GAF Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5 million related to retirement of debt for the quarter and year. Year-ago figures are pro forma. The company was acquired on March 29, 1989 in a leveraged buyout by a group of GAF executives. Accordingly, extraordinary items prior to the buyout are excluded from the figures.

title: Teheran Denies Direct Discussions With U.S. on Hostages in Beirut
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran denied today that any direct negotiations had been held with the United States on the fate of Western hostages in Lebanon. But he said in a news conference that American messages on the hostages had reached Teheran through Westerners and other intermediaries.

title: Dekalb Energy Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on divestitures of $40,000 for the quarter and $16,456,000, or $1.57 a share, for the year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,620,000, or 10 cents a share and $4,646,000, or 42 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, which included $648,000 gain on divestitures for both the quarter and year, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $3,464,000 which is primarily extinguishment of debt.

title: BMA to Sell Unit To Italian Insurer
description: The BMA Corporation said it would sell its insurance subsidiary to Italy's largest insurer in a deal valued at $285 million. BMA's share price fell $1.25 today, to $36.50, in over-the-counter trading. It dropped $3 on Tuesday, when the agreement was announced. ''It looks more like a fire sale than a sale,'' said Herbert Buchbinder, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Dynamics Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $536,000 for the fourth quarter and $496,000 for the year to establish a reserve for unrealized losses on the company's current marketable securities portfolio; a charge of $1,854,000 for a consumer product line restructuring and related product discontinuance and a tax credit of $843,000, or 21 cents a share. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $321,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included income of $3,964,000, or 98 cents a share, from settlement of patent award. Year-ago full year's income from continuing operations of $5,347,000, or $1.32 a share, included income of $385,000, or 10 cents a share, from settlement of business interruption claim.

title: AIDS Clamor at Colleges Muffling Older Dangers
description: After years of warning students about AIDS, many college health officials now say other sexually transmitted diseases pose a much wider threat, and they are questioning whether they should take a different approach in selling students on the wisdom of safe sex.

title: Northern Iowa Captures N.C.A.A. Berth
description: Troy Muilenburg scored 14 points and Northern Iowa sank crucial free throws down the stretch tonight as the Panthers beat Wisconsin-Green Bay, 53-45, in the championship game of the Association of Mid-Continent Universities tournament.

title: Berry Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Benetton Changes Its Ads
description: The Benetton Group has traded in its handcuffs for handholding in its new advertising campaign for the ''United Colors of Benetton.''

title: Calendar: Crafts and a Hint of Spring
description: Craft Auction, Fabri Mansion, Seven East 95th Street; 518-584-1819.

title: Highlander International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Antique Beds and Their Lookalikes
description: ANYONE who wants an antique bed or bed frame knows the predicament. The beds are rare and getting rarer, and when you can find one it is either unbearably rickety, too short and narrow, or requires bed linen of unusual proportions. And it is nearly impossible to find an antique bed frame to fit a modern king-size bed.

title: Brascan Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Liberals Starting a Journal As a Forum for New Ideas
description: Nobody will accuse liberals of having led the political debate during the past decade or so. Indeed, many liberals themselves acknowledge, a bit ruefully, that the ideas that made a difference in the 1970's and 80's came more often than not from conservatives. But a small group of liberal writers and professors, many with national reputations, are starting a new journal, hoping it will become the focal point of a renewal.

title: Teheran Denies Direct Discussions With U.S. on Hostages in Beirut;   Hostage Demands Pressed
description: A clandestine pro-Iranian group believed to be holding three of the eight Americans missing in Lebanon said today that it would not free the hostages before its demands are met.

title: A Queens Judge Serves 2 Months Of a Year's Term
description: Francis X. Smith, a top New York City judge jailed for perjury in a corruption scandal, was released from jail last month after having served two months of his one-year sentence. He said yesterday that his short time behind bars had reinforced opinions he had held as a judge.

title: St. Louis Paper's Staff Bars Use of Bylines
description: All but three of the reporters, photographers and artists at The St. Louis Post-Dispatch withheld their names from items published today as their union stepped up pressure in a contract dispute.

title: For Children, A Hurtless House
description: Tucked away in a housing development on some once-verdant farmland in New Jersey stands a house that will make every parent feel guilty. It is designed and decorated to be safe for children.

title: Hilton Hotels Rejects Bids; Sale Ended
description: Seven months after soliciting bids for all or part of the company, the Hilton Hotels Corporation rejected two acquisition proposals today and said it now intended to remain independent.

title: G.O.P. to Ignore Cuomo Plan And Use Old Budget as Guide
description: State budget negotiations took a novel turn today when leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate said that they would ignore the spending plan Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed in January. Instead, the leaders said, they will work from last year's budget and increase spending only where they think it is essential.

title: Sony's 'Palmtop' To Appear in April
description: The Sony Corporation said it would begin marketing in April a computer it calls a ''palmtop,'' which can recognize more than 3,500 handwritten characters. The machine is 8 inches wide, 6.2 inches deep and 1.8 inches high, and it weighs 2.8 pounds. It will retail for 198,000 yen, or $1,320.

title: Bond Prices Dip in Slow Session
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in extremely lethargic trading yesterday, as dealers watched developments in the foreign exchange markets and waited for the release tomorrow morning of February employment data.

title: Algoma Central Railway reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $320,000 and $257,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Included an extraordinary credit of $614,000, or 16 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Agassi Out of Match
description: Andre Agassi has decided not to play in the United States Davis Cup matches against Czechoslovakia, which begin March 30. He said yesterday that he did not think he would be well prepared. He will be replaced by Aaron Krickstein, ranked No. 6 in the world. Agassi is No. 8. Krickstein and Brad Gilbert will play singles against the Czechoslovaks, with Jim Pugh and Rick Leach playing doubles. (AP)

title: Pacer Systems reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $1,378,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Tax Cuts for Corporations Burden a School System
description: For much of this century, the General Motors factory here has been the bedrock of North Tarrytown's tax base. But now changes in the business world that have driven corporations to cut costs aggressively have come home to this Hudson River village.

title: 3 Brothers of Boy Killed in Bronx Were Also Mistreated, Police Say
description: The three brothers of a Bronx child whose father is accused of killing him were also victims of repeated abuse, the police said yesterday, and had been taken from their parents at least once between 1983 and 1985.

title: Chip Accord By A.T.&T. And NEC
description: In the latest of a series of technology accords that American companies hope will get them into the Japanese semiconductor market, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the NEC Corporation said today that they would cooperate on a number of chip technologies over the next five years.

title: Seeking AWACS, Saudis Gave to Fight Drugs
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia donated $1 million to Nancy Reagan's anti-drug campaign in 1985 while the Reagan Administration was considering a request from his country to buy surveillance aircraft, a former White House official said Tuesday.

title: Reedy Trial Put Off
description: The trial of William Reedy, who is charged with driving Billy Martin's pickup truck while intoxicated when the former Yankee manager was killed in an accident on Christmas Day, has been delayed another 30 days.

title: Baker (Michael) Corp.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Guide To Seeking Child Care
description: LEAD: Information on how to select the best child care, plus a state-by-state listing of local agencies, are part of a new booklet, ''The Family Guide to Child Care: Making the Right Choices,'' prepared by Family Service America, the oldest network of social-service agencies in the nation.

title: Judge Won't Bar North From Poindexter Trial
description: A Federal district judge today denied a request by John M. Poindexter that Oliver L. North be barred from appearing as a prosecution witness at Mr. Poindexter's trial.

title: Proposed Catholic Catechism Stirs Dispute Among Scholars
description: For the first time in more than 400 years, the Catholic Church is preparing to issue a comprehensive summary of its beliefs aimed at governing church teaching throughout the world, an effort that has provoked a sharp dispute among church scholars.

title: MDS Health Group reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: In Nicaragua, Victors Are Menaced
description: When she went to answer her front door here a few days ago, Yadira Castillo Hidalgo, a schoolteacher, was still euphoric about the victory of the opposition coalition over the Sandinista Government in national elections on Feb. 25. Then she found out what that victory meant for her.

title: Market Place;   Higher Yields From Municipals
description: FOR now, it is a marriage made in heaven, or perhaps at the Securities and Exchange Commission. The bride is municipal bond funds; the groom something called ''residual interest bonds,'' a new security announced yesterday by the financial engineers at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: TURMOIL SPREADS TO 2D 'HOMELAND'
description: Another nominally independent black homeland of South Africa was caught up in unrest today as up to 50,000 protesters in Bophuthatswana massed to complain about living costs and to demand the resignation of the homeland's president.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Peggy Lee Sings Her Lyrics
description: Peggy Lee has been writing songs for more than 40 years, and she usually includes several of them in her programs. Her new show, ''The Peggy Lee Songbook (and a Few Others!),'' which opened on Tuesday at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) is a showcase for lyrics she has written over the years to the music of a variety of composers, including Victor Young, Sonny Burke, Johnny Mandel and, most recently, John Chiodini, her guitarist, who also shares conducting chores with her pianist, Mike Renzi.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Selling The Concept Of Integration
description: THE financial problems affecting Saatchi & Saatchi are calling attention once again to the difficulties facing multinational advertising conglomerates that try to sell a smorgasbord of services.

title: A Tournament of Powerhouses
description: The reality in the college basketball industry is that some of the most meaningful conference tournament games this week will take place far from the bright lights of Madison Square Garden and a long way from the television cameras that spread the gospel of the Big East from coast to coast.

title: Chronicle
description: JACQUELINE ONASSIS agreed yesterday to give a group of Wampanoag Indians a plot of land and $100,000 in exchange for a small piece of beachfront property on Martha's Vineyard. The agreement, which was ratified by Judge John S. Macdougall Jr. in Dukes County Probate Court, ends a 10-year dispute over the property. The case put Mrs. Onassis' desire for privacy against the Indians' belief that they should retain tribal lands on the island.

title: Mexico to Sell Steel Concerns
description: Mexico announced plans today to sell off the nation's two leading steel companies, including its third-largest state-owned enterprise, as part of a sweeping privatization program.

title: After Fleeing New York, Witness In the Bensonhurst Killing Returns
description: John S. Vento, the witness in the Bensonhurst killing who disappeared two months ago, arrived at La Guardia Airport last night from Dayton, Ohio, where he had turned himself in to the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Monday.

title: Bush Says Inadequate Financing Imperils Transportation System
description: President Bush will announce a transportation policy on Thursday declaring that the nation's economy is ''at risk'' because of inadequate investment in public works projects, but seeking to minimize Federal subsidies for transportation.

title: Reviews/Music;   Groan (127 Minutes) and Drone (Eternal)
description: For two decades, the composer La Monte Young has been presenting grandiose, mystic concerts in which musicians groan away for hours accompanying a dense electronic drone, sitting in a dark, hieratic visual environment. These events, which have been fairly infrequent in recent years, are called Dream Houses, and the collection of musicians - who over the years have included some of the brightest lights of ''downtown'' experimental music - is called the Theater of Eternal Music. The visual settings by Mr. Young's wife, Marian Zazeela, go by the name of Time Light Symmetry Environments.

title: Beware of Pretoria, Nyerere Tells Mandela
description: Former President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania urged Nelson Mandela today to be wary of South African reform promises.

title: Cagliari Journal;   Island Braces for Soccer: Just You Wait, 'ooligans!
description: Saturday, June 16, has already been circled on calendars here as D-day. ''That,'' says Andrea Arrica, who heads the local committee for the World Cup soccer finals, ''will be the longest day.''

title: William Appleman Williams Dies; Gadfly of Foreign Policy Was 68
description: William Appleman Williams, a historian known for his sharp critiques of American foreign policy, died of cancer Monday at Newport (Ore.) Community Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived on the Oregon coast at Waldport.

title: Centaur Loses Court Ruling
description: National Intergroup Inc. announced this evening that the Delaware state court had upheld the company's contention that the Centaur Partners Group needs the votes of 80 percent of National Intergroup's shareholders to force the election of the majority of the company's board at its annual meeting in July.

title: China Sees Taiwan Instability
description: China expressed deep concern tonight over political battles in Taiwan that are taking place in advance of the presidential election there later this month, and strongly condemned the governing Nationalist Party for ''creating political and social instability.''

title: Low Risk Seen in Delayed Pregnancy
description: Women who put off starting their families until late in their child-bearing years face little extra risk of having premature or unhealthy babies, a study concludes.

title: A U.S.-BONN SPLIT ON LIBYA IS SEEN
description: Sharp differences have developed between the United States and West Germany over how to respond to evidence that Libya has resumed production of chemical weapons, Western officials said today.

title: Dow Slides 7.21 Points on Light Volume
description: Stocks moved narrowly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 7.21, to 2,669.59, in light volume, as traders marked time until tomorrow's key employment figures for February. The numbers are expected to show continued weakness in the economy.

title: Verit Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $30,000 and $64,000 for the quarter and six months, respectively. Figures for 1988 have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: College Notebook;   Clarkson Goalie May Shake Up ECAC Hockey
description: In the compact playoffs of college hockey the familiar imperative is: beware the team with a sharp goalie. An impenetrable goalie can ruin favorites or seedings and this weekend's ECAC Hockey tournament in Boston Garden has such a candidate.

title: Jury Awards Two Men $76 Million in Police Brutality Case
description: A jury awarded two men more than $76 million in damages last night, concluding that the men were shot at, beaten and charged with attempted murder without reason by five police officers in a midnight encounter on a street in Coney Island four years ago.

title: Overtreatment Is Found In Newborn Jaundice
description: Babies born at full term and in good health probably do not need to be treated if they develop signs of jaundice, researchers say.

title: Turner Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for latest periods are after preferred dividend requirements of $160,000 and $378,000 for fourth quarter and year, respectively.

title: American Vision Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Peter Glenn, 69, Dies; Talent Guide Publisher
description: Peter Glenn, a publisher of talent and modeling guides and directories, died of complications from AIDS on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: Afghan Leader Says Plotters Have Fled
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said today that Defense Minister Shahnawaz Tanai and others had fled to Pakistan by air after what he called the failure of a coup attempt on Tuesday.

title: Why Mandela Doesn't Take Role of a South African Dr. King
description: To the Editor:

title: Businessland Chain to Offer Products of Compaq Again
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that Businessland Inc., a leading retailer of computers, would again carry its products in the United States. Compaq withdrew its products from Businessland last April, complaining that the chain had struck preferential deals with Compaq's major competitors.

title: KEY RATES
Columbia Real Estate reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'Unselfish' Seminar For Knicks
description: rrAt halftime of Saturday night's game with the Nets at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks will finally retire Dick Barnett's No. 12 and hang a ''613'' banner representing Red Holzman's number of victories as their coach over 14 seasons.

title: CSC Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $8,240,000, or 95 cents a share, after restructuring of debt to Copperweld Corp. c-Net income

title: Canadian Energy Services Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bridge
description: The death last November of the British star Jeremy Flint serves as a reminder of a partnership that seemed destined for greatness. Two decades ago he played frequently with Jonathan Cansino, a brilliant performer whose effectiveness at the card table was sadly reduced by a brain hemorrhage suffered while in his 30's.

title: Brooklyn Tech Topples Stevenson
description: Adlai Stevenson's two-year reign was ended yesterday when Brooklyn Tech, getting a total of 41 points and 10 assists from its senior backcourt duo of Lamont Jones and Tyrone Paige, eliminated the two-time defending Public Schools Athletic League champions from the Bronx, 65-58, in a quarterfinal game at City College's Nat Holman gymnasium.

title: Hollinger Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11 million for the latest year and $4 million for 1988. These results included discontinued operations and extraordinary items, but the company did not provide a more detailed breakdown. The company said it has adopted new accounting policies, so that some items that previously might have been classed as extraordinary are now included in ordinary income as unusual items. It said unusual items totaled $39 million in 1989. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Redskins Sign Wilder
description: James Wilder, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' career leader in rushing and pass reception yardage, signed with the Washington Redskins yesterday after being left unprotected on the Buccaneers' 37-man roster.

title: USX Stock Drops In a Bet on Icahn
description: The stock of the USX Corporation fell sharply today as investors bet Carl C. Icahn would fail to notify the steel and energy giant by Thursday that he plans to wage a fight for control of the company at its annual meeting. Shares of USX lost $1.375, to $35.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Icahn, who owns about 13 percent of the Pittsburgh-based steel and energy giant, has threatened to raise his stake. In 1986, he made a $7 billion takeover offer for USX but later withdrew the bid.

title: Basic Shift In Japan Over Rates
description: While the Government has intervened heavily in the last two weeks to stabilize the tumbling stock market and bolster the yen, economists and business leaders here say these short-term tactics cannot alter the fundamental economic shift behind the turmoil: the era of extraordinarily low Japanese interest rates is ending.

title: Why Mandela Doesn't Take Role of a South African Dr. King;   White Moderate Parties
description: To the Editor:

title: Electro-Sensors Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $36,000, or 2 cents a share, for both the quarter and year.

title: Hearst Picks New Chief For Trade Book Group
description: The Hearst Trade Book Group, whose imprints include William Morrow & Company and Avon Books, named Howard Kaminsky its chief executive yesterday, effective April 1.

title: Uruguay Acts on Deficit
description: Uruguay raised fuel prices and utility charges Tuesday by up to 30 percent and proposed an increase in taxes to slash its budget deficit and cut inflation. The measures should cut the deficit to 2.5 percent of gross domestic product from 8.5 percent.

title: A.M.A. Urges Broad Health Plan
description: The American Medical Association today proposed a plan for providing all Americans with health care by expanding Medicaid and requiring employers to provide insurance to full-time employees.

title: Subaru of America reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $7.6 million on the sale of vehicle inventory which had been valued at historically lower costs in accordance with the LIFO method of inventory valuation. c-Net loss

title: Gene Implant Therapy Is Backed For Children With Rare Disease
description: Gene therapy for human disease took a leap from the theoretical realms of the laboratory toward the real world of practicing medicine today. A National Institutes of Health panel approved a proposal to treat children with a severe genetic disease by inserting new genes into their blood cells.

title: Signal Apparel reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $292,000, or 9 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. Latest year results included a gain of $585,000 related to reversion of assets from a terminated pension plan.

title: Pathe in $1.2 Billion Deal to Buy MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company, the film and television studio controlled by the financier Kirk Kerkorian, agreed today to be acquired by the Pathe Communications Corporation for $1.2 billion.

title: Canam Manac reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,448,00 and $8,106,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $500,000 for the quarter and $184,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Elaine de Kooning Tribute
description: A memorial tribute to the artist Elaine de Kooning is to be held at 6:30 P.M. on Monday in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, Seventh Street at Third Avenue. Among those scheduled to participate are the poet John Ashbery and the artists Grace Hartigan and Larry Rivers. Ms. de Kooning died of lung cancer on Feb. 1, 1989, at the age of 68.

title: Weiman Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,277,000 from an investment in a partnership and a charge of $259,000 due to an additional provision on the sale of a photographic division. c-Included a pretax charge of $920,000 for estimated charges on the sale of the photographic division.

title: Joe Sewell, 91, Hall of Fame Star Who Set Fewest-Strikeouts Mark
description: Joe Sewell, the sharp-eyed batter who struck out only 114 times in a 14-year major league career, died on Tuesday at his home in Mobile, Ala. Mr. Sewell, who was elected to the Hall of Fame by the veterans committee in 1977, was 91 years old and lived with his son, Dr. James W. Sewell.

title: Pan Am Offers Refund Policy
description: Pan American World Airways announced a new policy yesterday, promising a free flight to anyone with a valid complaint about service in first class on its flights between New York and San Francisco or Los Angeles and between Washington and Los Angeles.

title: Camouflaging Fur In Silk and Velvet
description: ''Vinyl, plastic, woven or nonwoven fabric, real or fake fur - if you like the material, you buy it,'' Karl Lagerfeld said. The designer for the Fendi collection of fur and ready-to-wear was explaining his eclectic approach after his show Tuesday night.

title: Give Me Injustice?
description: Many a national leader has served justice poorly, but President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast is certainly unusual in his open rejection of justice. Threatened by rising unrest in his West African nation, he declared this week that if faced with a choice between ''injustice and disorder, I shall not hesitate to choose injustice.'' A politically supple authoritarian, Mr. Houphouet-Boigny has ruled the Ivory Coast since it gained independence from France 30 years ago.

title: Suspected Spy Appeals His Ouster by State Dept.
description: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department diplomat dismissed last month after being named as a suspected Soviet agent, has protested his dismissal and will be granted a hearing before an appeals panel, a Government official said today.

title: Academy Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $630,000, or 1 cents a share and $1,503,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $509,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $3,494,000, or 5 cents a share, for the year, and the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,491,000.

title: Tile Mosaic Designs Created on a Whim
description: SUSAN BROWN and Denise Komisarket started out fixing bathroom floors for a Washington Heights landlord. ''That was the first time we'd ever done tile work,'' Ms. Komisarket recalled.

title: Iran Agrees to 2d U.N. Human Rights Inquiry
description: In another sign that Iran's leadership may be reaching for a closer relationship with the West, the Teheran Government agreed today to let a United Nations official make a second visit to the country to investigate accusations of unlawful executions, torture and other serious human rights violations.

title: Eastern Air Sale Of Routes Gains
description: The Justice Department has no objections to Eastern Airlines' proposed sale of its Latin American routes to American Airlines, the department said today. The proposed $471 million deal must still be approved by the Transportation Department and the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York overseeing the reorganization of Eastern.

title: Style Setters, Take a Number
description: IT'S called the Design 100. It's the World According to Metropolitan Home. The home furnishings magazine has awarded self-styled Oscars to fashion, interior and furniture designers; architects, business executives and no less than world leaders for design products and ideas.

title: Petroleum Equipment Tools reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Advatex Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss of $47,484 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $145,902, or 3 cents a share, for the year.

title: Goodspeed Musical Season
description: The Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., will open its 28th season on April 18 with ''The Chocolate Soldier,'' a musical based on George Bernard Shaw's ''Arms and the Man.'' The season will also include ''Pal Joey,'' opening July 4, and ''Bells Are Ringing,'' opening Sept. 26. Information: (203) 873-8668.

title: Temco Service Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Dance;   Aggression in an Atrium
description: For the last year and a half, the Arts amd Events Program directed by Alice Contini at the World Financial Center, adjoining Battery Park City, has produced many commissioned premieres.

title: Orioles Reward Olson
description: Gregg Olson, the 1989 American League Rookie of the Year, came to terms with the Baltimore Orioles yesterday on a one-year contract that will make him one of the highest-paid second-year players ever.

title: Cypress-I.B.M. License Talks Fail
description: Negotiations have collapsed between the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation on a proposal for Cypress to become a licensed manufacturer of I.B.M.'s 4-megabit and 16-megabit dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's. Terms were not disclosed, but Cypress had proposed trading technology and some cash for the license.

title: Photographic Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Escalade Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After $1.65 million restructuring charge at Escalade Inc.'s Marcy Fitness Products Inc. c-Net income d-Included a gain from an accounting change of $161,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Builders Transport reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from early extinguishment of debentures of $3,224,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Many West Germans are troubled by the tone of world debate on German reunification. A tone, they say, that indicates serious doubt about West Germany's commitment to peace and democracy. A1

title: Mining Services International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included net credits of $98,000, or 2 cents a share, and $35,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Coast Guard Says Oil Spill Was Major
description: More than 100,000 gallons of home heating oil spilled into the Arthur Kill on Tuesday after two mysterious explosions ripped apart a barge that had just taken on 4.2 million gallons of oil, Coast Guard officials said yesterday.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: STUDENTS who work a small number of hours during the school year or reasonable hours over the summer may show some academic and social gains, according to surveys of high school seniors conducted by the University of Michigan.

title: Weatherford International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $7,311,000 for the quarter and year, related to restructuring. The year also included an accounting adjustment gain of $526,000, or 4 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Congress, Hoping to Aid New Democracies, Finds Itself Shackled by Budget
description: As democracy blooms in capitals from Managua to Prague, policy makers in Washington are struggling to muster the foreign aid dollars and the political will to bolster a new world order.

title: Spartech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,242,000. The 1989 year restated to reflect sale of the polyethylene film division.

title: Poland's Inflation Slows
description: Poland's inflation rate fell to 7 percent in February from 78 percent in January, but industrial production also plunged, the Central Statistical Office said today. Production for January and February was 23.5 percent lower than in the corresponding period of 1989.

title: Farm Credit System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses on the repurchase of debt of $6 million for the quarter and $174 million for the year. Share earnings are not applicable. The latest quarter figures included $54 million from reversal of loan loss allowances; year-ago figures included $211 million from such reversals. Latest year figures included $285 million from reversal of loan loss allowances; the 1988 year figures included $680 million from such reversals. Data included Farm Credit insurance fund; data previously reported at Sept. 30 excluded the insurance fund.

title: The President's Bomb
description: President Bush planted a bomb right in the middle of maneuvers toward Israeli-Palestinian talks, lit it and stood back to see what would happen.

title: Texas Bank Said to Win Bidding for Savings Unit
description: The First Gibraltar Bank, which was created in 1988 when a group led by the financier Ronald O. Perelman consolidated five ailing Texas savings and loans, has emerged as the winner of a bidding contest for the San Antonio Savings Association, a person close to First Gibraltar's owners said today.

title: The House ethics committee decided yesterday not to continue its investigation of Representative Newt Gingrich. (The New York Times);   Ethics Panel in House Drops Its Investigation of Gingrich
description: The House ethics committee decided today to drop its investigation of Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip.

title: The Joys and Woes of Running the City Opera
description: When Christopher Keene became general director of the New York City Opera a year ago, he faced several acute problems. The most immediately threatening - the expiration of the company's contracts with its orchestra, soloists, dancers, chorus and staging personnel - resulted in his worst nightmare, a strike that led to the cancellation of what would have been his inaugural season.

title: Falcon Cable Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shearson to Dismiss 200 In Investment Banking
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. will dismiss about 18 percent of the workers at its investment banking division as part of a restructuring of the firm, Shearson executives said yesterday.

title: ISRAEL POSTPONES PEACE-PLAN VOTE
description: The Israeli Cabinet failed to complete a long and serious debate on the peace process and on the Israeli Government today. They postponed a critical vote until Sunday morning.

title: Surgery for New Rights Chief
description: Arthur Fletcher, the newly appointed chairman of the Federal Civil Rights Commission, today underwent his second triple-bypass heart operation in less than six months. Mr. Fletcher, 65 years old, entered George Washington University Hospital on Monday after doctors concluded that previous bypass surgery ''didn't take,'' said Barbara Brooks, a commission spokeswoman. He is expected to need six to eight weeks to recuperate.

title: Lindal Cedar Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $76,130 for the quarter and $453,970 for the year from discontinued operations, a loss of $172,414 on disposal from discontinued operations for the both periods, and the quarter also included an extraordinary loss of $97,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $204,237 for the quarter and $406,236 for the year.

title: Infotron Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Burns Throws 37 Hopeful Pitches
description: Britt Burns made his first pitch today in a comeback attempt with the Yankees, and although the reviews were not all favorable, the results gave the left-handed pitcher enough encouragement to continue.

title: Lawsuit Faults AIDS Care In New York State Prisons
description: Lack of AIDS prevention and care in New York State prisons is sentencing countless inmates to needless suffering and premature death, the Legal Aid Society has charged in a Federal class action lawsuit.

title: Reviews/Music;   Borodin and the Soviet Style
description: As the Soviet Union's barriers crumble, so certainly in time will one of the last remaining musical enclaves of idiosyncratic style. The Soviet school has prospered perhaps by its isolation; and in the process, it has more or less ignored contemporary trends toward lighter, finer musical phrasing and attention to historical accuracy. Its musicians simply go on applying their own values to whatever music is placed before them.

title: Trenary Takes Lead; Ito Far Back
description: Compulsory figures passed into history today in the world figure skating championships, but not without profound impact on Midori Ito of Japan, the defending women's champion.

title: Lockheed Rejects Effort by Simmons
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons said the Lockheed Corporation had rejected his effort to bring the issue of ''golden parachutes,'' or executive severence agreements tied to takeovers, to a formal vote of the company's shareholders. In a letter dated Tuesday, D. M. Tellep, Lockheed's chairman, wrote to Mr. Simmons that the proposal ''would create a diversion from other important business to be considered at the meeting.''

title: Boy, 13, Arrested in Burning of 11-Year-Old
description: An 11-year-old Brooklyn boy was abducted on his way to school yesterday morning, taken to a dingy garage, beaten, bound and finally set on fire by another youth who tried force him to smoke crack, the police said.

title: Policeman Slain in Kashmir
description: Kashmiri militants shot and killed an Indian policeman today and killed a Muslim they suspected of spying for New Delhi, the Governor of Jammu and Kashmir state said. Governor Jagmohan said the militants ambushed the Indian security forces as one patrol was taking over from another in a brief break in the curfew in place in the city for six weeks.

title: Personal Health
description: Every week or so, a 2-year-old with no known digestive problems suddenly grasps his abdomen in pain, vomits, then falls asleep. He awakes a few hours later acting perfectly fine.

title: Gap Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: The company said the latest periods' results included a one-time charge of 18 cents a share incurred in the fourth quarter for costs associated with the previously announced closing of its Hemisphere stores. The latest quarter and year results are for 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Special Outings for Retarded
description: Anthony Di Salvo believed entertainment for mentally retarded people was too often limited to arts and crafts behind closed doors.

title: Middle Age Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: To the Editor:

title: Canbra Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Armchair That Looks Like a Cart
description: ''SEVEN years ago, when I took my mother to a design shop in Berlin, she looked at all the wire-mesh furniture and said it reminded her of shopping carts,'' recalled Frank Schreiner, a designer who heads Stiletto Studios in West Berlin. ''That's how I came up with the idea.''

title: Review/Art;   A New Arts Complex That's Hard on Art
description: Until the local hero James (Buster) Douglas won the heavyweight boxing championship four weeks ago and was paraded through downtown Columbus, probably the biggest media event here in recent months was the opening of the Wexner Center for the Visual Arts on the campus of Ohio State University.

title: Ecology & Environment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: Revenue represented gross revenues.

title: A Nice Neighborhood
description: ''It's hip to be square,'' went the refrain of a rock tune popular a couple of years ago. Could there be better evidence of that than Fred Rogers, star of the Public Broadcasting System's longest-running show, ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood''?

title: A Sakharov Heir Is Back in the Arena
description: After a decade of suffering in the state labor camps and a day's triumph in the election booths, Sergei A. Kovalev, heir by conscience to Andrei D. Sakharov, seemed entitled to gentle laughter at his kitchen table.

title: Styles From Tudor to 60's
description: ''IN England there's an enormous move right now to use styles from the past in different ways,'' said Stephen Calloway, a curator of paintings at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. ''But people are often puzzled as to how to properly go about it.''

title: President Is Promoted To Top Post at MMR
description: The MMR Holding Corporation, the nation's third-largest mechanical and electrical contracting company, yesterday named Robert G. Bening chief executive. He will succeed James B. Rutland, who is appealing his conviction last year for bid-rigging.

title: Productivity Gain Stands
description: The Government left unchanged today its earlier estimates of gains in productivity of two-tenths of 1 percent for the fourth quarter of last year and of nine-tenths of 1 percent for the year.

title: Weingarten Realty Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that 1989 results included a one-time franchise-tax refund of $800,000, while 1988 results included a $1.1 million gain from the sale of interest-rate swap contracts, a $1.8 million lease cancellation fee and a $4.5 million gain from the sale of property.

title: No Charges Are Filed on Suffolk Wiretaps
description: A report released today by a special prosecutor investigating accusations of illegal wiretaps by the Suffolk County police said there was no basis for criminal charges, although the incidents did occur.

title: Doctors Say They Monitored Gathers
description: LEAD: The doctors who treated Hank Gathers for a heart ailment said today that they had closely monitored the Loyola Marymount basketball star after he fainted in a game in December. But the doctors declined to release any information about his diagnosis or whether they had told the player he risked death by returning to action.

title: Dinkins Appoints a New Head of WNYC
description: In an effort to put his own stamp on the city's television and radio stations, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Thomas B. Morgan, a writer and former political aide, to be president of the WNYC Communications Group. The group includes two radio stations, WNYC-AM and WNYC-FM, and a television station, WNYC-TV, Channel 31, all of them licensed and partly financed by the city.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Newport Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $164,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $80,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year, both from the repurchase of 10-percent senior secured convertible notes.

title: Odyssey Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $766,654 and $1,077,950 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $540,450 and $1,162,071 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Minority Enrollment Efforts Show Gains at Law Schools
description: After years of efforts to recruit more minority students, law schools are beginning to make progress, with 22 percent more minority students enrolled in the current school year than three years ago, the American Bar Association reports.

title: Reliance Electric Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for both periods $16 million in non-recurring expenses related to the company's December 1989 self- tender offer, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $16,000,000 which included gain on the sale of Toledo Scale, among other things. c-Net income d-After a loss of $3 million from discontinued operations. No per share figures were provided because the company is owned by an investor group, but has preferred shares traded on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Esterline Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extrarodinary tax credit of $254,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said that first quarter sales and net earnings reflect the first full-quarter contribution of the six former Criton Technologies' companies acquired in late September 1989. In addition, the company said that the share earnings calculation reflects a reduction in the average number of shares outstanding from 8.5 million last year to 6.6 million this year, a result of the repurchase of 1.9 million shares from Dyson-Kissner- Moran Corp. at the time of the Criton acquisition.

title: United Security Fincl Corp. of Illinois reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gain, before taxes and expenses, of $553,433 from the sale of a private placement which had been held as an investment. c-Net loss

title: Nonconsenting Adults Pay for Junk Bond Orgy;   Fatal Fines
description: To the Editor:

title: Componentguard Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: National Junior Police Force Wouldn't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME REPAIR
description: DOOR lock problems do not always require the removal or replacement of the entire knob and latch assembly. Most often, it is sufficient to remove the lock cylinder, the part with the keyhole. The cylinder can then be taken to a locksmith for repair, replacement or changing the key.

title: Ethnic Albanian Majority Fights Serbia and Party in a Yugoslav Province
description: They have scant access to the local press, none to large meeting halls, no computer or fax machine, no legal status and no bank account, but the freshly minted League of Democrats of Kosovo, representing ethnic Albanians, is rapidly becoming a major political force in Yugoslavia.

title: U.S. PLANS TO MAKE SWEEPING CHANGES IN LABELS ON FOOD
description: The Bush Administration announced plans today for mandatory nutritional labeling on virtually all packaged foods.

title: Legal Help for N.C. State
description: The state Attorney General's office and a private lawyer will help North Carolina State negotiate a contract settlement with Coach Jim Valvano, officials said Wednesday.

title: Luis Carlos Prestes, 92, Brazilian Communist
description: Luis Carlos Prestes, who led Brazil's Communist opposition for half a century, died today of cancer, doctors said. He was 92 years old. Mr. Prestes had suffered from leukemia, said Dr. Peylor Meira, administrator of the Beneficiencia Portuguesa Hospital, where Mr. Prestes died.

title: Ronson Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $71,000 and $251,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $58,000 and $226,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the discontinued operations' loss for the year included income of $77,000 as the result of the reversal of prior legal expenses. Results for latest year included income of $398,000 as a result of the settlement of a long-term receivable which had been reserved. Results for 1989 and 1988 have been restated to reflect the decision taken in December 1989 to discontinue the Ronson Metals Corp. operations. Both year ago periods included income of $105,000 related to recognition of previously deferred income, and the year also included income of $92,000 as a result of an abatement of interest and penalties for prior years. Preferred-share dividends were $48,000, compared with $49,000 in the latest and year-ago quarters and $196,000 versus $82,000 for 1989 and 1988, respectively.

title: Fund Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly mixed for the week ended yesterday, with tax-exempt funds rising and taxable funds off. ''Given the rate of inflation, interest rates here are aggressively higher by 75 to 100 basis points than what they should be in this business cycle,'' said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/ Donoghue's.

title: 'Love Affair With Style'
description: ''THEY had a flair that was incomparable,'' said Gerald Stiebel, the owner of Rosenberg & Stiebel, an art and antiques gallery on 57th Street.

title: DNA Plant Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arrest in Police Shooting
description: A 21-year-old man sought by New York City authorities in connection with the wounding of an undercover police officer last December was arrested tonight in Prince George's County, Md. Sgt. Paul Drula, a Prince George's Sheriff's Department spokesman, said that Luis Campbell was taken into custody without incident in Temple Hills and that the F.B.I. and District of Columbia Police assisted in the arrest. Mr. Campbell and another man were accused of ambushing two undercover New York City Police officers on Dec. 21 during a pre-arranged drug buy.

title: British Gas Sets Big Canadian Bid
description: In an attempt to build its Canadian gas business, British Gas P.L.C. bid $1.1 billion (Canadian) today for the Consumers Gas Company of Canada.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Hearst Magazines International, to Bozell International.

title: Balfour Maclaine Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Balfour Maclaine has a 74 percent equity interest in American Vision Centers Inc.

title: Chronicle
description: In his book on the Vietnam War, MORLEY SAFER delivers an unflattering picture of BILL MOYERS, then press secretary to President Lyndon B. Johnson. A chapter in ''Flashbacks'' recalls a high point in Mr. Safer's career as a CBS News correspondent, when in 1965 he filmed Marines setting a village aflame with Zippo lighters.

title: Serving Up the Future on Silver Plate
description: MASSIMO IOSA-GHINI, one of Italy's leading cartoonists, has a vision right out of science-fiction. In addition to expressing it in his cartoons, Mr. Iosa-Ghini is also an illustrator, painter and furniture maker.

title: Virgil M. Rogers, 92; Was Syracuse Dean And Headed Schools
description: Virgil M. Rogers, a former dean of education at Syracuse University who had served as a local school superintendent in three states died Saturday at the Birchwood Care Center in Syracuse, N.Y. He was 92 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: Sonesta International Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included pretax gain of $1,600,000 from settlement of a claim.

title: Ambitious Financier Behind Pathe
description: Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier, has stepped smartly from country to country and left a trail of lawsuits as he built a financial empire, rising far from his humble beginnings as a waiter on the Queen Elizabeth ocean liner.

title: 5 Weeklies Are Acquired
description: Five weekly newspapers in southwestern Connecticut and southern New York have been sold to Southern Connecticut Newspapers Inc., a unit of the Times Mirror Company that publishes The Advocate in Stamford and The Greenwich Time.

title: Environmentalists Fear Spills' Cumulative Toll
description: The multiple oil spills that have sullied the waters in and near the Arthur Kill in recent months threaten to reverse the progress that has been made in restoring wildlife to the narrow waterway separating New Jersey and Staten Island, environmentalists said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday showing the 1989 population of bald eagles described the National Wildlife Federation's midwinter eagle survey incompletely and omitted or misstated figures for some states. The survey includes migratory Canadian eagles and does not reflect the status of the nesting population of the lower 48 states; not all states are covered in the survey. The survey found 30 eagles in Massachusetts, 3,063 in Washington, 337 in Wisconsin, 1 in West Virginia, 521 in Wyoming, 8 in Delaware and 24 in North Dakota.

title: Gypsy Joe Harris, 44; Boxer Blind in an Eye
description: Gypsy Joe Harris, a welterweight contender whose boxing career ended with the discovery that he had concealed blindness in one eye, died on Tuesday. He was 44 years old. Mr. Harris, who suffered four heart attacks in the last two years, died at Temple University Hospital, where he had been a patient since Feb. 10. His sister, Daaiyah Waheed, attributed the death to heart failure.

title: Baseball Negotiators Try Again, But Arbitration Is Unresolved
description: Negotiators in baseball's labor dispute, contining to talk as the start of the regular season teeters precariously, exchanged ideas into the evening yesterday in an effort to resolve the issue of salary-arbitration eligibility.

title: Cheney vs. Webster
description: Does the right hand of the Bush Administration know what the left hand is doing? Not, apparently, on the crucial questions of what's happening, and likely to happen, in the Communist world, and therefore on how the U.S. should respond.

title: Takeover of Savings Unit Is Blocked by Federal Judge
description: In a case that will test the constitutionality of a key part of the savings and loan bailout legislation passed last summer, a Federal judge today barred regulators from seizing an ailing Chicago savings and loan association for 10 days. The move came after lawyers for the institution argued that the Government had disregarded its requests for assistance and that top regulators were unconstitutionally exercising authority.

title: Avinda Video reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dinkins Names New Chief Of Social Services Agency
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Barbara Sabol, the executive deputy commissioner of New York State's Department of Social Services, to head the city's Human Resources Administration - a job Mr. Dinkins has said is tougher than his.

title: Sutter Rejoins Cards As a Pitching Coach
description: Bruce Sutter, who achieved 300 saves in a 12-season career as a reliever and was one of the first pitchers to have success with the split-finger fastball, has returned to the St. Louis Cardinals as a minor league pitching instructor.

title: Wounds of 2 Parties;   Attack on Bush's East Europe Policy Hits a Target, but Then It Backfires
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt attacked President Bush this week in what many see as a vulnerable spot, accusing him of a halting, episodic articulation of American foreign policy goals and of pursuing a foreign policy that is ''adrift, without vision, without imagination.''

title: Applebee's International Inc. reports earnings for 14wks to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Air Group Inc., Seattle, said it was being sued by shareholders who are seeking an injunction in Deleware Chancery Court against a deal to sell 15 percent of Alaska Air stock to the International Lease Finance Corporation, a California airplane leasing company.

title: Postal Service Gains From U.P.S. Rate Rise
description: Even as the United States Postal Service seeks permission to raise its rates substantially about a year from now, it is benefiting from a windfall of new business at the expense of one of its main rivals, United Parcel Service Inc.

title: Citizens Security Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
At Pantheon, Closed Books
description: LEAD: Pantheon Books, a $20 million division of the $800 million Random House publishing empire, itself part of the $10 billion Newhouse family media conglomerate, has been in the news for more than a week - not, as might have been predicted, in the cultural pages of this paper, but in its financial sections.

title: Quotation of the Day
