description: ''The grocery store has become a Tower of Babel, and consumers need to be linguists, scientists and mind readers to understand the many labels they see. Vital information is missing, and frankly some unfounded health claims are being made.''

title: Anti-Abortion Proviso on Foreign Aid Upheld
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday upheld a Federal policy barring family planning aid to private foreign organizations that perform abortions.

title: Books of The Times;   The Making of a Senator In the Stealing of an Election
description: The Years of Lyndon Johnson

title: Cade Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the improved earnings and reduced sales are a result of its restructuring in 1989.

title: Philadelphia Subway Crash Kills 3; 150 Are Hurt
description: The last three cars of a six-car subway train derailed and crashed into steel pillars in a downtown tunnel during the morning rush hour today, killing three people and injuring about 150 others. At least six of the injured were in critical condition, including those crushed when the steel pillars pierced their car.

title: Yanks Renew Cary Pact
description: The Yankees yesterday completed their 40-man roster by renewing the contracts of the pitcher Chuck Cary and the outfielder Luis Polonia.

title: Vista Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sixers Move Ahead Of Knicks
description: The Knicks came to Philadelphia tonight to protect the Atlantic Division lead they had held since Nov. 18, when the National Basketball Association season was only 15 days old. But by the time the game at the Spectrum was one period old, it was obvious that they were not only going to relinquish the lead to the 76ers, but they were also going to be embarrassed.

title: Education Plays Role In Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Builder of Companies Takes on New Project
description: When last heard from in 1985, S. Robert Davis, an entrepreneur from Columbus, Ohio, had been defeated in a proxy battle for Orange-Co. Inc. a big citrus-growing and processing company he had built from a small investment.

title: Mobil Wins Refinery Vote
description: Voters in the Los Angeles suburb of Torrance have soundly defeated a proposal that would have required new pollution controls at the Mobil Corporation's refinery operations that could have cost $100 million.

title: Cobi Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,923,000, or 8 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: China Offers New Sign That Austerity Is Easing
description: In another sign that the Government is easing its tough austerity policy, one of China's biggest banks said today that it would provide more than $500 million in new loans to troubled enterprises in China's principal industrial regions.

title: Rediscovering the Warmth of Chestnut
description: LEAD: Chestnut - the sweet, edible nut-bearing chestnut - was a good, all-round wood, used in furniture and in building because it was available rather than because it excelled in any particular function. Gustav Stickley, for example, used it throughout Craftsman Farms, his house in Morris Plains, N.J.

title: Cuba Says It Is Ending Military Aid to Nicaragua
description: President Fidel Castro of Cuba said today that he is cutting off all military aid to Nicaragua before the new government takes office there next month, according to Cuba's official press agency, Prensa Latina.

title: In West Germany, Anxiety Over Unity
description: In the turbulent debate about German unification, West Germany's intellectuals reflect a national mood of confusion - a profoundly troubled mix of anticipation, anxiety and resentment.

title: Analogic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included net gain of $4.6 million from sale of company's interest in joint venture. The company's revenue for the year-ago 6-month period excluded a $7,513,000 gain from the sale of the remaining interest of the joint venture, Medical Electronics Laboratories Inc. Including this gain, it would bring total revenue for the 6-month period to $72,652,000.

title: DNA Tests Link Golub To Killing, Expert Says
description: A forensic expert from a genetic testing laboratory said today that bloodstains found at the scene of Kelly Ann Tinyes's slaying had identical DNA ''fingerprints'' to the blood of Robert Golub.

title: Pratt Order Placed By Singapore Air
description: In a deal potentially worth $2.2 billion, Singapore Airlines has placed orders and options for 234 PW4000 Pratt & Whitney engines, the jet-engine maker and the airline announced. The orders come on the heels of a record-breaking $12 billion year for Pratt in 1989 and represent ''the largest single order for the PW4000 on record,'' a Pratt spokesman, David Long, said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Lois Geller has been named president of AC&R Direct, a division of AC&R Advertising.

title: Datamark Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Legislation on Taxes
description: Plans to introduce legislation to end the tax deductibility of cigarette advertising in New York State and New York City will be announced today by Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis and Councilman Stanley Michels, both of Manhattan.

title: Banks' Profits Fell 35% in '89
description: Profits at American banks fell 35 percent in 1989, to $16.3 billion, largely because bad loans sharply eroded earnings in the second half of the year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: Route 66 Journal;   Now, Only Ghosts Ride On Highway of Dreams
description: From his easy chair behind the counter, Ernest Edwards likes to tell this story.

title: Review/Concert;   Vienna Philharmonic, Mahler and Levine
description: Of the dozens of orchestras that regularly visit New York, none generate quite the air of expectancy that accompanies the arrival of the Vienna Philharmonic. A skeptic might attribute that in part to the cumulative effect of publicity that over the years has established it in the minds of concertgoers as the most glamorous of all international ensembles. But the doubts of even the stubbornest skeptic might have been swept away by the Mahler Third Symphony that the Viennese performed under James Levine's baton on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: How the West Was Warmed: Quilts of Yore
description: IN 1984 a nonprofit organization called the California Heritage Quilt Project was formed to study and record the history of California quilts and quilt makers. The culmination of that project was an exhibition that traveled all over the state and the recent publication of ''Ho for California: Pioneer Women and Their Quilts'' (E. P. Dutton, $22.50).

title: Barely Off the Beaten Track in Milan
description: For the thousands gathered here for the winter collections, most of the action is in the Fiera, a mammoth complex of buildings for trade exhibitions where most high-fashion shows take place in a central building. But surrounding it are other buildings where mass-market manufacturers and smaller houses take booths to display their wares to buyers from all over the world.

title: Ex-Rep. Diggs Back in Politics
description: Charles Diggs Jr., who resigned as a Congressman from Michigan in 1980 after being convicted of taking payroll kickbacks, said today that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates. ''My principal reason for running is to be in Annapolis during the reapportionment consideration in 1991 and '92,'' he said. Mr. Diggs, who founded the Congressional Black Caucus, said he wanted to use his experience to help Maryland blacks when political districts are redrawn after the census.

title: Testimony of High H.U.D. Figure Is Being Sought Under Immunity
description: Congressional investigators are expected to announce today that they will seek immunity for a former top aide to Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Reagan Administration's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, in exchange for what the investigators say will be some of the most damaging testimony to date about Mr. Pierce's role in political favoritism at the housing department.

title: Shnork Kaloustian, 76, An Armenian Prelate
description: His Beatitude Archbishop Shnork Kaloustian, the Patriarch of the Armenians in Turkey, died Tuesday at Nork Hospital in Yerevan, Soviet Armenia. He was 76 years old and lived in Istanbul.

title: Noma Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $10,181,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Offering by Hertz Totals $50 Million
description: The Hertz Corporation yesterday priced $50 million in senior subordinated notes due 1997 through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: MY BLT was more sprouts than bacon, and my companion's sandwich was tuna mixed with tofu. The vegetarian chili was highly recommended. Clearly, we were dining in a college town, or the kind of town where men who used to have a ''spread'' (two acres) and an ''old lady'' (pigtailed, and a dab-hand with chapatis) go to turn into chefs and carpenters. This town that I am visiting is both, and something else as well. It is the America in which I never lived.

title: Officer Asserts He Was Target Of a Fatal Shot
description: A detective wounded in a shoot-out in which a state investigator was killed on Monday said the only shot fired by a suspect was aimed at him, according to an affidavit filed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about contra rebels in Honduras misidentified the large lake in southwestern Nicaragua. It is Lake Nicaragua, not Lake Managua.

title: Durkin Hayes Publishing reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said figures for 1988 are not comparable as Durkin Hayes was formed Jan. 1, 1989 after the merger of Listen for Pleasure and Hayes Publishing Ltd. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Article 833890 -- No Title
description: The Public Service Commission today rejected a $445 million request for higher telephone rates that had come under heavy political criticism because it was negotiated between the New York Telephone Company and the commission's staff rather than through the usual process of public hearings.

title: A Ford Moves Up at Ford Motor
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a series of executive changes today that included an important promotion for William Clay Ford Jr., improving his chances of one day running the company that his great-grandfather founded 87 years ago.

title: Reviews/Music;   Nettle, Markham and Pianos
description: David Nettle and Richard Markham, two British pianists who have been performing as a duo since 1979, made their New York debut on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Their playing was finely integrated, and melodic lines frequently passed from one piano to the other without the slighest variation in timbre or dynamics. At its best, their sound was appealingly transparent, although that was not always the case.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Telecredit Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Clean Fuels, Clean Air
description: As the Senate votes this week on proposals for amending the Clean Air Act, Americans' health and environment are on the line. If they are to be protected, the Senate must make long-overdue choices about fuels to be burned in cars and trucks.

title: INSIDE
description: Abortion Pill Called Safe

title: Ian Horvath Memorial
description: A memorial service for Ian Horvath, a founder of the Cleveland Ballet and a former soloist with the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater, is to be held at 3:45 P.M. on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. Among those scheduled to perform at the service, which is free and open to the public, are the dancers Cynthia Gregory and Christopher Gillis. Mr. Horvath, producing director of the Jose Limon Foundation, died of AIDS on Jan. 5 at the age of 46.

title: Gitano Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GORBACHEV WANTS LITHUANIA TO PAY BILLIONS TO SECEDE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has demanded that Lithuania pay compensation equivalent to $33 billion if the republic goes ahead with plans to secede from the Soviet Union, Lithuanian officials said today.

title: Futures Market Trading Model
description: The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that they had pared to 13 the number of companies competing to build models of electronic trading cards.

title: Review/Theater;   The Danger of Drugs, From People Who Know
description: ''Acid Paradise'' tells a familiar story of a likable young man gone wrong in the world of drugs. But the story is given the vivid and committed treatment of good street theater in a production presented by the Instituto Arte Teatral Internacional on Sunday afternoon at the atmospheric little theater of Cuando House, where it will be performed again today and tomorrow at 8 in English and on Saturday at 8 and Sunday at 4 in Spanish.

title: Nonconsenting Adults Pay for Junk Bond Orgy
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Change; the Man Rides On
description: Selling cigarettes these days would seem to be a difficult, even doomed, art. Not only has smoking long since fallen from social grace, but more recently campaigns directed at the groups that remain the most faithful smokers - women and minorities -have opened cigarette makers to charges of racism and sexism.

title: Bovar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $15,267,000, or 43 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,147,000, or 27 cents a share, for the year which is from the sale of land drilling operations. c-Net loss d-After extraordinary charges of $4,594,000 for the quarter and $88,122,000 for the year, which is mainly from the discontinuance of the offshore drilling operations. The company said it paid $4.2 million in preferred share dividends in all of 1988 and $1.1 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. There were no preferred share dividend payments in the latest year or quarter, following the company's financial restructuring last May. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Arab and Palestinian political setbacks in light of the changes in Eastern Europe misstated the number of Soviet Jewish immigrants to Israel. The highest monthly number of immigrants was roughly 5,000, in February.

title: Outboard Marine To Lay Off 3,100
description: The Outboard Marine Corporation, the manufacturer of Johnson and Evinrude outboard engines, announced plans to lay off 3,100 workers temporarily because of lagging boat sales. The company said it will stop building boat engines for several weeks.

title: Hydraulic Hose Broke Before Shuttle Landed
description: A ruptured hose spilled five gallons of hydraulic fluid inside the space shuttle Atlantis and caused a brief drop in pressure just before it landed Sunday but the astronauts were never in danger, the space agency has disclosed.

title: PEN Fiction Prize Nominees
description: Four novels and a collection of stories were nominated for the 1990 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction. The award is given each year to the most distinguished work of fiction by an American author published the preceding year in the United States.

title: Robert J. Flemma, 56, A Heart Researcher
description: Dr. Robert J. Flemma, a surgeon who led research into an artificial heart, died of heart disease on Wednesday at St. Luke's Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived in River Hills, a Milwaukee suburb.

title: As Italy's Communists Meet, Some Fight Tide
description: Fifty years ago, as a student at the University of Rome, Pietro Ingrao joined what then was the clandestine Italian Communist Party.

title: Lassonde Indus reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Sizzler Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
Treasuries Mixed in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday, as dealers reacted to comments by Manuel Johnson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, by selling shorter-term issues and buying long-term bonds.

title: USX Will Allow Vote On Proposal by Icahn
description: The USX Corporation, the giant steel and energy company, said yesterday that it had agreed to allow shareholders to vote on a proposal by the investor Carl C. Icahn to incorporate the steel business and spin off at least 80 percent of the company.

title: Telephone & Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $105,000 for the quarter, and the year included income from discontinued operations of $731,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Review/Piano;   Philippe Cassard in Debut
description: A piano competition born in Dublin in May 1988 had repercussions in New York on Wednesday evening, when the young French pianist Philippe Cassard gave his New York debut recital at Alice Tully Hall. The first prize in the G.P.A. Dublin International Piano Competition, sponsored by the G.P.A. (Guinness Peat Aviation) Group, includes recitals in London, Paris, New York, Vienna and Rome, and Mr. Cassard came to claim part of his award.

title: Review/Television;   Adventures in the Fight Against Drug Dealers
description: While some shows are already turning to reruns, the commercial networks continue to bring on new candidates for the weekly ratings competitions. Two of the more recent entries are ''Nasty Boys,'' on NBC tonight at 9, and ''H.E.L.P.,'' on ABC tomorrow at 8 P.M. Action is the main word in each case. And the executive producer of both series is Dick Wolf, formerly script consultant for ''Hill Street Blues'' and an executive producer of ''Miami Vice.''

title: Mother Accuses Sperm Bank of a Mixup
description: A 33-year-old woman has sued a Manhattan fertility clinic and a sperm bank, charging that they mistakenly substituted another man's sperm for her husband's. The woman is white, as was her late husband; she said the donor is black.

title: Profit-Sharing Pay Is Lower at Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said its 1989 profits would generate $166 million in profit-sharing payments, or about $1,025 for each employee, roughly one-third of last year's amount and the lowest payout since 1984.

title: Eastco Industrial Safety reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Fifth Dimension Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-recurring gain of $41,210, equaled to after-tax earnings of 4 cents a share. Corrected from Tuesday, March 6.

title: Nicaragua Votes for End to Washington's Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Sigma Designs reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
I.R.S. Says It's Turned Up No Reports on Ritter's Trust
description: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it had found no indication that a tax-free charitable trust of nearly $1 million set up by the Rev. Bruce Ritter of Covenant House in 1983 to aid runaway youths had filed annual reports with the Government, as required.

title: Central Guaranty Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   The Stresses In Marketing To Minorities
description: The Advertising column on March 9, about advertising to minorities, omitted a name among founders of the Mingo Group agency. In addition to Frank L. Mingo Jr. and Caroline R. Jones, they included Richard A. Guilmenot 3d. Mr. Guilmenot recently pointed out the error after a letter he wrote in March failed to arrive at The Times.

title: Top Operating Post Is Filled By Kemper
description: Continuing a corporate reorganization that has paid off in the stock market, the Kemper Corporation yesterday named David B. Mathis president and chief operating officer among several other executive changes.

title: $158 Million Bid for Justin
description: Justin Industries, a maker of bricks and leather boots, said today that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer for $18.50 a share, or about $158 million, for all of its 8.6 million shares.

title: Upper West Side Area Named Historic District
description: The New York City Board of Estimate acted yesterday to preserve the architectural character of much of 17 blocks on the Upper West Side of Manhattan by approving the designation of the area as the Riverside-West End Historic District.

title: How Malcolm X Handled Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music;   The Holmes Brothers' Complex Brand of Rocking Blues
description: There is a notion, spread by the music industry, that once a musical style no longer defines its times commercially, it is defunct and worthless. The Holmes Brothers, a New York-based rhythm-and-blues group that played at Mondo Cane on Monday night and that has just released one of the best blues albums of the year, kill that idea quickly. Rocking through a series of blues, rhythm-and-blues, and soul standards from the 1950's and 60's, the group showed that the music's audience - in this case, all white and young - may change, but the music need not lose any of its inventiveness or sense of play.

title: SENATOR TO SEEK BIG MILITARY CUTS
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee said today that he would seek to cut $12 billion from the Bush Administration's proposed military budget of $303.3 billion for the next fiscal year.

title: Reviews/Film;   Sibling Rivalry on the Road In a Vintage Coupe de Ville
description: ''Coupe de Ville'' is the story of one car that has its gas cap hidden in its tail fin and three brothers who wear their personality traits on their sleeves. Bobby Libner (Patrick Dempsey) is the baby and the wild one, the cute cutup, the brother most likely to yell obscenities at a teacher. Buddy (Arye Gross) is the middle brother, the peacemaker, the one who wears Bermuda shorts and loves a girl named Tammy. Marvin (Daniel Stern) is the eldest and bossiest. He is in the Air Force, likes things orderly and has a terrible temper, which is often on display. Each brother gets on the others' nerves.

title: Study Calls $2,200 Heart Drug No Better Than Cheaper One
description: An expensive drug that is widely used to treat heart attacks in the United States is no more effective than a cheaper alternative commonly used in Europe, researchers in Italy reported yesterday.

title: Notebook;   Japanese Bid for Sunday Silence
description: Sunday Silence had his first jog of the year at Santa Anita Monday, and some unexpected possibilities for last season's Horse of the Year began to unfold in the next few days. Sunday Silence will be heading to Chicago in August for a showdown with Easy Goer in a special race at Arlington Park, and could end his season on the Japanese island of Hokkaido.

title: Breaking the School Hammerlock
description: After barely two months on the job, New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, can claim an impressive victory: an agreement with leaders of the principals' union to allow transfers of ineffective principals. The agreement still requires approval by union committees and the State Legislature, but it marks a solid advance for Mr. Fernandez's reform agenda.

title: Executive Resigns at MGM Grand
description: MGM Grand Inc. said today that Clifford S. Perlman, who joined the company in December to head its planned casino and theme park in Las Vegas, Nev., had resigned.

title: Silcorp Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $8,972,000 which included a $10.5 million charge from the restructuring of U.S. operations, $1 million of writedowns in Canada and a gain of $2.5 million from the sale of surplus properties. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: California Biotechnology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UConn Coach Honored
description: Jim Calhoun of the University of Connecticut was voted Big East coach of the year yesterday after his team finished the regular season with a 25-5 record and won a share of the league title with Syracuse.

title: 2 Directors Succeed Baryshnikov at Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater has named Jane Hermann, its executive director, and Oliver Smith, the scenic designer and a director of the troupe for 35 years, as co-directors of the ballet company. The decision was reached by the company's board in a meeting on Wednesday. The appointments are effective immediately.

title: Banker's Note Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Net income

title: Youth Held in Burning of Boy Called Thuggish but Lonely
description: On the block where he lives, the accused youth is known as a bully with a vicious streak - a boy who taunted and beat smaller children, stole their lunch money and other property and sometimes whipped stray dogs into snarling fury and set them on one another for the fun of it.

title: Bush Was Duped on Hostage Call, U.S. Says
description: President Bush was duped into taking a telephone call to talk about freeing American hostages from a man he thought was President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, but the caller turned out to be a fraud, the White House announced today.

title: HPSC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $3,969,000 for the quarter and year from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Both year-ago periods' results included a provision for losses of $15 million. The latest year totaled 52 weeks, compared with 53 weeks for 1988 year.

title: Futures Officials May Compromise
description: In a change of heart that could help resolve several disputes between the futures and securities industries, two top officials in the futures business said here today that they would consider compromising on certain key issues.

title: Self-Improvement Pays Off;   Coleman Succeeds by Attacking the Weaknesses in His Game
description: When Derrick Coleman was growing up, up and up back in Detroit, on his way to becoming the self-described toothpick that would enroll at Syracuse University in 1986, there was this useful if painful drill he would practice to improve his ball-handling skills.

title: Chronicle
description: Weighty Washington and more than a few visitors turned out Wednesday night to fete the Italian Prime Minister, GIULIO ANDREOTTI, although they probably would have had another chance. This was his 104th visit to the United States since 1948.

title: Review/Film;   Trading In One's Innocence, Willingly
description: At the beginning of Curtis Hanson's ''Bad Influence,'' life seems to be going exactly the way Michael Boll (James Spader) had planned, though it's a life made up of Maalox moments.

title: Duramed Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $750,000 to cover potential liabilities related to a lawsuit for the quarter and the year included pre-tax charges totaling $2.2 million to cover costs incurred in recalling two generic drugs. c-Net income

title: Jewish Fear, Black Insensitivity
description: LEAD: Many blacks cannot understand why Jews react so strongly to comments by black leaders or officials that appear anti-Semitic. They see the Jewish community, especially its upper echelons, as wealthy, integrated with other white elites and powerful.

Luis Carlos Prestes, 92, Brazilian Communist
description: Luis Carlos Prestes, who led Brazil's Communist opposition for half a century, died on Wednesday of cancer, doctors said. He was 92 years old.

title: Economic Scene;   The Denial Of the Obvious
description: STEPHEN POTTER, the author of ''Gamesmanship'' and ''One-Upmanship,'' said an economist has two basic ploys. The first, labeled Economic Approach A, is to cloak the obvious in ''a little wild incomprehensibility.'' Thus, Mr. Potter's model economist, named Regil, would tell listeners that if they wanted to influence ''the general liquidity situation of banks and public,'' they had better not forget that the central bank's ''discretionary action on the cash basis took the shape of dealings in Treasury bills, the market rate of discount on which could and did fluctuate.''

title: Collins Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
Review/Film;   Gross Encounters in Comical 'House Party'
description: ''House Party,'' Reginald Hudlin's effervescent first feature, enters the life of its young hero, Kid (Christopher Reid), as if passing into another dimension of time and space. The screen glows with ominous hot-white light, the way it does when the little girl in ''Poltergeist'' crosses over to the other side of her television screen.

title: Sharm el Sheik Journal;   Hotels. Divers. Next for a Fragile Reef: A Bridge?
description: This is a place where the fish, the foreigners and the flights of entrepreneurial fancy blend in symbiosis: the fish bejewel the coral reef, the foreigners dive to see them and the entrepreneurs build the hostelries where the foreigners rest when the fish viewing is done.

description: Talking more like an underdog than an incumbent with a strong political base, Mayor Sharpe James announced today that he would seek election to a second four-year term on May 8.

title: Outdoors;   Ski Areas Offer Deals To Drum Up Business
description: rrSkiers are returning from New England with rave reviews about the snow conditions this season, calling them the best in many years. But, aside from obvious reasons to ski in the coming weeks - terrific snow surfaces, milder temperatures and uncrowded slopes and lodges - a few New England ski areas are offering a range of activities and lower prices to entice skiers to their mountains.

title: Upheaval in the East;   In East German Army Ranks, A Headlong Farewell to Arms
description: On paper, the mission of the East German Army's Eighth Motorized Rifle Division has been to strike into West Germany at the outbreak of war and to seize Hamburg, 60 miles to the west.

title: Will Probert Play?
description: Bob Probert, who was suspended by the National Hockey League last November before spending three months in prison on a conviction for importing cocaine, could be reinstated to the Detroit Red Wings this season, but team officials were uncertain yesterday if the former All-Star would play.

title: Shot in '73; Dies in '90: Case Ruled a Homicide
description: The death last week of a 35-year-old man who became a paraplegic more than 16 years ago when he was shot while attempting to rob a grocery store in Brooklyn has been was declared a homicide, the police said.

description: In another step toward deregulating the long-distance telephone market, the Federal Communications Commission proposed yesterday giving the American Telephone and Telegraph Company a freer hand in cutting or raising rates and offering additional services for large business customers.

title: Senate Passes Florio's Plan On Insurance
description: The New Jersey Senate today approved Gov. Jim Florio's automobile-insurance plan, giving the new Governor his first major legislative victory with a proposal he says will reduce premiums for the state's drivers by 20 percent in one year.

Sales in 1988 included the results of the company's U.K. subsidiary.

title: Washington Bank Agrees to Be Sold
description: The board of the Washington Bancorporation, the parent of the National Bank of Washington, agreed to sell the company to a group of investors for at least $134 million. The proposed deal is subject to approval by Federal regulators and shareholders, and the investors must still obtain financing.

title: Alice Munro's Stories of Changes of the Heart
description: The stories in this impressive new collection by Alice Munro are concerned, like her earlier tales, with what she once called ''the progress of love'': the ways in which love and friendship, passion and affection endure, shift and permute through time. It is a collection that attests, once again, to Ms. Munro's complete fluency in the short-story form, her emergence as one of the most eloquent and gifted writers of contemporary fiction. <TD WIDTH=2

title: Cat-Shooting Study to Go On
description: A committee at the Louisiana State University Medical Center concluded today that it should not stop researchers from firing pellets into the brains of anesthetized cats despite opposition from animal rights groups. Researchers say their findings will help them learn how to return brain-injured soldiers to active duty.

title: Paul Paroski Jr. Dies; Medical Chief Was 37
description: Dr. Paul A. Paroski Jr., medical director for the department of ambulatory care at the Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn, died of complications from AIDS on Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 37 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: The Future Is Now For Gartner, Rangers
description: The deal sent Ulf Dahlen from the Rangers to the North Stars for Mike Gartner. And in the not-too-distant future, in hindsight, Neil Smith will either have regrettably fallen for false illusions or proved that there was truth to his heretofore self-promoted reputation for evaluating talent.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Feld Troupe In 'Shadow's Breath'
description: Eliot Feld loves to create unusual shapes in space with his choreography - shapes which, in his best works, are both eye catching and thought provoking. Two fine examples of his inventiveness were offered by Feld Ballets NY on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: Mandela in Zanzibar; Then Flies to Ethiopia
description: Nelson Mandela addressed a rally here today before interrupting his tour of Tanzania to make a 24-hour visit to Ethiopia.

title: Our Towns;   At the Work Site: Quality Day Care At $60 a Week
description: B. J. Welsh named her 2 1/2-year-old son after Dylan Thomas not because she wanted him to be a poet, but because she and her husband liked the sound of the name and its lyric evocation of the sea. ''Dylan means 'borne on the waves,' or just 'washed ashore,' '' she said, ''and he came to us from overseas, so it seemed really appropriate.''

title: Review/Art;   Sculpture at the Whitney: The Radical Years
description: ''THE NEW SCULPTURE 1965-75: Between Geometry and Gesture,'' which has just opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art, should temporarily deflect charges that the museum lacks curatorial direction or courage. Although it is not without flaws, this is the museum's best and most focused survey of recent art in several years, and one of the more daring shows to be seen in a New York museum in a while.

title: David Teitelbaum, 69, Producer at NBC News
description: David Teitelbaum, a producer of news and documentary programs for NBC, died of cancer of the prostate on Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 69 years old and lived in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: Putting a Sharper Edge On Traditional Blues
description: While many performers think of blues as a purist's idiom that should remain true to its roots in the rural American South of the 1930's and 40's, Son Seals, the 48-year-old blues guitarist, is a proud synthesist. From the beginning of his career, Mr. Seals, who is to perform this weekend at the Village Gate, has worked to update blues with more contemporary styles. His music retains the grit and emotional pitch of early blues while incorporating elements of rock, rhythm-and-blues, swing and funk.

description: West Virginia's biggest teachers' union went on strike Wednesday for the first time.

title: Bush Transportation Policy Assailed
description: The Bush Administration's new transportation policy was sharply criticized today by many members of Congress and by state and local officials, most of whom disagreed with its shift from Federal spending toward local spending on mass transit and highways.

title: Hotel Chains' Woes: Just Too Many Rooms
description: Overbuilding, operating cost increases and stiffer competition among major hotel chains have turned the fast growth-and-earnings pace of the early 1980's into a crawl of consolidation and strains on profits, corporate executives and industry analysts say. Many experts believe that it will take the industry years to overcome most of the problems and that shakeouts could affect some familiar hotel names.

Market Place;   Making a Case For Steel Stocks
description: AFTER riding high much of last year, steel stocks have taken a fall in recent months, a result of tumbling steel prices, a downturn in orders from the automotive industry and general economic weakness. But steel industry analysts and executives insist that the current state of affairs is temporary and that a rebound is coming by the second half.

title: Gypsy Joe Harris, 44; Boxer Blind in an Eye
description: Gypsy Joe Harris, a welterweight contender whose boxing career ended with the discovery that he had concealed blindness in one eye, died on Tuesday. He was 44 years old. Mr. Harris, who suffered four heart attacks in the last two years, died at Temple University Hospital, where he had been a patient since Feb. 10. His sister, Daaiyah Waheed, attributed the death to heart failure.

title: Review/Music;   'Sound of Music' Takes On The Icons of a Heroic Past
description: From its first Broadway performance in 1959, Rodgers and Hammerstein's sentimental ''Sound of Music'' has not ranked high among the cognoscenti, even the cognoscenti of musicals. And it cannot be said that the New York City Opera's spring seasons of musicals at the cavernous New York State Theater, now in their fifth and apparently final year, have been greeted with universal acclaim, either.

title: Chock Full O'Nuts reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $564,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago quarter and 6 months periods included unrealized pretax gains on marketable equity securities of $1,133,000, or 8 cents a share, and $1,311,000, or 10 cents a share, respectively. The company said results included the operations of the instant coffee business of Tetley Inc. from its acquisition on Nov. 7, 1989 and of Jimbo's Jumbos Inc. from Nov. 14, 1988.

title: Saul Israel, Educator, 79
description: Saul Israel, a retired adjunct assistant professor of education at Fordham University and a former New York City high school teacher and principal, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: Celebrating Purim's Joy
description: Here is a sampling of events taking place in observance of Purim, which is Sunday. Purim celebrates the victory of Mordechai and Esther over the wicked Haman.

title: American Songs
description: Elizabeth McCullough, a soprano, is to sing songs by American composers at the Renee Weiler Concert Hall of the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street, tonight at 8. The program includes Aaron Copland's ''12 Poems of Emily Dickinson'' and selections from Ned Rorem's ''Women's Voices'' and William Bolcom's ''Cabaret Songs.'' Joan Krueger is to be the pianist. Suggested contribution is $5. Information: 242-4770.

title: 5 Correction Officers Indicted on Charges Of Attacking Inmate
description: Five correction officers, including two captains, were indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges that they assaulted an inmate at Rikers Island last June, ramming his head into a metal door. The prisoner is now a quadriplegic.

title: Labatt (John) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Democracy Divides Chicago Schools
description: The hallways were empty and the classrooms filled at Chicago's Spry Elementary School Wednesday morning. But outside a room where a parent-led council talked in closed session about hiring a new principal, nearly 100 angry parents crowded in front of the double doors.

title: Stocks Up in Light Trading As Dow Gains 26.58 Points
description: Stocks advanced in light trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 26.58 points, to 2,696.17.

title: Gartner Makes Himself A Factor
description: A week's worth of disconcerting trade rumors had been followed by 24 hours of nonstop interviews once the deal was done. Mike Gartner then stepped onto a plane, got off and stepped into a locker room of the Rangers for the first time. Twelve hours later, he boarded a bus, got in one brief skate and finally wound up in a hotel room here, hours from a game against the Flyers and perhaps only minutes away from a minor breakdown.

title: Standard Motor Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about executive changes at the Ford Motor Company misstated the age of William Clay Ford Jr. He is 32.

title: U.S. to Unveil Drug Plan With Wide Military Role
description: The Pentagon will announce a new anti-drug strategy on Friday that will increase the use of warships and airplanes in the Caribbean to help block drug shipments, officials said today. But the plan sets aside a politically troublesome proposal to post Navy ships off the Colombian coast.

title: Review/Art;   A Comic Guide to a London Both Foul and Fair
description: In a discreet and literally subterranean way, the great English draftsman and watercolorist Thomas Rowlandson (1756-1827) is enjoying a long-delayed apotheosis at the Frick Collection. We may doubt, in fact, that he could be better shown. The show is exactly the right size. The 84 items include some of the most famous images in the whole canon of English art, along with others - in their way just as good - that have never been exhibited before.

title: Yonkers to Replace Lawyers In Desegregation Challenges
description: The City Council has decided to replace the city's principal lawyer in its 10-year-old housing-and-school-desegregation case with three lawyers who will be asked to pursue new legal challenges to the Federal court orders.

title: Study Is a Blow to Genentech's Main Product
description: Genentech Inc. suffered a blow today with the release of medical data showing that its clot-dissolving drug, used to treat heart attacks, was no more effective than a competitive product that is less than one-tenth the price.

title: K Mart Has Loss In Quarter
description: The K Mart Corporation, one of the country's three largest retailers, today reported a $20.5 million loss in the fourth quarter and sharply lower earnings for the year.

title: Chronicle
description: Joining a heady complement of peers like Alfred Hitchcock, Orson Welles and Frank Capra, INGMAR BERGMAN will receive the highest award of the Directors Guild of America for his contribution to the cinema. The D. W. Griffith Award will be presented on Saturday in Los Angeles and ROBERT WISE, a previous winner, will accept it for Mr. Bergman, who is in Sweden.

description: The chairman of a House investigating panel said today that he would seek immunity for an imprisoned former aide to Samuel R. Pierce Jr. in exchange for information about Mr. Pierce's tenure as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * First Fidelity Bancorporation, Newark, a bank holding company, named Wolfgang Schoellkopf vice chairman and chief financial officer.

title: Douglas Plays Berg
description: The pianist Barry Douglas is to play Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' Alban Berg's Sonata (Op. 1) and the Tchaikovsky Sonata in G (Op. 37) at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. Mr. Douglas, who is from Belfast, won the gold medal at the Tchaikovsky International Competition in Moscow in 1986. Tickets are $17.50 to $22.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Never Underestimate The Injury in Rape

title: The Many Pleasures From Stage Filled By One, Only One
description: THE soliloquy is at least as old as Shakespeare, but it was not until the late 18th century that Johann Christian Brandes, a German actor and playwright, invented the monodrama. A short solo entertainment often accompanied by a chorus, it was used to lengthen an otherwise brief evening of theater. Undoubtedly, Brandes would have been amazed at the varieties of the genre 200 years later.

title: Trahison Des Clercs
description: When President Bush made gestures last year to the tyrants who rule China, he won the support of two China scholars in this country. Michel Oksenberg of the University of Michigan and A. Doak Barnett of the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies defended him against his many critics.

Review/Art;   Re-Creating a 1930 Show With Famous and Forgotten
description: There are obvious weaknesses in ''Nineteen Americans,'' at the Forum Gallery, which is something of a re-creation of a 1930 show at the Museum of Modern Art -the museum's second show, and its first devoted to American art. Some of the paintings are weak and anecdotal. The packed installation in the smaller of the two gallery spaces looks like an art shop. And the catalogue's declaration of friendship with Alfred H. Barr Jr., the founding director of the Modern and the organizer of the 1930 show, smacks of a self-serving attempt by a solid realist gallery to give itself a mainstream modernist stamp.

title: Nixon Treated as Hero In Halls of His Disgrace
description: Congressional aides with only distant childhood memories of Watergate applauded, cheered and jostled one another to shake his hand. Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, positively glowed. Even the worldly Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, seemed a bit nonplussed.

title: Reviews/Music;   Soviet Emigree Pianist Plays Brahms Sonatas
description: Elisabeth Leonskaja, a Soviet emigree pianist who substituted for an ailing Claudio Arrau in subscription concerts of the New York Philharmonic a year ago to considerable acclaim, gave her New York debut recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday evening to a mostly empty Kaufmann Concert Hall. Could the wintry turn in the weather have been that unexpected in early March? Or was the repertory the problem?

title: Campaign Finance Bill Clears First Hurdle of Many
description: In the start of what is expected to be a lively partisan debate, a Senate committee today approved a Democratic bill that seeks to place limits on campaign spending by candidates for the Senate.

title: Gordon K. Smith, Executive, 88
description: Gordon K. Smith, a retired insurance executive, died of leukemia on Wednesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 88 years old.

title: Deadline for Davis
description: Al Davis finally has to tip his hand today on his plans for the Los Angeles Raiders. But after 14 months of negotiations, Oakland officials are optimistic that the Raiders' owner is finally ready to return to that city.

title: Upheaval in the East;   SANDINISTAS MOVE TO CLAIM PROPERTY AND GAIN IMMUNITY
description: With less than two months before they are scheduled to hand over power to the opposition, Sandinista leaders are taking steps to enact sweeping changes in Nicaragua's laws, giving away large amounts of Government property and declaring immunity for all unprosecuted crimes that may have been committed during their 10-year rule.

title: Mayor Keeping Vow to Reopen Bronx Firehouse
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, keeping a political promise, said yesterday that he would let the New York City Fire Department reopen Engine Company 41 in the South Bronx, a firehouse that Mayor Edward I. Koch closed last year, after a long, bitter fight, to save money.

Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: More Defaults Are Predicted
description: A panel of credit experts told Congress today to expect an increase in the number of defaults by debt-burdened corporations in the early 1990's. But they said there was little that the Federal Government should do to reverse the trend.

title: Reviews/Theater;   Conducting Murky Business Unpleasantly
description: Challenge, response and then another challenge - Peter Mattei's ''Tiny Dimes'' is a boardroom-style battle for supremacy, conducted by two married couples and an executive who may or may not all be involved in the same business, what is referred to as ''the firm.''

title: Armani: Classic and Sensual
description: The fall and winter fashion shows here this week were a series of loopy turns, but Giorgio Armani, as usual in the past few years, set everything straight at the end. Retailers seeking truth in fashion believed they found it with Armani's stark daytime clothes and his expanded range of evening styles.

title: African Congress Faulted on Unrest
description: As unrest subsided in this township that South Africa claims to be in foreign territory, the Pretoria Government today suggested that the African National Congress and its allies were orchestrating the violence flaring in several of the homelands it had created.

title: Halifax Developments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about a barge explosion that resulted in an oil spill in the Arthur Kill between Staten Island and Linden, N.J., referred incorrectly to the owner of the barge. It is Cibro Petroleum Inc. of New York.

title: Senate Panel Clears Dunne for Justice Post
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to approve and send to the full Senate the nomination of former State Senator John R. Dunne of New York for Assistant Attorney General for civil rights.

title: Supradur Cos. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,005,000, or 98 cents a share, and included income from discontinued operations of $2,321,000, or $2.28 a share. The extraordinary gain is from tax loss carryforwards. Discontinued operations included earnings and gains from disposal of assets.

title: SAI Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter results included a charge of $100,000 related to settlement of claims relating to the 1985 sale of certain reinsurance treaties. Latest quarter and year figures were negatively affected by costs associated with SAI's 50-Forward Club venture. About $2.2 million of the 1989 year loss is related to the venture. Full year 1988 figures included a gain of $183,000 from the sale of SAI's headquartes building.

title: Newcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $1,250,000 for the closedown of Newcor Canada Ltd. c-Net income

title: Campeau Defaults on Loans, Placing Assets in Jeopardy
description: The Campeau Corporation may be on the verge of losing another chunk of its sprawling empire. The troubled Canadian company said yesterday that it had defaulted on $5.2 million in interest payments to two lenders, risking the loss of sizable assets, in both Canada and the United States.

title: Kabul Reports Mutineers Purged; Ex-Defense Chief Vows to Fight On
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said today that the military had been purged of mutinous soldiers, but the renegade general who led a violent coup attempt said from hiding that he would keep fighting.

title: Iraqi View on Oil Quota
description: The Iraqi oil minister, Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi, said today that OPEC's production-sharing agreement would stay unchanged for at least three months.

title: Tuition at Campus Is Free For All Black Freshmen
description: Florida Atlantic University this fall will offer free tuition to every black freshman who meets admission standards, school officials say.

title: Mont Saint-Sauveur InternaFtional reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Restaurants
description: When the Nice Restaurant opened five years ago on East Broadway in Chinatown, it was among the first of a new wave of cavernous, glittery Hong Kong-style Cantonese restaurants in the area. These are festive places to be sure. On any evening at this two-level, 500-seat extravaganza, you might encounter sprawling tables of 10 or more family members celebrating a birthday, a gaggle of schoolchildren and their chaperones clattering in another corner, and even a mirthful wedding reception complete with choral singers accompanied by dozens of wine-glass percussionists. Romantic dining this is not.

title: Deltona Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,642,000, or 30 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,574,000, or 46 cents a share, for the year, which included $1,670,000 gain on disposition of utility segment, and extraordinary tax credits of $1,490,000, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,929,000, or 35 cents a share, for the year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $222,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,405,000, or 25 cents a share, for the year, and extraordinary tax credits of $480,000, or 9 cents a share, and $1,392,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: CBS Reaches $1 Billion Deal To Televise N.F.L. Games
description: CBS announced yesterday that it had agreed to a new four-year contract to televise Sunday games of the National Football League for a total of just over $1 billion.

title: On Stage
description: Nichols, Feiffer and 'Elliot'

title: Mary Languirand Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Mary Languirand, a staff psychologist at the Brook Lane Psychiatric Center in Hagerstown, Md., was married yesterday at Temple Emanu-el in New York to Dr. Robert Bornstein, an assistant professor of psychology at Gettysburg (Pa.) College. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: Matec Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the latest quarter a gain of $933,000 from the sale of assets, compared with similar gain of $143,000 in the year-earlier quarter. c-Latest year net included a gain of $995,000 from the sale of assets, compared with a similar gain of $230,000 in 1988.

title: TIS Mortgage Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 year revenue results are for the period from Aug. 26, 1988, date of commencement of operations, to Dec. 31, 1988.

Information International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Portage Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: The 9th Circuit: Northwest v. California
description: In the debate over whether Congress should split the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, most of the talk is about whether the court is too large. Little mention is made of the northern spotted owl.

title: Terreri, Defense Help Devils Top Islanders
description: Brilliant goaltending and solid defense are the two essential ingredients needed in a drive for a playoff berth and the Devils displayed both tonight in their 4-2 triumph over the Islanders.

title: Billie Jean And the Millionaire
description: rrThey introduced Billie Jean King as the first woman to earn $100,000 in a single tennis season.

title: Review/Film;   A Tongue-in-Cheek Tour Of Hungary and Hollywood
description: ''Mr. Universe'' was shown as part of the 1989 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 25, 1989. The film, in Hungarian with English subtitles, opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Communications Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,707,726 and $1,378,577 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $44,572 for the quarter and $64,044 for the year.

title: Deb Shops reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Events in Celebration of Women's History Month
description: WINIFRED BORG, Gallery Art 54, 54 Greene Street (226-1605). Paintings and assemblage. Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., through March 18. Free.

title: Earl Scheib reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Friedman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
B.C. Gas Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $10,511,000 from writedown of Canadian Energy Properties. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Joseph M. Lyle, 77, Retired Vice Admiral
description: Joseph Melvin Lyle, a vice admiral in the Navy Supply Corps who was director of the Defense Supply Agency before he retired in 1967, died of cancer Tuesday at a nursing home. He was 77 years old, Mr. Lyle graduated from the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis in 1935 and was an assistant supply officer at Pearl Harbor when the Japanese attacked it on Dec. 7, 1941.

title: Margaret Eddy, 63, Pastor and Educator In East Harlem Posts
description: The Rev. Dr. Margaret Ruth Eddy, a Congregationalist minister, an educator and a community leader in East Harlem for 40 years, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 63 years old. In 1948, as a seminary student, Dr. Eddy was a member of the group ministry that founded the East Harlem Protestant Parish, and she remained involved there until 1972. She then served as pastor of the Church of the Resurrection for two years and later was dean of the East Harlem School of Faith, a leader of the East Harlem Healing Community and a member of the board of the East Harlem Churches and Community Urban Center.

title: Chronicle
description: MALCOLM S. (STEVE) FORBES JR., the new president and chief executive of Forbes Inc., sent a memo to employees yesterday. It read: ''In accordance with my father's wishes, you are receiving one extra week's pay. Also, all personal debts to the company of up to $10,000 shall be forgiven. As Pop put it, 'Like a lottery, it's pure chance as to who benefits.'

title: Computrac Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain of $434,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting adjusted.

title: Lufthansa Buying Stake in Interflug
description: The West Germany airline Lufthansa has agreed to buy a 26 percent share of Interflug, East Germany's state-owned carrier, a Lufthansa spokesman said. Details are still being worked out, the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity.

title: Bush Questions Israeli Claims to East Jerusalem, Creating Uproar
description: In a departure from usual Washington practice, President Bush has begun in recent days to raise questions in public about Israel's claims to sovereignty over East Jerusalem.

title: Notes are Offered By Export Group
description: The Private Export Funding Corporation is offering $200 million in five-year secured notes due 1995. The BT Securities Corporation will act as the issue manager.

title: BLUNT ARGUMENTS BY LAWYERS OPEN POINDEXTER TRIAL
description: In a sometimes fiery and indignant opening argument, the chief prosecutor in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter said today that he would show that the former White House official lied to Congress and engaged in criminal ''cover-up, deception and concealment.''

title: Reviews/Theater;   Primal Emotions When Sex Runs Amok
description: Erotic passion run amok is one of the hardest things to portray on the stage without its seeming either tinnily melodramatic or unintentionally funny. If the Intar Stage 2's production of Ana Maria Simo's heavy-breathing drama, ''Going to New England,'' has moments that seem both shrill and silly, her play still deserves credit for trying to go below the surface of soap opera histrionics to get at the primal emotions that erupt when sexual feelings go out of control.

title: This Time, Grady and Lincoln In Showdown to Gain Title Shot
description: After a week of upsets in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association and the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs, two favored teams finally fulfilled expectations yesterday.

title: Barge Unloaded As Arthur Kill Is Partly Opened
description: Parts of the Arthur Kill were opened yesterday, but the section where a barge exploded and spilled more than 100,000 gallons of oil remained closed to almost all marine traffic as the Coast Guard began unloading 3.8 million gallons of oil still in the damaged barge.

title: Jay Lovestone, Communist Leader Who Turned Against Party, Dies
description: Jay Lovestone, who briefly headed the Communist Party in the United States in the 1920's before becoming a staunch anti-Communist, died in his sleep Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Reviews/Film;   A Terminal Ad Man, a God, And a South Pacific Volcano
description: Not since ''Howard the Duck'' has there been a big-budget comedy with feet as flat as those of ''Joe Versus the Volcano.'' Many gifted people contributed to it, but there's no disbelieving the grim evidence on the screen.

title: A.C.C. Tourney Losing Its Glitter
description: To many in the Southeast, the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament is the premier athletic and social event of the year. But as the league clan gathers here this weekend to determine the championship, the talk is less of matchups and seedings than of a future clouded by the troubled basketball programs at two member schools.

title: Beijing Opera
description: Oi Shu-Fang's Beijing Opera Troupe is to present ''The Legend of Lady White Snake'' at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $15 to $20. Information: 454-7536 or 864-5400.

title: John Lobb Dies at 76; Led Northern Telecom
description: John C. Lobb, retired chairman of Northern Telecom Ltd., the Toronto-based communications concern, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Ligonier, Pa. He was 76 years old.

title: No More Lockout for No Strike? Players' Union Says No Way
description: In a move the union rejected as a blatant public relations ploy, Commissioner Fay Vincent yesterday asked baseball's club owners to lift their three-week-old lockout of players from spring training camps if the players pledged not to strike during the 1990 season.

title: Auctions
description: Tiffany Lamps

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: The assets of the nation's 499 money market mutual funds increased by $2 billion, to $390.79 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 153 institutional funds increased by $212 million, to $91.75 billion. The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds were up by $502.20 million, to $132.90 billion. The 101 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.29 billion, to $166.14 billion, the institute said.

title: John Harlan Jr., 71, Former U.S. Official
description: John G. Harlan Jr., a retired executive vice president and director of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemical Corporation of Edison, N.J., and former Federal official, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at his home in Gloucester, Va. He was 71 years old.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Defense Tries to Tie Valdez Spill to Helmsman
description: The Exxon Valdez ran aground on a jagged reef and spilled its cargo of oil because the helmsman failed to turn the ship as far as he had been ordered, an expert testified today on behalf of the tanker's skipper.

title: Top Random House Author Assails Ouster at Pantheon
description: The novelist E. L. Doctorow used the forum of the National Book Critics Circle's annual award ceremony yesterday to call the forced resignation of Andre Schiffrin as director of Pantheon Books an act of censorship that tarnished its parent company, Random House Inc.

title: Lifetime Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4.7 million from discontinued operations.

title: Inquiry Begun Into Claim Of Child Abuse at Center
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney is investigating claims that dozens of children were sexually molested at a now-closed unlicensed day-care center in Brooklyn last year, according to participants in the case.

title: Columbus Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included $183,000 loss from non- recurring litigation charges for the quarter and the year included $2,386,000 loss from dissolution of partnerships and $697,000 loss from special litigation and proxy expenses connected with an attempted hostile takeover. c-Net loss d-Included $49,000 loss from non- recurring litigation charges.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Navy Seals in Action

title: Baker's Trick
description: Why do you suppose Syria has finally told its ally Iran that now would be a good time to release the hostages held in Syrian-controlled Beirut?

title: Syrian Leader Assails Change In East Bloc as Boon to Israel
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today denounced political changes in Eastern Europe as beneficial to Israel and offered no promises of major liberalization by his own Government.

title: Brady Going To Group of 7 Talks in April
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that he will go to Paris next month to meet with financial leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations to discuss recent economic developments around the world.

title: Dragging Motor Is Suspected in Subway Accident
description: A derailment that killed three people and injured 162 aboard a subway train may have happened when a dragging motor on one car hit a track switch, Federal investigators said today.

title: Arkansas Seeks 7th Track Title
description: The Arkansas men's team will try to roll a lucky seven in the National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor track and field championships, beginning Friday in the Hoosier Dome.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Wherehouse President Also Takes Chief's Title
description: LEAD: Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., the music and video retailer based in Torrance, Calif., said yesterday that it had promoted Scott Young, its president, to the additional post of chief executive. Mr. Young relinquishes another title, chief operating officer.

title: Family Shopping Network reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included preferred stock dividend payments of $50,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Included $51,278 preferred stock dividend payment.

title: LSB Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $1.8 million for the quarter and year. The latest periods' results included the March 7, 1988 acquisition of Northwest Federal Savings and Loan Association, the Dec. 30, 1988 acquisition of Arrowhead Federal Savings and Loan Association, and the Aug. 9, 1989 acquisition of United Bankcard Inc. Share earnings are after payment of preferred dividends.

title: Management Realigned At Young & Rubicam
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. announced a nearly complete management realignment yesterday. Peter A. Georgescu, who had been president of Young & Rubicam Advertising, was named president of Young & Rubicam Inc., a title formerly held by the chairman and chief executive, Alexander Kroll. Joseph E. DeDeo, formerly president of Young & Rubicam Europe, was named president and chief executive of Y.&R. Advertising Worldwide.

title: Elders Planning Big Revamping
description: Elders IXL Ltd., one of Australia's largest companies, said today that it would spin off its agriculture businesses and sell other assets while retaining its brewing operations. Elders also said it would buy Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s breweries for an undisclosed price and enter into a joint venture with London-based Grand Met to operate the two companies' 8,500 pubs.

title: Atco Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included asset writedowns totalling $60,106,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: F.B.I. Denies Retaliation Against Agent
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation strongly denied today that a highly decorated counter-espionage agent was suspended because of his involvement in a discrimination suit brought against the bureau by its Hispanic agents.

title: Settlement Ends Prego Trial on Brink of Summations
description: A doctor who accused Kings County Hospital of negligence after she had contracted AIDS suddenly dropped her lawsuit yesterday, settling for an undisclosed sum.

title: Renaissance Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Gathers's Teammates Are Practicing Again
description: For the first time since the death of Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball team was a basketball team again.

title: Jackson Martindell, Financier, Dies at 89
description: Jackson Martindell, a financier, management consultant and onetime publisher of ''Who's Who in America,'' died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 89 years old.

title: 2 Die in Attacks by Rival Groups in Ulster
description: A truck driver was killed today in a machine-gun attack that the Irish Republican Army took responsibility for, and a Protestant paramilitary group said it killed an I.R.A. backer the day before.

title: At the Bar
description: Amid the run-of-the-mill puffery in the pages of Playbill, David Zippel's autobiography stands out. True, it lists his theater credits, most recently as lyricist for the Broadway musical comedy ''City of Angels.'' But instead of the usual nods to coaches, God and family, it ends with a bit of educational editorializing.

title: Fibronics International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net operating loss carryforward gain of $156,000.

title: Medical Management of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $140,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $118,000, or 1 cent a share, and also included a charge of $1 million related to severance arrangements with a former officer.

title: U.S. Says Latin American Nations Are Resuming Ties With Panama
description: The Bush Administration asserted today that it had persuaded several Latin American countries to resume normal diplomatic relations with Panama because the United States had reduced the number of its troops there to the pre-invasion level.

title: Mets Are Feeling the Stiffness of Long Delay
description: The Mets-in-exile continued their informal workouts today and reported that they were staying in good shape despite the three-week lockout of the spring training camps. But they said that it might take all of April before they could recover their skills and play at a major league level.

title: Indian Leaders Visit Kashmir In Hope of Defusing Tension
description: Prominent Indian political leaders, including Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal and former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, traveled today to Srinagar, the capital of Jammu and Kashmir state, to begin a political drive aimed at defusing an anti-Indian mood there.

title: Chamber Premiere
description: The New World String Quartet and the recorder player Michala Petri are to give the world premiere of Ezra Laderman's ''Talkin'-Lovin'-Leavin' '' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tonight at 8. Miss Petri, the New World players and the harpsichordist Edward Brewer are also to play works by Telemann, Heberle, Sammartini, Dutilleux and Vivaldi. Tickets are $17. Telephone 570-3949.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF

title: Big TV Deals Will Be at Top of the Agenda When N.F.L. Owners Meet Sunday
description: The National Football League owners hope to open their five-day annual meeting Sunday in Orlando, Fla., by endorsing new four-year television contracts that could nearly double their current annual television revenue of $17 million per club.

title: Ernest McMahon, 79, Former Rutgers Dean
description: Dr. Ernest E. McMahon, an author, educator and a former dean at Rutgers University, died of cancer last Thursday at the William Hill Health Center in Easton, Md. He was 79 years old and lived in St. Michaels, Md.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Oscar Peterson's Jazz

title: Guggenheim Gets $5 Million
description: The Tobishima Corporation, the Japanese engineering and construction company, will give $5 million to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Thomas Krens, the museum's director, announced yesterday.

title: Palestinian Leader Is Opposing Arafat On Talks With Israel
description: Coming out in open opposition to what he said was Yasir Arafat's policy of compromise, a Palestinian guerrilla leader called today for ''mobilizing all our energies'' to foil proposed Palestinian-Israeli talks under United States and Egyptian sponsorship.

title: Reviews/Music;   New Cast Takes Over In 'Faust' At the Met
description: A number of new faces have worked their way into the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Faust.'' Judging from Wednesday evening's performance, they have not mitigated its problems, and as is so often the case in cast-change situations at the Met, stagecraft has been loosened and ensemble blurred.

title: Cello Program
description: Alexander Baillie, a cellist, is to play Miaskovsky's Sonata No. 1 in D (Op. 12), Benjamin Britten's Suite No. 1 for Solo Cello, Bach's Sonata in D (BWV 1028) and Beethoven's Sonata No. 3 in A (Op. 69) tonight at Weill Recital Hall. Phillip Bush is to be the pianist. Tickets are $15. Information: 247-7800.

title: Review/Pop;   Gloria Estefan, Bilingually
description: Early in her Madison Square Garden concert on Wednesday evening, Gloria Estefan asked how many people in the spoke Spanish, how many spoke English, and how many spoke both languages. After all three categories were greeted with enthusiastic applause, the Cuban-American pop star expressed her delight and responded by singing a bilingual concert in which the choruses and occasionally the verses of many of the songs were split between the two languages.

title: Review/Film;   Berenger as a Private Eye In Rudolph's 'Love at Large'
description: Alan Rudolph operates on the cinema's dog-whistle frequencies, emitting a signal that's perceptible to only a select few. His latest film, ''Love at Large,'' features a theme song by Leonard Cohen, a mock 1940's ambiance and this film maker's customary band of lovelorn, soft-hearted adventurers rearranging their romantic destinies over and over again. In its own misty, coy and very precious way, it does have style and heart. There's an audience out there for it somewhere. You know who you are.

title: Mass Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that during the 1989 fourth quareter, it terminated its former S corporate status and became subject to federal and state income taxes.

title: Fairfild Shift Expected
description: Fairchild Publications is expected to announce a reorganization of its magazine group today, with one segment for retailing and fashion magazines, another for industrial and electronic publications and a third for financial publications. A person familiar with the changes said that they were being made to save money and to use the staffs more efficiently and that no big layoffs were expected. The fashion group would include Women's Wear Daily, the Daily News Record, Sports Style, Footwear News, Children's Business and HSD, which is devoted to home furnishings. The second group would be merged into Chilton/ABC, and the third would include Institutional Investor. Fairchild is owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc.

title: Hyde Athletic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that in the latest 3 months it changed its method of accounting for inventory, which resulted in an increase to net income of $843,000.

description: Friend of My Youth

The company said share earnings calculated on income before extraordinary items and the company did not provide final net share earnings.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

Watsco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Accordingly, revenues and earnings are reported for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, 1989, compared to the two months and 11 months ended Dec. 31, 1988. The company said results in the latest periods were aided by the strong performance of its Gemaire Distributors Inc. unit which was acquired in January 1989. Also contributing to the growth was the company's Dunhill Personnel System Inc. unit.

title: Southern Co. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Reviews/Dance;   Woe, Woe and Again Woe: A Catalogue of Complaints
description: Jeff McMahon is an intense and driven monologuist who moves with the elasticity of warm putty and the lightness of a leaf buffeted by changeable winds. Mind and body are blended inextricably in ''Discontents,'' a new work presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. The eveninglong piece is a tour de force of performing. But it is also greatly in need of editing.

title: Equitable Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chaparral Resources Inc. reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and included a non-cash writedown of $895,000.

title: Writers Union Is Seeking Changes in Book Contracts
description: In an open letter to publishers, the National Writers Union yesterday called for changes in standard book contracts that would give authors more money and better terms.

title: BRIEFS
description: * CSX Corp., Richmond, a transportation company, completed the sale of its CSX Energy Corp. to Enron Gas Processing, a subsidiary of Enron Corp., Houston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Boston Digital reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Prenor Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the increase in revenue reflects, among other things, the acquisition of Canwest Trust last May. It said 1989 net income is higher mainly due to the sale of one of its land development projects in Mississauga, Ont. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Apple Is Offering Longer Warranty
description: Apple Computer Inc. said its hardware products sold in the United States since Jan. 1 will be covered by a one-year limited warranty. Most personal computer manufacturers offer a one-year warranty, but Apple's warranty previously covered only 90 days.

title: Washington National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $18.3 million related to the sale of the direct response health insurance business and a $9 million charge from restructuring charges due to severance costs. c-Net loss Results for 1988 are restated.
