description: b-Net income

title: City Council Votes Own Budget, Up $3 Million
description: After hallway negotiations and a bit of shuttle diplomacy, the New York City Council yesterday approved a $21.6 million Council operating budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, an increase of $3.4 million over last year's budget.

title: GAF Settles Carbide Case
description: The GAF Corporation and one of its senior executives settled Federal civil charges today that they had illegally manipulated the stock of the Union Carbide Corporation in October 1986, after an unsuccessful attempt to take over the company.

title: Earl T. Wagner, Ex-Congressman, 81
description: Earl T. Wagner, a lawyer and former member of the House of Representatives, died of cancer on Tuesday at a Cincinnati hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: From Co-op to Rental to Condo;   1927 Structure Is Converted in Newark
description: When Mount Prospect Manor opened here in 1927, the city was going through a period of unbridled development. Newark ranked 14th in the nation in industrial production, its population was approaching half a million and Newark Airport was under construction.

title: Philip Gross, Superintendent, 86
description: Philip Gross, a retired construction superintendent, died yesterday at the Universal Medical Center in Plantation, Fla. He was 86 years old and had homes in Bayside, Queens, and Pembroke Pines, Fla.

title: Hosposable Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included reversal of deferred tax liabilities of $421,135, or 37 cents a share. c-Net loss

description: b-Reflects the establishment of a $20.7 million reserve on the company's real estate holdings and commitments and $1.6 million in reserves set aside for loans for the quarter and net additions to reserves of $26.5 million for the year. c-Net income

title: K Mart reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Exclusive of a provision to cover all expenses associated with the store- modernization program and other non-recurring charges, net income for the fourth quarter of fiscal 1990 was $395.6 million, or $1.97 a share. The latest fourth quarter included a pre-tax LIFO credit of $15 million, compared with a $55.2 million pre-tax LIFO charge for year-ago period. The latest year included a pre-tax LIFO charge of $90 million, compared with $160.2 million for prior year. In the latest year, net income amounted to $745.2 million, or $3.71 a share, exclusive of a pre-tax provision of $640.1 million the company established to cover all expenses associated with an expanded and accelerated K Mart store opening, enlargement, relocation and refurbishment program and other non-recurring charges. The 1989 period ended Jan. 25.

title: Cigarette Maker Cleared in Death of Smoker
description: A Federal jury decided Wednesday that the American Tobacco Company should not be held liable for the death of a lung cancer patient, rejecting claims that the company had failed to warn the public about the dangers of smoking cigarettes.

title: Hach Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
INSIDE
description: Savings Regulator Picked

title: Expert Testifies on Palm Print in Golub Trial
description: A fingerprint expert said today that a partial palm print, etched in blood in the basement where the body of Kelly Ann Tinyes was discovered last March, belonged to Robert Golub.

title: Keltic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included investment writedowns of $464,457 for the quarter and $514,457 for the year. c-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Kohl Sees Role for Other Nations in Talks on Unity
description: The West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, traveled to NATO headquarters today to reassure several Western European countries that they will not be excluded from consultations leading up to the reunification of Germany.

title: Engineered Support Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Trial of Experimental AIDS Drug To Be Continued, With Revisions
description: The Food and Drug Administration will allow a San Francisco group to continue clinical trials of the experimental AIDS drug compound Q, with revisions, officials of the group said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: Protesters Press Haitian Ruler to Resign
description: Thousands of anti-Government demonstrators across Haiti set up flaming tire barricades and burned cars today to protest the army's killing of a schoolgirl. At least three people were killed, including a soldier who was beaten to death by a mob.

title: Ducommun Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax charge of $154,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $283,000, or 9 cents a share for the year, and the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $456,000. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $3,522,000 and $5,213,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Review/Theater;   Homages to Martyrdom, By Vaclav Havel and for Him
description: The two short plays presented under the title ''By and for Havel'' depict Vaclav Havel in two dehumanizing guises. The first play, ''Audience,'' written by the Czechoslovak playwright and drawn from his life, is an ironic comedy about a dissident writer forced to work as a laborer. The second, ''Catastrophe,'' dedicated to Mr. Havel by Samuel Beckett, is a highly symbolic homage to the author's martyrdom.

title: Why We Won't Keep Still and Be Sprayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharedata Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Music;   Ever-Questing Bernstein Leads Viennese in Bruckner
description: Most music lovers couple the names Bruckner and Mahler. But while these two composers shared much - a late-19th-century central European background, a propensity for vast forces and grandiose lengths, even Roman Catholicism - they were in fact very different. One indication has been Leonard Bernstein's decades-long, internationally recognized success with Mahler, compared with his relatively infrequent forays into Bruckner.

title: Computer Horizons reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $1,042,000, or 43 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. c-Net income and the year is after a loss of $961,000 from an accounting adjustment. The company said latest quarter and year figures included a loss of $3.3 million related to restructuring and a charge of $600,000 for bad debt coverage and certain other reserves.

title: Patent Suit Becomes Trade Battle
description: A Swiss machine-tool company won a victory today over a Japanese rival in a battle that has been marked by bare-knuckles practices rarely seen in multinational business.

title: Second World Title for Browning
description: A yearlong odyssey ended for Kurt Browning of Canada tonight as he successfully defended his men's title in the world figure skating championships, putting to rest concerns that he was squandering his talents, rather than improving them.

title: Refac Technology DevelopFment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $286,000 and $1,160,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $327,000.

title: Capriati Beats Out The Jitters
description: There have been inevitable pressures attending the hasty appointment of Jennifer Capriati as the new queen of tennis in her debut performance as a professional.

title: Cotton States Life & Health Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect adoption of SFAS No. 97.

title: Europe Is Grabbing The Spoils of Peace
description: LEAD: With the Warsaw Pact in shambles, and even the Soviet Union hard pressed to organize a credible military threat, the old debate over ''burden sharing'' among the allies is changing. The question of how to pay for increased military expenditures has shifted to how to divide the benefits of peace.

title: Pall Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Haim S. Eliachar, 61, A Developer, Is Dead
description: Haim S. Eliachar, a developer who was a founder and the first president of the American Sephardi Foundation, died of lung cancer on Tuesday at his home in Boston. He was 61 years old and also had a home in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard.

title: Dr. Otto Aufranc, 80, Orthopedic Surgeon
description: Dr. Otto Aufranc, an orthopedist who was a pioneer in the surgical replacement of damaged hips, died at Glover Memorial Hospital here on Monday after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Crowds in Britain Fight Police Over a New Tax
description: Angry crowds pelted police with cans, sticks and bottles today as demonstrations against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's unpopular new ''poll tax'' erupted into violence.

title: Why Care if Baseball Doesn't?
description: The great baseball ''lockout'' of 1990 might better be called the Great Charade. The fans have been the only real losers in what was supposed to have been a swift and decisive contractual struggle between owners and players.

title: McDonald's Moscow Spot
description: Hoping to capitalize on the success of its new fast-food restaurant in Moscow's Pushkin Square, the McDonald's Corporation's ad agency, the Leo Burnett Company, has created a television commercial entitled ''Magic in Moscow,'' which documents the Jan. 31 opening of the outlet.

title: Notebook;   When Caddie Talks, Norman Listens
description: Greg Norman's spectacular sudden-death victory at the Doral Ryder Open on Sunday came after he was the beneficiary of some well-chosen words by his caddie of nine months, Bruce Edwards.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the old days we would have put out an arrest warrant. Now we just presume they're in West Germany. Most of them are soldiers who honestly don't see any point anymore in this.''

title: Pitt Rolls Past Boston College, 88-70
description: Boston College's painful season came to an end last night, and Pittsburgh's 88-70 victory in the first-round game of the Big East Conference tournament extended the Panthers' season by at least one more game.

title: Nominee Seen for Top Savings Regulator
description: After more than three months of searching, the Treasury Department has chosen a nominee for the top regulator of the nation's savings and loan industry, a permanent replacement for M. Danny Wall, Administration officials said today.

title: Eagle Telephonics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Banister Continental reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cybermedic reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $2,865 for the latest quarter and $52,825 for the year-earlier period.

title: G.T.C. Transcontinental reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Consilium Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Washington Talk;   Not Pretty. Seems to Work, Though.
description: Before President, complete sentences.

title: Atwood Oceanics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Coincidence, Bah
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Environmental Issues In Exxon Proxy Report
description: The proxy statement issued by the Exxon Corporation yesterday includes six shareholder proposals addressing environmental concerns, which indicates that the Securities and Exchange Commission approved their inclusion.

title: About New York;   How to Preserve A Strong Mind: Flex It Regularly
description: John Hough thinks it's high time to study computers. ''Youngsters are learning how to use them, but us oldsters know nothing,'' he says.

title: INSIDE
description: Talks Offered in Lebanon

title: Let Joe Doherty, Almost Seven Years in Detention, Out on Bail
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Bars 3 Airline Pilots For Drinking and Flying
description: All three members of a Northwest Airlines cockpit crew were under the influence of alcohol on a Midwestern flight Thursday, and their licenses have been revoked, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Review/Music;   Del Tredici, in a New Work, Is Again Bucking the Trend
description: David Del Tredici is a composer who likes to anticipate changes in musical fashion. In the late 1960's, when Serialism and other forms of atonality were the accepted modes in the academic world, he began a series of works based on ''Alice in Wonderland'' in which comparatively simple tonal formulas, lush orchestrations and accessibility developed into a recognizable personal style. Now, when much of academia has shifted toward tonality in one guise or another, Mr. Del Tredici is evidently countermarching in the direction of old-fashioned atonality.

title: Digital Offer Of Severance
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, trying to cope with a slumping computer industry and a weak New England economy, said today that it would soon offer a voluntary severance package to as many as 8,000 employees.

title: 400 at Rutgers Discover It Pays To Take a Test
description: About 400 students at Rutgers University received vouchers this week for at least $20 worth of books for taking one extra test during the week of regular midterm exams - a state test of general intellectual skills.

title: Clothestime Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss and included a gain of $663,000 from an accounting change.

title: Europe Giving Thatcher Bad Press on Germany
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is being described by influential British and West German newspapers these days as the skunk at the garden party of German unity.

title: Red Ransom Sidelined
description: The list of leading Kentucky Derby prospects continued to shrink today when Red Ransom was found to have suffered a torn tendon sheath that will probably force him to miss the Triple Crown races.

title: Baltek Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on involuntary conversion of assets of $428,000, or 17 cents a share, for both the quarter and year.

title: Stephen F. Austin Signs Ex-Tulane Coach
description: Ned Fowler, who resigned as head coach at Tulane University in 1985 after the Green Wave was involved in a point-shaving scandal that led to the cancellation of varsity basketball for four years, has been hired to rebuild the program at Stephen F. Austin State, in Nacogdoches, Tex. Stephen F. Austin won only 2 of 27 games this season.

title: Artists, Accepting Federal Grants, Worry About Strings
description: Grants are godsends for writers like Martha Collins, but she still had to think long and hard before accepting a $20,000 fellowship this year from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Review/Theater;   Dinner for 4 Ends With 3 And They Have a Problem
description: Jan and Ken are a typical New York couple living in a typical East Side apartment with a typical view from the terrace of some steel girders on a construction site. ''You've been Trumped,'' Jan's friend Lois observes later. There are also the typical five locks on the front door.

title: Dow Ends Positive Week With a Decline
description: Stocks gave up more ground yesterday in slow trading in the wake of a sharp rise in bond yields and computerized sell programs that depressed the market severely.

title: Retirement Is Reported Near For North Korea's President
description: Kim Il Sung, North Korea's ''Great Leader'' since 1948, will step down after his 78th birthday next month and hand day-to-day power to his son, a Japanese news agency reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are risks involved in engaging two vulnerable populations and no certainty of success. But they are nice risks.'' - Arnold Hiatt, chairman of Stride Rite, on workplace day care for children and the elderly. [8:4.]

title: Dynamics Research reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Loft Co-ops Pay More Than Fair Share of Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrano Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Europe Joblessness Dips
description: The average unemployment rate in the 12 European Community nations dipped to 8.6 percent in January from 8.7 percent in December, the European Community statistics agency said today. Unemployment was highest in Ireland, where 16.7 percent of the potential work force was out of work in January.

title: Saudi Oil Minister Predicts A 'Sellers' Market' in 90's
description: The Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, said yesterday that he did not anticipate an oil crisis in the 1990's but added that ''the market will slowly but steadily turn into a sellers' market.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: Firefighting and Environmentalism Clash
description: To the Editor:

title: El Paso Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $31,313,000 and $94,551,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $40,553,000 for the quarter and $39,508,000 for the year. The company said the loss from continuing operations for the latest year of $11,282,000 and net loss included a $16,178,000 after-tax regulatory disallowance. Results for the latest year also included an after-tax loss of $41,440,000 from the writedown of preferred stock investment and a $50,430,000 after-tax provision for losses related to the sale of some subsidiaries.

title: A Hospital That Calls to Ask How You're Doing
description: It is not a house call, but in a program that is rare if not singular in the New York City area, the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan is calling some patients at home several days after they visit the hospital's emergency room - just to check.

title: Judge Upholds AIDS Testing of Colorado Prisoners
description: A Federal district judge has upheld a requirement that all Colorado prison inmates be tested for AIDS and that those testing positive be segregated from the rest of the prison population.

title: Senator Makes Scathing Attack on Gephardt Over Criticism of Bush
description: In an unusual breach of senatorial custom, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the deputy Republican leader, delivered a scathing personal attack today on Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader of the House.

title: School Chief's Fast Start;   Fernandez Injects a Forceful Personality And Acumen at a Moment of Broad Dismay
description: Joseph A. Fernandez's ability to shake up the New York City school system swiftly is largely a product of his forceful personality and political cunning, combined with the right political moment, a moment of widespread dismay with the schools. As the new chancellor, Mr. Fernandez has moved at a speed that has startled even a city renowned for its fast pace. In little more than two months, he has removed two superintendents and three principals, seized a stronger role for himself in selecting district superintendents and on Thursday, in his biggest coup, won the right to dislodge ineffective principals from their schools.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Fear of Bonn Invigorates East German Communists
description: All but written off a few weeks ago, the humbled and shrunken Communist Party, restyled the Party of Democratic Socialism, has found a new voice as the champion of East Germans increasingly fearful of West Germany's overbearing political and economic embrace.

title: Westmin Resources Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $90.6 million gain on the sale of assets and a $30 million provision for a decline in asset values of mining properties. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Skull Is 'Phantom' of 2 Secret Space Missions
description: A human skull packed with some 125 radiation detectors was flown on the last two secret military space shuttle missions in an attempt to better understand the radiation hazards for astronauts, space agency experts said yesterday.

title: Moscow Applies to GATT
description: The Soviet Union has formally applied for observer status with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a spokesman for the 96-nation world trade forum said today.

title: Using Microbes to Get More Oil From a Well
description: Rebecca S. Bryant, a microbiologist in Bartlesville, Okla., obtained a patent this week for a method of using microbial organisms to get more oil out of a well.

title: Douglas Suits Joined
description: Federal District Judge Robert Sweet of Manhattan yesterday consolidated lawsuits by Donald Trump and Don King against James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, and tentativly set April 16 as the date for the trial dealing with their claims to Douglas's first title defense.

title: Art by Charles Saxon
description: About 70 drawings and watercolors by Charles Saxon, whose cartoons appeared in The New Yorker for 35 years, are on view through June 29 in the Rare Book and Manuscript Library of the Butler Library at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street. The exhibition is in observance of a gift from the artist's widow, Nancy, of 1,900 of his works. Admission is free. Hours: 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Monday to Friday. Information: 854-2231.

title: Review/Film;   Loot That Catches the Conscience of a Cop
description: Frank Daly (Brian Dennehy), in ''The Last of the Finest,'' is a Los Angeles cop who could never be accused of being less than zealous about his job. In fact, he's so dedicated that he keeps on working even after the job has been taken away. Daly and three young proteges are suspended from their duties after a drug investigation turns murderous, but they stay with the case because they know they're on to something big. Hitching its wagon to the headlines, the film lets Daly et al. stumble on a covert drug and gun-running operation devised to finance contralike forces in Central America.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about modified atmosphere packaging misstated a sales figure. Sales of TomAHtoes increased to 650,000 cases in 1989 from 20,000 cases in 1983, when they were introduced by Natural Pak.

title: Methane Gas Believed Cause Of Bank Explosion Fatal to 3
description: A buildup of methane gas has emerged as the likely cause of an explosion that destroyed a bank here Tuesday, killing three employees and injuring 14 other people.

title: Villanova's Free Throws Help to Sink St. John's
description: Facing the possibility that a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament depended on the outcome, Villanova's Wildcats confronted a St. John's team that had beaten them twice this season and defeated the Redmen, 70-60, in the quarterfinal round of the Big East Conference tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. IS STEPPING UP EFFORTS TO SEIZE CARGOES OF DRUGS
description: The Pentagon said today that it was beefing up efforts to intercept drug shipments by operating Awacs reconnaissance aircraft over the Caribbean and deploying a network of radar-carrying balloons across the southern United States.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Putting Up a Fence
description: If you are thinking about putting in fencing this spring, now is the time to prepare for it.

title: U.S. Proposes a U.N. Role In Nicaragua's Transition
description: The United States proposed today to use United Nations troops to separate the Sandinista and rebel armies in Nicaragua, but a meeting between Vice President Dan Quayle and the leaders of Spain and Venezuela failed to resolve differences over how quickly the Nicaraguan contras should be disbanded, Administration officials said.

title: North American National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $1,749,551 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes.

title: Volt Information Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a loss of $885,000 from discontinued operations, reflecting losses from discontinued full service reproduction and production operations, and an extraordinary gain of $48,000, or 1 cent a share, from repurchase of debt. c-After loss of $555,000 from discontinued operations, reflecting discontinued operations in the business information services market, which had been conducted through two joint ventures. The latest quarter results included a gain on the sale of securities of $601,000, or 6 cents a share, and an unrealized loss of $234,000 to reduce short-term equity investments to market value. The 1989 amounts have been restated to conform to the current year's presentation.

title: Rose's Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included $1,440,000, or 7 cents a share, favorable impact of downward adjustment to the company's LIFO accrual.

title: Bridge
description: There are few absolutes in bridge, and probably none at all in the area of opening leads. Against a no-trump contract the textbooks advise leading the jack from jack-ten-nine and two small cards, although that is often wrong: It will block the suit when the partner has a doubleton honor.

title: Porta Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Easy Profits in Soviet Skies
description: Negotiators from the United States and the Soviet Union plan to meet next month to try to complete accords that will significantly expand air service between the two countries.

title: Elan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; translated at the closing rate on Dec. 29, 1989 of U.S. $1.557 equaled 1 Irish pound.

title: Amrep Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: G.M. Rejects District's Plea for $2 Million
description: General Motors said today that it would not advance the Tarrytown School District $2 million, but that it wanted to help the district in any other way.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   In Israel, Another Path
description: Buffet tables covered with North Sea herring and fresh strawberries, bananas and porridge, chocolate croissants, and a dozen varieties of yogurt. The winter traveler to Israel expects such plenty in a Jerusalem luxury hotel, but on a recent trip to appraise the country's economic performance, American visitors found similar abundance in the dining room of a faded resort hotel in Nahariya, three hours north of Jerusalem and very near the Lebanese frontier.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Asserting that he had been cheated of $8.5 million, BILL COSBY has charged MARY WALLER, his former business manager, with fraud and embezzlement. Yesterday, Mr. Cosby's lawyers requested an early start for Ms. Waller's bankruptcy trial, saying they wanted to prevent her from depleting assets estimated at $10 million.

title: Offer Refunds, Condo Builder On L.I. Is Told
description: The New York Attorney General's office has told a condominium developer to offer millions of dollars in refunds to people who made deposits because the developer concealed financial difficulties with the project.

title: Shaw Industries Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is from Toronto and results are in Canadian funds.

title: Creation Story Echoes Through Many Cultures
description: To the Editor:

title: Mandela Ally Rebukes Pretoria
description: Walter Sisulu, a leader of the African National Congress, denied today that the group was responsible for the growing unrest in South Africa and said that the white-dominated Government had caused the violence by its policy of apartheid.

title: Live Entertainment Stock in Rebound
description: Shares of Live Entertainment Inc. jumped $1.50 today, to $17.75, in over-the-counter trading after the police implicated two sons of the company's slain chairman, Jose Menendez, in his death.

title: Electronic ID for Pets
description: A micro chip the size of a grain of rice might make the difference between finding a lost dog or cat (or bird or sheep or cow) and never seeing the animal again.

title: Atlas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $325,000 for the quarter and income of $30,000 for the 6 months, which included a loss of $140,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $170,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary tax gains of $616,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $731,000, or 12 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-Included income from discontinued operations of $306,000, or 5 cents a share, and $477,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago results are restated for discontinued operations.

title: 3 Get Prison In Du Pont Plot
description: Three men convicted of plotting to extort $10 million from Du Pont were sentenced on Wednesday to prison terms.

title: Bruce B. Benson, 68, A Professor of Physics
description: Bruce B. Benson, professor of physics at Amherst College, died of respiratory failure on Wednesday at Cooley Dickenson Hospital in Northampton, Mass. He was 68 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: Iranian Leader Mocks Bush Over Hoax
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran today described the United States as ''the biggest bully on earth,'' and he mocked President Bush for taking a telephone call from someone posing as Mr. Rafsanjani.

title: A School District That Does Well on Less
description: The school district for this growing town in the flatlands of central New Jersey offers one of the state's best education bargains.

title: Mordecai Gorelic, Theatrical Designer and Playwright, 90
description: Mordecai (Max) Gorelik, a theatrical designer who also wrote, produced and directed plays, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: St. Joe Paper Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hastings Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Figures are restated to reflect materials costing error adjustment.

title: Guilty Pleas By Hughes in Papers Case
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company pleaded guilty yesterday to two felony counts of unlawfully obtaining secret Pentagon budget papers over a seven-year period.

title: Violent Anger Rises in Britain As Date for 'Poll Tax' Nears
description: It must have seemed like a good idea when the Conservative Party proposed it in 1987: a ''community charge,'' the same for every citizen, to cover part of the cost of local government services and replace most real estate taxes.

title: Howell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $312,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included earnings from the cumulative effect of the change in accounting for income taxes of $3,792,000, or 79 cents a share. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,680,000 and $10,087,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, an extraordinary charge of $12,787,000 for both the quarter and year. Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $2,361,000, or 50 cents a share, included a gain of $936,000, or 20 cents a share, on sale of Canadian oil and gas assets.

title: Samuel Manu-Tech reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Hospitals Awaken to Staff AIDS Risk
description: Almost a decade after the AIDS epidemic began to sweep the nation, hospitals are only slowly beginning to take steps to protect their own health care workers or to care for them if they are infected in the line of duty.

title: Lima Journal;   On the Front Line in Guerrilla War: Power Pylons
description: Just off the Pan-American Highway, a desert lot here serves as a drive-in showroom for Peru's latest fashion in power pylons - pillboxes, electric fences and ''concrete pants.''

title: Using Echoes To Help Blind Find Way
description: Inspired by the natural sonar systems that bats and owls use to navigate through darkness, an electrical engineer in Florida has invented a device that uses echoes to help blind people find their way.

title: Chrysler Canada reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company, wholly owned by Chrysler Corp., attributed the earnings to softening vehicle markets, higher interest rates and the cost of incentive programs. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Give Coach V A Raise!
description: Coach V is being bashed from pillar to post. It's hard to pick up a newspaper these days without finding someone calling for everything from his resignation to his head. What's the world coming to?

title: CHRONICLE
description: DR. CHARLES H. MAYO 2D, the grandson of a founder of the Mayo Clinic, has been fined $4,000 by the Minnesota Board of Medical Examiners for failing to diagnose illnesses or injuries in four patients.

title: Rebuild, Don't Fix, Covenant House
description: LEAD: After the Rev. Bruce Ritter resigned this week as the head of Covenant House, a lawyer for the organization described it as being in ''a meltdown.'' If the nation's largest child welfare agency is to survive the current scandal, it must scrap Father Ritter's unorthodox policies.

title: Ron Wolin, 55, Dies; Sued Port Authority Over Ban on Leaflets
description: Ron Wolin, an antiwar advocate who brought a class-action lawsuit in the 1960's that allowed the distribution of political and religious leaflets in bus terminals and other transportation centers and that led to the right to solicit contributions in such centers, died on Sunday at Cabrini Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: No Time for Politics
description: Less than a year ago, the dirtiest word at the State Department was ''Genscherism.'' Official American wisdom held that the West German Foreign Minister was dangerously susceptible to the charms of Mikhail Gorbachev's ''new thinking,'' excessively eager for good relations with Eastern Europe and personally obsessed with openings to East Germany, his homeland.

title: Probert Reinstated
description: At the request of the Detroit Red Wings, Bob Probert, the All-Star forward who was banned from the National Hockey League last year after being arrested on charges of possessing cocaine, was reinstated by the league yesterday.

title: Plain Speaking in the Supermarket
description: Ending years of Federal indifference, Dr. Louis Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, proposes sweeping changes in the nation's antiquated food labeling system. But he'll need help from Congress to fend off industry pressure and prevent backsliding.

title: Gathers's Family Plans To Sue, Attorney Says
description: An attorney for the family of Hank Gathers said today that medical records showed that a reduction in Gathers's heart medicine had been requested by someone in the athletic department at Loyola Marymount University.

title: Saab-Scania Plans Plant in France
description: Saab-Scania of Sweden said it would open a new truck and bus factory in Angers on a site where Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan abandoned plans for a Subaru vehicle plant. The Swedish group, which also makes Saab cars and aircraft, said it would invest 1.7 billion francs, or about $300 million, in the next four years in three new plants in Angers to build Scania heavy vehicles and diesel engines.

title: Greyhound Bus Hit by Shots
description: A Greyhound bus carrying 29 passengers was struck by at least three bullets fired from a passing vehicle early today in central Ohio, the police said.

title: Chairman for Bank of New England
description: The troubled Bank of New England Corporation today named Lawrence K. Fish chairman and chief executive.

title: American Ecology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $1,770,000, or 60 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $2,167,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $174,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-Included income of $43,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a loss of $211,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations and losses from an accounting adjustment of $1,918,000 and $1,343,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest quarter's loss from continuing operations of $482,000 included $1,689 writedown of equipment and intangible assets after an evaluation of the competitiveness in the market. Year-ago quarter's loss from continuing operations of $19,508,000 included a $23.5 million provision for: estimated litigation settlement costs; the company's estimated share of the remedial and administrative costs for the Maxey Flats, Ky., LLRW disposal site; and other items. The company said the extraordinary item is a loss on the sale of discontinued operations. Figures for the year-ago full year included the 1988 fourth quarter charge of $23.5 million and an additional charge of $3.9 million for the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Germans Are Starting to Take Unity Into Their Own Hands
description: The border of 1945 in this region is melting even before reunification.

title: Shipping Furniture Overseas Is Costly
description: More and more American tourists will be heading for vacations abroad as the spring tourist season approaches. For many of them, part of the fun will be making a major furnishings purchase - perhaps an antique chest, a rug or fine crystal.

title: Mutombo in Command As Georgetown Gains
description: The coaches and players in the Big East Conference might have already seen the confident, aggressive, efficient Dikembe Mutombo dominating basketball games for Georgetown University.

title: LDDS Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges principally from the early extinguishment of debt of $206,000 and $3,473,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the results for the fourth quarter included a full quarter's contribution of the operations of Advantage Cos.

title: John Ben Shepperd, Ex-Texas Official, 74
description: John Ben Shepperd, a former Texas Attorney General who was active in state politics for decades, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Gladewater. He was 74 years old and also had a home in Odessa, Tex.

title: Soviet Georgia Wants Talks on Independence
description: The parliament of the Soviet republic of Georgia today condemned its forcible annexation to the Soviet Union more than a half-century ago and demanded talks on the restoration of its independence, a local press agency reported.

title: Jets Add a Receiver
description: In yet another signing linked to their new coaching staff, the Jets yesterday signed Carl Parker, a free-agent wide receiver who played the last two seasons with Cincinnati, where the Jets' new head coach, Bruce Coslet, was the Bengals' offensive coordinator.

title: Bail Denied Suspect Tied to Trooper Death
description: A man who law-enforcement authorities said was linked to a suspect in the death of a state trooper last Monday was held without bail yesterday by a Federal magistrate in Manhattan.

title: POLICE MOURN DEATH OF ONE OF THEIR OWN
description: State Police Sgt. Joseph Aversa, killed on Monday in an undercover drug operation gone awry on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, was honored and mourned here today in a Mass of police brotherhood.

title: New Head of Virginia School
description: John T. Casteen 3d, president of the University of Connecticut, has been named president of the University of Virginia, its Board of Visitors announced yesterday in Charlottesville.

title: Thruway to Update Most Restaurants
description: The New York State Thruway Authority has decided to replace nearly all its 27 restaurants on the superhighway between New York City and Buffalo.

title: Georgia Tech Brings an End To Turbulent Wolfpack Season
description: For the longest time, it looked as if North Carolina State and its beleaguered coach, Jim Valvano, would extend their bumpy season. But the squad that came to the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament with only seven scholarship players, a likely lame-duck coach, and five losses in its last six games wore out against Georgia Tech, and lost, 76-67.

title: Eldon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 4-for-3 stock split last June.

title: Davis Delays Decision
description: Al Davis is keeping Oakland hanging over whether he'll bring the Raiders back.

title: Cardinal Hayes Tops All Hallows for Title
description: The last time Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx won a Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship, there was one Germany and the United States was at war with it and most of the crowd of 3,300 packed into Fordham University to watch them win their second one last night were not even born.

title: Safecard Services reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Review/Jazz;   Making a Case for the Concert Setting
description: Though it's not often brought up, many jazz fans harbor the nightmare that jazz will become like classical music, cleaned up and locked away in the museumlike confines of America's concert halls. Jazz, whose backbone is improvisation, would no longer be improvisatory. Its creative urges would dry up and the form would blow away.

title: Let Joe Doherty, Almost Seven Years in Detention, Out on Bail;   Comparative Rebellion
description: To the Editor:

title: Athey Products Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said all share earnings have been restated giving retroactive effect to a 10 percent stock dividend distributed on July 21, 1989.

title: LEBANESE GENERAL SEEKS PEACE TALKS
description: Gen. Michel Aoun, the leader of the Christian faction of the Lebanese Army, was quoted today as saying that his war with a rival Christian force was over. He offered to negotiate with Syria and its Lebanese Muslim allies for an end to the country's 15-year civil war.

title: Ortega Warns of Strife Over Contras
description: In his strongest public comments since his defeat in national elections on Feb. 25, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has warned that if the American-supported contras are not immediately disarmed, he could not guarantee a peaceful transition of power on April 25.

title: Berkley Wallcoverings reports earnings for Year to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $101,000, or 2 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Your Money;   Knowing Rules On Charity Gifts
description: Charitable donations provide one of the few tax deductions left largely intact in the huge overhaul of the nation's tax laws in recent years, an important consideration for the 85 percent of people who say they give.

title: 33 Seized in Gambling Raids
description: A $328 million betting ring was broken by a series of raids that resulted in 33 arrests, District Attorney Denis Dillon of Nassau County said today. He said the betting ring operated out of neighborhood stores at 18 locations in Nassau County and in New York City. Officers seized more than $150,000, along with gambling records, recording devices, cassettes and television sets in the raids. A four-month investigation, which included electronic wiretaps at some of the betting parlors, was completed when 115 officers made the arrests late Wednesday night and early Thursday.

title: INFANTS' DEATHS SPUR RARE STEP BY AGENCY
description: The telephone call on Feb. 26 was from California, and the news was tragic. Yet another infant had been found dead, and for Terri Rogers, the circumstances were hauntingly familiar.

title: Fading Fast, Doctor
description: Isn't it terrible about this Trump story? All the attention it's getting? Newspapers, television, magazines all pumping out Trump gossip. They ought to be ashamed.

title: Seymour B. Wyler, 79, Antiques Store Owner
description: Seymour B. Wyler, owner of S. Wyler Inc., an East Side antiques store specializing in English silver and porcelain, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Campbell Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the year included an extraordinary charge of $60,868,000 which included a $58.4 million writedown of the carrying value of investments and a $6.8 million provision to cover costs of discontinued coal operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Pan Am Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain of $110.5 million on sale of Pan Am World Services, a contract services subsidiary. c-Included $89.1 million gain from sale of A320 aircraft delivery positions.

title: George and Toshiki - The Odd Couple
description: LEAD: After eight years of ''Ron'' and ''Yasu'' we now have ''Toshiki, my friend,'' and ''George,'' as President Bush and Japan's Prime Minister Kaifu referred to each other at the conclusion of their hastily called summit meeting in Palm Springs, Calif., last week. Why Presidents and Japanese Prime Ministers feel compelled to assert a first name camaraderie that cannot possibly exist between men who have met infrequently and who do not speak a common language is unclear.

title: Iran Squirms on Human Rights
description: This much has changed in Iran: Ayatollah Khomeini's successors no longer seal their ears to the world's censure of their behavior. Iran and Syria are now talking about freeing 17 hostages, including 8 Americans believed to be held by Shiite militants in Lebanon. And Iran has now agreed to a second visit by a United Nations investigator.

title: CPC-Rexcel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $782,600 pretax provision for restructuring. c-Net income

title: The Court's Deadly New Rules
description: The Supreme Court has shed all pretense of neutral justice on the matter of Federal court relief for state prisoners, especially those on death row. Not content with rejecting most death penalty appeals, a five-justice majority is now doing all it can to close the Federal courts even to inmates with meritorious legal claims.

title: Security Guards Should Be Licensed
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicare to Cover Some Liver Transplants
description: The Government will begin paying for certain liver transplants in Medicare beneficiaries, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, announced Thursday.

title: LTX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Baseball;   Strawberry Not Charged
description: The Los Angeles City Attorney notified Darryl Strawberry today that no charges would be brought in connection with the family fight between the Mets' outfielder and his wife on Jan. 26. But Strawberry will be required to continue his treatment for alcohol abuse and to write reports on his progress every other week for the next three months.

title: KEY RATES
MHI Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: c-Net income

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anderson Group P.L.C., Glasgow, and National Mine Service Co., Indiana, Pa., said Anderson would purchase for $8.875 a share, or $21 million, the 48.8 percent of National Mine stock it does not already own.

title: Isco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Lillian S. Rinenberg, Judge, 85
description: Lillian S. Rinenberg, a former administrative law judge and a lawyer in Queens for 60 years, died of a heart attack on Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. She was 85 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: BTU International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $623,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,101,000, or 20 cents a share, for the year.

title: Bowman Celebrates, But Trenary Falters
description: For all the wondrous performances this week in the world figure skating championships, few will remain as memorable as Christopher Bowman's madcap escapade on Thursday night, which won him a bronze medal in the men's singles competition.

title: Cassidy's Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $390,000, or 16 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cold War's Victims Deserve a Memorial
description: LEAD: In the whirlwind disintegration of repressive Communism, the brave citizens of Eastern Europe are exhuming the crimes of their past. In such a time, Hamlet's words ring out: ''Foul deeds will rise, though all the earth o'erwhelm them, to men's eyes.''

title: Covenant House Aide Is Charged in 2 Rapes
description: An employee of Covenant House has been arrested and charged with raping a 19-year-old woman twice, the police said early today.

title: Gioiosa Request Denied
description: Tommy Gioiosa, the longtime friend of Pete Rose who has said he placed bets for the former Reds manager, has been denied his request for a release from a Federal prison near Montgomery, Pa., where he is serving a five-year sentence on drug and tax-evasion charges. The decision was handed down Thursday by a Federal appeals court in Cincinnati.(AP)

title: Zenith Bets the Store on New TV
description: Among many consumers, the television sets of the Zenith Electronics Corporation have a reputation as old-fashioned and stodgy. But in stark contrast to that perception, the 67-year-old company is now betting its life on developing a television technology so advanced that most American manufacturers have shied away from it.

title: The Founder of Grove Press Tries to Buy Publisher Back
description: Barney Rosset, who founded Grove Press in 1951 but was ousted after it was sold five years ago, is attempting to buy back the house with the help of four independent publishers.

title: O'Connor Is Moving To Clear Up 'Mess' At Covenant House
description: John Cardinal O'Connor called the tangled affairs of Covenant House a ''mess'' yesterday and said the Archdiocese of New York was acting to rescue the organization by helping it find a new interim president.

title: For Younger and Older, Workplace Day Care
description: The Stride Rite Corporation is bridging the generations in the heart of its workplace with a day care center where working parents can bring not just their preschoolers but also their aging relatives.

title: Unemployment Remains Steady at 5.3%
description: The economy generated many more jobs in February than analysts had expected, but the growth was not sufficient to affect the civilian unemployment rate. It stood at 5.3 percent for the ninth straight month, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Chile's Civilian President-to-Be Acts to Calm Pinochet on Reprisals
description: As he prepares to become Chile's first elected President since 1973, Patricio Aylwin has sought to calm Gen. Augusto Pinochet's fears of prosecution for the political killings, disappearances and torture that took place under his rule.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Credit Card Trade-Ups
description: With the credit card market saturated, issuers of gold cards are pressing more affluent consumers to ''trade up'' because gold cards offer higher profits and lower risks. It makes sense for holders of standard Visa cards or Mastercards to consider switching to gold because the rates and annual fees for these cards are on their way down and are either lower than or competitive with the lowest charges for standard cards. Banks set their own credit standards and services, but both Visa and Mastercard require holders of gold cards to have a credit line of at least $5,000.
