title: J.A.M.  Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Basic American Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,400,000, or 19 cents a share. c-After an extraordinary reversal of tax loss carryforwards of $500,000.

title: Coleman's Block Keeps Orangemen on Top
description: A spectacular defensive play by Derrick Coleman kept top-seeded Syracuse from making a quick exit from the Big East Conference tournament last night.

title: Continental Materials reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net income

title: A Rauschenberg Exhibition Heralds Arts Union in Berlin
description: Robert Rauschenberg, the American artist, advanced East and West German cultural unification by a giant step today through an exhibition in the historic Alte Museum. For the first time, a major exhibition spanned the division of the city.

title: Perelman Group Wins Bidding for San Antonio Savings
description: An investment group headed by the financier Ronald O. Perelman has won the bidding for the San Antonio Savings Association, Federal regulators said today.

title: A Director's Life Imitates His Art
description: Last summer, as part of the Royal Shakespeare Company's London season, the English director Roger Michell found himself directing a group of British actors in a comedy by an American author about a group of American college professors and their students on a theater tour of England. The play - ''Some Americans Abroad'' by Richard Nelson -was a success, and this winter Mr. Michell found himself directing it with a group of American actors at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Snyder Oil Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $16.5 million writedown of oil and gas properties. Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units. Shares outstanding included general partner's 9.91 percent interest.

title: Woman in the News;   Head Nurse For Welfare
description: Shortly after Barbara J. Sabol took a job as the top lieutenant to New York's Commissioner of Social Services in 1987, she put on blue jeans and a sweatshirt and paid an unannounced visit to a welfare office in midtown Manhattan. She filled out an application and, like most others in the office, settled in for a long wait.

title: Apogee Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said included in 1989 expenses was about $460,000 of product development costs, compared with $219,000 in 1988.

title: Coffee Exports Spurt
description: World exports of coffee jumped by nearly 25 percent last year after international controls on sales were abolished in July, the International Coffee Organization said this week. Exports to all destinations in the last half of 1989 totaled 39.6 million bags, compared with 31.9 million in the comparable period of 1988, the organization reported. One bag equals 132 pounds. The quota system was abandoned July 4, when member governments failed to agree on terms for its continuation.

title: Abortion Curbs, Strictest in U.S., Win Idaho Vote
description: The Idaho House today approved a bill that would give the state the nation's most restrictive abortion law and provide abortion opponents the test they want for a United States Supreme Court decision on the issue.

title: Upheaval in the East;   MITTERRAND BACKS POLAND ON BORDER
description: President Francois Mitterrand today endorsed Poland's demand that West Germany sign a treaty recognizing East Germany's postwar borders with Poland before the two Germanys are united.

title: Fred Tan, 35, Is Dead; Made 3 Feature Films
description: Fred Tan, a film maker and critic, died on Wednesday in Veterans Hospital in Taipei, Taiwan. He was 35 years old.

title: Bonwit Stores To Be Sold
description: The L. J. Hooker Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell 5 of the 16 Bonwit Teller stores, including the flagship store in Trump Tower in Manhattan, to the Pyramid Companies, a real estate development and investment company based in Syracuse, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Carl Bailey Dies at 35; Ailey Company Dancer
description: Carl Bailey, a principal dancer and a teacher with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, died on Tuesday at Mount Carmel Mercy Hospital in Detroit. He was 35 years old.

title: Cuomo's War of Words Is Fought Bulk Rate
description: If Joe Bruno is your state senator, then you've been hearing from Mario Cuomo, your governor.

title: No Met Opera Today, But Lots of Singing
description: The Metropolitan Opera's matinee performance and radio broadcast today will be a concert instead of an opera, to continue the 50th-anniversary celebrations of Texaco's sponsorship of Saturday-afternoon live broadcasts from the house. The program will be arias, duets and ensembles by artists including Francisco Araiza, Mariella Devia, Jerry Hadley, Thomas Hampson, Kurt Moll, James Morris, Paul Plishka, Ashley Putnam, Gino Quilico, Neil Shicoff, Dawn Upshaw and Carol Vaness.

title: Frederick Evoy Kneip, Executive, 75
description: Frederick Evoy Kneip, a retired executive in the paper products industry, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Lakeland (Fla.) Regional Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Lakeland.

title: Colorado Pulls Upset in Overtime
description: Colorado, without a victory in the Big Eight Conference tournament since 1984 and playing for a coach who has already been dismissed, did today what the No. 1 team in the country failed twice this year to do: beat Missouri.

title: U.S. Settlement For Fred Alger
description: The Wall Street money manager Fred Alger has settled an administrative action with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the S.E.C. said this week.

title: Judge, in Shift, Discloses That Prego Will Get $1.35 Million
description: The judge in Dr. Veronica Prego's case reversed himself yesterday and disclosed that the AIDS-stricken doctor will be paid $1.35 million for settling her lawsuit.

title: A Second-Half Surge and a 3-Pointer Allow Auburn to Upset Louisiana State
description: John Caylor hit a 3-point shot with five seconds left to give Auburn a 78-76 upset today over 16th-ranked Louisiana State in the quarterfinals of the Southeastern Conference tournament.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the New Jersey Senate's approval of Gov. Jim Florio's automobile-insurance plan misstated the vote. It was 29 to 8.

title: Laser Radar May Help To Detect Wind Shear
description: Researchers at Stanford University have patented a laser-based radar that they think could help airline pilots detect wind shear, the pockets of air turbulence blamed for some fatal plane crashes.

title: RTI Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said 1989 figures included a gain on the sale of its Arkansas plant of $747,330, and additional income of $150,000 related to the grant of a non-refundable option for the purchase of the Salem plant. Also included is a charge of $271,090 in expenses associated with the Salem plant.

title: Connecticut Dominates Seton Hall
description: Connecticut played pressure defense for 40 minutes against Seton Hall yesterday at Madison Square Garden. The Huskies covered the court with flailing arms, shuffling feet and white jerseys. They deflected passes, turned steals into layups and hurried Seton Hall's shots.

title: Haitians Take to the Streets Again To Call for Military Ruler's Ouster
description: Demonstrations aimed at bringing down this country's military ruler continued for the fifth day today as protesters marched and built flaming barricades to block main roads.

title: Landlord Is Sent to Jail For Not Providing Heat
description: A man described by New York City officials as one of the city's most notorious landlords has been sentenced to five months in jail for failing to provide heat and hot water in seven buildings, municipal officials said yesterday.

title: General Signal To Sell 3 Units
description: The General Signal Corporation said it intends to divest itself of three units that supply telecommunications test equipment, transmission and network products, and data network diagnostic and control equipment. The proceeds will be used to repay debt.

title: Holly Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Deal in Armory Seizure
description: A sheriff who seized a National Guard armory here to house some prisoners when he ran out of space at his century-old jail last month has agreed to move to the state's suggested compromise site, a vacant armory in nearby Holyoke. But the agreement, worked out between the state and Sheriff Michael Ashe of Hampden County, is opposed by Mayor Martin Dunn of Holyoke, who says his city will fight it in court. The Holyoke site is next to a preschool and kindergarten.

title: Capriati, Brisk and Brash, Stuns Sukova
description: On one side of the net, the 13-year-old hugged the baseline and appeared unconcerned at finding herself under the spotlights in the quarterfinals of her first professional tournament. On the other side, the player tacitly assigned a villain's role, Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, all 6 feet 2 unsmiling inches of her, loomed like the giant from a fairy tale.

title: Collision Halts River Traffic
description: A tugboat and a freighter collided on the Mississippi River near Baton Rouge today, sinking at least three grain barges and setting loose up to 14 others, the Coast Guard said.

title: 3 Die in Collision of 2 Planes
description: Two small planes collided and crashed into a residential neighborhood during rush hour today. All three people in the two planes were killed, the authorities said. The planes crashed into homes in this suburb of Fort Lauderdale suburb, but there were no reports of injuries to anyone on the ground.

title: Senate Unanimously Backs Dunne for Civil Rights Post
description: The Senate today unanimously confirmed John R. Dunne as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, filling a 15-month-old vacancy at the Justice Department.

title: Federal Pioneer reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $7,000,000 from a provision for possible decrease in value of the company's investment portfolio and a possible loss relating to an investment by the company's pension plan. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Municipal Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA ROSE, the art writer who founded The Journal of Art, has suspended its publication with the current issue. The journal will re-emerge next fall with a new appearance and broader content, thanks to an influx of money from the R.C.S. Rizzoli Corporation New York and ALEXIS GREGORY, the owner of Vendome Press, who will be the new publisher.

title: Mineral Resources Intl reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Ban on Smoking in Airliners Doesn't Apply to the Cockpit
description: Smoke-free air in the cabin of an airliner may be better for the health of passengers, but Federal officials have determined that it is safer to let the pilots keep smoking.

title: Pathe MGM/UA Payment
description: The MGM/UA Communications Corporation said today that it had received $50 million from the Pathe Communications Corporation, the first installment in a $200 million down payment that Pathe must provide as part of its deal to acquire MGM/UA for $1.2 billion.

title: Day 24: Lockout Hits a Milestone
description: No meetings, no proposals, no baseball.

title: V Band Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Why Single Out Israel For Rights Violations?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pistons Cash In on Nets' Turnovers
description: There was only one thing in tonight's game as spectacular as the way New Jersey manhandled Detroit for most of three quarters: the way the Nets fell apart in the last 13 minutes and lost to the Pistons, 99-95.

title: Civilian Rate As Main Gauge
description: The Labor Department statistics published today by The New York Times show the civilian unemployment rate as the primary gauge of the nation's labor market rather than the overall rate, whose base includes domestically stationed military personnel.

title: Elmer T. Klassen, Who Oversaw Postal Reorganization, Dies at 81
description: Elmer T. Klassen, a former United States Postmaster General who rose from messenger to president of the American Can Corporation, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at a nursing home in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Palm Harbor.

title: Report Denied on Not Renaming Greenspan
description: A published report that President Bush is unlikely to ask Alan Greenspan to stay on as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board when his term expires in 17 months drew strong denials today from the White House and the Treasury. It also prompted ringing endorsements of Mr. Greenspan from both Democratic and Republican lawmakers.

title: Turbo Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $2.5 million for costs related to staff reductions and other cost-cutting programs. c-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Chartwell Lifts Stake in Avon
description: Chartwell Associates L.P. said it had raised its stake in Avon Products Inc. to 9.5 percent from 9.1 percent. Chartwell, an investment partnership of representatives of Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc., the Getty Oil family and the Fisher real estate developers of New York, is waging a proxy fight for four seats on Avon's board of directors.

title: Thaw Is Hinted In School Strike In West Virginia
description: What has become one of the most serious teacher strikes in the nation in recent years shut down more than half of West Virginia's schools today, the third day of the strike.

title: Burned Boy Undergoes Four Hours of Surgery
description: David Aupont, the 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who was critically burned in an attack on Wednesday, underwent four hours of surgery yesterday, as doctors removed damaged skin from his arms and replaced it with healthy skin from his legs.

title: Treasury Prices Fall on Jobs Report
description: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday after the Government reported an unexpectedly large rise in civilian employment in February.

title: PCL Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $8,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $224,000, or 4 cents a share. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Mongolia Communists Offer To Resign From Government
description: Mongolia's Communist leaders offered to resign today in the face of protests by thousands of people calling for multiparty democracy, Eastern European press agencies reported from the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator.

title: A Raw Nerve in Tokyo
description: As the largest industrial groups in Japan and West Germany explore collaborations in aerospace, automobiles and electronics, Tokyo's habitually nervous business community is facing a troubling question:

title: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 10, 1990
description: Companies

title: Zycad Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After income of $440,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. The 12 months for 1988 included $6.2 million relocation charge for the company's consolidation into its Menlo Park facility.

title: Religion Notes
description: Giving Gospels Away Just weeks after the Supreme Court ruled that materials distributed by religious organizations could be taxed, the Jehovah's Witnesses have stopped asking for contributions in exchange for their magazines, Bibles and other literature.

title: Transat A.T.  Inc. reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said the fiscal 1989 loss was due to strong competition in the travel marketing sector, $2 million in extra costs due to the late delivery of its third aircraft and modifications to its aircraft fleet. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Zaccaro's Conviction Upheld
description: The Vermont Supreme Court today upheld the drug conviction of John Zaccaro Jr., the son of Geraldine Ferraro, the Democratic candidate for Vice President in 1984. In a unanimous decision, the court rejected claims by Mr. Zaccaro's lawyers that his conviction in 1988 for selling cocaine should be reversed because the police operation in which he was arrested was conducted illegally and he was the victim of selective prosecution as a result of his mother's being well known.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Epic Health Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $139,161. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $105,980 and $253,230 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the loss for the year was comprised of an after-tax loss from operations of $572,633, an increase in the company's provision for uncollectable accounts receivables of $229,606 which arose in prior years, and an inventory shrinkage of $299,782.

title: Celerex Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NEW TV CONTRACTS FOR N.F.L.'S GAMES TOTAL $3.6 BILLION
description: The National Football League yesterday concluded a four-year television package for more than $3.6 billion, the most lucrative deal in television history.

title: New Drumstick Said To Be Easier to Control
description: David Hughlett, a professional drummer in Dallas, patented a drumstick this week that he said was faster, more powerful and easier to control than conventional sticks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Lending their star power to benefit the Gay Men's Health Crisis, MICHAEL DOUGLAS, MELANIE GRIFFITH, JANE CURTIN and CHEVY CHASE will be the hosts at a starry evening of pop music at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday. The idea originated with JOAN TISCH, an executive-committee member of Gay Men's Health Crisis; she passed it along to her son, JONATHAN M. TISCH, the president of Loews Hotels.

title: Peter-Adolf Thiessen, Atomic Scientist, 90
description: Peter-Adolf Thiessen, the East German scientist who was taken from the ruins of Nazi Germany to play a major role in developing the Soviet atom bomb, has died at the age of 90, the official A.D.N. press agency said today. The agency said he died on Monday.

title: North Says He Aided the Contras Under Direction From Poindexter
description: Prosecutors in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter summoned a wary Oliver L. North to testify today in an attempt to show that Mr. Poindexter knowingly misled Congress about Mr. North's far-flung efforts to aid the Nicaraguan contras.

title: Phone Venture In East Germany
description: Alcatel, a French-American telecommunications company, announced plans for a big joint venture in East Germany to overhaul the country's dilapidated telephone network. It said its West German subsidiary had signed an agreement with VEB Kombinat Nachrichtenelektronik of East Berlin to set up a jointly owned company that would eventually produce 900,000 high-technology digital telephone lines a year.

title: Atari Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $106,315,000 and $124,221,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the losses from discontinued operations in the year- ago periods represented operations of the Federated Group, which Atari decided to discontinue. It reflected the decision by writing off its remaining investment in Federated and providing for anticipated financial obligations and losses arising from this investment.

title: Books of The Times;   Turning Food Maxims (and Industry) Inside Out
description: Appetite for Change

title: Jay Feigus Dies at 97; Played Contract Bridge
description: Jay Feigus, a leading contract bridge player, died of heart failure on Thursday at his home in Middletown N.J. He was 97 years old.

title: Burger King Faces Charges It Violated Child Labor Laws
description: The Government has filed suit against the Burger King Corporation, charging that it violated child labor laws at many of its company-owned restaurants around the country.

title: Screaming Won't Help
description: ''I hear America singing,'' wrote Walt Whitman in the last century. Today, he would have difficulty hearing himself think. According to audiologists, 20 million Americans are exposed daily to persistent noise loud enough to cause hearing loss. The racket also contributes to high blood pressure, peptic ulcers, aggression, poor reading, lack of consideration and, understandably, the urge to give up.

title: Historical Society Maps Tour of Pound Ridge
description: LEAD: A DO-IT-YOURSELF guided tour through the roads of Pound Ridge is now available. Published by the town's Historical Society, the booklet, ''Heritage Trail Guide to Historic Pound Ridge,'' is intended to enhance motorists' appreciation of the area.

title: Community Colleges Fear State Cuts
description: ENROLLMENT for the current semester at Norwalk Community is 10 percent higher than last spring, one of the most dramatic increases in the school's history. And with a planned move to new quarters on Richards Avenue that would more than double its space to 122,000 square feet, the college was looking forward to even more growth.

title: 5 Bonwit Teller Stores Are Sold, Likely Insuring Retailer's Survival
description: An agreement by the Pyramid Companies to buy five Bonwit Teller stores is likely to insure the survival of one of the nation's oldest retailers at a time when a number of other famous chains have vanished.

title: Robert L. Kaufman, Executive, 63
description: Robert L. Kaufman, former president of Mollie Parnis Inc. and a former president of the New York Fashion Council, died on Thursday of complications from lung cancer at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: Campus Life: Simon's Rock of Bard;   Committee Clears Three Professors Of Harassment
description: A committee set up at Simon's Rock of Bard College has exonerated three professors accused by students of sexual harassment. The committee, comprising two students, two faculty members and one administrator, recommended unanimously that no disciplinary action be taken against the professors.

title: MOSCOW DAYS: LIBERATED BY HAROLD ROBBINS
description: LEAD: ''Russians love to read.'' Try to find a book or an article on the Soviet Union that does not contain these words. The sentiment is usually supported by circulation figures to prove that Soviet readers devour books without being prodded by expensive ad campaigns. But who needs statistics? From Minsk to Yakutsk, no living room is complete without a massive bookcase bursting with ''Complete Works.

title: Lifestyle;   The LP, the CD and the Cassette: A New Game of Musical Chairs
description: ''Do you have the new Rickie Lee Jones record?'' a house guest recently asked Ronald Prince. ''Sure,'' Mr. Prince remembers saying, pulling out a compact disk. ''How about Janet Jackson's 'Rhythm Nation?' '' the guest asked later.

title: Campus Life: Irvine;   Six Are Arrested Protesting Policy On Gay Housing
description: Six students were arrested last week at the University of California at Irvine in a demonstration protesting Chancellor Jack W. Peltason's refusal to permit gay and lesbian couples to live in family dormitories. The demonstrators blocked an entrance to the administration building.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Accountable Is Jim Valvano?
description: Holding the coach or athletic director responsible for the current state of big-time college basketball or football is like placing the blame for typhoid fever on Typhoid Mary.

title: Virginia and Georgia Tech Win
description: The mascot for the Duke Blue Devils wore a headband that proclaimed: ''Pride of North Carolina!'' But on a day when past form proved irrelevant, the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament got its first non-North Carolina final as Georgia Tech defeated Duke, 83-72, and Virginia eliminated top-seeded Clemson, 69-66, in semifinal games at the Charlotte Coliseum.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   Hard Times for Hoteliers in Hartford
description: A DECLINE in occupancy over the last several years has led to the closing of the Parkview Hilton, once the premier hotel in the heart of downtown Hartford, to a struggle for guests by a major new hotel and to the pullout of a major partner in still another.

title:
FILM;

Kathryn Bigelow Practices the Art of the Kill
description: LEAD: At first glance, Kathryn Bigelow seems the antithesis of what one might expect the director of a visceral, chillingly bloody thriller to be. She has a Rebecca-of-Sunnybrook-Farm look and a quiet, cultured voice. A mane of chestnut brown hair waves past her shoulders, framing a nearly model-perfect face.

title: Soviets and Hungary Agree on Troop Pullout
description: The Soviet Union and Hungary signed an agreement today calling for all Soviet troops to be withdrawn from Hungarian territory by the middle of next year, Hungarian radio reported.

title: Whistle-Blowers in Atomic Plants Would Be Protected by New Plan
description: The Department of Energy says it will propose procedures to protect nuclear weapons workers who complain about health or safety violations from retaliation by their employers.

title: POSTINGS: Don King's Town House;   Sparring Over a New Facade
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, has been hit with a violation citation by the Landmarks Preservation Commission because he changed the facade of a town house he owns at 32 East 69th Street without obtaining a permit as required by law. The five-story building, which is used as the headquarters of Don King Productions, is within the boundaries of the East Side Historic District and the commission must approve exterior alterations.

title: TOO EMBARRASSED NOT TO KILL
description: THE THINGS THEY CARRIED

title: Remedial School: Paying the Piper
description: SUFFOLK Community College has a classroom shortage. So much space is needed for remedial courses that the standard college departments are being squeezed into fewer rooms.

title: Seaford Is Divided On Library
description: A PROPOSAL to build a new public library in Seaford has divided this South Shore community, but the issue may be resolved Wednesday, when Seaford residents will vote on a $4 million bond issue to finance construction of the building.

title: For the Arbs, One More Nail In the Coffin
description: Just when those wonderful denizens of Wall Street, the arbs, thought things couldn't get worse, they did.

title: No Play, No Pay
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ingrid Grace to Wed James Fairchild
description: Gerd Morris Grace of New York and Charles B. Grace Jr. of Chester Springs, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ingrid Wiese Grace to James Burr Fairchild, a son of Mr. and Mrs John B. Fairchild of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: BE TRUE TO YOUR DEPRESSION
description: A BLUE FIRE

title: Death Penalty Ordered for Convicted Killer
description: A man convicted in a murder that was cited by the group claiming responsibility for two deadly mail bombs was sentenced Friday to die in the electric chair.

title: How Dreams of Clean Air Get Stuck in Traffic
description: ''LOVE AFFAIR'' isn't strong enough; the automobile is part of the American identity. And more and more it looks like the Mr. Hyde part.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The United State Postal Service, in a rush of marketing enthusiasm, has announced new issues for the next few months that include two popular themes: movie stars and sports heroes.

title: Claire Rosenblum to Wed Oren Cohen
description: Dr. and Mrs. William I. Rosenblum of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Claire Helen Rosenblum to Oren M. Cohen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Cohen of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Code Enforcement;   Violations Pile Up as Housing Improves
description: RUVIN SCHWARTZ knows how to find other people's money. The company he heads is Coldata, a collection agency in Valley Stream, L.I. It does work for New York City's traffic and environmental agencies, getting money from those who have ignored city fines.

title: Sins Of the Fathers
description: Letters come from Germany.

title: DOWN THE DRAIN WITH THE NEWS
description: HAPPY TALK

title: Eelco D. Swaak Marries Christina Ann Johnson
description: Christina Ann Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Johnson of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to Eelco Dewitt Swaak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reyer Swaak of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Robin Capoor officiated at the Unitarian Fellowship in Morristown, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;

The American Botanical Tradition
description: LEAD: AMERICANS seem to have an inferiority complex when it comes to gardening. We attempt to emulate anything that is English, whether suited to our climate or not. We feel that we must arrange borders like those at Sissinghurst and that we must mimic the garden designer Gertrude Jeykll's use of color.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Baltimore County, Md.;

Under $100,000 Near the Bay
description: LEAD: NEW town-house developments rising in the Middle River-Essex area near Chesapeake Bay in eastern Baltimore County are drawing buyers with low prices and taxes and proximity to major highways, Baltimore city's downtown and big suburban malls.

title: TEACHERS VOTING ON ENDING STRIKE
description: Striking teachers in West Virginia's 55 counties began voting today on whether to go back to the classroom on Monday in return for a promise by Gov. Gaston Caperton to resume talks over a pay increase and not to discipline strikers.

title: Course Record Broken By Youmadeyourpoint
description: Youmadeyourpoint, perhaps the most improved horse in Florida this winter, outran a strong field and broke a course record while winning the $157,600 Gulfstream Breeders' Cup Handicap on the grass today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Idaho Says No
description: In the indigo moment before the sun rises and the night is not yet gone, the vast lava plain that lies at the foot of the Lost River Range in eastern Idaho reveals itself - raw, empty, magnetic. In July, the wind blows hot, and dust rakes the brush and fills the gullies. In February, the sky turns deep blue, and blinding snow robes the western summits and chokes the craggy canyons.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Sliding Down the Up Scale
description: LEAD: IT all began two weeks ago when I tried on last year's slacks and the button was on one hip, the buttonhole on the other. Donald and Ivana will get together faster than the two ends of my slacks.

title: Tamils Flee Sri Lanka, but India Limits Entry
description: Thousands of ethnic Tamils who cooperated with Indian peacekeeping forces in Sri Lanka since 1987 are fleeing to India in boats, fearing violence when New Delhi's troops leave the island at the end of this month.

title: BUSH DISTRESSED AS POLICY FAILS TO MOVE CHINA
description: President Bush and many officials in his Administration say they are deeply disappointed by the failure of the Chinese Government to relax its repressive rule in response to numerous conciliatory gestures by Mr. Bush.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Baseball Impasse: Locking Out for No. 1
description: Why is baseball so consistently unable to reach collective bargaining agreements without a work stoppage? Since 1972, a strike or a lockout has occurred each time the old contract expired. The record of conflict stems partly from the need for the union to break down the system of paternalism and impediments to freedom in the players' labor market. The old wounds have been slow to heal and, despite the power shift toward the players, the parties continue as adversaries.

title: A Glimpse Behind The Bamboo Curtain
description: AS the mists rise each morning, the calm and graceful Nam Khan River in northern Laos slowly takes shape, ornamented with saffron-robed Buddhist monks on the banks and naked children swimming in the middle, and destined a few hundred yards later to end its journey in the embrace of the larger, ever-churning Mekong River. Above the confluence of these two rivers, the town of Luang Prabang sheds its sleep: peasants lug their vegetables to the village market, novice monks begin sweeping the temples and bicycles fill the dirt streets as the people go to market to buy and sell everything from papayas to owls.

title: Jane Sternick to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Sternick of Cranford, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Jane K. Sternick, and Patrick J. Hitchcock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Hitchcock Jr. of San Mateo, Calif. Miss Sternick, 24 years old, is an economic analyst for the California Bankers Clearing House Association in San Francisco. Mr. Hitchcock, 25, is a researcher at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Columbia's Research Park;   A 'Spec' Building Planned for Audubon Theater Site
description: ITS purpose and location alone would make the Audubon Research Building noteworthy: a speculative commercial development in Washington Heights.

title: Tech Notes;   Beauty of the Simulated Weld
description: Researchers at the College of Aeronautics, Queens, N.Y., and at Ixion Inc., a Seattle-based computer and video programming company, have devised an interactive video system that can teach oxygen acetylene welding under different conditions without danger.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CONNECTIONS TO THE WORLD: The Basic Concepts of Philosophy, by Arthur C. Danto. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) In a recasting of his book ''What Philosophy Is,'' Arthur C. Danto now proposes that it can be thought of as ''the effort to understand the relationships between subjects, representations, and reality.'' Last year our reviewer, Julia Annas, said he has written ''an elegant, unifying overview.''

title: Spying For Hanoi
description: It is early morning, Jan. 25, 1989, and the caravan - my ''60 Minutes'' camera crew and assorted hangers-on - is waiting at the Majestic Hotel in Ho Chi Minh City. Huang Mai Huong, my guide-interpreter, is looking very smug. ''Miss Mai,'' as I call her, has been wedding shopping in Ho Chi Minh City, which to someone from Hanoi is the equivalent of Hong Kong or Bangkok. She is due to be married in a few weeks to a young Hanoi diplomat. Although she is pleased at what she has found - raw silk for a wedding dress, boxes of sweets, and small gifts for relatives - I am not so sure she is so sure about the groom. When he receives his first diplomatic posting, she will not be allowed to travel with him. Without a great deal of confidence, she has already told me, ''The reason for this is that we are a poor country, and we cannot afford to send a whole family overseas.''

title: Shaking Down the TV Thunder
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Castorama
description: To the Editor: Last October one of the many kindnesses shown to us by our French friends in Nimes was to take me, a confessed do-it-yourselfer, for a look around the local Castorama. Peter D. Lawrence (''French Supermarkets of Stylish Wares for the Home,'' Travel, Jan. 7) nicely described the excellent examples of design found there, and the special style of some of the European solutions to home improvement needs. I wonder, though, how many readers know that castor is the French word for beaver, referring to the homeowner being ''busy as a beaver''? And that there is a competing chain called Bricorama, taking its name from bricolage, the French word for puttering around?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about states' revenue problems misstated New York's bond rating in some editions. It is now ''very good.'' A chart with the article referred incorrectly to Vermont's budget and the estimated deficit. Vermont is on a two-year budget cycle and is working to avoid a $90 million deficit for the fiscal years 1990 and 1991.

title: Miss Joyce Plans Autumn Wedding
description: A November wedding is planned by Katherine deLancey Joyce and Hugh Kilpatrick Webster, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Raymond Joyce Jr. of Washington, have announced. Mr. Webster is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Drury Webster of Bethesda, Md.

title: O'Rourke's Theme: Taxes and Cooperation
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke signaled the start of a new era of cooperation with the Board of Legislators last week in a sharply detailed State of the County address that recommended major changes in Westchester's tax collection and spending procedures.

title: The Court Cuts Off Another Exit From Death Row
description: CONSERVATIVES have railed for years against the Supreme Court's expansive criminal procedure rulings of the 1950's and 1960's. The Court was permitting the guilty to go free on ''technicalities,'' they said.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Accountable Is Jim Valvano?
description: If John Gotti is innocent, Jim Valvano is Mother Theresa.

title: Back to Basics on Chicken
description: THERE is a story, possibly apocryphal, of the novice cook who put a chicken in the oven to roast. After about 20 minutes, a revolting stench began to fill the kitchen. It turned out that this newcomer to the culinary arts did not know enough to remove the package of innards tucked inside the bird.

title: Variations On a Theme, The Movie Musical
description: 'THE Great American Backstage Musical'' begins in 1939 and ends in 1945 in Johnny's Bar, where having a fancy drink means putting olives in your beer.

title: 'Black Eagles,' a Tale Of War, Glory and Race
description: ''WE were young and strong and we knew we were going to live forever,'' recalls one of the Tuskegee Airmen. Looking back with pride and bravado, but not in anger, three legendary and yet unsung heroes recall their wartime glory - and how it was suppressed.

title: Road Maps
description: To the Editor: Apropos Betsy Wade's discussion of cartography (Practical Traveler, Jan. 14), I wish to bring to the attention of your readers a distressing observation. In Michelin's map of Northeast Africa (No. 954), the frontispiece shows the borders of Jordan including all of Israel, which goes nameless. Inside, in the larger fold-out map, the state of Israel is blotted out by an insert showing the mapped region in relation to Africa and the Near East.

title: Shaking Down the TV Thunder
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A CHARACTER TEST TO TAKE THE MEASURE OF AUDIO DEALERS
description: A letter tells us: ''I went to a local audio store and asked about the . . . loudspeaker you wrote about. The dealer said, 'Never heard of it.' Then he tried to sell me something else.''

title: New Zoning Proposed For an Old-Time Look
description: LEAD: FOR more than 300 years, most small towns in Connecticut have grown up around a town green, where houses with tiny front yards are clustered together on narrow streets. Today's zoning regulations, however, would prohibit construction of this characteristic New England village.

title: Yugoslav Albanians Honor Martyrs
description: A knot of solemn boys is gathered in front of a table draped with the red flag of Albania on which rests the framed color photograph of a young man.

title: Good Deeds, Great Gilbert & Sullivan
description: THE Simsbury Light Opera Company is distinctive on a number of counts, not the least of them having survived to celebrate its 45th anniversary season. And as one of only about a dozen non-university companies in the country that maintains its own set and costume shop, Simsbury not only makes its facilities available to other arts groups, but also shares its performance surpluses with education, performing arts and health maintenance organizations. Over the years, such gifts to the community have exceeded $75,000.

title: Q and A
description: Institutional Apartments

title: Lisa Gustin Is Engaged To Peter Fitzsimmons
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Gustin Jr. of Wellesley, Mass., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Lisa J. Gustin, to Peter Day Fitzsimmons, a son of Thomas H. Fitzsimmons of Mansfield, Conn., and the late Virginia Day Fitzsimmons. A June wedding is planned.

title: Playing Under One Roof: A Sports Mall
description: LEAD: BATTING practice, anyone? How about simulated golf, miniature golf, pool, billiards, ''hoop shoot'' - a basketball game - or video devices that make you feel as if you are racing around a speedway at 190 miles an hour?

title: Boccherini Up Front
description: In the 1950's heyday of the ''Baroque revival'' - how dim and distant that sounds, in this age of the early-music movement - the marketplace was flooded with integral ''i's'' and ''ini's.'' The long-playing record had just taken over the record business, and multidisk boxed sets proliferated of the complete concerti grossi of Vivaldi, Corelli, Albinoni, Galuppi, Torelli, Locatelli, Manfredini, Geminiani, Tartini and Boccherini. Among others. Today, those same composers live on in an eerie half-life, plugged in as filler on middlebrow classical FM radio stations.

title: Florida Wedding For Miss Bartram
description: Elizabeth Meagher Bartram, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Rensselaer Wardwell Bartram 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married in Palm Beach yesterday to Kirk Henckels, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Ross Henckels of Fort Worth.

title: Style Makers;   Ozey Thorpe Clothing Designer
description: As a teen-ager growing up in Washington, Ozey Thorpe remembers that it was not always easy finding men's clothing that complemented his 6-foot-6-inch frame. ''I used to tinker a lot with sewing machines as a kid,'' Mr. Thorpe said. ''That way, I was able to do my own alterations.''

title: Nancy Carlson to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Carlson of Boston have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Nancy Ann Carlson, and Dr. John Matthew Fisher, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Fisher of St. Albans, Vt. Dr. Carlson, 29 years old, is a chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington, where her fiance, 30, is an attending anesthesiologist.

title: Campus Life: SUNY Binghamton;   Fraternity Sues University to End Its Suspension
description: A fraternity at the State University of New York at Binghamton that was suspended last April after a rape investigation is fighting the suspension in court.

title: TYING THE KNOT
description: Given the somewhat shaky condition of the state of matrimony these days, one wonders at times how serious the recent marriage of food and wine really is. As someone once said about a prominent wedding: ''Too bad. It ended a beautiful relationship.''

title: Finding Out If It Will Play In Peoria
description: So how did they play in Enfield, Conn.? To test a long-held belief in the video industry that outside of New York and Los Angeles the country doesn't want to watch foreign films, Orion Home Video deployed 24 of its best foreign titles (such as ''Babette's Feast'' and ''Manon of the Spring'') in 500 exurban stores, all of them in prosperous towns and many of them near universities. The stores were asked to promote the titles and see what happened.

title: Double Standard?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Ludington Engaged to Wed
description: Callaway Anne Ludington, a business reporter, and Michael Paul Zuccarello, a sports columnist, both in St. Louis, plan to marry in September. Miss Ludington is the daughter of Gail C. Ludington of Boston and William F. Ludington of Stamford, Conn. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis C. Zuccarello of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Gillette's Record of Cruelty to Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Quilt Care Is In Valhalla
description: I've just finished reading the article about the outstanding James quilt collection [''County Couple's Quilts Chosen for Japan Tour,'' Feb. 18] . As a quilt collector and enthusiast I was especially interested. However, as a supremely satisfied client of Betsy Prokop, I can just imagine the frustration of potential quilt-owning clients, who will never be able to locate her through your article.

title: Tseng Kwong Chi, Photographer, 39
description: Tseng Kwong Chi, an artist and photographer who for the last 10 years documented the downtown art scene in Manhattan and particularly the works of the artist Keith Haring, died of AIDS early yesterday in his Manhattan apartment. Mr. Tseng was 39 years old.

title: ELECTION PROMISED
description: Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, Haiti's military ruler for the last 18 months, stepped down today after a week of nationwide protests. An army officer said a provisional government would take power within 72 hours to organize elections.

title: Teaching the 'Sir Winston' Method
description: In the stark Manhattan meeting room, under fluorescent glare, the studious, well-fed man in the three-piece suit chomped on a cigar. He put a derby on, took it off. He bellowed: ''We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills. We shall never surrender.''

title: Put a Cap on Campaign Spending
description: While the cold war may be over, we in Washington are locked in a campaign- spending arms race.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   When It's All Right To Be Two-Faced
description: Take a jacket made of fake lamb's fur, line it with polka-dot dress silk, and what have you got? An imaginative and versatile piece of clothing that has suddenly captured imaginations on both sides of the Atlantic. The jacket, designed by Dolce & Gabbana in Milan, Italy, is reversible, so it can look like a fur (actually a pile fabric that resembles caracul) with polka-dot cuffs, or a polka-dot jacket with fur cuffs and collar. Its two-sided allure was on view last week in Milan (photos at left), where the weather was sunny and mild, and in New York (at right), where it has been decidedly chillier.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CELEBRATING WOMEN

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Pine Valley Voters Consider Dissolution
description: LEAD: PINE VALLEY voters will decide March 20 whether the village should be dissolved and once again become an unincorporated area of the Town of Southampton. The three-square-mile community just south of the Riverhead town line was incorporated only two years ago in March 1988.

title: 'I Won't Discriminate Against Those Who Have Supported Me'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   An Intense Marinade for a Pork Tenderloin
description: For a main dish of marinated pork, the meat can be marinated overnight or for 20 minutes. The shorter time will not produce quite the same results, but the seasonings are so intense that even the quick version is very appealing.

title: Colgate and Rensselaer Win
description: John Fletcher, Clarkson's star goalie, made one mistake tonight that gave Colgate a score and ultimately a 5-3 victory over the Golden Knights in an ECAC Hockey tournament semifinal game at Boston Garden.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: SARA WILFORD;

What Is Too Young for Kindergarten?
description: LEAD: ONCE parents rarely thought of delaying a child's entrance into kindergarten. If the birthday came before the legal deadline - usually that they be 5 years old by Dec. 31 - the children were enrolled. If at a later date, maybe years later, one of the children had a problem keeping up academically or socially, then he was possibly ''left back.

title: Visiting Nurses Face Growing Competition
description: LEAD: NORTHERN Westchester's rural nursing corps began in 1898 with a handful of women who traveled by horseback or horse and buggy to dress the wounds of soldiers home from the Spanish-American War.

title: No Headline
description: HIGHER THAN HOPE

title: Data Bank/March 11, 1990
Susannah Labov Weds G. M. Page
description: Susannah R. Labov and Gregory M. Page were married yesterday at Delmonico's restaurant in New York by Samuel Morgenstern, a justice of the peace. The bride is a daughter of Dr. Teresa Gnasso Labov and Dr. William Labov, both of Philadelphia. The bridegroom is the son of Lieut. Col. W. Mark Page of Orlando, Fla., and the late Dr. Sarah Kerr Page.

title: ONCE UPON A TIME: THE REAL STORY
description: DON'T TELL THE GROWN-UPS

title: Betsey T. Winsor to Wed John Hartley Watlington
description: The engagement of Betsey Trent Winsor to John Hartley Watlington Jr., a son of Mrs. Watlington of Mangrove Bay, Bermuda, and the late Mr. Watlington, has been made known by her parents, Gayle Winsor of Asheville, N.C., and Fred Winsor of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: L. S. Miller to Wed Kathy A. Chazen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Chazen of Upper Nyack, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathy Ann Chazen to Lawrence Scott Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Miller of Peabody, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Basque Tour
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from an unusual adventure in the Basque country, sponsored by Backroads International. It was a two-week tour through the Spanish and French Basque country, conducted by Jim Beterbide, an American who now lives in Bilbao. He imparted fresh, interesting information. We visited small towns where the people treated us as guests. Their food was outstanding. The scenery and towns were remarkable. Included in the tour was the crossing of a swinging bridge 500 feet above the canyon floor (optional), a visit to the astounding caves of Oxocelhaya, a surprise ''running of the bulls'' in the town of Olite, a breathtakingly beautiful drive along the ocean between Bilbao and San Sebastian. The tour was leisurely and often altered to include festivals and special events. Plans are being made to offer the tour this summer and fall. For information contact Paulette Hurdlik, Backroads International, 757 St. Charles Avenue, Suite 203, New Orleans, La. 70130; 504-525-1273.

title: Gains In Child Support
description: LEAD: ''THE children are our clients,'' said Marion LaFranco, director of two new units in the County Department of Social Services. They were created to help ''children get the support of two parents regardless of their marital status,'' Mrs. LaFranco said.

title:
MUSIC;

Head of Choir Sees a Revival of Form
description: LEAD: THE English composer and conductor John Rutter, a familiar voice in liturgical music and a frequent visitor to New Jersey musical organizations, will bring his Cambridge Singers to Princeton this week as part of its American debut tour.

title: Classy Irene Pick In the Magnolia
description: Classy Irene, unbeaten in five races, heads a field of nine 3-year-old fillies Sunday in the $50,000-added Magnolia Stakes at Oaklawn Park.

title: INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: Lodgings Grand and Simple;   Palatial Hotels in Vienna For Dukes and Divas
description: IT doesn't take long to realize that Vienna is slightly off the pace of other West European capitals. The Viennese themselves are often the first to point this out, and they take some pride in it. One can sit for hours in a cafe with one cup of coffee. Or go to a ball. Or take the streetcar to the edge of the Vienna Woods and stroll on from there.

title: Housing: 'The Writing Is on the Wall'
description: After reading the two articles on housing in your Feb. 18 edition [''Housing Forum Presses Its Effort at Local Level'' and ''Union Housing Offer Attracts No Takers''] , I felt compelled to write in with my thoughts on that familiar Westchester oxymoron - ''affordable housing.''

title: Page Vincent to Wed Thomas Walker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Vincent Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Page Pendleton Vincent to Thomas Duncanson Walker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Walker of Barrington, R.I., and Stratton, Vt. A June wedding is planned.

title:
Newark Journal;

North Ward Fears the Loss of a Beloved Family Restaurant
description: LEAD: IT is hard to find anyone in the North Ward who has not dined on veal or ziti and danced the night away at a wedding or confirmation party at Biase's.

title: Treasures From a Napoleonic Trove
description: In French, the word ''Vitrine'' conjures up the imaginary and unattainable world that exists behind glass in shop windows and showcases. And each year, the glass of the now-famous gallery-long vitrine in the costume exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art must be cleaned of fingerprints several times a week, as the crowds press in for a closer look at the magical array of small decorative accessories that have become the heart of the shows.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Accountable Is Jim Valvano?
description: When the biggest apple in the barrel is rotten, it will poison the whole barrel. I think that time for North Carolina State's basketball program has come. It was inevitable.

title: For Rudolf Bing at 88, Operatic Drama Lingers
description: ''La Commedia e Finita - The comedy is over'': The final words of Leoncavallo's tragic opera ''I Pagliacci'' were the ones Sir Rudolf Bing chose on April 22, 1972, to ring down the curtain on his lordly and controversial 22-year tenure as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. A drama was indeed ending, but it was hardly the last that awaited Sir Rudolf, who could not have anticipated the quintessentially operatic tangle of tragedy and farce that lay ahead.

title: THE MUSICAL MYSTERY OF ST. JOAN
description: What is it about Joan of Arc that frustrates the efforts of opera composers to bring her to life? At least two dozen musical versions of this promising subject exist, but none has established itself in the repertory. There is no Joan to compare even remotely with adored heroines like Mimi, Violetta, Tatiana or the many other mistreated women who lead vivid stage existences. They may appear as pygmies beside the St. Joan of history, but on the operatic stage they live and she does not. Why?

title: Maternity Leave Confession: Grueling Days in Bootie Camp
description: CLUMP, bang, ouch - the thrust from the working world into maternity leave leaves scars.

title: Leslie Hodges to Wed Andrew Blau
description: Russell Fox Hodges of Rosemont, Pa., and Jean Glover Hodges of Ardmore, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Fox Hodges to Andrew McDara Blau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence McDara Blau of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Brucie Ketcham To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Bonbright Ketcham of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Bruce Ketcham to Thomas Mark Donahue, the son of Beatrice Donahue of Barre, Vt., and Bare Foot Bay, Fla., and the late Howard Donahue. A June wedding is planned.

title: Killed for Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Explaining the 'No' In a 15-to-1 Vote
description: At a special meeting of the County Board of Legislators on Feb. 13 the Board voted 15 to 1 for a budget amendment that restored over $14 million in spending [''Budget Impasse Comes to an End,'' Feb. 18] . By doing so, the Board voted to reinstate more than 450 jobs that County Executive O'Rourke had threatened to terminate. I was the only Legislator to vote against the budget amendment.

title: Technology;   The Giants Focus on The Image of a Check
description: Glenn Rifkin is features editor of Computerworld, a weekly trade newspaper, and co-author of ''The Ultimate Entrepreneur.''

title: When Nature Became God, Art Changed
description: In the heart of the sleepy village in ''The Starry Night'' is a Dutch church that van Gogh transposed to the south of France. Its interior is black, its steeple as protective and forbidding as a lance. Although the steeple is a lightning rod for the wave of light flowing across the pre-dawn sky, the church is untouched by the sea of energy and light bolting and spiraling through the cosmic night.

title: Once a Canvas Shoe, Now a Big-Time Player
description: Sneakers, those once-lowly and often ragged athletic shoes, have evolved into high-tech status symbols that, in turn, have become a source of growing concern among high school and college officials.

title: Devils Roll With 6 Goals in 2d
description: Six goals in the second period sparked the Devils to their most productive game of the season tonight and a 9-3 triumph over the Quebec Nordiques at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Style Makers;   Mark Hess, Stamp Designer
description: Mark Hess, an artist and a graphic designer, is used to turning out commissioned works - typically magazine covers - in a few days. But it took him two years to design his first stamp.

title: Jennifer Hyams Marries
description: The marriage of Jennifer M. Hyams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira L. Hyams of Jericho, L.I., to Scott B. Prizer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Prizer of East Hills, L.I., took place last evening at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson and Cantor Stephen Dubov officiated. Mrs. Prizer, 26 years old, is a product manager at the Williamsburgh Savings Bank in Brooklyn. The bridegroom, 27, is an associate at European Investors, financial advisers in New York.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Review/Music;   Violinist Gives Recital Using Instrument Made of Plastic
description: In ''The Graduate,'' Dustin Hoffman's character, Ben, is given a single word of career advice by a friend of his parents: Plastics. Presumably Ben ignored the suggestion, but by the time the film was made, in 1967, the Italian-born guitarist and instrument-maker Mario Maccaferri had proved the value of that advice, having made his fortune manufacturing plastic ukeleles, hangers, clothespins and tape cassettes. He had also been experimenting with plastic guitars and violins since the 1950's.

title: Cable TV Pact
description: The National Football League completed its television package for its international venture yesterday, agreeing to a four-year contract with the USA cable network, which guarantees that all World League of American Football games involving United States teams will be shown in the United States.

title: THE LURE OF THE OLD FLAME
description: TAKING SHELTER

title: BACK TO PSYCHEDELIA
description: Now that it's the 90's, looking back at the 60's with gales of laughter is a party game more popular than Trivial Pursuit. The funny clothes! The angry people! The drugs! The hair styles! What pretensions! What a hoot it all was! Weren't we silly! That about sizes it up for SIXTIES PEOPLE (Knopf, $24.95) by Jane Stern and Michael Stern, whose previous books include ''Elvis World'' and ''Square Meals.'' The current book is packaged as a collection of sociological essays on the generation that was. The chapters have titles like ''Perky Girls,'' ''Playboys,'' ''Hippies,'' ''Folkniks'' and ''Young Vulgarians.'' The content is part humor, part insightful observation and part just self-congratulatory in-jokes that tend to overstate the obvious. Everyone knows people dressed and acted bizarrely in the years between 1958 and 1967. But the reasons everyone was so durned peculiar and angry is never satisfactorily addressed. The essays are exceedingly sarcastic, a tone not tempered by the confession of the authors that they too were 60's people of the pseudo-hippie variety. Heaven knows, it's easy enough to make fun of the 60's generation - it's a bit like shooting fish in a barrel. We need some explanations, and the Sterns never provide them. The book is well researched and chock-full of fun facts - did you remember that Casey was Barbie's English friend? But that just leaves you wanting more: why were things that way, and have we changed at all? Even more irritating, the writing is erratic. Sometimes the essays are engaging, others plod like a 60's term paper. There is a wonderful book in here somewhere, but finding it is difficult. SHARON LIVETEN

title: The How and Why Of Turning Camera Shy
description: LEAD: SOME people like having their picture taken. I once saw the French movie star Isabelle Huppert in the middle of a photo shoot, and she seemed to enjoy every click of the shutter; it was as if she and the camera were old and good friends. I'm not like that at all - I have graduated from a childish surliness at having my picture taken to a glum acceptance that, for posterity, vacations and family reunions demand it.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Checking Out Cholesterol

title: Syracuse Holds Off Villanova
description: Syracuse was ranked No. 1 in the nation in January when Villanova defeated the Orangemen at the Carrier Dome. The Wildcats snapped the Orangemen's winning streak at six games in February in Philadelphia.

title: Singing Songs of the Irish Immigrants
description: LEAD: JANE MURPHY has ambivalent feelings about St. Patrick's Day. On the one hand, she looks forward to it every year. After all, she is a singer well known for the songs of Ireland.

title: Rights Group Sees Failure by Guatemala Chief
description: President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala has failed to move against a surge of killings, abductions and torture perpetrated by the army, according to a report released this week by Americas Watch, an independent human rights group.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: The pompous new head of a British intelligence service sends a top deskman to make a tour of various installations and pep them up. This is against all rules. Top deskmen are not supposed to be in the field. They know too much, and if they are captured and tortured, operatives may die and services may be compromised. Sure enough, the deskman is kidnapped by Iranians and put through the mill. How long can he hold out?

title: Comparing the Black Artist in the United States and Brazil
description: ''INTROSPECTIVES,'' a show by Americans and Brazilians of African descent, comes to the Bronx Museum of the Arts from the California Afro-American Museum in Los Angeles. There, it was organized by Henry J. Drewal, a professor of art history at Cleveland State University, and David C. Driskell, professor of art at the University of Maryland. The curators contribute essays to the catalogue, so do Sheila S. Walker, an associate professor in the department of Afro-American studies at the Univeristy of California at Berkeley, and Luiza Bairros, who is research coordinator for the Department of Labor in Brazil.

title: Principal's Incompetence Case Is Seen as a Test for Fernandez
description: When Sonia M. Rivera was appointed principal of the academically troubled Eastern District High School in Brooklyn in 1981, she had 19 years of experience in public schools and a reputation for hard work and dedication to students.

title: NOBODY'S VICTIM
description: NOTES OF A HANGING JUDGE

title: The Gossip Column
description: The attitude about gossip these days reminds me of an attitude people had about sex 20 years ago. It was called the sexual revolution, and it was as tiresome as can be. It ignored any possibility that people had copulated in Edsels, or that bonafide grandparents had in the past-and perhaps in the present - chased one another around the kitchen in their underwear. Trend reporting had it that people of a certain age - young - had invented sex outside marriage, outside the bedroom, and outside the pale.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Smudge of Spontaneity

title: Mixed Reviews
description: Washington is not without literary tradition, of course, but when a member of Congress writes a book that somehow makes money, it is often suspected that something unseemly has transpired. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, raised such suspicions about a book written by former House Speaker Jim Wright, who resigned last year after a House ethics panel found improprieties in connection with his book sales. Then questions were raised about Mr. Gingrich's own book, ''Window of Opportunity.'' The ethics panel looked into whether hebroke the rules when he allowed a group of investors to raise $105,000 to promote the book, paying his wife, Marianne, more than $10,000. Mr. Gingrich was several other trangressions, but it all blew over last week. The House panel admonished Mr. Gingrich on minor issues, but let the book matter drop. Mr. Gingrich said it had all been ''a political smear.''

title: In Stamford, Mexican Food and Style
description: HACIENDA DON EMILIO in downtown Stamford has so much space, with several tiered dining areas (divided into smoking and non-smoking sections) and so many tables and staff, that it smacks of an upscale, slicker version of a mass-feed chain.

title: Naturalist Illuminates World of the Night
description: DIANA KAPPEL-SMITH settled into a wing-back chair and began describing a five-month journey through a world of darkness. Leaving her home in Rowayton, she traveled in search of alligators in Louisiana kangaroo rats in Arizona, coyotes in North Dakota, octopuses in Hawaii and brown bats in Connecticut.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BURLINGTON, VT.;

Nonprofit Buys Rental Units
description: LEAD: VERMONT'S largest subsidized rental complex is undergoing a major renovation after its sale to a nonprofit limited partnership. The work and the sale assure the residents that their homes will remain livable and affordable.

title: Marcia Cleveland Engaged to Marry
description: The engagement of Marcia Elaine Cleveland to Mark Thomas Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Green of New York and St. Paul, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Carolyn Cleveland of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert W. Cleveland Jr. of North Palm Beach, Fla. A September wedding is planned. Ms. Cleveland, 26 years old, is an advertising sales representative for the Petersen Publishing Company in New York. She is a graduate of Yale University. Her father is an investor. Her grandfather Robert Cleveland of Rye, N.Y., and North Palm Beach, is the chairman of the H. O. Penn Machinery Company, the Caterpillar tractor dealer for New York, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Massachusetts.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Valentin Pavlov, the Soviet Minister of Finance, begins meeting with Nicholas Brady, Secretary of the Treasury, in Washington.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Planes Grounded, Air Service Cut Within India

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO!

title: POSTINGS: A New Kind of Mortgage;   The Fannie Mae Two-Step
description: One problem with long-term, fixed-rate mortgages is that most homeowners sell their houses long before their loans are repaid. This, in turn, forces them to pay higher interest rates for the first years than with an adjustable-rate mortgage. But if they have a short-term, adjustable-rate loan and decide not to move after all they usually must pay several thousand dollars in refinancing costs when obtaining a new mortgage, and sometimes face major increases in interest rates as well.

title: A Queens Woman Is Found Slain And Her Nephew, 19, Is Charged
description: A Queens woman was found stabbed to death in her bed Friday afternoon, and detectives later charged her 19-year-old nephew with killing her, the police said yesterday.

title:
FOCUS;

Some Say Slip Is an Adjustment, Not a Downturn
description: LEAD: Last June, when California real estate prices were sizzling, John P. Forhan moved from a modest house into a larger, more attractive one about a mile away in a fashionable section of this city.

title: Taking the Heat at American Express
description: Once again, the heat is on the American Express Company and its chairman, James D. Robinson 3d. Having been forced to rescue its brokerage subsidiary with a massive capital infusion, American Express is facing criticism for a series of missteps over the past decade.

title: THE TREASURE IN THE LACQUERED BOX
description: CINNABAR

title: Fashion;   Pushing Terry Cloth Off the Beach Blanket
description: Amid a design expansion in swim wear, beach cover-ups are being transformed from a functional to a fashion item.

title: Sports of The Times;   Tagliabue's 4-Month Blitz
description: About 9 o'clock one morning shortly after Paul Tagliabue moved into the commissioner's office at National Football League headquarters, a club owner phoned. After a brief conversation with one of Tagliabue's aides, the club owner, accustomed to Pete Rozelle's habit of arriving closer to 10 o'clock, left a message for ''when the commissioner gets in.''

title: STEAL THIS REVIEW
description: THE BEST OF ABBIE HOFFMAN. Edited by Daniel Simon with Abbie Hoffman. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $21.95.) At the Chicago conspiracy trial 20 years ago, the judge gently scolded Tom Hayden: ''Fellows as smart as you could do awfully well under [the American] system.'' Those words would have been lost on Abbie Hoffman, who remained, in his actions and, as this book shows, in his writings, incorrigibly and imaginatively subversive to the end. The self-styled ''cultural revolutionary'' - who committed suicide last year at the age of 52 and has since become, as Norman Mailer says in his foreword, ''our own holy ghost of the Left'' - chose the selections here from ''Revolution for the Hell of It'' (1968), ''Woodstock Nation'' (1969) and ''Steal This Book'' (1971). To those Daniel Simon has added essays and speeches from the 1980's, when Hoffman, no longer on the run from a drug charge, was working as an environmentalist and still trying to stir up student activism. What set him apart was his wit, a virtue as rare in American politics as it is in American comedy. This is his account of the ''language barrier'' between a zonked Yippie and members of the House Un-American Activities Committee: ''They spoke of Marx and I thought they meant Groucho. My interpreter said, 'No, they mean Karl Marx.' They spoke of Lenin and I thought they meant John Lennon of the Beatles. My interpreter said, 'No, they mean the guy without a first name.' '' If you liked Abbie - and don't mind reading about be-ins, bad acid trips and ''the politics of ecstasy'' - you'll like this collection. But it isn't really ''The Best of Abbie Hoffman.'' We saw the best of Abbie Hoffman inside a Federal courthouse, and outside the walls of the Pentagon.

title:
DINING OUT;

Charm and Serenity of Japan in Elmsford
description: LEAD: DINERS who have enjoyed the well-prepared food at Ichi Riki in Nyack will be pleased to know that John and Sue Koshiba have opened another version of their successful restaurant and sushi bar on this side of the Hudson, in Elmsford. Although this place has been open only two months, the high-quality dewy seafood, lovely serving plates, artistic presentations and serene atmosphere have already attracted an enthusiastic clientele.

title: Leslie Mills Wed To Peter Santos
description: Leslie Ann Mills and Peter Clark Santos were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., by the Rev. Douglas S. Phillips. Mrs. Santos is the daughter of R. Jeffries Mills Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Jo Ann Yow Mills. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Santos of Long Meadow, Mass.

title: Mr. Bush's Squeeze on Cities
description: Does it make sense to tax Iowa farmers so that suburban commuters can take the train into Philadelphia? No, says Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner in the Administration's long-awaited transportation policy statement: Transportation facilities produce local benefits. Let local governments pay more for their upkeep.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Campus Life: Wake Forest;   Movie Company Has Dreams Of a Home Run
description: ''Be about 20 minutes'' could be Michael Baron's break into stardom. Mr. Baron, a sophomore theater arts major at Wake Forest University, will say the line in the film ''Mr. Destiny,'' in which he will play a pizza-parlor worker who takes an order from Jim Belushi.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Burlington, Vt.;

Nonprofit Rentals
description: LEAD: VERMONT'S largest subsidized rental complex is undergoing a major renovation after its sale to a nonprofit limited partnership. The work and the sale assure the residents that their homes will remain livable and affordable.

title: Wall Street;   End of the 'Event-Risk' Nightmare?
description: Top-quality corporate bonds were among the first casualties of the takeover craze that defined the Drexel era on Wall Street. With each new debt-laden deal, another set of corporate investors awoke to find that their bonds, blue-chip assets the night before, were suddenly on their way to the junk heap.

title: Gia Costa and Bruce Newman Married
description: Gia Costa and Bruce Newman, a senior writer at Sports Illustrated in New York, were married yesterday at the Highlands Inn in Carmel, Calif., by the Rev. Garth Van Nest, a Unitarian minister. Mrs. Newman, 23 years old, graduated in December from Arizona State University. She is a daughter of Marilyn Costa of Verdi, Nev., and the late Sam Costa. The bridegroom, 37, is a son of Betty Newman of Evansville, Ind., and the late Alan Newman. He is a graduate of Indiana University.

title: Hawkins's Compelling, Luminous 'New Moon'
description: A New work by Erick Hawkins is not an ordinary event, simply because Mr. Hawkins is not an ordinary choreographer. For decades, he has, with integrity, stood apart from the mainstream of other contemporary dance. It is a choice, one suspects, imposed less by will than by necessity. To see Hawkins choreography is to have the sensation that it could have taken no other form, that any departure from Mr. Hawkins's usual esthetic would be in violation of his philosophical beliefs.

title: Beyond the Soviet Textbook
description: LIKE many other Americans, I have had an interest in world affairs, but never as much as now, after having spent three weeks as a student in a Moscow high school.

title: Marilyn J. Abraham, an Editor, Is Wed
description: Marilyn Jane Abraham and Alexander MacGregor 3d were married yesterday at their home in Mahopac, N.Y., by the Rev. Ann Tyndal, a Unitarian minister.

title: Barry in Baltimore.
description: Irv Levinson and Vi Krichinsky grew up on Appleton Street in southwest Baltimore, where they met more than 50 years ago and, later, were married. Today they're back for the first time in decades, along with Irv's younger brother Herb and a few cousins, and they can hardly believe what they see. Lining Appleton are 1940's vintage Cadillacs, Buicks, Chevrolets and Hudsons. The old street lights with large bulbs and iron filigree are there, too, and the trees have been clipped so they look as they did all those years ago.

title: Campus Life: Washington State;   Policy on Alcohol Is Transformed To Follow Law
description: Turn out the lights, the party's over, or at least that's the way it seems to fraternity members at Washington State University.

title: A Place to Drop In for a Chat, but Not in English
description: CACOPHONY can be beautiful, say members of a new foreign-language club that meets once a month here at Manhattanville College. The club, sponsored by the Cross-Cultural Center of the college, brings together native speakers of various languages with those who want to practice their own foreign-language skills.

title: Shaking Down the TV Thunder
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Capriati Reaches Slims Final
description: So far this week, a 13-year-old ponytailed phenomenon with a pink-handled racquet and a redoubtable backbone has ignored her homework and shredded her opponents. School is being held in abeyance as Jennifer Capriati, already a millionaire and evidently a genius, at least on the tennis court, continues to write her own history.

title: East European Workers Will Need Incentives
description: Many people think that laissez-faire capitalism will be a workable model for the redevelopment of the socialist economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Western advisers have consistently pushed for the creation of markets, free pricing and currency systems and an economy built on private enterprises. But the rush to markets, and the willingness to create economic insecurity, clearly carries with it a substantial risk of political turmoil.

title: Fashion;   In a World of Many Tribes, Shirts for Each
description: Everyone belongs to one tribe or another. Sometimes just for the weekend.

title: Playing Hedda Gabler As an Untamed Beast
description: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW described Hedda Gabler, the title character in Henrik Ibsen's play, as a woman with no ethical ideals, only romantic ones. He said that she had imagination and an intense appetite for beauty, but no conscience, no convictions.

title: Views on Enrollment At Private Schools
description: It is indeed ironic that some of the nation's girls' schools are facing a decline in enrollment just at the time when scholarly research indicates there are many advantages for the young women who choose to attend them.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Field of Dreams
