title: Kirk Varnedoe Is In The Hot Seat As Moma's Boy
description: One of the more curious objects at the Museum of Modern Art in New York sits on a long table in the fifth-floor office of Kirk Varnedoe. It's a square white mat populated by what seem to be high-tech chessmen, or futuristic warriors in a space-age board game. They are, actually, foam-core replicas of the museum's Brancusi sculptures, and they are giving Varnedoe, the museum's new director of painting and sculpture, a tough fight. Armed with a sheaf of architectural drawings, he is trying to figure out a way to shift a little here and shove a little there so that visitors will be able to walk all around the sculptures.

title: Diversions for Children in Bangkok
description: TRAVELING with children, especially small ones, no doubt promotes family unity but on occasion it can also present problems. Take a city like Bangkok, for example - not by reputation nor, from a first glimpse of its perilous traffic, by physical layout an ideal place for juvenile amusement.

title: Concern For the Soul Of the New Germany
description: THERE is a tendency among some thoughtful Germans to lament this winter's developments as a noble revolution gone tawdry. It is as if the purity of that night four months ago when Germans laughed and danced at the newly opened Berlin wall has been defiled by politics, commercialism, nationalism and intrigue.

title: Marry the Enemy, Mend His Socks
description: SOVIET WOMEN

title: What Kind Of Money?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lewis Percy
description: The reader approaching Anita Brookner's novels for the first time may be permitted a certain skepticism. Is she really as good as the critics say? And if so, how can she be so prolific? This convert's answer would be: yes, she is that good, and she keeps producing quality fiction at a calm, even rate precisely because she knows what she is doing.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Tax Credits Spur Low-Income Rentals
description: LEAD: THE supply of rental housing for low-income families - long a depressed segment of the state's residential market - has gradually increased in the last three years, helped by a Federal program that uses housing tax credits as incentives.

title: Robin D. Smith To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Robin Dunn Smith to Charles Howard Swanberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund R. Swanberg of New Canaan, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Smith of Hamden, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley;   Counseling on Religious Groups Encompasses Some Former Members
description: Responding to recruiting by nontraditional religious groups, administrators at the University of California at Berkeley have started a counseling effort.

title: John Hardiman, Lawyer, Is Engaged To Donna Ellen Landau, an Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Loeber Landau of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna Ellen Landau to John Louis Hardiman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Hardiman of Bridgeport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Only Washington Can Solve the Health Care Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Renews Trapping To Thin Beaver Population
description: The beaver, the official mammal of New York, is flourishing so well that it is considered a nuisance in some parts of the state.

title: THE LADY IS A SHRINK
description: LEAD:

title: COURTS ORDERING FINANCING CHANGES IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: A number of sweeping decisions by state courts are forcing legislatures to develop new systems for financing public schools in an attempt to remedy the disparities between rich and poor school districts.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Iron Bars Turn a Victim Into a Prisoner
description: LEAD: AFTER the neighborhood crooks broke into my apartment, or tried to break in, seven times in seven years, I figured that somebody should go behind bars. I preferred that the crooks go. But they wouldn't cooperate. So I took the plunge and put bars on all my windows.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Bethany
description: SITTING on a plateau between the Naugatuck and West Rivers, the 21-square-mile Town of Bethany is the epitome of country Connecticut.Flocks of Canada geese nest in fields bounded by weathered stone fences and deer can often be seen feeding at dawn and dusk.

title: Dr. Kim Gilbert and Laurence Rubin Are to Wed
description: Dr. Kim Lisa Gilbert and Laurence Mark Rubin, a son of Marilyn Rubin of Newton, Mass., and the late William Rubin, plan to marry in August, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stewart E. Gilbert of Floral Park, Queens, have announced.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 25 misidentified a building in East Berlin. It was the Museum of German History, not the German State Opera House. The caption also referred imprecisely to the tower in the background. It is more commonly known as the Fernsehturm (television tower); the tower known as the Funkturm (radio tower) is in West Berlin.

title: Reap What You Sew
description: I have taken over a basement room in which someone who lived here before had left a Ping-Pong table. It is now my sewing room. The table is just the right height for me, and I can spread out the fabric on its expanse of dark green when I cut out things. It's quiet there. I listen to the radio and work away, and a flat piece of cloth takes on shape as I work, grows breast-shaped curves and hips, gathers itself into a waistband, to which I have added an inch because I am fatter than I wish I were.

title: Frederick Evoy Kneip, Executive, 75
description: Frederick Evoy Kneip, a retired executive in the paper products industry, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Lakeland (Fla.) Regional Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Lakeland.

title: 3 Brooklyn Children Die in a Fire
description: Three young children, including a brother and sister, were killed last night in an apartment fire in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, police and fire officials reported.

title: Mandela, Ordered to Rest, Curtails Tanzania Schedule
description: Nelson Mandela, looking frail and tired, cut short his program of engagements in Tanzania today after doctors ordered him to rest, African National Congress officials said.

title: F.B.I. Vows to Punish Disclosure Of Data on Suspension of Agent
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has warned that it will discipline any employee found to have disclosed information about the suspension of an agent in a case said to involve allegations of spying for Cuba.

title: Review/Concert;   Marimba Quartet and Calabash Women
description: The Manhattan Marimba Quartet and Women of the Calabash opened a series called New Riffs at Town Hall on Tuesday night. The idea of combining the two groups seemed odd. The Marimba Quartet performs written works in the European classical tradition, dryly. The Women of the Calabash celebrates the African diaspora with songs and percussion, sentimentally.

title: How to Live With a Worrier
description: FOR the last few years - 29 and counting - my wife has thought I don't worry enough and that, of course, worries her. To my mind there are only a handful of things you really have to be concerned about: enough money for rent and groceries, your health and that of the ones you love, trying not to appear overly dumb in front of your children, and whether the planes you ride stay up long enough.

title:
ART;

A Keeper of the Heroic Flame
description: LEAD: WELDED sculpture did not begin in the United States. The first to work in this medium was probably the Spaniard Julio Gonzalez, who, in art history, usually takes a back seat to Pablo Picasso, to whom he taught iron welding techniques. But welded sculpture took a particular American cast in the hands, or should one say, with the torch, of David Smith, whose heroic pieces make him the equivalent in sculpture of the painter Jackson

title: Commissioner Stresses Freedom for Disabled
description: LEAD: TONI RICHARDSON, the new Commissioner of the State Department of Mental Retardation, was discussing her favorite television commercial. It pictures a strong-looking woman dressed in a karate costume, ready to spring into action. Only at the end of the message does the viewer learn that the woman participates in the Special

title: U.S. Pressed to Pay for Boat People in Hong Kong
description: Britain is pressing the Bush Administration to pay most of the cost of caring for the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people now being housed in its colony of Hong Kong, as well as for building a new refugee camp, possibly on Guam, diplomats and United Nations officials here say.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: There I was, cross-country skiing in Yellowstone Park with my friend Tom Telemark. Bald eagles swooped overhead and bison and elk congregated at steaming thermal pools only yards from the trail. Every hour and a quarter, give or take 10 minutes, Old Faithful gushed forth in the distance.

title: FOR CUNNINGHAM, DANCE IS AS MYSTERIOUS AS IT EVER WAS
description: It has been a year since the Merce Cunningham Dance Company last appeared in New York City. In that time, Mr. Cunningham has toured with his dancers to England, Italy, France and Germany, and from coast to coast in the United States. He has taught class regularly, conducted workshops and choreographed and rehearsed three pieces that will be performed at City Center during a two-week season that opens on Tuesday. Mr. Cunningham has also been performing - and will dance in all but one program at City Center.

title:
DANCE;

Choreographers and Unseen Pressures
description: LEAD: WHEN the Garden State Ballet raises the curtain this weekend at Montclair College, two issues unseen but nevertheless present and related to the artistic development of choreographers will accompany the performance of the three works on the program.

title: What If . . . ? New Movies In Other Hands
description: ''Revenge,'' the slow-paced, emotionally vacant, sensationally decorative film based on Jim Harrison's novella (with a screenplay by Mr. Harrison and Jeffrey Fiskin), had an earlier draft of its script co-written by John Huston and his son Tony. As a matter of fact, ''Revenge'' was at one point something Mr. Huston thought he might direct. According to his biographer Lawrence Grobel, the ailing and magnificently cantankerous Mr. Huston was considering ''Revenge'' in his final days, just after he had completed ''The Dead.'' The producer Ray Stark suggested that he meet with Kevin Costner, who would be the film's star.

title: Mutual Funds;   The Investor's Right to Know
description: Would you have changed your Superbowl bet if you had learned that Joe Montana wasn't going to start for the San Francisco '49ers? Would the German Army have amassed forces at the Normandy beaches had it known that Gen. George Patton was commanding the invasion? Would you like to know that Peter Lynch, the superstar manager in charge of Fidelity's Magellan Fund, was moving to Fund X?

title: The Next Generation of Doctors Is Hopeful;   No Family Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Muller to Wed Richard Crossman
description: Kimberly Anne Muller and Richard Terrance Crossman plan to marry in June. Miss Muller is the daughter of Anne B. Muller of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Leonard A. Muller of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mr. Crossman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Crossman of Riverside, Conn.

title: Review/Music;   Pianist Plays Rarity By Debussy
description: James Barbagallo's thoughtful and elegant choice of music for his Alice Tully Hall piano recital on Thursday night pretty much reflected the thoughtfulness and elegance with which it was addressed. Mr. Barbagallo played four Debussy pieces -including one of the neglected masterpieces of the keyboard literature, ''Hommage a Rameau'' - Schumann's Second Sonata, ''Masks'' by Robert Muczynsky and three pieces by Chopin.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Capital of a New Nation, Right Here
description: LEAD: WITH the American-Canadian trade agreement in hand, it is time for Step 2: Combine the two countries into one nation with the new capital in New Jersey - Franklin Township, Somerset County. But a few points must be settled first. Let me do that systematically.

title: UConn and Syracuse Advance to Final
description: The tendency is for the bright lights to obscure the view of all those winter nights in the past, when the University of Connecticut was regularly representing its conference in the national collegiate basketball tournament. There were many happy nights decades ago, in Storrs and around New England, when the successes within the Yankee Conference bonded fans throughout the state.

title: The Best Ways to Fight Drug and Alcohol Abuse
description: The words are familiar: ''I didn't get up one morning and say, ''I think I'll become a drug addict,' the way someone decides to be a fireman or a doctor. No one wants to become an addict. But once I got sucked up into the drug habit, I didn't know how to stop. I didn't know where to go for help.''

title: Holly Goodsell Plans a June Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles T. Goodsell of Blacksburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Holly Delight Goodsell to Gary Kevin Fechtmeyer, a son of Mrs. Bernard Potof of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Gary P. Fechtmeyer of Minneapolis. A June wedding is planned.

title: Views On Enrollment At Private Schools
description: The informative article ''Enrollment Slips at Many Private Schools'' focused almost exclusively on the marketing-related efforts to deal with this problem.

title: The Executive Computer;   The Font Wars: New Weapons Are Rolled Out
description: Six months after the first major battle of the so-called Font Wars, the smoke is starting to clear. One camp is led by Adobe Inc., which once had a virtual monopoly on outline fonts, the typography that is stored as mathematical formulas rather than as images formed by a collection of dots. The other camp is led by Apple Computer Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: EXCLAMATION POINT FOR BATTERY PARK CITY
description: ''My garden will never make me famous/ I'm a horticultural ignoramus,'' wrote Ogden Nash, but he did not know about the South Garden at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. For this garden was designed by two people who know relatively little about horticulture, the artist Jennifer Bartlett and the architect Alexander Cooper, and it has made both of them quite famous indeed.

title: Heart Transplant, Despite Fog
description: A relay of troopers from two states rushed a heart to a 13-year-old transplant patient Friday after fog forced doctors to land at an airport 50 miles away. Three doctors flying the heart from Tulsa, Okla., to Detroit had to land in Toledo, Ohio.

title: Leslie Glover Is to Marry Mark B. Pendleton in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Thomas Glover of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Glover, to Mark Bruce Pendleton, the son of Bruce Pendleton of Sagamore Hills, Ohio, and Judy Wilson of Jacksonville, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: Romanian Rebel Predicts Slow Progress
description: The clergyman whose defiance helped start the rebellion that toppled Romania's Communist dictatorship in December says he believes that centrist forces can retain enough strength in elections on May 20 to maintain momentum toward democracy.

title: Remembering When Diners Were for More Than Just Eating
description: LEAD: WHEN Christine Guedon and Stephen D. Lintner were teen-agers, they thought of the Oaklyn Diner as just a convenient place to extend a night out with friends, a setting in which they could stretch until the last possible moment their freedom from home and school.

title: The Next Generation of Doctors Is Hopeful
description: To the Editor:

title:
Fashion Preview;

PARIS
description: LEAD: It promises to be a top-heavy season, with an abundance of elegant coats and jackets in all lengths and silhouettes and for all occasions. As in Milan, sporty ideas are being dressed up in a mix of luxurious and colorful fabrics. Karl Lagerfeld calls his collection ''slim but comfortable, not tight but close to the body.

title: Safe Lifting Techniques
description: EVEN an hour of home improvement activities involving lifting can cause a sore back or even an injury that lasts for days or longer. Back muscles are among the body's weakest, and sedentary living causes the backs of many adults to be out of condition.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: The business executive couldn't believe his eyes. His golfing partner had gone off in search of a lost ball and when he followed unexpectedly, there was the man he believed he knew pretty well surreptitiously nudging along the ball with the toe of his shoe.

title: Italy's Communists Agree to a Metamorphosis
description: Ending four days of soul-searching, Italy's troubled Communist Party, the largest in the West, agreed at a meeting here today to transform itself into a new political grouping known for now only as The Thing.

title:
GARDENING;

The American Botanical Tradition
description: LEAD: AMERICANS seem to have an inferiority complex when it comes to gardening. We attempt to emulate anything that is English, whether suited to our climate or not. We feel that we must arrange borders like those at Sissinghurst and that we must mimic the garden designer Gertrude Jeykll's use of color.

title: A Golf Shoe Under Fire
description: Just two days after the United States Golf Association had declared golf shoes worn by John Huston in the PGA Tour Honda Classic to be illegal, the maker of the shoes, the Weight-Rite Golf Corporation of Tampa, Fla., plans to seek judicial relief.

title: Review/Dance;   Stressing the Athletic Side Of Choreographed Moves
description: Elizabeth Streb is one of several choreographers who during the past two decades have based dances upon athletic or gymnastic movement. Whereas some of them make gymnastics seem witty or fantastic, Ms. Streb emphasizes effort for its own sake. At their best, her works resemble vigorous games. At their worst, they are displays of stress and strain.

title: TALKING: Home Sites;   Glowing Guidelines Vs. Reality
description: THE last few years have witnessed a rise in the number of developments offering buyers the opportunity to acquire plots on which they can create their dream houses in compatible settings.

title: Campus Life: Centenary;   Love Is Message As Maya Angeloub Addresses 700
description: Maya Angelou was no stranger to the 700 people who listened to her speech at Centenary College of Louisiana here last week.

title: Alien Students Learn More Education Is the Key
description: It was Rap Day at John Dewey High School last week, and most of the workshops focused on sex and drugs. But in room 343, it was standing room only as students, teachers and professionals discussed the really hot topic of the times - the rights of illegal immigrant children.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Accountable Is Jim Valvano?
description: ''What did he know, and when did he know it?'' This now-famous question should be asked of Jim Valvano. A major college basketball coach sets the tone for his players on the court with the tactics he teaches them. He sets the tone for them off the court by his own behavior. If Jim Valvano was not aware of his players' unlawful activities, he is guilty of incompetence. If he was aware - and did nothing to bring it to light - he is guilty of complicity. Either way, he is personally accountable for his school's problems.

title: Nonprofit Community Groups Rebuild Housing in the Bronx
description: With a sweep of her hand, Charlene Moats traces the cycle of devastation and renewal that has changed the face of her Bronx neighborhood.

title: THE ART OF HISTORY WAS HIS CREDO
description: NOT BY FACT ALONE

title: SATURDAY NIGHT
description: Saturday night is the peak of the weekend - the high point of our precious time off (''Saturday Night,'' by Susan Orlean, Feb. 11). It's no wonder we embrace it as our most celebrated evening of the week.

title: Saving the Most On Europe Fares
description: PAN AMERICAN'S Eurosaver fare from New York to London for travelers leaving May 31 is $535 round trip. For those leaving the next day, it is $704. Much of the difference is in the season: May 31 falls within shoulder season, and June 1 begins the high season (and is a weekend departure).

title: Reward of 'Hoot Night': 20 Minutes of Stardom
description: LEAD: EVERY Wednesday evening between 7:30 and 9, John Couch receives a half-dozen or more telephone calls at the Kent Road Tavern in New Milford. The callers are musicians, singers, magicians and comedians arranging performance times for the evening's talent show at the rustic bar. There is no big stage here or high-voltage sound system.

title: Eric Schlager to Wed Beth M. Cherashore
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Cherashore of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Beth Madeline Cherashore, and Eric Dean Schlager, a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lawrence Schlager of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating. These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement. The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling. Would we be better off adding two-inch rigid insulation boards between the joists or installing it across the joists, or should we try to squeeeze more fiberglass in without a vapor barrier? Also, would we notice much improvement in warmth in the rooms by doing any of this?

title: OLDER CHILDREN AND DIVORCE
description: It seems to me that Barbara S. Cain's article ''Older Children and Divorce'' (Feb. 18) does not add anything new to that tired subject. We all know that everyone suffers in a divorce. However, everyone suffers growing up. The young people mentioned in your article might have had different problems in nondivorcing families, but problems they would have had.

title: Notes From the Revolution
description: The final days of 1989 brought with them the end of the Communist era. The system that had proclaimed itself the future of the world was buried in the ashes of burning Romanian towns. No doubt there will still be police and military relapses, no doubt various epigones of Communism will still tantalize with their baubles and sow dissension with their calumnies. But the idea has died. For Communism, it is the end. At last.

title: Other Pieces Of the Portrait
description: To the Editor:

title: Dreary Repositories
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping Center Within Industrial Park Upsets Merchants
description: LEAD: A STRIP shopping center will be erected in the most unlikely of places: within the 1,500-acre Hauppauge Industrial Park.

title: Shiite Leader Said to Back Moves to Free Hostages
description: A key Lebanese Shiite Muslim leader said in remarks published today that he was ''encouraging elements'' that may lead to the release of Westerners taken hostage in Lebanon.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating. These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement. The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling. Would we be better off adding two-inch rigid insulation boards between the joists or installing it across the joists, or should we try to squeeze more fiberglass in without a vapor barrier? Also, would we notice much improvement in warmth in the rooms by doing any of this?

title: Frances Stewart To Marry in April
description: The engagement of Frances Danise Stewart to Frederic Sanborn Waugh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Waugh of Southport, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Frances D. Edge of Chester, Ga., and Daniel P. Stewart of Forsyth, Ga. An April wedding is planned.

title: The Politics of Pornography
description: To the Editor:

title: Ingrid Von Lepal To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gottfried Kleiber of Sands Point, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for Mrs. Kleiber's daughter Ingrid Maria Elizabeth von Lepel and Charles McNulty, the son of Rosemary McNulty of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Charles H. McNulty.

title: SATURDAY NIGHT
description: You didn't mention the way in which many residents of New York City spend Saturday night. For many of us, it is a time to stay away from the nightspots and the crowds that crowd in from suburbia. It is a time to avoid the touring automobiles and roaming band of visitors. During the week, the noise of the city has a certain rhythm, a sense of purpose that is somehow absent from the weekend ruckus. Let's celebrate the joys of taking in a movie on Thursday night or a stroll after work on a sunny Wednesday evening; it's not that Saturday night in New York has lost its glow, but that we can find wonder any night of the week.

title:
ART;

Expressively Blending Metaphors
description: LEAD: PATON MILLER is a daring painter who tries to achieve an impact by testing his imagination and ours by blending metaphorical subjects with a powerfully expressive way of handling paint. Original, dramatic effects make him one of the major young talents working year-round on the South Fork.

title: Infiniti Drops Its More Sexy Shoe
description: This is the other shoe dropping. Two weeks ago, we talked here about the Infiniti Q45 sedan, Nissan's $38,000 would-be resident of the lux-lux neighborhood. But there is also a second Infiniti, very different and considerably less expensive, albeit equally high-falutin.

title: World Markets;   The Pitfalls of Closed-End Funds
description: First, the good news.

title: American Voices: Doubts As the Cold War Ends - A Special Report:   In U.S, Unease as World Changes
description: For Americans everywhere, the news from abroad in recent months has been both dazzling and disorienting.

title: Evening Hours;   Masked Ball 'In the Court Of the Sultan'
description: Guests arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria on Monday night in variations of dress suggesting a masked ball at a sultan's court. This year's Purim Ball, the Jewish Museum's annual fund-raising gala, had an Ottoman theme to herald the museum's spring exhibition, ''In the Court of the Sultan: Sephardi Jews of the Ottoman Empire.''

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday under the headline ''National Output'' gave an incorrect value for the gross national products of several countries. The numbers represented trillions of dollars, not billions.

title: Pamela Bernard Is to Marry in June; Her Sister, Jacqueline, Will Wed in '91
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Bernard of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Pamela Jill Bernard to Dr. Richard Scott Shames and of their daughter Jacqueline Lee Bernard to Mark Scott Rosenbaum.

title: Variation On a Theme: The Movie Musical
description: ''THE Great American Backstage Musical'' begins in 1939 and ends in 1945 in Johnny's Bar, where having a fancy drink means putting olives in your beer.

title: MEET YOU AT THE MUD RACE
description: ROOTIE KAZOOTIE

title: Groups Unite to Fight Airplane Noise
description: INCENSED by what they say is an intolerable level of jet noise over their homes, New Jersey residents in dozens of communities have banded together to draw the attention of politicians and government officials to the problem.

title: Corrections
description: A quotation in the front-page index last Sunday was misattributed. It was the interviewer - not Yuri A. Prokofiev, the Moscow Communist Party chief - who noted that for Soviet politicians, ''to be a Communist is a minus, and to be a Communist Party functionary is a huge minus.''

title: Advocates' Tactics on AIDS Issues Provoking Warnings of a Backlash
description: SOONER or later, anyone whose work involves issues related to AIDS could encounter the militant tactics of the group called Act-Up. For some scientists and Federal officials, it happened last August at a public meeting of the Food and Drug Administration in Washington.

title: Vick Kenyon Wed To Glen D. Caruso
description: The marriage of Virginia Caroline Kenyon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Kenyon of Los Angeles, to Glen Damien Caruso, a son of June Caruso of Elmhurst, Queens, and Michael Caruso of Las Vegas, Nev., took place yesterday at the chapel of Duke University in Durham, N.C. The Rev. William H. Russell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Cheers and Boos as Chilean Leader Says Goodbye
description: To supporters' cheers and opponents' cries of ''murderer,'' Gen. Augusto Pinochet ended his last full day in power today with a call for national unity behind his elected successor.

title: INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: Lodgings Grand and Simple;   A Group of French Hotels That Take a Vow of Silence
description: ''SILENCE of everybody secures the rest of all. Thank you not to forget it.'' So reads the English version of the rather stern French and German admonitions posted in the hallways of Le Chalet, a charming country inn four miles from Moulins, a market town of 25,000 in the Auvergne region.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: HAMDEN;

Food Sellers Heeding a New Takeout Order: Hold the Plastic
description: LEAD: JOYCE MARTINEAU says she is a reluctant pioneer. As the owner of Brooklyn Bagels in Hamden, she must comply with the town's new ban on the use of some plastic products, the first such regulation in the state.

title: Magical Evening Ends a Little Dimly
description: TThe omens seemed right tonight for the Islanders to end their dual streaks of 5 consecutive defeats and 11 games without a victory.

title: Angry at U.S. Rebuff, Jerusalem Tries to Show How Well It Treats Arabs
description: As he set out on a drive through East Jerusalem Friday afternoon, trying to demonstrate despite Washington's suggestion to the contrary that the Arab half of the city is an inseparable part of the Israeli capital, Mayor Teddy Kollek could hardly restrain his anger.

title: 'Mr. Clean' Takes on the Garbage Mess
description: As the first director of the Environmental Protection Agency in the early 1970's, William D. Ruckelshaus won praise for standing up to industry on a range of pollution issues. In 1983, he returned to the E.P.A. and restored public trust in the agency, which had become mired in corruption under Anne Gorsuch Burford. For his achievements, the media crowned him ''Mr. Clean.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington;

A Tower As Transition
description: LEAD: A NEARLY completed 68,000-square-foot office and retail building near Washington Circle, about a mile west of the White House, uses design elements of a row of historic town-house facades in a reflective black glass tower.

title: Correction
description: Two photographs with the Architecture View in the Arts and Leisure section on Feb. 25 were not credited. The photographs, which depicted drawings by Louis Kahn at the Yale University Art Gallery, should have been credited to the Louis I. Kahn Collection, University of Pennsylvania and Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission.

title: Gathers Policy Void
description: Hank Gathers had a $1 million insurance policy that he might have been able to collect on when his heart problem was first diagnosed, but it covered him only for disability, not death. The late Loyola Marymount basketball star bought the policy from Lloyd's of London last May, obtaining a bank loan to pay the $6,600 premium, said Mike Petersen, vice president of Petersen Marketing and Management Corporation, the Los Angeles representative for Lloyd's.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating. These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement. The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling. Would we be better off adding two-inch rigid insulation boards between the joists or installing it across the joists, or should we try to squeeeze more fiberglass in without a vapor barrier? Also, would we notice much improvement in warmth in the rooms by doing any of this?

title: Richards's Rivals: You Don't Say?
description: ANOTHER thing a faint heart never won is a Texas election. Ann Richards, who until recently was regarded as a shoo-in to win the Democratic gubernatorial nomination this week, has lately been losing ground in a rough-and-tumble campaign that has focused on two issues - the death penalty and drugs - and has left no room for subtleties of position on either.

title: Tomczak Aids Fund
description: Mike Tomczak, the Chicago Bears quarterback from Ohio State, has started an endowment to pay for a grant-in-aid for an Ohio State quarterback. He will contribute $100,000 over the next five years to provide the fund a $7,500 annual scholarship. . . . Dale Ellis of the Seattle SuperSonics, who suffered three broken ribs in an automobile accident on Jan. 12, was activated Friday. . . . The California Angels renewed the contracts of two pitchers, Jim Abbott and Mike Fetters, on Friday. Abbott, 22, was 12-12 with a 3.92 earned run average in his rookie season. Fetters, 25 years old, was 12-8 in 26 games for Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League and led the P.C.L. with 144 strikeouts.(AP)

title: Writers on Rolls
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Gene Therapy Moves A Step Closer to Reality
description: WITH an anatomy consisting of no more than a glob of genetic material wrapped in a protective coat of protein, viruses exist on the boundary between the living and the dead. Under a plan announced last week, these borderline creatures would be used as messengers to smuggle missing genes into the cells of children otherwise doomed by a devastating congenital disorder.

title:
ART;

Personal Mythology As a Common Bond
description: LEAD: IN selecting the eight artists to participate in the current exhibition at the Wunsch Arts Center's Sabbeth Art Gallery, Shirley Samberg was not looking for a group with stylistic or thematic affinities. As the show's guest curator, Ms. Samberg, who is an artist herself, chose colleagues whose only common bond is their expression of ''highly personal mythology.

title: A New London Theater Team Is Attracting Stars
description: In the rapidly gentrifying area of north London known as Islington, age-old pubs with names like the Slug and Lettuce vie for patronage with newly glamorized restaurants. Drunks inhabit the main thoroughfare, Upper Street, buttonholing for money the recently arrived yuppies, who are drawn to the area because of its proximity to London's financial center, the City. Posters exhort citizens in the left-wing district to boycott the Government's imminent ''poll tax,'' and the one movie house, the Screen on the Green, shows ''Born on the Fourth of July.''

title: Museum Takes Its Shows on the Road
description: LEAD: THE Bruce Museum's popular program on coastal ecology gives youngsters the chance to work with live animals and plants. The children discover how these organisms find food, avoid predators, withstand the waves and adapt for survival in an ever-changing environment.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Sports Section on Feb. 25 about the experiences of black players in the National Hockey League incorrectly described the professional level at which an incident involving Willie O'Ree, the first black player in the N.H.L., took place. The incident, in which O'Ree said he became entangled with a group of fans who made racial remarks and grabbed at his jersey, occurred when O'Ree was playing for the Quebec Aces in the minor leagues, not in the N.H.L. or at Madison Square Garden.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Accountable Is Jim Valvano?
description: If Coach Valvano had spent more time admiring the blue Carolina sky with his players instead of chasing the green American dollar, he would have developed a more solid and trustworthy relationship with his young men.

title: Lisa Kizilay Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Dogan Kizilay of South Orange, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Ayse Kizilay and Ralph Gilbert Mallory 3d, a son of Marjorie Garvey of Natick, Mass., and Mr. Mallory Jr. of Belmont, Mass. Miss Kizilay, an Allegheny College graduate, is the executive assistant to the director of the reproductive endocrinology and fertility division at the Medical Center of George Washington University, where Mr. Mallory is a senior.

title: MAJOR HUMAN DRAMA IN THE KITCHEN

title: FICTION
description: THE SUN IN CAPRICORN. By Paul Rosenblatt. (Watermark Press, 149 North Broadway, Wichita, Kan. 67202, $18.50.) Jonathan, a much beloved American who teaches literature and poetry in Rio de Janeiro, has been set up. A guerrilla named Verlande has tricked him into a compromising situation and the innocent academic has become ''a temporary liability'' who must be sent stateside. Eventually, Jonathan will depart as ordered, but before then he'll endure a rush of death squads, psychic rambling, political machinations and renewed love, all washed down by prodigious amounts of alcohol. Jonathan, aside from being a borderline drunk, is also something of a mystic, and so he is perfectly at home in Brazil, a surreal country where ''two parallel streets meet'' - although to Arthur, a hard-nosed diplomat, Jonathan is ''in the wrong time'' and doesn't realize that what's real ''can't be wiped away by dreams and by the imagination.'' Because he doesn't know this, Jonathan is delighted to enter a bizarre universe of plot and counterplot in which revolutionaries are closet Jesuits, while beggars turn into Nazi-hunting philosophers. In the course of their last days in Brazil, the scholar discovers himself; his wife, Carol, rediscovers sex; and readers find themselves weaving through a sometimes impenetrable jungle of metaphor and symbol. An unfinished cathedral; Jonathan's unbuilt dream of a literature center (his ''White Dove''); a ''mulata princess''; Roberto, the professor's double; even Burt Lancaster and Sir Thomas Browne come to represent different shades of the story's meaning. All this imagery is fine, if laid on a bit too thick, since a tangled plot sometimes needs a tangled telling. But the occasional overwriting (''I walk on the borrowings of the sun'') does give pause, for it detracts from an otherwise fine and engaging novel.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Holly Charms for Many Seasons
description: LEAD: Hollies are usually thought of as broadleaved evergreens with spiny leaves, yet there are three deciduous hollies known for their berry displays. These hollies can also tolerate slightly harsher winter conditions.

title: Music in Which Words Need Only Sound Poetic
description: Empty-headed pop music usually comes in the form of sleek, high-tech disco or pounding, three-chord rock. But the Church, an Australian quartet that has just released its seventh album, ''Gold Afternoon Fix'' (Arista AL-8579; all three formats) makes lightweight pop of a different sort. Instead of disco's synthetic tracks and drum machines, or commercial rock's tired riffs and cliched baby-I-love-you lyrics, the Church combines 12-string guitar, bass and drums with dreamy images to make an elegant surface of sound. It is, like stained-glass windows, intricate, beautiful to behold and wholly without depth.

title: U.S. Appears to Be Losing Control of Nicaragua Rebels
description: At a time when the intentions of the contras are crucial to Nicaragua's newly elected government, the Bush Administration finds it has less and less sway over the rebel force that Washington created and sustained for nearly a decade, Administration officials say.

It was only 12 weeks ago that U.S. troops invaded Panama, in the largest military operation since the Vietnam War. President Bush's political stock soared when the assault brought the capture and removal to Miami of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's fallen strongman.

title: No Need to Cry Over the Hue With This TV Set
description: Some video manufacturers hesitate to bring technically advanced and correspondingly costly products to the United States. Market research tells them that - unlike in Japan, Germany, Switzerland and Scandinavia, where there is widespread interest in technology - only 4 to 5 percent of American video buyers appreciate advanced engineering enough to pay a higher price. Retailers oriented toward mass merchandising are aware of this and do not want high-priced goods in their stores. This limits available outlets for high-quality equipment to a relatively small number of specialty stores.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: In Boris Spassky's contract for the Linares International Tournament, which began Feb. 18 in Spain, one clause read that he must, ''not make any compromises before move 40.'' The tournament sponsor, Luis Rentero, did not want the former world champion to show up in body but not in spirit, aiming for quick draws, as he so often does.

title: Currency;   The Pound Takes Another Beating
description: It is down, down, down for the British pound, which has fallen more than nine cents, to $1.6160, in the last two weeks. The Bank of England was in the foreign exchange market Friday buying the sagging sterling, which until several weeks ago had been one of the surprise strong currencies of the year. And the central bank may have to intervene again this week if the downward slide continues. The fortunes of the pound have turned sour on fears of inflation, higher interest rates and growing doubts about the performance and staying power of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. And the malaise has spread to the London stock market, which has managed to be volatile without gaining any ground.

The Red Sox did not disclose financial terms, but Burks reportedly signed a one-year contract for $475,000 guaranteed, plus incentives based on games and plate appearances worth an additional $75,000. Reed's contract was renewed for one year at about $300,000.

title: Don't Call Us . . .
description: White House Suspicions may have begun to percolate when someone noticed that the number supposedly left by the President of Iran had a Cleveland area code or some such. But what the heck, President Bush has often said he would talk to ''anyone, anytime'' about freeing American hostages in the Middle East. And, sure enough, the caller could have been almost anyone, for it certainly was not Hashemi Rafsanjani. The hoax call, placed sometime last month, was confirmed by the White House last week after CBS News broke the story. President Bush spoke briefly to someone claiming to be Mr. Rafsanjani and reiterated American policy on hostages that ''good will will beget good will.'' Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, insisted that the incident showed the President's willingness to extend himself. The Iranians snickered. In Teheran, Mr. Rafsanjani said, ''Iran is so important that the biggest bully on earth tries to contact its officials by telephone.''

title: Are Some Remakes Much, Much More Than Meets the Eye?
description: Like an oyster, an artist may be goaded by the chance presence of a tiny grain of creative sand into forming an unexpected pearl. The power of the homely grain may by mysterious even to the artist. ''For half a year,'' Ingmar Bergman once said, discussing his film ''Cries and Whispers,'' ''I . . . just had a picture inside about three women walking around in a red room in white clothes and I didn't know why. I couldn't understand these damned women - I tried to throw it away, I tried to write it down, I tried to find out what they said to each other, because they whispered. And suddenly it came out that they were watching another woman who was dying in the next room, and then it started.''

title: Keeping Track of the Sound's Polluters
description: THE effort to save Long Island Sound demands more aggressive action by state and Federal environmental agencies as well as a commitment by industries to obey clean-water laws, says a study by the Connecticut Public Interest Research Group. The study, called the Campaign to Save Long Island Sound, found that 84 percent of Connecticut companies with permits to dump waste into state waterways violated the environmental laws, said James Leahy, the organization's executive director.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 11, 1990
Review/Dance;   Cremins and Wyoming And an Overwhelming Hall
description: Some theatrical spaces enhance choreography. Others serve as purely neutral containers for it. Still others seem absolutely hostile to any form of dancing that might take place in them. One space of the last type is surely the Great Hall at Cooper Union, where on Thursday night Patricia Cremins and Wyoming, her New York-based company, presented ''Landing With and Without the Map.''

title:
GARDENING;

The American Botanical Tradition
description: LEAD: AMERICANS seem to have an inferiority complex when it comes to gardening. We attempt to emulate anything that is English, whether suited to our climate or not. We feel that we must arrange borders like those at Sissinghurst and that we must mimic the garden designer Gertrude Jeykll's use of color.

title: REFORM MOVEMENT GROWS IN MONGOLIA
description: The revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe appear to have swept eastward into Asia, with the Communist leadership in the remote nation of Mongolia preparing for a meeting on Monday that may lead to the ouster of its Politburo.

title: Staten Island Is Voting, but It's Only a Sitcom Secession
description: THIS November, Staten Island voters are supposed to go to the polls to decide whether their borough should takes steps to secede from the rest of New York City. The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, does not want the vote to take place. Nor does the Mayor of New York City, David N. Dinkins. Nor, it seems, do most state legislators from New York City, who were responsible for scheduling the vote in the first place. Moreover, it is extremely unlikely, no matter what Staten Island voters want, that the borough will ever separate from New York City. So why is the vote taking place? The answer is a lesson in the twisted logic that sometimes prevails in the State Capitol. It is an example of calculation and miscalculation more worthy of a bedroom farce than a text on good government. ''What we have here,'' Mr. Molinari said recently, ''is an extremely emotional issue that has been turned into a gigantic political hoax.''

title: Silent Enmity
description: During the eight years of the bitter Iran-Iraq War, no place was harder hit than Basra, Iraq's chief port and second-largest city, which, owing to casualties and citizens fleeing the siege, saw its population, once more than a million, diminish by half. Located on the Shatt al Arab waterway, Iraq's only access to the Persian Gulf, Basra was the site of three major battles, including its successful defense against Karbala, the two-month artillery and infantry offensive launched by Iran in December 1986 that is now seen as the turning point in the war.

title: All About/Accountants;   Rivalries, Responsibilities and Some New Risks
description: Forget about accountants being a mild-mannered bunch of milquetoasts. When it comes to competing for clients, they are actually some of the most ruthless predators known to humankind. As Barry R. Wallach, a tax expert with Arthur Andersen & Company, boasted, ''I kind of view nonclients as clients being held in trust for us by the competition until we get there.''

title: EX-LEADERS OF U.S. AND JAPAN TO MEET
description: Concerned about tensions between the United States and Japan, a group of former officials of both nations was reported today to be planning a conference on mutual problems that is to be attended by several former American Presidents and Japanese Prime Ministers.

title: Comparing Prices at Duty-Free Shops
description: WANDERING through duty-free shops to try on sleek Ebel watches, inhale seductive fragrances or admire the frosted curves of Lalique crystal has become as much a part of the itinerary for many travelers as lolling on pristine beaches or visiting landmark museums and temples.

title: THE LONG SHADOW OF AMBITION
description: MEANS OF ASCENT

title: Heightened Risk of Job Loss Is Seen in Greyhound Strike
description: With their week-old strike against Greyhound Bus Lines showing that it may be a long and bitter struggle, officials of the Amalgamated Transit Union insist that more than 7,000 union employees will be rehired no matter how the strike ends.

title: INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: The Taste of Three Cities;   Savoring Tuscan Staples In the Restaurants of Siena
description: ALMOST everyone who goes to Italy feels drawn to Siena's curving medieval streets, that perfect fan-shaped piazza, the glittering paintings with almond-eyed madonnas, and the exotic striped cathedral. No one goes there to eat. Of all the Tuscan towns, Siena has the worst reputation for restaurants. One guidebook advises avoiding restaurants altogether; just buy some cold cuts, it says, and head out of town for a picnic. Other guides are similarly unenthusiastic. But then most of the travel books we get are not written by Italians. They're written by Americans or by the French, often by writers whose taste buds have been dazzled by improvising American chefs' urbane variations on the rustic food of Tuscany. Forget the guidebooks here; how could food not be excellent in the green heart of Tuscany?

title: Co-op Crash: Just Fine With Me
description: In the 80's, we were asked to feel sorry for the homeless. In the 90's, we are asked to feel sorry for the people who share much of the blame for putting the homeless on the street. I have in mind those who, through frenzied real-estate speculation, have sent the value of New York City apartments soaring and who are only now beginning to pay fair property taxes based on those outrageous levels.

title:
FORUM;

Unions Should Stick to the Basics
description: LEAD: The corporate landscape of the 1980's has presented union leaders with major challenges. Unions have responded variously. Some have stuck with essentially traditional positions as they struggle to secure their members' rights and interests. Other labor organizations have ventured into new areas, daring even to become ''players'' in the financial markets.

title: Children Find a Human Head And Man Finds Legs Nearby
description: Three children playing on a Bronx street yesterday made a grisly find: a round object wrapped in a cloth that turned out to be a human head, the police said. The father of one of the children then found a plastic bag in a box nearby containing two legs.

title: Yet Another Golden Age In Dutch Painting
description: Exhibitions, like plays and films, are rarely without their headliners and supporting players. And in the case of ''The Golden Age of Dutch Manuscript Painting,'' at the Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan through May 6, top billing goes, hands down, to the tiny paintings in a Book of Hours from the middle of the 15th century that belonged to Catherine of Cleves.

title: FICTION
description: ECONOMIES OF THE HEART. By Christopher Zenowich. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The 10 stories collected in ''Economies of the Heart'' document a poor boy's introduction to the brutish world of manual labor, a world he chooses to enter so he'll make enough money to escape to college. Christopher Zenowich's protagonist is Bob Bodewicz, a younger version of the hero of Mr. Zenowich's recent novel, ''The Cost of Living.'' In the first two stories, which tell of abortive attempts to make money by raising chinchillas and reopening an old nickel mine, Bob learns that schemes will not suffice. The subsequent stories recount Bob's real jobs, first cleaning up a rat-infested factory and then toiling on his cousin's farm. The most inspired story is ''Field Work,'' in which Bob's near-Sisyphean task is to clear a seven-acre field whose stones have risen to the surface, as they do every few years. But while Mr. Zenowich is adept at evoking the spirit as well as the mechanics of hard physical labor, his portrayal of people is less than convincing. Even Bob, who is depicted almost exclusively at work, remains thinly drawn. The problem is partially a function of the book's form: the discrete stories inhibit the development of character, which might not be the case in a novel. The stories do not always add new dimensions, and at times the author repeats himself unnecessarily. The stories - selected snapshots of Bob's life - consider only the worst labors he must endure, such as picking out the stones and spreading manure in the fields. A bountiful harvest, however, is never reaped.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Spring Training for Beach Lovers at Coney Island
description: The Coney Island of dreams and memories - the magical seaside Brooklyn playground of wondrous amusements and rides - is still a part of New York.

title: Correction

The New Kids on the Block, five young white men from Boston who sing and play black pop, are taking their time hitting the stage. John Russell Wright, the group's black M.C., comes out on the cold January night to warm up the crowd, many of whose members were among the audience at a sold-out show just a week earlier in the same auditorium.

title: Maryland Requests Early Appeal Hearing
description: The University of Maryland has filed a letter of appeal with the National Collegiate Athletic Association, requesting that the appeal of sanctions levied against its men's basketball program be heard in April rather than in August.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: It would be reasonable to suppose that a player who is struggling in a difficult contract would always feel grateful when the defense errs and gives him an easy road home. But there can be rare exceptions for those more concerned with esthetics than results. Consider the diagramed deal played Feb. 25 in a Swiss Team event in Allendale, N.J.

title: Quality Control for Health Care
description: A painful back injury recently sent me to top medical specialists in Washington and New York. One doctor rated the injury an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10 and recommended immediate surgery. The other rated it a 2 and suggested plenty of rest and physical therapy. I opted for the latter and am in fine physical shape today.

title: Lithuanian Parliament Meets on Independence
description: A hastily called session of the nationalist-dominated Lithuanian Parliament appears virtually certain to proclaim the republic's independence amid a raging debate with Moscow over compensation.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Work Your Magic, O Tax Wizard
description: LEAD: THE heavy wooden door signals that this is the office of a man of importance. A cast-iron knocker announces my arrival. Carrying the necessary offerings: W-2 forms, 1040, records of child-care expenses. I wait dutifully, a penitent on the doorstep of a wizard.

title: Roberta Soble and Eric Dochter to Marry in May
description: May wedding plans for Roberta Pam Soble and Eric M. Dochter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Dochter of East Hills, L.I., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen I. Soble of Lido Beach, L.I.

title: PACE CARS PULLED FROM NEW JERSEY
description: The new Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police has abandoned the idea of using pace cars to try to slow down motorists.

title:
GARDENING;

The American Botanical Tradition
description: LEAD: AMERICANS seem to have an inferiority complex when it comes to gardening. We attempt to emulate anything that is English, whether suited to our climate or not. We feel that we must arrange borders like those at Sissinghurst and that we must mimic the garden designer Gertrude Jeykll's use of color.

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: COMPANIES

title: Unseating the Electrical Utilities' Monopoly
description: Electric utilities have flourished in the United States during the last half-century by virtue of being monopolies. But those monopolies are giving way to a new order as a growing number of small, independent power producers, and now joint ventures with the utilities themselves, enter the industry.

title: Master of Visual Jokes, Memorable Characters
description: Quirky is the word people like to apply to the Scottish-born director Bill Forsyth.

title: Military's Power Over South Africa: The Lid Is Off
description: SINCE F. W. de Klerk became President of South Africa six months ago, he has taken bold steps to turn away from the dead end of apartheid. While he has been most visible in laying the groundwork for negotiations with the country's black majority, he has also been working in the mine field of white politics.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating. These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement. The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling. Would we be better off adding two-inch rigid insulation boards between the joists or installing it across the joists, or should we try to squeeeze more fiberglass in without a vapor barrier? Also, would we notice much improvement in warmth in the rooms by doing any of this?

title: Water What?
description: Congressional Republicans did everything but tie yellow ribbons around the Capitol pillars last week in welcoming Richard M. Nixon back to Washington. The former President drew cheers from House Republicans who gathered to hear him deliver a lecture on foreign affairs. Then there were photo opportunities, a news conference and good cheer all around. Senator Bob Dole said he considered Mr. Nixon ''rehabilitated,'' but few were gauche enough to mention the ''W'' word or otherwise dredge up the reasons for Mr. Nixon's status as a one-and-a-half-term President. Instead Republican Congressional leaders, along with young aides who could barely remember Mr. Nixon's resignation in 1974, praised the former President's acumen in world affairs. Mr. Nixon reportedly turned a cautious eye toward the decline of Communism, calling it ''a change of the head and not of the heart,'' but went on to describe Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a ''brilliant practical politician.''

INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: Lodgings Grand and Simple;

Beds With Breakfast In England And Ireland
description: LEAD: IT had been a long but pleasant day of hiking on the sheep meadows of Cleeve Hill above Cheltenham Spa in Gloucester, England.

title: Gourmet Shops For Flavors of Spain
description: TO the stellar company of Peck's in Milan, Fauchon in Paris, Harrods Food Hall in London and Dallmayr in Munich, add Mallorca - the fine food shop that has been a fixture in Madrid for close to 60 years.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Where Are We? Lost and Found
description: LEAD: REMEMBER the famous Myron Cohen punch line, ''Everybody's got to be someplace''? Wasn't it the answer the wife's unlucky boyfriend, hiding in the closet, gave the husband's understandable curiosity?

title: U.S. Drafting Catch Limits As Sharks Grow Scarce
description: LEAD: THE shark - feared by bathers, prized by sport fishermen, exploited by Hollywood, and once plentiful in Long Island waters - will come under the protection of the Federal Government this spring in an effort to prevent certain species from being depleted by overfishing.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Top of the Morning
description: Tea and toast are usually all I can take for breakfast in the comfort of home, when what I really want is an excuse to put off going to work.

title: Coleman Carter Walker, Banker, 88
description: Coleman Carter Walker, a former vice president of Bankers Trust Company, died on Friday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: Reviews/Music;   Tenor From South Africa Makes Met Opera Debut
description: Deon van der Walt, a South African tenor, made an auspicious Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday night as Belmonte in Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail.'' Mr. van der Walt has sung the same role at the Salzburg Festival (a widely circulated televised production), the Royal Opera in London, the Bavarian State Opera in Munich and other prestigious theaters, and on Thursday one could hear and see why.

title: Outdoors;   Coping in the Coldest Climes
description: If you are a wanderer of the winter woods - whether skiing, snowshoeing, camping or hunting -with an inquisitive mind, ''Winter -an Ecological Handbook'' by James C. Halfpenny and Roy Douglas Ozanne (Johnson Books, 275 pages, paperback, $16.95) will add zest to your excursions.

title: On Encouraging A Healthy Life Style
description: In response to Robert Figlerski's essay, ''Encouraging a Healthy Life Style,'' R. S. McCord recommends ''eliminating the medical fringe.'' This response is simplistic and naive. The health care system in this country is both complex and complicated.

title: The Sound of Steel on Steel, the Flash of Metal, the Score
description: FENCING, says a student of the sport, combines cunning and speed with ''cloaked aggressiveness.'' Like chess, swordplay requires a strategy: like tennis or boxing, it demands both physical prowess and mental agility.

title: Bakker's Former House Burns
description: A fire Friday morning destroyed the sprawling lakeside house where Jim Bakker, the former television evangelist, once lived. Officials searched the ruins, but no one was found, and the police said neighbors had told them no one had been there recently.

title: Campus Life: Haverford;   New Policy Lets Students Regulate Campus Drinking
description: While most American universities are making control of on-campus drinking the concern of administrators, Haverford College has ratified a policy that puts responsible drinking in students' hands.

title: A Question About 'Glory'
description: To the Editor:

title: 110 Hospitalized in Houston After Leak of Mysterious Gas
description: A mysterious gas leak sent 110 people to hospitals Friday after they complained of nausea and vomiting, officials said.

title: Sports of The Times;   Antonio Gaudi Is Ready for the 1992 Games
description: Every set of Olympic Games has its dominant figure. In Rome in 1960 it was a boxer named Cassius Clay. In Montreal in 1976 it was a gymnast named Nadia Comaneci. In Seoul in 1988 it was a runner named Ben Johnson skulking out of town.

title: Cocaine Use Is Found By Motorman in Crash
description: A motorman on the Philadelphia subway train that crashed Wednesday, killing 3 people and injuring 94, has been suspended because he had used cocaine the day of the accident, a transit agency spokesman said today.

title: On Language;   Virile Women Target Tobacco Men
description: My heart goes out to the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. Taken over in a leveraged buyout; junk bonds sinking; publicly blasted into dropping its plan to make a pitch to sell its products to blacks. Nobody seems willing to walk a few steps, much less a mile, for a Camel.

title: CONFERENCE TOURNAMENTS
description: METRO

title: CORRECTION
description: The ''All About'' column on Feb. 25, discussing modems, misidentified a company listed among those dominant in that market. It is Multi-Tech Systems Inc. of Mounds View, Minn., not the Acer America Corporation. The article also referred incorrectly to the Telebit Corporation. It was one of the first makers of cellular telephone modems, not the first.

title: In Chile, a Stillborn Democracy?
description: LEAD: Last December, Patricio Aylwin was elected to the presidency in Chile in that country's first ballot in nearly 20 years. Unfortunately, his inauguration today does not magically transform the nation into a democracy. As with exiting dictatorships worldwide, the military is reluctant to yield power.

title: Nga Tran Engaged to Peter Manbeck
description: Mr. and Mrs. Tinh N. Tran of San Diego have announced the engagement of their daughter Nga Thi-Tuyet Tran and Peter Charles Manbeck, the son of Harry F. Manbeck Jr. of McLean, Va., and the late Lois L. Manbeck. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Airport's Neighbors Fight for Trees and Quiet
description: TO Louise Caputo, when the wind is just right, blowing in from the north, the noises fly through the sky like an airborne invasion.

title: Alan G. Bozian Weds Alison Overseth
description: Alison Overseth and Alan George Bozian were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Bruce W. Forbes. The bride is a daughter of Anneke deBruyn Overseth of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Oliver Enoch Overseth Jr. of Ann Arbor and Geneva. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bozian of Chatham, N.J.

title: British Journalist Given Death Sentence in Iraq
description: A correspondent for a British newspaper has been sentenced to death in Iraq after being convicted of espionage, and a British nurse has been sentenced to 15 years in prison on charges of helping him, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday about elections in the Soviet Union gave an incorrect figure for the population of the Russian republic. It is 147,386,000.

title: Academic Repeaters
description: Among the GTE Academic all-America men's basketball players named Friday were Alex Kessler of the University of Georgia and Philip Hutcheson of David Lipscomb College, both repeat first-team selections in the university and college divisions.

title: Vincent and Fehr Said To Hold Private Talks
description: The principals in baseball's labor dispute remained quiet yesterday but not inactive.

title: Jacqueline Ryan Marries Michael Gordon Zapson
description: Jacqueline Diane Ryan, a manager of customer service and marketing at Citibank in Long Island City, Queens, was married last evening to Michael Gordon Zapson, the vice president of the City Council of Long Beach, L.I., at the Metropolitan restaurant in Glen Cove, L.I. Judge Jerome B. Fleischman of Long Beach City Court officiated.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: The value of paper money is just a chimera unless you can convince someone of its worth. Today our conviction in the value of United States dollars is so high so that we accept them without a second thought although the bills are only redeemable in other bills or coins made of nearly worthless alloy.

title: 'Holding the Line'
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Basketball

title: Corrections
description: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on Feb. 25 included an outdated entry under the heading ''Restricted Fare.'' The $298 round-trip fare offered by T.W.A. between New York and Paris expired on Feb. 15.

title: Yonkers Man to Lead St. Patrick's Day Parade
description: LEAD: WHEN the St. Patrick's Day parade makes its way up Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Saturday, a Yonkers man will be out front, stepping to the wail of the bagpipes and the beat of the drums, leading the 125,000 marchers.

title: Missing Links?
description: If Oliver L. North and John M. Poindexter ever get together to swap stories about the Iran-contra affair, it may be a bit like a duet of ''Yes, I Remember It Well.'' Mr. North, testifying for the prosecution last week in Mr. Poindexter's trial, shared recollections that were at odds with what Mr. Poindexter has said under oath. For his part, Mr. North was clearly unhappy about being there. When not answering the prosecutor in snippish monosyllables, the former Marine Corps lieutenant colonel was arguing about the phrasing of the questions. Nevertheless, interesting tidbits did emerge. He said, for example, that he kept Mr. Poindexter, who is charged with obstruction of Congress and conspiracy, informed of details of the Iran arms deal, but some officials, like Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, were kept in the dark. And why was Mr. Regan told nothing? Said Mr. North, ''Don Regan was not in my chain of command.''

title: INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: The Taste of Three Cities;   High Energy at Parisian Brasseries
description: PARIS, we are endlessly assured, is no longer truly Paris but instead a city, like many others, in thrall to sheiks, Japanese conglomerates and fast-food operatives. It is true that foreign investment has changed the character of certain of the city's arrondissements, and that the once classy Champs-Elysees now has a hectic, honky-tonk glow to it. There are fast-food operations there, and also in the Latin Quarter, vending their incongruous french fries, and these days the American stroller who has long yearned to experience the sedate splendors of the Jardin du Luxembourg may well have a disconcerting encounter there with the discarded little plastic foam coffins that lately contained hamburgers from the neighboring McDonald's or Free Time, the French equivalent.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: SYLVIA DUBOIS may have been born in March 1768, but she was never quite sure. ''They didn't used to keep a record of the birth of niggers,'' she said. ''They didn't no more keep the date of a young nigger than they did of a calf or a colt. The young niggers were born in the fall or in the spring, in the summer or in the winter, in cabbage time or when cherries were ripe, when they were planting corn or when they were husking corn, and that's all the way they talked about a nigger's age.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: NINA AUSTENBERG;

Fighting Inhumanity to Animals
description: LEAD: EVEN though Nina Austenberg, the director of the Humane Society of the United States' Mid-Atlantic chapter here, says she is sometimes frustrated at having to juggle at least 15 animal protection issues on a daily basis, her own demeanor seems anything but frazzled.

title: Large Steaks and the He-Man Look
description: CAN an old-fashioned, throwback American steakhouse succeed at a time when cholesterol-conscious diners are discussing their HDL-LDL ratios more than their children's S.A.T. scores?

title: Artists Defend Creative Freedom
description: A panel of prominent West Coast artists defended their freedom of creativity and denounced censorship at a Congressional hearing this week at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, and they urged continued Federal support without restrictions for the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Development Slowdown Offers Planners a Breather
description: FOR the last five or six years local planning boards in the New York metropolitan area have been too busy wrangling with builders, worrying about the voters and wrestling with a host of new state environmental protection laws to think through a coherent new vision of the future of their communities.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Serenity In Song's 'Atlantis'
description: Yienan Song offered an imaginative and strangely soothing evening of dance in ''Daughters and Sons From Atlantis'' on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church (Claremont Avenue and 120th Street), where her Ancient of Days Dance Theater performs the piece through tonight.

title: Drunken Driving Statutes Criticized
description: NEW JERSEY'S drunken driving laws, now among the toughest in the country, have become so severe that their enforcement has begun to infringe on drivers' civil rights, say lawyers and advocates for motorists groups.

title: For Justice in Guatemala
description: Over two decades, Central America's bloodiest carnage has taken place not in El Salvador or Nicaragua but in Guatemala. An army counter-insurgency campaign and extremist death squads have taken some 75,000 lives. The civilian Government of President Vinicio Cerezo has brought some positive changes but has failed to halt politically inspired killings.

title: BEING SAFE
description: I was literally shaken by Patricia Volk's article ''Being Safe'' (Hers, Feb. 11). I used to run around the reservoir, but, thank goodness, I developed tendinitis in my hip; I can't run anymore. My apartment has been robbed; thank goodness, there is little left to steal. I've been assaulted on the street; thank goodness, it'll be I who attack the next person who moves toward me too suddenly.

title: 'New Ideas' Have A Familiar Ring
description: To the Editor:

title: Can a Change In Rules Alter Young Lives?
description: IN a crack-plagued Bronx neighborhood, public school students wear uniforms proudly. At a Bedford-Stuyvesant high school ringed by poverty, students know to leave their gold jewelry and the removable gold jackets for their teeth at home. And in a handful of New York City high schools, students routinely submit to metal-detector searches for weapons.

title: FICTION
description: IF I NEVER GET BACK. By Darryl Brock. (Crown, $18.95.) Submitted for your approval: Sam Fowler, a frustrated crime-and-disaster reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle whose wife has left him for a television anchorman, boards a train in Cleveland after his father's funeral, collapses and wakes up in 1869, surrounded by the Cincinnati Red Stockings, just as they are about to begin their legendary 64-0 season. The team invites Fowler to join them on their tour. Darryl Brock has researched the period so minutely and writes of baseball's early years with such affection that the reader cheerfully surrenders his disbelief to this winsome fantasy. Fowler visits Rochester, the ''Flour City'' filled with wheat dust, and Troy, N.Y., then a larger steel capital than Pittsburgh, with a mutton-chopped band of athletes whose future Hall of Famer, George Wright, makes less for the season than Will Clark now earns in an inning. Armed with 120 years of baseball history unknown to his teammates, Fowler invents the bunt, the intentional walk, even hot dogs, hamburgers and Cracker Jack. But the course of time-travel adventure does not run entirely smoothly. Our hero enrages sinister gamblers and falls in love with a teammate's sister, who embroils him in the doomed Fenian political intrigue to free Ireland. In his spare time, Fowler tours Manhattan with his literary idol, Mark Twain, to whose ''Connecticut Yankee'' Mr. Brock's book owes tribute. Hunted by gunmen and revolutionaries, will Fowler ever get back to his own century? Does he want to? Mr. Brock keeps the reader eager to find out. Beyond the first-novelist flaws - some fatty prose, a narrative viewpoint a bit inflated and self-conscious - this is an engrossing, even charming tale. By its final inning, the reader is sad to see it end.

title: Cuomo in the Lead in Counterattack on G.O.P.
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York said today that personal attacks on Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri for criticizing President Bush's policy toward Eastern Europe were part of a Republican pattern of evading major issues.

title: No Degrees of Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Views on Enrollment At Private Schools
description: The Jan. 21 article ''Enrollment Slips at Many Private Schools'' is certainly thought-provoking. But it surprises me that a plausible contributory reason for the decline in private-school matriculation has been overlooked. I am referring to the fact that the overall quality to education in the public school systems of New Jersey has been improving lately, relatively slowly perhaps, but steadily.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE PUBLIC SAFETY BUILDING;

New Structure Keeps Both the Criminal and the Public in Mind
description: LEAD: THE city's new Public Safety and Court Building at 77 South Lexington Avenue here has a split personality: the upper three floors are reminiscent of a fancy hotel or luxury mall; the bottom two levels, as the Public Safety Commissioner, John M. Dolce, puts it, ''are like the Bastille.''

title: Ban Strawberry, Young Fan Asks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FEZZIWIGS

title: Alaska Pipeline Faces Costly Work to Stop Rust
description: Buried in a mountain range deep in the Arctic Circle and completed in 40-below weather, critical sections of the nation's main oil pipeline are corroding and will require years of costly repair work.

title: INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: The Taste of Three Cities;   London Gets Into the Act For After-Theater Dining
description: LONDON, for all its reputation as a world capital, used to be an early closing town. Few restaurants took orders after 9 o'clock and, as for late-night bars and cafes, you could pretty much forget anything public - or legal. For theatergoers the alternatives were eat early or not at all. All that has changed in the last few years. In the new London restaurant scene it is possible not only to eat after the theater but also to eat well.

title: Sandinistas Have Trouble Accepting the Fact of Defeat
description: IN a single day of balloting last month, Nicaraguan voters tore the heart out of the Sandinista Government: its claim to represent the will of the Nicaraguan people. The transformation was nothing Sandinista leaders had imagined last year when, to repair their international image, they accepted calls to hold free, closely supervised elections. Nor, after a decade of war, could blame for the reversal be laid to the Sandinistas alone.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: It is early to plant if the soil is too heavy to dig and rake. Keep off the lawn if it is wet and soggy; allow the soil to dry thoroughly before using spreaders. Turn seedlings growing indoors near window sills so they do not bend toward the light. If seedlings are growing under lights do not forget to use half-rate, water-soluble fertilizer weekly. Prune shade trees. Finish trimming grapevines. Wait to prune roses.

title: Spirited Cordoba's Riches
description: ARGENTINA has become ridiculously cheap for travelers with dollars, and the elegant old mountain city of Cordoba is one of the greatest values. But $20 first-class hotel suites and $10 three-course meals with wine can't last forever in a place that gives such good quality, so if you want to see the other Argentina, the Argentina beyond Buenos Aires, now is the time.

title: Men's Style;   Milan's Great Escape
description: Standing shoulder to shoulder, their eyes shaded by Mountie hats, they looked like extras from a Nelson Eddy movie. But these young men were models, costumed for winter by Valentino, one of Italy's reigning fashion designers. And their cinematically scarlet jackets, lumberjack shirts and Hudson Bay blanket coats were not destined for the wilds but for some of the most exclusive men's shops in cities on several continents.

title: Ellen Unterberg Wed to A. G. Celli Jr.
