description: Ellen Rose Unterberg, a daughter of Susan Unterberg and Thomas Unterberg, both of New York, was married last evening at the Plaza to Andrew George Celli Jr., a son of Judge and Mrs. Celli of Rochester. Rabbi Bert Aaron Siegel and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: An April Bridal For Grace Gray
description: The engagement of Grace Elizabeth Gray to Benjamin Hill White has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. William B. Gray of New York. Mr. White is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David White of Eugene, Ore. The future bride is also a daughter of the late Reverend Gray. An April wedding is planned.

title: A Brooklyn Man Is Charged With the Theft of 15 Torahs
description: A Brooklyn man was charged with stealing 15 sacred Jewish scrolls from synagogues in New Jersey and Pennsylvania last month, the United States Attorney for New Jersey has announced.

title: Fallout From The Rooney Brouhaha
description: ''All's well that ends well,'' said Mike Wallace, without attribution. Andy Rooney was back on ''60 Minutes'' and everybody at CBS was happy about it, especially those who had suspended him. Not only that: Mr. Rooney expressed gratitude to the groups that sought to have him punished; it had been a learning experience. There hasn't been such a public display of good feelings since Iago befriended Othello.

title: POSTINGS: A Theater Rescued;   Wreckers Foiled Again!
description: The Lincoln Theater, a 65-year-old former playhouse in New Haven, has dodged the wrecker's ball and, in the best tradition of melodrama, has been revived - as the Little Theater on Lincoln Street.

title: Knicks Win One for Present as They Honor the Past
description: On a night when they relived some of their glorious past and may have got some hope for the future, the Knicks also attended to their present business and beat the New Jersey Nets, 110-91.

title: GOD IS THE WHIRLWIND
description: MERAB'S BEAUTY

title: Laura Hill Is Married
description: Laura S. Hill and Lyle G. Clark 3d, financial executives in New York, were married yesterday at the Marriott River Center in San Antonio by the Rev. Nell Linebarger, a United Methodist minister and an aunt of the bride. The bride, a daughter of Mrs. Crawford Reeder and Edward Hill, both of San Antonio, will keep her name. She is a vice president at the Chase Manhattan Bank. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Jr. of Austin, Tex., is a vice president and a senior portfolio manager at Nomura Capital Management. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title: For Students, a Preview of What the Real World Holds
description: LIFE was tough last week in Michael Rossi's sociology class at Hastings-on-Hudson High School. Kevin Gannon and Ruchi Khurana discovered their son, Peter, had a hole in his heart and would need major surgery. Bronwyn Fisher and Matt Bucko found their infant daughter, Jessica, dead of ''SIDS.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're just not a superpower anymore. Economically, we are not as strong as Japan or West Germany right now.

title: OLDER CHILDREN AND DIVORCE
description: For years, my siblings and I struggled with our parents' marriage problems, trying to provide support and keep them together. Finally, after seven years, they divorced and sold the family home. Both remarried. At my father's wedding, I gave a toast. I said that his wedding day was the last day of a job for me - a job that I was happy to hand over to his new wife. I explained how I had been confidante, wife and daughter, and that I was looking forward to being just his daughter. Everybody laughed, but it wasn't funny. I assumed that it would be a relief to have all the problems solved. It was not. My father no longer called me for long conversations, asking for advice and comfort. Instead, he'd call and in a cheery, unfamiliar voice describe all the new activities in his life.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Baby Love Forces Choice On a Career
description: LEAD: FOR many a new mother, deciding whether to return to work or stay at home to take care of her baby is an excruciating choice. I knew this, but only until actually in the throes of making that decision did I realize just how truly difficult it is.

title: Pay Cut Is Now a Seldom-Used Tool
description: Rich Gedman, the Boston catcher who has forgotten how to hit, suffered the maximum 20 percent pay cut this year, his salary plummeting from $1.15 million to $920,000. Life wasn't always so cruel to Gedman. In 1988, he batted .231 and drove in 39 runs and got a raise, from $980,000 to $1.15 million.

title: Colorado in Showdown With No. 1
description: Colorado, which keeps extending the career of Coach Tom Miller, defeated Oklahoma State, 82-72, today in the semifinals of the Big Eight tournament to advance to the final against No. 1 Oklahoma.

title: SAGE FROM MAO IN THE ANGEL CAVE
description: A GENERATION LOST

title: NONFICTION
description: FAKING IT IN AMERICA: Barry Minkow and the Great ZZZZ Best Scam. By Joe Domanick. (Contemporary Books, $19.95.) Barry Minkow belongs to the great tradition of American con men. At first glance, Mr. Minkow had the look of a modern-day Horatio Alger hero - an energetic if rough-edged lower-middle-class teen-ager who, while still in high school, had made the startling entrepreneurial leap from cleaning carpets after school to founding his own carpet-cleaning company, ZZZZ Best. From there, Joe Domanick says in ''Faking It in America,'' he catapulted his small business into a fast-growing concern; in April 1987 he was reputed to be worth $100 million. The news media soon touted Mr. Minkow as a rising star, and he did deserve scrutiny, but not for his business acumen: a multimillionaire at the age of 21, by 22 Mr. Minkow had been convicted of defrauding banks and investors of an estimated $40 million and sentenced to a Federal prison term of 25 years. It turned out that the charismatic Wunderkind had been a schemer from the start; at one point he even stole his grandmother's jewelry to stay afloat. In fact, all along ZZZZ Best seems to have been an elaborate pyramid scheme, powered by extravagant lies and fabricated deals. Mr. Domanick documents Mr. Minkow's rise and fall in vivid and painstaking detail. Unfortunately, what is lacking is a deeper probing of both the self-aggrandizing (and ultimately self-destructive) psychology that drove Mr. Minkow and his associates to defraud, and the dreams and illusions that allowed his investors to be duped.

title: April Wedding For Miss Dugan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Dugan of Chalfont, Pa., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Jean Marie Dugan and Stephen Brooks Faber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ross Faber of Madison, N.J.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

On the Stewardship of Public Places
description: LEAD: THE recent squabbling over the fate of Coindre Hall, the former Brown's estate, and that of the Little Jenny's boathouse is saddening. The particulars of ownership and upkeep seem to have taken a back seat to questions of the responsibilities of one generation taking care of what we've inherited, for the sake of the children to follow.

title: Social Events
description: Rossini at the Pierre

title: Question Of the Week;   How Accountable Is Jim Valvano?
description: The issue of Jim Valvano's accountability cannot be addressed until another question is considered: are the charges of point-shaving true or false?

title: Brandt, on Visit to Oder, Assures Poles on Border
description: Willy Brandt took the East Germany election campaign onto Polish soil today to assure Poland that most Germans do not question its right to live in areas that were German until 1945.

title: Look Who's Hooked on Drug Dollars
description: Federal law now allows the Government to seize drug barons' wealth - mansions, yachts, sports cars - and give a share to local cops who may have helped with the prosecution. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh calls that ''poetic justice.'' There is good reason to worry about distorted justice as well.

title: Athlete and Health: Many at Risk
description: Athletes, Terry Cummings said, don't like the ''no'' word.

title: Miss de Cholnoky Becomes a Bride
description: Andrea Ilona de Cholnoky, a daughter of Ingrid de Cholnoky of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church to Scott Curtis Wilson, the son of Mildred Boyd of Canton, Ohio, and the late Edwin P. Wilson. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop and the Rev. Sydney A. Woodd- Cahousac performed the ceremony. Dr. Corinne Elisabeth de Cholnoky and Verena Maria de Cholnoky, the bride's sisters, were her maids of honor. Joseph Axelrod was the best man.

title: POSTINGS: 72 Units in 15 Buildings;   Hard by a 9-Hole Golf Course
description: What will be one of the few housing developments in Westchester County adjacent to a nine-hole golf course is being built in the Village of Pleasantville. Named the Country Club at Pleasantville, the project will contain 72 two-story town house units in a cluster of 15 buildings. The units, the first of which is due to be finished late this summer, will have either two or three bedrooms and range from 2,400 to 3,400 square feet. Prices are expected to be $359,000 to $475,000. No units have been sold.

title: INSIDE
description: Uproar in Jerusalem

title: STREETSCAPES: The Tweed Courthouse;   Restoration for a Despised, but Hardy, Landmark
description: IT has been one of the most reviled buildings in the city's history, denounced as an eyesore and officially slated for demolition for three-quarters of a century until it was declared a landmark in 1984.

title:
Your Own Account;

Borrowing Against Your 401(k)
description: LEAD: Most employees who have the opportunity to contribute to a 401 (k) plan know that it's a good option for retirement savings. What many do not know is that it can also be the source of a loan to make a down payment on a home, buy a car, take a vacation or to satisfy just about any other need you may have for ready cash.

title: Trenary Captures World Title
description: Jill Trenary's long climb to the highest level of figure skating ended today when she won the women's title of the world figure-skating championships. The way it happened, though, provided little proof she is the best skater in the world.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Cairo
description: Cairo does not lend itself to easy or quick discovery. Even driving into town from the airport, the visitor is struck by the results of an unrestrained lurch into modernity: the noise of honking cars cramming the roads and bridges, the throngs of people on the streets below. With a fast-growing population of around 14 million, Cairo is generally more chaotic than exotic.

title: Challenge at Home for Adept Player of Racial Politics
description: In a city known for racial politics, no elected official speaks in stronger and more hostile terms than Representative Gus Savage.

title: The Pioneers of Wind-Shear Warning Systems
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Westchester County's environmental policies misstated Marc Moran's title. He is director of government operations.

title: Colleges Pursue Effort to Ease Bias
description: LEAD: THE 11 colleges in the county, although recognized statewide as leaders in trying to reduce racial bias on their campuses, agree that more needs to be done in both curriculums and extracurricular activities for their increasingly diverse student populations.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

An Album Celebrates One Man's Port Washington
description: LEAD: LIKE many hobbyists, W. Edward Baker did not begin his pastime with an eye toward making it a consuming passion. But the more he collected photographs and stories about Port Washington, his hometown, the more he got involved in piecing together its history.

title: TALK BEFORE SEX AND TALK AFTER SEX
description: DECEPTION

title: East Germany's Military Chief Acknowledges 'Signs of Dissolution'
description: The Defense Minister, Adm. Theodor Hoffmann, conceded on Friday that ''signs of dissolution'' existed in the military, but said an overwhelming majority of his forces were carrying out their duties responsibly, particularly those linked to East Germany's obligations under the Warsaw Pact.

title: In a War Over Taxis, 27 Die In a South African Township
description: A war between rival taxi companies has turned this quiet black township a dozen miles southeast of Johannesburg into a battleground.

title: Mongolian Communists Rally Against Foes
description: Thousands of Mongolian Communists staged their first rally today in Ulan Bator, criticizing new opposition movements as undemocratic and calling two of their leaders traitors.

title: A FATIGUE MANDELA REST, THEN HEADS FOR SWEDEN
description: Nelson Mandela ended a two-week, four-country African tour today and headed for Sweden despite suggestions that he might cancel his trip because of fatigue and mounting violence in South Africa.

title: On Economic Front, Changes Continue
description: G.M. Deal With East Germany. The largest American auto maker tentatively agreed to a joint venture with the larger of East Germany's two car makers. General Motors could invest as much as $600 million in the venture, which would make components and assemble cars at a factory near the West German border. Page D1.

title: U.S. Settlement For Fred Alger
description: The Wall Street money manager Fred Alger has settled an administrative action with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the S.E.C. said last week.

title: Union Pacific Deal Fails
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said its Union Pacific Realty subsidiary had terminated an agreement to sell its assets to the Koll Company. The agreement, valued at $532 million, had been announced in December.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Calvin Klein Cosmetics, to Chiat/ Day/Mojo in New York, for its Eternity and Obsession fragrance lines, with a budget of $20 million to $30 million.

title: Market Place;   Little Interest In Stock Baskets
description: FRIDAY was another typical day of trading in the New York Stock Exchange's so-called basket product: nobody bought one, and nobody sold one.

title: Official Resigns Over Remark On South Carolina Governor
description: The executive director of the state Democratic Party has resigned after calling the Republican Governor a fascist.

title: Entrepreneurs in Czechoslovakia Await Law
description: Martin Stepanek works at the Prague Zoo with large animals. It is a good job, but his heart is really in snakes and crocodiles, he said as he waited to register with a newly formed association of entrepreneurs. He would like to open his own pet shop.

title: Last Cast of 'Chorus Line' Wonders About Taking Its Next Steps
description: For 25-year-old Jack Noseworthy, singing and dancing in ''A Chorus Line'' was always the stuff of dreams. Last month, Mr. Noseworthy's dreams came true. He was offered, and he accepted, a role in the Michael Bennett musical, the longest-running show in Broadway history. And then came the afternoon of Feb. 21.

title: Chronicle
description: Stock-car racing, a peculiarly American sport, could not be more foreign to CARY ELWES, who was reared in London. So to prepare for his role in ''Days of Thunder'' with TOM CRUISE, he went to the source, the Daytona 500 and the Winston 500, to associate with drivers.

title: Realty Hurts American Express
description: The American Express Company's dabble into real estate in the 1980's is proving to be one of its biggest blunders.

title: Despite a Tobacco Heritage, Virginia Nears Smoke Curbs
description: Virginia, where tobacco has been king since Colonial times, has taken a major step toward limiting public smoking.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene;   As Big Agencies Get Bigger, Some Small Shops Thrive
description: For some people working on Madison Avenue these days, Mies vander Rohe certainly had the right idea: Less is more.

title: New Land Panel Has Trouble Gearing Up
description: The way New York City governs land, perhaps its most precious commodity, is in quiet turmoil these days, with the Dinkins administration behind schedule in putting in place changes under the new City Charter and developers rushing to act on big projects before the system changes.

title: PARLIAMENT IN LITHUANIA, 124-0, DECLARES NATION INDEPENDENT
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania, March 11 -Lithuania tonight proclaimed itself a sovereign state, legally free of the Soviet Union, and named the leaders of a non-Communist government to negotiate their future relations with Moscow.

title: Investor Suggests Lockheed Concentrate on the Military
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who is seeking control of the Lockheed Corporation, outlined his strategy for the company today, saying Lockheed needs to refocus on its core military and space businesses.

title: No Advantage for Disadvantaged Found in a 60's Military Program
description: A Vietnam-era program intended to give poor youths and those with low aptitudes a ''leg up'' on life by lowering standards for entry into the military was a failure, a new study says.

title: Review/Dance;   Wrinklings, Flutters, Tilts and Stamps as Major Events
description: Deborah Hay isn't an easy performer to watch or to understand. Her dances, like her stage presence, tend to be on the gnomic side. There is no man, for instance, in ''The Man Who Grew Common in Wisdom,'' a new work presented on Friday night at the Warren Street Performance Loft.

title: Christie's Reverses Stand on Price Guarantees
description: Christie's, one of the world's two major auction houses, has abruptly reversed a longstanding policy and has guaranteed a minimum price for a collection of artworks it is to auction in May.

title: Happy Packer
description: SOME National Football League players have wounded egos because their clubs did not protect them in the current Plan B free-agency period. Other players are upset because their clubs did protect them, thus depriving the players of a chance for big money.

title: Peugeot-Fiat Link Is Sought
description: The French Government suggested last week that Peugeot S. A., the nation's largest private industrial company, link up with Fiat S.p.A. of Italy to form an auto group big enough to withstand growing Japanese competition in Europe.

title: Rostenkowski Presents Plan to Cut Deficit
description: In what he described as a budget challenge to his own party and the Bush Administration, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee today called for a combination of tax increases and spending cuts, including a one-year freeze on increases in Social Security benefits.

title: 2 Inmates Are Shot As They Are Leaving Rikers Island Chapel
description: Two inmates in a crowd leaving a chapel service on Rikers Island were shot yesterday, the authorities said. But while correction officers found the .25-caliber gun on the floor outside the chapel, by last night they had no suspects and said they did not know the motive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Pro Bono
description: * Martha Voutas Productions will promote a ''fantasy auction'' at Sotheby's to benefit the Manhattan Center for Living.

title: POLITICAL TENSION IN ISRAEL DEEPENS
description: Labor Party ministers stormed angrily out of an Israeli Cabinet meeting today after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud party refused to put to a vote a plan by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title: Colombians Choose Centrist To Run for President in May
description: Voters chose a centrist today as the ruling Liberal Party's candidate in presidential elections scheduled for May, party officials said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Expressing the will of the people, the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Republic declares and solemnly proclaims the restoration of the exercise of sovereign powers of the Lithuanian state, which were annulled by an alien power in 1940. From now on, Lithuania is once again an independent state.''

title: G.M. Plans New Link In East Bloc
description: In the latest in a series of deals by Western car companies in Eastern Europe, the General Motors Corporation announced tentative plans today to form a joint venture in East Germany with Automobil-Werk Eisenach, the bigger of East Germany's two car makers.

title: U.S. Aid Sought Against Great Lakes Mussel
description: A prolific, inedible European shellfish that stowed away on freighters has become a multimillion-dollar menace in three years, lawmakers from Great Lakes states say.

title: A Papal Attack on Vatican II
description: LEAD: The appointment of Thomas V. Dailey as the new bishop of Brooklyn, the nation's largest diocese, fits into a pattern of institutional change in the Roman Catholic Church over the past decade or so.

title: Private Group Drafting Changes in Spy Laws
description: Nine private citizens who advise the leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee are drafting a proposal to change the Federal espionage laws, partly to strengthen the authority of investigators to search for spies, according to Government officials and private intelligence experts.

title: Let East German Mark Float to Its Own Level;   Exchange at Par
description: To the Editor:

title: West Virginia Teachers Vow To Continue Their Walkout
description: Striking teachers said today that they would continue their statewide school walkout until Gov. Gaston Caperton called a special legislative session to deal with their demands for a pay increase and financing of higher education.

title: Georgia Tech Tops Virginia in Final
description: A Georgia Tech team that may be just beginning to realize its strength completed a sweep through the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament this afternoon, defeating Virginia, 70-61, to capture the league title.

title: Government Begins Bias Inquiry at Citadel
description: The Justice Department has begun a formal investigation of Citadel Military College of South Carolina in Charleston to determine whether its policy of admitting only men violates the Constitution and laws against discrimination.

title: Celtics Top 76ers In Final Seconds
description: Joe Kleine was in an unfamiliar situation - taking the big shot with the game on the line and making it. But these are strange times for the Boston Celtics.

title: A Bittersweet Ending
description: Does the name Judith Campbell Exner ring a bell? She is a woman, now coming to the end of her life, who was used and abused by three powerful men.

title: Tickets an Issue In N. C. State Case
description: Robert Kramer improperly received game tickets from an unidentified North Carolina State player in 1988, an investigation by the school and the National Collegiate Athletic Association showed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   U.P.I. Seeks Arbitration
description: United Press International is seeking arbitration of its claim that the Reuters news agency has deprived it of photography revenue for the last five years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Public Policy Issues Draw Agency Man
description: AN advertising man who once battled for the wallets of the wealthy on behalf of Mercedes-Benz will now be fighting for the hearts and minds of citizens concerned about drug cartels in Colombia.

title: Air Force Officer Is Acquitted Of Sexual Relations Charge
description: An Air Force lieutenant accused of having sexual relations with a sergeant at a Titan 2 missile silo has been acquitted by a military jury.

title: Manila Acts on Deficit
description: The Philippines plans to take steps to trim the budget deficit and contain inflation to support sustained economic recovery, the Finance Secretary, Jesus Estanislao, said Friday. He said the measures included raising taxes on selected products, limiting Government spending, accelerating privatization of state-owned assets and eventually lowering interest rates. He told reporters the package had been approved by President Corazon C. Aquino's Cabinet.

title: Estonian Congress Calls for a Republic
description: In a major step toward achieving independence from the Soviet Union, a congress selected by a majority of Estonians living in Estonia today called on the United Nations and the Soviet Parliament to restore ''the free and independent republic of Estonia.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Power System Inc., New York, a utility holding company, named Stanley I. Garnett 2d chief financial officer. He replaces Alan J. Noia, who becomes executive vice president of Allegheny's Potomac Edison Company unit.

title: Ethnic Tension Marks Bronx Race for Garcia Seat
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has intervened in a South Bronx special election to help an early supporter and to reduce competition and tensions between black and Hispanic Democrats.

title: Traditions Fade Into the Past
description: As the 75th world figure skating championships concluded today with exhibition performances by the winners, the sport left behind part of its staid and traditional past.

title: Business Scene;   High Technology In Plants Abroad
description: WITH an energy not seen since the heyday of the multinationals 20 years ago, American companies are building factories overseas, buying companies and getting into all sorts of joint ventures. But while they expand their production abroad, they are somehow managing to do it without hiring a lot of foreign workers.

title: For Gorbachev, an Uncertain Anniversary
description: Outside a polling place in Moscow last week, a voter framed the issue as a bitter joke: ''What is the difference between the Soviet Union and the United States?''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DePaul Is Stunned At Snub By N.C.A.A.
description: LEAD: DePaul, snubbed by the N.C.A.A. tournament, was among the 32 teams selected for the National Invitation Tournament last night.

title: Glad Tidings For 64
description: College basketball's troubled season turned toward its traditional upbeat conclusion yesterday when the pairings for the 64 teams of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's basketball tournament were announced in a national telecast from Kansas City, Mo.

title: Mosbacher Goes to Talks in Tokyo
description: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher left today for trade talks in Tokyo, saying he wanted to convey to the Japanese ''a certain sense of urgency about the trade problem.''

title: Edye Kleiman and Rand Rosenbaum Are Wed
description: Edye Kleiman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Kleiman of Coram, L.I., was married yesterday at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., to Rand Kevin Rosenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Rosenbaum of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi Ronald Millstein officiated.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Mike Bienstock, associate media director; Howard Finkelberg, associate director of marketing sciences, and Buz Sawyer, management representative, have been named senior vice presidents at BBDO New York.

title: Question Box
description: Big East vs. A.C.C. I

title: Sports of The Times;   Zing Went the Strings for UConn
description: I SAW a young man sitting in the stands in Madison Square Garden yesterday wearing a deflated basketball for a hat and a basketball net pulled over it and covering his face like a veil.

title: Plenty of Whales Sighted Off Pacific Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Pop;   Patti LaBelle's Love Of Those in Love With Her
description: Probably not since Judy Garland has a pop diva encouraged more extravagant exchanges of love between a performer and her audience than Patti LaBelle. On Friday evening, at the final concert of a three-night engagement at City Center, the 45-year-old pop-gospel singer from Philadelphia was besieged by floral tributes, and one admirer even crept up on the stage to kiss her feet. The star, in turn, donated her false eyelashes and stockings to members of the audience, and allowed one fan to massage her legs with lotion.

title: Sandinistas Enact a Bipartisan Amnesty
description: Amending a controversial bill proposed last week, the Sandinista-controlled National Assembly approved an unconditional amnesty late Saturday that would cover all crimes committed by either side in the country's civil war.

title: Directors Honor Stone
description: Oliver Stone, the director of ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' won top honors from his peers on Saturday as the Directors Guild of America celebrated its own.

title: Grisly Look at Prison Life of Yesteryear By PETER KERR
description: Beware, all ye who enter, of Joe Baranyi, keeper of the Garden State's electric chair and curator of the mysterious New Jersey finger.

title: Koito Rebuff For Pickens
description: A Japanese auto parts maker last week rejected a demand by the American investor T. Boone Pickens to review the company's financial records.

title: Sondheim Celebration
description: ''Putting It Together,'' a two-hour celebration of the career of Stephen Sondheim on the composer and lyricist's 60th birthday is to be broadcast by WNYC-FM (93.9)at 2 P.M. on March 22. Produced by National Public Radio, the program is to feature Angela Lansbury as the host and include interviews with the producer and director Hal Prince and the singer Bernadette Peters. There will be commentary by Frank Rich, chief drama critic of The New York Times, and the lyricist Sheldon Harnick.

title: Argentine Inflation Rate
description: Living costs in Argentina rose more than 12,000 percent in the 12 months through the end of February, according to official figures released Friday. The National Statistics Institute said the consumer price index rose 61.6 percent in February alone, compared with a 79.2 percent rise in January. Prices rose 9.6 percent in February 1989. Private estimates put the February inflation rate well above the Government figure. The independent Institute of Economic and Social Policy calculated the increase at 115.4 percent, including a 22.1 percent rise in the final week of the month.

title: UConn Beats Syracuse for Big East Title
description: Suddenly frozen in time, the Connecticut Huskies strode one by one through the noise to the center of the court at Madison Square Garden to accept the wristwatches and handshakes that go to the champions of the Big East Conference tournament.

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Coalition Cracks

title: Books of The Times;   Some Troubled Children and How They Grew
description: The Untouched Key

title: Oklahoma Wins Title in Big Eight
description: Top-ranked Oklahoma opened a 17-point second-half lead on the shooting of William Davis and Jackie Jones then held on to beat Colorado, 92-80, today for the Big Eight Conference tournament title.

title: Venezuela and Banks Near Agreement on Debt Relief
description: Venezuela and its commercial bankers are moving toward a debt agreement that is expected to include a provision for substantial, but temporary, debt relief.

title: Let East German Mark Float to Its Own Level;   In Their Private Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: Elected President Replaces Pinochet
description: The long and often bitter era of military rule came to an end in Chile today with the installation of Patricio Aylwin, a genial Christian Democrat and longtime political figure, as the elected successor to Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Chronicle
description: For the opening of the opulent Teatro Amazonas in the heart of the Amazon rain forest, MARCIA HAYDEE, the Brazilian ballerina and director of the Stuttgart Ballet, will dance in ''Amazon Forest.'' The Villa-Lobos ballet, along with excerpts from a Brazilian opera and a symphonic work written by CLAUDIO SANTORO, an Amazonian composer, make up the program on March 17 for the re-opening of the theater, built in 1896 by Brazil's rubber barons.

title: Simon & Schuster Buys School Software Maker
description: Simon & Schuster, already a leading force in educational publishing, is expanding further through the acquisition of the Computer Curriculum Corporation, a software company providing computer-based learning systems for schools.

title: Two Liberations in Lithuania
description: Mikhail Gorbachev thinks Lithuanians are wrong to secede but accepts their right to be wrong. That's a mark of his liberation as well as theirs. Lithuania only declared itself independent yesterday. Now it must negotiate terms and timing. But Mr. Gorbachev has already said yes to the principle of a free Lithuania by agreeing to talks and by refusing to use force. What a welcome transformation in a land that Americans have known for half a century as a captive nation.

title: Don't Read His Lips
description: Here is another example of what close observers have come to expect of George Bush:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Following are the principal economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Lima Journal;   A Portrait of the Writer as the Rising Political Star
description: Long the detached observer, Mario Vargas Llosa dismissed politics a few years ago as ''a very dirty business.''

title: Trevino Already Seniors Star
description: Last year, nearly everyone who is anyone in golf was asked to speculate about how Lee Trevino would do on the Senior Tour. Reactions ran the gamut, but it turns out the most accurate prognostication was the most drastic.

title: Blind Analyst
description: WHEN Donald Wardlow, a ''color commentator,'' is ushered to his press box seat by a Seeing Eye dog named Duffer, heads inevitably turn. Sports fans watch in amazement as he unloads a bag that contains a microphone, a mixer, and a Braille typewriter.

title: Lebanese President Rejects Offer To Negotiate With Rebel General
description: The Syrian-backed Government of President Elias Hrawi has rejected Gen. Michel Aoun's offer to start peace talks to end the fighting in Beirut.

title: That Merciless Defense Did It
description: Six minutes into yesterday's Big East championship game between Syracuse and Connecticut, Derrick Coleman took a pass from Michael Edwards and slammed in an authoritative dunk.

title: Homeless, They Build For Peers
description: Dozens of tiny plastic crack vials litter the ground-floor hallway of the small tan brick apartment building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. That is the present.

title: Horse Racing;   Charon Remains Undefeated
description: The distance, the weights, and the odds were different, but the outcome was the same today at Gulfstream Park, when Charon beat Trumpet's Blare and De La Devil to win the $200,000 Bonnie Miss Stakes.

title: Pan Am Shuttle to Offer Hourly Papers to Fliers
description: All-news cable television and radio stations have obliged compulsive Americans to follow current events during midnight snacks, at the dinner table and even, for owners of waterproof radios, in the shower. Now even the afternoon flight home from an out-of-town meeting, a quiet respite in the sky from the tumult of information below, may have its own hourly newspaper.

title: Overhaul of Party Urged
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed an overhaul of the Communist Party as he pressed his strategy to de-emphasize the party's position. Page A10.

title: Girl, 2, Killed in Harlem Fire
description: A fire swept through a Harlem apartment yesterday morning, killing a 2-year-old girl who was found dead in her crib, the police said. The fire was contained in the top floor apartment at 301 West 152d Street. The infant's five brothers and sisters; her mother, Yvette Adams, 26; and her grandmother, Nettie Adams, 53, managed to safely flee the building. Police and fire officials said the cause of the blazewas under investigation.

title: Division I Names Top-Seeded Teams
description: Louisiana Tech, Washington, Stanford and Tennessee received the top seedings today for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I women's basketball tournament.

title: Bridge
description: The American tournament scene lost its much-loved oldest inhabitant Thursday when Jay Feigus of Middletown, N.J., died at the age of 97. He owned, apparently, two world records in competition of any kind and they may never be broken.

title: Proxy Fights Loom on a Variety of Issues
description: As the proxy season approaches, investors are girding for battle over everything from ''golden parachutes'' and ''poison pills'' to ousting directors.

title: Michigan State Prevails
description: A shot that Dwayne Stephens did not want to take proved to be the biggest basket of the season for Michigan State.

title: Sultan Denies Harrods Role
description: The Sultan of Brunei has denied that he played a role in the $1 billion takeover of House of Fraser P.L.C., the owner of the Harrods department stores, by the Fayed brothers in 1985.

title: The Mail Monopoly
description: Does the price of mail really have to go up again? Yes, and 30 cents for a first-class letter is still a bargain compared with prices in other countries. But costlier service could also be better service. The U.S. Postal Service is, and acts like, a monopoly. Competition is the answer.

title: Outdoors: Trekking For Hare in Snow
description: A QUEST for cottontail rabbits in Massachusetts helped begin a snowshoe-testing forest ramble in Maine.

title: Susan T. Hosat and Dr. Stewart Levine Married
description: Susan Tina Hosat and Dr. Stewart Alan Levine were married yesterday at Temple Shalom in Fresh Meadows, Queens, by Rabbis Stuart Berman and Pierce Neuman.

title: Timeout in Race
description: THERE are still two legs and some 12,000 miles to go in the six-leg, 33,000-mile Whitbread round-the-world yacht race, but by one measure the 22 boats representing four yacht classes and 13 nations have already sailed around the world, or an icy chunk of it, anyway.

title: Owners Approve TV Deals
description: The most lucrative deal in television history, $3.65 billion over four years, was unanimously approved here today by the National Football League owners in the opening session of their annual meeting.

title: Lockout Could Make or Break Carter
description: Except for the fan who waited all winter, who is the biggest loser in baseball's short spring?

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer malfunction, an article on Feb. 28 about a Supreme Court ruling on the treatment of mentally ill prisoners was scrambled in some copies. The opening paragraph should have read, ''The Supreme Court ruled today that prison officials can treat mentally ill prisoners with antipsychotic drugs against their will without first receiving permission in a formal judicial hearing.''

title: Calendar
description: Mar. 17: Townwide Fund St. Patrick's Run. Huntington, L.I., 8:30 A.M. A four-mile road race and one-kilometer fun run. Information: (516) 549-3006.

title: Reviews/Music;   Mussorgsky and Berg From Barry Douglas
description: The Irish pianist Barry Douglas, who won the Tchaikovsky International Competition in 1986, gave a backward glance in his recital at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening. His program included Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' which he performed to great acclaim in Moscow, and Tchaikovsky's Sonata in G (Op. 37). He has recorded both works.

title: 7 Hurt as Shots Pierce Roof of Greyhound Bus
description: A gunshot fired into a Greyhound bus outside Jacksonville injured seven people yesterday, the police and company officials said.

title: East Germany's Fizzled Revolution
description: LEAD: Just six days before East Germany's first free election in 56 years, the Communist party still controls much of the election process, West German politicians barnstorm the country and the opposition is in tatters. Have East German citizens won only a Pyrrhic victory in their populist uprising?

title: Chief of Abbott Labs Files Suit Over Ouster
description: Abbott Laboratories has taken the unusual step of removing its chairman, Robert A. Schoellhorn, and in turn, Mr. Schoellhorn has sued the company and four outside directors.

title: Bill Planned on Exchanges
description: A member of the Senate Banking Committee says he plans to propose a bill to put a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on the Security and Exchange Commission.

title: Community Service, Mark of Disgrace
description: LEAD: Maybe the mists of time have clouded my memory, but I always thought people active in community service were considered public-spirited citizens - role models. Today, the phrase has taken on a whole new meaning: punishment.

title: Two Years Temper Hopes in Baltimore
description: A little more than two years ago, when Kurt L. Schmoke took over as Mayor of Baltimore, expectations soared that he would get this troubled old port city moving in a new direction. Time has tempered those hopes. An athletic Rhodes scholar who had managed to become the first black elected to the job, Mr. Schmoke took office with a splash of national publicity. Soft-spoken, introspective, even a little shy, he had a far different agenda from that of his blunt-spoken, relentlessly political predecessor, William Donald Schaefer.

title: ABC's Top Programmer Sees His Guesses Pay Off, So Far, in Prime Time
description: When Robert A. Iger was named president of ABC Entertainment nearly a year ago, he felt as if he had entered a Federal witness protection program.

title: New Top Management Set at Robinson Nugent
description: Robinson Nugent Inc., a small maker of electronic connectors, has named a new president and chief executive, Larry W. Burke.

title: Higher Short-Term Rates Seen
description: Credit market analysts are predicting that short-term interest rates, which have recently been inching up, are likely to move even higher.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Hands-On Relief for Sore Athletes
description: LEAD: BILL RODGERS's first massage was memorable on several counts, not the least of which was that it happened by accident.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Discussion Yields Nothing but Talk
description: Three weeks before the day when the last exhibition games are scheduled, the baseball commissioner and the players' labor leader met again yesterday. The outcome, however, was the same as it was after their meeting the previous day: no progress in the labor dispute.

title: New Faces in Primary For Governor of Illinois
description: When voters turn out for the Illinois gubernatorial primary this month, they will face an unfamiliar choice. For the first time since 1976, the Republican ballot will not include the name James R. Thompson.

title: Toyota Said to Plan Big U.S. Test Site
description: In a move reflecting its push for growth in the United States and other markets, the Toyota Motor Corporation will build the world's biggest automotive proving ground near Phoenix, auto industry executives say.

title: Focused Sabatini Defeats Capriati
description: One volleyed, sliced, and worked the ball like a yo-yo; the other didn't. And today the quest of 13-year-old Jennifer Capriati ended in the blur of the topspin that wafted from Gabriela Sabatini's racquet as the determined Argentine put aside her own performance anxieties to defeat the first-timer, 6-4, 7-5, in the final of the Virginia Slims of Florida.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf

title: Panama's New Leader Fasts To Dramatize Need for Aid
description: Nearly three months after American forces invaded Panama, the Panamanian economy is in ruins and $1 billion in emergency aid remains stalled in the United States Congress. At the Metropolitan Cathedral here, President Guillermo Endara has devised an unusual but apt way to dramatize the plight of a country starved for money: he has gone on an indefinite hunger strike.

title: Lithuania's Long Path From and Back Toward Freedom
description: February 1918 Lithuania, an independent state and later a Grand Duchy under the former Russian empire, is proclaimed an independent kingdom under the protection of Germany.

title: Cost Doesn't Rule Out Pentamidine Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev Seeks Party Overhaul but Not Open Election of Congress
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed a basic overhaul of the troubled Communist Party, but stopped short of demanding competitive secret-ballot participation by all 19 million Communists in the election of the 5,000 delegates to the approaching party congress.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Gallimard Chief Gains in Feud
description: Antoine Gallimard, chief executive of the prestigious French publishing house that bears his name, has consolidated his hold over the company in an effort to end a family feud for control, a company spokesman said Friday.

title: Dinkins Takes Roast With a Dash of Humor
description: In the crowded ballroom of the New York Hilton Saturday night, an announcer introduced the Mayor of the City of New York, but David N. Dinkins was nowhere to be seen. The black-tie audience waiting for his rebuttal to the annual City Hall reporters' roast heard only whistling and the sound of running water.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   WPP Profit Up 89.4%
description: WPP Group P.L.C., the world's largest marketing communications conglomerate, said its 1989 profit after taxes rose 89.4 percent, to $66.1 million, or $1.19 a share, from $34.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in 1988. Revenues increased 83.7 percent, to $1.64 billion, from $892.8 million in 1988. The company said its improved performance was helped by the acquisition of the Ogilvy Group, whose operating margin increased, and to a continued rise in the operating margins of J. Walter Thompson and Hill & Knowlton.

title: Review/Music;   Sounds To Look At And Taste
description: ''Parabola'' at the Dia Art Foundation on Saturday night was the blanket title for a series of musical events meant to be seen - even tasted - as well as heard. Two performers and creators, Takehisa Kosugi and Fast Forward (yes, that is his name), perambulated an open space before a small audience in bleacher seats and made music on a number of instruments, household objects and themselves.

title: Kosovo's Night Curfew Ends After Lull in Ethnic Violence
description: Yugoslavia lifted a night curfew in Kosovo, where an Albanian human rights group has said 33 people have been killed by the authorities in ethnic riots this year, and reporters in the province said it was quiet this weekend.

title: Grady Is Focusing on P.S.A.L. Title
description: After beating its neighborhood rival, Abraham Lincoln, for the third time this season in a heart-stopping 47-46 Public Schools Athletic League semifinal yesterday, William E. Grady High School of Brooklyn is looking to be part of the first P.S.A.L. championship game at Madison Square Garden since 1964.

title: Review/Television;   Pointing a Lively Finger At Consumers' Frustrations
description: Now and then, amid the clutter of local news programs, one comes upon a useful and entertaining item, like finding in a junkyard a cuckoo clock that works. That is by way of drawing attention to ''The Hall of Shame,'' a consumer-friendly report by Arnold Diaz that can be seen Mondays on ''Channel 2 News at 5.''

title: Tips One Can Flip Over
description: rrA picture booklet with pages the size of baseball cards has been produced to instruct athletes on how to improve their play through animation.

title: Youth Service Bill Answers Bush's Call
description: To the Editor:

title: Clean Power's Strange Enemies
description: Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts owes a large debt to the owners of the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire: $2 billion. That's the cost of his refusal to help his New Hampshire neighbors devise an emergency evacuation plan.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 12, 1990:

title: Judy Tobias Is Wed to Lewis F. Davis
description: Audrey Judith Tobias, the treasurer and a former president of Waif Inc., a national organization that helps find homes for homeless children, and Lewis F. Davis, a builder, were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York by Judge George B. Daniels of City Criminal Court.

title: Romanians' Lives Quickly Improve
description: There was a birthday party here last week for Dana Madolciu, who turned 34, and in a number of ways it illustrated the remarkable changes that have taken place in Romanian households since the overthrow of President Nicolae Ceausescu in December.

title: Odd Surge in Deaths Found In Those Taking AIDS Drug
description: AIDS patients who have taken an experimental drug in a new and controversial distribution system have been dying at more than 10 times the rate of those who are taking the drug in standard tests, its manufacturer says.

title: New Airport Is Planned to Help O'Hare, but Where?
description: After years of debate over how to relieve congestion at O'Hare Airport here, a political tug-of-war has begun over where to build a new one.

title: Arab League Headquarters to Return to Cairo
description: The Arab League agreed in principle today to move its headquarters back here, in the high point of a two-year campaign by Egypt for full rehabilitation in the Arab world.

title: U.S. Says Coup Effort Shows Afghan's Weakness
description: Bush Administration officials said today that the latest coup attempt in Afghanistan showed that President Najibullah is weak and vulnerable and faces substantial opposition from within the Communist Party and the Afghan armed forces.

title: Review/Concert;   Celebrating 50 Years of Opera on Saturdays
description: The Metropolitan Opera began broadcasting its Saturday matinees to a national radio audience in 1931, but nearly called its series to a halt in 1939 when it had trouble finding a sponsor. In 1940, Texaco began sponsoring the weekly broadcasts, and on Saturday afternoon, the Met and Texaco celebrated their half-century alliance with a gala concert that was, naturally, broadcast live.

title: Martial Singher, French Baritone And a Noted Teacher, Dies at 85
description: Martial Singher, a French baritone who became a leading American operatic and concert artist and later a noted teacher, died of heart disease on Saturday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: Review/Music;   Guitarist of Japan via Spain
description: Kokichi Akasaka, a guitarist from Japan who has lived in Spain since 1977, made his United States debut on Saturday evening at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Bridge Illness: Anxiety Is Now The Suspect
description: An intense, costly search has failed to find a medical or environmental cause for the bizarre illness of 34 Triborough Bridge toll workers, leading bridge officials to suspect that the symptoms may have been psychosomatic.

title: 2d Suspect in Slaying Of Parents Surrenders
description: The second of two brothers accused of killing their parents at the family's Beverly Hills mansion last year surrendered to the authorities early today, the police said.

title: Review/Ballet;   Oakland Troupe Performs Cocteau's 'Train Bleu'
description: As a rule, ballets conceived by Jean Cocteau did not resemble ballets, and ''Le Train Bleu,'' which has now received a major and engaging reconstruction job from the Oakland Ballet, is no exception.

title: A Conductor's Replacement
description: Christof Perick is to make his New York Philharmonic conducting debut in a series of concerts starting March 22 at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall, replacing Klaus Tennstedt, who is ill. The program is to include Weber's Overture to ''Oberon,'' Beethoven's Sixth Symphony and Sibelius's Violin Concerto, with Kyung-Wha Chung as soloist. The concert is to be repeated on March 23, 24 and 27. Information: 874-2424.

title: New Yorkers Have Good Reason to Be So Rude
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Oil >Spills Turn Spotlight On New York's Vital Straits
description: Before four spills dumped hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill and the connecting Kill Van Kull this year, the two waterways were hardly known outside maritime circles, even though they carry more traffic than the Panama Canal. But the 16-mile channel winding between northern New Jersy and Staten Island is an important contributor to the economic vitality of the Northeast.

title: U.S. Advises Moscow To 'Respect' Lithuania
description: The Bush Administration urged the Soviet Union today to respect the decision of the Lithuanian parliament to restore its sovereignty, but stopped short of an explicit statement of recognition of the newly declared government.

title: Romania Marchers Seek Ouster of Communists
description: Anti-Government demonstrators marched today through the capital and in Timisoara, the cradle of the December revolution, protesting what they said was the continued prevalence of Communists and the dreaded security police.

title: For Some Publishers, Profit Goes With Quality
description: For nine years, Cornelia and Michael Bessie have published books that have earned them and their imprint a reputation as publishers of quality. Their authors have included Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, Theodore H. White, Doris Lessing, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Anwar Sadat and the Nobel laureate Peter Medawar.

title: Trade Negotiations Create an Uproar in Japan
description: The proper number of knotholes in a sheet of plywood does not constitute anyone's definition of subject matter fit for review by the leaders of Japan and the United States.

title: Writers to Confront Modern Composers
description: Philip Glass and Allen Ginsberg will be the first adversaries in a series, ''Face the Music,'' starting at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street.

title: Churchgoers Watch Shootings
description: A man apparently upset over divorce proceedings walked into a church today, shot his wife twice, then turned the gun on himself as 55 churchgoers watched, the authorities said. The woman, Tawanna Jo Lynch, 32 years old, was shot in the head and was in critical condition at a hospital in Oklahoma City. Her husband, David Leon Lynch, 31, was dead at the scene. The shootings occurred at the Byng Freewill Baptist Church about 11 A.M.

title: Let East German Mark Float to Its Own Level
description: In the proposed monetary union, the West German mark would supplant the East German mark. The correct exchange rate for the conversion has been hotly debated. Under the best circumstances, it is practically impossible to arrive at a long-run equilibrium exchange rate. In the German case, it is well-nigh impossible. An exchange rate favorable to the East Germans would put an inflationary penalty on West Germany, aggravate unemployment in East Germany and not stem the labor migration. A less favorable rate would jeopardize East German savings and pensions.

title: Metro Matters;   Japanese Work To Link Business To Philanthropy
description: Last fall, five days before the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo bought control of the Rockefeller Group, which owns Rockefeller Center, Mitsubishi's sister companies made another New York investment.

title: Nations Widen Role of Bank for East-Bloc Aid
description: A dispute over the role of a new international development bank to help Eastern Europe has been resolved with a decision that the bank will provide loans not only to the private sector, but also to public-sector projects like road building, European officials said today.

title: Eddie Antar's Assets Frozen
description: A Federal judge has frozen the assets of the founder of the Crazy Eddie electronics chain, who is being sought by Federal marshals in connection with an order to repatriate $52 million in overseas finances.

title: Archbishop Asks His Clergy To Test a Vaccine for AIDS
description: Nuns and priests in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles who are 65 years old or older have been asked to volunteer to be inoculated with an experimental AIDS vaccine.

title: A Freer, but Shrinking, Market
description: In Eastern Europe, Hungary is leading the way in shifting trade away from the Soviet Union and toward the West. The abrupt about-face has jolted many Hungarian companies that grew fat and happy relying on the huge Soviet market.

title: HAITI, NEAR CHAOS, GROPES FOR LEADER
description: Haiti was a country without a government today as political leaders failed to find a replacement for Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, who resigned on Saturday but did not immediately leave the country.

title: A School in the Bronx That Is Somehow Making It
description: Last spring, the rain began leaking into the small room on the fourth floor of the northern Bronx elementary school where Louise Warren teaches reading and writing to students who have fallen behind.

title: Chronicle
description: Bishop EMERSON J. MOORE, JOHN B. CARTER and Dr. BETTY SHABAZZ are to receive the New York Urban League's Frederick Douglass Award, the league's highest honor. The awards will be presented at a dinner on May 3, the 25th anniversary of the award presentation.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Play-by-Play Versus Educational TV
description: LEAD: MANY viewers of televised professional tennis are not only fans but also fanatic players. They would like to be able to play better the next time out than they did the time before they tuned in to a match. But the broadcast team covering the match has to be careful not to turn the telecast into a clinic.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shift on Ad Taxes
description: Gov. Wallace G. Wilkinson of Kentucky has dropped his proposal to impose a 5 percent sales tax on advertising. He made the announcement on Friday.

title: B.C. and Colgate Take Titles
description: Boston College and Colgate were both one goal better than their opponents tonight as they captured the championship matches in two college hockey tournaments.

title: Fire Kills 3 Children in Brooklyn
description: Three young children died Saturday night in a fire that choked their Brooklyn apartment with heavy smoke, and investigators said yesterday that they were searching for a woman who was supposed to be baby-sitting them when the fire broke out.

title: Soviet Georgian Actors Plan Debut in Brooklyn
description: A theater company from the Soviet republic of Georgia is to make its American debut with a production of ''King Lear'' from April 2 to 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section.

title: Vandeweghe Plays And Knicks Win
description: The great Kiki Vandeweghe mystery finally came to an end tonight when the Knick forward dressed for his first road game of the season. But how much of a factor he is going to be in the stretch run remains a significant question.

title: Books of The Times;   What Unmatching Underwear Can Do to Love
description: The Trick of It

title: Medical Examiner Tells Of Girl's Time of Death
description: Kelly Ann Tinyes had been dead for 18 to 24 hours when her body was discovered in a neighbor's basement in March 1989, the Nassau County Medical Examiner said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alliant Computer Systems Corp., Littleton, Mass., a maker of supercomputers, announced the resignation of Robert Lentz, its chief financial officer.

title: Cambridge Bioscience reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
China to Aid Joint Ventures
description: China will spend $210 million this year to bail out foreign joint ventures, including those involving big car makers, hit hard by a tough austerity program.

title: The Big Bailout;   Lawyers Hired by U.S. Thrive on Savings Crisis
description: For lawyers retained by the Government, the savings and loan crisis has been a boom. For many retained by the industry, it could be a bust. It all depends on which side they are on.

title: Swiss Insurer Buys Unit of Reliance
description: The Winterthur Swiss Insurance Company, one of Switzerland's largest insurers, said today that it had acquired a unit of the Philadelphia-based Reliance Insurance Company for $630 million in cash.

title: Carver Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ebenezer T. Breed, 90, Retired L.I. Physician
description: Dr. Ebenezer Thompson Breed, a physician on Long Island and surgeon for the Garden City police and fire departments for more than 35 years, died on Sunday at the health center at Vicar's Landing, a retirement community in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: Officials in Kansas Refuse to Hold Illegal Aliens Because of Jail Costs
description: Morris County officials say they recently picked up 10 illegal aliens for minor offenses but released them at the border of a neighboring county a few days later because of the cost of jailing them.

title: Western Capital Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Heinz (H.J.) Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the share earnings for the latest quarter and year- earlier periods reflect the 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a distribution of shares effective Sept. 27, 1989.

title: Washington Talk;   Hoax Shows the Limits Of Personal Diplomacy
description: In 1979 and in 1980, President Jimmy Carter sent a parade of potential negotiators, including his chief of staff dressed in disguise, three French lawyers, an Argentine businessman, an Egyptian journalist and a former Attorney General, to get American hostages freed.

title: JAPAN INVESTMENT IN U.S. PROPERTY OFF
description: Japanese purchases of United States real estate fell 10.7 percent in 1989, with investment shifting from office buildings to hotels and resort properties, the real estate accounting firm Kenneth Leventhal & Company said today.

title: Bowne & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Review/Television;   Flight From McCarthyism In Film by HBO and BBC
description: The new made-for-cable movie ''Fellow Traveler'' carries some significant credits: It was produced by Home Box Office and the BBC in association with the British Film Institute. The subject of the HBO Showcase presentation - which can be seen tonight at 11:30 - is blacklisting and red-baiting in Hollywood during the 1950's. That's in line with the pay-cable service's stated plan to make films that go beyond standard entertainment to tackle broader and perhaps more sensitive themes.

title: Medicaid Help for AIDS Patients Proposed
description: Unemployed New Yorkers with AIDS would have private health insurance premiums paid for through Medicaid, under legislation proposed today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Grasslands to Desert
description: Overgrazing, inappropriate agriculture and even the use of off-road vehicles have long been linked to turning semi-arid grasslands into desert. Now some researchers say they know the reason: such activities, they say, disrupt cycles that assure relatively even distribution of water and nutrients.

title: Dr. N. J. Pisacano, 65; Headed Medical Board
description: Dr. Nicholas J. Pisacano, a physician who headed the American Board of Family Practice for 20 years, died on Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Lexington, Ky. He was 65 years old.

title: Cuba Seizes Human-Rights Advocates
description: The Cuban security police have rousted at least 11 human-rights advocates from their beds in a series of early-morning raids, searching homes and confiscating papers and books, the Cuban press and rights groups here reported today.

title: Head of Manufacturing Is Appointed at Cadillac
description: Roy S. Roberts, a fast-rising executive who abruptly left General Motors 18 months ago to take a job at Navistar, is returning to G.M. at a rank below his previous one to take over the top manufacturing post at the No. 1 auto maker's Cadillac division.

title: American Museum of Historial Documents reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax gains of $6,000 for the latest quarter and $4,598 for the year-earlier period.

title: Edward Partin, 66; Union Aide Became Anti-Hoffa Witness
description: Edward Grady Partin, a teamsters' union leader whose testimony helped convict James R. Hoffa, the former president of the union, died Sunday at a nursing home here. Mr. Partin, who was 66 years old, suffered from heart disease and diabetes.

title: Woman Killed as Ornate Ceiling Collapses in Ansonia Hotel Shop
description: A once-ornate ceiling in a once-elegant Upper West Side hotel cracked and sent 4,000 pounds of plaster and concrete crashing down in a croissant shop there yesterday, killing one customer at the counter and injuring 16 other people in the store.

title: Tejas Gas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jets Add More Plan B's
description: The Jets, who have acquired more Plan B free agents than any other National Football League team this year, increased their total to seven by picking up two more offensive linemen. One was the Patriots' first draft pick of 1985 - Trevor Matich - and the other was the Chicago Bears' second draft choice last year, Dave Zawatson. Both are 270-pound tackles, bringing to four the number of offensive linemen acquired through Plan B. Matich also is the fourth former Patriots' player acquired by Dick Steinberg, now the Jets' general manager, after a long tenure with New England, where he ran the draft as well as other areas. Matich played with the Patriots until they dropped him before the 1989 opener. He spent the season with Detroit.

title: Poland's Leaders Praise Lithuanian Sovereignty
description: Poland's Solidarity-led Government, which began the unraveling of Soviet domination of Eastern Europe, voiced cautious approval tonight of Lithuania's declaration of independence. Lech Walesa and other Solidarity leaders said they were delighted.

title: Syntrex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Linguistics Professor Named Head of Middlebury College
description: Timothy Light, a professor of linguistics and Asian studies who has been acting president of Kalamazoo College in Michigan since 1989, has been named the 14th president of Middlebury College, the chairman of the college's board of trustees announced in Middlebury, Vt., over the weekend.

title: Andres Wines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Calgene Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Television;   Sad Stories, Happy Endings In New Jane Pauley Venture
description: Anybody whose breath has been bated over what Jane Pauley has been doing since her departure from the ''Today'' show can unbate. She returns to NBC at 10 this evening as host of a special called ''Changes: Conversations With Jane Pauley.''

title: Cabot Medical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
New England Bank Strategy
description: Lawrence K. Fish, who last week became chairman of the Bank of New England Corporation, said today that he plans to reduce the troubled holding company's work force, continue selling assets and possibly sell subsidiaries.

title: Chronicle
description: PEGGY LEE will join FRANK SINATRA, LENA HORNE and ELLA FITZGERALD when she receives the Pied Piper Award of Ascap. The organization's highest accolade, it goes to an entertainer for lifetime achievement. The award has been given nine times in the 28 years since it was established by Ascap, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

title: Rat Study Reignites Dispute On Fluoride
description: A long-smoldering dispute over the safety of fluoridating public water supplies has flared anew, forcing the nation's top health officials to reevaluate the risks and benefits of using fluorides to reduce tooth decay.

title: Chess
description: Jan Timman blundered in the opening of Game 1 of the final world championship candidates' match and lost to Anatoly Karpov on Thursday in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. After Games 2 and 3 were drawn, the score was Karpov 2 and Timman 1.

title: FFP Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,000 for the quarter and $534,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Included a loss of $44,000 for the quarter and income of $106,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. The net for 1989 included a nonrecurring credit of $331,000 (recored in second quarter 1989) attributable to a redetermination of unemployment tax rates for prior year. The 1988 data for discontinued operations was previously reported as equity in earnings of nonconsolidated subsidiary.

title: Completions Of Homes Up
description: Aided by record warm weather in January, the number of newly finished homes rose by 9.2 percent from December's levels, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.42 million units, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Subway Suspect Seeks Witnesses
description: A Manhattan man facing indictment in the beating death of a homeless man on a subway platform has asked a state judge to allow a grand jury to hear four witnesses whom he believes will be favorable to his case, defense lawyers said yesterday.

title: Birth Weight Trend Causes Concern
description: Atlanta, March 12 (AP) - After 10 years of improvement, the percentage of babies whose weight is low at birth is increasing, Federal experts in infant health say. Low birth weight is linked to infant mortality.

title: Strikers Vote on Contract for Replacements
description: Workers at an International Paper Company mill are awaiting results of an unusual election in which striking union members voted on a contract offered to their nonunion replacements.

title: Late Spring Could Slow Gooden's 1990 Debut
description: Scratch Dwight Gooden from opening day. In fact, the Mets say, scratch opening day. And, for that matter, scratch Gooden for probably the first week of the season, whenever it opens.

title: Tandem Planning A.T.& T. Venture
description: Tandem Computers Inc. said it would announce a strategic relationship with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Tuesday. The companies did not disclose the nature of the relationship, but industry sources said it was likely to be an agreement to jointly market Tandem's new S-2 system.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States Government is now the single largest operator of financial institutions, dwarfing Citibank, and yet we are doing little more than marking time.''

title: Efforts to Halt Wetland Loss Turn Their Attention Inland
description: A new and contentious phase has opened in the struggle over the future of the millions of acres of marshes, swamps, bogs, prairie potholes and bottom lands that not only provide an irreplaceable habitat for wildlife but also help replenish the nation's water supplies and control its floods.

title: Mongolian Politburo Urges An End to One-Party Rule
description: Responding to a growing democracy movement in this Communist nation, the Politburo proposed today that the ruling party give up its monopoly on power and that officials and dissidents work together on a new constitution. Under the new charter, rival political parties would apparently be able to compete in democratic elections.

title: Regan Warns of a Budget With a Gap of $1.5 Billion
description: Comptroller Edward V. Regan warned today that he would not approve a new state budget unless Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders found a way to close a budget gap he estimated at $1.5 billion.

title: Apple Authorizes Stock-Buying Plan
description: Apple Computer Inc. said its board had agreed to buy back up to five million shares of its common stock, or about 4 percent of its total outstanding, in the open market from time to time. Since July 1986, Apple has completed three share-repurchase programs, buying 20 million shares of common stock. It had 125 million shares outstanding on Dec. 31, the end of 1990's first fiscal quarter.

title: Hampton Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income Hampton said actual shares outstanding at Dec. 30, 1989, were 4,290,780, compared to 3,900,910 a year earlier. The company said product costs increased during the latest year because of a reduction in plant production utilization. In addition, the LIFO inventory provision during the 1989 quarter was about $500,000 higher than a year ago.

description: * Chrysler Canada Ltd., a unit of Chrysler Corp., said it would extend for two extra weeks the annual two-week summer shutdown at its minivan plant in Windsor, Ontario, to retool for new vehicles.

description: A vital witness in the impending Bensonhurst murder trial dealt the prosecution a major blow yesterday by telling the Brooklyn District Attorney that he would not keep his pledge to testify in New York City's most notorious racial case since Howard Beach.

description: Stocks seesawed in light trading yesterday, with the 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average ending the day up 3.38 points, to 2,686.71.

title: Study of Big Board Trading Limits Sought
description: The investigative arm of Congress said today that because of increased volatility in the securities markets over the last decade there was a need for a review of a key New York Stock Exchange rule that limits trading in listed securities to the Big Board or one of four regional exchanges.

description: Arab nomads and tribal farmers clashed in the western Sudan in the latest outbreak of an ancient feud over grazing rights, killing 69 people and burning down 14 villages, the Sudan News Agency reported today.

It is owned by MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., a company controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, and by the Texas banker Gerald J. Ford. The Ford Motor Company has no stake in it.

title: Suited for Work
description: Fashion in the office has taken a truly odd turn. Sit at a typical in-office meeting and it's hard to miss. The men, mostly, come without their jackets. The women, to a woman, come with their jackets on. Men show no compunction about displaying generous paunches. Women hide their unbusiness-like chests and not-so-flat stomachs.

description: Jose Canseco, the Oakland A's outfielder, picked off someone trying to steal. But it wasn't a base the culprit was after; it was Canseco's boat.

Raymond McCron, 69, Ex-Insurance Executive
description: Raymond C. McCron, former senior vice president and treasurer of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died of lung cancer on Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Chinese Party Calls for Closer Ties to Masses
description: In an acknowledgment of the gulf between China's leadership and its people, the Communist Party's Central Committee called today for stronger ties to ordinary citizens.

description: The space station Mir, the centerpiece of the Soviet program for the manned exploration of space, is limping toward a bittersweet milestone late this month.

title: Publishing Houses Run Short of Copy Editors
description: ''They are brachycephalic, web-footed cretins who ought to be in an institution learning how to make brooms.'' Florence King, a writer, was talking about copy editors.

title: Quirky Britain in Fashion's Sea
description: For an hour Sunday evening Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher chatted about fashion and seemed to be enjoying herself in the midst of turmoil here over taxes, economics and her leadership of the Conservative Party. She wore a tailored dinner suit of plum-colored brocade with a long, slender skirt by Aquascutum as she moved among the 500 people, members of the British fashion industry and their guests, at a Government reception at Lancaster House. It was an entertaining time for those attending the fall and winter fashion shows.

title: Ho Ryun Kang, 64, Ex-South Korean Aide
description: Ho Ryun Kang, a retired executive and former military officer and government administrator in South Korea, died of heart failure on Sunday at Our Lady of Lourdes Medical Center in Camden, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Lakewood, N.J.

description: The company said share earnings are restated for a 5-for-4 stock split last January.

title: An Athlete's Health And a Doctor's Warning
description: Dr. Milton J. Sands Jr. knew a lot was at stake as soon as he met Tony Penny in the coronary care unit of New Britain General Hospital. Mr. Penny was suffering chest pains and Dr. Sands suspected he had a serious heart problem. But even more troubling was that Mr. Penny was a college basketball player, and Dr. Sands feared his diagnosis would end a promising athletic career and a chance to emerge from poverty.

title: Political Memo;   Shadow Cast By Dukakis Over Cuomo
description: He's a Northeastern, liberal Governor with a Mediterranean heritage. He used to brag about his state's prosperity but now is beset by financial difficulties. And as New York's budget problems mount, politicians here are posing the inevitable question: Is Mario Cuomo at risk of becoming the next Michael Dukakis?

title: Why Lockheed Is Under Siege
description: Executives of the Lockheed Corporation, like those of many military contractors, have had a nightmare in recent years: that the depressed stock price and poor earnings record of the company, combined with its rich store of technology, will attract a corporate raider.

title: Managua Journal;   Sandinistas' Foreign Legion Is Faithful in Defeat
description: For 329 Thursdays in a row, dozens of American residents of Nicaragua have demonstrated in front of the American Embassy to show their support for the Sandinista revolution. At their latest demonstration, however, their usual denunciations of United States policy were mixed with uncertainty about the future of their own ''internationalist solidarity'' efforts.

title: Political Memo;   In Texas, the Negative Ad Is Losing
description: As campaigning for the Texas gubernatorial primaries reached a peak last week, secret negotiations were conducted by two high-priced media consultants, each representing a top contender in the Republican race.

title: Hope in Haiti. Yes, Haiti.
description: It's easy to wring hands about Haiti, the hemisphere's poorest nation and one with virtually no democratic tradition. In the 49 months since Jean-Claude Duvalier fell, four more governments have failed. Gen. Prosper Avril, the latest strongman, has now been prodded into exile. The free elections first promised for 1987 have not been held. Military men linked to the Duvalier regime have never relinquished real power.

description: With an area of about 600,000 square miles, Mongolia is slightly smaller than Arizona, New Mexico, Texas and Louisiana combined. The capital is Ulan Bator, with a 1986 population of about 500,000.

Nixon misidentified the building in which the House Judiciary Committee met to consider articles of impeachment against Mr. Nixon. It was the Rayburn House Office Building; the Russell Senate Office Building is on the other side of the Capitol.
