description: The last time that Kiki Vandeweghe played against the Bulls was in the sixth game of the Eastern Conference semifinal in Chicago on May 19. The Knicks were a running, pressing team that did not execute well in a half-court offense.

title: Suit Says Grandchild Got Cancer From DES
description: The parents of a 13-year-old girl who died from a rare vaginal cancer filed suit yesterday against Eli Lilly & Company, charging that the girl developed the illness because her grandmother took the drug DES while pregnant.

title: Modesto Journal;   'Cruising' Is Still Alive, but Not Well
description: On balmy weekend nights in this town made famous by the movie ''American Graffiti,'' McHenry Avenue is bumper to bumper with teen-agers headed nowhere, the boys on the prowl for girls and vice versa.

title: Patrick R. Fiorilli, Mayor, 59
description: Patrick R. Fiorilli, the former mayor who organized annual dandelion and eggplant festivals in Vineland, died at his home here on Sunday. He was 59 years old.

title: Celebrating a Life Steeped in Art, Friends Honor Elaine de Kooning
description: More than two dozen artists, writers, art critics, friends and former students paid tribute to Elaine de Kooning, the painter, art writer, teacher and wife of Willem de Kooning at a memorial service last night at Cooper Union in Manhattan. Mrs. de Kooning died of lung cancer on Feb. 1, 1989.

title: In the Wings, 3 New Ways to Handle Data
description: The three most popular basic software systems for personal computers are scheduled for overhauls and facelifts between now and the end of the year, and judging from the enthusiastic reports of people who have seen the prototypes, the changes will be welcomed by most computer users. DOS-Windows version 3.0, OS/2 version 2.0 and Macintosh System 7.0 are all expected to make computers easier to use, more powerful and more versatile.

title: Bush's Comment on Israel Divides U.S. Jews
description: President Bush's recent statement that in effect raised questions about Israel's claim to East Jerusalem has set off a dispute among some leaders of American Jewish organizations.

title: Luxembourg Watchdog
description: The Government of Luxembourg plans to establish a stock market watchdog agency to deal with insider trading, a Finance Ministry official said today. The planned bourse commissariat is part of draft legislation approved recently by the Government making insider trading a criminal offense, said the official, who asked not to be identified.

title: Property Trust of America reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $33,000, or 1 cent a share, on the sale of investments. The company said 1989 results were substantially affected by the inclusion of about $1,615,000 of costs incurred in connection with protecting shareholders against a hostile takeover attempt by Realty Acquisition Corp.

title: Babbages Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $96,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $138,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year.

title: Albany Is Asked to Speed Plan to Replace Tokens
description: New York City transit officials asked a state board today to speed the development of an automated fare collection system for subways and buses by diverting $162 million from other projects.

title: Augusta Wales Thomas, Lecturer, 87
description: Augusta Wales Thomas, a teacher and lecturer on flowers, gardens and restorations, died of pnuemonia on March 2 at a nursing home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 87 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Bias Is Rampant In Construction, Hearing Is Told
description: A New York City hearing on discrimination in the construction field heard a parade of witnesses yesterday describe sexual harassment of women on the job and discrimination against minority workers in hiring and advancement.

title: Market Facts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Replacement Workers: Management's Big Gun
description: To keep operating in a strike, more and more companies have been deploying a weapon they long shunned -hiring permanent replacements for workers who are on the picket lines.

title: Chronicle
description: Preaching and keeping the faith, TAMMY FAYE BAKKER made a comeback Sunday in the new home of the New Covenant Church in an industrial park southeast of Orlando, Fla. Mrs. Bakker, whose husband is the former television evangelist JIM BAKKER, said supporters had financed the new church.

title: John W. Larsen, 75, A Former Executive At Bowery Savings
description: John W. Larsen, a former president and vice chairman of the Bowery Savings Bank, died on Sunday at his home in West New York, N.J., after suffering a stroke. He was 75 years old.

title: Copper Miners Strike in Peru
description: Workers in Peru's vital copper mining industry went on strike today for better pay, adding to a wave of labor unrest less than a month before presidential elections. The walkout by workers at the Southern Peru Copper Corporation shut down the country's biggest copper mine, the Cuajone pit near the Chilean border, and its main copper smelter, a company spokesman said.

title: Archive Agrees to Buy Cipher Data
description: The Archive Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire Cipher Data Products Inc. for $8.25 a share, or about $114 million, ending a three-month-long takeover fight.

title: 40 at Random House Critical of Pantheon
description: Forty Random House editors and publishers issued a statement yesterday supporting Pantheon's ''high editorial standards'' but faulting Pantheon as not having practiced fiscal responsibility. ''There is no reason,'' the statement added, ''why Pantheon shouldn't live by the same fiscal rules as the rest of us at Random House and throughout the industry.''

title: West German Star, Pleasant and Plump, Ponders Her Appeal
description: These days, the West German film star Marianne Sagebrecht is finally beginning to accept the reality that she is recognized wherever she goes in the United States or Europe. But she says she still can't believe that so many men, women and children want to hug her.

title: 2d Suspect in Slaying Of Parents Surrenders
description: The second of two brothers accused of killing their parents at the family's Beverly Hills mansion last year surrendered to the authorities Sunday, the police said.

title: Rhone-Poulenc Link With Rorer Detailed
description: Announcing a definitive agreement to merge their drug businesses, Rhone-Poulenc S.A. and the Rorer Group said yesterday that Rhone-Poulenc would put up $1.68 billion in cash.

title: VW Deal For Venture In East Bloc
description: Volkswagen A.G., West Germany's biggest auto maker, today disclosed the biggest joint venture to date with East Germany, a $3 billion pact to build Volkswagens at sites where East Germany's Trabant autos are now produced.

title: Mary F. Goldson, 55, Social Work Professor
description: Mary Funnye Goldson, an associate professor at the Columbia University School of Social Work and a specialist in developing programs for families and children, died of cancer on Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Muslim Militants Are Seized In Egyptian Religious Strife
description: The police today arrested 11 Muslim militants accused of fanning sectarian violence, and their leader was reportedly electrocuted when he jumped out a window onto power lines while fleeing the authorities, an official said.

title: White House Sees 'Room to Talk' In Democrat's Plan on the Deficit
description: The Bush Administration signaled interest today in Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan to raise certain taxes and freeze domestic spending, while Democratic colleagues of the House Ways and Means Committee chairman responded with far more caution.

title: Raiders Planning Return to Oakland
description: Lionel Wilson, the Mayor of Oakland, received a telephone call today that he and the entire city have awaited for 13 months: on the line was Al Davis, who said the Los Angeles Raiders would, indeed, return to Oakland.

title: East Berlin Premier, In Letter to a Rabbi, Sees Some Nazi Peril
description: In a letter signed by an aide, Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany is quoted as saying that there is some basis for fears about a resurgence of nationalism, racism and anti-Semitism in East Germany as the two Germanys move toward union.

description: The citizens of the newly proclaimed state of Lithuania woke up today with a case of morning-after anxiety, the pride in their announced secession from the Soviet Union tempered by doubts about how and when it might disrupt their lives.

description: MCA Inc. agreed today to sell its money-losing LNJ Toys Ltd. subsidiary to Acclaim Entertainment Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash and Acclaim stock that sources said would total about $30 million.

title: For Macy, a Bitter Pill to Swallow
description: Afflicted by continuing high debt and costly competitive pressures, R. H. Macy & Company has been carefully preparing its investors, lenders, employees and suppliers for another bitter pill to swallow on quarterly losses.

Escort Price Raised
description: The Ford Motor Company said the average price of its 1991 Ford Escort car with popular options would be about 2.5 percent more than comparably equipped 1990 models. Base prices for two-door, four-door and station wagon models will range from $7,565 to $11,063. The new Escort, made at Ford's assembly plant in Wayne, Mich., will go on sale April 26. Ford also said it was increasing prices of some options on all cars except Escort and Festiva by $29 because of increased costs.

description: With the cheers from Chile's return to democracy still ringing in his ears, President Patricio Aylwin moved today to address the most troublesome problem he has inherited: old political crimes and political prisoners.

title: Ex-Captain of Tanker Blames Mate for Spill
description: A former tanker captain today blamed the third mate for the grounding of the Exxon Valdez, but conceded under cross-examination that the accident would probably not have happened if Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood had stayed on the bridge instead of going below.

title: New Jersey Court Voids 14th Death Sentence
description: The State Supreme Court today reversed its 14th death sentence in a row. The court ruled that there was insufficient evidence surrounding the confession of a man who had pleaded guilty to killing a pizzeria owner in Maplewood.

title: Salk Team Expands AIDS Vaccine Study
description: Dr. Jonas Salk and his research associates are expanding an experimental AIDS immunization program, spokesmen for Dr. Salk and the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday.

title: 'I'm Really Home but Screening Your Call'
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: Fashion vs. Comfort

title: Cablevision Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed 1989 losses to additional interest and depreciation and amortization expenses related to acquisitions during the year and in 1988.

title: Review/Art;   Landscapes Show Rembrandt's Peaceful Side
description: ''Rembrandt's Landscapes: Drawings and Prints,'' which opened Sunday at the National Gallery of Art, will give pleasure to anyone who likes Rembrandt and anyone who likes prints and drawings. What the exhibition will not do is provide a way of coming to terms with the polemics that have thrown almost everything about Rembrandt into question. These 99 works on paper seem as removed from the turmoil of recent Rembrandt scholarship as they seem untouched by the emotional swells and dramatic turbulence of Rembrandt's painting.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

A Traditional Leader For Columbia Savings
description: LEAD: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, which ran into trouble over its large ''junk bond'' holdings, has turned to an executive with a background in traditional lending and banking to be its new president and chief executive.

title: Deltak Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
National Semiconductor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Included gain on sale of discontinued operations of $45.1 million, less loss from discontinued operations of $4.8 million. c-Included gain on sale of discontinued operations of $45.1 million, less loss from discontinued operations of $37.7 million. The fiscal 1990 results included the reversal of certain non-recurring accrued expenses determined to be in excess of anticipated requirements. The credits amounted to $4.6 million in the current quarter and $8.9 million for the year-to-date. The charges were originally recorded in connection with the restructuring of certain Semiconductor operations announced in fiscal 1989. The $4.6 million credit primarily reflected lower costs than originally anticipated for the closure of operations at the Danbury, Conn., facility. In addition, the results of operations included $6.7 million and $10.6 million for the quarter and year-to- date, respectively, which reflected other non-recurring credit amounts. The third quarter amount included a $2.5 million gain associated with the sale of certain of National's photomask manufacturing operations to Du Pont Photomasks Inc., a Texas corporation, for $7.6 million.

title: A Final Salute for Hank Gathers;   Player's Funeral Brings Out the Best in Philadelphia
description: Eric Wilson Gathers was buried today, 20 miles from the Henry Rosen Projects where he was born and 3,000 miles from the cozy Loyola Marymount campus in Los Angeles, where he collapsed during a game on March 4 and died in a nearby hospital, less than a month after celebrating his 23d birthday.

title: Cavco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Curtail Chairmanships
description: To the Editor:

title: Polifly Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest periods is the result of a specific reduction of $14.1 million in the book value of certain real estate assets and a $5.2 million addition to the provision for posible loan losses primarily due to the depressed New Jersey real estate market. Polifly's loss for the quarter takes into account the available tax benefits of $3.8 million resulting from the losses and pre-tax operating income of $800,000 earned in the period.

title: West Bank Holds Small Appeal for Soviet Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Maker Had Deficit In 3d Quarter
description: After just a quarter of profitability, the National Semiconductor Corporation fell back into the red in its third fiscal quarter ended Feb. 25. The company today attributed the $10.2 million loss to pricing pressures on electronically programmable read only memory chips, or Eproms, a typical seasonal sales slowdown and the annual two-week closing of its production operations for the holidays.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Is It a Film? Is It an Ad? Harder to Tell
description: WHEN Pauline Kael, the film critic for The New Yorker, entitled the first collection of her criticism ''I Lost It at the Movies,'' the ''it'' presumably was a whimsical reference to her innocence and insularity.

title: The Big Bailout;   Federal Holding of Risky 'Junk Bonds' Grows
description: If the Federal Government keeps taking over ailing savings institutions, it may become the largest holder of ''junk bonds'' by the end of this year, analysts say.

title: Big Effort Is Begun To Reverse Decline Of Turtles
description: Turtles crawled the earth and swam in its waters before the dinosaurs appeared. Now they are facing the first broad-scale threat to their future in 200 million years, and some of the world's leading conservation organizations are gearing up to combat it.

title: The Royal Prerogative
description: The trial of John Poindexter should make us reflect on the Iran-contra affair: not the particular charges to be decided by a jury but the larger meaning. Why did it matter?

title: Oppenheimer Capital L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Oppenheimer Capital L.P. owns a 32.2 percent general interest in Oppenheimer Capital, an independent investment management firm.

title: On Horse Racing;   Backlash and Concern Over Japanese Buyers
description: rrWhen word got around last week that Japanese breeders were bidding to buy Sunday Silence as a stallion prospect, no one was overheard remarking what a boost he might bring to that nation's breeding industry.

title: North Tells of Document Destruction
description: Oliver L. North testified today that he saw John M. Poindexter tear up a potentially embarrassing order signed by President Ronald Reagan that authorized United States participation in secret arms sales.

title: Chip Report Shows Gain
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued to rebound in February as United States semiconductor orders declined slightly but shipments increased, a trade group reported today.

title: Gene Klein, 69, Sold N.F.L. Club And Later Owned Derby Winner
description: Gene Klein, the former owner of the San Diego Chargers of the National Football League and later a successful owner of thoroughbred race horses, died after apparently suffering a heart attack yesterday morning in California. He was 69 years old and had been in failing health for some time.

title: Business and Health;   Research Outlays To Aid the Aging
description: MEDICAL experts and their supporters in the business community are putting pressure on Congress to spend more for basic research on a number of illnesses that make life miserable and expensive for millions of elderly Americans.

title: Market Place;   Nortek Settles Complaint Of Lying on Stock Purchase
description: A longtime corporate raider, Nortek Inc., was accused yesterday of lying to the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing regarding its efforts to acquire another company.

title: United Cos Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Announces Order For Changes in DC-10's
description: The Government announced orders today that all DC-10 airliners be modified so they can be controlled when their hydraulic systems are damaged.

title: Players Association Shifts Tactics
description: While the league presidents delayed a decision on the cancellation of the baseball season openers, the Players Association took a step yesterday to strike an economic blow in their labor dispute with the owners.

title: William F. Raborn Is Dead at 84; Led Production of Polaris Missile
description: William F. Raborn Jr., a retired Navy vice admiral who led the development of the Polaris nuclear missile in the 1950's and later headed the Central Intelligence Agency under President Lyndon B. Johnson, died of cardiac arrest on March 7 at his home in McLean, Va. He was 84 years old.

title: Heart Tests To Focus On Women
description: The first large study of women and heart disease is being undertaken by the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions and six other medical centers after decades of research devoted solely to heart disease in men.

title: Abatix Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Warning: RJR May Endanger Kids' Health
description: The following is adapted from a letter written by Mark Green, New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, to Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of RJR Nabisco Inc.

title: Prenor Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the increase in revenue reflected, among other things, the acquisition of Canwest Trust last May. It said the gain in net income is mainly due to a gain on the sale of its 50 percent interest in a real estate company. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: Operating losses incurred in the closing down of four stores in January 1989 totaled $950,000, reducing year- ago quarter's net income by 50 cents a share.

title: Chronicle
description: HARRY B. HELMSLEY, whose wife, LEONA, is appealing a Federal income-tax fraud conviction, was admitted to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center yesterday after falling down a flight of stairs in his apartment at the Park Lane, said spokesman for the reala-estate and hotel executive.

title: The Big Bailout    A special report.;   U.S. HAS TROUBLE COPING WITH ITS SAVINGS EMPIRE
description: Seven months after President Bush signed into law the largest Federal bailout in history, savings and loan regulators are mired in bureaucratic bickering and frustrated by their inability to sell off hundreds of sick savings institutions quickly.

title: Simetco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $135,000 for both periods. c-After an extraordinary credit of $8,601,000 for the quarter and year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Tournament Will End Emotional Season;   All Except One Team Will Share the Inevitable Heartbreak of Being Defeated
description: The party invitations have been extended. The party continues to fuel the unprecedented riches that are being manufactured by and for college basketball teams at the end of a season characterized by the despair of tragedy and scandal.

title: Cave of Words
description: This was supposed to be the election year in which Congress tamed its urge to send free mail to constituents. But the House of Representatives seems destined again to overspend its postal allowance.

title: UConn Basketball: The Giddiness Rises
description: Douglas Roberts got the bad news in a telephone call from a friend Sunday night, even as the reality of the University of Connecticut's first Big East basketball championship was sinking in.

title: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
U.S. Lists Rules for Adjusting Census Count, to Dismay of Big Cities
description: The Commerce Department, in a move that stirred deep anger and disappointment among officials of big cities, today established strict tests that must be met before it will adjust the 1990 census figures to compensate for any undercounting of minority groups and poor people in inner cities.

title: Healthcare Services Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MILITARY LEADER AGREES TO LEAVE HAITI FOR THE U.S.
description: After what the American Ambassador called a heart-to-heart talk here before dawn today, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril left Haiti aboard a United States Air Force jet, and the only woman who sits as a judge in the country was nominated to be provisional president.

title: H. George Decancq, Engineer, Dies at 88
description: H. George Decancq, who was in charge of construction of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, died of Parkinson's disease last Tuesday in a nursing home in Rochester. He was 88 years old and had lived in Lakehurst, N.J., until he entered the nursing home three years ago.

title: Labor Closer to Split With Likud
description: As compromise efforts foundered, the Israeli Government moved closer to dissolution today when the Labor Party's governing body agreed to give Labor Cabinet ministers the power to end their coalition with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his Likud party.

title: Advanced Polymer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sales Spurt in Britain
description: Britain said today that retail sales rose by 2.4 percent in February. January's adjusted figure showed a fall of nine-tenths of a percent. Participants in investment markets had expected a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in February.

title: Paul Harris Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Net loss Results reflected a 14-week quarter and 53-week year for fiscal 1990, while the year-ago periods consisted of a 13- week quarter and 52-week year.

title: Yanks' Sax Is Playing The One Game in Town
description: The sun broke through again today, but there was still no baseball.

title: For Capriati, All the Magic and a Check
description: Jennifer Capriati's Big Adventure: A whirlwind week in Boca Raton, Fla., where she scared the proverbial pants off every Virginia Slims of Florida contestant she faced, including the one who finally beat her. A luncheon date at the condo of her favorite player and unofficial big sister, Chris Evert. A bunch of status symbol fans like Wilt Chamberlain and Gary Carter watching from the v.i.p. box. A cheerful high-five for the woman who defeated her, Gabriela Sabatini. A check for $28,000 for her troubles. Another hug for her father, the captain of her career, and an ingenuous acceptance speech in which she thanked her mother for making sacrifices and pledged ''a lot of love'' to her younger brother.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Restaurant Associates, a theme restaurant and food service operator, to Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis/Tracy-Locke, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Fighting the Deficit Too Bravely
description: ''I've participated in the binge of irresponsibility,'' says Representative Dan Rostenkowski. ''But, no more,'' vows the blunt chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Writing in The Washington Post, Mr. Rostenkowski outlines a bold plan to attack the Federal budget deficit with a combination of new taxes and spending cuts.

title: Met-Pro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Bonar Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 2
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Doubt Cast On Theory Of Changes In Genes
description: Scientists have challenged an unconventional idea that bacteria could purposefully alter their genes in beneficial ways.

title: Beame Is Hospitalized With Pains in Chest
description: Former Mayor Abraham D. Beame, complaining of chest pains, was taken by ambulance to Bellevue Medical Center late last night for tests, hospital officials said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * James Cannon has been promoted to vice chairman of BBDO Worldwide.

title: Aide Differs With Cheney on the Soviet Threat
description: Differing with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, a top Pentagon expert on Soviet affairs has endorsed the assessment of William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, that there is little chance of renewed Soviet dominance over Eastern Europe if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ousted by hard-liners.

title: East Germany's New Ideal: Prosperity Above All
description: This Saxon village is trim and prosperous enough to be in West Germany, yet its people cannot be sure that it will be allowed to survive.

title: Disputed Art Show to Go to Corcoran       Special to The New York Times
description: A traveling exhibition of the work of contemporary American and Soviet artists will open at the Corcoran Gallery of Art as scheduled on April 21, minus the work of one artist.

title: Insituform of North America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
As Romanian Elections Near, Politics Looks for a Direction
description: Romania's interim Parliament has had one thing in common with the United States Congress in recent days - delays. It had set itself the task of voting on two new laws. Instead, it debated politely, then postponed the vote until the following week.

title: Soviet Study Of Fed Set
description: Facing the task of establishing a new financial system to accommodate moves toward a market-oriented economy, two Soviet officials will take a first-hand look this week at the United States central bank and financial regulatory system.

title: KEY RATES
Tass Reports Arrests of 31 At Moscow Demonstration
description: The police arrested 31 people today at an unauthorized demonstration in which protesters shouted anti-Communist slogans, the official news agency Tass reported.

title: GORBACHEV CALLS LITHUANIA'S MOVE AN 'ALARMING' STEP
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today described Lithuania's declaration of independence as ''alarming,'' but he gave no indication of what the Kremlin's next move would be.

title: American Stores reports earnings for 14wks to Feb 3
description: Latest fourth quarter operating profits included a pretax charge of $32.5 million, compared to a pretax charge of $20,000,000 in the year-ago quarter for the company's Salmonella litigation. The litigation relates to the 1985 Salmonella incident at the company's Jewel Companies Inc. subsidiary. Latest year earnings included non- recurring gains on the sale of assets of 59 cents a share, including a gain of 12 cents a share realized in the fourth quarter from the disposition of assets. The company said the results of Lucky Stores Inc. are included from June 2, 1988.

title: Careers;   Environment Courses in M.B.A. Study
description: DUBBED ''trash and cash'' by students, a course with the formal title of ''Managing Environmental Issues'' attracted its quota of 25 master of business administration candidates last fall at the Boston University School of Management.

title: Optek Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Net income

title: Consolidated-Tomoka reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Evans, a Swimmer, Voted Top Amateur
description: Janet Evans, who set one world record and two American marks in swimming last year, won the Sullivan Award as the nation's top amateur athlete last night in Indianapolis. The award, presented by the Amateur Athletic Union, was based on accomplishments in 1989. Evans, an 18-year-old freshman at Stanford, was a finalist for the third consecutive year. A triple gold medalist in the 1988 Olympics, she set a world record last year in the 800-meter freestyle and American records in the 1,000 and 1,650-yard freestyles. The winner was determined in national voting by about 2,500 people, including members of the news media, past winners and the board of directors from the A.A.U. and U.S.O.C. The A.A.U. does not release the voting. (AP)

title: Crum Defends Spencer
description: Denny Crum, the Louisville coach, said yesterday that Felton Spencer, the Cardinals' starting center, would not have been arrested on reckless driving charges in Kentucky had he not been an athlete. ''Had it been anybody not in athletics, there would have been no questions,'' Crum said. ''It would have been a simple speeding violation.'' A Stanford, Ky., police officer reported driving 90 miles an hour to catch up with Spencer, who was briefly jailed Sunday following his arrest in Lincoln County before being released on bond. (AP)

title: Ms. Sabol's Agenda of Crises
description: It should not have taken Mayor David Dinkins of New York four months to find a Commissioner of Human Resources, but his choice is promising. Barbara Sabol, a 16-year veteran administrator at Federal and state social service agencies, has a solid reputation as an independent manager.

title: Luby's Cafeterias reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
School Panel Gets Accounts Of Corruption
description: Widening the picture of corruption in New York City's local school districts, two Brooklyn superintendents have told an investigative panel that they were pressured to hire relatives and friends of school board members. At stake for one superintendent was the renewal of his contract.

title: American Airlines
description: American Airlines Inc. said Monday it would add 39 domestic flights beginning next month, including two cross-country flights from Newark to Los Angeles. American also exercised options to buy seven MD-11 jumbo jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The expansion also includes service at Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and daily flights between Miami and both Newark and New York's Kennedy Airport - as well as new flights serving Dallas, Chicago and North Carolina.

title: A Shell Program That Really Shields You
description: There are essentially two kinds of people with hard disks in their computer systems: those who admit their files are a mess and those who lie about it.

title: Louis Maltese, Cyclist And Race Director, 83
description: Louis Maltese, a former bicycle racer who for decades promoted bike races around New York City and throughout the country, died after suffering cardiac failure on Saturday at his home in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 83 years old.

title: National Security Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Astrosystems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bush to Seek $300 Million in Funds for Chamorro
description: President Bush will ask Congress this week to provide the newly elected government of Nicaragua with $300 million in assistance to rehabilitate the country's war-ravaged economy, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Florida Bank Ratings Cut
description: Warning that the Florida real estate market faces a period of weakness, Moody's Investors Service on Friday reduced its ratings on Barnett Banks Inc. and the Southeast Banking Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Ukrainians demonstrating in Kharkov mistranslated signs carried by the demonstrators. They generally supported President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and perestroika; they did not call for his resignation.

title: Review/Dance;   Oakland Ballet's 'Giselle'
description: One of the most eloquent works of the 19th century, ''Giselle'' is also one of the most durable and adaptable of ballet's classics. It can look splendid when performed by a large ensemble in a great opera house. But because of its poignant scenario, it can be equally effective when danced by a small company on a small stage.

title: Soviet Congress Debates New Presidency
description: The Soviet Parliament struggled with the nation's long history of centralized and dictatorial authority today as critics and proponents agreed that the executive powers proposed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would give him broad new control over the life of the nation.

title: Peerless Tube Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a credit of $428,941 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes. The 1988 periods were restated.

title: Chronicle
description: When MARILYN MONROE died in 1962, she left 75 percent of her estate to LEE STRASBERG, who had been her coach at the Actors' Studio, and 25 percent to DR. MARIANNE KRIS, her psychiatrist. Yesterday ANNA STRASBERG, Mr. Strasberg's widow, lost her challenge to get control of that 25 percent of the estate.

title: Stuart Rosenberg, 67, A Rabbi and Author
description: Rabbi Stuart E. Rosenberg, a spiritual leader of Canada's Jews and an author, died of cancer yesterday in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had a winter home. He was 67 years old and also lived in Toronto.

title: F.A.A. Faulted on Crew That Drank
description: The chairman of a Congressional aviation subcommittee said today that a Federal safety inspector who allowed a Northwest Airlines jet to take off last week despite a tip that the crew had been drinking was poorly trained and should have tried to stop the flight.

title: Kollmorgen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,567,000 for the quarter and $12,915,000 for the year. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $712,000, or 7 cents a share and $8,165,000, or 77 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest quarter and year's losses from continuing operations of $14,658,000 and $18,898,000, respectively, included charges of $3.2 million in the quarter and $7 million in the year related to merger termination expenses, $9.5 million related to restructuring costs and $4 million related to unanticipated costs on a long-term military development program. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Review/Music;   Bernstein's Latest Thoughts on 2 of His Specialties
description: The Vienna Philharmonic ended its five-concert residency at Carnegie Hall with a Sunday afternoon program devoted to Leonard Bernstein's latest thoughts on Mahler's orchestral songs and Sibelius's First Symphony. The orchestra's ravishing sound, a joy on its own terms, was especially reassuring after the uneven Bruckner Ninth the ensemble unleashed on Friday evening.

title: Canal Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and included $391,000 income from discontinued operations.

title: Soviets, in Protest, Say C.I.A. Maligns the K.G.B.
description: Stung by a defector's charge that the K.G.B. once conspired to assassinate Pope John Paul II, the Soviet Union said today that it had complained strongly to the State Department that such accusations were ''clearly'' engineered by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Suspect Is Said To Tell of Setting Boy, 12, on Fire
description: A police detective told a Family Court judge yesterday that a 13-year-old suspect gave him a detailed description of tying up a young victim and setting him afire last Wednesday in Brooklyn.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Inch Up
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in sluggish trading yesterday, largely on continued strength in the dollar. Traders said a dip in the price of oil and other commodities also provided support, but for the most part activity was listless.

title: Nicaraguans on Both Sides Praise Embargo's End
description: After five years of deepening economic hardship, much of it attributable to United States sanctions, Sandinista officials and opposition business leaders today applauded President Bush's decision to end the American embargo on trade with Nicaragua.

title: Staples Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $972,000, or 9 cents a share for the quarter and $1,496,000, or 16 cents a share for the year. c-Net loss The company recently changed its fiscal year end to the last Saturday in January, from the Saturday closest to April 30.

title: Books of The Times;   The Life and Times of Goring, as Fiction
description: The Knight, Death and the Devil

title: Auto Dealerships Drop
description: The number of new-car dealerships in the United States fell by 337 last year, a survey by Automotive News has found. It was the largest decline since the early 1980's. The weekly automotive trade journal said on Monday that on Jan. 1, there were 24,576 outlets, compared with 24,913 a year earlier, a decline of 1.4 percent. Automotive News said the nation's Big Three auto makers lost 214 dealerships and overseas-based producers lost the rest.

title: Lady Jaspers Aiming To Beat Long Odds
description: Kathy Solano doesn't mind that at least one Las Vegas oddsmaker has made her Manhattan College basketball team a million-to-one shot to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's tournament. The way she sees it, only 47 schools have been given a better chance.

title: This Month: James O'Shea, Warren, Conn.;   The Troubles That Irish Food Has Seen
description: IN the kitchen of his weekend cottage in this northwest Connecticut village, James O'Shea, preparing an Irish meal for a group of friends, is fighting what he calls ''this amazing American idea of Irish food: that it's corned beef and cabbage and that's it.''

title: Gloom at Saatchi Spawns Anger
description: Maurice Saatchi said today that he and his brother, Charles, were cutting their $1 million salaries by 30 percent and that the other directors of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company were taking 10 percent pay cuts. But angry shareholders at the annual meeting here of the giant advertising and communications company said the cuts were not deep enough.

title: Now You Can Take On the Monster
description: A group of Canadian designers has come up with a new style of video game that permits the player to climb directly into the action. Using a video camera like those that look for shoplifters in stores, the system captures the user's movements and displays them instantaneously in the middle of the video game on the computer screen.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: President of Panama Ends His 13-Day Fast
description: President Guillermo Endara of Panama today ended a 13-day fast begun as ''an act of commiseration with a suffering people'' and as a protest against his country's worsening economic situation.

title: G-III Apparel Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Expert Links Bite Mark on Body to Murder Suspect
description: An expert in forensic dentistry said today that a bite mark on the body of Kelly Ann Tinyes, the Valley Stream teen-ager slain a year ago, was made by Robert Golub.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: OUR friend, the partygoer, writes:

title: Guidelines Issued in Noriega Trial
description: A Federal judge issued a sweeping order today on how lawyers in the drug-trafficking trial of General Manuel Antonio Noriega could handle classified information.

title: Home Loan Banks Offering Bonds
description: The Office of Finance for the Federal Home Loan Banks system priced four bond issues totaling $2.58 billion at par through various securities dealers yesterday.

title: Banque Indosuez Adds Risk-Management Post
description: Richard Sandor, a self-styled financial ''tinkerer'' who has created some of the futures market's most familiar interest-rate products, has been hired to organize a new risk-management unit for Banque Indosuez, the French merchant bank.

title: A Player's Hunger and Thirst And Longing for a Better Life;   Gathers Hoped to Gain Fame and Help His Family
description: Hank Gathers has been dead for almost 10 days and as his family, close friends and teammates begin the healing process, the question that remains unanswered is: How much did the Loyola Marymount star's determination to use basketball as a means to a better life for his family contribute to his untimely death?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Nabisco Brands Agrees To Settle Ad Charges
description: Without admitting wrongdoing, Nabisco Brands has agreed to pay $135,000 in costs to settle charges by 10 state attorneys general that advertising campaigns for several of Nabisco's products misled consumers about the nutritional value of the foods.

title: Chronicle
description: An aura of adulation hovered over the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night, when singers, friends and opera lovers honored two of its most beloved stars, JARMILA NOVOTNA and LICIA ALBANESE. They made their Met debuts 50 years ago, in an era when the Met was more a family than just a stop on the international circuit.

title:
Consumer's Choice In Public Education; A special report.;

Quest for Improving Schools Finds Role for Free Market
description: LEAD: Political leaders, including President Bush and education officials in at least 19 states, are promoting ''school choice'' as a cure for what ails public education. Give people the freedom to choose among schools, the argument goes, and the resulting competition for students will force schools to shape up or shut down.

title: Document Processor Appoints a Chairman
description: Document Technologies Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif., company specializing in image processing products, named Dwight Ryan as chairman and chief executive yesterday. Mr. Ryan, 54 years old, is a 28-year veteran of the Xerox Corporation.

title: Ballet's Ian Horvath Is Recalled In a Program of Words and Dance
description: Friends, colleagues and dance fans filled the Joyce Theater yesterday afternoon to pay tribute to Ian (Ernie) Horvath, producing director for the Jose Limon Dance Foundation, founder of the Cleveland Ballet, and a former soloist with the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater. Mr. Horvath, who was 46, died of AIDS on Jan. 5.

title: House Panel Approves Program Trading Curbs
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee approved a revised measure today that grants the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to curb program trading during times of high volatility in the market.

title: Nanometrics Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax benefits from tax loss carryforwards of $325,000 for the latest year and $230,000 for 1988.

title: Hawkins Chemical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Galtaco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $635,000 from discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Edith F. Lynton, 70, Personnel Economist
description: Edith F. Lynton, a government aide and an economist specializing in staffing problems, died of a heart attack on Monday after being stricken while on a flight from Fort Myers, Fla., to Newark International Airport. She was 70 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Let U.S. Flower Tariff Match Common Market's
description: To the Editor:

title: Uranium Miners Tell Panel Radiation Caused Ailments
description: Hundreds of former uranium miners and their family members, some speaking in their native Navajo, told a United States Senate committee today of ills they attributed to years of being exposed to radiation without being warned and pleaded for the Government to compensate them.

title: Ranger Oil Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $28,637,000, or 36 cents a share for the latest year and $5,222,000, or 7 cents a share for the year-earlier period.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE payroll tax increases of the last decade have hit lower- and middle-income families hardest, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan points out. If the tens of billions in surpluses piling up each year in the the Social Security trust fund are going to be used to paper over the current Federal deficit, he says, why not give working Americans a tax break?

title: Art by Charles Saxon
description: About 70 drawings and watercolors by Charles Saxon, whose cartoons appeared in The New Yorker for 35 years, are on view through June 29 in the Rare Book and Manuscript Library of the Butler Library at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street. The exhibition is in observance of a gift from the artist's widow, Nancy, of 1,900 of his works. Admission is free. Hours: 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Monday to Friday. Information: 854-2231.

title: Chase Plans Commodities Investments
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced plans yesterday to offer investments in commodity funds to institutional investors like pension funds and to wealthy individuals. Chase officials said the bank was the first to propose entering the commodity-fund business.

title: Pratt & Whitney Gets Engine Order
description: The Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation, Hartford, won a $130 million order to supply engines for 10 Boeing 757 aircraft on order by Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services, an Australian aviation concern. Pratt & Whitney said it would supply 20 engines and three spares.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Thursday about Susan Marshall misidentified the director of the World Financial Center's arts and events committee. She is Anita Contini.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Status Is Uncertain For Keye/Donna Team
description: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein is negotiating to sell its small New York office to Della Femina, McNamee WCRS. But Jay Taub and Tod Seisser, the creative team who run the operation, are still pondering their own future.

title: The Pheenom Exceeded Her Billing
description: rrRight about now, you ordinarily would be reading about some pheenom up from the Double-A league. But, hey, baseball ignores us, we ignore it.

title: EDUCATION: Lessons
description: There's an old yarn in academic circles about the state legislator who asked a college professor how much time he spent teaching. The professor, who taught three courses, each for three hours a week, replied, ''Nine hours.''

title: Marietta Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Emirates' Oil View
description: The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, called today for maintaining OPEC's $18-a-barrel reference price. He made the remarks at an oil seminar in Abu Dhabi. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which the Emirates is a member, has been adjusting production ceilings for its 13 member states to stabilize prices at around $18 for a 42-gallon barrel.

title: Reviews/Music;   Blood, Sweat and Oldies In New Alice Cooper Show
description: Alice Cooper was, unfortunately, a pop-culture prophet in the mid-1970's. Long before MTV, he realized that rock could be treated as a theatrical spectacle, and he anticipated slasher movies by putting his hard-rock songs behind blood-spattered, Grand Guignol vignettes. For audiences that wanted jokey titillation, Mr. Cooper became the tasteless entertainment of choice, and every so often he'd come up with a well-made hit single.

title: Fleet Aerospace Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Chief Picked For Comex
description: The members of the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday elected Martin Greenberg, a commodities firm executive and Comex member since 1976, to a two-year term as chairman of the board of governors of the exchange.

title: Nancy S. Ittleson, Foundation Director, 75
description: Nancy S. Ittleson, a member of the board of directors of Phoenix House Foundation, a drug rehabilitation center based in Manhattan, died of cancer on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75 years old.

title: G.O.P.'s Favorite Finds Weicker Complicates the Race
description: It was an ordinary Saturday morning here at the hilltop home of Representative John G. Rowland. Upstairs, Julianne, 9 months old and named for Bruce Springsteen's ex-wife, screamed for a bottle. Downstairs, R.J., 3 years old and named for his granddad, wiggled under his father's arm and cried at the mention of putting on his ''p-a-n-t-s.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Grand Metropolitan Food Sector, Minneapolis, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., London, a food and retailing conglomerate, appointed Chris J. Chamberlain senior vice president for business development. He replaces Gerard M. Murphy, who will work on strategic planning for Grand Metropolitan in London.

title: Salvador Rebels Say They'll Curb Raids
description: Guerrilla leaders announced today that they would stop attacking most nonmilitary targets to pave the way for new peace talks with the Government.

title: Barry Blau & Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said its results for the latest quarter have been materially affected by a decision to write off certain costs amounting to $565,040, incurred in a special merchandise program associated with Citicorp.

title: Xiox Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bruno Bettelheim Dies at 86; Psychoanalyst of Vast Impact
description: Bruno Bettelheim, the psychoanalyst whose deep empathy for children led him to a lifelong effort to heal the emotional wounds of early life, died yesterday at a retirement home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 86 years old.

title: Belmondo Revels in Playing Cyrano in Paris
description: There are neither bedroom scenes nor daring stunts to recall his action-packed movies, yet the part that has brought Jean-Paul Belmondo back to the stage could well have been written for him.

title: Banks Shut By Brazil For 3 Days
description: Brazil's central bank closed the nation's banks late today for the rest of the week until an emergency economic package is announced by President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello.

title: Bridge
description: Every declarer has played a slam that seems easy but suddenly becomes difficult. The struggling South, on the diagramed deal from the Regional Open Pairs on Feb. 17 in Cromwell, Conn., was Gail Greenberg of Manhattan. She is one of 10 women from the New York metropolitan area who have won world titles in the last decade.

title: Topics of The Times;   Detoxifying Households
description: Child-resistant caps on containers have dramatically reduced fatalities, but the toll is still high. About two million children a year ingest toxic household chemicals, accounting for tens of thousands of emergency room visits.

title: DISABLED PROTEST AND ARE ARRESTED
description: More than 100 protesters in wheelchairs were arrested today in the Capitol Rotunda after they boisterously demonstrated for swift passage of a civil rights bill for the millions of Americans with physical and mental disabilities.

title: Filtertek Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Critic's Notebook;   TV News in the Schools: Which Channel, if Any?
description: If more of America's schoolchildren knew the difference between Dan Quayle and Yasir Arafat, the competition between ''Channel One'' and ''CNN Newsroom'' would be moot. Unfortunately, tests of teen-agers keep revealing prodigious ignorance of much of what is going on around them. So the question becomes whether television can do anything to improve a painful condition; and, if so, whether either of the two daily news programs now being offered to schools may help in that job, and whether one is preferable to the other.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Chides Congress On Aid to Panama

title: Washington Talk;   Bush Bashing: Dirty Job, But Gephardt's Doing It
description: President Bush has many friends on Capitol Hill, keeps a locker in the House gym and prides himself on gentlemanly relations with leaders of the House and the Senate.

title: Upheaval in the East;   East German Race Is Neck-and-Neck
description: If the surveys in East Germany's first free election campaign are correct, the Christian Democrats and their partner parties have made strong inroads into what was regarded as the Social Democrats' hold over the electorate.

title: Nassau Cleared to Hire Police
description: Nassau County announced a settlement with the United States Department of Justice today that will allow the county to begin hiring new police officers for the first time in three years.

title: Memo on Weapon Plant Problems Is Inadvertently Sent to Governors
description: A daily briefing paper for Energy Secretary James D. Watkins was inadvertently faxed to governors' offices Monday, listing various problems involving radiation contamination and reactor safety at weapon plants around the nation.

title: Food Notes
description: Porridge in a Flash

title: Devils Start Burke and He's Super
description: The Devils ignored the tradition of staying with a hot goaltender in a stretch drive and it proved successful.

title: Aid Hanoi on Boat People, U.N. Official Urges
description: Faced with continuing United States opposition to the forced repatriation of boat people from Hong Kong to Vietnam, a leading United Nations official appealed today for a sharp increase in international aid to Vietnam. The aim of the aid would be to stop the boat people from fleeing Vietnam in the first place.

title: Bush Turns Down Bid To Help Negotiators
description: Baseball's labor dispute lay dormant yesterday as negotiators chose not to meet and President Bush opted not to become involved. The possibility of binding arbitration was raised and neither side rejected the idea outright, but the owners' labor spokesman said it would be ''a difficult sell'' for his side.

title: Paterson Bond, Securities Executive, 80
description: Paterson Bond, former managing partner of Orvis Brothers & Company, a former Wall Street brokerage house, died of cancer on Sunday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 80 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: Montreal Extends Islanders' Slump
description: On a night of playoff-like warm weather, the Montreal Canadiens brought playoff-level discipline and playoff-style patience to their game with the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Unesco in Uproar as Chief Proposes Overhaul
description: A new crisis has erupted within the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization as employees and member countries strongly resist plans by the agency's director to shuffle Unesco's administrative structure.

title: Book Notes
description: On the Block

title: Michael Livesey, 61, Noted Cameraman For Documentaries
description: Michael J. Livesey, a cameraman whose work was seen and widely admired on network and public television programs, died of cancer of the liver and the pancreas on Sunday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Ansonia Victim Struggled in the City, but Loved It
description: In the city where she dwelled and danced, on and off, for eight years, her life reflected the alchemy of New York, that particular mix of internationalism and down-home pride: Brazilian-born, with an Italian father and a Soviet mother, she studied ballet in the Soviet Union and worked as a tour guide, showing out-of-towners the Statue of Liberty, the Empire State Building and churches in Harlem where the choirs make the rafters ring.

title: Teaching Love of Party Is the Aim As China Brings the Arts to Heel
description: One of the clearest effects of the Government's violent suppression of the democracy movement last summer is evident in the reduced number of new films, plays and art exhibitions permitted to appear and in their sharply narrowed subject matter.

title: NORTH TELLS JURY OF PLAN FOR BUSH
description: Oliver L. North today confirmed a long-suspected but hazy footnote to the Iran-contra affair: that officials of the Reagan Administration had considered sending Vice President George Bush as an emissary to Iran in early 1986.

title: Weights on Old Ceiling Are Blamed for Collapse
description: The excessive weight of modern air-conditioning ducts, pipes and decorations suspended from a turn-of the-century plaster ceiling caused the ceiling collapse that killed one customer and injured 16 others on Monday in a croissant shop in a West Side hotel, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: Icot Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss The company said results for the latest quarter reflected the second full quarter of operations since the sale of the Eftpos business in June 1989.

title: Panel Votes Immunity for Ex-Aide to Pierce
description: The House Government Operations Committee voted unanimously today to grant immunity to a onetime aide of the Reagan Administration's Housing Secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., in exchange for new information about fraud and mismanagement at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Peanut Butter at 100 Still Loves Jelly
description: ENOUGH of this kid stuff. Now that peanut butter is 100 years old, let's face facts and stop beating around the bush. Isn't it time for peanut butter to grow up? It is almost embarrassing to admit. But this country is still serving most of its peanut butter with jelly when so many other parts of the world are using it subtly to enhance stews, thicken soups, or top grilled fish.

title: The New Vacation: Weekend at a Time
description: SETTING aside a week or two of vacation time is all but impossible these days for Doris Bader, a printing services consultant in Highland Park, N.J. ''I just keep putting it off and off and off,'' she said.

title: Phoenix Gets '93 Super Bowl if King HOliday Goes Statewide
description: Phoenix was awarded Super Bowl XXVII in 1993 at the National Football League owners' meeting today with one condition, and an effort was made by the owners to reduce the average time of games to about three hours.

title: Cavalier Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from early retirement of debt of $115,533 for both the quarter and year.

title: Phillips to Offer Propane Gas for Vehicles
description: In another sign of the effort by large energy companies to promote alternative fuels more aggressively, the Phillips Petroleum Company said today that it would market propane gas for taxis, buses and fleets of vehicles owned by private companies and government agencies in the Denver area.

title: Topics of The Times;   Justice Mocked in Iraq
description: Iraq is eager to attract Western investors and to be taken more seriously as a regional diplomatic voice. But President Saddam Hussein's violent tyranny has a lot to live down, notably its lawless use of chemical weapons in the Persian Gulf war and its persistent abuse of human rights. And now the Baghdad regime has ordered the execution of a British-based journalist who traveled to Iraq at the Government's invitation.

title: Single-Room Housing Won't End Homelessness;   A Generation Adrift
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Falls 12.16 Points in Light Trading
description: Stocks slumped in light trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 12.16 points, to 2,674.55, in the wake of a rise in bond yields.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Agency Acquires Big Software Account
description: Schell/Mullaney Advertising, a tiny new agency founded in part by alumni of the J. Walter Thompson Company, has lured the account of the big computer software company Computer Associates International away from Thompson.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Drop
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, pushed lower by stronger-than-expected February retail sales data and by reports that the West German Government has a plan to exchange West German marks on a one-to-one basis for the Ostmark, East Germany's currency, for savings.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Digest Will Promote Its Readers
description: READER'S DIGEST says it has more male readers between the ages of 25 and 49 than the largest news magazine, more female readers in that age bracket than the largest women's service magazine and that it reaches one-third of all the Americans who participate in ''public activities'' like voting and writing their Congressmen.

title: Quake Is Blamed in Applications Drop
description: Not long after the earthquake last October, an admissions officer at the University of California at Santa Cruz produced a poster that he mailed to high school guidance counselors around the country.

title: Panel Proposes A Speedometer In Each Subway
description: Federal safety officials today called for using speedometers on all New York City subway cars, saying that train operators had no way to know whether they were obeying speed limits.

title: 31 Are Hurt as Engine Rams Amtrak Train
description: A freight engine rammed a New York-bound Amtrak train sitting at a station early today, causing minor injuries to 31 passengers.

title: Chronicle
description: Among the restaurants the three chefs have variously worked for are Rakel, Le Cirque and the ''21'' Club.

title: Engine Failure Reported in Indian Jet Crash
description: Engine failure was responsible for the crash of an Indian Airlines airbus jet last month that killed 97 people, reports published here said today.

title: Trade Gap at $105.89 Billion In 1989, Lowest in 5 Years
description: The United States trade deficit declined to $105.89 billion last year, its lowest level in five years, as merchandise exports grew and travel abroad increased, the Government said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Lebanese Truce Breaks Down
description: An 11-day cease-fire between warring Lebanese Christian factions began to fall apart today as loyalists of Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea traded artillery shells and rockets in East Beirut and in the hills northeast of here.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, an article on Monday about Lithuania's declaration of independence misidentified the new president of Lithuania in some editions, as did a picture caption in other copies. He is Vytautas Landsbergis. The article also misidentified the Communist Party ideology chief of Lithuania. He is Justas Paleckis. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the port city of Klaipeda.

title: Beverly Hills Journal;   Real Life Produces Plot Fit For Movie
description: Just minutes from the studios where the most bizarre crime plots are hatched for movies and television, a searing real-life story of blood, money and alleged patricide is unfolding among the privileged of Beverly Hills.

title: Maybe Lunkhead Park?
description: Baltimore is building a new baseball park for the Orioles, and the big question is what to name it. Some people want it called Babe Ruth Park, or Babe Ruth Stadium, or Babe Ruth Baseball Emporium, or anything else that has Babe Ruth in it.

title: Fiscal Fire in New York
description: New York State has fallen into serious financial trouble. Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposed budget, just two months old, is already way out of balance. The outlook is so bad that the bond rating agencies have sounded the alarm. There's a fiscal fire. Where are the firefighters?

title: KEY RATES
Warning Labels Pave Road to Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music;   Blues at the Lone Star, Played, Shouted and Sung
description: Blues revues, which flourished from the 1940's through the 60's, were roof-raising fun. Competitive and exuberant affairs in which a slew of performers came out and took their turns at trying to win the audience, they offered listeners a wide variety of musical ideas and techniques. Over the last several years, blues revues have been making a comeback, this time playing to the young, white blues audience, and in theory that's a good thing. Pop music may dispense with its elders, but its elders don't dispense with pop; the stars of the past often have a whole set of tricks and abilities, both musical and visual, that make their performances explosively vital.

title: Khomeini's Son Urges No Concessions on Hostages
description: Two leading militants in the Iranian leadership have issued statements strongly opposing the release of Western hostages taken in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militias, stating that Iran should refrain from talks with the United States on the issue.

title: Plan Would Add To Lockheed Board
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who is waging a proxy fight for control of the Lockheed Corporation, said he wants a representative of the company's employees appointed to the military contractor's board. Mr. Simmons said that if he wins the proxy fight, he will recommend a new seat for a representative of Lockheed's employee stock ownership plan, which holds 18 percent of the company's shares.

title: Val Royal Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Interest Rates Up at Citicorp
description: Interest rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday, reflecting the rise in short-term rates in the last few weeks.

title: Dolphins Sign Paige
description: A former Jets fullback, Tony Paige, was signed by the Miami Dolphins yesterday as their first Plan B free agent this year.

title: In Bay Area, Not All Is Joy in Raiders' Deal;   Questions Are Raised as to Whether Big-Money Package Is Good or Bad
description: Expressions of joy by sports fans throughout the San Francisco Bay area, some strong reservations within the city government of Oakland itself and circumspect caution on the part of the area's other teams were the reactions to Monday's announcement that the Raiders would be bringing the National Football League back to Oakland.

title: Bonn Sets Mark Rate On Savings
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that East Germans would be able to exchange their personal savings at a one-to-one rate for West German marks, but that this rate would not apply to East German marks held by businesses or other institutions.

title: West's Exhibits Bring The Leipzig Fair to Life
description: The Leipzig Trade Fair, for decades a dull Communist showcase of East German industry, has been transformed this year into a bustling forum of East-West deal-making. With the recent democratic reforms in East Germany and hopes of strong growth fueled by the coming unification of the two Germanys, Western companies have flocked in record numbers to the one-week Leipzig fair, which began on Sunday.

title: Macy Lost $39 Million In Quarter
description: Citing turmoil in the retail industry caused by severe price competition during the holidays, R. H. Macy & Company yesterday reported a loss of $39 million in its second quarter.

title: Blind Robbery Suspect Seized
description: A blind man handed a threatening note to a bank teller Monday, collected $105 and then was arrested after he asked the teller to help him leave the building, the authorities said. The 27-year-old suspect, Jeffery Lee Flournoy, was seized by officers who had been summoned by the manager of the Bank of America branch.

title: Hong Kong Bank Gains
description: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, regarded as the largest bank in Asia outside Japan, reported today that its earnings rose 11 percent in 1989. Despite economic slowdowns in the bank's leading markets, the bank said its profits for the year rose to $4.77 billion (Hong Kong), or $612 million (United States), from $4.3 billion (Hong Kong) in 1988. The Hongkong bank owns New York-based Marine Midland Bank. Its Hongkong Bank of Canada is one of the largest in Canada and it operates in the Middle East through its British Bank of the Middle East.

title: ISRAELI COALITION DISSOLVES IN FIGHT OVER PEACE PLAN
description: Israel's coalition Government collapsed today when Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir dismissed Finance Minister Shimon Peres, the leader of the Labor Party, prompting the rest of Labor's Cabinet ministers to resign.

title: Medalist Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,698,000, which included a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,852,000.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Magazine At Conde Nast
description: Conde Nast Publications Inc., which already publishes 11 magazines in the United States, plans to start a new beauty magazine next year.

title: ISOLATE PRETORIA, MANDELA DEMANDS
description: Nelson Mandela called on foreign governments today to break diplomatic ties with South Africa and impose tougher economic sanctions to speed political change in the country.

title: A Doll for the 90's: Beautiful but No Bimbo
description: She is a symbol of the New Glamour; the embodiment of the sensibilities of the 90's encased in a shimmering gold brocade couture dress. Beautiful enough to be a model, smart enough to be a biochemist, rich enough to give generous gifts to her favorite charities and to support the arts. Her name is Mdvanii (pronounced Med-VAH-Nee) and she's on sale now.

title: Powell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $279,000.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Food Notes column last Wednesday about wines to drink with oysters misstated the ranking of the wines in the final tasting. The French muscadet placed third.

title: Grand Met Completes Brewery and Pub Deal
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food company, provided details today of its deal with Elders IXL Ltd. of Australia. Under the agreement, Grand Met will sell most of its breweries to Elders, and the two companies will jointly operate about 5,000 pubs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This decision is the most significant in the history of our Government. This is an important and powerful step on the road to democracy.''

title: Judge Chastised For Threatening In Private Calls
description: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct publicly admonished an acting State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn yesterday for misusing the prestige of his office to help his son.

title: A.T.&T.-Tandem Computer Venture
description: Tandem Computers Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said they would jointly develop and market computer systems combining Tandem's ''fault tolerant'' designs and A.T.& T.'s Unix operating system software.

title: Chronicle
description: SIMON JENKINS, a columnist who was Britain's Journalist of the Year last year, was named editor of The Times of London yesterday.

title: The Pop Life
description: Arista AIDS Benefit

title: Entree Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 6
description: b-Net income The company said 1990 9-month results were lower than prior year because of the sale of two operating units.

title: Knicks Throw Away Chance to Catch Bulls
description: The finish of last night's Knicks-Bulls game at Madison Square Garden centered around a 3-point shot attempt, which meant it resembled the finish of the game there between the same teams two months ago.

title: Chronicle
description: Previously, only about a dozen works on paper from Matisse's Moroccan period, 1912 to 1913, were known to scholars. ''Through networking, I bumped into a cache of 24 drawings in a private collection in Europe,'' Mr. Cowart said. To date, he has discovered 67 drawings.

title: Henefeld of Connecticut Has 2 Years' Eligibility
description: Nadav Henefeld, the former Israeli soldier who was voted Big East rookie of the year at Connecticut this season, will have only two more years of college eligibility, Coach Jim Calhoun said yesterday.

title: INDIA RE-EXAMINES ITS FOREIGN POLICY
description: In India, where a special relationship with Moscow has brought diplomatic and trade benefits for decades, the tumultuous collapse of European Communism and changes in the Soviet Union itself are forcing the most fundamental rethinking of New Delhi's foreign policies since independence in 1947.

title: Warning Labels Pave Road to Censorship;   Print Them Large
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Urges Congress to Act On Aid to New Democracies
description: President Bush expressed impatience with Congress today, saying it has failed to move swiftly on an aid package to Panama, and he urged lawmakers to act immediately to strengthen the wobbly new democracies taking form in Nicaragua and Panama.

title: Walter Orr Roberts Is Dead at 74; Expert on Climate's Effect on Life
description: Walter Orr Roberts, the founder of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, who was one of the first scientists to warn that technology was changing the earth's climate, died of cancer on Monday in Boulder, Colo. He was 74 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 26 about a ban on smoking on most domestic airline flights included an incorrect identification from The Associated Press for a Tobacco Institute spokesman.

title: Grady-Manhattan Center Title Game at Garden
description: When William E. Grady High School beat Manhattan Center in overtime in the semifinal of the Doc Turner Christmas Classic in December nobody knew that it might be a preview of the Public Schools Athletic League championship.

title: 'Invisible' British Deficit
description: Britain recorded a deficit in its so-called invisible trade in the last three months of 1989, the Government said today. It was the first quarterly deficit since such data were first collected in 1955. Figures from the Central Statistical Office showed a gap of $:713 million ($1.14 billion) in the last quarter of 1989 for the category, which includes banking, insurance, shipping and tourism.

title: Bullet Hits Doctor in Chest As She Sits on Park Bench
description: A young doctor sitting on a bench with her brother in Central Park was shot in the chest and wounded yesterday by a bullet that the police said was fired from a great distance.

title: American Integrity reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary charge of $1,480,000. The company said included in both the quarter and full-year revenue figures are pre-tax realized investment gains of $630,000 in 1989 and $59,000 in 1988.

title: Heart Labeling Unfazed
description: DESPITE one setback after another, the American Heart Association is not giving up on its HeartGuide program, officials said yesterday. The Food and Drug Administration has told the association repeatedly that it would seize products labeled with the HeartGuide seal as misbranded; the United States Department of Agriculture has refused to allow the labels on meat and poultry products, and more than half the original participants have withdrawn, at least temporarily.

title: Now, No Haitians Can Donate Blood
description: A Federal recommendation to exclude certain Haitians from blood donations as a safeguard against spreading AIDS has been expanded to all Haitians, and the change is being protested by Haitian organizations in New York City and Miami.

title: Procter & Gamble Acquires Rights to Distribute Maalox
description: In a strategic foray in the antacid wars, the Procter & Gamble Company announced plans yesterday to take over marketing and distribution in the United States of Maalox, the star antacid of the Rorer Group Inc.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Ah, Those Americans Abroad, So Crassly Pursuing Culture
description: ''I think this is the Pizza Hut where he wrote 'Troilus and Cressida,' '' said my theater-fanatic friend during a pre-matinee stroll in Stratford-on-Avon, England, a few summers ago. We had already passed the McDonald's where, we imagined, Shakespeare had written ''Twelfth Night.'' (Or was it ''As You Like It'' at Burger King?) As we later wolfed down curry just in time to make the curtain at the Royal Shakespeare Company's evening performance of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' we concluded that we had finally found a Stratford restaurant the Bard might have missed. Neither of us could recall a single mention of mango chutney in the banquet scene of ''Macbeth.''

title: Australia's Ramtron Names Electronic Chip Unit Chief
description: After careers at two major corporations, George J. Stathakis plans to try his hand at getting a start-up company up and running in the semiconductor industry.

title: An Insider Looks, Optimistically, at the University
description: Henry Rosovsky is that unfashionable thing these days: an optimist about higher education.

title: Texas Democrats in Runoff; G.O.P. Oilman Wins
description: Clayton Williams, an oilman and rancher who spent about $6 million of his own money on his first campaign for public office, won the Republican nomination for Governor of Texas tonight, winning by a large margin in every region of the state. In the Democratic race, two candidates were nearly tied will be in a runoff on April 10.

title: Cinemas Blossoming In Manhattan
description: THE collective message blaring from the marquees of all the new cinemas in New York might well be ''Movie Mania Grips Gotham.''

title: Single-Room Housing Won't End Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Denies Greenspan Rift
description: President Bush said today he was not at odds with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and had never discussed the possiblity of not reappointing Mr. Greenspan when his term expires next year.

title: Data I-O Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: The company said the full-year earnings decline was due in part to a reversal in interest income, from receiving $1,200,000 in 1988 to paying $351,000 last year, as well as an inability to offset taxable U.S. income by losses in its Japanese subsidiary.
