title: Excerpts From President's News Session on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Simon Bax has joined Chiat/Day/ Mojo Worldwide as vice president and director of finance.

title: London Journal;   In Highgate Cemetery, Marx Is Safe on a Pedestal
description: At the grave of Karl Marx, they come not to mourn Marxism but to ponder the flawed realities that sprang from its ideals, or to keep the faith, or perhaps even to bask in its new and somewhat paradoxical vogue.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Washington Power System Prices $603 Million in Bonds
description: The Washington Public Supply Power System tentatively priced $603 million in revenue bonds yesterday as part of its $2 billion refunding program for Nuclear Projects 1, 2 and 3, which issued debt when interest rates were higher. This financing is a refunding for Projects 1 and 2.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Hungarian Politician Urges End to Role in Warsaw Pact
description: Hungary's front-running opposition party said today that it would ask Parliament to annul the country's Warsaw Pact membership after free elections.

title: Coalition Rule Expected as Grenada Votes
description: Voters turned out in large numbers today on this Caribbean island to choose a new government.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Y.&R. Consolidation
description: Young & Rubicam has consolidated its promotional marketing offices under the name Cato Johnson Worldwide. William A. Power was appointed chief executive of the subsidiary, and Jean Paul Lafaye was named president of worldwide operations.

title: Market Place;   A Sense of Crisis In Tokyo Markets
description: THE steep rise of the dollar and the tumble of the yen in global currency trading are contributing to a growing sense of crisis in the financial markets here. Traders and investors say they see little prospect that monetary authorities can turn the situation around.

title: Harvard Doctor Named to Head Hospital Agency
description: A 39-year-old physician with a background in community activity was appointed president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday. He immediately pledged to give top priority to improving health care for the poor.

title: KMS Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dell Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The company said earnings in the latest quarter and year were adversely affected by higher-cost inventories of components purchased in late fiscal 1989, investments in expansion and research, and delayed introduction of new products.

title: General Leaseholds reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Trial Opens on Suit Over a Senator's Suicide
description: Opening arguments have been presented in a wrongful death lawsuit against the Government by the widow of Senator John P. East, who committed suicide in 1986.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHEN President John F. Kennedy ordered United States embassies around the world to begin serving American wines, the know-it-alls shuddered and affected great sympathy for our poor diplomats and their hapless guests.

title: China's Tranquillity Is Seen as Only Skin Deep
description: The Government assures foreigners that life in China has loosened up, but lately many Chinese are shaking their heads, whispering: ''Nei jin, wai song'' - ''tranquillity outside, repression within.''

title: Temco Service Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Stieb's Option Renewed
description: The Toronto Blue Jays yesterday exercised the 1990 option in the contract of their ace right-hander, Dave Stieb, for $1.6 million. Under the terms of Stieb's contract, signed in March 1985, the team had until Thursday to renew his option for 1990 or buy out the contract for $800,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Review/Music;   Celebrating a Birthday With Song
description: Although most music lovers know the name of the Swiss composer Frank Martin, few in this country have heard much of his music. And since Martin was an independent spirit who ranged widely in the slow development of his mature style, including a serious flirtation with serialism, fewer still have any distinct impression of his idiom.

title: The Evolution of the Floppy Disk for PC's
description: Floppy disks and disk drives, the portable storage systems generally considered a mundane part of personal computers, are undergoing a burst of innovation that will vastly increase their capacity and even allow them to replace hard-disk drives or tape drives in some computers.

title: House Panel Votes to Elevate The E.P.A. to Cabinet Status
description: The House Government Operations Committee today approved by voice vote a bill that would elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet level with creation of a Department of the Environment.

title: Court Clears Aid For Bhopal Victims
description: India's Supreme Court approved a Government plan to pay interim compensation of $12 a month to each of the 500,000 people living near the site of the 1984 Bhopal disaster. The Supreme Court also ruled that the Government must pay $44 a month to 3,110 people disabled by the toxic gas leak.

title: Time to Bring Baseball Under Antitrust Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Pacific Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Plan to Redo Apartments is $50 million Over Budget
description: A New York City program to renovate several thousand apartments for the homeless and the working poor is seriously behind schedule and at least $50 million over budget, city officials said yesterday.

title: About New York;   Lonely Crusade To Pay Tribute To the Dead
description: This column will ramble a bit, but hold to a central theme. The theme is death.

title: Insituform of North America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Corrected from Tues., March 13th.

title: President Criticizes Deficit Plan
description: President Bush took issue today with the main elements of Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan for cutting the deficit, those that would raise taxes and lower Social Security benefits.

title: Yields at Banks Are Mixed
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE intermingling of French and Russian cuisines goes back at least to the time of Catherine the Great, when noble Russian families took great pride in employing French or Swiss chefs. Lavish feasts usually began with a zakuska, an array of tidbits including caviar, herring, pates, cold fish, vegetables and breads, accompanied by vodka.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Procter & Gamble Move
description: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday switched the advertising account for its Safeguard soap from Wells, Rich, Greene to Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor. Procter & Gamble would not disclose a reason for the switch. The company also announced the promotion of Robert J. Herbold to senior vice president responsible for advertising and marketing services, as well as for market research and management systems.

title: The President Presses for Peace
description: President Bush yesterday announced a simple and appealing strategy to help Nicaragua and Panama meet their most desperate needs: national reconciliation and economic reconstruction. He ended sanctions against Nicaragua. And he urged Congress to approve an $800 million package for the two countries by April 8.

title: German Bank Aide Quits in Bond Dispute
description: A feud that has raged for weeks between several leading French banks and a West German bank over $3.5 billion in bond sales took its latest turn yesterday with the resignation of an official at the German bank.

title: EDUCATION: About Education
description: Even more tragic than the fate of students who drop out of school is that of half a million children who drop in irregularly or not at all. They are not truants; they may not lack the desire to learn. What they lack is a home from which to register as regulars for school.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Economic Border Urged Even After German Unity
description: The official in charge of the European Community's policies on Eastern Europe is urging that some form of border be retained between East and West Germany even after reunification.

title: Go Ahead, Slash the Military
description: LEAD: The aroma of the prospective peace dividend has Washington liberals salivating.

title: A BEAMING BARRY RETURNS TO WORK
description: After a seven-week absence in which Marion S. Barry Jr. was treated for alcoholism and what he said was a dependency on prescription drugs, the Washington Mayor resumed the duties of office today. He said he would fight the perjury and cocaine charges he faces, would not resign and would announce whether he would seek re-election ''in the very near future.''

title: Honda Blurs Line Between American and Foreign
description: When the Honda Accord became the best-selling car model in the United States last year - the first foreign car ever to do so - not everyone viewed the event as simply another sign of American industrial decline at the hands of Japan.

title: Tales Told in Stars: Michelin Adds and Subtracts
description: The 1990 Michelin Guide for France, published Monday, demoted Oustau de Baumaniere, one of the nation's longtime temples of gastronomy, from the top three-star rating to two stars. Oustau de Baumaniere in Les Baux de Provence, opened by Raymond Thuilier in 1946, was first awarded Michelin's three-star rating in 1954.

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Chrysler's Austria Mini-van Deal
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced a final agreement to manufacture its mini-vans in Austria. The deal, which had been expected, creates a new joint venture company in which Chrysler and the Austrian manufacturer Steyr-Daimler-Puch Fahrzeugtecknik G.m.b.H. will each own 50 percent.

title: Civilian Sworn In as Haiti's President
description: Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, the only woman on Haiti's Supreme Court, became Provisional President of Haiti today, and the chief of the army declared, with a snappy salute, that his forces were ''at your command.''

title: Bush Calls for Peace Talks in Mozambique
description: President Bush called today for negotiations to end Mozambique's 10-year civil war. He issued the plea after talks with Joaquim A. Chissano, the President of the formerly Marxist country.

title: Medical Imaging Centers reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Nutrition Labeling: To Be or Not to Be?
description: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter appears to be out of step with the rest of the Bush Administration on mandatory nutrition labeling. The day after the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, announced the Administration's proposals to require labeling on most packaged foods, Mr. Yeutter told the same audience that such regulations might be just another example of ''the heavy hand of government in the activities of Americans.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Upheaval in the East;   PARLIAMENT VOTES EXPANDED POWERS FOR SOVIET LEADER
description: The full Soviet Parliament voted overwhelmingly today in favor of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for a strong presidency and ended the Communist Party's seven-decade monopoly of political power in the Soviet Union.

title: Jets Get Strength Coach
description: The Jets, with a history of critical injuries that came at the wrong time, have upgraded the position of strength and conditioning coach to equal status with the assistant coaches.

title: USMX Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said record 1989 results were attributable to a full year's production from the Green Springs Mine in Ely, Nev.

title: Nevada Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics of The Times;   Back Where They Belong
description: In some circles, including the owners of other National Football League teams, Al Davis has a reputation as a hard man to get along with. But Mr. Davis can accommodate those who speak his language. On Monday, Mayor Lionel Wilson of Oakland offered a $660 million package if Mr. Davis would return his Raiders to the city of their birth. Mr. Davis promptly agreed.

title: Baseball's Silent Spring Taking a Toll on Many
description: Al Harazin, the master of the Mets' business affairs, considered the confused state of the business of baseball on the 27th day of the lockout of spring training camps and, quoting the King of Siam of the Broadway stage, admitted: ''Is a puzzlement.''

title: School Boards Said to Pad Their Payrolls
description: Two Brooklyn school superintendents said yesterday that their school boards had hired a total of 150 unneeded people to patrol cafeterias and perform clerical chores at a cost of almost $2 million a year.

title: India to Shake Up Birth-Control Bureaucracy
description: Prodded by social scientists' fears of impending demographic catastrophe, the Indian Government is preparing to decentralize the administration of population control programs, which have failed to curb runaway growth in the world's second-most-populous nation.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuania Move Is 'Illegitimate,' Gorbachev Says
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence, calling the decision ''illegitimate and invalid,'' and he ruled out negotiations with the three Baltic republics on their quest for sovereign statehood.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Unity Talks Begin Today
description: The four World War II Allies and the two Germanys are to begin initial talks on Wednesday on returning the full sovereignty that the Germanys lost with the defeat of the Third Reich in 1945.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Cash-Starved Parties Introduce Voters in Hungary to the Fund-Raiser
description: Democracy has its price, as Hungary's new political parties are learning now that they must pay the bill for the posters, leaflets, 30-second television spots, lapel pins, cigarette lighters, helicopters, hot-air balloons and other props of this country's first full-fledged electoral campaign in 40 years.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Security Inc., Pittsburgh, a security guard service, said shareholders had approved taking the company private for $62 a share, or about $30.2 million.

title: Ruling Finds Pension Fund Can End South Africa Stake
description: Clearing the way for the last phase of a process begun five years ago, New York City's chief lawyer said yesterday that its largest public employee pension fund could end virtually all its remaining investments in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian-Americans React With Joy After 50-Year Wait
description: A party in Chicago for a local Lithuanian-language radio program on Sunday erupted into a more spontaneous celebration. Just minutes earlier, Lithuania had proclaimed itself free of the Soviet Union.

title: Rejuvenating Faded Flavor Of 1990's Food
description: FOR 30 years, food producers have slowly been turning seasonal foods into foods for all seasons. Asparagus time, salmon time and even raspberry time have become any time. Today the idea of seasonal ingredients is as quaint as the image of Mom in a ruffled apron in the American kitchen.

title: Gorbachev Should Pay Lithuania
description: LEAD: On Sunday the Lithuanian Parliament unanimously adopted a declaration asserting Lithuania's independence from the Soviet Union. Even though Mikhail Gorbachev has termed the action ''illegal and invalid,'' his overall response to Lithuania's struggle for autonomy has been reasonable. The one startling exception is Mr.

title: Home Depot Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split last June.

title: Burger King Resignation
description: The Burger King Corporation, the struggling hamburger chain owned by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., said yesterday that the president and chief operating officer of its American operation had resigned, effective immediately.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday showing the civilian unemployment rate and the total rate misstated the total for February 1989. It was 5.1 percent.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about health workers who become infected with the AIDS virus on the job referred incompletely to the case of Dr. Hacib Aoun at John Hopkins University. The university corroborated his account of having become infected in the course of his duties.

title: Brazil Returns 10 Tons of Arms Sent by Cuba for Castro's Security
description: Brazil has sent back to Cuba a load of arms that arrived in Brasilia as part of Cuban security preparations for Fidel Castro's attendance at Brazil's presidential inauguration on Thursday, a newspaper and an official here said today.

title: Record 85 degrees Gets the Coats Off the Lion and the Lamb
description: A subway station guitarist took his act joyously above ground to Battery Park. A woman from East Harlem forsook her soap opera to frolic outside with her grandson. A videomaker from Tribeca basked in the sun - but brooded about global warming.

title: Motor Club of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Results were decreased by $2,100,000 because of increases in mandated assessments by the New Jersey unsatisfied claim and judgment fund and participation in the losses of the Massachusetts reinsurance facility.

title: Aspen Votes To Keep Mayor Who Supported Fur Sale Ban
description: Voters in this resort town voted today to keep the Mayor who tried ban fur sales but recalled a councilman who stood with him on the issue.

title: Upheaval in the East;   U.S. Shift Seen on Defense of Europe
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have prepared a new military assessment that indicates that NATO has the ability to mount an effective defense of Western Europe without resorting to nuclear weapons, Representative Les Aspin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today.

title: Retail Sales Decline 0.9% As Demand for Autos Slips
description: Retail sales fell nine-tenths of a percent in February, their steepest fall in four months, the Government reported today.

title: Rangers' Nicholls Not Equal to His Boasts
description: His intense anxiety in anticipation of the game had cost him a night's sleep, and now Bernie Nicholls, pale and perplexed, faced the prospect of losing another night's rest because of the acute embarrassment he felt in the wake of the game.

title: Asarco Fights Sale Of Freeport Unit
description: Asarco Inc. challenged the proposed sale of the Freeport-McMoran Inc.'s gold mining subsidiary to South African-controlled Minorco S.A. In a lawsuit filed in New York Supreme Court, Asarco said its interest in a joint venture with the Freeport-McMoran unit could be violated by the sale.

title: Health Concepts IV reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Due to increased marketing and personnel expenses. c-Net income The latest quarter's revenue increase reflected a higher patient census.

title: Company News;   Global Ventures By U S Sprint
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company announced four moves yesterday to expand operations overseas, including a preliminary agreement to provide high-quality international telephone links to the Soviet Union.

title: New York Is Advised to Cut Budget Further
description: In an unusually stern report, the New York State Financial Control Board warned yesterday that New York City's budget probably will not be balanced in the current fiscal year or the one that starts on July 1 unless it makes even deeper, more painful spending cuts.

title: Third Canadian General Invest reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Talking Deals;   Cash on the Table, Name on the Door
description: THE poultry king Frank Perdue may be better known for his tasty hens than for the teaching of accounting and finance. But at the business school at Salisbury State University in Maryland, Mr. Perdue is the man with the money. In 1986, he donated $2.5 million to Salisbury State, which promptly renamed its business school the Franklin P. Perdue School of Business.

title: Movers for a Precious Art Collection
description: FOR 26 years, John Hughes has been moving art and antiques for New York interior designers and private clients. For 15 years, he has been a principal mover for William Doyle Galleries. Although most household movers will move delicate oil paintings and rare antique furniture, such items often require special expertise.

title: S.E.C. Charges Brokerage Used 'Boiler Room' Tactics
description: In a case that offers a wealth of detail about how penny-stock ''boiler rooms'' operate, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit yesterday against a New York brokerage house, accusing it of having used fraud, lies and fictional analysts' reports to sell high-risk stocks by telephone to investors across the country.

title: Mongolia Ousts Leaders and Ends Communists' Monopoly on Power
description: The Communist Party replaced its entire leadership today and voted to give up its constitutional monopoly on power in preparation for free elections expected to be held later this year.

title: Second Scientist Links Bloodstains to Golub
description: The Nassau County District Attorney's office today called the final witness in its case against Robert Golub, who is on trial for the murder of 13-year-old Kelly Ann Tinyes a year ago.

title: Q&A
description: A Weeping Wall

title: Metro Matters;   It's the Fading Of the Green At City Hall
description: The rogues' gallery of New Yorkers convicted of corruption during the Koch administration provided one measure of the further decline of Irish-American influence in city politics: virtually none were of Irish descent.

title: Park-Shooting Inquiry Focuses on Rooftops
description: Detectives investigating the mysterious shooting of a young doctor in Central Park on Tuesday concentrated their search yesterday on the rooftops of buildings on Central Park West between 103d and 105th Streets.

title: A New Assault On Brazil's Woes
description: Harried by hyperinflation and mounting debts, a new young economic team takes office here Thursday carrying blueprints of free-market reforms designed to turn Brazil into an economic world power this decade.

title: SERBIAN SETTLERS FOR ALBANIAN AREA
description: The Serbian Parliament began today to consider legislation that would provide money for Serbs eager to resettle in the Kosovo region, which is now predominantly populated by ethnic Albanians.

title: C. Leonard Miller, 62, United Methodist Aide
description: C. Leonard Miller, an official of the United Methodist Church, died of pancreatic cancer on Friday at the Kettering (Ohio) Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Dayton, Ohio.

title: Plan for Selection of School Personnel Is Criticized
description: An attempt by the New York City Board of Education to widen participation in the selection of school administrators drew criticism yesterday, with teachers, principals and parents seeking safeguards to insure adequate representation.

title: Angelica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Multivest Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Securities Prices Rebound
description: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded yesterday, continuing a recent pattern of highly erratic movement.

title: France to Receive A Wealth of Picassos
description: France will receive a huge collection of Pablo Picasso's works in lieu of death duties on the estate of the artist's widow, Jacqueline, the Culture Ministry said today.

title: Brasilia Journal;   Brazil Gets the Picture: A Dynamo Is Taking Over
description: In Japan, he limbered up with karate kicks. In Italy, he bounced a soccer ball on his forehead. And here in Brazil's capital he donned a T-shirt and set out for a well-documented jog.

title: Charming Shoppes reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Armageddon: On a Dim Horizon or Around the Bend?
description: Apocalyptic movements have come and gone with far more certainty than all their predictions of the end of the world.

title: Bond News;   Sallie Mae Begins $200 Million Offer
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million in notes due April 5, 1995, through various securities dealers.

title: Victoria Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Panel Seeks at Least $5 Billion to Improve Child Care in U.S.
description: A new study by a panel of the National Academy of Sciences concludes that the nation's child care services are inadequate and calls on the Government to allocate an additional $5 billion to $10 billion a year to improve them.

title: North Korea Agrees to a Joint Tunnel Inquiry
description: A North Korean military delegation surprised its American and South Korean counterparts today by agreeing in principle to jointly investigate a tunnel dug underneath the heavily militarized border.

title: Bond News;   Chrysler Financial Prices Securities
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation yesterday priced $602.2 million in debt securities backed by automobile loans through Chemical Securities Inc., a unit of the Chemical Banking Corporation.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Poles Are Promised Role in talks on German Unity
description: The two Germanys and the four World War II Allies held their first formal talks on German unity today and emerged with an agreement to include Poland in the discussions when they came to the question of Polish borders.

title: Chronicle
description: DAVID ROCKEFELLER JR. came full circle Tuesday night when he gave a reception at the Cloisters for the 50th anniversary of the Tanglewood Music Center. ''My first job was with Tanglewood,'' Mr. Rockefeller said, explaining that he joined the Boston Symphony's management after graduation from law school. Tanglewood is the orchestra's summer home in Lenox, Mass. Guests included LUKAS FOSS, the composer and conductor; DAVID LLOYD, the tenor and retired director of the American Opera Center at the Juilliard School, and CARLOS MOSLEY, a former chairman of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Ex-Official Accused Of Lying and Theft
description: A former State Human Services Departmemt official was indicted yesterday and accused of conducting private business on state time, including a trip he took to the Virgin Islands.

title: Robec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pro forma provision for income taxes resulting from the company's termination of its S Corporation status on Oct. 2, 1989 of $46,000 and $2,023,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a pro forma provision for income taxes resulting from the company's termination of its S Corporation status on Oct. 2, 1989 of $628,000 for the quarter and $2,226,000 for the year.

title: Child Labor Law Violators Sought in Nationwide Raids
description: A 500-member Labor Department strike force fanned out across the country this week in an unannounced sweep of thousands of businesses, from fast-food restaurants to laundries, looking for violations of child labor laws.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an experimental AIDS drug, compound Q, referred incorrectly to the drug and its manufacturer. The drug is derived from a Chinese cucumber plant; it is not synthetic. Genelabs, which makes the drug, is an independent company, not a subsidiary of Sandoz Pharmaceuticals.

title: Geffen Records Sold to MCA For Stock Worth $550 Million
description: David Geffen, the pop culture impresario behind musicians ranging from the folk singer Joni Mitchell in the 1960's to the heavy metal group Guns 'n' Roses, agreed today to sell his record company to the entertainment conglomerate MCA Inc. for more than $550 million in stock.

title: Company News;   Browning Unit Fined $350,000
description: Cecos International Inc., the troubled hazardous waste disposal subsidiary of Browning-Ferris Industries, has been fined $350,000 by New York State environmental authorities for permit violations at its Niagara Falls landfill. Cecos was also denied permission to expand the site.

title: What to Do When an Old Screw Sticks
description: LEAD: If an 18th-century wood screw were placed beside a contemporary version that has been ''antiqued,'' even a blindfolded person could tell the difference. Early screws were hand-forged and had cuts that were slightly uneven, with the tapering toward their tips less marked. They also had blunt ends. It was not unusual to find the slots in the heads of handmade screws slightly off center.

title: Johnny Could Read in 1905, but Had to Go Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnny Could Read in 1905, but Had to Go Work;   Change Must Come
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter I. Feinberg, 79, Real-Estate Developer
description: Peter I. Feinberg, a real-estate developer, died of cancer of the pancreas on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: American Claims Evaluation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Gains 13.29 Points in Slow Trading
description: The stock market moved higher in slow trading yesterday, reflecting continued nervousness among traders waiting for the ''triple witching hour'' tomorrow, when index futures, index options and stock options all expire.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Monday about the issue of quality in book publishing misidentifed a publisher and rendered his name incorrectly in some editions.

title: Auto Sales Continue to Post Declines
description: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks continued to decline in early March, falling 3.8 percent compared with the comparable period of 1989.

title: Jerome Schnur Dead; TV Producer Was 66
description: Jerome Schnur, an award-winning director and producer of television shows, died of melanoma on Monday at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Technalysis Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Computer Telephone reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $804,000 from the sale of certain securities. The company said the decline in third-quarter revenues reflects the sale of two of the company's lines last year.

title: Democrats Working to Heal Rift Between Cuomo and Liberal Party
description: Democratic and Liberal Party leaders have begun discussions on healing strained relations between the Liberals and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and preparing the way for a Liberal Party endorsement of the Governor for re-election this year.

title: Must Germans Be Held Guilty by Race?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   Boris Yeltsin's Self-Portrait of a Soviet Maverick
description: Against the Grain

title: Corrections
description: An article headed ''Beverly Hills Journal'' yesterday, about a murder case, included an erroneous account from the police about a psychologist who had treated the two brothers charged in the deaths of their parents. The psychologist, Dr. Jerome Oziel, did not offer the police information about his patients, Joseph Lyle Menendez and Erik Galen Menendez, and had no contact with officers before they searched his home under a warrant last week, seizing records and tape recordings. The psycholo-gist argues that the materials are protected under patient-doctor confi-dentiality.

title: Fernandez Asks New Unit On Licensing
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, is circulating a plan here that would replace the independent board that licenses the city's teachers with a new licensing division under his control.

title: Lamps That Make Statements
description: YEARS ago, when she was starting out as a woodcarver, Virginia Restemeyer found herself combining carved and found objects into sculptures that had, she said, ''some social significance.''

title: In a Surprise, Pennzoil Appoints a New Chief
description: J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman and dominant leader of the Pennzoil Company since 1962, apparently has problems finding the person who will ultimately succeed him.

title: Louis Montelione, Judge, 71
description: Louis Montelione, a retired New York City administrative law judge, died of colon cancer on Saturday at his home in Massapequa, L.I. He was 71 years old.

title: Wajax Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $8,592,000 which represented additional estimated costs and losses related to the sale of the Pitman business. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Company News;   Icahn Sets Campaign On USX
description: Carl C. Icahn, who has proposed spinning off the steel business of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that he intended to conduct a vigorous campaign to win the votes of the company's institutional investors and other shareholders before the May 7 annual meeting.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: THERE are places throughout this country where corporate America goes to die: warm places with golf courses and beaches and clubs whose members are, as they describe themselves, ''the kind of people who'd be comfortable here.'' The kind of people who'd be comfortable play bridge, have fond memories of alma mater and, if male, have a predilection for plaid golf pants. They are also limited to certain religious persuasions and ethnic groupings.

title: FRIENDS PONDERING BETTELHEIM DEATH
description: Dr. Bruno Bettelheim, the eminent psychoanalyst who committed suicide on Tuesday, had been demoralized by a series of setbacks in his health, family life and work, friends said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about an experimental AIDS vaccine misidentified the university where the research is being done, and its spokeswoman. They are the University of Southern California - not the University of California at Los Angeles - and Katharine Munson. In addition, a spokeswoman for Dr. Jonas Salk was identified incorrectly.

title: Democrats Shift on Military Cutbacks
description: House Democrats said today that they had reached a consensus to forgo deep cuts in military spending for the next fiscal year and to seek more dramatic reductions in spending for future years.

title: General Mills reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 25
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $7.7 million. c-After a loss of $3,400,000 for the 13 weeks and income of $191.1 million for the 39 weeks, both from discontinued operations, and the 39 weeks also included a loss of $70 million from a cumulative effect to May 30, 1988 of changing to accrual accounting for postretirement health benefits. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued Vromans frozen novelties operations separately.

title: Market Place;   Can Witches Cast A Buying Spell?
description: THE witches are coming back tomorrow, after giving a mixed performance in their last big showing three months ago.

title: The Right Bush Push on Israel
description: What's the prognosis for Israeli-Palestinian negotiations? Very grim, with the collapse of the Likud-Labor coalition Government on Tuesday. What's the remedy? A new Israeli government, strong and united enough to pursue Israel's own plan for negotiating with the Palestinians.

title: Irish High Court Bars Extraditing 2 in I.R.A.
description: Ireland's Supreme Court has voted unanimously not to extradite two Irish Republican Army members who had escaped from Maze Prison in Northern Ireland.

title: Greenwich Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Greenwich said its revenues increased significantly in 1989 compared to 1988 due to recognition of $2.5 million as revenue in 1989 under the development and license agreement with Syntex Corp.

title: Tooth Fillings Found Improved by Bonding
description: A new type of plastic cement can make fillings bond better to teeth and prevent later tooth fractures, according to preliminary laboratory studies.

title: Jury Finds Man Guilty In '79 Slaying of Boy
description: Nearly 11 years after the body of a 13-year-old was found in Smithtown, a man was convicted of the slaying today.

title: Stroh Brewery and Grey End Their Relationship
description: The Stroh Brewery Company and Grey Advertising announced yesterday that they had ended their relationship. ''Due to reduced manpower and budgets'' at Stroh, the brewer said in a statement, ''we have been unable to agree upon terms with Grey.''

title: Review/Music;   Women's Choruses of Japan and U.S.
description: ''East Meets West,'' proclaimed the ads for Mid-America Productions' Carnegie Hall concert on Sunday evening, which featured seven women's choruses from Japan and the United States and the Manhattan Philharmonic, conducted by Peter Tiboris. Musically, however, East met West long ago.

title: ASA Ltd.  reports earnings for As of Feb 28
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. The company said net asset values per share are based on Johannesburg stock exchange closing prices converted to U.S. dollars at the commercial rand exchange rate in effect at the end of each period. Latest and year-ago quarters included net investment income of $7,864,131, or 82 cents a share, and $9,355,807, or 98 cents a share, respectively, excluding realized capital losses of $403,916, or 4 cents a share, and $268,878, or 3 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. Assets represent net assets.

title: American Medical Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $20,399, or 1 cent a share, and $191,327, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $97,099, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $3,867,345 for the year, both from litigation settlement.

title: Advance Ross Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Curtin Vocal Class
description: The soprano Phyllis Curtin is to give a master class on vocal techniques at 3 P.M. on April 1 at the Turtle Bay Music School, 244 East 52d Street. Ms. Curtin, the dean of the School of the Arts at Boston University, will be working with the finalists of the Center for Contemporary Opera International Opera Singers Competition. Tickets are $10. Information: 870-2010.

title: Furniture Fair in Milan Postponed Until April '91
description: THE lyrics might as well have been ''September in Milan.'' For 30 years, Milan in late September was the place to be if one was interested in modern furniture.

title: 90 Security Guards Go Out On Strike
description: The 90 security guards who patrol the sprawling Co-op City housing development in the Bronx went on strike last night in a dispute over wages.

title: Maine Court Bars Felons From Having Guns
description: A 1987 amendment to the Maine Constitution that says the right to bear arms ''shall never be questioned'' does not mean felons have the right to own guns, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: Failed Launching Leaves Satellite In Danger of Falling Back to Earth
description: A $150 million communication satellite was launched yesterday into a precariously low orbit that threatened to bring it plunging back to earth in a rain of fiery debris. The problems developed after the satellite failed to separate from a Titan 3 commercial rocket that was fired from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Wausau Paper Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included life insurance proceeds of $1,936,000, or 32 cents a share.

title: Company News;   I.B.M. Researchers Increase Speed of Silicon Transistors
description: In a development likely to extend the life of silicon as the leading material for manufacturing high-speed semiconductors, I.B.M. researchers have almost doubled the world's record for the speed of silicon-based transistors.

title: North, Ending Testimony, Speaks Softly and Haltingly of His Lies
description: In a series of intense rapid-fire exchanges with the Government prosecutor, Oliver L. North was asked today if he intended to ''lie and lie and lie'' at a White House meeting with lawmakers in August 1986 that he attended at the request of John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser.

title: Chairman of Robinson's
description: Kenneth L. Wilkerson has been named chairman of the Robinson's department stores in Los Angeles, effective April 1, the May Department Stores Company said yesterday. Mr. Wilkerson will succeed Elden Rasmussen, who is retiring. Mr. Wilkerson is now chairman of the Famous-Barr store division in St. Louis, which, like Robinson's, is owned by May. Robert L. Mettler will continue as Robinson's president and chief executive.

title: More Underclassmen Expected in the Draft
description: Professional basketball is abuzz again with rumors that a record number of underclassmen, including at least one freshman star, will declare themselves eligible for the National Basketball Association draft on June 27.

title: Abraham Halkin, 86; Taught Jewish Culture
description: Abraham S. Halkin, who taught Jewish literature, history and culture for nearly half a century before retiring from the Jewish Theological Seminary faculty in 1977, died on Friday in Jerusalem, where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: Video Jukebox Network reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tobacco Ad Vote in Europe
description: The European Parliament voted today for a total ban on tobacco advertising throughout the 12-nation European Community.

title: The Getty Is Said to Be Weighing Buying 'Irises'
description: Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' is now at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., which is considering the purchase of the work, staff members of the museum who declined to be named said yesterday. The painting was bought by Alan Bond, the Australian businessman, for a record $53.9 million at an auction in November 1987 at Sotheby's in New York.

title: Consolidated Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter and year figures included a pre-tax charge of $17 million, primarily for the cost of refocusing its business.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * British Airways P.L.C., London, has introduced Economy Select, an airline class that is more expensive than economy class but below first class and business class.

title: Abortion Pill Testing in California Is Urged
description: State Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp proposed today that California use its independent powers to allow clinical testing of the French abortion pill RU 486.

title: Semtech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a credit for cumulative effect of accounting change for income taxes of $30,000. The company said its earnings for all periods included results of Polycore Electronics Inc., since date of acquisition on Sept. 23, 1988.

title: Company News;   I.B.M. Introduction May Come Earlier
description: A computer industry analyst said he expected the International Business Machines Corporation to introduce the next generation of its most powerful mainframe computer earlier than had generally been expected. The analyst, Rick Martin of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., told Reuters yesterday that he expected I.B.M. to upgrade its existing 3090 mainframe computers to permit an incremental switch to the new technology, known by the code name Summit within the industry, in 1991.

title: Marcia Nauckhoff, 49, Official in Peace Corps
description: Marcia Dawkins Nauckhoff, a Peace Corps official and a former executive with Chase Manhattan Bank, died of breast cancer on Monday at her home in Washington. She was 49 years old.

title: Child Support Set
description: Darryl Strawberry has been ordered to pay $40,000 in back child-support payments, plus regular payments of $2,000 per month as a result of a paternity suit.

title: American Vanguard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $22,300 for the quarter and income of $90,500, or 4 cents a share for the year, both from discontinued operations, and gains on disposal of segment of $33,400, or 1 cent a share and $2,164,600, or 95 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $52,700, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and $135,000, or 6 cents a share for the year, and the year also included a gain of $113,000, or 5 cents a share from an accounting adjustment.

title: Soviet Crisis Worse, Economists Declare
description: The economic crisis in the Soviet Union is worsening and forcing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev toward a faster and more radical reorganization of the system, say Western and Soviet economists at an international conference here.

title: In Brazil, Radical Capitalism
description: Fernando Collor de Mello, inaugurated today as Brazil's President, takes charge of a nation in deep political and economic crisis. Brazil is also Latin America's dominant country. That makes Mr. Collor potentially the most important political leader in the region.

title: Princeton Still Confident
description: After their showing in last year's National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, the Princeton Tigers should enter this year's tournament confident they can advance past the first round.

title: Tel Electronics Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for both periods were less than 1 cent a share.

title: Company News;   First Pacific Pact
description: First Pacific Networks, a private company based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it had received a contract worth $150 million over five years to supply telecommunications equipment for Costa Rica's telephone system. First Pacific's equipment allows telephone conversations and computer data, as well as television signals, to be transmitted over a cable television system or optical fiber. First Pacific said its equipment would be manufactured in Costa Rica as part of the agreement.

title: Drug Ruling Is a Setback For Amgen
description: In a blow to Amgen Inc., a Federal judge in Boston yesterday ordered the Thousand Oaks, Calif., biotechnology company and Genetics Institute Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., to end their long feud and exchange royalty-free cross-licenses on a highly profitable drug.

title: Fireplace Manufacturers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months results included pretax profits of $134,836 and $40,721 from commercial property.

title: N.F.L. Will Increase Frequency In Its Steroid-Testing Program
description: The National Football League will test players for steroid use more frequently, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue announced today.

title: From a Skeleton Come an Inquiry Into a Homicide And an Indictment
description: It was the kind of case that usually ends up buried deep in the anonymity of police files - the victim never identified, the killer never caught.

title: John Root, 85, Is Dead; Broadway Set Designer
description: John Root, a Broadway set designer, died of heart failure on Tuesday at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: Rostenkowski Plan: A G.O.P. Triumph
description: In offering a plan to balance the budget by 1994, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Dan Rostenkowski, was trying to avoid two tax traps. In the process, he fell into a political trap of his own making.

title: Aifs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the losses are after tax credits of $924,000 in the latest first quarter adn $207,000 in the year-earlier period. Also included in the latest first quarter loss is an unusual charge of $400,000 due to writedown of the company's investment in United Education & Software Inc. Year-ago first quarter loss is after a gain of $810,000, or 24 cents a share, from settlement of litigation.

title: Shift in Racing Account
description: The New York Racing Association, which owns the Belmont Park, Aqueduct and Saratoga race tracks, has switched its advertising account from AC&R Advertising to another Saatchi & Saatchi agency, Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. An industry executive said the account bills about $10 million. The lineage of William M. Backer, the president of Backer Spielvogel Bates, helped the agency win the account, an association spokesman said. Mr. Backer worked on the account back in the 1970's, when he and the account were at McCann-Erickson.

title: Century 21 Is Putting Its Account in Review
description: The Century 21 Real Estate Corporation said yesterday that it was putting its approximately $20 million advertising account up for review. The company said the competition would include the incumbent agency, McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles. It did not say who else would compete. McCann-Erickson won the account from Wells, Rich, Greene in 1983.

title: A Gallery Where Dogs Are Welcome
description: WILLIAM SECORD opened his new paintings gallery on Feb. 10, to coincide with the Westminster Kennel Club's annual show, which is the sort of thing you do when you specialize in dog paintings. His inaugural show, titled ''British Dog Painting, 1840-1940,'' which continues through March 31, includes 35 works that range in price from $3,500 to $34,000.

title: Bridge
description: A handful of teams, significant in the history of the game in North America, have achieved an identity as a group rather than as a temporary collection of individuals.

title: Don't Worry, Rabbi
description: Question: Sage, can you give us a real-life example of the meaning of chutzpah?

title: Rosamond Lehmann, 89, Writer Of Love, Betrayal and Rivalries
description: Rosamond Lehmann, whose novels of love, betrayal and family rivalries were critically acclaimed, died in her home here on Monday, her family announced today. She was 89 years old.

title: Phone Company Seeks Rate Increase
description: Six days after its proposed rate increase of $445 million was rejected, the New York Telephone Company has filed a request for almost twice that amount, a move that would raise the average residential bill by more than a third.

title: Black Poet Says Faculty 'Nazis' Blocked Tenure
description: Amiri Baraka, the black poet and dramatist, today compared the highest-ranking English professors at Rutgers University to Nazis and members of the Ku Klux Klan for refusing to grant him a tenured appointment to the English faculty.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Loss for Prudential-Bache
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. had a net loss of $51 million in 1989, compared with earnings of $111 million in 1988, its parent company, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, reported yesterday.

title: Paper Rejects Stock Plan
description: As had been expected, the board that controls The St. Petersburg Times voted unanimously yesterday not to redeem the company's preferred stock, which has become a pivotal issue in the recent battle for the Florida newspaper.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: BARRY UNDECIDED ON RUNNING AGAIN
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. acknowledged today that he had ''caused some pain among people in this city'' but he refused to rule out a run for re-election this fall despite his indictment on cocaine-possession and perjury charges.

title: Graham Martin, 77, Dies; Envoy at Saigon's Fall
description: Graham A. Martin, a career diplomat who was the last United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, died of a heart ailment on Tuesday at Forsythe Hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 77 years old and lived in Winston-Salem.

title: Nomura Official Looks To Develop a Business
description: After years of heading the futures desk at Kidder, Peabody & Company, Joseph R. Schmuckler realized he was ready for new challenges. It was getting increasingly difficult to make money in computerized program trading in domestic markets, where Mr. Schmuckler made his reputation, and he felt he was ready for something more.

title: Browns Sign Clayborn
description: The Cleveland Browns yesterday signed Raymond Clayborn, a three-time Pro Bowl cornerback with the New England Patriots. Clayborn, 35 years old, who has played for New England since beginning his pro career in 1977, was an unprotected free agent. He has 36 career interceptions, seventh among active N.F.L. players.

title: Philadelphia Journal;   The Genius of Franklin As a Lure for Tourists
description: Three million tourists visit this city each year, but the Convention and Visitors Bureau says most people stay only long enough to satisfy their top three desires. In order, they are: finding a bathroom, visiting the Liberty Bell and running up the steps of the Museum of Art as enshrined in the movie ''Rocky.''

title: Review/Theater;   'Prelude to a Kiss,' a Fairy Tale Of Souls in Love and in Flight
description: Peter, the ingenuous hero played by Alec Baldwin in ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' loves the sign at the roller coaster: ''Ride at Your Own Risk.'' It promises a journey into ''the wild blue'' in which anything can happen. The same sign could be posted at ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' for Craig Lucas, the author of ''Reckless'' and ''Blue Window,'' has again written a play that propels the audience through hairpin emotional turns, some soaring heavenward and others plummeting toward earth, until one is deposited at the final curtain in a winded and teary yet exhilarating state of disorientation.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Narrow Victory on Vote
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev narrowly avoided being forced to face the first general election of his life today.

title: Westerbeke Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss

title: In Drugs, the Quality, Not the Name, Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: A RELIGIOUS PARTY HOLDS SHAMIR FATE
description: The fate of the Israeli Government and its peace initiative lies in the hands of a small, rigorously Orthodox religious party that won 1.5 percent of the vote in the last national elections.

title: Judge Says 2 Law Firms Must Tell Names of Clients Who Paid Cash
description: A Federal judge has ruled that two law firms in Manhattan must tell the Internal Revenue Service the names of five clients who paid their lawyers in cash. He said his decision would not compromise lawyer-client confidences.

title: 47 on Plane Arrested as Illegal Aliens in Atlanta
description: The immigration service said today that it had arrested 47 illegal aliens at the Atlanta airport early this morning during a stopover on a flight to New York from Los Angeles. The arrests closely paralelled an operation a year ago.

title: Walshire Assurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Another Hurdle to Seabrook License Is Lifted
description: A Federal appeals court today declined to issue a stay that would have blocked a full-power license for the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Latvian Lawmakers Ask Gorbachev to Begin Talks on Their Republic's Independence
description: Members of Parliament from Latvia petitioned President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to begin talks with them about gaining independence for their republic.

title: Texas Democrats Brace for a Runoff
description: After months of bitter campaigning, Texas Democrats had little to celebrate the day after their gubernatorial primary.

title: Review/Music;   Oratorio by Elder Scarlatti On Abraham and His Sons
description: History remembers Alessandro Scarlatti for the same wrong reasons as it does Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach. The first is known as the father of a famous son (Domenico), the second as the son of a famous father (Johann Sebastian). Yet from his musical stronghold in Naples, the elder Scarlatti dominated Italian opera in the latter half of the 17th century much as the younger Bach presided over Central Europe's transition from Baroque to Classical style about 75 years later.

title: Review/Television;   Ireland Celebrated in a Series of Special Programs
description: When the time rolls around for St. Patrick's Day, two things are certain: silly greeting cards and an unseemly squabble about selecting a grand marshal for the annual parade in New York. This year, its 229th anniversary, the event will once again be telecast live on Channel 11, beginning at noon. The Irish Tourist Board could hardly hope for a better commercial than these neatly packaged Irish colleens who are employed to attract travelers and multi-national corporations.

title: Subway Killing Suspect Tells Inquiry It Was Self-Defense
description: Rodney Sumter, the construction worker accused of killing a homeless man who attacked him on a Manhattan subway platform, told a grand jury yesterday that he had fought back in self-defense and to protect his 3-year-old son, his lawyer said.

title: U.N. Seeks to Take Over the Running of Cambodia
description: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council called on the four warring Cambodian factions today to agree to transfer ''all necessary powers'' to United Nations peacekeepers who would help administer the country and supervise free elections.

title: Charlotte Jo Avers, 63, A Professor of Biology
description: Charlotte Jo Avers, an educator, author and researcher in cell biology, died of cancer on March 6 at her home in Millstone, N.J. She was 63 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East;   East German Alliance Suffers a Blow
description: The conservative East German coalition allied with the West German Chancellor in the campaign for Sunday's East German elections suffered a damaging blow today when one of its leaders resigned after admitting he had been an undercover agent of the ousted Communist regime's secret police.

title: German Businesses Racing Toward Unity
description: While politicians take the spotlight in the days leading up to East Germany's landmark elections Sunday, business executives have been working feverishly behind the scenes to build a united Germany, brick by brick, deal by deal.

title: Computer Automation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $321,000 for both the quarter and 6 months which reflects loss on disposal of discontinued operations, which resulted from reducing the estimated realizable value of assets of the discontinued operations of $1.5 million from $2 million due to current discussions to sell the assets at the lower price. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $291,000, or 12 cents a share for the quarter and $439,000, or 18 cents a share for the 6 months.

title: Cuomo Writes Letter to Defend Abortion View
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, whose views on abortion recently prompted a Roman Catholic bishop to say the Governor risked going to hell, has written a 3,000-word letter defending his position.

title: Sonora Gold Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included $49.6 million writedown of Jamestown Mine. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Inventories Increase by 0.2%, Reversing December's Drop
description: Business inventories resumed their slow growth in January after a one-month decline, the Government reported today. But analysts said the gain of two-tenths of a percent confirms the sluggishness in the manufacturing economy.

title: Filmstar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30, from May 31.

title: Higher Profits at Auction Concerns
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. said today that its earnings for 1989 rose 82 percent from the period a year earlier, while another fine arts auction house, Christies International P.L.C., reported a 61 percent profit gain.

title: Royal Gold Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain on the sale of the interest in Bittner Packers Ltd. of $989,000, or 6 cents a share for the quarter and a loss of $244,000 which included a gain on the sale of Bittner Packers. The exact amount wasn't disclosed due to change in accounting policy. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ritter Gave Big Contracts To Relatives
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter awarded his niece and her husband fees of about $350,000 under multimillion-dollar no-bid contracts for work on Covenant House buildings around the country since 1982, the couple and officials of the organization said yesterday.

title: Another Great Drooper
description: To The Home Section:

title: Company News;   MGM/UA Tender Is Begun by Pathe
description: The Pathe Communications Company began its $20-a-share, $1.22 billion tender offer for the MGM/UA Communications Company. Pathe was expected to release details of its financing but did not. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing in Washington, Pathe said only that it had received ''a non-binding'' oral commitment to provide up to $200 million for the purchase. The rest of the financing will come from banks and agreements to sell or license unidentified assets.

title: Hope For the Working Parent
description: FOR the nation's working parents, the news is mixed.

title: Review/Music;   Tone Poems and a Novelty From Sinfonia da Camera
description: The Sinfonia da Camera is ''the professional chamber orchestra in residence at the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champagne.'' The description is taken from the program of the orchestra's New York debut on Friday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Doctors Bear Blame For Society's Failings
description: To the Editor:

title: Money-Fund Yields Rise
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up for the week ended yesterday.

title: Century Medicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $289,000, or 1 cents a share for the quarter and $396,745, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Astro-Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Cuomo Plan for Drug Centers In Campus Settings Is Shelved
description: A Cuomo administration proposal to build two 1,000-bed drug-treatment campuses, hailed only two months ago as a cornerstone of the Governor's anti-drug-abuse strategy, is being shelved because of unresolved questions about siting, design and financing.

title: American Shared Hospital Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $569,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and included an extraordinary gain of $300,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. Latest year loss included a previously announced $1,500,000 reduction in the net book value of Five Mobile CT and MRI Systems in the third quarter.

title: Paris Set for Bastille Opera Debut (But Is the Bastille Opera Ready?)
description: Famous long before its time and for all the wrong reasons, the ultramodern $400 million Bastille Opera house finally raises the curtain on its first opera Saturday, hopeful if not confident that controversy will at last give way to applause.

title: Iraq Executes British-Based Journalist Convicted of Spying
description: Iraq said today it had executed a British-based journalist who was convicted last week of spying by an Iraqi revolutionary court.

title: Making Dead Land Live Again
description: THE job is not quick and dirty. It is slow and dirty. And the time line is not measured in years or even decades. For landscape architects and designers, the task of turning garbage into gardens - reclaiming landfills - means transforming a toxic mass into a livable place over time.

title: Chronicle
description: As president of the Creative Coalition, RON SILVER is leading a group of performing artists, painters and writers who plan to rally on the steps of the Capitol next Tuesday. Other artists' organizations will join with Mr. Silver's group to mobilize support for Congressional reauthorization of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities, whose appropriations expire Sept. 30.

title: Escape From Gridlock?
description: Maglev may provide the high-speed carriers of the future.

title: People
description: * Donald V. Gill has joined the McDonald Group, Atlanta, as a senior vice president and creative partner.

title: Q-Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Petroleum Helicopters reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said its improved earnings reflect a rate increase that occurred Aug. 1, 1989, as well as lowered expenses.

title: Piper Aircraft's Rescuer Falters
description: For M. Stuart Millar, a man once heralded as the savior of the struggling small-airplane industry, the dream has run into the reality.

title: McCormick & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included income and gain on sale of discontinued real estate operations of $80,338,000, or $1.81 a share. Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on Jan. 19, 1990.

title: Penn St. Defeats Marquette
description: DeRon Hayes scored 4 of Penn State's final 5 points and grabbed an offensive rebound in the final minute that helped seal a 57-54 victory over Marquette in a first-round National Invitation Tournament game tonight.

title: Request for Visit Denied
description: Iraq turned down a request by Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd to visit Baghdad this weekend to press Britain's request for clemency for Mr. Bazoft, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Thousands of Romanians Flood Austria as It Tightens Entry Policy
description: An estimated 5,000 to 7,000 Romanians have flooded into Austria over the last 24 hours in an effort to beat the latest tightening of this country's traditional ''open door'' policy toward refugees fleeing Communism in Eastern Europe, Foreign Ministry and refugee officials said today.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: El Salvador Says It Welcomes Rebel Overture
description: Amid signs of divisions within the ruling party, the Government today welcomed a rebel peace initiative as a ''positive gesture,'' but did not provide a reciprocal initiative as demanded by the guerrillas.

title: Andal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the decline in revenues in the current quarter compared to last year resulted from the divestiture in July 1989 of 75 percent of Andal's ownership in its business of trading and distributing flat rolled steel and tin mill products. After elimination of the divested business, pro forma revenues and net loss would have been $12,618,000 and $117,000, respectively, for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1988.

title: Baseball's Cooperstown Ruins
description: rr''Ladies and gentlemen and visitors from other planets,'' the tour guide announced. ''On our next stop during this inspection of the Cooperstown ruins, you'll be able to see the few bricks remaining from the Baseball Hall of Fame.'' ''The what Hall of Fame?'' a tourist asked. ''Baseball,'' the tour guide said. ''Baseball was once known as America's national pastime. But nobody has played it now for 100 years. Not since 1990 when everybody decided not to watch it or even talk about it anymore.'' ''Why did baseball die?'' ''There was a labor dispute in 1990 between the club owners and the players that wasn't settled until long after the season had been scheduled to start. When the season finally did open, nobody went to the games. Nobody even watched it on television.'' ''You mean spacevision?'' ''No, in the years before interplanetary travel, it was known as television. All the baseball games were on television.'' ''What happened to the baseball players?'' ''They showed up at what were known as collectors shows to sign autographs, but nobody would pay for their signature anymore. Some of them were able to get real jobs. But a lot discovered that they weren't qualified to get a real good job. Some of those players, excuse me, all those ex-players could do was make appearances at a game known briefly as switcheroo.''

title: Belmont Shortens Gold Cup And Oaks
description: Two of American racing's last remaining tests of endurance, the Jockey Club Gold Cup and the Coaching Club American Oaks, will be shortened from a mile and a half to a mile and a quarter this year, Belmont Park officials announced today.

title: SmithKline Beecham reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $559 million from the merger. Results are in U.S. dollars; U.S. dollar conversion has been at $1.6145 to 1 pound sterling for both periods.

title: KEY RATES
Sidney Shenkman, Executive, 69
description: Sidney Shenkman, chairman of Extebank, the United States subsidiary of Banco Exterior Group of Spain, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: McGrath Rentcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VOTE IS A REBUFF FOR CHIEF JUSTICE
description: A group of the country's most senior Federal judges delivered an unusual rebuff to Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist on Tuesday, voting to modify a legislative proposal that would have placed strict new limits on Federal appeals by prisoners on death row.

title: Retelling 'A Hundred Legends'
description: IN 1987, a handful of friends decided to put together something that would be a historical document about the experiences of people suffering from AIDS.

title: U.S. Federation Signs 2
description: Paul Caligiuri and Eric Wynalda have signed playing contracts with the United States Soccer Federation, the federation announced yesterday.

Brooklyn Man Held In Fatal Plunge
description: A 28-year-old Brooklyn man was indicted yesterday in the death of a woman who plunged from a rooftop during an attempted rape, the Brooklyn District Attorney said.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $638,746. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $567,962 and an extraordinary charge of $9,100,575. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Carter, in Syria, Gets Hostage Commitment
description: Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa met with former President Jimmy Carter today and repeated his country's commitment to helping free foreign hostages in Lebanon.

title: Title Fight a Step Closer
description: A heavyweight title fight between the champion Buster Douglas and Evander Holyfield, the No. 1 contender, moved a step closer to reality yesterday when a judge cleared the way for purse bids.

title: Chemdesign Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gain of $1,100,000 from sale of product lines. c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $306,500, or 4 cents a share. Year-ago fiscal income from continuing operations of $3,392,689, or 49 cents a share, included net gain of $800,000 from sale of product lines.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $212,000 for the quarter and $1,145,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $898,000, or 34 cents a share.
