description: b-Net loss

title: Club Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the favorable results reflect a continued increase in sales in the Asian zone and a strengthening of its position and margins in the American zone, which in this quarter benefited from a significant increase in sales in Europe.

title: New-Music Groups In Series at Columbia U.
description: A performance by Sonor, an ensemble from the University of California at San Diego, will open a three-concert series by new-music groups from around the country at 8 P.M. on March 28 at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street. The opening-night concert is to feature music by Brian Ferneyhough, Robert Erickson, Roger Reynolds, Joji Yuasa and others.

title: Not a Cute Problem
description: To The Home Section:

title: Valedictory By Chairman Of the 4A's
description: Almost two weeks ago, the American Association of Advertising Agencies sent a notice to members attending this year's annual meeting to inform them that a seminar on winning new business and negotiating compensation was already booked solid. But there was still plenty of space, the association noted, in the concurrent session on direct marketing, public relations and sales promotion.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Adults often complain that doctors do not take their headaches seriously. Instead of distinguishing between types of headaches and trying to ferret out the factors responsible for their recurrence, many physicians automatically attribute headaches to emotional factors and prescribe drugs to relieve pain and anxiety.

title: Serrano and Molinari for Congress
description: Voters will be filling two Congressional seats in a special election next Tuesday - one in the Bronx, another in a district that includes Staten Island and a piece of Brooklyn. The winners serve only until the regularly scheduled general election in November, but whoever prevails next week will have the advantage. That makes Tuesday's election particularly significant, worthy of voter attention and a high turnout.

title: New Leaders Of Ad Group
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday elected Keith L. Reinhard, the chairman and chief executive of DDB Needham Worldwide, as its chairman for the next year. Mr. Reinhard succeeds Glen W. Fortinberry, who is also the chairman, president and chief executive of the Ross Roy Group.

title: Rangers Halt Leafs But Lose Leetch
description: Brian Leetch, his broken left ankle immobilized, his face ashen, was wheeled through a hallway crowded with spectators and out the door to a waiting ambulance.

title: Toys 'R' Us Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Beauty Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the latest quarter loss in part to sales returns of about $572,000, consisting primarily of the company's overnight nail miracle product, and about $215,000 of charges to increase inventory and bad debt reserves.

title: West Virginia Schools Shut for Rest of Week
description: Classes at public schools were canceled statewide today for the rest of the week after teachers rejected the latest proposal to end a weeklong strike.

title: Petrie Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on extinguishment of long-term debt of $57,100,000, or $1.22 a share. The company said that as of May 1, 1988, it ceased accounting for its investment in the common stock of Toy 'R' Us Inc. on the equity method. Petrie's share of their earnings through that date amounted to $4,533,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: Tubbs Has Sooners on the Run;   Oklahoma Coach Is Determined to Do Things His Way
description: Whether he is coaching or talking, Billy Tubbs never avoids a challenge. He says what he thinks, he coaches the way he believes, and when people find fault with him he rarely loses sleep.

title: Flight Crew's Drinking Prompts F.A.A. Action
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, responding to accusations that it mishandled a tip about drinking by an airline crew, today announced measures to improve its response in similar situations.

title: Salomon Seen Nearing Deal on Shearson Unit
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. is in final negotiations to purchase an asset management subsidiary of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., people involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Review/Dance;   Merce Cunningham Asks Questions in a Premiere
description: A great deal of activity always takes place within Merce Cunningham's dance pieces although very little of it is meant to be tangible or comprehensible in a narrative sense.

title: Greek Bank Faces Charges
description: A leading Greek bank and 13 of its employees were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on Federal charges of carrying out a money-laundering scheme that enabled clients to evade taxes on millions of dollars.

title: Chicago Rivet & Machine reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: STAINED grout between ceramic tiles can generally be cleaned with a liquid grout cleaner available from tile stores or with acid applied by a professional tile setter. But if the cement filler is cracked, crumbling or missing, it must be replaced. Otherwise tiles can shift and break, or water can seep behind them and cause major damage.

title: New Season At Met Opera Offers Debuts Of 2 Directors
description: The Metropolitan Opera is to offer its first production of Leos Janacek's ''Katya Kabanova'' in the 1990-91 season. The work, which will be the Met directing debut of the English director and author Jonathan Miller, will be one of five new productions in a 30-week season.

title: Negotiators Led to Water but Don't Drink
description: Negotiators in baseball's labor dispute saw each other in Manhattan yesterday, but they did not negotiate.

title: Bonray Drilling Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Big Splash for 'a Basketball Guy';   UConn's Calhoun Went From Success to Struggle to Success
description: It wasn't really necessary for the sun to come up Monday morning. For as the regulars came into the Sugar Shack, on the edge of the University of Connecticut campus in Storrs, the afterglow would have been more than enough.

title: Coverings for Floors And Walls and Chairs
description: THE quilted and reversible Jacquard rugs (or tapestries) can be put on the floor, hung on the wall or thrown over the sofa.

title: Split Between Army and Marines Surfaces in Debate on 3d World
description: The behind-the-scenes rivalry between the Army and the Marine Corps burst into public view today as the leader of each service laid claim to being the primary force for American military operations in the third world.

title: Company News;   Lockheed Proxy Battle Intensifies
description: The Lockheed Corporation maintained in newspaper advertisements today that Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor waging a proxy fight for control of the company's board, does not understand Lockheed's businesses. ''To our knowledge, neither Simmons nor any of the other NL director nominees has any experience as an executive officer with a major company in the defense industry,'' the advertisement said, referring to Mr. Simmons's company, NL Industries.

title: Trans-Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: c-Net loss and included $383,000 of income primarily from the sale of land previously held for investment.

title: Isomedix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $631,271, or 13 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: SOVIET PARLIAMENT ELECTS GORBACHEV TO THE PRESIDENCY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev won election today to a new executive presidency with the powers he says he needs to prevent the Soviet Union from crumbling under the weight of economic and ethnic crises.

title: Sunshine Mining Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Edison Brothers Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from extinguishment of long-term debt of $4,300,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said year-ago periods ended Dec. 31, 1988.

title: Optrotech Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Plant Said to Make Poison Gas in Libya Is Reported on Fire
description: A chemical plant in Libya, thought by the United States to be producing poison gas, was reported ablaze tonight.

title: One Housing Agency Is To Run Another
description: The Jersey City Housing Authority will be paid $100,000 by the Federal Government to try to repair and reorganize the embattled Passaic Housing Authority, officials said yesterday.

title: Bond News;   Preferred Issue From Allstate
description: Allstate Municipal Premium Income Trust yesterday commenced offering $125 million in adjustable-rate preferred stock through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds.

title: Savings Plan Challenged
description: A Federal judge is taking a constitutional challenge of President Bush's savings and loan association rescue program under consideration after acknowledging that a ruling against the Government could have a far-reaching impact. The Olympic Federal Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill., asked United States District Judge Royce C. Lamberth on Tuesday to block any Federal takeover of the weakly capitalized savings and loan association.

title: Report Indicates Ware Will Enter N.F.L. Draft
description: Andre Ware, the 1989 Heisman Trophy winner, will enter the National Football League draft next month and skip his final year at the University of Houston, The Houston Post reported yesterday.

title: Fed Survey Shows Growth Remains at a Sluggish Pace
description: The nation's economy continues to grow despite widespread weakness in the auto industry and a gradual slowing in construction activity, according to a survey by the 12 Federal Reserve banks published today.

title: Study Finds Less Cause for Worry on Nightmares
description: There is reassuring news about sleep's most terrifying moment, the nightmare. A series of new findings show that though nightmares are far more common than scientists had thought, they rarely indicate deeper emotional problems.

title: Griffin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   U.S. WARNS ALLIES ON AID TO SOVIETS
description: The United States threatened today not to join a new financial institution designed to funnel the bulk of economic assistance to Eastern Europe if the Soviet Union were to become a major borrower from the organization.

title: Medical Action Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jane McIntire Grigson, Food Writer, 61
description: Jane McIntire Grigson, a British food writer, died of cancer on Monday at her home in Wiltshire, England. She was 61 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Scandal Erupts in Soviet Parliament
description: A growing arms sale scandal involving Kremlin officials plunged the Soviet Parliament into a furor today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sought unsuccessfully to keep off national television.

title: Contemporary Piano Recital
description: The pianist Kathryn Supove is to play a recital of contemporary piano music at Weill Recital Hall on March 29 at 8 P.M. The program, titled ''The Exploding Piano,'' is to include Lukas Foss's ''Solo'' (1981), Frederic Rzewski's ''Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues'' (1978), Giacinto Scelsi's ''Five Incantations'' (1953), and the New York premieres of works by Augusta Read Thomas and Randall Woolf. The pianist will also play works by Iannis Xenakis, David Lang and John Zorn. Tickets are $10 and are available at the box office. Information: 247-7800.

title: To Her Deepening Political Troubles, Thatcher Adds a Party in Rebellion
description: Well into her third term, Margaret Thatcher is in political trouble as deep as any she has been in during nearly 11 years as Britain's Prime Minister.

title: Talks on Satellites Stalled
description: Talks between United States and Japanese negotiators have failed to make progress in trying to open Japan's markets to foreign space satellites, a Government trade official said today.

title: Calendar: Religious Items and Greenery
description: Shared Heritage, Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue at 69th Street; 212-439-4837.

title: Bond News;   Some Macy Debt Ratings Are Lowered by Moody's
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that it had lowered some debt ratings of R. H. Macy & Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries the Macy Credit Corporation and R. H. Macy Overseas Finance N.V.

description: b-Net income

description: International A3-13

title: The Cobbler, and Spring, Are Missing
description: Imagine a New Yorker who has just returned from a month out of town, during which time (friends have told her) she hasn't missed a thing. There have been the usual dirt and disorder, deaths and divorces, but otherwise, they say: ''Nothing's changed. It's the same old burg.''

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: DURING a visit to a friend's house when he was 4 years old, Bobby Dunlop took a toy car and put it in his pocket. Within seconds after the visit, he held up the tiny car for his mother to see.

title: Strong Sense of Focus Keeps Evans on Top
description: Who is this Janet Evans, the swimmer who on Monday won the Sullivan Award as America's outstanding amateur athlete?

title: Networks Electronic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not Broadway. We want to start with a success, but it will be two or three years before we can see how the Bastille Opera is really doing.''

title: Company News;   A.T.&T. Division To Be Reorganized
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would break up its financing unit into a group of separate entities under a new umbrella, the AT&T Capital Corporation. The reorganization puts the former AT&T Credit Corporation into a family of holdings that will provide financing and equipment leasing services at different levels for American Telephone and other companies.

title: Museum Asks, What Are Un-Stately English Homes Like?
description: Reserve may lead the English to design their homes in certain ways, but where their homes are concerned the English are anything but reserved. Indeed one might describe the English person's attachment to home as passionate.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armor All Products Corp., Irvine, Calif., a maker of car care products that is 83 percent owned by McKesson Corp., named Kenneth C. Hicken, its chairman, to the additional posts of president and chief executive. He replaces Jeffrey M. Sherman, who resigned.

title: United Security Fincl Corp. of Illinois reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized investment gain, before taxes and expenses, of $553,433 from the sale of a private placement which had been held as an investment. c-Net loss

title: INSIDE
description: Tough Terms for Shamir

title: Recycled Paper Spurs a New Debate: What Is It?
description: The American paper industry has pledged to recycle 40 percent of its output by 1995 to reduce the amount of waste paper now being buried in landfills. But the president of a company specializing in selling recycled paper said much of what the industry calls recycled paper was mill scrap that had never been used by the public.

title: Company News;   Court Backs Nintendo on Video-Game Suits
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Nintendo of America Inc. may sue retailers who buy unauthorized Nintendo video games from its competitors, strengthening Nintendo's dominant position in the industry.

title: Florio Plans to Balance Budget With $1.4 Billion Tax Increase
description: Gov. Jim Florio, facing a growing shortfall in tax revenue, is to propose a state budget balanced with $1.4 billion in new and higher taxes on Thursday. The budgets of many agencies would be cut to achieve what he says is the first actual reduction in state spending in 14 years.

title: Notebook;   McNall Acquiring 2 Hefty Wings
description: Bruce McNall has been criticized for creating divisions among his Los Angeles Kings by allowing some players to fly home from games on his small private jet while others stayed in hotels and flew on commercial airlines the next day.

title: New Plan Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Crayons Fill Gaps On Illness
description: WHEN Dawn Zarzano, a fourth grader, sits down with her crayons at Public School 95 in Brooklyn, chances are that she is not coloring the latest Smurf character. She is more likely to be coloring in a new book that deals with epilepsy, diabetes, mental illness and hypertension.

title: Corruption Debate, on the Air
description: Soviet television broadcast a parliamentary debate in which a leading opposition member accused the Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, of corruption. Page A10.

title: Bush's Assault on Israel
description: LEAD: The mainstream of the pro-Israel community generally has supported the Bush Administration's Middle East diplomacy. But surprises in the past two weeks have undermined much of that confidence and raised fears that a new tilt is occurring on issues of fundamental importance. Shock waves hit Israel at the wrong time, dismaying the Likud and

title: Rolland Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a writedown of $4,526,000 resulting from restructuring of the Mont-Rolland operations. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: N.F.L. Shift By Turner
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc.'s eight-game package of National Football League games for each of the next four years will appear on the TNT cable channel, not TBS.

title: Shamir Urged to Ease New Censorship Ruling
description: The quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, in charge of most of Israel's immigration services, is appealing to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to loosen the military censorship that has been imposed on news reports about Soviet Jewish immigration.

title: Quayle Talks With Ortega
description: Vice President Dan Quayle met with President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua again today and received a favorable reaction to the Nicaraguan aid package outlined by President Bush on Tuesday, a United States official said today.

title: P.S.A.L. Title To Grady
description: The Public Schools Athletic League championships returned to the main arena of Madison Square Garden last night after an absence of 26 years and it made its re-entry into the big time with flair: three title games, slam-dunk and 3-point shooting contests, a double-dutch jump-roping exhibition and nary an untoward incident from the crowd of 6,352.

title: John P. Carey, Executive, 87
description: John P. Carey, founder and president of the Carey Transportation Company until it was sold to Greyhound in 1961, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old and had been a lifelong resident of Manhattan.

title: Paris Sugar Market
description: The Paris sugar market this week moved its operations across the exchange in a bid to revitalize futures trading. The Paris futures exchange, Matif, moved the sugar trading floor 770 yards to the financial futures center, placing it next to the French Government bond pit, where Matif's most active contract is traded. The exchange hopes that traders in financial futures will be drawn to the unusual volatility of sugar prices. The Paris market lost more than one-third of its volume between 1986 and 1989, largely because of competition from the computerized London market.

title: Selling American Clothes in London
description: Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein, Donna Karan. Even in England they're household names. Their clothes are sold alongside those of Britain's own Jean Muir and Bruce Oldfield and of European designers like Sonia Rykiel and Romeo Gigli.

title: Arthur Mead Irwin Jr., Publishers' Representative, 72
description: Arthur Mead Irwin Jr., the owner of Mead Irwin Associates, publishers' representatives, died of lung cancer on Tuesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 72 years old.

title: J.W. Mays reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $21,829 and $71,543 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $37,000, or 1 cent a share for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $3,554,882 for the quarter and $4,414,853 for the 6 months. The latest quarter and 6 months' income from continuing operations of $773,283, or 36 cents a share and $560,847, or 26 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, included a pretax gain of $436,696. The company said this represents an amount in addition to the gain reported as of July 31, 1989 upon the condemation of certain parcels of the company's property for use in the Brooklyn, N.Y., Metro Tech Urban renewal project. Revenue represents rental income.

title: Review/Theater;   'Mom's Life,' a Solo Show With Three Characters
description: ''How do I teach kids with everything a sense of longing? How do I teach them about kids who long for everything?'' asks Kathryn Grody midway in her autobiographical one-woman play, ''A Mom's Life.'' That is one of the more philosophical questions that punctuate a breathless 90-minute monologue evoking, in occasionally smothering detail, the joyous but harrying experience of bringing up two young boys on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: The Curvaceous Baroque Is Given a Modern Manner
description: As the century of chrome and glass and right angles draws to a close, the curve is back. And with it, many design elements that have been out of favor, from putti to painted clouds, are reappearing.

title: Newalta Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 300 Protesters Call for Ouster Of Council's Education Chief
description: About 300 people, many of them college students, demonstrated outside City Hall yesterday, calling for the ouster of the chairman of the City Council's Education Committee for what they said was his racist attitude toward black and Hispanic people. The midday protest disrupted traffic in lower Manhattan and led to one arrest.

title: Clemson Defeats Manhattan, 79-55
description: Jackie Farmer, a junior center, scored 7 points in a crucial run that lifted Clemson to a 79-55 victory over Manhattan in the National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional tonight.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Earle Palmer Brown
description: Earle Palmer Brown said its Atlanta office had added several of the staff members and clients set loose by the reduction of Tracy-Locke's Atlanta office. Donald S. Morgan, the president of Tracy-Locke Atlanta, will take a still undetermined management position at Earle Palmer Brown, which said other staff moves were under negotiation. The clients confirmed as moving are Columbia Pictures, for the Southeast region, and the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, with combined billings of about $5 million.

title: Bellwether Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Zenon Rossides, Cyprus Diplomat At U.N. for 2 Decades, Dies at 95
description: Zenon Rossides, a diplomat who represented Cyprus at the United Nations for two decades, died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital after a stroke. He was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Woman in the News;   Firm Leader For Haitians Ertha Pascal-Trouillot
description: On a visit to Paris a few years ago with her husband, two thieves snatched the purse of Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, who on Tuesday became Provisional President of Haiti.

title: Mitchell Energy & DevelopFment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a $20,594,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Aubrey Wisberg, 78, A Writer and Producer
description: Aubrey Wisberg, a screenplay writer and producer with credits in more than 40 films, including ''The Big Fix'' and ''The Man From Planet X,'' died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chronicle
description: In the hopes of settling the dust that has swirled around the NBC ''Today'' show, BRYANT GUMBEL has acknowledged his role in hurting his own program. A year ago, Mr. Gumbel wrote an interoffice memo criticizing several aspects of ''Today,'' of which he is a host. After its contents became public, the show's ratings declined.

title: Alfin Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: TDK Account to HDM
description: After a creative shootout, TDK Electronics has awarded the $6 million account for its audio, video and computer recording products to HDM in New York. The other contenders included Della Femina, McNamee WCRS in New York; Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, and Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer. The previous agency was Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss.

title: PLM International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pioneer of Sit-In Movement Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News;   Combined Net Off at SmithKline Beecham
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said yesterday that it was encountering delays in reaping the benefits of the trans-Atlantic merger that created the giant pharmaceuticals and household products company last July.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 13 about reorganization plans by the American Jewish Committee referred incompletely to its intentions for a role in Western Europe and South America. The human rights group has since said that while ending its formal staff structure along geographic boundaries, it will continue to pursue issues of concern to the Jewish community wherever they arise.

title: Liqui-Box reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
General Magnaplate reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on the Business Technology page yesterday about a new type of video game misidentified the company that devised it. The company is the Very Vivid/Vivid Effects Group of Toronto.

title: ECI Telecom Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 816390 -- No Title
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, battered by the deterioriation in value of its huge ''junk bond'' portfolio, is trying to sell the entire portfolio as a unit in what would be the largest sale ever of the high-yield, high-risk securities, the institution's new chief executive said today.

title: Thousands Plan Life Below, After Doomsday
description: At least 2,000 followers of a religious group have streamed into majestic Paradise Valley here from around the world, preparing to spend years in underground shelters safe from the nuclear Armageddon they believe is imminent.

title: Savings in Japan Rise
description: Personal savings in Japan grew 11.2 percent in 1989, reaching a total of 700.08 trillion yen ($4.6 trillion) at the end of December, the Bank of Japan said on Tuesday. It was the largest yearly increase since 1981, the report said. Savings rose because of deregulation of interest rates on time deposits as well as larger company bonuses last year as Japan's economy boomed, the bank said.

title: Butcher Breaks Iditarod Record
description: Greeted by sirens, banners and shouts, Susan Butcher mushed into Nome in record time to win her fourth Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race in the past five years.

title: Getting a House Ready To Use From Toe to Cuff
description: DAVID and Annie Haines Keller have been restoring a shoe-shaped house near York, Pa., for three years, and in that time they have heard every shoe-related pun imaginable, including ''I'll bet this place keeps you on your toes'' and ''You must be well-heeled.''

title: Demand for Oil Off 6.7% in U.S.
description: Demand for oil dropped 6.7 percent in February, compared with the month a year earlier, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. But production fell even faster, so imports rose, according to the report.

title: Tarkanian's Rebels Jelling Right on Time
description: The University of Nevada-Las Vegas, the No. 2 team in the news-agency polls, will take its 29-5 record (including 15 victories in its last 16 games) into its opening National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game tonight against Arkansas-Little Rock (20-9) in Salt Lake City.

title: Total Energold reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included $18.4 million writedown of mineral properties and investments. c-Included writedowns of $38.1 million. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Wives' Revenge on a Much-Married Man
description: Demi Dieu (Bakary Bamba) is a big pineapple mogul in a small weedy Ivory Coast town, and by his own boastful lights he's a man to be reckoned with. (His nickname, labeling him a near deity, is self-chosen.) But to the five wives who minister to his every need and sometimes, when the mood strikes, feed him hot sauce so potent it makes him gasp, power is strictly relative.

title: Guam Approves Bill Posing a Challenge To Abortion Ruling
description: Nearly 9,000 miles from the Supreme Court, on the Pacific island of Guam, a territorial legislature has passed the most restrictive abortion legislation in the United States, a measure that explicitly challenges the constitutional right to abortion that was established in the landmark Roe v. Wade case. Since last summer's Supreme Court ruling in a Missouri case, which allowed states to limit access to services without removing the Federal right to abortion, advocates and opponents of abortion rights have been monitoring and lobbying the 50 state legislatures. But they say it never occurred to them that new legislation might originate on one of the far-flung islands where the United States has sovereignty.

title: Pepperell Acquires New Credit Lines
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. announced yesterday that it had established a new $1.2 billion credit facility with its major banks. It includes a $550 million term loan and a revolving line of credit of up to $650 million. They mature on Dec. 31, 1994. Interest on both will be at 150 basis points more than the prime rate, and the interest rates will be automatically reduced if the company satisfies certain financial conditions. The new credit facility, the company said, replaces a bridge loan that was to have matured on March 31.

title: Chronicle
description: For two years JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. has worked on a program to provide additional training for people working with the handicapped. Together with administrators at the City University of New York and health professionals, he helped develop Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities Studies, which started last month at the College of Staten Island. The program has 125 students, most of whom are recreation and home-care aides and want to advance in their careers.

title: Books of The Times;   In Fay Weldon's New Novel, The Devil Is a Man
description: The Cloning of Joanna May

title: New York Threatens to Reopen Census Suit
description: Lawyers for New York City have decided to return to court to force the Commerce Department to adjust the results of the 1990 census to compensate for people who were not counted.

title: Not-Guilty Plea in a Slaying
description: A Peekskill High School sophomore pleaded not guilty today to charges that he raped and killed a classmate. The student, Jeffrey Mark Deskovic, 16 years old, is accused of raping, beating and strangling 15-year-old Angela Correa, whose body was found last Nov. 17 in the woods near an elementary school. She was last seen on Nov. 15 when she left home to take pictures for a photography class.

title: A Lost American in Lebanon: After 5 Years, Trail Is Faint
description: Five years ago today in Beirut, in the clear light of a city that was just waking up to another weary morning of war, Terry A. Anderson played tennis for an hour on a court by the sea.

title: VATICAN RESUMING TIES WITH MOSCOW
description: The Roman Catholic Church and the Soviet Union re-established permanent official contacts today in a move that was expected to lead to a papal trip to the Soviet Union.

title: Upheaval in the East;   GORBACHEV TAKES NEW POST AND PLEDGES TO SPEED MOVE TOWARD A MARKET ECONOMY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev assumed the Soviet Union's new executive presidency today, and vowed to use his added powers to move his reluctant country more rapidly in the direction of a market economy.

title: Review/Music;   Two French Church Organists in Recitals
description: In France, the position of titular organist of a cathedral carries a kind of prestige that the closest American equivalent - a church organist post - does not quite equal. The reasons are complex and culture-bound, but to a large extent the status of French church posts grows from the fact that so many of the organists who held them were also composers who left enduring repertories of organ works and liturgical settings.

title: Chronicle
description: After three months of head-scratching on how it would fulfill its commitment to make JANE PAULEY a prime-time star, NBC has a plan. Yesterday, MICHAEL G. GARTNER, the president of the news division, announced that DAVID BROWNING would create five specials for Ms. Pauley, a former co-host of the ''Today'' show. Mr. Browning, a news producer for CBS in Los Angeles, will go to NBC as the executive producer of the programs, to be shown this summer as a kind of tryout for a weekly prime-time series. If the tryout plan sounds familiar, that's because it was precisely the way NBC introduced ''Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow'' last year; also an attempt to begin a successful prime-time news program, it failed. Ms. Pauley's first prime-time special since she left ''Today'' in December was broadcast on Tuesday and led the ratings.

title: John A. Onderdonk Jr., Cardiologist. 55
description: Dr. John Adrian Onderdonk Jr., chief of cardiology at the Chestnut Hill Hospital in Philadelphia, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Radnor, Pa. He was 55 years old.

title: A.T.&T. Offers Pension Shifts
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday offered a series of pension plan changes, including early retirement incentives for at least 20,000 non-management workers, to two unions yesterday.

title: New Poll Indicates Confusion Among Voters on Democrats
description: A new poll conducted for a Democratic group underscores what many Democrats feared: The voters have little sense of what the Democratic-controlled Congress is doing.

title: Review/Dance;   A Cunningham-Warhol Work Is Revived
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company is dancing fantastically at the City Center, where its second program of the season, on Wednesday night, included the premiere of Mr. Cunningham's ''Inventions'' as well as ''Rainforest'' and ''Pictures'' -wondrous works both.

title: Rebels Said to Kill 19 in Peru
description: Shining Path guerrillas shot and killed 19 peasants, nearly all of them women and children, in a small Andean hamlet where they had fled to escape rebel attacks in their own village, the police said today. The reported massacre occurred late Tuesday in Pishupiaco, 60 miles southeast of Huancayo, a major trading center in the Andes 120 miles east of Lima. The victims were 11 children between the ages of 2 and 10, 7 women and a 26-year-old man, the police said.

title: Skylink America reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included about $350,000 of depreciation and amortization charges. c-Net income The company added that interest expense increased to $119,187 in the current quarter from $2,246 a year ago.

title: Core Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Helping Airports Take Off
description: LEAD: The Transportation Department recently released an extensive study of airline deregulation and concluded that with a few exceptions, all is well. One of those exceptions is airport congestion.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 5 about marchers crossing the Edmund Pettis Bridge in Selma, Ala., on the 25th anniversary of the racial violence there, omitted the identity of the man at the right. He was Representative Donald M. Payne of New Jersey.

title: Lorraine Lester, Producer, 88
description: Lorraine Lester, a producer who worked in theater, films and television, died after a heart attack on Wednesday in the Coronary Care Unit of the New Rochelle Medical Center. She was 88 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Okinawan Folk Hero Fights The Good Hopeless Fight
description: This year's New Directors/New Films festival begins this evening with Go Takemine's ''Untamagiru,'' a colorful, satiric but often obscure variation on what is said to be a famous Okinawan folk legend. The film will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art at 6 P.M. and again at 3 P.M. on Sunday.

title: Chronicle
description: PRESIDENT BUSH says REPRESENTATIVE RICHARD A. GEPHARDT of Missouri, the House majority leader, really, truly, does not get under his skin, notwithstanding Mr. Gephardt's biting attacks on Mr. Bush's foreign policy. Yesterday, Mr. Gephardt put him to the test.

title: 3 Youths Stabbed, One Fatally, in Fight In the East Village
description: Three young men were stabbed, one fatally, during a fight last night with a group of youths on a street in the East Village, the police said.

title: Butchery in Baghdad
description: ''Thatcher wanted him alive. We sent him in a box.'' Such was the Iraqi Information Minister's grisly attempt at levity yesterday after his Government hanged Farzad Bazoft, a British-based journalist, as an alleged spy for Britain and Israel. Defying clemency pleas from Prime Minister Thatcher, the European Community and the U.N. Secretary General, Iraq has nailed its own sorry reputation in that same box.

title: Isao Sato, Actor, 40
description: Isao Sato, a Japanese-born actor who appeared in Broadway and Off Broadway productions, died on March 9 when his airplane collided with another near Miami. He was 40 years old.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-11

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Review/Theater;   'Heart of a Dog,' a Parable On the Ills of Soviet Society
description: Mikhail Bulgakov's novel ''Heart of a Dog'' is a malicious political parable on what the author envisioned as the inevitable corruption of a socialist state. Written in 1925 (and unpublished in the Soviet Union until 1987), the book follows the rise and fall of a mongrel scientifically transformed into a man but unable to avoid the curse of atavism. Behavior that is acceptable, even ingratiating, in a canine is indecent in a human.

title: George Sands Hastings, Lawyer, 90
description: George Sands Hastings, a retired vice president of the American Machine and Foundry Company, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 90 years old.

title: Notebook;   Where Are the 3-Year-Olds? Not Florida Bound
description: The hardest thing to handicap about the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park this Saturday is why nine horses were entered instead of 59.

title: Seller of Expensive Cigars Stops Buying From Cuba
description: Davidoff International, whose Havana cigars are among the most expensive and prestigious in the world, has formally ended relations with Cuba.

title: George R. Lyon, 67, Advertising Executive
description: George Robert Lyon, an advertising executive, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco. He was 67 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday headed ''Philadelphia Journal,'' about a tourism campaign featuring Benjamin Franklin, gave an incorrect date for a funeral procession to commemorate his death. It will be April 21; Franklin died April 17, 1790.

title: Apple Expects Strong Results
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that financial results for its second fiscal quarter, which will end March 30, will be better than previously expected.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Sarabeth's Kitchen

title: Guitarist to Perform
description: Scott Tennant, a guitarist, is to play music by Mauro Giuliani, J. S. Bach, John Dowland, Heitor Villa-Lobos, Joaquin Rodrigo, Andrew York and Carlo Domeniconi at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. Tickets are $10 to $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: 18 Rms. Riv Vu. Ghosts.
description: The bedrock legal principle of caveat emptor - ''let the buyer beware'' - applies just as much to ghosts as to shady Florida land deals, a judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: New Goldome Certificates Are Priced to Yield 10.3%
description: A $390.6 million sale of certificates backed by home equity loans from the Goldome Savings Bank of St. Petersburg, Fla., and serviced by the Goldome Credit Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Rams Rout Southern To Gain Second Round
description: It took 22 years and 10 trips to the National Invitation Tournament, but Fordham finally won another N.I.T. game last night.

title: Women's History Month Events
description: Women's History Month is being celebrated with a variety of events in New York City. Here is a sampling of events this weekend. For more information, consult the Women's History Month Calendar published by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, 52 Chambers Street, Suite 207 (566-3832).

title: Islanders Show Anger As Slump Grows to 14
description: Of the Islanders' 11 defeats and three ties in their 14-game slump, tonight's 5-4 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers was among the most maddening. One Islander showed his frustration at the final buzzer with a display of temper that might draw a review from league authorities.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anderson Mavor Investments Ltd., Glasgow, a unit of Anderson Group P.L.C., began a tender offer to buy all outstanding shares of National Mine Service Co., Indiana, Pa., a mine supplies company, that it does not already own for $8.875 a share, or a total of about $22 million.

title: Witness to Slaying Kills Assailant but Isn't Charged
description: A man shot to death a killer fleeing a slaying at a shopping mall in the suburban town of Irving on Monday, the police said, but they have decided to not file charges against him.

title: Stalking Greatness At the Age-30 Frontier
description: Although Paul Azinger has been the PGA Tour's most consistent player for the last three years, it is hard to resist judging him for what he may become rather that what he already is.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Pact Due
description: The United States and the Soviet Union should be able to seal a new long-term grain trade agreement at a meeting next week in Vienna, the chief United States delegate to the talks said today ''As far as I am concerned, we can and should wrap it up next week,'' said the deputy trade representative, Jules Katz, who will lead the American team to the meeting.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Tuesday about the funeral of Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball player, misidentified the housing project where he grew up and the college for which his brother Derrick plays basketball. Mr. Gathers lived in the Raymond Rosen Projects in Philadelphia. His brother plays for California State Polytechnic University, Pomona.

title: TRADE TALKS FAIL TO PRODUCE GAINS FOR U.S. OR JAPAN
description: Six months after opening talks on the deep-rooted causes of their trade problems, Japan and the United States are dissatisfied with each other's concessions. And the Japanese are fearful that the discussions themselves are making tensions even worse.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Review/Film;   Mingling Sex and Politics In a Gay Bar in Manila
description: ''Macho Dancer'' wants to be a sexy homosexual film and to comment about social conditions in the Philippines at the same time. But before long it's easy to discover the true interests of the director, Lino Brocka.

title: Economic Scene;   U.S. Lessons For Soviet Reform
description: DESPITE Mikhail S. Gorbachev's high standing abroad and his unopposed election as the Soviet Union's first Executive President, his popularity appears to be sinking like a stone with his own people as a result of his failure to deliver on his economic promises.

title: Harold Medina, U.S. Judge, Dies at 102
description: Harold R. Medina, a Federal judge for more than three decades, who achieved lasting fame for his handling of the trial of 11 Communist leaders in the 1940's, died in his sleep on Wednesday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., where he was admitted on Monday with a slight fever, his grandson Standish Forde Medina Jr. said. Judge Medina was 102 years old. Judge Medina, who retired from the bench at the age of 92, lived at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood. He had made his home for many years in Westhampton, L.I. He also maintained an apartment in Manhattan.

title: Orlando Joining the World League
description: Orlando was awarded the first World League of American Football franchise today as the National Football League club owners concluded their five-day meeting here.

title: At the Movies
description: South of the Border

title: Michigan State Edges Murray State in Overtime
description: Someone apparently forgot to tell 16th-seeded Murray State it had little chance to win its opening-round game with top-seeded Michigan State today in the Southeast Regional.

title: Executives Making Bid For Saks
description: The management of Saks Fifth Avenue said yesterday that it had joined forces with a Japanese retailer in an offer to buy the 46-store chain from B.A.T. Industries, its London-based parent.

title: Denying Pleas, Iraq Hangs British-Based Reporter
description: Defying all calls for clemency, Iraq today hanged an Iranian-born British journalist it had convicted of espionage, in what Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher described as ''an act of barbarism deeply repugnant to all civilized people.''

title: Bush to Streamline Advisory Panel on Intelligence
description: President Bush will soon make major changes in his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, converting what has been a wide-ranging watchdog over the intelligence community into a far smaller panel of expert policy advisers, Administration officials said today.

title: Central City Chorus
description: Charles Pilling will conduct the Central City Chorus in psalm settings and motets by Felix Mendelssohn and Johannes Brahms, and Mendelssohn's Organ Sonata No. 1, at 7 P.M. on Sunday at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. The soloists are to be Elizabeth Pruett, soprano; Deborah Andrews, mezzo-soprano; Darrell Lauer, tenor; Richard Christopher, baritone, and Lawrence Maycher, organist. Admission is $10. Information: 838-0808.

title: Lithuanian Move Rejected
description: The Soviet Parliament overwhelmingly rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence, but the resolution was stripped of vague threats of retaliation. Page A6.

title: Golden Defense Sends UConn Past Boston
description: Most of the sellout crowd at the Hartford Civic Center had watched in shock as its top-seeded Connecticut Huskies fell 3 points behind Boston University in the third minute of the second half tonight and called for a timeout.

title: Juvenile Justice Too Lenient in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop/Jazz;   The Pogues' Celtic Sound With a Dash of Punk
description: ''I've never been to New York on St. Patrick's Day before,'' said Shane MacGowan, lead singer for the Irish band the Pogues, in a recent telephone interview from London. ''I've got mates who've been there, and they say it's mad.''

title: Florio Defends Higher Taxes, Urging State to Face Reality
description: Gov. Jim Florio told the Legislature today that his plan to impose $1.4 billion in new taxes in the next fiscal year was unavoidable if New Jersey is to look the future squarely in the eye.

title: Syncor International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $170,000, or 2 cents a share, and $718,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $69,000, or 1 cent a share, and $128,000, or 1 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Knicks Expand on Loss Column
description: The Knicks lost the first time they played the Hornets in Charlotte. They did the same against the Heat the first time in Miami and the Magic in Orlando.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Marketing Gets a New Emphasis
description: Although some advertising executives worry that agencies are resisting the call to diversify the range of communications services they offer, there is increasing evidence that their message is getting through.

title: Christie's Sculpture Expert Resigns After Bid on Statue
description: The head of the sculpture department at Christie's London auction house resigned on Wednesday night after it was disclosed that he had tried to buy a statue that is now on the market for an estimated $11.2 million for about $5,200, a Christie's spokesman said.

title:
Condos by the Sea;

Housing in Long Beach For the Affluent Elderly
description: LEAD: After years of hectic construction activity, development in Long Beach, L.I., has slowed to one major project.

title: American Airlines
description: The AMR Corporation announced ambitious plans to spend $20.9 billion in the next five years to increase the size of its American Airlines fleet by about 50 percent, to 759 planes. AMR's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, said in a speech on Wednesday to employees at American's maintenance center in Tulsa, Okla., that the plan depended on profits generated by the current fleet of 510 planes. He said the airline expected to add 51 new aircraft to its fleet by the end of the year.

title: No Testimony by Hazelwood
description: Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood's defense lawyers rested today without calling him to the stand to give his own description of the Exxon Valdez grounding, which resulted in the nation's worst oil spill. After presenting one rebuttal witness, the prosecution also rested. Captain Hazelwood, from Huntington, L.I., is charged with one felony and three misdemeanor counts stemming from the spill of nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound in Alaska a year ago.

title: Cruise America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included pretax charge of $4,092,000 for a contested liability.

title: Beauty Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the latest quarter loss in part to sales returns of about $572,000, consisting primarily of the company's overnight nail miracle product, and about $215,000 of charges to increase inventory and bad debt reserves.

title: U.S. Steelmaker In French Merger
description: The J & L Specialty Products Corporation agreed to be acquired by the French stainless steel producer Ugine Aciers de Chatillon et Gueugnon S.A. Terms were not disclosed. J & L said that it would keep its Pittsburgh headquarters and that the Paris-based Ugine would appoint a new board.

title: Elmer L. Hann, 89, Shipbuilder Who Helped in Japan's Recovery
description: Elmer L. Hann, an American shipbuilding executive who was instrumental in rebuilding Japan's industry after World War II, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Kuakini Medical Center in Honolulu. He was 89 years old.

title: Youthful War Victims Help U.S. Teen-Agers
description: For Rouba Dabbagh, 19 years old, of Beirut, war means hiding in school for days at a time because if she leaves she risks being shot on the street. For Khim Chhay, 15, now of Los Angeles, it means recollections of running thousands of miles to escape the Khmer Rouge. For Dana Eloya, 16, of Ramat Gan, Israel, it means threats of reprisal for her work on behalf of Palestinian rights.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Whittle Magazine For Beauty Salons
description: Whittle Communications yesterday disclosed its plans to distribute its latest magazine in beauty salons across the United States. Called American Style, the oversized, slick magazine with short articles is modeled after Southern Style, which Whittle distributed to Southern beauty salons from 1987 to 1989.

title: S.E.C. Files Fraud Charges
description: Just out of college, Andrew B. Worden opened at least 30 brokerage accounts and defrauded several brokerage firms out of more than $130,000 through the practice known as free riding, the Securities and Exchange charged yesterday.

title: Value Line Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Study Asks New Safeguards For Refugees Asking Asylum
description: A new study by a public interest law group says that political considerations in the United States have undercut the humanitarian aims of the 1980 Refugee Act, and it calls for greater safeguards for those seeking asylum here.

title: Review/Film;   'For All Mankind,' or, the Joys of Space Travel
description: Three decades after American space travel began, some people remain amazed at this seemingly impossible accomplishment, while many others regard the idea of men on the Moon with calm, jaded acceptance. It is, after all, a scientific achievement that a generation has grown up taking for granted. ''For All Mankind,'' a documentary compiled from NASA film of the nine manned flights that went to the moon between 1968 and 1972, re-creates the sense of immensity involved in space travel: the grandeur of its ambition, the complexity of its physical details, the sheer infinity of space.

title: Cholesterophobia Spreads Through the Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Telco Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
INSIDE
description: No Trace of Drug in Gathers

title: New A.T.P. Chief
description: After what the board of the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour termed a ''long and exhaustive search and consideration of people inside and outside of tennis,'' Mark Miles of Indianapolis was unanimously selected yesterday as the new chief executive officer of the I.B.M./ A.T.P. Tour. He will replace Hamilton Jordan, who will become chairman of the board. Miles, 36 years old and a native of Indiana, is currently director of corporate relations for Eli Lilly and Company, an agricultural, medical-instrument and pharmaceutical concern with annual sales of more than $4 billion.

title: U.S. Sees Benefits for Peace Plan in Israeli Move
description: Bush Administration officials said today that the fall of the Israeli Government will cause at least a short-term pause in the peace process, but could actually enhance the prospects for Israeli-Palestinian negotiations in the long-run.

title: St. John's-Temple a Mirror Image
description: When the first round of this bracket of the East Regional opens with four games on Friday at the Omni, third-seeded Duke (24-8) plays unpredictable Richmond (22-9), surging U.C.L.A. (20-10) opposes always tough Alabama-Birmingham (22-8) and second-seeded Kansas (29-4) meets unheralded Robert Morris (22-7).

title: New Brazil Chief Vows Economic Revolution
description: Vowing to work a free-market revolution in Brazil, Fernando Collor de Mello was inaugurated here today, becoming the youngest President of Brazil ever and the first to be popularly elected in 29 years.

title: KEY RATES
Traffic Alert
description: Because of the St. Patrick's Day Parade tomorrow, a number of streets in Manhattan will be closed. The parade begins at 11:30 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue and heads north to 86th Street. Streets will close at 10:30 A.M. and reopen around 2:30 P.M.

title: Explosion in Rural Hamlet Raises Troubling Questions
description: Robert Shaffer first thought the strange white cloud might be fog. Then the ground shook. The air exploded. Flames flashed. A few hours later, after the fires died and the smoke cleared, eight homes in this rural hamlet, 40 miles southwest of Albany, lay charred and in rubble.

title: Reviews/Dance;   A Carnival of Music, Acrobatics and Sambas in the Aisles
description: It is carnival time at the Marquis Theater, where Franco Fontana's ''Oba Oba '90'' has settled in through April 22. As colorfully irrepressible as it was when it played in New York in 1988, the revue offers more than two hours of lavish production numbers, spectacular acrobatics and lilting music that take the audience on a somewhat haphazard promotional tour of Brazil.

title: Candle Recall: Nice Scent, French Style, Minor Blast
description: More bad news for the Perrier crowd.

title: OPEC in Strong Position at Meeting
description: OPEC oil ministers will start a meeting on Friday in which they will wrestle with how to play a strong hand: essentially whether to settle for oil prices at about $18 a barrel or to try to raise them.

title: On Stage
description: A Pair of Biographies

title: Absurd Theater At the Garden
description: rrNormally, at this time of year, we would all be fretting about one beloved baseball team or another trying to regroup amidst orange groves or cactus plants. But the owners and the players have locked themselves out of their own home and are now quarreling on their doorstep, the dummies. Just ignore them.

title: Fetter Has Busy Day: 1 Record, 2 Victories and a Finish in 3d
description: Ten years ago Jill Sterkel became the first woman to swim 50 yards faster than 23 seconds. Today, Leigh Ann Fetter became the first to break 22 seconds.

title: Accord on Defaulted Bonds
description: Holders of defaulted bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System could receive as much as 32 cents on the dollar or as little as 10 cents under an agreement announced today by two groups sharing a $753 million settlement fund.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Thompson Has Toys 'R' Us
description: After a six-year split, Toys ''R'' Us has returned its advertising account to the J. Walter Thompson Company. The creative director for the campaign will be Linda Kaplan, who is responsible for the company's catchy old theme song, ''I'm a Toys 'R' Us Kid.''

title: Xtra Board Is Ousted By Holders
description: A closely watched proxy fight, the first of several battles for corporate control expected this year, ended yesterday when shareholders of the Xtra Corporation ousted its management.

title: Campeau Divisions Will Miss Deadline
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation will not meet a bankruptcy court's mid-May deadline for filing a reorganization plan and will ask for more time, the lead lawyer for the department store chains said. ''We will be seeking an extension of the exclusive period,'' said David Heiman of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue at a court hearing. He was referring to a period granted under the Chapter 11 bankruptcy law during which the Campeau Corporation units have the exclusive right to plan their reorganization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All we can tell you now is that the five of us have the deepest conviction that Mongolian society should be entirely renewed, that democracy should develop, that all human rights should be insured, and that social justice must prevail.''

title: Plan Milk Production, Then Make Cow
description: Two scientists here have developed a technique to identify genetic traits in livestock in advance, making it possible to plan with unheard-of precision the milk or meat production of animals before they are born.

title: Chemdesign Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gain of $1,100,000 from sale of product lines. c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $306,500, or 4 cents a share. Year-ago fiscal income from continuing operations of $3,392,689, or 49 cents a share, included net gain of $800,000 from sale of product lines.

title: Threat Issued On Hostages
description: A Muslim group holding three American professors hostage threatened today to kill them if the United States Government fails to meet its unspecified demands.

title: Thermo Cardiosystems Promotes an Engineer
description: Thermo Cardiosystems Inc., which has developed a battery-powered device that can take over the pumping function of the heart, has named as its president Victor L. Poirier, a medical engineer who helped develop the new product.

title: ABM Gold Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Likud Couldn't, Labor Might . . .
description: LEAD: Is Israel a deadlocked democracy that cannot decide between war and peace? Does it exemplify tragically how domestic political interests hamper a nation's capacity to break a cycle of violence by bold initiatives? Or are we witnessing an admirable but painful struggle between genuinely alternative approaches to a critical decision?

title: False-Alarm Apology
description: Mike Abdenour, trainer for the Detroit Pistons, apologized to authorities in Auburn Hills, Mich., yesterday after pleading no contest in District Court to a misdemeanor charge stemming from a false emergency report. Abdenour conceded having a call placed March 6 to the city's 911 emergency number to report that a Detroit player had collapsed during practice. He said he wanted to test the emergency crews' response time in light of the death of Hank Gathers of Loyola Marymount. (AP)

title: Commtron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Sounds Around Town
description: Barron-Riley Trio

title: Upheaval in the East;   51 Years After Hitler Marched In, Prague Welcomes a German Chief
description: Fifty-one years to the day after Hitler arrived here at the head of an occupying army, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today greeted the President of West Germany with a speech that equated anti-German feeling with anti-Semitism, and an offer to build a Europe free of recriminations.

title: Bellwether Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
As Officials Brace for Delay, Owners Plan New Proposal
description: On the day baseball officials plan to announce the cancellation of the first games of the regular season, the owners' bargaining committee will make a new proposal to the union today in an effort to end the dispute that has kept spring training camps closed for four weeks.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Agency Votes to Sell Houses Owned by Savings Units
description: The Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency managing the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, today approved its first program to sell the housing stock of failed savings institutions to low- and medium-income families.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Soviet Congress Rejects Lithuanian Secession Move
description: The Soviet Parliament today overwhelmingly rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence as invalid, and it directed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to protect Soviet citizens and interests in the republic.

title: Scientists Seem Nearer Their Dream for Hydrogen: Making It Metal
description: Since 1935, scientists have dreamed of converting hydrogen into a metal with wonderful properties. Now, physicists have reported here that they are a little closer to that elusive goal.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: After 17 Years, Panther Conviction Is Upset
description: The conviction of a former leader of the Black Panther Party on attempted murder charges in the machine-gun attack on two New York City policemen in 1971 was reversed yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice. He ordered a new trial.

title: Chicago Rivet & Machine reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Television;   Telling the Story of Monty Python, in 2 Episodes
description: When the Monty Python troupe celebrated its 20th birthday last year, two documentaries were made by Tiger Television for the BBC for the occasion. They are now being presented on the Showtime pay-cable channel under the very appropriate umbrella title ''20 Odd Years.'' The first part, produced by Mark Redhead, is ''Life of Python,'' a collection of interviews with the performers, whose recollections are illustrated with clips from their television shows and films. It can be seen tonight at 10.

title: Market Place;   Some Opportunity In Country Funds
description: THE country-fund mania that swept share prices to a 31 percent premium at the end of January is subsiding. This means there may be some attractive investments soon in these funds that buy stocks in companies of a single country or region, analysts say.

title: Oscar J. Youngberg, Accountant, 94
description: Oscar J. Youngberg, a retired certified public accountant, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Huntington, L.I. He was 94 years old and lived in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Treasury Prices Ease in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits after Wednesday's strong rally and awaited the release of new economic statistics.

title: Review/Art;   In a Few Strokes, a World of European Elegance
description: Not for some time has New York City been presented with two more extensive drawing shows than ''Renaissance Into Baroque,'' at the National Academy of Design, and ''Woodner Collection: Master Drawings,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The latter includes some 150 works that form a virtual compendium of artistic activity in Europe since the Middle Ages.

title: Stuart MacClintock, Intelligence Aide, 70
description: Stuart MacClintock, a professor of philosophy who became an intelligence analyst for the Federal Government, died of cancer on Monday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 70 years old.

title: Lawyers at Legal Aid Deserve High Praise
description: To the Editor:

title: Hand-Bell Concert: 100 Clappers Clapping
description: THE pursuit of exotica is by now an unexotic commonplace of 20th-century musical culture. Most such pursuits range out to third-world terrain, the more distant the better. But it is perfectly possible to unearth exotica right in one's own backyard. And the practitioners of these strange rites often turn out to be ordinary folk.

title: Midwest Regional;   Razorbacks Deal Tigers a Heartbreaker
description: After 40 minutes of all-out effort and emotion, the Princeton Tigers left the Erwin Center tonight with sad faces and nothing to savor. The end result was another gut-wrenching post-season defeat.

title: Jury Acquits 3 In the Removal Of School Piano
description: Assemblywoman Aurelia Greene, her husband and a former Bronx school superintendent have been cleared by a jury on grand larceny and other charges stemming from the removal of a baby grand piano from a school to the Greenes' house in 1983.

title: Super Food Services reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 10
Ernakulam Journal;   A Success Story That All Can Read
description: A little over a year ago, K. R. Rajan got to thinking that sooner or later some place in India would be able to declare itself totally literate. In a nation where 500 million people cannot read and write, the achievement would be epochal.

title: Soviets Propose Reduction in Armed Forces of Unified Germany
description: The Soviet Union called today for cuts in the armed forces of a united Germany as part of any agreement on German unification.

title: 2d Raid on Late Flight in 2 Days Produces 53 More Illegal Aliens
description: Federal immigration agents raided an Eastern Airlines flight today for the second time in two days and seized 53 more illegal aliens, including three Romanians, the authorities said.

title: Yes, Economic Incentives for the Soviets
description: It is self-evident that the people of Eastern Europe have much to gain from freedom and democracy. What is less obvious, but no less important, is what America can gain: billions in defense savings, thousands of jobs, new markets and a chance to pull our children from the brink of nuclear Armageddon.

title: St. Patrick's Day: The Parade and Much More
description: It's a strange thing, the way the Irish take over New York on St. Patrick's Day. Strange because in this city of endless diversity - of citizens from the corners of the earth who have unpacked their bags to stay -the Irish are the best at persuading the rest of us that the rest of us, too, have some special attachment to that Atlantic island off the coast of Europe.

title: 27 Indicted on Charges Of Dumping Illegally
description: Twenty-seven people have been indicted on charges that they dumped thousands of tons of solid and hazardous wastes from New York City in Monmouth and Ocean Counties, officials said.

title: At the Bar;   Warning (from lawmakers): Never judge a lawyer by his matchbook cover.
description: Until now, perhaps the most maligned entrepreneurs in this city were its ''tin men,'' the fast-talking aluminum-siding salesmen depicted in a 1987 Barry Levinson movie of the same name. But if some newly proposed legislation is enacted, the tin men may be displaced by lawyers.

title: U.S. Indicts an Opium Warlord
description: The Justice Department today announced the indictment of a Southeast Asian opium warlord who, Government officials said, has supplied much of the heroin found on the streets of New York City in recent years.

title: Reviews/Theater;   A Kaleidoscope of Language Onstage and on Video
description: On one level, John Jesurun's ''Everything That Rises Must Converge'' is an incoherent play on the subject of language. That fact alone says something about the difficulty of communication, which is at the root of Mr. Jesurun's new work, a deeply layered multi-media theater piece that will leave audiences alternately fascinated and exhausted. Fascination wins by a millimeter, because of the playwright's originality and his command of theatrical and electronic techniques.

title: Worthington Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,688,000 and $2,022,000 which both included $750,000 aftertax loss from sale of U-Brand Corp. unit. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $509,000 for the quarter and $197,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 501 money market mutual funds increased by $60.3 million, to $390.77 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 154 institutional funds decreased by $789.5 million, to $91.01 billion. The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds were up by $716.5 million, to $133.62 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds rose by $133.3 million, to $166.14 billion, the institute said.

title: Southmark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net loss from discontinued operations of $9,806,000 and $4,851,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and also included an extraordinary credit of $238,000, or 1 cent a share, and $26,674,000, or 59 cents a share, for the same periods, respectively, from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Just Wait Till 1990!
description: President Bush's education goals for the year 2000 ring with all the certainty of old New Year's resolutions. In 1983 President Reagan issued a set of goals that included reducing the high school dropout rate from 30 percent to 10, by 1990. President Bush now calls for reducing the high school dropout rate from 30 percent to 10, by 2000.

title: Gansler Being Kept As U.S. Team's Coach
description: Despite criticism from some players over his constant lineup juggling, Bob Gansler won a strong vote of confidence yesterday to retain his job as coach of the United States national soccer team.

title: Church's Bomb Shelters to Be Inspected
description: Local officials said today that they would begin making random inspections of bomb shelters owned by a church group whose members are ready to live underground because they fear an imminent nuclear attack.

title: Commerce Secretary Issues Warning on Japan's Surplus
description: After two days of meetings with Japanese Government officials, trading companies and political leaders, the United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, warned today that Japan's trade surpluses had ''achieved a semipermanent status.''

title: Group Lifts Stake In Coles Myer
description: An investment group led by Solomon Lew, the vice chairman of Coles Myer Ltd., has raised its stake in the Australian retailing concern to 21.7 percent from 17 percent. The K Mart Corporation, the Troy, Mich., discount store chain, also controls 21 percent of the Coles Myer shares. Coles Myer, Australia's largest retailer, operates K Mart stores in Australia and New Zealand.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Spies of the Future
description: Why does the hound not bark?

title: Upheaval in the East;   Dissident Named Chief Of an East Berlin Party
description: With the first free elections in this country only three days away, a conservative coalition allied with the West German Chancellor elected a longtime dissident as its leader today to replace a man who admitted he had been an undercover agent of the ousted Communist Government's secret police.

title: Celebrating Changes in Czechoslovakia
description: The recent changes in Czechoslovakia will be celebrated with an evening of reflections by Czechoslovak writers and diplomats, and Czechoslovak music and theater at 7 P.M. on Sunday at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. The program, called ''Prague Spring 1990,'' also will include videotapes of the country's 1989 revolution and of an address by President Vaclav Havel.

title: Investigators For Schools Are Criticized
description: In a stinging report issued yesterday, the commission examining the New York City public school system said the work of the Board of Education's chief investigative arm was ''reminiscent of the Keystone Kops'' and deserved blame for much of the corruption and crime within the system.

title: 2 Plays, $5, a Bargain
description: At a time when theater ticket prices have reached $60, Playwrights Horizons is introducing a $5 ticket for two new productions at its second-floor Studio Theater at 416 West 42d Street. This springtime bargain, called the New Theater Wing, begins with ''Subfertile,'' a comedy by Tom Mardirosian about an anxious man celebrating his 40th birthday with a museum dinosaur skeleton. Performances are today, tomorrow, and Tuesday through March 23 at 8 P.M., Sunday and March 25 at 2 and 7 P.M. and on March 24 at 3 and 8 P.M. The series continues, from May 30 to June 10 with Migdalia Cruz's ''Miriam's Flowers,'' a play about a teen-age girl in the Bronx. Reservations: 279-4200.

title: Forest City Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,565,000 for both the quarter and year and an extraordinary credit of $1,690,000 which represents the gain on the early extinguishment of debt related to Forest City Southwest less the loss associated with the early extinguishment of letters of credit of apartment division for both the quarter and year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Rich and Poor in One World of Film
description: IF Whit Stillman's droll portrait of Park Avenue debutantes and their beaus catches on, it is quite possible that the acronym UHB (short for Urban Haute Bourgeoisie and pronounced ''ub'') will become a new slang term. UHB is the term invented in the film ''Metropolitan'' by Charlie, a bespectacled collegiate philosopher in an uppercrust clique nicknamed the S.F.R.P., for Sally Fowler Rat Pack, who hang out together at seasonal balls and in their families' gold-trimmed apartments over the holidays.

title: EFFORTS TO LIFT ERRANT SATELLITE
description: Engineers tried to lift an errant $150 million communication satellite into a higher orbit today so it will not plunge back into the earth's atmosphere in the next few weeks.

title: West Regional;   Ball State Triumphs With No Time Left
description: For Paris McCurdy of Ball State, beating Oregon State was a simple matter of following instructions.

title: Washington Talk;   Chief Justice Is Off Cue As the Curtain Is Lifted
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist usually has the votes he needs these days when it comes to deciding cases. Once he was the Supreme Court's most frequent dissenter, in the days when the institution's center of gravity was far to his left. Now he speaks for a solid conservative majority on many issues that come before the Court.

title: Autonomy for Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics Doesn't Count At Census Bureau
description: To the Editor:

title: License Issued to Seabrook
description: As expected, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today signed a full-power operating license for the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire. The signing came one day after the plant's opponents, including the State of Massachusetts, failed to persuade a Federal appeals court to issue a stay blocking the license.

title: I.B.M. Work Station Wins Test
description: In recent years the upstart personal computer known as a work station has spoiled the minicomputer business by attaining comparable speed at far lower prices. Now comes the first independent confirmation that a new work station from the International Business Machines Corporation can solve certain scientific problems faster than even one of the most powerful supercomputers.

title: Our Towns;   From Mean Turf To Green Lawns And Back Again
description: It was Scott Fitzgerald who observed that the very rich are not like you and me - and not, as Hemingway retorted, because they have more money. The same might be said of the very poor, and that, too, it is not merely a matter of money.

title: Restaurants
description: For several years so much attention has focused on Manhattan's downtown dining scene that one could forget there is anyplace to eat above 79th Street. While it is true that most gastronomic tributaries flow south, it is reassuring to paddle upstream and find some places holding their own.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   The Quayle Trip: Jaguars and Palms
description: Look, in that chair, who is that giving a lesson on handling television cameras? Is it a media consultant? Is it a press secretary? No, it's Vice President Dan Quayle.

title: A Drexel Brainchild Haunts 'Junk' Market
description: A once-obscure bond, invented by Drexel Burnham Lambert to encourage financing for takeovers and leveraged buyouts, is now instead contributing to problems in the ''junk bond'' market.

title: Review/Film;   A Deranged Yuppie With a Thing for His Lover's Gun
description: Kathryn Bigelow's police thriller ''Blue Steel'' gets off to a brilliant start as it introduces the bright, eager rookie Megan Turner (Jamie Lee Curtis) and meticulously examines the tools of her trade. With fetishistic fascination, Ms. Bigelow inventories every feature of Megan's brand-new uniform and, at the police academy's graduation ceremony, captures the tears of hope and idealism in her eyes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Monday about Simon & Schuster's purchase of a school software maker misidentified a textbook company previously acquired by Simon & Schuster. It is Silver Burdett. v
