title: Zonic Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods restated to reflect taxes, interest and penalties incurred from payroll and other related tax filings, deposits and payments.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Excerpts From Gorbachev Speech on Presidency
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech after being sworn in to an expanded Soviet presidency, as provided in translation by the official press agency Tass:

title: Bomb Destroys a French Mosque In Latest Display of Race Tension
description: A bomb explosion destroyed a mosque in western France today in what the police described as the latest manifestation of racial tensions in this country.

title: Drug Program Is Said to Curb Peer Pressure
description: A drug prevention program that teaches high school students ways to resist social pressure can significantly curb marijuana and cigarette smoking, but not alcohol consumption, a three-year study by the Rand Corporation has found.

title: Child Labor Violations Widespread
description: In a three-day nationwide sweep of businesses, Federal investigators found 7,000 children who appeared to be working under illegal conditions, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced today.

title: Coke's Prizes: Reporters Win
description: Seeking to get the word out about its latest promotion -soft drink cans stuffed with prizes - the Coca-Cola Company has sent 200 reporters samples containing $5 bills.

title: Rolland Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a writedown of $4,526,000 resulting from restructuring of the Mont-Rolland operations. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Hispanic Agents Maintain Bias Persists in F.B.I.
description: More than a year after a Federal court found widespread discrimination in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, tensions are growing among Hispanic agents who were at the center of the landmark lawsuit, and many say they are now the targets of retaliation by the bureau.

title: Libyan Plant Said to Be Out of Action Indefinitely
description: Bush Administration officials said today that Wednesday's fire at a Libyan chemical weapons plant caused extensive damage and knocked it out of operation indefinitely.

title: Brady Sees Bigger Role For S.E.C.
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Administration was studying plans to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission that would strip at least some authority from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Bioplasty Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Flames Make Most Of Lapses by Devils
description: The Devils were outclassed by the Calgary Flames tonight in addition to enduring uninspired performances by the vast majority of their players, and the result was a 5-4 defeat at the Olympic Saddledome.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Tuesday about a contract vote at the International Paper Company mill in Jay, Me., referred incorrectly to proceedings to remove the United Paperworkers International Union as bargaining agent for employees. An employee, not the company, filed the petition with the National Labor Relations Board for decertification.

title: 5,000 Files Erased From Poindexter's Computer
description: Two prosecution witnesses in John M. Poindexter's trial testified today that more than 5,000 computer messages were deleted from Mr. Poindexter's personal computer in late November 1986 after investigators began combing the National Security Council files for Iran-contra documents.

title: Century Medicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $289,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $396,745, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: National Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Hoechst to Buy A Carbide Business
description: A subsidiary of the Union Carbide Corporation will sell a specialty chemical business to the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, a West German company, for an undisclosed price, officials said. The Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Company said it had reached an agreement to sell its primary alcohol ethoxylates business. The chemicals are agents used to make household products like laundry detergents and cleaners.

title: NBC Sues Columbia And Sony
description: The National Broadcasting Company sued the Sony Corporation and its Columbia Pictures subsidiary today, charging that Columbia had sabotaged a joint venture with NBC to distribute home videos.

title: Western Union reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $5.6 million from settlement of negotiations with ITT Corp. in connection with the pruchase price paid for ITT World Communications Inc., income of $5.1 million from settlement of liabilities under a pension plan and a restructuring charge of $5.5 million. c-Included $215 million and $1.018 billion of restructuring charges for the quarter and year, respectively. Revenue for 1988 included $20,320 and $170,424, for the quarter and year respectively, of revenues from network services and other services formerly provided or to be discontinued, which are not included in 1989 revenues.

title: Review/Dance;   Reviving the Work of a Modern Pioneer
description: The Third Annual Doris Humphrey Festival, which continues through Saturday night at the Pace Downtown Theater (Spruce and Gold Streets) allows dancegoers to see some rarely revived works by one of the pioneers of modern dance. From the 1930's to the 50's, Miss Humphrey and Martha Graham were widely regarded as equally innovative choreographers. But since Miss Humphrey's death in 1958, many of her works have remained unproduced. And some of those that have been reconstructed have taxed their dancers' interpretive abilities.

title: Chronicle
description: The 16-year marriage of CHARLES SAATCHI, an advertising millionaire and art collector, and his wife, DORIS SAATCHI, was ended yesterday by a London divorce court judge. Mrs. Saatchi, 52 years old, was granted a divorce from her husband, who is 45, on the grounds that they had lived apart for two years, she in New York and he in London. Married in 1973, they have no children. Mr. Saatchi and his brother Maurice founded Saatchi & Saatchi, the vast advertising agency, of which he is now a director. It was once estimated that his collection of contemporary art included 800 works valued at more than $250 million.

title: West Having Trouble Collecting Soviet Debts
description: After decades of paying their foreign obligations in full and on time, some Soviet companies are having difficulty making payments on contracts with Western suppliers, according to West German bankers and businessmen.

title: Connecticut Bank Bill Advances
description: The Connecticut House and Senate on Wednesday approved legislation that allows out-of-state banks to buy Connecticut banks.

title: Covenant House, Still Unswept
description: Every day the news about Covenant House grows grimmer. And every day, therefore, it becomes more urgent to reassure the conscientious citizens whose contributions support the organization. The survival of Covenant House requires a wholly new board of directors.

title: Safe Oil Transport Requires Only the Will
description: To the Editor:

title: Gencorp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a loss of $1,000,000 for the latest quarter and the year-earlier period included income of $135,000,000, or $4.26 a share which included a gain of $137 million from the sale of broadcast properties.

title: What Makes Italy a Major Black Market in Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Green Light for Colt
description: Robert Irsay, the owner of the Indianapolis Colts, has granted Eric Dickerson, his unhappy star running back, permission to approach two teams - the Giants and the Redskins - in an attempt to put together a possible trade for himself. Coach Joe Gibbs of the Redskins said he did not believe his team could obtain Dickerson. George Young, the Giants' general manager, said negotiating a trade for Dickerson ''is not one of my priorities.''(AP)

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sammy Price's Pianism

title: The Cost of Fanaticism
description: Nancy Klein of Long Island, 10 weeks pregnant, was severely injured in a car crash on Dec. 13, 1988. For two months she was in a coma. Doctors had little hope that she would come out of it, but they thought she might have a better chance if she had an abortion. Her husband, Martin, told them to go ahead.

title: Shift at Kentucky Fried
description: The Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation said yesterday that the president of its American operations had resigned. Steven Fellingham, 44 years old, had been president of Kentucky Fried Chicken-USA since May 1988. He resigned yesterday to ''join another company,'' Kentucky Fried Chicken said in a statement. Mr. Fellingham has not named the company, a spokesman said. Mr. Fellingham is to be succeeded by Kyle Craig, 43, an assistant to Pepsico Inc.'s chairman, D. Wayne Calloway.

title: When Census Visits the Poor, Fear Often Answers
description: In a government-subsidized building in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx, a man in his early 60's shares a one-bedroom apartment with three relatives - his son, his daughter-in-law and their 9-month-old daughter - without the knowledge of the landlord, the welfare office and anyone else who might take an interest in such an arrangement.

title: Review/Film;   Hoods With a Habit, in 'Nuns on the Run'
description: Jonathan Lynn's ''Nuns on the Run'' must be some kind of gallant, upside-down certification of the awe in which most of us continue to hold Roman Catholic nuns.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about pillows that may cause infants to suffocate misidentified one pillow. It is Comfort Tote, not Comfort Tot.

title: Auctions
description: Avant-Garde Art

title: Rangers Hope Patrick Can 'Step to the Fore'
description: James Patrick, with a sobering visit to the hospital behind him and aware of a radically altered future, sat in the lobby of the Rangers' Toronto hotel early yesterday. The 26-year-old defenseman talked, paused, then shook his head over and over again.

title: Review/Art;   Extremes of Sculpture in 3 Bruce Nauman Shows
description: For nearly a quarter of a century, Bruce Nauman has specialized in sculpture that is grating and challenging, that refuses to take maybe for an answer. You may say yes, you may say no - you may say both in tandem. But indifference to the artist's figurative fragments, or to his abrasive multi-media installations, or to the intimations of violence that run throughout his art, is not very likely.

title: No Trace of Heart Medication In Gathers, Autopsy Indicates
description: An autopsy showed that Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball star who collapsed in a game and died shortly thereafter, did not take his prescribed heart medicine for at least eight hours before his death and presumably longer, the chief Medical Examiner said here today.

title: Drexel's 'Junk Bond' Pricing Service Ends Today
description: At the end of business today, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent filed for bankruptcy last month, will end its pricing service on more than 3,000 ''junk bonds,'' orphaning as many as 1,000 smaller issues in which other Wall Street dealers do not make markets.

title: Yankee Energy System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yankee Energy was created July 1, 1989, as a spinoff from Northeast Utilities. Prior to July 1989, operating results are as a division of Connecticut Light and Power Co., a Northeast Utilities subsidiary.

title: A Judicial Maverick Is Worn Down in Arkansas
description: Since John Purtle left the Arkansas Supreme Court, its deliberations have gone far more smoothly. His former colleagues can break for lunch sooner and wrap things up earlier in the afternoon. Above all, there are fewer - far fewer - dissents.

title: Review/Film;   Another Incarnation For 'Lord Of the Flies'
description: William Golding's ''Lord of the Flies,'' long a fashionable novel with adolescent readers or others with a taste for broad allegory, is now a fashionable-looking film. Shot in lavish color (unlike Peter Brook's much more stark black-and-white 1963 version), and so thoroughly Americanized that its characters bring with them the kind of light-sword used in ''Star Wars'' and make reference to the television show ''ALF,'' this ''Lord of the Flies'' features a cast of young actors seemingly chosen on the basis of lean physique and languid good looks. They could just as easily, and perhaps more productively, be modeling designer denim.

title: Upheaval in the East;   New Mongolian Leadership Vows to Hold Free Election
description: Mongolia's newly chosen Communist Party leadership pledged today to institute far-reaching changes and to hold free elections in which opposition parties will be allowed to compete.

title: The First President
description: Mikhail Gorbachev is not the father of his country but his election yesterday provokes contrast, and comparison, with the father of ours. Mr. Gorbachev, having already run the Soviet Union for five years, has now become its first full-fledged President. ''Prezident'' is the way some Russians transliterate the term, but the important difference between chief executives there and here is not one letter. It's one word: legitimacy.

title: Man Charged in Killing Of Sister Over a Legacy
description: The body of a woman found stuffed in a wooden crate last week at a bus stop on West End Avenue was identified yesterday as a Manhattan actress who the police said had been feuding with her brother over a family inheritance.

title: Drug Raid on Wall Street Bars
description: Four bars in the Wall Street area were raided last night by plainclothes narcotic detectives who arrested 46 people on drug charges, the police said.

title: CABINET IS OUSTED IN ISRAELI DISPUTE OVER PEACE TALKS
description: The Israeli Parliament dissolved the Government today over Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's refusal to accept terms for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks that were suggested by the United States.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Procter & Gamble Company, to Grey Advertising, for Lestoil cleaner.

title: 2d Lebow Brain Test
description: A second brain biopsy is scheduled today at Mount Sinai Medical Center for Fred Lebow, the founder of the New York City Marathon and the New York Road Runners Club.

title: Couple Settle With S.E.C.
description: An Ohio woman and her estranged husband, who were accused of an insider trading scheme involving the stock of Revco Drug Stores and two other companies, settled without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Federal regulators said today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

7 Hired From Drexel To Bolster Jefferies
description: LEAD: Jefferies & Company, the Los Angeles-based brokerage subsidiary of the Jefferies Group, has moved to increase its activities in high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' by hiring seven former employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., including Marc Rapaport, a key executive at the collapsed firm.

title: By Haydn and Others
description: The mezzo-soprano Florence Quivar is to sing songs by Haydn, Brahms, Faure and Hermann Goetz tonight at 8 at Weill Recital Hall. Her pianist is to be Jeffrey Goldberg. Tickets are $15. Information: 247-7800.

title: Xerox Notes
description: The Xerox Corporation is offering $200 million in notes due in 2000 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Underwriters gave the notes a 9.75 percent coupon and priced the issue at par to yield about 110 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.Noncallable for the life of the issue, the notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

title: One Investigation, One Year
description: Events in the yearlong investigation by the Board of Education's Inspector General into reports of drug abuse by Matthew Barnwell, the principal of P.S. 53 in the South Bronx at the time.

title: Dow Gains 7.88 Points; Volume Sags
description: Stocks marked time yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 7.88, to 2,695.72, in the fourth day of light volume this week. With interest rates on bonds remaining almost unchanged, traders had no clear sign of the way stocks might go.

title: Ruling Gives New Deduction To Thousands in New Jersey
description: About 300,000 New Jerseyans who work in New York are entitled to a new deduction from their New Jersey taxes.

title: Seagram Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company attributed the results to improved sales from its beverage operations; to the contribution of its Martell and Tropicana operations, which were acquired in April 1988; and to earnings derived from its holdings in DuPont Co.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., the food company, announced that Carl V. Stinnett, senior vice president for sales and marketing and president of the Campbell Enterprises division, will retire effective April 30.

title: New Shearson Vice Chairman
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. announced yesterday that an executive from its parent, the American Express Company, had been appointed as vice chairman of the firm.

title: Columbia Coach Quits
description: Wally Halas, head coach at Columbia University for the last three seasons, resigned yesterday. His team was 2-12 in the Ivy League and 4-22 over all this season. In three years under Halas, Columbia was 18-60.

title: Lone Star Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the year is after an extraordinary charge of $1,564,000 due to the early extinguishment of debt. The company said the latest quarter and year results included an after-tax provision of $257,609,000 to provide for all the costs and expenses associated with the company's restructuring program and to provide for certain other unusual items. Year-ago quarter and year included a pretax income of $75,162,000 from the disposition of assets.

title: Life of Suspect in Sister's Slaying Is Touched by the Macabre Again
description: When David Brushingham arrived in New York a year ago in a beat-up sedan with Florida license plates and asked his younger sister to take him in, he was a destitute man with a troubled past, haunted by death and hounded by bankruptcy, the police and family friends say.

title: Governor Florio's Budget Bombshell
description: It took Jim Florio only a few months to admit something he wasn't prepared to concede last fall when he was running for governor: New Jersey needs new taxes. The time has come, Mr. Florio said this week, to confront ''harsh realities and hard decisions.'' He then unveiled a budget with $1.4 billion in tax increases.

title: British Jobless Rate Dips
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 5.6 percent in February from 5.7 percent in the previous month, the Government reported this week. The jobless rate stood at 6.8 percent a year ago, the Department of Employment said. Without seasonal adjustment, the number of unemployed was 1.676 million in February, compared with a revised 1.687 million in January and 2.018 million in February 1989.

title: B.A.T. Declines Comment on Saks
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. of London had no comment yesterday on the discussions involving bids to purchase its Saks Fifth Avenue or Marshall Field chains in the United States, a spokeswoman for B.A.T. said in New York. Several expressions of interest or bids were received for each company in the initial round of offers, which concluded this week. B.A.T. put both Saks and Field's up for sale several months ago in an effort to thwart a hostile takeover bid by Sir James Goldsmith.

title: Antar Misses Court Session
description: Eddie Antar, the founder of the defunct Crazy Eddie electronics retail chain, did not appear in Federal District Court today, opening the way for the Government to seize a disputed $52 million.

title: VW and Czechs Talk of Venture
description: The auto maker Volkswagen A.G. said it was in joint-venture talks with the Czechoslovak engineering group Skoda. A VW spokesman, Ortwin Witzel, said the talks were in the initial stage.

title: Review/Music;   Conductor Expresses Czech Roots Without Gemutlickheit
description: To his great credit, Zdenek Macal had the full attention of the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening. Mr. Macal, whose principal occupation at the moment is music director of the Milwaukee Symphony, has not conducted the Philharmonic for almost 15 years, and his return trip to Avery Fisher Hall was wisely routed through his native Czechoslovakia. The music, in other words, was by Smetana, Dvorak and Janacek. His players clearly liked what they were doing.

title: Film Festival;   Twins From Budapest, Singularly Independent
description: ''My 20th Century,'' a new Hungarian film written and directed by Ildiko Enyedi, is a number of wondrous things.

title: Wayward Satellite Boosted Into Safer and Higher Orbit
description: Temporarily at least, engineers got a wayward communication satellite out of harm's way today by lifting it to a higher orbit.

title: The Game, The Grave And Gathers
description: The bright lights of the Long Beach Arena and the swift players on the basketball court and the thundering crowd and the glossy brass bands were inevitably linked last night to an unmarked grave in a simple Pennsylvania cemetery.

title: Review/Dance;   A Gathering Of Friends In Tap Shoes
description: Four pairs of feet held a party on Monday night at the Top of the Village Gate. Those feet were fine company. So were the people attached to them. They'll be having parties every Monday night for the rest of this month at the Gate, at Bleecker and Thompson Streets.

title: Your Money;   How to Choose A Filing Status
description: When selecting a filing status for income tax returns, the best choice can be less obvious than it seems, tax professionals say.

title: Useful Tip For All Seasons
description: Jumper cables are usually sure bets for starting cars with battery trouble, but using them properly is essential. The cables' jaws have to be properly attached to a working battery in another car. Here's how.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT H. EDWARDS is to become the new president of Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., on Aug. 15. Currently he is the head of the department of health, education and housing in the secretariat of the Aga Khan, which runs schools, community health programs and hospitals in East Africa and South Asia. Previously Mr. Edwards was president of Carleton College in Northfield, Minn.

title: Abraham Hershson, Retired Executive, 89
description: Abraham Hershson, a retired manufacturing company executive and a philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Thursday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL O'DWYER got a St. Patrick's Day plum yesterday when Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS appointed him Commissioner for the United Nations and Consular Corps. A former City Council president, political powerhouse and activist in Irish causes, Mr. O'Dwyer, 82 years old, had lobbied for a job in the city administration.

title: Mortgage Rates Are Up
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.34 percent, up from 10.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.55 percent this week, up from 8.5 percent the week before.

title: Court in New Jersey Voids Rate Increase for Blue Cross
description: An appellate court panel today struck down a 24.6 percent rate increase granted to Blue Cross and Blue Shield in January. The court said the way the increase was applied to 600,000 subscribers subverted the organization's ''statutory purpose of providing affordable protection to a broad-based community.''

title: OWNER'S NEW PROPOSAL IS SAID TO IGNORE SALARY-ARBITRATION ISSUE
description: With their spring training lockout 30 days old, baseball's club owners gambled yesterday that they could get an agreement with the players by offering a new proposal that ignores the issue the union has felt most strongly about: salary-arbitration eligibility. The owners, in fact, withdrew their bonus-pool concept, which would have benefited players with two to three years of major league service.

title: Rebels in El Salvador Warn Of an Increase in Fighting
description: Guerrilla leaders criticized the Government and the armed forces today and warned of an increase in fighting.

title: Evans Boosts Stanford
description: Since 1973, when East Germany burst on the scene, America's female swimmers have been overshadowed. That may soon change.

title: In Europe, Hope for the Irish
description: At first glance on this St. Patrick's Day, Ireland's lament recalls Winston Churchill's lament. Addressing Parliament in 1922, Churchill spoke of the changes wrought by World War I - empires overturned, ideas transformed, the map of Europe altered. ''But as the deluge subsides and the waters fall short,'' he said, ''we see the dreary steeples of Fermanagh and Tyrone emerging once again. The integrity of their quarrel is one of the few institutions that has been unaltered in the cataclysm which has swept the world.''

title: The Deadbeat of America
description: Rockefeller Center, Columbia Pictures, CBS Records. What other American icons do the Japanese want to buy? They can have it all. Here in the Tarrytowns, we've learned that Japanese corporations, and not American ones, make the best neighbors.

title: Producer Prices Unchanged in February
description: After posting the biggest increase in more than 15 years in January, producer prices were unchanged last month, the Labor Department said today.

title: Basketball: East Regional;   St. John's Routs Temple; Duke Is Next Opponent
description: For most of St. John's surprising but uneven season, Greg (Boo) Harvey and Malik Sealy have been counterweights for the Redmen's burdensome inconsistency. Harvey, the 6-foot senior guard, and Sealy, the versatile 6-8 sophomore forward, have bailed their teammates out of numerous jams. In Harvey's case, it has been with clutch shooting; in Sealy's, it has been with explosive do-whatever-it-takes performances.

title: Broadcasting Awards Given For Coverage of Disasters
description: San Francisco and Charleston, S.C., radio and television stations won Peabody Awards on Thursday for their coverage of two natural disasters: the earthquake in the San Francisco Bay area last October and the hurricane that swept the Carolinas and the Caribbean last September.

title: Mortgage Delinquencies
description: The delinqency rate for home mortgages held steady in the final three months of 1989 after jumping sharply in the previous quarter, a trade group said this week. The group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said a seasonally adjusted 4.99 percent of mortgage payments on one-to-four-family homes were 30 days or more late.

title: Georgia Gulf Revises Recapitalization Plan
description: ATLANTA, March 16 (Reuters) -

title: About New York;   Where the Food Comes Sweeping Down the Plain!
description: It was just 7:30. But already at the James Beard House in Greenwich Village people were sticking the brightly colored feathers that adorned the swizzle sticks into their hair.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 17, 1990
description: International

title: Control Data Shift at Top
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that its chairman, Robert M. Price, retired on Thursday but remains chairman of the company's board.

title: Oppenheimer Multi-Governent Trust reports earnings for As of Jan 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net assets per share.

title: Immigrant on Subway Is Slain by a Harasser
description: An immigrant from Hong Kong on his way home from his job in a Manhattan shoe store was stabbed to death on a Brooklyn subway train by a man who witnesses said would not stop harassing him, transit officials said yesterday.

title: In West Virginia, Some Are Told to End Strike
description: The state Supreme Court upheld a lower court's order today that striking teachers in one county return to work, but it later overrode a statewide back-to-work order issued by another judge.

title: Sea Containers Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included an extraordinary gain of $22 million.

title: Oppenheimer Multi-Sector Inome Trust reports earnings for As of Jan 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net asset per share. Net investment income during the first quarter were $7,765,352, or 30 cents a share, compared with $7,700,317, or 27 cents a share, in year- ago period.

title: Housing Starts Fell Last Month
description: Housing starts fell 7 percent in February but remained well above the level of the last 11 months of 1989, the Government reported today. Analysts said the building pace could not be sustained.

title: First Goal Met On Recycling; Next Is Harder
description: New York City's new mandatory recycling program, a grand-scale effort to change the behavior of millions, is expected to achieve its modest first-year goal. But as it begins to move into the city's poor neighborhoods, dismaying results have raised serious questions about its future.

title: Turkey Remains Confident It Will Join European Community
description: Some political analysts here fret that the West's preoccupation with Eastern Europe has pushed Turkey onto a back burner - even worse, perhaps off the stove - in its dogged pursuit of full membership in the European Community.

title: Kay Jewelers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Farley Sale Of Cluett To French
description: In another setback in his attempt to acquire all of West Point-Pepperell Inc., the Chicago industrialist William Farley agreed today to sell the textile giant's Cluett, Peabody division, maker of Arrow shirts and Gold Toe socks.

title: Review/Pop;   Janet Jackson Fleshes Out Her Own Video Image
description: Janet Jackson is starting at the top. Music video clips carried both her 1986 album, ''Control,'' and her current one, ''Rhythm Nation'' (A & M Records), to No. 1. Studio-simulated song-and-dance extravaganzas made her a star although she never had performed her hits live. Now, on her first tour as a headliner, she has to prove herself in real time.

title: 3 PILOTS DISMISSED IN ALCOHOL ABUSE
description: Northwest Airlines today dismissed the three pilots who were accused of flying a Boeing 727 with 91 passengers aboard last week while under the influence of alcohol.

title: U.S. MAY CHARGE GI IN PANAMA KILLING
description: The United States Army is expected to charge a soldier with murder, claiming after an investigation that the soldier shot a Panamanian prisoner during the American invasion of Panama, army officials said tonight.

title: Upheaval in the East;   East German Communists End Campaign on Upswing
description: The former Communist Party, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, wound up its campaign tonight for Sunday's first free parliamentary elections in East Germany with the largest and most enthusiastic rallies the capital has seen.

title: Shamir Fights for Control of Party After His Government Collapses
description: While the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, scrambled to make deals to form a narrow coalition Government, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, defeated on Thursday by a vote of no confidence in his leadership, struggled today to hold on as leader of the Likud party.

title: Secret Space 'Hardware' Threatening to Fall
description: The Defense Department said today that ''hardware elements'' carried into orbit by the space shuttle Atlantis last month were expected to re-enter the atmosphere soon.

title: Business Stakes East Bloc Claims And a 'Gold Rush' Hits Hungary
description: With some of the biggest companies in the United States leading the way, Hungary has become corporate America's main port of entry into Eastern Europe. In recent months, General Electric, General Motors, Levi Strauss, McDonald's and others have set up businesses in Hungary, and the stream of American concerns seeking joint ventures here is accelerating daily.

title: Basketball;   Well-Matched Teams To Square Off in East
description: La Salle's Explorers have won 30 of 31 games, yet continue to hear questions about their credibility.

title: Now, for Peace in Salvador
description: LEAD: Now that democratic elections in Nicaragua have set the stage for peace and national reconciliation, eyes are turning to neighboring El Salvador, where the combatants in Central America's bloodiest civil war are arguing over whether to resume negotiations.

title: Dayton Hudson reports earnings for 14wks to Feb 3
description: The company noted that the provision for the LIFO inventory accounting method resulted in a pre-tax charge to the latest year's earnings of less than $1 million, compared with a charge of $44 million in the year- earlier period. For the latest fourth quarter the LIFO provision resulted in a credit of $32 million, or 26 cents a share, compared to a charge of $8 million in the year-ago period.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Xtra Corporation referred incorrectly to a proxy contest between the management of the USX Corporation and Carl C. Icahn. Mr. Icahn has proposed spinning off USX's steel business, not unseating the company's board.

title: 5 Found Dead in Jersey City; Gas Leak Is Suspected
description: The Jersey City police discovered five partially decomposed bodies yesterday in the basement apartment of a building on Clinton Avenue on the city's west side.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a drug prevention program that was described in the journal Science referred incorrectly to participating students. They attended junior high school, not high school.

title: Cuba Fights New Telecast From U.S.
description: Days from the start of direct television broadcasts from the United States to Cuba, Cuban officials are calling them illegal and considering ways to stop them.

title: Gelinas Suspended
description: Martin Gelinas, a left wing with the Edmonton Oilers, was suspended for five games by the National Hockey League yesterday for deliberately hitting Dave Ellett, a Winnipeg Jets defenseman, on the head with his stick in a game last week. No injury resulted.

title: Cross-Training Shoes Fit the Needs of More Than One Sport
description: New technology has changed the look of athletic footwear dramatically in the last decade. The all-around sneaker has been replaced with intricate footwear for individual sports activities. But the newest wave is a return to the basics: a cross-training shoe that fits the needs of more than one sport, yet makes the sneaker look like a distant cousin.

title: Film Festival;   A Speck of Mankind In the Boundless Sands
description: An almost-silent film shot in the violent sandstorms of the Iranian desert, ''Water, Wind and Sand'' fulfills one purpose of the New Directors/New Films series: it is stylistically fresh and daring. The story begins when an adolescent boy returns from working in a distant city and learns that his family has left its drought-stricken village. Passing by corpses of sheep and cattle, he sets out to find his family and discovers the brutal need to fight hunger, thirst and isolation.

title: Baker (J.) Inc.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: The company said the increased sales in the fiscal 1990 periods reflect acquisitions made in April and May of 1989.

title: Tokyo Banks' Deal in China
description: Four Japanese banks have agreed to make a loan to a Chinese state company, the first since a military crackdown last June, but they denied that the move involved any change of policy or return to business as usual.

title: Output Rises On Strength In Vehicles
description: The nation's industrial output rose six-tenths of a percent in February, the Government reported today, but the increase reflected a resumption of automobile production and practically no strengthening elsewhere.

title: Beliefs
description: The usual response to news about the morals of young people is: View with alarm. That has been pretty much the reaction since January when the Girl Scouts of America released the results of a general survey of the beliefs and values of girls and boys from fourth grade to the end of high school.

title: 2 Iowa Energy Producers Join
description: Iowa Resources Inc. and the Midwest Energy Company of Sioux City, Iowa, agreed to merge into a new holding company to be called Midwest Resources Inc. The merger will combine companies with total annual revenues of $933 million and total assets of $2.3 billion.

title: Former National Security Aide Testifies Poindexter Distrusted Congress
description: With the prosecution rapidly winding down its case against John M. Poindexter, a former aide to the National Security Council testified today that Mr. Poindexter expressed his dislike and distrust of Congress as lawmakers were pressing him in 1986 to explain the White House role in aiding the Nicaraguan contras.

title: Review/Theater;   Chilling Life On The Rock Circuit
description: Midway in ''I Think It's Gonna Work Out Fine,'' a music-theater fable loosely based on the story of Ike and Tina Turner, Rita Golden, the sexy lead singer of the traveling rock-and-roll show Prince Golden and His Royal Revue, is punched in the face by her husband because she has hidden his gun. Rita, who is portrayed by Rhodessa Jones with a raw, feisty bitterness, turns to the audience and says with a sneer, ''Yeah, he hit me! Is that what you all here were waiting for?''

title: Disney Plans Big Expansion
description: The Walt Disney Company has announced plans to build residential areas around its parks in the United States and to expand its attractions in Europe and Asia.

title: Art Exhibit Unsettles Airport Workers
description: The panel of hands is surely the most startling piece of art on the wall of the airport's baggage claim area - white hands, fashioned from plaster and tape, groping, grasping, clinging to each other. The hands overshadow even the chest X-ray and the side view of a skull in a neighboring artwork.

title: How Jericho Fell and Alexandria Burned;   Don't Blame Caesar
description: To the Editor:

title: Handy & Harman reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year net both included after-tax profits of $2,536,000, or 18 cents a share, from reductions in the quantities of precious metals inventories valued under the LIFO method of accounting, and the year- ago quarter and year net included similar income of $3,180,000, or 23 cents a share for the quarter and $3,877,000, or 28 cents a share, for the year.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: Manor Care Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included gains on sale of property of $1,159,000 in the quarter and $3,670,000 in the 9 months.

title: Candidate as Californian: A Northerner Goes South
description: A Southern California winter sun warmed the courtyard of the chic Bistro Garden restaurant in Beverly Hills the other day while the woman who wants to be the next Governor met with the rich and the powerful. It was far in climate and spirit from the chill fog and Victorian elegance of Dianne Feinstein's San Francisco.

title: Upheaval in the East;   A Piece of the Pie for Each East German?
description: Facing almost certain defeat in parliamentary elections on Sunday, the Government of Prime Minister Hans Modrow has proposed a fanciful plan to divvy up the property of the Communist state into 16 million equal shares, offering one share to each East German citizen.

title: Basketball: Midwest Regional;   Hoyas Roll Past Texas Southern, 70-52
description: The sight of Georgetown's 7-foot-2-inch center, Dikembe Mutombo, was intimidating enough for Texas Southern today. But his 18 points, 16 rebounds and 3 blocked shots were too much.

title: IRT Station to Take 2 1/2 Years
description: The Transit Authority cut in half yesterday the schedule to rebuild the Intervale Avenue-163d Street station on the IRT White Plains Road line in the Bronx. The board of the authority said the work would take two and a half years, instead of the estimated five years. The stop has been closed since March 15, 1989, when a botched token robbery ended in a fire. The authority said city engineers instead of contractors would demolish the stop and draw new plans. A contractor will rebuild the stop, at a cost of $5.2 million.

title: Treasuries Gain on Economic News
description: The Treasury securities market advanced sharply yesterday on further signs of weakness in the economy's manufacturing sector, which would give the Federal Reserve little incentive to tighten credit.

title: N.C.A.A.: Southeast Regional;   Northern Iowa Stuns Missouri With 3-Pointer
description: When Northern Iowa took a timeout with only 10 seconds left and the team's coach, Eldon Miller, inserted Maurice Newby into the lineup, the Missouri Tigers recognized Miller's plan. The score was tied at 71-71. The task for Newby, a junior guard who had made two 3-point shots in 12 minutes of play, was to shoot if free.

title: Japan's Latest American Foray
description: Japanese financiers are making a strong push to expand their role in financing new office buildings in the United States just as American banks, dismayed by shrinking profit margins and loan losses from a glut of unoccupied buildings, are becoming more cautious and cutting back.

title: Patents;   Body Motion Translated Into Musical Notes
description: Dancers and athletes have often been described as embodying poetry in motion. Now there may be music to go with the poetry. The Yamaha Corporation of Japan, maker of electric pianos, has patented a musical instrument to be worn by performers that translates arm and hand motion into musical notes.

title: Basketball;   76ers Lose 19-Point Lead But Rally to Slip Past Nets
description: Hersey Hawkins and Charles Barkley scored 25 points each tonight, but the Philadelphia 76ers still had to rally to beat the Nets, 119-110, after losing a 19-point lead.

title: Environmental Bond Plan Faces Resistance
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposal for the largest environmental bond act in the state's history is encountering unexpected opposition from state legislative leaders, who said today that they may sharply scale it back or even reject it.

title: BRAZIL'S NEW CHIEF GIVES RADICAL PLAN TO HALT INFLATION
description: Unleashing a radical attack on inflation, Brazil's new President sent Congress a package today that declares a moratorium on the internal debt, privatizes state companies, ends subsidies, imposes new taxes, loosens foreign exchange controls, declares a new currency and opens the country to imports.

title: Basketball;   Rutgers Defeats Holy Cross On Late-Game Dominance
description: Mike Jones hit 10 free throws down the stretch to help Rutgers to an 87-78 victory tonight over Holy Cross in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Carl Jr. Expands
description: Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc. signed a licensing agreement to establish its Carl's Jr. fast-food restaurant chain in nine Pacific Rim countries. The agreement is with the MBF Group, a financial services firm based in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, which already operates Grandy's fast-food restaurants in the Pacific. According to the agreement, Carl's Jr. restaurants will begin opening in Malaysia in early 1991 and expand to Singapore, Australia and Hong Kong. Others will open in Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Taiwan and New Zealand. Terms of the agreement were not released. Karcher already has an agreement to open restaurants in Japan.

title: Unitrode Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included pre-tax charge of $14,252,000 related to workforce reductions, the closing of a manufacturing facility, writedowns in the carying value of certain assets, discontinuance of product lines and other restructuring actions. c-Net income

title: Land's End Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Winslow Martin; Management Consultant, 68
description: Winslow Martin, a retired management consultant for Arthur D. Little Inc. in Cambridge, Mass., died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 68 years old and also lived in Grantham, N.H.

title: Planning for Retirement, and Enjoying It
description: Investigate before you invest has long been a watchword on Wall Street. But when it comes to buying a retirement home, particularly in a distant state or country, the purchase is all too often made site unseen. Others travel to the area they are interested in and see only real-estate salespeople.

title: Gendis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Restated The company said a change in the method of accounting has increased latest period earnings by $443,000 and $951,000 for the fourth quarter and fiscal year, respectively. The year-ago quarter and year earnings have increased by $153,000 and $319,000, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Radical Fiscal Measures Are Proposed for Brazil
description: The inflation-fighting package presented by Brazil's new president to Congress today includes the following major provisions:

title: How Jericho Fell and Alexandria Burned
description: To the Editor:

title: Castro Says He May Trade More in Latin America
description: Cheered by his first visit to Brazil in 30 years, Fidel Castro said today that Latin American markets could make up for the loss of trading partners in Eastern Europe.

title: Guilty Plea For Builder
description: The General Development Corporation said today that it had agreed to plead guilty to one count of conspiring to violate the Federal mail fraud law.

title: Zymos Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary gain of $5,785,000, or 20 cents a share, from the conversion of long-term debt to equity.

title: Puerto Ricans Deserve to Have Statehood
description: To the Editor:

title: CII Financial Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results are for the period from March 11, 1988, the company's inception, to Dec. 31, 1988.

title: Reporter Hanged in Iraq Had Once Robbed Bank
description: The Iranian-born journalist hanged as a spy by Iraq on Thursday was described today as a convicted bank robber who had been sentenced in 1981 to 18 months in a British jail.

title: How Jericho Fell and Alexandria Burned;   Academic Folklore
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The Spring National Championship of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon with 10 days of play in prospect, but one major title had already been decided. The Grand National Pair Championship, which began at the grass-roots level last summer, was won here Thursday night by Sidney Lazard and Jack LaNoue of New Orleans.

title: Magna Interntional reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Contained a provision for writedown of assets of $152,965,000 and included gains of $11.7 million on the issue of shares by one of company's subsidiaries and $8.6 million on the disposal of real estate. All these are on a pre-tax basis. c-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Busy Agenda At the Tracks
description: The $500,000 Florida Derby, which is the first Grade I race of the year for 3-year-olds, and the $50,000 Swale Stakes, featuring the season debuts of Summer Squall and Senor Pete, will be run Saturday at Gulfstream Park amid a busy weekend of prep races for the Kentucky Derby on May 5.

title: Review/Music;   Imported From Brussels: An Early Mozart Opera
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's opera initiative, which got under way with a flash last season, has had its travails of late. Two promising productions fell through; its artistic director, Matthew Epstein, resigned, and earlier this week the Metropolitan Opera withdrew from a collaboration planned for next spring.

title: Ware Opting for Draft SPORTS PEOPLE:
description: ''This is by far the most difficult decision I have had to make in all my years,'' the University of Houston quarterback said yesterday at a news conference in Houston. ''I have cherished my three years here, but for a variety of reasons, I am declaring myself for the N.F.L. draft.''

title: A Guilty Plea by Grumman
description: The Grumman Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest military contractor, pleaded guilty to two criminal counts of unauthorized use of secret Pentagon documents, the Justice Department said today.

title: Michael S. Weisberg; Executive, 36
description: Michael S. Weisberg, executive director of Multitasking Systems of New York and a former assistant business editor of The Daily News, died of AIDS on Tuesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 36 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: 3 Are Wounded In 2 Shootings In the East 70's
description: Three people were shot on the Upper East Side last night in two incidents only four blocks and a few minutes apart - a man wounded in the chest for unknown reasons and a woman dragged into a car and shot in the leg in a robbery in which one of the thieves was also wounded.

title: Pic 'N' Save Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Families of Hostages Tell of Living A Seesaw Life of Hope and Despair
description: Thomas Cicippio feels like a hostage, too.

title: Tumor Seems to Mellow G.O.P.'s Combative Chief
description: Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, says the discovery of a benign tumor in his brain has caused him to tone down his pit-bull style of politics.

title: DE KLERK TO MEET WITH DELEGATION LED BY MANDELA
description: President F. W. de Klerk announced today that talks between the Government and an African National Congress delegation led by Nelson Mandela would open in Cape Town on April 11.

title: William H. Lang, 78, Retired Steel Executive
description: William H. Lang, a retired steel company executive, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in Belleair, Fla.

title: KEY RATES
Perestroika on the Prairie
description: The idea of a central committee putting together a five-year plan for agricultural production seems archaic in the age of perestroika. But that's exactly what we are about to see in Congress.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday headed ''First-Generation Reset Bonds,'' about a type of bond devised by Drexel Burnham Lambert, gave an incorrect price for GACC Holding's bonds. They have recently been trading in the mid-$80 range per $100 of face value.

title: Leader in U.N.'s Battle on AIDS Resigns in Dispute Over Strategy
description: The American physician who is widely credited with organizing the United Nations' worldwide fight against AIDS resigned today in what he said was a dispute with his boss, the head of the World Health Organization.

title: German Voices: One City's Unease Over Unity - A Special Report:   UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   United Germany a Hot Topic, But Many Ask, Why So Fast?
description: Situated on a broad plain, this city of 142,000 has much in common with other German urban centers: a ducal castle with vestiges of a moat, a university, medium-sized industries, a splendid museum, handsomely restored patrician houses and remarkably clean streets.

title: Inside
description: An East German Phoenix

title: A Hook Shot And a Record
description: Philip Hutcheson of David Lipscomb University hit a running 5-foot hook shot in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics tournament tonight and became the career scoring leader of college basketball.

title: Study of Addicted Babies Hints Vast Cost
description: State welfare agencies in eight cities reported that nearly 9,000 babies were born in 1989 to mothers addicted to crack, according to a new survey by the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Florio's No-Growth Budget Forcing Schools to Scramble
description: In recent days the School Superintendent here, Dr. Harold Morris, has had three preliminary $40 million budgets for the next academic year on his desk.

title: Isaiah H. Wilson, 80, Retired Food Executive
description: Isaiah Herbert Wilson, a retired food industry executive, died of a heart attack on March 8 at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 80 years old and had lived in Great Neck, L.I., before moving to Rocky Hill, Conn., and more recently to Lexington.

title: A 'Witching' Lift Pushes Dow Up 45.50
description: Stocks rallied strongly in spirited trading yesterday for the week's best gain by far, with the much-anticipated ''triple witching hour'' playing a significant role.

title: Patents;   A Nicotine Drug Patch to End Smoking
description: Transdermal drug patches, which dispense medication into the blood stream through the skin, may have a new use: helping cigarette smokers to quit.

title: CARTER SAYS SYRIA AIDS ON HOSTAGES
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said in Damascus today that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria promised to help win freedom for hostages held in Lebanon.

title: U.N. Asked to Expand Its Force in Nicaragua
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar asked the Security Council today for ''urgent approval'' to expand the United Nations observer group in Central America and to add a battalion to help in the voluntary demobilization of the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Texas Utilities reports earnings for 3mos Feb 28
Patents;   A Training Baseball Bat To Strengthen a Swing
description: An aeronautical engineer and a professional golfer have teamed up to invent a training bat to strengthen a baseball player's swing.

title: Bensonhurst Witness Indicted
description: John S. Vento, regarded as a major prosecution witness in the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Bensonhurst until he changed his mind about testifying, was indicted yesterday on charges of second-degree murder. Bail was denied, and he remained in jail. Mr. Vento, who had agreed to testify in exchange for immunity from prosecution, fled in December. He surrendered last week in Ohio and was arrested on Monday, after having informed prosecutors that he would not testify.

title: 3 Youths Facing Trial Together In Jogger Case
description: Three of the six defendants in the Central Park rape case were ordered yesterday to stand trial on April 16. The three others were ordered to be tried later.

title: Review/Dance;   Merce Cunningham's Way With Space
description: Some choreographers contend with space. They have dancers battle it, push aggressively through it or create the illusion that they are tugging or slashing at it. Merce Cunningham treated space in a different way in ''Trails'' and ''Five Stone Wind,'' the two works the Merce Cunningham Dance Company presented for the first time this season on Thursday night at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the St. Patrick's Day Parade today, a number of streets in Manhattan will be closed. The parade begins at 11:30 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue and heads north to 86th Street. Streets will close at 10:30 A.M. and reopen around 2:30 P.M.

title: Minister Resigns in India
description: Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, one of India's most prominent political figures, resigned from Prime Minister V. P. Singh's administration today, threatening to split the ruling coalition. Mr. Lal, a peasant leader from the northern state of Haryana, did not give reasons for his resignation. It followed a bitter campaign against him and his son, the Chief Minister of Haryana, by critics in the Singh Cabinet and the press.

title: Tom Harmon, Heisman Winner As Michigan Tailback, Dies at 70
description: Tom Harmon, an all-America tailback at the University of Michigan who won the Heisman Trophy a half century ago, died of a heart attack late Thursday in Los Angeles soon after completing a round of golf. He was 70 years old.

title: Leetch Has Surgery On Broken Ankle
description: Brian Leetch, the accomplished young Ranger defenseman, underwent two hours of surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan yesterday to repair his fractured left ankle and a torn ligament. He suffered the injuries in the Rangers' 8-2 victory Wednesday night over the Maple Leafs in Toronto.

title: Mexico Angry at U.S. Over Use of a Satellite
description: Mexico has complained that the United States used a satellite to observe drug cultivation without Mexico's knowledge and that Washington has not responded to requests for an explanation.

title: U.S. Jews Hold First Papal Meeting in 2 Years
description: A delegation of American Jewish leaders met with Pope John Paul II in Rome yesterday, ending the two-year hiatus in such high-level audiences brought on by tensions over the existence of a Roman Catholic convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

title: Europe Picks Up Speed
description: The momentum is growing now to speed integration of the European Community as the best way to deal with the dramatic changes going on. Some old arguments about states versus supranationalism are resurfacing.

title: Patents;   A Guidance System For Surgical Lasers
description: A physicist and ophthalmic surgeon at the University of California at San Diego obtained a patent this week on a three-dimensional guidance system for surgical lasers.

title: American Building Mainteance Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from insurance settlement of $1,387,000, or 35 cents a share.

title: Leucadia National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $37,902,000, or $2.86 a share, for the quarter and $41,588,000, or $3.11 a share, for the year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,313,000, or 10 cents a share and $5,716,000, or 43 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a charge of $2.4 million which reflected the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes resulting from the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96. The company said discontinued operations included the company's railcar leasing and management operations, which were sold on Oct. 27, 1989, and the company's electronic visual communications subsidiary, which was sold on Dec. 22, 1989. The company said the net gain on these sales ($37,100,000 after taxes, including $7,500,000 applied to reduce the excess of purchase price over net assets acquired) is reflected in 1989 results of operations. Included in income from continuing operations for the years 1989 and 1988 were pretax net securities gains of $11,823,000 and $21,097,000, respectively. In addition, 1989 results included gains of about $18,300,000 on the sales of certain properties and units in a related condominium project developed by the company. As a result of the loss of certain significant trading stamps customers, a provision of about $5,400,000 for restructuring the stamp subsidiary's operations was also included in 1989 results.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The maternal instinct gets blocked out because the only thing that matters is the addiction.'' - Kate Vandegrift, director of a rehabilitation program for crack-addicted mothers in Philadelphia. [8:1.]

title: Upheaval in the East;   East's Call of Freedom: Hopes and Many Parties
description: Standing on their granite pedestals in the middle of the Theater Square, Goethe and Schiller, two of the brightest luminaries of this ancient center of German culture, gaze sternly on a scene they have not witnessed for many a decade.

title: Dinkins Appoints New Housing Chief
description: Saying that he intends to continue the huge New York City housing program begun by the Koch administration, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday selected one of the plan's architects to be the new city housing commissioner.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., a supplier of aerospace and aviation products and services, said its AAR Financial Services Corp. subsidiary had sold six Boeing 727-200 aircraft to DHL Airways Inc., an air express company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: How Jericho Fell and Alexandria Burned;   Samson's Reputation
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberty Scholarships Open Colleges to Poorest
description: To the Editor:

title: Crash Injures Pruett
description: Scott Pruett, who was voted the co-rookie of the year in the 1989 Indianapolis 500, seriously injured the knee, kneecap and foot of his left leg yesterday in a crash during a test session at the Fairgrounds track in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Death Penalty Vetoed By Cuomo for 8th Time
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today vetoed a bill that would have reinstated the death penalty in New York, as he has done in each of the last seven years.

title: William J. Simmer; Spokesman, 39
description: William J. Simmer, public-affairs director of the Regional Plan Association, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Dirty Stereo Gear
description: Spring cleaning should include the stereo system, if you want to continue to get top performance from it. Dirt, dust, cigarette smoke and air pollutants can degrade the performance of CD's and records, phonographs, tape decks and even cable connections. Luckily, the solutions are simple and for the most part inexpensive.

title: Irwin Overcomes Hazards to Take Lead
description: Hale Irwin, whose 22-year career has been distinguished by victories on difficult courses, negotiated high winds and dry, bumpy greens today to take a one-shot lead after two rounds at the Players Championship.

title: The Obliging Fellow
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski wants to raise taxes. He is a Democrat. He is also chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, always called ''the powerful Ways and Means Committee'' because it has a lot of say-so about taxes.

title: The Outcry Over Spilled Oil
description: The public is fed up with the oil industry's sloppiness. There are thousands of oil spills a year, many of them dribbles, a few disasters. Last week a barge exploded in the Arthur Kill waterway, which runs between Staten Island and New Jersey, sending 100,000 gallons of home heating oil into waters near the Pralls Island bird sanctuary. It's the third time this year that spills have threatened the slowly returning wildlife.

title: Bolshoi Ballet Returning For U.S. Summer Tour
description: The Bolshoi Ballet has announced an American tour, to open with a two-week residency at the New York State Theater from July 10 to 22.

title: Genovese Drug Stores reports earnings for 12wks to Feb 2
description: Year-ago quarter and year are comprised of 13 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: 4,022 at U S West Take Retirement
description: Slightly more than 4,000 U S West Inc. managers and administrators have accepted the company's latest voluntary retirement program, a U S West spokesman, Dick MacKnight, said. He said 4,022 people left the payroll last month.

title: NBC IS SELLING MULTIMEDIA 51% OF CLEVELAND TV STATION
description: NBC will sell a majority ownership stake in WKYC-TV, its Cleveland television station, to Multimedia Inc., the companies announced yesterday.

title: Motion to Sequester Jurors In Oil Spill Trial Is Rejected
description: Lawyers for Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood were turned down today in their effort to have his jurors sequestered because of the vast publicity that could accompany the coming first anniversary of the nation's worst oil spill.

title: Attack on Peruvian Candidate
description: Pro-Cuban rebels in Lima have bombed the campaign headquarters of Mario Vargas Llosa, the novelist who is the leading presidential candidate here, causing damage but no casualties, the police said.

title: Ballet Theater Aide Quits
description: John Taras, associate artistic director of American Ballet Theater, resigned on Thursday. Mr. Taras cited artistic differences with Jane Hermann, who was named co-director of the company with Oliver Smith on March 7, as the reason for his resignation. Mrs. Hermann said the decision had been mutually agreed upon. Mr. Taras was appointed by Mikhail Baryshnikov, Ballet Theater's former artistic director, in 1984. His resignation is effective immediately.

title: Vancouver Journal;   Where Minorities Find Riches and Resentment
description: When David Lam and his family arrived here as immigrants, friends back home gave him three months until he came to his senses and returned to Hong Kong.

title: Cheney Calls 50% Cut a Risk to Status
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the United States would fall from superpower status if military spending were cut in half over the next decade, as proposed by some military experts.

title: Books of The Times;   Authors Newly Make the Holocaust Connection
description: Testimony

title: Greyhound Striker Is Charged With Firing at Bus
description: A driver for Greyhound Lines was arrested at his Connecticut home today and charged with one of more than a dozen incidents of gunfire aimed at the company's buses since the drivers' union went on strike two weeks ago.

title: In a Confusing Game of 'Musical Teachers,' a Class Still Learns
description: Elvis Tejada, an 8-year-old student at Public School 94 in the northern Bronx, discovered in January that his class was about to get a new teacher -again. Elvis, who hates to lose even a moment when he could be learning something new, was fed up.

title: U.S. Seizes 55 More Aliens In Raid at Los Angeles Airport
description: In their third raid in the last three days aimed at illegal aliens taking eastbound flights from this city, Federal immigration agents seized 55 Latin Americans at Los Angeles International Airport today.

title: Cheer Lithuania, but Don't Meddle
description: The Bush Administration welcomes efforts by the Baltic States to free themselves from Moscow's grasp. It also refuses to grant diplomatic recognition and economic aid. That position is principled and practical.

title: Lionel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Even More, Paris Is the Place to Show
description: With the Karl Lagerfeld opening on Friday, the serious part of the French fall and winter showings began. Not too serious, of course. Not with bracelets worn three at a time on the sleeves of jackets - on the upper arm, just below the elbow and at the wrist. Or single earrings dangling past the bosom, or elaborate gold medallions on the chest.

title: Norton Gets BTR Bid; Stock Soars
description: In its most ambitious attempt to expand into the United States, BTR P.L.C., the British conglomerate whose holdings include Dunlop and Slazenger sporting goods, made an unsolicited $1.64 billion offer today for the Norton Company, a leading maker of abrasives, ceramics and other industrial materials.

title: Viatech Inc. reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinry credits of $127,000, or 10 cents a share, for latest 12 months and $527,000, or 43 cents a share, for 1988.

title: No Low-Income Catch In Social Security Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: The Instincts of Parenthood Become Part of Crack's Toll
description: Crack can overwhelm one of the strongest forces in nature, the parental instinct, specialists in drug addiction say. As a result, some of them say, the United States is giving birth to a new underclass of disadvantaged youth like none seen before.

title: G.O.P. Tries for Dynasty In S.I. Race for Congress
description: City Councilwoman Susan Molinari is trying to carry on a Staten Island Republican dynasty in a special Congressional election on Tuesday.

title: Gambro of Sweden To Buy Cobe Labs
description: The Swedish medical supplies company Gambro A.B. agreed to acquire Cobe Laboratories Inc. of Lakewood, Colo. for $37 a share, or a total of $253 million. Gambro, which is based in Lund, Sweden, said Cobe would become a fully owned subsidiary. Cobe's board recommended that its shareholders accept the bid.

title: Jim Lyons, 69, Dies; Management Adviser
description: Jim R. Lyons, a retired management consultant and philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Thursday while vacationing at Las Brisas Hotel in Acapulco, Mexico. He was 69 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Upheaval in the East;   The Question of Sovereignty Is Everything in Estonia
description: Forty-nine years after Soviet soldiers exiled his family to Siberia, a gray-haired man named Lennart Meri moved back toward his boyhood, stepping to the blackboard at Public School No. 10 to chalk up the word ''sovereignty.''

title: Family of Ex-Negotiator Believes He Is Still Alive
description: Terry Waite's entry in Britain's Who's Who reads the same today as it did more than three years ago, when he disappeared in Beirut on a mission to negotiate the release of Western hostages. Listed among his interests are ''international affairs and politics'' and ''travel (especially in remote parts of the world).''

title: Ivory Coast's Dissidents Testing Length of Leash
description: Having ruled this West African country with nearly absolute power for three decades, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny is under increasing political challenge amid growing economic and social disarray.

title: Chavez Faces Toughest Challenge
description: In the recent past, Julio Cesar Chavez, the World Boxing Council super-lightweight champion, has come to be recognized by many experts as the best fighter, pound for pound, in the sport.

title: Construction Remains A White Male Domain
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   New Kind of Mortgage
description: Thousands of people who want to become homeowners find themselves further away from their goal each year because of high interest rates and high prices. The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, recently introduced a ''two-step'' mortgage for first-time buyers, and now 80 lenders around the country offer it. To date these lenders have committed $800 million to the new mortgage. The two-step mortgage, a cross between fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages, begins with a low interest rate, which is adjusted only once, after seven years, to a new rate that cannot be more than 6 percentage points higher than the initial rate. Rates on these mortgages are based on a formula tied to the 10-year United States Treasury bill. Here is a national sample of the range of interest rates being charged for various mortgages. Banks will charge points, each point being 1 percent of the mortgage; the more points a buyer can pay, the lower the mortgage interest rate will be. $ Type of Mortgage Current Rate Year Ago Two-Step 9.825%-10.25% N.A. 30-year fixed 10.25%-10.75% 11.00% Adjustable 8.40%-8.50% 9.00%-9.50%

title: James Ortman Is Dead; Jewelry Executive, 78
description: James Ortman, president of J. Ortman Inc., a Manhattan jewelry concern, died on Tuesday at New York University Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and Quogue, L.I.

title: Basketball: West Regional;   Loyola Coasts With 45 By Kimble
description: Loyola Marymount, still mourning the death of Hank Gathers, sprinted past New Mexico State by 111-92 tonight in the first round of the West Regional behind Bo Kimble's 45 points.

title: Hints of Strategies Emerge in Arguments at Hearing in Marcos Case
description: In what amounted to an overture for the trial of Imelda Marcos, all the main characters took their positions for the first time in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, and amid bickering lawyers and lengthy speeches, hints of upcoming legal strategies could be heard.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said results in adjusted new Israeli shekels for both periods is at the exchange rate in effect at Dec. 31, 1989 of Nis 1.963 equaled $1.00. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Horace R. Moorhead; Executive, 84
description: Horace Reynolds Moorhead, a retired treasurer of the former Gulf Oil Corporation who served as a financial officer of several other companies, died of heart disease on Monday at a retirement village in Bryn Mawr. He was 84 years old.

title: Webcott Plans Del Webb Fight
description: Webcott Holdings, the largest shareholder in the Del Webb Corporation, said today that it plans to mount a proxy fight to increase its representation on the company's board and remove barriers to a possible takeover of the company.

title: National Health Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Howdy, Stranger
description: Through his Cable News Network, Ted Turner has viewers in some 90 countries, and he wants them to know that as far as he is concerned, they are not just a bunch of foreigners. In a memo to news personnel last week, Mr. Turner banned the use of the word ''foreign'' where the word ''international'' will do. The word was banned not only on broadcasts but in conversation and writing related to company business. It's all in the name of friendship. Mr. Turner wrote: ''The word 'foreign' implies something unfamiliar and creates the perception of misunderstanding. In contrast, 'international' means 'among nations' and promotes a sense of unity.'' To show that he means business, Mr. Turner listed a schedule of punishments for employees who utter or write the forbidden word on company time. First offenders are to be warned; subsequent offenses call for fines of up to $100 per offense. It was unclear how enforcement would be handled - perhaps by some sort of language-security guards.

description: TOASTMASTERS

description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Purdue;   Professor Appeals Loss of Pay Raise Over a Letter
description: Nearly 11 months have passed since a Purdue University professor sent a letter critical of the university's personnel practices, a letter that led to his being denied a merit raise.
