title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Those of us who have to sort trash into piles of glass, cans and paper are already aware that there is a garbage crisis. Americans generate more than our fair share of refuse, much of it in the form of non-cycled, non-biodegradeable plastic.

title: Q and A
description: Conflict on a Condo Board

title: Marilyn Mallonn Becomes a Bride
description: The Holy Spirit Lutheran Church in Leonia, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Marilyn Evelyn Mallonn and Ernest Anthony Feirer. The Rev. Michael Magwire performed the ceremony.

title: Feud Lingers for Cuomo and 'Rapp'
description: Only one person calls Clarence D. Rappleyea by his first name, and it's not his wife. It's Mario Cuomo, ''and he does it only because he knows it irritates me,'' said Mr. Rappleyea, the Republican leader of the New York State Assembly, whom everybody else just calls ''Rapp.''

title: Anne Segrest Weds Ned McCulloch in Georgia
description: Anne Elizabeth Segrest, an associate in the law firm of Gordon & Barnett, and Edgar H. McCulloch 3d, a lobbyist for the Service Employees International Union, both in Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Calvin Chesnutt performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Athens, Ga.

title: Kendall S. Smith Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Bowen Smith of Greenwich, Conn., and Claiborne, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kendall Simmons Smith to Clifford Lowell Voges, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger L. Voges of Greenwich. A September wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cement deck around our swimming pool has become dark and dirty looking. Scrubbing with bleach solutions has not helped much. Do you know of anything we can use to make the deck look nice again?

title: Down With Mass Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Women in Delhi Angered by Smoking Pitch
description: The introduction of a new brand of Indian cigarette aimed at upwardly mobile women has galvanized women's groups and health organizations in India, where anti-smoking campaigns had barely begun.

title: Providence Eliminates Maryland By 77-75
description: Tracy Lis had 23 points to lead Providence College, the Big East Conference champion, to a 77-75 victory over Maryland today in the second round of the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament.

title: Keep Those Economists Out of the Vineyards;   A Meaningless Average
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeanne E. Folts to Wed Jason E. Leo
description: The Rev. and Mrs. James E. Folts of Brownsville, Tex., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Jeanne Elizabeth Folts, and Jason Elliman Leo, a son of the Very Rev. and Mrs. James Richard Leo of Paris.

title: Mail Carrier Arrested On a Heroin Charge
description: A Yonkers mail carrier was arrested yesterday in the Bronx on drug charges after officers said they found him with a small amount of heroin that a friend had just purchased, the police said.

title: From Black Tie to Glass Tie
description: MEN. YOU CAN TAKE them anywhere, but you can't dress them up. This stereotype seems to have haunted males ever since Adam decided that fig leaves were sufficient attire. But although many men still feel they would rather don a straitjacket than a tuxedo, others are discovering that formal can be fun. Some are even creating their own brand of chic - or chicanery.

title: Easy Victory for Unbridled
description: Unbridled scored an easy victory today in the $500,000 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park, but the afternoon's most impressive performance by a Kentucky Derby prospect came in another race and from a colt who was beaten.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   A Garden as Spring's Gateway in Central Park
description: The first signs of spring are already evident at the Conservatory Garden, a formal garden tucked away in the northeast corner of Central Park.

title: New York Area's Population Growing, but Graying Faster
description: The population of the New York region will increase only moderately but grow significantly older during the next three decades, according to new projections.

title: 'Caller ID': More Than Progress
description: Re: '''Caller ID' Stirs Debate on Phone Privacy,'' Feb. 11:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: South Hadley, Mass.;

College Project Getting Bigger
description: LEAD: MOUNT HOLYOKE COLLEGE has decided to invest an additional $5 million in the Village Commons complex here. Upon completion, expected next fall, the $15 million development will have added 135,000 square feet of commercial and residential space to this bedroom community of 17,000 people.

title: Howard Kaplan to Wed Jennifer Lacks
description: May wedding plans for Jennifer Monique Lacks and Howard Jay Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kaplan of New Rochelle, N.Y., have been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Sanford A. Lacks of Brookhaven, L.I.

title: As the East Germans Vote Today, They Choose for Europe as Well
description: East Germans will vote on Sunday in an election that marks a turning point for the Germans, Europe and Communism.

title: Washburn's Regrets
description: HE got an early start on his professional career by jumping to the National Basketball Association after his sophomore season at North Carolina State, but the way Chris Washburn sees it, he might have made more money and kept more of it if he had stayed in school another year.

title: Prize-Winning Pianist Returning to Greenwich
description: IN 1979, at the age of 11, the Korean-born pianist Ju Hee Suh made her debut with Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic. Five years later, she appeared with the Greenwich Symphony, and now barely into her 20's, the prize-winning performer is returning to Greenwich to play Rachmaninoff's Second Concerto. The orchestra, under its music director, David Gilbert, will also perform Bach's Orchestral Suite No. 4 and the Symphony No. 1 of Samuel Barber, just a few weeks after the 80th anniversary of Barber's birth. The programs will be offered Saturday evening at 8:30 and next Sunday afternoon at 4, in the Greenwich High School auditorium (869-2664).

title: Roy Marsden: More Than a Civilized Copper
description: ''Death seems to provide the minds of the Anglo-Saxon race with a greater fund of innocent enjoyment than any other single subject.'' So wrote Dorothy L. Sayers in 1934, and what is noteworthy is how, in Britain, women have come to dominate detective fiction. From Agatha Christie and Margery Allingham to today's P. D. James and Ruth Rendell, the business of crime and punishment, with the detective as avenging deity, has become very much a female affair.

title: Nature Evoked by Works in Fiber
description: ''FIBER EXPRESSIONS'' is an exhibition with an amalgam of natural forms, traditional fabric techniques and high-tech materials.

title: U.S. Drug Agency Office in Florida Is Bombed
description: A building that housed offices of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration was destroyed by a large bomb and fire early today.

title: THE GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: BETTER LUCK NEXT TIME, KIPLING: REJECTION SLIPS FOR THE AGES
description: Why, oh why, were the merits of remarkable books ever in doubt? Perhaps nothing is so painful as rejection, and nothing so sweet, especially to an author, as wrongful rejection overruled by history. The assessments that follow did not deter the writers from trying again, nor the public from ultimately reading the books. They are excerpted from ''Rotten Rejections: A Literary Companion,'' edited by Andre Bernard and with an introduction by Bill Henderson, to be published next month by Pushcart Press.

title: A DURABLE HERESY
description: SPINOZA AND OTHER HERETICS

title: Smoke Fells Firefighters In Skyscraper's Cellar
description: Five firefighters were hospitalized for smoke inhalation yesterday after battling a fire that broke out in the cellar of a largely unoccupied 50-floor office building on Lexington Avenue and East 51st Street in Manhattan.

title: CONTENTMENT IS HARD WORK
description: FLOW

title: Amy Slove to Wed Thomas Jakobson
description: The engagement of Amy Beth Slove and Thomas Andrew Jakobson has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lawrence Slove of Westfield, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Alan R. Denzer of Greenwich, Conn., and Peter Jakobson of New York and Elberon, N.J. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: This is a good week to use fertilizer, especially on woody plants and lawns. But it is too early to remove winter protective mulches from garden borders, flower beds and younger plants; wait. Prune roses when forsythia blooms. Try sharp smelling spice or ground red pepper to discourage squirrels, mice, rabbits and other furry invaders from damaging flowers and plants.

title: JULIA ROBERTS FACES A TEST OF CHARACTER
description: In Garry Marshall's new romantic fantasy, a pretty woman is seen walking down the street, and she is indeed - as Roy Orbison sings - the kind you ''like to meet.'' But in this post-modern Cinderella story, with Shavian overtones and Los Angeles locales, the heroine happens to be a hooker. And the man who would be her Prince is a mendacious corporate raider whose only regal trait is a passion for opera, specifically Verdi.

title: Islanders Are Led By LaFontaine
description: Night after night, the games were dropped, the chances at points slipped away. Still, even as the futility stretched to more than a month, the Islanders woke up to the fact that they were not sunk yet.

title: A SMALL GIRL IN GERMANY
description: FLOATING IN MY MOTHER'S PALM

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BENNINGTON, VT.;

First Condos For Industry
description: LEAD: BENNINGTON COUNTY'S first industrial condominiums, created in the historic Holden Leonard Mill complex here by the nonprofit Southern Vermont Development Council, are attracting interest but sales have been slow. The $3 million project, financed with Federal, state and local loans, is meant to provide space with equity for local businesses and to help attract outside firms, said Thomas Bluto, the council's development director.

title: Mandela Says He'll Lead Panel In April Session With de Klerk
description: Nelson Mandela returned home today and said he would lead the African National Congress delegation that has been invited to meet President F. W. de Klerk on April 11.

title: Stemming the Losses: Trying for a Leaner Macy's
description: In the fickle world of consumption in which R. H. Macy & Company makes its living, every day is another dollar and every day may bring another horror. How is one going to sell those weasel-skin mufflers that only yesterday seemed so haute couture? Why did the buyer have to take 7,000 of the musical cutting boards?

title: Goodbye to a Gravy Train
description: As the hands on the clock swept toward midnight, all hands on deck filed into a conference room in the headquarters of ESPN, the cable television sports network.

title: Students' Problems Tied to Society's Ills
description: The letters in today's Long Island section [Feb. 18] will suggest to some that lack of dedication on the part of teachers is the reason student performance is so poor.

title: Saudis and Soviets: Oil's Odd Couple
description: The Soviet Union is the world's largest producer and second-largest exporter of oil. Saudi Arabia is the largest exporter.

title: Surgery for Driver
description: A DAY after he crashed into a concrete barrier while testing a race car in West Palm Beach, Fla., Scott Pruett, the co-rookie of the year in the 1989 Indianapolis 500, was reported in fair condition yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, where he underwent surgery to repair multiple fractures of both legs. The 29-year-old Pruett also suffered two fractured vertebrae, a hospital spokesman said.(AP)

title: Laura House Affianced
description: May wedding plans for Laura Lynne House and Jonathan Avram Kramer, a son of Mrs. M. Eli Kramer of New York and the late Mr. Kramer, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Junius House of Tarboro, N.C. Miss House, 25 years old, graduated from Vassar College, as did her fiance, and is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at George Washington University. Mr. Kramer, 26, is a real-estate broker at Barrueta & Associates in Washington.

title: GETTING DOWN TO EARTH
description: The descriptions often sound like they're from the back of a cereal box - words like ''back to nature'' or ''unprocessed.'' Indeed, designers and manufacturers are becoming downright earthy, shunning the synthetics in favor of the naturals.

title: Dede C. Zeluck Weds John H. Caron
description: At the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia, Dede Cynthia Zeluck, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Zeluck of Haddonfield, N.J., was married yesterday to John Higman Caron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Blackwood Caron of Greenwich, Conn. Judge Stephen Levin of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas performed the ceremony.

title: ELEKTRA CLASSICS IS ABOUT TO MAKE ITS FIRST BIG SPLASH
description: Apparently record companies - no matter how big - more and more feel that pop and rock aren't enough to make them perceived as ''full-line'' record companies; one must be in the classical business, too. Thus it was that Warner Communications (now Time Warner) took the plunge in 1988, buying the Hamburg-based Teldec organization and obtaining a 20 percent interest in the French Erato label, which had been affiliated with RCA. Those ventures, under the corporate banner of Elektra International Classics, are now beginning to bear fruit in the American market, with a large series of releases on both labels scheduled for May.

title: Players Hurt in Crash
description: SEVEN members of the Central Connecticut State tennis team were injured, three of them seriously, Friday night when a van carrying them from the Orlando, Fla., airport was struck by a car that crossed the median of an expressway.

title: Walter T. Ridder, 72, Retired News Executive
description: Walter T. Ridder, a retired news executive who helped create the Knight-Ridder, Inc., communications organization, died after a long illness Saturday in his home in McLean, Va. He was 72 years old.

title: Outsiders Seem to Lead In a Chicago Campaign
description: In some ways, it seemed astonishing for Mayor Richard M. Daley, son and namesake of this city's most famous political boss and kingmaker, to belittle the importance of political parties.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Finding The New Me
description: LEAD: I STARE at the glowing dawn sky from my plane window; is it beautiful? I don't know. It is 6:30, and I am on my first business trip. People all around me are yawning, sleeping, eating, reading, talking; I sit, bleary-eyed and elegantly dressed, sensing the pounding of my heart.

description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cement deck around our swimming pool has become dark and dirty looking. Scrubbing with bleach solutions has not helped much. Do you know of anything we can use to make the deck look nice again?

title: Lifestyle;   Street Vending Booths Open With the Leaves
description: Michael Eldred was doing his dance, the one he calls ''pitching and hawking.'' It involves stomping, clapping and shouting to get the attention of people walking by his table on a Brooklyn Heights sidewalk, a table loaded with children's books.

title: Amanda Mullally To Marry in May
description: Mrs. Mandeville Mullally of Lawrence, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter Amanda Mandeville Mullally to Matthew Bouvy Drake, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Griffith Drake of Portland, Ore. Miss Mullally also is a daughter of the late Mr. Mullally Jr. A May wedding is planned.

title: Digging In
description: It could be that the de-Communization of Eastern Europe is naught but a Soviet ploy to lull the West into ill-defended complacency. If so - and Elizabeth Clare Prophet believes it is - any Soviet invaders could be in for a surprise when they reach Paradise Valley, Mont. There, Mrs. Prophet, leader of the Church Universal and Triumphant, has assembled more than 2,000 of her followers and bade them prepare to sit out World War III in a huge complex of underground shelters on the church's 33,000-acre ranch. The followers, who paid up to $6,000 each to reserve shelter space, have tons of food, a lot of guns and their theologically eclectic New Age faith. Mrs. Prophet has recently predicted increased East-West tensions, seeing a a particularly ''dangerous period'' around April 23. Meanwhile, however, the church has frictions with its neighbors, who say that work on the shelters is damaging the environment.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: UMass;   Electronic Sex: Does It Qualify As Scholastic?
description: The discovery of an electronic bulletin board for sexually explicit stories on the mainframe computer at the University of Massachusetts here has sparked a debate over whether campus administrators can censor computer mail.

title: Hungary's Spicy, Exotic Wine
description: THE main highway from Budapest to the Tokay region runs northwest, skirting Eger, where the famous Bikaver, or Bull's Blood, is made, to Miskolc, a grimy industrial town where the truckers stop before pushing on into the Soviet Union. But wine lovers turn off to the right at Miskolc and something of a miracle seems to take place. The grime and smoke give way to rollings hills, forests and little villages out of Chekhov. Tokay itself is such a village, only 40 miles from the Soviet border.

title: For John Gibbons, the Music Is Always the Message
description: ''Landowska was one of those performers whom we listen to now with a mixture of horrified awe and enormous respect,'' says the harpsichodist John Gibbons of the legendary keyboard virtuoso. ''The values were rather different in those days. It was completely acceptable for an interpreter to change instrumentation, notes or anything in the score, as long as what the performer felt was the message of the music was coming through.''

title: Ivy Covers New Ground
description: TRADITIONALLY, THE MAN WHO FAVORS THE IVY League look is a man who comports himself according to the Protestant work ethic. He values steadiness, reliability and industry. For decades, his uniform has been a Brooks Brothers suit, rep tie and button-down shirt. ''It's what sociologists call 'an instrumental orientation,' '' says Ruth P. Rubinstein, a professor of sociology at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan. ''It's a look that says, 'Hey, I can perform the job. I am always going to interact in the way that's appropriate.' ''

title: Ernst Bacon, a Composer Known For Echoing America, Dies at 91
description: Ernst Bacon, a prolific composer, pianist, conductor and teacher whose career spanned more than six decades, died of heart failure on Friday at his home in Orinda, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: Debate Deepens Over Artistic Costs Of Art Subsidies
description: ON the eve of their annual descent on Congress to seek Federal support for the arts, the artists and institutions that make up America's loosely knit cultural lobby are fractious and divided as never before. At issue is whether to accept restrictions like those passed last year on Federal financing for ''obscene'' art as a necessary evil or as a challenge to be vigorously confronted.

title: Review/Music;   Delafose's Traditional Zydeco Style
description: John Delafose and the Eunice (La.) Playboys don't bother with any of zydeco's latest borrowings: no funk, no rock, no country-and-western, just the homegrown heritage of Cajun two-steps and waltzes tinctured with blues and rhythm-and-blues. Wednesday night at Tramps, in the band's New York City debut, the closest thing he sang to a pop song was the Johnny Horton hit ''The Battle of New Orleans,'' from 1959. Mr. Delafose's traditionalist zydeco has been filling Gulf Coast dance floors since the mid-1970's, and at Tramps there was no mystery why - it had the beat, the tunes, and the heart.

title: LOVE AS A BURDEN, A CALLING AND, SOMETIMES, A CATHARSIS

title: Couch Potatoes, Unbound
description: With the arrival of cable television, VCR's and video rental stores, futurologists predicted that Saturday nights at the Bijou would go the way of community sings. Why would people stand in long lines, pay $7 and suffer whisperers in a cramped movie house when they could be home in their jammies eating microwaved popcorn with an incredible choice of things to see?

title: Cajun Cooking in a Homey Atmosphere
description: CANNERY CAFE in the center of Canaan, in the state's northwest corner, is the kind of place weary travelers dream of finding, but rarely do, when passing through an unfamiliar town at mealtime. The modest storefront facade sends few signals of the delicious food that awaits within.

title: Pascal Gayle Batson 3d, Psychiatrist, 43
description: Dr. Pascal Gayle Batson 3d, a psychiatrist who was formerly on the staff of the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, died of AIDS last Monday at his home in Washington. He was 43 years old.

title: Heading for the Road in Eastern Europe
description: ''EVERY day brings changes,'' said Alexey N. Mesiatsev, the deputy general director of Intourist in New York, ''not just in opening roads but in our societies.'' Asked how many miles of road in the Soviet Union were open to drivers from the West at the end of February, he smiled wistfully, implying that it was difficult to say.

title: NONFICTION
description: COUNTERFEITER: The Story of a Master Forger. By Charles Black and Michael Horsnell. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) ''Successful counterfeiting requires not only skill, patience and a great deal of capital to buy the range of complex machinery which is the forger's stock-in-trade, but an intense appreciation of security.'' So instructs Charles Black, a British master forger who in the 1970's devised and developed a sophisticated method of photolithographic counterfeiting. With Michael Horsnell of The Times of London, Mr. Black tells the strange saga of his escapades in counterfeiting, which began at his home in Kent, where he assembled a cedar shed that, he boasts, was ''the finest forger's den in the history of counterfeiting.'' Police officials later discovered the plates for dollar and pound notes and traveler's checks drawn on the Barclays, Lloyds and National Westminster banks, along with an offset litho machine, a hand letterpress printing machine, numbering boxes and a supply of magnetic ink. Mr. Black claims that his operation was the biggest forgery production center in the world. A set of his printing plates and a series of his forged bank notes are preserved in Scotland Yard's museum of criminal artifacts. However, the story of Mr. Black's techniques, goals and encounters with the law is less amusing than he and Mr. Horsnell seem to think. Mr. Black is a little too pleased with his accomplishments in ''the art of counterfeiting.'' He forgets that the ''art'' is also a threat to national security and international economies - and a felony.

title: Mystique Plus Business Sense Equals Success
description: It takes only a phrase, a few bars of music, an expression:

title: China
description: To the Editor: I read Carol Kramer's article ''China After Tiananmen Square'' (Travel, Feb. 18) with a mixture of fond memories and sadness. Having completed a tour a few weeks before the Tiananmen incident, I relived our stay (and the guilt we felt when we first arrived) at the incredible Shanghai Hilton, our lovely hotel in Xian and the adventure of traveling on old Russian planes between cities. Our Chinese waiters and bellhops assured us that the hotels we stayed in gave them an opportunity for a better life.

It is the Inwood Canoe Club, and what is left of it sits 300 yards south of Dyckman Street in a quiet cove along the Hudson River, in the shadow of Fort Tryon Park in northern Manhattan.

description: Approval has been granted by the City Council here for the world's tallest building. But will it ever be built? And, if it is, will the sky-high rents needed to recoup construction costs make it difficult to attract tenants?

title: Blue Collars, Both Fashionable and Frayed
description: With enough money, ingenuity and chutzpah, movie makers can do anything. They are able to re-create 19th-century Africa, the battles of the Civil War, volcanic eruptions and the new Dark Ages that will follow World War III. In movies, fetuses can talk and horses fly. Movies make the impossible look ordinary. What they can't do with any ease is imagine the time and place we live in now.

title: San Juan's Cultural Heart
description: IT is well known that San Juan's major hotels have gambling casinos and nightclubs in which one can hear slick popularizations of Latin culture, but what is less familiar is the city's many venues for music, dance and film. Even if you don't gamble and don't like nightclubs, you can usually find something interesting to do in the temperate evenings. Like any other metropolitan center of 1.5 million, San Juan has a Fine Arts Center(Centro de Bellas Artes). It was constructed in the late 1970's in Santurce, the larger city surrounding Old San Juan and its Condado beach and hotel district and a short taxi ride away from where tourists normally stay. The center's three halls (salas) seat2,000, 750 and 450. Also in the San Juan area are universities that sponsor cultural performances and many independent cultural organizations.

The film, ''Longtime Companion,'' which explores the effect of the disease on the gay community over eight years, was unlikely to find backers with bales of cash begging to finance it.

title: SHAPING A TRADITION
description: Men's fashion moves forward not by leaps but by small steps, and changes are often imperceptible. All the more reason to welcome the spring of 1990 as a season of real - and sometimes radical - shifts in style. Conventional tailoring hasn't been scrapped so much as re-examined, with the emphasis on comfort, mobility and self-expression. It is Giorgio Armani who has made the first move to alter the shape of the 1990's. In a surprising about-face, the Milanese inventor of the angular, big-shouldered and much-imitated power suit has turned away from his own tradition. The new Armani jacket - patterned on the English model, with its natural shoulders and nipped waist - is long, lean and liberating. Its loose fit and non-aggressive spirit have left their mark on men's fashions this year. Also changed is the way clothes are worn. Combinations that seemed jarring a decade ago suddenly make sense. It's a rare man these days who hasn't tossed a foul-weather parka over a business suit or dressed down a blazer with a rugged denim shirt. As men shrug off a standard uniform, style will be defined by the way clothes are mixed.

title: BUSH IS REPORTED READY TO RETREAT ON MILITARY MONEY
description: Faced with widespread pressure from Congress and elsewhere, the Bush Administration has decided to retreat on the 1991 military budget and accept cuts almost as large as those that lawmakers are urging, senior Government officials say.

title: All About/Commuter Airlines;   Deregulation Left Only the Strong

Just 12 years later, Air Wisconsin has become the nation's largest commuter airline. Its turboprops and jets, with as many as 100 seats, carry more than two million passengers a year.

title: THE LADY SOMETIMES VANISHES
description: We are the parents of the Ralph Ferrandina mentioned in ''The Lady Sometimes Vanishes,'' by Nancy Malitz, (Feb. 25). Teresa is so pure of heart and soul that it appears unreal. We don't believe her career ever comes first; it is people who come first. She has helped us and our son by giving him a bonus of life for the last three years. As parents, how can we ever repay her or forget her? To us, the lady never does vanish.

title: Here Boy!
description: It seems that dogs have a new best friend up in Alaska. Susan Butcher last week won her fourth victory in the grueling 1,158-mile Iditarod Trail Dog Sled Race. Along the way she set a new record time of 11 days, 1 hour, 53 minutes and 28 seconds for the Anchorage-to-Nome run, earning $50,000 in prize money plus a $25,000 bonus from her sponsor, a dog food manufacturer. All credit went -where else? - to the dogs. ''This team has been absolutely incredible,'' she said. ''I've never had a team go as strong as this.'' With her victory, women have won five of the last six Iditarod races - Ms. Butcher intends to make it six of seven next year - inspiring T-shirts reading, ''Alaska: Where men are men and women win the Iditarod.''

title: Should the Poor Get the Housing That Koch Built?
description: A SINGULAR achievement of former Mayor Edward I. Koch's last term was the creation of a huge housing program, which has already produced about 3,500 new subsidized apartments in formerly abandoned buildings in New York City's poorest neighborhoods. About 13,000 other apartments are under construction, and a total of 47,000 are to be renovated by the mid-1990's. The effort is the most ambitious in the nation, far exceeding affordable-housing initiatives by any other city or state.

The informant was Philip Leonetti, not Mr. Salerno. And the case should not have been cited as an example of the flaws attributed by the reviewer to the book.
