title: NONFICTION
description: NIGHT AND FOG. By Arne Brun Lie with Robby Robinson. (Norton, $18.95.) Half of ''Night and Fog'' is the story of the Norwegian Arne Brun Lie's year as a political prisoner of the occupying Nazi Government. The other half is the story of how Mr. Lie got up the nerve to talk about that year. The two halves run alongside each other the length of the book and somehow never quite cohere. That can be a bit jarring, but it is not really a problem, because Mr. Lie, an inexperienced writer who worries about ''the clumsy feel of a pen in my hands,'' with the help of Robby Robinson, an English teacher in Massachusetts, writes engagingly and well. Mr. Lie was a schoolboy who had just begun training with the Norwegian Resistance and had not yet shot a gun when the Nazis ''disappeared'' him and put him in a special ''night and fog'' camp for enemies of the state. (''Night and fog'' was the Nazi designation for their program for political prisoners; they stamped its initials on uniforms, broke its victims down with ''cat-and-mouse torment instead of instant death'' and called them ''the already dead.'') Forty years later, Mr. Lie skippered a 37-foot cutter from Boston to Oslo and, during long watches, talked out his repressed memories. The moral of the story is that he survived through dreams: Arne Brun Lie the camp prisoner dreamed of meat pudding, sailboats, fjords and even elephants, while Arne Brun Lie the survivor dreamed guiltily about surviving and was finally tortured by dreams into speech. The tragedy of it, for a world where ''disappearing'' and abusing political prisoners is still commonplace, is that it took Mr. Lie so long to talk - and, by talking, to heal.

title: GOD IS HER MOTHER
description: LEAD:

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Southeast Regional;   Georgia Tech Squeaks Past L.S.U.
description: Appropriately enough, the ball ended up in Kenny Anderson's hands. And after surviving 10 blocked shots, a 15-point blitz by Louisiana State in the game's opening minutes, and a final, desperation shot by the Tigers' Maurice Williamson, Georgia Tech watched the last second tick off the clock in a breathtaking 94-91 victory over L.S.U.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: As Spring Nears, Flowers Can't Be Far Behind
description: LEAD: CIVIC-MINDED residents whose thoughts turn to horticulture with the vernal equinox might want to visit the Westchester Beautification Conference Thursday at Pepsico headquarters in Purchase. The free conference offers three workshops on landscaping and planting community spaces.

title: Correction
description: Last Sunday, this column misidentified President Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury. He was Salmon P. Chase.

title: LINDA FAIRSTEIN VS. RAPE
description: As the 1972-73 coordinator of the Rape Prevention Committee for NOW-NYC, I was pleased to read ''Linda Fairstein vs. Rape'' (Feb. 25). At the time of our campaign to have a rape unit established, the District Attorney's office operated on a rotation system. Any woman brave enough to press charges against a rapist would be assigned to whatever lawyer was next in the rotation line. How much less traumatic for the victim to work with one prosecutor in Linda Fairstein's sex-crimes unit, a lawyer with a special understanding of the aftermath of rape.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;

9-Screen Start For a 2d Phase
description: LEAD: THE second phase of an 11.5-acre development along the Delaware River waterfront has begun with construction of a 36,000-square-foot, $6 million movie theater on Delaware Avenue between Reed and Dickinson Streets.

title: Jefferson Ruling Could Help Poindexter
description: To the Editor:

title: PASSIONS AND PASSING GLANCES
description: LEAD:

title: Spill Forces Evacuation
description: About 12,000 gallons of the chemical solvent cumene spilled aboard a tanker in the Delaware River during unloading this morning, forcing the evacuation of about 250 people from a three-block area. Five workers at a pier near the spill were treated at a hospital for headaches and nausea after breathing the fumes of the chemical.

title: S & L's: Big Money, Little Outcry
description: BEFORE the decade is out, the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry is expected to cost the Government more than $200 billion. That is much more than the Government will spend on such critical social problems as preschool education, drug control and aid to the homeless. It is more than will be spent on highways, air traffic control and pollution abatement. It amounts to more than $1,300 for every American taxpayer, and it will not enhance national security, promote economic growth or improve public welfare one bit.

title: A DRIVING PASSION
description: A DESERT SCENE IN WHICH MILlions of dollars change hands under a tent seems better suited to an oil-rich sheikdom than an Arizona polo field called Horseworld. Compounding the strangeness is that the commodity being bought and sold here is not the four-legged means of transportation of years gone by, but the machines that made them nearly obsolete - automobiles.

title: Support Group Eases Family Burdens
description: LEAD: WHEN Barbara Fussiner encountered problems in caring for her aging mother, a friend who was in a similar situation offered her one bit of advice, ''Go see Muriel Banquer.''

title: At Hispanic Fete, Finale for a Quatro
description: LEAD: FOR six generations, the family of Casimiro Flores has been making quatros, Puerto Rican guitarlike instruments that produce a higher pitch - ''sing so sweet,'' their maker said - because they are fashioned out a single piece of wood.

title: New Clue Is Uncovered in Bank Explosion
description: Investigators said today that they had pinpointed a leak in a propane gas line near a bank where an explosion killed three employees and injured 14 other people last week.

title: Anne Adler and John Tarbell Jr. Wed
description: Anne Southall Adler, a daughter of Anne Freeman Adler and Julius Ochs Adler, both of New York, was married yesterday to John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr., the son of Mrs. Tarbell of Needham, Mass., and the late Mr. Tarbell. The Rev. Jane P. Henderson performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

title: The Fallout From Military Cutbacks
description: SAM GEJDENSON, the 41-year-old Bozrah Democrat who has been elected five times to Congress from Connecticut's Second District, has long been an advocate of economic diversification to make Connecticut less reliant on defense industries.

title: Lynne Katsafouros Friedman - T-Shirt Artist
description: A dog is a dog is a dog and a cat is a cat is a cat - to non-dog and non-cat people. But to the enormous fraternity of pet owners, their cats and dogs are as beloved as children. It's therefore no surprise that when Lynne Katsafouros Friedman appeared in public last year in a T-shirt with a hand-painted poodle on it, strangers approached, and when they discovered she had painted it herself, asked if she would do one for them. Thus was a business born.

title: In Fairfield, 'The Ice Cream Sunday'
description: JUST imagine that Oscar Wilde hadn't written ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' We might have been spared ''The Ice Cream Sunday'' by Frank Salisbury.

title: Funds Restored To Keep All County Parks Open
description: WITH the unexpected arrival of springlike weather last week, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's announcement that all county parks will remain open this season seemed propitious.

title: Review/Theater;   'Spare Parts,' and Baby Makes Four
description: Lois and Jax, the embattled protagonists of Elizabeth Page's comedy ''Spare Parts,'' are a lesbian couple who decide, without really thinking ahead, to have a child. As the play opens, Lois is making love with Henry, a young man she has picked up in a bar and gone home with for the sole purpose of insemination. Neither she nor Jax has bargained for the possibility that the man chosen to be the father will turn out to be a soft-hearted romantic who remains smitten with his date and who, upon discovering she is pregnant with his child, insists on taking on the responsibilities of an expectant father.

title: PAN AM 103: THE GERMAN CONNECTION
description: LEAD: John Boyd had never investigated an air disaster. He rarely even flew. As chief constable for the tiny police district of Dumfries and Galloway, in southwestern Scotland, he was used to rounding up stray dogs and looking into cases of suspectd sheep anthrax. But as he stood on a kitchen chair the night of Dec.

title: NIAGARA FALLS GOTHIC
description: THE WHIRLPOOL

title: Blossoms and Bullets
description: There's a touch of spring in the air in New York City and something else, too: stray bullets. One day last week, one struck Amy Rosen while she ate her lunch in Central Park. That evening, another struck Loretta Rivera as she walked home from a pizza parlor in Brooklyn. Dr. Rosen, luckily, survived her chest wound. Ms. Rivera died on a street so riddled by shootouts that none of her neighbors expressed surprise.

title: Employers Find Child Care Is Good for Business
description: LEAD: MANY couples in the state have two jobs and children, raising the question of who takes care of the children.

title: Opening in Baseball Talks Reported
description: The first significant sign of possible movement by the owners on salary arbitration, the lone remaining major issue in baseball's labor dispute, crept into their talks with the players yesterday.

title: The Gospel According to Alec McCowen
description: It was Alec McCowen's 64th birthday. There were bluebells in the woods near Chichester, where he was playing the tyrannical father in a stage adaptation of Henry James's ''Washington Square.'' So he did what any other sensitive person would have done under the circumstances: he went for a contemplative walk. ''There I was in this lovely place,'' he recalls, ''and suddenly, without realizing it, I found myself reciting bits of St. Mark's Gospel. It was then I realized I had to do it again.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Q and A
description: Bulb Displays in Britain

title: Max Nierman, Commodities Trader, 90
description: Max Nierman, a commodities trader and member of the Chicago Board of Trade for more than half a century, died Friday at the Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 90 years old and lived in Palm Springs.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Song Trips by Molly Scates
description: Molly Scates, a singer and actress from Tennessee, makes good use of her inherited and acquired backgrounds in the act she is doing on Tuesday evenings this month at Eighty Eight's, 228 West 10th Street. Her program focuses on Broadway songs, with a few pop songs, both current and ancient, and just a touch of top-flight country (Patsy Cline and Hank Williams) as seasoning.

title: WHEN BRITISH JUSTICE FAILED
description: Arguably, the best criticism of the death penalty I have ever heard came from someone who is for it. In Kevin Toolis's excellent article ''When British Justice Failed'' (Feb. 25), Justice Donaldson is quoted as telling the three men among the Guildford Four that they would have been executed, had hanging been allowed.

title: In Transylvania, the Battle for the Past Continues
description: After teaching history in this small, predominantly Hungarian village in Transylvania for more than 30 years, Istvan Vincze is used to shifts in the official version of the truth.

title: Keep Those Economists Out of the Vineyards;   Lacks Human Element
description: To the Editor:

title: Rowdiness and Politics Skip Parade
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, carrying a black shillelagh and wearing a ''Free Joe Doherty'' button, led 125,000 marchers yesterday in the 228th St. Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue, past hundreds of thousands of horn-blowing, green-clad and usually sober spectators.

title: INSIDE
description: Inquiry on Panama Killings

title:
The Executive Life;

Humiliating Times For a Boss Who Smokes
description: LEAD: In business corridors, smoking has become the great new equalizer, at least in the minds of some chief executives who are unable to quit. Cigarettes are no longer a symbol of strength, machismo and style, and smoky rooms, no longer synonymous with serious business. Executives who smoke these days tend to feel weak, embarrassed and ashamed.

title: Where the East Bloc Rocks
description: ON a Friday night in Prague in June, as couples strolled across Wenceslas Square or promenaded down the Narodni Street toward the National Theater, Czechoslovak rock fans lined up outside Chelmnice, one of the hottest spots to hear rock in Central Europe.

title: Review/Theater;   Rubber-Faced Lunacy According to Hoyle
description: For the finale of his one-man clown show, ''Feast of Fools,'' Geoff Hoyle does something incomparable with his three legs. All three are trousered and shod and they peep out from under a long greatcoat. Mr. Hoyle walks on stage at the Westside Arts Theater as if it were the most natural thing in the world to be a triped. Then he begins to dance with himself, swirling and dipping, two feet in the air, one on the ground and vice versa, until he becomes an Astaire-and-a-half soaring in ballroom abandon.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cement deck around our swimming pool has become dark and dirty looking. Scrubbing with bleach solutions has not helped much. Do you know of anything we can use to make the deck look nice again?

title:
Haworth Journal;

Borough Uses Windfall for a New Library Building
description: LEAD: MUCH to June E. Lewin's surprise, what appeared to be a routine job as the director of a small-town library developed into a project many librarians would covet when the town used a windfall for a new library building.

title: Architect's Lament: Moscow So Drab
description: ''Moscow is the capital of unfortunate people,'' declared Aleksei A. Klimenko, an architectural historian, his native bitterness resonating across the soul-weary posture of the city.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: The Rangers will win the Stanley Cup (hopefully soon and hopefully often) when we have put together a strong organization from top to bottom which works hard and develops its player talent. ''Deals'' can be an important ingredient in achieving success, but ''deals'' are only one part of a number of factors needed to succeed. We believe we have put the basics in place and will continue every effort to bring our loyal fans the cup they deserve.

title: 6 Reported Dead in New Fighting in Lebanon
description: Exchanges of artillery between warring Christian factions reportedly killed six people and wounded nine others in the hills east of here today.

title: Tanzania Is Still Limping Despite Outside Aid
description: Five years ago the Tanzanian economy was such a hopeless case that its leaders jettisoned their long-held opposition to what they regarded as the world's financial police - the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank - and signed up.

title: William Rockefeller Is Dead at 71; An Ex-President of the A.S.P.C.A.
description: William Rockefeller, a former president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and a former chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Association, died of lung cancer on Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and had homes in Rye, N.Y., and Paul Smiths, N.Y.

title: About Men;   The Bookworm Turns
description: IN HOW MANY FILMS have I seen the touching episode of the father tossing a football to his son, or shooting hoops or going fishing? Hemingway used to drag his toddler along while he blasted ducks out of the sky. Even Paul Simon plays baseball with his kid.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: West Regional;   Louisville Falls Flat In Loss to Ball State
description: Ball State raced to a 17-point lead, then survived a last-second shot to upset listless Louisville, 62-60, today and advance to the semifinals of the West Regional.

title: STREETSCAPES: 9 East 91st Street;   A Soviet Palazzo Off Fifth Ave.
description: IT is now Manhattan's chief mystery house, a giant Italian palazzo at 9 East 91st Street, shuttered and vacant for years. It was scheduled to be opened in 1975 as a Soviet consulate as soon as a corresponding American consulate in Kiev was built. But President Jimmy Carter froze the process after Soviet troops moved into Afghanistan in 1979.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Downtown Brooklyn;   Two Tall Office Towers Planned on a Single Block
description: AT once symbiotic and competitive, two enormous commercial projects, within 60 feet of one another on a single block in downtown Brooklyn, have emerged from complex negotiations and are now in the final stretch of the city's review procedure.

title:
MUSIC;

Debut and New Set for State Opera
description: LEAD: WHEN the New Jersey State Opera performs Verdi's ''Nabucco'' twice this week, the company will unveil a new set, marking the first time that the State Opera has used only sets specially designed for it for an entire season.

title: At Ballet Theater, a Return to Beginnings
description: The appointment last week of Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith as co-directors of American Ballet Theater obviously heralds a new phase in the troupe's history. But through its importance, this decision by the board of an internationally ranked company also symbolizes the implicit closing of a strange era. It is one that saw an unprecedented number of ballet companies headed by male stars, some of whom continued their dancing careers.

title: Review/Theater;   'The Importance of Being Earnest'
description: Oscar Wilde, having been importuned to cut an entire act from ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' attended one of the final rehearsals before its premiere and remarked: ''It is a very good play. I wrote one very like it myself.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Making a Livable Present Out of the Past
description: LEAD: A 14-UNIT subdivision on Goose Hill Road in Cold Spring Harbor being developed by Piping Rock Builders of Locust Valley on a former 30-acre horse farm contains an unusual house for the buyer who prefers the historic to the new.

title: 'I Feel, I See, I Hear, I Know'
description: For nearly two months Nadav Henefeld, a 6-foot-7-inch import from Israel, had been enrolled at the University of Connecticut although ineligible to practice with the basketball team because his Scholastic Aptitude Test scores had not been high enough. But he was granted a second chance to take the test. And now, a few hours before the Huskies' exhibition game last Nov. 1 against Marathon Oil, a touring Oklahoma amateur team, the UConn athletic office was informed that Henefeld was eligible.

title: Catholics' Right to Speak . . .
description: LEAD: In the debate over abortion, which is probably the most vexing social problem America faces, the Roman Catholic Church's leadership is often accused of ''imposing its will'' on the Catholic laity and, through it, on our pluralistic society. Such assertions bespeak a misunderstanding of the nature of the church.

title: Cashing In
description: Over the last few years in the entertainment industry, independent record companies have been selling like food during a famine. Geffen Records, one last independents left on the shelf, has been the focus of a shopping war in recent months as much for the talents of its owner, David Geffen, as for its roster of artists, which includes Guns 'n' Roses, Aerosmith and Ricki Lee Jones. MCA Inc. last week walked away with Geffen, the company and the man, for a whopping $550 million in stock. The deal includes a long-term contract for Mr. Geffen and makes him, at 47, one of the richest people in the country. Said Mr. Geffen, who founded his company 10 years ago, ''The record business is the best business in show business. It requires the smallest investment, it has the least risk, and it has some of the best payoffs.''

title: James F. Gilliam, Professor, 75
description: Dr. James F. Gilliam, a professor at Princeton's School of Historical Studies for two decades before his retirement in 1985, died on Friday after a long illness, at the Merwick Nursing Home in Princeton, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Cyclists May Be Banned At Rockefeller Preserve
description: LEAD: THE state is expected to decide this week whether to prohibit the increasingly popular sport of cycling in the 750-acre Rockefeller State Park Preserve here. If a ban is enforced, the adjoining 2,500-acre Rockefeller family estate will join in the same prohibition.

title: HOMETOWN HORRORS
description: LEAD:

title: M.T.A. Proposes Rail Line to Link Major Airports
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have introduced a plan for rail service to airports that would be financed by the state, city and local transit agencies.

title: ON THE BALLOT: EAST GERMANY'S PARTIES
description: MAJOR PARTIES

title: Ms. Schumacher To Marry in May
description: Brig. Gen. and Mrs. William J. Schumacher of Redstone Arsenal, Ala., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Leslie Karen Schumacher and Gilman Dana S. Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilman S. Burke of New York.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Farmingdale $175,000

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: East Regional;   UConn's Pressure Leads to 74-54 Rout
description: Can a basketball team be in serious trouble when the score is 5-2?

title: WHAT'S A POOR WRITER TO DO?
description: THE WRITERS' TRADE

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

At 3, an Age for Testing Limits
description: LEAD: IT is late afternoon and the winter sun is setting all too quickly outside my living room windows. I have my book and a cup of tea; my son John, who is 3, is asleep on the floor in the midst of his 93d viewing of the ''Where the Wild Things Are'' videotape. The watery light falls on his smooth face, and outlines his curled hand.

title: Chavez Wins in Final Round
description: Julio Cesar Chavez knocked out Meldrick Taylor in the final seconds of a spirited 12-round bout between junior welterweight champions here at the Hilton Hotel tonight, but it was a controversial ending. Chavez was behind on two of the judges' cards at the time that Referee Richard Steele stopped the fight with just two seconds remaining.

title: Nancy E. Field to Marry Terrell Linton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Field of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Field, to Terrell Barr Linton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Terry E. Linton of Cullman, Ala. A June wedding is planned.

title: In the Front Lines of the Battle to Win Minds and Hearts
description: IT was that most delicate of proceedings, the parent-teacher conference. Only this particular morning, at Rippowam Cisqua School, an independent day school here, the participants were play-acting in front of an audience.

title: FOCUS: Chicago;   World's Tallest Building Raises Questions
description: APPROVAL has been granted by the City Council here for the world's tallest building. But will it ever be built? And, if it is, will the sky-high rents needed to recoup construction costs make it difficult to attract tenants?

title: Cuomo's Opposition Is a Short List
description: TALK to any New York Republican leader and invariably he or she will say that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is vulnerable this year, ''if only we had a candidate.''

title: Elizabeth Berry To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Berry of New York and Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Mills Berry to Donald Henry Gips, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Gips Jr. of Princeton, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Route 1 Development Moving to the North
description: LEAD: EARLY next year, work will begin on the transformation of a patch of green off Route 1 in North Brunswick into a million-square-foot office complex, underscoring a tilt to the north in the corridor's corporate market.

title: Council Seeks Accord On Indian Burial Sites
description: AMERICAN Indians and archeologists are sometimes at odds over the treatment of Indian burial sites. The Indians are in general most concerned that the sites be respected and preserved, while the archeologists are usually more interested in what can be learned from them.

title: W. Virginia Teacher Unions Urge Strike's End
description: A strike that has crippled public education in West Virginia for the last 10 days neared an end today when leaders of the state's two main teacher unions urged their members to return to work on Monday.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article last Sunday on air pollution and automobiles misidentified the group for which Michael Oppenheimer is a senior scientist.

title: MANDLEA'S PARTY
description: THE STRUGGLE

title: Correction
description: A photograph with the Architecture View column on March 4 appeared without a credit. The photograph, of the new J. P. Morgan corporate headquarters on Wall Street in lower Manhattan, was by David Anderson.

title: Review/Music;   Prize-Winning Harpist Gives a Solo Recital
description: The U.S.A. International Harp Competition was first held in Bloomington, Ind., in July, and it is to take place every three years. the competition presented its first gold-medal winner, Maria Casale, in recital on Tuesday night at alice tully Hall.

title: Stephanie Kupin, Principal, Is Wed
description: Stephanie Kupin and Mark David Greenwald, both school administrators in New York, were married last evening at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I., by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein. Mrs. Greenwald is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kupin of Yonkers. Her husband is a son of Jenny Greenwald of New York and the late Jay Greenwald.

title: TALKING: Rent Rules;   Tenant Rights In Flux
description: TENANT rights, especially in a highly regulated environment like New York City's, are in a constant state of flux. Court decisions, administrative rulings and legislative amendments make it hard for tenants and landlords to keep up with their rights and responsibilities. This is particularly true for the narrowly focused changes that do not make headlines when they are announced.

title: Composer Turning Poetry Into Music
description: LEAD: ''WHEN you think of famous composers, you think of dead German men,'' said Jeanne Singer, a pianist and composer from Manhasset. ''Women composers are a kind of hidden minority.'' The 65-year-old Mrs. Singer is helping to change that with the release of her first compact-disk record in May.

title: The Battle Over Regulation of the Futures Markets
description: Washington's version of a hostile takeover is starting to take shape. No money is on the table and no stock will change hands. But the outcome could change the markets far more - and far longer - than even the biggest billion-dollar deal.

title: Truth in Child Care
description: Not long ago a doctor who is the mother of four young children called me with a story. She thought it was big, big enough for a big newspaper. Her day care center was closing.

title: How the Spirit Of Morocco Seized Matisse
description: The rain began to fall just a few hours after Henri Matisse installed himself in the Hotel Villa de France in Tangier at the end of January, 1912. For days it poured. ''Shall we ever see the sun in Morocco?'' the artist complained in a letter to Gertrude Stein after his first week.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Storm-Struck Forest Reopens In Puerto Rico

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Working Through the Pain of Loss
description: LEAD: THE end of a marriage is never easy. The pain that accompanies the loss of a relationship is overwhelming. How many of us have survived this ordeal and found there is life after divorce?

title: Science on Easter Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopes for Peace Run Into the Politics of Paralysis
description: IF the views of their elected representatives are any indication, more than half the Israeli people are willing to make at least some small concessions to start negotiations for peace. Why then did an attempt to take the first tiny step bring the Government crashing down last week?

title: More Power to the Regulators
description: Since the crash of 1987, America's financial markets have taken a number of actions that attempt to corral the more abusive aspects of program trading. But events clearly show that even stronger measures are required not only to restore the integrity of the markets, but to help stem what is rapidly becoming an international crisis.

title: WHEN DOES A PERSON STOP BEING A PERSON?
description: A GRACEFUL PASSAGE

title: A Daring Economic Plan Arouses Debate in Brazil
description: Brazilians reacted today with praise, dismay and concern for their new President's radical economic program, which intends to tame the nation's daunting rate of inflation and eliminate the $31 billion federal deficit in one year.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: As of this weekend, the new additions have yet to prove their value on the road to the cup. (The team was winning when Nicholls joined and later, when Gartner was added.) The line of Kisio-Muller-Ogrodnick is the most consistent and productive. The rest of the team - when uninjured - is of major value. And oh, those rookies!

title: Rising Values
description: To the Editor:

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

It's Time to Give College Players a Cut
description: LEAD: NOT long ago, Charles Shackleford of the New Jersey Nets admitted that he had received money from an agent while attending college. He held a news conference at which he said that accepting the money was wrong, and went on to explain that he had since repaid it in full. Immediately, questions were raised about both his integrity and that of North Carolina State University, which suddenly cowered at the prospect of having to return revenue it had received based on its performance in the National Collegiate Athletic

title: G.I. Faces Panama Murder Charge
description: The Army is investigating accusations that two American soldiers killed Panamanian prisoners during the American invasion of Panama, and it is likely to charge at least one of the soldiers with homicide, Army officials said today.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A Furrier's Wife Braves Slings and Arrows of Activists
description: LEAD: IT'S a jungle out there, and I don't have the advantage of camouflage. I'm a furrier's wife, I wear what my husband makes and I know what it's like to be an endangered species. I found out first hand when I decided to speak up on a nationally syndicated talk show.

title: Marci L. Spector Is Engaged to Mitchell B. Rose
description: Marci Lynn Spector, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Spector of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., and Mitchell Brian Rose, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Rose of Kings Point, L.I., plan to marry in December.

title: Rising Values
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Stanford;   New President Sets a Precedent At Law Review
description: The Law Review of Stanford University, one of the most prestigious law journals in the nation, has elected Shauna D. Jackson president. A second-year law student from Olathe, Kan., she is the first black woman to head the law review here.

title: Blue Collars, Both Fashionable and Frayed
description: And now, ladies and gentlemen, heeeeer's - the Common Man.

title: Pipeline to Open at Blast Site
description: A pipeline that ruptured and allowed propane to leak and explode last week will be put back into service within a month, long before investigators know what caused the explosion that killed two people, officials said. Officials at Texas Eastern Products Pipeline Company of Houston said the rebuilt pipeline will be tested by running water under high pressure through the line from Watkins Glen to Selkirk, where the pipeline ends.

title: Development As a Solution
description: Repeatedly throughout the article [''Pine Barrens Suit Halts Construction,'' Feb. 25] , the developers made the point that their development in the Pine Barrens would solve the areas economic problems by creating new jobs and/or new housing. Donald Patrick reasoned that some 6,000 Manorville residents would greatly benefit from having their jobs closer to home.

title: What's Doing In: Warsaw
description: Warsaw wears its woes more prominently than its wonders. It seems at times to have more coal grit to coat its soulless apartment blocks than sunlight to bathe its golden Old Town. But this year the city is wrapped in a sense of history being built day by day, which visitors can feel even behind unappealing facades.

title: China
description: To the Editor: I was very distressed to see the article about China on Feb. 18. We have been told that many people suffer unfairly when sanctions are applied, but now we understand that they have been very successful in helping to bring about the beginning of the end of apartheid in South Africa.

title: Axelrod Defends His Insurance Plan
description: ON a recent Friday morning, Dr. David Axelrod, the State Commissioner of Health, stood behind the lectern in a large ballroom at the Westchester Marriott Hotel here, speaking to more than 350 people about his proposed universal state health insurance plan. At times his speech seemed more like an appeal than a lecture.

title: 1,500 Hold Rally in Romania Against Hungarian Demands
description: About 1,500 people demonstrated in the northern Romanian town of Tirgu Mures today against the demands of local ethnic Hungarians, witnesses reported.

title: Waiting For O'Neill: Candidates Biding Time
description: THINK of the race for governor as one of those sliding-tile picture puzzles, where all the little squares move around, but nobody knows what the final picture is supposed to look like. That is the scene political experts in Connecticut are trying to gauge.

title: Arts Day to Focus on Children's Creativity
description: LEAD: BEFORE the days of television and computer games, when two little knees and a blanket could create mountains and valleys, educators did not speak of the need to exercise a child's imagination. In today's world, a child can attend courses designed to stimulate the imagination and provide opportunities for creative expression.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MEMPHIS;

338-Acre Mix Taking Shape
description: LEAD: HUMPHREYS CENTER, a 338-acre residential and commercial development on the eastern periphery of Memphis, is rapidly emerging as a community in its own right.

title: Karen L. Strong, Teacher, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Wilson Strong of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Linn Strong, to Albert Denison Reinhardt 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reinhardt Jr. of Dalton, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: Returning to Track, Antley Wins Three
description: Chris Antley was almost too choked up for words yesterday at Aqueduct after he won his first race in seven months.

title: Butterflies
description: To the Editor: ''A World of Butterflies in Florida'' stirred happy memories of seeing butterflies last winter at Callaway Gardens in Georgia. Seventy miles southwest of Atlanta, Callaway has the largest glass-enclosed butterfly house in the country. Tropical vines and shrubs and cascading water plus computer climate control keep butterflies flying all year. Sit on a bench and in no time a butterfly may land on your hair or hand. A surrounding outdoor butterfly garden attracts some 70 native species by late spring.

title: Review/Rock;   Creatures On Tour
description: A sojourn in Spain for two members of Siouxsie and the Banshees -the singer Siouxsie Sioux and the drummer Budgie - turned into a record album, ''The Creatures,'' and now a North American tour. The Creatures are still ''just the two of us,'' as Ms. Sioux said from the stage of the Ritz on Wednesday night. Well, not quite - they brought along canned music to back themselves up.

title: The Making of a Census: First, Cardboard Desks
description: Just over a year ago Bill Buchanan, a personnel specialist between jobs, was given 5 assistants, 150 unassembled cardboard desks, a budget of $500,000, an office key and a mission: Make sure the residents of 42 counties in western North Carolina are counted in the 1990 census.

title: The Packaging of Junk Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: Starting to Mend
description: THE Phoenix Suns guard Jeff Hornacek underwent successful arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove torn cartilage in his left knee, the team announced.

title: W. L. Hughes to Wed Rebecca Chase
description: Mrs. Ryland Ellis Dickinson Chase of New York has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Rebecca Ellis Chase and William Leggette Hughes, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Hughes of Durham, N.C. The prospective bride is also a daughter of the late Mr. Chase.

title: 3-Party Merger in Seoul Fails to Resolve Deadlock
description: Even though President Roh Tae Woo has formed an overwhelming legislative majority by merging two opposition parties into his ruling party, he was unable to break a deadlock on major bills in a special session of Parliament that ended this week.

title:
DINING OUT;

Neighborhood Eating Spot in Larchmont
description: LEAD: SOON to celebrate its first anniversary in the spot once occupied by the Colony, Hope and Anchor makes a welcome addition to the small selection of comfortable neighborhood eating spots in this Larchmont area. The place is clean, bright and means business, the potential opulence suggested by the soft arches and stained glass dropped in favor of minimalist white walls and tablecloths and pictures that require study close up to be appreciated.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Dayton;   Condom Giveaway Divides Opinion At Catholic School
description: A condom giveaway on St. Valentine's Day at Dayton University has divided student opinion.

title: Carved Mahogany Evokes an Opulent Colonial Culture
description: At a time when American antiques are breaking records in the auction market, connoisseurs who spend time here are discovering that among the island's cultural resources is the handsome 19th-century mahogany furniture of the West Indian colonial tradition - at reasonable prices. Mahogany was introduced into Barbados only in the late 18th century; earlier, most of the local furniture was made of cedar, which was indigenous to the island.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE WESTHELP NANCY Q. KEEFE CENTER;

Without the Hoopla, the Homeless Move Into a Neighborhood
description: LEAD: MENTION Westhelp and most people probably think of Greenburgh, and the ongoing controversy there over the proposed construction of transitional housing for the homeless. But December saw the opening of another Westhelp project, one that has generated far less publicity, the Westhelp Nancy Q. Keefe Center on Franklin

title: Outdoors;   Deer Kill Down 6% In New York State
description: Hunters in New York State killed 181,879 deer last fall, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation reported. Although this was a 6 percent decrease from 1988, the number of bucks taken, 99,589, was a record high. The previous record, set in 1987, was 97,595.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Harvard;   Men's Clubs Illegal? Can't Say, Panel Rules
description: After more than two years of controversy, a Massachusetts state commission has dealt a setback to Harvard students who say that exclusive undergraduate men's clubs on campus illegally discriminate against women.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: The Struggle To Preserve Old Churches
description: FOR a quick glimpse of the problem, take a two-minute walk in Brooklyn Heights, New York City's best-preserved enclave of 19th-century brownstones, its first landmark district and a neighborhood with a glut of religious real estate.

title: A Life In the Theater
description: On March 5, the former Ritz Theater on West 48th Street, owned by Jujamcyn Theaters, officially became the Walter Kerr Theater. It is scheduled to open formally on April 16 with ''The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson. During the festivities, Mr. Kerr, the retired chief drama critic of The New York Times, reminisced about the theater he has known over the years. Excerpts from his talk follow.

title: THE GUIDE
description: VISITING PIANISTS

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A Taxing Review of 1989
description: LEAD: MY life flashes before me - my life for the taxable year 1989, that is. I am not in a hospital, floating several feet above the bed as doctors and nurses struggle to revive my lifeless body. I am sitting at my desk in Ossining surrounded by piles of canceled checks.

title: Stasny Again Fires Devils to Victory
description: The goaltending, the defense, the special teams, the offense - everything worked effectively for the Devils tonight in their 4-1 triumph over the Oilers at the Northlands Coliseum.

title: HE HAD A FOOTNOTE
description: THE TRICK OF IT

title: Bill Farley Learns More of The Downside
description: Going down. And down.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: When Anne Meara was growing up on Long Island, she was convinced her family was like no other. She had no intimate knowledge of other families, but she just knew that they and their beautifully modulated voices lived in perfect harmony in an atmosphere of sweet reason. When she was a little older, she knew that romance wasn't romance unless there was background music and, in the distance, a sunset or some other bit of glorious nature.

title: Evening Hours;   Tuxedo or Toga: Roman Holiday At the Library
description: The Young Friends of the Library chose the Ides of March, the anniversary of Julius Caesar's assassination, for Bacchanal, the group's second annual fund-raising event, at the New York Public Library on Thursday night. Dress was black tie or toga, and many guests chose the latter, accessorizing their cream-colored gowns with garlands of ivy, fur slippers and leopard-spot shawls. And that was just the men.

title: THE NATION: S & L Politics;   And Who Did What With the Money?
description: THE Government has initiated scores of civil and criminal lawsuits against financiers whose savings and loan associations went bankrupt. Some have been indicted, some have been acquitted and many have shifted their energies to other kinds of business.

title: Agreement Ends 5 1/2-Week Sit-In in Selma
description: The mediation of a local judge has brought an agreement ending a sit-in by demonstrators who lived in tents at City Hall for five and a half weeks.

title: FERNANDO VS. ISABEL
description: THE DOGS OF PARADISE

title: Preserving Cemeteries Touched by History and Neglect
description: WHEN the town of Mamaroneck held its annual meeting in April 1807, the minutes record that one of the agenda items was to officially recognize Col. Gilbert Budd for ''faithful and impartial services'' to the town. Colonel Budd was a Continental Army officer during the Revolutionary War who served many years as Town Clerk and Supervisor.

title: Farewell to a Latin Deadbeat
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Mount Holyoke;   A New Downtown Rises, With Help, From the Ashes
description: Julia Murphy can still remember the time four years ago when two fires set by an arsonist had left the center of town here in ruins. ''It was still smoking, literally, and there was debris everywhere,'' said Miss Murphy, a senior English major from Hartford. ''All that was left across from the college was a tanning salon and Joe's Shoe Repair.''

title: Ande E. Donald Weds Peter Frost
description: Ande Elizabeth Donald, the daughter of Jean Ramsden of Johannesburg and the late James Keith Donald, was married yesterday to Peter Corwin Frost, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Frost 3d of Providence and Narragansett, R.I., and Eleuthera, Bahamas. The Rev. David L. Jones, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Mount Grace Country Hotel in Magaliesburg, South Africa.

title: Managing;   When Two Take the Top Seat
description: For 60 years, Novo Industri and Nordisk Gentofte, two Danish companies that sold insulin, were bitter enemies. ''At both companies, the main motivation was to kick the competition,'' said Mads Ovlisen, Novo's chief executive.

title: Ms. Cohen to Wed Thomas Ginsberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton D. Cohen of Minneapolis have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Susan Beth Cohen, and Thomas Barry Ginsberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Herman Ginsberg of Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

title: The Executive Computer;   Is It Word Processing, or Desktop Publishing?
description: The most powerful word-processing programs have been borrowing features from desktop publishing programs for some time, allowing people who work with words to embellish their documents with graphics, illustrations, multiple columns and fancy typography. Now, a new generation of desktop publishing programs is borrowing features from the word-processing programs, including spelling checkers, search-and-replace abilities, document templates (or style sheets) and other features that make editing easier.

title: THEIR STREET WAS PAVED WITH GOLD
description: THE HOUSE OF MORGAN

title: New & Noteworthy
description: KILLSHOT, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $5.95.) With two professional hit men on their trail, a Detroit ironworker and his wife find out just how much shelter the Federal witness protection program really affords. Elmore Leonard ''dazzles as he sprinkles his work continually with unexpected convolutions,'' Ann Rule said here last year. ''In 'Killshot,' Mr. Leonard does not disappoint us; the reader is kept continually off balance, a step behind the action, tugged cunningly into blind alleys.''

title: Bottle Audit Fails to Find Unclaimed Nickels' Fate
description: New Yorkers failed to redeem 1.7 billion beer and soda containers last year, a special state commission reported this week. But after six months of study the panel appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said it could not determine whether the beverage industry was reaping a windfall profit from all these unclaimed nickels.

title: 'Bedroom Farce': 3 Couples Rampant
description: THREE bedrooms and four couples set the stage for Alan Ayckbourn's comedy ''Bedroom Farce,'' now at Theater Three in Port Jefferson through next Saturday.

title: Delicious Squid Has a Drawback
description: As a person who tries to watch his weight and keep in fair physical condition, I am constantly reading articles about foods and recipes and their effects on our bodies.

title: 'Caller ID': More Than Progress
description: All the controversy associated with Caller ID could seemingly be addressed by simple improvements in the current technology. Here is how a ''new and improved'' Caller ID would work for me:

title: POSTINGS: Tax Abatement;   Beating City Hall
description: ''Go fight City Hall'' usually means, ''Don't bother, you can't win.'' But the owners of 184 cooperative apartments at 50 Lexington Avenue fought - and won - and now may get up to $10 million in tax abatements. The dispute involves their claim to 10 years of abatements under New York City's 421a program. The developer, Behrouz Ben Hakimian, broke ground for the building in October 1985, a month before the city ended 421a abatements for luxury developments in Manhattan below 96th Street. The program, which continues elsewhere in Manhattan and in the other boroughs, encourages apartment construction.

title: Kimble Is Inspired With 45 Points
description: Few who were there Friday night will ever forget it. Perhaps some of the details will fade, but the emotion will linger in memory.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: There is no way that the Rangers' cup will ever runneth over until the Rangers get a bonafide heavyweight to insure that their star players do not get runneth over.

title: Pan Am Flight 103: The West German Tie
description: Two months before Pan Am Flight 103 crashed into the village of Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people, the man who fashioned the bomb that destroyed it and other terrorists were seized in West Germany and almost immediately released, two writers say. After the crash, they charge, the West Germans moved to conceal their errors from investigators.

title: SCHOOLS WITHOUT TEACHING
description: LEAD: KILLING THE SPIRIT

title: Lynn Pawliger to Wed Jeffrey David Ginzberg
description: Lynn Ellen Pawliger, an assistant vice president and project manager at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, and Jeffrey David Ginzberg, a partner in the law firm of Perelmutter, Potash & Ginzberg in Seymour, Conn., are planning a June wedding. The announcement was made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Steven M. Pawliger of New York.

title: Misguided Latin Policy Has Bipartisan History
description: To the Editor:

title: Repairing Wallboard
description: MINOR wallboard damage - dents or small holes - is relatively easy to repair by smoothing spackling compound over the blemish and repainting the area. But repairing large holes requires modest carpentry skills and sometimes ingenuity.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Wing and a Prayer: Ducky the Swan Triumphant
description: LEAD: WHEN Ducky, a gangling cygnet with an injured wing, was rescued last fall from Mill Pond in Water Mill and delivered safely to an animal hospital in Southampton, those of us involved in his rescue thought the adventure was over and that he would be fine. It turns out he wasn't fine, and his adventure had just begun.

title: When the News Outpaces the Curriculum
description: LEAD: LONG before the events of the last six months in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, New York educators recognized that high school students were not adequately being taught about those parts of the world. As a result, the State Department of Education several years ago devised a ''global studies'' curriculum that would replace what had been a focus almost exclusively on American and Western European history.

title: Wall Street;   The Mystery of the Rising Stock
description: The shares of Southland Communications Inc., a small paging company based in Santa Ana, Calif., jumped 43 percent in over-the-counter trading last Wednesday. With refreshing candor, the company's executives put out a statement that day saying they knew of no reason for the rise in the share price.

title: American Politics Loses Way As Polls Supplant Leadership
description: As America's democratic visions and values seem to triumph around the world, an unhappy consensus has emerged at home that domestic politics has become so shallow, mean and even meaningless that it is failing to produce the ideas and leadership needed to guide the United States in a rapidly changing world.

title: Fan Evaluates Bianchi Deals
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Currency;   Going in Two Directions
description: It was a week of inaction, with mixed results for the dollar. The head of the Bank of Japan returned from a trip to Europe but did not act to raise the country's official discount rate, a move that most analysts have been expecting and feel is necessary to support a very weak yen. So the yen fell a little further against the dollar. At the same time, the Bundesbank and other European central banks stopped selling dollars in what had been an effort to weaken the dollar against the mark. Despite the pause, the dollar weakened anyway. That was because inflation numbers on Friday and comments by President Bush favoring lower interest rates in the United States made some traders fear that rates could be heading down, which would make the dollar less attractive.

title: Splendor Restored At Eastman House
description: ''HE was the first citizen of Rochester, the Kodak king,'' said William Seale, a former White House historian who oversaw the recent $1.8 million restoration of the George Eastman House in Rochester. The house, a National Historic Landmark, reopened to the public Jan. 30, having been closed for 14 months. It offers new insights into the life of the corporate chieftain after he invented the Kodak camera and popularized photography.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: If one can dream for a moment, Bernie Nicholls will pass the puck to Mike Gartner, who will shoot the puck between the legs of Mike Vernon in overtime of the seventh game of the Stanley Cup final. In reality, Phil Esposito's many trades did not help the Rangers win the cup, so why should Neil Smith's trades be different?

title: POSTINGS: On a 1705 Land Grant;   Offices for SoHo
description: A major union local, a prominent local church, a cultural group and a real estate developer have worked together to move forward a 23-story office building now under construction at 101 Avenue of the Americas in the so-called Hudson Square area of SoHo. The 31,000 square feet of land on the west side of the avenue between Grand and Watts Streets is owned by the real estate arm of The Parish of Trinity Church, which acquired the property under a grant from Britain's Queen Anne in 1705. In recent years the site had been used as a parking lot and as the two-screen theater and headquarters of Film Forum, a nonprofit cultural theater.

title: THE LADY SOMETIMES VANISHES
description: Ms. Stratas may have taken a self-imposed absence of eight years from the Metropolitan Opera, but, professionally speaking, she was hardly inactive during that time. In 1985, Ms. Stratas recorded a second album of Weill songs for Nonesuch, this time with the Y Chamber Orchestra; in 1986, she starred in the Broadway musical ''Rags,'' for which she won the Drama Desk Award and was nominated for a Tony; in 1987, she was featured as Julie in the complete EMI recording of Showboat; and appeared in 1988 as Despina in the Jean-Pierre Ponnelle film of Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutte (already released in Europe). Ms. Malitz made mention of Ms. Stratas's 1988 portrayal of Berg's Lulu at the Theatre de la Monnaie, in Brussels, but neglected to say that this was, in fact, her first opera performance since 1982.

title: Ms. Dineen and Sean Sullivan to Marry in May
description: A May wedding is planned by Christina Marie Dineen, a senior at Boston College, and First Lieut. Sean Patrick Sullivan of the Marine Corps.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Heady Days in Prague
description: ''PRAGUE THE GOLDEN'' was always beautiful, but for the last 21 years the mood was sullen, brooding, resentful. Today Prague is radiant with the pride of a people who succeeded in wresting democracy from the grip of Communist dictatorship. The really hard work may be yet to come, but for now they are basking innocently in their freedom like students on the first sunny day of spring under the medieval spires and Baroque domes of a city that is one of the glories of European culture.

title: Butterflies
description: To the Editor: It was encouraging to read in ''A World of Butterflies in Florida'' (Travel, Jan. 28) that Coconut Creek visitors go home with information on the importance of native plants to native butterflies. When preferred plants disappear, butterflies are at risk. Adult butterflies sip nectar from many flowers - primarily yellow, orange, pink and purple ones - but the females require specific plants as host plants for their eggs and food for the caterpillars. Monarchs need milkweed; pearl crescents need asters; black swallowtails like Queen Anne's lace, dill or parsley. To bring butterflies to a garden, one can easily plant black-eyed Susans, butterfly weed, monarda, coneflowers, corepsis - even in terrace pots.

title: Leader Warns Poles of More Change
description: Six months after taking office as the Eastern bloc's first non-Communist Prime Minister since the early postwar years, Tadeusz Mazowiecki counts his major achievement as maintaining the confidence of Poles in the face of difficult changes.

IN SHORT;

FICTION

IN SHORT;

NONFICTION

title: Food;   WHAT COMES NATURALLY
description: IT WAS A DARK AND STORMY AFTERNOON in the dead of winter. I had just picked my way around a sad slab of salmon with limp but woody asparagus and tomatoes the color and texture of wet ash. Partly to prolong leaving a warm neighborhood restaurant, but mostly to cheer myself up, I succumbed to the waiter's hard sell on the special dessert, a ''harvest'' tart.

title: 18 DAYS: A SOUTH AFRICAN JOURNAL
description: LAST FALL, MY WIFE AND I PLANNED AJU February holiday in South Africa, where I could revisit old friends, and show Sally the country for the first time.

title: A Police Death Raises Questions
description: I am writing in response to the article headlined ''Questions For Guido'' and, in fact, in response to the entire situation surrounding the death of Detective Wustenhoff and the subsequent funeral ceremonies. I am writing because I have additional questions.

title: Extra Innings
description: WITH the major league baseball season threatened by a labor dispute, some college teams may be trying to fill the gap by extending their own seasons a bit. That, at least, seemed to be the case in Seattle on Friday when four teams played four consecutive extra-inning games against each other. As a result, what would have normally been 36 innings of baseball turned into a 49-inning, 17-hour marathon that lasted from 9 A.M. Friday to 2:04 A.M. yesterday.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cement deck around our swimming pool has become dark and dirty looking. Scrubbing with bleach solutions has not helped much. Do you know of anything we can use to make the deck look nice again?

title: Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: There is no question that Roger Neilson's coaching and the addition of Bernie Nicholls and Mike Gartner have enabled the Rangers to become true Stanley Cup contenders. But the Rangers will lose in the Wales Conference championship to either Buffalo or Montreal.

title: LISTENERS PAY A HIGH PRICE FOR LOUD MUSIC
description: Hearing loss is not a reportable disease. There are no official statistics. But doctors suspect that this incurable ailment is becoming epidemic and that the willful or ignorant misuse of audio equipment is a major cause.

title: After 15 Years, Plan for I-84 Truck Stop Still Angers Residents
description: WHEN George L. Giguere drives the rural stretch of Interstate 84 between Manchester and the Massachusetts border, he sees an opportunity where other people see just trees.
