The fighting of World War III in Europe, seen through Russian eyes. 11 2 DADDY, by Loup Durand. (Warner, $5.95.) A thriller about the operations of a Nazi task force charged with recovering a huge fortune. 12 7 BILLY BATHGATE, by E. L. Doctorow (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) The life of a 1930's gangster. 13 1 HONOR'S SPLENDOR, by Julie Garwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) An English nobleman's attempt to use his sister as a pawn to avenge a crime brings her romance. 14* 2 WHISPERED KISSES, by Janelle Taylor. (Zebra, $4.95.) The stormy romance of a Texas heiress and a mysterious British safari guide. 15 8 MUTATION, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) A physician's attempt to create a superior child results in a prodigy that turns into a terror. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 17 ALL I REALLY NEEDED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 14 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Grace Catalano (Bantam, $3.50.) The lives and predilections of the five members of a teen-age singing group. 3 25 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinness. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J. woman. 4 334 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck (Touchstone/S & S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 5 5 MURDER IN LITTLE EGYPT, by Darcy O'Brien. (Onyx, $4.95.) The Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde life of a physician in an Illinois community. 6 8 BORN ON THE FOURTH OF JULY, by Ron Kovic. (Pocket, $4.50.) The autobiography of a former Marine, gravely wounded physically in Vietnam, spiritually on his return home. 7 1 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Anne M. Raso. (Modern Publishing, $2.50.) A new illustrated biography of the singing quintet from Boston. 8 94 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 9 2 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) From Boston's North End to the White House, the story of a political dynasty. 10 7 IN BROAD DAYLIGHT, by Harry N. MacLean. (Dell, $4.95.) The 1981 killing of a man on Main Street in Skidmore, Mo., witnessed by 45 people, a case that was never brought to court. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 6 50 SIMPLE THINGS YOU CAN DO TO SAVE THE EARTH, by The Earthworks Group. (Earthworks Press/Publishers Group West, $4.95.) Ways to combat environmental problems. 2 81 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 3 2 GOING WITHIN, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $5.95.) A "guide for innertransformation" through meditation. 4 71 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $5.95.) The latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 5 14 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1990 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico.

title: Evans and Jorgensen Win 3 N.C.A.A. Titles
description: Janet Evans and Janel Jorgensen may be 18-year-old Stanford freshmen, but they swam like old hands tonight in the final races of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's championships.

title: U.S.-Peruvian Teams Renew Drive on Coca
description: After a yearlong break to strengthen security, a joint Peruvian-American force has resumed eradication of coca plants in the Upper Huallaga Valley, a guerrilla stronghold in northern Peru that is the source of half of the world's cocaine crop.

title: Patient's Lawsuit Says Saving Life Ruined It
description: In some ways the case of Edward H. Winter is a prototypical miracle of modern medicine.

title: Two Arrested by Undercover Drug Agents
description: Two Brooklyn men, one of them a Brinks Armored Car guard, were arrested and charged with selling two kilos of heroin to undercover F.B.I. agents, the authorities said today.

title: 'Settings' Enliven a Historic House
description: CLOTHING folded up and ready to be packed in trunks, linens piled up for ironing and books scattered on the bed are familiar sights to families packing for trips. But such sights are not so usual in historic houses, where each item is usually neatly in place. To breathe some life into a historic house, however, the curator, Renee T. Williams, has carefully created a bit of a shambles at the Stowe House, a home of Harriet Beecher Stowe in Hartford.

title: Assessing the Corporate Fitness Craze
description: James L. Ketelsen took up running after he had double bypass heart surgery in 1979. He started with 20 minutes a day, then moved up to 30 minutes when his company's in-house fitness manager recommended it.

title: Nina Shippen Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Edward Shippen of Riverside, Conn., has announced May wedding plans for her daughter Nina Brooks Shippen and Thomas Mathew Lenz, a son of Carolyn R. Swift and John W. Lenz, both of Providence, R.I. Miss Shippen, also a daughter of the late Mr. Shippen, is the assistant to the chief executive of Pilgrim Health Care in Norwell, Mass. She graduated from the Columbia University School of Nursing and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Lenz, a vice president and the associate general counsel at the Signature Financial Group, investment managers in Boston, received an undergraduate degree and a J.D. from Harvard University.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We've tended to trivialize issues to the point where meaningful debate has become almost impossible.''

title: On Language;   Chutzpah At Camp Greentop
description: MALCOLM FORBES wasn't around to enjoy it, but his newest publication made its debut last month: !Forbes von Burda, (with the exclamation mark in front), described as a ''business/lifestyle monthly'' (with a virgule separating business from lifestyle, part of the trend in which slash triumphs over dash).

title: A Tough Act to Follow in a Fishbowl
description: RESTAURANT sequels, like those of movies, are usually a disappointment. Experience has taught moviegoers and savvy diners alike to cringe at any new title followed by a Roman numeral.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $450,000

title: Wax and Wigs and a Sense of Magic
description: ASIDE from spending most of his weekly allowance and other spare change on makeup, invading his mother's kitchen cabinets for supplies and utensils to create monster get-ups, being told by classmates he was weird and getting picked up by the police on charges of disguising his identity (he was walking the streets dressed as Frankenstein's monster), Kevin C. Haney describes his childhood in a Cincinnati suburb as ''pretty normal.''

title: Hotels: Bargains, Scarce Rooms
description: ALTHOUGH Prague is well accustomed to a brisk tourism, it has a permanent shortage of hotel rooms and one of the highest hotel occupancy rates of any city in the world: about 90 percent for the whole year.

title: Making Their Mark
description: PAUL EQUALE

title: Sharpton Criminal Trial to Begin Tomorrow
description: The criminal trial of the Rev. Al Sharpton, one of New York City's most flamboyant and vocal civil rights leaders, is set to begin tomorrow in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: The Nuts and Bolts Of East-Bloc Travel
description: FROM the East Berlin side of the Brandenburg Gate to Wenceslas Square in Prague, Americans are discovering Eastern Europe in record numbers, particularly as the changes in governments there have led to the loosening of visa and customs procedures. However, the resulting confusion at border crossings and crowds in consulates may still mean lost time, effort and frustration for travelers.

title: Why Steinbeck's Okies Speak to Us Today
description: The image of the dust bowl migration is imbedded in American consciousness, permanently linked to our memory of the Great Depression. It was an epic event. More than a million people, most of them dispossessed farm families, left the declining agricultural regions of Texas, Arkansas, Missouri and Oklahoma during the 1930's and moved west to California. Though millions of other Americans uprooted themselves in those years, the travails of the ''Okies''captured attention in a way those of other groups did not. That was in great part because of the publication in 1939 of John Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath,'' which the Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago now brings to New York in a production opening Thursday at the Cort Theater.

title: Greyhound and Union Meet On Proposal to Settle Strike
description: Representatives of striking drivers for Greyhound Lines presented a proposal here today in the first meeting between the bus company and the union since the violent strike began two weeks ago, but no details were disclosed.

title: Deep Chill on China
description: By refusing to make even token efforts to reform their ways, China's hard-line leaders have achieved something that seemed impossible a few months ago: an American consensus on China.

title: Fashion;   The Urban (and Urbane) Spring Sandal
description: This spring, women's sandals have been re-invented so that they can be worn to the office, and the platform shoe, an icon of the 40's, has returned. What's common to both styles is the muted colors: peach, lemon, olive and creamy tomato. This season, many of the freshest styles are also affordable, selling for less than $100.

title: Review/Music;   Contemporary Anguish In Corigliano Symphony
description: There are all kinds of reasons why the current Chicago Symphony subscription concerts at Orchestra Hall are significant. But the most compelling is that they mark the arrival of a major new orchestral score, one that addresses a terrible crisis of our time and also manages to make impressive sense on abstract esthetic terms.

title: A TELEVISED WAR OF ATTRITION
description: INTIFADA

title: Technology;   A State-of-the-Art Plant Refines Newspaper Recycling
description: Thomas Eck, the Southeast Paper Manufacturing Company's assistant technical manager, understands every cog in every machine in Southeast's recycled-paper plant here. He cheerfully answers the same questions, again and again. Ask him if he is bored, and he says, ''Oh, no, this is fun.''

title: Review/Dance;   More Humphrey Revivals
description: There is no question about the devotion to the dance of Doris Humphrey that drives the American Dance Repertory Theater, which performed on Thursday at the Pace Downtown Theater. Nor is there any question that Humphrey's work is a relatively neglected part of American dance history. It is certainly true that dances look different in different times, as was suggested in a comment in the program notes, in which Humphrey called for the constant ''resensitizing'' of dances.

title: Salvadorans Consider Sweeping Amnesty for Military
description: The National Assembly here is considering a sweeping petition to pardon current and former military people accused or convicted of common crimes and human rights violations.

title: Tech Notes The Tiny 'Wobble Motor'
description: Researchers at the University of Utah have developed a tiny motor - about the size of several human hairs - that they say may someday be used in scientific instruments and surgery.

title: THE SOUND OF POP MUSIC ISN'T ALL ROCK
description: So complete has been the illusion of dominance established by rock-and-roll that it is sometimes easy to forget that popular music is a lot broader than rock, even including the very pop music against which rock rebelled.

title: Football Owners Wimped Out on King Holiday
description: Any other year at this time, you might be reading the annual heart-rending saga of some old pitcher trying to make it through one more spring training.

title: Forget Lions and Lambs, Try To Get Birds to Feed Together
description: WHEN peace comes it will be ushered in on my bird feeder. Certain political pundits, pondering peace, suggest that recent events in Eastern Europe presage an era of peace; soon the Messiah will ride through the Brandenburg Gate on a white donkey. I know differently. The age of peace will not arrive until the occupants of my bird feeder get their act together.

title: For an Off-Season Taste Treat, Roasted Tomatoes
description: IF you yearn for the taste of tomatoes but are unimpressed by their quality at this time of year, try roasting them. Ripe hothouse or hydroponically grown tomatoes taste wonderful when cooked this way. They look a mess but they develop an intense flavor, sweet yet sharp, and almost carmelized. They are good with almost any food that likes the flavor of tomato.

title: Diane Aronson, Teacher, Weds
description: Diane L. Aronson and Bruce Martin Meyers, teachers at the Dalton School in New York, were married yesterday in New York at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Aronson. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Anti-U.S. Threat in Panama
description: A terrorist group has claimed responsibility for the fatal crash of two United States helicopters and the bombing of a discotheque, and it threatened more attacks on Americans and United States property. The group calls itself the December 20 Movement after the date of the American invasion of Panama. One American soldier was killed in the grenade attack on the discotheque on Feb. 28. The helicopter crashes killed 11 soldiers.

title: Checking for Drugs in the Workplace
description: TO test or not to test is the question confronting small companies struggling to develop comprehensive drug-abuse policies.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: I have been a dedicated dyed-in-the-Ranger-blue fan for more than 30 years. I, and many others like me, know. We know that if the Rangers obtained Gretzky, Lemixeux, Yzerman, Coffey, Borque and Messier, they would probably manage not to win the cup. Why? The answer, we know is simple but takes a lifetime to truly understand. It's the Rangers.

title: Latin America Is Transformed; Making Progress Is Another Matter
description: THERE were smiles and embraces all around as the popularly elected leaders of Latin America came together last week to meet the two newest members of their club: Patricio Aylwin of Chile and Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil. But the festive atmosphere barely began to convey the mix of giddy pride and apprehension permeating the region.

title: Time to Assess the Ravages of Winter
description: DESPITE unusual spells of mild weather, part of it called the January thaw, this has been a rough winter for plants. Gardeners who have been outside for their annual inspection may have been surprised to find that many of their plants, particularly the broadleaved evergreens, were burned.

title: Mutual Funds;   The Hidden, Hated and Half Dead
description: It was a marketers' nightmare: On the day that the Chase Manhattan Corporation launched its Vista Growth and Income Fund, the Dow lost more than 500 points in the dizzying drop that turned October 19, 1987, into Black Monday.

title: IN A CLASS BY HIMSELF
description: In every college game he has ever played, Philip Hutcheson has scored in double figures. In every college course he has taken, he has received an A. The unassuming Hutcheson, a student at David Lipscomb University in Nashville, has scored more points in a career than any college player in history. But one drawback keeps the gangly redhead from being the model player-student: He is not a particularly outstanding athlete.

title: Margaret Miller, Teacher, Married
description: The Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Margaret Ann Miller, a daughter of George J. Miller of Haverford, Pa., and Ann Wall Miller of Bailey, Colo., to Steven James Derrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Derrick of New Richmond, Wis. The Rev. Stephen Michie performed the ceremony.

title: TV Coverage of Plane Crash
description: I read with considerable interest your story on News 12 Long Island's coverage of the Avianca plane crash (Feb. 4).

title: AIDS: The Price of Vendetta
description: In the annals of medicine, cures for diseases have come through one person's inspiration or years of research by teams of scientists.

title: THERE IS NOTHING LIKE THIS DAME
description: MAGGIE SMITH - OR DAME MAGGIE SMITH, TO USE HER NEWLY ACQUIRED TITLE - approaches the Hyatt Carlton Tower hotel in Knightsbridge, showily twirling her left arm in the air. A grand theatrical gesture from a star whose career has shown no shortage of them? Perhaps, but this time, there's an element of triumph in the motion: the notorious arm whose injury partly caused the Broadway postponement of ''Lettice and Lovage'' for a year, is on the mend, and Maggie Smith wants to illustrate its recovery with a flourish. Its theatricality well suits the actress's current role as the extravagant, middle-aged spinster, Lettice Douffet, in the play opening next Sunday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: A Vote for Veeck
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   Reality and Illusion in 4 Liederbach Works
description: Three guest artists appeared with Fourworks in ''Reality and Illusion,'' an evening of works choreographed by the company's director, Marijeanne Liederbach, in a benefit performance on Tuesday evening at Marymount Manhattan Theater.

title: Young Pitcher Dies After Surgery
description: Steve Georgiadis, a sophomore pitcher for Florida, died of heart complications today after surgery on his left shoulder, the university said.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Fashion;   Visors Are Casting a Fancier Shadow
description: Until recently, visors were seen mostly on the beach, tennis court or fairway. And the ones for women generally came in pastel pink, blue or white. But that was before the shun-the-sun movement.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Labels For Life's Stages
description: LEAD: I TOOK a walk last week with Lopey, our daughter's 6-month-old pup. The dog has great potential, and she's bound to improve with age (a thought I also apply to myself). Given time, she'll calm down, stop chewing on everything and settle into a more mature dignity. Eventually, she'll ''find herself'' and become a predictable companion.

title: FICTION
description: VERGING ON THE PERTINENT. By Carol Emshwiller (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) When the aliens land, I hope Carol Emshwiller is around to explain what's up with Earth women these days. She certainly knows how to take the Martian view of ordinary domestic life - how to get at the truth of things by rendering them strange. The best tales in ''Verging on the Pertinent,'' her second collection of short stories, accomplish this with sly wit or brainy despair; more often it's both. There's a neglected wife who tries to escape her marriage by trekking into the mountains and taking up with a bear who might be better suited for family life. Soon, though, he's lumbering in at 3 A.M. ''As usual,'' she thinks, watching him turn his shaggy back on her and fall asleep. Disappointments are lurking for men, too, especially the ones who go in for the apotheosis of feminine beauty. Thus a nice-enough guy guarding a statue of a woman in Washington Square is horrified when a real woman is found to be living inside. She has a breakfast nook and dusty window sills. She strings her wash between the statue's knees. ''You can't hang underwear here,'' the man protests feebly. ''You have to find another place. This is art.'' Then there's the saga of Queen Kong, a giantess who scales the World Trade Center clutching ''a fairly important and rather fat executive'' at the end of a bad day. Only some of the 17 stories are this fierce or funny; others seem to lose their way. And it's tough to curl up with the whole collection at once; it's too cerebral, too coolly ironic for that. But read this book slowly, with time off between the tales, and you start to appreciate how often Ms. Emshwiller works like some intrepid surveyor, stepping back as far as possible without falling over the edge.

title:
ART;

Visual Ambiguity In Organic Shapes
description: LEAD: FOR the ninth consecutive year, a nationwide juried competition sponsored by the Northport Galleries, an artists' cooperative, has resulted in a display of the winners' works at the co-op's headquarters in Huntington.

title: World Markets;   Bullish, but Just Barely, on Gold
description: ''So,'' you ask, ''where is the price of gold going?'' ''Up,'' say the gold prognosticators, the gold bugs. This is the beginning of a new bull market.

title: Rachel Asher, a Legal Aid Lawyer, Is Engaged to Andrew Kuhn, a Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Asher of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Rachel Asher and Andrew E. Kuhn, a son of Marianna Kuhn of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Edward Kuhn Jr. Ms. Asher, a staff lawyer in the civil division of the Legal Aid Society in the Bronx, graduated from the University of Michigan. She received a law degree from Rutgers University and studied at University College at the University of London. Her father is publisher of Grove Weidenfeld Books in New York. Her mother, Linda Asher, is an editor at The New Yorker magazine.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The remarkable developments in the Soviet Union have trickled down in a modest fashion to bridge. Last May an invited Estonian pair crossed the Atlantic for a successful tour that included a second place in the prestigious Cavendish Pairs. In July they and their teammates played in the European Championships in Turku, Finland.

title: Rules on Pilots' Drinking Are Debated
description: The dismissal of three Northwest Airlines pilots for allegedly flying under the influence of alcohol has focused renewed attention on Federal rules that govern flying and drinking.

title: Livingstone
description: To the Editor: In ''Ten Escapes to the Exotic'' (Travel, Dec. 24), Jane Perlez refers to David Livingstone as ''the English explorer.'' David Livingstone was born in Blantyre, Scotland, and should have, therefore, been referred to as a Scottish explorer.

title: The Future Is Suddenly Everyone's Business
description: AS the election season opens in Eastern Europe, starting today with East Germany, ordinary people find themselves talking about a future they know little about.

title: Increasingly, Stray Shots Find a Mark
description: If there was ever any comfort in the knowledge that most murder victims know their attackers, even that has fallen prey to the random violence inflicted on New Yorkers and other city dwellers. Death by bad luck, typically at the hands of drug dealers with powerful weapons, has a powerful effect. It is the fear of being caught in the wrong place at the wrong time, the wariness that causes sidewalk strollers to hunch their shoulders and look around at a sudden loud noise.

title: Saving The Pine Barrens
description: Poor little bulldozers wagging their tails at Suffolk County's pine barrens. All they want to do is to clear a few more trees.

title: Of Rain And Rheumatism
description: To the Editor:

title: A June Wedding For Mary Mead
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mead of Washington have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Mary Hayward Mead, and J. Mark Lennon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lennon of Haddonfield, N.J.

title: Your Own Account
description: The idea behind the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was to simplify taxes. Whether that has worked is debatable, but there are now far fewer ways to cut taxes. Still, taxpayers have dozens of questions on what is allowable under the Internal Revenue Service code. The following are some that accountants hear regularly.

title: Alexandra Daly and Michael Clurman Are Engaged to Be Married in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Maher of Washington have announced May wedding plans for Mrs. Maher's daughter, Alexandra Elise Daly, and Richard Michael Clurman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clurman of New York.

title: East European Jews Bring Mixed Reports Of the New Societies
description: A group of prominent Jews from Eastern Europe have come to the United States to express hope for rising Jewish consciousness in the region and to voice concern over new signs of anti-Semitism.

title: Virus May Lead to Ban on Monkey Imports
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control is considering banning most primate imports after a rare, deadly virus turned up in monkeys in at least two laboratories, officials said Friday.

title: Wheeling Across Iowa
description: PERHAPS it was my unexplained Easterner's fondness for the Midwest or had something to do with the approach of my 50th birthday, but as soon as I heard a friend's enthusiastic recounting of his marathon bicycle ride clear across Iowa I knew that this was something for me. Never mind that I had never done even any semi-serious cycling or that my exercise consists mostly of a few weekly sets of tennis and a bit of winter basketball. I simply had to join about 10,000 others - college students, grandmothers, lawyers, factory workers - in pedaling 479 miles from the Missouri to the Mississippi in this annual seven-day trip in the July sun.

title: Seeing Hungary at a Gallop
description: LEAD: HUNGARIANS have been horsemen since Hungary began. In A.D. 896 seven tribes came galloping over the Carpathian Mountains onto the fertile plain of the Danube and founded the kingdom of the Magyars where Hungary is today. Hungarians have gone on riding ever since.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Simple Dish That's Ubiquitous in Coastal Mexico
description: There are dozens of dishes all over Mexico, especially in the coastal areas, that are a variation on this theme: Fish with vegetables and chilies. Many recipes call for baking the fish and cooking the potatoes separately, then combining them with the rest of the vegetables and cooking further. But the results are equally flavorful if the fish is cooked right along with the vegetables, which saves time and pots.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch;   A Day for Expansive Meals and Hearty Appetites
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current.

title: THE CASE FOR GRAD SCHOOL
description: In response to ''About Men: A Case For Grad School,'' by Mark McGurl (Feb. 18), I pity the writer for his self-deprecating reaction to the relative successes of his former girlfriends. Life is strange, entropic for either sex, and we must fight the inclination to pit ourselves against our fellow humans and against the mentality that promotes such a limited understanding of other people. He is a journalist; she is a banker; she is a social worker. Society needs all of these people, their motives are secret, hidden, unavailable.

title: New Rules Cut Use of Tranquilizers
description: AS a result of a state regulation aimed at limiting prescriptions for such tranquilizers as Valium, the use of such drugs has been cut in half, to 250,000 prescriptions a year in Nassau and 150,000 in Suffolk, according to State Department of Health officials.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Putnam Valley
description: LEAD: ''WHEN you look at a map, we're not there,'' said Barbara Doyle, director of the Putnam Valley Historical Society, ''and that's wonderful.'' This is, of course, hyperbole, since the Town of Putnam Valley, one of six in Putnam County, covers more than 43 square miles. But Ms. Doyle, a 13-year resident, fears its increasing popularity.

title: In Homage, a Comedy Of Mistaken Identities
description: JUST imagine that Oscar Wilde hadn't written ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' We might have been spared ''The Ice Cream Sunday'' by Frank Salisbury.

title: Mississippi Census Taker Shot
description: A census taker in this southern Mississippi town was shot Thursday by a 71-year-old man who said he had been pestered lately by boisterous teen-agers. The census taker, Harmon Broome, 52 years old, was treated at a hospital for face and neck wounds and discharged Friday. His assailant was identified as Cornelius Starks, who was charged with aggravated assault.

title: American Politics Loses Way as Polls Supplant Leadership
description: This series originally ran in The New York Times in 1990.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Cracks in the Walls of Memory
description: LEAD: AS I pull out of my parents' driveway and head down Matson Hill, I look once more at the house next door. It looks solid, lived in - a comfortable house. But it's not the home it used to be. In my mind, another wall cracked, another piece of foundation chipped off, when Mom died.

title: Sandlot Values Recalled Fondly
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Amy A. Brown, Planning to WedA Fellow Banker
description: The engagement of Amy Allyson Brown to John William Fraser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth William Fraser Jr. of Eden, N.C., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Sherburne Carleton Brown of Southampton, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Brown, who is 28 years old, is a graduate of Southampton High School and Cornell University. She is an assistant vice president in the consumer banking group at the Chemical Banking Corporation in New York. Her father is the chief of pediatrics at Southampton Hospital.

title: AND ON OUR RIGHT, THE BAY OF PIGS
description: LEAD:

title: A Brother and Sister, on Screen and Off
description: LEAD: HOW many 11-year-olds can boast that Meryl Streep danced and sang with them in her trailer while filming the movie ''She-Devil''?

title: Case Dropped
description: AFTER losing a round in court, Josephine Thornton, the mother of David Croudip, the Atlanta Falcons' defensive back who died of a cocaine overdose in 1988, has given up her legal battle to claim $200,000 in life insurance proceeds from her daughter-in-law by proving that the younger woman administered the fatal dose.

title:
DINING OUT;

Indian Cuisine With More Than Curry
description: LEAD: INDIAN food is often dismissed by those who are unfamiliar with the exotic Eastern cuisine as nothing more than hot curries. But the spicing varies with each dish, and what we think of as curry is nothing more than specific spices blended into a preparation. Many dishes have no curry flavor, and the degree of heat ranges from blistering to none whatsoever.

title: Heaven and Hell, The Baroque And Zeffirelli
description: The inspiration may be baroque, but when Franco Zeffirelli speaks about his new production of ''Don Giovanni'' at the Metropolitan Opera, which opens Thursday, he leaves little doubt that the execution will be vintage Zeffirelli.

title: Irene Neal - Jewelry Maker
description: What others discard - plastic six-pack rings and torn fishing line - Irene Neal gathers to make jewelry. For Mrs. Neal, a 53-year-old sculptor and painter, the inspiration came from a deep-sea diving project that she, her husband and their two children made with the oceanographer Jean-Michel Cousteau.

title: Jury in Trial of Judge Says It Is Deadlocked
description: A jury has reported being deadlocked on all eight charges against a Federal district judge accused of trying to influence criminal cases on behalf of friends, but it has been ordered to continue deliberations.

title: A REPORT INDICTS SUDAN ON RIGHTS
description: The military junta in the Sudan has introduced an era of repression marked by the detention and torture of suspected political opponents that surpasses the worst excesses of the longtime military Government that ruled from 1969 to the mid-80's, a human rights observer group says.

title: Data Bank/March 18, 1990
THE OUTSIDER MAY BE YOU
description: COLLECTED STORIES OF WALLACE STEGNER

title: Concerts Turn Attention to Children
description: SEVERAL concerts this week will feature children or will be performed for them. The most ambitious project is today at 2 P.M., when the Allegro Chamber Ensemble appears under the umbrella title of ''Imagination Concerts: A Family Series.''

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Livingston $170,000

title: Pastimes: Gardening;   A Peek Behind an Extraordinary Scene
description: They will appear sometime next month as if by magic at garden centers, nurseries, supermarkets and discount stores. Rows and rows of plastic trays will be stuffed with sturdy seedlings, most of them with their first flowers.

title: Cohesive Bucks Beat Knicks
description: The problem-plagued Milwaukee Bucks were missing two starters last night, Jack Sikma and Greg Anderson, along with Ricky Pierce, whom many consider the National Basketball Association's best sixth man, but the Knicks' puzzling slide continued.

title:
ART;

Mansion and Former Factory Offer Varied Views of Women
description: LEAD: WOMEN'S History Month is being celebrated in New Haven with a flurry of exhibitions - some 30 in all. This writer visited two of the most promising and found them to be good foils to each other.

title: Court Upholds Disclosure Law for Party Leaders
description: In a decision that could further diminish the roles of political party leaders in government in New York, leaders at the state level and those in counties with large populations will be required to make extensive financial disclosures, under an ethics law upheld last week.

title: China
description: To the Editor: It seems ironic that China would attempt to exploit the art of the Buddhist religion (''Serene Haven of Buddhist Art,'' Travel, Jan. 14) after having so devastatingly destroyed much of the art of Tibet. Unfortunately, suppression of the Tibetan people continues and we see no evidence that persecution has in any way lessened over the years.

title: South Africa Loosens Gag, and the Press Pipes Up
description: When President F. W. de Klerk announced last month that the Government would release Nelson Mandela and legalize the African National Congress, he opened the door to another kind of liberty: freedom for South African newspapers, broadcasting outlets and book publishers to cover the country as they choose.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. STANTON PEELE;

Addiction and the 'Disease Mythology'
description: LEAD: AS far as Dr. Stanton Peele is concerned, Americans are addicted to addictions. The implications of the phenomenon on individual psychology, public health and society in general are disastrous, he says.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
description: Your question this week sent me into such spasms of laughter that it took a corner of the coffee table to bring my head back to its senses.

title: Minister Quits, Shaking Indian Government
description: Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, one of India's most prominent politicians, resigned from Prime Minister V. P. Singh's administration on Friday, threatening to split the governing coalition.

title: NONFICTION
description: The quincentenary of Columbus's discovery of the New World is upon us, and Franco Cardini's EUROPE 1492: Portrait of a Continent Five Hundred Years Ago (Facts on File, $50) is disguised as a commemoration of that event. More accurately, the book is a general treatment of European life at the end of the 15th century. (Mr. Cardini seldom uses the word Renaissance, preferring to think of the period as an overlap of the Middle Ages and the modern world.) His book begins with a portentous description of Columbus's first sighting of land at San Salvador and a hint that other events of 1492 (the death of Lorenzo de' Medici and the expulsion of the Arabs and the Jews from Spain) were equally symbolic of the transition from the old world to the new. But those ideas are never developed, and Columbus is scarcely to be heard from again. That quibble aside, ''Europe 1492'' consists of page after page of beautiful, wonderfully well-chosen details from paintings, woodcuts and manuscript illuminations by Botticelli, Bosch, Memling and other masters, which cast light on diverse aspects of life in the period. The intelligent but undemanding narrative, sprinkled with passages from Vasari, Machiavelli and other Renaissance figures, provides an agreeable accompaniment to the illustrations. There are routine sections on the politics, religion and cultural differences of Europe, but Mr. Cardini, a professor of medieval history at the universities of Bari and Florence, is most entertaining in his discussion of the somewhat offbeat: peripheral populations in Europe (Africans, Muslims, gypsies, Jews), other alienated groups such as beggars, foundlings and lepers, and the widespread poverty, cruelty, disease and physical discomfort that are not always a part of the popular view of the Renaissance. A generally high standard of reproduction and a generous format help to make the book a visual pleasure.

title: Rarely Seen Works From Tanzania
description: MOST of the African art shown in this country comes from peoples living west of the Great Rift Valley. The Bamana and Dogon of Mali, the Yoruba of Nigeria and Benin, the Pende of Zaire and the Fang of Gabon are but a few of the familiar names.

title: ALL ABOUT EVERYTHING IN JUST ONE COLUMN
description: It must be some peculiar twist in the DNA that drives human beings toward extremes of every sort. In politics, whole nations will periodically swing from soul-numbing repression to nearly chaotic freedom, or back again. One school of rigorous poets finds in the 17 syllables of haiku the secret of the universe, while another believes truth is only revealed in random, half-conscious verbiage. An art gallery would find space to display the spare lines of Klee's ''Twittering Machine'' as well as the wall-filling extravagance of Caravaggio's ''Sacred and Profane Love.''

title: Fashion;   FRESH FROM NATURE'S MOLD
description: On his strolls along the Thames, Tom Binns used to scoop up pocketfuls of sea glass - old bottle tops really - sculpted by currents and washed up on the banks. These pale, irregular fragments have long held a special fascination for the designer, who has only to grind them to turn them into rings.

title: A Dimmer View Of Sports' Impact
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Older-Consumer Habits Alter Business Patterns
description: LEAD: THE emergence of the affluent, mature consumer, the empty-nesters who bought their homes when mortgage payments ran $300 monthly, not $3,000, is changing the way Long Island does business.

title: Par for the Course
description: KILLEEN, TEX., IS HOME TO about 68,000 people and the Army base at Fort Hood. It's a bit of a downtrodden place at the moment, in the wake of the budget-cutting proposal by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney that would substantially shrink the military presence there. On the bright side, however, is miniature golf, whose image in Killeen is undergoing state-of-the-art refurbishing. The local franchise of Putt-Putt Golf Courses of America Inc. will soon reopen one of its three courses in an extravagant, artificial atmosphere, featuring a fountain, a mountain and Fiberglas wild animals. ''The elephant is life-size,'' says Don Clayton. ''Maybe it'll be standing in pampas grass.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;

Coming: A Co-op for Boarding Horses
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION of what is believed to be the country's first cooperative for boarding horses - the Equus Club - is expected to begin within the next six months on a 152-acre tract in South Salem, off Silver Spring Road near the Connecticut border.

title: Legislators Preparing For Scrutiny Of Television
description: IN the middle of an Ardsley Village Board meeting last year, the doors burst open as trustees were considering an alteration plan for the municipal building. Paul Ryan, a local resident who had been watching the meeting on cable television, marched in with an idea for a different design.

title: Lower Taxes? Here's How
description: IN recent months, the Long Island Weekly section has published two articles from retired principals concerning increases in taxes. They complained about inordinate spending in some districts and a resultant deterioration in quality of life. They accused school administrators of rationalization and waste, scare tactics and intimidation. They neglected other significant elements.

title: Review/Film;   And Now on the Screen: Lambada!
description: The lambada, once a Brazilian dance, was carpetbagged to Paris. There, entrepreneurs turned a Bolivian pop song and a common-denominator Caribbean beat into a pan-European hit and dance craze, involving undulating, bikini-clad rumps and female-groin-to-male-thigh contact. Some parties hope the lambada will catch on here, but if the onrush of hype hasn't already befuddled Americans about what, exactly, it is, ''Lambada'' and ''The Forbidden Dance,'' two films released Friday, should easily complete the job.

title: POSTINGS: A Bid for Restoration;   The Kings Of Flatbush
description: One of New York City's grand old moviehouses of the 1930's, the Loew's Kings Theater, or ''The Kings'' as it was more commonly called by the residents of Brooklyn's Flatbush neighborhood at that time, may be restored to its original flamboyancy if city officials have their way. The city's Public Development Corporation is soliciting ideas about how best to use the theater, which has been dark for 12 years. The city owns the property. Slathered with gilded Baroque and Art Deco details, the showcase theater contained 3,200 seats when it was completed in 1929. The onetime movie palace is on Flatbush Avenue between Duryea Place and Tilden Avenue in what was once the heart of that old neighborhood's retail section.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Susan Ingersoll Wed in Virginia
description: At the Garth Chapel in Charlottesville, Va., Susan Phelps Ingersoll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps Ingersoll Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Timothy John Burgess, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brook Gene Burgess of Keyser, W. Va. The Rev. Maurice A. Fetty, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony. The bride was attended by her sisters, Lauren Ingersoll Murray and Elizabeth Wilcox Ingersoll. Jeffrey Scott Burgess was his brother's best man.

title: Miss Haggerty Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Haggerty of Summit, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Ann Haggerty and Gregg H. Beldock, the son of Florence Milan of New York and Howard N. Beldock of Fort Lee, N.J. Miss Haggerty, a graduate of Hollins College, is a manager of program operations at the ABC Radio Network in New York. The prospective bridegroom, a graduate of the University of Vermont, is the president of the Bullrock Construction Corporation, a real-estate development and construction management company in New York.

title: Miss Rice Weds Stuart Harris Jr.
description: St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kathleen Anne Rice, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rice of Manhasset and Naples, Fla., to Stuart William Harris Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Richmond. The Rev. Anthony Refalo performed the ceremony.

title: About Long Island;   For Japanese Students, the Fast Track Means Saturday School Bells
description: VOLVOS and Buicks idled in front of the Great Neck South High School as parents waited for their children. Although it was Saturday, it was just another school day for the 367 students attending the Japanese Weekend School. In Japan, children go to school six days a week. On Long Island they do too.

title: Are You Codependent?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: AS have most Americans, I have sat in front of the television set each evening excited, bewildered and sometimes stunned by the pace of change in Eastern Europe.

title: Ex-Nazi Guard Loses Citizenship But Is Allowed to Remain in U.S.
description: A retired Chicago butcher who was a Nazi concentration camp guard in World War II has been stripped of his American citizenship but will be allowed to remain in the United States.

title: Prague's Fine Vintage
description: PRAGUE this spring has a supplementary reason for feeling like a city woken from a bad dream to a world full of promise and delight. Its wine cellars are stocked with the 1989 vintage, one of those that almost sing with perfume. The pale-gold glassfuls from the taps of its wine taverns have the rare quality of effortless excellence that harks back to the days before brand names and back-labels or indeed labels at all.

title: THE CASE FOR GRAD SCHOOL
description: Last year I got a B.A. in philosophy. Now I am waiting tables, writing, and taking pictures; it's a beginning. I'm not sure what will come of it, but I do know that I won't spend my years parading other people's causes, not that it's not useful, it's that I've made other choices. Nor will I wear $200 paisley ties, the usefulness of which I would call into question.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: In the battle for control of the vast colonial wealth of the North American colonies, France and England were opponents. The pawns were the tribes and leagues of Indians that held the control and wealth of a wide area. Agents of each European power were quick to make any alliance with the Indians that could hurt the other. To that end French or English soldiers were sent on long expeditions into uncharted areas known only through the tales of trappers. The agents brought bribes for the Indians: jewelry, iron goods, knives, muskets and, for special occasions, medals.

title: UNSETTLING THE OLD WEST
description: GHOST TOWNS ARE AMONG HER FIRST EXHIBITS. Patricia Nelson Limerick, who teaches Western history at the University of Colorado, takes out a bundle of glossy black-and-white prints that she keeps at her home in Boulder and shows me scenes of dilapidated cabins, saloons, sagging mining shacks amid empty landscapes.

title: Budapest's Grand Design
description: IF each city has its niche in time, then the turn of the century is where Budapest naturally belongs. It has the boulevards and the opera, the cafes and the trams, the public gardens and private villas. And now, as another era and another century come to a close, it is showing signs of the same freneticism and languor, the same eagerness to do business and seek pleasure that characterized its golden age in 1900.

title: CRIME
description: In the 18 years she has spent as a crime reporter for The Miami Herald, Edna Buchanan has picked up a lot of stuff besides her 1986 Pulitzer Prize. She has learned police procedures, met strange characters and collected many sad, weird stories, some of which went into her true-crime study ''The Corpse Had a Familiar Face.'' But she saved some good stuff for her first novel, NOBODY LIVES FOREVER (Random House, $17.95).

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Exit King Oat Bran, the Tyrant
description: LEAD: EATING breakfast cereal has never been easy, but with the death of King Oat Bran, it has become even more complicated.

title: M.B.A. Mentality
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen Turner, Back in the Steamy South
description: The way Kathleen Turner tells it, the first time she saw herself on the big screen she had much the same reaction as most viewers did. It was 1981; the movie was ''Body Heat,'' in which Ms. Turner, as the murderous seductress Mattie Walker, and William Hurt as Ned Racine, the lover she betrays, enact some of the sweatiest, most fevered scenes of passion that Hollywood has ever dared. The humidity remains memorable, and the film created an image for Ms. Turner that clings to her still.

title: Molitor Stands With Players
description: Stung by reports that he had undermined his union's position by back-channel communication with team management, Paul Molitor of the Milwaukee Brewers left the baseball negotiations last night insisting that he stands firmly behind the negotiating position of the Players Association.

title: After Killings, Turks Fear a Repeat of the Past
description: The killings of two policemen in January were bad enough. But after gunmen in recent weeks killed a leading lawyer and a prominent newspaper columnist, in street attacks in Ankara and Istanbul, Turks have begun nervously asking themselves whether they are back to the terrorism that led to a military coup in 1980.

title: Battle and Rampal Postpone Joint Recital
description: Because of a scheduling conflict, the joint recital by the soprano Kathleen Battle and the flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal scheduled for March 25 at Alice Tully Hall has been postponed to Feb. 24, 1991.

title: >More Than a Potato, A Lesson in Life
description: LIKE many New Jerseyans, I have a vegetable garden out back. I grow a half-dozen tomato plants, a few rows of beans, some zucchini - a vegetable smorgasbord. I get a deep satisfaction from working the soil and making things grow. And in raising a portion of our food organically, I enjoy the feeling that I am doing something worthwhile both for my family and for the environment. It never occurred to me to carry out an economic analysis of my costs and receipts. I just grew what I felt like and tried to be sensible.

title: Testing the 'Bump' in Bumpers
description: There were some good things about my first car. For one thing it cost $125. I traded in savings bonds for it, actually what we called war bonds when my grandmother bought them for me.

title: Problems Are Reported With New Spy Satellite
description: A new American spy satellite has apparently malfunctioned after less than a month in orbit, and parts of it are expected to be destroyed re-entering the atmosphere within a month, United States and Soviet military space officials say.

title: THE HEART HAS ITS JUSTICE
description: DOING JUSTICE

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended March 3

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Karajan vs. Karajan vs. Karajan vs. . . .
description: The one title that appears most frequently in the late Herbert von Karajan's discography is Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony, which he recorded seven times over a period of nearly 50 years, with orchestras in Berlin, London and Vienna. The symphonies with which he is most readily identified, though, are Beethoven's, and in that material his recording statistics are impressive. He made no fewer than four complete recordings of the nine in less than 35 years, following individual recordings of Nos. 5, 7, 8 and 9, and managed to work in another one of No. 7 along the way (for a total of six versions of that work).

title: Picking a Banjo Through 50 Years of Protests
description: TO hear Pete Seeger tell it, the singer and political activist is falling apart. His voice is ''50 percent gone,'' he says, and he gets by only by ''persuading the audience to sing along.'' His memory is going, too, and that's not all. ''I can't remember where I put my hearing aid five minutes ago,'' he says.

title: Democracy, Gorbachev's Way
description: AMERICA was all the rage last week at the Kremlin Hall of Congresses, as the remodelers of the Soviet Constitution fashioned a new Western-looking Presidency for Mikhail S. Gorbachev and legalized a multiparty system. From the debate in the hall and the banter in the corridors, a visitor might have gathered that the Soviet people, having sampled McDonald's and Bon Jovi, were ready for Madison and Jefferson.

title: READ ALL ABOUT IT
description: THE NATION'S NEWSBROKERS

title: U.S. Gives $10 Million to Help Boat People
description: The State Department said today that President Bush has released an additional $10 million to help resettle Vietnamese refugees, most of whom have gone to crowded camps in Hong Kong after dangerous sea voyages.

title: Comprehensive History of New York City's Irish Under Way
description: The Irish have been in New York since the place was established, almost, but there has never been a book that has told the whole story of their role in the life of the city. Now a group of scholars, mostly but not exclusively Irish, has begun a project that they say will be the first to tell the complete history of the Irish in this city in one book.

title: THE INNER SANCTUMS OF THE NEWARK MUSEUM
description: If there is any reward in architecture to staying the course, it is to be seen right here on Washington Street, where the Newark Museum has recently completed a $21 million reconstruction and expansion. The architect the museum hired was Michael Graves - not the internationally famous Michael Graves of today, architect of Whitney Museum additions and Walt Disney World hotels, but the young and struggling Michael Graves of 1967, a faculty member at the Princeton University School of Architecture. That was the year Mr. Graves was recommended to the Newark Museum's director, Samuel C. Miller, as a talented comer. In those days Mr. Graves was supplementing his teaching salary by designing a few modest house additions, and the invitation to design the museum represented his bid for the big time.

title: A Collection of Sculpture Easy on the Eye, and on the Intellect
description: A GOOD title being hard to find, the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson must be congratulated for '' 'Lite' Works,'' because the show of sculpture it identifies contains at most a couple of calories. To put it another way, the art is as easy on the intellect as it is on the eye and mainly this is because the eight sculptors involved use materials that call for neither a vast studio space nor an arsenal of tools.

title: McIlvaine Feels Sorry for Young Players
description: Joe McIlvaine, the good shepherd who tends the flock of Mets yearlings, calls them baseball's ''prisoners of war,'' but they are not penned in any camp. The problem, as McIlvaine and many other personnel people view it, is that they should be in camp.

title: U.S. to Investigate Products' Environmental Claims
description: The Federal Trade Commission has announced an investigation into the environmental claims of products from trash bags to hair spray, saying it would vigorously pursue deceptive advertising and packaging.

title: Teen-Ager Dies And 6 Are Hurt In Shootings
description: One teen-ager was killed and six others were seriously injured in two unrelated shootings late Friday and early yesterday outside of restaurants in Queens and Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Connecticut Town Becomes the Caboose Capital
description: This crossroads community has become the caboose capital of Connecticut, if not of the continent.

title: Miss Salzhauer To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Salzhauer of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elisabeth Anne Salzhauer to Blair Axel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kermit Axel of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

For Psychic Wounds, Time Still Heals Best
description: LEAD: ALONG with the expected furor and frenzy and human drama surrounding the recent Avianca jet crash on Long Island, a curious new phenomenon was also asserting itself: the post-catastrophe healer.

title: Seven City Hostelries
description: WHEN Archduke Otto of Habsburg recently revisited Hungary on two separate occasions, he stayed at the Gellert Hotel on the west bank of the Danube River. It was the newest and most sumptuous establishment in town when he was last in the country - in 1918, as a 5-year-old prince. If, like the Archduke, you are the son of the last Emperor of Austria-Hungary, and if, furthermore, you are able to enchant Hungarians by your fluency in their language, as the 77-year-old Archduke and member of the European Parliament does, you can presumably pick your own hotel even on short notice. Otherwise you will probably have to take whatever accommodation - in the price range you indicate - you can get. Sure you may state your preference, but the chances that it will be met are not too bright unless you make reservations weeks or even months ahead, furnishing precise and unchangeable arrival and departure dates.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional;   Carolina Shocks Sooners, 79-77
description: North Carolina proved something today to Oklahoma, to the rest of the country and to a tournament committee that seeded the Tar Heels eighth in their region. And by defeating the country's No. 1-ranked team, North Carolina established itself as a legitimate contender for the national championship.

title: TRAUMATIC FROM THE VERY BEGINNING
description: LEAD:

title: ADDING UP THE COSTS OF CHANGES AT THE TOP
description: Man-hunting, like bear-baiting, has no place in a civilized society. Yet in the last month or two the manhunt has become a fact of life in the cultural life of New York. Just the other day, Andre Schiffrin - universally admired and respected as the head of Pantheon Books, and the son of the initiator in Paris of the Bibliotheque de la Pleiade, from which the ongoing Library of America derives - was dismissed from his post. No sooner had John Dobkin revitalized the National Academy of Design over a period of 11 years than a conservative counterattack prevailed and, with it, a likely return to old and sleepy ways. And, not two weeks ago, Tom Armstrong was dismissed from the directorship of the Whitney Museum of Art.

title: Donna J. Jackson, Writer, Is Engaged
description: June wedding plans for Donna Jeanne Jackson and Arthur John Mehrle 3d have been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Michael J. Strok of Annapolis, Md. Mr. Mehrle is the son of Jean Baskett-Mehrle of Evansville, Ind., and Mr. Mehrle Jr. of Houston.

title: Balloon Shorts Out 7,000
description: An aluminum St. Patrick's Day balloon floated into a substation this afternoon and caused a short-circuit that left more than 7,000 homes in Waterbury, Cheshire and Wolcott without power. A Northeast Utilities spokesman said crews had to do extensive work before power was fully restored just before 4 p.m. The small aluminum balloon was covered with St. Patrick's Day pictures, and had apparently drifted away from a reveler.

title: Alison C. Rinehart and Scott C. Lee, Students, Plan to Be Married in June
description: The engagement of Alison Christie Rinehart to Scott Charles Lee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Lee of Fallbrook, Calif., has been announced by her parents, Christie Walter Rinehart of Redondo Beach, Calif., and Stanley Marshall Rinehart 3d of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Songs and Dances Welcome Spring
description: ON Tuesday, the vernal equinox will occur, and spring will begin. People around Connecticut will mark the occasion with activities that include climbing mountains and planting peas.

title: Elizabeth Waters To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Waters of Port Washington, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Waters, and Kevin John Kells, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Kells of Miami.

title: Star Wars
description: Joan Quigley is no crass self-promoter, of course, but it must have been difficult to stand silent while other people hogged the credit for changing the course of history. Ms. Quigley, who was Nancy Reagan's astrologer, asserted in a memoir published last week that Mrs. Reagan's 1989 memoir greatly understated the astrologer's influence on the Reagan Presidency. Mrs. Reagan said that Ms. Quigley's advice had nothing to do with policy. But Ms. Quigley contends in her book, ''What Does Joan Say?,'' that through Mrs. Reagan she had ''a direct line to the President'' that she used to persuade him to, among other things, change his attitude toward Mikhail S. Gorbachev before their summit meeting in Geneva. She wrote, '' 'Ronnie's evil empire attitude has to go before he can meet with Gorbachev,' I told her.'' The rest, as they say, is, well, something.

title: Taroudant
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from a seven-day stay at Taroudant, I thought I'd keep this authentic Moroccan spot to myself. Lo and behold, a piece extolling its virtues appeared in the Travel section (''Palmy Days at a Hideaway in Morocco,'' Dec. 31).

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Button-Down Set Is Loosening Up
description: O.K., class, clear your desks; it's time for a quiz. Today is March 18. That means the season is: (A) winter, (B) spring, (C)summer or (D) all of the above. The correct answer, as anyone who has been in New York City the last few days knows, is D. Those who are majoring in fashion appreciation also know that this is also called a transitional period, when the weather is a bit too warm for heavy winter wools but, most days at least, a little too brisk for lightweight clothes.

title: NEWSPAPER COLUMNISTS: LITERATURE BY THE INCH
description: Pick up a newspaper anywhere in the United States and you will be addressed by insistent strangers known generically as columnists because each occupies, more or less, a column of newsprint. The term also has an apt association with the I-shaped pillar from which the columnist can harangue the populace - like St. Simeon Stylites of Syria, who spent 30 years preaching from the top of a column in the fifth century. He has come to be the patron of an unruly calling.

title: Casinos in New York City Appear Unlikely
description: The possibility of legalizing casino gambling in New York City is being studied by the City Council's Committee on Economic Development, but the idea has drawn criticism from Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Triumphant Opening For New Paris Opera
description: The new opera house, built on the site of the Bastille prison, had its grand opening today. The crowd roared with approval at the first Paris performance of ''Les Troyens,'' a seldom-performed work by Berlioz.

title: Jazz That Speaks Latin, and Vice Versa
description: Though jazz and Latin music have mingled regularly over the last century, their relationship has always been uneasy. Despite their similar roots, their rhythms and sense of form are different, and from the 1940's on, their uses have separated. Where Latin music, meant for dancing, is still essentially functional, jazz has long been content to use the vestiges of the dance impulse - riffs, swing - to keep the rhythms supple.

title: WARSAW ALLIANCE SPLIT ON GERMANY
description: The Foreign Ministers of the Warsaw Pact, meeting here under new, democratic conditions, failed to agree today on whether a united Germany should be neutral or aligned with the West. The Soviet Union was left alone in its rigid opposition to Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The 4A's Get A Call From Congress
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee called on the advertising industry on Saturday to help sell his deficit-reduction package to the nation's business community.

title: Advance Ross Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Gorbachev Denies That an Ultimatum Has Been Issued to Lithuania
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev denied today that any ''ultimatum'' had been issued to Lithuania to end its program of reclaiming independence from the Soviet Union.

title: Crystal Oil Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $309,000, or 1 cent a share, for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss The company said latest quarter and year net included charges related to a provision in lieu of income taxes of $870,000 and $2,370,000, respectively. Year-ago quarter and year figures both included a charge of $4,309,000 related to debt conversion expenses.

title: Symbion Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CHRONICLE
description: AUDREY HEPBURN will join a symphony orchestra to tell the story of Anne Frank in music and words, The Associated Press has reported.

title: Bridge
description: A little-known partnership from Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, zoomed to an impressive victory in the Open Pairs, the first major championship of the American Contract Bridge League's spring nationals here Saturday night. Don Campbell and Barry Harper scored 70 percent in the first final session, and wound up two boards ahead of their nearest rivals to win their first national title.

title: Olympus Capital Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago fourth quarter results included a $10.8 million loss recognized in connection with the sale and restructuring of about $260 million of assets to reduce interest rate risk and provisions for losses on loans, leases and real estate owned of about $5 million. The latest fourth quarter included provisions for loss totaling about $2.2 million. Olympus said the results from operations for 1989 were adversely affected by provisions for losses on loans, leases and real estate owned of $14,554,000.

title: Munsingwear Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 6
Letting Go: Skiing Without Poles
description: ANDREA MEAD LAWRENCE, double gold medal winner in the l952 Winter Olympics, skis without poles. Chuck Hildreth, who won a gold medal in the World Disabled Championships, skis without poles. Children, until they are 5 or 6 years old, ski without poles.

title: CONSERVATIVES BACKED BY KOHL TOP EAST GERMAN VOTE SOLIDLY BUT APPEAR TO NEED COALITION
description: A group of conservative parties, led by the Christian Democrats and actively supported by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, scored a surprising victory on Sunday in the first free election in East Germany. The eastern Germans had not freely cast their ballots since Hitler abolished the Weimar Republic after coming to power in 1933.

title: Versatile Skier
description: REAL skiers win either way: Nordic or Alpine. At least that's how Ray and Reed Robinson, father and son skiers from Lake Tahoe, Calif., have done it.

title: Mudd Takes Players Title by One Stroke Over Calcavecchia
description: Jodie Mudd struck a rare blow for the public golfer today when he outdueled Mark Calcavecchia in a back-nine shootout to win the Players Championship.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: 'Wars' Wound Candidates and the Process
description: Dick Lamm, the former Governor of Colorado, thought about running for the Senate this year. Many Democrats urged him to enter the race.

title: Arkansas' Coach Gets Timing Right
description: When Nolan Richardson arrived as coach at Arkansas five seasons ago, he said it was only a matter of time before the Razorbacks reached the Final Four. Their time may come this year. By defeating Dayton, 86-84, on Saturday night, Arkansas (28-4) became one of the final 16 teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the first time since 1983.

title: Mafia Island Journal;   In a Many-Splendored Sea, Scientists Crave a Park
description: Venus, a teen-age beach boy who idles away his days on the white sands of this remote speck in the Indian Ocean, stretched out his bare arm toward the fierce sun. He judged the angle with the horizon. ''One o'clock,'' he said in halting English. ''No watches,'' he added ruefully. The geographic location he explained by pointing south and saying, ''The Comoros and then away, away, South Africa.''

description: It took the Greeks only 10 years to capture Troy, but they did not have to face the problems that confronted the people who planned the Bastille Opera. Although actual design and construction of the $400 million house began eight years ago, more than 20 years of artistic and political struggle preceded its opening Saturday evening with Berlioz's ''Troyens.'' Now, it appears, the siege of crises has been lifted.

title: Pollution's Toll in Eastern Europe: Stumps Where Great Trees Once Grew
description: Across a mountain range where East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Poland meet lies the bitter fallout from industrial schemes conceived in the Kremlin four decades ago.

title: How to Find Minority Teachers
description: Eight of every 10 New York City public school students are from minority groups while 7 of every 10 teachers and principals are white. Should there be somewhat closer correlation? Surely yes. That's the goal of a comprehensive affirmative action plan for hiring and promoting more minority employees now under consideration by the Board of Education. It merits approval. With 112,000 employees, the board is one of the city's major employers, but it has adopted only patchwork programs for increasing the proportion of minority staffers. That's why Gwendolyn Baker, the only black on the seven-member central board, pushed the board to consider a comprehensive approach.

title: Repair New York's Dented Shield Law
description: News organizations will have a hard time informing the public if they are routinely hauled into court to produce notes or unused television footage about a crime or accident that becomes the subject of court action. Half the states therefore have journalistic shield laws, and nearly all states have produced judicial decisions restricting some subpoenas to news organizations.

title: Tokyo Tries to Find Out if 'Salarymen' Are Working Themselves to Death
description: Since well before Japan's emergence as an economic superpower, its hordes of white-collar workers have been the stuff of cartoon caricatures: blue-suited men who spill out of jammed trains every morning, push paper in overcrowded offices all day, drink in the Ginza district all night and die early from the stress of their unrelenting work.

title: Los Angeles Plans Art to Soothe Rail Riders
description: Nothing so much defines the newer suburbs of Los Angeles as their visual banality, endless miles of palms and hazy air hovering above factories that produce missiles and all manner of 21st century wizardry but little to enchant the eye.

description: It's a sad commentary on the sport that with one day until spring and two weeks until the season was supposed to begin, the closest New Yorkers are getting to big league baseball is at the New York Public Library in Manhattan.

title: You Take Manhattan; I'm Gone
description: LEAD: ''It's strange,'' remarked an old friend as my furniture came off the van. ''Your coming home the very day they ship Ava Gardner here in a pinewood box.'' Indeed, the famous Tar Heel was buried over in Smithfield almost simultaneous with the emptying of my last packing crate. Everybody back in place, one way or another, one reason or another.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I voted in genuine secrecy. No one told me in advance how to vote, and I have no fear of immediate reprisals tommorrow at work for voting the way I wanted. In my heart, I feel as if I just voted for the first time.''

title: Wake Up and Smell the Sambuca
description: Some years ago, many Americans tossed out their electric percolators, turned up their noses at instant coffee and began experimenting with bizarre contraptions and exotic beans in their quest for that perfect brew. Kenyan coffee, dripped through a filter in an hour-glass Chemex, was an early favorite; the whine of Italian espresso machines rose with the dawn.

title: Washington at Work;   Education of the Health Secretary: When and When Not to Speak Out
description: The moment of emergence came in the air over Europe: From the cocoon of the academic doctor and political cipher, after a year of painful problems, a more assertive Cabinet Secretary came forth.

title: When the Business of Music Becomes Even Bigger
description: When Diana Ross and the Supremes sang ''Someday We'll Be Together'' in 1969, they probably weren't thinking about the way the record business would reorganize over the next two decades. But when the film-and-music conglomerate MCA agreed to buy Geffen Records last week for stock worth $550 million, taking it away from the larger distribution network of Time Warner, it was one more reminder of the consolidation that now prevails in the record business.

title: Review/Opera;   Mannes College Troupe Revives an Offenbach Rarity
description: The Mannes College of Music has presented several successful early opera productions in recent years, through the efforts of Paul C. Echols and his Mannes Camerata. Two years ago, Mr. Echols extended the school's operatic reach into the 19th and 20th centuries with a second troupe, the Mannes Opera Ensemble. On Saturday evening, Mr. Echols led his student singers and orchestra in a lively staging of Jacques Offenbach's ''Bavards'' at Mannes.

description: The Horse Latitudes

title: Residents of Canal Street Find the Bargains Are Costly
description: Andre Graham, a student at Rutgers University, drove his new red Isuzu into Manhattan yesterday to shop for a car stereo. By early afternoon he had parted with several hundred dollars and a dealer had installed a pair of wheel-sized speakers and a powerful amplifier for him. His browsing, the purchase and the installation all took place along Canal Street.

title: Suburban Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Opposition Sees Gain in Moscow Vote
description: Encouraged by its role in crafting the new national presidency, the budding Soviet political opposition predicted further progress today as citizens voted in local and republic elections in various parts of the nation. Most crucial for the opposition was a battle with the Communist Party for control of the Moscow City Council.

title: Ex-Rep. Moffett Trying Comeback in Connecticut
description: In the towns of the Naugatuck Valley, where blue-collar Democrats went heavily for Ronald Reagan in 1984 and mostly never came back, Toby Moffett is trying to come back himself.

description: Stu Jackson, the Knick coach, has tried to pull his team out of its unexplainable slide with patience, with anger and with a soul-searching team meeting. Nothing has worked.

title: British Growth Rate Off
description: British economic growth was cut in half last year, according to official figures released Friday. Gross domestic product, which measures goods and services produced, grew by 2.3 percent last year, compared with a 4.6 percent increase in 1988. The increase last year was slightly above a forecast of 2 percent by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, in November.

description: A driverless car filled with explosives rolled toward a hotel early today where Syrian soldiers are based, but it careened off course into sandbags and the bomb was defused safely, the police said.

title: Cardinal Acts To Replace Ritter's Aides
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, who recently agreed to name an acting president of Covenant House, expanded his involvement in its frayed affairs yesterday by saying that he would name the new executive's three top associates as well.

title: Baseball's Labor Dispute Settled With Compromise On Arbitration

WALTER JACOBS usually found his patients to be a little bit timid, even though they included the world champions Henry Armstrong, Joe Louis, Jack Dempsey, Sandy Saddler, Beau Jack and hundreds of other fighters in his 50-odd years of practicing dentistry. title: Jails Chief Receives Volatile Welcome
description: In his first week as New York City Correction Commissioner, Allyn R. Sielaff, a 58-year-old lawyer, has already found himself immersed in the problems of a volatile and overcrowded jail system with more than 20,000 inmates and 12,000 employees at 15 jails.

title: First Fidelity Agrees to Pay $30 Million to Settle Lawsuit
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation, one of the country's largest bank holding companies, has agreed to pay $30 million to settle a shareholders' lawsuit that accused it of withholding information on bad loans made by a Philadelphia subsidiary.

description: President Najibullah told his Communist Party today that it should surrender its monopoly on power and hold a special session to write the change into the Afghan Constitution.

description: As Israel struggles to form a new government over a period that could last weeks or months, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir will be a very busy man.

title: Noah Loses to Qualifier After a Third-Set Lapse
description: With hissing palm trees as a backdrop, Yannick Noah, who is accustomed to asserting himself rather grandly at the Lipton International Players Championships, lost his flair at the worst time tonight, in a third-set tie breaker against the qualifier Mark Kratzmann, who defeated him, 6-4, 2-6, 7-6.

title: Romanians Take Stock Of Damage
description: At the Foreign Trade Ministry, the leaders of Romania entrusted with reviving the country's export industry recently made an alarming discovery: no specialists in foreign trade were being trained in the country.

Deborah Sanders Marries
description: Deborah Lynn Sanders, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Saul L. Sanders of Montville, N.J., was married yesterday at Temple Beth Tikvah in Wayne, N.J., to Eliot Studnitzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Studnitzer of the Bronx. Rabbis Solomon I. Berl and Martin Freedman officiated. Mrs. Studnitzer, 31 years old, graduated from Allegheny College. She is the assistant manager at Kuoni Travel in New York. The bridegroom, 30, is a pharmacist and a graduate of the Long Island University College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences. He is the president of A. J. & E. Drugs in Plainview, L.I.

title: Outdoors: Zero In For Final Cleaning
description: HAVING just spent the better part of an hour removing a patch of rust from the barrel of one of my deer rifles and re-bluing the offending spot, I am moved to remind other sportsmen to take a careful look at their guns before beginning to sort out their fishing gear.

title: Fordham and Rutgers Meet Tonight
description: Nick Macarchuk, Fordham's basketball coach, has seen Rutgers play a couple of times this season, and he didn't like what he saw.

title: Market Place;   Sharedata Slipped As Its Stock Rose
description: AS 1989 ended and the new year began, Sharedata Inc. was struggling to survive after the loss of the only profitable products it ever had, computer game versions of the popular television shows ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy.'' Insiders were funneling in cash, and the company was paying interest rates of up to 30 percent to keep the doors open.

title: Cuomo's Fiscal Battle With Judge Pits Dollars and Judicial Dignity
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Republican he appointed Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, Sol Wachtler, are engaged in an extraordinary behind-the-scenes struggle that goes beyond their differences over budget issues to a personal clash over the role of the courts.

title: MAJOR FLAW FOUND IN SPACE STATION PLANNED BY NASA
description: Federal experts have belatedly found that the $30 billion space station Freedom, the planned centerpiece of the nation's program for the manned exploration of the solar system, cannot be built as designed because its vast array of parts would start to break down before the station was completed.

title: Still a Stir Over Chavez Bout
description: It was late Saturday night and still there were questions about precisely what had happened, only hours before, to conclude the stirring bout between the junior-welterweight champions Meldrick Taylor and Julio Cesar Chavez.
