description: His close colleagues were not surprised when William F. Reilly resigned as president of Macmillan Inc. on Friday to become president and chief executive of K-III Holdings, a New York company in which Kolberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company has a 75 percent stake.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   A Youth Unbroken by the Cultural Revolution
description: In a re-education camp during the Chinese Cultural Revolution, a guard asks a prisoner to identify the melody he's playing on a makeshift wind instrument. The hapless man blurts out ''Mozart,'' then quickly saves himself by adding, ''It's a song called 'Mozart Dreams of Mao Zedong.' '' Though ''China, My Sorrow'' is not always so pointed or witty, it is a deft and oddly lighthearted tribute to the traditions and spirit of freedom that survived the Cultural Revolution.

title: Immigrants and Jobs: When Being Legal Isn't Enough
description: When Newayit Hassen, a refugee of the Ethiopian civil war, applied for a job at a Brooklyn home-care service, she was turned down because her refugee card did not have a picture - even though pictures are not required and the cards do not carry them.

description: A gas explosion killed 13 people, destroyed a four-story building and started a large fire here today, the official press agency said. The blast injured many people, some critically, in the middle-class area of central Teheran, and the toll was expected to rise.

description: It's not as if the Rangers were left trembling by it, but they clearly felt the rumble of the Devils just 6 points behind them in the Patrick Division.

description: Summer Squall and Unbridled, who emerged from Saturday's racing at Gulfstream Park as the top Eastern prospects for the Kentucky Derby, will both be pointed for the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland on April 14, their handlers said today.

description: Four years after being driven from the Philippines and six months after the death of her husband, Imelda Marcos tomorrow will become the first wife of a foreign head of state to go on trial in the United States.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   A Child's Response to the Tyranny of Grown-Ups
description: In Melbourne, Australia, in the mid-1950's there was a rabbit blight. Rabbits overran the countryside so dramatically that they were labeled pests and exterminated. Even pet rabbits were rounded up and confined. At the same time, anti-Communist sentiments were prevalent in Australia, just as they were during the McCarthy period in the United States.

title: How to Pay for Politics Honorably
description: Rapid reform, in Congress? All of a sudden, that's a plausible possibility. The Senate, its honor on the line, is edging closer to cleaning up the way its members finance their campaigns. A solid bill backed by the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, has passed the Rules Committee and is heading quickly to the floor. Key Republican senators, weary of obstructionism, have now joined negotiations aimed at bipartisan agreement.

title: He's Discreet, but Poised to Unseat Thatcher

title: Review/Music;   Assorted Challenges Greet New Jerseyans at Carnegie
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and its music director, Hugh Wolff, seem to delight in strutting their stuff at Carnegie Hall, where they have received excellent notices in one demanding concert after another. On Saturday evening, they returned to Carnegie with two brilliant orchestral workouts, Berlioz's brief overture ''Le Corsaire'' (Op. 21) and Lutoslawski's magnificent Concerto for Orchestra. The program also offered a composition that, in its frequent chamberlike demands, poses orchestral challenges of a different sort, Mahler's ''Knaben Wunderhorn,'' with Susan Graham, mezzo-soprano, and Kevin McMillan, baritone.

title: Hungary's New Sports World
description: With a magnificent spring-like day as a backdrop Friday, many of Hungary's great fencers of the past honored one of their own, Aladar Gerevich, on the occasion of his 80th birthday. Between 1932 and 1960, he won seven Olympic gold medals in saber ''and probably would have won more,'' said one of the celebrators, Pal Schmitt, were it not for the cancellation of the Olympics in 1940 and 1944 because of World War II.

description: Sol Zausner, former chairman and president of the Zausner Foods Corporation, who introduced commercially produced creme fraiche to cooks in the United States, died of kidney failure yesterday at his home in Martinsville, N.J. He was 71 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Kelley & Wallwork Get Steinway Piano Job
description: Steinway & Sons, the venerable piano makers, have switched their advertising account to the Boston agency Kelley & Wallwork. The previous agency, Lowe Tucker Metcalf, took over the $1 million account from the Boston agency Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson just last year, but because of creative differences no campaign ever ran.

description: Most of West Virginia's 22,000 teachers voted today to end their strike over pay and other education issues that have closed schools or curtailed classes statewide for the last 12 days.

title: Terry Quimby, Executive, 86
description: Terry Quimby, a former fashion industry advertising executive and director of an art galleryr, died of heart failure Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86 years old. Mrs. Quimby was born in Manhattan. After graduating from New York University, she began working in the fashion industry, eventually directing the advertising departments of the Elizabeth Arden and Helena Rubenstein cosmetics companies.

description: The artworks reported stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston include some of the finest paintings in a collection known worldwide for its Old Master and 19th-century art.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18

title: DEMOCRAT SEEKING DEEP MILITARY CUT
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee called today for a $20 billion cut in military spending for next year, $5 billion deeper than one he suggested only two weeks ago and nearly twice the size of the cut the Bush Administration has indicated it will now accept.

title: Winner at Xtra Calls Proxy Fights Wearing
description: Robert M. Gintel, who emerged the winner last week in the Xtra Corporation proxy fight, said he was not eager to get involved in another anytime soon.

title: Don't Change Mitchell-Lama Housing Rules in Middle of Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Stable Prices Expected For Television Ad Time
description: After half a decade of sharp increases, the cost of buying television advertising time in advance this year will probably remain close to the $4 billion spent last year, advertising and network executives say.

title: Toronto Dominion Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations, or 3 cents a share; the actual amount was not immediately available. Discontinued operations represented LDC operations. Per share figures reflected a 100 percent stock dividend paid last July. The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Raritan Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
William Platt Jr., 84, Lawyer on Long Island
description: William B. Platt Jr., a Southampton, L.I., Village Attorney for more than 20 years, of heart failure on Friday at Southampton Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Walter T. Ridder, 72, Retired News Executive
description: Walter T. Ridder, a retired news executive who helped create Knight-Ridder Inc., died after a long illness Saturday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 72 years old.

title: Amcast Industrial reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
Icahn's USX Plan May Be Gaining Support
description: Carl C. Icahn's proposal that the USX Corporation sell all or most of its steel holdings is apparently gaining some support among the company's institutional investors.

title: Flooding in Alabama Leaves 3,700 Homeless
description: Two days of flooding across southern Alabama have left at least 3,700 people homeless and killed nine others, and this town remained a muddy pond today after its levee failed.

title: Iranian Official Says All Hostages May Be Freed Within 10 Months
description: Iran's First Deputy Foreign Minister said today that the chances of freedom for American and other Western hostages held in Lebanon have never been brighter. On the basis of his observations during a recent trip to Beirut, he predicted that they could be released within 10 months.

title: Fast-Acting Celtics Crush Nets, 122-106
description: Futility, a constant companion of the Nets, appeared early today.

title: IN-FIGHTING DISRUPTS MEETING OF FRENCH SOCIALISTS
description: With five years still to go before France's next presidential elections, a crucial congress of the Socialist Party ended in disarray today with bitter in-fighting between aspirants hoping to succeed President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Mandate for Unity 'as Soon as Possible'
description: In their surprising endorsement of a conservative alliance led by the Christian Democrats, the East Germans declared loudly that, as a young voter named Susanna Frank put it, ''We should get out of this mess as soon as possible.''

title: Thousands Gather In Taiwan to Press Democratic Cause
description: Thousands of protesters rallied in a downtown park today to demand swifter democratic change and to denounce elderly members of the electoral college that will choose Taiwan's President this week.

title: Question Box
description: Bevo Francis the Pro

title: Johnstown Savings Bank reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
description: b-Included $12 million of year-end charges, including $7.5 million loss on securities designated for sale and $2.5 million of additional provisions for losses on loans and real estate. c-Included $5,134,000 provision for additions to loan loss reserves.

title: Walter S. Mack, Who Made Pepsi The No. 2 Cola Maker, Dies at 94
description: Walter S. Mack, the former president of Pepsi-Cola who made it the nation's No. 2 cola drink in the early 1940's, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: Boston Thieves Loot a Museum Of Masterpieces
description: Dressed as police officers, thieves broke into the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here early this morning and made off with 12 priceless artworks, including paintings by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Degas and Manet.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 19, 1990:

title: Beauticontrol Cosmetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The L.I.R.R.: The Line Riders Love to Hate
description: Here is what more than 272,000 riders on the Long Island Rail Road put up with every day: They rush to catch their trains, stand when there are no seats, bear unexplained delays, suffer late trains and brave shabby stations.

title: Strike Closes West Bank Stores and Schools
description: Masked Palestinians armed with axes and knives roamed a West Bank town today to enforce a strike called to protest United States plans for preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, Arab reports said.

title: Review/Concert;   At Fisher, a Group From Beethoven's Hometown
description: With the inexorable movement toward reunification of Germany, Bonn's days as a national capital appear to be numbered. As the birthplace of Beethoven, however, the city retains an older, subtler distinction, which it continues to wear proudly despite the awkward fact that the composer high-tailed it permanently to the headier musical atmosphere of Vienna at the age of 21. A Beethoven Society was among Bonn's purveyors of orchestral music during the last century, and when the city built a new, acoustically innovative hall for its municipal orchestra in 1959, it called it the Beethovenhalle and renamed the orchestra to suit.

title: Arden International Kitchens reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Investment Bankers Play Football's Newest Position
description: There was an extra player in the huddle when the National Football League prepared for its contract negotiations with the televison networks: an investment banker.

title: Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Grasping Stardom At Age 17
description: ONE of hockey's brightest hopes for the future could be seen in one of hockey's darkest rituals during a Junior A match between the Oshawa Generals and the Hamilton Dukes on a chilly March night in southern Ontario.

title: Abortion And Capital Punishment.
description: For the eighth consecutive year, Gov. Mario Cuomo has vetoed a bill that would have returned capital punishment to New York. In the last seven, his veto has been narrowly upheld.

title: New Bid for Protection By U.S. Textile Lobby
description: Afraid that the Bush Administration will give away too much during international negotiations, the domestic textile industry is preparing another legislative push during this election year seeking import restrictions.

title: Home Federal Savings Bank of Ga.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Robert Mitchell Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Georgetown Shocked by Xavier, 74-71
description: Everybody practices shooting. The Xavier players practice fouling and getting away with it. They did it masterfully today in a 74-71 victory over Georgetown in the Midwest Regional of the national collegiate basketball tournament.

title: Florida Employers Insurance reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year results included increases to claim reserves for its 1987 and 1988 policy years totaling $8.5 million.

title: Laurention Bank Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Mayflower Co-operative reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Adults and Child, 4, Are Slain in Bridgeport
description: A four-year-old child and two adults were found dead with gunshot wounds to the head in an apartment here late Saturday, the police said yesterday.

title: Custom Replays
description: THE day is probably not very far off when if you want to take a look at a particular play from a particular major league game a few seasons back, you'll simply hit a couple of keys on your remote compu-video control panel and sit back as the play unfolds before your eyes on your super-high-definition, wall-size, flat-panel, three-dimensional-display video screen. (The hard part, given the current labor dispute, could be getting a live game on your screen.) Or maybe you'd like to see, in sequence from the first-base camera angle, every swing a certain player made one season against left-handed pitchers with a 2-2 count in the late innings of road games against first division teams. Push-push, click-click, the swings scroll forth one after another in living color.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Magazine Plan By 5 Papers
description: Five big daily newspapers have teamed up to market a Sunday magazine, called Entertaining.

title: Plans for Wheeling Steel
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, which has operated under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since 1985, will file two plans for reorganizing its debts by April 3, lawyers for the company said last week. Lawyers who attended a bankruptcy hearing, which ended late Thursday, said one plan would come from the company's management and creditors, including a New York investment banker, Ronald LaBow. The second plan will be drawn up by a shareholder committee headed by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Modatech Systems reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Barons Oil reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $638,746. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $567,962 and an extraordinary charge of $9,100,575. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Syracuse Stops Virginia, 63-61
description: Syracuse withstood a boisterous enemy crowd, an emotional performance by the Virginia players for their departing coach and all the wacky bounces the basketball took late in the game this afternoon to win, 63-61, in Southeast Regional play at the Richmond Coliseum.

title: Review/Concert;   2 Operatic Sopranos Keep the Spirit in Spirituals
description: When Sir Michael Tippett, modeling his oratorio ''A Child of Our Time'' (1941) after Bach's Passions, sought a contemporary counterpart of the Lutheran chorale, universal for the age in significance and appeal, he found it in the American black spiritual. The English composer thus affirmed what had already become apparent: that the spiritual, popular throughout the 19th century but largely displaced in black churches in this century by gospel music, is destined to survive as a sort of classical music, remote from its original function of comforting or perhaps subtly inciting an oppressed population.

title: Nobel Prize Money Increased
description: The money awarded to Nobel Prize recipients is being raised to $653,000 from $489,000, the head of the Nobel Foundation was quoted as saying today. The foundation is hoping to return the ultimate value of the award to what it was worth in 1901, when it was created by Alfred Nobel, said the official, Stig Ramel.

title: BSD Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said its financial statements have been restated to reflect the October 1989 suspension of its Ultrathermics Inc. subsidiary's operations.

title: Devils Confident After Good Trip
description: The Devils are overflowing with confidence. Two victories on a three-game road trip have strengthened their hold on second place and brought them closer to the Rangers in the Patrick Division.

title: Vertex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: OPEC Sees Need to Add More Output
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a weekend meeting here today with a consensus emerging that worldwide demand for oil is rising fast enough to require investments in new production by the middle of this decade.

title: The Japanese Are Working Themselves to Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Moniterm Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 400 Honor Seegers' Folk Protests
description: The songs of a half century of political protest punctuated the stillness here today as folk singers and friends of Pete and Toshi Seeger gathered in a downtown neighborhood center to mark a special occasion.

title: Hibernia Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The bank revised its fourth quarter results after its management determined that an additional loan loss provision was necessitated by a change in circumstances, concerning two extensions of credit. The bank previously reported fourth quarter net income of $415 and full year net of $615,611, or 77 cents a share.

title: U.S. Found Lagging in Children's Well-Being
description: Children in the United States are more likely than children in 11 other industrialized countries to live in poverty, to live with only one parent or to be killed before they reach the age of 25, according to a Government report released today.

title: Granite Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: BankAtlantic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,331,000 on sale of Federal Home Loan Bank advances. c-Net income

title: Microlog Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Samuel H. Friedman, 93, Editor And Ex-Socialist Party Candidate
description: Samuel H. Friedman, who was twice the Socialist Party's candidate for Vice President, died on Saturday after a bout with pneumonia. He was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Now, Convertible Skates
description: Athletes can switch from ice-skating in the winter to roller-skating in the spring with the same pair of boots, using recently introduced skating components.

title: Making a TV Film of the Book 'Common Ground'
description: How do you make a two-part television series out of a 659-page book about race and class in America? You do it by zeroing in on its human dramas and reconstructing Boston in Toronto because it's less expensive to film there and because Boston wouldn't allow make-believe demonstrations.

title: Computer System Intruder Plucks Passwords and Avoids Detection
description: A computer intruder has written a program that has entered dozens of computers in a nationwide network in recent weeks, automatically stealing electronic documents containing users' passwords and erasing files to help conceal itself.

title: American Shared Hospital Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $569,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and included an extraordinary gain of $300,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. Latest year loss included a previously announced $1,500,000 reduction in the net book value of Five Mobile CT and MRI Systems in the third quarter.

title: Syria Is Willing to Talk to Israel, Carter Says
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, who arrived here after meeting with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria in Damascus, told Israeli officials today that Syria was willing to hold peace talks with Israel.

title: American Fedl Savings (Duval County) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter results reflected a charge of $347,300 made to increase the specific loan loss provision established for a loan secured by a Fort Walton Beach, Fla., shopping center.

title: PARENTS SEE GIRL IN CUSTODY FIGHT
description: Hilary Foretich, the 7-year-old girl who was sent into hiding from an American court and her father, has seen him and her mother for the first time in more than two and a half years.

title: Skylink America reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included about $350,000 of depreciation and amortization charges. c-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Y.&.R. Loses Heublein
description: Heublein Inc., the alcohol importer, and Young & Rubicam have parted company. Y.&.R. had the accounts for Finlandia vodka, Jose Cuervo tequila and Inglenook wine. Estimated billings were about $7 million.

title: New and Renewed: Opera Houses Open in Paris and Brazil;   Arias Grace the Amazon Once Again
description: The glow of a French chandelier dimmed, black-tie patrons settled into chairs upholstered with wine-red velvet, and soon the clear Italian syllables of a soprano aria were heard once again in the Amazon.

title: National Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The bank said its provision for loan losses was $26.5 million, down from $37.5 million a year earlier. It said its net income from regular operations, excluding the impact of sovereign loans, was $75.1 million, down from $78.7 million a year earlier. The year-earlier figure included $7 million of gains from the sale of securities. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Mortgage Delinquencies
description: The delinquency rate for home mortgages held steady in the final three months of 1989 after jumping sharply in the previous quarter, a trade group said last week. The group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said a seasonally adjusted 4.99 percent of mortgage payments on homes that house up to four families were late by 30 days or more. That compares with 5 percent in the July-September period. The foreclosure rate edged down in the fourth quarter, to 0.98 percent, from 0.99 percent in the previous quarter.

title: New Chapter in Yankee Saga
description: Yankee fans who hoped that last year's amicable settlement was the last dreary chapter in the long and distracting dispute between George Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield were inflicted with a rancorous epilogue yesterday.

title: German Car Makers Defend Status
description: When the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company began shaping plans to make luxury cars, one of the first things they did was to buy several Mercedes-Benz and BMW autos and meticulously dissect them.

title: Altus Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its decrease in losses for 1989 compared with 1988 resulted from decreases in provision of loans and real estate, and non-interest expenses of $9.8 million and $3.4 million, respectively, being partially offset by a $10.2 million decrease in net interest income.

title: Karen Schlesinger Weds Gary Yablon
description: The marriage of Karen Joan Schlesinger to Gary Howard Yablon took place last evening at the Park East Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated.

title: Cognitronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $273,000, or 12 cents a share. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $195,000 and $396,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: White-Collar Boxers in Fight Gyms
description: LEAD: THOSE who exercise regularly sometimes want a more interesting or varied routine.

title: Family Steak Houses of Fla.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $146,500, or 2 cents a share, from a change in accounting for deferred income taxes. Results in the latest fourth quarter included a gain of $146,800 from the sale of land and a one-time expense of $53,000 for financial and investment banking services. Fourth quarter 1989 earnings were also negatively affected by an $83,600 loss in the Rustic Inn joint venture, which arose primarily as a result of expenses incurred in opening and operating losses of a new Rustic Inn in Orlando, Fla. in November 1989.

title: Changing Spirit at Random House
description: Two months ago, Alberto Vitale took the wheel of the Cadillac of American publishing, Random House. From the outside, this majestic vehicle for the best in books -from James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' its first big commercial success in the 1930's, to E. L. Doctorow's ''Billy Bathgate,'' a recent best seller - looked as smooth and stable as ever. But stability has suddenly given way to bumpiness, and some wonder where the Cadillac is heading.

title: MHP Machines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Nooney Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jan Rowland Is Married
description: Jan Rowland was married yesterday in Canberra, Australia, to Calvin Michael Konner, the first secretary at the United States Embassy in Canberra. The civil ceremony took place at the home of the American Ambassador, Melvin F. Sembler, in Yarralumla, a suburb of Canberra. The bride, 38 years old, is an art instructor at Daramalan College in Canberra. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rowland of Destiny Springs in New South Wales, Australia. Her husband, 42, is the son of Bernice Konner of Brooklyn and the late Sol Konner.

title: First Amarillo Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $111,000, or 4 cents a share, from tax loss carryforward. c-After an extraordinary credit of $774,111, or 27 cents a share, which included gain of $140,000 from early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $525,000 from tax loss carryforward. d-After an extraordinary credit of $1,194,570, or 42 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Trump Plaza Hotel Gives Account to Babbit
description: The Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City has moved its advertising account from the Baltimore agency Van Sant Dugdale Advertising to the New York office of Babbit & Reiman Advertising.

title: Many Doctors Recommend Disputed AIDS Drug
description: Many doctors say they are advising their patients with AIDS to keep taking an experimental drug whose safety has been questioned by some AIDS researchers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Job for Lintas
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation awarded the account for its Consumer Specialty division lines of personal and home care products to Lintas:New York. The account, which bills an estimated $10 million, was formerly handled by Chiat/Day/Mojo and Campbell-Mithun-Esty.

title: McRae Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
First Essex Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Writers Guild of America gave its annual awards last night on both coasts. Actually, the guild has East and West Coast branches, which give awards separately and national awards together. If that seems confusing, consider that ART BUCHWALD got an award from the East Coast guild on the West Coast. Then, he went to the West Coast branch's dinner in Beverly Hills at the Beverly Hilton Hotel.

title: Risa Uvlin Weds Jeffrey W. Davis
description: Risa Faith Uvlin was married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue to Jeffrey William Davis. Rabbi Saul J. Berman performed the ceremony.

title: 'Model Minority' Label Taxes Asian Youths
description: Zhe Zeng, an 18-year-old junior at Seward Park High School in lower Manhattan, translates the term ''model minority'' to mean that Asian-Americans are terrific in math and science. Mr. Zeng is terrific in math and science, but he insists that his life is no model for anyone.

title: Japan Venture Set by Texas Instruments
description: In the latest move in a trend toward American-Japanese alliances in microelectronics, the most successful United States semiconductor maker in Japan, Texas Instruments Inc., said today that it would form a joint venture with Kobe Steel Ltd.

title: Text of Soviet Statement Warning Lithuania Against Breaking With Moscow
description: Following is the text of the Soviet Government's statement yesterday on Lithuania, as provided by the English-language service of the official press agency Tass:

title: California Pension Plan
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System has for the first time allocated money to invest in corporate restructurings and venture-capital funds. The system, the largest public pension fund in the United States, with assets worth more than $55 billion, will allocate up to $1 billion to invest in projects with a typical lifespan of about five years. The system is using the Pacific Corporate Group of La Jolla, Calif., to find suitable investments.

title: Arizona Instrument Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Interview for Penders
description: Tom Penders, the University of Texas coach, who has led his Longhorns to the Midwest Regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, has agreed to a formal interview for the vacant coaching job at the University of Florida, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday.

title: Norman L. Spelke, 79, Ex-Banker in Stamford
description: Norman L. Spelke, a retired Connecticut banker, died of Alzheimer's disease on Thursday at the John Douglas French Center in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Laguna Hills.

title: Officeland Inc. reports earnings for Year Nov 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $330,981 and after an extraordinary credit of $786,889, or 7 cents a share. c-Net loss included a loss of $1,742,693 from discontinued operations and after an extraordinary loss of $2,975,136. Share earnings reflected a 3-for-1 stock split which took effect on Feb. 9, 1990.

title: Terence C. Langetieg, Executive, 41
description: Dr. Terence C. Langetieg, a vice president in the research department at Salomon Brothers Inc., died of cancer yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 41 years old and lived in New Providence, N.J.

title: After Early Struggles, Celtics Moving Up
description: Red Auerbach was once asked why the Boston Celtics were constantly under scrutiny. The Celtic president thought awhile and said: ''Our winning tradition. Anything that we do, good or bad, is magnified more because of who we are and what we have done.''

title: Graphic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: National Western Life Ins reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The 1988 periods were restated.

title: Possis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Bailout Cost Seen Rising
description: Financing for the bailout of the savings and loan industry will be at least $30 billion and possibly as much as $162 billion short of the amount needed, a Congressional report said today Legislation enacted in August provided $50 billion to close or sell failed savings associations through 1992. But $48 billion of that will be needed to cover losses at the 383 institutions seized by the Government through March 5, said the report, which was submitted by Representative Bruce F. Vento, Democrat of Minnesota. Mr. Vento is chairman of an 18-member House Banking Committee group tracking the performance of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created to oversee the bailout.

title: A Colorful Lacroix, a Younger Chanel and More
description: Fashion, sometimes magical and sometimes mad, kept pouring down the runways in the last few days as the heavy hitters came up to bat. The avant-garde designers were more controlled, the established houses more lavish as the fall and winter ready-to-wear openings entered their second week.

title: Nike Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
White House Resisting Further Pentagon Cuts
description: The White House said today that it was not willing to accept major cuts in its proposal for the military budget in the fiscal year 1991 and that it believes it has already offered Congress adequate reductions.

title: Norwegian Union Raises
description: Norway's main union organization agreed last week to a basic 4 percent pay increase in 1990 as a result of central wage negotiations. The deal was in line with the Government's aim to keep wage increases at or below the rate of inflation. When talks opened a week ago, the Norwegian Federation of Trade Unions initially demanded an increase of up to 5 percent for its 350,000 members.

title: Derailed Car Stops Transit To Queens
description: Rail service between Manhattan and Queens was shut down for several hours last night, stranding tens of thousands of riders as workers cautiously re-railed a freight car containing 33,000 gallons of liquid propane that had jumped the tracks in Queens.

title: Pride in Fur Is Promoted By Alaskans
description: Alaska natives who depend on trapping for their livelihood plan to market native-made fur products to counter the animal rights movement's campaign against wearing fur.

title: VALDEZ SPILL JURY FACES 2 QUESTIONS
description: From its beginnings as a case of many issues, the trial of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood has come down to just two central questions: Was he drunk on the night last March 24 when his tanker, the Exxon Valdez, ran aground on a reef in Prince William Sound? And was he reckless to leave the bridge and go to his quarters just before the grounding?

title: Aetna Suit Tries to Stop Claims by New Jersey
description: An insurance company began a legal battle today to block state plans to recoup millions of dollars officials claim private insurers owe to the Joint Underwriting Association.

title: NASA Defends Space Station Building Plans
description: The space agency denied yesterday that unusually high maintenance and repair needs would jeopardize construction of the proposed $30 billion space station Freedom.

title: Saint Laurent Enters Hospital to Rest
description: Yves Saint Laurent entered the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine on Saturday afternoon and will not be at his fashion show on Wednesday for the first time since he opened his house in 1962. His physician, Dr. Michael Prendeville, said the designer had suffered a major nervous collapse and had been advised to rest for several weeks.

title: Jayark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Corrections
description: An article on March 10 about the West Virginia teachers' strike misstated Mississippi's rank among the 50 states and the District of Columbia in teachers' annual salary. It is 45th, not 51st.

title: Upgrading Education Begins in the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: Three D Departments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Arch Petroleum Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Allstate Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
By the Tallis Scholars
description: Victoria's Requiem is among the works to be sung by the Tallis Scholars at a presentation of music from the Spanish Renaissance on March 28 at 8 P.M. at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th Street. Sponsored by Gotham Early Music and Concerts at St. Mary's, the concert is also to feature works by Francisco Guerrero and Cristobal de Morales. Tickets are $15 and $20. Information: 921-2939.

title: Cooper Development Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HRE Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains on the sale of properties of $124,000, or 2 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $121,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: John D. Niles, 55, Dies; Partner in a Law Firm
description: John Denison Niles, a partner in the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton in Manhattan , died of pancreatic failure, a complication of AIDS, yesterday at New York University Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Orofino Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Throw Out The First Microwave
description: In taking so long to agree on their labor treaty, the club owners and the players have invented microwave baseball. Put the pitchers and the hitters in spring training for less than three weeks, set the timer for only two weeks of exhibition games, then hope their arms and bats are heated properly by April 9 when the season starts. Instead of a celebrity throwing out the first ball at each opener, somebody should throw out the first microwave.

title: Greenstone Rabasca Roberts reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago comparative figures are not provided because the company went public on Feb. 10, 1989.

title: Venmar Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $112,322, or 2 cents a share. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $6,190,815. The company said it completed the sale of its F.P. Inc. unit to a group fo F.P. Inc. managers for $1,637,360. The 1988 results were restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: PHLcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $880,000, or 6 cents a share, from discontinued operations. The latest year's income from continuing operations included restructuring costs of about $5.4 million.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Dealers in Treasury securities took some profits yesterday following the rally on Friday, but overall prices were narrowly mixed in sluggish trading as traders awaited reports due this morning on consumer prices and the merchandise trade deficit.

title: Airport Drug Efforts Snaring Innocents Who Fit 'Profiles'
description: After a long flight from a vacation in his native Nigeria, a young man who is a legal United States resident and who works as a pharmacist here retrieved his bags and headed for what he thought would be a routine walk through the customs check at Intercontinental Airport.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's election to the new Soviet presidency referred incorrectly to his vote percentage. The 59 figure was his percentage among the members of Congress, whether voting or not.

title: 2 Drug Concerns In Product Accord
description: The XOMA Corporation, a therapeutic products company in Berkeley, Calif., and Ortho Biotech, a division of the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, will develop two products for treating immune-related diseases. The products are designed to eliminate specific disease-related cells without causing harm to other cells. The products can be used with grafts and organ transplants.

title: Albatross Wanders Far Afield
description: By attaching radio beacons to wandering albatrosses and monitoring them by satellite, French researchers have found that circular foraging flights by the birds sometimes exceed 9,300 miles, more than eight times the distance that had been assumed. In some cases they cover 560 miles a day.

title: Partech Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $226,054. c-After extraordinary credits of $32,666, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $89,998, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Rig Count Falls in Week
description: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs declined by 15 last week, to a total of 908, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The decrease conforms to previous first quarters when the count generally was in decline, said Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist at Baker Hughes. The count remains well ahead of the 1989 tally at this period.

title: Red Sox To Throw The First Pitch
description: To their surprise, the Boston Red Sox will have the belated honor of throwing out the first ball on Opening Day of 1990, when they face the Detroit Tigers at Fenway Park at 1:05 P.M. on April 9.

title: Footprints in the Sands of Time
description: When people die, their histories usually die with them. A favored few may be the subject of biographies or the authors of autobiographies, and others may leave notes on their lives or have information collected by diligent descendants. But these are exceptions.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page yesterday about advance sales of television advertising misidentified the network that is developing a comedy series based on the film ''Big.'' It is CBS.

title: Back to Work With Mixed Views
description: Baseball people generally avoided biting the hand that feeds them as they returned to work today after a 32-day lockout that resulted in a high-priced new basic agreement between the 26 clubs and their 1,040 players.

title: Talking Business; with Blaydon of Amos Tuck;   Easing the Cost Of M.B.A. Degree
description: After seven years as dean of the Amos Tuck Graduate School of Business at Dartmouth College, Colin C. Blaydon announced recently that he would step down to write and consult. A nationally recognized expert on corporate governance, Professor Blaydon is also interested in the future of management education. His comments in a recent telephone interview follow:

title: Ralph G. Gulley, 87, Architect and Ex-Dean
description: Ralph G. Gulley, founder and first dean of the School of Architecture at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., died of heart failure on Sunday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Higgins of Michigan To Enter N.B.A. Draft
description: Sean Higgins, a junior on the University of Michigan basketball team, said yesterday that he would declare himself eligible for the National Basketball Asssociation's June draft.

title: U.S. Judge Cleared of Obstructing Justice but Faces a Retrial
description: In the first prosecution of its kind, Federal District Judge Robert P. Aguilar was found not guilty today of one count of obstruction of justice, but the jury could not reach a verdict on seven other counts, including racketeering.

title: In Detroit, a Drug Recovery Center That Welcomes the Pregnant Addict
description: The Eleonore Hutzel Recovery Center here admits patients whom other hospitals and treatment programs avoid: pregnant addicts.

title: Riverbend International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: First quarter 1990 results included accrual of about $264,000 for estimated costs associated with the closing of its fresh fruit packing facility in Weslaco, Tex.

title: Plains Resources reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Figures reflected a 1-for-5 reverse stock split effected Feb. 16. The company's net income in latest year is translated to a loss per share of 6 cents because of the inclusion in the primary per share calculation of accumulated but undeclared 1989 dividends on the company's $1.30 cumulative convertible preferred stock.

title: Biologists Identify 'Impresario' of Life In Vitamin A
description: The question of how a single fertilized egg blossoms into a complete human infant is one of the magnificent puzzles of biology, and scientists are just beginning to pinpoint the key genes and molecules that direct the intricate unfolding. But in a rush of new experiments, researchers have made the surprising discovery that one of those crucial impresario molecules of life is not some exotic or arcane compound, but retinoic acid, a familiar derivative of vitamin A. Retinoic acid lately has won fame as the active ingredient in Retin-A cream, a treatment for acne and, more debatedly, the feathery wrinkles of age. The molecule also made news as the main component of Accutane, a more potent anti-acne drug that can cause extremely serious birth defects if women use it during pregnancy.

title: KOHL IS REPORTED INTENT ON SLOWING UNITY WITH EAST
description: Though the landslide victory by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political allies in East Germany demonstrated a yearning there for quick union, the Bonn Government now appears increasingly intent on following a slower and more cautious path to German reunification.

title: West Europe Leaders Voice Praise Plus Worry About German Election
description: Western European governments today hailed the results of the first free elections in East Germany in 40 years as a triumph of democracy, and worried nervously about what they meant.

title: U.S. Officials Say Outcome Promises to Benefit NATO
description: The Bush Administration today hailed the election in East Germany as a victory ''for all who support democratic values'' and some officials said it would increase the chances that a unified Germany would remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Dragon Introduces Voice 'Typewriter'
description: A Massachusetts technology company introduced what it said was the first commercially viable ''typewriter'' that operates by human speech instead of touch. Dragon Systems Inc. in Newton said its Dragon Dictate had a basic vocabulary of 30,000 words, with an 80,000-word dictionary built in as a backup, and could print out more than 40 words a minute when operated by an experienced user.

title: Thermwood Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Seabrook Nuclear Plant Doesn't Deserve License;   At the Energy Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Movie Process in Which the Screen Disappears
description: The company that makes movies to be shown on screens the size of a six-story building is about to introduce a film technology in which a wraparound screen seems to disappear and the audience experiences what is called ''total visual involvement.''

title: Gerber Charge Set
description: The Gerber Products Company said it would take an after-tax charge of $8.3 million, or 22 cents a share, against its fourth-quarter income to consolidate its Gerber Childrenswear business. The move will eliminate certain ''nonstrategic product lines and reduction of excess manufacturing capacity,'' the company said. The charge includes losses on the sale of three manufacturing plants, write-offs, employee termination costs and the liquidation of inventories.

title: MNX Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included losses from Intermodal operations of $1.1 million and $1.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Also included fourth quarter special charges for ESOP contribution of $1.9 million and combined loss on disposition of revenue equipment and adjustments to equipment depreciation of $4.1 million. c-Net income

title: CSP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Raven Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
At Pantheon Books, A Welfare Mentality
description: LEAD: It was pathetic, this rally in support of the welfare mentality.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bolt Beranek & Newman, Cambridge, Mass., a diversified high-technology corporation, appointed Charles H. Ide president of its BBN Systems and Technologies Corp. subsidiary. He replaces David C. Walden, who becomes a corporate senior vice president.

title: American Guaranty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected $39,000 loss from continuing operations for the quarter and a $84,000 gain from continuing operations for the year, and losses from discontinued operations of $15,000 and $118,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Reflected losses from continuing operations of $220,000 for the quarter and $383,000 for the year, and losses from discontinued operations of $488,000 and $2,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Chronicle
description: ROBERT H. BORK, whose rejection by the Senate in 1987 for a seat on the United States Supreme Court was regarded as a crucial political moment for Ronald Reagan, appeared at the Court today, this time as an advocate. Mr. Bork represented Citibank, which is asking the Court to rule that it is not liable for repaying two $1 million certificates of deposit issued by its Manila branch in 1983 to a Singapore subsidiary of the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco.

title: A Lucrative Crime Grows Into a Costly Epidemic
description: The theft at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on Sunday is the largest and latest in what art experts and law enforcement authorities are calling an epidemic of art thefts. Spurred by soaring art prices and the increasing resourcefulness of thieves, art theft now ranks as one of the most lucrative forms of crime, they say.

title: A.M.A. Expels 31 Doctors
description: For the first time, the American Medical Association is revoking the membership of doctors who have been convicted of felonies, sold illegal drugs or otherwise behaved unethically. The association recently revoked the membership of 31 physicians, the group's general counsel, Kirk Johnson, said.

title: Whitehall Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Where Balloons Fail In Clearing Arteries, New Devices May Help
description: Researchers are working on more than two dozen new devices that are designed to clear heart arteries by cutting, drilling, burning or pulverizing obstructions.

title: Nanette Guilford, Met Opera Singer, Voice Teacher, 86
description: Nanette Guilford, a soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera from 1923 to 1932, died of an intestinal infection on Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Registering in California
description: To the Editor:

title: C.F.T.C. Set for Review, Chief Says
description: The Federal agency that regulates commodity futures says it is ready to review its role in that market with politicians and rivals bent on clipping its authority.

title: Televideo Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Year-ago figures included a loss of $53,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Baker Outlines Aid to Foes of Apartheid
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the Bush Administration would like to use the National Endowment for Democracy to channel political and electoral advice to the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups in South Africa as it did in helping Solidarity in Poland and the opposition parties in Nicaragua.

title: Moses Shapiro, 79, A Retired Executive And a Lawyer, Dies
description: Moses Shapiro, retired chairman and chief executive of the General Instrument Corporation, died of complications after surgery yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.

title: Multifoods Filling By Archer-Daniels
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the giant grain company based in Decatur, Ill., has acquired 6.7 percent of the International Multifoods Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Archer-Daniels-Midland said it had acquired the shares of the Minneapolis-based company for investment purposes. A Multifoods spokesman could not be reached for comment. The company has 12.8 million shares outstanding.

title: The Stuff Political Dreams Are Made On
description: Willie L. Brown Jr., Speaker of the California General Assembly, did not have to tell the 1,000 well-to-do donors to the Democratic cause why seven United States Senators had rushed here from Washington to join them for a chicken dinner in early March.

title: Pretoria Trust Fund Aims at Black Social Ills
description: The Government has set aside $780 million, nearly 3 percent of its annual spending, for a trust fund that will seek the participation of the African National Congress and other black groups in attacking housing, education and other problems in South Africa's black townships.

title: Chronicle
description: Mr. Wiesel won a more personal battle yesterday, when DONALD T. REGAN agreed to withdraw a charge of duplicity in his memoirs, ''For the Record,'' in exchange for Mr. Wiesel's dropping the threat of a $10 million lawsuit. The former White House chief of staff wrote that Mr. Wiesel went on television in 1985 to plead that President Ronald Reagan not visit the Bitburg military cemetery in West Germany, where Nazi Waffen SS officers are buried. Mr. Regan said Mr. Wiesel had promised him he would not make a televised statement.

title: U.S. Cellular Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Deadly Toadstools
description: Q. How does toadstool poison kill?

title: Continental Homes Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from early retirement of debt of $162,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $507,000, or 14 cents a share, which included gains of $325,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change for income taxes and $182,000 from early retirement of debt. The company said the latest third quarter included about $590,000 of pretax profit from the company's California joint ventures compared to $628,000 for the year-ago third quarter.

title: Review/Music;   All-German Program by the Melos Quartet
description: The Melos Quartet, one of the most durable and worthwhile of West Germany's string ensembles in the postwar era, came back to New York on Sunday afternoon. Their all-German program at Alice Tully Hall offered Mendelssohn's Capriccio for String Quartet, the Schumann Third Quartet and the Brahms Second.

title: Seaman Furniture Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reflected $200 million writeoff of goodwill, a $30.8 million gain on the settlement of debt in connection with a restructuring, and $400,000 in restructuring costs. c-The company did not provide comparable figures. Seaman went public in 1988.

title: Manufactured Homes reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $2,958,000 for the latest year and $1,776,000 for 1988.

title: Suspect's Parents Testify in L.I. Murder Trial
description: The father of the man accused of killing 13-year-old Kelly Ann Tinyes and then hiding her body in his family's basement, testified today that a side door of the family home was broken and could have been opened with a hard push.

title: Whitman To Focus on Food, Bottling
description: The Whitman Corporation announced today that it planned to sharpen its focus on food and soft drinks by selling the Hussmann Corporation, a food-service equipment maker. Whitman's board said the proceeds would be used to reduce the company's $1.8 billion debt and to pursue soft drink bottling or food industry acquisitions.

title: A Co-op in India Thrives Off Snakes and Rats
description: It is harvest season in the grain fields along the Coromandel coast, and that means boom time for the Irula snake and rat catchers' cooperative.

title: Panama Asks Payments for Arms Seized by U.S. Troops in Invasion
description: Panama's new Government, strapped for cash and impatient with delays in aid promised by the Bush Administration, is demanding compensation for large arms caches seized by American troops in the December invasion.

title: Japan Loan Rate Lifted Sharply
description: Under heavy pressure from the turmoil in the stock market and a weak yen, the Bank of Japan ended weeks of speculation by announcing here at midday that it was raising its official discount rate a steep one percentage point, to 5.25 percent, its highest level since 1981.

title: Books of The Times;   He Spoke of Art, but Made His Money in Movies
description: Ben Hecht

title: Libya Says Several Are Held In Rabta Chemical Plant Fire
description: Libya's Ambassador to Italy said today that several people had been detained in connection with the fire last week at a chemical plant that Washington says made chemical weapons.

title: Market Place;   New Challenges Confront Conrail
description: AFTER years of uncertainty, huge cuts in manpower and the elimination of many unprofitable operations, the Consolidated Rail Corporation is heading for more stable times.

title: Brazil Leader's Inflation Plan Wins Him High Credit Rating
description: Shirt open to the sun, Manoel Joaquim de Oliveira paused from selling papayas to give his thoughts on Brazil's No. 1 conversation topic: the new Government's radical anti-inflation program.

title: SOVIET INSURGENTS VOTED INTO POWER IN THE 3 MAIN CITIES
description: The emerging political opposition scored a series of triumphs across the Soviet Union in election results released today, winning majorities over the Communists in the Moscow, Leningrad and Kiev City Councils and electing significant numbers of insurgents in republic Parliaments.

title: Nicklaus in Senior Open
description: Jack Nicklaus, who earlier this year became eligible for the Senior PGA Tour by turning 50 years old, has agreed to play in the United States Senior Open, the United States Golf Association announced yesterday. The 1990 Open will be played June 28-July 1 at the Ridgewood (N.J.) Country Club.

title: BIGGER BUDGET GAP IS SEEN BY DINKINS AS TAX MONEY LAGS
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that New York City faces an additional budget gap of at least $700 million for the fiscal year that starts on July 1. He ordered city agencies to prepare $500 million more in cuts that would severely trim services, and said more new taxes would be needed.

title: West Virginia Teachers and Pupils Back in Class
description: Thousands of teachers and students returned to classes today for the first time in nearly two weeks, ending West Virginia's first statewide teacher strike but leaving the issue of wages unsettled.

title: Help for Macintosh Graphics
description: Apple Computer Inc. formally introduced a powerful new member of the Macintosh family today, the Macintosh IIfx. It is Apple's first work station, a category intended for demanding uses like computer-aided engineering and design, scientific modeling and complex financial analysis.

title: Valley Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Seabrook Nuclear Plant Doesn't Deserve License;   Save Conversion Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo, Under Fiscal Pressure, Floats Idea to Raise Gas Tax
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, under pressure to take firm action to solve the state's financial problems, today proposed raising New York's gasoline tax for the first time in 18 years.

title: Circus Circus Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-During the fourth quarter the company recognized a writeoff of about $1.4 million, related to the demolition of certain rooms and a resturant at the edgewater hotel and casino, as part of an expansion project involving a 988-room tower for both the quarter and year. c-Included a gain from cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change of $9,235,000, or 29 cents a share.

title: Transcisco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,127,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,819,000, or 86 cents a share. Year-ago 12 months' results included a gain from the sale of a subsidiary of $3.8 million.

title: Navigators Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Manhattan Legislator To Lead Schools Panel
description: A heated internal battle over the selection of a new head of the influential Assembly Education Committee has concluded with the selection of Angelo Del Toro, a Manhattan Democrat, legislative officials said today.

title: Steego Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $494,000 and $1,492,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,232,000 and $2,135,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest 9 months' income from continuing operations included a gain of $8.4 million from the sale of the company's agri-equipment replacement parts business and a loss of $2.6 million from the sale of its U.S. automotive replacement parts operations. Year-ago 9 months' loss from continuing operations included a gain of $1.4 million from the sale of a Canadian property.

title: Mr. Kohl's Divisive Appeal for Unity
description: Voting in their first free election since 1932, East Germans commendably turned out en masse to register their desire for a quick, sharp break with their Communist past. They threw their support behind right-of-center parties backed by West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who held out hope that rapid unification soon would bring economic prosperity.

title: After 25 Years of One-Party Rule, 3-Way L.I. Race
description: After a quarter-century of one-party rule, this waterfront village in Nassau County is engulfed in a hotly contested three-way race for Village Hall.

title: Greyhound Vows No New Talks In Strike Until Bus Attacks Cease
description: Officials of Greyhound Lines Inc. said today they would not resume talks with striking drivers until attacks on buses and replacement drivers stop, but a union leader pledged to meet any time with company negotiators.

title: Tacoma Boatbuilding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included those of United Shipbuilders of America from April 1, 1989.

title: Vicorp Restaurants Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 18
Unpredictable but Evenly Matched Contenders in the Final 16
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has produced some form of a men's Division I post-season basketball tournament for 51 years. Few of the tournaments, however, have been dotted by as many upsets and last-second heroics as the 1990 tournament, which moves into its round of 16 on Thursday and Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not an everyday theft.

title: Valley Forge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Interest Rate Drop Is Seen
description: Interest rates have peaked and should start falling this spring, a group of private economists predicted today.

title: On Horse Racing;   Waving a Big Goodbye To a Winter in Florida
description: rrIt has never been easier than it was today to wave farewell to the swaying palms and sunny beaches of another Florida winter. After this dark and disappointing season of racing at Gulfstream Park, the seagulls of Jamaica Bay seem to be beckoning sweetly, and returning to the usually dreary confines of Aqueduct sounds like a vacation.

title: Coca-Cola Report On Profit Margins
description: The Coca-Cola Company's profit margins widened last year in every region of the world except the home base in the United States, the company said in a report to shareholders. Coke's operating profits as a percentage of sales in the slow-growing American market eased to 11.6 percent in 1989, from 11.8 percent the previous year, the report said.

title: Congressional Races In Bronx and on S.I. To Be Decided Today
description: While it is a normal day for most New York City residents, people in two Congressional districts in the city will elect new representatives for interim terms today.

title: Almost Intact Mammoth Is Found
description: An almost intact baby mammoth, frozen for at least 12,000 years, has been found in Western Siberia, scientists have reported.

title: Cheney Blamed for Press Problems in Panama
description: A report commissioned by the Pentagon has concluded that an excessive concern for secrecy on the part of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney prevented reporters from covering crucial engagements in the invasion of Panama.

title: Anac Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 10
description: b-Included non-cash, pretax charge of $233 million (after-tax $185.2 million) to accrue for costs associated with Revco's previously reported program to divest 712 drug stores.

title: Review/Ballet;   San Francisco 'Sleeping Beauty' Underlines Russian Influences
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty'' is a century old this year, and the San Francisco Ballet has both celebrated its anniversary and given itself a whopping present of a box-office success with a dazzling new version of the grandest 19th-century ballet created by Tchaikovsky and Marius Petipa.

title: Hand Washing Reduces School Contagion Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: STIRLING MOSS, the former British race-car driver who won 222 races, including 16 Grand Prix events, suffered a broken thigh when he was hit by a car while riding his motor scooter in London yesterday. It may take six months for the 60-year-old former champion to recover from the injury. Mr. Moss, whose career began in 1950, said he was driving at 20 miles an hour, on a trip to the market to buy coriander. (AP)

title: Wind Of Change
description: A premise of political life in all the black countries of southern Africa has suddenly been thrown into question. It is the rooted belief that South Africa menaces the life of the country.

title: Official at MCI Retiring Again
description: V. Orville Wright is retiring from the office of chief executive of the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: African Group Agrees To Pretoria Contacts
description: The Organization of African Unity agreed today to begin direct contacts with the South African Government in an effort to find a peaceful end to apartheid.

title: Eagle Food Centers reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 3
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,296,000 from writeoff of deferred financing costs.

title: For U.S. Coach, Budapest Hits Close to Home
description: The traffic along the footpath was uncommonly heavy. Mothers and fathers with young children and strollers. Lovers arm in arm. A young couple reined to an oversize Dalmatian. Groups of teen-age boys following groups of teen-age girls. And vice versa.

Spelling Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

Xoma Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Xoma completed in November 1989 its merger with International Genetic Engineering Inc. The merger has been accounted for as a pooling of interests and, accordingly, these results included amounts for International Genetic for all periods presented.

title: Chronicle
description: World leaders, thinkers and Nobel laureates who have said they will participate this summer in an international conference on religious and ethnic hatred include JIMMY CARTER, VACLAV HAVEL, HENRY A. KISSINGER, MARIO VARGAS LLOSA, FRANCOIS MITTERRAND, LECH WALESA and ELIE WIESEL. The Nobel Institute and the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity are joining forces to stage the conference, ''Anatomy of Hatred: Resolving Conflict Through Dialogue and Democracy,'' from Aug. 26 to 29 in Oslo.

title: U.S. GIVES CONTRAS ULTIMATUM ON AID
description: The Bush Administration said today that the contras would have to lay down their weapons before the United States provides money to finance their return to civilian life in Nicaragua.

title: Humble Froth Offers Clues to Novel Materials
description: The humble soap bubble is guiding scientists in the creation of a new family of materials that are expected to touch off a revolution in technology.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Voters will fill two Congressional seats in special elections today. The winners serve only until the regularly scheduled general election in November, but whoever prevails today will have an advantage. The polls are open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. Here are our endorsements:

title: 76ers Climb Into First Place
description: The Philadelphia 76ers took over tonight's game in the fourth quarter, and they took over first place in the process.

title: Nike Profit Rises 29.3%
description: The athletic shoe and apparel giant Nike Inc. said today that its profit for its third fiscal quarter climbed 29.3 percent from a year earlier as its revenue jumped 24.4 percent. Nike said its profit totaled $63.1 million, or $1.67 a share, for its quarter ended Feb. 28, up from $48.8 million, or $1.30 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the most recent three-month period increased to $577.9 million from $464.7 million a year earlier.

title: Survival Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Really Useful Stake To Holmes a Court
description: The entertainment company Really Useful Group P.L.C. said the Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court had bought a 4.18 percent stake, threatening the plan of the British composer Andrew Lloyd Webber to take the company private. Mr. Lloyd Webber is offering 233 pence, or $3.75, a share, for the stock. He owns 82.5 percent of its 33.2 million shares. The bid values the company at $:77.4 million, or about $125 million.

title: Alpine Group reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains on extinguishment of debt of $45,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $13,921,000, or $2.84 a share, for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,598,000. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,617,000 and $4,379,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: Sculptor of Embryos

title: KEY RATES
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 18, about a speech by Deng Xiaoping to the committee drafting laws to govern Hong Kong after China takes control, misidentified the man at the right. A reader's letter, delayed in delivery, points out that he was Ji Dengkui, a former Deputy Foreign Minister, not Prime Minister Li Peng.

title: Chase Revises Plan
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced a revision to its dividend reinvestment and stock purchase plan to eliminate the purchase of shares at a 3 percent discount to market value. Chase offered to sell new shares at a discounted price in October 1989 to rebuild its equity capital after taking special losses from its loans to developing countries. Enough stock was bought through to plan to raise Chase's equity to about 4 percent of its assets, from a low of 3 percent in October.

title: Lost on Earth: Wealth of Data Found in Space
description: Scientists seeking to mine the huge trove of data gathered at great risk and expense in 30 years of space flight have found that much of it is so badly labeled or stored that extracting useful information can require years of ingenious detective work.

description: b-Included income of $27,000, or 1 cent a share,, for the quarter and a loss of $120,000 for the 9 monhts, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $77,000 and $147,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

Harry T. Morris, Executive, 75
description: Harry T. Morris, a magazine executive, died on Friday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Stamford, Conn., after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

description: b-Net income

title: Trans World Music reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Consolidate Norex reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.
