description: b-Net income and after extraordinary credits of $688,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,336,000, or 6 cents a share, for the 6 months. The company said the decrease in second-quarter and 6-month revenue from year-ago periods was due to a reduction in programming available for distribution.

title: Administration Seeks $47 Billion To Upgrade the Aviation System
description: In an effort to break the tightening gridlock at the nation's airports, the Bush Administration today proposed spending $47 billion to upgrade and operate the nation's aviation system over the next five years.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS

title: An Edge for Incumbents: Loopholes That Pay Off
description: In his first term in office, Representative Greg Laughlin, Democrat of Texas, has learned how business is done on Capitol Hill. Lobbyists calling on the Congressman often stroll past the desk of a senior aide and drop off campaign contributions of as much as $10,000.

title: Police Say Their Chinatown Sting Ties Mob to the Garment Industry
description: On the surface, the loft was just another noisy garment factory in Chinatown with 25 women hunched over sewing machines at a company run by six supervisors.

title: COMPANY NEWSB.P. to Reduce Staff by 1,150
description: The British Petroleum Company said today that it was cutting 1,150 jobs, or nearly half the staff, at its London headquarters in a reorganization intended to lower costs and make the oil giant more flexible.

title: German Losers Reject Victor's Invitation
description: After their election victory on Sunday, the Christian Democrats invited the Social Democrats and liberals today to discuss forming a broadly based coalition government with their Alliance for Germany, but the Social Democrats rejected the idea.

title: Poland to Get U.S. Corn
description: Poland will get United States corn instead of butter as initially announced under President Bush's $100 million food-aid package, the Agriculture Department said today. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said 173,225 metric tons of surplus corn would be donated to Poland instead of the 10,000 tons of butter originally specified. The 173,225 tons of corn - equal to about 6.8 million bushels - is owned by the department's Commodity Credit Corporation. At recent prices, the corn would have a United States farm value of about $16 million.

title: Warner Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
RCM Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Terry Quimby, a former advertising executive in the fashion industry, misidentified a surviving daughter. She is Elizabeth Timberman, not Pimberman. The obituary also misstated the day of her death. It was Saturday, not Friday.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $932,000 representing a charge from reversal of an earlier tax benefit, and included a tax benefit of $4,068,000. c-Net income

title: Carter Criticizes Israelis on Palestinian Rights
description: Former President Jimmy Carter criticized Israel today, accusing the military of abusing the rights of Palestinians by shooting demonstrators without cause, demolishing their houses and jailing Arabs without trial.

title: Careers;   Job Turmoil Takes a Toll On Loyalty
description: ONE business commodity in short supply, and growing shorter, is corporate loyalty, both the loyalty of employees to the company and the loyalty of the company to its workers.

title: Albania Could Settle Rights Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Phones Ringing (Eerily?) For Nyack Spook Home
description: The phones have been ringing at real-estate offices in Rockland County. A patient in a psychiatric hospital called. So did a para-psychologist from Florida. And so did the Amazing Kreskin, all the way from his hotel room in Atlantic City.

title: Verbal Fix for the Undercount?
description: The Commerce Department remains biased against improvements that could give many cities a fairer share of Federal funds based on population. New York and other large cities, which suffer because census enumerators can't find thousands of minority members and poor people, have gone to court to ask for a sign that Washington really seeks ''the best census ever.'' But the only answer Commerce seems capable of is oh, maybe.

title: Enzo Biochem Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LDI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Excluded a one-time benefit of $1.45 million, or 29 cents a share, resulting from a change in the method of accounting.

title: Sallie Mae Offers Notes Due in '95
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million in floating-rate notes due March 23, 1995, through two co-managers, Morgan Stanley & Company and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Moore Medical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included charge of $4.2 million related to markdowns of Latex examination gloves for the quarter and included charges totaling $5.7 million related to settlement of litigation and markdowns of Latex examination gloves for the year. c-Included charge of $12.4 million related to markdowns of Latex gloves.

title: Rutgers Eliminates Fordham in the N.I.T.
description: Keith Hughes and Earl Duncan transferred to Rutgers from Syracuse two seasons ago. They are roommates and the leading scorers for the Scarlet Knights.

title: By Design;   Up From the Schoolyard
description: Sometimes it takes a while for a street fashion to work its way up to the heights of style. The backpack, an integral part of Paris children's school uniforms for years, has now become the essential accessory of the fashionable.

title: Volkswagen and Czechs In Talks About Venture
description: Volkswagen A.G., Western Europe's largest automobile manufacturer, is holding wide-ranging talks with a Czechoslovak auto maker, Skoda, on possible areas of cooperation, a Volkswagen spokesman said today.

title: Low Level of Medication in Gathers's Test
description: New test results show that Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball star who collapsed in a game and died shortly thereafter, was taking his prescribed heart medicine but at less than therapeutic amounts, the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner said here today.

title: Soybean Prices Up Sharply On Developments in Brazil
description: Prices of soybean futures rose sharply today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk of lower-than-expected Brazilian soybean yields and diminishing fears that Brazil's economic reforms will lead to a flood of soybean marketings.

title: Michener Threatens to Quit Random House in Protest
description: James Michener, who has published more than 30 books with Random House, threatened yesterday to leave the company for ''some small house, obedient to the old traditions.''

title: Moscow Is Said to Consider Urgent Economic Measures
description: A package of 17 emergency economic changes that would move the nation toward a free-market economy has reportedly been submitted to the Supreme Soviet with the aim of enactment by July 1.

title: Review/Television;   A Technological Leader And Its Seeds of Decline
description: A thousand years ago, China produced a series of technological achievements that, in the words of ''The Genius That Was China,'' put it ''at the cutting edge of knowledge of the medieval world.'' The nature of those achievements and the reasons for the country's scientific somnolence after the 13th century make up an illuminating four-part series from ''Nova.'' The elegantly shaped opening hour, ''Rise of the Dragon,'' can be seen tonight at 8 on Channel 13.

title: Worldwide Computer Services reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
Qintex Unit Posts Loss
description: Qintex Entertainment Inc., a producer and distributor of television programs, has reported a quarterly loss of $3.8 million on sales of $8.2 million. The company is stalled in bankruptcy proceedings and is looking for a buyer or investor.

title: A Portrait of a Collector: Ian Woodner and His Drawings
description: It is probable that no private person has recently assembled a more spectacular collection of master drawings from the 14th to the early 20th centuries than Ian Woodner, an 87-year-old New York developer whose assembled purchases are on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art until May 13.

title: Soviets Seek Bond Advice in U.S.
description: The Soviet Union, struggling to invigorate its economy, is turning to American financial experts for advice on raising money to build much-needed projects, from hospitals to factories.

title: Patterns
description: Orange (Spice Added)

title: Stephen McCarthy, 81, A Research Librarian
description: Stephen A. McCarthy, a research librarian who was former director of university libraries at Cornell University, died of cancer Sunday at Anne Arundel Medical Center in Maryland. He was 81 years old and lived in Annapolis, Md.

title: Perkin-Elmer Sells One Chip Unit
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation yesterday took the first step toward spinning off its troubled semiconductor business by selling its electron-beam-technology division. The buyer is a management team backed by six United States corporations, including I.B.M. and Perkin-Elmer itself.

title: New Construction Tool
description: A new class of material has been developed that contains properties that engineers have long sought for the construction of dams, tunnels and buildings, particularly in earthquake zones, scientists in Japan report.

title: Baseball Negotiators Cleaning Up Loose Ends
description: With the owners' 32-day lockout ended and spring training beginning, major league and union officials worked yesterday on plans to keep players healthy and the season whole.

title: Robbins & Myers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain of $1.1 million from final adjustment of a federal income tax audit, which was mostly offset by a $1 million restructuring charge for investment in new manufacturing techniques.

title: Diversified Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $329,000.

title: RJR Nabisco Stake Is Sold by Drexel
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has sold its stake in the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation at cost to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. The sale, made on Feb. 23, was disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing and indicated that shares in the company were still valued at about the same level they were when the company was taken private in 1988 in a buyout led by Kohlberg, Kravis.

title: Mauna Loa Macadamia Parters reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: A Good Deal on Prison Cells
description: With prison crowding in New York State at a critical point, Gov. Mario Cuomo and his Corrections Commissioner, Thomas Coughlin, offer an excellent deal: 3,000 prison cells for the price of 1,700, in half the time. Why do state legislators hesitate?

title: Concept Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
Minister's Move Ends Indian Cabinet Crisis
description: Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal has withdrawn his resignation from the Indian Government, ending a brief political crisis.

title: Researchers Win Fight With U.S. on Documents
description: The Supreme Court today rebuffed the Federal Government's attempt to charge processing fees to a private group that collects Government documents for use by researchers and the news media.

title: Top Executive Quits at U.P.I.
description: Paul Steinle, president of United Press International, has resigned to form a broadcast production company, U.P.I.'s chairman, Earl W. Brian, announced on Friday. The announcement said Mr. Steinle would form Steinle Communications, which will emphasize news and information programming.

title: Our Towns;   Little Guys, Larger Dreams, And the Big Easy
description: Every afternoon, the Boys Club sends a yellow school bus through the city's poorest neighborhoods. Sometimes 100 boys crowd on, but many do not wait for the Boys Club bus. They walk or bike or ride a city bus, lining up in front even before doors open at 3:30.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/A2-13

title: The City's Diplomat
description: The job of running New York City's ''foreign ministry,'' the liaison office to the United Nations, would challenge the most experienced diplomat. It involves everything from helping U.N. delegates cope with New York's difficult housing market to resolving sensitive matters of diplomatic immunity.

title: Ross Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Dow Rallies 14.41 Despite Japanese Selloff
description: Stocks shook off a sharp selloff in Japan yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rallying 14.41, to 2,755.63, after being down 27 points early in the day. Some analysts cautioned, though, that the rally might not last.

title: Strawberry's Debut Is Full of Enthusiasm
description: Darryl Strawberry arrived at the Mets' training camp at 9:40 this morning, soon after the camp was opened for business 32 days late. He was the prodigal son, and he arrived carrying a baseball bat and wearing a golden cross on a golden chain and a large tattoo on his upper left arm that read ''Lisa.''

title: RJR Revises Income Figure
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. has disclosed that by eliminating a questionable selling practice it reduced its operating income last year by about $360 million, or nearly 18 percent of its net operating income.

title: Moody's Reduces Ratings On Massachusetts Debts
description: The rating on $9.09 billion in Massachusetts general obligation debt and debt issued by state agencies with backing by the state, was lowered to Baa, from Baa-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: Poindexter's Reassurance on Aid Ban Is Recalled
description: The former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee testified today the Reagan White House assured him in 1985 and 1986 that the National Security Council was obeying a Congressional ban on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Measure Barring Most Abortions Is Signed by Governor of Guam
description: Gov. Joseph F. Ada signed into law on Monday the most restrictive abortion legislation in the United States, and opponents said they would fight the measure all the way to the Supreme Court.

title: Players Are Back and Eager to Play
description: On the first day of baseball's belated spring training, after four weeks of warmth and sunshine and cool afternoon breezes, a half-dozen Yankee players gathered up their bats and gloves, walked slowly across the infield grass and began to work out. Then it rained and thundered. The rain did not stop until late in the day, until after the players had taken batting practice, had thrown a little, and then packed and left. It was not a typical spring day, but this has not been a typical spring.

title: Yankees-Mets Is Still On
description: The Mets and Yankees announced yesterday that their weekend series of two exhibition games in New York would be played on the weekend before the delayed baseball season starts, one week later than planned.

title: Unions Making New Bid for United Airlines
description: United Airlines' three unions and its largest investor said yesterday that they were joining to try to buy the carrier for $150 a share in cash plus notes and stock in a new company.

title: AQUINO ADOPTING A BOLDER FRONT
description: President Corazon C. Aquino's efforts to reassert control over her fate and show the decisiveness the country longs for have had some unintended and embarrassing consequences. But the changes are being noted here and may have improved the chances that she will last out her term.

title: Chess
description: The fourth game of the final world championship candidates' match in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, saw an exceedingly strange reversal of roles on the part of the two combatants, the former titleholder Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union and Jan Timman of the Netherlands.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Midwest Inc., Wichita, Kan., said its board had authorized the buyback of up to $5 million of its common capital stock over two years.

title: Citibank Seeking to Join Automated Teller Network
description: Citibank, which has refrained from sharing its automated teller machines with other banks in the New York City area, is trying to join one of the two largest national networks on terms that would give Citibank's depositors access to other banks' machines but would limit other bank customers' access to Citibank machines, bankers said.

title: Datametrics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $46,500, or 1 cent a share. c-Net loss

title: Founder of Proxy Firm Expected to Plead Guilty to Fraud
description: Donald C. Carter, the adviser to a generation of takeover artists, is expected to plead guilty today to two criminal charges stemming from an investigation of fraudulent billing practices at the company that bears his name, people involved with the case said yesterday.

title: Arc International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Acid Rain Report Unleashes a Torrent of Criticism
description: A comprehensive Federal report that was supposed to resolve the issue of how much damage is caused to forests by acid rain has come under criticism from some distinguished scientists who are reviewing it.

title: American Drug Chief Resigns
description: Richard A. Scott, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Drug Stores unit of the American Stores Company, has resigned, the company said last week.

title: Fonar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $535,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $598,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $71,000 and $505,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Boston Museum Says It Was Uninsured for Theft
description: The 12 works stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here on Sunday, in what experts now believe was the biggest art theft in history, were not insured, a spokesman for the museum said today.

title: DWG Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $753,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,103,000, or 6 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: AEP Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago shares outstanding are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split, effective last Dec. 7.

title: U.S. Shoe Picks Chief Officer
description: The United States Shoe Corporation reported today that Bannus B. Hudson, president of its Lenscrafters Optical division since 1987, had been named its chief executive officer.

title: Weight Gain Risk Highest From 25 to 34, Study Finds
description: People are most likely to gain weight as young adults, and black women are especially vulnerable, according to a decade-long study of nearly 10,000 people from ages 24 to 74.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Lowe Marschalk Opens Creative Services Unit
description: To free its creative and account groups from the nitty-gritty of technical executions, Lowe Marschalk has formed a creative services department that incorporates the various groups that produce advertising. Susan Johnson, most recently at Ogilvy & Mather, will join Lowe Marschalk as executive vice president and creative services director, and will coordinate such functions as print production, traffic flow and proofreading.

title: Robin Harris, 36, Dies; A Comedian and Actor
description: Robin Harris, a comedian and actor who appeared in the movies ''Do the Right Thing,'' ''Harlem Nights'' and ''House Party,'' was found dead in a hotel room here on Sunday, officials said. He was 36 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about a Brooklyn woman, Loretta Rivera, who was killed by a stray bullet referred incorrectly to a photograph she carried. It was of her companion, Liz Melendez, not of a man.

title: Williams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Bridge
description: The youngest team in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship has made its presence felt in the event, which began here on Sunday.

title: Getting Burned By the Frying Pan
description: Kentucky Fried Chicken's middle name is beginning to spell trouble.

title: Deutsche Mark Uber Alles
description: Helmut Kohl, the West German Chancellor, likes to sell himself short. ''You know,'' he often says with mock modesty, ''I make a living out of being underestimated.'' On Sunday, he did it again, and in a big way that is going to shape Central European history for years to come.

title: Engineering Measurements reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: A Top Position Is Filled By Warner-Lambert
description: The Warner-Lambert Company yesterday named Lodewijk J. R. de Vink as president of United States operations, moving him onto a track that could take him to the presidency. Warner-Lambert's chairman and chief executive, Joseph D. Williams, 63, who faces mandatory retirement in August 1991 at age 65, has said that he will be succeeded by Melvin R. Goodes, 54, the company's current president and chief operating officer.

title: Moses Moskowitz, 80, Chief of Jewish Group
description: Moses Moskowitz, secretary general of the Consultative Council of Jewish Organizations, died of pneumonia yesterday at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 80 years old and lived in Flushing.

title: Eric Meyers, 47, Dies; A Miami Trial Lawyer
description: Eric Barton Meyers, a trial lawyer who was a senior partner in the Miami firm of Shutts & Bowen, died of colon cancer on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. He was 47 years old and lived in Miami.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The

title: New India Budget Stresses Farming and Export Push
description: India's 14-week-old centrist Government today made its first substantial economic statement with the presentation of a budget that is pro-agriculture and pro-export.

title: Florio Urges Taxing Rich
description: Behind the cascade of numbers released last week with Gov. Jim Florio's new budget stands a startlingly clear statement of philosophy by New Jersey's new Governor: he plans to shift money from the rich to the poor.

title: Earth Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
Frequency Electronic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: Pay in China Is Criticized
description: Many Chinese businesses are paying managers too much, an influential Beijing newspaper said on Friday.

title: Moscow Putting Added Pressure On Lithuanians
description: The Soviet Government sharply increased its pressure on Lithuania today, ordering Kremlin ministries to step up protection of vital Soviet installations in the republic and forbidding them ''to enter into any negotiations whatsoever'' with the Lithuanian government about transferring control of Soviet enterprises to its authorities.

title: Safeguard Health Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
An Edge for Incumbents: Loopholes That Pay Off
description: WASHINGTON, March 19

description: b-Included non-recurring income of $700,000, or 13 cents a unit, from a change in accounting principle, and a one-time non-cash property writedown of $1,077,000. Share earnings are in units.

title: Suspect Sought in New York In Slaying of 4 in Connecticut
description: The police searched here and in New York City today for a man wanted for questioning in the murder on Saturday of four people, including a 4-year-old boy. Another boy, 2, was injured. Sgt. Richard Herlihy said the police were looking for Jason Day, 26, of Bridgeport, a former companion of one of those slain, Lisa Gibson, 24. The others killed were Ms. Gibson's brother, Raymond, 27; Theresa Hamilton, 23, and her son, George Green, 4.

title: Los Angeles Journal;   Restoring A Mural Obliterated By Outrage
description: Writhing across a downtown wall, the angry creation of Mexico's great muralist David Alfaro Siqueiros achieved its aim as an outcry against oppression of the indigenous races of the continent: it shocked.

title: Oil Industry Is Criticized on Safety
description: Some environmental and safety officials say the recent rash of oil spills and accidents at petrochemical plants may be traceable to financial pressures on the petroleum industry in the 1980's that led companies to reduce skilled technicians and put an emphasis on cost cutting rather than flawless performance.

title: Heico Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,480,000 which reflects a one-time charge due to the previously announced sale of its laboratory products business, which was completed March 6. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $337,000.

title: Eaton Vance Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the latest quarter included gains of 35 cents a share from investments in two precious metal mining limited partnerships, compared with similar gains of 8 cents a share in the year-earlier period.

title: Dickerson Will Retire
description: Eric Dickerson, the seventh-leading rusher in National Football League history, says he will not be back with the Indianapolis Colts next season and intends to retire.

title: Canamax Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it had a gain of $11.4 million in 1989 from the sale of non-core assets.

title: Federal Express Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After income of $18.1 million, or 35 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on fiscal years prior to 1989 of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Intek Diversified reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Review/Recital;   An Intimacy
description: Fitting a mezzo-soprano voice as rich and resonant as Florence Quivar's into a chamber music space like Weill Recital Hall threatens an embarrassment of riches. And indeed her evening of songs and arias there on Friday began as such.

title: Morris Abrams, Industrialist, 99
description: Morris Abrams, an industrialist and philanthropist, died on Sunday at his home in Neponsit, Queens. He was 99 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Gray-Flannel Golf Shorts May Be Passe
description: Hal Riney, the San Francisco advertising auteur, introduced a seminar at this year's meeting here of the American Association of Advertising Agencies with several slides featuring questions he is often asked at such sessions.

title: ARTILLERY DUELS BY RIVAL CHRISTIANS RAGE FOR 6 HOURS NORTH OF BEIRUT
description: Artillery exchanges raged for six hours today between warring Christian factions in the hills above the port of Junieh, 15 miles north of here.

title: No Experiments
description: The best tip-off to the resounding victory of East Germany's Christian Democratic alliance in Sunday's elections came in a remark by a prospective voter a couple of weeks ago. ''We're not interested in new approaches, some kind of 'third way' between Communism and capitalism,'' the man told a Western reporter. ''We've been guinea pigs too long already.''

title: Beijing Journal;   Without Apology, a Defender of Deng Tells Why
description: He is ostracized by intellectuals and hailed by the leadership. He is the author of newspaper columns and recipient of death threats. The writer in question is He Xin, a social commentator and one of the best-known intellectual supporters of the present Government.

title: Response Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included charge of $2.94 million for restructuring and reorganization.

Microsoft President Comes From Boeing
description: The Microsoft Corporation has found a new president and chief operating officer in its own backyard. He is Michael H. Hallman, president of the Boeing Company's Computer Services division, near Microsoft in the Seattle area.

title: IGI Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $149,947.

title: At Last, Namibia
description: Namibia, fitted out with a brand new, democratic Constitution and a freely elected, biracial, multiparty Government, becomes the world's newest independent state today. It also becomes the newest challenge to Western generosity and creativity in foreign policy.

title: Fax Corp. Is Accused of Franchise Fraud
description: The fast-growing industry built around credit-card-operated facsimile machines may be attracting fraudulent operators, a Federal Trade Commission official said yesterday.

title: Review/Music;   From Cincinnati, a Blending Of Spain and Central Europe
description: Spanish and Central European performers aren't ordinarily considered compatible, but Monday evening's concert by the Cincinnati Symphony at Carnegie Hall disproved that stereotype.

title: A Swamp of Political Abuses Spurs Constituents of Change
description: The chairmen of the Democratic and Republican parties, two men who agree on very little, have both taken up the call for free television time for candidates and the major parties.

description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $4,320 and $258,307 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $321,846 for the quarter and $391,243 for the year.

Guam's Abortion Law Tested By A.C.L.U. Lawyer's Speech
description: A speech by an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer who went to Guam to try to stop the Governor from signing an anti-abortion bill has become the first test case of the new law.

title: Nortek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $10,050,000, or 74 cents a share, for the quarter and $14 million, or $1.02 a share, for the year, and extraordinary credits of $8.9 million, or 65 cents a share, and $16 million, or $1.17 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Included income from discontinued operations of $1.8 million, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $13 million, or 89 cents a share, for the year, and extraordinary credits of $1.3 million, or 9 cents a share, and $6.4 million, or 44 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Vallen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings adjusted to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split distributed on or about Jan. 17.

title: 6-Day Film Series On Amazon Region
description: Films about the Amazon region, including some never shown before in the United States, are to be presented in a six-day series beginning on Tuesday at the Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street.

title: Hudson's Bay Co.  reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $46,300,000, or $1.38 a share. c-After an extraordinary loss of $27,000,000. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Premier Industrial reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Sports People: Hockey;   Ranger Deal for Bennett
description: The Rangers yesterday announced that they had agreed in principle to a contract with Rick Bennett, the highly regarded 22-year-old left wing from Providence College.

title: Patrick Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Atlas Citron's First Client
description: Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre, the San Francisco agency formed earlier this month by four executives from Hal Riney & Partners, has picked up its first client.

title: Phoenix Network reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: At the Nation's Table
description: DOLORES SNYDER, a Dallas cooking instructor, believes that deep within the soul of many a Texas iced-tea drinker lurks an Anglophile yearning for a good, hot ''cuppa,'' and maybe a rectangle or two of shortbread. Miss Snyder should know: for 12 years she has been teaching the art of English tea service throughout the state.

title: Chronicle
description: PIERRE TRUDEAU has enraged many Canadians with his new book. In ''Towards a Just Society: The Trudeau Years,'' published this week by Penguin Canada Ltd., he attacks the effort by Quebec nationalists to secure a special status in Canada's Constitution.

title: Allied Products reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $2,141,000 from an accounting adjustment. c-Net income Year-ago results are restated; net income for 1988 was increased by $1,089,000, or 21 cents a share, by adoption of the change. The latest year's results included a $10 million pretax charge associated with writedown of certain inventories and closure of certain operations. The company said the earnings in 1989 also reflected about $1.6 million pretax charge associated with a credit and debt-restructuring agreement. Also included in the latest year's results are pretax gains of about $700,000 from termination of a pension plan, and about $1.9 million from sale of assets.

title: Youth and Dreams Enliven Paris Styles
description: Valentino clipped a couple of decades off the age of his clothes by the simple expedient of puffing out his skirts. Several top-flight designers here have followed a similar youthful line, leading Karl Lagerfeld, the worst offender, to ask with mock seriousness, ''Where can we go next?''

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: AN unusual warm spell in the East has seen an early run of the migratory shad, one of the season's great delicacies. Preparing shad and its rich, distinctive roe is a seasonal ritual dating back to the American Indians. Shad season runs for about five months along the Atlantic coast, beginning in the St. Johns River in North Florida and ending in the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Shad was introduced to West Coast waters in the late 19th century and are now found in rivers from Northern California to Washington.

title: Wine Talk
description: A TASTING of vintage port is an experience in sensual overload. Superficially, there is no difference between a port tasting and a red wine tasting; substantively, nothing is the same. The richness, the power, the nuances of the ports are considerably harder to appreciate, and articulate, than those of the red wines.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters in Business Day yesterday misstated the position of the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, Richard C. Breeden, on jurisdiction over stock index futures. He has not demanded the power to regulate stock index futures; he has said there is an urgent need to resolve jurisdictional disputes over stock index products but has not made specific recommendations.

title: VENEZUELA AGREES TO DEBT PROPOSAL
description: Giving a lift to the Bush Administration's debt policy, Venezuela and its bankers announced agreement yesterday on the basic terms of a plan for debt reduction and new loans.

title: Art's Way Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
Hechinger Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included a gain of $3,200,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Corrections COMPANY NEWS;   BRIEFS
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Wednesday misstated details of a transaction between the Continental Corporation and the NAC Re Corporation. NAC Re is acquiring the stock and licenses of the Harbor Insurance Company from Continental, but the accounts insured by Harbor will continue to be managed by Continental.

title: All of Toscanini's Recordings to be Issued
description: The long-awaited release of all of Arturo Toscanini's approved performances for RCA Records was announced yesterday at a news conference on the stage of Carnegie Hall, where many of the recordings were made.

title: Angola Sees Gain in a Free Namibia
description: The President of Angola says independence for Namibia will give a military advantage to his Government in its long-running war with rightist rebels.

title: Gloria Estefan Hurt in Crash Involving Her Group's Bus
description: Gloria Estefan, lead singer of the musical group Miami Sound Machine, suffered a broken vertebra today when a truck ran into the band's bus on a snow-covered highway in the Poconos.

title: Upheaval in the East;   The Romanian Revolution Over, It's Back to Old Hatreds in Transylvania
description: More than two months after a revolution that briefly united them, the Hungarians and the Romanians who live together in what is now Romanian Transylvania are once again locked in a centuries-old rivalry that is reviving nationalist fervor on both sides.

title: A Swiss Curb On Laundering
description: Swiss legislators have passed a bill that outlaws the laundering of money from criminal activities and requires financial institutions to check customers' identity.

title: Frederick R. Clark, 73, Lawyer and a Banker
description: Frederick R. Clark, a lawyer, banker and former chairman of the New York Power Authority, died of heart failure on Monday at Naples Community Hospital in Florida. He was 73 years old and lived in Loudonville, N.Y., and in Naples.

title: Market Place;   Japan's Yen Strategy May Weaken Stocks
description: When a country has two problems, sometimes it must choose to fight only one of them.

title: Trade Deficit Widened by Oil Imports
description: The trade deficit widened to $9.3 billion in January as oil imports surged to refill stocks depleted during December's record cold, the Commerce Department reported today. In December, the trade deficit totaled a revised $7.7 billion.

title: H-Bombs to 'Star Wars': An Insider's View;   Dialogue of Two or More
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater;   Revisiting the Humor of Smoking and Cholesterol
description: Bad habits aren't what they used to be, and neither is ''Bad Habits,'' the twin bill of one-act plays by Terrence McNally that has been given a catch-as-catch-can revival by the Manhattan Theater Club. In the distant year of 1974, when ''Bad Habits'' made its hilarious New York debut, the characters' vices of chain smoking, high-cholesterol gluttony, martini guzzling and sexual adventurism were regarded more as amusingly naughty acts of rebellion, however self-destructive, than as one-way tickets to the grave. Today about the only bad habit harmless enough to elicit universal laughter - and be assured Mr. McNally does not neglect it - is the spirited picking of one's nose.

title: Security Pacific In Purchase Deal
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Santa Clarita National Bank for $52.5 million worth of Security Pacific common stock.

title: FAILED KABUL COUP CHANGES OPINIONS
description: The failed coup this month in Afghanistan, which united a hard-line Communist general with a fundamentalist guerrilla leader, has shaken the long-held assumptions of nearly all the principals in the nation's long civil war, Afghan exiles, diplomats and others say.

title: Outboard Buying Grumman Boats
description: The Outboard Marine Corporation reached an agreement in principle with the Grumman Corporation, based in Bethpage, L.I., to acquire assets of its Grumman Boats division. The unit makes aluminum recreational boats, including canoes. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Book Notes
description: Bidding for Grove

title: Sports People: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;   Illinois Player in Draft
description: Jeff George, the Illinois quarterback, announced yesterday in Champaign, Ill., that he would forgo his final year of college eligibility to enter the National Football League draft. College juniors must declare their intentions to the N.F.L. by tomorrow. The 6-4, 216-pound George completed 474 of 789 passes in two years with the Illini, and his 5,189 passing yards placed him third among all Illinois quarterbacks. (AP)

title: Caller Says He Broke Computers' Barriers To Taunt the Experts
description: A man identifying himself as the intruder who illegally penetrated part of a nationwide computer linkup said yesterday that he had done so to taunt computer security specialists who have denounced activities like his.

title: H-Bombs to 'Star Wars': An Insider's View
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard S. Humphrey, Retired Ad Executive, 91
description: Richard Sears Humphrey, retired president and chief executive of the H. B. Humphrey Company, a former Boston-based advertising agency, died Sunday at his home in Water Mill, L.I. He was 91 years old.

title: Big O Tires Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Precious Metal Prices Fall, With Gold Leading the Way
description: Precious metal prices plunged yesterday as the dollar advanced against most leading foreign currencies. A sharp rise in Japanese interest rates also made platinum, gold and silver more expensive to buy in that nation, which has become a major consumer as well as dealer in precious metals.

title: Eastern Europe Loan Agency
description: A plan to create an international lending agency to aid the recovery of Eastern Europe may be completed by July, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today ''There is a sense of urgency among our European colleagues,'' Mr. Brady told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, ''to get this job done'' by the time the economic summit meeting is held July 9-11 in Houston. The leaders of the Group of Seven nations - Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, the United States and West Germany - will attend.

title: Growing Use of Electricity Raises Questions on Supply
description: Electricity use, up by 50 percent since the first oil crisis, in 1973, will continue to grow strongly in the next few decades, far outpacing the increase in non-electric energy, experts attending a conference at George Washington University here said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Tokheim Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Paychex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Robert E. Bondy, 94, Social Work Executive
description: Robert Earl Bondy, a social worker who was a former executive director of the National Social Welfare Assembly, died of a stroke on Saturday at University Hospital in Tampa, Fla. He was 94 years old and lived in Tampa.

title: International Telecharge reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said its fourth quarter 1989 net income included federal income tax carry-backs of $294,000, and certain other infrequently occurring items that have a net positive impact of $961,000.

title: JURY TRIAL BACKED IN UNIONIST SUITS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that union members who sue their labor union for damages for failing to represent their interests are entitled to have the case heard by a jury.

title: Six Dance Companies To Perform in Brooklyn
description: The Ballet de Nancy with Patrick Dupond and the Jose Greco Spanish Dance Company are among the six troupes scheduled to take part in a dance series starting in October at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues.

title: For Free Namibia, The Fight Goes On
description: LEAD: Namibia, for decades a subject of international dispute and bloody conflict, becomes an independent nation today. The United Nations-monitored transition has succeeded beyond expectations, but what is the future of Namibia? The once colonial territory, at last in charge of its own fate, is up against some powerful obstacles.

title: Continental Air and Denver Sign Lease on New Airport
description: Ending a yearlong stalemate, Continental Airlines said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Denver officials to lease space at the city's new $2.3 billion airport.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: NEW HAVEN has long been the gastronomic capital of Connecticut. It is the alleged birthplace of the hamburger (at Louis Lunch) and the calzone (at Tony and Lucille's). It is also home to what some consider the nation's best pizza (at Pepe's or Sally's on Wooster Street).

title: 800 Unesco Staffers in Paris Briefly Walk Out in Protest
description: About 800 staff members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization conducted a two-hour strike today to protest a major restructuring of several divisions and the appointment of new senior officers at the organization by its Director General, Federico Mayor Zaragoza.

title: What Multinationals Do Isn't Tax Cheating
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Fall in Brisk Trading; Dow Off 16.89
description: Stocks fell in brisk trading yesterday after twice trying to stage an advance, with the Dow Jones industrial average breaking through 2,768 at one point before falling back sharply.

title: News Summary
description: InternationalA2-18

title: Coslet Barks Orders: Forward, March, Jets
description: The transformation of the Jets has begun without a backward glance.

title: Census Peers Into Corners to Count Homeless
description: Working through the night, census takers peered into the shadows of underpasses and derelict buildings and canvassed shelters, bus stations and doorways yesterday and today in the Government's first attempt to count the nation's most elusive group: the homeless.

title: Mets' Johnson Is Looking Forward
description: Davey Johnson stood in the debris of baseball's short spring today, and said: ''We have only a few bats. We had to borrow helmets from the Dream Week camp. Eleven of our guys still aren't here. And the uniforms are coming South by truck from New York.''

title: Again, Cuomo Offers Menu Of New Taxes
description: For the second day in a row, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed new taxes in a slowly unfolding plan to close a $1.5 billion budget gap.

title: Fannie Mae Prices 6-Month Security
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday priced its first ever six-month debenture through its regular sales group of securities dealers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As of today, we are masters of this pastoral land of our ancestors. The destiny of this country is now in our own hands.''

title: Critic's Notebook;   New Role for the Movies: Peeping Tom
description: A mischievous, movie-struck little boy called Toto leans out the window of the Cinema Paradiso's projection room and looks out on the public square. As the grandfatherly Alfredo turns the projector around, the image of a Chaplinesque comedian glides across the walls of the room and out in the open air, to reappear as a gigantic moving picture on a building across the way. It is easy to miss Alfredo's dialogue at this moment, and maybe that's just as well. He actually says, ''Abracadabra.''

title: Samson Energy Co.  L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Serrano and Molinari Elected In Special Congressional Races
description: Assemblyman Jose E. Serrano and City Councilwoman Susan K. Molinari won special elections yesterday for House seats in the South Bronx and Staten Island.

title: Liposome Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Humana Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain of $9.6 million, or 9 cents a share, from a favorable court decision in a federal tax case covering fiscal years 1977 through 1979, which were offset by a charitable contributions charge of $1.3 million and an extraordinary loss of $8.6 million on early extinguishment of debt.

title: Books of The Times;   What Constitution Says vs. What Presidents Do
description: The Rockets' Red Glare

title: Bay Meadows-Calif Jockey Club reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ESI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $513,072 from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: Knicks Fail to Find the Answer
description: The Orlando Magic, another expansion team the Knicks are supposed to beat, came to New York last night with 16 losses in their last 17 games, including 9 in a row, and an 11-game losing streak on the road and without their starting backcourt of Reggie Theus and Sam Vincent.

title: On-Line Software Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $151,000, or 3 cents a share, in connection with the company's purchase at a discount of its convertible subordinated debentures. c-After extraordinary gains of $675,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,516,000, or 41 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from same footnote mentioned in latest 9 months.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Neutral-Germany Stand By Soviets Is Softening
description: Soviet foreign policy experts have indicated that Moscow might eventually compromise on its demand that a united Germany be a neutral nation outside NATO.

title: Western Corporate Enterpr reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings were higher due to inclusion of 12 months' results of International Aviation Terminals Inc. (IAT), compared to 4 months in 1988 and improved profits of IAT and Facs Records Centre. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Cardinal Accepts Discord on Abortion
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, said today that public officials, whether Catholic or not, who believe that abortion is wrong were obliged to pursue policies reflecting this moral conviction. But he said there was room for legitimate disagreement on what that would mean in actual political practice.

title: Real Estate;   Development Aids Cultural Institutions
description: LAND development that spins off benefits for cultural institutions has a long history in New York City, going back at least as far as 1890, when commercial space was built into the Mercantile Library on Manhattan's Astor Place to help repay its construction costs.

title: Review/Ballet;   San Francisco Ballet in Classical and Contemporary Modes
description: (Missing)

title: Wickes Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $27,355,000 for the quarter and $236,668,000 for the year, and extraordinary credits of $126,466,000 and $167,510,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from gains on retirement of debt. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $10,626,000 for the quarter and $3,108,000 for the year. During 1989 Wickes completed the sale of the Wickes furniture division, the Elco Group of Companies, A.P.S. Inc., and the Heat Transfer Group. Results of these operations are classified as discontinued operations, and prior periods have been accordingly restated. Included in discontinued operations for the latest periods are after-tax gains on disposal of $43,055,000 for the 13 weeks and $253,220,000 for the fiscal year. Wickes was acquired in December 1988 by WCI Holdings Corp., a company jointly owned by Blackstone Capital Partners L.P. and Wasserstein Perella Partners L.P.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * George C. Cowan has joined Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss as a senior vice president and management supervisor.

title: Avoiding Fire in Lithuania
description: The last thing Soviet and Lithuanian leaders should want is a showdown over Lithuanian independence. But that's exactly where they seem to be heading, as Soviet planes buzz Vilnius, the capital, and the leaders there continue to insist that Lithuania is already a separate state.

title: Economic Scene;   An Old Trade Idea Wins New Favor
description: THE latest round of trade negotiations between the United States and Japan is provoking rancor but few results. The Japanese have charged that America does not invest enough in education and research and development, while the United States contends that Japan's distribution network remains closed.

title: Iran Official Speaks of Effort to Free Hostage
description: A senior Iranian official has said that ''as a good-will gesture'' Teheran is working for the release of one hostage held in Lebanon.

title: Edper Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company attributed the gain in net income mainly to the investment of $360 million of common equity raised in 1989 through a private placement and an initial public offering of 4 million common shares. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Global Income Plus Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Burmese Military Is Forcing Mass Migration From Cities
description: At least 500,000 Burmese are being forced to move from Myanmar's cities to new, ill-prepared outlying towns where malaria and hepatitis are rampant, diplomats say.

title: Islanders' Loss Puts Rangers in Playoffs
description: One New York team clinched a playoff berth in the Patrick Division tonight when the Islanders played in suburban Washington in one of their most important games of the season.

title: Education: Lessons
description: Evaluating schools in this country has always been a political battlefield.

title: Nuvision Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $1.3 million pre-tax charge for store closings.

title: Letter: On Energy;   Hawaii Cuts Need for Fossil Fuels
description: To the Editor:

title: Geffen Starts A New Label
description: David Geffen, who last week agreed to sell Geffen Records to MCA Inc. for $550 million in stock, said today that he had started a new record label that would focus on developing new artists.

title: Penn Treaty American reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Executone Information reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago figures are restated to reflect discontinued operations. Comparative results for the full year unavailable; company was formed July 1, 1988.

title: MDC Corp. reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $356,466, or 3 cents a share. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Covenant House Still Helps Get Homeless Kids Off the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Kentucky Fried Chicken and rival chains misidentified the parent company of El Pollo Loco, a fast-food chain. It is TW Holdings Inc., a publicly traded holding company based in Spartanburg, S.C.

title: Devils Stay Off Balance And Stumble to Flyers
description: With a lot of distraction from the opposition, the Devils never found any rhythm tonight and suffered a 3-2 setback to the Flyers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Taiwan Seeks Talks With Protesters
description: More than 6,000 students and thousands of onlookers gathered in a city park today to demand greater democracy, and there were reports that the President would convene a national conference to discuss the pace of political change on the island.

title: Upheaval in the East;   U.S., in Sharper Tone, Is Worried By Soviets' Pressure on Lithuania
description: The White House sharpened the tenor of its statements on Lithuania today, saying an increase in the Kremlin's political pressure against the republic's independence movement was ''cause for concern.'' The Bush Administration called on Moscow to open immediate talks on self-determination with the Lithuanian Government.

title: AOI Coal Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Island Park Challenge Fails
description: The party that has controlled Village Hall here for 25 years rebuffed its first serious challenge in recent memory today to win the elections for mayor and all three trustee positions. The winning party, the Unity Party, defeated candidates from the Integrity Party and the Independent Party.

title: Proxy Firm Founder Pleads Guilty to Theft and Fraud
description: Donald C. Carter, who turned the prosaic business of proxy solicitation into a tool for corporate takeover battles, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan today to stealing $1 million from clients and filing false New York State income tax returns.

title: Education;   Free Graduate School for Minority Students
description: Four hundred minority students in Pennsylvania will have the opportunity to attend graduate school at no cost under a new program to encourage postgraduate work.

title: Sports People: BOXING;   Soviet Card Introduced
description: At a news conference at Mickey Mantle's Restaurant in Manhattan yesterday, the promoter Lou Falcigno, president of Momentum Enterprises, presented the five Soviet amateur boxing champions who will make their professional debuts on March 27 at Bally's in Reno, Nev.

title: Columbia Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year results are restated to reflect October 1988 merger with O'Connor Products Co., which was accounted for as a pooling of interests, and the effect of a 2-for-1 stock split on June 9, 1989.

title: 'Cat and the Fiddle' In a Concert Version
description: A concert version of Jerome Kern's ''Cat and the Fiddle'' is to be presented in six performances starting on April 18 at 8 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall. With original orchestrations, this is believed to be the first New York revival of the show since it opened on Broadway in 1932.

title: Fayston Journal;   Inviting Vermont To Learn How to Ski
description: Her legs still wobbling from her maiden voyage down the Easy Street trail, Debra Maloney-Evans finds she is actually enjoying herself. For Mrs. Maloney-Evans, this slushy Sunday at Sugarbush's Mount Ellen Ski Area is her first outing on Alpine skis in nearly 20 years, and she admits to having had her doubts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Huntington Bancshares Inc., a bank holding company in Columbus, Ohio, to Meldrum & Fewsmith, Cleveland, with a budget of $7 million.

title: U.S. Concern on Lithuania
description: Washington said an increase in Moscow's political pressure against Lithuania's independence movement was ''cause for concern.'' Page A18.

title: New Generations Bring New Vision To Food Business
description: THE food business in America came of age over the last decade. In some families involved in the industry, members of a younger generation were also coming of age. Today many of them are in charge.

title: Chronicle
description: RICHARD M. FURLAUD has been elected chairman of Rockefeller University's trustees. He will take over the job on July 1, succeeding DR. WILLIAM O. BAKER, the retired chairman of Bell Laboratories. Dr. Baker, who has been the trustees' chairman since 1980, will retire.

title: Jury Being Picked in Killing of New Jersey Family
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of John Emil List on murder charges filed against him more than 18 years ago after the bodies of his wife, three children and mother were found in their Westfield home. All had been shot.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL;   Shoulder Injury Forces Krukow to Retire
description: Because of his continuing shoulder problems, Mike Krukow, the San Francisco Giants' only 20-game winning pitcher in the last 17 years, announced his retirement from basball yesterday. Krukow, 38 years old, became a free agent last October after a torn rotator cuff injury that ended his season in June. For his career, Krukow had a 124-117 record and a 3.90 earned run average in 369 major league games with the Chicago Cubs, the Philadelphia Phillies and the Giants. In 1986, he had a 20-9 record to become the Giants' first 20-game winner since Ron Bryant in 1973.

title: Bamberger Polymers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Prosecution Rests in Poindexter Case; Judge Rejects Motion for Acquittal
description: The prosecution in John M. Poindexter's trial rested its case today, leaving the defense facing a formidable challenge as it seeks to counter potentially damaging testimony linking the former national security adviser to wide-ranging efforts to mislead Congress about the Iran-contra affair.

title: Nycom Information Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Namibia Achieves Independence After 75 Years of Pretoria's Rule
description: After 75 often restive years under South African control, Namibia was born today as the world's newest independent nation.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   A Communist Adrift in a Changing World
description: ''Palombella Rossa'' (''Red Wood Pigeon'') introduces American audiences to Nanni Moretti, reported to be one of Italy's wittiest social satirists as well as a triple-threat movie maker. The film is to be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 9 P.M. as part of the New Directors/New Films series.

title: Novo Nordisk A/S reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated at the Dec. 31, 1989 exchange rate of U.S. $1.00 equaled DKr. 6.6075. The 1988 figures for the merged company are included in this statement for purposes of comparison and were calculated on a pro forma basis. The share earnings represented American Depositary Share.

title: The Shape of Cabs to Come
description: The Chevrolet Caprice, the boxy foot soldier for the New York City taxicab fleet and the nation's police departments, is getting a makeover. The 1991 model, which is now on sale and will roll into fleet service this fall, is styled with aerodynamic curves more in keeping with the latest automotive fashion.

title: South Africa Seen as Ready to Sign Nuclear Pact
description: After talks here in 1988 and last year, officials of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union say they believe that South Africa is poised to sign the 1970 treaty limiting the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Lawyer to Lead City Inquiry Into Dinkins's Cable Stock
description: A prominent New York City lawyer was appointed yesterday as special counsel in the city's inquiry into whether Mayor David N. Dinkins violated city ethics rules in connection with stock he held in a broadcasting company while he was Borough President of Manhattan.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Next Generation

title: Wesco Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Limousine 'Dumping'
description: The Commerce Department issued a final ruling today that imported stretch limousines from Canada were being sold at less than fair value on the American market. The ruling paved the way for possible anti-dumping duties on the cars. If the United States International Trade Commission finds that the cars have injured American producers, duties of about 5 percent would be imposed to compensate. The commission, an independent agency that monitors adherence to United States trade law, is to act within 45 days.

title: 3Com Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Education;   Great Expectations Hobble Black Superintendents
description: When summer returns to the oak-shaded streets of Jackson, Miss., Benjamin O. Canada hopes to be settling into his job as Superintendent of that city's public schools.

title: DEMOCRATS TO ASK FOREIGN AID SHIFT
description: In their first formal challenge to the Administration's foreign-aid priorities, Senate Democrats plan to propose that more than half of the $800 million in emergency aid that President Bush has requested for Panama and Nicaragua be redirected to assist the new democracies in Eastern Europe.

title: China's Premier Urges Tighter Control
description: Prime Minister Li Peng opened the annual session of China's legislature today with a call for tighter control on what he described as ''hostile elements at home.''

title: Chicken-Chain Builder Set to Revamp Carvel
description: The Carvel Corporation, a franchiser of ice cream products, has named an executive with Kentucky Fried Chicken, Steven V. Fellingham, as chairman and chief executive to spruce up the chain and its profits.

title: CBL Medical reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   France Urges West Germany to Speed Unification
description: Worried that West Germany is wavering in its commitment to the European Community, France urged it today to absorb East Germany as rapidly as possible and again focus attention on European integration.

title: Michigan Yields At 5.8% to 6.85%
description: The Michigan Municipal Bond Authority yesterday tentatively priced $57.7 million in tax-exempt local government loan program revenue bonds for the Detroit School District.

title: Jury Gets Valdez Spill Case After Opposite Portraits of Hazelwood
description: The case of Joseph Hazelwood went to the jury today after a prosecutor portrayed him as a reckless drunk and a defense attorney called the Exxon Valdez skipper a scapegoat of political powers.

title: Cocaine Burning Spurs Complaint of Pollution
description: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has been accused of violating Colorado air pollution standards by burning half a ton of cocaine in an incinerator last month.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Hearst Corp.'s Canal One Deal
description: Seeking a foothold in European television production and distribution, the Hearst Corporation said Monday that it had purchased 20 percent of a French television production company and 50 percent of a distribution company. Both companies are affiliated with Canal Plus, one of the biggest pay-television companies in the world.

title: U.S. Says Arafat Sticks to Word On Renouncing Terrorism in Israel
description: The State Department, in a report sent to Congress, credits Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, with adhering to his commitment renouncing terrorism.

title: Socanav Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago periods' results were restated. The results for the latest quarter and 6 months included Steinberg Inc. from the Aug. 22, 1989 date of acquisition. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Parking Tickets: Many Get Off, A Report Says
description: A state watchdog group yesterday confirmed what many motorists in New York City have long suspected: traffic agents selectively hand out parking violations.

title: Jury Screening Starts in Marcos Trial
description: By the end of a long dreary day in a fluorescent-lighted room with windows facing nothing but courthouse brick, Imelda Marcos's notebook was crammed with trivia. She knew that Laverne Hairston likes to watch ''China Beach'' and ''L.A. Law,'' that Manuel E. Rosa enjoys westerns and that Samuel Cerezo plays paddle ball.

title: Eating Well
description: MICROWAVE ovens have not been high on anyone's list of important safety concerns for several years now. Fears that small children will be exposed to low levels of radiation escaping from poorly sealed doors seem to have died down.

title: Shoney's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 18
description: b-Included pre-tax gain of $5,271,000 on sale of stock.

title: Huskies Find Their Identity In an All-Out Defense
description: ''Presshuh! Presshuh! Presshuh! Presshuh!''

title: Corrections
description: Articles from March 8 through March 19 about a Brooklyn boy who was set afire gave an incorrect rendering of his surname initially provided by the family. A family lawyer now says the name was changed from Aupont to Opont when the family of the boy, David Opont, came to the United States from Haiti.

title: Capucine, 57, Dies; French-Born Actress In Films of the 60's
description: Capucine, the patrician French actress who starred in international movies of the 1960's like ''The Pink Panther'' and ''What's New, Pussycat?,'' was killed on Saturday in a fall from her eighth-floor apartment in Lausanne, Switzerland. She was 57 years old.

title: Budget Plan For Britain
description: Amid growing criticism of its management of the economy, the British Government today presented a cautious budget, which is aimed at fighting inflation partly by encouraging Britons to save and by raising taxes on tobacco, alcohol and gasoline.

title: Auctioneers Underwrite Reward In Art Theft
description: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum announced today that it would offer a $1 million reward for information leading to the recovery of the 12 masterpieces stolen from the museum on Sunday in what is believed to be the largest art theft in history.

title: Venison: Low Fat And Farm Raised
description: FRESH venison, once considered a seasonal treat, is now appearing all year on the tables of consumers who yearn for a red meat that is tender, tasty and lean. It is served regularly in many restaurants across the nation and sold in many supermarkets and specialty shops.

title: What Multinationals Do Isn't Tax Cheating;   Weak Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey City Biddy Team Loses
description: The Jersey City Biddy basketball champions were eliminated from the national Biddy championships in New Orleans yesterday, but got an extra day to tour the city. The state Biddy champs came back from a 16-point deficit to tie the game at 65, before losing 67-65 to Gary, Ind. ''They went down fighting,'' said Gary Greenberg, operations director of the Boys Club, which sponsors the team for 12- and 13-year-olds. ''I'm not disappointed at all. I'm just happy the kids had the opportunity to experience a new place.'' He said they spent yesterday ''cruising around seeing New Orleans.''

title: Martech USA reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Debris From Secret Satellite Is Burning Up, Pentagon Says
description: Debris from a secret American spy satellite has begun falling from space and burning up from the heat of re-entering the atmosphere, the Pentagon said today.

title: Education;   On Welfare and Truants
description: A statewide program that cuts welfare payments to families whose children have poor school attendance records has been ineffective at keeping children in school, at least in Milwaukee County, a study by the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee says.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Agent for Jackson
description: Chris Jackson, Louisiana State's leading scorer in both his freshman and sophomore seasons, announced on Saturday that he would forgo his final two years of college eligibility to enter the 1990 National Basketball Association draft. Yesterday, he became a pro athlete officially when he signed a player-agent agreement with Eddie Miller, a lawyer from Gulfport, Miss., who is one of his longtime friends.(AP)

title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
description: b-Reflected restatement for the effects of a change in accounting principle concerning incremental nuclear outage maintenance costs.

title: Manhattan Viewers Not Fuzzy About Cable Companies
description: More than half the cable television subscribers in Manhattan who answered a city survey released yesterday said they had had ''repeated or prolonged'' reception problems in the last two years. More than a third rated their reception as no better than fair.

title: New Mexico & Arizona Land reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said a major part of the 1989 loss was due to an operational loss of $980,000 suffered by the Tucson Inn at the airport. The company also said it had a writedown of $2,460,000. The hotel was sold in January.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: United Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $476,000, or 5 cents a share. The latest periods' results included the operations of Metex Corp. from March 8, 1989, the date of acquisition.

title: Raanana Journal;   State of Israel Just Now: A Big Welcome Wagon
description: On a quiet, tree-lined street in this affluent town, Binyamin Krivonosov sat in his new apartment and surveyed three couches and armchairs, two coffee tables, two dinette sets and two refrigerators crowding the room.

title: Relief Convoy Crosses Rebel Line in Ethiopia
description: A convoy of 12 relief trucks crossed military lines in northern Ethiopia today to begin an operation aimed at feeding a million starving peasants in rebel-held areas.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   A Finnish Version of Small-Town Frustration and Violence
description: When a mother locks her drunken, violent middle-aged son in the barn toward the end of ''Plainlands,'' it is the only positive action a woman takes in this Finnish film that suggests machismo can be translated into any language and culture. The first feature by Pekka Parikka, an established television director, is a familiar story about aimlessness and barely suppressed violence born of small-town frustration. Though Mr. Parikka's work is prettily photographed and has a sustained, deliberate rhythm, ''Plainlands'' never goes beyond a glib exposition of this idea.

title: Citicorp Rates Drop Slightly
description: Interest rates slipped yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper for the first time in about five weeks, but the decline was slight.

title: Chronicle
description: In an unusual collaboration, three music festivals have commissioned three new works from three American composers. The works will then be performed at each of the festivals.

title: Review/Television;   The War Is Over, but 'China Beach' Continues
description: Inventive, imaginative, adventurous: these are just a few of the adjectives least likely to be applied to the bulk of weekly television series. Prime time remains dedicated to safe formulas and reusable stereotypes.

title: Atlantic American reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from repurchase of long-term debt of $258,000, or 3 cents a share,, for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary credit from repurchase of long-term debt of $2,811,000, or 29 cents a share,, for the quarter and year.

title: Kelley Oil & Gas Partners reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Hundreds in the Arts Rally For Grants Without Strings
description: Hundreds of artists, writers, actors and leaders of arts organizations gathered in the nation's capital today to rally and lobby in behalf of Federal support for the arts without restrictions.

title: Privatize Social Security
description: LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan recently identified the immediate problem with Social Security: excess revenues being used to fund unrelated Government spending. But that just obscures the more important point that the entire system is unfair, illogical and economically harmful.

title: Army Uses Computers to Recruit Nintendo Generation
description: At first glance, the new advertising for the United States Army's R.O.T.C. recruitment campaign could be mistaken for a Nintendo video game.

title: DePaul Extends Mark With Campus Victory
description: Stephen Howard's bank shot with two seconds left gave DePaul a 61-59 victory over Cincinnati tonight in a second-round National Invitation Tournament game and a 44-game winning streak at Alumni Hall despite a 10-year interruption.

title: Time Limit Is Upheld For Suit in Tax Case
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a taxpayer may not sue for a refund of an erroneous Federal tax payment after the time limit for filing such suits has expired, even if the Government is to blame for the overpayment.

title: All's Well For the Mets, For Now
description: As the first Met to take batting practice, Howard Johnson swung at the first pitch and pulled a long high drive down the left-field line that had the look of a home run until it curved foul. But the 600 spectators in St. Lucie County Sports Complex cheered anyway. Several minutes later, when HoJo strolled out of the batting cage, the fans applauded.

title: A.C.C. Using Tourney To Regain Respect
description: This was supposed to be a down year for the haughty Atlantic Coast Conference, a fact apparently reflected in the unusually low seedings given its teams in the 1990 National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Conagra Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $6 million from nonrecurring items. Year-ago results are restated. Share earnings reflected a 2-for-1 stock split in December 1989.

title: Bridgford Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
Fleurian Beats Fog-Bound Becker
description: While Boris Becker gave too convincing an imitation of a noontime somnambulist, Jean Fleurian, an eccentric Parisian wearing his last pair of sneakers and shorts too new, too large and held up by a safety pin, was wide awake.

title: John Higgins, 69, Dies; Aide to Ex-F.B.I. Chief
description: John R. Higgins, a former administrative assistant to J. Edgar Hoover, died on Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J.. He was 69 years old and lived in Roseland, N.J.

title: Vincent Monitors Report
description: The baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, is looking into reports that George Steinbrenner paid $40,000 to a man who helped the Yankee owner in his dispute with Dave Winfield, the commissioner's office said yesterday. Until he knows more about the matter, the office said Vincent would have no comment.

title: 13 Yankees Missing as Spring Camp Opens
description: It could have been any day in any camp in any spring training site in Florida or Arizona.

title: INSIDE
description: Serrano and Molinari Capture House Seats

title: Gift From the Sea: The Abundant Scallop
description: SOMEDAY I hope to visit Santiago de Compostela, in northwestern Spain. This historic city, at the end of a famous medieval pilgrimage route, houses the shrine of St. James the Apostle. It fascinates me because the route is marked by the emblem of St. James, scallop shells.

title: Softkey Software Pdts reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Boxing: Notebook;   Power Struggle to Control Chavez
description: On Saturday night, Julio Cesar Chavez was the beneficiary of a decision that the referee, Richard Steele, made in the waning seconds of his 12-round junior welterweight title match. Steele stopped the fight soon after Chavez had knocked down Meldrick Taylor, although there were only two seconds remaining in the final round and Taylor was comfortably ahead on two of the three judges' scorecards.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Green Point Savings Bank, Flushing, Queens, promoted Bernadette Lynch-Arias to executive vice president.

title: Upheaval in the East; Man in the News;   An Uneager Leader - Lothar de Maiziere
description: It is one of the curiosities of politics of the two Germanys that the Christian Democratic leader now likely to form the next and last government of East Germany is so different from the Christian Democratic Chancellor in Bonn.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Continental Air Chooses Wells, Rich
description: AFTER scrutinizing five disparate agencies for seven weeks, Continental Airlines yesterday appointed Wells, Rich, Greene, an agency built on airline advertising, to handle its nearly $50 million account.

title: Upheaval in the East;   BONN WILL CUT AID TO EAST GERMANS WHO MOVE TO WEST
description: Moving to stem the migration of East Germans to West Germany, the Bonn Government decided today to put an end to special reception centers and most benefits for East German resettlers on July 1.

title: Reading Test Scores for New York City Schools
