description: Following are the rankings of New York City's 619 public elementary and 180 junior high schools released yesterday by the Board of Education. The rankings are based on the percentage of students scoring at or above grade level on reading tests given in May 1989.

title: New York in Bid for Cup
description: New York City and New Haven, Conn., have formed a task force to bring a major part of the 1994 World Cup soccer tournament to the metropolitan area.

title: Credit Card Issue By MNC Financial
description: MNC Financial Inc., a Baltimore-based bank holding company and one of the three largest issuers of credit card securities, yesterday priced a $500 million issue of these types of securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Pentagon to Aid the Press in Coverage of Combat
description: Responding to criticism that it impeded news coverage of the invasion of Panama, the Pentagon said today that it would take steps to make it easier for the press to cover military operations.

title: Miniscribe Corp. Receives 3 Offers
description: The Miniscribe Corporation, the financially troubled computer disk drive maker, has received three preliminary bids, its chairman, Richard Rifenburgh, said. He said the company expects formal offers later this week. Mr. Rifenburgh would not disclose the bidders or their offers, but he said he was optimistic a deal could be reached.

title: Lawyer Asserts Boy Slain by an Officer Was Trying to Flee
description: A lawyer for the family of a 14-year-old robbery suspect killed by a police officer in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn on Jan. 31 charged yesterday that the boy was running away from the officer when he was shot in the back of the head.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Moscow and Lithuanians Stand Firm
description: A nervous standoff continued today between the Kremlin and Lithuania, with separatist officials making a show of inviting volunteers to sign up for a future Lithuanian ''territorial defense system'' and Russians living in the Lithuanian capital responding with their own vigilante program.

title: Out of the Pits: Why P.S. 182 Can Read
description: Public School 182 in the East Bronx learned yesterday that it had made a phenomenal comeback - the educational equivalent of moving from the league cellar into pennant contention.

title: Removing The Perils, And Keeping The Spray
description: Aerosol sprays propelled by hydrocarbon gases like propane and butane face increasing restrictions on emissions associated with the formation of smog. While containers that deliver their product through a pump can often be substituted, many consumers prefer the smoother, more continuous spray of an aerosol.

title: Shareholders' Suit Favors BTR's Bid
description: A group of shareholders of the Norton Company filed a class-action lawsuit in favor of a $1.64 billion takeover offer by BTR P.L.C. of Britain. The group asked that Norton's management seek to ''maximize shareholder value'' in weighing the offer. Thomas Shapiro, a lawyer for the shareholders, declined to identify them or provide details about the size of their holdings in the Worcester, Mass, abrasives and ceramics company.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.5%
description: Consumer prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent last month as a surge in the cost of clothing more than offset a record decline in the price of fuel oil, the Labor Department said today.

title: Retail Group Post Expected
description: John J. Schultz, the former president and chief executive of B. Altman & Company, is expected to be named president of the National Retail Federation's store services division, formerly known as the National Retail Merchants Association, retailing executives said yesterday.

title: President Wins Initial Test On Clean Air Compromise
description: President Bush and the Senate leadership tonight withstood the first major test of their compromise bill to reduce air pollution, when the Senate narrowly refused to impose stricter controls on automobile emissions.

title: Chariot Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $7,129,000 which included a gain of $6,584,000 on sale of discontinued operations. c-Net income

title: Adobe Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
Metropolitan Diary
description: SPRING FASHIONS: NEW YORK

title: Bridge;   By Alan Truscott
description: It was a battle of the sexes in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here Monday night, and the women were winning most of the skirmishes.

title: TCS Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Avatar Holding Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago figures are not comparable; Avatar Holding adopted the installment method of profit recognition for homesite sales effective Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Aris Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $45,000, or 1 cent a share. Latest quarter's share earnings was after payment of preferred dividends. The company said that it acquired its sole operating subsidiary, Lamonts Apparel Inc., on Sept. 21, 1989. Revenues for 1989, consisting wholly of sales from Lamont's 49 stores, are not comparable with prior year's first quarter sales of $70.3 million.

title: Bank Yields Are Mostly Up in Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly up for the week that ended yesterday.

title: One Germany - in Both Alliances
description: Two hundred and one years ago last August, the nobles and clerics of the French National Assembly, in a single memorable night of revolutionary zeal, voted to divest themselves of the rights and privileges they had accumulated under the old regime.

title: KEY RATES
Before They Get Dumb
description: I am introducing granddaughter Lucy, age 5, to the ''e-u'' words.

title: O'Neill Decides He Won't Run For a Third Term in Connecticut
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he would not seek a third full term in office, citing the ''political realities'' facing him and saying he had no taste for the negative campaign tactics he believed necessary to win re-election.

title: Founder May Take Gulfstream Public
description: The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, which was sold on Monday to an investor group headed by its founder, Allen Paulson, will probably be taken public again in a few years to enhance the investors' profits, Mr. Paulson said.

title: The Search for a Cleaner Way to Make Steel
description: For years, steel industry executives have voiced a need for a way to produce steel without using air-polluting ovens that convert coal into the fuel known as coke to heat the blast furnaces. But the issue has taken on new urgency now that Senate leaders and the White House have agreed, in clean-air legislation, to retain a deadline of 1995 for steelmakers to install stringent anti-pollution technology.

title: Good Demand Is Reported For Massachusetts Offering
description: One day after Moody's Investors Service announced that it had lowered the general obligation debt rating of Massachusetts, to Baa from Baa-1, the state tentatively priced a $360.5 million general obligation bond issue through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Hungary Dominates United States, 2-0
description: Soccer in Hungary has never been the same since 1986, when the national team lost to the Soviet Union, 6-0, in the World Cup tournament in Mexico. Hungary has struggled under eight coaches, the last of whom, Kalman Meszoly, was appointed in January, just after the team failed to qualify for the 1990 World Cup finals in Italy.

title: Food Notes
description: New Ale, New Beer

title: The Avant-Garde Think Bodysuit First
description: Think of spandex exercise clothes: tights and a leotard, or a one-piece bodysuit. That's where it all starts. Then add layers. A parka or a T-shirt, an abbreviated sweater or a chiffon dress. If you're feeling fairly sedate, you might wear a long tailored jacket. You might even pull on a skirt, but it must be either micro-mini or nearly ankle-length.

title: Stephen Caiazza, 46, AIDS-Care Specialist
description: Dr. Stephen S. Caiazza, a physician who had dedicated himself to the treatment of patients with AIDS, died of complications from the disease on last Wednesday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Raytheon Enters Guilty Plea
description: The Raytheon Company pleaded guilty today to obtaining secret Air Force budget documents illegally, and it agreed to pay $1 million in fines and penalties.

title: Move Expected On Valvano
description: A decision on the fate of Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State basketball coach, might be announced in the next day or two, according to a published report.

title: House Tax Bill Aims At Foreign Concerns
description: House Democratic leaders today introduced legislation intended to help the Government collect taxes owed by United States subsidiaries of foreign-owned companies.

title: Brokerage Settlement Made
description: Nearly two and a half years after the stock market collapse of 1987, creditors of a failed brokerage firm have reached a settlement with former options investors who lost $12.4 million that day.

title: Dinkins Aides Say He's Picked Labor Chief
description: Eric J. Schmertz, a labor mediator and former dean of Hofstra University Law School, has been selected to be New York City's chief labor negotiator, aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday.

title: Court Rejects Federal Restriction on Abortion Counseling at Clinics
description: The Federal appeals court in Boston has declared unconstitutional the 1988 Federal regulations preventing Government-financed family planning clinics from doing abortion counseling.

title: Peres Chosen to Try to Form Israeli Cabinet
description: President Chaim Herzog chose Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, this evening to take on the difficult job of trying to form a new Government. The President urged Mr. Peres to complete the task as soon as possible.

title: New Boveri President Happy to Stay in U.S.
description: Asea Brown Boveri Inc., the American electrical engineering giant formed when ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. of Switzerland acquired Combustion Engineering Inc. in January, said yesterday that Gerhard Schulmeyer had been named president and chief executive officer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Investigator Says Space Station Flaws Are Ignored
description: A leader of a 12-member NASA investigative panel asserted yesterday that the space agency was hiding from a serious flaw that threatens to jeopardize the proposed $30 billion space station Freedom.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Atlantic Supplement
description: The Atlantic magazine, combining a desire to report the rise in corporate philanthropy over the last decade and to increase advertising revenues, will publish an annual supplement called ''Private Profit Public Gain,'' which will be distributed with its September issue. The Atlantic said it would donate a tenth of the supplement's net revenues to charity.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: BRADLEY OGDEN, the chef who pioneered new-wave Americana at Campton Place Hotel in San Francisco, recently moved across the Golden Gate Bridge and reopened the historic Lark Creek Inn. Nestled in Larkspur, a picture-postcard Victorian town in Marin County, the sprawling inn was built as a private home in 1888 and still has plenty of country charm.

title: Flexible Bond Trust Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago results are for the period from Dec. 29, 1988, when the firm began operations, through Jan. 31, 1989. Net income represented net investment income.

title: Scheduling Problem Is Nearly Solved
description: Major league officials, player representatives and CBS executives spent yesterday grappling with the calendar, trying to find a way to reschedule at least some of the six games that had to be scratched from the opening week of the season without unduly disturbing the network's fall programming plans.

title: Mature Sanders Wins National Championship
description: Summer Sanders won her first national swimming championship tonight. But even that, she said, was not the best thing that had ever happened to her.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Up Sharply
description: Treasury bond prices moved sharply higher in a volatile session yesterday, as traders gave more weight to rumors of significant Japanese purchases of zero-coupon Treasury bonds than to economic reports that suggested inflation was still a problem.

title: Jackson Disputes Report
description: Stu Jackson, the Knicks' coach, said that a report yesterday that he and Mark Jackson were involved in a shouting match after Thursday night's loss to the Timberwolves in Minnesota, was ''exaggerated and blown out of proportion.''

title: Marcos Art Sale Discussed
description: The chairman of Sotheby Holdings Inc., A. Alfred Taubman, and the president of the auction house, Michael L. Ainsley, are in Manila, meeting with President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines to discuss the possibility of auctioning $100 million worth of art and jewelry collected by Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, Sotheby's confirmed yesterday. The collection is said to include Old Master and Impressionist paintings and French 18th-century furniture, as well as silver and jewelry.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Shevardnadze Comments
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that Moscow had no desire to use force to deal with the Lithuanian drive for independence, or any intention of doing so, but the Soviet official was careful not to categorically rule out a military option.

title: Stars Stake a Piece Of Big Sky Country
description: LEAD: WITH brick buildings from another era scattered along a quiet two-block main street, this town is like any number of other ranching communities scattered across the high plains at the foot of the Rocky Mountains - except that Brooke Shields has just bought a place nearby, Mel Gibson has a spread to the east, and Ted

title: T. Roland Berner, 80, Chairman Of the Curtiss-Wright Corp., Dies
description: T. Roland Berner, chairman and president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation for the last 30 years, died of a heart attack on Sunday while visiting relatives in Boston. He was 80 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Banks Balk at Costs of Japan
description: United States trade negotiators have been hammering away for years to open Japanese markets, yet many American companies, even giants like Citibank, the nation's largest bank, find Japan a daunting challenge. They have discovered that the real problem is not so much governmental or cultural barriers, but that doing business here is too costly and competitive to justify a major effort.

title: The Behemoth and the Boson
description: The price of the United States' latest atom-smasher has just jumped a little - from $5.9 billion to $8 billion - and the designs aren't even completed. Before it leaps again, there's time for second thoughts. This dinosaur of a machine may crush more fruitful kinds of physical research.

title: GTE Contract
description: The GTE Government Systems Corporation, a division of the GTE Corporation of Stamford, Conn., received a $879.2 million contract from the Army for work on telephone equipment. The contract is part of GTE's continuing work on a battlefield telephone and teleprinter system being built by GTE and Thomson CSF of France. The latest contract is for work on 11 mobile sets and is expected to be completed by November.

title: Power Fails Briefly At Nuclear Station; No Danger Is Seen
description: A truck accident caused a failure of electrical power at the Plant Vogtle nuclear station in this eastern Georgia town today, but the resulting brief emergency did not affect the plant's safety, the Georgia Power Company said.

title: Review/Television;   Tom Brokaw Looks At the Hollywood of Today
description: How many movie biggies can be accommodated on a pinhead of a documentary? That seems to have been the challenge of ''The New Hollywood'' the NBC Special tonight at 10. Starting with the much advertised fact that the movie business is controlled by huge conglomerates and dedicated to smash hits, Tom Brokaw goes around asking hot producers, agents, directors and actors how they feel about the pressure to come up with blockbusters. The consensus is that, yes, the pressure is deplorable but talent will out and that they personally are making good livings yet not compromising their integrity.

title: 6 Hurt at British Oil Refinery
description: An explosion and fire struck a major oil refinery early today, injuring six workers, the authorities said. Firefighters brought the blaze under control at the Shell chemical processing plant at Stanlow about 10 miles from Liverpool, a spokesman for Shell U.K. Ltd., said. Ten people were in the plant at the time of the blast, and six were injured, including one person with serious burns, the BBC reported.

title: Big B Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $503,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: About New York;   Searchers' Cry: Will a Real Hero Please Sing Out!
description: Sir Kenneth Clark wrote in his book ''Civilization'' that opera is one of Western man's strangest inventions. ''It could not have been foreseen by any logical process,'' he said.

title: ACM Government Opportunity reports earnings for As of Jan 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net assets per share.

title: Manischewitz Is Accused of Price-Fixing
description: The Justice Department accused B. Manischewitz & Company of price-fixing yesterday.

title: Ames Suspends Annual Dividend
description: Ames Department Stores Inc., which expects to post its first annual loss, suspended its annual 10-cents-a-share common stock dividend. Ames's directors said the dividend would not be paid until the company became profitable. Ames paid a quarterly dividend of 2 1/2 cents on Thursday.

title: Systematics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Data Support Benefits Of Fluoride for Teeth
description: To the Editor:

title: Rep. Savage Claims Victory in Illinois
description: Representative Gus Savage has claimed victory in the Democratic primary for nomination to a sixth term in Chicago's Second Congressional District after an unexpectedly strong challenge from a relative newcomer.

title: Lendl and Sabatini Lose at the Lipton
description: On a sunny day where tenacity meant more than tenure, the Lipton International Players Championships lost both its defending champions.

title: ISRAELIS COMMENCE POWER BARGAINING
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, called Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, this morning and asked him if the Likud party would be interested in joining a Labor-led government. The answer was an unequivocal no.

title: El Salvador and Rebels Reportedly Agree to Talks
description: The Salvadoran Government and the leftist guerrillas have agreed to begin talks and to a tentative time frame for signing a peace treaty, senior Government officials said today.

title: Take Your Mark, Get Set: Go, Loyola!
description: How did Paul Westhead, the basketball coach at Loyola Marymount, arrive at his unusual, fleet, flying, headlong, nonstop, all-out, full throttle, full court, race-horse, shoot-as-soon-as-you-get-the-ball style of play? ''Quickly,'' he said. This was and was not a quip.

title: Budget Minuet in Albany
description: New Yorkers, confronted with a deficit-ridden state budget and a declining economy, need answers. Instead they're getting piecemeal proposals from their Governor, and little but evasion from Albany's Republican leaders.

title: Clarcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Paradise Fruit Co. reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gain of $114,076, or 13 cents a share, from insurance payments of a storm damage claim.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about two special Congressional elections in New York City misstated the vote totals in the 14th District, because of an error by the News Election Service. The final results were:

title: U.C.L.A. Back on Scene In the Title Sweepstakes
description: More than the billion-dollar television package, more than the proliferation of office pools from coast to coast, a basic difference in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament could be found in the respectful words of the coach of the 1990 U.C.L.A. Bruins and the challenge felt by one of his players.

title: Money-Fund Yields Are Up
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Power Corp. of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After $42,993,000 in extraordinary charges of Power Financial Corp.'s affiliate, Pargesa Holding S.A. c-Included the fourth quarter charge and gains on the sale of interests in Consolidated-Bathurst Inc. and Montreal Trustco Inc. d-After extraordinary losses of $1,456,000 for the quarter and $3,367,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Summagraphics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said its year-ago periods' results were reduced by about 5 cents a share for the quarter and 16 cents a share for the 9 months, due to a limitation on the use of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: Golden Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PARENT & CHILD
description: Polly Edmunds suspected something was wrong when, by the age of 3, her son Daniel could say only a few words and appeared a bit clumsy. Many friends and even some professionals told her simply to wait for him to catch up. Others accused her of babying him.

title: Hunt Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
Canadian Express reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $44,715,000 and $148,729,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively. The company said both years' losses resulted from provisions for the diminuition in value of the company's investments. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Colony Pacific Explorations reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The company said a substantial portion of the latest year's loss of $669,000 is related to the write-down of mineral properties in Alaska and British Columbia. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Notebook;   A Minnesota Group Is Pursuing the North Stars
description: Harvey Mackay of Minneapolis said yesterday that he might meet with representatives of the Minnesota North Stars' ownership as soon as tomorrow to look at their financial books and prepare a offer to buy the team.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Hazelwood Judge Rejects Jurors' Request
description: The jury in Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood's trial began deliberations today and sought exhibits dealing with whether the skipper was intoxicated when his tanker, the Exxon Valdez, ran aground last March and began spilling almost 11 million gallons of crude oil.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Iran Allowing Travel By Soviet Azerbaijanis
description: Iran announced today that for the first time in 72 years of Communist rule in the Soviet Union, Soviet Azerbaijanis were being allowed to travel in large numbers to Iran.

title: Outdoors;   Multi-Event Races Are Becoming More Popular
description: Snow or no, multi-event competitions still go on. At least that has been the experience at ski areas where such competitions have been held in the past. This year, with a new fall of snow in Vermont, things look more promising than ever.

title: Quilting, Weaving, Cultivating
description: Craft Times Three, Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street at Central Avenue, Newark; 201-596-6550.

title: Chronicle
description: The line between the press and the personages blurs tonight when TINA BROWN, the editor of Vanity Fair, gives a benefit attended by many of her cover subjects to aid another Vanity Fair subject, Phoenix House.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., a maker of power tools, said it had issued 2.5 million common shares to the 401(k) employee savings plan of its Emhart Corp. subsidiary for $47 million.

title: Health: Personal Health
description: Spring is here, the season of birds and bees, flowers and trees and wheeze and sneeze for millions of Americans with seasonal allergies. When the runny nose and itchy eyes become sufficiently annoying, most will reach for one of the dozens of over-the-counter or prescription drugs that promise relief from allergy symptoms.

title: Texas Billionaires Victorious on Hog Farm
description: The Bass brothers, a family of Texas billionaires, were victorious on Tuesday when voters in Weld County rejected a proposal that would have required a huge hog farm to build a $10 million plant to treat manure. The vote was 14,706 to 6,334.

title: Pentagon Tells Where It Lags in Weapons
description: The Pentagon told Congress today that the Soviet Union held significant leads in a weapons technology critical to national security and that Japan led the United States in five other strategic technologies.

title: Mandela Chides Baker on Talking With de Klerk, but Praises U.S.
description: Nelson Mandela scolded Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today for scheduling a meeting with President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa on Thursday, saying that such an encounter would only enhance Mr. de Klerk's stature before he had done anything serious to dismantle apartheid.

title: Ford Paid Jaguar $2 Billion Premium
description: The price of the Ford Motor Company's $2.5 billion acquisition of Jaguar P.L.C. was five times the British auto maker's actual net asset value, Ford disclosed in its annual report, which was sent out on Monday. Ford said it paid $2 billion over what it said was the fair value of Jaguar's net assets, which it pegged at $500 million.

title: Sandinistas Are Said to Yield on Army
description: The chief negotiator for President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro says that he believes a basic agreement now exists with Sandinista leaders on the full transfer of control over Nicaragua's military and security forces on Mrs. Chamorro's accession to power on April 25.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Invention, Design, Engineerng Assoc.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $74,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $185,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $46,000, or 2 cents a share, and $83,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Measurex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
Converting to Peace
description: Shareholders in Fortress America aren't waiting for Washington to convert from cold war defense to a diversified economic offense. If ''peace dividend'' is the political phrase of the moment, the next one is ''conversion.'' Paying attention to retooling of defense industries from military to consumer production is good sense. As people in California have found, it is also good politics.

title: The Navy's Disloyalty to Its Own
description: Eleven months after the explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard the U.S.S. Iowa, the Navy holds to its unproven, probably unprovable charge that one dead crew member was the culprit.

title: Kiddie Products reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Katalin Kovago has been promoted to management director of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and appointed to the agency's operating committee. Patricia Malkin has been promoted to senior vice president and creative director at the agency. Scott Carouge, Charley Cordle, Claire Hassid and Dick Holt have been promoted to senior vice presidents and associate creative directors.

title: Mongolia Picks a New President
description: Mongolia's Parliament chose the Foreign Trade Minister and initiator of the country's open-door policy as its President today, shortly after accepting the resignation of former President Zhambyn Batmonh.

title: Mideast: Still Not Ready for Peace
description: Peace, the conventional wisdom goes, seems to be breaking out everywhere. So why are the Arabs and Israelis unable even to begin talking about how to negotiate eventually? And how well has the Bush-Baker team done as Middle East peacemakers?

title: Chicago Dock & Canal reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Dance;   Movements And Sound Arranged By Chance
description: A marriage of high tech and the irrational has run through many of Merce Cunningham's dance pieces over the decades, and ''Polarity,'' his latest premiere, embodies this seeming contradiction.

title: Calendar: Ceramics, Antiques and Tours
description: Urban Chronicle, 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-996-1100.

title: Philharmonic Season to Open Sept. 12
description: Leonard Bernstein is to conduct three subscription series for the New York Philharmonic in December as part of the orchestra's 1990-91 season, with his newest composition, ''Arias and Barcarolles,'' and the Mendelssohn oratorio ''Elijah'' among the works to be performed. The season is Zubin Mehta's last as music director; he is to lead 39 concerts. Guest conductors include Charles Dutoit, Neeme Jarvi, Erich Leinsdorf, Christof Perick, Andre Previn, Giuseppe Sinopoli, Leonard Slatkin, Klaus Tennstedt and Franz Welser-Moest in his Philharmonic debut.

title: Agency Trying to Speed Up Rescue Effort
description: In an effort to accelerate the pace of the faltering savings and loan bailout, the top Federal manager of the rescue effort today announced changes in policy intended to make hundreds of insolvent institutions more attractive to potential buyers.

title: Board Clears Dinkins for a Cable TV Vote
description: The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board ruled yesterday that Mayor David N. Dinkins may participate in a vote today by the Board of Estimate on land-use matters involving cable-television franchises in Manhattan. The vote concerns whether cables now under the streets may remain there.

title: Edna R. Yardley, 87, Aide to Code Breaker
description: Edna Ramsaier Yardley, the widow and collaborator of Herbert O. Yardley, a pioneer code breaker, died of a stroke on Tuesday at her home. She was 87 years old.

title: Canstar Sports reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $4,500,000, or 30 cents a share, which included a $1 million gain and a $3.5 million tax credit. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,300,000, or 9 cents a share, which included a $1.2 million write-off and a $2.5 million tax credit. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Winfield Is Hailed On Return
description: A head of state could not have been greeted by a larger throng of reporters. Just after noon today, Dave Winfield drove into the players' parking lot, walked into the Yankee clubhouse and resumed a career that had been dormant for one year and two days.

title: Rutgers Is Eliminated In N.I.T. Quarterfinal
description: Penn State jumped off to an 11-point lead in the first four and a half minutes of its National Invitation Tournament quarterfinal game with Rutgers tonight and for a while looked as if it was going to send the Scarlet Knights right out of their own building. But the Nittany Lions had to turn back a Rutgers rally and hold on for a 58-55 victory.

title: Moto Photo Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Biotech Research Labs reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Aztec Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: A group of women brought off the upset of the day on Tuesday by ousting the fourth-seeded squad in the third round of Vanderbilt Knockout play here.

title: One Liberty Properties reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: b-Included financial advisory and transaction-related expenses of $1,401,414 for the latest year and $2,043,244 for 1988.

title: Review/Music;   Brahms, Front and Back
description: Amy Kaiser led the Dessoff Choirs in a concert of German music, sacred and secular, on Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Music by Brahms began and ended the program, and clustered around the intermission was a glance backward, in the form of two Heinrich Schutz psalm settings, and a leap into the 20th century for Heinz Werner Zimmermann's ''Vesper'' (1962).

title: Despite Problems, the Census Bureau Hails Its First Count of the Homeless
description: The Census Bureau today concluded its first broad-based effort to count the people who sleep in the shelters, subways, flophouses and garbage-bag tents of America.

title: Books of The Times;   Life (and It's Cheap) in a Colonized Culture
description: Dogeaters

title: Close to Home
description: I had imagined my arrival, that I'd come in the door and call out something ridiculous like ''Honey, I'm home.'' First I'd hear the tinkle of the bell I had hung around her neck during the last year. Then out she'd step from wherever she was hiding and walk, unsteady on her paws, toward the object of her constant affections. But I came home too late, and all that remains of Calypso is the collar with the little bell.

title: Maze of Shops for Adventurous in Paris
description: You can always spend your francs at Hermes or Christian Lacroix on the chic Faubourg St.-Honore or check out the new Emporio Armani on the Place Vendome, where a sweat shirt costs $100. But an adventurous shopper might have more fun exploring the Marais, the old Jewish quarter of Paris in the Third Arrondissement, where fashionable boutiques are sprouting among kosher food stores, Moroccan pastry shops, art galleries, cafes and tranquil parks. It is a lovely and lively place to spend an afternoon.

title: MGI Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Oakley Sidelined For 6-8 Weeks
description: Short of losing Patrick Ewing with a season-ending injury, the news yesterday could not have been worse for the fast-slipping Knicks. They lost Charles Oakley, their best rebounder and one of their better passers and defensive players, for six to eight weeks with a broken bone in the left hand.

title: Doubt Raised on Bone Disease Treatment
description: A widely used treatment for osteoporosis, a debilitating bone disease that afflicts millions of people, does not prevent the tiny fractures that cause the spine to collapse, a new study has found.

title: Dog Got a Bad Bite? Try Orthodontia
description: WHEN the veterinarian says it's time for the dog's dental checkup, certain questions inevitably arise: Does a dog get cavities? Does a dog need to brush every night? Does a dog need to floss? Does a dog need braces? The answers are no, yes, no and sometimes. Dentistry for animals is the fastest-growing branch of veterinary medicine. In a 1988 survey, 5.2 percent of pet owners said their pets had had dental work on their most recent visit to the vet. That is more than twice as many as in 1982, according to a mail survey with 30,000 respondents done by the American Veterinary Medical Association, whose headquarters are in Schaumburg, Ill.

title: Caspen Oil Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Harton Singer Semple, Golf Official, 69
description: Harton Singer Semple, who was president of the United States Golf Association in 1974 and 1975, died of heart failure on Sunday in Augusta, Ga. He was 69 years old.

title: Silence Is a Lie
description: Former President Jimmy Carter arrives in Jerusalem, carrying with him the gift some prominent travelers love to bring to the Israeli capital - a package of sharp criticisms to be publicly unwrapped and displayed.

title: New Hampshire In Turnpike Issue
description: The State of New Hampshire priced a $100 million issue of turnpike-system revenue bonds yesterday with a maximum yield of about 7.48 percent for an issue due 2020.

title: Jersey College Chief Leaving for Tulsa Post
description: The president of Fairleigh Dickinson University, Robert H. Donaldson, was appointed president of the University of Tulsa today.

title: CHILEAN GENERAL IS BADLY WOUNDED
description: A former Chilean Air Force chief, an original member of the military junta that seized power in 1973, was shot and seriously wounded today. A Communist guerrilla group took responsibility for the attack.

title: Cabbies Practice Passenger Selectivity to Protect Themselves;   Worse in a Wheelchair
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Securities Off in Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell in light trading yesterday, as dealers took profits after Tuesday's rally.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-19

title: Clarus Corp. reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included a $1.6 million provision for a writedown of loans receivable. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Trizec Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Theater;   McCowen Returns in 'St. Mark's Gospel'
description: Alec McCowen's ''St. Mark's Gospel'' is a performance as revelation. Without theatrics, he tells the story of Christ as recounted by Mark. Though Mr. McCowen has given this solo performance innumerable times in the last two decades, his actor's art has kept his delivery extraordinarily fresh. The story is told every time as if for the first time.

title: After Casting, Something For Serving Catch of Day
description: SPRING'S green buds are tweaking the tips of branches, and for fishermen, that means only one thing: trout season nears. For fly-fishermen who can't wait to get on the stream, Woodmere China has a diversion.

title: Chronicle;   By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON
description: Mayor David N. DINKINS, who said he ''learned how to move the pieces 40 years ago'' but has never really played chess, took on the world champion, GARY KASPAROV, in a good-humored match yesterday in the Blue Room at City Hall to call attention to the news that New York City will be host to the first 12 scheduled matches of the World Chess Championship, set to begin Oct. 8. It will be the first time since 1907 that a World Chess Championship has been held in the United States, the Mayor said. The remaining games, as many as needed, will take place in Lyons, France.

title: Martin's Widow Files an Action
description: Billy Martin's widow has filed a notice of claim charging the town of Fenton, N.Y., with negligence in her husband's death in a motor-vehicle accident Dec. 25.

title: A Future In Hardware
description: ''MEN are said to be happiest when shopping in hardware stores,'' said the New York jewelry designer Alex Streeter. But being an artistic fellow, Mr. Streeter, 41 years old, decided to forsake hardware stores in favor of his own chromed pewter light switch plates, towel hooks and handles.

title: Channel 2 Receives 11 Emmys
description: Several independently produced news programs and two locally produced public-television programs won local Emmy Awards on Tuesday. The Emmys were presented for programs produced in New York State and northern New Jersey from Sept. 1, 1988, to Aug. 31, 1989.

title: Hong Kong Journal;   Is the Skyscraper Looking Daggers at Neighbors?
description: The Bank of China moved this week into its new Hong Kong headquarters, a spectacular glass tower designed by I. M. Pei and already heralded as one of the most distinctive buildings in the world.

title: As Always, Yanks Look To 'the Man'
description: rrHalf an hour before the Yankees' workout, Don Mattingly was putting on his spikes when Deion Sanders, an outfielder when he's not returning punts for the Atlanta Falcons, approached.

title: Steinway Offers Tours
description: For the first time in its 136-year history, the piano maker Steinway & Sons is giving free guided tours of its factory in Astoria, Queens. The three-hour tours will be given on Fridays at 9 A.M., except for the first two Fridays in July and the Friday between Christmas and New Year's. For information and reservations: (718) 721-2600.

title: Household Offers Extendible Notes
description: The Household Finance Corporation, a unit of Household International Inc., is offering $187.97 million in extendible notes with a final maturity of April 1, 1995 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Defensive Line of Jets Gets New Coach and New Look
description: The Jets' defense may break this year, but with a new 4-3 it won't bend.

title: Abbott Labs Is Penalized
description: The Food and Drug Administration has barred Government agencies from buying certain drugs from Abbott Laboratories, contending the company failed to correct violations of quality standards at a suburban Chicago plant.

title: Man Is Found Not Guilty In Death of Police Officer
description: A 26-year-old former convict who was charged with killing a police officer on a Brooklyn street last year was acquitted yesterday of murder.

title: Yanks to Play First Home Game April 12
description: The Yankees, who lost six home games when the season was pushed back a week, found a new slot for one of them yesterday.

title: USX Advises Holders To Vote Against Icahn
description: The USX Corporation, in its first official response to a proposal by Carl C. Icahn to spin off at least 80 percent of the company's steel business, said in proxy material issued yesterday that the plan would hurt the company and advised shareholders to vote against it.

title: Safiyeh Firouz, Iranian Princess, 87
description: Princess Safiyeh Firouz, a member of the Iranian royal family deposed in the 1920's, died of a heart attack on Tuesday. She was 87 years old and lived here in exile.

title: Synergistics Indus reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Restoring a Desk Surface With Leather
description: LEAD: Early writing tables and desks were covered with a coarsely woven fabric known in France as bure. The fabric, resembling baize, was at first blue and then green, which has been the choice for many a cloth-covered desktop to this day.

title: Mitchell Fisher, 86; Rabbi Left the Pulpit To Become a Lawyer
description: Mitchell Salem Fisher, a rabbi who resigned his pulpit to become a lawyer, died of a heart ailment on Monday at Greenwood House, Home for the Jewish Aging in Ewing, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: F.C.C. Chief Urges Accord In Networks-Studios Fight
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission warned the television networks and Hollywood producers yesterday that if they cannot negotiate an agreement in their dispute over program distribution, the commission will begin a full-blown rule-making proceeding.

title: Geneva Mathiasen, 91; Led Council on Aging
description: Geneva Mathiasen, former executive director of the National Council on Aging, died of heart failure on Tuesday at a nursing home in Suffern, N.Y. She was 91 years old and lived in Tuxedo, N.Y.

title: Jefferies Tries to Change Image
description: Gregg Jefferies, the rookie everybody loved to hate last season, arrived in the training camp of the Mets with an olive branch today and said: ''I'm not a pouter, but I guess it looked like I was pouting. I'm sorry. I've learned. I've matured.'' It looked like pouting, all right. There he was, the ''phenom'' who took baseball by storm when he hit .321 with 6 home runs in the final 29 games of 1988. But then there he was in 1989, the teacher's pet, getting personal lessons from Davey Johnson on how to play second base, but struggling along at .182 for three months and taking it very hard, indeed, flinging his helmet and sulking and throwing tantrums while his teammates sizzled.

title: Volatility Jolts Stocks In Tokyo
description: The deeply troubled Tokyo stock market went through its most volatile day ever today as the plummeting value of the yen and Government efforts to strengthen it set share prices swinging wildly and left investors and market professionals stunned.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Campbell-Mithun-Esty President Leaving Post
description: Laurence M. Wassong, the president and chief operating officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty, announced his resignation yesterday. He said he would remain a consultant to the agency and would manage several of its accounts.

title: Lord Rothschild, 79, a Scientist And Member of Banking Family
description: Lord Rothschild, a scientist and member of the famous banking family who was linked to one of Britain's most well-known spy scandals, died Tuesday. He was 79 years old.

title: Setback for Bailout and Savings Regulator
description: In a decision that could upset much of President Bush's savings and loan bailout, a Federal judge ruled today that the appointments of the nation's top savings and loan regulator and his immediate predecessor were unconstitutional and that their actions were invalid.

title: Aztar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $127,130,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $1,265,000 for the quarter and $3,898,000 for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary tax credit of $563,000, or 1 cent a share. Year-ago results are restated to conform to current year's presentation.

title: Norton Board Reviewing Offer
description: he board of the Norton Company met in New York yesterday to review the $1.64 billion buyout offer from BTR P.L.C. but made no announcement afterward. Norton's board has asked shareholders not to tender their shares to BTR until the board responds to the offer. The board has said that it will respond to the $75-a-share bid by March 29.

title: High Court's Ruling Limits Law on Grand Jury Secrecy
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that state laws prohibiting grand jury witnesses from ever making public their own testimony violate the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech.

title: Talking Deals;   Schwinn Is Building Bikes The U.S. Way in Hungary
description: ''A friend of mine came into this factory the other day and said, 'Boy, it's changed; it's hardly recognizable,' '' said Laszlo Nogradi, general manager of the Schwinn Bicycle Company's 14-month-old joint venture in Hungary.

title: Washington Talk;   The Vision Thing Again, But Some Don't See It
description: Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, could barely suppress his grin. How long, a reporter had asked, would a newly published report on the Bush Administration's national security strategy remain in effect?

title: Intensity Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included $7 million writedown of oil and gas properties and production equipment and a $934,000 loss from operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Meatpacker Settles with OSHA
description: In a settlement the Government hopes will become a model for the industry, one of the nation's largest meatpackers agreed to pay a fine of nearly $1 million and to try to offer workers more protection from injuries caused by repetitive motion.

title: Hotel Investors
description: The Hotel Investors Corporation and Hotel Investors Trust, a hotel management company and real estate investment trust whose shares are paired for trading, said they had retained Salomon Brothers Inc. to consider selling their two Las Vegas, Nev., casinos: the Bourbon Street Hotel and Casino and the King 8 Hotel and Gambling Hall. In February, the companies agreed to sell their interest in 31 hotel properties for $185.5 million to an affiliate of the EIE International Corporation, a Japanese company. Shares of the companies were unchanged at $4.75 today, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Metro Matters;   Rockefeller Plea: Turn From Greed To Public Service
description: It might strike cynics as paradoxical to hear David Rockefeller complain about capitalistic greed, but with communism - and New York City's streets - disintegrating, he wondered, what kind of example are Americans and New Yorkers setting for the rest of the world?

title: Bamboo Coaxed to Flower in Lab; Global Impact on the Crop Is Seen
description: In a significant advance for the cultivation of one of the world's most important timber and fodder crops, scientists say they have coaxed bamboo plants to flower in the laboratory, a feat never before managed. Bamboo in the field can take more than a century to flower and produce seeds.

title: Upheaval in the East;   With 3 Dead, Soldiers Break Up Romanian and Hungarian Mobs
description: Army tanks and troops separated rival, taunting crowds of Romanians and ethnic Hungarians today in a Transylvania city where three people were killed and 300 hurt in fighting on Tuesday night between mobs wielding iron bars, scythes and pitchforks, witnesses said.

title: Albany Votes Protections For Reporters
description: The New York State Senate today gave final approval to a measure that protects news organizations from having to turn over to the courts virtually any information gathered by their reporters or television crews.

title: Dinkins Names Labor Mediator To New Position
description: Signaling his intention to give City Hall a more active role in labor issues, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday the appointment of a new chief labor negotiator and gave him an expanded mandate to get involved in private-sector labor disputes.

title: Britain Opens Inquiry Into '74 Pub Bombings
description: The British Government announced today a new police inquiry into the controversial case of six men convicted of murdering 21 people in the bombings of two Birmingham pubs in 1974.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The New York Post Aims to Improve Image
description: In a new advertising campaign entitled ''The Three Biggest Lies in New York,'' The New York Post acknowledges that it has an image problem. A candid television commercial and several different billboard ads repeat things people say when they'd rather not tell the truth. The first two lies differ from ad to ad. For instance, ''I love being single.'' Or, ''I don't have any spare change.'' Or, ''I only watch Channel 13.'' The third lie is constant: ''I never read The Post.''

title: Head of Retail Group Plans To Resign to Do Consulting
description: After 19 years as president of the National Retail Merchants Association, the nation's largest retail trade group, James R. Williams is stepping down to form his own consulting business, to lecture and to write. Mr. Williams will remain a consultant to the association after he officially leaves the staff position on April 2.

title: NAMIBIA STRESSES A MIXED ECONOMY
description: As Namibia celebrated its first day of independence today, President Sam Nujoma proclaimed his Government's commitment to a mixed economy and invited foreign investors to come and help break the country's dependence on South Africa.

title: Sage Analytics Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: International Telecharge Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said its fourth quarter 1989 net income included federal income tax carry-backs of $294,000, and certain other infrequently occurring items that have a net positive impact of $961,000. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Dinkins's 2-Pronged Budget Strategy
description: In revealing a new gap in New York City's budget for the coming fiscal year, Mayor David N. Dinkins on Monday not only put pressure on the Governor, legislators and other politicians to help him now, but may also have made it easier for himself in deciding how to spend money later.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PLANNING for the purchase of new kitchen cabinets, either to install yourself or to have installed professionally, is a remodeling project most people can handle. The key to success is to make detailed drawings of the proposed new arrangement.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * Siboney Advertising, an agency partly owned by Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., has acquired a majority interest in Martinez & Associates, a Dallas agency specializing in the Hispanic market.

title: Taiwan President Re-elected; He Meets Protesters
description: President Lee Teng-hui was re-elected today by an overwhelming majority of Taiwan's National Assembly delegates, some escorted to the ballot boxes in wheelchairs, and then promptly met with student demonstrators to discuss their demands for greater democracy.

title: Fernandez Backs Designating Subway Cars for Students
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has begun exploring the idea of designating police-patrolled subway cars for students as a way to protect children from violence as they go to and from school.

title: Q&A
description: To Paint Siding

title: World Trade Grew in 1989
description: International trade volume could slow slightly this year, with inflation and rising interest rates in industrialized nations hampering expansion, the world's main trade forum reported today.

title: WD-40 Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Dramex Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $126,000, or 4 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Initio reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $75,892 for the quarter and $110,021 for the 9 months, and extraordinary tax credits of $221,930 and $148,907 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included income of $3,039 for the quarter and a loss of $11,936 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Brown Appoints Panel to Review Gun Guidelines
description: Saying that New York City faces ''an unprecedented level of violence,'' Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown yesterday appointed a committee to review guidelines on when officers are to fire their guns.

title: Strike Stalls Greyhound's Revival
description: When Fred G. Currey acquired Greyhound three years ago, he was convinced there was only one way for the dominant national bus line to survive against the airlines and their discount fares. Prices would have to be slashed and service improved to prevent travelers from choosing to fly or not make the trip at all.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian Soldiers Are Outcasts in Soviet Army
description: Virginijus Vitkauskas came to the Lithuanian government's Commission on Military Service this morning, his right eye swollen and purple and his upper teeth punched out. He was the victim, he said, of soldiers in his unit, who said they would teach the young Lithuanian what they thought of his republic's drive for independence.

title: F.B.I. Releases Sketches Of Art Thieves in Boston
description: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum reopened today as the Federal Bureau of Investigation released composite sketches of the two thieves who stole 12 masterpieces from the building Sunday in the largest art theft in history.

title: American Monitor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Metro Datelines;   Swan Killing Plan Pressed by Agency
description: Although many people are opposed, Connecticut wildlife officials still intend to reduce the state's mute swan population by invading the birds' nests and shaking their eggs.

title: When Designers Take the Cake, the Cake Takes Surprising Shapes
description: THE members of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, which turned 75 years old last week, specialize in the design of maps, annual reports, brochures, exhibitions, posters, books and magazines. Their considerable talents are generally not available for creating three-dimensional objects out of flour, butter and sugar.

title: U.S. ENDS ITS CURBS AGAINST NAMIBIA
description: President Bush today lifted all economic sanctions that had been imposed on Namibia while it was under South African control and promised to make the newly independent African nation a full trading partner of the United States.

title: U.S. and Japanese to Meet on Trade
description: Administration officials said today that a meeting Friday between Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and his Japanese counterpart is intended to head off major trade disputes this summer and to consider moves to check the recent fall of the yen.

title: White House Opposes Restrictions on Arts Grants
description: Rejecting proposals by Senator Jesse Helms, the Bush Administration told Congress today that it opposed legislation to control the content of art supported with Federal funds.

title: One, Another, Then Just a Few More
description: WILL ROGERS never met a man he didn't like. Judyth van Amringe has seldom met an object she didn't like.

title: Del Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Browns' Risien Retires
description: Cody Risien, a right tackle with the Cleveland Browns for 11 seasons, announced yesterday that he was retiring because of family responsibilities and a string of injuries and operations. Risien was a seventh-round draft pick in 1979 out of Texas A&M and played in 146 games for Cleveland, 140 as a starter. His most recent surgery was on Feb. 8, when he had bone spurs removed from his right elbow and torn cartilage in his left knee repaired. (AP)

title: Cognos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a loss of $4.7 million associated with the restructuring of the company during the first and second quarters. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Report Faults Cable Companies in Manhattan
description: In another round of sparring over whether to renew Manhattan cable television franchises, a law firm hired by the city said the two companies that now provide service ''appear not to meet the city's future cable-related community needs and interests.''

title: 3 Charged With Fraud In Arms Bids
description: The long-running Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing practices led to the indictment today of a former Navy official and two consultants to military contractors.

title: 16 Held as Suspects in a Queens Crack Ring
description: Sixteen people who the authorities said were members of a major violent Queens crack ring were arrested yesterday in police raids on their homes.

title: February Deficit Grows
description: The Federal budget deficit totaled $36.42 billion last month, 30.1 percent higher than the $27.87 billion imbalance in February 1989, the Treasury Department reported today. Receipts totaled $65.17 billion in February, up 5.3 percent from the same month last year. But expenditures amounted to $101.58 billion, a 13.2 percent increase over February 1989. For the first five months of the 1990 fiscal year, the deficit was $97.52 billion, just $2.48 billion less than the Gramm-Rudman deficit target for the entire year.

title: More on Cousy
description: Bob Cousy, the star guard for the Boston Celtics in the 1950's and early 1960's, who resigned last month as president of the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., reportedly quit because of his displeasure with the way the hall handled its recent election of players. The Worcester (Mass.) Telegram and Gazette reported yesterday that Cousy quit because the executive committee ordered a new vote after none of the 16 nominees for admission received the 18 votes required from the 24-man honors committee. The newspaper said Cousy had strongly protested the executive committee's decision to repoll the honors committee, but his objection was overruled.

title: Nuclear Plant Shuts Down
description: Oregon's only nuclear generating plant ceased operating Tuesday after a monitor of the steam flow between the reactor and the turbines was discovered to be incorrectly set. The Trojan plant, about 35 miles northwest of Portland, was to have been shut anyway at midnight Tuesday for three months of maintenance work. A spokesman for Portland General Electric, which owns the plant, said the plant was never in danger and the steam monitor did not govern radioactive systems.

title: Best Costumes for a Walk on Coals
description: WHERE can I find a Celtic lap harp? (The Music Inn, at 169 West Fourth Street.) Can you arrange for me to go on patrol with the Guardian Angels? (Call ''G.I. Joe'' at 212-397-7822.) Are there other catfish lovers in New York? (Try the Royal Order of Catfish Lovers, P.O. Box 3376, Grand Central Station, N.Y. 10163.) These are examples of the 200 queries posed each week to Manhattan Intelligence, a six-month-old SoHo company that answers questions about Manhattan in eight languages, including Dutch and Japanese.

title: Hungary Halts Emigre Flights After Muslim Threat
description: The Hungarian airline has suspended flights carrying Soviet emigrants to Israel, the official press agency said today. The action came six days after a militant Muslim group in Lebanon threatened to attack airlines and airports that help transport the new wave of Jewish settlers.

title: 3 Killed as 2 Couples Are Attacked in Bronx
description: Two men and a woman were shot to death in two separate attacks on two married couples in the Bronx last night, the police said.

title: Nytest Environmental Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Crisis in Book Publishing? That's an Old Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Sylvan Keiser, 82, Retired Psychoanalyst
description: Sylvan Keiser, a retired psychoanalyst, died on Saturday at his home in Sacramento, Calif., after a long illness. He was 82 years old and had lived in Manhattan for most of his professional life.

title: George Y. Lesher, 64, Heart-Drug Developer
description: Dr. George Yohe Lesher, a scientist who discovered drugs used in treating heart disease, drowned in a canoeing accident on Saturday at Normans Kill in Guilderland, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived in East Greenbush, N.Y.

title: Furon Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter and year included a gain of $2,576,000, or 18 cents a share, from the sale of various assets. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: An Acting Director Is Chosen For AIDS Program at W.H.O.
description: Dr. Michael Merson, a 44-year-old American, was named today as acting director of the World Health Organization's program to fight AIDS. He succeeds Dr. Jonathan Mann, who resigned last week in a dispute with the head of the agency, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima.

title: Ads by Daily News Seeking to Replace Mailers in a Strike
description: The Daily News has placed a classified advertisement in today's issues of the major daily newspapers in the metropolitan area, including The New York Times, seeking replacements for its mailers in the event of a strike.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Scoresby's Response To Success
description: SCORESBY has become the fifth-largest brand of Scotch in America - without advertising. Scoresby Scotch has grown into the largest brand in California, indeed the Western United States -without advertising. While sales of domestic Scotch declined by 4.6 percent last year, Scoresby's sales grew by more than 11 percent - without advertising.

title: Varity Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ANTI-ABORTION BILL IN IDAHO TAKES AIM AT LANDMARK CASE
description: The Idaho Legislature is expected to approve an abortion bill on Thursday that is specifically intended to persuade a pivotal Supreme Court Justice to overturn the landmark ruling that legalized abortion nationwide.

title: X Factors in the Round of 16
description: Pete Gillen, the basketball coach at Xavier, chuckled when he was told that Tom Penders, the Texas coach, was portraying the Longhorns as a poor, downtrodden underdog team that had beaten all sorts of odds to reach the round of 16 in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: For This Artist, Cliches Provide a Herd of Ideas
description: WATCH what you say to Lynn DiNino. Any offhand remark about ''bringing home the bacon'' is likely to result in a deadpan fabric sculpture. ''I'm inspired by cliches,'' the Seattle fabric artist said.

title: INSIDE
description: Grand Jury Secrecy Limited

title: NEW STROKE VALUE FOUND FOR ASPIRIN
description: Daily doses of aspirin or another blood-thinning drug dramatically reduce the risk of stroke from a heartbeat irregularity that affects more than a million Americans, researchers said today.

title: List Will Use Insanity Defense, Judge Says
description: John E. List will argue he is innocent of fatally shooting his family 18 years ago because of his mental condition at the time, the judge presiding over his trial said today.

title: Scientific Measurement Sysems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Abortion Right Backers See a Victory
description: The outcome of a little-noticed suburban legislative race overshadowed other results in Tuesday's statewide primary here, and it may have cost a prominent conservative and ardent abortion foe her seat in the Illinois General Assembly.

title: Marshall Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Doubt on Bone Therapy
description: Researchers say a widely used treatment for a debilitating bone disease that afflicts millions of people is ineffective. Page B15.

title: The Subtle Arts of Growing Elephant and Other Ears
description: IN households where there is more than one dedicated gardener, disagreements sometimes occur about whether certain plants deserve a place in the garden. Frederick McGourty tells just such a story in his delightful recent book, ''The Perennial Gardener,'' (Houghton-Mifflin, $24.95).

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Western Union's Debts May Force Bankruptcy
description: The Western Union Corporation, plagued by huge debt payments, said yesterday in a filing that it may be forced to seek bankruptcy protection.The 139-year-old company that pioneered global business communications with its telegraph and telex services mentioned the possibility in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Japanese Halt Underwriting
description: Japanese securities firms are halting equity-linked financing of Japanese companies at home and abroad until the falling Tokyo Stock Exchange recovers, officials said today.

title: Depleted Rangers Turn to Rookies and Falter
description: Dump it in, dump it out, dump it anywhere, but don't do much of anything with the puck.

title: New Restrictions on Smoking For Riders on Amtrak Trains
description: Amtrak, the Federal passenger rail line, will impose new limits on smoking in its trains starting April 1.

title: New Reports At N.C. State
description: North Carolina State's board of trustees, stunned by new information regarding the academic performance of Jim Valvano's basketball players, has directed its attorney to seek the coach's resignation, a newspaper reported.

title: Dow Falls 10.81 After an Early Rally Fails
description: Stock prices gave way to profit taking yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average sliding 10.81 points, to 2,727.93. The Dow fell back sharply after a brief early-morning spurt to 2,751.

title: C. van Ravenswaay, Museum Director, 78
description: Charles van Ravenswaay, a museum director and specialist in American frontier history, died of cancer on Tuesday in Cokesbury Village, a retirement community in Hockessin, Del. He was 78 years old.

title: Canada Wants Banks To Record Cash Deals
description: In an acknowledgment of Canada's emerging role as one of the world's leading havens for concealing illegal narcotics profits, the Canadian Government has shifted policy and proposed the adoption of a law requiring banks and other financial institutions to maintain records of large cash transactions.

title: Salant Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $700,000 in the fourth quarter and year related to estimated losses on accounts receivable due from Allied and Federated stores; the year also included a charge of $6.5 million related to restructuring costs. c-Net income The 1989 and 1988 periods included the results of Manhattan Industries from May 1, 1988, and Denton Mills Inc. from Feb. 4, 1989.

title: Cannell to Buy Ohio Station
description: Cannell Communications Inc. said on Tuesday that it would acquire WUAB-TV in Cleveland from the Gaylord Broadcasting Company. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Healthcare Technologies reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said results are in U.S. dollars; all dollar figures are calculated using the exchange rate as of Dec. 31 of 1.963 new Israeli shekels to $1.

title: Corruption 'Prosecutor' Urged by School Board
description: The New York City Board of Education, going further than the recommendation of an investigating commission, proposed yesterday that the school system's inspector general be granted ''the full powers of a special prosecutor.''

title: Michael Prendergast, 76, Democratic Leader, Dies
description: Michael H. Prendergast, a former chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee and a former State Director of Public Safety, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Haverstraw, N.Y.

title: Peronist Workers Rebel in Argentina
description: The growing conflict between President Carlos Saul Menem and those who elected him - the rank and file of the Peronist Party - broke out today into a one-day strike by state workers and a large march on the Congress.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Kohl's Foes Want NATO Recast If a Reunified Germany Is to Join
description: A committee of the opposition Social Democrats led by the party's standard-bearer said today that a united Germany might remain in NATO until the establishment of a new European security order, but only if the alliance abandoned much of its current strategy.

title: Health: Psychiatry;   Brain Structure Differences Linked To Schizophrenia in Study of Twins
description: In the first clear evidence that subtle abnormalities in brain structure are associated with schizophrenia, scientists have found differences in brain anatomy between identical twins, one with the disorder and the other normal.

title: National Service Indus reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
First Illinois Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,217,000 and $13,128,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period.

title: Logitek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Crisis in Book Publishing? That's an Old Story;   Pantheon's Niche
description: To the Editor:

title: Even as U.S. Fights for Entry, Some Companies Quit Japan
description: For nearly two decades Avon Products Inc. was one of America's biggest success stories here, a company that spent years tailoring its products for Japanese women and learning how to outsmart a distribution system that has defeated many foreign companies. It paid off: Last year Avon reaped a quarter of its corporate profits in Japan, even though the country accounts for less than a tenth of its sales.

title: Koala Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Hornbeck Offshore Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included the effect of non-recurring charges totaling $2,223,000 recorded in connection with reorganization of two limited partnerships in which the company served as the general partner. c-Net income Prior years have been restated for adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 96, relating to income taxes.

title: The Substance of a California Exhibit Is Substance
description: NEW materials drive design as much as imagination does. Consider how different Mies van der Rohe's and Marcel Breuer's chairs might have been without the invention of tubular steel.

title: H.E.R.O. Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Clean Air Compromise Survives Another Attack
description: Senate leaders turned back another major challenge to their agreement with the White House on clean air legislation today as the Senate defeated an amendment to strengthen the ability of the Federal Government to clean up urban smog. The vote was 53 to 46. It now appears that the Senate-Administration compromise legislation, reached after a month of intense closed door negotiations, is likely be upheld by the full Senate despite strong opposition by environmentalists and their allies. On Tuesday night the chamber voted down an amendment that would have broken the agreement by requiring stricter controls on pollution from automobiles.

title: Rituals Of Keeping Memories
description: ''Forget Me Not: Ritual and Remembrance in the Lives of Rhode Island Women,'' an exhibition sponsored by the Rhode Island Historical Society, examines the way Victorian women memorialized rites of passage.

title: Sequa Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,498,000 for the quarter and $4,637,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,307,000 and $4,080,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest periods' results reflected the inclusion of a $15.1 million pre-tax loss on transactions concluded in the final quarter of 1989 to restructure Sequa's aerospace group. Results for all periods reflected the reconsolidation of the company's men's apparel division, which had previously been classified as a discontinued operation.

title: Dump Search In New York: Exporting City's Refuse
description: Fifteen months ago, in an effort to keep the giant Fresh Kills Landfill from filling up too fast, New York City doubled the fee it charges private garbage haulers for the right to dump trash there.

title: Acton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $1,571,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $6,986,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Included an extraordinary charge of $224,000. The 1989 earnings included $11,252,223 of income realized in connection with the sale of the company's shares of Land of Lincoln Savings & Loan resulting from the acquisition of Land of Lincoln by Household International and included about $11,910,000 of gain from the sale of the company's Cable Television System located in Beaufort County, S.C. The company said the fourth quarter 1989 loss was primarily due to a decline in the value of certain securities in the company's investment portfolio.

title: KEY RATES
Secret Ballots To Be Allowed
description: The directors of Texaco Inc., the Amoco Corporation and the Foxboro Company have agreed to allow secret ballots for proxy votes, according to the office of the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman.

title: Pilot of Plane in Ocean Plunge Is Accused of Fraud
description: Thomas Root, the attorney who ditched his plane in the Atlantic Ocean last summer, was indicted today on 33 counts of fraud and other crimes involving radio stations he was representing before a Federal agency.

title: Upheaval in the East;   In a Pact, Poland Opens Doors to U.S. Business
description: President Bush and the Prime Minister of Poland signed a treaty today to increase American investment in Poland. It was the first such United States agreement with one of the newly emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.

title: Upheaval in the East;   GORBACHEV TELLS THE LITHUANIANS TO TURN IN ARMS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made use of his new executive powers tonight to tighten Soviet resistance to Lithuanian independence, ordering civilians in Lithuania to surrender private firearms to representatives of the central Government, and putting foreigners under stricter controls in traveling to the increasingly anxious republic.

title: Morgan Hydrocarbons reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Growing Up Flabby in America
description: FOR nearly four decades, health and fitness experts, educators, parents, even Presidents, have prodded and cajoled and used other powers of persuasion in a futile attempt to whip America's youngsters into shape. Not only was there a collective sense that Johnny couldn't read; he couldn't touch his toes either.

title: Getty Buys van Gogh 'Irises,' but Won't Tell Price
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum announced yesterday that it had acquired ''Irises,'' the painting by Vincent van Gogh that has come to epitomize the extravagance of the booming art market. The work was bought for an undisclosed sum from Alan Bond, an Australian industrialist who bid a record $53.9 million for it at an auction in November 1987 at Sotheby's in New York.

title: TV Debates Need third Party Candidates;   Ban Political Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Dorothy Spence Illson, Magazine Editor, 70
description: Dorothy Spence Illson, a retired editor at Life and Fortune magazines, died of cancer on Tuesday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital Medical Center. She was 70 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday, about a census taker interviewing a homeless man at a church in Manhattan, misidentified the church. It was St. Paul's Chapel at Broadway and Fulton Street.

title: A Setback for Bailout, And a Bid to Speed It
description: In a decision that could upset much of President Bush's savings and loan bailout, a Federal district judge ruled that the appointments of the top savings regulator and his predecessor were unconstitutional.

title: Columbia Pictures Fills Out Its Top Team
description: Peter Guber and Jon Peters, who have run Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. since shortly after the company was acquired last fall by the Sony Corporation, finished filling out their top management team yesterday by naming Frank Price chairman of the Columbia Pictures film studio.

title: New Report Links Law on Aliens To Ethnic Bias Against Workers
description: Three years after it took effect, a major immigration law has resulted in widespread ethnic discrimination against people legally entitled to work, a new report says.

title: Power Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $46,634,000 mainly from the company's share of a writedown taken by Pargesa Holding S.A. of its indirect interest in Drexel Burnham Lambert Group. c-After extraordinary losses of $1,206,000 for the quarter and $4,153,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Managers Scrambling to Get Teams Ready Managers Are Scrambling to Get Teams Ready
description: The manager's desk is uncluttered and clean, even now, on the second day of spring training with so much work still to do.
