In front of Bucky Dent, besides the tape recorders belonging to reporters, there are only the necessities: a briefcase, two telephones and, perhaps most important of all, a sheet of paper with a typewritten itemized agenda.

title: Care Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place;   Funds Questioned On Quoted Yields
description: IN the fast-growing world of money market funds, two have stood out over the last year, largely because they have managed to pay higher interest rates than their competitors. They have done this by charging either no management fee or a lower one than other funds.

title: Review/Recital;   Christa Ludwig Takes On Schubert's Raw Despair
description: Anyone who listens carefully to Schubert's ''Winterreise'' can understand why the question used to arise whether this painful study of a disintegrating human personality should be performed in public. Written in the composer's dying months, the 24-song cycle is almost clinical in its depiction of a mind ravaged by abandoned hopes, delusions and loss of contact with society. No wonder this bleak reverie about a ''winter's journey'' into despair and resignation, if not immediate death, finds so few singers capable of sustaining its interior drama over an uninterrupted 90-minute span.

title: Greentree Software reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Counting the Homeless: A Lonely, Iffy, Wary Job
description: Under a steady drizzle, Edward Diaz and Elizabeth Cruz walked briskly along deserted streets and pathways on the Lower East Side of Manhattan shortly after midnight yesterday, two lonely figures in search of a third.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Hard-Line Albania Ushers In What It Calls 'Democratization'
description: Without great fanfare, Albania has embarked on a far-reaching program of what its Communist leadership calls the ''democratization'' of the country's social and economic institutions.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Moscow Victors Act to Promote Freer Markets
description: Having soundly defeated the Communist Party at the polls, the democratic insurgents taking over the Moscow City Council plan to name Gavriil K. Popov, an outspoken congressional deputy and economist, as the new Mayor in an attempt to make a free-market showcase of the capital.

title: Architects Recognize 17 Projects
description: A round house designed with a crafts collection in mind and a pair of two-story lofts that now resemble ''a building within a building'' were among the entries cited as the best and most creative work of New York architects in a competition sponsored by the American Institute of Architects.

title: A 1940's Texan Rides High, in a Book
description: The depiction of a former Texas governor in a new and influential book has puzzled historians in the state, who say he was not the towering figure portrayed in the book.

title: Soviets Pull Out Advisers at Ethiopia Fronts
description: The Soviet Union has withdrawn all its military advisers from the battle zones in Ethiopia's civil wars, the Soviet Ambassador to the Sudan said today.

title: TV Debates Need Third Party Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabbies Practice Passenger Selectivity to Protect Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Eackles Leads Bullets Past Nets
description: Ledell Eackles, who was filling in for the injured Jeff Malone, scored a career-high 40 points tonight to lead the Washington Bullets past the Nets, 136-106. The Nets have lost 21 consecutive games on the road.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Set Record on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose by 64.7 million shares, or almost 12 percent, in the month ended March 15, to a record level. Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

title: Review/Television;   A New Tale by P. D. James on 'Mystery'
description: Swaddled for a couple of months in the rather precious company of Agatha Christie's Hercule Poirot, public television's ''Mystery'' turns tonight to the detached irony of P. D. James's Adam Dalgliesh. Art Deco is giving way to contemporary grime, tidy little stories to grim social explorations. Finicky Poirot has little in common with dour Dalgliesh. Getting under way tonight at 8 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channel 21, the six-part adaptation of ''A Taste for Death'' skillfully preserves Ms. James in top form.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Poindexter Loses Fight for Reagan Notes
description: A Federal judge ruled today that former President Ronald Reagan did not have to turn over excerpts of his private diaries to John M. Poindexter, saying the assertion of executive privilege by Mr. Reagan and the Bush Administration outweighed Mr. Poindexter's need for the material.

title: Chronicle
description: The Republican candidate for Governor of Texas, CLAYTON WILLIAMS, said yesterday he would feel uncomfortable running against ANN RICHARDS, a Democratic candidate for the same job, because she is a woman.

title: An Accounting Star Dims a Bit
description: Kenneth Leventhal & Company's headquarters are in the same sleek Century City office tower that appears on ''L.A. Law,'' the hit television show about a brash and high-powered law firm. Fitting quarters, it seems, for the firm that has long been the elite boutique of the accounting profession.

title: Masterpieces: Not Usually Vulnerable or Very Vulnerable Indeed
description: The theft of 12 masterworks from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on Sunday may be the biggest art theft in history, but it is hardly unique. Enough stolen masterpieces are still ''out there,'' art professionals and police specialists say, to fill a museum.

title: Kodak to Sell Verbatim Division
description: The Eastman Kodak Company agreed to sell its Verbatim Corporation unit, which makes computer disks and other information products, to the Mitsubishi Kasei Corporation, an affiliate of the Mitsubishi Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Mitsubishi will buy all Verbatim stock and will obtain Verbatim's floppy disk business and digital cassette tape businesses.

title: Belcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shares outstanding reflects a 1-for-5 reverse stock split effective Feb. 15.

title: Coca-Cola Rebuffed by India
description: The Coca-Cola Company today lost its bid to return to India when the Government turned down an application that would have allowed the soft-drink maker to compete with domestic producers.

title: In Violent Crimes, Test for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Filibuster on Abortion Drones On in Maryland
description: A filibuster in the Maryland Senate against a bill to update the state's abortion law droned through its seventh day yesterday, with proponents of the measure still unable to come up with the single vote they needed to shut off the talking.

title: Corrections
description: A report in About New York yesterday on an audition of heroic tenors by the foundation established by Lauritz Melchior misstated the age of the music patron Alice Tully. She is 87.

title: Group Buys Stake In Bay Meadows
description: A group led by Robert S. Gunderson, the chairman of the board of the Bay Meadows Operating Company, has bought a 6.8 percent stake in Bay Meadows and said it intends to wage a proxy fight for three additional seats on the board of the San Mateo, Calif., concern. Bay Meadows runs thoroughbred racing at the Bay Meadows Race Track. The track is owned by the California Jockey Club, a real estate trust.

title: Colonial Municipal Income reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Top Players Honored
description: Lionel Simmons of La Salle and Jennifer Azzi of Stanford were named winners of the 1990 Naismith Awards yesterday as the nation's best collegiate basketball players. Administered by the Atlanta Tipoff Club, the awards are based on voting by 400 coaches, sportswriters and basketball enthusiasts. They will be presented April 5 in Atlanta.

title: 3 Officers Acquitted in Fatal Struggle With Disturbed Brooklyn Man
description: As dozens of fellow police officers cheered, three officers were acquitted yesterday of assaulting an emotionally disturbed 40-year-old who died shortly after a struggle with the officers two years ago in Brooklyn.

title: Peat May Get Pepsico
description: KPMG Peat Marwick is expected to win the auditing account today for Pepsico Inc., the food and beverage company, said Arthur W. Bowman, the editor of an Atlanta newsletter on the accounting profession. A Pepsi spokesman in Purchase, N.Y., said only that the board's audit committee would meet today. Five of the six largest accounting firms have been competing for the $9 million account since it became known last month that the company's former auditors at the sixth firm, Ernst & Young, had dropped the account.

title: Boston Company Official Appears Choice for Chief
description: John R. Laird, who joined the Bos-ton Company last year, is expected to be named chairman and chief executive of the international financial services firm.

title: New Report Shows Loss At Shawmut
description: The Shawmut National Corporation said yesterday that after an examination by Federal banking regulators it had revised its 1989 earnings to show a loss of $128.9 million. In January it had reported a profit of $201.7 million.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Metro Datelines;   Environment Bonds Supported by Miller
description: New York State's proposed environmental bond act gained a crucial supporter yesterday when Assembly Speaker Mel Miller said he would ''strongly support'' it.

title: Corrections
description: The headline on a short article in Business Day yesterday about the Hearst Corporation's entry into French television misidentified the French company that sold stakes in two of its units to Hearst. It is Canal Plus.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International, Chicago, a maker of products for the graphics industry, appointed Steven F. Kaplan senior vice president for finance and corporate strategy. He replaces John H. Shuey, who resigned, as the company's chief financial officer.

title: Administration to Back Switch to Merit Raises
description: The Bush Administration is preparing legislation to award pay increases to Federal employees based on performance, rather than how long they have been on the job, a spokesman said today.

title: In Absentia, Saint Laurent Still Dazzles
description: Yves Saint Laurent's show, without Saint Laurent, brought the fall and winter fashion shows to a close just before noon today. It was a stripped-down presentation with a lot of punch and some loose edges.

title: Nitpicking Democracy in New York
description: Anyone who doubts that New York State's complex, fussy ballot requirements need drastic overhaul ought to consider the legal comic opera that marred this week's special election for Congress in the Bronx, won handily by the Democratic nominee, Jose Serrano.

title: Little League Lockout Heads Toward Court
description: Major league baseball has ended its lockout, but there is no sign of progress in the baseball dispute here. Talks have broken off. One side has locked up the bats and balls. As the fight heads for court, opening day may be in jeopardy for the Selden-Centereach Little League.

title: Notebook;   Despite Her Legal Blindness, Dual Holes-in-One
description: A 74-year-old legally blind woman made holes-in-one on the same hole on consecutive days this week. Her achievement is believed to be the first occasion that the feat has been accomplished by a person with serious vision impairment.

title: The Privilege of Secrecy
description: Executive privilege, the right claimed by a President to withhold information from Congress or the courts, is mentioned neither in the Constitution nor in the constitutional debates of the nation's founders.

title: Keeping a Pledge
description: During his 1988 campaign, George Bush promised that if he was elected President, there would be no new taxes.

title: Lebow Treated For Brain Cancer
description: Fred Lebow, the director of the New York City Marathon and the president of the New York Road Runners Club, was told yesterday that he has brain cancer. Lebow, who was to begin radiation treatments immediately, underwent extensive testing after being admitted to Mount Sinai Medical Center on Feb. 14 with a growth in his skull that was detected by a neurological examination.

title: Elscint Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $27,738,000, or 70 cents a share. c-Net loss The company said as of April 1, 1988, it changed its fiscal year end from March 31 to Dec. 31, in accordance with an amendment to the Israeli income tax law.

title: Metro Datelines;   U.S. Seeks Control Of Teamsters Locals
description: Federal prosecutors filed a racketeering lawsuit yesterday against two teamsters locals at Kennedy International Airport, seeking a court order to place them under the supervision of a trustee.

title: New TV Standard Chosen
description: The Federal Communications Commission today selected one of two competing standards for high-definition television, a technology that will give viewers movie-quality pictures in the home.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column on Monday about Sharedata Inc. misstated the month during which the company estimated a loss for the quarter that ended Dec. 31. The company made the estimate, of a loss of $500,000, in January 1990, not November 1989.

title: China's Army Is Cared For in a Lean Budget
description: The Government acknowledged today that it faced grave budgetary difficulties, but at the same time proposed a budget for 1990 that includes a sharp increase in military spending.

title: Texas Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,441,000 for the quarter and $4,248,000 for the 9 months. The 1989 figures were restated to consolidate all subsidiaries.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a spectacular success for the breeding of bamboo. It's a breakthrough that could have real significance for a quarter of the world's population.''

title: G.O.P. Figures' Feud Erupts in Public
description: A bitter feud between two of the Republican Party's best-known political consultants has spilled over into the gubernatorial races in Ohio and Connecticut.

title: Bombs Hit Guatemala Town
description: Six bombs exploded today in the provincial capital of San Marcos, including two at the homes of high-ranking politicians, the police said. One bomb exploded at the residence of Governor Carlos Godinez of San Marcos and seriously wounded his 24 year-old daughter, according to the police in San Marcos, 157 miles northwest of the capital. Another bomb damaged the house of Mayor Alfonso Villagran. San Marcos is a base to growing number of opium farmers. It is also a transit point for migrants and a center of guerrilla activity.

title: House Leaders Are Split on Day Care
description: After eight months of deadlock over how to help low- and middle-income families pay for child care, House Democrats have resolved crucial issues of financing but remain divided over whether to subsidize day care centers operated by religious institutions.

title: Review/Theater;   Turner and Durning in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'
description: It takes nothing away from Kathleen Turner's radiant Maggie in ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' to say that Broadway's gripping new production of Tennessee Williams's 1955 play will be most remembered for Charles Durning's Big Daddy. The actor's portrayal of a 65-year-old Mississippi plantation owner in festering extremis is an indelible hybrid of red-neck cutup and aristocratic tragedian, of grasping capitalist and loving patriarch.

title: Commerical Metals reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Success and the Single Woman
description: Life as a single woman in the post-feminist age isn't all that it's cracked up to be. Limitless choices may exist on the professional front, but the deck of social attitudes is still stacked against us. Until recently this was a mere suspicion, confirmed only by my single, female, thirtysomething friends who are decidedly biased.

title: Panama Expels Cuban Envoy For Not Recognizing Endara
description: Panama said today that it was expelling Cuba's Ambassador, charging that Cuba had refused to recognize the new Government of President Guillermo Endara.

title: Time Warner Adviser Named Chief of Unit
description: Robert W. Pittman, the young executive who brought to the world the MTV music video network and the Morton Downey Jr. show, among other efforts, was named president and chief executive of Time Warner Enterprises, the business and strategic development unit of Time Warner Inc., yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: BASKETBALL: East Regional;   Last-Second Shot Puts UConn in the Clear
description: The people in the stands in blue and white, the ones who had gone along on Connecticut's unforgettable ride, were standing numbly, arms at their sides. Connecticut's pressers had been pressed. A 19-point second half lead over the Clemson Tigers had become a nightmarish 1-point deficit.

title: Guggenheim to Sell 3 Works to Help Buy Others
description: To help finance its planned multi-million-dollar purchase of Minimalist works from the collection of Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, the Guggenheim Museum will sell paintings by Wassily Kandinsky, Marc Chagall and Amedeo Modigliani in May at Sotheby's, Thomas Krens, the director of the Guggenheim, had said recently that such deaccessioning was being considered as an option, but he would not specify the works involved. But, reached by telephone Wednesday in Tokyo, where he was on museum business, he said the paintings - Kandinsky's ''Fugue'' of 1914, Modigliani's ''Boy in Blue Jacket'' of 1916 and Chagall's ''Birthday'' of 1923 - were at Sotheby's for inclusion in a May sale.

title: Nets Suspend Morris For Next Two Games
description: When the Nets visit the Indiana Pacers tonight and the Cleveland Cavaliers tomorrow night, they will carry an 8-game losing streak and a 21-game road losing streak into the weekend. They will not be carrying Chris Morris, the second-year power forward, who has started all 66 games this season.

title: Washington Talk;   Reagan Tape: The Star Flickers, but Just Dimly
description: Ronald Reagan always seemed like a regular guy, on the silver screen or in the White House. It was one of his strengths.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Warning From Argentina
description: In the best of times, Argentine politics tends toward melodrama. In the worst, it tends toward military coups. Eight months into President Carlos Saul Menem's term, times are getting very bad. It is in the U.S. interest to help Mr. Menem master his gathering problems. But the main responsibility is necessarily his alone.

title: Biondi Stays in Form Despite a Busy Agenda
description: Eighteen months ago, in the Seoul Olympics, Matt Biondi won seven swimming medals, including five gold. Since then he has become a one-man marketing operation, and to the delight of the people in the sport he is still swimming and still winning.

title: INSIDE
description: Mental Health Fund Inquiry

title: Kelly Feels Fortunate To Get Back to Work
description: He is three months and thousands of miles removed from the invasion, but Roberto Kelly is not likely to forget four days in December that made him fear for his life.

title: Books of The Times;   Of Freud and His Obsession With the Enigmatic
description: Reading Freud

title: News Summary
description: International A2-10

title: New Chairman at Saab
description: Saab-Scania A.B. said this week that Anders Scharp, managing director of Electrolux A.B., would replace Sten Gustafsson as Saab's chairman. Mr. Gustafsson has been chairman since 1983. Saab-Scania recently introduced the commuter turboprop Saab 2000 airplane, merged its money-losing car division with the General Motors Corporation and decided to expand Scania's truck division. Mr. Gustafsson will step down at the end of April.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   The Dance Is Over, but the Whirl Goes On
description: ''I think we're all in a sense doomed,'' says Charlie Black, who takes the long view.

title: German Is Charged in Libyan Case
description: The state prosecutor investigating West German participation in building a Libyan chemical plant thought to be producing poison gas announced formal charges today against the head of the company suspected of playing the major role in designing and constructing the plant.

title: Chronicle
description: Meanwhile, the poor Republicans can't get anyone to run against Gov. MARIO M. CUOMO. One potential candidate, EVAN G. GALBRAITH, a former United States Ambassador to France, was thwarted yesterday when a state appeals court ruled that he didn't meet the five-year residency requirement.

title: Newsome Coming Back
description: Ozzie Newsome, the 34-year-old Cleveland Browns receiver who has caught more passes than any other tight end, said yesterday that he intended to play a 13th season in the N.F.L. Newsome had considered retiring after last season, when his production slipped to 29 catches for 324 yards. But he met last weekend with Art Modell, the team's owner, before making his decision.

title: At the Movies
description: Making Romantic Films

title: Use Army Camps for Younger Prisoners;   What of the Victims?
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrain Turns Bumpy in Connecticut Race
description: Connecticut's political terrain has undergone two profound changes this month with former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s return from retirement to run for governor as an independent and Gov. William A. O'Neill's abrupt announcement that he would not seek re-election.

title: New Kennedy Center Head Likely to Be Named Today
description: James D. Wolfensohn, an investment banker, arts patron and amateur cellist, is expected to be named on Friday to succeed Ralph P. Davidson as chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a member of the center's board said today. The 43-member board is to meet at noon.

title: Bush Position on Art Group Evokes Protests From Right
description: The refusal by the Bush Administration to endorse restrictions on the content of Federally financed arts programs sparked fierce protests from the social and religious right today in what may turn out to be the first major test of the President's ability to keep ardent conservatives as happy members of his party.

title: Winfield Sutphin, 71, TV Minister in 1950's
description: The Rev. Winfield Blair Sutphin, a nationally known television preacher in the 1950's, died of pulmonary failure on March 12 at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: Pop/Jazz;   Tomorrow's Stars Today In Brooklyn's Small Clubs
description: What makes Brooklyn clubs so nice is similar to what makes the borough itself pleasant: smaller crowds, less pressure and more variety than in Manhattan. While the level of talent is not as high as in Manhattan, that is not always the point. Brooklyn clubs, if one can make generalizations at all, are good places for novice musicians and artists to learn about stagecraft, to experiment without the fear of failing in front of high-paying audiences. Brooklyn offers surprises - the chance of coming across a group or a musician who is enormously proficient, but not yet known. And at cheaper prices, and in a more relaxed atmosphere.

title: Herman Katz, 90, A Former City Clerk And Assemblyman
description: Herman Katz, a former New York City Clerk and a former Assemblyman from the Yorkville section of Manhattan, died on Wednesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan and Katonah, N.Y.

title: In Namibia, South African Is Center of Attention
description: President F. W. de Klerk has used the celebration of Namibian independence to engage in perhaps the most extensive and varied international diplomacy that a South African leader has undertaken since apartheid was ushered in 42 years ago.

title: Walks and Rides for the Curious
description: Brooklyn's many neighborhoods, famous attractions and little-known pleasures can be discovered with the help of a variety of guided bus and walking tours offered in coming weeks and throughout the year.

title: New Shops With an Emphasis on the Edible
description: Rather than being concentrated in one area, Brooklyn's food shops are scattered about the borough like raisins in a Lenten hot-cross bun. Here is a sampling of some fairly recent newcomers to Brooklyn's eclectic gastronomic scene.

title: Review/Film;   Romantic Passion Awakened at a Japanese School
description: ''Summer Vacation: 1999'' was shown as part of the 1989 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 24, 1989. The film, in Japanese with English subtitles, opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Hunts Yield Stake in Penrod to Lenders
description: The Hunt brothers of Texas have given up their 50 percent stake in the Penrod Drilling Company to a group of lenders, apparently after failing to get financing to pay their bills.

title: Braniff Ends Pact On Sale of Assets
description: Braniff Inc. terminated an agreement to sell some of the airline's assets because the intended buyer did not meet a $1 million payment deadline. The Coastal Maine Holdings Corporation had asked the United States Bankruptcy Court in Orlando for authorization to buy Braniff's flight certificates, operating manuals and trademarks.

title: M.T.A. Panel Backs Automated Fare System
description: New York City transit officials today cleared the first of two hurdles to installing automated fare collection on subways and buses.

title: Agassi 'Pounds Better' and Beats Courier
description: Animosity in their quarterfinal match was out of the question, insisted Andre Agassi and Jim Courier, the young American turks who lived and trained together as junior players, but were never playmates.

title: Review/Film;   High-Rolling Boy Meets Streetwalking Girl
description: Yes, yes, the 80's are over. But isn't there room in the time capsule for ''Pretty Woman,'' the romantic comedy about a lovelorn corporate raider and a sweet, wholesome streetwalker from Hollywood Boulevard? This one truly deserves a place. It is something special.

title: Walker to Start
description: Kenny Walker, who came off the injured list three days ago after missing eight games with tendinitis of the right knee, will replace Charles Oakley as the starting power forward tonight when the Knicks visit the Hornets in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Albany Tale: Commissioner to Knishener
description: Julio A. Martinez, pressured to resign last December as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's commissioner of drug treatment, is going back to work at the State Capitol. But not in government, and not as a commissioner.

title: BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional;   Arkansas Routs North Carolina
description: Tournament-tough North Carolina was the school steeped in basketball tradition, presumably the big boys on the block. But in the Tar Heels' meeting tonight with Arkansas in the semifinals of the Midwest Regional, the Razorbacks turned out to be the bully as North Carolina seemed to grab Arkansas by its tail and hang on for life.

title: Review/Film;   Climbing The Ladder To Success In 'Shock'
description: Michael Caine has become one of that small number of actors who can appear in the occasional terrible movie without being embarrassed or held accountable. He is too strong a personality to be damaged by a trifle on the order of ''A Shock to the System,'' the new comedy to which he gives far more help than he ever receives.

title: Review/Art;   Avant-Garde Dusseldorf In Tumult and in Horror
description: One of the strengths of ''War, Resistance and Politics: Dusseldorf Artists 1910-1945,'' at the Jewish Museum, is that it sheds light on Dusseldorf as an avant-garde center. Before World War I, the art in the city was largely identified with its traditional art academy. After the war, artists there began to engage the social and political situation of their country, and that engagement has now itself become a tradition at the Dusseldorf art academy.

title: Chronicle
description: Doctors successfully operated on GLORIA ESTEFAN's spine yesterday to repair two vertebrae damaged when her tour bus was hit by a truck Tuesday in Pennsylvania. DR. MICHAEL NEUWIRTH, an orthopedic surgeon at the Orthopedic Institute Hospital for Joint Diseases in Manhattan, said the four-hour operation was successful.

title: Minnesota Rebuilds Respect
description: The ashes that Clem Haskins and his players have turned into beauty at the University of Minnesota were once ugly, smoldering ashes, the kind that a simple sweep never cleans.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   High-Tech Alibi in 'Double-Edged Knife'
description: In ''Double-Edged Knife,'' the Brazilian story of intrigue, a lawyer (Paulo Jose) suspects that his sultry wife may be unfaithful. He sets a trap for her and soon discovers that she is having an affair with his partner, who has contrived to send the husband on a business trip from Brasilia to Sao Paulo so that, figuratively speaking, the mice may play. The lawyer has in mind a few games of his own. He arranges an alibi and returns home to shoot his wife and his partner dead.

title: Wider Recall of Food Supplement Is Sought by U.S. After 19 Deaths
description: The Food and Drug Administration today called for nearly all supplies of the food supplement L-tryptophan to be removed from the market because of continuing reports linking its use to a sometimes fatal blood disorder.

title: Ship Captain Acquitted of Felony But Is Convicted on Minor Charge
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the captain of the Exxon Valdez, was acquitted today of the most serious charges involving the worst oil spill in United States history, but was convicted of a single charge of misdemeanor negligence.

title: Ex-Drexel Executive May Join Paine Webber
description: After 15 years with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment house that collapsed last month, G. Chris Andersen is preparing to land on his feet in a big way.

title: Kidder Invests in Spain
description: Kidder, Peabody International announced yesterday that it had purchased 25 percent of a leading Spanish investment banking firm, Benito Y Monjardin, for undisclosed terms. Kidder said it would sell a portion of the stake to G.E. Capital, a financial unit of Kidder's parent, the General Electric Company. It will also sell a portion to So.Pa.F., a Kidder affiliate in Milan, Italy. Benito Y Monjardin engages in equity underwriting, corporate finance, trading and other businesses. Kidder's move was part of an effort to seek opportunities for merger and acquisition work in Spain, said Michael A. M. Keehner, president of Kidder, Peabody International. Such business is expected to develop rapidly as Europe moves toward dropping economic barriers in 1992.

title: Top Dollar for Kelly
description: Jim Kelly, the quarterback whose five-year, $8 million contract with the Buffalo Bills expires next year, is about to become the highest-paid player in the National Football League, The Buffalo News reported yesterday.

title: Nunn Opens a Double Attack In Military Spending Debate
description: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee sharply criticized the Defense Department today for spending plans that he said were based on outdated assumptions about the military threats facing the United States.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Land Reform Party Creating a Niche in Hungary
description: When it was his turn to speak before a small but patient gathering of voters here in a rural area west of Budapest, Mihaly Izso, a candidate for the Independent Smallholders Party, offered up a few simple ideas.

title: New Jersey Acts To Take Over School System
description: Five months after seizing control of schools in Jersey City, the New Jersey Department of Education has taken the first step toward a takeover of the troubled 23,000-student district here.

title: Economic Scene;   The Transition In East Germany
description: THE Berlin wall, built to keep East Germans from fleeing to the West, now stands as a powerful symbol of the coming unification of the two Germanys.

title: Schub Piano Recital
description: The pianist Andre-Michel Schub will play Beethoven's 32 Variations in C minor (WoO 80) and Sonata No. 12 in A flat (Op. 26); Bartok's ''Out of Doors'' (Op. 81), and Schumann's ''Arabeske'' (Op. 18) and Symphonic Etudes (Op. 13) at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $17.50 to $22.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Krystian Zimerman
description: The pianist Krystian Zimerman is to play Schubert's Impromptus (D. 935), Liszt's ''Nuages Gris,'' ''Notte'' and ''Funerailles,'' and Grazyna Bacewicz's Sonata No. 2 at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. Tickets are $9 to $23. Information: 247-7800.

title: Restaurants
description: The Brooklyn dining scene is often noted for its diversity, economy and lack of pretension, but rarely for its romance. Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights are fine for a week-night dalliance, but with few exceptions, Manhattan still has the patent on the Big Date. Adele, an alluring little restaurant in a former carriage house in Park Slope, is striving to offer a romantic neighborhood alternative.

title: Acquisitions by Persis
description: The Persis Corporation, a Honolulu newspaper company, has acquired Media Holdings Inc., publisher of Nashville! and Advantage magazines, the two companies announced on Wednesday. No price was released. Other Media Holdings publications include the Nashville Area Business Directory, Nashville's Visitor Guide and ''How To Do Business'' books dealing with the Memphis, Nashville, Knoxville and Chattanooga markets.

title: Colt Unit Sold; Connecticut Among Buyers
description: The State of Connecticut joined yesterday with a group of investors and managers and 1,000 striking workers at Colt Firearms in a leveraged buyout of the 154-year-old Hartford concern, ending a bitter four-year strike.

title: LAW: At the Bar
description: When J. Willard Hurst attended Harvard Law School in the 1930's, the study of legal history was nonexistent. Oh, yes, some professors had studied obscure legal doctrines and there was one superannuated scholar studying history, but it was Roman history, and he stalked Langdell Hall like a ghost.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Medical Technologies, San Franciscoexexndnd u until Mchch 30 the closing of its acquisition of Imed, the intravenous infusion-pump manufacturing division of the Fisher Scientific subsidiary of the Henley Group.

title: Trapped in the Terror of New York's Holding Pens
description: Elizabeth Sarpong still has nightmares about the places where she was frightened and confused for 45 hours last summer, where the air was thick with the smell of urine, feces and infection.

title: Another Push on Valvano
description: Negotiations have resumed to secure Jim Valvano's removal as head basketball coach at North Carolina State University.

title: Court Erupts As Judge Frees An Ex-Panther
description: A Manhattan courtroom erupted into a thunderous, foot-stomping celebration yesterday when a judge freed a former Black Panther Party leader whose conviction and 25-year-to-life prison sentence in the attempted murder of two New York City police officers was overturned last week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''And I'm President of the United States, and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli!''

title: Robert A. Sander, Headed Food Company
description: Robert A. Sander, president and chief operating officer of Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc., in Edina, Minn., died of cancer on Monday at University Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., where he was undergoing treatment.

title: WAR ON INFLATION GIVES A QUICK JOLT TO BRAZIL ECONOMY
description: In less than a week, Brazil's radical attack on inflation has changed the face of this city, often called Brazil's economic locomotive. Traffic has thinned, plane flights have been canceled, the stock market has plunged, layoffs have spread and prices have started to drop.

title: More Greyhound Buses Are Hit by Gunfire
description: Three more Greyhound Lines buses were hit by gunfire Wednesday night and early today, bringing to at least 17 the number of such incidents around the country since the company's drivers struck Greyhound three weeks ago.

title: Saab-G.M. Unit Set Up
description: The General Motors Corporation and Saab-Scania A.B. have completed setting up a joint auto-making venture in Europe, the Swedish company said this week. G.M., the world's largest auto maker, and Saab-Scania, Sweden's second-biggest vehicle maker after Volvo A.B., agreed on Dec. 15 to form a joint auto-making company, called Saab Automobile A.B. Ownership of the new company is split 50-50 between Saab and G.M., which is spending about $600 million to acquire half of the corporation's auto business.

title: Unesco Has Earned Renewed U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Le Roman de Fauvel'
description: The Waverly Consort will present ''Le Roman de Fauvel'' at Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 o'clock and Sunday at 3 P.M.. The work, which comes from an anonymous 14th-century French manuscript that is in the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris, is a fable about a donkey, Fauvel, and has been part of the Waverly Consort's repertory since 1976. There will be a free lecture tomorrow at 4 P.M., ''Le Roman de Fauvel: Politics, Adultery and Charivari in Early 14th-Century France,'' by Elizabeth A. R. Brown, a professor of history at Brooklyn College and the City University of New York. Tickets are $20 to $30. Information: 666-1260.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Willing to Renew Talks
description: Leftist guerrillas today welcomed the Government's announcement that it was willing to resume negotiations to settle the 11-year-old civil war without any preconditions.

title:
LAW;

Drastic Moves Urged to Ease U.S. Courts' Load
description: LEAD: After more than a year of scrutinizing the entire Federal judiciary, a panel established by Congress is about to recommend steps to cut the burdensome workload of Federal district judges by more than a third. Several types of civil cases commonly heard in Federal court would be transferred elsewhere.

title: Criminal Charges Filed Against Pilots
description: Federal and state officials filed criminal charges against three former Northwest Airlines pilots today, saying the violated laws against operating a commercial airliner while under the influence of alcohol.

title: Jobs Lost as Farah Shuts Sewing Unit
description: Farah Inc., the apparel maker that lost $589,000 in the first quarter, has laid off the workers remaining on its sewing line, a union leader said. The El Paso-based company gave a 60-day notice to more than 50 workers, said Antonio Sanchez, manager of the joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers' Union.

title: A Home for a Bustling Borough's Memorabilia
description: How do you tell the 350-year-long story of New York's most populous and arguably most colorful borough in a small gallery with a relatively minuscule budget?

title: Bland Field for Bay Shore Stakes
description: New Yorkers hoping to see some legitimate Kentucky Derby prospects in Aqueduct's traditional prep races are having a lean season that will not improve with the running of the Bay Shore Stakes tomorrow. The only good news is that the Gotham, two weeks later, is beginning to look a lot more promising.

title: Jets' New Center Is Motivated
description: Bent on revenge against his old team, Trevor Matich has joined the Jets and may even become their starting center.

title: Robert H. Bahmer. 86, Former U. S. Archivist
description: Robert H. Bahmer, who retired as Archivist of the United States in 1968, died March 14 at the El Gen nursing home in Las Vegas. He was 86 years old and had lived in Chevy Chase, Md., before moving to Las Vegas in the early 1970's.

title: Old and Disabled In the Soviet Union
description: To the Editor:

title: Students in Taiwan Agree to End Their Largest Democracy Rally
description: Several thousand students withdrew peacefully this morning from a public square in the capital, ending the largest student demonstration here in 40 years, after they discussed their demands Wednesday night with President Lee Teng-hui.

title: Eastern Pilots Accept Pact With Wage Cuts
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it had reached an interim agreement calling for wage and benefit cuts by members of its pilots' union, but that the cost savings would be less than half the amount needed to allow the airline to emerge from bankruptcy court protection.

title: Marathon Oil to Sell a Cleaner-Burning Gasoline
description: The Marathon Oil Company, in an effort to popularize a cleaner-burning gasoline, says it will begin selling in limited quantities the first reformulated unleaded gasolines that can be burned by virtually all car engines.

title: Meese, in Iran-Contra Testimony, Sticks to His Story and Poindexter
description: Testifying on behalf of John M. Poindexter, former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that Mr. Poindexter asked for his help in preparing a truthful account of the secret arms sales to Iran as the Iran-contra affair was unraveling in November 1986.

title: Auctions
description: 2 Pairs of Screens

title: Use Army Camps for Younger Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Beatlefest '90
description: Beatlefest '90, an annual weekend-long celebration of the Beatles, is to be held at the Meadowlands Hilton Hotel, 2 Harmon Plaza, Secaucus, N.J., starting this afternoon at 5:30. The program includes panel discussions featuring Gerry Marsden, the lead singer of Gerry and the Pacemakers, and Ray Coleman, the author of ''Lennon'' and ''The Man Who Made the Beatles,'' a biography of Brian Epstein. Also on the program is an auction of suits worn by the Beatles, provided by Gordon Millings, the group's tailor. There will be continuous showings of Beatles films and video clips, a memorabilia flea market, trivia contests and performances by Beatles sound-alike bands. Beatlefest hours are 5:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. tonight; noon to midnight tomorrow, and noon to midnight on Sunday. Tickets are $12 today and $16.50 tomorrow and Sunday. Information: (800) 232-8537.

title: Cuomo Must Take Lead On Campaign Finance
description: To the Editor:

title: Baker Reports a Pledge by de Klerk
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa had told him that his Government was on an irreversible course toward creating a nonracial democracy.

title: Chronicle
description: Galvanized by the United States Supreme Court decision that abortion rights are to be decided by state legislatures, two Long Island Democrats are entering the 1990 campaign. SHERRYE HENRY, a former radio interviewer, and LINDA BIRD FRANCKE, an author, plan to run in the area that includes the Hamptons, long a Republican stronghold.

title: Article 881190 -- No Title
description: Hospitals around the country have diverted $40 million to $100 million in Federal mental health funds to other purposes, including swimming pools, volleyball courts and maids, a House subcommittee and a consumer advocacy group say.

title: Our Towns;   A Dog's Portrait: Make Him Young And Full of Spots
description: The wipers clicked steadily as Ellen Fisch drove to her next portrait commission, an elderly Dalmatian with cancer. This was a major dog for her, she felt: Danny, a favorite pet of Georgia Haridopolos, a breeder of many champion Dalmatians. ''I've been after her for a while,'' Mrs. Fisch said.

title: Treasury Prices Rise on Rumors
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher again yesterday, as traders were buffeted by rumors throughout the session.

title: Why Fryer Put on a Clean Shirt
description: They'd be making a road trip and be about to climb on the team bus when Hank Gathers, the 6-foot-7-inch center for Loyola Marymount University, would look Jeff Fryer, the 6-2 guard, up and down.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Dr. John's Voodoo

title: Two Not-So-August Outposts for Modern Dance
description: For years, dance in Brooklyn was mostly a matter of the large companies presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In 1985, smaller-scale and more informal modern dance began to become established in less august theater spaces in the borough, principally at BACA Downtown, and Spoke the Hub Dancing's Gowanus Arts Exchange.

title: Gooden Impressive In Test of Shoulder
description: Dwight Gooden walked into the stadium from the practice mounds at 1 o'clock sharp today to pitch live batting practice for the first time this spring. Not exactly the World Series, but a milestone for the ace of aces of the Mets, who hasn't started a game since he tore a muscle in his right shoulder last July 1.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Lunch on the Roof

title: Gain for Italian Media Law
description: The Italian Senate passed a bill today that would restrict ownership of television and newspapers, and ban commercials during film, opera and theater productions on television. The measure is seen as a major threat to the television empire of the Italian media holder Silvio Berlusconi.

title: Insider Data Case Settled
description: An employee of a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. settled charges today that he had traded on insider information before Grand Met announced that it was buying the Pillsbury Company in 1988.

title: Full Baseball Season Preserved As All Agree, 'Let's Play 162!'
description: After failing to find a way to fit 162 games into a period designed for 156 games or to push the season and the post-season back as much as a week without disrupting the CBS fall programming plans, major league baseball and the network split the difference yesterday.

title: TV Weekend;   What Hemingway Wrote, and Then Some
description: First published in the September 1952 issue of Life magazine, Ernest Hemingway's novella, or long short story, ''The Old Man and the Sea'' became a film starring Spencer Tracy in 1958. A new television adaptation, which can be seen on NBC on Sunday at 9 P.M., offers Anthony Quinn as Santiago, the Cuban fisherman who pits himself against a gigantic marlin. Once again a Hemingway work proves curiously resistant to television tinkering. Remember the disaster visited upon ''The Sun Also Rises'' a few years ago?

title: Havel Says His Predecessors Sent Libya Explosives
description: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia said today that the ousted Communist Government in Prague had shipped 1,000 tons of lethal Semtex explosives to Libya, which had passed it on to terrorist organizations.

title: Leftist Candidate Assassinated at Bogota Airport
description: A leading left-wing politician was assassinated at the Bogota airport today, and troops used tear gas and gunfire to disperse hundreds of demonstrators accusing the Government of complicity in the killing.

title: Facts on File Sale Is Seen
description: Facts on File Inc., a New York book publisher and information service to libraries, is being offered for sale, publishing industry executives said yesterday, ''At this time we have no comment,'' said Thomas Conoscenti, the division vice president for North American and European publishing at Commerce Clearing House Inc., the Chicago company that owns Facts On File.

title: NBC and 'Cosby' Producers Deadlock Over Deal
description: The negotiations between NBC and the producers of ''The Cosby Show'' remain deadlocked over the record financial demands made by the production company, an NBC executive said yesterday.

title: A Top Officer Sues Gruntal
description: In a move that has prompted his dismissal, the vice chairman of the investment house Gruntal & Company has filed suit against the firm; its parent company, the Ambase Corporation, and certain officers, charging that they schemed to inflate the price of Ambase stock.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Behind the Lithuania Crisis; Military and K.G.B. Make Gorbachev Err
description: Why does a competent leader start doing things that are palpably ineffective and even self-defeating? Usually because the pressures on that leader are far greater than generally perceived, and maybe more specific and ominous.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: KEY RATES
Bridge
description: Semifinal play in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals began here this afternoon following a night of comebacks: three of the four quarterfinal matches turned around after midnight.

title: Review/Theater;   A Prophet With Drums And a Tale To Tell
description: For more than two decades, an obligatory set piece in most arena-size rock concerts has been the drum solo. In a typical display of percussive pyrotechnics, the drummer, given 5 to 10 minutes to strut his stuff, attempts to pack as much aggressive grandiosity as he can muster into a thunderous blitz that usually has less to do with music than with simply showing off.

title: Sagging Islanders Lose To Kings and Reach Cellar
description: Kelly Hrudey made 17 saves in two periods and Mikko Makela scored a goal to lead the Los Angeles Kings to a 3-1 victory tonight over the Islanders.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Altschiller Account
description: Jose Eber Inc., a newly formed company that manufactures premium hair care products, gave its $20 million advertising account to Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis/Tracy-Locke. Jose Eber formerly licensed his products to Faberge. The finalists for the account included Hal Riney & Partners, TBWA, Calet, Hirsh & Spector, Deutsch, and Omon.

title: Upheaval in the East;   New Army Chief in Argentina
description: President Carlos Menem has appointed Gen. Martin Felix Bonnet as the army's Chief of Staff, succeeding Gen. Isidro Caceres, who died Wednesday after heart surgery. General Bonnet, 55 years old, had been General Caceres's second-in-command.

title: Upheaval in the East;   400 Albanians Hospitalized
description: More than 400 ethnic Albanian teen-agers were hospitalized today in Podujevo, a town in ethnically divided Kosovo Province, with signs of poisoning, officials reported. Official Radio Belgrade said about 4,000 ethnic Albanians gathered in the streets of Podujevo upon hearing the news. Some of them beat up Serbs and Montenegrins, accusing them of poisoning classrooms of Albanian pupils.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Larry Cole, United States media director of Ogilvy & Mather, and Fran Devereux, United States personnel director, have been named executive vice presidents.

title: Tel Aviv Stocks Rebound
description: The Tel Aviv Stock Exchange edged 1.3 percent higher today in a rebound from Wednesday's drop of 7.16 percent. The market's fall occurred when the exchange reopened Wednesday after a 15-day employee strike. Israel's coalition Government collapsed during the strike.

title: Review/Film;   Wanted: A Man. Any Man. Even a Circus Clown Will Do.
description: The Soviet romantic comedy ''Lonely Woman Seeks Life Companion,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room, isn't remotely funny, but perhaps that's fitting. Its story is no laughing matter. A tall, regal, reserved 43-year-old woman named Klavdiya (Irina Kupchenko) has grown so despairing over her unmarried status that she posts five little notices in the vicinity of her apartment complex, with their message more or less that of the film's title. She appears sad, nervous and uncertain about having taken this drastic step.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Pact Is Reached
description: The United States and the Soviet Union came to terms today on a new long-term grain agreement that guarantees an export market for an additional million tons of American wheat, feed grains and soybeans annually over the next five years, the Government announced.

title: F.B.I. Beginning Internal Inquiry On Bias Reports
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, has ordered a broad internal inquiry into reports that Hispanic agents have been the target of a recent campaign of harassment, F.B.I. officials said today.

title: On Stage
description: 'Shadowlands' Is en Route . . .

title: 'I'm President,' So No More Broccoli!
description: It was a proclamation that every child, and many adults, have dreamed of making.

title: Woman Kills Children and Self
description: A woman apparently despondent over marital and financial troubles shot her three children to death, then killed herself after scrawling ''God please forgive me'' in crayon on a wall of the family's home, the police said. The dead were identified as Roxanne Fernandez Jones, 32, and her children, Brandy Fernandez, 16, Leticia Fernandez, 13, and Jeremiah Jones, 7. In the family's home in Reseda, 20 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles, detectives found a .22-caliber rifle and a suicide left by Mrs. Jones.

title: Japanese Plan to Buy Control of Southland
description: One of Japan's largest supermarket and retailing chains said tonight that it had agreed to acquire control of the troubled Southland Corporation, owner of the 7-Eleven stores, the largest convenience store chain in the United States and one of the largest victims of a ''junk bond'' strategy that went awry.

title: Seeded Teams Stay Alive and Eager
description: There has not been an upset, a surprise or a jolt of any kind yet in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey tournament. The quarterfinal games this weekend find the seeded teams intact, one through four in the East and the West.

title: Upheaval in the East;   SOVIET PAPER LINKS MOSCOW TO KATYN
description: Wartime records that have been concealed for decades show that the Soviet secret police, not German invaders, killed thousands of Polish officers in the Katyn Forest 50 years ago, a Soviet newspaper has reported.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Celebration

title: Upheaval in the East;   Gorbachev Pressing Lithuanians To Shun Any Self-Defense Plans
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign of psychological pressure on Lithuania intensified today as he demanded that the Vilnius government end any plans for a self-defense system and ordered the K.G.B. to reinforce Soviet border posts.

title: Mellon to Issue Preferred Stock
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh, one of the nation's 20 largest bank holding companies, said yesterday that it would issue $160 million in a new series of preferred stock tied to a previously announced acquisition of 54 branches of Meritor Savings Bank.

title: Bank Unit Aided By Pinnacle West
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation infused more than $450 million in capital into its insolvent savings and loan subsidiary Merabank, which was seized by the Government on Jan. 31. The company said it had been released by three Federal agencies from further financial obligations under an agreement signed when Merabank was purchased by Pinnacle West in 1986.

title: New Finale Would Appall Beckett
description: To the Editor:

title:
Market Place;

2 Winners Seen In Restaurants
description: LEAD: WITH competition among fast-food chains fierce and many restaurant stocks trading well below their 365-day highs, two related restaurant companies based here deserve investor consideration, analysts say.

title: Concern Over Tokyo Stocks Sends the Dow 32.31 Lower
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday amid widening concern over the plunging stock market in Japan and new fears that the American economy could be heading into a recession.

title: Israelis Kill 2 Arabs and Seize 2 in Nablus
description: Two Palestinians wanted by Israeli security forces were shot and killed by soldiers in the ancient casbah of Nablus today after they ignored an order to halt, a military spokesman said.

title: Chronicle
description: STEVE MARTIN, who writes much of his own zany material, has donated original film scripts and other writings to a University of Texas library. The first batch, including drafts, revisions and final shooting scripts for the screenplays of ''Roxanne'' and ''Three Amigos,'' has arrived at the Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center on the Austin campus.

title: G.M. Rebates On Mini-vans
description: The General Motors Corporation today offered the first rebates on its three mini-van models in a bid for a greater share of the market dominated by the Chrysler Corporation.

title: 763 Burmese Houses Gutted
description: A fire burned down 763 houses and left almost 4,000 people homeless in the Myanmar capital of Yangon, according to a report today. It took three hours to control the blaze, said the report from the country formerly known as Burma. According to the report, the fire began Tuesday in a house and quickly spread. There was no mention of casualties.

title: Marks on Body Not From Bites, Dentist Testifies
description: A forensic dentist said today that two wounds said to be bite marks on the body of Kelly Ann Tinyes did not match dental impressions taken from Robert Golub, who is charged with killing her.

title: America, Land of the Unfree
description: LEAD: ''Go to the Berlin wall. It's the most fantastic experience you'll ever have in your life!'' This couldn't have been described better. That feeling of relief and exhilaration running through my body while watching every kind of character from geniuses to lunatics banging holes into the wall! What a great way to do violence to a bad memory of a whole era that you were suddenly given the power to crumble.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Businessland Inc., San Jose, Calif., a retail microcomputer systems and related business equipment company, named Leo Korman senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Review/Theater;   New Era for 'Grapes of Wrath'
description: IT'S not just because audiences must step around homeless people to get to the theater that the time is right for the Steppenwolf Theater Company's majestic adaptation of ''The Grapes of Wrath.''

title: Review/Film;   'Henry,' the Disturbing, Almost-True Story of a Serial Killer
description: Alfred Hitchcock once said of ''Psycho'' (with what possible dissembling he never let on): ''People will say: 'It was a terrible film to make. The subject was horrible; the people were small; there were no characters in it.' '' But he claimed not to care. ''It wasn't a message that stirred the audience,'' he said, ''They were aroused by pure film.''

title: At Last, a Child Care Bill?
description: Congress has a chance now to pass vital legislation long stalled by territorial battles in the House of Representatives. It can enact a bill that will make it possible for the working poor to get decent child care for their children - and complement two Administration initiatives that will put more money in the pockets of the poor.

title: Upheaval in the East;   LITHUANIA ASSAILS MOSCOW'S TACTICS AS CONVOY ARRIVES
description: Lithuanian officials sought today to sustain their claim of sovereignty even as Soviet forces rolled through town to emphasize President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's assertion that Moscow's writ still holds sway here.

title: Reebok Removes TV Ad After Complaints From Viewers
description: Reebok International Ltd. has pulled a television commercial for its new Pump basketball shoe after complaints from parents.

title: Rohr Gets Jet Job
description: Rohr Industries received a contract valued at about $1 billion from International Aero Engines to design and manufacture the nacelles - the aerodynamic structures that surround jet engines - for International Aero's V2500 engine for the MD-90 airliner built by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. McDonnell Douglas has orders for 95 of the MD-90 jets and has received options for another 155. The first flight is scheduled for the summer of 1993.

title: BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional;   Xavier Runs Out of Gas as Texas Prevails by 102-89
description: Xavier thoroughly outplayed Texas for a little more than a half tonight. But after building a 16-point second-half lead, everything for the Musketeers unraveled. They rushed shots. They did not rebound or play the kind of defense that had rattled Texas. They rushed shots. They made sloppy passes, did not get back on defense and ran into foul trouble. And they rushed more shots. Xavier's penchant to run, run, and run some more while tossing errant shots brought their demise and induced a spirited 102-89 Texas victory before 16,413 in Reunion Arena.

title: Review/Art;   A Sprinkling of Exhibitions Near Factories and the Water
description: Brooklyn has long been a major site of that essential art-world ritual, the studio visit, the pilgrimage that dealers, critics and collectors make to encounter artworks and artists in their natural habitats. The borough is home to many artists, and countless others commute from Manhattan for bigger, lighter, less-expensive working space.

title: China Takes Court to Task
description: While commentary on Supreme Court rulings tends to be a domestic product, the Justices have an attentive foreign audience as well. A scathing critique in a Beijing newspaper has made that clear.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 505 money market mutual funds increased by $199 million, to $391.23 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 156 institutional funds increased by $530.9 million, to $91.88 billion. The assets of the 247 general-purpose funds were down $968.9 million, to $132.57 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds rose $637 million, to $166.78 billion, the institute said.

title: Limits on Assault Rifles Voted
description: A House subcommittee voted Wednesday to restrict the sale and possession of assault rifles made in the United States and to require a minimum sentence of 10 years for a person carrying one while committing a crime. President Bush banned the importing of the semi-automatic rifles last year. The bill approved Wednesday by the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime would require the Administration to extend the ban to domestic-made versions that the President determines have no sporting purpose.

title: Help for Penn Relays
description: George Steinbrenner, who was running in the Penn Relays in Philadelphia long before he began running the Yankees, has organized a group to provide financial aid to rescue the annual event this year.

title: A Retirement At Newsweek
description: After 25 years with Newsweek, Howard W. Smith announced plans yesterday to retire as the magazine's worldwide publisher at the end of the year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
description: * The American Advertising Federation announced that the Chicago Museum of Broadcast Communications would be the site of the Advertising Hall of Fame.

title: Review/Operetta;   Students' 'Countess Maritza'
description: In recent years, the Brownlee Opera Theater at the Manhattan School of Music has specialized in operatic rarities and 20th-century works. It was decided, however, that since the ensemble's function is educational, it should also explore different parts of the literature. This time, it turned its attention to Viennese operetta.

title: In Center Field for Mets: A Big Question Mark
description: Center field is the only job vacancy the Mets have this spring and they have only one candidate to fill it: Keith Miller, who played seven games there last season. But they don't know whether he will win the job by acclamation or default, or how long he can hold it before they plunge into the trading market for help.

title: Stock Prices Rise in Japan
description: The stock market remained shaky and volatile early today after Thursday's wild swings, but a wave of program trading late in the day lifted prices for the day.

title: Idaho Approves Stiff Abortion Curbs
description: The Idaho Legislature approved the most restrictive abortion law in any state today after an emotional debate that touched on subjects like Romanian dictators and pioneer values.

title: Cray Computer Is Still Fastest
description: The Cray Research Corporation has retained its title as maker of the world's fastest computer in a new set of measurements conducted by the Center for Supercomputing Research and Development at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

title: Whooping Cough Vaccine Found Not to Be Linked to Brain Damage
description: A study has found no evidence that a widely used whooping cough vaccine causes brain damage, researchers say.

title: BASKETBALL: East Regional;   U.C.L.A. Rallies but Loses to Duke
description: Whether the shots are dropping or the feel has temporarily disappeared, an important part of Phil Henderson's role on the Duke Blue Devils remains clear.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Spotting the Trend Before It Takes Off
description: PAUL AHERN'S colleagues at Ahern & Heussner say he is less an ad man than a cultural anthropologist, a fellow who delights in exploring and analyzing the rituals and mores of a people. Fortunately for them - and him - the people he loves to analyze are consumers.

title: A Brooklyn Update: Where the Action Is
description: BROOKLYN has had a long and illustrious history as a center for fine arts and popular amusements. Now, New York's most populous borough is forging a new history, as shown by the array of galleries, nightclubs, performance spaces and food shops that have recently opened. These additions to Brooklyn's cultural map are usually different from similar venues in Manhattan. Many new Brooklyn galleries and clubs, for example, are places where artists and performers can test ideas and abilities. They are usually less crowded, less expensive, less formal, and friendlier than their counterparts across the East River. The newcomers include an adventurous theater in a former downtown soap factory, artist-run exhibition spaces near the gritty north Brooklyn waterfront, a French patisserie hidden in the Boerum Hill section and a museum that chronicles Brooklyn's decidedly colorful past. Articles about what's new in Brooklyn are on pages C26 and C27.

title: Health Data Show Wide Gap Between Whites and Blacks
description: High homicide rates, AIDS and lack of medical care are continuing to cut short the lives of black Americans, while the health of whites is improving, the Federal Government said today.

title: Rayburn Wright, Conductor, Teacher And Trombonist, 67
description: Rayburn Wright, a conductor, trombonist, arranger and teacher, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Rochester. He was 67 years old.

title: Ulan Bator Journal;   With Genghis Revived, What Will Mongols Do?
description: He may have killed people by the millions, but he was also a great nationalist and one of the most brilliant commanders in history. So, in one of the most unusual political rehabilitations in any Communist country so far, Genghis Khan is re-emerging as a national hero.

title: St. Louis Tops DePaul, 54-47
description: St. Louis overcame mediocre shooting tonight to hold off DePaul, 54-47, in a quarterfinal-round game of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: James H. R. Cromwell Dies at 93; Married 'Richest Girl in World'
description: James H. R. Cromwell, a wealthy businessman who was briefly a politician and diplomat and best known in the 1930's and 40's as the husband of ''the richest girl in the world,'' Doris Duke, died of a pulmonary ailment on Monday at the Marin Terrace retirement home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 93 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Times Group Sets Up New Ad Marketing Unit
description: The New York Times Company Magazine Group has formed a new advertising sales and marketing unit, which will allow marketers to buy packages of advertising in the group's magazines, books and videos. The new unit will also fashion advertising packages including customized magazines and sports promotions.

title: Tories Suffer Big Defeat in Special Vote
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party suffered an election rout on Thursday in a district it had won easily in the 1987 national elections.

title: Korea, U.S. In Beef Pact
description: South Korea has resolved a dispute with the United States over beef imports, averting possible trade sanctions, trade ministry officials said today.

title: Avon Stake Held By Goldman, Sachs
description: The New York investment firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company has purchased 6.5 percent of the preferred stock of Avon Products Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Goldman, Sachs said it had purchased the shares as an investment. It said that between Dec. 28 and March 9, it made net purchases of 119,500 preferred shares on the open market for prices ranging from $24.75 to $28.12 a share.

title: Saturday Australia Vote May Bring In Opposition
description: Australians vote on Saturday in national elections that opinion polls show could bring the Conservative opposition to power and end the seven-year Government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke.

title: Bondholders Balk at Southland's 'Junk Bond' Plan
description: Bondholders and analysts said yesterday that the Southland Corporation's plan to sell control to a Japanese company and then exchange Southland ''junk bonds'' for new bonds and stock with much lower face value would probably be rejected by creditors as inadequate.

title: Wisconsin Leaders Back Curb on Sale Of Growth Hormone
description: In a setback to four of the nation's largest chemical and drug companies, the Wisconsin Legislature voted today to bar temporarily the commercial use or sale of genetically engineered growth hormone intended to increase milk production in dairy cows.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: U.S. Sues a Long Island Village, Charging Bias in H.U.D. Housing
description: The Federal Government filed a civil-rights suit yesterday against the Long Island village of Island Park, contending that officials of the virtually all-white suburb had schemed to provide their relatives and friends federally subsidized houses while excluding black applicants.

title: Let Lithuania Go
description: A Soviet diplomat buttonholed me to say he had read my book about Lincoln - and wasn't there a remarkable similarity between the challenge of secession that Lincoln faced in 1861 and the challenge Mikhail Gorbachev faces from the Baltic secessionists today? How could I square support of Lincoln's decision to preserve the Union with my incendiary column titled ''Free the Baltics''?

title: 4 Goals for Thomas Against the Devils
description: After being outskated, outhit and outscored by a large margin for two periods, the Devils rallied for two goals early in the third period tonight to make things tight for the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Format Emerging for Advanced TV
description: The high-definition television picture has become a little clearer this week.

title: Maurice Cloche, 82, French Film Director
description: Maurice Cloche, a director best known for his Oscar-winning film ''Monsieur Vincent,'' died on Tuesday at his home in Bordeaux after a long illness. He was 82 years old and had Parkinson's disease.

title: Ingersoll Scrambles to Avoid Default
description: After successfully expanding his newspaper empire through much of the 1980's, Ralph Ingersoll 2d was scrambling today to avoid a default on some of his company's high-yield ''junk bonds.''

title: Jason Boe, Oregon Politician, 61
description: Jason Boe, a former President of the Oregon Senate who dominated the Legislature in the 1970's, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at University Hospital here. He was 61 years old and lived in Portland.

title: USX to Sell Off Art
description: The USX Corporation plans to auction 64 works of art from its collection this spring, said Christie's auction house, which will handle the sale. A spokeswoman for Christie's said the collection is expected to sell for $3.5 million to $5 million. The auction house said the art includes Impressionist and other 19th-century and 20th-century works. The Pittsburgh-based USX, an energy and steel producer, said it had decided to sell the collection to take advantage of the favorable art market. The paintings had been displayed at its headquarters here.

title: Eunice Matthew, 73, Professor of Education
description: Eunice Matthew, a professor of childhood education at Brooklyn College until her retirement in 1985, died on Monday after a fall at her home in Manhattan, where she was recovering from spinal surgery. She was 73 years old.

title: 12 Injured in Foundry As a Furnace Explodes
description: At least a dozen people were injured last night, three of them seriously, when a furnace exploded at the U.S. Pipe & Foundry Company, officials said.

title: A Subway Passenger Falls Through Brooklyn El Tracks
description: A 54-year-old leaving a train yesterday in Brooklyn lost her footing and fell through the tracks of an el station 25 feet to the street, transit officials said.

title: Bush Administration Opposes Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Facts in Connecticut
description: Gov. William O'Neill of Connecticut has decided not to run for re-election, with good reason. His mishandling of the state's budget crisis last year, highlighted by a billion-dollar increase in taxes, sent his popularity into a nosedive. Foreseeing a mud-slinging campaign for which he has no stomach, he wisely opts for honorable retirement. His successor will have to pick up the pieces.

title: UAL Agrees To Coniston Negotiations
description: The board of directors of the UAL Corporation agreed yesterday to negotiate with Coniston Partners and three of its unions on a buyout of the company, even though the board found the amount offered to be too small and had doubts on whether the group could get the financing.

title: Ballesteros's Game Needs A Big Shot of Confidence
description: His swing is firmer and more studied than in the wonder years, but Seve Ballesteros hasn't lost the big-cat grace that almost by itself was enough to declare him the best golfer in the world.

title: Curtiss-Wright Fills Top Posts
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation said today that it had named Shirley D. Brinsfield chairman and Charles E. Ehinger president. The appointments of Mr. Brinsfield, formerly executive vice president and a director, and Mr. Ehinger, also previously an executive vice president, fill the vacancies created by the death of T. Roland Berner earlier this week. Curtiss-Wright also appointed Mr. Ehinger as a director.

title: Lower-Income Housing;   New Jersey Town Sees 2 Projects Straining Services
description: Seven years after the New Jersey Supreme Court mandated affordable housing for the area, the township of Branchburg in Somerset County is finding that the new homes it authorized in the wake of the decision are causing a growth spurt that is straining services.

title: Sutton May Raise Its Bid for DeSoto
description: The Sutton Holding Corporation, the New York concern that has been pursuing DeSoto Inc. since November, said it might be willing to raise its $50 bid for the Des Plains, Ill., paint and chemical maker to ''at least $55 per share in cash'' if it was given permission to discuss its plans with third parties. Last month, the DeSoto board said that it would explore all alternatives to maximize shareholder value and that it would provide confidential information to interested parties if the prospective bidders agreed not to discuss bids with any third parties.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: In a Clanging of Bureaucracy, Children's Statue Falls
description: It was closer in looks to the tin Woodman in ''The Wizard of Oz'' - the way he was before Dorothy arrived with that life-renewing squirt of oil - than the Statue of Liberty or General Sherman on his shiny gold horse at the edge of Central Park. It stood, tall and proud, on a vacant city-owned lot in East Harlem where the children who built it could see its all-seeing solar-powered eye.

title: Savings Regulator Nominated
description: Scrambling to neutralize the effects of a Federal judge's ruling that could bring the Government's bailout of the savings and loan industry to a virtual standstill, President Bush today nominated T. Timothy Ryan Jr., a former top lawyer for the Labor Department, as the nation's chief Federal savings and loan regulator.

title: BASKETBALL: Women's N.C.A.A.;   Washington Defeats South Carolina
description: Karen Deden scored 17 points and started a 17-2 second-half run that gave Washington control of the game as the third-ranked Huskies defeated South Carolina, 73-61, tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideast Regional semifinals.

title: William K. Beard, 91, A Magazine Executive
description: William Kelly Beard, a retired business publications executive, died on Thursday at White Plains Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Waging War of Words at Marcos Trial
description: Ted Laguatan appears nearly every day outside the courthouse door, a stocky man who prefers gray sports jackets and purple ties. He has a round unstartling face and under normal circumstances in these early days of the Imelda Marcos trial, he might disappear into the background. But Mr. Laguatan is an envoy of Corazon Aquino, the President of the Philippines. With the help of a press agent, he is in New York on a mission.

title: Broken Steam Pipe Spews Asbestos
description: A ruptured underground steam pipe on the Upper East Side spewed asbestos into the street yesterday, leading officials to close off a seven-block stretch of Madison Avenue and adjacent side streets, disrupting traffic, forcing stores to shut and requiring residents to be escorted home by the police.

title: Review/Photography;   Paul Laster Treads a Painterly Path to Reality
description: Since the early 1980's, the territory between painting and photography has been defined by the difference between unique, handmade originals and images that are photo-mechanically reproduced. But such a distinction is not so sharp as it first appears. As the work of an artist like Andy Warhol makes clear, the seemingly distinct domains of originals and reproductions can be made to overlap.

title: Promise at Midnight
description: It was a scene of amiable chaos.

title: Profits Up 32.6% at Guinness
description: The British liquor company Guinness P.L.C. said today that its profits rose 32.6 percent last year.

title: METHADONE UNITS FAULTED IN REPORT
description: At a time when the Bush Administration is considering a proposal to expand the number of methadone maintenance programs, the General Accounting Office has concluded that many methadone centers are not effective in weaning addicts from heroin.
