title: Upheaval in the East;   Bush Urges Gorbachev to Avoid A Military Assault in Lithuania
description: President Bush appealed to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to avoid using military force in Lithuania as the Administration sought to balance its formal support for Lithuanian independence with its concern for stability in Eastern Europe.

title: If Menem Falters in Argentina . . .
description: LEAD: Beginning on Easter 1987, Argentine military officers rose in three rebellions against the armed forces high command and the Government of President Raul Alfonsin. The officers who led those protests have come to be called ''carapintadas'' - painted faces - because of the combat face paint worn during those confrontations.

title: 2 Sign Lucratively
description: Just two weeks after the National Football League completed a television agreement that will guarantee each team an average of $32 million a year for the next four years, two teams began to pass on the big bucks to their star players.

title: In Chicago, Renewed Uproar on Bigotry
description: Days after winning a bitterly fought primary election here, Representative Gus Savage is back in the trenches, this time in a battle over remarks he made in the closing days of the campaign.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-6

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Southeast Regional;   Georgia Tech Edges Spartans in Overtime
description: The wild, winding road to the Final Four, already filled with upsets and spine-tingling finishes, took a crazy and controversial turn tonight. Georgia Tech, a team that has specialized in heroic comebacks and last gasp victories this season, outdid itself tonight in defeating top-seeded Michigan State, 81-80, in overtime.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: DUCHESS OF YORK gave birth to a 7-pound-1 1/2-ounce daughter by Caesarian section last night at Portland Hospital in London. Both mother - often known in the tabloid press as Fergie, after her maiden name, Sarah Ferguson - and baby were doing well. The baby has no name yet but will be known as Her Royal Highness, Princess (fill in her first name here when she has one) of

title: Oil Industry's Anti-Spill Plans
description: The oil industry said yesterday that it would take modest actions aimed at preventing spills in New York Harbor and making responses quicker. Environmental groups criticized the measures as ineffectual.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Fixing Your Makeup
description: Has your makeup outlasted its shelf life? Makeup that sits in a drawer or handbag exposed to atmospheric and temperature changes can break down. Ingredients in cosmetics, like those in food, can separate or turn rancid. And each application introduces dirt and oil, though this can be mitigated by using clean brushes and applicators. Dr. Janice Teal, director of product and package safety for Avon cosmetics, said mascara poses the most danger because applicators often touch the eye. Suntan lotion has the longest shelf life; its ingredients must survive high temperatures. Here are guidelines on when to replace makeup. $ Type of Makeup Shelf Life Replacement Signals Liquid foundation 2 years Oil separation Lipstick 2-3 years Beads of oil on sides Liquid mascara, eye pencil 3 months Contamination by bacteria and fungi, though not detectable, occurs with use Eye shadow, face powder 2-3 years Flaking Suntan lotion 5 years or more No visible signs

title: Brooklyn Teen-Ager Is Charged in Assaults
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested early yesterday and charged in a series of sexual assaults of five girls ranging in age from 9 years old to 17, the police said.

title: List Trial Won't Be Moved
description: An appeals panel today rebuffed an attempt by John E. List, who is accused of killing his family 18 years ago, to move his trial out of Elizabeth and sequester the jury because of the publicity his case has drawn.

title: New Credit Card From A.T.&T. Due
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will announce on Monday that it is starting its own credit card, people familiar with the company's plans said. A.T.&T. scheduled a news conference at its Manhattan headquarters. The company will introduce a new card combining the billing of A.T.&T. credit-card calls with the billing of meals, hotel rooms and other goods and services, the sources said. An A.T.&T. spokesman declined to comment.

title: Mongolia, Too, Ends Communist Monopoly
description: Mongolia's Communist legislators formally abolished their party's monopoly on power today and approved elections with more than one candidate. But the election law was drafted before recent democracy protests and does not mention a role for opposition parties, officials said.

title: Brazil Eases Money Plan
description: Brazil's President, Fernando Collor de Mello, announced changes today in his drastic anti-inflation plan, giving concessions to several sectors.

title: Nets Lose On the Road
description: Rik Smits had 30 points and 14 rebounds tonight as the Indiana Pacers handed the Nets their 22d consecutive road loss and ninth succcessive defeat over all in a 125-109 decision.

title: Subway Information, the Map Excepted, Isn't User Friendly
description: To the Editor:

title: No Indictment In a Killing At IND Stop
description: A grand jury yesterday declined to indict a construction worker who said he had acted in self-defense when he killed a homeless man by slamming his head onto a subway platform at Columbus Circle in January.

title: 400 Protesters In Manhattan Attack Racism
description: Denouncing what they termed a ''conspiracy to destroy black youth,'' about 400 demonstrators marched through upper Manhattan yesterday, snarling traffic and holding noisy rallies, but they were prevented from entering a bridge and highway by 150 police officers in riot gear.

title: Review/Pop;   With the Dense Band, Texture Is Melody
description: David Moss's Dense Band dispenses noisy free improvisation in handy, accessible form - song-length pieces with a beat. The Dense Band, which performed on Monday night at the Knitting Factory, is built around Mr. Moss's talents as a drummer and a free-form vocalist. Whether or not he is sitting at his drum kit - which includes a steel drum, an electronic drum pad and various crumpled cymbals as well as ordinary trap drums - he can pour out syllables, meaningless or not.

title: David Singer, Professor, 63
description: David Singer, a professor of economics, died of cancer on Tuesday at the home of a friend, Sheila Steckel, in Manhattan. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cardinal Nominates 2 for Covenant House
description: John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday submitted the names of two priests for the Covenant House board to consider for acting president and vice president of the troubled charity.

title: Man Charged With Extortion Threats to Steinbrenner
description: A man who says he aided George Steinbrenner in his feud with Dave Winfield over contributions to the Winfield Foundation was arrested yesterday and charged with threatening physical harm to Steinbrenner and Winfield and with trying to extort money from the Yankees' owner, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Bid for Allegheny
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge said Thursday that he would probably choose a New York investment group's $650 million bid for financially ailing Allegheny International Inc. if the group can raise the cash. Japonica Partners is competing with Allegheny International's management to take over the Pittsburgh-based maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances. The company is operating under protection from its creditors. The management bid is worth about $570 million and would pay off creditors and shareholders with stock in a reorganized company.

title: About New York From Parasites To Benefactors: Power of Thanks
description: ''This is where it all began,'' said the man called Smooth, pointing across the street to the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian Resolution
description: Following is the text of a resolution passed by the Lithuanian Parliament early this morning, as translated by the Lithuanian Information Service:

title: Review/Pop;   Doom, Folksy and Surreal
description: John Cale and Bob Neuwirth envisioned a cracker-barrel apocalypse in ''The Last Day on Earth,'' a set of songs they wrote together and presented on March 16 at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights. It was a kind of song cycle; the selections were played virtually without interruption, and a recurring theme appeared at the beginning, middle and end. By turns folksy and surreal, bleak and wry, the songs added up to a shrug of the shoulders in the face of impending doom.

title: Ronald Lyman Jr., 84, Investment Executive
description: Ronald T. Lyman Jr., who retired in 1970 as a general partner of Scudder Stevens & Clark after 40 years with the Boston investment firm, died of a stroke on Monday at Roper Hospital in Charleston, S.C. He was 84 years old and lived in Boston and Charleston.

title: Hewlett-Packard In Scottish Closing
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company will close its plant in Livingston, Scotland, and move its operations to three other sites. The plant repairs computer boards and assembles work stations. Its 240 workers will be offered jobs elsewhere with the company. The computer, electronics and instruments company acquired the Livingston plant when it bought Apollo Computer Inc. in May 1989.

title: A 'Really Tough' Agassi Beats Berger Handily and Moves to Final
description: This week, Andre Agassi described himself as ''complicated, very complicated.'' But he also pledged to be uncomplicated while on the tennis court, which is why he has earned the opportunity to play for the $179,000 title at the Lipton International Players Championships on Sunday.

title: Pine Valley, L.I., Fades Into Pine Valley, R.I.P.
description: This village has been called many things in its two years of life: a developer's dream, an experiment in self-determination, a joke. Now call it defunct.

title: Gorbachev's Vast Overreaction in Lithuania
description: LEAD: When it comes to reading the thoughts, feelings and intentions of nationalists in his sprawling and diverse land, Mikhail Gorbachev demonstrates little of the political savvy that he brings to other domestic and foreign affairs.

title: Nicaragua Rebels Agree to Start Disbanding Troops in Honduras
description: The Nicaraguan rebels agreed today to disband their forces in Honduras by April 20, five days before the inauguration of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua.

title: Language Again Threatening To Split Canadian Federation
description: For the second time in 10 years, Canada is caught in the throes of an emotional and divisive debate over its future as a united country. Once again, the issue is language. For the moment, the tone - in either French or English - is pessimistic.

title: On AIDS, Compassion and Confusion
description: The surge of deaths among patients taking an experimental new AIDS drug, DDI, does not necessarily mean the drug is to blame. AIDS activists have brought about changes in the traditional methods of testing drugs. The new methods represent a compassionate response to AIDS sufferers. They also risk confusion.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: The Rev. RALPH DAVID ABERNATHY, the civil rights leader, was hospitalized in Atlanta yesterday for a low-sodium condition caused by diuretics he had been taking for heart disease. DR. ROBERT KAUFMANN, Mr. Abernathy's physician, said he was in fair condition and had not suffered a heart attack.

title: Arafat Presses Soviets on Jews' Migration to Israel
description: Yasir Arafat says the Palestine Liberation Organization has asked the Soviet Union to adopt specific measures to slow the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel.

title: Dinkins Woos His Party To Win Its Convention
description: Seeking to promote his city's image and economy, Mayor David N. Dinkins, a vision of urban glamour, arrived in Indiana today, intent on persuading the Democratic Party to hold its national convention in New York City in 1992.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST/SATURDAY, MARCH 24, 1990
description: International

title: Lockheed Battle
description: The Texas investor Harold C. Simmons said on Thursday that he would probably sell about $1 billion worth of assets in the Lockheed Corporation's technology and electronics services businesses if he wins control of the company. He said no final decision would be made until after a review of the company's financial records. Lockheed, the nation's sixth-largest military concern, has more than $2 billion in assets in the technology and electronics services divisions, which have produced scanty profits. Chief among the problem divisions is Sanders Inc. in Nashua, N.H., according to Mr. Simmons and his chief lieutenant, J. Landis Martin.

title: Final Four: Another Version
description: While the big-time ''programs'' are competing to reach the Final Four of college basketball, one school has already won its national championship. The University of Rochester in upstate New York defeated DePauw of Indiana for the Division III title last Saturday. The final score was 43-42.

title: Upheaval in the East: Belgrade Journal;   Tito's Image, a Few Reluctant Steps Behind Stalin's, Is Slowly Carted Away
description: Hardly a day has gone by in recent months without some act to cut the heroic image of Tito down to size, revealing the late President as exceptionally greedy, mendacious and vainglorious.

title: New Kennedy Center Head Says He Has Pledge of Aid
description: James D. Wolfensohn, an investment banker, arts patron and chairman of Carnegie Hall in New York, was selected today to become chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Up a Bit
description: Prices of Treasury securities meandered in a narrow range yesterday before closing slightly higher. Traders were extremely nervous and unwilling to take significant positions because of several factors that developed during the week, dealers said.

title: Cocoa Pact Extension
description: The world's largest cocoa-producing countries agreed today to support a two-year extension of the International Cocoa Agreement, with all provisions on price supports frozen for the period, a spokesman for the producers said.

title: No Shortage, but Costlier Coffee
description: No matter what economic changes are made next in Brazil, the world's largest exporter of coffee and the largest supplier to the United States, American coffee drinkers will almost certainly be paying more next month at the supermarkets.

title: Search Is Halted for 9 Lost in Bering Sea After Trawler Sinks
description: The Coast Guard suspended its search for nine men today after concluding that they had drowned when their fishing trawler capsized and sank in the frigid Bering Sea.

title: East Bloc Trade Shift Seen
description: The United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, said today that a substantial streamlining of Western curbs on high-technology exports to Eastern Europe is likely to be completed by June.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Victor in East Germany Now Says He's Ready to Head Government
description: Lothar de Maiziere, chairman of the Christian Democratic Union, which won the parliamentary elections on Sunday, ended five days of uncertainty today by declaring his readiness to head East Germany's first freely chosen and non-Communist Government.

title: French Publishing Feud Ends Up in the Courts
description: The family feud that has convulsed Editions Gallimard for the last two months ended up in court today when Antoine Gallimard's brother and two sisters formally challenged his control over France's most prestigious publisher.

title: Knicks Plunge Into Third
description: Maybe the Knicks should put Patrick Ewing out on the floor alone and let him play one on five. The result probably would not be much worse than what happened to the Knicks tonight as they lost by 106-93 to the Hornets, who have the worst record in the National Basketball Association at 13-53.

title: Loyola Held to 62 Points But Still Beats Alabama
description: Just when the Loyola Marymount team seemed to have finally run out of steam and come to the end of its glorious and melancholy journey, one that had captured the interest and curiosity of a nation, the Lions found a way to win.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday headed ''Overall U.S. Market for Cigars'' referred incorrectly to sales figures shown for big manufacturers.

title: Doing Hard Time in the Art Pen
description: News of the big art theft from a Boston museum made my day.

title: A Year After Spill, Progress on Safety
description: A year after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, the nation is making halting progress toward improving the safety of oil transportation.

title: Spills, Explosions, Accidents: A Deadly Pattern
description: LEAD: Why is so much oil spilling into the waters in New York City's harbor?

title: Patents;   New Rods Said to Cut Danger of Lightning
description: Two Florida inventors won patent approval this week on a class of lightning rods shaped like feather dusters. The advantage of the rods, they say, is that they dissipate far more of the ground's static electricity and sharply reduce the chances of being struck by lightning.

title: Religion Notes
description: A Receding Issue As Israel's major parties struggle to put together a government with potential coalition partners, one bargaining chip that caused consternation for many American Jews in the past is missing. This time around, none of the small, pivotal religious parties is demanding legislation that would narrow the definition of who is Jewish.

title: Fixed Mortgages Drop
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are now averaging 10.26 percent, down from 10.34 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, up from 8.55 percent the week before.

title: Parents Drawn to a School of Excellence
description: Bernard Russo, a 36-year-old video engineer, camped overnight outside City Hall here. His mission: to enroll his 5-year-old daughter, Lilly, in the Daniel Webster Magnet School.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: The Baltic Bind;   Lithuania Seems to Dare Gorbachev to Act And He Seems Only to Harden Its Resolve
description: From the sidelines, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Lithuania seem to be two prideful political forces blundering toward a fateful collision.

title: 2 Die in Rubble As Wall Crashes Into Warehouse
description: A 15-foot-high concrete-block wall under construction collapsed yesterday morning in Brooklyn and crashed through a warehouse ceiling, killing two people and seriously injuring several others, the authorities said.

title: AIDS Viral Discovery Again at Issue
description: A new disagreement between American and French scientists has erupted over their competing claims to have discovered the AIDS virus, with the leader of the French research group urging the head of the United States team to admit that he was mistaken.

title: 10-Day Vehicle Sales Off 9.5% As Season Gets a Slow Start
description: The automobile industry's important spring selling season has started poorly. Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks in mid-March were down by 9.5 percent from a year ago, with all of the Big Three companies reporting declines today.

title: Taking Heat Part of the Job For Lundine
description: Shortly after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo assigned Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine to lead New York's lobbying for a coveted Federal contract for an atom smasher, Mr. Lundine was spit at and pelted with stones by Rochester residents who opposed the project.

title: Bald Eagles Are Not Yet Out of the Endangered Species Woods
description: To the Editor:

title: George Cooper, 61, City College Professor
description: George Cooper, deputy chairman of the department of biology at City College of the City University of New York, died of cancer on Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Orangeburg, N.Y.

title: ABC Adding a Cartoon Based on Roseanne Barr
description: ABC has announced the addition of three new half-hour children's programs to its Saturday morning schedule, including an animated show about Roseanne Barr as a 10-year-old. The programs are to join the schedule on Sept. 8.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 10 about Ron Wolin, an antiwar advocate who brought a successful lawsuit to permit the distribution of political and religious leaflets in publicly owned transportation terminals, misstated later decisions on the issue. Unlike transportation terminals, privately owned shopping centers in New York and nearly all other states are still permitted to limit leaflet distribution and solicitation.

title: Republican Chairman Is Hospitalized Again
description: The Republican national chairman, Lee Atwater, was hospitalized today for the second time this month. He complained of queasiness that aides said was caused by an imbalance of medication for treatment of a benign brain tumor.

title: Still A Long List
description: The official murder of a British freelance journalist, Farzad Bazoft, in Baghdad put the spotlight on Iraq for a few days. It should stay there. Torture, summary execution, flagrant violation of the most basic human rights have not been wiped out, and Iraq remains one of the world's worst offenders.

title: Review/Film Festival;   A Japanese Greengrocer Stricken by 'Chinese Fever'
description: ''Beijing Watermelon,'' Nobuhiko Obayashi's new Japanese film, is a sentimental but never a convincingly sweet tale about a Tokyo greengrocer who nearly bankrupts the family business by helping a succession of poor Chinese students.

title: Doubling the Guarantee on a Computer
description: Here is a tip for people buying a home computer: Charge it on either a gold Visa or a gold Mastercard. Simply by using one of the bank cards, your computer's guarantee will be doubled, up to an additional year. That may not be the case if you pay for the system using American Express.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing misstated the number of people cleared of charges. Two men, not one, have been acquitted. In addition to Dale Schnittjer, a vice president at Teledyne Electronics, who was cleared on three criminal charges last April, Leonard L. Ingram, a former official of Lee Telecommunications Inc., was acquitted on nine criminal charges in December.

title: A 'Distressed' Baker Sees Soweto and Also Apartheid
description: Greeted by scattered chants of ''power is ours,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met here today with leaders of the African National Congress, who urged him to keep pressure on South Africa's white-minority Government.

title: Government Approves Novel Drug To Treat Immune System Disease
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a novel type of drug yesterday for the treatment of a rare genetic disease that devastates the immune system.

title: Boeing in Move To Double Shares
description: The Boeing Company is seeking shareholder approval to more than double the number of common shares outstanding to 600 million, but the company said in its proxy statement that it had no immediate plan to issue more stock. Boeing has 230.6 million common shares outstanding. Shareholders will vote on the proposal at the company's annual meeting on April 30.

title: Perrier in Talks With Cadbury
description: The French drink company Source Perrier S.A. said it was discussing the sale of its soft drink business to Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. of Britain. Perrier's soft drink brands include Oasis and Bali orange squashes, Pschitt sodas and Gini lemonade. Perrier's mineral water business is not included in the soft drink segment.

title: Review/Film;   Roy Scheider in a Parable of the Cold War
description: Col. Jack Knowles (Roy Scheider) is the sort of guy who, upon hearing that three bullies stole his young son's bicycle in the schoolyard, wonders why the boy couldn't hang on to it; after all, there were only three of them. This kind of attitude made him a hero in Vietnam, but since then he has been a belligerent misfit. Still in the military, and now stationed in West Germany near the Czechoslovak border, Knowles remains a sorehead and a ticking time bomb.

title: Review/Dance;   Two Premieres by Helgi Tomasson
description: Contrary to expectations - or fears - Helgi Tomasson is not turning the San Francisco Ballet into a copy of the New York City Ballet, where he danced for 15 years under George Balanchine's tutelage.

title: Anthony J. Prudenti, Contractor And G.O.P. Leader, Is Dead at 61
description: Anthony J. Prudenti, a contractor who was Suffolk County Republican chairman from 1980 to 1984, died of a heart attack on Thursday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Blue Point, L.I.

title: F.T.C. Reviews Genentech Deal
description: The Federal Trade Commission has requested more information for its antitrust review of the proposed acquisition of a majority of Genentech Inc. by Roche Holding Ltd., the two companies said today. Jack Murphy, a spokesman for Genentech, said it was too early to tell whether the additional Federal review would delay the completion of the transaction.

title: Soviets to Curb Jews' Flights to Israel
description: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings today to find a way to counter the Soviet decision.

title: Subway Information, the Map Expected, Isn't User Friendly;   Add a Short Form
description: To the Editor:

title: List of Japan Goals Cited
description: The United States Government has given Japan a list of more than 200 suggested policy changes aimed at eliminating barriers faced by foreign companies operating in Japan, a news report said today.

title: Soviet Georgian Troupe
description: The Rustavi Company, a Georgian folk music and dance troupe from the Soviet Union, is to make its American debut at 8 P.M. on April 5 at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street. The 60-member group plans six performances, the last on April 8. Tickets are $20 to $35 at the box office and Ticketron outlets. Information: 496-7070 or 947-5850.

title: John Jardine, Football Coach, 54
description: John Jardine, who coached the Wisconsin football team from 1970 through 1977, died of heart failure today at the University of Wisconsin Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: Robert Karplus, 63; Professor Improved Teaching of Science
description: Robert Karplus, a professor of physics at the University of California at Berkeley for more than 35 years who led in developing new techniques for teaching science in elementary schools, died of a heart attack on Thursday at a convalescent home in Moraga, Calif. He was 63 years old and lived in Orinda, Calif.

title: Movie Studios Angry at NBC
description: Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, demanded yesterday that the NBC network grant Hollywood producers equal time to rebut charges made in an NBC News documentary on Wednesday night.

title: Durables Orders Up By 3.3%
description: A rebound in dealers' orders for automobiles pushed orders for durable goods up by 3.3 percent last month, the Government said today, but the recovery after January's record plunge offered little hope that manufacturing was pulling out of its slump.

title: Bolivians Kill Trafficker's Son
description: The son of one of Bolivia's biggest drug traffickers has been killed in a gun battle with the police, television reports said. The dead man, Roberto Suarez Levy, was killed on Thursday night after the police surrounded his house in this southern Bolivian town. His father, Roberto Suarez Gomez, is serving a 15-year prison term for producing and selling cocaine.

title: Wrecked 'Robot' to Be Rebuilt, New York Officials Say
description: The day after New York City bulldozed a statue built by East Harlem children, city officials promised yesterday to restore it.

title: Federal Proposal Would Require Van Services for Disabled Who Can't Use Buses
description: In a move welcomed by advocates for the disabled, the Bush Administration has proposed that operators of federally aided bus lines be required to provide door-to-door service in specialized vans for disabled people who do not benefit from wheelchair lifts and other special devices on buses.

title: Corrections
description: A report in ''At the Movies'' in Weekend yesterday about John Frankheimer's new film, ''The Fourth War,'' misidentified one of his previous films. It is ''The French Connection II,'' not ''The French Connection.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are under constant pressure from the outside. A certain kind of psychological warfare is being waged against Lithuania.'' - President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania. [1:6.]

title: Moscow Limits Flights Taking Jews to Israel
description: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings to find a way to counteract the Soviet decision. The Soviet announcement said that Aeroflot would no longer issue tickets to Soviet Jews planning to emigrate to Israel by flying through Hungary, a heavily used transit point. The Soviet announcement came as Yasir Arafat said in Casablanca, Morocco, that the Palestine Liberation Organization has asked Moscow to adopt specific measures to slow immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel.

title: Heart Study Finds Need to Cut Overall Fat in Diet
description: Reducing the amount of fat in the diet is more important than changing the kinds of fat consumed in preventing obstructive lesions in the heart arteries, researchers said yesterday.

title: Your Money;   Errors That Lead To an I.R.S. Audit
description: Taxpayers can minimize the likelihood of an audit by the Internal Revenue Service if they avoid certain common errors and are alert to areas the I.R.S. considers prone to abuse.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL:Southeast Regional;   Hot 2d Half Propels Minnesota
description: Undersized, underdog Minnesota executed its defensive game plan to perfection tonight and bounced Syracuse from the national collegiate tournament with an 82-75 victory in a Southeast Regional semifinal.

title: UAL Will Let Davis Buy Additional Shares
description: The UAL Corporation said yesterday that it had changed its standstill agreement with Marvin Davis to allow the West Coast investor to buy additional shares in the company.

title: Patient 76ers to Retire Chamberlain's No. 13
description: Wilt Chamberlain, the second-leading career scorer in National Basketball Association history with 31,419 points over 14 seasons, has seen his jersey number, 13, retired by the Los Angeles Lakers, for whom he played his six final seasons, ending in 1973. Now the Philadelphia 76ers, with whom he played three and a half seasons in the mid-1960's, would like to honor their home-grown 7-foot-1-inch hero, too.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Crown Cork Adds Can Units
description: Continuing its buying binge, the Crown Cork and Seal Company agreed today to buy the food and beverage metal canning units of the Continental Can Company in a purchase that will make Crown the nation's biggest maker of metal packaging.

title: Review/Theater;   The Excesses of 'Baal,' Reflected in Its Staging
description: In Bertolt Brecht's first play, ''Baal,'' written when he was 20 years old, the protagonist is a poet who leads a life of ''sensational immorality.'' The play was indirectly prophetic of what might have become of Brecht himself if he had not continued on his course toward art, philosophy and self-realization. Baal, in contrast, is a portrait of self-indulgence in the extreme, and he ends as a figure of despair.

title: Bush Notes 'Filth' but Rejects Censors
description: President Bush said today that some federally financed art exhibits included filthy, blasphemous and sacrilegious material, but he nonetheless rejected Government censorship of the arts.

title: Unocal Unit Sale
description: The Unocal International Corporation, a unit of the Unocal Corporation, said it had agreed to sell its oil and gas subsidiary, Unocal Norge A.S., to Total Marine Norsk A.S. for $322 million. The sale, subject to regulatory approval in Norway, is expected to close in May. Unocal's shares rose 87.5 cents today, to $30.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Protests Attack on 2 in Zaire
description: The United States has protested to Zaire over attacks on two lawyers who were investigating human-rights practices there, State Department officials said today.

title: Recourse for Shoddy Work
description: For several months, William Drozdal waited for a contractor to finish the front of his house after parts of it were ripped off during a renovation project. But after reading a newspaper article, Mr. Drozdal, an accountant in Rochdale, Mass., learned that he, too, had been ''ripped off,'' as he put it.

title: Sobol Reverses Self on Chancellor
description: New York State's Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, said last summer that the position of New York City schools chancellor should be abolished. But today he reversed himself and endorsed the agenda of the current Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez.

title: Secret Reports at Trial Hint Congress Knew of Rebel Aid
description: John M. Poindexter's lawyers disclosed in court today a summary of classified information indicating that a House committee was told in late 1985, when aid to the Nicaraguan rebels was barred by Congress, that the United States was apparently directing their insurgency.

title: Yes You Can Root For Baseball Teams
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW'S FORCES STEP UP PRESSURE ACROSS LITHUANIA
description: The Soviet authorities sent a column of tanks and paratroopers rumbling past an all-night session of the Lithuanian Parliament early this morning, in what witnesses described as the strongest attempt yet to intimidate the republic into abandoning its declaration of independence.

title: Losing an Air War With Castro
description: What may have seemed a good idea to many Cuban exiles in Miami - beaming U.S.-made TV programs at Cuba - gives worrisome signals of turning into a turkey. Every bit as troubling, arguments over the new service have damaged morale at the already existing and highly professional Radio Marti. This is a double misfortune, and Congress needs to look at both operations.

title: Maryland Legislature Halts an Abortion Move
description: A committee of the Maryland House of Delegates voted tonight to reject a package of two bills on abortion that the State Senate passed early today after an eight-day filibuster.

title: Running Up the Credentials
description: With a string of impressive performances in track, road racing and cross-country in the last 10 weeks, Lynn Jennings, a Yankee individualist who loves to train alone, has emerged as the leading female distance runner in the United States.

title: Food Delivery Test By General Mills
description: General Mills Inc. has begun an experimental business delivering casual food like chicken wings, roast chicken and sandwiches to customers ordering by telephone. Called Bringer's, the service is provided to people who live in southwest Minneapolis and parts of suburban Edina, Richfield and Bloomington.

title: Valdez Captain Told to Join Oil Cleanup
description: The judge in the trial of Joseph J. Hazelwood sentenced him today to serve 1,000 hours of community service cleaning the beaches fouled when the Exxon Valdez ran aground a year ago Saturday while under his command.

title: Dow Up Slightly for Day, but Falls in Week
description: Stocks rose slightly yesterday after the rebound in Tokyo, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 8.56 points, to 2,704.28, in slow trading.

title: U.N.L.V. Repels Ball State Rally, 69-67
description: Ball State came within several seconds and one shot of upsetting the University of Nevada-Las Vegas tonight in the semifinal round of the West Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum.

title: Umpires Refusing to Work Spring Games
description: Miffed at not having a say in the revised regular-season schedule, major league umpires said today that they would protest by not working spring training games.

title: For Sunday Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Patriots Sign 6 in Plan B
description: The New England Patriots signed six Plan B free agents yesterday, including three former Giants: the running back George Adams, the tight end Zeke Mowatt and the offensive tackle Damian Johnson. The team also added the center Bob White, formerly of Dallas, and the linebackers Richard Harvey from Buffalo and Richard Tardits from Phoenix. The Patriots also announced that the quarterback Doug Flutie would not be offered a contract. (AP)

title: Saving Unit Seizure Is Allowed
description: On Wednesday, Federal District Judge Royce C. Lamberth agreed and issued a preliminary injunction blocking the takeover.

title: Fed Nominee Backs Policy On Inflation
description: David W. Mullins Jr., the Bush Administration's first nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, testified today that he supports the central bank's current strategy of fighting inflation by keeping interest rates high.

title: Probert Returns
description: After a 13-month absence from the National Hockey League because of involvement with cocaine, Bob Probert resumed play with the Detroit Red Wings on Thursday night against the Minnesota North Stars and had Detroit's only goal in a 5-1 loss.

title: Grady and Hempstead Reach Final
description: The game for New York City scholastic bragging rights was played 200 miles upstate at the Civic Center tonight in one semifinal of the New York State Federation of Secondary Schools Athletic Associations Class A tournament.

title: INSIDE
description: Valdez Skipper Sentenced To 1,000 Hours of Cleanup

title: Unlikeliest of Friends Find Learning a Joy
description: There are 1,300 students at Public School 94 in the northern Bronx, but it is impossible to miss Richard Segarra. At age 12, he is a husky 5 feet 10 inches tall, bigger than most of the teachers, a sixth grader with the proportions of the high-school linebacker he hopes to be.

title: Review/Opera;   New 'Don Giovanni,' From Zeffirelli
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Don Giovanni,'' its first staging of Mozart's Olympian tragicomedy since the celebrated Eugene Berman production more than 30 years ago, is beautiful to look at. That can come as no surprise: the director and set designer is Franco Zeffirelli, who always brings to opera a painter's vivid sensitivity to colors and an obsessive need to splash his ideas on large canvases. It can be said without hesitation that this ''Don Giovanni,'' which had its premiere on Thursday evening, will look opulent enough for the most extravagant tastes. With slightly more caution, one would add that this staging is a rarity among the director's recent work in not seriously misrepresenting the score.

title: Upheaval in the East;   U.S. Is Alarmed as Kremlin Steps Up Troop Movements
description: United States officials anxiously monitored signs of abnormally high Soviet military activity in Lithuania late tonight amid mounting concerns in the Administration that the Kremlin may be contemplating harsh action against the secessionist movement there.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Hard Labor on the Plantation, Updated
description: As black workers cut sugar cane in the 1940's, a narrator notes that these happy laborers are following the ''hereditary urge to go back to the plantation.'' That archival clip, included in Stephanie Black's ''H-2 Worker,'' suggests how little the plantation mentality has changed in nearly 50 years, though today the sugar-cane growers rely on Jamaicans imported to Florida for six months every year.

title: Mountain of Nuclear Waste Splits St. Louis and Suburbs 888>
description: Nearly half a century after a company here began processing fuel for nuclear weapons, St. Louis and several western suburbs are battling over a new disposal plan for millions of cubic yards of dirt contaminated with uranium, thorium, radium, actinium and other radioactive elements that are polluting the water, soil and air.

title: Former Keating Lobbyist Got No-Bid U.S. Contract
description: A lawyer who in 1988 pressed regulators to refrain from seizing a failing savings and loan was given a $49,000 no-bid consulting contract last year to advise a Federal agency involved in the bailout of the savings industry.

title: U.S. Resists Japan Plea To Aid Yen
description: Japan asked the United States today for help in checking the fall of the yen, but the United States went along only part way, arguing that the reasons for the yen's weakness are largely Japanese and that there is little Washington can do.

title: Statehood for Capital Opposed by President
description: President Bush said today that he opposed statehood for the District of Columbia, the subject of renewed debate in this troubled, heavily Democratic city.

title: Pickens Adding To Koito Stake
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman and corporate raider, will raise his stake in the Koito Manufacturing Company, a Japanese auto-parts maker, to 30 percent from 26.4 percent, a lawyer for Mr. Pickens said today.

title: Bridge
description: Teams headed by Dan Morse of Houston and Zia Mahmood of Manhattan clashed in the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here today. After 16 deals of a scheduled 64, Morse led Zia by 29 imps.

title: Upheaval in the East;   A Soft-Liner Struggles In Hungary's Hustings
description: A year ago, Imre Pozsgay was a major force for change within Hungary's ruling Communist Party. Five months ago, he was considered a sure bet to be President.

title: As Scores Drop, Schools Look for Lessons
description: At Public School 153 in Co-op City in the Bronx, there was the delicious feeling last year that they had beaten the odds. Test scores showed that almost 95 percent of the students read at grade level or above, raising the school's rank to 9th from 328th among the city's 616 elementary schools.

title: Patents;   Synthetic Bag Starts A Bagpipe Dispute
description: W. L. Gore & Associates Inc. is making angry noises about bagpipes. The Newark, Del., company makes Gore-Tex, the breathable, waterproof fabric, and last year patented a synthetic bag to replace the traditional animal skins used on Scottish bagpipes.

title: Canadian Invents Dialogue For Her Historical Figures
description: The Whirlpool

title: KEY RATES
School Safety and the Social Contract
description: Does a society that compels students to attend school have a duty to insure their safe arrival and departure? Absolutely. But New York City is not doing its duty. Violence by youths against schoolmates, and against any adults who get in the way, is an increasing phenomenon.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp., Pittsburgh, said it had increased its stake in Midway Airlines Inc., Chicago, to 12.4 percent, or 1.2 million common shares.

title: Give Iran Credit for the Strides It Has Taken
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. ;

title: New Opera By Bolcom Is Postponed
description: A work by the composer William Bolcom that was to have had its New York premiere this summer at the Mostly Mozart Festival has been postponed because of scheduling difficulties, a spokesman for Lincoln Center said.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Automobile Loans
description: If you are trying to finance a new automobile with a five-year loan, you may find it more difficult to get one these days. Banks, finance companies and other lenders are trying to discourage such long-term financing in many ways, including offering fewer of those loans to car buyers, charging higher interest rates and tightening the eligibility standards for applicants.

title: Vincent Tends to Healing Process
description: Four days after baseball ended its 32-day lockout of spring training camps, Commissioner Fay Vincent appeared in the dugout of the Mets' camp today, sat on the bench wearing a white sun visor, watched batting practice and said: ''I'm here to watch and to heal.''

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE IN COMPUTER PACT
description: The United States and Japan said today that they had reached preliminary agreement on measures that would significantly open the Japanese market to the most powerful American-made computers.

title: DEMOCRATS WARM TO MOYNIHAN PLAN
description: The top leaders of the Democratic National Committee, led by the party's chairman, Ronald H. Brown, today strongly endorsed a plan to cut Social Security taxes, despite opposition among the Democratic leadership in Congress.

title: With Bulbs, Light and Price Are the Key Considerations
description: Consumers who think they can spot the bargains and the pitfalls in the supermarket aisles should pay close attention in the light bulb section, a part of the store where choices are multiplying, where common terms don't mean what people think they do, and the important measure, light, is almost always overlooked.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: A Federal judge in New Orleans has ordered the Rev. DANIEL BERRIGAN to pay a $500 fine for contempt of court by Monday. Mr. Berrigan, a Jesuit priest, was 1 of 24 people who were either convicted of, or pleaded guilty to, charges of blocking an elevator in a Federal building. They were arrested on Dec.

title: Most of Xerox's Suit Against Apple Barred
description: A Federal judge today dismissed almost all the closely watched copyright lawsuit filed by the Xerox Corporation against Apple Computer Inc.

title: Dinkins Picks His Ambassadors to 3 Ethnic Groups
description: Calling them ''my eyes and ears in their communities,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday appointed directors of three ''constituency offices'' - for Latino Affairs, African-American and Caribbean Affairs, and European-American Affairs.

title: Mr. Bush's 'Big Tent' for Art
description: That he has a passion for country-and-Western music is all that most Americans know about President Bush's esthetic leanings. This week, however, they found out something more, and better. In opposing Senator Jesse Helms's proposals to hamstring the National Endowment for the Arts, Mr. Bush proved himself to be a friend to all artists.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional;   Arkansas and Texas in Showdown
description: Buckle your seatbelts on Saturday afternoon for an exhilarating example of what everyone here is calling the new wave of college basketball, a style that's high on freewheeling shots and low on patience, offering pressure defense for 40 minutes, and a thrill a second.

title: Patents;   Insecticides That Are Safe For Humans
description: Researchers at a California company won two patents this week involving insecticides derived from bacteria that they said do not harm humans.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: True to form, RICHARD PRYOR has already decided to turn his heart attack into comic material, his agent said. The comedian was in stable condition yesterday at Wesley Hospital in Brisbane, Australia, where he was taken on Tuesday after a heart attack that doctors described as minor.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: East Regional;   Anatomy of a Miracle: How the Huskies Won
description: Alaa Abdelnaby, a senior on the basketball team at Duke University, was waiting in his team's dressing room at Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Thursday night when he heard a frightening sound that made him think something terrible had happened outside.

title: Peace Movement Hasn't Run Out of Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware Mixing Different Issues
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
Andover Journal;

Small Borough's Quiet Life to Face 590-House Development
description: LEAD: THIS village of 915 residents does not need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows. When it comes from one direction, it smells like cow manure, and when it comes from the opposite direction, the air thickens with the smell of chocolate from a nearby M & M/Mars factory.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 25, 1990
Helter-Skelter Growth? No, a Worthy Plan
description: CITIZENS in New Jersey know what unplanned growth will bring: a blighted environment, gridlock in farm country, cities in deeper decay, communities that have lost their sense of place.

title: A Sculptor in Wood Joins Two Painters for Blue Hill Show
description: AT the Blue Hill Cultural Center here, it is spring. The Canada geese, without which no such center is complete, are stomping around the lake and the equally predictable Henry Moore bronze figure, a splash of verdigris in a taupe landscape, seems ready to join them.

title: Eyes to Left, Democrats Edge Toward the Center
description: Two very different political visions collided here today: A group of centrist Democrats asserted that the national party must change to reclaim the support of middle-class voters, while the Rev. Jesse Jackson asserted that the American mainstream was moving toward him.

title: Review/Music;   Prize-Winning Pianists In Consecutive Recitals
description: When a piano competition offers its winner an Alice Tully Hall recital and when the first prize is shared, what is the equitable solution? Simple multiplication, according to the Palm Beach Invitational International Piano Competition - two winners, two full recitals, back to back on a single evening.

title: LITHUANIAN AIDES WON'T TURN OVER ARMY'S DESERTERS
description: Lithuanian officials refused today to comply with Moscow's demand to turn over hundreds of army deserters, declaring that they would not be intimidated by the Kremlin's theatrical early morning parade of tanks and military vehicles here in the Lithuanian capital.

title: Lawrence Challenges State on Expressway
description: LEAD: TAKING a page from the Village of Westbury's book, the community of Lawrence has hired a lawyer to investigate the state's environmental-impact survey of the newly completed Nassau Expressway, a major highway running through the small village of 6,000 people.

title: Managing;   When the Boss Wears a Hula Skirt
description: Dave Holmes realized that the meeting was turning into a disaster. After three uplifting days, the top worldwide managers in Du Pont's wire and cable unit had suddenly become defeatist and morose.

title: India, Stymied, Pulls Last Troops From Sri Lanka
description: India withdrew the last of its troops from Sri Lanka today, ending an ill-fated three-year involvement in the island's ethnic strife.

title: When It Counts, Kohl Shows, He Cannot Be Counted Out
description: CHANCELLOR HELMUT KOHL customarily reaches his maximum heft at this time of year, just before his annual Eastertime course of weight reduction. A year ago, with public opinion polls tracking a precipitous plunge, the bulk seemed to be political dead weight. This year it looks like pure gold: Mr. Kohl stands at the peak of his career, and if things keep going his way, by this time next year he could be the first chancellor of a reunited Germany.

title: Film Career Born From a Sense of Loss
description: LEAD: JON AVNET and his latest cinematic production, ''Men Don't Leave,'' share some similarities: both can be funny, poignant, offbeat and affectingly imperfect.

title: Former Car Saleswoman Peddles Romance to 'Workaholics'
description: AS today's fast-track couples scramble to keep on top of their jobs and raise the children, there is little time left for anything else, least of all romance. So believes Candice Barnett-Foti, who is building her business by trying to make every day Valentine's Day.

title: Review/Dance;   Observations on Life's Abrasiveness
description: No one could accuse Donald Byrd of timidity. From the start of his choreographic career in the mid-1970's, Mr. Byrd has taken on complex issues including prejudice, the effects of negative reviews on artists, the AIDS crisis and life seen as an evening in a disco. His choreographic voice - and electric presence - are both velvety and intensely abrasive. And those facets of Mr. Byrd were much in evidence on March 16, when Donald Byrd/The Group presented three dances at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Seles Wins Lipton With Ease
description: The Lipton's new and youngest champion, Monica Seles, still 16 and sprouting fast, had quieted her renegade giggle and erupted in less triumphant grunts in the year that passed since she captured her first and only championship at Houston.

title: On Environment And Convenience
description: This is in response to Dan Harrison's attack on County Legislator Paul Feiner's introduction of legislation to ban styrofoam food containers in Westchester [Letters to the Westchester Editor, Feb. 18] .

title: Troubling Doubles in 'Jekyll and Hyde'
description: WATCH out for a spate of ''Jekyll and Hydes.'' No fewer than three musical adaptations of the 1886 Robert Louis Stevenson classic are going around. Another, a Ridiculous Theatrical Company production, which is in a class by itself and may be the most sensible approach of all, has just closed in New York. Then there's ''Mary Reilly,'' a recently published retelling of the Stevenson book written from the perspective of a maid in Dr. Jekyll's employ.

title: Dr. Priscilla Meyers to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur V. Myers of Richmond have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Priscilla Claire Myers and Dr. Michael Anthony Rossetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Rossetti of New York. Dr. Myers, 28 years old, is a dentist, as is her fiance, 27. Both are graduates of the Medical College of Virginia. Dr. Myers, who graduated from Bucknell University, plans to practice in Greenwich, Conn. Dr. Rossetti, a graduate of the University of Richmond, has a practice in Stamford, Conn.

title: The Menu Puts On Its Spring Garb
description: THE weather has felt like spring on and off for weeks but now it's official. And like the wardrobe and the garden, it's time for the menu to change Springtime calls for asparagus, artichokes, shad, soft-shell crabs, your own newly created salads, new potatoes, fresh herbs, scallions and light soups, stews and pasta dishes. Strawberries should begin to highlight the desserts. Given an unlimited budget, fresh morels can soon be added to the list.

title: Visitors to Vilnius Glimpse Their Parents' Past
description: When the lights flickered out in President Vytautas Landsbergis's office one evening this week, Carla Gruodis feared Moscow was at work again, turning up the psychological pressure on the Lithuanian President and his rebellious Government.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The ''Your Own Account'' column on March 11, discussing loans against 401 (k) plans, misstated the tax deductibility of interest on such loans in 1990. No interest deduction is allowed for 401 (k) loans secured by employee pre-tax contributions.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Charles H. Keating is scheduled to testify at a United States District Court hearing in Washington on the Government takeoveof Lincoln Savings.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LINCOLN, MASS.;

Subsidies Aid 'Farm Village'
description: LEAD: HELPED by a state program of low-cost mortgages and a local subsidy on land costs, a condominium complex designed to resemble a 19th century farm village is taking shape in this suburb 20 minutes west of Boston.

title: Holman in Hall
description: He has won 21 Professional Bowling Association championships, not to mention more money, $1.4 million, than any other P.B.A. bowler, so it should come as no surprise that Marshall Holman has been elected to the P.B.A's Hall of Fame in Akron, Ohio.

title:
FOCUS;

Linking Development to High-Speed Rail Systems
description: LEAD: A consortium of nine firms formed by a leading engineering and consulting company is trying to attract capital and real estate development to help build a $2 billion privately owned high-speed rail system linking major Ohio cities.

title: Review/Music;   Argentine Rock Star Makes New York Debut
description: Lanky and bespectacled, his hair falling in his eyes and with a scraggly mustache, Charly Garcia looks more like a distracted graduate student than a rock star. But in Argentina, he has been a major figure in rock for nearly two decades as a member of two leading groups, Sui Generis and Seru Giran, and as a band leader since 1982. His New York debut last Sunday night at the Ritz drew 1,500 fans who shouted along on every familiar song.

title: Gorbachev Picks a New Cabinet: Old Allies and a Few Hard-Liners
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has named his first Cabinet, balancing the choice of some of his closest partners in change with two figures who have been openly hostile to aspects of his program, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PERCY AND THE FIVE HOUSES

title: The C.I.A. And the Drug War: A special report:   C.I.A. Shedding Its Reluctance To Aid in Fight Against Drugs
description: Criticized for years by some senior Government officials for not taking a more active role in the war on drugs, the Central Intelligence Agency seems to have abandoned its former reluctance.

title: New Piece Added To Puzzle on Perez
description: On the fifth day of a gentle spring, with the Yankees working under a warm sun and George Steinbrenner observing from the dugout, the mystery of the missing pitcher took another strange twist.

title: Fashion;   Just the Thing for Dazzling Everyone on the Avenue
description: Come Easter, three weeks hence, some people will stick bunny ears through holes cut in their straw hats and take a stroll down Fifth Avenue. Others will place things like stuffed chickadees, wooden soldiers, origami tulips and dried fruit on their hats, as they take part in the annual procession past St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: HISTORY IS FALSE BUT THIS IS TRUE
description: CHEKHOV'S SISTER

title: Suspect Is Held in $20 Million Book Thefts
description: A middle-aged man with a long history of psychiatric problems and arrests for theft has been charged with possession of $20 million worth of stolen rare books.

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: All college athletes in revenue-producing sports should be paid. To ease the burden on smaller, less affluent programs, the N.C.A.A. should set aside money from all tournament revenue and provide participants their shares. All athletes would be paid equally, using minimum wage as a guideline, just as if their extracurricular activity were a part-time campus job. The N.C.A.A. should allocate a maximum number of hours per year per sport so that there is no way to abuse this player allowance with inflated practice hours or lengthened schedules. This would be an equitable way for the dedicated athlete to remain amateur yet be able to enjoy life on campus without undue financial burden.

title: HER SISTERS, HERSELF
description: THE CLONING OF JOANNA MAY

title: Schools' Responsibility For Low Self-Esteem
description: While I am reluctant to sound a dissonant note about the schools' attempt to build self-esteem, I feel compelled to write to speak negatively about a Band-Aid approach to children's emotional well-being.

title: Black Hopes in the U.S. and South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina to Extradite Ex-SS Man
description: The Argentine Supreme Court has rejected all appeals and ordered that Josef Schwammberger, an accused Nazi war criminal, be extradited to West Germany. Mr. Schwammberger was arrested more than two years ago on a ranch in Cordoba province.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 25, 1990

LEAD:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving. We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood. We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves. Can you offer some pointers?

title: Freud, Though a Genius, Was Also Human
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   Works Large and Small By Cunningham Troupe
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company offered two big works and a little one on Wednesday night at the City Center Theater (131 West 55th Street). Fifteen dancers swept across the stage in a repeat performance of Mr. Cunningham's recent ''Inventions.'' And 14 human figures were on view in this season's first performance of ''Field and Figures.''

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: College athletes are already paid. They live in preferred accommodations called athletic dorms. They eat at special restaurants called training tables. They get weekend trips - staying at five-star hotels, when motels are available to provide the same basic services. They are provided with great seats at all their games, tickets that are often scalped. The only thing they don't get is a 1099 form each January.

title: ABOVE ALL, SHE HATED DIRT
description: EVER YOURS, FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE

title: NONFICTION
description: GREAT PLAINS PATCHWORK: A Memoir. By Marilyn Coffey. (Iowa State University, $21.95.) The novelist Marilyn Coffey has put together an entertaining, insightful collection of stories, combining fact and legend, about her beloved central plains between the mid-1880's and the late 1950's. ''Like a speck on the eastern horizon appears a wagon loaded with Coffeys,'' who in 1885 migrated west to the Great Plains from Illinois. There were 10 of them - great-grandfather James, his wife, Mary, their seven sons and a daughter. The Coffey boys were a raucous bunch who liked a good joke, usually physical, and would try anything once - great-uncle Ben even entered a ''bear-wrassling'' contest and won. Stories of the family are integrated with graphic firsthand descriptions by survivors of the natural disasters that periodically struck the Plains - floods, grasshopper infestations, tornadoes, man-made mischief on a grand scale. Ms. Coffey offers insights on what it is to grow up in Middle America. It ''gives one a different perspective on history than the typical Easterner has, an inside-out view.'' As a child, she ''never doubted for an instant'' that she ''was dead center in the middle of everything . . . a world narrowed by dust storms, bread lines, and Al Capone.''

title: Enforcement of Guam Abortion Law Is Barred
description: A Federal district judge here has temporarily blocked enforcement of a new Guam law that is the most restrictive abortion statute in any American jurisdiction.

title: Reflections On a Cold Place
description: YOU'RE GOING TO SEE some changes on the ice,'' a construction engineer told me as we changed into polar garb for the flight from New Zealand to Antarctica. ''Whatever you do, don't get caught throwing away a cigarette butt or beer can.''

title: CAPITALISM'S CHANCES: A U.S. Expert's View;   Prognosis for Soviet Economy Is Grave, but Improving
description: LAST week Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed a tantalizing peek at how he intends to use his new powers as President to push through radical economic changes. Nikolai Petrakov, Mr. Gorbachev's new personal adviser on economics, broke the news in a rather matter-of-fact interview with a Soviet press agency in which he likened the new reform to Poland's cold-turkey plunge into a market economy.

title: Elliott S. M. Gatner, Educator, 75
description: Elliott S. M. Gatner, who retired in 1981 from Long Island University after helping to shape that institution in a 45-year career as a history professor, librarian and administrator, died of lung cancer on Friday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Bellerose, Queens.

title: Washington and Tokyo Reducing Trade Tensions
description: The United States and Japan have begun to defuse the trade tensions threatening to destroy their global partnership.

title: SURVIVING HISTORY
description: I DISCOVERED NATALIA Ginzburg in 1971. I was in Florence; my friend and I, having just graduated from college, were doing the contemporary version of the grand tour: a trip around Europe carrying backpacks, hitchhiking, staying in cheap pensiones. I decided that I should buy an Italian book; I went into a bookstore and my eye fell on Natalia Ginzburg's Le piccole virtu. I don't know why that was the book I decided to buy; there were other Italian writers I knew and had read. Perhaps it was her name - suggesting ethnic complications. Perhaps it was the title - ''The Little Virtues'' - which appealed to me as a new way of looking at the moral life. Perhaps it was the fact that it was by a woman - Ginzburg may have been the only woman writer whose books were in the bookstore - and in 1971, a fledgling writer myself and a feminist enthusiastic at the birth of the new movement, I was eager for connections with writers of my own sex.

title: Pastimes: Gardening;   A Shady Nook Flourishes, If Planned
description: When people say they have too little sun to grow flowers, I like to show them a tiny ''garden room'' by the northeast corner of my house in Princeton, N. J. It is nine-feet by nine and one-half feet, shaded, and filled with wonderful blossoms.

title: QUIXOTIC IN HIS OWN RIGHT
description: CERVANTES

title: Victorious Finale For Grady
description: William E. Grady High School of Brooklyn completed its finest basketball season ever tonight by winning the New York State Federation Class A championship with a 78-67 victory over Hempstead of Long Island before a crowd of 3,292 at the Civic Center here.

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: As I sit here writing my check to pay another installment of my student loan, my heart bleeds for today's student athletes. Having their dorm rooms, tuition and books paid for isn't enough. The universities now need to pay them some spending money on the side.

title: From a Highway 'Hi!' To a Grunt, and Worse
description: A postscript to driving along the highways of New Jersey (Letters, Feb. 28):

title: Cuomo, to Close Budget Gap, Urges Increase in Alcohol Tax
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who spent much of the last week dribbling out proposals for new taxes to close a potential $1.5 billion budget gap, focused on a new target today: alcohol.

title: Tennis in Italy
description: To the Editor: What you told F. W. B. of Boseman, Mont., about finding tennis courts in Italy (Q & A, March 11) was all well and good; tennis clubs are listed in the telephone directory. But there is another, quite simple way to find out if a hotel or resort has a tennis court: look for the symbol (crossed tennis racquets) in the Michelin red guide to Italy.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Phoebe Neville Plays With Fire, Literally
description: Phoebe Neville often suggests an oracular priestess in her dances, and when she literally plays with fire by tossing a fireball from one gloved hand to another in her solo ''Memory,'' she again seems to possess a magic power.

title: Congratulations Are Not Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: May Wedding Plans For Kimberly Rosso
description: May wedding plans for Kimberly Michelle Rosso and Michael Peter Morovich, a son of Ann Morovich of Far Rockaway, Queens, and the late John Morovich, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Rosso of Manhasset, L.I.

title: Scott Moger Wed To Patricia Crews
description: Patricia Crews and Scott Moger were married last evening by Rabbi Phillip A. Labowitz at the Brazilian Court Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Zagor of New York and Norwich, Vt. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Moger of Sunrise, Fla.

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: Yes, pay college basketball players! Rename Division I the N.C.A.B.A. (with B for basketball) and continue the championship format as it exists now, recognizing it for what it truly is: a revenue-producing business with paid athletes whose primary interest is athletics, who are representing the college during their contracted four-year tenure.

title: AIDS Deaths Near Another Awful Record
description: AIDS is fast becoming the worst epidemic of the century in New York City. The disease has already claimed the lives of more than 16,000 men, women and children, and health officials suspect the actual number is higher than medical records show.

title: Plus Ca Change . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Evening Hours;   The Guests Sang For Their Supper
description: Franco Zeffirelli's production of ''Don Giovanni'' made its debut on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera, the 13th new production underwritten by Sybil Harrington, the Texas philanthropist. Carroll and Milton Petrie gave the opening-night party, and the guests applauded the principals as they arrived at the champagne supper.

title:
FOCUS: High-Speed Rail Systems;

Development to Help Pay for Mass Transit
description: LEAD: A consortium of nine firms formed by a leading engineering and consulting company is trying to attract capital and real estate development to help build a $2 billion privately owned high-speed rail system linking major Ohio cities.

title: Evening Hours;   More Black Business Executives Are Plugging Into the Charity-Gala Circuit
description: The stars of black charity galas now come not only from the worlds of sports, entertainment and politics. Increasingly black corporate executives, entrepreneurs and heads of minority-owned businesses are turning heads in the ballrooms where elegantly dressed couples dine and dance for causes.

title: Fashion;   Easter Isn't Just for the Bunny Rabbit
description: Tradition holds sway again on the bunny trail, with ruffles and lace for girls and nautical themes for boys this Easter, perhaps because the holiday offers a rare chance to get the children into dress-up clothes.

title: Japanese Rice in Its Many Guises
description: A DARKLY gleaming lidded lacquer bowl is set before the diner. He (or she) mumbles ''Itadakimasu'' (I receive), lifts the lid and sets it aside. The glossy white grains carefully mounded within give off a sweet fragrance. Chopsticks are raised and plunged into the steaming rice. The meal begins.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving. We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood. We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves. Can you offer some pointers?

title: Seeking Unity, Pace Awaits New President
description: PACE UNIVERSITY has reached to Chicago for a new president to help focus the identity of an increasingly comprehensive and complex educational system as it prepares for a new century.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving. We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood. We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves. Can you offer some pointers?

title: The Executive Computer;   Listen Closely: Your Files May Be Talking to You
description: A document can convey intelligence, but until recently it lacked intelligence of its own. This newspaper, for example, cannot write itself, deliver itself to subscribers, or tailor its contents automatically to the interests and reading level of a particular subscriber.

title: Unnatural Habitat
description: THE GOOD NEWS IS THAT EPIDENDRUM ilense (above), a rare orchid native to Ecuador, is being propagated in cultivation to the degree that it is available to collectors. The bad news is that ilense has almost certainly disappeared from its natural habitat, a casualty of the dwindling rain forest.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Hotels in SoHo;   Lodgings for Tourists and the Innovative Art World
description: AS unlikely as they may sound in the loft district that was once called Hell's Hundred Acres, and as unwelcome as they may be in the eyes of some neighbors, a couple of hotels may soon be under way in the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District, with several more to follow.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: There can be little doubt that bridge is the ideal game for those with physical handicaps. The tournament world readily adapts to accommodate them.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   New York City's Losses, Fairfield's Gains
description: A SURGE of leasing activity in Fairfield County, particularly by companies moving out of New York City, is turning Fairfield commercial realtors here bullish for the first time in almost three years.

title: New Chef Arrives at Beijing in Stamford
description: THE names may change in the restaurant business, but often the premises, the ownership and sometimes even the type of cuisine remain the same. That is largely the case with the new Beijing restaurant in downtown Stamford, whose previous name was Ching Ching. The cream-colored walls, dark wainscoting and seating arrangements are familiar and seemingly changeless.

title: Miss Dalton Wed To J. E. Bloomer
description: St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary Frances Dalton, a daughter of Mrs. James Joseph Dalton of Seattle and the late Mr. Dalton, to Jeremy Eardley Bloomer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Eardley Bloomer of Oley, Pa. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: Felix Salmaggi, 77; Impresario Produced Operas in Brooklyn
description: Felix W. Salmaggi, an opera impresario and theater manager, died of cancer on Monday at the Hospice of Northern Virginia in Arlington, Va. He was 77 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: You Have 43 Minutes. Now Tell Us All About Your Household.
description: Only at the very end, and in excruciatingly small type is there an acknowledgment of the persnicketiness of the dirty big job.

title: Pretoria Starts Looking at School Integration
description: The Government of President F. W. de Klerk is considering changes in South Africa's segregated system of education that could open the way for black children to start attending some white public schools next year.

title: JUNGLE IS WINNING THE COCAINE WAR
description: The battle in the jungle is doomed from the outset as again the Bush Administration -- like its predessors -- ignores a basic tenet of economics: if there is no demand, there will be no need for supply (''In the Cocaine War, the Jungle Is Winning,'' by Michael Massing, March 4). The produce of the jungles in South America is feeding what the article refers to as ''the nation's immense, insatiable habit.'' Drug traffickers are engaged in bringing their product to a busy marketplace.

title: Trade Tensions Ease
description: The United States and Japan are making headway on trade disputes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

What Real Moms Are Made Of
description: LEAD: VALENTINE'S DAY left me exhausted and resentful. I was asked to contribute to the Valentine's Day party at my son's preschool by making red Jell-O in a foil-lined cake pan. New ways to prepare Jell-O have never been part of my repertory, but I persevered.

title: As U.S. and Soviet Hostility Ebbs, Missiles Are Matched in Museums
description: In a project intended to symbolize the winding down of the cold war, nuclear missiles of the kind that the Russians and the Americans have aimed at each other will soon be placed side by side in museums in Washington and Moscow.

title: Margaret Harkin Married
description: Margaret M. Harkin and Joseph P. Richardson were married yesterday at St. Aedan's Roman Catholic Church in Pearl River, N.Y., by the Rev. Albert Polt. Mrs. Richardson, 23 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Harkin of New City, N.Y. A graduate of Fordham University, she is an officer in consumer banking at the Chemical Banking Corporation in New York. The bridegroom, 24, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Richardson of Pearl River. He is a graduate of the State University of New York at Plattsburgh and an assistant account executive at the Geltzer & Company public relations concern in New York.

title: State Grant to Finance Restoration of Wetlands
description: LEAD: THE State Department of Environmental Conservation has awarded Larchmont and the town of Mamaroneck a $618,965 grant for the restoration of the 64-acre Premium River-Pine Brook wetlands complex on the edge of Long Island Sound. The site is on the border of Larchmont, New Rochelle and the town of Mamaroneck.

title: Now, Slyly, Comes The Yuppie Devil
description: When Mephistopheles shows up wearing a gold Rolex he's truly a creature for our age. Meet the yuppie devil: relaxed, assured, the very model of casual elegance even if he has no visible means of support. He loves risks, particularly if they're being taken by others. He loves comfort, especially comfort of the high-tech, high-gloss kind. He would be indistinguishable from any other fashionably louche high roller were it not for his more or less selfless interest in the affairs of others. Like any self-respecting devil, he enjoys watching others go wrong. Seducing his prey, however, is a very different game compared with what it used to be. It was once easy enough to further the cause of corruption simply by playing upon the avarice of potential victims. But today's target could be too well- heeled to care about financial temptation. If anything, the reverse may even be true: today's bright-eyed young corporate type may already have been showered with more material success than he knows what to do with. In this case, the job of the yuppie devil is to take it away.

title: Crusader for Affordable Housing
description: LEAD: Robert B. O'Brien Jr., a crusader for affordable housing for 30 years, said he learned as a boy growing up in Summit in a family of bankers that history did not just occur. It is financed.

title: Bonnie Raitt Captures the Heart of Her Generation
description: One of the biggest attractions of the pop music world is following the spins of its wheel of fortune and watching where the golden arrow comes to rest. Each month brings a surprise or two, but when a deserving artist like Bonnie Raitt is suddenly, unexpectedly rewarded, one's fascination in the whole hit-making process becomes rekindled.

title:
DINING OUT;

Korean Fare, Authentic and Tantalizing
description: LEAD: FROM sushi bars to Sichuan storefronts, Asian dining spots are fairly common throughout New Jersey.
