But until recently, Korea's bracing cuisine, which combines elements of Japanese (with fortifying noodle soups and teriyaki-like grills) and Chinese (with stir-fried dishes and hot pots) and the zest of Thailand, has been poorly represented.

title: CANON CONFIDENTIAL: A SAM SLADE CAPER
description: Her name was Estelle. I should have known the broad spelled trouble when she came into my office and started talking about the canon. The literary canon.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Yugoslavia Police Deployed to Quiet Unrest
description: The Government sent soldiers across the province of Kosovo today to restore order after renewed unrest touched off by a mysterious illness affecting hundreds of ethnic Albanians.

title: As Highways Crumble, Bush Stumbles
description: The Bush Administration has once again spoken out of both sides of its mouth: first, amid much fanfare, it declares that fixing the country's transportation system is in the national interest; then it turns around and sticks the states and localities with the bill.

title: 27 Injured at Airport in Tokyo
description: Twenty-seven people were injured today in an evacuation of a Cathay Pacific Airways jet from Hong Kong with 300 passengers that began leaking fuel after landing at Narita airport here, officials said. Strong winds rocked the inflatable escape chutes, knocking the passengers down, officials said. All but one of the injured were released later today after treatment. The TriStar jet, made by the Lockheed Corporation, began leaking large amounts of fuel.

title: Quayle Backs Moscow on Army Deserters
description: The Soviet Union is entitled to pursue deserters from its army but should not act against the independence movement in Lithuania, Vice President Dan Quayle said today.

title: Governor Urges Great Leap and Volunteers to Go First
description: THE Governor of New Jersey has come came up with an alternative to tiptoeing around tax increases: jump in with both feet, to the tune of $2 billion; and while you're at it, overhaul the tax system, wipe out a $580 million deficit and redistribute wealth all at the same time.

title: Back in Spring's Pocket: Play Ball!
description: Out of the corner of my eye, I catch the morning's headline: ''Baseball Settles Contract.''

title:
FORUM;

In Defense of Program Trading
description: LEAD: Once again, program trading is in the spotlight. It seems that every time the market experiences a significant drop - as it recently did in Tokyo - or loses the confidence of the investor, it is attributed to program trading. No hard facts are presented, no detailed studies are cited, just blunt claims and emotional outcries.

title: Currency;   More of the Usual Ups and Downs
description: The dollar is still going in two directions these days, continuing to strengthen against the yen while weakening against the German mark. The victory of a coalition of conservative parties in the East German elections last Sunday added pressure to the drive to unify the Germanys, and that in turn helped push the mark up against the dollar. Meanwhile, the yen continued to fall, even though the Bank of Japan raised the official discount rate by a full percentage point, to 5 1/4 percent. The higher rate, which helped to spark a major stock selloff in Tokyo, was viewed as too little, too late by traders. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto are meeting this weekend to discuss the exchange-rate situation. $ Last Previous Year Week Week Ago Japanese Yen 154.30 152.65 131.25 per Dollar W.German Mark 1.7140 1.6985 1.8715 per Dollar Canadian Dollar 1.1755 1.1835 1.1901 per U.S. Dollar British Pound 1.6010 1.6190 1.7210 U.S. Dollar per British Pound Gold $389.10 $400.00 $392.00 Republic National Bank

title: THE CORE OF THE CONFLICT
description: PALESTINE AND ISRAEL

title: Villages and Beaches Along the Costa Verde
description: FOR most visitors to Brazil, the only glimpse of the land mass between Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo comes as a green blur from the window of an airplane, en route from one city to the other. The area is known as the Costa Verde, or Green Coast, and even from an altitude of 23,000 feet there is no mistaking why. The aquamarine sea and the emerald forests rising up from the shore are the region's two dominating features, and at ground level they become even more imposing, offering the promise of both relaxation and adventure in the form of hundreds of beaches and thousands of acres of unspoiled tropical wilderness.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Fairfield, Conn.$295,000

title: Princeton Beckons Future Engineers
description: LEAD: A DAY spent at Princeton University during its recent National Engineers Week has made Tanya Martin reconsider her career plans.

title: Rita Caviglia, Planner, to Wed
description: The engagement of Rita Caviglia to Robert White Gadsden has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Eugene John Caviglia of Montauk, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: U.S. Taking Watchful Attitude
description: The United States has made it clear to the Soviet Union that using force in Lithuania would harm Soviet-American relations but is still accepting Moscow's assurances that no such action will be taken, Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said today in an interview. Other Administration officials said there were signs of heightened Soviet military activity in the Baltic republics but no indication of an impending crackdown. They said concern about that possibility had ebbed somewhat since the most recent display of military strength by Moscow early this morning.

title: Should Instant Replay Be Used in Basketball?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Marital Split-Ups and Reunions in 'Legal Tender'
description: ARTHUR WALLACE, a smarmy divorce lawyer, is railing about the decline of the nuclear family. Forty-seven percent of the households in New York City are merged - the result of split-ups and remarriages.

title: Colorful Needlepoint That Reflects Brazil
description: LIKE much of Brazil's heritage, the tradition of Brazilian needlepoint comes from its Portuguese past. The stitches found in intricate needlepoint tapestries or rugs have been developed from the Portuguese Arraiolos stitch, named after a small town in Portugal.

title: SHE BELONGED TO SCULPTURE AND THE NIGHT
description: LOUISE NEVELSON

title: Robert A. Miller, 47, A Menswear Designer
description: Robert A. Miller, a member of the new generation of black fashion designers, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AN ISLAND In LIMBO
description: Mr. Weisman glorified Puerto Rico's independence movement and implied that this option is the only one that will leave Puerto Ricans with dignity. He has forsaken Puerto Rico's political reality. When Puerto Ricans talk of ''el pais,'' (the country), the vast majority refer to our people, not a nation-state. We are proud of our culture and heritage, however the majority of Boricuas are not nationalists and the independentistas do not have a monopoly on our culture. The United States is viewed differently in Puerto Rico than throughout the rest of Latin America. Our society, our way of life, even our language, has been Anglicized to an extent. Many Puerto Ricans view reality not with resentment but with acceptance and pride in our United States citizenship.

title: Price of Helping New York City's Poor: Bidding for Legal Aid
description: A plan to make legal aid agencies bid for the right to represent some children in Family Court has opened a dispute over the way the city hires lawyers to represent poor people.

title: Bias in Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester and Suffolk Fighting For Lyme Funds
description: IN a case of competitive shuttle diplomacy, Westchester and Suffolk County officials have been flying back and forth to Washington to plead for Federal help in fighting Lyme disease.

title: Eric Savitch Wed To Miss Brecher
description: Alison Fay Brecher and Eric Scott Savitch were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York by Rabbi Philip Graubart, assisted by Rabbi Paul Siegel and Cantor David Lefkowitz. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernd Brecher of Hartsdale, N.Y. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin R. Savitch of White Plains.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Dead Poets Society

title: Dominican General, Charged by U.S., Flees
description: A retired general in the armed forces of the Dominican Republic has jumped bond and returned to his homeland rather than face trial on charges of a bribery scheme aimed at freeing seized drug-smuggling planes, the Government says.

title: Mass Graves in East Germany
description: An East German newspaper today reported the discovery of mass graves of thousands of people, including civilians, who died at a former Soviet prison camp set up after World War II.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: East Orange $106,500

title: Miss Kamerschen Becomes a Bride
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Kathryn Ann Kamerschen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Kamerschen of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward James Streator 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Streator Jr. of London. The Revs. Terence L. Elsberry and John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

title: New E.M.S. Response Time
description: To improve response times, top officials of the Emergency Medical Service have told managers they want emergency vehicles to react to calls within seconds and personnel to spend no more than 15 minutes at scenes of emergencies, an E.M.S. official said last night.

title: Will All This Tax Talk Lead to New Taxes? (Hint: It Usually Does)
description: SUDDENLY, prominent Congressmen are proposing higher taxes and President Bush is reading their lips. Almost overnight, a Federal tax increase seems possible.

title: Alvin R. Jennings, 85, Managed 'Big 8' Firm
description: Alvin R. Jennings, a former managing partner of Coopers & Lybrand and a past president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, died of a stroke on March 14 in Miami, where he lived in retirement. He was 85 years old.

title: SANDINISTA SWIMS AGAINST THE TIDE
description: If Sandinista militants doubted the political orthodoxy of a comrade named Herty Lewites Rodriguez, they got their proof on election day. While other Sandinista candidates were crushed in the national balloting on Feb. 25, Mr. Lewites turned this tidy village into a something of an electoral miracle, leading his hometown Sandinista ticket to victory by a margin of 24 percentage points.

title: THE THORN IN GORBACHEV'S SIDE
description: AGAINST THE GRAIN

title: A Concern With Painting the Unpaintable
description: All of Gerhard Richter's work can be seen as a struggle with ideology. He has moved back and forth between abstract and figurative styles, and between small hazy photorealist still lifes and landscapes and large gestural abstractions so physical that they seem to take over their room. He has consistently tried to make art that is provocative and pleasing without advancing any one program or theory. He is one of the few artists who can raise the issue of ideology itself.

title: FIFA Goes Against Instant Replay
description: Italy's national television network, which will serve as the host broadcasting company for the 1990 World Cup finals in Italy this year, has developed what could be the ultimate officiating aid, a sophisticated replay system that simulates any conceivable camera angle and works within seconds.

title: Review/Theater;   Trying to Adapt to Inhospitable Terrain
description: ''And the Soul Shall Dance,'' Wakako Yamauchi's Depression-era drama, remembers the time when California law forbade Japanese immigrants to own their own land. Farmers who had come to the United States in search of a better life were obliged to sign two-year leases on the property they cultivated. Many families found themselves moving from farm to farm eking out a subsistence living. Their treatment as second-class citizens was profoundly demoralizing; added to the language and cultural barriers they faced, it made social and economic assimilation extremely difficult.

title: WHAT PRICE GLORY?: TOO HIGH
description: THEY SAY GOOD BURGUNDY IS hard to find these days. Maybe so. But a Burgundy-lover wandering around the wine shops in New York City recently would have had no trouble finding some really superb wines. How about a 1985 Grands-Echezeaux or a 1985 Beaune Greves or a 1986 Richebourg or a 1985 Clos de la Roche or a 1986 Le Montrachet or perhaps even a 1987 Corton-Charlemagne?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the South African press located the city of Grahamstown incorrectly. It is in Cape Province, not Natal.

title: Further Thoughts On Fur
description: I found Marlene Fanta Shyer's ''Changing Thoughts on Fur'' [Opinion, Feb. 18] to be a curious mixture of confusion, fallacy, rationalization and hypocrisy.

title: Review/Music;   Reprise of the 50's and 60's In Edmunds's Rock Revue
description: In prospect, Dave Edmunds's Rock-and-Roll Revue was a fine idea. Mr. Edmunds - a Welsh guitarist, singer and producer who is one of the most knowledgeable fans of basic rock-and-roll - would sing a few songs, then lend his band to kindred spirits: the 1950's Bronx doo-wopper Dion, the English songwriter Graham Parker and the Texas blues-soul singer Kim Wilson of the Fabulous Thunderbirds. But in practice, the nearly two-and-a-half-hour concert on March 16 at the Ritz grew dutiful and tedious, one stolid three-chord song after another.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Mandatory Recycling? No Thanks
description: LEAD: I HAVE been espousing causes for more years than I care to reveal. One of my losing passions in Darien has been housing for the moderate-income elderly, a cause that never takes root in my town. But now I can reveal that I am against a laudable cause, one that all earnest people endorse: recycling.

title: POSTINGS: New Yorker Move;   Tilley's Packing
description: The New Yorker, whose shabby, cluttered, out-at-the-elbow offices have been a constant in the midtown literary scene since 1935, finally is moving - but only 60 feet south. Now at 25 West 43d Street, Eustace Tilley will flit across to 20 West 43d and more space in November, along with 300 other employees.

title: The Complete Return on Investment
description: Behind every tract of rain forest that is cleared, every factory that is shuttered and locked and every oil-clogged beach lies an investment decision. These decisions may have paid big dividends to shareholders and other investors - they may have made certain individuals wealthier - but they also have harmed the economy, society and environment.

title: Mt. Vernon 'Magnets' Offer Students a Choice
description: LEAD: PARENTS here are being asked this month to choose among new theme-based programs for their elementary and middle school-age children, while district officials lobby Albany legislators for the $2.7 million to carry out their recently adopted magnet-school plan.

title:
The Executive Life;

Casting Success Aside For the Good Life
description: LEAD: At dawn every weekday morning, Peter Moyer feeds his daughter's pony, bundles his three children into the Jeep and drives eight miles through the valley at the base of the Teton Mountains to drop them off at school. By 8:30, he is at his desk in a bare, two-room law office across the street from the courthouse in the center of this town of about 5,000 people.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT is just after 9 A.M. on a Friday in the middle of the month. Many of the stiff plastic chairs at the Essex County welfare office on Rector Street in Newark are already filled with women and babies, grandmothers, lunch bags and, here and there, a few men. Phones ring and ring unanswered, and from behind the long counter a woman calls for the next client.

title: E.P.A.'s Objections Give Hope to Critics Of Planned Pipeline
description: FROM its beginning almost four years ago, the story of the Iroquois pipeline has not been pleasant. In meeting after meeting with residents of the towns along its proposed route, the company planning it has encountered a loud and long barrage of verbal and legal opposition. Nevertheless, the project's propects became stronger.

title: Searching for Quality Medical Care
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Only Connect

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 18 about skiing in Switzerland referred incorrectly to Zermatt. As a reader has recently written to point out, Zermatt indeed has snow-making machines, at the Rothorn-Blauherd-Sunnegga area and the Theodul section.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Realist Finds 'Bright Clear Sadness' in Skies and Shadows
description: A PAINTER in the 1950's was, for all practical purposes, better Red than Realist, and the situation didn't improve much with the advent of the New Realism known as Pop. Indeed, it seems now this movement did as much as Abstract Expressionism to make representation the self-conscious undertaking it is. Still, Realists were getting attention at that time, and one of them was John Button (1929-1982), whose mini-retrospective is now at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: AN ISLAND In LIMBO
description: Alan Weisman's article (''An Island in Limbo,'' Feb. 18) helps to bring more understanding to the problem facing Puerto Rico for so long. I cannot agree more with Cancel Miranda's statement, ''Any foreigner has more rights than Puerto Ricans in their own land.'' I visited Puerto Rico and came back pained.

title: Mental Health Budget Cuts Seen as Breach of Trust
description: LEAD: PROPOSED state budget cuts in mental health services have united health workers, administrators, citizen providers and Long Island lawmakers in opposition to what they see as the state breaking a covenant.

title: Harmon to Chargers
description: The Phoenix Cardinals signed two free agents on Friday, but the one they really wanted got away.

title:
ART;

Diverse View of Hispanic Ethnicity
description: LEAD: MAKING a case for a shared heritage among Hispanic artists of diverse backgrounds, ''Culture Shock,'' the current exhibition at the Discovery Art Gallery in Glen Cove, brings together the efforts of 10 individuals whose works reflect their ethnicity.

title: LEBANON GENERAL MAY OPEN ATTACK
description: With his ammunition dumps resupplied, Gen. Michel Aoun, commander of the Christian part of the Lebanese Army, is ready to open a new offensive to suppress his militia rivals in the Christian enclave north of here, Lebanese military officials said today.

title: An Actress Who Uses Her Inner Voices
description: MAGGIE JAKOBSON - that's the way her family spells it - has dubbed voices for television cartoons, taught sign language to a chimpanzee and swum with dolphins.

title: Team Led by Texan Easily Wins Bridge Title
description: The most prestigious event in the contract bridge calendar, the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, was won Friday night by a group headed by Dan Morse of Houston. His teammates were John Sutherlin of San Francisco, Tom Sanders of Nashville, Bill Pollack of Englewood, N.J., Mike Kamil of Bergenfield, N.J., and Ron Gerard of White Plains.

title: Cyclists Vow to Fight Rockefeller Trail Ban
description: LEAD: THE state announced a temporary ban last week on all cycling along the 14 miles of trails in the Rockefeller State Park Preserve. The ban, to take effect on April 1, also will be enforced on the 50 miles of trails on the adjoining Rockefeller family estate.

title: Go-Ahead for Daniels
description: After passing cardiovascular tests performed on Friday in Atlanta, Kal Daniels was given permission to participate in full spring drills with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: WestHelp Debate Enters Final Stage
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: LaFontaine Nets 2 As Islanders Tie
description: Pat LaFontaine scored his second goal of the game and 51st of the season with 44 seconds left in the third period to give the Islanders a 5-5 tie with the Edmonton Oilers tonight.

title: Juilliard Quartet's Beethoven Cycle
description: My attention has been called to the Feb. 25 article ''Tokyo Quartet Playing Beethoven Cycle.''

title: Technology;   Truckers Swap CB's for Satellites
description: Richard Pullman, a truck driver, got a rude awakening on New Year's Day, when he discoverd that thieves had stolen his truck and cargo while he was sleeping in a motel in Evanston, Wyo.

title: An Wang, 70, Is Dead of Cancer; Inventor and Maker of Computers
description: An Wang, the founder of Wang Laboratories and the inventor of a doughnut-shaped ring of iron that served as the core of computer memory until the microchip came along, died of cancer yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 70 years old.

title: Jill Rose, Teacher, Becomes a Bride
description: Jill Andrea Rose, a teacher in the Westside Montessori School, and Steven G. Shapiro, a partner in the law firm of Mantel & Shapiro, both in Manhattan, were married last evening at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Lawrence Colton performed the ceremony.

title: Campus Life: Harvard;   Conservatives Start Magazine To Preach 'Truth'
description: Frustrated by what they call a moral wasteland on campus, politically conservative Harvard students have founded a magazine that they say preaches the ''absolute truth'' on issues like abortion, homosexuality and affirmative action.

title: Melee Produces a Favorite as Mitterrand Heir
description: Having watched and waited as two leading contenders bloodied each other in an image-bruising power struggle, Prime Minister Michel Rocard has emerged as favorite to become the Socialist Party's candidate to succeed President Francois Mitterrand.

title: 'Weapon' Test: Rentals Boom, Sales Pop
description: A month ago in this space a question was posed: Would ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' Warner's smash-hit cop thriller released on Feb. 8 at $24.98, sell as well as or better than it rents? Furthermore, would a movie rated R sell in a family-oriented market? And would it sell after the Christmas season - in years past, the prime time for selling videos? With studios counting on mass sales of comparable films in the future, all of video awaits the answers.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: If the world were as simple as we sometimes wish it could be, cameras would look the same, do the same things and cost the same. But man's ingenuity knows no bounds, so we are faced with a plethora of models, features and competing brands.

title: Poland's 1920 Soviet Invasion Planted Seeds of Hitler-Stalin Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: East Marion $1.5 million

title: The Brouhaha Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: In Oregon, Literary Lodgings
description: IMAGINE a hotel room decorated in shades of black and blood. Dangling above the bed is a sinister-looking ax blade; at the foot of the bed, a freshly bricked-over passageway, behind which some poor soul, the tip of whose cap is still visible, has met an untimely end reminiscent of ''A Cask of Amontillado.'' Presiding over the macabre scene, its beak slightly open: a stuffed raven.

title: A Democratically Evolving Hungary Heads Into Unknown at Polls Today
description: As they vote on Sunday to elect a government freely for the first time in more than four decades, Hungarians will continue a process that began here almost two years ago, long before the political whirlwind that swept through the rest of Eastern Europe last fall.

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.;   A Lofty Experiment In Curriculum Fizzles
description: Three years ago, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Committee on Curricula approved a 12-subject experimental program titled ''Human Contexts of Science and Technology.'' It was an attempt to make undergraduates more aware of the impact of science and engineering on society.

title: Social Events
description: Evening on Ice

title: Q and A
description: Change in Co-op Shares

title: California Bankers No Longer Fear Outsiders
description: For years, California bankers have been bracing for the second California gold rush. Come next January, banks from other states can expand into the state's huge and lucrative market. And bankers in the state have feared that New York giants like Citicorp, Chase and Chemical would swoop in and buy large California banks, creating continent-spanning empires.

title: All About/Composite Materials;   Light and Tough, New Materials Head for the Mass Marketing Stage
description: From the outside, today's automobiles still appear to be nearly all steel. But about 8 percent of their weight consists of composites -strong, light combinations of complementary substances. Bumpers, doors, body panels and station wagon tailgates are all commonly made from these materials. Ten years ago, the composite content was less than 2 percent; by the year 2000, some producers of composites contend, their materials will predominate.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Mar. 10

title: Jennifer Downey To Marry in May
description: Jennifer Alison Downey and Rene Clement Dussault are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. John A. Downey of New York and Elsie W. Downey of Closter, N.J., have announced. Mr. Dussault is a son of Evelyn Dussault of Schenectady, N.Y., and the late Rene C. Dussault. Miss Downey, 29 years old, is a special-education teacher at the Dr. Edmund Horan Center in Manhattan. A graduate of Muhlenberg College, she received a master's degree in special education from the University of Pittsburgh. Her father is the chairman of the department of rehabilitation at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Her mother is an administrative assistant to the Presbyterian chaplain at Columbia University.

title: THE MUSIC GOES ROUND AND ROUND
description: The guiding force behind music in our time is recycling. As if trapped in some futuristic society marooned in space, composers seem forever doomed to sift through the same dusty files in search of reusable materials. We have become so used to this circular activity that in talented hands it can pass for creativity or even genius. Bet on it: any day now, a new wave of composers will discover the sonata and other Classical forms, as Stravinsky and Hindemith did more than half a century ago. Simplistic repetition is currently enjoying a good run, but in the wings warming up for an encore can be heard a chromaticism as dense as Scriabin's ''Poem of Ecstasy.''

title: Bracing for a Hungry, Crawling Horde
description: As the population of gypsy moths begins to rise throughout the Northeast, one state, New Jersey, is about to begin the largest spraying program in its history to try to counter the devastation that the leaf-eating insect is expected to inflict this year.

title: TALKING: Conversions;   Gaining Control of The Board
description: ANYONE who bought a cooperative apartment in a New York City conversion in the last few years probably assumed that the shareholders would quickly take over control of the board of directors and the building from the sponsor.

title:
Style Makers;

Sally Fox, Entomologist
description: LEAD: It was a mistake that Sally Fox discovered cotton growing naturally in a rainbow of pastel colors. An entomologist working on natural pest control, she began cross-breeding brown cotton with white in her spare time to produce a fiber suitable for her hobby, home spinning.

title: Miss Sheahan Engaged to A. J. Holly
description: Jacqueline Ann Sheahan, the daughter of the late Deirdre J. Sheahan of Mendham, N.J., and the late Donald P. Sheahan of New York, and Arthur Joseph Holly, the son of Mrs. Arthur J. Holly of Bloomfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Holly, have announced plans to marry in June.

title: Death Overseas: After Cairo Fire
description: WHAT happens when a family member dies abroad? Events after the deaths of Marver and Sheva Bernstein, two of the four Americans who were among the 17 people who died in the Heliopolis Sheraton fire in Cairo March 1, offer a case study of how the State Department responds to such incidents overseas and provide insights that people hope they will never need.

title: TRESS ARE US
description: AN OAK SPRING SYLVA

title: Former A.T.P. President Cries Foul
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Lure of History and Interpretive Power
description: Why does one listen to old recordings, especially to very old ones with their surface noise and low-end reproduction of sound? One potent reason is the simple lure of history. Records now reach back far beyond the memories of even the most senior concertgoers, and to the extent that musical interpretation is an important sphere of endeavor, its history is worth understanding.

title: Review/Music;   A John Coltrane Disciple
description: Near the end of his first set on Monday at the Bottom Line, the English saxophonist Courtney Pine silenced his backup trio and performed a tour de force. Using circular breathing to play nonstop, he reeled off hyperfast arpeggios, John Coltrane's ''sheets of sound'' technique, to create a thick, pulsating, slowly changing drone that went on and on - at first stubbornly, then with its own unearthly timing. Closer to post-Minimalist new music than to jazz, freed of the necessity to follow a chord progression or to swing, it was Mr. Pine's most successful solo of the set.

title: Searching for Quality Medical Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheila A. Maher Married To Gregory John Mayer
description: Sheila Anne Maher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Maher of Palm City, Fla., was married yesterday to Gregory John Mayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Mayer of Ludlow, Vt. The Rev. Philip Galiano, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at O'Byrne Chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y.

title: UPDATED, A SINGULAR SPEAKER RETAINS ITS APPEAL
description: For good reasons as well as bad, audio lives by unceasing innovation. New ideas constantly come along, partly to keep the kettle boiling (that's a bad reason) and partly because nothing is ever quite good enough for perfectionists (let's call that a good one).

title: Deborah Clare Wise, Writer, Marries Brooke Unger, Editor and Publisher
description: Deborah Clare Wise and Brooke Unger were married yesterday at the Sudbury Registry in Suffolk, England, by Doreen Capon, the superintendent registrar. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen George Wise of Houghton Hall in Cavendish, Suffolk. Her husband is a son of Prof. Irwin Unger of New York and the late Bernate Unger.

title: Review/Theater;   'The Nature of Things'
description: ''I'm a wild animal; no one can tame me,'' says David Cale, expressing his outsider's vision of the world. There is something undomesticated, almost anti-theatrical about this performance artist. Those unfamiliar with his work might wonder if he had just wandered on stage from the audience. Because the sky is blue, he asks if he is breathing blue air - and he contemplates what birds are thinking about as they fly, leaving the suggestion that thinking might be antithetical to flying. In such a fashion, he tries to project himself into other spheres of existence.

title: GENE-ALTERED ITEM APPROVED BY F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved what it says is the first genetically engineered food product for humans, an enzyme used in making cheese.

title: Nancy Gilbert to Marry K. K. Holland
description: The engagement of Nancy Porter Gilbert to Kenneth Kimball Holland has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Frederick A. Gilbert of Osterville, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Hers;   Two Weeks of Love and Resentment
description: I STRAIGHTENED UP from my weeding as the frenzied mutterings of anger reached me from the house. My muscles tightened. The screams were so muffled I could barely hear them. ''Get away from me, you filthy slut. Leave me alone!''

title: Planning Can Head Off Water Problems
description: NOW is the time to think about having enough water for the garden. Although no one can ever predict the weather accurately, it is practical to think ahead. Even those pundits who forecast weather several days in advance are often wrong.

title: Style Makers;   Alviero Martini, Graphic Designer
description: It's a safe bet that when Alviero Martini arrived at Kennedy International Airport from Italy recently, he had more bags than any other traveler. He was carrying dozens of samples of his new luggage collection, and you might say it stopped traffic. ''Everyone wanted to know where I got it,'' he reported with glee. ''They all wanted to buy it.''

title:
Your Own Account;

Taking Time Off for the Family
description: LEAD: Mary Loftus had spent six years working her way up and was prime-time news anchor at KSNT-TV in Topeka when she became pregnant. She arranged to take a six-week leave after her son, John, was born in June 1983. The day she got home from the hospital, the station manager and executive news director called to say they wanted to stop by.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

East End Vacation-Home Market Softens
description: LEAD: FOR the last two years, the soft vacation-home market in Long Island's East End has been shielded from price reductions because sellers could rent out their houses over the summer to offset expenses while they waited for the market to turn.

title: Honecker and Wife Hounded From New House by a Mob
description: The disgraced former East German leader, Erich Honecker, today left the pastor's house where he has been staying, only to be hounded out of his new place of lodging by protesters who shouted ''Pig! Pig!'' as he sped away.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE ATTRACTIONS

title: POSTINGS: Housing Class;   Making The Right Choice
description: Rapid changes in New York's real estate market are leading to confusion among many home seekers: Is it better these days to buy or to rent, and what, and where, and even how?

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Southeast Regional;   Michigan State Bothered
description: On the eve of the Southeast Regional final matching Minnesota and Georgia Tech for the right to go to the Final Four, a team that won't be going to Denver next weekend was still smarting today over a play from Friday night's game.

title: Meg Jacobs, Lawyer, Wed in Nashville
description: Margaret Louise Jacobs, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Kenneth Jacobs of Nashville, was married there last evening at the Temple to Samuel Allan Flax, a son of Mrs. Louis Flax of Rockville, Md., and the late Mr. Flax. Rabbis Randall Falk and Stephen Fuchs officiated.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Seeking Old Manhasset in the Shadows of Memory
description: LEAD: MY family moved to Manhasset the same year Lord & Taylor, Best & Company and W. J. Sloane's did. It was 1951, the year Manhasset's Miracle Mile was advertised as ''a new idea in shopping.''

title: FACTS DON'T TELL THE STORY
description: LEAD:

title: Short-Form Films Bolster Long-Range Objectives
description: Television viewers this week will have a chance to see three short, offbeat movies that are the results of a project designed to nurture a fresh crop of directors eager to try their hand at feature-length films. Presented under the umbrella title ''Triple Play,'' the package will be shown on PBS's American Playhouse series Wednesday at 9 P.M. The stories are of the sort that seldom make it to the small screen, not to mention the big one, and in fact, were not originally intended to be seen by a television audience at all.

title: Q and A
description: Cruise Escorts

title: PHILIPPINE DREAM FEAST
description: LEAD: DOGEATERS

title: Britain on Five Pints a Day
description: MY husband, John, and I and two of our sons, Ian, who's 23, and Kit, who's 20, recently returned from two weeks spent investigating a canyon. Not the Grand Canyon, but the canyon that separates their generation from ours; we did our exploring while on a trip to England and Scotland, but it's the canyon I'll remember when Moffatt and Edinburgh, Ironbridge and Kings have faded. With every day that passed, my husband and I realized increasingly that we were looking at the United Kingdom through very different eyes than were our sons.

title: Bavaria's Rococo Splendor
description: BAVARIA, in the 18th century, was one of the largest states in Germany, a prosperous electorate whose rulers and people shared a taste for cheerful splendor, and in the rococo, then the prevailing international style, they found just the right way to express themselves. The result is a dazzling series of secular and religious buildings, many of them set in spectacular Alpine landscapes.

title: Florio's Fast Start Draws Support And Questions
description: IF Gov. Jim Florio's first two months in office are any indication, he is going to leave the state much different from the way he found it.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: From Off Broadway, 'Anything Goes'
description: THE next time you hear that ''Anything Goes'' is coming around, you might as well ask, ''Which 'Anything Goes?' is it anyway?''

title: Lori S. Winters to Marry
description: May wedding plans for Lori Susan Winters and Theodore Rapp Samuels 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rapp Samuels of St. Louis, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morley D. Winters of St. Louis. Miss Winters, 30, graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University and received an M.B.A. from Northwestern University. She is a product manager at Colgate-Palmolive in New York. Her fiance, 35, is a vice president at the Capital Guardian Trust Company in New York. He graduated cum laude from Harvard University, where he also received an M.B.A.

title: Marcia Perlstein Is Wed To Dr. Lawrence B. Lusk
description: Marcia Harriet Perlstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Perlstein of Oakland, Calif., was married last evening to Dr. Lawrence Bradley Lusk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Lusk of White Plains. Rabbi Robert S. Kirschner officiated at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco.

title: Missing Minute
description: Being saved by the bell is one thing. What happened in New Jersey Friday night was downright ridiculous. Indeed, after Bobby Czyz won a unanimous decision from Uriah Grant in a light heavyweight fight in Atlantic City, the biggest question was whether the bout had been a boxing match or an episode of ''The Gong Show.''

title: Life: The Mini-Series
description: This month's winner of the life-imitating-art award is the robbery a week ago at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. You may recall that two thieves made off with more than $200 million worth of masterpieces: Vermeer, Rembrandt, Degas, Manet and, somewhat inexplicably, a bronze beaker from the Shang dynasty.

title: THE MAN WITH THE GOLDEN SWING
description: ON A MILD, LATE-JANUARY DAY, WHILE his fellow professionals scramble toward a weekend payday on the Monterey Peninsula some 3,000 miles away, Curtis Strange is back home on the range, hard at practice. With monotonous regularity, Strange, a lanky, prematurely gray-haired 35-year-old, slaps golf ball after golf ball into the slight Virginia breeze. First, a series of soft wedge shots that seem to hover momentarily before dropping, like darts to a board, to an imaginary flagstick some 110-115 yards away; next, short irons, which send the red-striped range balls rippling off toward a row of tall pines and the James River beyond.

title: An Unfinished Paragraph
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Bowers and Merena, Inc. of Wolfeboro, N. H. will hold an auction Wednesday through Saturday at the Vista International Hotel, 3 World Trade Center, New York City. Colonial-era paper money and copper coins, tiny California fractional gold pieces, Hard Times tokens and the ''king of Canadian coins'' - a 1921 half-dollar are just a few of the many incredible coins to be sold.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: 2 Killed When Bus Overturns in Westchester
description: Two people were killed and 32 injured today when a tour bus returning to Massachusetts from New York City overturned on Interstate 684 in Armonk, officials said.

title: Seaside Retreat Offers a Respite From Life's Dizzying Pace
description: THE road leading into the Mercy Center in Madison hugs a stretch of woods that taper out to the sea. Nearby, in an open parcel, stands an old greenhouse, several sand-colored buildings and a towering 18-room mansion built in the 1940's by W. T. Grant, the dime-store magnate. The house was built of brick and California redwood. Its giant windows reflect the changing colors of the sea and sky.

title: Mozart's Golden Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Quilts for Babies With AIDS
description: When Ellen Ahlgren heard that thousands of babies infected with the AIDS virus were living out their short lives in cold and sterile hospital cribs, she decided to make them some quilts.

title: Expansion Reminder
description: If the owners and the players have a new labor contract, can a timetable for major league expansion be far behind?

title: Serious Times, Trivial Politics
description: News flash: The Kennedy Library at Harvard University, to encourage better leadership, will bestow its first Profile in Courage Award this year on a public official who follows his conscience instead of the opinion polls.

title: Canada, Where Officers Halt All Cars and Drivers Cheer
description: ''GOOD evening, ma'am. This is a ride spot-check.

title: Route 135: Dead End at Both Ends
description: LEAD: ONCE the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway, Route 135 never made it to Oyster Bay, and an extension north only to a positive terminus at Route 25A is resisted and unfunded.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: DR. JORDAN J. COHEN;

A Medical School Dean Balances Technology and Teaching
description: LEAD: ADMINISTRATOR, physician, researcher, teacher, author. All those roles describe Jordan J. Cohen, M.D., who in July 1988 became dean of the Medical School and professor of medicine at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: WHEN BRITISH JUSTICE FAILED
description: Kevin Toolis's article helped to rectify the slander against four blameless individuals. The author, however, may have overlooked the most sobering aspect of the case: was it bigotry - or racism - that triggered the illegal and excessive response of the authorities?

title:
DANCE;

'Dark Comedies' on Family Life
description: LEAD: THE many dimensions of human relationships inform the works of Danial Shapiro and Joanie Smith, whose company, Shapiro and Smith Dance, currently in residence at Montclair State College, will perform Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. on the Montclair campus. For this husband-and-wife team of dance makers, marriage, parenthood, family relationships and domesticity provide choreographic fodder that they transmute into dances that often ricochet wittily around the stage.

title: Lenin Is Alive and Well and Reporting From Lithuania
description: AMID the feast of information and candor set forth by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, it is worth pointing out that the spectral figure of agitprop - the weary old Bolshevik specialist in manipulating information - still holds a high place at the table of glasnost. In the war of nerves between the Kremlin and the breakaway republic of Lithuania, Soviet Government dominance of most information channels has been on display with a pervasiveness that Lenin first dreamed of.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional;   Arkansas Pulls Free Of Texas at the Line
description: For all the high-flying rebounds and wondrous shots that Arkansas and Texas tossed at each other here this afternoon, the finish came down to one of basketball's most elementary phases: free throws. Hit or miss. Arkansas missed plenty in the waning minutes, but the Razorbacks' Ron Huery made two crucial ones with 16 seconds left to lift Arkansas to an 88-85 victory and the Midwest Regional championship before 16,143 in Reunion Arena.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: TEMPE, ARIZ.;

Mixed Project Downtown
description: LEAD: A $150 MILLION mixed-use project on 22 acres is proving to be a key element in the growth of this city's once rundown downtown.

title: Conference On Trees: Their Care And Future
description: LEAD: TREES - their placement, growth, maintenance and health - are the topic of ''The Urban Forestry Conference'' to be held April 3 from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., at the Westchester County Center.

title: STARK CYCLADIC FIGURES HAUNT CONTEMPORARY COLLECTORS
description: Travelers to Greece more than a century ago returned to other European countries with the eyeless, mouthless Cycladic idols that historians at the time described as primitive, even ugly. Today these 5,000-year-old white marble figures - most of which depict women with their arms folded flat against their chests - are among the most prized of ancient artifacts and are viewed by many curators, historians and collectors as, in Picasso's words, ''magical objects.''

title: A Word of Caution About the Squid
description: As a person who tries to watch his weight and keep in fair physical condition, I am constantly reading articles about foods, recipes and so forth and their effects on our bodies.

title: Focus Turns To Those Behind The Camera
description: Except in obscure publications, cinematographers never get credit for the look of a movie. It's not that directors deliberately usurp the praise. But parceling out credit is so complicated that the director becomes the winner by default.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: RUTH CAMPOPIANO;

Generating Enthusiasm for Teaching
description: LEAD: RUTH CAMPOPIANO has been celebrating the joy of teaching for 34 years. Throughout her career, as she has moved from the high school classrooms where she taught both Spanish and French to administrative posts and back to the classroom again, she has always, she says, been ''a tiger'' on the subject of education.

title: Nicaragua Rivals Praise Contra Move to Disband
description: All sides in Nicaragua's long civil conflict today hailed the contras' agreement on Friday to disband their army, apparently eliminating the most important obstacle to a peaceful transfer of power on April 25 between the Sandinistas and the newly elected government.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Vancouver
description: Political and business leaders have been saying for years that for Vancouver the future is the Pacific Rim, but, it seems the future is now. This city on the west coast of Canada is thriving with new citizens, new buildings and new investment.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: LARCHMONT YACHT CLUB;

The Men Who Go Down to the Sea, and Start Cleaning Up
description: LEAD: THE ''Knights of the Round Table'' are at it again. Nailing, hammering, scraping, doing all those things that come with spring cleanup. Down by the water, demolishing old docks, building new ones, they work as vigorously as if they were being paid great sums for their efforts.

title: Sabra Chartrand And Joel Brinkley To Marry in May
description: Sabra Elizabeth Chartrand, a reporter for the Jerusalem bureau of The New York Times, and Joel Brinkley, The Times's bureau chief in Jerusalem, plan to be married in May. The prospective bride is a daughter of David P. Chartrand of Kirkland, Wash., and Gina Petitto of Seattle. Mr. Brinkley is a son of David Brinkley of Chevy Chase, Md., the ABC News correspondent, and Ann F. Brinkley of Washington.

title: The Hunt for Art Fit for a Czar
description: LEAD: Peter Batkin is a roly-poly figure, a cheerful amalgam of Luciano Pavarotti, Nubar Gulbenkian and Mr. Pickwick. His beard, or ''whiskers'' as Pickwick would put it, fringes his cheeks like a large tortellino. He affects a floppy bow tie and gray-and-white two-tone brogues: from a distance you would swear they are spats.

title: Gerald Bull, 62, Shot in Belgium; Scientist Who Violated Arms Law
description: Gerald V. Bull, a Canadian-born rocket scientist and international arms consultant who ran afoul of a weapons embargo against South Africa, was shot to death on Thursday night at his apartment in a suburb of Brussels, the authorities said. He was 62 years old.

title: Review/Theater;   Cherry Blossoms and Revenge in Japanese Fable
description: ''Lost in a Flurry of Cherries,'' the Japanese experimental drama that ends its residence at La Mama E.T.C.today, is only about 70 minutes long. But by its end, the cold, mysterious play with spectacular stage effects leaves one feeling wind-blown and a little breathless from its energy.

title: PICTURING PAPA
description: The life of Ernest Hemingway has been chronicled, celebrated and analyzed so exhaustively that its scenes now constitute the elements of a myth, the periodic retracing of which has become a kind of pilgrimage (or gravy train) taken by writers and readers alike. A. E. Hotchner, the author of ''Papa Hemingway,'' a classic of Hemingway hagiography, has hit the trail again and served up in HEMINGWAY AND HIS WORLD (Vendome Press, $45) an encyclopedic buffet, full of fascinating rare photos of Hemingway and others, as well as color photos of book jackets, memorabilia and scenes from such favorite locales as Paris, Italy, Spain and Africa. The text is arranged chronologically, with entries on the novelist's friends, wives and favorite places, as well as cities and historical events identified with him. Although he works almost exclusively with information that has been sitting out on the literary steam table for years, the author manages to give a sense of the wide swath that Hemingway cut through this century. Mr. Hotchner, who was a friend of Hemingway's, tends to insert himself into the book at inappropriate times, like someone straining to be included in a group photograph, and more than a few warmed-over chestnuts from ''Papa Hemingway'' are served up undisguised. As a result, ''Hemingway and His World'' plays musical chairs, circling memoir and biography but never sitting down. But, even with its weaknesses, this handsome, appealing book provides a satisfying overview of the trajectory of the novelist's life, a movable feast if ever there was one.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I come from a small Midwestern town, and this only happened in places like Los Angeles or Dallas or New York or Chicago. I was from Iowa. I had never given it a thought. But now I'm going to do my damnedest to keep it from happening to another woman.''

title: Tribe Wins Money in Settlement of Land Suit
description: The Puyallup Tribe signed away its claim to much of its land today for money, promises of jobs and education and a part of Tacoma's waterfront.

title: Slorc Crimes in Myanmar
description: Behind closed doors, Myanmar's military rulers are committing monstrous deeds. The latest is a mass forced relocation of the urban population reminiscent of Pol Pot's Cambodia. The outside world could bring effective pressure for change - but only if all concerned put humanity ahead of commercial advantage.

title: Champion Diver Is Still on the Rise
description: Mark Lenzi is the world's best 1-meter springboard diver. He is an outgoing, courteous, refreshing youth of 21.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Lentils That Don't Linger in the Pot
description: Dried beans, peas and lentils are the trend-setting foods of the 90's, appearing on menus where nutrition and taste meet. One big drawback is that they take so long to cook. An alternative is canned beans, and as canned foods go they are among the best. And while lentils do not come in cans, they do come in more than one color.

title: Small World
description: Sometimes science is served best by unscientific methods. For years researchers wondered if the hairy-eared dwarf lemur still existed; they had never seen one alive. Last week it was reported that the animal, the second smallest primate (the mouse lemur is smaller in dry seasons), was alive and well in a Madagascar rain forest. Braving leeches and malaria, a West German biologist, Bernhard Meier, spotted four of the creatures last year. The event was called one of the biggest rediscoveries of a mammal in a decade. Just 5 1/2 inches long, with a 7-inch tail and weighing 3 1/2 ounces, the animal jumps like a cricket and eats bugs while hanging from branches. How did Mr. Meier find them? One lemur appeared in his headlight beam one night. And the others? The key was a stray dog that joined his search party. The guides lifted the dog up to sniff holes in trees, and at one point he began to bark. ''That was the secret to how we found them,'' Mr. Meier said. ''I don't think that is a real scientific way to bring things out.''

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: Gary Kasparov did not have an easy time in the Linares International Tournament in Spain, which ended Feb. 24. For the moment he has given up the Gruenfeld Defense, which he used with reasonable success against Anatoly Karpov in their last two title matches. A good guess is that he does not want everyone he meets to be educated in its niceties as a result of seeing his Karpov games.

title: FINLEY KUMBLE SAT ON A WALL
description: SHARK TANK

title: Cheryl Jagolinzer Married To Jonathan Grant Marcus
description: Cheryl Ann Jagolinzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt Jagolinzer of Framingham, Mass., was married last evening in Newport, R.I., to Jonathan Grant Marcus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Marcus of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Mark Jagolinzer, a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Oceancliff Resort.

title: Eastern Europe
description: To the Editor: The article ''Suddenly, It's Eastern Europe'' (Travel, Feb. 11) failed to highlight one of the great attractions of visiting Eastern Europe this year: remarkably low prices not seen in Western Europe for decades. Currency reform in several Eastern European countries gives tourists more local money per dollar than ever before.

title: Monkey Imports Are Cut as Virus Spreads
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control has halted imports by three of the nation's largest monkey dealers because of concerns about a spreading virus.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Paris Wears Air of Flair All Its Own
description: What is it about Paris that brings out that extra bit of flair in the way women dress, that makes an outfit look just that much smarter than it would anywhere else? Who knows for sure, but some things are better left unanalyzed. What is certain is that this past week at least, the clothes on view in the City of Light were as arresting as ever, especially those in black and white, the color combination of the moment.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Kyle Woodward To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Kyle Kathleen Woodward to Richard Carl Savarese has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Woodward of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The wedding is to take place in June.

title: Countdown For Rangers
description: After 48 years, a run of bad luck even a rigged roulette wheel might have trouble reproducing, the numbers could finally break right for the Rangers today at Madison Square Garden.

title: Shelley B. Weinstock Weds Paul V. Bartick
description: Dr. Shelley B. Weinstock, an assistant professor of chemistry at Barnard College, and Paul V. Bartick, a children's author and a staff consultant at the Children's Television Workshop in New York, were married last evening at the Columbia University Chapel. Rabbi Michael Paley officiated.

title: Fighting the Competition for Funds to Fight Lyme Disease
description: THE first Federal allocation for studying Lyme disease is the incentive for a contest of sorts between Westchester and Suffolk Counties, whose officials are competing here for a share of the $500,000 available.

title: Gunsel
description: To the Editor: Regarding the derivation of ''gunsel'' (Letters on Travel, Jan. 21), the word does indeed derive from the old middle-high German word Gansel (little goose). It is used to describe young, if empty-headed, girls. With that meaning, the word is still used in Bavaria, Austria and the German-speaking section of Switzerland.

title: Prospect of Arms Pacts Spurring Weapon Sales
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are increasing foreign arms sales in advance of major new agreements to slash the level of conventional forces in Europe, American officials and arms industry executives say.

title: Brazil's Wild West
description: IT was after dark when the bus to Xapuri in northwestern Brazil ran out of gas about a mile from town. An earlier breakdown on the highway from Rio Branco, the capital of Acre state, had stranded the 50 passengers aboard for five hours until a replacement bus arrived. At roadside, as the group shared soft drinks and candy bars, an easy camaraderie sprang up. When the bus shuddered to its final halt, it was all laughter as everyone scrambled out for the moonlight hike into town. ''The Acre express,'' said one traveler, giving the battered bus a farewell kick on the fender.

title: FRESH AIR AND SUNSHINE
description: Pilgrim, Kings Park and Central Islip Psychiatric Centers were once New York State's largest mental institutions. According to Kings Park's director, Marge Glueck, Long Island was selected as a site for these facilities because of its proximity to New York City's mentally ill and because of the Island's ''fresh air and sunshine,'' which was then a popular treatment for mental health.

title: Petra
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to see the article (Travel, March 4) on my favorite place, Petra. I know it well, having spent several months over the past few years engaged in photographic work there.

title: Marjorie Hagerty, Student, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce C. Hagerty of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Tobin Hagerty, to Scott Drew Carroll, a son of Valerie Carroll of Peekskill, N.Y., and the late Donald P. Carroll. The wedding is to be next year.

title: New Explosion Threat Seen at Nuclear Plant
description: Some tanks that store atomic waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation could explode and spew radiation into the air because hydrogen gas is building up inside them, a new Federal study says.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Zoning for Compatibility;   Market Test for a Windsor Terrace Condo
description: THE last act has opened in a long-running zoning drama in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn.

title: The 25th Baroque F estival Opens
description: THE Hoff-Barthelson School in Scarsdale opens its 25th yearly Baroque Festival tonight at 7 P.M. and it continues later at several sites as student, faculty and guest artists perform.

title: Campus Life: Carnegie-Mellon;   Using Balloons To Bring Attention To Women's Place
description: Orange balloons wandered around Carnegie-Mellon University's Pittsburgh campus this month, signaling the celebration of International Women's Day. The balloons, provided by the Carnegie-Mellon Women's Center, were distributed to passers-by - female passers-by that is. Men who wanted balloons were refused.

title: Why Study History? And Whose History?
description: THERE are many very good reasons for studying history in school.

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: The question is not whether the college athlete should be paid; he (or she) is paid now, in an approved, legitimate, and generous way. At Notre Dame for example, each of the 19 incoming football scholarship freshmen receive a yearly benefit (tuition, room, board) having an approximate value of $15,000.

title: A Green Party Mayor Takes On Industrial Filth of Old Cracow
description: In this city of rapid political change and some of the foulest air, water and soil in Poland, a former farmer has moved into a local palace, pledging that the fight against the filth has begun.

title: Sports of The Times;   Ryan Would Strike Out Asterisks
description: In the fallout from baseball's labor dispute, one temporary rule threatens the sanctity of its statistics. Ordinarily a starting pitcher must complete at least five innings in order to be eligible for a victory. But for the first 14 days of the season that opens on April 9, three innings will be enough. During the negotiations the change was requested by Orel Hershiser of the Los Angeles Dodgers, presumably to protect starting pitchers from risking arm trouble by laboring to last five innings. But the starting pitcher who could benefit the most, Nolan Ryan, would rather retain the five-inning minimum.

title: PARTING SHOTS
description: LEAD:

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: Sure, go ahead and pay the college athlete; continue to foster the illusion of success that participation in a Division I program perpetuates. An illusion I might add that will principally affect the black athlete, already disillusioned by the prospects of acquiring a piece of the American Dream.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Dinner Is on a New Wave
description: LEAD: ''NOT ME!'' I declared, staunchly holding out against modern technology. ''I don't want a microwave.''

title: Freud, Though a Genius, Was Also Human;   'Mysterious Terrain'
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservative Alliance Makes Gains in Australia Vote
description: A conservative coalition made significant gains in parliamentary elections today, but it may not have won enough seats to wrest power from Prime Minister Bob Hawke's Labor Party, unofficial results showed.

title: About Cars
description: A truck from Oldsmobile?

title: JAILHOUSE BLUES: THE BALLAD OF THE MARIN COUNTY JAIL
description: It is like a vast stucco spaceship, set gracefully into the brown hills just north of San Francisco, and it stands as Frank Lloyd Wright's crowning achievement on the West Coast as surely as the Guggenheim Museum culminates his career on the East Coast. The building is the Marin County Civic Center, a combination office building, courthouse and library, and it was conceived not only as an adventurous piece of architecture but also as a visionary piece of planning: a unified governmental center for a growing suburban region. The open, sprawling complex was intended to be Marin's symbolic anchor, giving this forward-looking county what most suburban areas never have - a true public realm.

title: Vienna Choir Boys Will Return to Hartford
description: PERENNIAL favorites during the holiday season, the Vienna Choir Boys will return to Bushnell Memorial Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. for a spring concert.

title: Schools' Responsibility For Low Self-Esteem
description: It is so rare that the press pays any attention to the need for schools to promote positive self-esteem in children that one hesitates to criticize the well-meaning article [''How 'Magic Circles' Build Self-Esteem,'' Feb. 18] .

title: HOW THE TAX CUT LOOKS NOW
description: THE GROWTH EXPERIMENT

title:
ART;

Prints Highlight Skill and Technique
description: LEAD: ONE festering irritation in the art world is the burden felt by print makers who see respect for technical traditions challenged by the free-spirited ventures into their field by artists known mostly as painters and sculptors.

title: A Paragon of Civility?
description: To the Editor:

title: For 90's Cinderellas, One-Night Gowns
description: LEAD: THE price tags on the sequined jackets, ball gowns and cocktail dresses at the shop called Going in Style in Stamford are nearly as dazzling as the clothes themselves, averaging $100 to $125 on designer gowns and one-of-a-kind dresses that typically cost five times that. The styles are current, and a wide selection of colors and sizes is offered.

title: Susan M. Holgate Weds R. S. Barron
description: The wedding of Susan Mary Holgate, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clement J. Holgate of Short Hills, N.J., to Robert Sean Barron, the son of Manuel Barron of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Gloria Barron, took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of Summit, N.J. Msgr. William P. Divine and Rabbi Charles J. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: THE MAGNIFICENT CHILD
description: RENOIR ON RENOIR

title: A Writing Project Spans the Age Gap
description: The words collaborative and interdisciplinary do not trip off the tongue of the average 9-year-old, but some fourth graders at the Post Road School here have learned them in a special way.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The on-going debate among hobbyists about whether ''philatelic creations'' deserve a place in a serious collection takes an odd twist in an odd corner of the world, the South Pacific island of Niuafoo.

title: Burke Produces As Devils Win
description: The Devils got into sync at the Spectrum this afternoon and ended a losing streak at two games with a 5-2 triumph over the Flyers.

title: Lifestyle: Outing;   Tokens, Please, For a Ride
description: Since ancient times, cities have arisen out of transportation routes. New York City was no different: today's metropolis emerged from a prosperous port, but it emanated also from the metropolis below. Its streets cling to the massive transportation network beneath them. A visit to the New York Transit Museum in Brooklyn offers a chance to explore the workings of that network at leisure. The museum is a tribute to the city's underworld, the 714-mile subway system. Visitors enter through a tidy subway station entrance, where the price of admission is $1.15 and a transit token is legal tender (those 17 and under get in for 55 cents).

title: Raccoons Thriving And Posing A Threat
description: LEAD: THE Hollander family of Westbury threw a party on its redwood deck late last summer. The first guests to arrive were a family of raccoons.

title: Spira Released on Bail
description: Howard Spira, a self-described gambler who was arrested Friday on Federal charges that he threatened George Steinbrenner and tried to extort money from Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield, was released on bail yesterday.

title: Steinbrenner-Spira: Tale of the Tape
description: When George Steinbrenner initially encountered Howard Spira, the Yankees' owner seemed only too eager to hear what the man on the other end of the telephone had to say about Dave Winfield.

title: Setting the Poet's Record Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: Ah, Symplocarpus Foetidus
description: In a season of premature cherry blossoms and untimely tulips, one all-American plant is giving no ground to this headlong spring - symplocarpus foetidus, less elegantly known as skunk cabbage. After poking its tip out of half-frozen soil, it waited to open its burnished green and purple sheaths and now, right on schedule, is sprouting the big leaves, which, when stepped on, smell terrible. It flourishes in swamps and along streams, and fine stands of it can be seen around the Van Cortlandt Park golf course and just south of the Prospect Park Zoo.

title: A Swindler the Second Time Around Is Also a Witness for the Prosecution
description: Two decades ago, a swindler named Michael Hellerman carried out a series of stock frauds involving top mobsters and then became an informer who testified against his former associates.

title: BUSH'S CABINET: WHO'S UP, WHO'S DOWN
description: At the first informal meeting of the Bush Cabinet, in Blair House a week before the Inauguration, George Bush pulled a handwritten list out of his pocket and read what he called ''The Marching Orders.''

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Middle Eastern, Spanish And (of Course) French
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current.

title: Correction
description: An article last week about people involved in savings and loan failures included erroneous statements about Thomas M. Gaubert, the former head of the Independent American Savings and Loan Association of Dallas. Mr. Gaubert has not been sued in a civil case by the Government. In an agreement with regulators, he was banned from the savings industry in 1986 because of dealings with an Iowa savings institution that led to large losses, not because of the failure of his own institution. Mr. Gaubert was national finance chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign, not treasurer. And his real-estate investments are concentrated in residential properties, not distressed ones.

title: POSTINGS: U.S.-Canadian Project;   Downtown Hotel
description: A rapidly expanding Canadian hotel company, the Journey's End Motels Corporation of Belleville, Ont., has entered into a deal to erect a 31-story hotel at 15 Cliff Street between John and Fulton Streets - the fourth hotel project in the financial district since the stock market crash of October 1987. Construction is to start in May.

title: Raising a Paper Militia at Washington's Headquarters
description: LEAD: AN army of toy soldiers marched across a tabletop at Washington's Headquarters Musuem in North White Plains last Sunday.

title: Constant Din Is Getting Cairo Residents Down
description: Honking his car horn to summon a friend from an apartment house above, the driver seemed unperturbed when an egg launched by someone in the building splattered on the road close to where he was parked.

title: Miss Hecker Wed To J. A. Taufield
description: Loren Celia Hecker and Jeffrey Zane Taufield were married last evening at the Burden mansion in New York by Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein. The bride is the daughter of Wilma K. Hecker of New York and the late Marvin S. Hecker. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Robert S. Taufield of Englishtown, N.J., and the late Mr. Taufield.

title: A SOFT FOCUS ON A SHARP CONFLICT HAS ITS RISKS
description: Even a generally first-rate television production can leave the impression of an opportunity missed - especially when the focus in on the extraordinarily urgent subject of racial tensions in the United States.

title: Review/Music;   Soviet Clarinetist Visits The Washboard Kings
description: Stanley's Washboard Kings, a jazz quintet that features washboard and the combination of comb and tissue paper that is sometimes known as a blue blower, was a sextet at its weekly session on Tuesday at the Cajun Restaurant, 129 Eighth Avenue near 16th Street.

title: Philip Sher to Wed Anita Moss in June
description: The engagement of Anita Miriam Moss to Philip Matthew Sher has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Moss of New York. Mr. Sher is a son of Miriam Sher of Johannesburg. A June wedding is planned.

title: After Trial, Valdez Captain Says, He Is More Cynical
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood remembers that in the worst of times, when his name was splashed in headlines and the lawsuits rolled in like the tide, he identified with the persecuted hero of a classic novel.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley;   Protesters Win Some Concessions On Admissions
description: After two days of student protests demanding that the University of California at Berkeley insure greater ethnic diversity of students, faculty, staff and curriculum, university administrators have made several concessions on minority admissions.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Freehold Is Getting Its First Major Mall
description: LEAD: IN its passage from farmland to suburb over the last decade, Freehold Township has drawn myriad housing projects and office and industrial parks to its 38 square miles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Cross-Country

title: Film to Videotape: A Ticklish Transfer
description: ''One of the major missions of a cinematographer today,'' says Allen Daviau, the cinematographer Steven Spielberg entrusted with the filming of the fabulous ''E. T.'' ''is guiding the marriage of video and film technology.'' Mr. Daviau's statement reflects the fact that nowadays movies are seen far more frequently on the home television screen than in the theater. It also underlines problems that to many movie makers prove a constant source of frustration.

title: Sarina Monast Becomes Bride of Kenneth Bronfin
description: Sarina Monast, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Monast of Buzzards Bay, Mass., was married last evening to Kenneth Bronfin, a son of Fred Bronfin of New Orleans and the late Saralyn Bronfin. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Review/Music;   Brahms by Trio and Guests
description: Concerts devoted to the works of a single composer may lack the variety we expect of an evening in the concert hall. But one virtue they offer is unity. The listener, once drawn into the composer's world, need not jump centuries and styles every 20 minutes.

title: A Name, a Face and a Rape: Iowa Victim Tells Her Story
description: Nine months after she had been raped, with her trauma still fresh and the case against her assailant languishing in court, Nancy Ziegenmeyer was sitting in the Grinnell College library, studying the law of sexual assault. During a break in her work, she came across a column in The Des Moines Register.

title: A Movie Teenager With Real-World Problems
description: Emily Lloyd doesn't play the sort of movie teenager who worries about what she's going to wear to the high-school prom or about having a date with the handsome senior who also happens to be the Harvard-bound captain of the football team.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

When Best Friends Walked a Boardwalk
description: LEAD: REMEMBER when your best friend moved away? You were about 10 years old, and you sat on the curb with your head between your knees while tears dripped into the storm sewer. Occasionally, you'd look up at that big blue moving van, and when she came out with the parakeet in its cage, you knew it was over.

title: THE DRINK OF MILLIONS
description: Before reading ''The Drink of Millions'' I would have assumed that Joseph Conway, head of the Bureau of Water Supply, had at least an inkling that it is important to conserve water. Isn't his agency responsible for all those ''Don't Drip New York Dry'' posters I see in public restrooms and on the subway? I was shocked to learn that his offspring ''take showers many times a day, for extended periods of time''! Apparently Mr. Conway feels that his family is exempt from responsibility regarding water conservation.

title: Nosedive Persists For Nets
description: Steve Kerr, the National Basketball Association leader in 3-point shooting percentage this season, sparked a 39-point second quarter for Cleveland by making all four of his 3-point attempts as the Cavaliers beat the Nets tonight, 115-108.

title: Romance and a Happy Ending, Together at Last
description: In the 1930's and 40's, Fred and Ginger and all those other starry-eyed cloudland couples met to the music - sometimes real, sometimes metaphorical - of romantic love. Now there are Peter and Rita, the hero and heroine of ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' Craig Lucas's charming new play at the Circle Repertory Company. As played by Alec Baldwin and Mary-Louise Parker, the two are throwbacks to a more congenial era for romance, in life as well as in art. Recorded musical interludes of the title song and other ballads additionally evoke a nostalgic past. Despite obstacles on their path to marital bliss - arising from Mr. Lucas's use of an intricate plot device - love triumphs, just as it did in Hollywood.

title: Not Merely a Dictator
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN BRITISH JUSTICE FAILED
description: I couldn't help but notice in the photographs accompanying your article ''When British Justice Failed,'' by Kevin Toolis (Feb. 25), on page 35, in the photograph of the aftermath of the bombing of the Horse and Groom, the two men who appear to be comforting the dazed woman in the foreground bear an uncanny resemblance to the two Irish Republican Army men as pictured in the inset photographs.

title: Duke Passes Its Final Four Exam, Again
description: Live by the buzzer, die by the buzzer. Connecticut tried it once too often at this regional, and will not be heading west as a consequence.

title: Patients Are Frail
description: LEAD: MILLY is 87 years old. She was hospitalized for 45 years until five years ago, when she came to live with her Family Care Program provider, Carmel Guesno, a former health aide at Kings Park Psychiatric Center, and Carmel's husband, Gilbert, a steamfitter.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It's not necessarily survival of the fittest in the dance world; it may only be survival of the luckiest. When a production vanishes from a repertory, no one can predict if it will be gone for a season or for all eternity. Shockingly few creations of the past were notated when they were new. Even in our own age of film, videotape and crusading notation societies, numerous dances still go unrecorded.

title: Two Chinas
description: Taiwan is not the ''Free China'' it claims to be. But at least it now shows willingness to move in that direction, in contrast to a deepening chill in mainland China. Taiwan's reforms are worth encouraging, both for themselves and for the healthy example they might set for future leaders in Beijing.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: KANSAS CITY, MO.;

Conventional Wisdom
description: LEAD: CITY officials hopes that an expansion of the 14-year-old convention center here will reinvigorate the downtown area and re-establish Kansas City as one of the country's premier convention sites.

title: Discovering a Tax Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: In New 'Hierarchy,' Mets Seek Balance
description: They are gone but not forgotten. And, this may come as a shock to students of ''chemistry'' in sports, the mythical men of the Mets are not entirely missed.

title:
MUSIC;

Playing the Harmonica, Classically
description: LEAD: ROBERT BONFIGLIO, who is considered the leading American harmonica virtuoso, says that although the harmonica as a folk instrument is the most widely played instrument in America, only a handful of classical harmonica performers have managed to build successful careers.

title: Purdue Coach Says He Erred
description: Coach Gene Keady of Purdue has acknowledged in a letter to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball committee that he made inappropriate comments after Purdue's elimination from the N.C.A.A. tournament last Sunday.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lincoln, Mass.;

Subsidies Aid 'Farm Village'
description: LEAD: HELPED by a state program of low-cost mortgages and a local subsidy on land costs, a condominium complex designed to resemble a 19th-century farm village is taking shape in this 247-year-old suburb 20 minutes west of Boston.

title: THE AUTHOR FROM CALCUTTA
