description: SATYAJIT RAY: The Inner Eye. By Andrew Robinson. (University of California, $29.95.) Film buffs will be fascinated by ''Satyajit Ray,'' a study of India's most widely acclaimed director. Born into a gifted Calcutta family in 1921, Mr. Ray shot his first movie, ''Pather Panchali,'' with amateur actors and no script; its budget was so minuscule that at one point the director had to pawn his wife's jewelry to buy lunch for his crew. The film went on to win him international recognition for its haunting, lyric beauty, and his subsequent work has put him in the ranks of the leading directors. Most of Andrew Robinson's impressively researched book discusses the 34 movies Mr. Ray made from 1950 to 1989, as well as his music, his fiction and the children's magazine he has edited since 1961. There are shooting diaries, detailed backgrounds to the scripts and insightful critiques of Mr. Ray's films gleaned from reviews and interviews with the film maker. Only about a quarter of the book is biographical. Even here, the author is more interested in discussing Mr. Ray's development as an artist than in giving a personal account of the man himself. A single paragraph covers Mr. Ray's courtship and marriage; his wife is scarcely mentioned thereafter, though his close family life has been very important to him. He emerges as a modest, friendly but extremely private person. Still, Mr. Robinson, a television producer in England, uses his informal writing style to illuminate the director's genius, and the 150 photos and illustrations provide visual testimony to Satyajit Ray's immense contributions to the world of film.

title: CENSUS QUESTIONNAIRE: LINK TO DEMOCRACY AND SOURCE OF DATA
description: Census questionnaires are arriving in households across the nation this month, ready to collect bits of personal information that will send representatives to Washington, reveal new markets to businesses and teach Americans a little more about themselves.

title: NO LONG-TERM PLAN ON MILITARY SAVING
description: At a time when receding Soviet military power suggests that hundreds of billions of dollars will be cut from the Pentagon budget in this decade, the Bush Administration and Congress are so absorbed in the politics of the moment that neither has begun to develop a strategy for using the money.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Namibia misstated the starting date of the war of independence there. The war, which ended in 1989, began in 1966, not 1986.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about corporate health and fitness programs misstated the number of workers participating at the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. It is 97,000, not 70,000.

title: Carole Bernstein, A Lawyer, to Wed
description: Carole Rose Bernstein, a daughter of Irene Bernstein of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Alan Bernstein, and Dr. Neil David Herbsman, a son of Dr. Horace Herbsman of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Brenda Herbsman, have announced their engagement. A December wedding is planned.

title: Jack D. Gunther, 82, A Chemical Executive
description: Jack Disbrow Gunther, a chemical industry executive and conservationist, died of pneumonia on Friday in Hartford Hospital in Hartford.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WIND: Stories, by Leigh Allison Wilson. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Set in upstate New York, Leigh Allison Wilson's second collection of short stories is about lost souls wandering through a world where nothing much makes sense. ''While the hard-edged, unembellished Oz that she dares to dream is a land we may not eagerly enter, it is also one we cannot easily leave,'' Jennifer Krauss said here last year.

title: Sheila Carey Weds
description: Sheila A. Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Carey Jr. of Locust, N.J., was married in San Francisco yesterday to Parker S. Bryan, a son of Carleton F. Bryan of San Francisco and the late Carol P. Bryan. C. Zook Sutton, a retired judge of Alameda County (Calif.) Superior Court, officiated at the Pacific Union Club. Mrs. Bryan, 36 years old, is a design consultant at Sun Valley Interiors in Ketchum, Idaho. Mr. Bryan, 38, is a building contractor and a ski instructor in Sun Valley.

title: Ms. Shearman to Marry N. G. Fluehr
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fisher Shearman Jr. of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Nicole Dolores Shearman to Nicholas George Fluehr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David George Fluehr of Carmel, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: On South Africa, U.S. Redefines Its Role for a Time of Transition
description: LISTENING to Nelson Mandela chastising Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last week for deciding to meet with President F. W. de Klerk, it was easy to wonder whether anything had really changed in the debate over American policy toward South Africa.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: World Markets;   Betting the Ranch on Reunification
description: With the victory by a group of conservative parties in East German elections last Sunday seeming to pave the way for a quick reunification of the Germanys, investment strategists are busy picking ''unification plays.''

title: NEW YORK
description: CONTRADICTIONS, YES. CONTROVERSY, NO. IN AJU thimble, that will be the most provocative story from the American fall fashion market. As Seventh Avenue's top designers and manufacturers gear up for the all-important showings that start this week and crescendo the next, it is clear that no dramatic silhouette shifts are in store. Hemlines are staying short (designers showing them mid-thigh, but planning to ship them above the knee); shoulders keep some padding (but only a bit); shorts often replace skirts; dresses become as basic a necessity as skirts, and clothes still delineate the figure (though in a less structured manner). Layering continues to be the most desirable way to dress. No controversy here. The kick will come from the contradictions. For example, designers have become captivated by a pastel palette that conjures up Easter more than it does Labor Day. Fabrics usually associated with daytime, like tweed and flannel, are being cut up for evening wear - or the other way around. Bare dresses that one would think appropriate for night are being shown for day, under coats or jackets. Some of the most interesting outfits mix all these contradictions together.

title: THE DRINK OF MILLIONS
description: New York City plans to add hundreds of millions of gallons daily to its water supply - from the polluted Hudson River (''The Drink of Millions,'' by Elizabeth Kolbert, March 4). The plan relies on the Army Corps of Engineers High Flow Skimming Project.

title: AND NOW BACK TO YOU, BARBARA
description: BARBARA WALTERS

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Douglaston
description: LEAD: THE steepled, colonial-style Zion Episcopal Church on Northern Boulevard in Douglaston and the tree-shaded old churchyard surrounding it could be somewhere in New England, so bucolic is its 12-acre hilltop setting.

title: Campus Life: Vanderbilt;   400 Students Join 3-Week Program On Eating Smart
description: Some 400 Vanderbilt University undergraduates are on a three-week regimen of low-fat, low-sodium and high-fiber foods intended to make them healthier and wiser - and perhaps a trifle wealthier, too.

title: Ms. McLoughlin To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Marianne McLoughlin to John Michael Marquardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Marquardt of Glencoe, Ill., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. McLoughlin of Rye, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: Unsticking a Window
description: WHEN spring presents the opportunity to open a home to the outdoors, owners of double-hung windows often find them stuck tight. Sometimes, the cause is paint applied during a winter remodeling; most of the time, the cause is swelling of wooden window parts because of moisture.

title: Helping Hands For Injured Wildlife
description: Congratulations to Cindy and Joe Bogan for their compassionate aid to wildlife (''Couple's 2d Career Is Caring for Wildlife,'' Feb. 18). Ocean County has its own dedicated wildlife rehabilitators in the persons of Virginia and Arne Andresen of Toms River, who have been restoring the health of all manner of wild creatures for 17 years.

title:
ART;

Paintings of Eros, Photos of Hands
description: LEAD: HAVING expanded to 8,000 feet of exhibition space, the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art at Snug Harbor on Staten Island can give the 10 painters in ''Figuring Eros'' the equivalent of a one-person show each.

title: Easter in Naples: Mangia Bene!
description: THE FOOD OF NAPLES, LIKE THEJU city itself, is at its most exuberant at Easter when this ancient town shakes off the torpor induced by Lent and the gray damp of a Mediterranean winter. Neapolitan cooks are brimming with vitality, turning out feasts with gusto. But the food at Easter feasts throughout the city is far from the pizza and spaghetti with red sauce that most Americans associate with Naples. This is a time when many local cooks revive the aristocratic traditions of a rich, complex past.

title: Everyman Image Was Governor's Asset
description: AFTER more than nine years in office, William A. O'Neill is still often regarded - and will likely be remembered - as the state's accidental Governor, a caretaker who held the office through luck, timing and political skill.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bethel, Me.;   Builders Pay Growth Fees
description: FACED with a rise in tourism and second-home development, officials in this western Maine mountain town are requiring developers to assume many of the public costs of growth. They must help to pay for sewer and road construction and for the hiring of staff to review projects.

title: QUESTIONS, QUESTIONS
description: Will Dave Winfield, Kirk Gibson and Dwight Gooden be ready for the start of the season? Are Carlos Baerga, Eric Anthony and Ben McDonald ready to take their places as major league starters? Do Gary Carter, Dan Quisenberry and Bill Buckner have enough left to warrant being given jobs? Can Rick Aguilera adjust to a pivotal new role? Can Lou Piniella learn enough about his new team and new league to jolt the Cincinnati Reds out of their under-achieving existence?

title: The Green Movement in the Fashion World
description: Saving the planet is very much in vogue. It's also in Harper's Bazaar, Elle and Mademoiselle.

title: On Language;   Tickety-Boo and NASA, Too
description: ENCLOSED IS AN article from The Houston Post of Feb. 12,'' writes Andrew Hero, the kind of specific citator that lexicographers like, ''which uses the expression tickety-boo.''

title: Campus Life: Columbia;   Students Repair Storm Damage At Health Center
description: Thirty-six students from Columbia University and Barnard College spent spring break helping to repair a Methodist health center and camp that was severely damaged by Hurricane Hugo.

title: Cottage Rentals
description: To the Editor: The recent discussion regarding excessive profits by American agencies renting cottages in Britain (Letters on Travel, Jan. 14) prompts us to share a similar experience. We wrote to a series of British rental agencies directly. Several responded promptly with brochures, including one from an agency in Virginia. Clearly, one of the British companies has an arrangement to send all American inquiries to this firm. The brochure has the British address covered with a label from the Virginia firm, and a price list, in dollars, enclosed.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Nanook of Smithtown

title: Li Zhen Is Dead at 83; Chinese Army General
description: Li Zhen, a veteran of the Long March and the first woman to become a general in China, died on March 11, China Daily said today. She was 83 years old.

title: Dreams of Pitching Machines
description: In rented quarters here in a nondescript office park on the northern outskirts of Atlanta, Mickey A. Hall is busy living out his own version of ''Field of Dreams,'' the movie about a farmer who builds a baseball stadium in his cornfields in response to an inner voice.

title: Flying With Film
description: To the Editor: I recently shepherded 100 rolls of 35-millimeter film across more than 25,000 miles of the Far East where our worst enemies were a series of high-powered X-ray machines and a handful of inquisitive baggage examiners. Some machines carried the false assurance: ''X-Ray Safe,'' and every examiner politely and firmly said, ''This machine will not damage your film.'' If I had followed their advice, those cartridges would have tunneled their way through 15 machines.

title: Human Rights Abuses Raising Little Alarm in Peru
description: International organizations increasingly rank this strife-torn Andean nation among the world's violators of human rights.

title: CHINA AND ISRAEL EXCHANGE OFFICES
description: China and Israel have exchanged unofficial liaison offices to coordinate the growing contacts between them, but diplomats and Chinese officials say Beijing is very unlikely to grant diplomatic recognition to Israel anytime soon.

title: WOMEN POSSESSED
description: WOMBS AND ALIEN SPIRITS

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: Absolutely not. College is not an institution where athletes should be paid. They should pay attention to getting good grades and completing school. If it gets that far, why not pay high school athletes? This way by the time they reach college, they can be well off within four years, or less.

title: British Columbia
description: To the Editor: I found it ironic that on the day we were making a 10-hour journey home from Whistler, British Columbia, to New York you published a glowing report on ''Endless Trails in Western Canada'' (Travel, Jan. 21). Our experience was quite different from your reporter's.

title: Knick Playoff Tickets
description: With the Knicks apparently headed for the playoffs, the team has announced details of a postcard lottery to allocate tickets to home games.

title: Review/Dance;   Imago's Divertissements for Blobs, Frogs and Slinkys
description: Three huge blobs and a giant baby took over the stage on March 17at the Triplex Theater I of the Borough of Manhattan Community College. One blob even rolled into the audience and seized a woman's shoe for its dinner. At moments like these, Imago, the Theater Mask Ensemble, was inspired fun that had the audience squealing with laughter.

title: Amy Zuker Marries Dr. S. S. Schwartz
description: Temple Bat Yam in Newport Beach, Calif., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Amy Lyn Zuker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert Zuker of Newport Beach, to Dr. Steven S. Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack W. Schwartz of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Marion Nammack a Bride
description: Marion Paisley Nammack and Richard Stuart Paganello, account executives at Authenticolor, a New York graphics concern, were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York by the Rev. Richard Leonard. Mrs. Paganello, 34 years old, is a daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Griswold Paisley Delacroix Nammack. She is an honors graduate of Vassar College. Mr. Paganello, 36, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paganello of Secaucus, N.J. He graduated from Fairfield University.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There's no question that as far as kids are concerned, parents can be downright embarrassing at times. It's true that some parents manage to scrape by and that some are actually O.K. But generally, in the eyes of most offspring, parents could stand a lot of improvement.

title: Power Plants Face Strike of Reactor Technicians
description: Radiation technicians will go on strike Monday at 38 nuclear power plants that have closed down for refueling, according to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which is seeking recognition as the workers' bargaining agent.

title: A Trip Down Memory Lane in Baldwin
description: RAAY-NOR'S CABIN sits on the south side of Sunrise Highway in Baldwin, a nostalgic reminder of the past. This time capsule of a restaurant, which opened in 1949, shows little evidence of the culinary changes of the last 40 years.

title: T. J. Corcoran to Wed Elizabeth Sargent
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Alexandra Sargent to Theodore John Corcoran, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Corcoran of Somers, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Diana Woods Sargent of Penllyn, Pa., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Hugh Alexander Anderson Sargent of Gywnedd Valley, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE GUIDE
description: VINTAGE QUILTS

title: Building Barriers
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Did You Say Prenuptial Agreement?
description: LEAD: THIS spring, a man's fancy may turn to thoughts of love; a woman's is turning to prenuptial agreements.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington;

'40 Bus Depot As a Lobby
description: LEAD: A FORMER Greyhound terminal built in 1940 is being preserved as a lobby for a 12-story, $200 million, 455,000-square-foot office and retail building. The project is being developed in the East End of the central business district by Manulife Real Estate, a subsidiary of Manulife Financial of Toronto.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: James D. Heslin, Executive, 60
description: James D. Heslin, an executive with the Tishman Construction Corporation for 23 years, died of a heart attack on Thursday at St. Clare's Hospital in New York City. He was 60 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Richard R. Wins by a Nose
description: Richard R. regained the lead from For Really in the final stride of a stretchlong duel to win the $110,800 Bay Shore Stakes by a long nose yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Review/Dance;   'Gloria,' A New Work Set to a Vivaldi Cantata
description: The music was liturgical, but the choreography looked pastoral. Nevertheless, the sacred and the secular harmonized today when the Garden State Ballet offered Peter Anastos's new ''Gloria'' at the Montclair State College Memorial Auditorium.

title: More on Mexico's Debt
description: The complex nature of the debt agreement negotiated between Mexico and its creditor banks last month has led to some confusion regarding its implications for Mexico's economy.

title: Egyptian and Syrian Leaders Meet With Qaddafi in Libya
description: In their first encounter since their countries ended a 12-year rift in December, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today in Libya, the official Libyan news agency said.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: JUDITH GEDIMAN;

Book Tracks the Aftermath of Adoption
description: LEAD: UNTIL recently, adoption in this country was a secretive process. No reliable statistics were even compiled on the number of adoptions in the United States before 1975, when the Federal Government began keeping records. The most commonly accepted estimate is that five million Americans, 2 percent of the population, were adopted.

title: Flood-Control Projects Become an Infrastructure Problem
description: ''EVERYBODY'S insurance was the levee, and it's gone,'' lamented a resident of Elba, Ala., which was largely under water last week after flood waters ripped through the town's 52-year-old levee.

title: SHE, TOO, CONTAINED MULTITUDES
description: LEAD:

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: Idealistically, no. They are amateurs and should be treated as such. Realistically, yes, they should be paid. Perhaps a weekly or monthly stipend determined by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's board for the particular sport in question.

title: Nancy L. Mullins To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry L. Mullins of Lynchburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Lee Mullins to Jonathan Philip Steinberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Steinberg of Westport, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Woman's Honor
description: ''History cannot remember a time when we did not hate our women,'' Gerry Spence, the Wyoming lawyer, wrote in his 1986 book, ''Trial by Fire: The True Story of a Woman's Ordeal at the Hands of the Law.'' He was referring to Miss Wyoming, whom he represented in a libel suit against Penthouse magazine. But he has been expressing similar sentiments about his latest client, Imelda Marcos, the widow of Ferdinand E. Marcos. She was in Manhattan last week for jury selection in her forthcoming trial. Federal prosecutors say the Marcoses, who fled Manila in 1986, stole $168 million from the Philippine Government and, with the help of Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman, hid it in a web of dummy corporations and Manhattan real estate. Mr. Spence is hoping to make Mrs. Marcos, whom he calls ''a small, fragile woman,'' appear as downtrodden as other underdogs he has represented: Andrea Dworkin against Hustler, and the Karen Silkwood family against Kerr-McGee.

title: EMPTINESS RUNS IN THE FAMILY
description: LEAD:

title: THE ODD COUPLE
description: BEAUTY AND THE BEAST

title: Campus Life: Purdue;   The Race Is On To Ready Students For Globalization
description: As more free markets open in Eastern Europe, progress continues on the Pacific rim and Europe moves toward economic unification in 1992, Purdue is striving to keep pace by adopting curriculum changes that will internationalize the outlook and training of its students.

title: Corrections
description: The article ''Adding Up the Costs of Changes at the Top'' in the same issue misidentified the creator of the film ''Railroad Turnbridge.'' It is the work of Richard Serra.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a producer's schedule change, a theater listing and a picture caption on page 45 of the Arts and Leisure section today, about the Off Broadway play ''Neddy,'' are outdated. The play, at the American Place Theater, opens next Sunday, not today.

title: Review/Theater;   Woman's Many Lives In 'El Eterno Femenino'
description: Rosario Castellanos took the title of her play ''El Eterno Femenino'' from Goethe, but nothing else. ''The eternal feminine leads us on,'' the German poet says at the end of ''Faust.'' To the Mexican novelist and poet, this famous tag line was obviously something of a joke, perhaps a bitter one, and her dark comedy supplies a feminist corrective to women's history. But her vision of women's fate might make some feminists uncomfortable.

title: Freud, Though a Genius, Was Also Human;   We Learn From Errors
description: To the Editor:

title: What About Me?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Funds;   A Good Day for Bottom Fishing
description: Skittish investors should stay out of today's ''junk bond'' market. But conditions are ideal for ''bottom fishers,'' the hardy souls with a strong tolerance for risk who scout for bargains in the ruins. And, according to Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser, closed-end funds are the best bargains in today's junk market.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Old Tiffany Building;   A Beleaguered Retail Palace
description: FOR more than 40 years, 401 Fifth Avenue, the old Tiffany Building at 37th Street, has been a notorious object lesson in how not to treat a landmark. Its facade is begrimed, its windows are dirty and storefronts have been shoved into what was once the most elegant selling floor in New York.

title: The Art of Luring Japanese Executives to American Firms
description: American and European corporations are hunting a rare and elusive quarry: the high-level Japanese executive willing to abandon lifetime employment with a Japanese company for speedier advancement and more money at a Western concern.

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: Colleges with major basketball and football programs should be allowed to recruit talented athletes who are academically unqualified and hire them to play their sports. These players would receive salaries, live in apartments off campus, and have four years of eligibility. They would neither attend classes nor earn credits toward degrees. They would be minor league athletes in their sport.

title: FICTION
description: LOOSE JAM. By Wayne Wilson. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Poor Henry Brown. Standing on his redwood porch in yuppified Morro Bay, Calif., this Vietnam veteran, sometime guitarist, record-store manager and reluctant hero of Wayne Wilson's ''Loose Jam'' sees his old Army buddy Miles Duckworth coming right for him. Miles, a one-legged casualty of the war and the 60's, is ''humping along between those crutches like some strung-out apostle with a load of bad news that just couldn't wait.'' The news is that a maniacal veteran, nursing a grudge from the war, has found Miles and wants his blood - and maybe Henry's too. Miles, who once played a mean piano (''the voice of a generation,'' said the album notes), is disgusted by the new life Henry has made for himself in their 15 years apart. So he helps Henry lose his job as ''a flunky for a bunch of . . . suits'' and nearly destroys his house. Henry and Martha, his beloved, are compelled to help Miles escape to Ventura, but the wrathful veteran, known for more than half the book only as the Policy Man, tracks them down for the novel's predictably violent denouement. And, in the process, what might have been a series of bluesy riffs on redemption or reconciliation, or the inevitability of retribution, turns into a plodding arpeggio. In this first novel, the characters mouth cliches that recall the worst excesses of Kerouac, and there is very little that is evocative, insightful or sympathetic. The fractured plot cuts between the here-and-now, the way-back-when and the just-a-few-hours-ago, and coincidences wait in ambush like snipers. But the brief excursions back to Vietnam are diverting, if only because they distract us from the dreariness of Mr. Wilson's boozy, dope-filled New Age California.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: West Regional;   Loyola-U.N.L.V. Game A Clash of Images, Too
description: Some see the West Regional final matchup between Loyola Marymount University and the University of Nevada, Las Vegas here Sunday as classic: the good guys (L.M.U., if you've been following the sports news the last couple weeks) against the bad guys (U.N.L.V., if you've been following the sports news the last few decades).

title: Nancy Ellen Haar and A. F. Buffa Are Married
description: Nancy Ellen Haar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence M. Haar of Port Washington, L.I., was married last evening to Anthony Francis Buffa, a son of Betty M. Buffa of Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., and the late Sebastian A. Buffa. Rabbi Ramie Arian officiated at the Columns in Manhattan.

title: Miss Polk Weds Thomas Donahue
description: The marriage of Terrell Elizabeth Polk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Polk of Lake Charles, La., to Thomas Raymond Donahue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Donahue of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony.

title: Diane Dillworth, Banker, to Wed
description: May wedding plans for Diane E. Dillworth and Richard E. Mayberry Jr. have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Dillworth of Hollis, Queens. Mr. Mayberry is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayberry of Rochester.

title: Peres at an Impasse in Forming Israeli Government
description: After several days of intensive consultations with the small religious parties that could put him in power, the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, has made no visible progress toward obtaining the one vote he needs to form a new Government.

title: Fredricka Shakespeare to Wed in Fall
description: Deborah Shakespeare of Palm Beach, Fla., and Frank Shakespeare of La Jolla, Calif., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Fredricka Stefanie Shakespeare and Mark Scott Manning, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay W. Manning of McFarland, Wis.

title: Figure Skating Gets a Warning
description: To the Sports Editor:

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) The problems of finding your way through life, as depicted in verse and pictures. 3 3 9 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam Dalgitesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 4 5 30 CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy (Putnam, $21.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords. 5 4 9 THE BAD PLACE by Dean R. Koontz (Putnam, $10.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes and consequences of his behavior. 6 7 4 BITTER SWEET by LaVyrie Spencer. (Putnam, $18.95.) A widow's ordeal after meeting her high school flame, now a less than happily married man. 7 6 3 THE SCIONS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Plan for New Tax In Canada Irks Tour Companies

title: Susan Brown and Brian Haumersen Plan to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Harman Brown Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Susan Harman Brown and Brian Wilfred Haumersen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Haumersen of Cambridge, Md.

title: School Takeover: Gentle Words, Tough Action
description: FIVE months into the nation's first complete state takeover of a public school system, Dr. Elena J. Scambio, the state-appointed Superintendent in Jersey City, is trying to combine the big stick with a soft touch as she seeks to lift the city's educational system from the morass it has floundered in for years.

title: Hospitalized Children Fight Fear With Play
description: LEAD: IN a colorful self-portrait drawn just a few minutes before she received one of the first liver transplants performed at Yale-New Haven Hospital, an 8-year-old girl carefully detailed the purple barrettes in her ponytails and the butterfly embroidered on the front of her favorite red dress. But she left out her arms and legs.

title: Matching the Handicapped With Jobs
description: MATTHEW MURPHY, a 24-year-old a page at the Scarsdale Library, recently bought a bicycle with his own money. ''He is so proud of it,'' said his mother, Helen F. Murphy. ''His wheels have made him even more independent. And knowing that he earned the money himself gives him such satisfaction.''

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Women's N.C.A.A.;   Victory for Virginia
description: Dawn Staley scored 6 of Virginia's 9 overtime points as the Cavaliers beat Tennessee today, 79-75, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I East Regional final.

title: Data Bank/March 25, 1990
Thai Wants Cambodia Refugees in Neutral Camps
description: The Thai Prime Minister has proposed moving about 276,000 displaced Cambodians from existing border camps to neutral ones free of political control by the warring Cambodian factions.

title: INSIDE
description: An Wang Is Dead at 70

title: Joanne Zaiac Becomes Bride
description: Joanne Zaiac, a management supervisor at Wunderman Worldwide, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam in New York, was married last evening to Robert D. Coven, an associate at Paine Webber in New York. Rabbi Gary Glickstein officiated at Temple Beth Sholom in Miami Beach. The bride, who is 28 years old and will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Zaiac of Bay Harbor, Fla. She is a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard University. Mr. Coven, 32, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Coven of Worcester, Mass. A graduate of the University of Michigan, he received an M.B.A. from Syracuse University.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: State Tries to Halt Garbage Growth
description: LEAD: STATE officials say they want to reduce the piles of garbage Connecticut residents generate. But as the production of garbage keeps increasing, officials say, a proposed package of legislation, regional planning and education is intended to keep the amount of refuse at current levels.

title: When Developers Fail To Complete Projects
description: THE early buyers in new suburban housing developments usually look forward to the day when construction stops and the bulldozers are silent. But for more and more new homeowners these days, the silence may signal the developer's default on the project, leaving them to worry about paving the roads, paying for the sewers and installing the tennis courts.

title: Latin Drug Cartels, Squeezed, Are Turning to Ecuador
description: As other Latin American countries clamp down on illicit narcotics, Ecuador is emerging as an important shipment point both for importing chemicals needed to produce cocaine and for exporting the drug itself to the United States, Federal officials say.

title: Elizabeth P. Guest, 79, A Patron of the Arts
description: Elizabeth Polk Guest, a patron of classical music in New York and Washington, died of a heart attack on Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was 79 years old and lived in Islesboro, Maine, and Front Royal, Va.

title: Tokyo's Bubble Bursts With A Vengeance
description: ''This has the feel,'' said the man from Nikko Securities, ''of a bubble being burst.''

title: AN ISLAND In LIMBO
description: As Puerto Rico's only United States Representative, I closely read your article on Puerto Rico's political status. The issue is as complicated and many-layered as Alan Weisman tries to present in his piece, but a few of his observations provoke raised eyebrows among the veterans of this debate over statehood, independence or commonwealth (which I favor).

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: College athletes should be paid; too many of them spend years of their lives entertaining the public without ever receiving the lucre now associated with a professional career. However, unlike the pros, all college athletes should be paid the exact same wage, whether they are starting centers or benchwarmers. In addition, every college league should have a draft in order to eliminate the illegal competition for talent, and scholarships should be for six years (four years of half-time attendance while playing and two years of full-time attendance which can be cashed-in even after a professional career).

title: Wall Street;   Another Way to Find 'Sell' Signals
description: As if enough unpleasantries were not already associated with the month of April - showers, taxes and fools - a stock market forecaster in Chicago has added another: losses.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: EMILY GIANNATTASIO;

When the Patient Is Dying at Home
description: LEAD: IN early 1989 when the White Plains Hospital Center asked the state to certify its existing hospice program, other hospices opposed the request, arguing that the hospital's hospice was not needed and that they could better meet the needs of terminally ill patients who wished to die at home.

title: THEREFORE CHOOSE LIFE, NOT ROBOTS
description: LEAD:

title: Review/Dance;   Somber Choreography In Morningside Festival
description: The fifth annual Morningside Dance Festival got off to a briskly produced start on Tuesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The weeklong festival, presented by the Department of the Arts in Education at Teachers College of Columbia University, opened with eight works that stressed the virtues of solid craft and literate themes.

title: Casinos Seek Answers to Scarcity of Employees
description: LEAD: FACED with a tight labor market, casino officials say they are finding it increasingly difficult to fill a shortage of workers for service-oriented jobs like cashier, security guard and food preparer. They say their inability to fill such jobs threatens the continued growth of the multibillion-dollar industry.

title: Democrats Wonder About the Campaign
description: HEBRON'S Democratic chairman, Robert McKay, arrived early for the party's town committee meeting at Town Hall on Tuesday evening to turn on the lights and set up the metal chairs. He unfolded a few extra, he said, because this was the meeting to pick delegates to the state nominating convention in July.

title: Ruth Margot Wharton to Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Lennard Wharton of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ruth Margot Wharton to Stephen J. McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. McDonald of Canton, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Terrorism: New Targets
description: Now the terrorists of the Middle East are threatening to bomb the planes and airports of some of the countries that supplied them with explosives and guns for so long - the Soviet Union and its recent satellites in Eastern Europe.

title: Exiled to Alma-Ata
description: Stalin's dictatorship was not so loose as to allow the world-renowned Trotsky, whose visage was known to tens of millions of Russians, to move about the country and then ''flee'' to Mexico.

title: Gray Hairs and Creaky Limbs: Benchmarks of Aging
description: AT first I blame the bed for my morning stiffness, for the pain in my lower back. The bed is old, the mattress soft. The box spring broke when we moved into this house several years ago. ''It's got to be the bed; look how long we've had it,'' I say to my wife.

title: Agreement Ends Strike At 11 Hawaiian Hotels
description: The strike by workers at 11 Hawaii hotels ended today when the sides agreed to a tentative five-year contract that will achieve pay parity with hotel workers on the mainland, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions on page 31 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about historic recordings, are reversed. The picture at the top right shows Ferruccio Busoni; the one next to it shows Alfred Cortot.

title: Jesse Jackson's 'Stunning Victory'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music;   An Assortment for Oboe
description: Thomas Gallant, a young oboist, has had a worthy career championing new music and other frontiers of his instrument's repertory, and he put together a piquant assortment of mostly marginalia for his program on Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall. But it proved a self-effacing showcase for his own talents.

title: Berlin
description: To the Editor: I was shocked at the use of the word schizophrenia regarding a divided Berlin (Travel, Feb. 25). Multiple personality disorder would be the correct phrase - several different personalities.

title: Lifestyle;   U.S. Students Are Heading East for 'Piece of the Wall'
description: Laurel Watts, a student at Brown University, grew up believing that Communism was a ''done deal.'' Now that the regimes are unraveling, she wants to see what is going on, especially among her counterparts. ''They're a curiosity to us because they're the people we weren't supposed to meet,'' she said.

title: April Ann Oliver, Reporter, Is Wed
description: April Ann Oliver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wade Hampton Oliver of Columbia, S.C., was married yesterday to Dr. Jay Jeffrey Schulkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schulkin of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Robert C. Neville, a Methodist minister and the dean of the Boston University Divinity School, performed the ceremony at the chapel of Princeton University in Princeton, N.J.

title: The Accuracy Rate In Machine Translation
description: Peter Wheeler's recent letter to the New Jersey editor in response to my interview on machine translation seems to miss certain points. First, I was not talking about how to run a translation service business. I was talking about fully automatic high-quality machine translation systems.

title: James A. Kloiber Marries Stephanie Anne Wagoner
description: Stephanie Anne Wagoner, the daughter of Geraldine C. Wagoner of Mahwah, N.J., and the Rev. Roy W. Wagoner of Bergenfield, N.J., was married yesterday to James Allen Kloiber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Kloiber of Fort Atkinson, Wis. The Rev. James Steele officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: Retelling a Psychopathic Killer's Tale Is No Joke
description: It was well past midnight as police cruisers and ambulances converged, screeched to a halt and disgorged dozens of paramedics and police SWAT teams in front of the Allegheny County Soldiers and Sailors War Memorial Hall on Fifth Avenue. High drama turned into low comedy when a paramedic knocked over a stretcher, a cop had an unmanly struggle getting out of a cruiser and another cop's gun belt fell off.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Castro, Piqued, Says Quayle Is 'a Dandy'
description: President Fidel Castro has rejected a critical comment by Vice President Dan Quayle about the Cuban leader's military dress. ''These are my clothes and I'm going to carry on wearing them while I have them,'' Mr. Castro said at a news conference in Havana on Friday night.

title: What Should Schools Teach About Vietnam?
description: LEAD: ''THE biggest problem I have when I walk into a classroom is that kids wonder why I don't have a bandana, tattoos all over me and carry a giant knife.

title: Tech Notes;   Using Lasers to Repair a Cornea
description: A two-year-old company, Phoenix Lasers Systems Inc., in San Francisco, has applied laser techniques developed for the military to ophthalmic surgery. The new system combines a low-energy blue-green laser with a computer workstation. The system is employed in the surgical technique called refractive keraplasty, which is used to alter the shape of the cornea to repair vision impairments, including near- and far-sightedness and glaucoma. The laser tracking system, which was developed for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars,'' is capable of focusing on areas of the cornea as small as a single cell. The laser can ionize unwanted corneal tissue. Or it can project a three-dimensional image onto the workstation monitor so the surgeon can plan each incision before the operation begins and track the incisions throughout the procedure.

title: WELCOME TO THE LOWER DEPTHS
description: FOREPLAY

title: SCHUYLERVILLE STANDS STILL;
description: A FEW YEARS AGO I BOUGHT AN OLD house in a village named Schuylerville, 30 miles north of Albany, on the Hudson River. I'd gotten priced out of the rental market in nearby Saratoga Springs, which was awash with prosperity and tourists, and Schuylerville was full of real estate ''bargains.'' Nestled beneath steep hills running down to the riverbank, it was a sad-looking town, clearly fallen on hard times. Many of the storefronts were vacant, with dusty ''for sale'' signs taped in the windows. The surviving business establishments included a tattoo parlor, a liquor store and a shop that sold dented cans of food at cut-rate prices.

title: Loss of State Subsidies Threatens 3 Bus Lines
description: THREE small bus lines, serving 7,000 riders a month in the Danbury, Middletown and Windham areas, could stop running as early as June 30, unless the state agrees to pay about $238,000 a year in subsidies to keep them going.

title: Wendy Akins Engaged To Jonathan Doniger
description: Wendy M. Akins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Akins of Alta Dena, Calif., and Jonathan D. Doniger, a son of Audrey C. Doniger of Westport, Conn., and Alan F. Doniger of New York, are planning a May wedding.

title: In re: Marketing Parameters For Great American Novel
description: JAMES MICHENER has said that books are a ''marvelous instrument of civilization,'' imbued with the power ''to monitor and give guidance to nations.'' Harry Hoffman, chief executive of Waldenbooks, the largest American bookstore chain, recently asserted that books are often ill-conceived products that are filled with too many pages and too much small print to be able to ''counter things like Nintendo and television.''

title: Outdoors;   Disagreement on Striped Bass
description: There is considerable disagreement among biologists and anglers over whether Atlantic coast stocks of Atlantic striped bass have recovered sufficiently to allow more harvesting by sport and commercial interests in the coming season.

title: For Dating Outside Gang, Penalty Was to Be Death
description: A band of youths who call themselves the Legion of Doom mandated the death penalty for members who dated outside the group, and they tried to carry out the sentence on an 18-year-old member, the police charge.

title: Charles Smyth, 94; Chemistry Professor Worked on A-Bomb
description: Charles P. Smyth, a chemist on the Princeton University faculty for more than 40 years, died on March 18 at his home in Bozeman, Mont. He was 94 years old.

title: THE AGING HOOPSTER
description: I am responding to Darren Kazimir's letter analyzing the basketball skills of those ''older guys'' (About Men: ''What Do You Call an Aging Hoopster,'' by Erich Rupprecht, Feb. 4). As the wife of a 41-year-old die-hard lunch-hour basketball player, I see my husband as a competitive sportsman with a fervor for basketball bordering on a religious experience. He loves the camaraderie on court. He loves to sweat, and to stay in shape. Of course he knows that he doesn't play like he did on his high school team, but that's not the point. He good-naturedly shows me his black and blue thighs, scraped nose and jammed fingers. If he has thrown an elbow or tripped someone on the way to a layup, it is attributed to overzealousness, not overcompensating for his lost abilities. He's the first to admit to being a klutz out there, but he loves the game and that's all that matters.

title: Boston
description: To the Editor: I was most surprised to read that visitors to Boston are advised to call the Boston Garden for information on tickets for Celtics games (''What's Doing in Boston,'' Travel, Jan. 7). One has as much chance of obtaining Celtics tickets from the Garden box office as winning the lottery. Boston is a sports crazy city, and the few available Celtics tickets that are not owned by season ticket holders are sold only in the fall before the season begins and attract very, very long lines of hopeful fans. Boston is a great place to visit, but unless you have friends in high places, forget about seeing the Celtics when you're here.

title: Negligent But No Worse
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood was by himself before the jurors, and perhaps that helped him. In the end, they did not hold him responsible for the Exxon Valdez spill last year, though he was convicted of a misdemeanor and sentenced to pay $50,000 and spend 1,000 hours cleaning oil-stained beaches.

title: How Cable TV Is Like Con Ed and the Post Office
description: FROM Manhattan, where television signals can't leap tall buildings in a single bound, to Manhattan, Kan., people cannot live without cable television. But much as they love it, some viewers love to hate it, too.

title: Miss Howland, Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rushton W. Skakel of Greenwich, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced October wedding plans for Mrs. Skakel's daughter Elizabeth Marion Howland and Robert E. Mallozzi 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mallozzi of Darien, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: A successful sports program can be a university's foremost attraction when it comes to recruiting students, not just athletes but eggheads such as myself. While at the University of North Carolina, I carried out my plan to have a double major: English and basketball attendance. Student athletes are a useful commodity, they bring exposure and revenue to colleges. Meanwhile, studying, practices, and travel allow no time for earning a salary at a real job. Pay student athletes respect and pay them money.

title: Just Say No Mustard
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has had commissioners leave state service for the private sector before, but Julio A. Martinez will be the first to turn up under the Governor's second-floor window at the State Capitol in Albany selling hot dogs, knishes and soda. Mr. Martinez, a former heroin addict who was often described as ''inspiring'' by Mr. Cuomo, was pressured into resigning as the state commissioner of drug treatment in December after an investigation found that drug-treatment money he had steered to programs run by his friends failed to treat anybody. Mr. Martinez, who denies the accusations, said last week that he had obtained his vendor's permit for a spot on the sidewalk next to the Capitol and will open his hot dog cart for business tomorrow. The former commissioner, who now calls himself ''the knishener,'' said he just wanted to sell hot dogs and was not trying to annoy the Governor. Mr. Cuomo, he said, is still one of his heroes. ''He's always talking about how his mother and pop ran a grocery store,'' Mr. Martinez said of the Governor. ''What's the shame in me selling hot dogs?''

title: Mexico and Chile Renew Ties
description: Chile and Mexico renewed diplomatic relations on Friday, more than 15 years after they were broken by Mexico in protest over the military coup that ousted President Salvador Allende Gossens. A ceremony here marking the restoration of relations was attended by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and his Chilean counterpart, Patricio Aylwin.

title: Corrections
description: The Record Notes column last Sunday misidentified the company for which Daniel Barenboim recorded Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations. The label is Erato.

title: In the Tombs of the Etruscans
description: A SLIGHT rush of musty, stone-cooled air wafts through the opening as the guide pockets his key and steps into the dark behind the door. He flicks on a feeble light to illuminate a narrow stairway leading down into the tomb, and motions for us to descend.

title: From a Dark Convoy, Stalin's Specter Looms
description: When Povilas Zavadskas arose and saw the tanks go by his front window at 4 o'clock this morning, all the shadowy appeal to memory that is at the heart of Lithuania's struggle for sovereignty was before him.

title: Coslet Sets Tone: Tough Yet Tough
description: No loitering, no talking, no negativism. But have fun, guys.

title: The Fine Art Of Disappearing Into a Role
description: Sit in a room long enough with Margaret Tyzack and sooner or later, as at that fabled Parisian cafe, everyone you know will pass by. Miss Tyzack, who opens with Maggie Smith in Peter Shaffer's ''Lettice and Lovage'' this evening on Broadway at the Barrymore, is a natural chameleon, with a temperament so mercurial that she seems, as she talks, to take on a new persona with each thought. It would probably be impossible to see Miss Smith in a play or movie - or, for that matter, the subway - without realizing who she was; there is something about Maggie Smith that announces itself. But it would be quite easy to watch Miss Tyzack in a riveting solo performance one night and fail to recognize her at breakfast the next day. In fact, throughout much of her career it has been a point of pride with her to ''disappear'' into her roles.

title: Democrats Approve Rules To Allow Earlier Primaries
description: The Democratic Party today approved the rules under which it will pick its 1992 Presidential candidate, and did so with a speed and civility that was almost breathtaking to party leaders who lived through the fierce squabbles of the last two decades.

title: Daily Doses of Affection for Newborns
description: Babies born too soon, too small and too sick are given a fighting chance in the neonatal unit at University Hospital here. The infants' emotional growth often rests in the arms of volunteers who have nothing to give but their love.

title: Style Makers;   Lynda Sandhaus, Artist
description: They came to New York from Israel a year and a half ago. She was planning to pursue her painting, he was thinking of ''spending some time in Central Park enjoying his life.'' But somehow, Lynda and Shimon Sandhaus's big adventure took an unexpected turn. The couple started a business of reproducing fragments of Mrs. Sandhaus's paintings and drawings on a collection of stationery items - folders, notebooks, diaries, wrapping paper, pencils and storage boxes.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Golf on Saturday, but Not for Women
description: LEAD: WOMEN have come a long way. They are police officers, doctors, lawyers, members of the executive suite. Some fraternal organizations welcome them. The New York Athletic Club accepts them, and even Princeton eating clubs must allow them to dine with their fellow students.

title: Poison Gas Laws: Still Leaking
description: When Libya's poison-gas plant burned down last week, many people were relieved. Instead, they should have been horrified - just as they were by the recent revelations that Czechoslovakia's ousted Communist Government had shipped 1,000 tons of lethal Semtex explosives to Libya.

title:
DINING OUT;

Taste and Mood of Spain in White Plains
description: LEAD: FOR 15 years, the white-plastered Moorish facade of Meson Castellano has welcomed diners to the some of the pleasures of Spanish-Continental dining. Inside, a dark wooden partition partly screens the cozy bar from the dining area and lends an exotic Spanish moodiness, borne out further in the many folksy and charming pitchers, plates and tiles that decorate the room.

title: Softer Line
description: Roman Catholic leaders have been talking as if being a little bit against abortion is like being a little bit pregnant. But Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago says reasonable minds, or at least politicians' minds, can differ on the subject. Even while Catholic officeholders are more or less obligated to oppose abortion, he said, they should not have to fear punishment for disagreeing on how to do that. Cardinal Bernardin did not name names, but Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has been given a hard time by his Archbishop, John Cardinal O'Connor, and by Auxiliary Bishop Austin Vaughan, who said Mr. Cuomo was in danger of going to hell for being soft on abortion. Cardinal Bernardin spoke just after Guam adopted the strictest abortion law in the nation and two days before the Idaho Legislature approved a similar bill. Since neither claimed to be constitutional, the next group to face the issue will probably be wearing black robes.

title: Men, Women and China
description: To the Editor:

title: Meg MacDonald, News Anchor, Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret A. W. MacDonald, a news anchor at WSOC-TV in Charlotte, N.C., and M. Duncan Grant, a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Pepper, Hamilton & Scheetz, were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Church of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Robert Doss performed the ceremony.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Prune rose of Sharon, large-flowered hydrangea, buddleia and other shrubs that will flower on this year's growth. Apply general garden fertilizer to trees and shrubs; wait to uncover perennials. Use a spading fork to turn the compost pile. Prune roses. Rake up winter debris from the lawn and use a calibrated spreader to apply lime and fertilizer. Indoors, transplant seedlings to individual pots; if growing them under lights use water-soluble fertilizer at one-quarter rate.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on March 18 about a horse cooperative in South Salem, N.Y., incorrectly described its rings. There will be four indoors and one outdoors.

title: UConn Eliminated at Buzzer in Overtime
description: The University of Connecticut's basketball season of a lifetime ended suddenly this afternoon with the same type of buzzer-beating shot that two nights before had extended it.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lisa K. Guglielmone and Frederick J. Gillis Marry
description: The marriage of Lisa Kathleen Guglielmone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tito W. Guglielmone of Oakdale, L.I., to Frederick Joseph Gillis, a son of Miriam Gillis of Port Charlotte, Fla., and the late Judge Joseph A. Gillis of Detroit, took place yesterday at St. John Nepomucene Roman Catholic Church in Bohemia, L.I. The Rev. Robert E. Guglielmone, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Scary To Contemplate
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Interns Get a Taste of Business
description: LEAD: IN Robert Leiterman's classes at Brentwood High School, the students are learning about cookies: not how to make them, but how to improve marketing strategies to increase sales.

title: THE GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: How 'Strykeforce' Beat the Clock
description: It began with a half-dozen ''toolies'' fastened on a dream. There was the understanding they would be set free of the ''mucky-mucks.'' And the inspirational spirit was a plucky man named James D. Stryker, whom colleagues call the Strykeforce, as if he were a comic-strip superhero of business.

title: In a Turnabout From Trial of North, Poindexter Prosecutor Seizes Drama
description: It was with the greatest of patience that Dan K. Webb, the prosecutor in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter, began questioning his first witness, Oliver L. North.

title: While Land Prices in Japan Soar, Officials Fight Back With Words
description: Each of the last four years, the Government of Japan has declared a well-publicized war on this country's astronomical and still-rising land prices, the world's highest. But despite the strong oratory, the soldiers in the war never seem to leave their barracks.

title: WATER GONE, BUT SHOCK LINGERS
description: There are still people in Elba, Ala., who remember March 14, 1929, when flood waters from the Pea River inundated the small southeastern Alabama community, almost wiping it off the map. But once the 3.2-mile-long levee surrounding the town was built in 1938, no one ever expected to see that kind of devastation again.

title: The Modernist Who Dared to Be a Romantic
description: One could argue that modernism, for all its art-for-art's-sake veneer, is at heart Romantic. Painters like Piet Mondrian, sculptors like Constantin Brancusi and photographers like Alfred Stieglitz all wanted to get to a spiritual dimension with their pared-down forms, and they relied on inner sensibility as their means of discovery. Yet few respected 20th-century artists have dared to be conventionally Romantic in terms of subject matter and style. One curious exception is the Czechoslovak photographer Josef Sudek.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Memories of a Cold War Childhood
description: LEAD: I WAS 10 years old when I read the headline in bold black letters across the evening paper: ''Khrushchev - War or Peace?'' I was frightened. I remember bringing the paper to my mother and asking her if there was going to be a war. She told me I was too young to worry about such things.

title: POSTINGS: Nyack Condos;   20 Units, 5 Shops Downtown
description: ''It's going to be very artsy-craftsy,'' is the way John H. Lese describes a condominium project he has started in the center of the Hudson River village of Nyack, N.Y. The 20 two-story town houses and five shops are in four Victorian-style buildings that Mr. Lese says are being designed with projecting bays, wide board fascias and trim, and clapboard and brick finishes to ape some of the village's older buildings. Mr. Lese, from Port Chester, N.Y., says he is blatantly seeking to play off the heritage of a town in which the Art, Craft and Antiques Dealers Association sponsors street fairs several times a year. The 27,000-square-foot project was designed by John Sullivan Architects of Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: To Be Young in France
description: To the Editor:

title: JULIAN BREAM SETS OFF IN A NEW (OLD) DIRECTION
description: ''I'm all for change and variety,'' says the guitarist and lutenist Julian Bream. ''Your experience of life is to a large part distilled into your performing. As you grow older, you concentrate on aspects of music that you perhaps only touched on earlier.''

title: Freud, Though a Genius, Was Also Human;   Nothing Has Improved
description: To the Editor:

title: Ewing's 51 Points Aren't Enough
description: As Patrick Ewing sat in front of his locker last night, the 7-foot center must have been asking himself, ''How much more can I do?''

title: Nascar Limits Test Sessions
description: In an effort to control costs, keep sponsors in Winston Cup racing and prevent the best-financed teams from taking over, Nascar has put a limit on private test sessions.

title: A View of Edith, Eternal Child, Octogenarian Snow Angel
description: ''I BURIED three husbands,'' she told me. ''I don't think I have the energy for another one.''

title: Dr. Sylvia R. Kodsi to Wed Dr. Michael E. Rettig
description: Dr. Sylvia R. Kodsi, a resident in ophthalmology at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York, and Dr. Michael E. Rettig, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the New York University Medical Center, plan a May wedding.

title: Deedee Rodolitz Is Married to Alan J. Ransenberg
description: At Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Diane L. Rodolitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Rodolitz of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening to Alan J. Ransenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Ransenberg of Skokie, Ill. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal and Cantor Tibor Kelen officiated.

title: Cinema Studio To Close Doors After 30 Years
description: Cinema Studio, a small two-screen movie house near Lincoln Center that has attracted a loyal following with a mix of foreign and offbeat first-run films for 30 years, will close its doors soon - perhaps as early as Thursday.

title: Boy, 14, Held in 6 Sex Attacks
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was in custody yesterday on charges that he raped or sexually abused six girls, aged 9 to 17, often in hallways or elevators or on rooftops in the Brownsville section, the police said.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: HYPERION (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95; Spectra/Bantam, Paper, $4.95) and THE FALL OF HYPERION (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95) by Dan Simmons make up a single thousand-page novel about the last days of a vibrant yet self-destructive galactic civilization called the Hegemony. If the Hegemony is doomed, it is because, in exchange for the knowledge needed to conquer the stars, the human species has sold its soul to a hive of machine-based intelligences known as the Technocore. If there is any hope for human redemption, it is to be found on the planet Hyperion.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving. We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood. We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves. Can you offer some pointers?

title: Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
description: I realize that colleges are making a lot of money from these athletes but the opportunity for an education, when used wisely, is far more beneficial. The scholarship for an education should be the real prize. Money and the chance to play in the big leagues has become the creed of too many young athletes. Giving huge sums of money now will only perpetuate the belief that money is the only motivating factor.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'TWO TRAINS RUNNING'

title: Miss Slayback to Wed Gary J. Sikora in May
description: Judith Lynn Slayback, an electrical engineer, and Gary Joseph Sikora, a senior engineer, both at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in Baltimore, are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Russell Slayback of Greens Farms, Conn., have announced. Mr. Sikora is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sikora of West Mifflin, Pa.

Groupe T.C.G.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $3,589,000, or 26 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hazard Sign for Soviets As the Ukraine Wavers
description: If President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is alert to the omens of his decomposing realm, he may have noticed the strong election-day showing of Genrikh O. Altunyan and Yegor I. Kravtsiv, two former political prisoners who campaigned in Kharkov on a platform of full independence for the Ukraine.

title: JHM Mortgage Securities LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-earlier results are for the period from start of operations on Oct. 28, 1988.

title: Battling Back
description: THE Citadel baseball team has a half-destroyed home field, an almost unplayable practice field and one professional prospect. The military college in Columbia, S.C., also has the longest active N.C.A.A. Division I winning streak.

title: British Debate Bill Covering Emigres' War Crimes
description: Parliament is heatedly debating whether to allow the prosecution of British residents accused of committing Nazi war crimes in the Baltics, Byelorussia and the Ukraine.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,232,000 for the quarter and $3,734,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,242,000 and $6,114,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $427,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,722,000, or 87 cents a share, for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CONTRAS SAY MOST WILL NOT DISBAND
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders, who last week announced their agreement to demobilize, said today that most of their forces would not be disbanded in the next few weeks. Instead, they said, most contra fighters will remain in enclaves inside Nicaragua with their weapons for months after the inauguration of the country's new President, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sound Bites Have Teeth
description: There is hardly a political discussion today regarding the Federal budget that does not make some reference to George Bush's lips. The sound bite that opened doors for Candidate Bush now leaves President Bush little room to maneuver.

title: Reviews/Music;   Symphony Space Offers A Full Day of Gershwin
description: Symphony Space offered its first free daylong Wall-to-Wall concert in 1978 to celebrate the conversion of the abandoned movie theater into a concert hall. Having devoted full days to composers ranging from Bach to Cage, Symphony Space added George Gershwin to its list on Saturday, when it made him the subject of its 20th Wall-to-Wall marathon. The concert began at 11 A.M. and ran through 10:30 P.M. Most of it was broadcast live by WNYC-FM.

title: Hadson Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said in the fourth quarter of 1989 its Defense System Group recorded a provision of $10 million for an anticipated loss on a fixed- price development contract. The total loss provision recorded in 1989 related to this contract amounted to $14,700,000.

title: Bethel Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months' net income figures reflected a writeoff of an investment of $48,000.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Four Winding Lines to View Pictures and Get an Answer
description: Inside Public School 67, police officers kept order as hundreds of people arrived in clusters to learn the whereabouts of missing friends and relatives. The crowd was organized in four lines, starting at an entrance at 179th Street and Honeywell Avenue, going through a dining hall and lobby, and ending in a room where only one family or group of friends at a time viewed pictures.

description: The year-ago quarter was accounted for on a liquidation basis. The company has subsequently decided not to liquidate.

title: Al Sears, 80, Arranger And Saxophonist, Dies
description: Al Sears, a tenor saxophonist in major jazz bands and an original swing arranger whose own band toured American Army camps in World War II, died of lung cancer on Friday at his home in St. Albans, Queens. He was 80 years old.

title: Survivors of Bering Sea Sinking Heard No Alarm
description: Survivors of a vessel that listed and quickly sank in the Bering Sea say an alarm failed to sound and may have cost some of the nine missing crewmen their lives, an investigator said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Freedom in a Locked Ward in Vilnius
description: At midnight the scene at the city psychiatric hospital seemed a microcosm of the state of Lithuanian independence.

title: Anne Gugler, 87, Dies; An Actress and Dancer
description: Anne Tonetti Gugler, a Broadway actress and dancer who was a founding resident of an enclave of actors and artists in Rockland County, died of cardiac arrest on Thursday at her home in Orangetown, N.Y. She was 87 years old.

title: 38 Illegals Detained in Ohio
description: Police stopped a rental truck near here Saturday and found 38 illegal aliens hiding inside. The aliens, all men, were sent back to Mexico by airplane. The police in Cleveland were lead to the truck by a report from a resident in Chardon, 24 miles northeast of Cleveland, who said that it had appeared in the village early Saturday with men acting suspiciously.

title: The Living Search the Faces of the Dead
description: Jerome Ford stared at the photographs spread on the table at Public School 67 in the Bronx yesterday. He recognized five faces: his wife's three brothers, a teen-age niece and a cousin. He realized what the photographs meant: the five had been trapped when an illegal social club was transformed from an oasis of dancing and drinking into an inferno.

title: Reviews/Music;   A Pianist Juxtaposes Charles Ives and Art Tatum
description: Steven Mayer's piano recital Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall was devoted to two innovative American composers of the first half of the 20th century. The fare consisted of about 40 minutes of music from each: the ''Concord'' Sonata of Charles Ives and 11 solos of Art Tatum.

title: Spring Tryout Season Gives New Shows Time to Bloom
description: So far, everyone has resisted calling it spring cleaning or spring training, but what will take place on television over the next several weeks is likely to establish a spring tradition for the broadcast networks.

title: Officer at Russ Berrie Given President's Post
description: Stuffed animals. Ceramic mugs. Key rings. Picture frames. All these are called variety impulse gifts and are the province of Russ Berrie & Company, which has named a new president and chief operating officer, A. Curts Cooke.

title: Shift by Carnation
description: The Carnation Company has shifted all of its pet food advertising, which had been mostly at Lintas in New York, to other Interpublic Group agencies in Los Angeles, where Carnation is based. Dailey & Associates will get Friskies dry cat food, Friskies Buffet canned cat food, and the Grand Gourmet and Mighty Dog canned dog foods. McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles will handle Fancy Feast canned cat food. The pet food accounts bill an estimated $20 million.

title: Pressure On the Fed Increasing
description: The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee is probably not going to approve a change in monetary policy when it meets tomorrow in Washington. But a growing number of analysts say the central bank may now be leaning toward its first tightening of policy in nearly a year.

description: The voice at the other end of the phone sounded calm and unconcerned. Pascual Perez said not to worry, he would be in camp soon, he would be ready to pitch and he was eager to join his new Yankee teammates.

title: Business Scene;   Global Strategies Vs. National Ties
description: FOR many American manufacturers, putting factories abroad - going global - is a top priority. They are learning to be as much at home in Europe and Asia as they are in the United States, and in the process they are redefining the meaning of ''home country.'' Having one is still important, it seems, but not in the old sense of the phrase.

title: At the Garden, Players Face a Calamity on Ice
description: JAMES PATRICK, headed to the locker room after the first period of a game in Hartford on Nov. 18, could not figure out why the official from the Madison Square Garden Network was standing there motioning to him. After all, Patrick, a talented defenseman for the Rangers, had already taped an interview before the start of the game.

title: Struthers Wells reports earnings for Year Nov 30
description: b-Net income and included a $152,000 tax loss carryforward.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Fancy Footwork Wherein Lurks Meaning
description: When two choreographers share an evening, the result is not necessarily a varied program. That was demonstrated Thursday night when the Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company of Union, N.J., and the Manhattan-based Sue Bernhard Dance Works performed as part of the Fifth Annual Morningside Dance Festival at the Theater of the Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue (between 120th and 121st Streets).

title: Fighting Resumes in Lebanon
description: Hundreds of artillery shells rained down on most parts of the Christian enclave here today as fighting resumed between rival Christian forces, virtually shattering a cease-fire that began early this month.

title: Monarch Avalon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Dance;   Merce Cunningham's Way With a Mood
description: The world of Merce Cunningham's ''Shards,'' performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Friday at the City Center, seems timeless and immutable until the surprise of its final moments. The eight dancers, clad in simple, dull green and black leotards and tights, might almost be fish hovering in still waters made dim by William Anastasi's lighting and his earth-colored, scrawled backdrop. David Tudor's contemplative electronic score brings an extra sense of privacy to this hushed and quiet world.

title: The Century's Worst Fires
description: Following are some of the worst building fires, in terms of lives lost, in the United States and its possessions since 1900.

title: Fans of Rushing Rivers Gather
description: GLOBAL warming might melt glaciers and threaten the environment, but a different type of global warmth attracted a contingent of 75 Russians and participants from more than 30 other countries to take part in the Nantahala '90 Rally, a 12-day whitewater rafting event that ended today at the Nantahala Outdoor Center (N.O.C.) in western North Carolina.

title: Stewart & Stevenson Servces Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Reporter's Notebook;   The Diplomat Dances Away From Trouble
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d found himself caught the other day in what was, for him, a difficult choice: a chat with either the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, or the recent Democratic Party presidential aspirant, Jesse Jackson. Mr. Baker opted for Mr. Jackson. The awkward moment unfolded at midnight on Wednesday as Mr. Baker and other world leaders crammed into the reviewing stand in Windhoek to watch Namibia become independent.

title: The Best Day of the Year
description: IT was a year ago next Saturday that we were standing around the dome in Seattle, (I never can get the names of all those caverns straight), waiting for the Final Four doubleheader to commence.

title: No Joy in Ewing's Milestone
description: Patrick Ewing usually saves his displays of emotion for the basketball floor. Once a game is over, the 7-foot 255-pound center for the Knicks becomes, as his teammate Kenny Walker once put it, a ''giant teddy bear.''

title: Archbishop Runcie to Retire
description: The Most Rev. Robert Runcie said today he will retire next January as Archbishop of Canterbury, the leader of 70 million Anglicans worldwide. He made the announcement at a morning service at Canterbury Cathedral marking the 10th anniversary of his enthronement, his London office said.

description: A judge has cleared the way for a union representing employees of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation to sue the Wickes Corporation for damages stemming from a failed 1986 takeover attempt of Owens-Corning by Wickes.

title: Texas Candidate's Comment About Rape Causes a Furor
description: The Republican gubernatorial nominee apologized today for an off-the-cuff remark suggesting that some victims of rape should ''relax and enjoy it.''

title: Chronicle
description: ARTHUR MILLER has been invited to Prague for productions of ''The Archbishop's Ceiling,'' which he wrote in 1975, and ''The Crucible,'' which he wrote in 1953. The former work, which had its premiere at Washington's Kennedy Center in 1977, has never been performed in New York City, but that omission should be corrected next season when the Lincoln Center Theater puts on the play.

title: Reviews/Dance;   The Poignancy of Parent-Child Conflicts
description: ''Fill These Shoes,'' performed by Corning Dances and Company at the Triplex Theater on Thursday, is a delightful and poignant ''dance play,'' as the choreographer describes it, about parents and children. ''They say that alcoholism is hereditary, occasionally skipping a generation,'' Beth Corning says in the piece. ''I say that becoming our parents is hereditary, and never skips a generation.'' By the end of ''Fill These Shoes,'' a young woman has grown up and realized how hard it is to be independent just as her mother is learning to live her own life - with a good deal more success.

title: BII Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ray Goulding, 68, Genial Satirist As Part of Bob and Ray, Is Dead
description: Ray Goulding, who was half of the Bob and Ray comedy team that delighted radio and television audiences for more than four decades with low-key humor and gentle satire, died of kidney failure on Saturday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 68 years old.

title: A Large Gain In Tokyo Issues
description: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange surged today to their second-highest gain in one day, fueled by a selloff in stock-index futures, brokers said.

title: Machine Tool Orders Fell by 3.4% Last Month
description: New orders for American-made machine tools in February fell by 3.4 percent from January, the third consecutive monthly decline. The drop reflected a slowing of the economy and a stagnancy in the automobile industry.

title: Reviews/Music;   A Pianist Does It His Way
description: The English pianist Stephen Hough won the Naumburg Competition in 1983 and has frequently been heard in New York City since then, not only as a recitalist but also in chamber music and as a concerto soloist. On Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall he offered a program that brought together a few standard works, a conservative contemporary score and some curios by virtuoso pianists who also composed.

description: This is no time for militantly anti-Communist and/or anti-Soviet Americans - or any others - to demand immediate recognition of Lithuania's independence or a U.S. ultimatum to Mikhail Gorbachev to let that country go.

description: Keycorp, a banking company based in Albany, has merged two of its banks to create the Key Bank of Eastern New York, with Robert M. Curley as president and chief executive.

description: Vytautas Landsbergis, who presides over Lithuania in its battle for sovereignty, seems an unlikely man to be thrust into a confrontation with a superpower.
