title: Klaus E. Knorr, 78, Professor; Argued Against Use of Military
description: Dr. Klaus E. Knorr, professor emeritus of public affairs at Princeton University and the director of its Center of International Studies from 1960 to 1968, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: The New Hungary Faces Economic Mess
description: Despite two decades of market-oriented reforms that sought to make Hungary Eastern Europe's most successful economy, the departing Communist regime will bequeath an economic mess to the government that emerges from the two rounds of elections that began yesterday. The second round will be held April 8.

title: Capitals Defeat Flames
description: Alan May, the most penalized player in the National Hockey League, turned scorer today, getting the go-ahead goal in the third period as the Washington Capitals beat the Calgary Flames, 4-1, to enhance their playoff chances.

title: Reviews/Music;   Proof That Conductors Do Make a Difference
description: Anyone who doubts that conductors can change the sound of an orchestra and do it on short notice should have gone to Avery Fisher Hall a week ago and then again on Thursday night. In successive weeks, Zdenek Macal and Christof Perick have filled in at the New York Philharmonic for the scheduled conductor, Klaus Tennstedt. They made the Philharmonic sound like two different orchestras.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Happy Land Reopened and Flourished After Being Shut as a Hazard
description: The social club where 87 people died early yesterday was ordered closed at least once in the last 16 months because it was a fire hazard, Mayor David N. Dinkins said last evening.

title: Tracking the Subways: Outdated System Fails
description: New York City subway riders know the frustration. They sit in a tunnel in a crowded train or wait on the platform for a late one, and no one tells them why.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Patrelle Company And Guests Of Stature
description: As a choreographer, Francis Patrelle knows how to make dancers look good. title: A YEAR AFTER SPILL, SCARS AND DOUBTS
description: On the first anniversary of the Exxon Valdez oil spill, Alaska's top environmental official walked the oil-stained beaches along Prince William Sound, inspected several newly found dead otters and said that not enough had been done to assure Alaskans that another spill would not foul the shoreline.

title: Offshore Bids Up Sharply
description: Oil companies bid $589.5 million last week for the right to drill in United States waters in the Gulf of Mexico, the biggest total in five years and a sign that the industry is recovering.

description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $14,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $242,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year. c-Net income d-Included extraordinary credits of $206,000, or 2 cents a share, and $377,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said it will have a non-recurring writeoff of $140,000 in the first quarter related to unamortized debenture costs on 12 percent debentures that were retired before maturity.

description: Six days after the spring training camps were unlocked, Davey Johnson put the Mets through their sixth straight double workout today and then said, ''I'm ready to play.''

description: It was exactly 79 years ago yesterday that a fire swept through the Triangle Shirtwaist Company in Manhattan's Greenwich Village, killing 146 workers and touching off a national movement for safer working conditions.

description: The bodies of two men and a woman, believed to have been dead for almost a week, were found in an apartment here yesterday.

description: When Grove Weidenfeld was put up for sale three weeks ago, its balance sheet was said to be awash in red ink. But prospective buyers are seeing only green - namely, Grove's backlist of about 600 books that have remained in print long after their orginal publication.

title: Mechele Plotkin Becomes Bride of Sander Flaum
description: Mechele Plotkin and Sander A. Flaum were married yesterday at the Americas Society in Manhattan. Rabbi Hillel Friedman officiated.

title: Clash of Cultures Grows Amid American Dream
description: Marjorie Gaines and Cirillo Guerrero are neighbors, after a fashion, in this slice of Southern California where two very different visions of America have come into conflict.

title: New Product For Agency: Democrats
description: ''THIS is no tube of toothpaste,'' said Joey Reiman, the chairman and chief creative officer of Babbit & Reiman Advertising, about the latest product his agency is pitching. ''We're talking about very big ideas that go way beyond making your teeth brighter.''

description: The 1989 periods restated to reflect the cumulative effect of an accounting adjustment. For the 9-month period net income was increased $19,585, or 2 cents a share.

title: Fappaburst Wins the Comely
description: Students of time and admirers of perfection knew there was a very special filly racing at Aqueduct this winter. After yesterday's Comely Stakes, those who require a test of class now know it as well.

title: Miss Zuckerman Weds P. K. Hirsch
description: Roberta Frances Zuckerman was married yesterday at the Burden mansion in New York to Peter Kaden Hirsch. Rabbi James Prosnit and Cantor Ephraim Biran officiated.

title: 2 Shot Dead in Manhattan
description: Two men were shot to death on a street in Manhattan's West Side last evening in an apparently drug related dispute, the police said. The incident occurred at 6:45 P.M. in front of 200 West 109th Street, said Sgt. Edward Burns, a police spokesman. He said that no weapons were found at the scene and that there were no known witnesses to the shootings. Both victims, who were not immediately identified, were pronounced dead on arrival at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: Film Promoted To the Disabled
description: The film ''My Left Foot,'' which is nominated in five categories, including best picture, for the Academy Awards that will be presented in Los Angeles tonight, has been the beneficiary of an unusual movie-marketing campaign.

Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Connecticut Cancels More Drivers' Licenses
description: The number of Connecticut motorists who have lost their licenses under a new drunken driving law continues to rise as the police use the authority for ''on-the-spot'' suspensions granted under the ''per se'' law.

title: Cardinal's Choice to Fill In As Covenant House Leader
description: The head of legal affairs for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was named the acting president of Covenant House, and an Upper West Side pastor was made his deputy, John Cardinal O'Connor announced yesterday.

title: Liberian President Leads the Good Life While His Country Grows Poorer
description: The delivery of a new luxury plane for the personal use of the Liberian President made front-page headlines in January in this impoverished West African country.

The Editorial Notebook;   For Police: A $76 Million Question
description: What's the price of lost public trust? According to one New York City jury, it's $76 million. The panel awarded that to two Brooklyn men it found to have been callously abused by police. The case, coming at a time of heightened concern about rising violence, including police shootings of suspects, underlines the desirability of having civilians oversee law enforcement.

title: J.H. Raspberry, Longshoremen's Union Leader, 56
description: J. H. Raspberry, the president of the South Atlantic and Gulf Coast District of the International Longshoremen's Associationm died of a heart attack Thursday at age 56.

title: Soviet Scholar Says Trotsky Turned Down Higher Office
description: Trotsky turned down a chance to sidetrack Stalin and rule revolutionary Russia because he feared his Jewish roots could stoke anti-Soviet feeling abroad, according to a Soviet historian.

description: A Federal judge today extended an order barring enforcement of the most restrictive abortion law in any American jurisdiction.

description: Alfred H. Greenberg, the editor in chief of Skiing magazine for more than a decade, died of leukemia on Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

Bridge
description: The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began its final day here today with the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship the main topic of discussion. A team led by Dan Morse of Houston and comprising John Sutherlin of San Francisco, Tom Sanders of Nashville, Bill Pollack of Englewood, N.J., Mike Kamil of Bergenfield, N.J., and Ron Gerard of White Plains won a convincing victory Friday night. They won by 81 imps against a group led by Zia Mahmood of Manhattan.

title: Luna Bijou Marries
description: Luna Bijou and Jonathan Israel Zemmol were married yesterday at the New York Hilton. Rabbi Zvulun Lieberman officiated. Mrs. Zemmol, 26 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bijou of Brooklyn. A graduate of New York University, the bride is a vice president of the Yellow Door, which owns jewelry and gift shops in Brooklyn and Deal, N.J. The bridegroom, 27, a Babson College graduate, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Zemmol of Birmingham, Mich. He is a public-affairs director at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.

title: Clean Air Debate: Odd Allies and Formidable Foes
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, former leader of the Democratic majority and longtime power on Capitol Hill, walked through the corridors of Senate office buildings last Tuesday dropping off handwritten notes asking his colleagues for help.

description: Thousands of crime victims who may be entitled to compensation for their suffering are not receiving it because the New York State board that awards benefits conducts inadequate investigations, a state legislative panel has concluded.

Rather, it is a waist belt designed to give you the buoyancy to exercise freely. With your legs and arms suspended in water, you are able to simulate any activity that might be part of a fitness routine on land.

Exercisers find they need another prop: a low bench for stepping up and down in a choreographed routine set to music. They call their program step training.

description: When the national collegiate men's swimming championships ended Saturday night, so did the career of perhaps America's most successful modern swimming coach. Or at least part of that career.

description: An outbreak of rabies among raccoons has crossed the Delaware River into New Jersey and is moving rapidly across the northern part of the state toward New York, causing serious concern, health officials in both states report.

title: Review/Music;   Manic Energy Paces a New Parisian Band
description: Manu Chao, leader of Mano Negra, hit the stage of the Cat Club on Thursday night with a leap and rarely stood still for the next 90 minutes. His manic energy paces the band, a hyperactive octet that sings in four languages (English, French, Spanish and Arabic) and seems willing to try any pop style from the last 30 years. Like another new Parisian band, the Negresses Vertes, Mano Negra presents an up-to-the-minute kind of multicultural skiffle. The music seems raucous, sweaty and informal, but it's not haphazard; the full band can switch genres at the drop of a chapeau.

description: The title ''A Wopbopaloobop A Lopbamboom'' would look odd on a movie theater marquee, but there's very little likelihood that it will ever wind up on one. Even film festival audiences will be sorely tried by this feature from Luxembourg in which various aging teen-agers posture unconvincingly and vent their free-floating existential angst.

title: Atwater Leaves the Hospital
description: Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, was released from George Washington University Hospital today after physicians adjusted the medication he is taking for a brain tumor, an aide said. The 39-year-old Mr. Atwater took radiation treatment at the hospital Saturday. A small, nonmalignant tumor was discovered this month on the right side of his brain after he collapsed as he was making a speech.

title: Reviews/Music;   A French Orchestra Visits With Maazel at the Helm
description: In a long and varied career, the American conductor Lorin Maazel has worn many hats, and in recent years he has doffed several of them. The next one will be the music directorship of the Orchestre National de France, a title he assumed in 1988 after becoming principal guest conductor in 1977. He now plans to leave the orchestra next year.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Sage Drilling reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSIDE
description: Labor Ahead in Australia

title: Adweek Units to Shut
description: The advertising trade magazine Adweek is ending publication of Ad Day, its daily news update, and Winners, its bi-monthly creative magazine. Ad Day, which is two years old, is closing immediately. The April-May issue of Winners will be its last. Adweek said it made the moves to devote its resources to its core weeklies, Adweek and Adweek's Marketing Week.

title: Sexes Differ, Coaches Find
description: FOR 14 years, Randy Reese has been the men's and women's coach at the University of Florida. He has won national team titles with both. He is 43, and his hair is all gray.

title: Susan Sullivan Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Susan Maureen Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Sullivan of Hicksville, L.I., to Marc Joel Gottridge, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gottridge of Plainview, L.I., took place yesterday at the Metropolitan restaurant in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim and the Rev. Wayne Puls, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Gail Ostrove Wed To Robert Kantor
description: Gail Jayne Ostrove and Robert Andrew Kantor were married yesterday at the Rainbow Room in New York. Rabbi Dennis Math officiated.

title: Duras and Her Thoughts of Love
description: To describe Marguerite Duras as a little old lady, even though she is all three things today, is to ignore the flirtatious twinkle in her eye that perhaps helps explain why, at the age of 75, she keeps on writing and thinking about sex and love.

title: A Bad Bill Where a Fix Would Do
description: An impartial auditor examines the books of a corporate pension plan and determines that it is overfunded. Money, therefore, can be withdrawn without jeopardizing promised payments to current or future retirees. So the corporate managers remove the excess money and give it to shareholders.

title: Joanna Bache and Steven Tobin Wed
description: Joanna Bache, the daughter of Kenneth Bache and Mary-Frances Bache of Annapolis, Md., was married there yesterday to Steven Mitchell Tobin, a son of Dr. Jordan Tobin and Dr. Dianne Tobin of Columbia, Md. Cantor Siegfried Rowe performed the ceremony at the Great Hall of St. John's College.

But this afternoon Georgia Tech, led once again by its three-man gang, defied wisdom and the odds.

title: In Magazines, It's a Man's World Once Again
description: Ever on the lookout for what is truly hot, the magazine industry has come up with a sizzler. It has discovered men.

title: Toward a Campaign of Substance in '92
description: Although the start of the 1992 Presidential primary season is two years off, memories of television's coverage of the 1988 campaign are only too fresh. So proposals for dealing with the media manipulators the next time out are welcome. Among the problems most deserving of attention: How to turn the Presidential debates into substantive exchanges rather than packaged preenings? How to resist cluttering the evening news with ''photo opportunities'' that allow press agents to peddle their goods? How to combat political commercials that play loose with facts? And how to counter the predilection of television news itself for the peppy picture and the snappy quote?

description: Seven people remained hospitalized yesterday after two cars and a church bus returning from an off-Broadway show collided on Interstate 684, killing the two car drivers and injuring 51 people.

title: Fiat Widens Soviet Deal
description: Fiat S.p.A. has agreed to expand its joint auto venture with the Soviet Union to include the manufacture of engines and transmissions for the entire projected annual production of cars at the Yelabuga plant outside Moscow, a Fiat spokesman said last week. Fiat will roughly triple the number of engines and parts to be made at the plant, the spokesman said on Friday. Under terms of the initial agreement, Fiat agreed to provide machinery and parts for the annual production of 300,000 A-93 cars starting in late 1993 or 1994. The Soviets were to furnish the engines and transmissions for the remaining two-thirds of total annual production. The A-93 is a small sedan based on Fiat's popular Panda model.

title: Spectacular Eagle Wins for Gamez
description: From 176 yards on what statistically was the most difficult hole on the PGA Tour last year, Robert Gamez, a 21-year-old rookie, holed a 7-iron for an eagle 2 and a one-stroke victory over Greg Norman today in the Nestle Invitational at Bay Hill.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   The Anguish and Banality of Boredom
description: ''The Seventh Continent'' is one of the most stylish films in this year's New Directors/New Films series. With its fragmented pattern of beautifully composed and repeated images from middle-class life, it rejuvenates a 1960's style that would seem to be exhausted by now. But the Austrian writer and director Michael Haneke pulls viewers through a good portion of the film on the sheer strength of his visual flair, avoiding the classic trap of how to create a film about boredom that is not boring.

title: Britain's Inflation Eases
description: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 7.5 percent in February from 7.7 percent in January, but the rate is expected to move higher in coming months, the Government said Friday. The retail price index rose sixth-tenths of 1 percent in February from January, the Central Statistical Office said. It said the March figures would probably be raised by increases in mortgage rates and in excise duties announced in the new budget.

title: Now Open at a New Location: Nearly 400 Hot Dogs Served

Sheldon Shkolnik, 52, A Concert Pianist, Dies
description: Sheldon Shkolnik, a concert pianist who played with many American orchestras, died of AIDS on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 52 years old.

title: Gold Falls As Mideast Sales Jump
description: Gold prices plunged yesterday in New York in near-panic selling on reports of unexpectedly large sales by Middle Eastern interests. Statisticians at the Commodity Exchange in New York said the decline of more than $23 an ounce was the biggest one-day drop since Feb. 28, 1983, when bullion plunged by $42.50, to $400.50.

description: The year-ago quarter was accounted for on a liquidation basis. The company has subsequently decided not to liquidate.

Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union drew the seventh game and won the eighth and ninth games to capture the final world championship candidates' match with Jan Timman of the Netherlands yesterday in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Karpov will now challenge the world champion, his countryman Gary Kasparov, next October. The first half of the title match will be held in New York, and the finish in Lyons, France.

title: Happy Days With Bob and Ray
description: ''There must have been a lot of people swimming the Channel that year because they had food expert Mary Margaret McGoon swimming to Boston Light, pushing grapefruit rinds out of the way as she went. And then in this skiff alongside . . . Oh, I wish you could have heard it!''

title: Business and Health;   Insurers Testing Basic Coverage
description: WITHOUT waiting for Congress, which seems reluctant to act on important health insurance issues in an election year, insurers in a number of states are testing new types of coverage for at least some of the 31 million Americans who lack health insurance.

title: High Court Agrees to Rule on When Supervision of School Desegregation Should End
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a major unresolved question in the legal legacy of school desegregation: what standards a formerly segregated school system has to meet to free itself of continuing court supervision, including court-ordered busing.

title: Asamera Minerals reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $1,041,000, or 4 cents a share for the latest year and $2,797,000, or 11 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: Cuomo May Be Blamed, But Ratings Aren't Votes
description: Republican leaders predicted today that they will be able to pin the downgrading of the state's credit rating on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo like a badge of fiscal dishonor. But Democratic officials and political consultants, both in New York and in Washington, said that credit ratings are too abstruse a subject to make for potent political symbolism.

description: Memoirs

title: Move to Keep Raiders
description: The Los Angeles Coliseum Commission voted yesterday to authorize its president, N. Matthew Grossman, to sign an agreement with MCA-Spectacor for management of the Coliseum.

title: Fluids May Aid Response Of Controls
description: ENGINEERS at the University of Michigan are experimenting with inexpensive liquids that, in response to high electric fields, can change from the consistency of water to peanut butter in a fraction of a second. These electro-rheological fluids are the focus of efforts to develop simpler, faster mechanical controls for cars, airplanes and submarines.

title: Hughes Supply Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Results were adversely affected by a downturn in sales caused by bad weather and a slowdown in construction activity. In addition, management increased provisions for bad debts and inventory writedowns. These additional provisions totaled about $2,000,000 more on a pretax basis than in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1989. c-Included a pretax gain of $400,000 from the sale of excess property for both the quarter and year.

title: NEW YORK IS GIVEN CUT IN BOND RATING BY CREDIT AGENCY
description: In a rebuke to the state's political leaders, the Standard & Poor's Corporation today lowered New York's credit rating by two notches, leaving the state with the third lowest rating in the nation.

description: The company said there are no comparable year-ago figures because the company went public on Feb. 10, 1989.

description: Sales of existing homes dropped 2.3 percent in February as mortgage interest rates continued to rise, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: Jackson Threatens To Approach U.N. On Statehood Issue
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson threatened today to take the case for District of Columbia statehood to the United Nations but said such a move ''would be a last resort.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers' Rochefort Comes On Strong
description: It has been, without doubt, one of the more delightfully rude of introductions. Normand Rochefort, largely unknown to his teammates, his prospective fans and his now regular opponents, has clearly decided that the best way to gain recognition is to dispose of bodies. It's been an inspired bit of incivility.

title: Raleigh Journal;   Farewell To Politics, With Hard Feelings
description: Gov. James G. Martin said he was like the veterinarian-taxidermist who could honestly say that ''either way you get your dog back.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: President VACLAV HAVEL of Czechoslovakia is recovering normally after a hernia operation Saturday in Prague, a spokesman says. He will spend a week in the hospital and will need about another week to convalesce after his hospital stay.

description: b-After extraordinary charges of $18,936,000 for the quarter and $23,978,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After extraordinary charges of $3,351,000 and $5,725,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter's extraordinary charge mainly due to extraordinary losses and unusual charges from the rationalization and restructuring of Provigo Inc. The company also said in the 1989 third quarter Provigo contributed $2,863,000 to its earnings but this year, Provigo contributed a negative $16,664,000. Empire said the latest 9 months' extraordinary credit included the company's $3,945,000 share of Wajax Ltd.'s $8,592,000 losses from discontinued operations and Empire's $20,131,000 share of Provigo Inc.'s losses from discontinued operations of $82,600,000. Preferred dividends exceeded net income in the latest 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: OPPOSITION LEADS IN HUNGARY'S VOTE
description: Given their first chance to elect a government freely in 45 years, Hungarian voters split their vote between two newly formed parties from the anti-Communist opposition that are now battling over how quickly the country should complete its transition to a free-market economy.

title: Stocks in Tokyo Decline Slightly
description: Stock prices declined slightly today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The United States dollar opened higher against the Japanese yen.

title: In Asia, His Cold War's Over
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's dramatic diplomacy has transformed Europe and transfixed Americans. Less noticed, he has also started breaking the cold war ice in the Far East. But President Bush acts as if there's nothing new on the Pacific horizon.

title: Place Resources Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: J.P. Agrees to Be Bought
description: J.P. Industries said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $17.30 a share by a buyer it did not identify. J.P., a maker of engine and transmission components, said it would issue more information soon. J.P. has about 10.8 million shares outstanding. Its stock fell 75 cents today, to $16, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Spurs On Brink Of Record Turnabout
description: The year was 1979, a season of basketball turmoil in Boston and one of only eight in their 44-year history in which the Celtics failed to make the playoffs. Eighteen different players wore Celtic green that year as Boston finished with a 29-53 record, the second worst in the National Basketball Association.

title: TWA Inc. reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $12,008,000. The 1988 results are not directly comparable due to the company's merger in 1988. The company said it posted a profit of $249.7 million for all reporting periods in 1988. The figure included non- recurring gains of $190.5 million from the sale of Texaco common stock and a cash judgment from long-standing litigation. TWA also attributed the decline in the latest period to a $193.9 million increase in interest expense in 1989, an increase in operating expenses, and a remaining net positive change of $71.2 million in all other item classifications principally comprised of the difference in income tax provision and credit between the two annual periods.

title: Colombian Quits, Charging Letup on Drugs
description: The senior Cabinet minister involved in the war on drugs resigned on Sunday, saying that the Government of President Virgilio Barco Vargas had weakened in its crackdown on traffickers.

title: Forced Sale of Gas Ingredient to Army Is Weighed
description: The Bush Administration is considering legal action against two chemical companies to compel them to sell to the Army an ingredient needed to make poison gas, Pentagon officials said today.

description: b-Net income

title: Chalone Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Crop Insurance: Many Would Miss It
description: Farmers had never been particularly fond of it. And most taxpayers probably didn't even know of it, although it cost more than $5 billion over the last decade. But now that the Bush Administration has threatened to scrap Federal crop insurance, it has more friends than ever.

title: Philips to Build TV Tube Plant
description: The Philips Display Components Company said it would build a $100 million color-television picture-tube plant in Saline, Mich. The plant, which could eventually produce high-definition television picture tubes, is scheduled to begin operating in July 1992. Plans call for the production of a million 27-inch color-television picture tubes a year.

title: John Stamler, 51, Dies; New Jersey Prosecutor
description: John H. Stamler, the Prosecutor in Union County, N.J., for 13 years, died of cancer on Sunday at his home in Scotch Plains, N.J. He was 51 years old.

Upheaval in the East;   Soviet Troops, Storming Hospital, Seize Lithuanian Army Deserters
description: Armed Soviet troops stormed a psychiatric hospital early this morning and arrested a group of Lithuanian deserters from the army who had taken refuge there since the republic's proclamation of independence on March 11, witnesses said.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15

title: ABORTION STUDIED BY IDAHO GOVERNOR
description: Gov. Cecil Andrus, under mounting pressure from the public and his own family, said today that he would consult outside experts before deciding whether to sign the nation's most restrictive state abortion law.

title: Game Gives the Germans a Pleasing Taste of Reunification
description: After months of planning and preparation, East Germany and West Germany united today, but their efforts were rebuked by the rest of the world.

title: Pico Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Washington Post Plans Books on the Economy
description: The Washington Post is lending its name to a new and expensive book series for corporate and Government executives designed to enlighten them on economic trends. ''The Washington Post Company Briefing Books'' will be marketed primarily through direct mail to a proprietary list of 130,000 people selected for their potential interest in the subjects and their potential willingness to pay $195 a volume. The first book, ''The Age of Diminished Expectations,'' by Paul Krugman, an international economist, is a summary and analysis of the state of the nation's economy. Other subjects being considered include biotechnology, tax policy and United States-Japan trade relations.

title: U.A.W. Faces Test at Mazda Plant
description: The auto industry is closely watching a dispute between the Mazda Motor Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union over the use of temporary employees.

title: Patient's Marrow Emerges as Key Cancer Tool
description: DOCTORS have long suspected that colossal doses of chemotherapy and radiation could triumph over a number of otherwise fatal cancers. The only hitch was that doses large enough to overcome the tumor frequently killed the patient as well, generally by destroying the bone marrow, the body's crucial factory for making cells for the blood and immune system.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Honecker Won't Be Charged With Count of High Treason
description: Prosecutors said today that they were dropping plans to charge Erich Honecker with high treason, saying there were no legal grounds to do so. But they said the deposed Communist leader was still under investigation for corruption and abuse of power.

title: Seaboard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.S. Needs a Domestic Marshall Plan First;   European Aid Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Western
description: Best Western International will add 50 hotels in southern Asian countries by 1993, the lodging chain said. The first hotels will be in Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Uday Management Services Pvt. Ltd. of New Delhi said it had organized the Best Western South Asia group and would establish Best Western's first affiliate hotels in the region, adding five hotels in the first year. It estimated that the affiliate hotels would generate nearly 50,000 annual room nights for the chain.

title: John Forsyth Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $600,000 provision for anticipated restructuring expenses. c-Included two extraordinary charges totalling $568,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: John Dexter, 64, English Director Of Both Theater and Opera, Dies
description: John Dexter, a leading English director of theater and opera, died of heart failure in a London hospital on Friday. He was 64 years old. Mr. Dexter, who won two Tony Awards, was known for the sweep of his directorial imagination with contemporary plays as well as with classics. One of a corps of directors who in the late 1950's and early 60's led the Royal Court Theater into the arena of new and venturesome plays, he was closely identified with the early work of Arnold Wesker. Under the leadership of Laurence Olivier, he also served for seven years as an associate director of England's National Theater. In more recent years, as a director of opera and as director of productions for the Metropolitan Opera (from 1974 to 1981), he achieved a second international reputation.

title: Daily News Offers 30% Pay Raise to a Union
description: The Daily News yesterday offered to raise the salaries of its largest union - the Newspaper Guild - by about 30 percent over three years.

title: Upheaval in the East;   FLOW OF GERMANS EBBING FROM EAST
description: The number of East Germans moving to West Germany has dropped considerably since the East German election a week ago, although officials warned that it was too early to declare that the heaviest flow is over.

title: Kevlin Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
By Design;   Back to the Flirtatious 60's
description: From the top of the coif to the sole of the boot, the spirit of the 1960's has saturated French fashion for fall 1990. If you want to be ahead of the rest, start now to revamp your hair and makeup.

title: Dinkins Details Additional Cuts In City Budget
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday announced details of the city's latest budget cuts for the current fiscal year, a $75 million reduction that he said would cut ''to the very marrow of city services.''

title: Suddenly, China Looks Smaller in the World
description: If maps were based not on the physical dimensions of nations but on perceptions of their importance, the world would have to be redrawn: China has shrunk dramatically by that standard over the last year.

title: Loft Law Keeps Tenants Chic but Not Safe
description: Per Jensen's landlord cracked most of the walls in his loft on Bond Street in lower Manhattan while trying to install a restaurant in the basement in 1982. Huge holes appeared in the hallways and ceilings. The landlord refused to fix them.

title: In One State, 41 Pilots Lost Driver's Licenses
description: At least 41 pilots of passenger aircraft have lost their Minnesota driver's licenses in the past seven years because of alcohol abuse, a published report says.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Albania Opens Phone Links With Some Western Nations
description: Albania has opened direct telephone service with the West, lifting some of the restrictions that have made it one of the world's most isolated countries.

title: Drawing Out the Manager's Best
description: BESIDES storing and manipulating information that has been fed to it, a personal computer can draw out information and procedures that are stored in the user's head, helping managers to manage better. That's the premise of a collection of software from Winsight, in Princeton, N.J.

title: Summit Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: The New South Africa?
description: One model being considered by the Government for a constitutional settlement in South Africa calls for a two-chamber parliament. One house would be elected on the basis of one person one vote, without regard to race. The other would represent racial groups and perhaps geographical regions.

title: Cordero Is Cheered At Arabian Track
description: Angel Cordero Jr. was surprised to hear railbirds chanting his name as he neared the wire of a two-and-a-half mile race Sunday called the King's Trophy. The 47-year-old jockey did not expect a rooting section in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Cordero was there to ride Passing Ships, the first American thoroughbred ever to win the nonbetting race, for Prince Mubet bin Abdullah.

Unlocking the Secret of Duke Tourney Success
description: The record maintains that during an era of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament that has transformed unthinkable upsets into anticipated events, Duke University has achieved a rare succession of successes against a backdrop of Gothic architecture and creative, hoop-headed crazies.

title: Orthodox Leader in Israel Appears to Spurn Peres
description: A 92-year-old rabbi may have dealt a death blow to Shimon Peres's chances of forming a new government this evening when he told more than 10,000 followers that they could not support the Labor Party because it was not supportive enough of strict Judaism.

title: Fujitsu Fills Positions
description: The computer maker Fujitsu Ltd. on Friday promoted its president, Takuma Yamamoto, who is 64 years old, to chairman. It also promoted its executive director, Tadashi Sekizawa, 58, to president. The position of chairman had been vacant for some time. A vice president, Matami Yasufuku, 63, will become vice chairman, and an executive director, Kazuo Watanabe, 65, will be a vice president.

title: Police Issue Orders To Shutter 14 Clubs Already in Violation
description: Police teams sent into the field by Mayor David N. Dinkins to crack down on illegal social clubs yesterday found 14 clubs operating despite orders to close.

CHRONICLE
description: Lawyers for IVANA TRUMP filed papers yesterday in New York State Supreme Court. Not divorce papers, but a 24-page complaint asking for an equitable share of the property acquired in her 13-year marriage to DONALD TRUMP. The amount: 50 percent of $5 billion.

title: TV's Man of Many Voices Tries the Big Screen
description: ''Might be gooood, could be baaaad, don't know if it would be pru-dent at this junc-ture,'' President Bush was saying in his truncated syntax, in answer to a question about whether the comedian Dana Carvey should leave television's ''Saturday Night Live'' for a feature-film career. ''Goin' do it? Not goin' do it? Don't know. Too early to tell. Not enough informa-tion. Bar and I, we think he's likable. Does a pretty weak impression of me, though - in that movie kinda thing.''

title: Arizona Land Income Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Wednesday misstated details of a transaction between the Continental Corporation and the NAC Re Corporation. NAC Re is acquiring the stock and licenses of the Harbor Insurance Company from Continental, but the accounts insured by Harbor will continue to be managed by Continental.

title: Of Mother Russia - and a Hat
description: Lithuania notwithstanding, there is little doubt that Mikhail Gorbachev is doing all he can to reform his country, but there is no doubt that he will have a very hard time.

title: New Light Being Shed On Early Mechanisms Of Coronary Disease
description: HEART disease begins in childhood, accelerates in adolescence and is firmly established in the arteries of 25 percent of white men by the age of 35, researchers have found.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Vance Elected to Board
description: David Vance, vice president of racing operations for the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, has been elected to the board of trustees of the New York Racing Association, which operates Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga. Vance, whose election must be approved by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, will continue to work for DeBartolo, who owns Louisiana Downs in Bossier City, La., Thistledown near Cleveland and Remington Park in Oklahoma City. Vance would become the first employee of another racing organization ever to sit on the N.Y.R.A. board.

title: Inland Gold & Silver reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that the decline in gross sales and net income in the 1989 year was primarily due to management's decision to defer the sale of 12,965 ounces of gold beyond yearend.

title: WALKOUT HAMPERS 3 NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: A strike by itinerant radiation technicians yesterday was effective at two nuclear reactors in Florida and one in Georgia, but its success at 34 other plants was not clear.

title: Dire Regan Predictions Finally Gaining Respect
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan's dire warnings about New York State's finances, an annual rite in Albany, took on new urgency yesterday with the reduction of the state's credit rating.

Tracing the Club's Owners
description: The trail of ownership of the Happy Land Social Club, where 87 people died early Sunday, leads from the club operator who died in the fire to several prominent real-estate developers who owned or leased the site.

title: Man Gets 131 1/2-Year Term For Sexually Mutilating Boy
description: A county judge imposed a 131 1/2-year prison sentence on a man convicted of raping, sexually mutilating and trying to kill a 7-year-old boy, three times the maximum term for the crime under state law.

title: Murder Threat Is Described In List Case <
description: Days before she and the rest of her family were slain in 1971 in their house in Westfield, 16-year-old Patricia List tearfully told a teacher that her father, John E. List, had threatened to kill them, the teacher, Edwin Illiano, testified today.

title: Shandwick Ranked as Largest Firm
description: Shandwick P.L.C. has become the largest public relations firm in the annual listing compiled by O'Dwyer's Directory of Public Relations Firms. Net fees collected by the London-based firm rose by 48 percent in 1989, to $180 million, enabling it to leap over Hill & Knowlton, whose fees totaled $164 million in 1989, and Burson-Marsteller, which collected $159.9 million.

title: Del Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss was principally attributable to additional inventory writedowns and increased advertising and promotional charges totalling about $4.5 million. Included in this is a $2.5 million charge attributed to the streamlining of a product line.

description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $6,000,000 for the quarter and $20,000,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $4,000,000 and $164,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest quarter loss from continuing operations of $102,000,000 reflects a loss of $55 million from the disposition of a division and the year's loss from continuing operations of $207,000,000 included a gain of $165 million from the sale of a unit.

title: Upheaval in the East;   For Lithuania, Few Allies in Moscow
description: After two weeks of battling with Moscow over the sovereignty of their tiny republic, the Lithuanians may or may not be independent, but one thing is clear: they are on their own.

title: Review/Television;   As Poland Wakes Up to a Daily Nightmare
description: Having captured the first euphoric hours of freedom in Eastern Europe, television is now faced with the harder job of reporting on the painful realities of life after Communism. ''Poland: The Morning After,'' tonight's resolutely uneuphoric offering from ''Frontline,'' focuses on the rocky present and shaky future of a people who are beginning to question what they have won with the victory of Solidarity. (The darkly enlightening program at 10 P.M. on Channel 13 is preceded by a discussion on ''Adam Smith's Money World'' of Eastern Europe's economic woes and opportunities from the point of view of Western investors.) The producer of ''The Morning After,'' Ofra Bikel, uses the discontents of coal miners, farmers and workers in a big tractor factory to bring home the meaning of the nation's grim economic legacy. And she reports on the dire political implications for the new democracy as recently awakened expectations run up against hard reality.

title: Clean Air Costs Will Raise Electricity Bills;   Pesky Nuclear Waste
description: To the Editor:

Going Down to Wire In N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: They say that time heals all wounds. But for teams that have been eliminated from the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament on last-second shots, time is a heartless thief who snatches treasured dreams and leaves a permanent scar.

title: Sharp's 4-Pound Notebook
description: THE Sharp Electronics Corporation has developed a four-pound notebook-style personal computer that has, according to people who have seen it, a display screen superior to most other portables, an internal hard disk capable of storing the equivalent of more than 20 million characters and a relatively powerful Intel 80286 microprocessor.

Japan to U.S.: Tighten Up. U.S. to Japan: Loosen Up.
description: Japan has a few ideas how President Bush can move quickly to tighten up the American economy. To start with, he should strictly limit every American to just a couple of credit cards. Then he should build a network of bullet trains across America, impose a stiff gasoline tax and get rid of low-interest car loans, all to get gas-guzzlers off the road. And he should ban the tax write-off for many types of home mortgages because it subsidizes consumption, not savings.

title: Did Einstein's Wife Contribute to His Theories?
description: THE genius behind Albert Einstein's theories of light, space and time may have been a little-known collaborator, his first wife, according to recent re-examinations of his life.

title: Eli C. Carlebach, 65, Rabbi of Synagogue On Upper West Side
description: Rabbi Eli Chaim Carlebach, the co-rabbi of Congregation Kehilath Jacob on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with his twin brother Shlomo, died of a heart attack on Friday after leaving a synagogue in Hillside, N.J. He was 65 years old.

description: Supreme Court to Rule On Busing and Job Safety

title: Taheya Kazem, Nasser's Widow, 66
description: Taheya Kazem, widow of President Gamal Abdel Nasser, died on Sunday. She was 66 years old. No cause of death was announced. Nasser, who ruled Egypt in the years after the overthrow of King Farouk, died of a heart attack on Sept. 28, 1970.

title: Mr. Padgett, Bo's Triple And a Rookie
description: Shortly after 1:30 yesterday afternoon, with a warm sun peeking through fluffy clouds, nine members of the Kansas City Royals hopped up out of their first-base dugout, trotted to their positions and turned toward the American flag fluttering beyond right field. Holding their blue caps over their hearts, they stood still for the national anthem. And moments later, Storm Davis was pitching to Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox.

title: 2 Large Dutch Banks Begin Merger Talks
description: The two largest commercial banks in the Netherlands have begun merger talks aimed at creating the world's 20th-largest bank, officials of the two companies announced today.

title: Bernard Krief Bid
description: Bernard Krief Consultants, a French management consulting group, has offered to buy Hay Group Inc., the largest consulting unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., for $120 million.

title: E.P.A. Office Recommends Against Dam Project Near Denver
description: In a decision likely to rekindle the wrath of developers and their political supporters in the West, the Denver office of the Environmental Protection Agency formally recommended today that construction of a $1 billion dam project in Colorado be prohibited.

title: Alcohol Tied To the Deaths Of 105,095 In U.S. in '87
description: The national Centers for Disease Control has reported that 105,095 Americans died from injuries or diseases linked to alcholic beverages in 1987, the latest year for which figures are available.

title: Geac Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $6,250,000, or 30 cents a share, mostly from the sale of the Canadian financial software product and related assets. c-After an extraordinary credit of $1 million, or 5 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 5 Accused of Selling Cancer Patients' Pills
description: Dying cancer patients have been raising money by selling their pain pills to a drug ring, the authorities say.

title: Koerner Gets 8-Year Term
description: Paul Koerner, an investment adviser convicted of fraud in a platinum scheme that bilked investors of millions of dollars, was sentenced last week to eight years in prison.

title: KEY RATES
Procter-Silex Venture Set
description: Nacco Industries said today that it planned to combine its Procter-Silex subsidiary with Hamilton Beach, a subsidiary of Glen Dimplex Ltd. of Ireland.

title: Multi-Use Credit Card Is Offered by A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday introduced a combination telephone-calling card and general-purpose credit card affiliated with Visa and Mastercard International.

title: Review/Music;   New Kids on the Block End Tour
description: Squeaky-clean, cheerful and bursting with energy, New Kids on the Block earned the nonstop screams that greeted them tonight at the Brendan Byrne Arena. They are the teeny-bopper idols of the moment, having sold eight million copies of their second album, ''Hangin' Tough'' (Columbia), and the five-member vocal group faced an overwhelmingly female audience of children and teen-agers with parents in tow.

title: Stratford American reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: 21 Indicted in New England As Core of Organized Crime
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today announced the indictment of 21 men he said were leaders or important members of organized crime in New England. He said the indictments were based on ''extraordinary'' evidence drawn from secret recordings that should conclusively prove for the first time the existence of the Mafia in the United States.

title: Jetborne International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Wanted on the Space Station: Better Suits, Robots and Parts
description: FUTURISTIC projects that the space agency once pursued half-heartedly are now soaring to prominence as NASA struggles to cope with a threat to the success of the proposed $30 billion space station Freedom, the centerpiece of the nation's program for the manned exploration of the solar system.

title: Why Ratings Are Watched
description: Credit evaluations by Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the nation's two largest and best known rating agencies, carry a great deal of weight in the financial community and among investors.

title: Peril of Third-World Famine Is Seen by U.N. Food Agency
description: Despite generally good weather, the world continues to grow less grain than it eats and stocks have fallen for the third year running, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies on March 16 about the hanging of a journalist in Iraq misstated his birthplace. He worked for a British newspaper but was born in Iran.

title: Victims of Fire at Social Club
description: Following is a tentative list of 83 of the 87 people killed in the fire at the Happy Land Social Club Inc. The others were not identified.

title: Prosecutors Try to Establish A Poindexter Lie to Reagan
description: Prosecutors in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter sought today to suggest that the former national security adviser misled President Ronald Reagan about American involvement in a contra-resupply mission in which a plane was downed by Nicaraguan soldiers in October 1986.

title: Grief Deepens as Horror of the Disaster Sinks In
description: Curiosity-seekers and emergency workers with round-the-clock appetites kept Miguel Jimenez busy at the All-American Food Shop on Southern Boulevard yesterday, cooking and serving and brewing gallons and gallons of coffee. But Mr. Jimenez kept hoping that two regular customers would stop in - the girls who always bought bagels on their way to Roosevelt High School.

title: 8 Die as South African Police Fire On Protesters in Black Township
description: The South African police opened fire today on black anti-apartheid and hospital workers reported that eight people were killed and hundreds wounded.

title: Mets Feel 'Strange' But Win In Rally
description: Six days after the training camps were unlocked, two weeks before the regular season was scheduled to open, the Mets played their first exhibition game of the bobtailed spring today. And although they rallied with six runs in the last two innings and defeated the Houston Astros, 7-2, they all conceded that this was a strange way to do business.

title: Altai Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $1,352,000, or 61 cents a share, which included $123,000 from discontinued operations and $1,229,000 gain on sale of assets.

title: Peril Is Seen in Halting Heart Drugs Abruptly
description: People with high blood pressure who take medications known as beta blockers temporarily increase their risk of chest pain or heart attack if they abruptly stop taking the medication, a study says.

title: Rig Count Down Again
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by another 15, to a total of 893, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The decline was attributed to seasonal factors. But the count so far this year remains well ahead of the 1989 tally, when 766 rigs were working, Baker Hughes said.

title: Dow Manages Small Gain in Thin Trading
description: Stocks barely moved into the plus column yesterday, with market activity slowing to its second-lowest level of the year.

The third quarter and year-to-date results reflected a positive adjustment of $606,000, or 19 cents a share, associated with the sale of Micronics in March.

title: Bridge

description: FORGET the old maxim that memory deteriorates with age. The new wisdom, emerging from recent studies, is that there are several kinds of memory, only one of which worsens in old age.

description: Long Island's two suburban counties each have 15,000 homeless people, according to the Coalition for the Homeless. In response, Suffolk County has opened or is developing over a dozen sites to permanently house homeless families. Nassau County has yet to open one.

title: Analyst Who Criticized Trump Casino Is Ousted
description: An analyst who refused to retract negative comments about the financial prospects of Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal casino has been dismissed by his Philadelphia brokerage firm. The move caused an outcry in the financial analysts' community, which bristles at any suggestion that investment analysts are not free to criticize potential or current corporate clients.

title: Fed Changes Foreign-Margin Rule
description: The Federal Reserve Board said last week that it would allow large brokerages to establish margin accounts on foreign securities. Margin accounts allow customers to purchase securities on credit and borrow against securities.

title: Albany's School Assignment: Incomplete
description: It was a stunning breakthrough when New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, negotiated an agreement with the principals' union to allow removal of incompetent principals. But that is only part of a long reform agenda. It and other parts still require action from the State Legislature.

title: Bankers Trust Debt Ratings Are Downgraded by S.&P.

description: A. Michael Spence, a renowned economist and the second-highest administrator at Harvard University, today was named the next dean of the Stanford University Graduate School of Business.

title: Review/Television;   Prosecutors As Heroes For the 90's On ABC
description: NBC's ''L.A. Law'' gave us defense lawyers as overachieving yuppies for the onward and upward 1980's. ABC's ''Equal Justice,'' having a special two-hour premiere at 9 this evening, offers prosecuting lawyers as flawed heroes for the stressful 1990's. The setting changes but the formula stays more or less the same.

title: Hobart Carr, 78, Dies; A Professor of Banking
description: Hobart C. Carr, professor of banking at Adelphi University and professor emeritus of banking at New York University, died on Sunday at University Hospital in Mineola, L.I., several days after suffering a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

description: At a time when many Roman Catholic bishops feel it is their prime duty to speak out on abortion, Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee has decided to listen.

title: Coral Reefs Off 20 Countries Face Assaults From Man and Nature
description: CORAL reefs off the coasts of more than 20 countries are suffering from increasingly severe human and natural assaults, new research shows.

description: * O. Berk Co., Union, N.J., a supplier of glass, plastic and aluminum containers and closures, named Norbert Gaelen chairman and chief executive. The company named Marc M. Gaelen president and chief operating officer.

description: WHILE most of the 1980's were years of soaring fame and profits for Nordstrom Inc., the specialty-apparel retailer based in Seattle suffered some unusual setbacks as the decade came to a close.

title: A Child-Support Lawsuit Keeps Perez Out of Camp
description: Pascual Perez, who was expected to arrive in the Yankees' training camp on Tuesday, still faces problems leaving the Dominican Republic because of a lawsuit filed against him regarding child support.

title: Benjamin Siegel, 73, Scientist and Educator
description: Dr. Benjamin Morton Siegel, a scientist and educator, died on Thursday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida after a brief illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Sarasota.

Economic Ambassador
description: President Bush today gave Frederick V. Malek the rank of ambassador in his role as director of this summer's economic summit meeting in Houston. Mr. Malek, the president of Northwest Airlines, is working part time preparing for the July 9-11 meeting for the leaders of the world's seven leading non-Communist industrial nations.

title: Death in Seconds: Toxins or a Searing 'Flashover' Suspected
description: Of the 87 people killed in the flash fire at the Happy Land Social Club, many were felled so swiftly that they appeared to have died within seconds, rather than minutes, as more often happens in a fire.

title: Singapore Air's Marketing Plans
description: Singapore Airlines is holding talks with its partners, Delta Air Lines and Swissair, on creating a new marketing image for their alliance, a Singapore Airlines executive said. The Straits Times quoted the airline's managing director, Cheong Choong Kong, as saying, ''The next step for Swissair, Delta and Singapore Airlines is to work out a joint identity and to market this so that travel agents would know of this identity.''

title: Drexel Trims Insurer Stake
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. disclosed today that it had reduced its holdings in the First Executive Corporation below 5 percent from 6.3 percent.

title: John J. Fowler Jr., Banker, 68
description: John J. Fowler Jr., former president and director of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York, died of congestive heart failure on Sunday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Is Castro Planning Another Mock Trial?
description: LEAD: Tania Diaz Castro, a respected poet who recently campaigned for signatures for a referendum on the legitimacy of Fidel Castro's 31-year dictatorship, again is the target of Government repression. Cuban exiles believe, with good reason, that her life may be in danger.

title: Some Tough Lessons From 'Near-Death'
description: IT was only 8:30 A.M., but Owen J. Lipstein already looked tired. The knot of his wide orange necktie was pulled well below the collar button of his shirt, his brown hair looked as if it had not been combed since the night before. He offered a Pepsi - his favorite morning drink - and said, ''We're on the verge of a new company, which is exciting.''

title: Really Useful Plan in Doubt
description: Stoll Moss Theaters Ltd., the entertainment company of the Australian businessman Robert Holmes a Court, said Friday that it had acquired a 6.61 percent stake in Really Useful Group P.L.C., threatening Andrew Lloyd Webber's plan to take the company private.

title: Lincoln Move Is Questioned
description: Aides to Charles H. Keating Jr. ordered Lincoln Savings and Loan Association to advance its holding company $14.2 million for taxes in 1986, a Federal judge was told today. But the Government contends the money was never paid to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Gantos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Strasbourg Journal;   In 9 Languages, Parliament Demands a Bigger Say
description: Every month, at an annual cost of more than $65 million, several hundred metal boxes full of documents are trucked in from Brussels, almost 1,000 civil servants arrive from Luxembourg and 518 politicians travel from a dozen capitals so that the European Parliament can hold a weeklong session in Strasbourg.

title: COURT TO REVIEW FETAL SAFETY PLAN
description: Placing itself squarely at the center of a debate over the place of women in the industrial work force, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether employers can bar fertile women from jobs that might endanger a fetus.

title: 'Driving Miss Daisy' Wins 4 Oscars, Including One for Jessica Tandy
description: ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' a sentimental film about the relationship between an elderly Southern Jewish widow and her black chauffeur, won four Oscars tonight, including best picture of 1989 and best actress, in an Academy Awards presentation that offered many surprises and odd contradictions but few clear clues to trends in film.

title: Guam Judge Extends Order Blocking Law on Abortions
description: A Federal judge today extended an order barring enforcement of the most restrictive abortion law in any American jurisdiction.

description: The man who the police say has admitted starting the fire that killed 87 people in a Bronx social club Sunday morning was described yesterday as a Cuban Army deserter and street hustler who had lost both his job and his girlfriend in recent weeks.

title: Reuter Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Koch Bill Cracking Down On Clubs Died in Council
description: A centerpiece of the Koch administration's promised crackdown on New York City social clubs - a bill to require owners of clubs closed for safety violations to post a large bond before re-opening - died in a City Council committee last year after members said it might penalize innocent landlords.

title: Protestant Militant Seeks a Way Through Ulster Deadlock
description: Peter Robinson is a frustrated man, and all those who have long awaited a break in the political deadlock here are delighted.

title: Review/Music;   Sound, Movement and Touching Things
description: The Belgian Logos Duo presented a program of music and related art at Roulette on Wednesday evening that was full of ideas, some merely peculiar, others strikingly clever. Ideas in themselves, however, are not art, and as brief as most of the pieces were, they tended to drag on long after their initial fascination had waned.

description: For several days now, some of the telefax machines that had been relaying a steady stream of messages to Chicago from Lithuania have been silent. Overseas telephone calls placed to Vilnius don't always go through, even after hours of trying.

title: Quad's Recall
description: Quad Pharmaceuticals Inc. said it was recalling 22 products that did not meet Federal standards for manufacturing changes. The Food and Drug Administration said the products were used in hospitals for intravenous treatments and were not common consumer items. Quad is a subsidiary of Par Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Spring Valley, N.Y. The company said it was laying off 110 of its 380 employees in response to the recall, which it said would cost $4 million.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Fighting Abates in Transylvania but Not the Anger
description: ''Huns! Huns!'' the Romanian crowd chanted, jeering their ethnic Hungarian neighbors.

They might never have been exposed even to the danger of mass death had they been able to afford a more spacious lounge that conformed to building laws and liquor authority regulations. In part, they suffered for the crime of being poor.

A single host was assigned to guide the ungainly Oscar proceedings through preening, joking, song, dance, movie lore, kitsch and 23 awards, trying to make it all seem shorter than three hours-plus.

Theodore S. Cart, 91, Founder of 2 Concerns
description: Theodore S. Cart, founder of two companies in Trenton, died on Sunday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 91 years old. Mr. Cart founded the Pocono Rubber Cloth Company, manufacturer of material for automobile tops, in 1920. Five years later he organized Atlantic Products, which manufactured luggage and sporting goods, as a division of Pocono. Atlantic Products was sold to Cluett, Peabody & Company Inc. in the early 1970's. Pocono Rubber Cloth went out of business.

title: American Nursery Products reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The Rough and Rutted Road to the Future
description: Paris was a group show. If a single leader had to be chosen, Christian Lacroix would win by a nose, but Emanuel Ungaro, Claude Montana and Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel would be close behind. What dazzled most was the professionalism and, yes, the glitter of the presentations and the infinite variety of approaches to fashion.

title: Quicksand For Banks
description: Bankers knew their problems with real estate loans were mounting, but Federal examiners now suggest that the problems are far more serious than the bankers have admitted.

title: Barge Strikes Wreck, Spewing Oil in Channel
description: The Intracoastal Waterway was partly reopened today after a barge struck a shipwreck Sunday night, leaking nearly 35,000 gallons of light crude oil.

title: Morrison Petroleums reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about maple syrup production in the United States and Canada misstated the year in which Vermont's output was 5.8 million pounds. It was 1985, not 1988.

title: Carter Denies Undermining Mets
description: Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez will forever be linked in Mets' history as the veteran star players who came from other teams, served as co-captains and team leaders and helped win a World Series. Now they are being linked in another way: They are being blamed for creating a negative influence that undermined the Mets' chances last year.

title: Fremont General reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $107,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,153,000 for the quarter and $4,021,000 for the year, and extraordinary credits of $1,201,000, or 11 cents a share, and $2,115,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: McFarland Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a net charge of $5,123,000 from the writedown of oil and gas properties and a separate non-recurring charge of $148,000.

title: Review/Music;   Style for Period Instruments
description: Searchers for appropriate 18th-century style on period instruments still stumble over the more mundane problems of playing the right notes, playing them in tune and doing both with confidence. Sergiu Luca, in his violin-keyboard concert with John Gibbons at Weill Recital Hall on Friday, spent the evening as a model illustrator of how things were approached ''back then'' - with straightened, husky-sounding violin tone, with vibrato used as emphasis and accent rather than as blanket tone color, and with small subdivisions of phrase carved from longer melodic arcs.

title: Callon Consolidated Partners reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
5 Soviets to Make Debut
description: Five boxers from the Soviet Union - each with extensive amateur backgrounds - will make their American debuts as professional fighters tonight at Bally's Hotel and Casino in Reno, Nev., on a card to be televised by the USA Network.

title: The U.S. Needs a Domestic Marshall Plan First
description: To the Editor:

title: Physicians Insurance Co. of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $42,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $503,000, or 16 cents a share, for the year. c-Included income of $1,672,810, or 54 cents a share, from discontinued operations. d-Net loss and included a loss of $3,579,203 from discontinued operations.

title: U.N. Aides Assess Task of Disbanding the Contras
description: Thrust abruptly to the center of debate on the future of the contras, United Nations officials arrived here today for meetings on how to carry out a new but vaguely worded plan for overseeing the dismantling of the anti-Sandinista guerrilla army.

title: Avon Agrees To Give Seats To Chartwell
description: Avon Products Inc. agreed yesterday to include two directors nominated by Chartwell Associates L.P. on its board, ending the threat of a proxy fight by the investor group.

title: Kansas City Southern in a Sale
description: Kansas City Southern Industries sold a controlling interest of its Martec Pharmaceutical subsidiary to a West German company, Ratiopharm G.m.b.H. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: New Electric Motor
description: Using recent advances in high-temperature superconductor technology, engineers have built a model electric motor using a coil made of a superconducting ceramic.

title: Newscope Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Return France To NATO
description: The big questions on the future of Europe have moved off the streets and back into diplomatic chambers now, where nothing goes quickly and there are no dramatic pictures. And the old unresolved security problems, shelved for so long, are again the focus of trouble.

title: Heldor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Coho Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Factors Predict Skin Cancer, Study Finds
description: People having at least one of six characteristics run a higher than normal risk of getting the most deadly form of skin cancer, a new study suggests.

title: Management Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
No Decision on Valvano
description: No resolution was reached on the fate of Jim Valvano during a 90-minute meeting in Raleigh yesterday, but his lawyer said he thought Valvano could remain as the North Carolina State basketball coach.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase by 6.1% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday a rise of 6.1 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-March.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   2 Explorations of Generational Conflicts
description: Finding an original way to explore generational conflicts may be as difficult as creating a harmonious relationship with your parents. You have to try, but don't expect perfection. ''Two Lies,'' a 25-minute film by Pam Tom, a Chinese-American writer and director, and ''Maicol,'' a 90-minute feature by an Italian director, Mario Brenta, both take on the question of whether single mothers can preserve their own identities without forever warping their children.

title: Strategies to Let Elderly Keep Some Control
description: Home care services, adult day care and a host of other programs to aid the disabled elderly are proliferating as more people search for alternatives to traditional nursing homes.

title: Intergroup Meets With Centaur
description: National Intergroup Inc., the Pittsburgh holding company with interests in drug distribution and steel, said its chairman, Howard M. Love, had met twice with officials of Centaur Partners, an investment firm engaged in a proxy battle to increase Intergroup's 12-member board by three seats.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a loss of $152,000 from discontinued operations. The company said this year's fourth quarter net is after a LIFO charge of $4.1 million, which reflected a reversal of the LIFO charge made during the first 9 months, and compared with a credit of $100,000 a year ago. For the full year, the LIFO credit was $200,000, compared with a charge of $3.2 million a year earlier.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Chronicle
description: Ambassador YURI V. DUBININ has given a new Soviet magazine, a monthly full-color publication called Vestnik (which means Chronicle), its Washington debut.

title: About New York;   A Heavy Burden: Burying Eileen, Sam, Liz and F/C
description: A cold wind whistled across Hart Island the other morning. It bent the leafless trees and swamp grass, and sent whitecaps dancing on Long Island Sound.

title: Winter Strawberry: Its Life and Its King
description: PLANT CITY calls itself the ''Winter Strawberry Capital of the World,'' and Robert E. (Roy) Parke is its undisputed king.

title: House Search Is Upheld In New Jersey Killings
description: A judge today upheld the police search of John E. List's house in Westfield that led to finding the bodies of his wife, three children and mother, as well as evidence pointing to Mr. List as their killer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armor All Products Corp., Irvine, Calif., which makes automotive products, named Mervyn J. McCulloch executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Review/Television;   New Host and New Technology, But a Familiar Oscar Show
description: Advice to Oscar the Diplomat: stay home. The effort to make this year's Academy Awards show an international media miracle led to nothing but headaches. Beyond opening up whole new worlds of triple feedback (from a malfunctioning microphone in Moscow) and global indiscretion (''Don't Cry for Me, Argentina'' was not the ideal musical lead-in for the show's Buenos Aires segment), the scheme to connect Hollywood with these and other capitals fell flat. The Oscar show's special commercials said it better, from Coca-Cola's ''I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing'' to an ode to ''food, folks and fun'' in honor of McGlasnost.

title: F.A.A. Is Undecided on Risk Of Radiation to Plane Crews
description: Nine months after the Federal Aviation Administration published data showing that some pregnant women receive far more radiation on airliners than Federal standards allow, the agency is still evaluating whether protective action is needed.

title: Ford Cutting Jobs At British Factory
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would eliminate nearly 3,000 jobs at one of its British car assembly plants. The first 400 jobs at the Halewood factory near Liverpool will be cut by the end of the year, and the rest will be dropped over five years, a spokesman said.

title: Edward Cristy Welsh, Economist And Space Program Pioneer, 81
description: Edward Cristy Welsh, an educator and economist who played a leading role in developing the nation's space program, died of a stroke on Sunday at the Charter House nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 81 years old and had lived at the nursing home for two years.

title: EATING WELL
description: CONDIMENTS like soy sauce, ketchup, mustard and barbecue sauce are added to food primarily for flavor. But they can add a lot more than that: unwanted calories, sodium, fat and sugar.

title: CANDOR IS REPAID ON AIRLINE SAFETY
description: To encourage airlines to come forward with safety problems they uncover, the Government announced today that it would no longer fine carriers that voluntarily admit to inadvertent violations of Federal safety rules.

title: Knicks End Slide at 6 And Gain on Leaders
description: Much of the basketball talk in New York for the last 16 days had centered on the Knicks' six-game losing streak: how it happened, why it happened and would it ever end.

title: Cobb Eyes N.F.L.
description: Six more underclassmen, including the running back Reggie Cobb of Tennessee, have been cleared for the N.F.L. draft, bringing to 28 the number of non-seniors who will be included in the April 22 selections. Cobb, who was suspended from his college team last fall after failing a drug test for the third time, was one of four running backs in the group approved since last Friday, the cutoff date for applying. Another was Braxston Banks of Notre Dame.(AP)

title: Countrywide Credit Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,314,000, or 12 cents a share, from the repurchase of $18,732,000 of the company's 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2011.

title: Bush Selects 4 for Arts Commission
description: President Bush released the names of four people yesterday whom he intends to appoint to a 12-member commission that will review the grant-making procedures of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Using Self-Esteem To Fix Society's Ills
description: IT is being called a vaccine against drug abuse, teen-age pregnancy, welfare dependency and other social ills. But some experts are calling it little more than yet another ''feel good'' approach to life's travails.

title: Commissioner Investigating Steinbrenner's Payment to Spira
description: John Dowd, the Washington lawyer who conducted baseball's six-month investigation of Pete Rose last year, is now investigating the George Steinbrenner-Howard Spira case for Commissioner Fay Vincent.

title: LITHUANIAN POLICE GUARD PARLIAMENT AS PRESSURE RISES
description: The leaders of Lithuania marshaled their meager police force to protect government and communications centers here today after Soviet troops seized young Lithuanian army deserters and secured the republic's Communist headquarters early this morning.

title: Banks Offering Check Program
description: Banks across the country are rapidly joining the ranks of those that offer their checking account customers insurance programs that cover goods purchased by check against loss and breakage, and extend manufacturers' warranties.

title: Not-So-Crazy Talk From Japan
description: Just who do the Japanese think they are? Tokyo's negotiators and Washington's have been talking jargon to each other for seven months about ''structural impediments'' to trade. Now the Japanese have found a way to show America how it feels to be patronized.

title: U.S. Sees Rapid Movement On Mexican Trade Talks
description: The United States and Mexico are moving more rapidly than expected toward opening negotiations on a free-trade agreement, Administration officials said today.
