title: Family Dollar Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Johnson Products reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $72,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $233,000, or 6 cents a share, for the 6 months, and the 6 months also included gain of $369,000 from sale of stock of Johnson Products Nigeria. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $8,000 and $589,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included $2.2 million gain on sale of real estate.

title: New York's Budget Squeeze;   Comptroller Predicts Budget Gap May Grow
description: The New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said yesterday that the city could face a budget gap this year that is far greater than that previously estimated by budget officials.

title: Wukeshu Journal;   The Perfect Union Still Eludes a Checkered China
description: Bi Shucai furrowed his brow into a hundred wrinkles as he tried to think of the differences between himself, a member of the ethnic Sani minority, and the Han Chinese people who rule the country he lives in.

title: INSIDE
description: Help for Bomb Workers

title: Reviews/Music;   'Last Emperor' Composer Blends Pop of 5 Continents
description: ''I hear what you never heard/I see what you never saw,'' Ryuichi Sakamoto and Nicky Holland sang on Thursday night at the Ritz. They could have been singing about Mr. Sakamoto's band, a coalition of performers from five continents that included the Senegalese singer Youssou N'Dour, a trio of singers and sanshin (lute) players from Okinawa, the singer and guitarist Arto Lindsay from New York and other performers from the United States, Brazil and Britain. Mr. Sakamoto, who is Japanese, was making international music, but he came up with a hodgepodge rather than a hybrid.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Bronx Social Club's Sublease: How a Firetrap Skirted the Line
description: A lease for the Bronx social club where 87 people died in an arson fire early Sunday shows that the building's landlord was aware that the club was to be used as ''a bar and game room.'' But responsibility for making sure the club complied with the law was left to the club's owner, Elias Colon, who was killed in the fire.

title: Toys 'R' Us Japan Bid
description: In a case seen as a challenge to barriers against entering the Japanese market, the Japanese Government has agreed to consider a United States toy company's move to open a store in the country, officials said today. Toys ''R'' Us Inc. has announced plans to open a 53,800-square-foot discount store in Niigata, 160 miles northwest of Tokyo. Local shopkeepers have strongly opposed the move. Under Japan's Large-Scale Retail Stores Law, intended to protect small retailers, they must be consulted before the opening of any large stores in their areas.

title: Copper Prices Drop Sharply After Comex Limits Buying
description: Copper prices plunged yesterday even though there is a growing global shortage of the important industrial metal.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Ted Block has been named executive vice president of FCB/Asia-Pacific.

title: Don't Blame Drug Program for AIDS Deaths;   Too Quick to Criticize
description: To the Editor:

title: KLM Gets Right to Serve Baltimore
description: The Department of Transportation yesterday granted KLM Royal Dutch Airlines the right to fly between Amsterdam and Baltimore. The route was the first awarded under a program in which foreign airlines can more easily receive permission to fly to United States cities with little overseas air service.

title: Foreigners Told to Leave Lithuania
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today ordered all foreigners to leave Lithuania, charging that the presence of journalists and diplomats was encouraging militants in their defiance of Soviet power.

title: The First Aphrodisiac?
description: To The Living Section:

title: United Illuminating Co. reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: b-Net income Results for the latest 12 months included a charge of $10.95 a share reflecting the effect of a change in accounting principle. The accounting change is related to non-cash writeoffs to recognize reductions in the recoverable cost of the Seabrook Unit 1 power facility. The year-ago 12 months included a similar charge of $2.37 a share.

title: Greyhound Offers Rewards in Bid To Stop Attacks on Buses in Strike
description: Greyhound Lines offered $100,000 rewards today for information leading to the conviction of those reponsible for gunfire aimed at terminals and the company's buses in a drivers' strike that is now nearly a month old.

title: Chronicle
description: The Rev. PAUL H. SHERRY was inaugurated last weekend as president of the United Church of Christ, a 1.6-million-member religious organization with headquarters in Cleveland. Dr. Sherry, 57 years old, was elected last July for a four-year term. He replaced the Rev. AVERY D. POST, who retired after 12 years as head of the church.

title: Market Place;   Tracking Down A Utility's Cash
description: TO many investors, just how much cash a company has can be an important indicator of financial health. But an investor seeking to learn the cash position of Dominion Resources Inc. at year-end may be confused.

title: Oscar, With Taste
description: Cher wasn't there. Viewers can always depend on Cher's dress, or undress, to cheer up an Academy Awards show. The vulgar opening musical number wasn't there, either. Viewers could always depend on it for at least two days of coffee break conversation. (''Would you believe . . .?'') Last year's female fashion statement - prom queen run amok - had subsided into a certain cool minimalism, though there were still enough beads and sequins, plunges and slithers to memorialize Mae West. Only a few hairdos reminded us that some women lose their head when they place it in a stylist's hands. The thank-you's were mercifully brief. On the whole it was tasteful.

title: B.A.T. Plans Sale Of Breuner Chain
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said it would sell its 18 John Breuner Company furniture stores to the Prism Capital Corporation, a merchant bank in New York, for $92.5 million in cash. The deal is to be completed by June through Batus Inc., B.A.T.'s American subsidiary.

title: About Education
description: Children whose homes and neighborhoods are in disarray are supposed to find stability in their schools.

title: Tiny Black College Takes High Road in Sciences
description: Xavier University, a few buildings on a dot of land squeezed between a highway, a drainage canal and rows of housing projects, hardly seems the stuff of educational legend. But this small college, where students' combined S.A.T. scores average a relatively low 840, excels at a task that has daunted far bigger and richer schools: turning out black doctors and pharmacists.

title: Merrill Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a previously reported $1,792,000 writeoff of investment in Sorg Inc. c-Net income

title: Choices, Choices
description: To The Living Section:

title: Tropical Diseases on March, Hitting 1 in 10
description: Nearly one person in 10 on earth now suffers from tropical diseases, and with unrelenting development and civil unrest the number is expected to increase steadily, a report by the World Health Organization said today.

title: The Oscar Winners
description: FILM: ''Driving Miss Daisy'' (Warner Brothers).

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * U J A-Federation of New York, to Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Co., for a fund-raising campaign to help resettle Soviet Jews in Israel.

title: New York's Budget Squeeze;   Bond Rating: A Censure of Bickering
description: More than just an indictment of the state's finances, the lowering of New York's credit rating on Monday was a censure of its political process.

title: Mets' Aces in Fine Form
description: For four dazzling innings tonight, the Mets shattered the confusion of baseball's bobtailed spring when they threw a pair of Cy Young Award winners against the Yankees and produced a pair of rave performances.

title: Job Hoppers Take Losses On Housing
description: Just as housing prices here rose in step with the metropolitan region's economy through the mid-1980's, they are stumbling now that the economy has slowed and businesses are trimming back.

title: Sweeping Changes Are Ordered at Nuclear Plants
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins today ordered critical changes in how the nuclear weapons industry monitors the health of 100,000 workers at 17 principal plants and laboratories.

title: Economic Scene;   Fed vs. Treasury On Dollar's Value
description: EARLIER this month, at a conference in Tokyo, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Manuel H. Johnson, said he was ''not uncomfortable with the current level of exchange rates.'' Hidden in that off-the-cuff comment may be a growing rift between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department over the dollar.

title: Florida to Act In Bass Suit
description: The Attorney General of Florida, Bob Butterworth, said last week that he would intervene in a lawsuit filed by the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass over dividends paid to the Poynter Institute, a media center that runs The St. Petersburg Times and other publications.

title: Serving Observant Jews
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bridge
description: A foursome from Harvard scored a convincing victory in the North American Collegiate Bridge Championship played during the weekend as part of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Fort Worth. Michael Mitzenmacher, James Colen, Franco Baseggio and Bill Cole headed a field of six teams, which had qualified from grass-roots play, in a preliminary round-robin. Then they defeated Illinois by 137 imps in the semifinal, and the California Institute of Technology by 144 in the final.

title: Prudential-Bache Said to Plan Staff Cuts
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. plans to dismiss 300 to 500 employees as part of a reorganization of the firm, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Listen, We Have to Regulate This Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Perez Finally Arrives; Has a Brief Workout
description: Pascual Perez, the Yankees' $5.7 million man, finally arrived for spring training tonight, eight days late and hours after authorities in the Dominican Republic agreed to defer court action in a paternity case brought against the 32-year-old pitcher.

title: Norwest Bank Deal Is Cleared by Fed
description: The Norwest Corporation said it had received Federal Reserve approval to acquire the First Interstate Corporation of Wisconsin, and it expects to close the deal about May 1. Under the agreement, First Interstate will become Norwest-Wisconsin.

title: The Happy Land Club in City Records
description: June 6, 1985: Alex DiLorenzo 3d buys the site for $885,000.

title: Terms Set For Merger Of Shearson
description: The American Express Company reached a final merger agreement with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to acquire all of the brokerage's common shares it does not already own, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Leslee Reis, 47, Dies; Illinois Restaurateur Won Many Awards
description: Leslee Reis, a restaurateur credited with bringing cosmopolitan dining to the Middle West, died of a heart attack on Sunday while on vacation in New Orleans. She was 47 years old and lived in Evanston, Ill.

title: New Packaging That Spared the Environment
description: New ways of packaging consumer goods are being developed and some old ones revived as environmental concerns grow, the cost of disposing solid waste rises and state and local governments adopt measures to promote recycling and degradability.

title: Tax Sleuths Turn to Technology
description: When not in the field ''wiring up'' undercover operators, Thomas F. Bushery, a special agent with the Internal Revenue Service, spends his days in a studio-like office near the Loop listening through headphones to often incriminating conversations.

title: Model Home-Care Program: Savings and Human Dignity
description: Wisconsin's home care program is one of the most ambitious in the nation.

title: Review/Theater;   Love Arrives in 'Mama, I Want to Sing' Sequel
description: ''The Story Continues,'' proclaims the subtitle of ''Mama, I Want to Sing, Part II,'' the sequel to the long-running musical.

title: A Banned Diet Aid May Still Be on Sale
description: Despite a Government recall of nearly all products containing the dietary supplement L-tryptophan because of reports linking its use to a sometimes fatal blood disorder, Federal health officials warn that the product may still be on the shelves.

title: Food Notes
description: From L.I., Early Caviar

title: Vanderbilt Is Driven By Former Cabbie
description: St. Louis is hoping that its second straight journey to the National Invitation Tournament championship game produces a different outcome. The Billikens lost the title to St. John's last season. Vanderbilt, their opponent this time, is trying to turn a former New York City cabdriver into an N.I.T. champion in his first season as head coach.

title: Furious Rally Gives Rangers a Gratifying Title
description: In the morning, their eyes will be back on the prize that matters most. But for a night, anyway, the Rangers could close their eyes to everything but the exquisite satisfaction of making something proud of a regular season and at the same moment exorcising a bit of burdensome history.

title: Topps Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
U.S. Seeking Trade Pact
description: The United States wants the Soviet Union and all participants at a 35-nation economic conference being held here to sign a declaration committing themselves to Western-style free-market principles, United States officials said today.

title: Review/Music;   The Cambridge Singers In Their New York Debut
description: Judging a book by its cover, warns the old saw, may not be the wisest way to select reading matter. To apply the same folk wisdom to music, a live concert by an artist or an ensemble known only from its recordings should be approached with a caution verging on skepticism. Uncomfortably often, it is technology, not practice, that makes perfect.

title: Chairman of Jaguar Plans to Retire in June
description: After 10 years as chairman of Jaguar P.L.C., the British luxury car manufacturer, Sir John Egan said yesterday that he will retire at the end of June.

title: IDB Communications Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said in the latest fourth quarter it reduced its estimated effective income tax rate and sold a 50 percent interest in certain operating equipment. These items increased fourth quarter net income by about $550,000.

title: Book Notes
description: Michener Talks

title: In Beijing, It's Easy To Smell A Rat
description: LEAD: ''Ma'am, we're kinda busy here. And quite frankly, no one else has ever seen hide or hair of them.''

title: Triple Transplant Recipient Dies After Hepatitis Sets In
description: The 26-year-old woman who last December became the world's only heart, liver and kidney transplant patient died of complications from hepatitis on Monday night.

title: Jet Engine Companies Add to Ties
description: In a move to spread costs and assure access to European markets, the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it would tighten its links to Daimler-Benz A.G., the big West German auto, aerospace and electronics manufacturer.

title: T&N Buying JP Industries
description: JP Industries, an engine components supplier, said it had agreed to be acquired by T & N P.L.C. of Manchester, England, for $17.30 a share in cash, or about $186.8 million, and the assumption of about $185 million in debt.

title: Accord on Control of Nicaraguan Army
description: Representatives of the Sandinista leadership today recognized the right of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to exercise full authority over the country's Sandinista-dominated army and security forces.

title: James Kahn; Executive, 64
description: James Kahn, the president of the Pension Planning Company of Manhattan, a division of Republic Hogg Robinson, was killed in an automobile accident en route to the airport in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Monday. He was 64 years old and lived in White Plains and Palm Beach.

title: Chronicle
description: The new artistic director of the English National Ballet is IVAN NAGY, who for 10 years was one of American Ballet Theater's noblest dancers. Mr. Nagy's appointment was announced last night in London by LADY HARLECH, the chairwoman of the company's board.

title: Food and Garbage Don't Mix, Truck Bill Says
description: The House overwhelmingly passed legislation today to prevent trucks used to ship food from hauling garbage on the return trip.

title: New Disclosure in Avianca Crash
description: The captain of an Avianca jetliner that crashed on Long Island in January told his co-pilot to declare a fuel emergency, but the co-pilot never used the critical word ''emergency'' in relaying the message to air-traffic controllers.

title: Justices Restrict Corporate Gifts For Politicians
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the power of the Federal and state governments to restrict corporate involvement in political campaigns.

title: A's Getting Under Way With an Angry Canseco
description: No one could ever call one of Jose Canseco's home runs a cheap shot, but today, Canseco was loaded with talk about cheap shots, not home runs, but the kind he said the Oakland Athletics' general manager took at him earlier this year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., filed a criminal complaint in Taiwan, contending that five people infringed its copyrights and trademarks.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the causes of death for the 87 victims of the fire at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx misidentified the director of the trauma center at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He is Dr. Roger Yurt.

title: Simmons of LaSalle Wins Eastman Award
description: Lionel Simmons, who accumulated 3,217 points - the third-highest total in National College Athletic Association Division I history - and grabbed 1,429 rebounds during a four-year career at La Salle University, yesterday was named the 16th recipient of the Eastman Award.

title: A Yankee Comes Back To Baseball
description: On the afternoon when the major leaguers and their owners gave us baseball games again, a vicious wind assaulted the playing fields at Malverne High School, slashing into the spines of all assembled.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Reviews/Dance;   Tranquillity and Rumbles
description: Although the organization called itself Ton Simons and Dancers, only one other person appeared with him on Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue. Brenda Daniels joined the Dutch choreographer in three exquisite duets that paid tribute to introspection.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Institutional Investors to Get A Seat on Lockheed's Board
description: The Lockheed Corporation, seeking to shore up support from institutional shareholders in its bitter proxy fight with a dissident investor group, agreed today to name a new director, not yet identified, to its board to represent the interests of such investors.

title: First Connecticut SBIC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $206,629 and $188,654 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After a capital loss of $31,337 for the quarter and a capital gain of $99,992 for the 9 months.

title: John L. Morkovsky; Catholic Bishop, 80
description: Bishop John L. Morkovsky, retired head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Galveston-Houston, died of a stroke on Saturday. He was 80 years old. Bishop Morkovsky led the diocese from June 1963 until his retirement in 1985.

title: 5 Soviet Boxers Win But Get Mixed Reviews
description: The Red Invasion, as it was billed, arrived successfully tonight as five Soviet boxers contracted to the New York-based promoter Lou Falcigno made their American pro debuts without losing in a ballroom of Bally's Casino Resort.

title: WINE TALK
description: CHARDONNAY is the Budweiser of white wines. It simply dominates the spectrum of white table wine. Even people who think they are getting away from chardonnay by drinking French or Italian wine are often drinking chardonnay without knowing it.

title: A Second President Is Named by USLife
description: The USLife Corporation, a major life insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had named William A. Simpson, a California insurance executive, as president. The company already has a president, and it appears that there will be two.

title: Telesphere Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The 1989 fourth quarter net benefited from the reduction of previous tax accruals and from the reversal of leased equipment writeoffs taken in early 1989. The net income was also net of a $300,000 reserve set up to provide for litigation filed dirung 1989.

title: Fiscal Fire Alarms, and Fire, in Albany
description: As threatened, the top bond rating agencies have now downgraded New York State's credit rating, leaving no doubt that the state is in serious financial trouble. With the legal deadline for approving the next budget now just four days away, leaders in Albany can no longer afford political games at public expense.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Hondurans Lack Place to Grieve Over Fire
description: Honduran authorities were told yesterday that more than 60 of the 87 people killed by the fire in a cramped Bronx social club were their countrymen, and in Tegucigalpa the President declared a day of national mourning.

title: For Cars, a Lighting Idea With No Bulbs
description: rrWith headlights, brake lights, warning lights and instrument panels, a typical car can have as many as 80 light bulbs, all consuming power, all gradually wearing out. The General Electric Company is developing a way to replace them all with one central lighting system.

title: Canadian Mining & Energy Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Restated The company was formed Oct. 1, 1988, through a merger of Saskatchewan Mining Development Corp. (SMDC), and Eldorado Nuclear Ltd. As a result, the 1988 figures included SMDC's results for the full year, and Eldorado's results for the fourth quarter only. The company is wholly owned by the governments of Saskatchewan and Canada, and has no publicly traded shares. The company said the reduced earnings mainly reflected the impact of interest charges accruing from $650 million of funds borrowed when the company was formed. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Man Slain in South Africa Town Where Police Fired on Marchers
description: A young schoolteacher died on a quiet street corner in this black township today, becoming another statistic in a confrontation between the police and inhabitants that began Monday when the police fired on a crowd of demonstrators.

title: Eastern Gloomy on Earnings
description: Eastern Airlines told its creditors yesterday that its inability to win back business travelers had cut its revenues and that it could therefore no longer guarantee to pay them 50 cents on the dollar as promised.

title: Foreign Doctor Calls Ailment In Yugoslavia Mass Hysteria
description: A doctor on an international team sent to investigate a mysterious illness in Kosovo province said today that it was a case of mass hysteria among ethnic Albanians.

title: KRG Management reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Way to Save Lithuania
description: LEAD: The stakes are too high in Lithuania and the risk of a military crackdown too great for the Administration simply to call for a peaceful resolution. Rather, the U.S. should declare its intention to extend formal diplomatic recognition to the new Lithuanian government in the event that President Mikhail

title: Chronicle
description: GLENDA JACKSON was chosen last night to stand for Parliament as the Labor Party candidate for the constituency of Highgate and Hampstead in northwest London. She said she would give up acting if elected.

title: New Office Software Is Offered by A.T.&T.
description: A.T.& T. introduced an office computer software system yesterday that is designed to link desktop computers built by two of its rivals, I.B.M. and Compaq.

title: 2 Performers Leap With Aplomb Into the Abyss of True Love
description: ''You've got to jump off that cliff every night and just do it,'' said Alec Baldwin, the actor. ''I think this is one of the hardest things I've ever done.''

title: Congress Begins Eisenhower Tribute
description: Congress today turned back the clock a few decades, paying tribute to Dwight D. Eisenhower as a hero of war, an architect of peace and a no-nonsense Kansas farm boy affectionately known to millions of Americans simply as ''Ike.''

title: Islanders Stumble Closer to Elimination
description: This is how drab it has become around the Islanders: Players and fans were reduced tonight to watching the team's fate on the scoreboard and then television.

title: Woodward's Ltd.  reports earnings for Year Jan 27
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $17,183,000 which reflected costs associated with a fourth-quarter restructuring that involved the elimination of 625 full-time positions. c-Restated to reflect adjustment in inventory valuation. Revenue for 1989 included $17.8 million from Woodward's credit card operations, which the company sold in January 1989. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Crowley, Milner & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Stocks Climb Sharply as Dow Gains 29.28
description: Stocks fought off a general malaise yesterday, advancing sharply on slow volume in a rise that analysts said was helped along by computerized program trading.

title: Restoring Old Buildings Takes Special Skills
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's Budget Squeeze;   Ratings Given by Agencies to Shape Interest Rates for Years
description: When rating agencies assess state and local governments with a letter grade, they are doing more than just issuing an opinion. They are shaping the interest rates governments will pay for years, even decades into the future.

title:
EDUCATION;

Milwaukee Parents Get More Choice On Schools
description: LEAD: In a move that for the first time extends parental choice in education to private as well as public schools, the Wisconsin State Legislature has passed a bill allowing 970 low-income students from the Milwaukee Public Schools to use state funds to attend private, nonsectarian schools.

title: Epsilon Data Management reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $42,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Michigan Offers Tax-Free Bonds
description: The Michigan Municipal Bond Authority is tentatively offering $74 million in tax-exempt local government loan program revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.25 percent for a long-term bond due in 2009.

title: Brazilian Loans Decline In International Trading
description: The price of Brazilian debt has fallen since the country's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, announced his tough economic program 12 days ago. But traders in the highly specialized market that deals with such debt say the decline is not a reflection of unhappiness with Mr. Collor's program.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Unlawful Clubs Posing Hazards In Other Cities
description: From seedy speakeasies called ''blind pigs'' in Detroit to chic underground clubs in Los Angeles, unlicensed nightclubs pop up in cities around the country, local officials say.

title: In Arkansas, Basketball Gives Racial Harmony a Big Assist
description: While the Arkansas players scattered after practicing for the school's first appearance in the Final Four, Robby Gibson and Ike Hughes were at the Barnhill Arena entrance, running and leaping and tossing an imaginary basketball at an imaginary hoop. One day, both said, say in the year 2000, they just might be Razorbacks on their way to a Final Four.

title: Alexander's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 10
description: b-Reflected a $14,794,000 after-tax gain on sales of a store lease and property for the stores located in Menlo Park, N.J., and White Plains, N.Y. c-After a loss of $3,416,000 from an accounting adjustment. Year-ago 6 months' income from continuing operations of $25,618,000, or $5.15 a share,, reflected $10 million after-tax gain on sale of the lease on the store located in Milford, Conn., which closed in July 1988.

title: Circle K Seeks A Revamping
description: The Circle K Corporation, the nation's second-largest operator of convenience stores, said it would try to renegotiate its debt because of liquidity problems. The company said a revamping could be completed without filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: A Change of Taste: Plain, Hearty Food
description: TRAVELING around the country 30-some weeks a year to teach cooking classes, I eat often in restaurants, some great, some not so great. Occasionally my stomach rebels against my excesses and I long for some plain, unadorned vegetable soup like the garlic soup that is an early spring favorite at my house.

title: Mayor's Car Used in Getaway
description: An inmate who walked out of the Nesaygo County Jail during a jail church service Sunday night and made his getaway in the Mayor's car surrendered today, the authorities said. The 25-year-old inmate, Dean Dilts, who was awaiting sentencing for armed robbery, walked six blocks and stole a 1977 Buick from Mayor Russell Gilbert's driveway, the police said. The car was later found abandoned in the town of Holland. Mr. Dilts called the police to turn himself in, and was picked up in his hometown of Muskegon.

title: Treasury Issues Fall in Quiet Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers placed bids on $10 billion worth of new two-year notes - the only real activity of the day.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Contrarian Approach At Barneys
description: WHEN it comes to reckoning with their past advertising, both agencies and clients grow skittish. They want to promote pride in their heritage, but with modernity at a premium in the disposable world of consumer products, any hint that a company is not contemporary can be deadly.

title: Bid of $38 a Share Made for Apple Bancorp
description: Stanley Stahl, a New York real estate developer who holds a 30.3 percent stake in Apple Bancorp Inc., last night made a $38-a-share cash offer for the New York City-based savings bank company. Mr. Stahl's offer values the company at $174 million.

title: As Big Brokers Trim, The Small Add Talent
description: Amid the chaos and upheaval on Wall Street, several small and foreign investment-banking and brokerage houses are finding reason to celebrate.

title: A New Emphasis on Finishing Touches
description: FRENCH designers have always used accessories to give emphasis to their fashion statements, draping their models with piles of jewelry, scarfs, bags and hats. At a time when clothes aren't changing dramatically, accessories can add excitement to a wardrobe - and do so less expensively than a new dress or jacket. Women know that, and so do designers.

title: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Up Slightly for the Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were slightly up for the week ended yesterday.

title: Peanut Butter Warning
description: To The Living Section:

title: Rene Enriquez, 56; Played a Lieutenant In 'Hill Street Blues'
description: Rene Enriquez, an actor who portrayed Lieut. Ray Calletano on the award-winning television series ''Hill Street Blues,'' died of pancreatic cancer at his home in suburban Tarzana on Friday. He was 56 years old.

title: License Is Revoked for Pilot of Jet That Slid Off La Guardia Runway
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it had revoked the pilot's license of the captain of the USAir jetliner that skidded off the end of a runway at La Guardia Airport six months ago, killing two people.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Collaboration In Dance And Music
description: Robert Kovich and John King are good company. Mr. Kovich has set several of his modern dance pieces to music composed and performed by Mr. King, and the two have developed a freewheeling creative partnership. Mr. Kovich also works with imaginative costume and lighting designers and dancers. So a program presented by the Robert Kovich Company on Sunday night at the 14th Street Dancecenter was spirited. But the heart of the program was the stylishly complementary work of Mr. Kovich and Mr. King.

title: Hope Is Held Out on Space Station Problems
description: The leaders of a study who said a proposed $30 billion space station would require prohibitive maintenance told Congress today that they felt NASA had solutions available. But they said the agency needed to act quickly.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Is Fit
description: After several days of inconvenience, the United States national soccer team will play East Germany Wednesday night in its first match since losing, 2-0, last week to Hungary in Budapest.

title: Giovanna Borradori, Author, Is Wed To Arturo Zampaglione, a Journalist
description: Giovanna Borradori, an author of books on 20th-century philosophy, and Arturo Zampaglione, the New York bureau chief of La Repubblica, a daily newspaper in Italy, were married yesterday in Milan, Italy. The ceremony was performed by Milan City Councilman Guido Aghina at Villa Reale di via Palestro, a museum. The bride is the daughter of Professor and Mrs. Dario Borradori of Milan. Her husband is a son of Gerardo Zampaglione, the Italian Consul General in Calcutta, India, and Mrs. Zampaglione of Rome.

title: U.S. Praises Poland's Plans To Fly Soviet Jews to Israel
description: The United States praised Poland today for agreeing to fly Soviet Jews to Israel and deplored the decision of the Hungarian airline, Malev, to stop flights in the face of threats of terrorism.

title: Sequa Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,498,000 for the quarter and $4,637,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,307,000 and $4,080,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest periods' results reflected the inclusion of a $15.1 million pre-tax loss on transactions concluded in the final quarter of 1989 to restructure Sequa's aerospace group. Results for all periods reflected the reconsolidation of the company's men's apparel division, which had previously been classified as a discontinued operation. Corrected from Thursday, March 22, editions.

title: Lambert Somec Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: What's in a Hyphen? For the Slovaks, Plenty
description: While ethnic frictions elsewhere in Eastern Europe have led to clubbings and shootings, in this nation of gentility and literary tradition, the Czechs and Slovaks are locked in a different type of ethnic battle, one over a hyphen.

title: East Germans Unlock a Murky Past: Nazi Prisons Turned Soviet Prisons
description: In a desolate heath at the edge of this town 75 miles north of Berlin, Harry Schulz, a 33-year-old Communist historian, pointed to a fresh mound of earth. A sprig of green, newly planted, seemed to be losing its battle to take root, but freshly cut flowers had been laid on the grave.

title: Colleague Denounces Comments By Illinois Congressman as Bigoted
description: Remarks made by Representative Gus Savage of Illinois in the closing days of his successful Democratic primary campaign have been condemned as ''divisive and bigoted'' by the House Democratic whip, Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Fire Suspect's Relationship: Placid 8 Years, Angry 5 Weeks
description: Lydia Feliciano loved reggae and salsa, and she often went dancing late into the night. In recent months, she had worked weekends, checking tickets and earning $150 a night at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx.

title: Sihanouk Sees 'Stumbling Blocks' to a Settlement
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he was pessimistic about the chances for a settlement soon in Cambodia, and he accused Vietnam of moving its border to seize Cambodian territory.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS a Frenchman, I learned early to love the anise-like flavor of fennel, and today I use it in endless recipes to add a fresh, snappy touch. The French have a particular fondness for the flavor of fennel and anise. Fennel, a vital ingredient in the summery cuisine of Provence, is used in all sorts of salads, soups and stews. Anise flavors the popular French aperitifs, Pernod and Ricard. For many years in this country fennel was all but ignored in favor of celery, its similarly textured but less assertive cousin. Today, most supermarkets carry the pale green bulbs. When buying fresh fennel, look for crisp, fully formed bulbs that have no discoloring or soft spots. Fennel, like celery, can wilt in humid conditions. If it is not too far gone, it can be refreshed in ice water.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about skin cancer referred incorrectly to a researcher, Darrell Rigel.

title: British Review Of Airline Deal
description: The British Government referred British Airways P.L.C.'s purchase of a 20 percent stake in Sabena World Airlines to the monopolies commission today for a review of its impact on air service to and from Britain.

title: Moscow Worries About Effect of Nationalist Tensions on Army
description: The crackdown on military deserters in Lithuania reflects growing Soviet concern over the cohesion of the Soviet Army in the face of ethnic tensions and draft evasion in several non-Russian republics, American officials and military experts said today.

title: Group Split Over Law On Drugs
description: A split has developed in the biotechnology industry, pitting the two leading companies against two other major companies in the field. At issue is how much protection should be awarded to those first in the market with a product.

title: Congress Looking Into the Diet Business
description: A CONGRESSMAN who has investigated the misuse of infertility drugs and cosmetic surgery over the last decade threw down the gauntlet before the diet industry this week.

title: Review/Theater;   'Making Movies,' a Satire Of the Celluloid World
description: A first-time film director is making a movie about disgruntled marines on the island of Guam. Naturally he is shooting it on location - on a farm outside Schenectady. Wildly over budget, he hopes to recoup his fortunes with a dramatic final scene, but, as the cameras roll, three cows amble into the picture, adding a jarringly bucolic note to the battlefield.

title: Watch Company Is Fined in Green-Card Suit
description: For the first time, an administrative law judge has ruled in a trial that a job applicant is protected from discrimination on the basis of United States citizenship under the Immigration Act.

title: Embattled Tobacco Still Pays the Bills
description: Robert W. Conner knelt in the mugginess of his greenhouse, gently fingering tiny seedlings of cantaloupe, watermelon, broccoli and cucumber, some of the thousands of sprouts that will be transplanted next month to fields on the more than 4,000 acres that he farms. But he noted that the melons and vegetables didn't amount to much next to the profits from his main crop, tobacco.

title: Books of The Times;   When Baseball Was Young and Play Was Rough
description: If I Never Get Back

title: Dr. Michel Mirowski Is Dead at Age of 65; Made Heart Implant
description: Dr. Michel Mirowski, the principal developer of a device that controls sometimes fatal irregular heartbeats, died of cancer on Monday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 65 years old and lived in Owings Mills, Md.

title: Real Estate;   Toys 'R' Us Called Lift for Herald Center
description: A RETAILING phenomenon that has grown to more than 500 stores but lacks a Manhattan outlet, Toys ''R'' Us Inc., has leased most of four floors in Herald Center, the retail complex opposite Macy's that has been dogged by problems since opening six years ago.

title: A Bulgarian Town's Killer Is Industrial Pollution
description: In this valley under the snowcapped Balkan Mountains, old people remember the time when everyone grew roses, acres of roses, which they pressed into oils for perfume and medicine.

title: $775 Million Worth of Notes Priced by New York State
description: The State of New York yesterday priced $775 million in short-term notes due Dec. 28, 1990, through competitive bidding, one day after Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered the state's short-term debt ratings to MIG-2 and SP-1, respectively, from MIG-1 and SP-1+.

title: Fuller (H.B.) Co.  (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,400,000. The company said the extraordinary charge related to losses caused by looting and destruction of its operations in Panama following the United States' military action in December 1989.

title: Dominant Devils Take 3d Straight
description: Even a severe critic might have had difficulty finding any fault with the way the Devils played in their 4-1 triumph over the Washington Capitals tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Don't Blame Drug Program for AIDS Deaths;   A Promising Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Frenchtex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Blowers Has Fast Start In Bid for Infield Spot
description: Almost six months ago, when the final game of the regular season was over, Mike Blowers gathered up his belongings in the Yankee clubhouse, said his goodbyes to his teammates, left the stadium and boarded a plane for Florida.

title: Hazelwood's Acquittal Clouds the Exxon Case
description: Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood's acquittal on the most serious charges against him complicates the question of legal responsibility for the Exxon Valdez oil spill and how the Exxon Corporation will fare in pending civil litigation, lawyers in the cases say.

title: Circle K Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and included an after- tax gain of $14,437,000 from sale of commissary operation for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included an after-tax gain of $6,409,000 from sale of Ice manufacturing operations.

title: Review/Music;   Ukrainian Festival With Absurdist Humor
description: The Ukrainian Contemporary Music Festival presented by the Ukrainian Institute of America at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening was neither particularly contemporary nor very festive. Of its four works, one - Boris Lyatoshynsky's ''Sonata-Ballada'' (Op. 18) for piano - was from 1925, and two others were from 1971. And the only trace of lightheartedness occurred in the absurdist humor (itself somewhat dated) of Valentin Silvestrov's ''Drama'' (1971). What the program did offer, in good performances, was varied and sometimes interesting fare by four skilled composers, though nothing approaching a masterpiece.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Yellow Pages Space
description: The Yellow Pages Publishers Association said it would commit $62 million in ad space in its directories to the anti-drug campaign of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America.

title: Don't Blame Drug Program for AIDS Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts at First Union
description: The First Union Corporation said it plans to cut operating costs by $35 million this year and $70 million in 1991 after its recent acquisition of Florida National Banks Inc. The company told shareholders in its annual report that substantial pretax savings are projected from ''eliminating duplicate facilities and job functions.''

title: Lessons
description: Richard Lavoie walked briskly around the room pointing to an animal-picture book, randomly asking the audience to name the animal, imitate its sound and think of a story featuring that animal.

title: New York's Budget Squeeze;   New York City Wary on Rating Cut
description: Fiscal experts said yesterday that the lowering of New York State's credit rating would have no immediate impact on the rating of New York City bonds but that it might make it even harder for the state to help the city with state aid in the future.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10

title: Marcos Trial Fascinates and Splits Filipinos
description: For most Filipinos, Imelda Marcos's trial in New York is the latest episode in a long-running soap opera on the perils of power. Following the courtroom spectacle in local news accounts, they remain fascinated by the latest twist in Mrs. Marcos's story - from poor provincial beauty to glittering First Lady and now, to the widow on the dock.

title: House Panel Approves Aid to Central America
description: A House committee approved President Bush's urgent request for aid to Panama and Nicaragua today, but not before nearly tripling, to $2.4 billion, the overall cost of the bill containing the funds.

title: KEY RATES
Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: b-After a loss of $815,000 from discontinued operations. c-After income of $7,134,000, or 7 cents a share, from discontinued operations. The 1990 revenues included $64,051,000 from discontinued operations, compared with $204,244,000 from discontinued operations included in 1989 revenues.

title: Slumps in the Past For Agassi and Seles
description: In the aftermath of the Lipton International Players Championships, the women's winner, 16-year-old Monica Seles, gave herself something to giggle about by soaring to a career-high ranking of No. 4 on the Virginia Slims computer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Smithsonian's Lighter Touch
description: Like other relatively highbrow magazines, Smithsonian is concerned about being overlooked by young media planners, who, those magazines fear, often favor trendier publications.

title: REPUBLICANS AGREE NEW YORK IS FACING BIGGER BUDGET GAP
description: Apparently chastened by a downgrading of the state's credit rating on Monday, Senate Republicans agreed today that the gap in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed 1990-91 budget had grown to $1.5 billion.

title: The Din Of Popcorn Fills the Land
description: THE popcorn business is hot but not necessarily buttered. There are a host of new products, including light microwave and white cheddar cheese versions, and even a new appreciation for this ancient American snack by serious chefs.

title: Proposed New York State Budget Would Hurt Farm Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Blame Drug Program for AIDS Deaths;   Clinical Trials Improve
description: To the Editor:

title: Umpires to Return Friday
description: Major league umpires agreed today to return to work in spring training games on Friday while pay and other related issues are resolved through binding arbitration. United States District Judge Norma L. Shapiro announced the agreement between baseball and union officials in open court following closed-door sessions that began this morning.

title: U.S. Tests TV Station Aimed at Cuba
description: The Government this morning began its first test of a United States-financed television station that broadcasts programming directly to Cuba.

title: Navy Spy Asks Court to Cancel Guilty Plea
description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, a former Navy intelligence analyst who was sentenced to life in prison after he admitted spying for Israel in 1986, has asked to withdraw his guilty plea and be tried for espionage, one of his lawyers said today.

title: Export Firm's President Is Found in East River
description: The body of the president of an international company that inspects shipments to developing countries was discovered floating in the East River on Sunday, the police said yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Disney Names a Zoologist To New Environmental Post
description: The Walt Disney Company yesterday created the new post of corporate vice president for environmental policy and named Kym Murphy to fill it.

title: Korea's Growth Eases
description: South Korea's gross national product grew 6.7 percent last year after inflation, the slowest level of real growth since 1982 and a reflection of sluggish exports, central bank officials said today. The Bank of Korea said the 1989 growth rate was far below the 12.4 percent reported for 1988

title: Bush to Jays' Opener
description: President Bush is going to mix pleasure with business next month as he attends a baseball opener in Canada, and he even will get to watch a team partly owned by his son.

title: The Pop Life
description: Knopfler Just for Fun

title: Ribbs Out of Indy 500
description: Willy T. Ribbs, who enlisted the support of Bill Cosby last November in his attempt to become the first black driver to compete in the Indianapolis 500, has abandoned his plans to drive in that race in 1990.

title: Stride Rite reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 2
C.F.T.C. Role Is Seen at Risk
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was quoted today in a newspaper as saying that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission could be the big loser in its dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A Black Is Shot In a High School In Bensonshurst
description: In what the police called a bias-related incident, a 14-year-old black was shot in the wrist yesterday at a high school in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: Review/Harpsichord;   Trevor Pinnock Plays Bach
description: The English harpsichordist Trevor Pinnock gave a fine recital of Bach works at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. That may come as no surprise, since Mr. Pinnock is a performer of proven skills and established reputation.

title: Halston, Symbol of Fashion In America in 70's, Dies at 57
description: Halston, the designer who personified American fashion in the 1970's, died of complications from AIDS Monday night at Pacific Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco. He was 57 years old and had lived in New York before moving to San Francisco earlier this year.

title: Oscars Off in Ratings
description: The Academy Awards ceremony, broadcast from 9 P.M. to 12:35 A.M. on Monday by ABC, drew its smallest audience in three years. The program had a 27.9 rating, the A. C. Nielsen Company said, and was seen by 48 percent of the television audience. ABC estimated that 70 million people watched at least part of the program. Last year, the program had a 29.8 rating, and the 1988 show also did better than the 1990 edition. In prime time, from 9 P.M. to 11 P.M., the Oscars had a 29.6 rating. NBC had a 9.8 rating and CBS had an 8.5 rating.

title: Poindexter Defense Abruptly Rests Case
description: After less than six days of testimony, defense lawyers in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter abruptly rested their case today without calling the former national security adviser to testify about his own actions in the affair.

title: Illinois Tool Works To Acquire Buell
description: Illinois Tool Works agreed to acquire Buell Industries for common stock worth $17.25 a share, or about $39 million. Stockholders of Buell, based in Waterbury, Conn., have the option of receiving part of the transaction in cash. Buell makes fasteners and precision metal components.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Nature, Suggested By Eddies And Tides
description: Nancy Meehan, a choreographer who continues to go her own way, has created a splendid and original new work in ''Nine Leaf Window.''

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Club Victims Taken to Funeral Homes
description: Seventy-four bodies from the fire at a Bronx social club were taken from the morgue to funeral homes yesterday, and most will be flown to Honduras after viewings this week.

title: Rates Rise At Citicorp
description: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday for the second consecutive week.

title: U.S. SOFTENS TONE ON LITHUANIA ISSUE
description: After days of steadily tougher talk on Lithuania, the White House softened its tone today. In the wake of the first overt use of Soviet military force in the Baltic republic, the United States made it clear that it was not prepared to take Lithuania's side in a test of wills with Moscow.

title: Cautious Courage About Lithuania
description: Soviet and Lithuanian leaders both have shown signs of losing their sense of restraint in recent days. That's all the more reason to welcome the cautious courage of President Bush and other Western leaders. They understand the dangers of choosing sides and refuse to be drawn into one-sided Soviet-bashing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We made a mistake. We didn't agree fast enough that there was a problem. O.K., that's behind us. Now we want to be constructive and get this done.''

title: U.S. and Japan to Work Together On Weapons Systems Research
description: In a collaboration that reflects Tokyo's growing skills in military technology, the United States and Japan have reached a basic agreement to cooperate in research on three technologies likely to be critical to future American weapons systems, officials of both Governments say.

title: Ex-Navy Chief Offers a Plan to Cut Spending
description: John F. Lehman Jr., who helped push a military buildup as Secretary of the Navy during the Reagan Administration, told Congress today that the Navy should not cut back on its size but could make substantial savings by reducing overseas commitments and shifting a major part of the fleet to the reserves in light of a reduced Soviet threat.

title: Oracle Net Flat in Period
description: The Oracle Corporation reported today that its third-quarter earnings were flat despite record revenue.

title: Pennsylvania to Toughen Bill to Thwart Takeovers
description: In a move that could severely hinder proxy fights in Pennsylvania, the state's Legislature moved on Monday to make what is already the nation's toughest state anti-takeover statute even tougher.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about schizophrenia misidentified an advocacy group, and an article on Friday about community mental health programs referred to it incorrectly.

title: Reviews/Music;   Ritual and Technology
description: It is appropriate if not poetic that programs like the one on Saturday evening at the the Asia Society should emanate from a series called Music From Japan. Here in four segments, deeply embedded ritual shook hands with modern technology. Everyone feels such culture clashes, but they are never more compelling than among the past-rooted and future-driven Japanese.

title: Reviews/Music;   Yes It Was, Despite Name
description: Legal strictures prevent Jon Anderson, Bill Bruford, Rick Wakeman and Steve Howe from calling themselves a reunited Yes, although they were respectively Yes's singer and lyricist, drummer, keyboardist and guitarist in 1971-72, the band's best lineup. But Yes fans filled Madison Square Garden on Friday night for the final show of a world tour by Anderson, Bruford, Wakeman, Howe, with the old quintet lineup completed by Tony Levin on bass and augmented with a guitarist and a keyboardist.

title: Savings-Unit Pledge Made
description: A top Federal regulator promised today to give sympathetic treatment to struggling savings and loan institutions that try to raise more cash to avoid being taken over by the Government.

title: Time to Acquire Sunset Magazine
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Lane Publishing Company, the publisher of Sunset magazine and Sunset Books, in a deal valued at $225 million.

title: William T. Scott, 71, New York City Aide In 70's Fiscal Crisis
description: William Thomas Scott, assistant to the president of the United Federation of Teachers and a former deputy city comptroller who played an important role in rescuing the city from its fiscal crisis in the 1970's, died of a heart attack on Monday at a friend's house in Tarpon Springs, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: Reviews/Film Festival;   A Soviet Sociopolitical Parable, Maybe
description: ''Saint's Day'' is a reminder of how little most of us know about the variety of life within the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which our popular propaganda has so long seen as a single forbidding monolith of dreary sameness.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: They Horripilate Too
description: I just came back reeking from the million-dollar shed. That's what we call the garden shed at the back of the yard in honor of what it cost to have it fixed up to house a lawn mower and some rusty pruning shears in decent style.

title: Bankruptcy Pay Ruling
description: Federal Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. granted a request yesterday in Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati by Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation to take back about $5.3 million due to Thomas M. Macioce, the former chairman and chief executive of Allied Stores.

title: Amplicon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Last Word in Recycling
description: New York City's Sanitation Department collects 17,000 tons of residential trash and garbage a day, and recycles about 700. Under a city law that took effect last summer, the amount recycled is to reach 4,000 tons by 1994. The department is tackling its huge task one neighborhood at a time, gradually educating New Yorkers to bundle their newspapers, magazines and corrugated cardboard once a week in stacks no more than 18 inches high and tied with ''sturdy twine.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Study Finds High Risk to Overweight Women
description: A large study of middle-aged and younger women has shown that being overweight by virtually any degree increases the risk of heart disease.

title: CONTRAS REPORTED BACK IN NICARAGUA
description: In their camps here in the steep green hills along the border in Honduras, Nicaraguan rebels say most of their fighters have quietly slipped back into Nicaragua and that each day more young men with automatic rifles are following them.

title: Ford to Shut Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would shut its assembly plant in Lorain, Ohio, next week, idling about 2,700 hourly workers. The closing results from slow sales of the Thunderbird and Cougar models assembled at the plant, which was also closed for four of the first six weeks of 1990. A market analyst at Ford said that sales of full-sized specialty cars like Thunderbird and Cougar ''have been considerably weaker this year than the car market in general.''

title: Warwick Insurance Managers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $7.5 million addition to loss reserves after further evaluation of losses due to increased frequency, emergence and severity of claims experienced in the 1989 period. The strenghening of reserves was also attributable to the impact of the company's higher net retention level of $250,000 for accident years 1987 and subsequent. c-Net income

title: The Mood Is Ethnic, The Style Is Classic
description: GEORGE STAVROPOULOS does not have to go far to tune into the ethnic craze that is surfacing in many fashion centers. All he has to do is turn to his own heritage, since he was a couturier in his native Greece before he set up shop in New York in the 1960's. His heritage is classic, and nothing has been developed to best the drapery on ancient statuary.

title: De Benedetti Is Questioned
description: The financier Carlo de Benedetti was questioned on Tuesday for six hours by a judge about his 65 days as a vice president of Banco Ambrosiano, the bank whose failure in 1982 was at the center of an Italian scandal. At the end of the questioning, Mr. de Benedetti told reporters he was ''serene and satisfied'' because he was able to tell the magistrate ''the total honesty of my behavior.''

title: Israeli Army Drops Ban on Press Group Run by Palestinians
description: The Israeli Army lifted a ban on a Palestinian news agency today, two years after the authorities shut it down by military order.

title: Retooling for Peace Will Take Some Planning;   No Windfall
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15

title: Oracle Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Review/Rock;   Songs, Growls and Humor By Canada's Alannah Myles
description: The older rock-and-roll music grows, the more its early days are becoming haloed in myth.

title: Chiat Vying For Reebok
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo has jumped into the competition for the $40 million Reebok International athletic shoe advertising account, which the agency resigned in January when the sneaker company decided to put the account into review.

title: FREE-TRADE TALKS WITH U.S. SET OFF DEBATE IN MEXICO
description: In a break with the policy of economic nationalism that has prevailed here since the Mexican Revolution of 1910, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has agreed to consider negotiations for a free-trade agreement with the United States.

title: Rose Putts As Piniella 'Relaxes'
description: Only a few miles from where the Cincinnati Reds were perspiring, his white Mercedes convertible, its top down and its burgundy interior shining in the warm sun, was parked outside the Walden Lake Polo and Country Club's luxurious clubhouse. Out on the third green, Pete Rose, putting right-handed, stroked a four-footer. When the ball slid by the cup, he stared at the sky.

title: Rita Wallsh, Psychiatrist, 56
description: Dr. Rita Wallsh, a psychiatrist in Manhattan, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 56 years old.

title: Horizon Healthcare reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $68,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $168,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: 87 Die in Blaze at Illegal Club in Bronx
description: Eighty-seven people, crammed into an illegal Bronx social club, were asphyxiated or burned to death within minutes in a flash fire early yesterday morning. The police later arrested a man who they said had set the blaze with gasoline after a quarrel there.

title: The U.S. Intervenes
description: Once again, and for the second time in a year, the United States has allowed Communist governments to dictate American foreign policy.

title: Chemical's Banking Plan
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation has abruptly decided to revise its dividend reinvestment plan to eliminate features that were causing sharp quarterly spikes in the reported short interest in the bank's shares, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: First Bancorp (N.C.) reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
Issues of 'Junk Bonds' Off Sharply in Quarter
description: Underwritings of ''junk bonds'' shrank dramatically in the first quarter, reflecting the disarray in the market for these high-yield, high-risk securities and the downfall of Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Retail Group President
description: As expected, John J. Schultz has been named president of the National Retail Federation's retail services division in New York, effective Sunday. He succeeds James R. Williams, who is resigning to become a consultant. Mr. Schultz was most recently president and chief executive of the B. Altman & Company chain of department stores. The Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer, closed six of the seven Altman stores after filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in this country.

title: Fund Backs Lockheed
description: The New York City Employees Retirement System said today that it would vote its shares of the Lockheed Corporation in favor of the company's current management and board in their proxy battle with the Texas investor Harold C. Simmons.

title: ATOM BOMB PARTS SEIZED IN BRITAIN EN ROUTE TO IRAQ
description: Six people were arrested in Britain today in what American and British officials said was an attempt to smuggle electronic devices used to trigger nuclear weapons to Iraq.

title: Basketball;   Penders Agrees To Stay At Texas
description: Tom Penders, the Texas basketball coach, reportedly a candidate for jobs at Virginia, Florida and North Carolina State, has agreed to a seven-year, $735,000 contract, Athletic Director DeLoss Dodds said today. The move ends weeks of speculation that Penders was considering leaving Texas.

title: Subway Service Is Disrupted By Derailment on No. 1 Line
description: Subway service on the No. 1 Broadway Local line was halted shortly after 9 P.M. last night when the last car of a 10-car train derailed just north of the 215th Street Station in upper Manhattan, Transit Authority officials said.

title: Zentec Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   SOVIET VIEWS SEEN TO SPLIT BY REGION
description: Soviet citizens of different nationality differ sharply in their views on the Communist Party, the Soviet Army and a wide array of other issues, according to the first poll of Soviet citizens ever conducted jointly by Soviet and American survey researchers in many sites spread across the Soviet Union.

title: CHC Helicopter reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is changing its year- end to April 30. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: House Ready to Debate Measure Expanding Child Care Assistance
description: After months of internal wrangling and fitful attempts at compromise, the House of Representatives on Thursday will consider a long-sought bill expanding Federal assistance for child care.

title: Basketball;   No Death-Benefit Policy
description: A $1 million disability insurance policy was purchased last year before a heart condition was detected in Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball star, but it did not contain a death benefit, said Dr. Bruce G. Fagel, a lawyer for the Gathers family.

title: Guardian Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Basketball;   Vanderbilt Hangs On And Captures Title
description: Vanderbilt, which had a seven-game losing streak this season and needed to come back from 17-point deficits to win two recent games, survived a late rally to defeat St. Louis, 74-72, last night in the championship of the 53d annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. Missionary Shot to Death At Home in South Lebanon
description: An American missionary was killed Tuesday night by masked gunmen at his home in the Israeli-designated ''security zone'' in southern Lebanon.

title: Accounts
description: * Okidata, a marketer of computer peripherals, to Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Study Rejects View That Decontrol Cut Air Fares
description: The first study of United States airline fares to account for changes in jet-fuel costs has found that contrary to the Government's recent findings, inflation-adjusted fares have risen since the industry was deregulated in 1979.

title: Philippine Army Destroys a Guerrilla Camp
description: Philippine Government troops destroyed a heavily fortified Communist rebel training camp after two days of fierce fighting that left 59 insurgents and a soldier dead, the military reported today.

title: Albany Protest On AIDS Funds Brings Arrests
description: More than 80 people were arrested at the State Capitol today during an AIDS protest in which demonstrators blocked offices, staged ''die-ins'' in the hallways and covered parts of the building with red tape and banners.

title: NASA Concedes Space Station Cost May Rise
description: Under close questioning, NASA officials conceded for the first time today that solving maintenance problems on the proposed space station might require design changes that would drive up its cost.

title: Paper Shifts In Detroit
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. and the Gannett Company today announced the departure of William J. Keating as president and chief executive of the Detroit Newspaper Agency.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: FRIENDS stayed in my apartment while I was away, homeless people. They arrived with about 13 suitcases and duffels and departed without a shopping-bagful of dishes. I am keeping the dishes for the duration, which is to say until my friends are settled down. They have been wandering about town for 18 months.

title: Pittsburgh & West Virginia Railroad reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Horizon Gold Shares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from extinguishment of debt of $63,354 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-After extraordinary tax credits of $92,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the 9 months.

title: Retooling for Peace Will Take Some Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Nippon TV and Vatican
description: An aspect of the Sistine Chapel restoration that sometimes raises eyebrows is the financing provided by the Nippon Television Network Corporation of Japan (NTV), presumably because of the notion in some quarters that any prominent Japanese stake overseas must somehow be sinister.

title: Stars to Go Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $835,000 for the quarter and year, which included $1 million gain from settlement of contract dispute. c-After an extraordinary credit of $43,568,000, or $5.16 a share, for the quarter and year, which included $1 million gain from settlement of contract dispute. d-Net loss The company said 1989 and 1988 figures are not comparable due to a major decrease in scale of its operations between the two periods and debt restructuring completed in April 1989. The latest year's loss before items of $484,000 was from debt restructuring.

title: Books of The Times;   Shana Alexander Unravels the 'Bess Mess'
description: When She Was Bad

title: Hockey: Notebook;   N.H.L. Players Needed to Fortify National Teams
description: When children play pickup baseball games on a sandlot, they look around to see who has shown up, then choose sides.

title: Devcon International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its latest quarter net income was adversely affected by decreased demand due to hurricane Hugo.

title: All Apartment Dwellers Would Feel Co-op Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Hockey;   Subdued Rangers Prepare for Challenge of the Playoffs
description: The Rangers, with a mix of desire and discipline, managed to keep both their faces and their priorities straight over the last couple of weeks. The Patrick Division title would have to be in hand before many smiles would be in evidence. Moreover, they promised that even those delayed, deserved grins would be fleeting, gone quickly because the Stanley Cup playoffs would be coming in a hurry.

title: Investor Halts Crossland Plan
description: The Crossland Savings Bank said that the Coast-to-Coast Financial Corporation of Chicago had withdrawn its offer to invest new capital into the Brooklyn-based savings bank. Crossland, which had $21.5 million of shareholder capital and needs another $186 million to comply with Federal regulations, said it was developing other plans to raise capital. The savings bank has $13.5 billion of assets and offices in seven states outside of New York.

title: Record Companies to Put Warnings on the Raw
description: The major record companies have agreed to place a uniform warning label under the disposable wrapping of recordings whose lyrics may offend some listeners. The labels, which will read ''Explicit Lyrics - Parental Advisory,'' are to be uniformly applied on albums, cassettes and CD packages, making it easier for consumers to identify such recordings.

title: Busch Adds Officers In Broad Realignment
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies yesterday announced a management realignment that included an expansion of corporate personnel and a new president for its Anheuser-Busch Inc. beer subsidiary.

title: Sunrise Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said its Oak Mitsui joint venture would build a new copper foil plant in Camden, N.J., at an estimated cost of $60 million.

title: Trouble Right Here in Cincinnati: Furor Over Mapplethorpe Exhibit
description: An exhibit of photographs that ignited a ferocious debate last summer over Federal financing of sexually explicit art is headed for Cincinnati, a city that casts itself as a bulwark in the war against pornography. And the ruckus has begun.

title: India Acts to Extend Punjab Rule
description: Facing a surge in violence and a deteriorating political climate in the Indian state of Punjab, the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh plans to renew its special powers to rule the state through an appointed governor.

title: Spectrum Control reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Reflected pre-tax charge of $150,000 required for an EPA study and charge of $400,000 for a change in accounting that reduced capitalization of assets. c-After income of $886,000, or 16 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Hockey;   Boston University an Unexpected Surprise
description: Michigan State is out and Boston University is in, and that is the major surprise in the semifinal lineup for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's hockey tournament at Joe Louis Arena in Detroit.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Farrakhan's Soft New Voice and Same Message
description: After two years or so out of the public eye, Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, has come forth with a message to America. Interviews with The Washington Post and The Washington Times early this month have been followed by appearances on ''Prime Time Live,'' ''Donahue,'' ''CBS This Morning'' and ''Larry King Live.''

title: Artistic Greetings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
38-Year Plutonium Loss at Plant Equals 7 Bombs
description: Seven nuclear bombs' worth of plutonium escaped into air ducts at the Rocky Flats weapons plant near Denver over the 38 years of the plant's operation, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: International Dairy Queen reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
Rise in Minimum Wage Offers Minimum Joy
description: ''I sew front pockets,'' Filena Craft says of her work at the Reltoc Manufacturing Company here, where she is among 100 workers who make men's cotton pants. Ms. Craft, who is 27 years old, earns the Federal minimum wage of $3.35 an hour and takes less than $100 a week home to the trailer where she lives with her two young daughters.

title: General Development Filing
description: The General Development Corporation said today that several groups had expressed an interest in acquiring all or a part of the troubled Miami-based developer.

title: Colorocs Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: International Lease Finance reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Upheaval in the East;   The Standoff In Lithuania
description: The Kremlin's decision to try to draw a veil over Lithuania's independence crisis by ridding the republic of foreign journalists amounts to a tribute of sorts to the increasingly fragile presidency of Vytautas Landsbergis.

title: Driver-Harris reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $21,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $144,000, or 11 cents a share, for the year. c-Net income d-Included extraordinary tax credits of $294,000, or 22 cents a share and $507,000, or 39 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Calstar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Equity Silver Mines reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Rights at Issue as Brazil Fights Inflation
description: As the Brazilian police detain bankers, shopkeepers and journalists on charges of ''economic crimes,'' Brazilian lawyers have charged that civil liberties are among the first casualties of the nation's war against inflation.

title: Article 387790 -- No Title
description: The UAL Corporation has disclosed in proxy materials that Stephen M. Wolf, its chairman, president and chief executive, was paid $575,000 in salary and another $575,000 in bonus for total compensation in 1989 of $1.15 million.

title: U.S. Missionary and His Wife Are Reported Slain in Liberia
description: Villagers today found the bodies of a missionary couple slain in Liberia's eastern Nimba County, where Government troops battling rebels have killed hundreds of civilians, diplomats said.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AS unpleasant as the prospect of repairing a toilet may seem, more so is living with a toilet that needs repair. Fortunately, most toilet problems are relatively easy to fix.

title: F.C.C. Tilt to Minorities Weighed by High Court
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Constitution permits the Federal Government to favor blacks and other minority members in the awarding of licenses to operate radio and television stations.

title: INSIDE
description: Link to Israel Is Restored

title: CHRONICLE
description: In an unusual action, VISCOUNT LINLEY, the nephew of QUEEN ELIZABETH, has brought a libel action against the British newspaper Today for printing that he had been banned from a bar for throwing beer.

title: Women Seem Optimistic About Tour
description: The first major L.P.G.A. tournament of the decade begins Thursday and the players gathered here for the Nabisco Dinah Shore have been shedding the tentative layers that enclose their optimism about the success of their tour under its new commissioner.

title: Savings Nominee Challenged
description: President Bush's choice as the next chief regulator of the nation's savings and loan industry today faced a highly skeptical Senate Banking Committee, whose members voiced deep worry that his lack of experience in the financial industry did not qualify him for the job.

title: Wary Public Gets a New Bran (Rice)
description: For cereal makers, the next bran craze may be fizzling before it even gets off the ground.

title: Upheaval in the East;   FOLEY SUPPORTS BUSH ON LITHUANIA
description: President Bush won support today from the Speaker of the House for his policy on Lithuania as he confronted lawmakers who have been urging him to take a stronger stand in favor of the Baltic republic's bid for independence.

title: 4 Bedrooms, 7 Baths, 1 Pool and 1 Cave
description: CAVERNOUS houses are not unusual in this affluent suburb in the foothills of the Santa Cruz Mountains near San Jose. It is the house with the cavern that has cachet.

title: Mideast Bids Lift Treasury Prices
