description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in fairly active trading yesterday, spurred by the heavy bidding of Middle East investors at the Treasury's auction of new four-year notes.

title: Mutual Fund Champion Quits as Magellan Head
description: The most successful mutual fund manager in history announced his retirement yesterday at age 46. In a dazzling career, Peter Lynch guided the Fidelity Magellan Fund to an almost 25-fold return, making it the star of an era when the Dow Jones industrial average grew fourfold.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Listeners addicted to that morning pill, STEVE POST, the reliably cranky host of WNYC-FM's ''Morning Music'' program, were startled to hear yesterday that he had been ousted by MARY PEROT NICHOLS, who is leaving as president of the WNYC Communications Group and who is a sometime target of Mr. Post's caustic humor.

title: Stifling the Noise Plague Of Modern City Living
description: ''NEW YORK CITY has eight million residents and eight million noise problems,'' said Peter George, an acoustical consultant whose specialty is ridding homes and businesses of unwanted sound.

title: Retooling for Peace Will Take Some Planning;   End Draft Registration
description: To the Editor:

title:
CURRENTS;

Conceits Of a 1789 Fantasy
description: LEAD: IN the late-18th-century French garden of Le Desert de Retz, the natural and artificial worlds collided provocatively. The ruins of a Gothic chapel, a part of a Greek temple and a fragment of a huge column seemed to be the remnants of some earlier civilization.

title: Alexander Energy Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: Events: Artworks (W.P.A. and Beaux)
description: Art of Place Circa 1936, Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway at Washington Avenue; 718-638-5000.

Cuomo Seeking to Cut State Pension Contributions
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, already clashing with Republican lawmakers over how to close a $1.5 billion budget gap, is now battling with the custodians of two large retirement funds for public employees.

title: Gerald F. Wright, Engineer, 85
description: Gerald F. Wright, a former investment counselor and consulting engineer in Manhattan, died on Tuesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 85 years old.

title: Electro Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income.

title: People
description: * Anita M. Stewart, formerly a senior vice president at Ayer, has been appointed director of advertising and sales promotion at Texaco Inc.

title: G.O.P. Leader: Animosity's Part of Job
description: The Governor is furious with him, and the Assembly Speaker is exasperated. State budget analysts curse him privately and commissioners grimace at the mention of his name.

title: Defendant Silent as Defense Rests in L.I. Slaying
description: The defense in the Robert Golub murder trial rested its case today without calling Mr. Golub to the stand, insuring that the jury's verdict will depend almost entirely on circumstantial evidence.

title: CCA Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $119,026.

title: Washington at Work;   Bush's Adviser on Domestic Policy: The Perfect Person to Win the Point
description: Roger Porter has a theory that you can learn a lot about people by watching them on the tennis court.

title: Soviet Airline Agrees To Buy G.E. Engines
description: The General Electric Company's aircraft engine division announced yesterday that Aeroflot, the Soviet Union's national airline, had chosen its jet engines to power 10 twin-engine airplanes from Airbus Industrie.

title: Review/Piano;   Krystian Zimerman Brings Balance to Brahms and Liszt
description: When it comes to pianistic flair and virtuosity, Liszt is seldom made to serve as anyone's straw man. But the Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman began an interesting program at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, changed from the one originally announced, with two uncharacteristically understated late works by Liszt, ''La Lugubre Gondola'' and ''Nuages Gris.''

title:
CURRENTS;

Sculptural Interiors
description: LEAD: ''LOS ANGELES offers a certain freedom in being a non-city,'' said Michele Saee. ''It allows you to do things you can't do in 19th-century cities like New York.''

title: Euro-Nevada Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bad Luck Babies
description: Children born to poor parents in this rich country all too often get a rotten start. As a report from the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality points out, America ranks a humiliating 20th in the infant death rate. And, according to the Centers for Disease Control, the number of low-birthweight babies keeps rising.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Karl-Marx-Stadt Swings to the Right
description: A bronze head of Marx, about as tall as four men, broods from a massive stone pedestal in front of the nine-story headquarters of the old Communist Party. Behind the towering monument, a wide swath of the building is covered by a bronze plaque on which is repeated many times, in four languages and huge letters, the message, ''Workers of the World, Unite.''

title: Thomson Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $475 million, or 88 cents a share, on the sale of oil and gas operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $56 million, or 10 cents a share. The company was formed in June 1989 from the merger of Thomson Newspapers Ltd. and International Thomson Organisation Ltd. The financial information is presented as though the companies were combined since their inception. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Pacific Aqua Foods Ltd.  reports earnings for Year Dec 30
description: The company did not have any operations in year-ago period. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Libya Takes Key Step to Extend Range of Bombers
description: Libya has successfully tested a system to refuel fighter-bombers in flight, a major advance toward extending the range of the aircraft and giving them the ability to carry heavier payloads, Pentagon intelligence reports say.

title: Cineplex Odeon reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $19,850,000 gain on the sale of the live theatre division, $8,676,000 in expenses relating to employee termination costs, $3,488,000 relating to charges for the expected cancellation of an aircraft lease and $871,000 in costs for the activities of the company's special board committee. The company also had a loss on investments of $4,446,000 and its film distribution businesses posted a loss of $9,367,000. c-Included a $47,478,000 gain on the sale of 50 percent of Universal Studios Florida, a $19,850,000 gain from the sale of the live theatre division, a $25,500,000 loss from U.S. distribution activities, a $15,153,000 loss on investments, a $3,824,000 charge on extinguishment of a credit facility, charges on extinguishment of a credit facility, charges totalling $7,175,000 from the decision not to proceed with a U.S. limited partnership transaction, advisory fees and expenses of $2,615,000 related to proposals to acquire the company, charges totalling $8,676,000 for employee termination, and a $3,488,000 charge from the expected cancellation of the aircraft lease. d-Net income

title: French Plan to Restrict Ads: Less Wine and No Smoking
description: The French Government announced plans today for a strong antismoking and antidrinking campaign, increasing the price of cigarettes 15 percent starting next year and restricting advertising.

title: Jo Blair Hughes, 80, A Supersaleswoman Of Fashion, Is Dead
description: Josephine Blair Hughes, a super-saleswoman who sold high-fashion clothes to socially prominent women for four decades, died on Monday in her apartment in Manhattan. She was 80 years old and had been bedridden for several years.

title: KEY RATES
Sports People: TRACK AND FIELD;   Bush Awards Owens His Fifth Gold Medal
description: Jesse Owens, the late sprinter and long jumper who won four gold medals at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, received a fifth gold medal yesterday for ''humanitarian contributions in the race of life.''

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: * First Fidelity Bancorporation, Lawrenceville, N.J., a bank holding company, announced the retirement of Edward D. Knapp as vice chairman. He will be replaced by William P. Tuggle 3d.

description: b-Included a $687,000 gain on the sale of the company's orange groves and a $35.3 million restructuring charge. c-Net income

title: Morgan Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $33,065,000 for the latest year and $71,225,000 for 1988, both from discontinued operations, which comprise company's interest in Morgan Trust Co., which it sold last year, and Elite Insurance Management Ltd. and Meci Properties Inc. As reported, Morgan Financial took $30 million in provisions in 1989 related to its investment in Meci. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Donald Davidson, Baseball Official, 64
description: Donald Davidson, a special assistant with the Houston Astros whose baseball career spanned more than 40 years, died today after having suffered from cancer. He was 64 years old.

title: About Time Democrats Noticed California
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomson Securities In Chapter 11
description: Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., once the nation's ninth-largest brokerage, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. The move was an effort to begin the final stage of a liquidation the firm began last fall.

title: Newmark & Lewis And Brick Church
description: Newmark & Lewis Inc., a leading regional retailer of appliances and electronics, agreed to acquire substantially all the retailing assets of Brick Church Appliances Inc., a New Jersey appliance and electronics chain, as well as a 220,000-square-foot warehouse and office building. The purchase price is $7.8 million in cash and the assumption of certain liabilities.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The singer GLORIA ESTEFAN walked without the aid of crutches or a cane yesterday, a week after undergoing surgery for spinal injuries suffered when her band's bus was struck by a truck on a snowy road in eastern Pennsylvania.

title: Morton R. Tolleris, 81, Criminal Court Judge
description: Morton R. Tolleris, a retired Criminal Court judge, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Electronics: It's Not Home Without It
description: FOR generations of Americans, setting up a home meant buying furniture, bedspreads, china and cutlery. But to a generation raised on omnipresent audio and video gadgets, the hope chest is electronic.

title: Long-Range Libyan Bombers
description: The Pentagon says Libya has successfully tested a system to refuel fighter-bombers in flight, enhancing their range for attack. Page A15.

description: LEAD: The Oshkosh Truck Corporation has named R. Eugene Goodson as its new chairman and chief executive, replacing John P. Mosling, the founder's son, who is retiring at the age of 74 after 53 years with the company.

title: Rescuing Purebreds From the Pound
description: Lady is having almost as much trouble as the Tramp staying out of the pound these days.

title: Putting My Best Shot Behind Me
description: We made a mistake. We didn't agree fast enough that there was a problem. O.K., that's behind us. Now we want to be constructive and get this done. - Gov. Mario M. Cuomo With all due respect to Governor Cuomo, usually an articulate public man, I don't mind the mistake (about New York's budget gap) as much as the use of that most pervasive of contemporary cliches - ''behind us,'' supposedly meaning ''in the past'' and usually suggesting ''forgiven and forgotten.''

title: Review/Music;   Soprano Takes Up Berlioz's Gauntlet
description: ''Les Nuits d'Ete,'' Berlioz's setting of six moody poems by Theophile Gautier, is generally performed by sopranos or mezzos nowadays, though the cycle does not lie comfortably for any single voice type. Barbara Hendricks, who took on the work in company with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, was therefore fairly typical among recent interpreters in that her voice seemed wrong for the music's demands much of the time. One had to admire what her light soprano and her keen intelligence, against all odds, were able to make of Berlioz's darkly expressive cycle.

title: Addenda
description: * Poppe Tyson Advertising & Public Relations has signed an affiliation agreement with V/F Inforcom, Moscow, a marketing consultancy.

description: b-Net loss

title: Baseball;   'Nervous' LaPoint Passes First Test
description: He has played in 264 big league games over eight seasons, has pitched 1,324 innings, won 73 games, lost 75, been traded six times and released once. But Tuesday night, just hours before he was to throw in an exhibition game, Dave LaPoint could not sleep.

title: Julius J. Schaefer, Transportation Broker, 72
description: Julius J. Schaefer, a transportation broker, died of a heart attack on March 22 at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach. He was 72 years old and had homes in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Topics of The Times;   Concert for Non-Instruments
description: he last-minute arrivals surged into their seats just as the New York Philharmonic began to play. Unsuppressed coughs punctuated the piece. When the orchestra concluded, about 50 latecomers rustled in.

title: Reviews/Music;   Audrey Hepburn in Debut Of Work on Anne Frank
description: As with most concerts given in the United Nations General Assembly Hall, an inspiring setting with horrendous acoustics, music was hardly the only point, or even the main one, of the ''Concert for Life'' sponsored by the United States Committee for Unicef on Sunday evening. The event, which followed similar concerts in Philadelphia, Chicago and Houston, benefited the committee and featured Unicef's good-will ambassador, the actress Audrey Hepburn, along with the New World Symphony Orchestra and its founding conductor and artistic director, Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: Officials in California Town Limit Night Cruising in Cars
description: Looking for ways to fight vandalism, drugs and gangs, the City Council in the town that inspired the film ''American Graffiti'' has approved an ordinance to limit what the movie celebrated: the weekend rite of automobile cruising.

title: British Rules on Stocks
description: The Department of Trade and Industry today announced tougher requirements for the disclosure of stock purchases, making it more difficult for buyers to build up secret stakes in publicly held companies. Starting in June, stock buyers will have to disclose to the companies the purchases of stakes of 3 percent or more, compared with the previous 5 percent or more. Also, the disclosures must be made within two business days of the purchases, rather than the current five business days.

title: Tele-Metropole Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Net income The 1989 periods restated to reflect the acquisition of an interest in Pathonic Network Inc. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Cleansed of Centuries of Grime, Sistine Ceiling Shines Anew
description: After a decade of cleaning, the Sistine Chapel ceiling is free at last of its latticework of scaffolding, and neck-craning visitors can see the full expanse of Michelangelo's 16th-century frescoes.

title: Maps That Aren't for Getting Somewhere
description: ''TO tell you the truth,'' said Anthony Baratta, a New York decorator, ''I really don't know much about maps themselves. For me, they are beautiful, stylish objects.''

title: Atlanta Journal;   The Killing Was Real; The Story Was a Lie
description: The story has come to sound familiar: a horrible, racially charged murder; a desperate hunt for a black suspect, and then the slow unraveling of the hoax behind the headlines.

description: THE national telephone monopoly of Spain, Telefonica de Espana S.A., is most popular with investors and stock analysts who use its services least.

title: Judging Books By Their Covers
description: LEAD: The body of an angel soars in three dimensions, spine straight, long hair flowing. Immense, feathery wings spread from his powerful torso. This is not a painting, though colored; nor is it a sculpture, though molded. It is a contemporary book cover.

Bennett held a 4-year-old mentally disabled child on his lap at a center in Jacksonville, Fla.

description: ''You have to know who Cincinnati is to understand why we're throwing such a fit. We don't selectively enforce murder laws so we can't selectively enforce pornography laws.

One Man's Simplicity, Another Man's Moderne
description: LEAD: IN the 1930's, Gilbert Rohde used exotic-sounding woods like maidou burl and East Indian laurel to design home furnishings for the mass market. Although he was the son of a German cabinetmaker, Mr. Rohde, who died 1944, advocated manufactured furniture that was simply executed. Even Art Deco styles he deemed ''most monstrous designs.

title: Talking Deals;   Group May Gain Control of Penrod
description: WITH the Hunt brothers of Texas removed from any role in the Penrod Drilling Corporation, a syndicate of 10 banks and an investor group headed by Richard E. Rainwater are expected to decide soon who will control the world's largest offshore oil and gas driller. If events work out, the group led by the Fort Worth investor may end up controlling the company for far less than rival bidders have offered to buy it outright.

title: Waiting List Dissolves
description: East Germans used to wait up to 15 years to get behind the wheel of a Trabant, but they can now have a new auto in 24 hours. A reporter for the youth newspaper Junge Welt, who tested claims that a Trabant could now be had as easily as a Volkswagen in a West German showroom, said he had successfully ordered one by telephone for pickup the next day. The fall of the Communists opened the door to sales of Western cars, which have all but eliminated demand for the archaic Trabant, which is to be phased out in favor of a Volkswagen-based car.

title: FT Capital reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

title: GTE Debentures
description: The GTE Corporation yesterday priced $250 million in 30-year debentures through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Underwriters gave the issue, which has a maturity of April 1, 2020, a 9 7/8 percent coupon and priced it at 98.441 to yield 10.04 percent, or about 155 basis points more than the Treasury's 30-year issue. The debentures are nonrefundableb for 10 years and are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Review/Dance;   Civilization Stripped Of Veneers
description: Wendy Osserman is certainly an ambitious choreographer. That was made clear by the performance the Wendy Osserman Dance Company gave on Monday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace. Yet lofty intentions do not inevitably produce admirable works of art. Ms. Osserman's creations were never as imposing as the themes that inspired them.

title: Circuit Research Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Albany Urges 1% Reduction In Local Aid
description: State leaders have proposed a 1 percent cut in financial assistance to local governments to help fill the projected $1.5 billion gap in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's 1990-91 budget, legislative sources said today.

title: Outdoors;   A Series of Programs Heralds Trout Season
description: If you aren't anticipating the April 1 opening of New York State's trout season with your usual zest, a visit to the Manhattan store of the Orvis company might prove helpful.

title: Boxing;   Nunn and Handlers Spar
description: There is trouble in the camp of Michael Nunn, the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: JEANNE BARRETT says that her parents have been fighting for as long as she can remember. The battles weren't constant, but they were regular and set the tone for family get-togethers and holiday celebrations. Last fall Ms. Barrett, her sister and two brothers, all in their 20's, decided to confront their parents about the fighting and the effect it was having on everyone in the family.

title: In Zimbabwe, Voting and Threats of Violence
description: As Zimbabwe's third elections got under way today, hundreds of citizens waiting patiently to cast their ballots gave little indication of the violence and intimidation that has marked the campaign.

title: Guilty Plea In Pentagon Fraud Case
description: The Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing fraud scored a big advance today when a private consultant at the center of the investigation pleaded guilty to bribery and tax evasion and agreed to cooperate in the inquiry.

These revenues have been offset against operating expenses and the resulting operating income of $1,500,000 has been credited to the estimated liability for closing costs.

title: Korean Stocks Decline Again
description: South Korean stocks fell today to a 15-month low as investors sold on the conviction that the Government was not in control of the economy, brokers and analysts said.

title: Panama Journal;   The 'Maximum Chief' Is Humbled in His Tomb
description: The image of Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, arm outstretched as he leads his people into the Panama Canal Zone, dominates the huge mural outside the Legislative Palace here. Inside, however, the Panamanian Assembly is debating a proposal to paint over the mural as part of a Government drive to erase from national consciousness all favorable references to the founder of the military Government that ruled this country until Dec. 20.

title: A.T.&T. Issues Job-Cut Plans
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company provided details on its planned closing of some facilities and the elimination of 6,000 jobs, prompting an angry protest from its largest union, the Communications Workers of America.

title: Home Sales Rose by 3.1% In February
description: High interest rates and declining consumer confidence depressed sales of new homes in February, although they bounced back slightly from steep declines in the previous two months, the Commerce Department said today.

Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: On the day after he tested his repaired right shoulder for the first time in a game in 1990, Dwight Gooden gave the Mets the answer they had waited eight months to hear: ''Question mark? No. It's gone from my mind.''

title: Review/Television;   Weighing The Rights And Wrongs Of Welfare
description: Tonight's edition of ''48 Hours,'' at 8 o'clock on CBS, digs into America's welfare system, which Dan Rather too accurately calls ''the helping hand that almost everyone hates.''

title: Sports People: Baseball;   Rangers' Franco Ailing
description: Julio Franco, the All-Star second baseman of the Texas Rangers, complaining of chest pains, left the Port Charlotte, Fla., training camp yesterday and took a flight to a Cleveland clinic for a checkup. Franco, who hit .316 last year, fifth highest in the American League, said the pains bothered him after an exhibition game against the Pittsburgh Pirates on Tuesday night. Franco, 28 years old, said he had pains in the left side of chest wall near his ribs. He told the broadcaster Eric Nadel that the pains could have been caused by drinking too much coffee.(AP)

title: Dow Gains 6.75 Points in Slow Trading
description: Stocks went nowhere yesterday in slow trading, plodding ahead by 6.75 points, to 2,743.69, in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Percy Beard, Olympic Hurdler, 82
description: Percy Beard, a silver medalist in the 110-meter hurdles in the 1932 Olympic Games at Los Angeles and the coach of the track team at the University of Florida from 1936 to 1964, died Tuesday in Gainesville, Fla., after a long illness. He was 82 years old. Mr. Beard, who set five world records in hurdles events from 1931 to 1934, was a seven-time Amateur Athletic Union champion hurdler. While track coach at Florida, he founded the Florida Relays, one of the country's top collegiate events.

title: Bradwell Turner, British Officer, 92
description: Comdr. Bradwell Turner, who led a daring rescue of 299 Allied seamen held prisoner on a German ship in 1940, died on March 21 at the age of 92. The cause of death was not disclosed. Commander Turner led a boarding party from the British destroyer Cossack, which freed the prisoners from the German supply ship Altmark in a Norwegian fjord in February 1940.

title: Henry Hecksher, 79; Served O.S.S. in War And Later the C.I.A.
description: Henry D. Hecksher, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, died of complications of Parkinson's disease yesterday at the Medical Center of Princeton, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Suspect Wrote About Killing Family in '71
description: Before fleeing 18 years ago for the life of a fugitive, John E. List wrote a letter to his pastor in which he told how and why he had just killed his wife, his three children and his mother in their house in Westfield, N.J. Today a judge admitted that letter as evidence in his murder trial and released the text.

title: Mourners Grieve Amid a Crush of Coffins
description: At funeral homes in the Bronx yesterday, the mourners filed by in ones and twos and threes. They waited in long lines behind police barricades as they inched their way into tiny chapels jammed with coffins and the horror of mass death.

title: Sports People: College Basketball;   New Coach for Aggies
description: Texas A&M began a coaching youth movement yesterday by naming 30-year-old Kermit Davis Jr. the basketball coach. ''We wanted a young, aggressive coach that plays an up-tempo offense and aggressive defense,'' John David Crow, the Aggies' athletic director, said. ''We think we accomplished our goal.''

title: Rostenkowski Is Half Right
description: ''Adopt my plan to fix the budget deficit - or come up with a better one.'' That's the challenge issued by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title:
CURRENTS;

Honoring a Prophet In His Own Land
description: LEAD: IN 1992, the city of Genoa, Italy, will celebrate the unification of the European Community by observing the 500th anniversary of another lucrative economic mission: the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus.

title: Bitter Battle Imperils School Superintendent
description: The superintendent of School District 10 in the northwest Bronx is fighting fiercely to hang on to his job in a battle so vitriolic that it is now dominated by charges of racism and anti-Semitism rather than questions of educational performance.

title: Seven Lives
description: It is impossible to measure what was lost early Sunday morning when 87 people fell victim to what the police have described as a dollar's worth of gasoline and an arsonist's match. Almost all who died in the fire at the illegal Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx were immigrants or the children of immigrants. Some left behind stories of making it in a new world, and some left stories of struggle and even defeat. But all left stories. Some of their tales are recounted on page B4, portraits of the lost lives of seven people who went out last Saturday night, most with the simple urge to dance.

title: Basketball;   Nets End Slump Against Knicks
description: The Knicks got a shocking reminder tonight that their deep-rooted problems have not been solved. They had one of their poorest first-half performances of the season, falling behind by 18 points to the Nets, a team that had lost 11 consecutive games. And in the process, the Knicks were badly outrebounded, badly outplayed, and badly outhustled by a team that has much less at stake than they do.

description: b-Reflected $61,000 gain on sales of assets and $26,000 loss on early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and reflected $194,000 gain on sales of assets and $17,000 loss on early extinguishment of debt.

title: Information Solutions reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said its 1989 net loss was due primarily to settlement of a 1989 lawsuit brought against an ISI Texas unit and a lease recourse guarantee made on a system leased in 1989, which caused $155,000 in unusual expenses to the company's 1989 statement of operations.

title: Yields Post Slight Rise
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were slightly higher for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Rail Buyer Sought
description: The trustee for the bankrupt Delaware & Hudson Railway Company has been given less than two more weeks to find a buyer for the freight carrier or face the liquidation of the nation's oldest continually operated railroad. United States Bankruptcy Judge Helen Balick granted a request on Tuesday from the trustee, Francis Dicello, for an extension to continue operating the road while a buyer is sought. The judge set an April 11 date to determine whether the rail line will be sold or if liquidation should begin. Mr. Dicello said the deadline for offers is April 6.

title: Drexler Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $246,000.

title: Desjardins Trustco reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,547,000 and an extraordinary charge of $9,799,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 7 Victims: Their Stories, Struggles and Dreams of Better Lives
description: Israel Bulnes did not know that his son, Tonio, had gone to the Happy Land Social Club until morning.

title: Baseball;   Rosters Won't Expand For Opening of Season
description: Labor relations between baseball's club owners and players, which were supposed to improve with the new collective bargaining agreement, are off to a running stop.

title: Waterford Backs Stake by Investors
description: Stockholders approved a plan by two investor groups to take a 29.9 percent stake in the troubled china and crystal maker Waterford Wedgwood. ''It is now signed, sealed and delivered,'' said a spokesman for Fitzwilton P.L.C, the industrial holding group set up by Anthony F. J. O'Reilly, the Irish-born chairman of the H. J. Heinz Company, the United States food giant.

title: New Antidepressant Is Acclaimed but Not Perfect
description: Buoyed by broad medical acclaim and exuberant patient testimonials since its debut less than three years ago, the drug Prozac has become the most widely prescribed antidepressant in the United States.

title: ACAP Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Soccer;   United States Shows Signs of Improvement
description: The United States national soccer team ended its brief European tour tonight not unlike the way it began last week in Budapest, with a loss. But the play of the Americans against East Germany was far more encouraging than it had been for some time.

title: Dinkins Bill Would Close Clubs Immediately
description: Reacting to the fire that killed 87 people in an illegal Bronx social club on Sunday, the Dinkins administration has drafted legislation to allow New York City to padlock immediately any eating or drinking place ordered closed for violating fire or safety codes.

title: National Lampoon reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Allou Health & Beauty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are restated. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Precision Drilling reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included unusual credit of $5.2 million, reflecting forgiveness of bank debt, offset by $5.1 million charge from writedown of rig equipment. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: BRITISH TV NAMES BOMBING SUSPECTS
description: A broadcast dramatization tonight identified four men who it said were Irish Republican Army members responsible for the bombings of two Birmingham pubs in 1974 that killed 21 people. The program concluded that six men serving life sentences for the attacks were wrongly convicted.

title: Artful Hunt for Smuggler Suspects
description: As far as Ali Ashour Daghir knew, the soft-spoken American with whom he met in London last September was the manager of export and finance for a company in San Marcos, Calif., not far from San Diego. Mr. Daghir and two Iraqi engineers were there to conclude a deal to purchase 85 special capacitors, 40 of them with specifications identical to those used in setting off nuclear weapons. They discussed how to disquise the objects to get them past United States Customs.

title: Digital Metcom Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Out of the Belfry, Into the Garden
description: HANGING upside down in a rough-hewn chamber of red cedar with 30 to 50 companions might not be everybody's idea of a happy home.

title: Torchmark Makes Offer For Insurer
description: The Torchmark Corporation, an insurance company based in Birmingham, Ala., said today that it had offered to acquire the much larger American General Corporation in a deal with a face value of $6.3 billion.

title: Basketball;   As a Lawsuit Looms on Death of Gathers, Many Major Questions Remain Unanswered
description: More than three weeks after the death of Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball star, questions exist about whether team officials were adequately trained to deal with the medical catastrophe that took his life.

title: The Health Cost Explosion, Evaded
description: America's tattered health insurance system cries out for reform. Congress turned for guidance to a bipartisan commission that now offers some useful ideas. But it evades the central issue. The commission boldly proposes an $86 billion-a-year plan to provide universal health insurance. But it doesn't say where the Federal share, $66 billion, would come from.

title: No, My Friends, We Won't Go Slow
description: LEAD: There is an old Lithuanian fairy tale about a young princess kidnapped by a foreign king. The king loves her very much (for her beauty) - almost as much as Mikhail Gorbachev loves Lithuania (for its grain, meat and seaports). Every time the princess expresses a desire to visit her old parents, the king gives her a pair of shoes to wear down before she can go home - first wooden, then glass, then iron.

title: Hockey;   Islanders Stay Alive With 3d-Period Flurry
description: The Islanders kept alive their faint hopes for the playoffs when they rallied from a 2-0 deficit tonight and defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-3.

title: Schneider Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 17
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Hungarians Will Again Fly Soviet Jews to Israel
description: The Hungarian state airline will resume flights of Soviet Jews to Israel that were suspended last week after the carrier received threats from Arab fundamentalists, the state press agency reported today.

title: Reviews/Music;   In Boston, a Chorus Presents a New Oratorio on Slavery
description: The Cantata Singers are celebrating their 25th season, and the culmination of that celebration came Friday night at Symphony Hall with an ambitious world premiere of a commissioned oratorio by Donald Sur called ''The Slavery Documents.''

title: Doubts Raised Over Bush's Tax Plan for Savings
description: The Bush Administration is counting on its proposed Family Savings Plan to generate more revenue than it would cost, but the Senate's chief tax writer is skeptical.

title: Guild Is Gaining Major Role In Labor Talks at The News
description: After The Daily News's offer on Monday to raise hourly wages significantly for members of the Newspaper Guild, that union has emerged as an important player in the paper's bitter labor negotiations with its 10 unions.

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 7 percent stock dividend payable May 17, 1990.

title: Head of Wang In 2 More Posts
description: Richard W. Miller, president of Wang Laboratories Inc., was named yesterday to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive.

title: Lechters Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Compuflight Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Pact Lets Jacobs Seek CML Votes
description: The corporate raider Irwin L. Jacobs has settled his court fight with CML Group Inc. and will be allowed to solicit consents demanding that the Acton, Mass., retail store owner call a special shareholder meeting. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Jacobs said that under the settlement, the record date for the consent solicitation will be set for April 18 and the solicitation will end one month later.

title: Patrick O'Brien, 64, Horse-Racing Official
description: Patrick W. O'Brien, a well-known figure in thoroughbred racing who had been involved in the sport in New York for more than 40 years, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: Burger King Team
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/ New York has bolstered its forces on the Burger King account, hiring an award-winning creative team from Baltimore, Tom Amico and Jim Proimos, as associate creative directors. They formed Amico/Proimos Creative last year after leaving Smith, Burke & Azzam, where their advertising had garnered a Silver Lion at the Cannes advertising festival.

title: Sports People: PRO FOOTBALL;   Dorsett Retires
description: The second-leading ground gainer in National Football League history, Tony Dorsett, said on Tuesday that he had signed his retirement papers two days after auditioning last week with ESPN for a job as a television sports broadcaster.

title: Other Countries Do Much More for Disabled
description: Several industrialized nations, including Canada, Britain and the Scandinavian countries, do much more than the United States to support long-term care for the severely disabled.

title: Farm Credit Banks In 3-Part Financing
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced a three-part financing of consolidated systemwide bonds through its regular selling group of securities dealers and dealer banks, with all the bonds for sale at par.

title: State, or Labor Market, May Set Higher Minimum
description: Even before it goes into effect Sunday, the new national minimum wage of $3.80 an hour is out of date here.

title: United Education & Software reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,486,000 for the quarter and $5,470,000 for the 9 months. Both losses from discontinued operations included a net charge of $4,953,000 on disposal of servicing operations. The latest periods' losses from continuing operations included a pretax charge of $24,462,000 related to reorganization costs, asset sales and writedowns.

title: Don't Blame Wall St. For New York Rudeness
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: One of New York City's few surviving rubber bridge clubs, the Gotham, has been quartered for a quarter of a century in the Olcott Hotel at 27 West 72d Street. Duplicate play, which has had mixed fortunes there over the years, will be revived beginning tomorrow.

title: In Las Vegas, Rebels, No Outlaws
description: The University of Nevada-Las Vegas, whose basketball team plays Georgia Tech on Saturday in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Assocation tournament in Denver, is like most colleges -except for a little more sand on the campus, a little more cacti, and the fact that it is located less than a mile from a place called the Strip, where, among other wonders, a new simulated volcano erupts every 15 minutes in the evening in front of a new hotel named the Mirage, where a local exotic dancer and pneumatic institution known as Bambi Jr. performs, and where a book doesn't have quite the same meaning as it does on the campus.

title: Lung Chin, 84, Is Dead; Leader in Chinatown
description: Lung Chin, a merchant and community leader in Chinatown for more than 60 years, died of cancer on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 84 years old and had lived at 37 Mott Street since 1915, several months after emigrating from China.

title: A New Hand Cracks the Whip
description: Can Flavio Togni - the man the ringmaster calls ''the world's newest circus sensation'' - fill the shoes of Gunther Gebel-Williams? ''He's still wearing them,'' said Mr. Togni of the soon-to-retire star of the Greatest Show on Earth. ''Also, you know, our shoes are different sizes,'' the 29-year-old animal trainer from Italy added, laughing.

title: MTV Rolling Out Comedy Network
description: MTV Networks jumps into the race to establish an all-comedy cable channel on Sunday with the introduction of HA! the TV Comedy Network.

title: First Chicago Profit Outlook
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, said today that troubled real estate loans will cause a drop of about 50 percent in first-quarter earnings compared with the 1989 period. In last year's first quarter, First Chicago earned $120 million, or $1.72 a share.

title: Publisher Is Appointed At Philadelphia Papers
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. has named a publisher for Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., which publishes The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News, ending the present structure of management by a three-member team that had included the editors of the two papers.

title: Orbit Oil & Gas reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: There were no share earnings because preferred share dividends exceeded net income figures. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Franciscans Stripping Ritter of Special Status as Inquiry Ends
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter's Franciscan superiors have ended an inquiry into allegations of sexual misconduct against the 62-year-old priest and have directed him to return to a friary, the order said last night.

title: Review/Art;   Wesley's Decorative Slant Lurks Amid the Abstract
description: John Wesley's paintings resist easy description. From his first New York exhibition in 1963 and for several years after that, Mr. Wesley was categorized as a Pop artist and it is not difficult to see why. At Fiction/ Nonfiction in SoHo are 22 works by the California-born painter from the years 1963 to 1973, a few of which allude to cartoon characters like Popeye, all of which are painted in a flat, hard-edged, schematic style that is reminiscent of comic book design.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Music From Hungary Muzsikas, Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, at Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights (718-858-2424). Muzsikas plays slightly updated Hungarian folk songs that are ready to join a European Community. The pungent harmonies, angular leaps and vertiginous slides that fascinated Bela Bartok and the impassioned sound of the Hungarian fiddle are still in the music, and some of the songs still spiral up to galvanizing peaks. Yet the traditional style has been tempered with gentler instruments like recorder and guitar, and with the voice of Marta Sebastyen, whose sweet, slightly smoky timbre recalls the English singer Sandy Denny. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $12 and $15.

title: Beard Oil reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Iraq Said to Build Launchers for Its 400-Mile Missiles
description: Iraq has constructed for the first time launchers for missiles within range of Tel Aviv and Damascus, according to classifed American intelligence reports. While the weapons could be used for offensive purposes, American intelligence experts believe that the missiles are intended in part to discourage any possible Israeli attack on Iraqi nuclear or chemical weapon installations.

title: Stephen Bander, Corporate President, 43
description: Stephen Bander, president of the National Systems Corporation, died of a brain tumor yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Russ Togs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,550,000, or 21 cents a share, from a payment received from Bidermann Industries U.S.A. Inc. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,393,000. The company said its pre-tax loss from continuing operations in the latest full year included $5,823,000 of expenses from start-up costs for new divisions, a writeoff of goodwill and a provision for certain severance and consulting costs.

title: KEY RATES
Rita Wallsh, Psychiatrist, 56
description: Dr. Rita Wallsh, a psychiatrist in Manhattan, died of pancreatic cancer on Wednesday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 56 years old.

title: Music Beyond the Notes, By Six Rising Artists
description: THIS weekend, at clubs across New York City, youth is being served.

title: National Medical Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,291,000 from redemption of 8 percent debentures. Year-ago periods' revenues included majority of the operations within the Long Term Care Group, which was spun off to shareholders Jan. 31.

title: Black Assistant Prosecutor Resigns in Bensonhurst Case
description: An assistant prosecutor in the Bensonhurst racial-slaying case has resigned from the Brooklyn District Attorney's office amid reports that he felt he was to be a ''token'' black at the prosecution table in the case's first trial opening on Monday.

title: Free-Agent Market Isn't Quite Bustling
description: With two days remaining in pro football's Plan B free-agency period, signings have been slow and big-dollar contracts have been scarce. One player agent, Tom Toner of Del Mar, Calif., suggested collusion by National Football League clubs to keep costs down.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 506 money market mutual funds decreased by $522.1 million, to $391.62 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 158 institutional funds decreased by $603.7 million, to $91.39 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were up by $495.6 million, to $133.87 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $414.0 million, to $166.36 billion, the institute said.

title: Bank of Boston Expecting a Profit
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Ira Stepanian, said the company expected to show a profit for the first quarter that ends on March 31 but at lower levels than for the corresponding period last year. Speaking at the company's annual meeting, Mr. Stepanian did not give a specific forecast for the 1990 first quarter.

title: Bush Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included $388,000, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting method change for both the quarter and year.

title: Tuesday Morning Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shouldn't Justice Redeem as Well as Punish?;   Doing Real Penance
description: To the Editor:

title: The Best Are Missing For U.S.-Czech Match
description: While tennis players generally agree that the Davis Cup is unlike any other event they play, especially for its nationalism, team format and connection to what is now 90 years of history, matches rarely feature each country's best players.

title: Kaneb Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said in the latest fourth quarter the provision for discontinued operations was adjusted, which increased income by $8.5 million, or 27 cents a share, compared to a loss from discontinued operations of $49,825,000 in the year-ago quarter. Latest year reflected a loss from discontinued operations of $68,647,000, versus a loss from discontinued operations of $77,480,000 in the prior year. Latest quarter and year included income of $3,747,000 and $55,704,000, respectively, primarily from a gain on the sale of senior preference units of Kaneb Pipe Line Partners L.P., a master limited partnership formed to own and operate the company refined petroleum products pipeline business. Latest quarter and year also included extraordinary gains of $863,000 and $8,492,000, respectively, on the purchase of certain subordinated debentures and a senior note. Latest year reflected a charge of $2,100,000 from the cumulative effect of the adoption of FASB No. 96.

title: G.M. Is Backed On Plant Closing
description: An arbitrator ruled that the General Motors Corporation was within its rights under a labor contract with the United Automobile Workers union in 1988 when it closed an assembly plant in Pontiac, Mich., that produced the Pontiac Fiero. But the subject of plant closings and job security will probably be a primary issue when Big Three and union negotiators begin bargaining for a new contract later this year. The current pact expires in September.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Position At Needham
description: Frederick D. (Sandy) Sulcer is leaving D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, where he has been director of business development since 1978, for DDB Needham Worldwide, where he will become vice chairman.

title: Centuri Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,505,000, or 18 cents a share, for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $228,000 for the quarter and income of $3,736,000, or 24 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations and an extraordinary tax charge of $334,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $126,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year.

title: L.A. Gear Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Prize-Winning Pianist
description: David Korevaar, the pianist who won the University of Maryland William Kapell International Competition in 1988, will play Beethoven's ''Pathetique'' Sonata, Brahms's Paganini Variations, Dohnanyi's ''Ruralia Hungarica'' (Op. 32a) and Lowell Liebermann's Piano Sonata No. 2, tomorrow evening at 8 at the Bernhard Mayer Auditorium of the New School, 66 West 12th Street. Tickets are $8. Information: 741-5690.

title: Continental Settles Lawsuit
description: Continental Airlines has settled a $336 million lawsuit against United Airlines that charged United with unfair competition in the use of its computerized reservations system.

title: Senate Rejects Plan on Aid to Miners
description: The Senate, upholding the President and its own leadership by the slenderest of margins, rejected a proposal today for special aid to coal miners who would lose their jobs if clean air legislation was passed by Congress.

title: 41 A.L. Games Rescheduled
description: The American League yesterday rescheduled the 41 games postponed by the 32-day lockout and set four of them for July 11, the day after the All-Star Game, which is traditionally an off day.

title: Grand Jury in Dallas Clears Man Who Fatally Shot Slayer
description: A Dallas County grand jury declined Wednesday to indict a 25-year-old man who fatally shot a gunman after seeing him kill a woman in a shopping mall's parking lot earlier this month.

title: Cruising New York's Waters
description: Manhattan's cruise season has begun. Here are the schedules.

title: Sparkling Colgate Is Stalking a Title
description: Because Colgate is a small college with only 2,700 students and a name that draws laughter from some people, its hockey players are accustomed to barbs from foes on the bench or strangers in the stands.

title: Black Enrollment in College Up After Long Decline, U.S. Says
description: Reversing years of decline, enrollment of black students at colleges and universities in the United States increased from 1986 to 1988, particularly in private institutions, according to new figures compiled by the United States Department of Education.

title: Autoclave Engineers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $10,000 for the quarter and $564,000, or 13 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: George A. McKenna, Security Chief, 79
description: George A. McKenna, a retired battalion chief in the New York City Fire Department and a former manager of security at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Sunday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Holliswood, Queens.

title: Chronicle
description: PEN, the writers' and editors' society, will honor two writers in absentia at its annual benefit on Wednesday at Roseland in New York. They are BEI DAO, a leading Chinese poet and the founder of Today, a literary journal banned in China, and JACK MAPANJE, a Malawian poet.

title: STUDY FINDS BIAS, FORCING A REVIEW OF 1986 ALIEN LAW
description: Congress must thoroughly re-examine the merits of a landmark immigration law because of a report today that said the measure had produced a ''widespread pattern of discrimination.''

title: Chronicle
description: In true cowboy fashion, SONNY BONO leaped on his steed and nabbed a transgressor. Mr. Bono, the Mayor of Palm Springs, Calif., a desert resort 100 miles east of Los Angeles, spotted a motorcyclist rocketing through an intersection last weekend on Palm Canyon Drive, the main thoroughfare. Astride his own black Harley-Davidson, the Mayor chased the speeder down and issued a warning, The Associated Press reported.

title: Brandenburg Ensemble
description: The pianist Yefim Bronfman is to be the soloist with the Brandenburg Ensemble in Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 2 (Op. 19) at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8. The program, which is to be conducted by Alexander Schneider, also includes Mozart's Violin Concerto No. 5 (K. 219), with Pamela Frank as the soloist; two Mozart Marches (K. 335), and Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 4, with the flutists Laura Gilbert and Laura Barron and the violinist Todd Phillips as the soloists. Tickets are $20. Information: 874- 6770.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Smartfoods for Mullen
description: Smartfoods Inc., a popcorn manufacturer owned by Frito-Lay Inc., has selected Mullen Advertising to handle its nationwide introduction, which is set for April 9. Smartfood popcorn has been available only in New England, where the brand was marketed through promotions conducted by Mullen, which has held the popcorn company's public relations account since 1986. Billings for the advertising account were not disclosed. The typical budget for the national introduction of a snack food is about $10 million, an advertising executive said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't spurn the accident victim who didn't wear a seat belt. We don't reject the cancer patient who didn't quit smoking cigarettes. We try to love them and care for them and comfort them. We do not fire them. We don't evict them. We don't cancel their insurance.''

title: Saks Being Sought By Eight Suitors
description: Eight potential buyers have been invited into the second round of bidding for Saks Fifth Avenue, the fashion chain put up for sale by B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., according to executives close to Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which is handling the sale. The bidders include several foreign companies. About a dozen potential bidders indicated their interest in the 47-store chain. But the number invited to remain for further reviews of Saks's operation is considered large and promising in terms of strong bids. Saks is estimated to bring around $1 billion.

title: Ryan Looking Beyond 1990
description: Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers, who is 43 years old, says he might pitch beyond the 1990 season despite hints at retirement a few months ago.

title: Nasdaq Would End Trades in Most Penny Stocks
description: The Nasdaq over-the-counter market, responding to a crackdown on ''penny stocks'' by regulators, proposed new rules today that would end trading in most stocks worth less than a dollar. The rules would scratch hundreds of penny stocks from the 4,910 issues now traded on the Nasdaq.

title: Shouldn't Justice Redeem as Well as Punish?
description: To the Editor:

title: Higher Risk of Rare Cancer Found for Vietnam Veterans
description: A long-awaited Federal study released today said that Vietnam veterans had a higher risk of contracting a rare cancer but that the risk could not be linked to exposure to the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: Rejection Seems Likely For Savings Nominee
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said late today after consulting with his colleagues that the committee was likely to reject the the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. as the nation's next top savings and loan regulator.

title: U.S. Sues Northrop Corp.
description: The Northrop Corporation, which last month pleaded guilty to criminal fraud charges, was sued today by the Justice Department for more than $5 million in related civil damages involving false test results on jet parts.

title: Former Principal Draws Probation in Drug Case
description: Matthew Barnwell, the former Bronx elementary school principal whose arrest set off an investigation of corruption in New York City school boards, was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation, drug rehabilitation and 150 hours of community service for his conviction of cocaine possession.

title: Tokyo Market Off Sharply
description: Stock prices fell sharply today, with the Nikkei index of 225 stocks losing more than 1,000 points to close below 30,000.

title: Sharpton Set Up Fraud, Prosecutor Tells Jurors
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton was portrayed yesterday by a state prosecutor as the mastermind of an ''ugly fraud'' who used a phantom charity in Brooklyn to steal more than $250,000 to promote his entertainment business interests and to satisfy his ''hunger for money.''

title: Fire in the Bronx;   A Phone Call To the Landlord
description: A landlord of the Bronx social club where 87 people died in a fire early Sunday was told last year that a ''vacate order'' had been issued for safety violations, according to one of many documents released yesterday by the New York City Fire Department.

title: Lamenting Larks
description: Starting Sunday, little kids can stay out longer, big kids and adults can get home from work before the street lights go on and householders can save a few pennies on the electric bill. It's the beginning of daylight saving time, an idea for energy-saving that originated in Britain in 1907 and, since the energy crisis of the 1970's, starts in this country on the first Sunday of April. That being April 1, it's showing up very early.

title: Veto of Idaho Abortion Bill Is Possible
description: Faced with one of the most difficult decisions in his long political career, Gov. Cecil D. Andrus, today offered the first hint that he might veto a restrictive abortion bill passed by the Idaho Legislature last week.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Books of The Times;   Horrors as No More Than Part of Life
description: Because It Is Bitter, and Because It Is My Heart

title: Imetal to Merge With Copperweld
description: Imetal S.A., a French industrial holding company, and the Copperweld Corporation said they had agreed to merge. Under the agreement, each outstanding Copperweld share will be converted into the right to receive $17 in cash. Imetal, based in Paris, owns almost 5.8 million shares, or about 65.2 percent, of Copperweld's common stock. The company had offered in January to acquire Copperweld for $15.50 a share.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified the director of Nutrition Learning Centers in Cedarhurst, L.I. She is Layne Lieberman-Anapol.

title: Winfield Finally Bats in a Game
description: It was nothing much to speak of: Dave Winfield popped up, grounded out, walked and hit into a force play. When he got back to the Yankee clubhouse, he was covered with dirt and perspiration and still looking for a hit but - as he has said often this spring - he was glad to be back.

title: 50th Performance By Free Theater Project
description: The Free Theater project will present a program in honor of its 50th performance today at 12:30 P.M. at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 50th Street.

title: Hadson Energy Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the increased rate was due to change in accounting for income taxes resulting from its 1989 reorganization. The 1988 earnings included a gain, net of tax, of $1,115,000 related to settlement of take-or-pay contracts.

title: Medar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $140,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $43,197 for the quarter and $875,361 for the year. The 1988 figures reflected reclassification of interest related to debt assumed by Medar from discontinued operations to continuing operations.

title: 400-Bottle Drug Error Spurs F.D.A. Recall
description: The Food and Drug Administration has announced an emergency recall of 400 bottles of desipramine, a generic antidepressant drug.

title: Temporary-Job Pioneer Giving Up Olsten Title
description: William Olsten, a pioneer in the temporary-employment business, is stepping down as chief executive of the Olsten Corporation at age 70, but plans to remain active as chairman.

title: Corrections Gilbert and Sullivan Players Send an SOS to Gershwin Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players' production of George Gershwin's ''Of Thee I Sing'' misidentified the actor shown. He was Alan Hill.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Dinkins Says Adviser Served On 116th St. Center's Board
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that his new Hispanic affairs adviser had been a board member of an East Harlem community center that was cited for fire-safety violations last year and should have been closed as a threat to life, yet stayed open.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Honoring Mel Lewis ''A Tribute to Mel Lewis,'' Bernhard Meyer Auditorium, the New School, 66 West 12th Street (741-5690). Before his death on Feb. 2, Mel Lewis, the drummer who led his big band on Monday nights at the Village Vanguard for 23 years, had been scheduled to bring a sextet from his band to Paul Weinstein's ''Jazz at Six'' series at the New School tonight. The concert will still go on, but as a commemoration to Mr. Lewis. Danny Gottlieb will take Mr. Lewis's role with the sextet, which will play selections from the group's last recording, ''Lost Art.'' The other members of the sextet are Dick Oatts, alto saxophonist; Gary Smulyan, baritone saxophonist; John Mosca, trombonist, and Ken Werner, pianist - all longtime members of Mr. Lewis's band -and a newer member, the bassist Scott Lee. Tickets for the concert, which is to run from 6 to 7:15 P.M., are $8 at the door or may be reserved by calling 741-5690.

title: LITHUANIA OFFERS TO DISCUSS A VOTE ON ITS SOVEREIGNTY
description: Leaders of this republic's embattled independence government sent a signal of compromise to the Kremlin tonight, saying they were ready to discuss the difficult issue of a referendum on secession if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed to talk with them.

title: Nichols Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
U.S. Securities Prices Tumble
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, pushed lower by overnight selling in Japan and end-of-quarter liquidations by American dealers.

title: Lindsay Manufacturing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Promotions at Polaroid Part of Reorganization
description: In what it termed a broad reorganization, the Polaroid Corporation announced yesterday that Sheldon A. Buckler, executive vice president, would be promoted to a newly formed Office of the CEO to share leadership with I. McAllister Booth, president and chief executive.

title: Kentucky Acts To Reorganize School System
description: The Kentucky General Assembly voted yesterday to abolish its system of financing and operating the state's 1,500 public schools and to substitute an entirely new philosophy and structure of management.

title: Repair U.S. Postal Service Until It Breaks
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Pro Bono
description: * Transportation Displays Inc. has created an environmental campaign for buses that starts April 1. The theme is, ''Acid Showers Bring No Flowers.''

title: Drop Gross's Charges, Axelrod Recommends
description: The State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, today recommended dropping misconduct charges against New York City's former Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot Gross.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Latest full year figures included a gain of $1,584,000, or 15 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Cubans in Florida

title: VSE Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,885,000 related to writeoff of loans to S.S. Monterey Partnership for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Muti to Quit Philadelphia Orchestra
description: Riccardo Muti, in a surprise announcement at a rehearsal of the Philadelphia Orchestra, said yesterday afternoon that he had decided to give up the orchestra's music directorship when his contract expires in August 1992.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about money market funds misidentified the distributor of Evergreen Tax-Exempt Fund. It is the Evergreen Asset Management Corporation.

title: Liberty Homes Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $872,000, or 19 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Satellites Find No Sign of Global Warming in 80's
description: Data from weather satellites show no evidence of global warming in the 1980's, scientists say, but it will take at least another decade of measurements to draw a firm conclusion.

title: Frisch's Restaurants Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $951,064, or 18 cents a share.

title: Beijing Avoids New Missile Sales Assurances
description: The United States has sought but failed to obtain additional assurances from China that Beijing will not sell medium-range missiles to the Middle East, Administration officials said today.

title: Enquirer Sets Deal for Star
description: The National Enquirer and The Star, two of the country's largest-circulation weekly supermarket tabloids, will be owned by the same company if a $400 million deal struck yesterday is completed and approved.

title: Mussmann And Troupe: Enigmas In Motion
description: A stump can be many things. Most obviously, it's what remains in the ground after the rest of a tree has been cut. As a noun, stump can also mean a rostrum or a tramping step. As a verb, it can mean to perplex, baffle and challenge.

title: Mets Make Their First Roster Cuts of Spring
description: The job market on the Mets took a pair of plunges today when three roster slots were eliminated and 10 rookies were demoted as victims of the mean arithmetic of baseball's short spring.

title: American Broadcasters Can Praise Soviet Official
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns;   Layoffs and Age: Discrimination Or Prudence?
description: Fred Hemsley is a man of routine. Each day he puts out the flag. Thursday nights he and his wife sing in their church choir. For 15 years Fridays have been the bowling night. They've been married 32 years; they've owned the same house 29.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Domestic Crimes in a Drama From Finland
description: The sordid true-life crime story that unfolds in the Finnish film ''Homebound'' would undoubtedly seem more riveting on the page, with a broader background, less matter-of-fact treatment and more attention to the story's undercurrents. ''Homebound,'' directed by Ilkka Jarvilaturi, explores a mother-son relationship that leads to suicide and murder. That relationship, as depicted in the film, is unquestionably a complex and troubled one. But in a culture in which a mother might walk in on her naked son in bed with his naked girlfriend and converse with the young man as if nothing were unusual, perhaps repressed sexual stirrings simply do not command much attention.

title: Motorola Told to Stop Selling Chip
description: Ruling in a bitter patent dispute, a Federal judge today ordered Motorola Inc. to stop selling what is perhaps its most important computer chip: the microprocessor used in machines made by Apple Computer Inc., Sun Microsystems Inc., the Hewlett-Packard Company and Next Inc.

title: Review/Theater;   Homer in Song and Dance In 'Golden Apple' Revival
description: Few vintage musicals have a greater cult reputation than John Latouche and Jerome Moross's cracker-barrel satire of Greek mythology, ''The Golden Apple.'' The 1954 show, which the York Theater Company is reviving for the second time in 12 years, transplants Homer's ''Iliad'' and ''Odyssey'' from ancient Greece to the rural village of Angel's Roost, Wash., at the turn of the century.

title: 2d Yugoslav Exchange
description: Communist-ruled Yugoslavia opened a second financial market today in the northwestern city of Ljubljana, and it immediately outshone the other exchange in Belgrade.

title: Review/Film;   Big-Screen Debut for Television's Dana Carvey
description: ''Opportunity Knocks'' is a thin, complacent comedy tailor-made to suit the talents of Dana Carvey, the latest ''Saturday Night Live'' alumnus to coast onto the movie screen. Mr. Carvey is an able impressionist, and the film is fine whenever he's given a chance to become George Bush or Mick Jagger or (in one instance) a Chinese leper. That's not often enough. When Mr. Carvey is required to be himself or to act, things are much worse.

title: TPI Enterprises reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: b-After income of $4,372,000, or 19 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $3,509,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Cut Defense Slower, and Faster
description: Two Democratic Senators have now set the probable boundaries for the critical debate on how to cut military spending. James Sasser of Tennessee wants to slash as much as $20 billion from next year's outlays of $306 billion. Sam Nunn of Georgia wants to reduce outlays much less at first but then phase in larger cuts, and he's right.

title: Colombian Drug Chiefs Threaten War
description: Asserting that the Government had betrayed a secret peace pact, Colombia's cocaine traffickers threatened today to renew their war against the state.

title: Henry W. Happel, Lawyer, 78
description: Henry W. Happel, a retired senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Brown & Wood, died on Sunday at Riverhead Hospital on Long Island after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Quogue, L.I.

title:
Strong Sales in New Condos;

Fast Sellout Expected at Trump Palace
description: LEAD: The 57-story Trump Palace, under development by Donald J. Trump on Third Avenue at 69th Street, will be the tallest building on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Its apartment prices, which average $1,000 a square foot, are also among the loftiest in the city for new condominiums, and yet they do not seem to be a deterrent to sales.

title: LAW: At the Bar
description: Fifteen years ago Royall Victor, the newly installed presiding partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York, likened leading a large law firm to ''being the only fire hydrant on a block with 50 dogs.''

title: Review/Music;   30 Years of Songs From Martin Charnin
description: ''Martin Charnin: The Hits and the Ms.'s'' is a revue surveying Mr. Charnin's 30-year songwriting career in which the lyricist and sometime composer acts as ringmaster of his own retrospective.

title: CBS Plans New Round of Staff Cuts
description: CBS Inc. plans to cut dozens of employees from its staff, executives at the network said yesterday, either through a strict review of all job openings or dismissals spaced out slowly.

title: Dinkins Request For 4 to Resign Starts a Struggle
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has touched off a political struggle by asking for the resignation of the top administrator and three members of the new Voter Assistance Commission, set up under the new City Charter to be a nonpolitical agency to encourage voter registration.

title: Sanliurfa Journal;   Dam Is Watering Hope for a New Fertile Crescent
description: With its horse-drawn carts and rickety shops, this placid farming center in Turkey's southeast does not exactly scream boom town.

title: Drug Tests Suspend 2
description: Antonio McKay, world indoor 400-meter champion last year and a gold medalist in the 1988 Olympic Games, and Trevor Black, a long jumper from Jamaica, have been suspended by The Athletics Congress for three months because they tested positive for substances commonly found in over-the-counter medications, the athletics organization said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Centaur Partners L.P., an investment group, will not bid for National Intergroup Inc., Pittsburgh, an insurer, of which it owns 16.5 percent.

title: U.S. Shoe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included a charge of $7.4 million for accounting adjustments related to Marx & Newman division. c-Included a charge of about $3.1 million related to store closings for the quarter and year. The latest periods were comprised of 14 weeks for the quarter and 53 weeks for the year.

title: Isidore Adler, 73, Dies of Cancer; Chemist of the Moon's Dark Side
description: Isidore Adler, a scientist, educator and researcher who was among the first to map the chemical composition of the back of the moon, died of cancer on Monday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 73 years old and lived in Silver Spring.

title: Costco Wholesale Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 18
Review/Art;   The Burden of Isolation, In Baselitz 'Hero' Paintings
description: The West German painter Georg Baselitz gained fame in the United States in the early 1980's for his strident paintings of inverted figures, canvases whose loony arbitrariness abstracted the world by simply turning it on its head. Generally grouped into the Neo-Expressionist category, his paintings earned a mixed response; to no extent did Mr. Baselitz's work evoke the same respect as the art of his compatriots Sigmar Polke, Gerhard Richter and Anselm Kiefer.

title: Restaurants
description: There is something extraordinarily uplifting about a bustling New York steakhouse: the animated camaraderie of urban warriors back from corporate combat, the snappy pace of the staff, the aura of abundance, the refreshing lack of pretension. Smith & Wollensky, a paean to protein in midtown, exudes that winning feeling by the magnum.

title: Penn Traffic Co. reports earnings for 14wk to Feb 3
description: b-Included company's portion of net loss in its 24.3 percent stake in GND Holdings. The company's portion of net loss for fourth quarter was $4,920,000. The 1989 periods included the results of Big Bear Inc., since date of acquisition, April 1, 1989.

title: A Storied Rivalry Is Reviving: Nicklaus and Trevino in Seniors
description: Rain and lightning today kept Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino from firing the opening shots in their first official duel as senior golfers, but it's a certainty that plenty of electricity will remain in the air after the weather clears.

title: Buffalo to Halt Bus and Subway Tomorrow Night
description: The financially troubled Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority voted today to suspend bus and subway service in the region after their last runs on Saturday night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Eastern Is Pressed On Its Debt
description: After almost a year of supporting Frank Lorenzo's plans to rebuild Eastern Airlines, the carrier's unsecured creditors are apparently running low on patience. People close to the creditors' committee said yesterday that it was considering actions that could lead to the liquidation of the airline unless Mr. Lorenzo upholds an earlier promise that the creditors will be paid 50 cents on the dollar.

title: Unreal Estate
description: In a recent letter to The Times, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York observed that secret protocols to the Molotov-Ribbentrop nonaggression pact in 1939 assigned Estonia and Latvia to the Soviet Union's ''sphere of influence'' and Lithuania to Nazi Germany's. Subsequently, he noted, Stalin paid Germany $7.5 million in gold to get Lithuania, too.

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Fire Survivor Tells Of 'All the Screams' He 'Can't Forget'
description: A doorman raced up the narrow back stairs of the Happy Land Social Club, a light wave of smoke trailing him. ''Fire! Fire!'' he shouted as he burst onto the dance floor, but the scores of revelers hesitated in fear.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burlington Industries, Greensboro, N.C., a subsidiary of Burlington Holdings Inc., New York, announced the resignation of Richard Altman, president of its Burlington Knitted Fabrics division. Frank S. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive of Burlington Industries, will assume Mr. Altman's responsibilities.

title: George, Howie, Donald
description: This bizarre scenario came to mind nearly two weeks ago when the story first surfaced about George Steinbrenner's little problem with the gambler. Remember, the players were still locked out by the owners. Baseball was being trashed by everybody. It was hard for a fellow to get any personal publicity.

title: In Namibia, U.N.'s First Hurdle Was Highest
description: For Martti Ahtisaari, the bleakest days of his long watch over Namibia's transition to independence came nearly a year ago, when guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization, entering the country from Angola, were attacked by South African-led security forces.

title: Vivra Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: There were no common share earnings for the year-ago quarter because the company was spun off from Community Psychiatric Centers in August 1989.

title: Review/Film;   Nonstop Action in 'Mutant Ninja Turtles'
description: The difference between ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' the live-action film and ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' the animated television show can be measured in whiskers, matted fur, beady eyes and desiccated paws. These belong to Splinter, the wise old rodent who is the mentor of the four title characters, a debonair fellow in the animated version and a thoroughly disgusting one here. Try hard to picture this rheumy-eyed, realistic-looking rat before deciding to take a small child to see this film.

title: Advisers in Forefront Of New Proxy Wars
