description: Harold C. Simmons, the Texas investor some would call a corporate raider, knew he had an image problem when he decided to seek control of the Lockheed Corporation. So he made a videotape to portray himself to institutional shareholders as a hardscrabble former drugstore owner who created an enormous fortune with brains, hard work and American values.

title: U.S. Gives Details of Charges In Nuclear-Arms Parts Case
description: Five people and two companies have been charged with conspiring to smuggle electronic devices used to detonate nuclear bombs to Iraq, according to an indictment by a Federal grand jury in San Diego that was unsealed today.

title: Economic Scene;   The 2-Front Battle Facing Moscow
description: LITHUANIA'S struggle for independence from the Soviet Union has virtually blotted out from public attention President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision earlier this month to accept the advice of his liberal advisers and move rapidly to establish the basis for a market economy. A set of decrees is expected shortly from the Government on paving the way. But the battle to keep the Soviet empire from disintegrating could cause Mr. Gorbachev again to delay his plans for a radical reform of the system.

title: New Incentives Offered by Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company fattened cash rebates and lowered interest rates on some company-financed loans on six car and truck lines. The car maker's current incentives will extend through April 30 to try to move some of its slow-selling models before the 1991 versions appear.

title: On Stage
description: A Double Dessert

title: INSIDE
description: Trouble for Abortion Bill

title: Bush, in First Address on AIDS, Backs a Bill to Protect Its Victims
description: In his first address on AIDS since he took office, President Bush appealed today for compassion toward people infected with the AIDS virus and expressed support for a bill that would outlaw discrimination against people with AIDS and other diseases.

title: Right Questions About Long-Term Care
description: ''Most of the things that are likely to help solve the long-term care problem are being tried in some pilot project somewhere, but we're really still at the very beginning.'' So said Dr. Burton Reifler of Winston-Salem, N.C., the operator of a pilot project, in the four-part New York Times series on long-term care that concludes today.

title: Cray in Deal To Acquire Supertek
description: Cray Research Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Supertek Computers Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash. Supertek, a privately held company based in Santa Clara, Calif., manufactures a mini-supercomputer compatible with Cray's machines. Cray said the purchase would accelerate its entry in the mini-super market.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Joseph F. Barone has been named president of Gillespie Advertising, Princeton, N.J.

title: Johnny Neun, Triple-Play Fielder, 89
description: Johnny Neun, one of only nine major league players to execute an unassisted triple play, died of pancreatic cancer Wednesday at Union Memorial Hospital. He was 89 years old.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Taste of the Tropics

title: Review/Photography;   Hybrids by Larry Johnson Stretch Language to Its Limits
description: That words are as much representations as pictures - in a way, they are pictures - has been a subject of interest to artists as diverse as Jenny Holzer, Barbara Kruger, Bruce Nauman and Ed Ruscha. Compared to their work, Larry Johnson's images of short paragraphs of text are less theatrical, but perhaps because they are unvarnished photographs, they seem even more disembodied and confounding.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the allure of the Academy Awards broadcast misidentified a Washington public relations executive who had been hostess to Oscar-watching parties for 10 years. She is Karen Doyne.

title: India Inquiry Accuses Airbus and Others of Bribes
description: The Indian Government's top investigating agency today accused the European consortium Airbus Industrie, an American company and four former Indian airline officials of bribery and corruption in the award to Airbus of a contract worth nearly $2 billion for dozens of aircraft.

title: In Connecticut, the Wide-Open Battle Begins for O'Neill's Job
description: The wide-open battle to succeed Gov. William A. O'Neill has begun in earnest, with Democrats and Republicans in towns across the state appointing delegates to the party conventions that will nominate candidates in July.

title: Pretoria Names Delegation for Talks With Rebels
description: The South African Government announced today that virtually its full leadership would turn out to meet the African National Congress at talks scheduled for April 11.

title: Lockheed Gives In to Big Holders
description: The outcome of the Lockheed Corporation's proxy fight with a group headed by Harold C. Simmons may not be known for several weeks, but it became clear at the company's annual meeting today that institutional shareholders have already become winners in the battle.

title: Review/Film Festival;   'Little Fish,' Soviet Comedy About a Country Cousin
description: Hang onto your hats, folks. ''There appears to be a wild and goofy movement of young film makers in Soviet Kazakhstan.''

title: Sister Carol Brody, Educator, 58
description: Sister Carol Brody, director of the Weekend College at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., died on Tuesday at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx after a brief illness. She was 58 years old and lived at the college.

title: Delinquent Loans Drop
description: The number of consumers who are behind by 30 days or more on bank loan payments declined in the final three months of 1989 after rising to a 10-year high in the previous quarter, the American Bankers Association said this week. It said that 2.64 percent of installment loans were delinquent as of Dec. 31, compared with 2.88 percent on Sept. 30 and 2.49 percent a year earlier. The delinquency rate is based on a survey of 800 banks. It includes personal loans and those involving autos, mobile homes, recreational vehicles, property improvement and home equity.

title: Review/Recital;   A Pianist Journeys Back in Time
description: Robert Helps was born in 1928, but the pianist and composer's recital on Monday night at Town Hall was like a trip back to another era of musical avant-gardism.

title: Umpires Agree To Return
description: Major league umpires say they will return to work Sunday under a new agreement that reimburses them for games canceled during the 32-day lockout and gives them three more vacation days in the regular season.

title: Landlord Sentenced To Two Years in Jail For Lack of Repairs
description: A landlord was sentenced yesterday to two years in jail for repeatedly failing to comply with New York City orders to remove violations and make repairs at two apartment buildings in Brooklyn.

title: 150 at Jails Call In Ill; Cause Is Undetermined
description: An unusually large number of captains in the New York City jail system - at least seven or eight times the average number - called in sick yesterday, the Department of Correction said. There was no immediate explanation for the reported illnesses and the union that represents the captains said it had not sanctioned any job action.

title: Program Sales Hurt Stocks; Dow Off 15.99
description: Stocks fought an uphill battle but fell back in listless trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average sliding 15.99 points, to 2,727.70.

title: Plattsburgh Gets Probation
description: The ice hockey program at SUNY-Plattsburgh, a Division III school, has been put on probation for two years for rules violations that the National Collegiate Athletic Association said included having athletes live at the homes of boosters.

title: How to Cut Albany's Deficit
description: LEAD: Before the 1980's, big state government budget deficits seemed to be rare events, but in recent years they have been in the headlines often. There were deficits in the rust bowl states in the severe recession of 1982, in the oil patch states in mid-decade and, now, in New York, Massachusetts, New Jersey and some other states.

title: Baltics to Baghdad
description: From the Baltics to Baghdad, the umbrellas of appeasement are unfurling.

title: Quarex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Fire in the Bronx;   Hearing on Club Safety Finds Officials at Odds
description: The New York City Council and the Dinkins administration clashed yesterday over whether the city needs new laws to crack down on unsafe social clubs or has simply failed to enforce existing ones adequately.

title: New Mother Finds Competitive Edge
description: When Juli Inkster called it ''definitely the toughest tournament I've ever been in,'' the 29-year-old golfer was not referring to last year's wire-to-wire, five-shot victory at the Nabisco Dinah Shore. Instead, she was talking about the birth of her first child, Hayley Carole, early last month.

title: Kohl Urges Poland to Admit Past 'Injustice'
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany urged Poland today to acknowledge that it inflicted ''an injustice'' on Germans who came under Polish rule after World War II.

title: For Eastern Europe, Free Trade, Not Aid
description: As Eastern Europe emerges from an economic dark age, America has a unique chance to create jobs, hope and opportunity there -not through aid but through free-trade agreements, like the one we're now discussing with Mexico.

title: Bonn Far Right Loses Steam As Germans Focus on Unity
description: German unity might seem to be the stuff of right-wing dreams. In fact, it has proved something of a nightmare for the far-right Republican Party.

title: AIDS Outbreak Is Forcing China To Confront Virus and Drug Use
description: A report that 146 peasants from Yunnan Province on China's southwest border used dirty drug needles and infected themselves with the AIDS virus has sent shivers throughout China.

title: NBC Says 'Cosby' to Return, Without a Bonus Agreement
description: After months of sometimes bitter negotiations, NBC said yesterday that ''The Cosby Show'' would return to the network for a seventh season this fall. The one-year agreement between the network and the Carsey-Werner Company, which produces the show, was concluded yesterday.

title: Everybody's Still Alive!
description: Geoff Courtnall's goal late in the second period tonight allowed the Washington Capitals to clinch a Patrick Division playoff spot with a 2-2 tie that dimmed the Philadelphia Flyers' playoff hopes.

title: 11 Are Killed in Kashmir Gun Battles
description: At least 11 people were killed today in gun battles between pro-independence Kashmiris and Indian paramilitary forces in Srinagar, the capital of Jammu and Kashmir state, news reports said.

title: Testing Privacy Rights in the World of the Deaf
description: No one disputes that three years ago, Robert Rewolinski strangled his longtime girlfriend, Catherine Teeters. He was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison here.

title: 7 Days Magazine Is for Sale
description: Just two years after it was started, 7 Days magazine, which has amassed a small but dedicated following among Manhattan's trend-setters, is up for sale.

title: Child World Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Getting the Facts on Long-Term Care
description: Here is a list of organizations, books and consumer guides that provide information on long-term care:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday about Allied-Signal Inc.'s planned copper foil plant misstated the site. It is Camden, S.C.

title: Sephardic Jews Mark 500th Anniversary
description: The Sephardic Jews are already observing the 500th anniversary of their expulsion from Spain, an event that began in 1492, just as Columbus was sailing on his epochal voyage. Even as the Great Navigator set his course westward, many Jews set their hopes eastward, to the Ottoman Empire, whose Muslim rulers had invited them to settle in an energetic realm that extended from deep in the Middle East to the Balkans, opposite Italy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: New Pact for Welsh
description: George Welsh, the most successful coach in University of Virginia football history, has signed a new, eight-year contract that gives him the option of moving into athletic administration, Jim Copeland, athletic director, said yesterday in Charlottesville.

title: Appeals on S.I. Wetlands Seek to Stop Environmental Giveaway;   Hardship Gantlet
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Are Reeling And Face Jordan Next
description: While the Nets spent yesterday planning for their future, the Knicks were still worried about the present.

title: Market Place;   Investors Shifting To Stock Funds
description: AS the stock market scored choppy gains in March, small investors continued the trend of buying stock mutual funds that was begun in February, fund managers said yesterday. In January, for the first time in seven months, more investments had been withdrawn from such funds than were put in.

title: Giovanni Costigan, 85, A Professor of History
description: Giovanni Costigan, a history professor emeritus at the University of Washington who was a leading political and social liberal in the Northwest, died of a heart attack on Saturday in Seville, Spain, where he was a guest lecturer on a European tour. He was 85 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: Norton Board Rejects $1.64 Billion BTR Bid
description: The Norton Company said yesterday that it had rejected a buyout offer of $75 a share from BTR P.L.C., a British conglomerate.

title: New Debt, and Discipline, for New York
description: In the foreground, New York leaders are battling over the state's next budget. But meanwhile, they are finally beginning to respond to criticism of the sloppy fiscal practices that have helped put the state into its fiscal morass. In what amounts to an admission of guilt, politicians of both parties concede that they've let the state get deeply into debt, and want to borrow enough to retire all or part of an accumulated deficit that's reached nearly $5 billion - a record high.

title: Former Tyson Trainer Files for Bankruptcy
description: Kevin Rooney, who earned millions of dollars as Mike Tyson's trainer before Tyson dismissed him in 1988, has filed for bankruptcy protection after one of his homes was seized.

title: POLAND RESHAPING ITS LOCAL VOTING
description: Poland is preparing for free elections for a completely reorganized local government that Solidarity supporters hope will break the grip of the Communist Party bureaucracy throughout the country.

title: Appeals on S.I. Wetlands Seek to Stop Environmental Giveaway
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art;   The Independent Works of an Insider's Outsider
description: Since the sculptor Alain Kirili moved to New York from Paris in 1977, he has been keeping his own counsel and thinking his own way. He has praised the ecumenism of Barnett Newman and the struggle of David Smith against what Mr. Kirili calls ''American Puritanism.'' He has expressed his ''passion for femininity and grace'' and a voluptuous French ease. He has criticized the provincialism that for him is reflected in the policy of the Whitney Museum of American Art - in the heart of the city that symbolizes the melting pot of America - to exclude the work of non-American artists.

title: Schools Faulted in Audit on Fire Safety
description: Most New York City public schools are not adequately protecting their children and staffs against the possibility of fire, the State Comptroller's office said yesterday after its auditors found numerous schools with empty fire extinguishers, clogged sprinklers and missing exit signs.

title: Ex-Bulgarian Official Is Held On Charges Linked to Camp
description: Authorities today arrested a retired Deputy Interior Minister who ran a camp in northern Bulgaria in which hundreds of prisoners may have been killed during Todor Zhivkov's Government.

title: New York Court Says Defendants Can't Reject Jurors Based on Race
description: New York's highest court today became the first in any state to rule that lawyers for criminal defendants cannot dismiss prospective jurors because of their race. In issuing the unanimous decision, the court also upheld the manslaughter convictions of three young men in the Howard Beach racial attack case.

title: Spinning Stories Metaphorically: Dances From Life
description: DANCE is an inherently metaphoric art. Two very different worlds are suggested by the mere presence of a single person or of two on an empty stage space. As much can be suggested about a human emotion in a moment's turn of a body or lifting of an arm as in long pages of philosophy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Lester J. Maitland Is Dead at 91; First to Fly From U.S. to Hawaii
description: Lester J. Maitland, a hero of pioneer aviation who became an Episcopal priest late in life, died on Tuesday night at a rest home in Scottsdale. He was 91 years old.

title: Leo Schwartz, Surgeon, 87
description: Leo Schwartz, a retired New York surgeon who was an ear, nose and throat specialist, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 years old and had lived in Florida for 17 years.

title: Broker Case Is Settled
description: Howard A. Rubin, a former head mortgage bond securities trader at Merrill Lynch Goverment Securities Inc., settled Federal disciplinary charges today that he had failed to keep accurate books and records about certain sales of mortgage-backed securities in April 1987.

title: Belgium Eases Its Abortion Law
description: Overcoming 17 years of opposition by Christian Democratic parties, the Belgian Parliament approved a law this afternoon that would allow abortions in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy for women ''in a state of distress.''

title: Fire in the Bronx;   Social Clubs Quickly Turn Heavy Profits for Investors
description: The economic ladder in the social club business spans the gap between street-smart entrepreneurs in New York City's poorest neighborhoods and wealthy, established real-estate operators - and along the way, everyone seems to make money.

title: Donald Davidson, Baseball Official, 64
description: Donald Davidson, a special assistant with the Houston Astros whose baseball career spanned more than 40 years, died on Wednesday after having suffered from cancer. He was 64 years old.

title: Devils Clinch Second Place
description: The Devils' 6-4 triumph over the Rangers tonight was a feeling-out process of what might happen in two weeks between the cross-river rivals. It was a game of muscle-flexing, of establishing a foundation in case the teams meet in the Patrick Division final of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Lowe Tucker Is Ready for Prime Time
description: URGENT plea to clients from Lowe Tucker Metcalf: please assign television commercials immediately!

title: Review/Pop;   Rickie Lee Jones Mingles Past and Present, Time and Ego
description: Rickie Lee Jones gets away with enough quirks to sink half a dozen other singer-songwriters. She sings, most of the time, in a mewling voice, slurring her words in phrases that seem all but oblivious to the beat. Her songs drift and ramble, in languid vamps that are always on the verge of dissolution; her lyrics do not shy away from childishness or melodrama as she sings about the utopian power of love. Yet when her first tour since 1982 brought her to the Ritz on Tuesday, opening a two-night stand, Ms. Jones was radiant in her eccentricities, holding the sold-out house rapt as her voice curled and soared through her songs.

title: Auctions
description: Cast-Iron Toy Cars

title: Review/Theater;   Relearning the Lesson of Miller's 'Crucible'
description: ''The Crucible'' is not only Arthur Miller's most-produced play; it has also become his most continually relevant work of political theater. By focusing on the Salem witch hunts of the 17th century, the playwright placed the outrage of McCarthyism in historical perspective and created a drama that has remained meaningful to succeeding generations. Gerald Freedman's articulate revival at the Roundabout Theater Company is as resolute as the play itself.

title: Arts Aide Backs Cincinnati Museum
description: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts today applauded the decision of a Cincinnati museum to seek a ruling from the courts on whether the sexually explicit photography of Robert Mapplethorpe is obscene.

title: Quiet Times at Georgia Tech
description: It is 1 o'clock on a typically sunny Georgia afternoon. On a normal day the Georgia Tech campus would be aswarm with more than 12,000 students making their way to and from classes. This afternoon, however, the 330-acre campus is virtually deserted.

title: Washington Talk;   Activism, 1990-Style: All Lips, No Money
description: Starting with his acceptance speech at New Orleans, George Bush has clung firmly to a pledge of no new taxes. It has become the hallmark of his Administration, as he intended from the start.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

President Appointed At New Rockwell Unit
description: LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it had combined three divisions into a large new military electronics organization and had named John A. McLucky, a long-time company executive, as its president.

title: Greenspan Favors S.E.C. As Stock Futures Regulator
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave tentative support today to Treasury Department efforts to increase the regulatory power of the Securities and Exchange Commission and reduce that of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: For a Comfortable Old Age, Plan for Care, Experts Advise
description: As the average cost of a nursing-home stay climbs to nearly $30,000 a year, experts agree on one main piece of advice for those concerned about preparing for their old age: plan early for long-term care.

title: Congressman Accused of Anti-Jewish Remarks Offers Rebuttal
description: Seeking to stem mounting criticism, Representative Gus Savage defended himself today against accusations that he had made anti-Semitic remarks in his re-election primary campaign and reiterated his contention that he had been a target of Jewish groups seeking his defeat.

title: Jefferson Smurfit In Recycling Deal
description: The Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C. agreed to buy a Southern California newsprint recycling mill from the Giant Group Ltd. for $95 million plus $25 million later if Jefferson Smurfit decides to expand the mill within several years. The mill, the Golden State Newsprint Company in Pomona, Calif., also operates 10 recycling centers.

title: Harrington to Colorado
description: The University of Colorado announced yesterday that Joe Harrington of Long Beach State had been hired as head coach. Harrington replaces Tom Miller, who was dismissed before the Buffaloes ended the season at 12-18, their fourth successive losing season under Miller and their sixth in a row over all. ''It's a situation similar to the one I had when I took over at Long Beach,'' Harrington said. ''They have been last in the conference the last five years.''

title: Karl Brown, 93, Hollywood Pioneer In Cinematography
description: Karl Brown, a pioneering Hollywood cinematographer who worked on D. W. Griffith's 1915 silent film epic, ''The Birth of a Nation,'' and wrote several screenplays, died Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 93 years old.

title: House, 265-145, Votes to Widen Day Care Programs in the Nation
description: The House of Representatives today passed a bill that would both expand day care programs and provide more money to programs that already exist.

title: Dallas Voting System Is Ordered Revamped
description: Seven months after voters approved a new system for electing the City Council, a Federal judge has ordered that another plan be drawn within 30 days to offer better representation to black and Hispanic people. He also ordered new elections as soon as possible but set no date.

title: Torchmark Offers Slate
description: The Torchmark Corporation intensified its efforts today in its $6.3 billion bid for the American General Corporation, offering a surprise slate of nominees for election to the company's board at its annual meeting on May 2.

title: The Two Nations
description: Any idea that political change can quickly heal the divisions in South African society is dispelled by a visit to this community. It is an African settlement built on the barren sand of the Cape flats, 20 miles from the lush gardens and mountains of Cape Town.

title: Women's Coaches Assail Sooner Plan
description: When the University of Oklahoma announced this week that it was dropping its women's basketball program, the school expected little reaction. Instead, the announcement hit here like a wind sweeping off the plain and energized the Women's Basketball Coaches' Association, which was convening in conjunction with the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four.

title: TV Weekend;   Open Season on Husbands as Comedy Stars Return
description: Two of television's most successful comedy actresses are returning to the grind of a weekly schedule. Jean Stapleton, for years the dizzy but shrewd mate to Archie Bunker on ''All in the Family,'' can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS's ''Bagdad Cafe,'' based on the 1988 Percy Adlon movie. Her co-star is Whoopi Goldberg. Tomorrow at 9:30 P.M. on NBC, Carol Burnett offers a ''special sneak preview'' of ''Carol and Company,'' an anthology series featuring a new comic sketch each week.

title: Scott's Liquid Gold reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PUERTO RICO ASKS FOR SECRET FILES
description: The Justice Department and Puerto Rican lawmakers are battling for custody of secret Government documents that the legislators say could indicate Federal involvement in one of the most serious political scandals in the history of Puerto Rico.

title: Hearst Fills Vacant Post
description: Gilbert C. Maurer, the executive vice president of the Hearst Corporation and president of its Hearst Magazines division, has been named chief operating officer of the parent corporation.

title: Newmont Selling Stake In Coal Unit
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell its controlling interest in the nation's largest coal company to Newmont's largest shareholder, London-based Hanson P.L.C.

title: Researcher Defends 'Cold Fusion' Work But Draws Criticism
description: In his first appearance at an open scientific meeting in many months, a scientist who claimed to have achieved ''cold fusion'' presented no new data today that would be likely to persuade skeptics that the disputed findings were real.

title: Acclaim Entertainment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Weekends at Dusk, a New Met Museum
description: LAST fall, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced plans to stay open late on Friday and Saturday evenings instead of Tuesdays, it seemed that another well-established tradition was being needlessly tinkered with; it wasn't broken, so why fix it? How could a museum hope to compete for attention on weekend evenings, hours already so flooded with entertainment options?

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums BOB BERKY PROGRAM, a show of mime, magic and clowning by Mr. Berky at the Very Young People's Program, 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $8 and $12. Information: 996-1100. ''ALADDIN,'' a play by the Gingerbread Players, directed by Dolly Guinther with musical direction by Ben Sloane, shows at 7:30 tonight and 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at St. Luke's Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, Queens. Admission: $5. Information: (718) 268-6021. ''LOLLIPOPS'' CONCERT, a program for children 3 to 5 years old, presented by the Little Orchestra Society, directed by Dino Anagnost, 10:15 and 11:30 A.M. tomorrow, and 1:15 and 2:30 P.M. Sunday, at Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street. Tickets: $25. Reservations: 704-2100. ''THE REMARKABLE MR. PUSS IN BOOTS,'' a show directed by Nicolas Coppola, with 18th-century French settings and costumes, noon Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the Puppetworks, 338 Sixth Avenue, at Fourth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Admission: children, $4; adults, $5. Information: (718) 965-3391. ''PUFF THE MAGIC DRAGON,'' a puppet show by the Papageno Puppet Theater, with Susan Delery Whedon, noon and 2 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, and ''Hansel and Gretel,'' 1 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at 173 West 81st Street. Admission: $4; $6 for both shows. Information: 874-3297.

title: G.E. to Buy Risky Assets Of Kidder
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company announced a substantial recasting of its balance sheet yesterday that will shift troublesome assets to its parent, the General Electric Company.

title: Urgent Action Needed On Ethiopia Food Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey in Moscow Sees a High Level of Anti-Jewish Feeling
description: A survey of tolerance in the Soviet Union has reported ''disturbingly high levels of anti-Jewish feeling,'' according to the American Jewish Committee, which helped finance the project.

title: King Stirs Animosity In Douglas Hometown
description: In 1492, Columbus discovered America. Last week the city of Columbus, Ohio, discovered the fight promoter, Don King. It's a toss-up which was more of a revelation.

title: Mobil Ends Environmental Claim
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would remove the word ''degradable'' from boxes of its Hefty plastic trash bags. In doing so, it is apparently bowing to demands from environmental groups and the threat of legal action by the attorneys general of eight states.

title: On Derby Trail, 3 Preps for Preps
description: The three Kentucky Derby preps tomorrow might better be called Derby-prep preps. Each is a warm-up for a more significant prep race under similar conditions next month that is likely to draw the same cast.

title: Dealers Don't See a Trend In Sharp Drop of the Dollar
description: The dollar dropped sharply yesterday against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies, but dealers argued that the decline did not signal an end to the recent upward trend.

title: More Blacks Attend College
description: Federal figures show that enrollment by black students in American colleges rose from 1986 to 1988, reversing years of decline. Page A16.

title: Consumer Spending Up Slight 0.4%
description: Consumer spending narrowed to a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in February, the Government said today.

title: Cuomo Reveals List of Big Cuts In Budget Pact
description: To goad members of the Republican-led State Senate to drop their insistence that the state's budget gap be made up through spending cuts alone, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today made public the list of cuts that he and legislative leaders had agreed on privately.

title: Arkansas and Duke in a Race to the Final
description: Everyone expects the Arkansas-Duke semifinal on Saturday to continue the uptempo, run-and-execute style that has marked this year's sprint toward college basketball's national championship.

title: American Healthcare Management reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $30,455,000, or $2.62 a share, for both the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included an extraordinary charge of $5,168,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,295,000, or 11 cents a share, for the year. Extraordinary credit included an extraordinary gain on restructuring debt and asset writedowns and other expenses associated with the reorganization. Also included in 1989 results were $4.7 million of bankruptcy professional fees, a $2.7 million adjustment of prior receivables from the medicare and medicaid programs, a $2.9 million increase in the company's provision for doubtful accounts and a resumption of interest payments.

title: Treatment Is Said to Reduce Disability From Spinal Injury
description: For the first time, researchers have shown that drug treatment can reduce paralysis and other disability in people with serious spinal cord injury.

title: Review/Music;   Philharmonic and Dutoit Treat Innocence Gently
description: Although to scan most orchestral programs you might think otherwise, a good concert need not have as its centerpiece something bone-rattling and apocalyptic. Charles Dutoit and the New York Philharmonic did very nicely on Thursday evening with nothing more pretentious than Ravel's ''Mother Goose,'' the sweetly innocent ballet suite also known as ''Ma Mere l'Oye.'' The conductor's insight into the elfin appeal of this apparently simple but actually challenging music was evident at every moment during the seven numbers that make up the score.

title: Who Must Pay Taxes Quarterly
description: For most taxpayers, the moment for settling accounts with the Internal Revenue Service comes just once a year. But for the 10 percent required to estimate and pay taxes during the current year, April 16 is merely one of four deadlines - the others are the 15th of June, September and January. And with changes in the tax code brought about by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, and a growing elderly population, the number of people who pay quarterly is likely to grow.

title: Putting the National Interest First
description: Could it be that a Congressman would say no to a multimillion-dollar military installation in his home district? Meet Byron Dorgan, North Dakota's sole Representative, who has withdrawn his support for putting MX missiles on railroad cars. Having backed research on the proposed rail system, he now opposes construction, despite the fact that the Pentagon proposes spending $70 million to put part of the system at Grand Forks Air Force Base.

title: U.S. Urged to Resolve Problem at Arms Plant
description: The Governor of Colorado has urged the Energy Department not to reopen Rocky Flats until it has solved a safety problem that left the nuclear weapons plant's air ducts clogged with 62 pounds of plutonium.

title: U.S. Lifts Rules So 8 Can Grieve in Honduras
description: Eight relatives of victims of the Bronx social club fire whose immigration status is unclear have received special permission from the Immigration and Naturalization Service to return to Honduras to bury their dead.

title: Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included a charge of $2,164,000 on the sale of Abercrombie & Fitch. c-Net income and included income of $1,612,000, or 27 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The 1989 year's income before items included a gain of $20,951,000. The latest year included an after- tax LIFO charge of $125,000, compared with $216,000 for 1989. The latest quarter included an after-tax LIFO credit of $309,000, or 5 cents a share, compared with a credit of $216,000, or 4 cents a share, for year- ago period. The latest periods comprised of 14 weeks for the quarter and 53 weeks for the year, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Administrators, Not Teacher Committees, Make Good Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Sterilization Inc. reports earnings for 12mo to Dec 31
Lawyers Bring Poindexter Trial To a Heated End
description: In an impassioned closing argument, the chief prosecutor in the trial of John M. Poindexter said today that the Government had presented ''overwhelming evidence'' against the former national security adviser, justifying a verdict of guilty on all five criminal charges.

title: J. O. Hirschfelder, 78, Atom Bomb Developer
description: Joseph Oakland Hirschfelder, a physicist and educator who contributed to the development of the atomic bomb, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Madison, Wis. He was 78 years old.

title: Chemical Bank Pushing Cuts in Costs
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation, in a push to bring its expenses down to levels comparable with other large banks, announced job cuts and other measures yesterday intended to save $60 million annually. The changes, however, will cause a special $52 million reduction in first-quarter earnings.

title: Wall St. Underwriting Fees Are Staying at a Low Level
description: Corporate America kept to a steady pace in raising money from the securities markets in the year's first quarter, but that trend brought little joy to Wall Street, since underwriting fees remained low.

title: Review/Music;   From Subway to the Concert Stage
description: James Graseck began playing his violin in the New York City subways and on the street when he was a student at the Juilliard School, in the 1970's. And although he completed his master's degree and gave a well-received debut recital, he has decided not to climb the career ladder in the usual way. Apart from a few years of teaching, in Georgia, he has continued playing in the subways, these days under the auspices of the Metropolitan Transit Authority's ''Music Under the City'' program.

title: Stage II Apparel Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
For Mexico, It's No Fad
description: This week's announcement that Mexico and the United States would seek to negotiate a bilateral trade agreement appears to be part of a trend. Last year the United States and Canada signed such a pact, and now Senator Phil Gramm has called for offering similar agreements to the struggling countries of Eastern Europe if they create market-based economies.

title: Fed Stayed With Policy In February
description: Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their February meeting to continue the policy aimed at maintaining high interest rates to keep inflationary pressures under control, according to minutes released today.

title: Fernandez Takes Greater Control in Local Districts
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez moved yesterday to strengthen his authority over New York City's local school boards, appointing three trustees to take over the financial operations of one Brooklyn district and temporarily blocking the forced departure of the superintendent in another.

title: Telescope, Bugs Out, Is Put Aboard Shuttle
description: A $2.1 billion telescope has been loaded into the space shuttle Discovery for an April flight after 40 mosquitoes that invaded a cargo shelter from a wildlife preserve were captured.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: Islanders' Playoff Puzzle
description: Ten years after they defeated the Philadelphia Flyers at Nassau Coliseum to win their first Stanley Cup, the Islanders will be playing the Flyers there again tonight with playoff consequences for both teams. This time, though, it is to squeeze into a spot in the National Hockey League playoffs, which begin next week.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Kohl Emerging as Europe's Top Leader
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany is becoming the dominant leader of the 12-nation European Community, something that seemed evident today in his confident mood and manner after two days of talks with the community's biggest skeptic, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: MOSCOW'S FORCES SEIZE 2 KEY SITES FROM LITHUANIANS
description: Soviet forces took over the State Prosecutor's Office in the Lithuanian capital today and seized the printing plant where the republic's main independence newspapers are printed, Lithuanian officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc. said it was discussing the sale of its four Swiss clinics with a number of potential buyers. The planned sale is part of the company's international divestment program.

title: GAF Fined; Executive Sentenced
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a senior executive of the GAF Corporation to a six-month prison term yesterday and fined the company $2 million for manipulating the stock of the Union Carbide Corporation for two days in 1986.

title: Japan Delays N.T.T. Move
description: The Japanese Government said today that it would wait five years before deciding whether to break up the nation's pre-eminent telecommunications company, whose recent stock slump has been linked in part to investors' worries about a breakup.

title: Baker's Tone on Jerusalem Settlement Softens
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in an apparent softening of United States opposition to Israeli settlements in Arab East Jerusalem, has said that Jews have the right to live in all parts of the city.

title: Ampal-American Israel Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary income of $1,275,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Computer Sales to the Soviets
description: The Pentagon will no longer block exports of the least powerful American mainframes, leaving control to the Commerce Department. Page 31.

title: Maxwell Stewart, 89, Editor and Economist
description: Maxwell S. Stewart, a retired editor, author and economist, died on Tuesday at his home in Sun City Center, Fla. He was 89 years old and also had a residence in Annandale, N.J.

title: Killings in '89 Set a Record In New York
description: More people were slain in New York City last year than ever before, and the killings in 1990 will eclipse that record if the trend set in the first two months continues, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said yesterday.

title: Oneok Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months' share earnings and year-ago 6 months' shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 split paid Feb. 28.

title: Legislators Say Rises in Tuition Are on the Table
description: For months, lawmakers here had vowed that raising tuition at the state's public universities would be unmentionable when this year's budget negotiations came around. That's because they tried it last spring, but were humiliated when students seized campus buildings in protest and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed the increases anyway.

title: Barbara Baer Capitman, 69, Dies; Created Miami Art Deco District
description: Barbara Baer Capitman, whose vision and persistence helped to turn a rundown area of Miami Beach into a vibrant Art Deco historic district, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. She was 69 years old and suffered from diabetes and heart tremors.

title: Coping: With Spring Gardening
description: The folk wisdom used to be that March would ''come in like a lion and go out like a lamb.'' But this year March appears to be going out like a lion across most of the country. So far, spring snows, rainstorms, sudden dips in temperature and high winds have put outdoor gardening chores on hold. Patient waiting is essential.

title: Ferranti-Case Investigation
description: The Federal Government is investigating the former vice chairman of Ferranti International P.L.C., James Guerin, in a possible fraud that may have involved hundreds of millions of dollars, according to court documents.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 31, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Evelyn Dawson Winn, Designer, 81
description: Evelyn Dawson Winn, who as ''Suzy Perette'' designed women's clothes in the 1950's and early 1960's, died of a heart attack on Monday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. She was 81 years old and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Court Bars Moving Trial in Killing of 5
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday rejected requests by John E. List to move his murder trial out of Union County to prevent publicity from influencing the jurors.

title: G.O.P. Chief's Enemy Is Now Illness
description: Lee Atwater, who used to revel in making his political enemies squirm, who used to jog with the President and spar with the press, now says the moment when he feels most in control is when he goes to the hospital for the daily treatment to fight the tumor in his brain.

title: Kurt Weinhold, 88; Managed Opera Stars
description: Kurt Weinhold, a former president of Columbia Artists Management, died of emphysema on Friday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: Kind Word for Lyndon Johnson
description: With a couple of initials tacked on to the end of it, the name on the brass plaque on the door in a nondescript office building in midtown Manhattan could be that of a dentist or an accountant. The man who answers the door, in his staid blue suit, sensible tie and no-nonsense horn-rims, could easily be either of them, but there are no initials after the name. The plaque says simply Robert A. Caro.

title: Enscor Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 4 Garbage Haulers See Charges Dropped
description: A State Supreme Court justice dismissed an indictment yesterday charging four garbage collection companies and two individuals with conspiring to restrain trade by dividing territories in Westchester and Putnam counties and Connecticut.

title: U.N. Investigating a Killing
description: The recent killing of a Palestinian United Nations refugee official in the Israel-occupied West Bank appeared to be unrelated to his official duties and a fuller investigation is being carried out, a U.N. spokesman said today. The refugee official, Yasser Qazmouz, was reportedly attacked during the night on Tuesday by masked assailants who suspected him of helping Israeli forces.

title: A Reminder
description: Daylight saving time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow. Clocks are set ahead one hour.

title: Costs of Oil War Cited
description: An oil research specialist was quoted this week as saying that OPEC states lost more than $200 billion in revenue because of their price war in the mid-1980's. Quoted in a United Arab Emirates oil journal, Nicolas Sarkis, head of the Paris-based Arab Center for Oil Studies, said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could have avoided the oil price collapse if they had not started undercutting each other. In 1986, world oil prices fell to below $10 from $28 a barrel.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Outdoor Furniture
description: With spring come new materials, styles and patterns for outdoor furniture. Consider durability, maintenance and design when you make a purchase, and remember to choose seating materials that withstand the weather in your area. Vinyl straps are easy to clean and will last a long time. Textilene, a polyester fabric used for outdoor cushions, is cool to sit on and resists sun damage but can stain. Polyester fiberfill is a quick-drying stuffing for cushions that resists mildew. Here is a look at a variety of frames for outdoor furniture. $ Frame Advantages Aluminum Stands up to all weather, lightweight, easy to maintain. Resin Tough, pliable plastic framing that will not fade or yellow in direct sunlight. Vinyl Polyvinyl chloride frames are lightweight, durable and resist fading and yellowing. Wrought Iron Decorative, easy to clean, lasts a lifetime. Very heavy. Wolmanized Pine Wood that has been pressure treated to protect against decay. Durable. Moderately heavy. Outdoor Wicker A strong synthetic fiber that resists water.

title: Killer of Girl, 9, In Connecticut Is Ruled Insane
description: A three-judge panel today acquitted a mental patient of murder and escape in the stabbing death of a 9-year-old girl last summer, finding him not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: Official Offers to Meet Critics
description: Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. was sworn in yesterday as New York City's new Health Commissioner, and he made conciliatory overtures to critics of the appointment. He promised ''to meet with those individuals and community groups that must have input into the decision-making process, including those who have been critical of me and of past Health Department efforts.'' Officials of several major AIDS organizations opposed Dr. Myers because, as Indiana's Health Commissioner, he supported the tracing of the sex and drug partners of those infected with the AIDS virus and the quarantine of people who knowingly spread the virus.

title: California Execution Stayed: State Is Appealing to High Court
description: California's first execution in 23 years was blocked today when a Federal appeals court judge said Robert Alton Harris, convicted in 1979 of the murder of two teen-age boys, might not have had adequate psychiatric help at his trial.

title: Dr. Arthur Wooten Jr., A Retired Chemist, 67
description: Dr. Arthur Lee Wooten Jr., a retired research chemist and educator, died of cancer on Thursday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 67 years old.

title: Albany Debates Aid for Students on Welfare
description: An ideological battle over the future of New York's welfare system is being waged in Albany, and much of the debate centers on women like Pauline M. King - a former drug addict, teen-age mother, high school dropout and now an honors graduate of Onondaga Community College.

title: Mandela's Group Said to Cancel Talks With Pretoria Government
description: The African National Congress has reportedly decided to postpone indefinitely its meeting with the South African Government scheduled for April 11.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Still Falling
description: Prices of Treasury securities continued to decline yesterday on new signs that the economy might be improving.

title: Ex-Player at Iona Says Valvano Gave Him Money, Paper Reports
description: Jeff Ruland, a former National Basketball Association center, said he took unspecified amounts of money from Jim Valvano while the North Carolina State coach was coaching at Iona, The Philadelphia Daily News reported today.

title: Let Vermont Troublemakers Try to Secede
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Surplus Off in Month
description: Increased imports helped Japan slash its current account surplus by 32.4 percent in February, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: Are Some Catholics More Equal Than Others?;   Vatican II on Liturgy
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID DOUGLAS DUNCAN estimates that during his 17-year friendship with PABLO PICASSO, he took more than 50,000 pictures of the artist and his works. Mr. Duncan, also known for his war photography, has published four books on Picasso and his world.

title: Child Care Means Dad As Well as Mom
description: To the Editor:

title: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Pre-Paid said the loss in the latest year was largely related to $1.7 milliom in restructuring costs. The company said year-ago figures included a gain of $1.1 million, or 10 cents a share from an accounting change.

title: Colgate and Wisconsin Reach Final
description: Dave Gagnon, Colgate's goalie, saved his team one more time tonight. Gagnon thwarted the best efforts of a quick Boston University team as the Red Raiders beat the Terriers, 3-2, in a semifinal match of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I hockey tournament.

title: Hicks, Muse Buys 7 Insurers
description: Hicks, Muse & Company, a private investment group specializing in leveraged acquisitions, said today that it had completed the previously announced acquisition of seven insurance companies from the I.C.H. Corporation for $530 million.

title: 4-Way Tie For Lead In Tradition
description: The anticipated Duel in the Desert between Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino was closer to the Bust in the Dust at the first round of the Tradition tournament here today.

title: Nonunion Workers And UAL Buyout
description: The UAL Corporation's nonunion employees are seeking legal advice after failing to arrange discussions with union workers who are trying to put together an employee buyout of the airline. An internal UAL newsletter said representatives of the nonunion workers had authorized their financial adviser, the First Chicago Corporation, to negotiate on their behalf with the buyout group.

title: Doctor Aboard Copter Is Hit by Ground Shots
description: Gunshots fired from the ground struck a low-flying military helicopter on a medical mission yesterday, wounding a doctor on board and forcing the craft to make an emergency landing in northern New York, the authorities said.

title: Teacher in Drug Case Is Given Probation; Officials Urged Jail
description: A high school gym teacher who pleaded guilty to snorting cocaine in the parking lot of a New York City school was placed on five years' probation yesterday, despite urgings by Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez that he be sent to jail.

title: Savings Post Nominee Clears Senate Panel
description: After last-minute lobbying by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the Senate Banking Committee voted today to send to the full Senate the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. as the nation's top savings and loan regulator.

title: Beliefs
description: A deeply embedded religious practice, long believed central to a whole spiritual outlook, is widely abandoned within a few years. The abandonment occurs silently, spontaneously, without anyone's urging it and almost without discussion.

title: At P.S. 92, a Hope That Money Will Flow Again
description: When Barbara DeMaria, a teacher at Public School 92, learned yesterday that Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez had dispatched trustees to take over the fiscal and personnel affairs of Community School Board 17, her first thought was for the children: Maybe now there would be enough money for supplies, for security guards and for a recently eliminated reading program.

title: Simpler Plan Sought in Congress To Identify All Eligible for Work
description: Leading members of Congress said today that the nation should adopt a simpler, more secure method of identifying citizens and legal aliens in an effort to prevent job discrimination against Hispanic and other minority workers.

title: Rabies Precautions
description: Veterinarians and public health officials are urging pet owners to have their pets vaccinated against rabies. Even though the deadly virus has been virtually eliminated from pets in many parts of the country, officials warn that rabies remains prevalent among wild animals, especially raccoons and skunks. They say pets should be vaccinated to guard against bites from infected animals and the passing of the virus on to humans.

title: Gene Therapy Weighed by U.S. Panel
description: The first formal proposal ever made to treat children with severe hereditary diseases by inserting foreign genes into their cells entered the most important phase today in the long effort to win Government approval.

title: Liberation Leader and 10 Others Slain in Kashmir
description: A leading pro-independence militant was killed in fighting in Jammu and Kashmir today and 10 other people died in a separate incident, the authorities said. The deaths struck a blow against the powerful movement that has swept the region for more than four months.

title: J.A.L.-McDonnell
description: Japan Air Lines has placed 10 orders and 10 options with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to buy new MD-11 jetliners from the company. The deal is worth about $2 billion. The jets are scheduled to be delivered beginning in mid-1993. J.A.L. is one of 30 customers that have placed a total of 340 orders and other commitments for the MD-11, which replaces McDonnell Douglas's DC-10. The Douglas Aircraft Company, the McDonnell Douglas subsidiary building the jets, began flight-testing earlier this year and hopes to receive Government certification by the end of the year.

title: Talks on 27-Man Roster MESA, Ariz., March 30 -
description: The season-opening 27-player roster that was, then wasn't, may still be.

title: Grist Mill Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
About New York;   When Every Day Brings a Lesson In Being a Hero
description: On Thursday, the Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross gave Felipe Diaz a plaque for his heroism in rescuing a woman who fell from the Staten Island Ferry last August.

title: Sports People: PRO HOCKEY;   Gretzky May Be Out
description: Wayne Gretzky's back problem is more serious than first thought and could sideline the Los Angeles Kings' star for the beginning of the National Hockey League playoffs, which start next week.

title: Japan's Inflation Rises
description: Japan's consumer price index climbed 3.6 percent in February from the period a year ago as a cold weather snap pushed up food prices and a weak yen caused a rise in wholesale prices, the Government said today. It said February's year-to-year gain was the largest since November 1981, when consumer prices rose 3.8 percent. Compared with the previous month, consumer prices were up three-tenths of a percent.

title: U.S.-Japan Telecommunications Accord
description: The United States and Japan agreed on a telecommunications accord today that is expected to open the Japanese market further, and tonight they were nearing an accord on increasing sales of American satellites to Japan.

title: Mission Resource Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 year results included gain on sale of property of $4,287,938. Share earnings are in units.

title: Italy Prepares, in Its Way, for the World Cup
description: In the high-wire act that most people call Italy, where Government disaster is often only a misstep away, doomsday scenarios are in full bloom for the World Cup soccer finals that will be held here in June.

title: 10,000 Crack Vials Confiscated in Raids
description: In simultaneous raids, officers from the Manhattan North Tactical Narcotics Team last night battered down the doors of a former social club and an apartment 39 blocks away in Harlem, arresting 11 people on drug and weapons charges, the police said.

title: Allwaste Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: 5-Year Vivaldi Festival To Start on May 9
description: A five-year festival of the music of Vivaldi and other Baroque composers is planned by the Little Orchestra Society under its conductor, Dino Anagnost, in conjunction with the Metropolitan Singers/The Greek Choral Society.

title: Robert Ward Blauvelt, Executive, 71
description: Robert Ward Blauvelt, former president of Porcella Vicini & Company, a Manhattan shipping concern, died on Wednesday at his home in Franklin Lakes, N.J., after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Dakotas Lawmaker Retires
description: Brynhild Haugland, the nation's longest serving state legislator, has announced that she is retiring after 52 years in the North Dakota House of Representatives. Miss Haugland, an 84-year-old Republican from Minot, has been re-elected every two years since 1938. She headed the Committee on Social Services and Veterans' Affairs for 22 sessions.

title: Redskins Let Williams Go; Sign Rutledge
description: The Washington Redskins said yesterday they would not renew the contract of 34-year-old Doug Williams, the quarterback hero of their Super Bowl victory two years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Thursday about the Colorado-Ute Electric Association's intention to file for bankruptcy protection misstated its financial condition. Colorado-Ute says its debt totals $819 million, of which $407 million is owed to the Federal Government.

title: Patents;   A Device to Keep Autos Constantly Tuned Up
description: Two physics professors at Syracuse University patented a circuit this week that might one day make it possible for an automobile to keep itself constantly tuned up.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;

Univision Threatens To File for Bankruptcy
description: LEAD: Univision Holdings Inc., which operates the country's largest Spanish-language television network, threatened yesterday to file for bankruptcy court protection if it could not negotiate the purchase of $270 million worth of ''junk bonds'' from investors.

title: Coach's Intensity Brings Success To Duke Team
description: When he was a young man, Mike Krzyzewski considered abandoning his family name for something less conspicuous, something easier to spell and pronounce. His father, for instance, had switched to Kross.

title: Development Officials Named
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., the former head of the American Stock Exchange, was appointed chairman of the New York City Public Development Corporation yesterday. The quasi-public organization is responsible for directing the city's commercical, industrial and waterfront development.

title: A.T.&T. Card Offers New Connection
description: Millions of Americans are being asked to try yet another credit card, this time the American Telephone & Telegraph Company's new calling and general-purpose card. The first word is that it seems to be a good deal for many consumers.

title: Continental Health Affiliates reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included bad debt provisions of $12,984,000 in the latest year, compared with $5,511,000 in the year- earlier period.

title: New York's Example for Juries
description: Keeping a citizen off a jury because of race is a gross civic crime. It affronts the citizen, the legal system and anyone seeking justice. New York's highest court merits credit for reinforcing that principle in a way for other states to emulate.

title: Are Some Catholics More Equal Than Others?;   Like Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Will Avoid Inflaming Crisis, Bush Assures Gorbachev in Note
description: President Bush has sent a letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealing for a peaceful end to the Kremlin's dispute with Lithuania and assuring the Soviet President that the United States is ''not trying to make things difficult'' for either side in the Baltic conflict, the White House said today.

title: Inside
description: Night on New York Streets:

title: F.D.A. panel urges AZT for children
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee voted overwhelmingly today to recommend that the agency approve the drug AZT for treatment of children with AIDS.

title: Harken Energy Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a reversal of tax loss carryforwards of $1,783,000. c-Net income and included extraordinary tax credits of $639,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,052,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year. Latest year figures included a $13.5 million operating loss resulting primarily from commodity trading activity. In addition, 1989 included $3.5 million in expenses from Harken's unsuccessful effort to acquire Tesoro Petroleum and a $7.9 million gain from the sale of its 80 percent stake in Aloha Petroleum Ltd., its Hawaiian Petroleum retailing unit.

title: Colombo Journal;   Killing Stirs a Land Cowed by Deaths
description: The death squad came for her only child at 3:30 on a Sunday morning in February. Mother and son were torn apart in a few moments of confusion and blinding terror.

title: Mr. Donut Ruling
description: A Federal judge has lifted a restraining order that blocked the sale of the Mr. Donut chain to its biggest competitor, Dunkin' Donuts. United States District Judge Franklin S. Van Antwerpen ruled on Wednesday that Mr. Donut franchise owners could pursue their lawsuit to block the sale on antitrust allegations, but he said the franchise owners had failed to prove they would suffer irreparable harm while they pursued their lawsuit. The owners contend the sale would drive them out of business or force them to make expensive conversions. Dunkin' Donuts is No. 1 in the nation with some 1,600 stores, while Mr. Donut has about 550 outlets.

title: Buddy, Can You Spare a Bomb?
description: If the papers are right, and sometimes they are, Iraq sent somebody out to buy atomic-bomb triggers. That seems like a tough purchasing job. Imagine:

title: Review/Music;   California Visitors With New American Works
description: Sonor, the chamber group that played on Wednesday night at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, is a major performing arm for the active music department at the University of California at San Diego. Mostly, Sonor plays new music by American composers, many of whom are either affiliated with the school or have written music for performers who are.

title: BTR Acts to Force Norton Meeting
description: The British conglomerate BTR P.L.C., whose hostile bid for the Norton Company was rejected on Thursday, asked a Federal court to force Norton to restore its canceled April annual meeting. The Worcester, Mass., plastics and ceramics company Thursday rejected BTR's offer of $75 a share, or $1.64 billion, as inadequate. Norton also canceled its April 26 annual meeting and scheduled a special shareholders meeting for June 26, saying it needed more time to consider other deals.

title: Frank Haynes Jr., 45, Lawyer at Prudential
description: Frank L. Haynes Jr., vice president and assistant general counsel at the Prudential Insurance Company in Newark, died on Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Werner Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Connecticut Coach Honored by A.P.
description: Coach Jim Calhoun of the University of Connecticut kept telling his players this season that ''if we worked hard as a unit, good things would happen to us individually.''

title: U.S. Lists Barriers To Trade
description: The Bush Administration published an inventory of global trade barriers today, listing 35 countries and 2 regional trading blocs that it said maintained the ''most important'' obstacles to American exports.

title: Your Budget, New York, and Your Call
description: It will not help the debt-ridden New York State government pass a new budget by the Sunday deadline, nor will it improve the state's credit rating, which sank to its lowest level ever this week.

title: Patents;   Weight-Lifting Devices For Wheelchair-Users
description: The manufacturer of Nautilus exercise equipment has patented a line of weight-lifting machines for people who use wheelchairs. But the company is so fearful about lawsuits stemming from possible injuries that it may never market them.

title: A Radio Station Fights To Keep Its Watts Up
description: For the first three hours of his morning show, Ken Freedman roamed through the music world's frontier, segueing from ''Cafe Thorax'' by Zut Un Feu Rouge, an experimental pop band from Sweden, to Liberace's version of ''Tico Tico'' to ''Rondevouz'' by Real Fish, a group whose signature sound is a chorus of women yelping in Japanese.

title: Lennar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Rival Lebanese Christians Battle Fiercely, Killing 26
description: Rival Christian forces fought pitched battles for control of Lebanon's Christian heartland today, leaving at least 26 people dead, as a rickety truce between the factions finally fell apart, the police said.

title: Lincoln Suit Is Dismissed
description: A judge dismissed a suit today that had been filed by the American Continental Corporation against Federal regulators, which accused them of hurting the survival chances of its Lincoln Savings and Loan Association subsidiary by leaking confidential information.

title: Wave of Light Injuries Washes Over Mets
description: The first wave of light casualties struck the Mets today when Darryl Strawberry, Gregg Jefferies, Tim Teufel and Tom O'Malley came down with minor injuries that will cost them playing time in an already short spring-training season.

title: Mississippi River Gaming Venture
description: International Game Technology agreed to a venture with the Connelly Group to develop and run riverboat gambling operations on the Mississippi River at Davenport, Iowa. The Reno-based International Game, which designs and produces gaming products and systems, said it would invest $100 million in hotel and riverboat centers and hold a 45 percent stake in the partnership.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Post 1.3% Increase
description: Prices farmers received for raw products increased 1.3 percent from February to March, raising the overall commodity index 2.7 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Thai General Quits to Join Cabinet, Winning Quick Leg-Up in Politics
description: After months of speculation, the commander in chief of the Thai Army resigned today to join the Cabinet as Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister.

title: 81 Nations Seeking More Food Aid for Africa
description: The United States and the representatives of more than 80 other countries appealed today for additional donations of food and money for Ethiopia, Angola, Mozambique and the Sudan. They called existing pledges inadequate and said that without further aid hundreds of thousands of people could die of starvation this year.

title: High Court to Rule Quickly on Flag-Burning Law
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to a Bush Administration request to rule on the constitutionality of the new law against flag burning and to do so under an accelerated timetable. The Justices set May 14 for argument, making a decision by early summer highly likely.

title: North American Biologicals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $241,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $510,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year, both from operating loss carryforwards. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss of $146,000. d-After an extraordinary credit of $175,000, or 1 cent a share, from operating loss carryforward.

title: Auburn and Stanford To Play for the Title
description: Auburn handed top-ranked Louisiana Tech its first defeat in 33 games and knocked out the Lady Techsters, 81-69, tonight in the semifinals of the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: King Gains Shore Lead
description: Nancy Lopez missed the cut today for the first time in a major championship and only the third time in her 13-year career on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: American Health Services reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $75,645 which represented loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $5,431,614 which included a loss of $1,376,974 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Fitch Is in Foul Mood After Another Ejection
description: Before tonight's game was over, Coach Bill Fitch and Purvis Short had been ejected, and two other Nets players had been called for technical fouls. At least the Nets did not lose without a fight.

title: Rethinking U.S. Sanctions on South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Two well-known New York bridge personalities found themselves sitting next to each other on a park bench a month ago and exchanged greetings. ''Hello, Tom.'' ''Hello, Bob.''

title: Bulgaria Sets Election Dates
description: Bulgaria's ruling Communists and opposition leaders said today that the country would hold its first free elections in 40 years in June, completing the sweep of East European countries moving to democracy. Participants in round-table talks between Communists and the opposition said the elections would be held in two stages on June 10 and 17.

title: Korda Steps In And Stuns Gilbert
description: The plan was to use him only in an emergency, and no one really expected anything like that. But as Czechoslovakia's second-round Davis Cup match against the United States approached and it became evident that Miroslav Mecir's injured back would prevent him from playing, Petr Korda got his chance.

title: Bracknell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Are Some Catholics More Equal Than Others?;   Familiar From Column
description: To the Editor:

title: The Knights of the Padlock Sweep Forth
description: The quiet street glistened in a light rain as the raiding parties gathered and grumbled over the assignment: another night of inspection that would take many on wild goose chases, a few into dingy basements and firetrap lofts, into the eerie nightworld of illegal social clubs.

title: Hurley Proving He's Focal Point For Blue Devils
description: The focal point stepped off the floor at McNichols Arena and into the bright lights of examination. Bobby Hurley folded his arms across his blue Duke practice jersey and listened to the questions.

title: Patents;   Alternative To Cortisone For the Skin
description: The steroid cortisone rivals aspirin as one of the most widely used medications. Thanks to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation, cortisone relieves a host of skin irritations, from poison oak to eczema and psoriasis. Taken orally, it can relieve asthma and other forms of lung congestion.

title: Knicks Miss the Big Shot and the Big Rebound
description: The Knicks finally got Michael Jordan to miss a key shot in overtime tonight, but then they missed the rebound. Stacey King, the Bulls' rookie power forward, left alone underneath after Kenny Walker left him to help stop Jordan, grabbed the ball and put it in with 12.9 seconds left to give Chicago a 107-106 victory here at Chicago Stadium.

title: The Case for the Mentally Ill
description: Under the budget cuts, whole mental health clinics would be closed. What will happen to the people who depend on them for therapy? The suicidal will become more suicidal. Some will die. The extremely irrational will become more irrational and even less able to cope.

title: 4 Hurt When a Taxi Crashes Into a Bank
description: A taxi crashed into the front of a Citibank branch at the Avenue of the Americas and 23d Street yesterday morning, seriously injuring the driver and slightly injuring three pedestrians.

title: People and Groups
description: Circumstance has a way of tripping up thought by categories, and global communications now make that evident. After all, the yardstick has to be a moral sense.

title: KEY RATES
Rospatch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $6,374,700 for the quarter and $16,874,700 for the year, from disposal of company's technical products group, and included $1 million charge to income to provide for expected costs from environmental contamination at its Michigan plant, for the both periods. c-Net income and after income of $17,600, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a loss of $236,800 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Sports People: PRO FOOTBALL;   Court Upholds Bonus
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia has ruled that Kelvin Bryant, a running back for the Washington Redskins of the National Football League for the last four seasons, is entitled to collect about $500,000, the remainder of a $1 million bonus he was promised for signing in 1983 with the Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football League, which went out of business in 1986.

title: Idaho Governor Vetoes Measure Intended to Test Abortion Ruling 26
description: After a week of intense lobbying and threats to the economy of his state, Gov. Cecil D. Andrus of Idaho tonight broke ranks with some supporters and vetoed a bill that would have given Idaho the most restrictive abortion law in the country.

title: New Move By Federated
description: Federated Stores Inc., the American parent of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, said yesterday in Cincinnati that it was filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code to facilitate the reorganization of both Federated and Allied.

title: Review/Circus;   A Full Cast of Fauna, Hamming It Up
description: The weather may not be giving much sign of the season, but New Yorkers who need reassurance that spring is really here will find it at Madison Square Garden, where the circus has moved in for its spring sojourn.

title: Integon Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Grants and Gifts Assist Harlem Troupe's School
description: Dance Theater of Harlem, which announced severe cutbacks last month, as well as the summer closing of its ballet school, has received $50,000 challenge grants from the Chase Manhattan Bank and the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: A-Plant Broke Cleanup Vow, Ohio Charges
description: The State of Ohio filed contempt charges against the Federal Department of Energy and the operator of the Fernald uranium processing plant today, accusing them of violating a cleanup agreement.

title: Lincoln Center Discussion
description: Six new Lincoln Center administrators will take part in a round-table discussion at the Paul Recital Hall of the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street, on Monday at 6 P.M. They are Christopher Keene, general director of the New York City Opera; Robert Lindgren, president of the School of American Ballet; Robert Marx, chief of the New York Public Library's Performing Arts Research Center; Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center; Fred Sherry, artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and Hugh Southern, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. June LeBell of WQXR Radio will be host at the event, called ''New Faces,'' which is part of the Lincoln Center Offstage Series. Tickets, which include a reception, are $13 and are available through Center Charge, 874-6770.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Off-Duty Officer Kills a Man In a Robbery Case, Police Say
description: An off-duty police officer shot one man to death early yesterday and wounded another when they tried to rob him as he walked to his home in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: A Shoot-'em-Up in the Making
description: The second Final Four game here at McNichols Arena on Saturday, between Georgia Tech (28-6) and Nevada-Las Vegas (33-5), features the Yellow Jacket threesome commonly known as Lethal Weapon III. They shoot. They dazzle. They dribble. Then they shoot some more.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Two Documentaries Linked by Theme
description: The New Directors/New Films series heads toward its close meekly tonight, with two adequate but pedestrian documentaries. Loosely connected by the theme of American cities, their strongest link is the worthiness of their subjects and their unadventurous nature as films.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As the administrator of Central Park and the founder of the Central Park Conservancy, ELIZABETH BARLOW ROGERS is more accustomed to giving than receiving awards. BROOKE ASTOR, on the other hand, is used to getting them.

title: Motorola Freed to Sell Chip in Hitachi Suit
description: A Federal judge temporarily lifted his own order today and allowed Motorola Inc. to continue to sell a vital computer chip that serves as the core of computers made by several United States manufacturers.

title: Nominee for Savings Post Admits Trying Drugs in 70's
description: This morning, the Treasury thought its battle to get T. Timothy Ryan Jr. confirmed as the nation's top savings and loan regulator would be won or lost on the basis of whether he was a strong manager, a tough enforcer and a quick study of the savings and loan crisis.

title: Dow Off 20.49 After 'Buy' Programs End
