description: In another quiet session yesterday, stocks slid after traders turned off computerized ''buy'' programs that take advantage of momentary price swings.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Visiting U.S. Lawyer Expert on the Baltics
description: William J. H. Hough 3d, the Manhattan lawyer who is advising the Lithuanian government, published a legal study of the republic's 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union and testified before Congress on the subject.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Willard Moves Up
description: Ralph Willard, who served as an assistant to Coach Rick Pitino for two seasons with the Knicks and this season at the University of Kentucky, became his own boss on Thursday when he was appointed head coach at Western Kentucky University. On his 44th birthday, Willard became Western Kentucky's ninth coach, replacing Murray Arnold, who resigned after four seasons with the Hilltoppers.

title: Few Bargains at U.S. Auctions
description: At a ''smuggler's auction'' in Rockville, Md., in the dilapidated back room of the National Trade Center, auctiongoers fidget and mumble in rows of folding chairs, raising fingers as an auctioneer calls out bids for a rack of Oriental rugs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Norton Company's rejection of a buyout offer from BTR P.L.C. misstated the date for a special meeting of shareholders. It is June 26, not June 1.

title: Forecasts on Plantings
description: Corn farmers intend to increase plantings this spring to 74.8 million acres, up 4 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said today. Soybean plantings are expected to drop 2 percent, to 59.4 million acres, it said. Wheat plantings for 1990 were forecast at 77.6 million acres, up 1 percent from last year. The 1990 planting figures were based on an annual survey of 75,000 farmers to help determine how much land may be used for crops this year.

title: U.S. Says Fire at Libya Arms Plant May Be a Hoax
description: Bush Administration officials said today that a chemical weapons plant in Libya might still be functioning and that they were investigating the possibility that a fire reported at the installation two weeks ago was part of a hoax engineered by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's leader.

title: Chrysler Extends Rebate Program
description: The Chrysler Corporation extended cash rebates through May 31 on all of its 1990 model cars and trucks except for mini-vans and a convertible. Chrysler's rebate program had been scheduled to end on Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The bill is drawn so narrowly that it would punitively and without compassion further harm an Idaho woman who may find herself in the horrible, unthinkable position of confronting a pregnancy that resulted from rape or incest.'' Gov. Cecil D. Andrus, vetoing an abortion bill. [1:1.]

title: Harry Bridges, Docks Leader, Dies at 88
description: Harry Bridges, a leading figure in America's 20th-century labor movement who organized the West Coast longshoremen in the 1930's, died of emphysema yesterday at his home in San Francisco, the longshoremen's union reported. He was 88 years old.

title: Are Some Catholics More Equal Than Others?
description: To the Editor:

title: Larizza Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,360,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the 1989 results were adversely affected by operating losses from the company's Pulsar Plastics operation in London, Ontario, sharply higher interest costs and $16.3 million in nonrecurring charges. The nonrecurring charges included a provision of $9.5 million related to the closing of the Pulsar operation. Pulsar experienced significant operating losses during the year, the cost of which is included in the 1989 results from operations. The $9.5 million provision included $1.9 millino for intangibles written off, $5.3 million for assets written down to estimated net realizable value, and a reserve of $2.3 million for losses expected during the shutdown period. An additional $1.8 million nonrecurring charge was recorded to provide for an expected loss on the sale of the company's plating operation which has plants in Peterborough and Whitby, Ontario, Canada. Other nonrecurring charges included $2.8 million for other intangibles written off and loan fees of $2.2 million related to the company's credit agreement signed in January 1989.

title: U.S. Easing On Exports Of Computers
description: The Pentagon said today that it would no longer block sales of the least powerful American-made mainframe computers to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, leaving control of such exports to the Commerce Department.

title: New Courses and Even Votes At Czechoslovak Universities
description: A few weeks after the start of the Czechoslovak revolution last November, Lubos Dorfl was sitting in a reading room at the Law School of Charles University here when, he says, something extraordinary happened.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The DUKE AND DUCHESS OF YORK have named their week-old daughter PRINCESS EUGENIE VICTORIA HELENA. She left Portland Hospital in London yesterday with her parents.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Riding the Concorde to New York for tonight's performance (with PRINCE PHILIP in attendance) of ''Aspects of Love,'' ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER talked about the movie version of ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' The musical is still going strong on Broadway.

title: New Xerox Copier
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced a new copier that can ''phone home'' for help when it senses a problem developing. The Xerox 5065, a mid-volume copier that produces 62 copies a minute, is the first Xerox copier to offer a built-in ''remote interactive communications'' system, which continuously checks the copier's performance and alerts a central computer when it notices a potential problem, a Xerox spokesman said. The central computer uses an artificial intelligence system to decide whether a service call is needed.

title: Japan Sobered by Recent Stock Slide
description: As prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange shuddered and plunged last week, the switchboards at the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation lighted up with shareholders expressing amazement, shock and disbelief: This was not supposed to happen, they all said.

title: Grass-Roots Television: Where Tape Is Cheap
description: Covering the annual town meeting here is a two-cameraman affair. Richard Thodal, a machinist who is the technical director of Middlebury Community Television, keeps one camera trained on town officials in the front of the room and monitors the equipment deck while Louis Megyesi, a high-school teacher, pans the audience with the second camera. At the regular Tuesday night selectmen's meetings, Mr. Thodal often does it all by himself.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In Sex-Abuse Case
description: A transit police detective posing as a parochial school student in Brooklyn pulled a badge from her high school uniform yesterday and arrested a man on charges of sexual abuse, the police said.

title: Ralph M. Freeman, Federal Judge, 87
description: Ralph McKenzie Freeman, a senior Federal district judge, died Thursday after undergoing surgery for a ruptured aorta at William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich. He was 87 years old.

title: Brooklyn Jury Indicts Officer In Boy's Death
description: A Brooklyn grand jury indicted a police officer on a manslaughter charge yesterday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed 14-year-old robbery suspect on Jan. 31.

title: Appalachia Resents Label of 'Third World'
description: A San Francisco travel agency's plans for a nine-day tour of the ''Third World in America'' has angered directors of tourism in the Appalachian region.

title: Calton Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Patents;   Products You Thought You Could Do Without
description: A number of patents have been granted in the last two weeks for products that many people may have never thought they needed:

title: Lockheed Missile Work
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company unit of the Lockheed Corporation has received a $352.2 million Defense Department contract for the Navy's Trident missile program, the department said today.

title: Will Albany Save Our Heritage?
description: It will be a tragic failure of vision and leadership if, because of the New York State budget crisis or other reasons, the single most important initiative of the Cuomo administration is permitted to founder.

title: TRIAL IS DELAYED IN OMAHA SCANDAL
description: A Federal magistrate said today that Lawrence E. King Jr., a prominent businessman who was once active nationally in the Republican Party, is mentally incompetent to stand trial on charges of conspiracy and fraud in connection with the collapse of a credit union for the poor.

title: After 20 Years in the House, Rep. Frenzel Says He'll Retire
description: Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, a 20-year veteran of the House, announced unexpectedly today that he would not seek re-election in November.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Sly Hints and Fragments Create a Picture Puzzle
description: It is summer, 1914. As the inspired poetaster might say, storm clouds are gathering over Europe. In Stockholm the days are long and limpid. Linnea (Amanda Ooms), a young woman from the country, is befriended by the beautiful, worldly Anna (Helena Bergstrom), who is just about her age and has a photography studio next door to Linnea's attic room. Anna is a free soul.

title: Digital Metcom Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Corrected from Thursday, March 29, editions.

title: Books of The Times;   The Crusader in the Unseen Wheelchair: A New Life of F.D.R.
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt

title: Airbus Denies Charges
description: Airbus Industrie today denied accusations by India's top investigative agency that the aircraft company's directors had bribed former officials of the Indian Government officials to win a $1.47 billion airplane contract. The European consortium threatened legal action against the unidentified sources of the charges made Thursday by the Central Bureau of Investigation in New Delhi. In a statement, Airbus voiced ''astonishment by these fantasy-like accusations.''

title: Gamblers At Odds With U.N.L.V.
description: Lem Banker, professional gambler, was disgusted. He lives in Las Vegas, that neon city that is to Banker what the pearly gates are to St. Peter. But recently for him and fellow sports speculators in Nevada a pall has been cast over the place.

title: Helen Hoke, 86, Writer and Publisher Of Children's Books
description: Helen Hoke, who wrote nearly 100 children's books and set up and ran children's book divisions in five publishing companies, died of bronchial pneumonia on Monday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. She was 86 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Housing Dept. Opens an Inquiry On Contracts to Ex-Reagan Aides
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that it had opened an investigation of nearly $200,000 in no-bid Government contracts that were awarded last year to three former Reagan Administration officials, including one who was also the chief of staff to the Bush Administration's Housing Secretary.

title: Ambassador Financial Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said about $11 million of the 1989 losses were attributable to the losses and discontinuation of its home building operations.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;   Bowden Signs Contract
description: Bobby Bowden of Florida State signed a ''lifetime'' contract Thursday that makes him one of the highest-paid coaches in the United States. Bowden, who has run the football program at Florida State for 14 years (his record is 122-40-30), will receive $708,692 this year and $690,000 annually in subsequent years. (AP)

title: Prosecutor's English Does Not Harm Law
description: It makes no difference if prosecutors go after criminals with indictments that use bad English, the state's highest court has ruled.

title: Bush's Blind Eye on Nepal
description: LEAD: This year's explosion of democracy in Eastern Europe is reverberating in the remotest corners of Asia. Still, over the last month, the fledgling demands of the people of Nepal to restore a multiparty system of democracy have met with brutal repression by the absolute monarch who has ruled Nepal for the last 30 years, King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah

title: PALESTINIANS MARK '76 LAND SEIZURES
description: Thousands of Palestinians and Israeli Arabs held rallies and protest marches today to mark the 14th anniversary of Land Day, when riots broke out over Israeli confiscation of Arab land.

title: Grand Jury Votes to Indict Suspect in Social Club Fire
description: The man accused of setting the fire at the social club that killed 87 people on Sunday in the Bronx, was indicted yesterday on 178 counts, including murder, attempted murder and arson.

title: Review/Dance;   Nutty Sweetness, Young Love, a Trip and a Ritual
description: The mood was for the most part light and even frivolous on Tuesday when the Fifth Annual Morningside Dance Festival presented its second showcase program at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: United Artists Entertainment Co. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: There were no comparable year-ago figures because of the merger with United Cable Television Corp. on May 25, 1989. The company said interest, certain non-cash expenses relating to the merger with United Cable Television, and certain non-recurring charges related to operations which the company has elected to discontinue contributed to its net loss. United Artists Communications and United Cable Television were merged into a new entity, United Artists Entertainment. The results of operations for United Cable are included in United Artists Entertainment's results from that date forward.

title: Talks Held on Sale Of Child World
description: Jeffrey A. Cole, the chairman of the Cole National Corporation, said he had held talks with third parties interested in acquiring Cole's entire 82 percent interest in Child World Inc., a toy retail chain based in Avon, Mass. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Cole said he was considering a sale of the shares and expects the talks with the third parties to continue. Cole National holds 9.37 million Child World shares, which are worth $126 million at current market prices.

title: A Eurotunnel Director Quits
description: Eurotunnel P.L.C., the British-French consortium building a rail tunnel under the English Channel, said on Thursday that Tony Ridley had resigned as a director.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Senator Robert C. Byrd misidentified him. He is the former Senate majority leader; Senator George J. Mitchell now holds the post.

title: Nobel Industries And Gillette in Deal
description: Reaching agreement on a plan announced in December, the Gillette Company said it would sell its European skin and hair-care operations to a unit of Nobel Industries of Sweden for $107 million. The deal, expected to be completed within the next 60 days, includes such Gillette European brands as Silkience shampoo and Aapri skin care. Gillette will keep about $30 million in receivables, it said.

title: Factory Orders Rebound With 1.8% February Rise
description: Orders to factories for manufactured goods in February bounced back 1.8 percent from January, when they had their steepest plunge in 16 years, the Government said today.
